https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/16/busin.main_headline: Business People; NEW CHIEF EXPECTED AT ABRAHAM & STRAUS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/16/busin.print_headline: Business People; NEW CHIEF EXPECTED AT ABRAHAM & STRAUS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/16/busin.body_text: **********John Burden 3d, president of Burdine's, a Miami department store group, is expected to be named today as chairman and chief executive officer of Abraham & Straus. Howard Sokol, Burdine's executive vice president, is expected to succeed Mr. Burden there. **********Lasker M. Meyer, chairman and chief executive officer since February 1980, will leave those posts in the fall to return to Foley's department stores in Houston. The 55-year-old Mr. Meyer, who had been Foley's president before joining A.&S., is expected to be named chairman of Foley's upon the retirement of Stewart Orton at the end of the current fiscal year. A.&S., Burdine's and Foley's are all store divisions of Federated Department Stores Inc., of Cincinnati. A Federated spokesman said earlier this week that the company would not comment on reports involving its store divisions. **********According to trade sources, the 39-year-old Mr. Burden will receive a base annual salary of $200,000 and, like Mr. Meyer, will be given an interest-free loan of $750,000 to relocate to New York and purchase a cooperative apartment. In Mr. Meyer's case, the loan was secured by an interest in his co-op and is payable in full if he leaves his job or no longer resides at the apartment. **********Mr. Burden, a former executive at the Bamberger's division of R.H.  Macy & Company, joined Federated as a merchandise manager in 1971. He was named vice president and general merchandise manager in 1973, executive vice president in 1976 and president in 1978. **********Mr. Sokol, who is 36, joined Burdine's in 1969. He advanced to senior vice president and general merchandise manager for men's, women's and children's wear. As executive vice president, he was in charge of merchandising for all divisions.  Thomas L. Friedman

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/10/busin.body_text: **********Starting tomorrow, shoppers at the Grand Union store in Stratford, Conn., will be hearing a friendly female voice reciting the cost of the items they are purchasing, the total and the amount of change they have coming. The source of the entire litany will be an amplifying box on a display pole adjacent to the electronic cash register. **********No, the grocery chain has not trained its checkout personnel to be ventriloquists. It has chosen the Stratford store to test the region's first talking scanner. A device known as a speech synthesizer will give a verbal accounting of all readings made by the electronic scanner from the printed computer code on each package or container as it is recorded and passes through the checkout. **********Grand Union said it was aiming to reduce consumer confusion and concern over the speedy operation of the scanner. If the speech synthesizing device, dubbed the ''Positalker,'' can accomplish that on nine checkout lanes during the next six months, the 856-store supermarket chain will install more of them, although officials would not estimate how many or how quickly. 'Humanizing' Touch **********Henry T. Johnson, Grand Union's vice president for corporate marketing, said that the scanning cash register systems ''are far more accurate than traditional checkout systems.'' But he said that the speed of the checkout system was creating some uneasiness among shoppers. The voice synthesizer will ''humanize the process,'' he said, and also give the consumer a check on the accuracy of the prices recorded. **********The speaker will recite only the pricing information, not the names of the items, since that would slow the checkout process, according to a spokesman for National Semiconductor Corporation. The Santa Clara, Calif., computer maker supplies both the ''Datachecker'' scanning system being used by Grand Union and the speech synthesizer. **********Items are listed on a lighted digital display near the cash register and are printed on the register tape. The Grand Union spokesman said that since the ''Positalker'' is an attachment to the existing checkout system, the cost is just $3,000 for the nine units, compared with the approximate $135,000 cost for a single electronic cash register and its central processor. Translates Scanner Code **********The speaking device is an electronically triggered mechanism that matches the proper verbal response to the digital codes being read and translated by the scanner. Scanners ''read'' the computer printed code on packages as the items pass over the optical scanner of the checkout and record the name of the item and its price on the electronic cash register or point-of-sale system. **********The National Semiconductor speech synthesizer is already in use in eight supermarkets west of the Mississippi. These include the King's Supermarket and Safeway in Denver; Kroger, H.E. Butt and Safeway in Houston; Bashe's in Phoenix, and Albertson's in San Jose, Calif. **********In the original installations, the voice synthesizer first used a male voice. But, according to National Semiconductor's spokesman, shoppers insisted that the man's delivery was too much of a monotone and that a woman's voice would be ''softer.'' Besides, the spokesman added, ''Since most supermarket checkout operators are women, shoppers felt that the voice talking to them should be feminine, too.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/26/busin.main_headline: INTEREST RATES SURGE OVER DOUBTS ON BUDGET
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/26/busin.print_headline: INTEREST RATES SURGE OVER DOUBTS ON BUDGET
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/26/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates rose sharply yesterday as the credit markets concluded that President Reagan's budget proposals would not be enough to prevent upward pressure on interest rates in the future. **********In yesterday's trading, the most tumultuous activity was in the long-term bond market, where prices dropped by more than two points and yields rose to record levels. The bellwether 13 7/8 percent Treasury bonds due 2011, for example, fell 2 5/8 points, or $26.50 per $1,000 bond, to 92 1/4, where the yield to maturity is 15.05 percent. **********Interest rates also rose in the short-term markets, partly because of signs that the recent decline in short-term rates had run its course. By late in the day, six-month Treasury bills were bid at 14.7 percent, up from 14.36 percent earlier in the day. **********On the heels of the steep price declines, the Federal Reserve reported that a key measure of the money supply expanded by $1 billion last week, in line with expectations. **********Although discussion about large Federal budget deficits and the resulting Treasury borrowing requirements has dominated the credit markets in recent weeks, many analysts said that the latest upturn in rates was caused by more than just the volume of future Treasury issues. They explained that the Fed's determination to keep money supply growth under control meant that short-term interest rates would remain high and could increase. **********Yesterday, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A.  Volcker, reminded the markets of the Fed's intentions to combat inflation through the money supply. In a speech at t he National PressClub in Washington, D.C., Mr. Volcker said th at progress had been made in the last two years, and predicted tha t inflation would decline slightly next year, to less than a 10 percent growth rate. **********Despite the lower inflation outlook, traders were worried that the Fed would again be forced to curb money supply growth by making credit scarcer in the banking system and thereby encourage higher rates. **********''The financial markets are coming to realize that interest rates are going to remain high for a considerably longer period than they thought,'' said H. James Toffey, managing director of the taxable fixed-income department at the First Boston Corporation. **********''Investors are asking,'' Mr. Toffey added, ''how do I justify buying stocks or bonds if I can earn 16 percent in the money market for the foreseeable future?'' If short-term rates are not expected to decline substantially, then investors are loath to buy a longer-term issue that offers a lower yield and greater price risk than a shortterm investment due in six months or less. **********Late yesterday, the Fed announced that the closely watched M-1B measure of the nation's money supply reached $433.7 billion in the week ended Sept. 16, registering a $1 billion increase. M-1B, which consists of c urrency in circulation and all types of checking accounts, is still several billion dollars below the Fed's target forthis year, al though it is up $1.9 billion in the last two weeks. **********Increases in the money supply are inevitable following the Fed's practice in recent months of increasing the supply of credit in the banking system, analysts said. Yesterday, however, there was at least one sign that the Fed was not willing to continue to supply increasing amounts of money to the system. Over the last 13 weeks, nonborrowed reserves in the banking system have grown at a 22 percent annual rate, but some experts say that growth cannot continue without causing an inflationary increase in money supply. Fed Drains Reserves **********A recent sign that the Fed was not continuing to make credit still more plentiful was yesterday's action to temporarily drain credit from the banking system by arranging temporary sales of securities.That action came when overnight loans among banks in the Federal funds market were extended at about 14 percent, well below the 15.37 percent average for the week ended Sept. 23. **********While many investors are deserting the long bond market, yields in that sector have climbed even though inflation has dropped slightly over the past year. For example, 30-year Treasury bond yields were just over 12 percent when President Reagan took office in January, rose to 13.2 percent by midyear and now are above 15 percent. **********Securities dealers agreed that investor demand for issues due in more than two years was weak, despite a chorus of economists and salesmen who say that bonds are an attractive investment. As prices were plunging yesterday, one dealer said: ''The lack of buyers is the main factor. The President's program for more budget cuts was not encouraging, but it did not make things worse.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/world.print_headline: REAGAN, IN OTTAWA, PLEDGES AMITY; DIFFERENCES ON EL SALVADOR REMAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/world.body_text: **********President Reagan addressed the Canadian Parliament today with a speech full of pledges of friendship but devoid of concessions for settling the disputes over American military aid to El Salvador and such issues as fishing rights and pollution. **********The speech, in that respect, matched the tone and outcome of private meetings among Mr. Reagan, Prime Minister Pierre Eliott Trudeau and their chief advisers. No communique was issued at the end of the 27-hour visit, Mr. Reagan's first foreign trip as President. **********Participants said that the private meetings produced agreement on broad policy goals - the pursuit of a political rather than a military solution in El Salvador, for example. But the meetings ended with the Canadian Minister for External Affairs, Mark MacGuigan, opposing the United States decision to send arms and military instructors to the Central American nation, while Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. insisted that the United States would stick to its plans. **********Mr. MacGuigan did say that there was ''broad common ground'' on the goal of self-determination for El Salvador and that Canada was satisfied with the Reagan Administration's promise to work in good faith to settle fishing rights and boundary disputes, complete the Alaska natural gas pipeline, in which Canada has invested heavily, and resolve cross-b@order conflicts over environmental quality. Haig Calls Meetings a Success **********Mr. Haig, joining Mr. MacGuigan at a news conference, said the meetings were a success because they set up a ''substantive framework'' for future discussions. Solutions to ''vexing interest issues'' must come later, he said. When reporters pressed for details on the El Salvador impasse, Mr. Haig complained, ''You're doing your best to get a row started, aren't you?'' **********In their speeches to Parliament this morning, Mr. Reagan and Mr.  Trudeau struck this same balance between cordial agreement on goals, and stout defense, in careful diplomatic language, of their separate national intersts. **********Mr. Reagan used his appearance before a joint session of the Canadian Senate and the House of Commons to describe his ''nearrevolutionary steps'' aimed at restoring conservative economic policies in the United States, and to ask for Canada's support for a policy of stern anti-Communism. ''Across the oceans, we stand together against the unacceptable Soviet invasion into Afghanistan and against continued Soviet adventurism across the earth,'' he said. **********Mr. Trudeau, in a soft, almost whispery voice, suggested that Mr.  Reagan belonged to an American tradition of hostility to government interference. ''But here in Canada,'' he said, ''our own realities have sometimes made it necessary for governments to further enterprise. Those realities and that necessity are still with us today.'' **********Then, warning against an impulse to ''oversimplify'' world issues, he urged on Mr. Reagan a policy of patience toward the Soviet Union.  Mr. Trudeau said that in the Polish crisis, the Russians, given time, ''may accommodate themselves at least to the dynamics of their own region.'' **********This contrast between the liberal and conservative philosophies was not lost on the Canadian legislators convened in Commons, a vaulted hall decorated with fluted columns, panels of carved stone and intricate stained-glass windows. The Progressive Conservative Party members applauded vigorously and shouted ''hear, hear!'' as Mr.  Reagan described his budget-balancing techniques. But members of Mr.  Trudeau's Liberal Party sat silently or slowly yielded up a few perfunctory hand claps. Reagan Stumbles During Speech **********At one point Mr. Reagan stumbled so badly in his speech that some journalists said later that they feared that he might be suffering a physical attack. But aides said that Mr. Reagan was simply confused by his own interlinear notes, written in small handwriting in the text of his speech, and that his subsequent omission of a reference to the fishing treaty to divide the catch on the Georges Bank was inadvertent. **********Mr. Trudeau, in remarks to reporters after the speeches, expressed regret that the Administration had abruptly withdrawn that treaty from consideration by the United States Senate. The Reagan move surprised the Trudeau Government and contributed to the substantial turnout of hostile demonstrators who greeted the President yesterday. **********Mr. Trudeau said Canada still insisted that the fishing treaty be linked irrevocably to a boundary treaty involving the Canadian-American demarcation line in the Gulf of Maine. ''We view the United States gesture of withdrawing the treaty as an indication of their determination to solve the problem in other ways'' short of a ''fish war,'' Mr. Trudeau said as Mr. Reagan listened. **********''The other area, of course, of great concern to Canada was crossboundary pollution,'' Mr. Trudeau added, citing the problems of acid rain and pollution in the Great Lakes and other bodies of water. On these points, he said, Mr. Reagan gave him ''assurances that the United States has the will and the determination to cooperate with us in preserving the environment for ourselves and for posterity.'' **********Two matters of substance, settled by subordinates before Mr. Reagan and Mr. Trudeau met here, were completed today. Mr. Haig and Mr.  MacGuignan signed a renewal for five years of the North American Air Defense Command, a joint air warning and defense system. An agreement giving people who work in both nations uniform coverage under Social Security and its Canadian counterpart was approved, too.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/09/busin.body_text: **********The merger of three New York, Florida and California savings and loan associations into what would become the nation's largest federally chartered savings and loan association was approved by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. **********It was the first interstate consolidation of savings and loan associations since the bank board moved in March to permit such mergers as a means of bolstering the financially ailing thrift industry. **********The merger combines the West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York and the Washington Savings and Loan Association of Miami Beach into the Citizens Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco, which is owned by the National Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh through a subsidiary, the United Financial Corporation. **********The combined association will have assets of $6.8 billion, with 136 branches in the three states. The New York and Miami Beach units will continue under their former names as divisions of Citizens Savings. **********The bank board said that the major factor in the merger was the willingness of National Steel to provide $75 million in cash to the new association. The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which insures savers' accounts up to $100,000, will provide financial aid ''over time to the resulting association, but no F.S.L.I.C.  assistance was involved from the outside,'' the board said. **********In a separate action, the bank board also approved the merger of the Franklin Society Federal and Savings and Loan Association of New York into the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rochester. The new association will have assets of $2.2 billion and will operate 55 offices. **********The savings and loan industry has been hard hit by inflation and high interest rates. To attract money, its members have had to pay interest on savings at higher rates than they earn from mortgages and through the last five months have recorded substantial losses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/world.print_headline: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION TO CONDUCT INQUIRY ON SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/world.body_text: **********The United Nations Human Rights Commission decided today to have a special representative investigate the reported "grave violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms" in El Salvador. **********In a resolution adopted by 29 votes to 1, with 11 abstentions, the commission said that the special investigator is to present his findings at its next annual session after making an interim report to the General Assembly this fall. **********Only Uruguary voted against the proposal, which was submitted by Denmark, Ireland and the Netherlands.  The United States abstained because of objections to a reference in the text of what it views as an ambiguous resolution in which the General Assembly called on "all governments" to refrain from sending arms to El Salvador. **********Richard Schifter, the United States representative, called on the commission to examine "intensively" all types of human rights abuses in El Salvador so that they "may be brought to a speedy halt."

Hanseatic will continue to do business under its name, but now has the benefit of Securities Groups' $62 million of paid-in capital, officials said. **********Securities Group is a partnership that started business in December 1978.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/06/busin.print_headline: DU PONT VICTOR IN COSTLY BATTLE TO BUY CONOCO
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/06/busin.body_text: **********The most expensive corporate takeover battle in history ended yesterday with the Du Pont Company announcing that it had acquired a controlling interest in Conoco Inc., America's ninth-largest oil company. **********The chemical company will pay $7.57 billion in stock and cash to acquire Conoco in a deal that will make Du Pont the seventh-largest industrial corporation in the United States, just behind the Ford Motor Company. It is now ranked 15th in the Fortune 500 list. **********''This is so much bigger than anything that has every happened before in mergers,'' said Robert Powers, chairman of Smith Barney Inc., an investment bank. ''With all the lines of credit now being established by other oil companies, this could well be the start of a new wave of mergers and acquisitons in the energy field.'' **********Began Buying Shares **********E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company was able to claim victory in its multibillion-dollar bidding war with the Mobil Corporation and Joseph E. Seagram & Sons for control of Conoco after it began early yesterday to buy the 55 percent of Conoco stock attracted by its tender offer. The purchases started shortly after the passing of a midnight Tuesday deadline that Du Pont had set. Until that hour, the thousands of Conoco shareholders who had submitted their stock to Du Pont for purchase at $98 a share had the right to retrieve their shares in favor of a better offer from Seagram or Mobil. **********In addition, Du Pont was able to begin buying the tendered stock because the Justice Department, in the best indication yet that the Reagan Administration does not oppose mergers that create huge corporations, said late Tuesday that the merger would not violate antitrust laws. **********Du Pont agreed to begin paying $98 in cash for up to 38.7 million of Conoco's 86 million outstanding shares and to exchange 1.7 Du Pont shares, a unit worth $80 at the close of yesterday's trading, for each share of all the remaining Conoco stock. At 3:45 A.M., Du Pont began sending payments for the 37.9 million shares that had actually been tendered for cash, while key executives toasted the occasion in a champagne celebration at an elegant Wilmington hotel near company headquarters. An additional 9.4 million Conoco shares that were tendered for the stock portion of the offer will be exchanged on Aug.17 for Du Pont shares. Three-Month Marathon **********For Conoco, the day's events marked the end of a bizarre threemonth marathon that saw three of the nation's biggest corporations deploy an army of lawyers and investment bankers in a battle for its undervalued oil, natural gas and coal assets. It now becomes part of the world's largest chemical company.  The two companies had combined sales last year of $32 billion. **********Conoco had endorsed the Du Pont offer and had opposed the Mobil and Seagram bids. Both the chairman of Du Pont, Edward Jefferson, and Conoco's chairman, Ralph E. Bailey, expressed ''delight'' yesterday that the merger was being consummated. **********''Chemical companies in recent years have been increasingly worried about oil companies using their oil reserves to develop into the petrochemical business,'' said Paul Christopherson, who follows Du Pont for Kidder, Peabody. ''Du Pont will be the one chemical company in the whole world that has put all those concerns behind it.'' The vast majority of chemicals produced by Du Pont have hydrocarbons as their raw material. Advantage to Du Pont **********Mr. Christopherson said Du Pont's merger with Conoco should also remove some of the volatility in the chemical company's earnings, which have tended to rise and fall in line with the swings in prices of hydrocarbons and other raw materials. In 1980, Du Pont earned $716 million on revenues of $13.6 billion. Conoco earned $1.02 billion last year on revenues of $18.71 billion. **********Du Pont stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $47.125, up $1.50, bringing the total value of its offer for Conoco to $7.57 billion. The largest previous corporate takeover in history was the Shell Oil Company's acquisition of the Belridge Oil Company in 1979 for $3.65 billion. Conoco closed at $91.875, down 38.5 cents, almost double the price at which it had traded in May when other corporations, attracted by its low stock price, began bidding for the company. Analysts have estimated Conoco's breakup value at $100 to $150 a share. **********Conoco first appeared susceptible for acquisition after Canada's Dome Petroleum Ltd. successfully acquired Conoco's controlling interest in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company last May. In the process, Dome called for Conoco shareholders to tender their stock and they did so in overwhelming numbers. Seagram Started Chain **********Seagram started the competition for the remainder of Conoco's assets on June 25 with a $73-a-share offer for 41 percent of Conoco's shares. It was quickly joined by Du Pont and Mobil, the nation's No.2 oil company, in a dizzying round of bids that made millions for arbitragers and investment housesand tidy profits even for individual stockholders with just a few shares. In May, before the bidding started, Conoco stock was being traded at $50 a share, just over half its current value. **********While neither Mobil nor Seagram, the Canadian liquor company controlled by the Bronfman family, publicly conceded defeat, insiders at both corporations indicated that the fight for Conoco was over. **********Yesterday afternoon Seagram extended its deadline for purchasing Conoco stock, from midnight yesterday to midnight Friday, on the basis of its own final tender offer of $92 a share for 51 percent of the stock. Analysts said Seagram's stake in the new Du Pont-Conoco company could go as high as 20 percent, which would make it the second-largest shareholder after the duPont family and their trusts, which control about 22 percent. Payments Ordered **********With Du Pont the clear winner, Mobil, which had offered to pay $120 a share for almost half of Conoco's stock, announced that it had instructed its depository, the First National Bank of Chicago, to return the roughly 2.2 million Conoco shares attracted by its tender offer. This will enable stockholders to tender the shares either to Seagram or Du Pont. The value of Mobil's bid, worth $8.8 billion in cash and securities, exceeded the successful Du Pont offer, but the Justice Department declined to give Mobil immediate antitrust clearance, apparently making stockholders unwilling to tender to Mobil. **********Mobil said it would tender to Seagram the 735,800 Conoco shares that it had purchased between July 1 and 3, before its takeover offer. Payments by Seagram **********Seagram began executing payments in its tender offer for Conoco stock on Aug.2, paying $92 a share. By last weekend, Seagram had purchased 15.5 million Conoco shares, or 18 percent. **********Mr. Christopherson, of Kidder, Peabody, said Seagram's $92 offer may have attracted as many as 5 million to 10 million additional Conoco shares since last weekend. **********Du Pont has issued 80 million new shares to pay the stock portion of its Conoco purchase, which means it will now have a total of 236 million shares. If Seagram were to obtain 20 million Conoco shares, that would translate into 34 million Du Pont shares, or 14 percent of the company. If it received 25 million shares, the Bronfman family, which controls Seagram, would control 18 percent of Du Pont's stock.  Mr. Christopherson said the duPont family and trusts combined will control only about 22 percent of Du Pont after Conoco is absorbed and their holdings are diluted. **********Analysts have speculated that Seagram may try to trade its shares and cash for a Conoco subsidiary, the Consolidation Coal Company. The coal company, the nation's second largest, is of little use to Du Pont and its sale could be used to cover the $3.8 billion which Du Pont had to borrow to help pay for the Conoco purchase.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/busin.body_text: **********Good News on Grain **********Recent estimates about the record size of this year's grain crop, which agriculture specialists once feared would be meager, are apt to be a boon to consumers, exporters and livestock farmers well into 1982. **********Assuming little damage is done at harvest time, the size of the wheat and corn crops, currently estimated at 2.8 billion and 7.7 billion bushels respectively, should soften grain prices and ease food price inflation next year. **********Jason Benderly, an economist at Bache & Company, expects food prices to rise between 5 and 7 percent, compared with an 8 percent annual increase in 1981. **********Exports to the Soviet Union, which has not had a good harvest, are likely to be far above the 6 million metric tons currently on the books, perhaps as high as 18 million tons. **********Among farmers, the record crop seems likely to benefit livestock breeders most, and farmers in the Southeast, experiencing their third drought in four years, the least. Although high interest rates continue to hurt breeders, lower grain prices should help ease production costs, and help profit margins next year.

Mr. Timerman made the charges as a member of the studio audience, when the moderator, Bill Moyers, took questions from the audience. **********Mr. Camilion's statements were the first to be made by the Argentine Government in response to a book published in the United States by Mr. Timerman's father, Jacobo Timerman, who says that he was tortured during his two-and-a-half-year imprisonment here.

A.T.& T. has awarded a $20 million contract for the project to the North American Philips Corporation. **********The system will handle up to 140 million bits of information a second, Bell said. At that speed, it would take one-tenth of a second to transmit the text of a typical 76-page newspaper.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/busin.body_text: **********The Boeing Company, the world's leading producer of commercial aircraft, said it expects to furlough an additional 1,300 employees by the end of the year because of a slowdown in airline orders. **********The company also said that it expects to lay off an additional 2,000 to 3,000 employees in the first half of next year as increased military business only partly offsets a steep decline in commercial orders. **********So far this year, Boeing has laid off 4,300 in the Seattle area, where 77,300 of its 104,000 employees work. **********A Boeing spokesman attributed the cutbacks to a drop in production of existing models, the 747 and the 727, and to the airlines' inability because of financial problems to step up orders for new models, the 757 and 767. **********Last week the company reported that its third-quarter earnings tumbled to $92.5 million, or 96 cents a share, from $139.8 million, or $1.45 a share, in the period a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/07/world.main_headline: PRESIDENT TERMS AID FOR SALVADOR A HELP TO RIGHTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/07/world.print_headline: PRESIDENT TERMS AID FOR SALVADOR A HELP TO RIGHTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/07/world.body_text: **********President Reagan defended increased military aid to El Salvador today, saying that the United States was ''helping the forces that are supporting human rights in El Salvador'' against left-wing ''terrorists.'' **********Answering five questions on El Salvador at a news conference, Mr.  Reagan said that the United States would view with ''the gravest concern'' any right-wing attempt to overthrow the Government headed by President Jose Napoleon Duarte. **********But Mr. Reagan declined to say whether such a right-wing takeover would result in a complete suspension of United States military and economic aid. And he said that guerrillas who ''boast of having killed somewhere above 6,000 people in the last year'' were the principal human rights violators in El Salvador. **********Security Forces Blamed **********Liberal Democrats in Congress and the United States Catholic Conference, which represents American Catholic Bishops, have blamed the Salvadoran security forces for most of the thousands of political killings in El Salvador in the last year, including the deaths last December of three American nuns and two American labor officials.  Those deaths led to a temporary suspension of American military aid. **********Today, Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Senator Paul Tsongas, Democrats of Massachusetts, announced that they would present legislation next week halting all American military aid to El Salvador until an investigation of the Americans' murders is completed. **********Mr. Reagan said that ''we realize that there is a risk and a danger'' that the military advisers in El Salvador or en route would be targets for the guerrillas there. But he said that the Administration did ''not foresee the need for American troops'' to protect the advisers. The Administration is sending an additional 26 advisers, above the 19 sent by President Carter. **********He said that the military aid had been sent at the request of a ''friendly country'' and was a continuation of aid given by the previous Administration. Several Statements of Support **********Mr. Reagan's declaration of support for the Salvadoran Government followed similar statements yesterday by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and other officials. These statements came in answer to rumors that right-wing officers were planning a coup to oust President Duarte. **********''What we're all intending to say is that we could have to view very seriously such an attempt and such a coup,'' said Mr. Reagan.  ''We're there at the request of the Government. We're supporting a Government which we believe has an intention of improving the society there, for the benefit of the people, and we're opposed to terrorism of the right or left. It would be of the gravest concern to us if there were such a thing.'' **********Before the President's news conference, the State Department said that the electoral process announced by President Duarte yesterday with the installation of a national electoral commission offered a ''peaceful, democratic'' way to end the guerrilla war in that country. **********William J. Dyess, a department spokesman, said that the United States ''strongly supports'' the commission, which will prepare for elections of a constitutional assembly next year. **********''We believe this progress toward elections will permit the people of El Salvador to choose their leaders and determine the future of their country,'' he said. **********The United States has been informed, Mr. Dyess said, that Mr.  Duarte would support the presence of an independent observer team in his country ''to insure that the elections are fair.'' **********Although no details have been announced, the governing junta headed by Mr. Duarte has said that the election of an assembly to modify the constitution would be followed in 1983 by national elections for a constitutional government. New Economic Aid Weighed **********During the last 14 months, El Salvador has been torn by political violence in which left-wing guerrillas have been trying to overthrow the Government. **********The Reagan Administration, in addition to sending the 26 additional military advisers, has added $25 million in equipment and arms to an earlier package of $10.4 million in military aid. The Administration is also considering an increased economic aid program, which the Salvadoran Government says is essential in helping it overcome the threat from the guerrillas. **********Mr. Dyess said that the electoral proposals of Mr. Duarte's Government offered ''an excellent chance to bring stability to the country and to establish a viable political process.'' **********The Government has extended for another month an offer of amnesty to guerrillas who lay down their arms under a so-called ''pacification plan.'' **********At the same time, Francisco Aquino, a Salvadoran banker who has been Ambassador to the United States for the last year, announced he would leave his post April 1. **********No replacement for Mr. Aquino was announced, but it was expected that Mr. Duarte would name a figure from the Salvadoran Christian Democratic party to represent his Government here at a time when cooperation with the United States in economic as well as military aid will be a key political issue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/busin.body_text: **********Trading opened today in domestic certificates of deposit on the Chicago Board of Trade, marking the start of an intense battle for dominance of the market. **********The Board of Trade competes directly with the New York Futures Exchange, a unit of the New York Stock Exchange, where C.D. trading started two weeks ago. And the rival Chicago Mercantile Exchange will enter the market next week. **********Board of Trade officials in Chicago predict that only two exchanges will survive the coming battle. They believe the board's large infrastructure of experienced floor traders with access to substantial capital give it an edge over the other two exchanges. **********''There will probably end up being a primary and a secondary market,'' predicted Leslie Rosenthal, chairman of the C.B.T. ''And we'll be one that's in.'' **********Predictably, the New York view was different. Frank J. Jones, senior vice president and chief of economic research at N.Y.F.E., has said repeatedly that the C.B.T. would have difficulty trading a ''perishable commodity'' such as C.D.'s because that exchange has traditionally been a market for non-perishable commodities, such as grains and 20-year Treasury bonds. **********The C.B.T. contract calls for future delivery of 90-day, $1 million C.D.'s, issued by the country's leading banks. C.D.'s represent amounts of $100,000 or more deposited with banks for specified time periods. **********An estimated 3,474 contracts changed hands yesterday on the C.B.T., against 2,588 traded on opening day at the N.Y.F.E. Volume has since eased at the New York Futures Exchange. Trading volume was 1,641 contracts yesterday. **********Analysts predict that bankers will quickly become the contract's biggest users. They maintain that certificates of deposit provide an effective hedging mechanism for banks' mortgage and loan portfolios. **********Meanwhile, in New York, evidence of the coming battle has already begun to arise. Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. has increased commissions for small Treasury bond and Treasury bill contracts executed at the New York Futures Exchange, making it financially more attractive to trade in New York rather than Chicago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/05/busin.body_text: **********The revised tax plan announced today by the President includes these highlights: **********INCOME TAX CUT: A cut of 5 percent Oct. 1, followed by a cut of 10 percent on July 1, 1982, and another 10 percent cut July 1, 1983.  MARRIAGE ''TAX PENALTY'': A phased-in reduction in taxes paid by married couples of $400 million next year, $4 billion in 1983, $7.2 billion in 1984 and $8.6 billion in 1986. **********It would be accomplished by allowing the lower-earning spouse to deduct 5 percent of income up to $30,000, or a $1,500 limit, in 1982, and 10 percent, with a $3,000 limit, in 1983. **********ESTATE AND GIFT TAXES: All estates up to $600,000 would be exempt from inheritance taxes. The White House estimated that this would exempt 99.6 percent of estates. The current gift tax exemption of $3,000 a year for recipients would be raised to $10,000. **********SAVINGS AND INVESTMENT INCENTIVES: The Administration would make permanent the current temporary exclusion from taxes of the first $200 in interest and dividend income for individuals and $400 for married couples. **********ACCELERATED DEPRECIATION: Buildings would be depreciated over 15 years, instead of the 10 years originally proposed by the Reagan Administration, equipment over 5 years and vehicles over 3 years.  The write-offs for vehicles and equipment would remain unchanged from the President's earlier proposal. **********RETIREMENT SAVINGS: The maximum annual deposit in individual retirement accounts would be raised to $2,000 from $1,500. And employees covered by company for tax-deductible retirement accounts of up to $1,000 a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/30/busin.body_text: **********The rate of inflation in the European Common Market rose to 13.8 percent last year from 9.9 percent in 1979, the group's statistics bureau said today. **********The biggest increase in prices among the nine members last year was in Italy, with 21.2 percent. **********But in Greece, which became the 10th member of the European Economic Community this month, prices rose 24.7 percent. **********West Germany had the lowest rate, 5.5 percent. Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Belgium also had comparatively low inflation. France, where prices rose by 13.6 percent, and Britain, with an 18 percent increase, were among those worst hit by inflation. **********The bureau did not comment on the inflation statistics, but E.E.C.  officials have pointed to the rising cost of imported energy as a primary cause. They have urged members to curb oil consumption and seek alternative sources of energy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/26/busin.body_text: **********In a political gesture to the French Government, the United States has ended the ban on the import of certain steel products from Creusot-Loire of France, Administration officials said today. The Carter Administration had imposed the ban in retaliation for the company's agreement to build a steel mill in the Soviet Union. **********The officials said that the Federal Register would disclose tomorrow that a formal agreement has been reached with the French Government to allow the resumption of imports from Creusot-Loire. **********Creusot-Loire had agreed to build a $350 million electric steel plant in Lipetsk after an American company, Armco, had canceled plans to build a more elaborate plant in the same locale, 350 miles south of Moscow, because of the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan. **********The official reason given for the ban last November was that the nickel alloy in the steel may have come from Cuba in possible violation of the trade embargo against that country. The French Government insisted that the nickel did not come from Cuba. A Technical Accord **********Working through its lawyer, William N. Walker of New York, Creusot-Loire appealed directly and through the French Government to the Reagan Administration and was told that the new American leaders did not want to ''harass'' an ally. As a result, a technical arrangement was completed by which the French Government certified that the steel did not contain nickel from Cuba. **********But officials acknowledged that the decision to resolve the problem was more political than anything else. It had first been planned to announce the decision when Foreign Minister Jean Francois Poncet of France was here last month. **********But the transaction was not concluded until last week, when the Treasury Department and the French Embassy exchanged letters, officials said. The value of the Creusot-Loire exports to the United States is about $50 million a year, officials said. **********The dispute with France had been bitter, officials said. The Carter Administration said that the French company was trying to substitute its own contract for one that had been worked out by Armco, of Middletown, Ohio, and the Nippon Steel Company of Japan.  The French, however, insisted that Creusot-Loire was not building the same kind of plant that had been planned by the Japanese-American group. **********The French said that their plant was smaller and less technologically advanced. What disturbed the Carter Administration was that France was continuing to deal in any technology at all with the Soviet Union after the Afghanistan intervention.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/12/busin.body_text: **********Subroto, president of OPEC, said that the group did not anticipate any increase in the price of its oil during 1982, which would mean a decline in real terms. **********Mr. Subroto, Indonesia's Mines and Energy Minister, told a con ference of the Asian Council on Petroleum that ''the feeling amongOPEC members is that we should freeze the price in 1982 so as to givea chance to t he world to recuperate from economic sickness. **********''This means that the real price will decline, dependent on the rate of inflation,'' he said.  Mr. Subroto said that world oil demand would rise slightly in first quarter 1982, to 50 million barrels a day, but would then drop to 47 million in the second and third quarters. **********He said that a shortfall between global production of 46.6 million barrels a day and the demand at the start of the year would be covered by continuing draw-down on stocks. **********Production by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was expected to be 22.7 million barrels a day by the year's end, against 26.8 million at the start of 1981, and was expected to stay at around 22 million through 1982. **********Oil stocks of the non-Communist world were expected to be 4.04 billion barrels at the end of 1981, compared with 4.4 billion at the start of the year, This would leave average stocks sufficient to meet 101 days' supply, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/world.main_headline: U.S. PLANS A MISSION TO SOUTHERN AFRICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/world.print_headline: U.S. PLANS A MISSION TO SOUTHERN AFRICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration has ended a major policy review and plans to announce that it will send a high-level mission to Africa to explore ways of bringing about the independence of South-West Africa, as well as settling other key problems with South Africa. **********Administration officials said today that the White House was expected to announce shortly, perhaps as soon as Monday, that Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State-designate for African Affairs, would visit the so-called front-line states of Angola, Botswana, Mozambique, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe, as well as South Africa. **********A purpose of the mission, officials said, is to open a constructive dialogue with South Africa on ways to bring about change in that country, while reassuring the black African leaders of the Administration's interest in finding an internationally acceptable formula for ending South Africa's control of South-West Africa, also known as Namibia. U.S. Seeks Support in Africa **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who met yesterday with the External Affairs Minister of Nigeria, Ishaya Audu, and held a reception for African ambassadors last night, has been concerned about speculation in many parts of the world that the Reagan Administration would drastically revise American policy toward Africa, with a bias toward South Africa. **********Mr. Haig is said to hope that the Crocker mission will produce more support in Africa for American policy and provide a catalyst for reviving the Namibian talks, which have been stalemated since January. **********The details of the policy review will not be made public at this time, officials said, so that Mr. Crocker can discuss American ideas with the African leaders in confidence. **********Mr. Audu said yesterday that he was ''personally optimistic'' about the American policy. As to Namibia, he said, ''I'm convinced that the United States has very positive plans of furthering this in the direction that we all would like to see.'' **********Nigeria is crucial because it is the most populous African country and because its oil wealth has become a major political force on behalf of bringing about a solution in Namibia. **********One element of the policy review became known last week when the Reagan Administration pledged $75 million in economic aid to Zimbabwe, formerly Rhodesia, for each of the next three years, for a total of $225 million. **********In another gesture to the Africans, the State Department announced that the Administration had reaffirmed the policy of forbidding highranking South African military officers from coming to the United States for talks with American officials and prohibiting American officers from traveling to South Africa. **********Earlier this month, four high-ranking South African military intelligence officers visited the United States on visas that the State Department said had been obtained improperly. It said that the officers had not been identified on the visa applications as military men. While in the United States some of them met with officials of the National Security Council and the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency. **********In addition, one of them met with Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, but she contended that she also did not know ahead of time that he was a military officer. Bush to Attend Refugee Conference **********As another sign of American interest in Africa, Vice President Bush will attend an international conference in Geneva on April 9 and 10 that will be devoted to the problem of African refugees. **********Acknowledging the speculation about American policy toward Africa, Mr. Haig said last Thursday before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee, ''I understand that there are a lot of nervous messages, if you will, on the airwaves, with respect to future American policies in southern Africa.'' **********Mr. Haig, in his statements on Africa to the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, said: ''Let me assure you, we are sensitive to a number of inherent contradictions in the area. One is the need to maintain an effective dialogue with the Government of South Africa as we pursue the changes that we have historically sought there that are desirable. Namibian Independence Urged **********''Secondly, is to recognize that the so-called front-line states have a vital interest in the outcome of the situation, especially Namibia. We have already endorsed an independent Namibia which would receive the support and approval of the international community.'' **********Mr. Haig said that he had been discussing the Namibia situation with the four Western nations that, with the United States, had taken the lead in seeking to promote a negotiated settlement since 1977.  They are Britain, Canada, France and West Germany. **********''We'll soon initiate a program that the President has already considered at some length,'' he said, alluding to the projected Crocker mission. **********Mr. Haig also said that it would be wrong to label African countries that receive Soviet military aid ''Marxist'' even if they may call themselves that. Africa and Soviet Aid **********He said, ''An increasing number of black African states that have become the recipients of Soviet military equipment and increased levels of Soviet influence are having second thoughts about the desirability of that kind of relationship which is essentially inorganic.'' **********''It is built almost exclusively on the provision of lethal weapons,'' the Secretary said. ''It does not include the kind of developmental assistance that turns developing states into modern states.'' **********''Many are very free about labeling these recipient states as Marxist,'' he said. ''Some have suggested they will be Marxists or democrats, depending on their assessment of which label will bring them the progress for their people that they seek. And I'm one that shares that view.'' **********In addition to the unresolved Namibia question, the Crocker mission is expected to discuss such questions as future relations with Angola. Washington has refused to establish diplomatic relations with Angola because of the continued presence of about 20,000 Cuban troops. Issue of Aid to Angolan Guerrillas **********The Angolans have said in the past that the Cubans would leave once there was a Namibian solution, ending the threat of South African military intervention. An issue that has received considerable attention is that of future American aid to the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, a pro-Western guerrilla organization known by its initials as Unita and headed by Jonas Savimbi. Mr. Savimbi had been scheduled to visit Washington, but the State Department said that the trip had been postponed indefinitely at his request. **********The Reagan Administration is planning to ask Congress to lift the law barring aid to groups such as Unita, but that legislation is unlikely to be acted upon before the end of the summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/21/world.body_text: **********Israel has moved to make it more difficult for Jewish emigrants arriving in Vienna from the Soviet Union to go anywhere else but Israel. **********Nearly 85 percent of the emigrants reaching Vienna with visas for Israel have gone elsewhere in recent months. **********Of these, 90 percent went to the United States as refugees. **********The Jewish Agency for Israel, which handles immigration to Israel, this week began giving assistance to emigrants to go elsewhere than Israel only if their motives are to join parents, children or spouses. Others are being offered the option of flying to Israel or remaining in Vienna. **********Arye Dulzin, chairman of the agency, said in Jerusalem today that only 700 Jews had left the Soviet Union last month compared with 2,000 in July 1980 and 4,000 in July 1979. ''The dropouts are sealing the fate of tens of thousands of Jews who wish to leave Russia,'' he said. **********Mr. Dulzin said that the Austrian Government was informed of the change in policy two weeks ago.  He said prospective emigrants in the Soviet Union have also been apprised of the new situation through the Dutch Embassy, which looks after Israeli interests in Moscow, and through other means.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/busin.print_headline: Slow Steel Growth Predicted in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/busin.body_text: **********Hiroshi Takano, the executive vice president of steel making for Nippon Kokan K.K., Japan's second-largest steel company after the Nippon Steel Corporation, said yesterday that the era of rapid expansion for the Japanese steel industry had come to an end and that his company foresees growth in steel output falling to 2 percent to 3 percent a year. **********In recent years, Japanese steel producers enjoyed annual increases in raw steel production of up to 20 percent as the industry expanded to meet growing demand at home, and as it penetrated such major markets as Europe and the United States. **********In an interview in New York, Mr. Takano said that his company did not foresee much growth in steel exports for Japan and that this sitution ''will remain so for considerable time in the future.'' **********He said that China was not expected to become a major market for Japanese steel exports because it was suffering from a lack of foreign exchange to pay for them. **********Mr. Takano estimated that the United States this year would import 5.1 million to 5.6 million metric tons of steel from Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/29/busin.main_headline: Market Place; A Fund Invests In 4 Industries
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/29/busin.print_headline: Market Place; A Fund Invests In 4 Industries
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/29/busin.body_text: **********IN the past, when an investor sought appreciation through mutual funds, he usually selected among growth funds that represented a cross section of industries. Few funds concentrated on a specific industry, and some of their investors became unhappy when the chosen group fell out of favor. The problem has grown as market leadership has shifted more frequently in recent years. **********Now the Fidelity Management and Research Company is offering a new vehicle called Fidelity Select Portfolios, which is intended to appeal to individuals interested in four specific growth sectors: precious metals, energy, technology and health care. **********Investors in the fund who favor one or more of these groups will be allowed to shift from one to another as many as four times a year without charge. Any additional changes in the same year will cost $50 each. **********Peter Lynch, who is a vice president of Fidelity Management and Research, the $11 billion Boston-based money management concern, observes that some segments of the stock market have enjoyed ''startling'' performance for extended periods while the market as a whole has done less well. In the last 15 years, he noted, the market has been relatively even as measured by both the Dow Jones industrial average and the broadly based Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks. **********In recent months the health care sector has been strong and the technology category has been somewhat less so, while the energy and precious metals groups have been weak. **********Mr. Lynch said that any investor buying shares of the new fund could pick a group in hopes of market appreciation and then let professionals analyze and choose securities within the group. **********''Thus, the investor makes the strategic decision, and Fidelity carries out the tactics,'' he said. ''More-over, the fund pays commissions at the institutional rate, which can be 75 percent lower than the individual would pay - 10 cents a share or even less.'' The fund is a no-load vehicle, so investors obtain fund shares at their net asset value without having to pay extra for a sales commission. **********In addition to the right to shift from group to group, the investor has the option of moving into a special account for Fidelity Cash Reserves, one of the company's money market funds. Thus the investor can strike a defensive position during periods of an uncertain stock market. **********Mr. Lynch said Fidelity might create more sectors for the fund (in addition to the present four) if other industries begin to look promising. Each of the four portfolios, he added, is managed by a specialist who works full-time in that segment of the market.  Apparently no similar funds are in registration at this time.  Fidelity is so sure that the flexibility offered by the new fund will appeal to investors, however, that it expects competitors to offer similar funds in the future. **********Fidelity Select Portfolios opened for investment last Tuesday.  Applications are made by mail or telephone to the headquarters of the company, so the new fund has taken in little money so far. **********The minimum initial investment is $5,000. If an investor wants to participate in more than one portfolio, $5,000 is required for each.  Subsequent purchases are available in $250 minimums - $1,000 if made by telephone. Mr. Lynch said all normal mutual fund services would be available, including reinvestment of dividends and capital gains. **********Mr. Lynch cautioned that the new fund would offer ''absolutely no guidance as to which section of the market covered by the various sectors of the fund is thought to be most attractive at a given moment in time.'' **********It remains to be seen, of course, whether the market performance of any of the four chosen groups will be better than that of other groups. It also remains to be seen whether Fidelity's money managers will do better than the average within each chosen sector. **********Technically speaking, the new vehicle is known as a ''series'' fund. It is the latest of several mutual funds that offer an investor a choice among specialized portfolios. **********For example, Vanguard's no-load Warwick Fund offers three separate portfolios of tax-exempt securities. In that fund the categories are set apart by maturity, with short-, medium-and long-term portfolios offered. Other tax-exempt series funds offer a choice on the basis of maturity or quality of bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/07/busin.body_text: **********Four labor unions are considering wage concessions to help bail out financially ailing Pan American World Airways, union officials said today. **********Representatives of the unions will meet with Pan Am's chairman, William T. Seawell, this week to discuss what labor leaders described as ''direct employee financial involvement'' in the airline, which lost $87.8 million last year. **********Pan Am, which acquired National Airlines last year, saw its losses mount to $114.5 million in the first quarter and is facing a longterm debt of $1 billion. **********In a letter to Mr. Seawell, delivered last Thursday, the unions' Pan Am Joint Labor Council said it recognizes ''the urgency of the corporation's economic situation and will do whatever is necessary to make it survive.'' **********Allen Widdicombe, a board member of the Pan American chapter of the Flight Engineers' International Association, confirmed that the unions were considering wage concessions, but added that ''we're not willing to give them a blank check.'' **********In addition to financial aid, the unions said in the letter to Mr.  Seawell that they envisioned a plan that ''would involve employee input into the decision-making process in developing a long-range corporate philosophy and strategic operating plan.'' **********One union unwilling to offer assitance to Pan American represents flight attendants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/08/world.main_headline: AMID AN INCREASING SENSE OF CRISIS, POLISH PARTY LEADERS CALL A MEETING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/08/world.print_headline: AMID AN INCREASING SENSE OF CRISIS, POLISH PARTY LEADERS CALL A MEETING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/08/world.body_text: **********Amid a sense that Poland is drifting toward crisis once again, the Communist Party Central Committee scheduled a meeting for Tuesday to discuss the situation in the country and prepare for a national party congress. **********The move came as Poland's Communist allies were reported to be putting substantially increasing pressure on the party leadership here to get the situation in hand. **********(In West Germany, the television network ARD reported that the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee sent an ''ultimatum'' to the Polish Central Committee and that the Soviet message was the main reason for Tuesday's meeting, according to The Associated Press.) No More Compromise **********Poland's Deputy Prime Minister, Mieczyslaw Rakowski, said in a speech that the party had exhausted its capacity for compromise in dealing with Solidarity, the independent trade union organization.  Mr. Rakowski will meet Solidarity negotiators tomorrow. **********He said that the patience of the authorities and of Poland's Eastern bloc neighbors was running thin, and he declared that the very existence of the country was at stake. **********Such language has not been heard here for several months, and it was one more sign that the crisis is heating up again, at a time of a widening rift between the party leaderships in Warsaw and Moscow. Protests and Hunger Strikes **********In the last week, there were protests against prison conditions, hunger strikes to support the release of political prionsers and a vote by Solidarity to stage a two-hour warning strike this week. **********There were also events that did not make the headlines but that indicated a new and possibly dangerous direction of popular discontent. For the second time, a monument to commemorate the deaths of Soviet soldiers in World War II was desecrated, this time in the town of Rybnik. A five-pointed star was ripped off and an inscription was painted over on a monument in a cemetary containing the ashes of more than 1,800 Red Army soldiers. **********In the western city of Poznan, the Soviet Consul General died under mysterious circumstances after shots were fired inside the consulate Tuesday night. Various stories made the rounds - that he was killed when a hunting gun he was cleaning accidentally discharged, or that there had been an altercation with an employee. **********In the absence of any reliable information - the Soviet Embassy has refused comment - there is no reason to read a political motive behind the act. Still, rumors and apparently even anonymous leaflets have circulated that the Consul, Rudolf Skvortsov, was assassinated. **********Solidarity, meeting without its chairman, Lech Walesa, who was in Geneva to attend an international labor organization conference, voted to go ahead with a two-hour protest strike in four northern provinces on Thursday. **********The protest is intended to make the authorities honor a pledge to investigate and reveal the names of officials responsible for calling in the police who beat up Solidarity members while evicting them from a local council meeting in Bydgoszcz on March 19. Church Opposes Strikes **********The strike vote, 22 to 13, was taken despite the pleadings of Bishop Jan Michalski, who addressed the delegates in person and said he was speaking in the name of the late Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski. He told them that the Roman Catholic Church firmly opposed further strikes and that the delegates carried the fate of the nation in their hands. **********Solidarity and Government negotiators are scheduled to meet tomorrow to try to resolve the issue. Both sides have expressed confidence that they can settle it without a strike, and this may well be the case. But the fact that a strike vote was taken seemed to point to a resurgence of militancy on the part of local Solidarity leaders. Suspension Period Due to End **********On April 10, Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski won a resolution in Parliament that called for a two-month suspension of strikes. The suspension period ends on Wednesday. **********Many union leaders appear to feel that the Government has not accomplished much during its grace period. None of the longstanding list of union demands, ranging from a curb on censorship to the promulgation of a new trade union law, have been satisfactorily concluded, although some progress has been made. **********The police in Bydgoszcz sent an open letter yesterday to a party conference in that city in which they disclaimed responsibility for the incident last March, in which three Solidarity members were seriously injured. They warned that they did not want to become political scapegoats. **********''We consider that the sources of the events of March 19 lie beyond the leadership of the Bydgoszcz civic militia,'' the letter said, as quoted by Warsaw radio. ''The right people must be brought to account, and not functionaries who are just carrying out their duties. We demand that the political and administrative authorities do not treat our organs as an instrument for their own exclusive purposes.'' **********People close to the investigation have privately said that the police used to evict the Solidarity members were brought in from other localities. Some Police Are Organizing **********As a further sign of restiveness, the police have recently begun to organize their own independent union in various parts of the country, although this is not being done under Solidarity's auspices. **********The tensions are rising at a time when the Soviet and Eastern bloc press in general is stepping up a campaign against the Polish party leadership, which in a rare move called a congress for July 14. The Soviet press has implicitly supported a small, hard-line faction in southern Poland called the Katowice Discussion Forum. **********Last week Tass, the official Soviet press agency, carried a dispatch from Warsaw that described how a Solidarity leader in the southern town of Zawiercie had threatened violence against the Communist authorities if they did not remove a Soviet flag from a local council building and change street names associated with the Soviet Union. **********The union man, Bohdan Krakowski, told Western journalists that he had been misquoted. He said he had asked only that the Polish flag be allowed to fly alongside the Soviet flag ''so that everyone might know that we are living in a Polish city, not a Soviet city.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/03/world.body_text: **********The funeral service of Terry Fox, a 22-year-old college student who died Sunday of cancer, was televised nationally today as part of an extraordinary tribute to Canada's greatest national hero in memory. Since Monday, flags on federal and many provincial buildings have flown at half-staff, an honor usually reserved for major public officials. **********Hundreds of memorial services were held across the country, one of them before the Parliament building in Ottawa, as Mr. Fox was buried in his hometown of Port Coquitlam, British Columbia. A star school athlete before he lost a leg to cancer in 1977, he aroused wide admiration last year by attempting a ''marathon of hope,'' running across the country on one good leg and an artificial leg to raise funds for cancer research. **********He was stopped halfway through when cancer spread to his lungs. The marathon attempt raised more than $20 million, and more money began to flow into offices of the Canadian Cancer Society this week.
