https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/28/busin.body_text: **********Following the threat of a hastily mounted proxy fight between members of the founding family, a new chief executive officer and a new chairman have been elected at the Tasty Baking Company, a producer of cakes, pies and biscuits and a distributor of toys and graphic arts materials. The changes at the Philadelphia company came after it reported losses in the last three quarters. **********Nelson G. Harris, the 54-year-old president, was named to the additional post of chief executive officer. Philip J. Baur Jr., 50, who had been vice chairman, was appointed chairman. His brother-inlaw, Paul R. Kaiser, 64, who had been chairman and chief executive officer, became chairman emeritus. **********''I will make an in-depth marketing study and then take whatever steps are necessary to see that our products are in step with the marketplace,'' Mr. Harris said in a telephone interview. ''I will spend a great deal more time on policies, strategic planning and corporate concepts.'' **********A few weeks ago, a dissident group, including Mr. Harris and Mr.  Baur, said that it would nominate five directors to the company's nine-member board to change management policies. Last Thursday night, the members of the Baur family, which co-founded Tasty, met and decided on the management changes that were announced to stockholders at the annual meeting the following day. In addition, Louise B.  Kaiser, Mr. Kaiser's wife and Mr. Baur's sister, resigned as a director, allowing for the election of the five dissidents and the four board members who supported the previous management. **********Mr. Harris, a lawyer and a certified public accountant, worked early in his career for his father's accounting firm, which handled the Tasty account. He joined the corporation in 1953 and moved upward in the hierarchy until leaving 15 years later to become president of the Horn & Hardart Company. Mr. Harris became president of the Industrial Valley Corporation in 1970 and returned to Tasty two years ago as president and chief operating officer. **********Mr. Baur has been at Tasty for 30 years, becoming vice chairman and president of its Tastykake unit in 1979. Mr. Kaiser, who began his career at the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company, came to Tasty in 1951 as a vice president and has been head of the company since 1952. **********''My present thinking is to recommend to the board that a portion of the senior officers' salaries and all or part of the directors' fees be withheld until dividends are resumed,'' Mr. Harris said.  ''And I do plan on making a very comprehensive analysis of various costs, including the utilization of the company airplane.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/25/busin.main_headline: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN OCTOBER BY A SLIGHT 0.4%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/25/busin.print_headline: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN OCTOBER BY A SLIGHT 0.4%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/25/busin.body_text: **********With housing prices falling and food inflation slowing, the Consumer Price Index rose by only four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the smallest increase in six months. **********Spread over a year, such a monthly increase would add up to an annual inflation rate of only 4.8 percent, not compounded. That was a welcome slowdown from the pace of more than 10 percent in the summer months and economists said they expected the index to continue to show small rises for several more months. **********A decline last month of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the sale price of houses was symptomatic of the way many economists hope that the current recession as well as high interest rates -which have been savaging the housing market - will squeeze down inflation. **********'Not Seen Since the 1930's **********''We have a deflation in prices of homes of a magnitude we have not seen since the 1930's,'' said Michael Sumichrast, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, the housing industry's major trade group. **********''This sagging economy is having a favorable effect on the inflation rate,'' added Robert Ortner, the Commerce Department's chief economist. **********The slight October rise in the price index meant that, since Jan.  1, the index has risen at an annual rate of 9.6 percent. With moderate increases expected for November and December, it appeared likely that the Administration would realize its forecast of a 1981 rise below 10 percent in the nation's most widely followed measure of inflation at the retail level. Summarized by White House **********Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, told President Reagan in a memorandum summarized by the White House that he hoped the October index would contribute to further declines of interest rates, which started to fall last month from the unusually high summer levels. **********Home loan interest rates, which have been on an upward path for two years or more, edged down in October by one-tenth of 1 percent, thus contributing to the more moderate performance of the price index. All of the slight easing came from Federal agency reductions in maximum interest rates on federally underwritten home loans. **********Analysts believe that conventional loan rates have started to come down in recent weeks and will continue to do so gradually through the winter. **********Such a trend would offset increases in other components of the Consumer Price Index, just as the upswing of mortgage rates was seen as exaggerating inflation. **********Theodore Torda, a senior Commerce Department economist, commented that the October index was ''an aberration on the low side'' because the ''underlying inflation rate, we think, is still in the range of 8 to 9 percent.'' **********Other analysts said that small rises in the index would help moderate wage increases and so contribute to an easing of cost-price pressures. Wage increases in a number of union contracts are tied to increases in the price index. **********By comparison, the index had risen 1.2 percent in September, or at an annual rate of 14.4 percent, not compounded. Rising food and housing costs had contributed to the September jump, before the growing recession changed this trend in October. New Experimental Variation **********The October rise of four-tenths of 1 percent, calculated after adjustment for normal seasonal changes, was appreciably below the adjusted rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent that would have occurred in October under a new experimental variation of the index, known as C.P.I. X-1. The housing component in this index uses an estimate for rents instead of home purchase costs. The difference in the two indexes reflected the considerable effect on the current index exerted by changes of house prices and mortgage interest rates. **********The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which compiles the price index, announced on Oct. 27 that, starting with January 1983, it would use rental data instead of home purchase costs in calculating the Consumer Price Index. **********Many analysts have said that, in periods of rising prices and loan rates, such as 1978-81, the house purchase factor distorted the index, if only because few consumers buy a house every month or even every year. Officials of the Carter and Reagan Administrations, however, resisted substituting rents for home ownership costs partly on the ground that declining house prices and interest rates would slow the overall rise of the index. Exactly that happened in October and is expected to be repeated. Below Two Million Mark **********The Bureau of Labor Statistics said that the decline in house prices was concentrated in the Northeast and North Central states.  The National Association of Realtors reported that, because of high mortgage interest rates, sales of existing houses in October fell to an annual rate of 1.92 million, slipping below the two million mark for the first time in 10 years. **********Sales have dropped 39 percent in a year, said the association's chief economist, Jack Carlson. He added that the typical price of an existing house fell by $1,900 in October, to $65,200, a decline that was roughly double what usually occurs in October, often an off-month for home sales. **********Mr. Carlson forecast that further declines of house prices and mortgage loan rates would exert a moderating effect on the price index over the next few months. He forecast that mortgage loan rates would slide from more than 17 percent now to ''14 or 15 percent by spring.'' **********The Bureau of Labor Statistics delayed publication of a companion monthly report on nonfarm earnings until Wednesday because of the partial shutdown of the Government on Monday. 'Rebasing' of Index Postponed **********The bureau also announced that it had postponed indefinitely, because of cuts in its budget, its scheduled January 1982 ''rebasing'' of the price index. The index's base, now 1967 prices taken as 100, was to be shifted to 1977. That change would not affect the size of monthly changes in the index. **********Prices of food and beverages rose by two-tenths of 1 percent last month, well below their July-September pace of eight-tenths of 1 percent a month. Prices of fresh fruits and vegetables fell. Beef slipped after large summer increases. Pork rose less than in the summer. Restaurant meals were up seven-tenths of 1 percent. **********The transportation component of the index jumped 1.2 percent because of the fifth consecutive increase in the prices of used cars and a 1.2 percent rise, after seasonal adjustment, in gasoline prices. Also higher were automobile finance charges, which had been reduced in August and September to promote sales. Medical Costs Up 1 Percent **********Medical care costs climbed 1 percent last month, the 10th consecutive month of increases of nine-tenths of 1 percent or more.  Charges for hospital rooms had another large increase, rising 1.6 percent. Profesional fees rose seven-tenths of 1 percent. Drugs and medical supplies increased eight-tenths of 1 percent. **********Within the housing component, prices for heating oil and electricity declined but prices rose again for natural gas. Rent and household furnishings were higher. **********On the 1967 base of 100, the October index stood at 279.9 - goods and services that cost $100 in 1967 cost $279.90 last month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/17/world.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; COOL HOSTAGE NEGOTIATOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/17/world.body_text: **********Deputy Secretary of State Warren M.  Christopher has seldom enjoyed the limelight, preferring instead to work hard and discreetly backstage, so it probably suited him fine this afternoon to be absent from the White House when President Carter named him one of 15 recipients of the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor. **********But even though Mr. Christopher was 4,000 miles away in Algeria, trying to negotiate the freedom of the American hostages in Iran before time runs out on the Carter Administration, Mr. Carter got the slim, taciturn Californian on the phone from the East Room to praise him for service to country. **********''Warren Christopher,'' Mr. Carter said, reading the official proclamation honoring the 55-year-old No. 2 State Department official, ''has the tact of a true diplomat, the tactical skills of a great soldier, the analytical ability of a fine lawyer and the selfless dedication of a citizen-statesman. His perseverance and loyalty, judgment and skill have won for his country new respect around the world and new regard for the State Department here at home.'' **********The description contained most of the adjectives and superlatives heard around this hypercritical capital when Mr. Christopher's name is mentioned. But then the President went further. Departing from his text, he rated Mr. Christopher the ''highest'' of all Administration officials in Washington. Most Sensitive Problems **********As the top aide to Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and then to Edmund S. Muskie, Mr. Christopher has handled some of the most sensitive diplomatic problems faced by the Administration. **********He helped smooth the way for passage of the much-disputed Panama Canal treaties, helped win approval of shipments of high-technology arms to Arab nations and went to Taiwan to reassure the Nationalist Chinese when the United States and China moved to strengthen ties.  In Taipei demonstrators broke a window in his limousine and he suffered cuts and bruises. **********When Soviet troops moved into Afghanistan, Mr. Christopher was sent to Europe for talks with allied governments about imposing sanctions. For several months he has concentrated almost exclusively on efforts to free the hostages in Iran, shuttling back and forth between Washington and Algiers, the meeting point for intermediaries, often going for long stretches without rest but always emerging from the work sessions with the unrumpled demeanor of a diplomat. Strong at Negotiations **********Mr. Christopher's greatest strength is said to be his ability to negotiate. Unfailingly courteous and soft-spoken, cool and collected, organized and prepared, he is said to have a knack for winning concessions without making his adversary feel boxed in.  ''Never get mad except on purpose,'' he tells aides. **********While negotiations are under way and especially when they are over, Mr. Christopher avoids reporters. In a town where egos usually intrude, he sometimes seems to have none. **********A longtime friend says that the Deputy Secretary's lack of ego and his great caution are the main reasons he has never held a Cabinetlevel post in three decades of being in and out of Washington. ''This is a town of games and risks and politics and Chris just doesn't play that way,'' the friend added. ''He was trained as a lawyer and he's a lawyer's lawyer. But if you don't play in Washington, you're always going to be No. 2.'' Mechanic, Not Philosopher **********Others say Mr. Christopher has never been given a Cabinet job because he is not true Cabinet material. ''More a mechanic than a philosopher,'' says Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens. **********When Mr. Vance resigned as Secretary of State last spring over the abortive raid to free the hostages in Iran, there was speculation for a few days that Mr. Christopher might be moved up. But in the end, President Carter named Mr. Muskie. **********Warren Minor Christopher was born Oct. 27, 1925, in Scranton, N.D.  His father, a banker, was hit hard by the Depression and illness, and the family moved to Los Angeles. After serving in the Navy, Mr.  Christopher received a law degree from Stanford University in 1949, doing so well that Justice William O. Douglas asked him to serve as his clerk for a year. Dabbled in California Politics **********After that he returned to Los Angeles and joined O'Melveny & Myers, one of the largest and most influential law firms on the West Coast.  As a young California lawyer, Mr. Christopher dabbled in Democratic politics, and eventually his political associations led him to Washington, where he served as a trade negotiator, then in a group looking into the causes of urban riots, then as Deputy Attorney General in the Johnson Administration. **********In 1973 Mr. Christopher was approached about becoming the special Watergate prosecutor. He turned down the job on the ground he had not been promised enough freedom. **********Mr. Christopher is married to the former Marie Josephine Wyllis, and they have four children. An earlier marriage ended in divorce.  He spends his scarce free time with his family or on the tennis court. He also jogs, arising at 5:30 for his daily run, sometimes on the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal towpath.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/28/world.main_headline: A BOLD POLISH PAPER WINS READERS BUT WORRIES CENSORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/28/world.print_headline: A BOLD POLISH PAPER WINS READERS BUT WORRIES CENSORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/28/world.body_text: **********Some months ago Maciej Szumowski, the editor of the Cracow daily newspaper Gazeta Krakowska, was having technical difficulties with the press run. The paper was late and still not on the stands when his phone rang. It was a call from Solidarity union leaders in the gigantic Nowa Huta steel mill: They just wanted him to know that they were drawing up strike plans because, they assumed, the censor had stopped publication. **********The assumption was not so far-fetched, for Gazeta Krakowska is considered the most outspoken and courageous newspaper in Poland and has had more than one brush with the censor. The fact that a few hours' delay in publication was almost enough to shut down the largest steel mill in the country shows how much workers value the abstract right to read relatively unfettered news. **********It is perhaps a lesson not to be lost on the authorities, who have pledged to rein in the press and other mass media to try to mollify the Soviet Union. A letter from the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party this month charged that the Polish news media had fallen into the hands of ''the enemy'' and were being used to ''undermine socialism.'' **********The reaction to the letter has not been, for the moment at least, a 180-degree turn. Newspapers still carry accounts of events not usually covered in the Communist world and commentaries critical of the Government, although television, which responds more quickly to control from above, seems suddenly vapid, with a great deal of air time devoted to official ceremonies and ambassadors presenting their credentials. Journalists Urge Freer Expression **********Last week the journalists' association passed a resolution that said, in effect, that the press must continue its role of reflecting the national need for freer expression. Journalists must be responsible for what they write and must be conscious of the interests of the state, but should not abandon a critical outlook, it said. **********The changes that have taken place are largely behind the scenes.  Jozef Klasa, the Central Committee member in charge of press, radio and television, a liberal, resigned. He was replaced by Leslaw Tokarski, editor of the weekly magazine Perspektywy, who is a onetime protege of Stefan Olszowski, ranking hard-liner on the Politburo. The position is critical in determing how much control is exerted over editors and television producers. **********The Government is also attempting to reopen negotiations on a draft bill to curb censorship that had finally taken shape after months of talks with Solidarity, the independent union organization. The draft exempts from censorship informational bulletins for internal distribution by trade unions, and the authorities now want the exemption stricken out. **********The Polish press has come such a long way that it is hard to imagine it returning to a docile preoccupation with non-news. Many newspapers now feature long articles on the housing shortage, the collapse of medical facilities, corruption and profiteering by former party officials, and social problems ranging from drug addiction to homosexuality, which have been taboo for decades. Polish Ties With Soviet Are Taboo **********The only articles that appear to be out of bounds for the official, or censored, press are those that raise questions about Poland's relationship and military alliance with the Soviet Union, and those that directly attack the principles of Marxism-Leninism. But even here the boundary is sometimes tested. **********Some time ago Tygodnik Powszekny, the independent Roman Catholic newspaper, printed an attack on the management of the Polish economy that included this observation: ''Whereas the crisis of capitalism is a crisis of overproduction, in a planned economy it is a crisis of underproduction. The present economic crisis is the direct consequence of our system.'' **********The Polish press is now the most free in the Eastern bloc, including Yugoslavia, one Polish columnist said. But for all that, it is restrained. **********One factor in the new freedom has been a flood of ''independent'' newspapers, estimated to number between 100 and 200. Some of them bypass the censor, which is illegal but tolerated by a weakened state apparatus. Union Publishes Newspapers **********Almost every major Solidarity office has its own publication, which may be nothing more than a mimeographed sheet appearing daily, packed with information and opinion. There are also new nationwide newspapers, including Solidarnosc, the national union's weekly, with a circulation of 500,000, and Rzeczywistosc, or Reality, a new organ for conservatives that emphasizes nationalism, egalitarianism and Communist orthodoxy. Its circulation is 150,000. **********Even Trybuna Ludu, the staid and rather flat national voice of the Polish United Workers' (Communist) Party, has changed. Its articles about Solidarity reflect a degree of acceptance that is heretical to other countries, and it is no longer easily found on newsstands in Moscow and Prague. **********One irony in the situation is that it has been the Communist Party newspapers, especially in the provinces, that have been in the forefront of change. **********The unquestioned champion of the new press freedom is Gazeta Krakowska, the Communist Party newspaper of Cracow. Mr. Szumowski, a 42-year-old former television reporter and documentary film maker, and his wife, Dorotea Terkowska, a columnist, have transformed it into the most sought-after publication in Poland. Making Muckraking History **********Last fall Gazeta Krakowska made muckraking history when it published investigative reports about corruption by party officials in a nearby town. The article was even cited at a party meeting, which then expelled several officials, as support for the charges against them. It was the first case in Poland of investigative reporting that led to a direct result. **********During the Bydgoszcz incident last March, in which policemen beat up Solidarity activists, the paper again excelled. Other journalists, including those working for the Polish press agency, P.A.P., complained bitterly that their dispatches were altered beyond recognition. Gazeta Krakowska solved the problem of official sensibilities by printing three full-length front-page articles, one giving the official version, another the union's side and a third with its own facts and conclusions. **********Mr. Szumowski is modest and circumspect about his accomplishments.  He is not a crusader or a ground breaker, he said, just a newspaperman who believes in using ''good, journalistic workshop skills.'' **********''The party has called for a dialogue, and I treat that call seriously,'' he said. ''If there's to be a dialogue, well, let's have a dialogue.'' **********''I take the party at its word, and I treat seriously the agreements it struck with Solidarity,'' he added. ''There are opponents of the method of dialogue I represent - and there are people who would like to break the social accords.'' **********Mr. Szumowski has been fortunate in that the local Cracow party leadership is among the most enlightened in the country. When he becomes embroiled with the censor he calls upon the local first secretary, Krystyn Dabrowa, for support. **********The trick, he found, is often in the presentation. ''Take Bydgoszcz. Many journalists wrote about it accurately, but they couldn't get their stories printed. It's not enough to be courageous. You must support that with a knowledge of the political conditions. If a journalist hasn't learned over the past 10 years how to ski through the slalom of censorship, he won't be able to suddenly regain his agility.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/busin.main_headline: HOLDER'S SURPRISE OFFER SNAGS UA-COLUMBIA BID
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/busin.print_headline: HOLDER'S SURPRISE OFFER SNAGS UA-COLUMBIA BID
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/busin.body_text: **********The joint effort by Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. to acquire fast-growing UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc.  hit an unexpected snag yesterday when United Artists Theatre Circuit Inc. announced a tender offer that could yield it a total of nearly 50 percent of UA-Columbia's shares, at a price $10 above the bid by the two big publishers. **********The movie chain, which is already one of UA-Columbia's major shareholders, said it would offer $85 a share in cash for up to 22 percent more of UA-Columbia, 725,000 shares, eclipsing the $75 offered last month by Dow Jones and Knight-Ridder. From the beginning, United Artists Theatre Circuit has vehemently opposed that proposal as inadequate and has threatened to take whatever steps it deems necessary - including litigation - to block it. **********Since the theater chain already owns 27.6 percent of UA-Columbia's stock, if it manages to pick up the additional 725,000 shares, United Artists would control 49.6 percent of the stock, enough to effectively thwart any takeover attempt. At the $85 price, the additional shares would cost the company a total of $61.6 million. **********UA-Columbia's board approved the proposal from Dow Jones and Knight-Ridder last month by an 8-to-6 vote and was scheduled to meet yesterday morning to vote on a definitive agreement. The unexpected action from United Artists Theatre Circuit, however, disrupted those plans. What was expected to be a fairly routine meeting ended up starting two hours late and lasted well into the evening. 'A Complete Surprise' **********A UA-Columbia official said there would be no comment on the theater chain's tender offer before today. He did note that the development ''came as a complete surprise,'' and said, ''When we went home last night, we had no idea at all that this was coming.'' The United Artists tender offer is scheduled to begin today. **********Knight-Ridder and Dow Jones both said only that they were studying the development. During prepared remarks at the Dow Jones annual meeting yesterday, however, Warren H. Phillips, the company's chairman and chief executive, cautioned shareholders that it ''would be a mistake to draw conclusions at this stage.'' He said, ''This is a normal tactic to be expected in this sort of thing.'' **********United Artists Theatre Circuit declined to elaborate on its intentions with respect to UA-Columbia, saying that the tender offer papers will be self-explanatory. However, an official at Drexel Burnham Lambert, which is acting as the movie chain's investment banker and has been hunting for another suitor for UA-Columbia, would not rule out the possibility of a forthcoming offer from another party. **********In trading yesterady on the over-the-counter market, UA-Columbia stock responded to the new development by surging 5 1/2, to 78 1/4 bid. Knight-Ridder was unchanged at 34 1/4; Dow Jones was up 3/8, to 76 3/4. **********In a separate development yesterday, United Artists Theatre Circuit said that it had decided to scrap a plan to take the company private that had been under consideration since early last year. It did not elaborate on the reasons for the decision. First Bid in February **********The first offer for UA-Columbia came in late February, when Dow Jones, a diversified publisher that owns The Wall Street Journal, and Knight-Ridder, one of the country's biggest newspaper chains, offered $72 a share for all the common stock of the cable operator. In early March, they sweetened the proposal to $75, or a total of $247.5 million. Though the proposal represents one of the biggest offers for a cable operator, there was speculation that the price would not be sufficient to satisfy all of UA-Columbia's shareholders. **********Despite negative votes from the five directors representing United Artists Theatre Circuit, the UA-Columbia board approved the offer in principle, though it left the company free to entertain additional bids before a definitive agreement was ratified.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/20/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: I was dismayed by Barbara Daniel's letter ''Pro Bergmann'' (Nov.  29), responding to ''Relax, Social Security Is Doing Its Job'' (Nov.  15). Anyone who really believes that an individual's current payments into the Social Security system provide even a modicum of guarantee that, upon retirement, corresponding benefits will be returned to them does not understand the financial plight of the system. **********Far from a storehouse of benefits, our Social Security system is a hand-to-mouth operation struggling to keep afloat. And, as the Reagan Administration has rightfully noted, the ratio of hands to mouths is dwindling significantly. **********The system is headed for inevitable bankruptcy unless fundamental corrective measures are taken. Stop-gap measures, such as interfund transfers, may postpone the day of reckoning. Further increases in the tax burden on the working portion of our population - some of which are already legislated - can stave off financial collapse of the system, but not without adverse effect on the work-and-save incentive. **********Contrary to Miss Daniel's belief that high employment policies will remedy the situation, the only hope for long-term viability of the Social Security system, and the United States economy in general, is to encourage more productive employment through capital investment.  Incentives are needed to work and save, not to retire and consume.  Fundamental overhaul of Social Security, without imposing hardship on those already dependent on it, is a JAMES E. MCNABB Wilton, Conn.  Dec. 2, 1981  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.  Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Business Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/world.body_text: **********Lady Diana Spencer, who will marry Prince Charles this summer, had breakfast with Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother today after moving into Clarence House, the official London residence of the 80-year-old grandmother of the Prince. **********Later, Buckingham Palace dismissed as ''speculation'' a report here in The Guardian that the Prince's mother, Queen Elizabeth II, would appoint him governor general of Australia after he married. **********Lady Diana changed residences after an announcement of the engagement yesterday by Buckingham Palace.  A palace spokesman said the royal family had chosen Clarence House to be Lady Diana's home until the marriage because she would be close to people who can instruct her on the strict code of royal conduct.  The residence is 200 yards from the palace, where the 32-year-old Prince and heir to Britain's throne proposed to her a few weeks ago in his private sitting room.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/02/busin.body_text: **********Oil companies have begun pressing petroleum producing countries to reduce prices substantially, with some companies refusing to accept oil they consider too high-priced, petroleum industry analysts and oil traders said yesterday. Such pressures have already provoked price reductions or elimination of special surcharges by Kuwait, Iraq and Egypt. **********Companies discuss the accelerating moves in only the most guarded terms for fear of angering foreign suppliers. But they privately concede that the moves are prompted by the current glut of world oil, which in turn has led to painful losses by almost every refinery in the world. It is routine for companies to lose $3 or more on every barrel of oil processed in the present market, although many companies are still posting profits from their drilling operations.. **********Sharply lower demand, low utilization of refineries and soaring interest rates are making it impossible for companies to pass on the cost of their chief raw material, crude oil, analysts say. **********''The oil companies want to make their case politely, but they're in anguish,'' said Halsey Peckworth, editorial director of Platt's Oilgram Price Reports, a trade publication that closely tracks petroleum markets. Taking on the Producers **********As a result, the international oil companies - whose fortunes have seemed to move in tandem with those of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries since the first big price run-up in 1974 - today find themselves in a quiet war with OPEC nations and other oil producing countries, such as Mexico, Egypt, Norway and Britain. Last month's inconclusive OPEC meeting seemed to solidify the already apparent opposition to the pricing posture of producers, a major oil company official suggested. **********For consumers, analysts suggest that the emergence of the companies as advocates of lower crude prices may be some of the best news in years, following as it does a drop in retail gasoline prices of nearly 10 cents a gallon over the past two months. **********''It's going to be a great summer for petroleum consumers,'' said a planning official of one of the world's biggest oil companies.  The industry's drive for lower prices, which appears to involve most Western companies, began in the Persian Gulf region, where companies have forced Kuwait, Qatar and Iraq to abandon surcharges they formerly added to official selling prices. But its focus has shifted to the countries that sell some of the highest-priced oil in the world: Libya, Nigeria, Algeria, Mexico, Malaysia, Indonesia and the North Sea producers. Companies Take Hard Line **********Focusing attention on the industry's new stance was a statement made over the weekend by C.C. Garvin Jr., chairman of the Exxon Corporation, who said that the giant oil company had ''more oil than we see a market for.'' **********''Where the prices are not competitive with the marketplace, we think there should be an improvement,'' he urged.  The Shell Oil Company is taking a similarly determined perspective, having already walked away from a firm crude contract in Malaysia. ''We simply cannot continue to pay,'' said Henry Sullivan, manager of Shell's hydrocarbon business. **********''Those people who can terminate their contracts have terminated them,'' said a top international official of a major oil company.  ''Those that can't are negotiating and raising all the hell they can.'' Scope of Campaign **********The scope and intensity of the worldwide industry's campaign to cut oil prices is evident from a variety of recent developments: **********- Companies have walked away from long-term contracts with Malaysia, Indonesia, Nigeria and elsewhere, according to crude oil traders. Moreover, companies are pressing producers to allow them to reduce the amount of contract oil they take, without being compelled to forfeit the entire contract. **********- Libyan oil, the highest-priced in OPEC, is being offered in the market at a $2 discount by a French trading company, Mr. Peckworth said. Such price-shaving at the expense of other producers of highquality, low-sulfur oil could represent a significant price breakthrough, analysts suggested. **********- Industry delegations, from Japan as well as the United States, are said to have quietly visited Mexico to try to persuade the state oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, to cut as much as $5 from the price it charges for its best grade of crude. Mexico responded yesterday by saying it can only guarantee to maintain current price levels until July 1. Skeptical of Impact **********To be sure, longtime oil analysts are skeptical of whether the companies will be able to reduce foreign crude prices to nearly as much as they apparently would like. ''I don't think anyone in their right mind expects $41-a-barrel oil to come down to $35,'' said Marshall Thomas, markets editor of Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, a trade publication. He said that a reduction ''to maybe $37'' seems to be the unofficial industry ''target.'' **********The depth of the price reductions the companies seem to be seeking is clear when official government selling prices are compared with prices prevailing in the spot market, where oil not under long-term contract is sold. Because the spot market is governed by the forces of supply and demand, analysts sometimes argue that it is the truest calibrator of prices. **********Oil from Norway's Ekofisk field, priced officially at $40, draws only $35 in the spot market. Crude from the British Forties field there, offically pegged at $39.25, draws $7 less in the spot market. **********Two sharp reductions over the past two months in the price of Egyptian oil - traditionally closely linked to spot prices - are indicative of what might happen if this was the principal index for oil prices. Since April, that country's best grade of crude has fallen by $4.50, to $36. **********''It's certainly not a healthy situation,'' W.G. Magers, a vice president of the Sun Company, said. ''There are some gutty decisions we're going to have to make soon.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/18/busin.main_headline: 2 BANKS START VENTURES WITH MONEY FUNDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/18/busin.print_headline: 2 BANKS START VENTURES WITH MONEY FUNDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/18/busin.body_text: **********The First Interstate Bancorporation, a big Los Angeles-based bank holding company, and the First National Bank of Springfield, Ill., a medium-sized institution, have started joint ventures with money market mutual funds. **********The two banking companies are thus allying with an adversary that the banking industry has widely criticized. The funds compete with the banks and thrift institutions in providing check-like services.  But they pay far higher rates on customer deposits because they are not subject to the interest-rate ceilings that apply to banking institutions. **********Many other banks are interested in initiating programs similar to the two joint ventures, which both started in the past few weeks.  ''We've had inquiries from all over the country,'' said Dean C.  Countryman, vice president of First National of Springfield. He will be in New York this week advising a New York bank, which he declined to name, that wants to set up a joint venture with a money fund. **********These moves are further evidence that the banking industry, struggling to hold on to clients and deposits in an era of high interest rates and stiff competition, is flexing its muscles and moving into new areas. In so doing, the banks are stretching the traditional definitions, and possibly the legal ones as well, of what banks can and cannot do. Investment in Dreyfus Funds **********For its part, the Illinois bank offers an individual checking account that automatically invests the unused balance in any one of three of the Dreyfus Corporation's money market funds, three funds in the Fidelity Group or in repurchase agreements. To qualify for the high-yielding program, an individual must put a minimum of $15,000 in the new checking account. **********The arrangement available at First Interstate's 21 banks in 11 Western states is somewhat different. Along with Dreyfus, First Interstate has established its own money market fund, Pacific American Liquid Assets. First Interstate is the manager and principal adviser for the fund, which is now offered only to the custodial accounts in the trust departments of its affiliated banks. **********Dreyfus handles all the administrative and marketing chores, such as paper work, filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission and supplying clients with information about the fund. **********Under the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, banks are forbidden from underwriting or marketing securities. Money market mutual funds, marketed as shares, are securities. **********''We're in a gray legal area with this program,'' concedes James B. Fox, president of Western Asset Management Company, the investment advisory arm of First Interstate. ''In effect, this is a straightforward money market fund.'' **********However, First Interstate is not, technically speaking, marketing the fund, even though it is available only to its clients. ''All we're doing is acting as an adviser to an open-end mutual fund,'' said R. Jeffrey Taylor, counsel for First Interstate. ''That is permissible.'' 'Selling Accounts' **********In both the joint ventures, Howard Stein, chairman of Dreyfus, explained: ''The banks are selling accounts. They aren't selling a fund.'' **********How widespread such joint ventures could become is uncertain and much depends on the future course of banking regulation. For instance, if banks are permitted to set up their own money market funds, many big banks would have little need for cooperative efforts with the fund industry. **********However, under present restrictions, banks are more and more likely to link up with their sometime adversaries, the money funds. As Mr.  Fox of Interstate noted, ''The only way we could have done this is through a joint-venture arrangement.'' **********Also, the funds have proven expertise in the field. ''We can get them into the business quickly,'' Mr. Stein said. ''We know how to run a money fund.'' **********At present, it seems that joint approach to financial products is a concept that will be expanded. ''There will probably be some other joint venture product areas between major funds and banks,'' said Mr. Fox of First Interstate's investment subsidiary. ''We've already had some exploratory conversations with Dreyfus on this subject, but I can't be any more specific.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/07/busin.body_text: **********Amid growing hostility to Canadian takeovers of United States companies, Interior Secretary James G.  Watt today expressed reluctance about proposals that revoke the right of Canadians to own stock in corporations that have mineral leases on Federal lands in the United States. **********''It would be inconsistent with U.S. investment policy and send a signal to other countries that the U.S. acknowledges investment limits as a legitimate foreign policy tool,'' Mr. Watt told a House Energy subcommittee. **********'' **********But Mr. Watt said he was reserving judgment on whether Canada should continue to be granted reciprocal status with the United States under this nation's Mineral Lands Leasing Act. If Canada loses its position as a reciprocal country, the United States Government can seek cancellation of leases held by corporations that have Canadian investors. **********Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, the subcommittee chairman, has accused the Administration of stalling in making a decision on Canada. Mr. Dingell noted that members of Congress, troubled by Canadian investment and economic policies, have proposed placing a nine-month moratorium on the purchase of more than 5 percent of the stock of American energy corporations by Canadians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/17/busin.body_text: **********Columbia Pictures Industries and the Outlet Company announced that their respective boards had approved the previously announced merger of Outlet into a Columbia Pictures unit. **********The transaction is still subject to approval by shareholders. **********Outlet, based in Providence, R.I., owns five VHF television stations and seven AM and FM radio stations. Columbia Pictures has interests in the distribution of motion pictures and television shows, amusement games and broadcasting. **********When the agreement was first announced in July, analysts put a value of $45 a share on the transaction, or about $166.5 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/04/busin.body_text: **********The market for new houses continued to deteriorate in January, with sales dropping 6.5 percent from December on a seasonally adjusted basis, the Government reported today. **********A housing industry spokesman said that high mortgage rates were the principal cause of the drop.  The Commerce Department and the Department of Housing and Urban Development reported that the total number of new one-family houses sold in January was 34,000, approximately the same number as in December. Howevere, since past results indicate that January sales normally rise, the seasonal adjustment shows a decline. **********The report said that the seasonally adjusted annual rate of new home sales for January was 493,000, down from December's 527,000 annual rate. The January figure was 17.3 percent below the January 1980 annual rate. December's figure was down 5.7 percent from November, the report said. **********The December rate had earlier been reported at 545,000, a 3.4 percent decline from November.  ''As long as you have high interest rates, people are not beating on the doors to buy,'' said Michael Sumichrast, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. ''Financing is hard for buyers to get,'' he said. ''It's not a very good way to do business.'' Mortgage Average **********The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported mortgage interest rates averaging 15.37 percent nationally in early January, and Mr.  Sumichrast said he doubted that the rate would fall below 14 percent in the near future. **********''I think all interest rates will come down,'' he said, but not enough to make a big difference in housing sales.  A survey taken by the builders' association indicated that February sales might show ''marginal improvement,'' Mr. Sumichrast said. But he added, ''It isn't going to be a good year at all.'' **********The median price for new houses sold in January was $67,200, down slightly from December's median of $67,800, according to the report.  Mr. Sumichrast said the price drop was an indication that developers were making great efforts - and were offering bargain prices - ''to sell what they have rather than start anything new.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/21/world.main_headline: Druse Sheik Takes Seat In the Israeli Parliament
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/21/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Druse Sheik Takes Seat In the Israeli Parliament
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/21/world.body_text: **********A Druse sheik, Jaber Muadi, ignored warnings of vengeance by armed Bedouins against his clan and took a seat in the Israeli Parliament today to replace a Bedouin leader who was murdered in Jerusalem on Jan. 12. **********The Bedouin, Sheik Hamad Abu Rabia, was shot to death after he had allegedly reneged on a pre-election undertaking to vacate his seat in mid-term in favor of the Druse. **********Elders of the Abu Rabia tribe in the Negev suspected that the dispute was the motive for the assassination. Three Druses from Yirka, Sheik Jaber's village, are being held as suspects. The Druses are an Arabic-speaking ethnic group that is an offshoot of Islam. **********Last week Israeli officials persuaded elders of the Abu Rabia tribe to put off the blood vengeance required by their tradition until the police completed their investigation. However the elders said their agreement would not hold if Sheik Jaber, who automatically inherited Sheik Hamad's seat under the election procedures, actually occupied it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/08/world.main_headline: I.R.A. PRISONERS IN ULSTER CALL NEW BRITISH RULES INADEQUATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/08/world.print_headline: I.R.A. PRISONERS IN ULSTER CALL NEW BRITISH RULES INADEQUATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/08/world.body_text: **********Irish Republican Army prisoners in Maze Prison outside Belfast reacted critically today to the British Government's new prison rules for Northern Ireland. **********In a statement smuggled out of the prison, they said the decision to allow prisoners to wear their own clothing was ''a positive move in the right direction.'' **********But they descr ibed as vengeful and inadequate a proposal to count only half the time they have spent on protests toward their early release for g ood behavior. The prisoners had wanted to count all the time lost bec ause of protests. **********More Time in Jail **********''It means that in most cases the prisoners will have to serve two and a half years extra in jail,'' the statement said.  Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary, James Prior, announced the changes yesterday after a seven-month hunger-strike campaign in Maze Prison was ended last weekend. **********A Government spokesman said Lord Gowrie, the minister responsible for prisons, would meet with the prisoners to help explain details of the new rules. Protestant Calls It a Sellout **********Ian Paisley, the militant Protestant leader, and his supporters have attacked the changes as a sellout to the jailed I.R.A. members.  Members of Mr. Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party walked out of a reception given last night by Mr. Prior at which he intended to explain the new rules. **********Mr. Prior said yesterday that prisoners would be allowed to wear their own clothing and would be entitled to 50 percent of the normal remission of their sentences after they conformed to prison rules for three months. Demand on Political Status Denied **********He refused to concede the hunger strikers' main demand for political prisoner status. He said that two of their other demands, on prison work and free association, were not compatible with a civil prison, although there was room for development. **********Mr. Prior said that the prisoners' education should be improved and that they should be allowed more opportunities to associate together. But, he added, ''there will be no question of a political or military system of administration or any return to special category status.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/09/busin.main_headline: SENATE TO CONSIDER CREDIT CARD FEES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/09/busin.print_headline: SENATE TO CONSIDER CREDIT CARD FEES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/09/busin.body_text: **********Amid mounting opposition, the Senate this week will consider legislation that would extend a ban on charging credit card users an extra fee when they use their cards. **********The legislation passed the House with little opposition several weeks ago, but questions have now arisen about who would benefit from the surcharge ban, which expired Feb. 28. **********Currently, merchants pay a 3 percent to 5 percent fee to the card issuer for each credit card purchase. This cost, an estimated $1.5 billion in 1980, is passed along indirectly in the price of goods to both credit card and cash customers. **********The major credit card issuers, the American Express Company, Visa and Mastercard, maintained that without the ban on consumer surcharges, credit card holders would be penalized for using their cards. Opponents of extending the ban contend that the merchant fee hides the true cost of credit card purchases, interferes with the free market, encourages inflation and penalizes cash customers. House 'Caved In' **********Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, one of the chief opponents of the surcharge ban, said that it only benefited banks and credit card companies. He said the House ''caved in'' in passing the credit card surcharge ban bill. **********Representative Frank Annunzio, Democrat of Illinois, and sponsor of the bill in the House, said that in a society that has 60 million credit card users, it would be punitive to ask cardholders to pay an extra fee whenever they used their cards. **********''We are a nation of credit card junkies addicted to popping plastic,'' said Mr. Annunzio.  During the House hearings, the major credit card issuers and the American Bankers Association testified in support of the surcharge ban. The Federal Reserve Board testified against the ban extension.  No consumer groups testified. **********''There was nobody we thought who was concerned about the issue,'' said Curtis Prins, staff director of the subcommittee on consumer affairs, House Committee on Banking. ''The Congress is protecting the credit card user from being bilked. Right after the ban expired we were contacted by a man who ate dinner at a restaurant and got a 4 percent surcharge on his bill because he used his credit card.'' Lower Prices for Cash Purchases **********The diner's situation illustrates the heart of the issue for opponents of the surcharge ban. They maintain that without it, consumers who use cards would know and bear the cost of credit card usage. Furthermore, consumer groups say merchants are likely to offer cash customers lower prices, making credit card buying less attractive, without a ban on surcharges. **********''Credit card users should pay the legitimate cost of using their cards. We don't need cash customers subsidizing their use,'' said Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts. Mr. Frank offered an amendment eliminating the ban, but House rules required that the bill go to the floor without amendments. **********''That bill was rushed through the House,'' said Mr. Frank.  ''People came up to me on the floor after I voted against it and asked why. When I explained it was because the surcharge ban was a subsidy of the credit card industry they said they wished they had known that earlier. I think I could win that amendment on the floor if we go to a House-Senate conference.'' **********A House-Senate conference on the bill is a possibility because of opposition to the surcharge ban from consumer groups, the Federal Trade Commission and other groups that testified before the Senate. Consumer Opposition Arose **********Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, is co-sponsor of the Senate bill along with Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah.  Initially, Senator Chafee planned to poll members on the bill but eventually held hearings. Mr. Chafee was convinced that extending the surcharge ban protected consumers. During testimony, however, consumer groups testified against the surcharge ban extension. In addition to the Federal Trade Commission, the surcharge ban was also opposed by the Federal Reserve Board, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, and several other groups. **********Senator Proxmire introduced an amendment that would eliminate the surcharge ban to the bill. In the meantime the deadline on the ban expired. **********Opponents of the reinstitution of the ban, including the consumer groups and Senator Proxmire, began to look for allies for their cause. By last week, several free market organizations such as the National Taxpayers Union and the Council for Competitive Economy had contacted Mr. Garn to express their opposition to the surcharge ban. **********''Our support of free competition leads us to oppose the surcharge ban, an anticompetitive regulation that interferes with business people and consumers and that is out of step with the economic views expressed by the voters in November,'' said Sheldon L. Richman, the council's research director. **********The expiration of the customer-surcharge ban means that merchants now can pass on their card costs to credit card holders alone. The expiration is not, however, expected to alter the business practices of retail merchants who do a high volume of business with credit card holders. They are unlikely to pass on the fee to buyers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/07/busin.body_text: **********The Chemical Bank lowered its prime lending rate yesterday to 19 1/2 percent, the lowest level among the nation's largest banks.  Despite signals from the Federal Reserve System that it does not intend to allow interest rates to drop as precipitously as they did earlier last year, some bankers believe that market pressures will force a rapid reduction in interest rates. **********Such thinking was partly the reason why the Chemical Bank, the nation's sixth largest, set its prime at 19 1/2 percent yesterday, down from 20 1/2 percent, according to Thomas S. Johnson, executive vice president. **********At most major banks across the country, the prime stands at 20 1/2 percent. On Monday, however, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company lowered its prime rate to 20 percent, as the Marine Midland Bank did yesterday. Other Loan Rates Tied to Prime **********The prime is the rate banks charge on loans, usually for 90-day periods, to their most creditworthy corporate customers, although many of these companies are able to borrow below the prime for loans with shorter maturities. The prime is particularly important because rates on many other loans are tied to it. **********Chemical's decision to lower its prime was largely based on a sharp decline in the rates it must pay for its own funds, Mr. Johnson said. But equally important, he added, is Chemical's expectation that short-term interest rates will continue to decline. **********Mr. Johnson said Chemical recognized that the Fed was adverse to allowing a sharp and rapid decline in money market rates, such as occurred in early 1980, when the prime rate dropped to 10 3/4 percent from 20 percent in a three-month period. **********In addition to statements by Fed officials, Mr. Johnson noted that in recent days the central bank had not intervened in the financial markets to lower the relatively high rate on Federal funds, money that banks trade among themselves. Yesterday, for example, rates on Federal funds averaged about 20 percent, not far below the peak reached during the height of the tight-money policy. Fed Options Viewed as Limited **********But Mr. Johnson said the Fed was limited in its ability to buck market forces. He expects the economy to slow, thereby reducing corporate borrowing from banks. Long-term interest rates will also decline, he says, and this will cause many companies to return to the bond markets. Funds obtained in the bond markets would be used to repay bank loans. **********The result, Mr. Johnson said, will be a sharp reduction in borrowing from banks. Thus, even if the Fed remains cautious about adding money to the banking system, the supply will decline sharply enough to cause a steep slide in interest rates. And because the Fed will still want to keep the growth of the money supply within its targets, it will be reluctant to take too much money out of the system to bolster interest rates, Mr. Johnson said. **********Yet, the Chemical official does not expect rates to drop so rapidly as last year. He predicts short-term rates will again drop about 10 percentage points, but over six months instead of three.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/07/busin.body_text: **********The Reading Company said it had agreed to a Government settlement that provides $121 million for railroad properties transferred to Conrail and others in 1976.  Included in the settlement was 8 percent interest on the principal amount compounded annually from April 1, 1976, Reading officials said. **********The settlement stems from claims against the United States and the United States Railway Association on behalf of Reading and its subsidiary and associated companies, some of which were operated by Reading under leases, for railroad properties transferred under the Regional Rail Reorganization Act of 1973. **********Until Reading receives its share of the proceeds from settlements by its subsidiary and associated companies, it will have insufficient money to pay all of its debts due from reorganization of the company, company officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/18/busin.main_headline: CORPORATE PROFITS ARE COMING UP SHORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/18/busin.print_headline: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS; CORPORATE PROFITS ARE COMING UP SHORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/18/busin.body_text: **********Profits tumbled at many corporations in the third quarter, compared with results in the same period last year. The lackluster performance pushed stocks lower and raised fears of a worsening economic slump.  I.B.M. was off 21.6 percent; International Paper, 23.6 percent; Reynolds Metals, 19.4 percent; Boise Cascade, 40.6 percent; CBS, 2.5 percent, Burroughs, 23.2 percent, NCR, 29.9 percent and Honeywell 30.8 percent. **********Westinghouse posted a 14.4 percent earnings increase. Also in the plus column: Penn Central, up 80.6 percent; G.T.E, 84.7 percent.  Grace, 41 percent; Allied, 79 percent; Philip Morris, 20.6 percent; Alcoa, 8.8 percent; Kodak, 5.7 percent, and Pepsico, 16 percent. **********Stocks dropped. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 851.69, a loss for the week of 21.31 points. **********Brokerage-house net fell. Merrill Lynch profits tumbled 29.2 percent in the third quarter and E.F. Hutton profits fell 38.9 percent. **********Bank profits were mixed. Operating net at J.P. Morgan fell 26.6 percent. First Chicago earnings tripled; Chase Manhattan net climbed 20.3 percent and Bankers Trust 18.2 percent. **********Treasury Secretary Regan urged delay in higher interest rates for passbook savings accounts, now set to go to 6 percent Nov. 1. He said the move would hurt thrift units. **********Industrial production fell eight-tenths of a percent in September to its lowest level in more than a year, the Federal Reserve said. **********The money supply soared by $5.6 billion in the first week in October, the Fed said. Analysts cited special circumstances for the bulge and said growth would be stabilize. **********The prime rate was lowered to 18 percent from 19 percent at major banks. **********New-car sales declined 34.7 percent in the first 10 days of October, the Big Three makers reported. The period marked the beginning of the 1982 model year. **********Retail sales increased a sluggish four-tenths of a percent in September, the Commerce Department said. **********Business inventories rose seven-tenths of a percent in August and some analysts saw it as an involuntary buildup in light of lagging sales. **********OPEC may end its squabble over oil pricing. Venezuela indicated that it no longer opposes a $2 cut to $34 a barrel. A resolution could come at a meeting later this month. **********Northrop was picked by the Air Force to be the prime contractor for initial development of the Stealth bomber, designed to be undectable by radar. **********LTV lost a round in its efforts to take over Grumman. A Federal judge, saying a merger would raise antitrust questions, granted a preliminary injunction to block the takeover temporarily. **********Allegheny International outbid IC Industries for Sunbeam. IC withdrew after Allegheny offered $532 million. IC's best offer was $525 million. **********Fuji Photo enters the instant camera market this week in Japan, a move that foreshadows worldwide competition for the other two makers, Kodak and Polaroid. **********New-car sales declined 34.7 percent in the first 10 days of October, the Big Three makers reported. The period marked the beginning of the 1982 model year.
