https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.main_headline: Exxon to Increase U.S. Energy Outlay
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Exxon to Increase U.S. Energy Outlay
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.body_text: **********The Exxon Corporation said that it planned to increase sharply its spending in the United States on enhanced energy recovery, the coaxing of oil and natural gas out of properties where deposits cannot be reached by conventional means. **********The Exxon U.S.A. division of the world's largest oil company will spend $150 million on enhanced recovery projects this year, an outlay ''more than four times as large'' as its 1980 expenditures for similar ventures, a spokesman said. **********The $150 million outlay represents about 9 percent of Exxon's planned domestic oil and gas production spending this year and 1.4 percent of the $11 billion 1981 capital budget the company has announced. **********The spokesman said that much of the $150 million would be spent on a ''secondary recovery'' project at the Prudhoe Bay oilfield in Alaska, where water will be pumped into the field to stimulate petroleum production.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/21/world.main_headline: POLISH UNION CALLS FOR URGENT TALKS ON A PROPOSED FIVE-DAY WORKWEEK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/21/world.print_headline: POLISH UNION CALLS FOR URGENT TALKS ON A PROPOSED FIVE-DAY WORKWEEK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/21/world.body_text: **********The Polish labor union leadership called today for urgent negotiations with the Government over the issue of a five-day workweek and said all Saturdays would continue to be nonworking days pending an accord. **********The position, adopted after a long and contentious meeting of the union's national commission, appeared to represent a defeat for Lech Walesa, the union chairman. **********He had argued against forcing a confrontation over the issue. **********Mr. Walesa was also criticized by several colleagues for having met yesterday with Prime Minister Jozef Pinkowski, immediately on returning from a six-day visit to Italy. The other union leaders said Mr. Walesa was not familiar with the causes for strikes that had broken out during his absence and should not have entered into talks before a meeting of the national commission. **********The accusations were the strongest made in public so far against Mr. Walesa, the hero of the summer strikes, and they indicated that he might be losing his hold over more militant union leaders. **********Several local chapters, including Gdansk, have threatened a series of warning strikes for Thursday to force the Government to concede to the five-day workweek. The Government agreed in principle last summer to institute free Saturdays but now contends that it wants to introduce them gradually to minimize production losses. **********Reflecting a growing mood of dissatisfaction with the pace of promised changes, the union also charged that the Government's carrying out of the agreements reached last summer was ''highly unsatisfactory.'' It called for the establishment of a joint conference with the Government within the next two weeks to review progress in realizing the accords.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/08/world.body_text: **********Secretary General Kurt Waldheim will formally present to the 156 member countries tomorrow his two-year, $1.54 billion zero-growth budget for the United Nations. It will be the first time since 1954 that a Secretary General has submitted a budget that does not provide for the expansion of the world body. **********''The proposed program budget does not provide for any growth in real terms,'' Mr. Waldheim explained. But he noted that the budget, which must be approved by two thirds of the General Assembly before the end of its session in December, would be able to keep pace with inflation. **********In putting together his bud get, the Secreta ry General was caught between the demands of the Assembly for incre ased services and the refusal of the wealthy nations to increase th eir contributions to theorganization. **********''Whether we like it or not we are in the center of public opinion,'' said Helmut Debatin, the Under Secretary General, who did the actual work on the budget. ''Developing countries are concerned if they are not getting what they say they are entitled to. The Secretary General is put against the wall.'' 20 Nations Were Opposed **********Despite overwhelming support in the Assembly last year for increases in the world body's expenditures, they were opposed by 20 nations from the East and West that finance nearly 80 percent of the organization's budget. This was a clear signal to Mr. Waldheim that he could not expect additional financing for the next two years. **********While he will not refer to that vote in his address tomorrow, Mr.  Waldheim defended his budget as ''maintaining and strengthening the financial credibility of the organization at a time when many member states face serious economic and financial difficulties.'' **********At the same time Mr. Waldheim complained that the work of the United Nations would inevitably be impaired by the no-growth budget.  The Secretariat in particular, he said, ''cannot successfully and efficiently accomplish the ever-widening tasks assigned to it without being granted adequate means.'' **********In a draft text of his speech to the budget review commission of the General Assembly, Mr. Waldheim acknowledged that ''the organization cannot in its financial policy neglect the economic and financial positon from which member states view its budgetary requirements, as it is they who have to bear the financial burden.'' **********Under the complicated budgetary process of the United Nations, Mr.  Waldheim's proposed budget is reviewed by two committees, one a 16-member advisory panel and the other a committee composed of each of the 156 member-countries. At any point in the three-month review deletions or additions may be made to the budget, although historically there is little precedent for substantial changes being made in the Secretary General's budget. **********The budget is not put together with expenditures strictly linked to anticipated income. Rather, the Secretary General's $1.54 billion budget, of which only $250 million will come from taxes on staff income and other money-raising activities, is a statement of the proposed expenditures for programs that have been mandated by the General Assembly. The total expenditures, which this year come to $1.25 billion, are then assessed against the member nations according to a formula based on population and gross national product. **********Contributions range from the United States's assessment, which accounts for 25 percent of the world bo dy's budget, or about $150 million per y ear, to those of underdeveloped countries, which are assessed at o nly one tenth of 1 percent, or about $60,000 a year. **********In the past 20 years the budget of the United Nations, 75 percent of which now goes on salaries, has grown from about $60 million a year to its current annual level of more than $600 million, with a concomitant expansion of the staff from 4,000 to more than 11,400.  Mr. Waldheim explained the growth as a direct consequence of the increasing demands of the General Assembly. Constant Call for New Programs **********In each session the Assembly has called for the United Nations to create more programs, ranging from agricultural assistance in Asia to programs to incorporate ''environmentally sound'' features into urban planning in Latin America, as well as an array of conferences and councils on what are deemed urgent political issues. **********Mr. Waldheim indicated that with the necessary belt-tightening, the organization's ''economic, social and humanitarian'' functions would remain a priority and that cuts would occur elsewhere. **********Reflecting the increasing austere fiscal situation of the United Nations, Mr. Waldheim will admonish some of those member nations that have been dilatory in meeting their financial obligations. If a member fails to pay its assessment for two years, it is deprived of a vote in the General Assembly. And while there are no member nations, excluding South Africa, that are in that position, the lateness with which some countries pay, has, in Mr. Waldheim's words, ''strained to the breaking point the cash position of the organization.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/14/world.main_headline: MOURNING IN ULSTER AND PARADING TOO
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/14/world.print_headline: MOURNING IN ULSTER AND PARADING TOO
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/14/world.body_text: **********Thousands of Protestants today celebrated a 1690 victory over Roman Catholic forces a few hours after a sixth hunger striker died this morning at Maze Prison here. **********The death of 26-year-old Martin Hurson at 4:30 A.M. was signaled to Catholic areas by the ritualistic clattering of garbage can lids by women. But perhaps because the death came as a surprise - the other deaths came after hunger strikes that lasted several days more - the violence that followed was far more modest than the reaction to the five other deaths. **********James Dooge, the Irish Foreign Minister-designate, who met with British officials on Friday, called today for direct talks between the British Government and the hunger strikers, who are demanding status as political prisoners. **********''Every death in the Maze Prison was a victory for the Irish Republican Army,'' Mr. Dooge said.  Among the reasons for the increasing pressure from Dublin is the fact that another hunger striker, Kieran Doherty, who has not eaten in 52 days, is a member of the Irish Parliament. **********The new Irish Government of Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald took office last month with only a narrow majority, and it is believed that Mr. Doherty's death may result in the election of a successor from the opposition party. **********Passions have been further inflamed by the revelation during the weekend that an army raid Friday on the funeral for Joseph McDonnell, the hunger striker who died five days ago, had resulted in the capture of a key I.R.A. leader, now in the hospital. **********Patrick Adams, 30, was a former Belfast commander of the I.R.A.  Provisionals. His brother is vice president of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political arm. **********How the Government will react on Wednesday, when Mr. Hurson is to be buried, remains uncertain. Mr. Hurson, a bachelor, was arrested in November 1976 and sentenced the following October to a 20-year term for possession of explosives and attempted murder. **********Other deaths are likely to follow quickly. Besides Mr. Doherty, Kevin Lynch has been without food for 51 days. Thirty-seven people have died in violence since the first hunger striker died early in May. **********Although the incidents this morning consisted of stone-throwing by youths and a minor gun battle, security forces were on full alert for the celebration of the Battle of the Boyne of 1690, at which William of Orange and his Protestant followers defeated the Catholic army of James II. The holiday was celebrated a day late because it fell on a Sunday. **********Although the Belfast parade passed within a few blocks of Catholic areas, no trouble was reported. The police said about 30,000 people participated in the Belfast march, and a Protestant group said 100,000 participated in marches across the province. **********The rows of Belfast marchers, attired in traditional orange and black, played their fifes and drums undisturbed. There were armed policemen at virtually every corner, screens at intersections near Catholic neighborhoods, and army helicopters flew overhead.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/09/busin.main_headline: Commodities; Key Topics At Industry Convention
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/09/busin.print_headline: Commodities; Key Topics At Industry Convention
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/09/busin.body_text: **********WHENEVER 700 top figures of the commodity industry gather for the annual meeting of the Futures Industry Association, there are usually more than that many trade topics discussed. But last week's meeting of the group in Boca Raton, Fla., was decidely unusual. **********For one, the industry leaders, their spouses, bankers and assorted other participants could not conceal their joy over President Reagan's nomination of Philip Johnson for the chairmanship of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Mr. Johnson was former chief counsel to the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's biggest futures exchange, and is regarded as the the leading legal authority on commodity trading. His nomination was announced just before the meeting began. **********As a result, Mr. Johnson canceled his appearance and many of those who did speak abandoned their usual attacks against the Federal agency and the equally standard laments about the overregulation of their industry by Washington. Instead, much of the addresses centered on three topics of mounting concern to the commodity industry. **********One is the rising attacks by the Internal Revenue Service and Congress on the use of commodity futures to postpone or minimize tax payments. The second is industry's campaign for the legalization of trading in commodity options, which were outlawed in June 1978 after years of scandals. The third is how much of the C. F. T. C.'s regulatory power should be assumed by the industry itself. **********The I. R. S. and its supporters in Congress have long fought against the use of tax straddles - the simultaneous purchase and sale of futures contracts in two tax years - to roll over tax liabilities, convert short-term gains into long-term, or otherwise shelter income. **********''While we view the Reagan Administration as friendly, its positions on fiscal reform could encourage the I. R. S. and Congress to step up their attacks on tax straddles,'' one brokerage house executive noted. Currently, the I. R. S. is prosecuting a record 700 tax straddle cases and there are several bills in Congress that would outlaw such straddles. Whether or not the I. R. S. wins its cases, they are a costly burden to those involved, including brokers, and also frighten many potential users of these tactics, he said. **********The subject of commodity options was aired more openly at the seminars and recreational grounds of the Boca Raton Hotel. Options are the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell commodities at a specified price within a fixed period of time. A trader's risk is limited to the premium paid and, unlike futures, which are promises to buy or sell commodities under similar terms, protect the trader from margin calls. **********Dr. Henry G. Jarecki, chairman of the Mocatta Metals Corporation and a leading expert on options, tackled the issue in a witty speech that delighted his seminar audience. Mocatta, the American affiliate of the 300-year-old London metals trading house, is one of the few companies permitted to trade options since the ban, and does so only through a handful of brokerage houses. A psychiatrist and former teacher at the Yale University Medical School, he said, somewhat tongue-in-cheek: **********''You all will probably be permitted to trade options soon. And as soon as the first trouble reappears they will be banned again, no matter what kind of trouble. Unless measures are taken, the same crooks, flakes and other assorted nuts will enter the options business and start ripping off the public. **********''We at Mocatta blew the whistle on some of the more notorious crooks and flakes - Goldstein, Samuelson & Company, Collins & Day and Alan Abrahams, also known as Lloyd Carr -which gulled the public out of tens of millions of dollars before they were put out of action. The cost to the industry was a tarnished reputation and the ban on most options tradiing. Today, most exchanges have filed to trade options because they know the market is there. How long it will be there is something else again.'' **********Paul Sarnoff, research director at Rudolf Wolff Commodity Brokers Inc., took the issue of options further: ''All one needs to be a futures or options merchant is $200 for a C. F. T. C. registration, $250,000 in capital - and arrange for a clearing member of a futures exchange to execute the business. The public often does not know that their business is not being directly handled by the prestigious clearing member. They often learn this after their 'broker' vanishes or, as has been the case several times recently, the non-clearing dealer goes bankrupt.'' **********Because the clearing house of each exchange closely monitors the assets and liabilities of members, the financial health of the 110 or so clearing members was not in question, Mr. Sarnoff said. ''The problem is the link between the customer and the nonclearing member, and this should be looked into before the ban on options is lifted,'' he added. **********As for the industry's move toward self-regulation along the lines of the National Association of Securities Dealers, a number of critics said privately that this could weaken the role of the C.F.T.C. to the point where the much more feared Securities and Exchange Commission would take over. **********These fears were reinforced recently when the S. E. C. granted the Chicago Board Options Exchange, which trades in stock options, the right to trade in options on Government National Mortgage Association debt instruments. Ginnie Mae futures have been a lucrative product of several commodity exchanges, which have sought in vain thus far for C. F. T. C. approval to trade options in these financial instruments as well.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/busin.body_text: **********WORKERS are putting the finishing touches on the stainless-steel sculpture suspended in the Park Avenue Atrium, the glittering new headquarters of the JWT Group, come October. Hill & Knowlton, which JWT aquired 14 months ago, inherits the hacienda-style offices in the Graybar Building, and its attractively priced lease. **********The two moves are some of the more conspicuous examples of synergy for the JWT Group since it took over Hill & Knowlton, the world's largest public relations firm, along with Euro-Advertising, a nineagency network in Europe, and World Wide Agency, a recruitment advertising agency, last year. The relocations also indicate the untarnished optimism of the JWT Group, the J. Walter Thompson Company's parent, and of its chairman and chief executive, Don Johnston. **********That optimism is not founded on the current bottom line. The JWT Group, like much of the industry, has been bumping up against advertiser resistance to spending. Despite rosy predictions last year, JWT took a beating in the first half of 1981, thanks to currency translation losses, a postponement of client expenditures on advertising, large real estate outlays and high interest costs. **********This, Mr. Johnston said last week, is an ''aberrational year.'' ''There's a lot of uncertainty about spending patterns,'' he added. ''The timing of up-front buying has been slower. There's an awful lot hanging on the fourth quarter of this year.'' For the future, however, Mr. Johnston said he is confident about the benefits of expanding the JWT empire. **********Mr. Johnston speaks of the various companies in the group as ''brands'' with discrete brand personalities. ''We felt it made a lot of sense to have two separate brands,'' he said of Hill & Knowlton and J. Walter Thompson. By sheltering the brands under a corporate umbrella, Mr. Johnston said, the JWT Group allows them to grow without a commensurate growth in overhead. The arrangement offers opportunities for improving productivity that are otherwise foreclosed in the advertising-public relations world, he said. ''It frees Thompson and Hill & Knowlton from having to take care of the plumbing,'' Mr. Johnston added. **********The Hill & Knowlton partnership has already proved handy, especially overseas, where the public relations agency can be ushered into the offices of clients by the long-established J. Walter Thompson Company. But ''it's worked both ways,'' insisted Mr.  Johnston, citing Gerber, Kellogg and Dart & Kraft as some of the clients who have been propelled by Hill & Knowlton into the arms of J. Walter Thompson or vice versa. **********Then there is World Wide which, despite the name, was pretty much confined to the United States until Thompson absorbed it, renamed it Thompson Recruitment Advertising and opened offices abroad. ''We were fascinated with the potential of high-volume, fast-turnover business with a lot of blue-chip clients,'' said Mr. Johnston. **********Euro-Advertising, as Mr. Johnston has said in the past, represents a ''second track'' abroad for JWT - with the implication that third, fourth and more ''tracks'' may be added. ''In Europe, a mature market, it's almost too late to start your own agency,'' he said.  ''But you can still grow by getting a flanker brand.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/10/world.body_text: **********Michael Foot, the leader of the opposition Labor Party, failed to wear black at a memorial service yesterday for Britain's war dead, causing an uproar that could threaten his political future. **********Mr. Foot, 68 years old, wore a green jacket, plaid tie and brown shoes at the annual memorial service at London's Cenotaph while everyone else, from Queen Elizabeth II and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher down, wore black. **********A major newspaper, The Daily Telegraph, attacked him in an editorial, questions were asked in the House of Commons and there was a call for his resignation as leader of the opposition. **********"The coat was undone and hanging off his shoulders, as if he was just about to take part in a demo rather than take part in a solemn act of respect and remembrance," said one outraged Labor Member of Parliament, Walter Johnson. "If this is a measure of his leadership, it is time we had a change," he declared. **********Mr. Foot responded today: "I certainly meant no disrespect to the dead or anyone else. In any case, respect for the dead isn't a matter of the clothes you wear."

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/21/world.main_headline: MILITANT VIEWS AMONG TURKS TROUBLE BONN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/21/world.print_headline: MILITANT VIEWS AMONG TURKS TROUBLE BONN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/21/world.body_text: **********Unconfirmed reports that Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk seized in the shooting of Pope John Paul II, lived among Turkish workers in West Germany after his escape from prison have focused attention on a spread of militancy among the Turks in West Germany.  In public, Bonn officials have affirmed that no evidence has appeared to indicate that Mr. Agca was ever in West Germany. **********Today, a Government spokesman denounced the Turkish Government's criticism of West Germany's inability to apprehend Mr. Agca, saying that Turkish information intended to lead to his arrest was ''inadequate and materially misleading'' and hindered rather than helped the search for Turkish extremists. **********High officials acquainted with the problem conceded, however, that intense, though secret, investigations were continuing to check reports that Mr. Agca spent time in West Germany. **********1.4 Million Turks in West Germany **********Though Bonn stopped the influx of foreign migrant workers six years ago, there are four million foreigners in the country, roughly 1.4 million of them from Turkey, including dependents. **********Government officials say that a polarization of Turkey in the late 1970's, as the country's economic and political structure began to disintegrate, led to growing radicalization and militancy among Turkish groups in West Germany. **********A recent report by Bonn's domestic intelligence agency estimates that there are about 50,000 members of Turkish extremist groups in West Germany, roughly 26,000 of them in right-wing groups. **********''The influence of the groups varies greatly, on their jobs and at home,'' said Jurgen Miksch, who oversees the German Evangelical Church's migrant worker aid efforts in Frankfurt. ''The extremists would like to control workers' daily lives. They tell them, 'Go here. Don't spend your time there.' Generally, it creates an atmosphere of intimidation.'' Left Said to Grow More Active **********The Government's analysts say that since the coup that brought the military junta of Gen. Kenan Evren to power last September, activity has increased on the left, where opposition to the military regime is strongest. But labor union and church officials among Turkish workers here accuse the Government in Ankara of turning a blind eye to extremism on the right. **********The rising militancy among Turkish workers is sometimes attributed to Bonn's sluggishness in social integration of Turkish workers and their families, who remain apart from German life because of differences in language, customs and religion. **********The major left-wing organization is the Federation of Turkish Labor Organizations in Germany, a grouping of two older unions that claim to have about 20,000 members. It is closely allied with the outlawed Turkish Communist Party, which has its exile headquarters in East Germany. West Germany's labor union movement avoids all contact with the organization. **********The major right-wing organization is the Federation of Turkish Democratic Idealist Associations, an umbrella organization for about 200 purportedly cultural groups throughout Europe. The federation's headquarters, in Frankfurt, says it has 50,000 members, roughly 35,000 of them in West Germany. **********Government analysts say Turkey's National Action Party, a rightwing party outlawed in Turkey, established the Federation of Idealist Associations as a front after overseas activities of Turkish political parties were banned in 1976. **********''The extremists here are a mirror image of Turkey,'' said a Bonn analyst. ''The same organizations are here, the suborganizations and the splinter groups.'' Ideas of Turkish Superiority **********The work of the organizations, analysts say, is to build strong units in exile to pursue their political goals clandestinely in Turkey. The analysts say most of the right-wing groups support ideas about superiority of the Turkish people and of Islam and they propagate the idea of turning from the West and establishing a Turkish Islamic empire. **********The groups are financed by a system of tithes exacted from members, as well as by generous contributions from affluent supporters, the analysts say. There are numerous reports, stemming chiefly from leftist sources, that drug trading and dealing in weapons are sources of finance, as the groups exploit the frequent travels of Turks between their homeland and Western Europe. Islamic Revival Among Turks **********Though the National Action Party and the federation are secular groups, they have developed ties to Islamic bodies in West Germany, tapping a significant Islamic revival among Turkish workers, specialists reported. **********Union leaders say an Islamic resurgence is partly a result of renewed Islamic consciousness spurred by the 1979 Iranian revolution against the Shah and partly the wish of Turks living in an alien culture to preserve their ways. **********''They seek national identity in religion,'' a labor union study said. ''The reason is fear that their children could be alienated from their parents and culture.'' **********Radical Islamic groups, seeking the overthrow of the Turkish Government and establishment of a nationalist Islamic state, have allied themselves with groups like the idealist federation. Today, there are more than 200 Islamic centers, operated by conservatives, 63 of them in heavily industrialized North Rhine-Westphalia, where many Turks work. **********Recent documentation by West Germany's labor federation pointed out strong anti-Western, anti-Semitic and anti-Christian currents in the Islamic centers' publications. Some analysts suggest that this was the atmosphere in which Mr. Agca conceived the need to kill the Pope.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/27/busin.body_text: **********Citing declining petroleum demand nationwide, the Mobil Corporation said it would close its refinery in Buffalo by this fall. **********Company officials said that, over the past two years, demand for petroleum products in the United States fell by more than 10 percent, or by more than 2 million barrels daily. **********Mobil's seven refineries in the nation together operate at about 70 percent of capacity, the company said, but the Buffalo refinery has been processing only 20,000 barrels a day out of a daily capacity of 43,000 barrels, for a capacity utilization of less than 50 percent. **********The Buffalo unit is unable to refine heavy residual oil into distillates such as gasoline or heating oil, and is not able to process high-sulfur-content crude, the company said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/world.main_headline: BANGLADESH LEADER SAID TO THWART ARMY PLOT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/world.print_headline: BANGLADESH LEADER SAID TO THWART ARMY PLOT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/world.body_text: **********Abdus Sattar, the 75-year-old judge elected President of Bangladesh yesterday, reportedly thwarted a plan by army officers during the campaign to install him as the civilian head of a military regime. **********Mr. Sattar, who won a sweeping victory in Sunday's election, which is being challenged as unfair by his leading opponent, had originally been persuaded to seek the presidency by leading army figures. At the time, just after the assassination of President Ziaur Rahman, Mr. Sattar, then the Vice President, was hospitalized with serious ailments. He told close aides that he feared he would be unable to campaign, but changed his mind in the face of arguments that the party built around the charismatic personality of President Zia could disintegrate without his candidacy. **********According to highly placed Bangladeshi sources who refused further indentification, it was Lieut. Gen. H.M. Ershad, the country's chief of staff, who made the most telling arguments for Mr. Sattar's entry into the race. But, as the campaign developed and the opposition Awami League was drawing large crowds, some of the same officers reportedly became hesitant. **********At one point during the monthlong campaign, General Ershad visited Mr. Sattar and put to him a suggestion for a military takeover that had been discussed by the army leaders. Although, according to a source close to the new President, the conversation never proceeded beyond the theoretical, Mr. Sattar, then acting president, rejected the idea immediately and told the officers that if they moved to seize power he would immediately retire to his house in Dacca. Secret Poll Conducted **********Mr. Sattar's view gained the support of Maj. Gen. Mohabbat Chowdhury, who is the director general of military intelligence.  General Chowdhury was reported by the sources as taking the position from the outset that if Mr. Sattar headed a military regime, he would be playing into the hands of the opposition candidate, Kamal Hossain. To relieve the anxiety of his fellow officers, General Chowdhury reportedly conducted a secret nationwide poll, which showed that Mr.  Sattar was running well ahead. Once this was circulated, talk of military intervention dissipated. **********According to the highly placed sources, Mr. Sattar has shown himself in these events to be a tough and stubborn leader who is not prepared to compromise what aides call a lifelong committment to due process and constitutional correctness. One man said that the President is fond of saying, ''I have nowhere to go but the grave,'' meaning that at the age of 75, with a recent history of poor health, he finds it easy to uphold convictions. **********At the Presidential Palace tonight, the newly elected leader, wearing an open-necked shirt, said in answer to a question that he had no intention of expanding the role of the army, as General Ershad had suggested in a recent interview with a British journalist. ''The army has a role to protect the sovereignty of the country and I don't think any other role is possible,'' he said. **********At the news conference, he said the election returns, which so far have him leading Mr. Hossain by 12 million votes to 4 million, represented ''a victory of the concept of Bangladeshi nationalism expounded by our late leader.'' He claimed that the election had been held ''peacefully and in a most free and fair way all over the country,'' and he termed the poll here as the ''freest and fairest election ever held in this part of the world.'' **********The opposition continued today to dispute such assertions, citing incidents of alleged intimidation at the polls and charging that through his control over the media and having military transport at his disposal, the Government candidate had an unfair advantage. A spokesman for Mr. Hossain's Awami League said the party had decided this afternoon to stage a series of demonstrations building to a nationwide protest next Monday challenging the result.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/10/busin.main_headline: Credit Markets; RATES UP DESPITE FED MOVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/10/busin.print_headline: Credit Markets; RATES UP DESPITE FED MOVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/10/busin.body_text: **********Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday, despite moves by the Federal Reserve to supply more credit to the banking system temporarily. **********According to many analysts, the near-record interest rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market is the main obstacle to lower interest rates in all maturities. In the absence of the long-awaited drop in the funds rate, and because of a heavy supply of new issues, most interest rates have been rising since mid-June. **********In the long-term bond market, for example, the bellwether 13 7/8 percent Treasury bonds due 2011 were offered late in the day at 102 7/8 to yield 13.47 percent, compared with 12.55 percent on June 15. **********Tax-exempt yields are even closer to the peaks set earlier this year, as shown by $150 million of Aaa-rated Georgia bonds that were offered with yields ranging from 7.75 percent in 1982 to 10.25 percent in 2001. Underwriters led by Chase Manhattan said that less than $29.8 million of the bonds were still unsold. Reserves Added **********Yesterday the Federal Reserve temporarily added reserves to the banking system by arranging one- and four-day purchases of securities, but analysts stressed that the action was not necessarily a sign that the Fed is trying to make bank reserves less scarce and thereby encourage lower interest rates. **********Amid the uncertainty about the timing and extent of any near-term drop in short-term rates, the Treasury sold new one-year bills at an average rate of 13.74 percent, up from 13.15 percent at last month's sale, but well below the record 14.62 percent at May's auction. **********In the money markets, the additional reserves supplied by the Fed's temporary purchases were not enough to cause much of a drop in the Federal funds market, which opened at 19 3/4 percent, traded as high as 20 3/4 percent and averaged about 20 1/8 percent. **********Some money center bankers who are responsible for money market borrowings said that yesterday's high funds rate might have been caused partly by heavy demand from banks that were trying to offset today's transfer of more than $2 billion of previously frozen Iranian deposits to the New York Federal Reserve Bank. That transfer drains reserves from the banking system, and was perhaps one reason why the Fed temporarily added reserves to the banking system yesterday, analysts said. Drop in Rates Expected **********Bankers agree that one reason for the higher-than-expected funds rate over the past month has been the widespread expectation that interest rates are going to drop. **********''Most people are expecting interest rates to fall and they are therefore borrowing heavily in the short-term markets,'' said Thomas Johnson, executive vice president at Chemical Bank. Along with many other market participants, Mr. Johnson said that the lower funds rate would come about because slow money supply growth would ultimatly encourage the Fed to make reserves slightly less scarce. **********He noted that M-1B had declined for two consecutive months and that M-2 growth had slowed to about a 4 1/2 percent annual rate in June and May. **********Among those predicting lower interest rates in the near future and later this year were economists at Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc.  who wrote in a recent publication that current high interest rates ''are only transitory in nature and are being affected by high short rates and an overwhelming bond calendar, both of which require a winding down period.'' **********Lacy Hunt, an economist at Fidelity Bank is another who expects lower interest rates in the second half of the year. He estimated that real gross national product might fall in the third quarter, and that inflation would continue to decline, with the Consumer Price Index rising at a 7.5 percent annual rate over the next three months. **********Thirty-year Treasury bond yields could fall below 12 percent during the fourth quarter of this year and the first quarter of 1982, he said, while the bank prime rate could fall four percentage points by the end of 1981. (000 omitted in dollar figures) **********Average Price 86.112 counted Rate 13.735% Coupon Yield Low Price 86.087 counted Rate 13.760% Coupon Yield High Price 86.158 counted Rate 13.690% Coupon Yield Accepted at low 87% applied for $8,526,965 Accepted N.Y. applied for $7,278,100 .Y. accepted $3,603,400 ncompetitive The one-year bills is dated July 16 and matures July 15, 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/12/busin.print_headline: BRITAIN: LESSONS FOR REAGAN; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/12/busin.body_text: **********For the Reagan administration, the beleaguered Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Britain has become more a political object lesson than a lesson in economics. **********Since May 1979, when Mrs. Thatcher led the Conservative Party to a sweeping victory, her administration's performance has been watched to see whether Britain's stagnant, inflation-ridden economy could be revived with strict fiscal discipline or whether it was perhaps irretrievably doomed to be a perpetual example of mismanagement. **********But now, as Mrs. Thatcher copes with a rain of criticism, the Reagan team seems most impressed with how the public's impatience for solutions to pressing economic problems can so overwhelm a new Government that its policy initiatives are aborted or discredited before being tried. **********David Stockman, Mr. Reagan's choice to head the Office of Management and Budget, sees a warning in Mrs. Thatcher's political difficulties. **********''I'm afraid,'' he said, ''that if the Reagan administration doesn't demonstrate some results in terms of improved interest rates, the inflation rate, unemployment and the economic growth indicators by the summer of '82, we're going to see the same strains developing even more insistently.'' Tension Among Conservatives **********The fear that public discontent might climb to politically intolerable proportions before a Reagan economic program can show results accounts in part for the Reagan Administration's repeatedly stated intention to act forcefully from the onset. The new administration hopes to avoid the heavy strains that it sees developing among Mrs. Thatcher's supporters. In Britain, many Tories openly worry that the austerity the country is enduring to curb inflation is not the answer, or that the price of success will be too high. **********In the Reagan team's view, the need to deal with Britain's urgent economic troubles has largely preempted Mrs. Thatcher's more fundamental plans. **********As Alan Greenspan, a top Reagan strategist, observed, ''She has not yet implemented the requirements for reducing the public-sector borrowing requirement (the Government deficit) or, as a consequence, the rise in the money supply, both of which are integral parts of the solution.'' **********When Mrs. Thatcher won office, many Britons, including some who did not particularly like her, regarded the Lincolnshire grocer's daughter as representing the country's ''last chance,'' with failure leading inevitably to a Government headed by left-wing elements of the Labor Party and the virtual end of free enterprise. **********As it happens, Mr. Reagan's election has coincided with the first comprehensive efforts to appraise Mrs. Thatcher's efforts. Her honeymoon is over, and with the economy in deep recession and unemploymemt at the highest levels since the 1930's, there are many who see in Britain a discrediting of conservative policies. Public-Sector Wage Rises **********Reagan advisers here, when asked what they have learned, invariably start by observing that while Mrs. Thatcher is being pilloried for supposedly imposing savage spending cuts and iron-fisted monetary control, she has actually carried out nothing of the kind. In fact, during her tenure, Government spending and borrowing have raced ahead, and the money supply has climbed even faster than the doubledigit inflation rate. **********But even in theory, much less in practice, Mrs. Thatcher's strategy appears less daring than that discussed by Mr. Reagan.  Although she did plan substantial tax cuts, now largely deferred, to spur incentives, Mrs. Thatcher's Government has not subscribed to the supply-side economics of Mr. Stockman, Representative Jack Kemp and Senator William V. Roth. **********As Mr. Greenspan and others see it, the trouble is not with Mrs.  Thatcher's prescription; it is that she has yet to administer the medicine. **********Various explanations have been offered for this failure of execution, including the need to prop up distressed nationalized industries, a problem not shared by the United States, and a decision by Mrs. Thatcher to keep a pledge to give big pay rises to publicsector employees. **********Mrs. Thatcher concedes that her first attempts at budget-cutting were too timid, and this mistake of starting too slowly has made a strong impression on the Reagan team. **********Those who advocate the Kemp-Roth tax plan are less concerned about budget-cutting and deficits. They contend that sharp tax cuts will generate enough additional economic activity to make up the lost revenue quickly. **********Some say the British experience has provided a reverse confirmation of the Kemp-Roth thesis. As the British economy slumped, business subsidies, unemployment payments and other Government payments have risen while tax revenue declined, thereby adding to the deficit. Much the same has happened in the United States. **********''The fatal mistake,'' ventured John D. Mueller, an aide to Representative Kemp, ''was for the British to cut back on the incentive side and hope budget austerity would get them through.'' **********Another error ascribed to Mrs. Thatcher is her preaching of sacrifice while the average Briton's income was still rising - resulting in a loss of credibility. According to the Reagan ''supplysiders,'' people's expectations are so important to curbing inflation that an erosion of public confidence that things are on course makes it harder, for example, to persuade workers to accept moderate wage increases. **********It is not overlooked here, however, that some things are now going Mrs. Thatcher's way. The balance of payments has swung into hefty surplus, and the inflation rate, though much higher than when she came to office, has come down rapidly of late, to just over 15 percent. **********And the widespread distress in the corporate sector does seem to be forcing it to become more efficient.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/28/busin.print_headline: Company News; Conoco to Close Minnesota Refinery
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/28/busin.body_text: **********Conoco Inc., the nation's ninthlargest refiner, said it would close its refinery in Wrenshall, because of sharply reduced demand for petroleum products and an excess of refining capacity in the industry. **********The action by the Stamford, Conn., company follows similar closures in the past three weeks by Mobil, Texaco, Gulf Oil and Standard Oil (Indiana. **********Conoco said the refinery was operating at only 50 percent of capacity and provided about 5 percent of its total supplies. The company's five other refineries operate at 75 percent of capacity, a spokesman said. The Wrenshall unit, built in 1953, is dependent on costly, low-sulfur crude oil and is unable to process high-sulfur crude, which is less costly and more available, the company said.

Mr. Bush came to the Philippines for the inauguration Tuesday of President Ferdinand Marcos.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/06/busin.body_text: **********The American subsidiary of Britain's Royal Insurance Company has named George W. Ansbro, 53 years old, as president and chief operating officer, effective next Jan. 1. He will succeed William C.  Simpson, 63, who will retire from the New York-based organization.  J. Roy Nicholas, a 59-year-old executive of the American company, continues as chairman and chief executive officer. **********The American subsidiary is responsible for about one-third of the parent corporation's $2.9 billion in premium revenue, principally in property and casualty insurance **********''The insurance industry is suffering from a very competitive cycle in which the rates have not kept pace with inflation working on losses,'' Mr. Ansbro said yesterday. ''On the other hand, the industry is also benefiting from high investment returns from high interest rates. In terms of return on equity, therefore, the industry is seeing reasonable results at this point in time.'' **********Mr. Ansbro has been with Royal for his entire career, starting in 1946 in California. He became a vice president 28 years later and a senior vice president in 1976. **********Mr. Simpson, a native of Britain, joined the company in 1937 and was transferred to the United States 10 years later. He became a senior vice president in 1968, executive vice president in 1973 and president two years ago. Mr. Simpson is a former chairman of the Insurance Information Institute, the trade association for the nation's property and casualty insurers. **********Mr. Ansbro said that Royal sells through independent agents and brokers because ''we feel that they are trained to properly assess the needs of the policyholder. We don't think that we can duplicate these functions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/world.print_headline: Argentine Cargo Plane Said to Crash in Soviet
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/world.body_text: **********A plane entered Soviet airspace from Iran on Saturday, collided with a Soviet plane near Yerevan in Armenia and crashed, the Tass press agency said today. **********The Argentine Foreign Ministry said in Buenos Aires that a Soviet jet fighter intercepted an Argentine cargo plane near the Soviet-Turkish border on Saturday, and it assumed this was the incident involved in the Tass report. **********The Tass account said: ''The crew of the plane did not respond to any inquiries by Soviet air traffic control services and to attempts to render help to it, and continued its flight over Soviet territory, performing dangerous maneuvers. Some time later the plane collided with a Soviet plane, crashed and burned.'' ---- **********BUENOS AIRES, July 22 (AP) - An Argentine Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that a cargo plane belonging to Transporte Aereo Rioplatense, ''on entering Turkish territory from Iran, changed its route for reasons unknown and headed for the Soviet border, where it was intercepted.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Cemetery Concern Has New President
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/17/busin.body_text: **********''It's a real estate business like any other,'' said Richard Kaufman, 39, who has been appointed president of Morlan International Inc., an owner and operator of 19 cemeteries in the United States and Canada. ''The ground has to be maintained well, or else we have nothing to sell.'' **********Mr. Kaufman succeeds Robert M. Shay, 44, who was named chairman and remains chief executive officer of the company, which is based in Philadelphia. **********Mr. Kaufman began his career as a registered representative with a predecessor firm of Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., in 1967 and joined the Texas International Company, an oil and gas developer, three years later. He was a vice president of that corporation when he joined Morlan in 1976 as a vice president for real estate and human services. He became executive vice president and chief operating officer shortly thereafter. **********Mr. Shay, who was attending a meeting of the American Cemetery Association in Acapulco, Mexico, yeserday, was a partner in the Philadelphia law firm of Fox, Rothschild, O'Brien & Frankel before coming to Morlan. He became its president in 1969. **********Calling cemeteries ''an inflation hedge,'' Mr. Kaufman observed that his company's assets were primarily real estate and the funds of customers making advance payments. ''This is one of the last industries in the United States to be conglomeratized,'' he added.  ''We're looking to expand quite agressively in the Sun Belt areas.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/12/busin.main_headline: A CO-OP IS CREATED ON CITY ISLAND WITH REBUILT COTTAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/12/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; A CO-OP IS CREATED ON CITY ISLAND WITH REBUILT COTTAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/12/busin.body_text: **********Ira Scherr is an advertising copywriter. Virginia Scherr, his wife, runs a business that processes hospital medical records for physicians. She has 47 employees and an office in a converted garage. The Scherrs have three teen-age sons. **********That would be quite enough for most people, but not the Scherrs.  They have lived for 20 years on City Island, that boat-infested spit of land jutting into Long Island Sound from the Pelham Bay section of the Bronx. Their comfortable house on the island's east shore overlooks Hart Island and the distant King's Point section of Long Island. **********An irresistible compulsion led them two years ago to purchase an oversized 1898 house at 33 Tier Street, with the intention of renting it out on a year-round basis. The house was not the only attraction.  The property is 100 feet wide and runs back 400 feet to the water, from which there is a splendid view of the Harlem Yacht Club and Sagman's boatyard. **********On the property stood a series of small one-bedroom cottages with shingled roofs. Since the 1950's they had been rented out on a seasonal basis by the owners of the main house, which was itself divided into four apartments. **********Mr. Scherr, as he put it, has ''dabbled in rehabilitation.'' He is a formidable fellow with hammer and saw. His thought was to rehabilitate the buildings and rent them out on a year-round basis. **********But two problems put that idea to rest. The Scherrs decided they would not be able to manage a property with so many tenants. And the cost of rehabilitation could not be recouped from the rents in a reasonable period of time. **********And so the Scherrs find themselves, two years later, as the owners and sponsors of a cooperative conversion project with a total sales offering price of $1.39 million. With themselves as the general contractors, they have done a total rehabilitation of main house and cottages into up-to-date, year-round housing with a marked California look. **********The main house has been converted into one floor-through and two duplex apartments in which some windows are circular in shape to resemble huge portholes. The cottages, flanking a winding path of newly installed cobblestones, have been imaginatively rebuilt with special touches everywhere. **********They have skylights and large windows oriented toward the water views, open and informal floor layouts, circular stairways, and stained-glass decorative windows. No two houses are exactly alike, but they all have a facade of nutty-brown clear cedar siding.  Kenneth Koons of the Bronx was the architect. **********In all, there are 12 housing units in eight buildings, and offstreet parking for 10 cars. The largest of the cottages has been built up into a two-family house, but most of the cottages are single-family units. Seven of the apartments have been sold and the first buyers will arrive next month. **********An 1,800-square-foot apartment in the large cottage sold first, for $160,000 (excluding the buyers' portion of a $75,000 mortgage allocation for the entire project), the Scherrs said. A waterfront cottage sold for $115,000. Another sold for $110,000 and a third for $105,000. The three apartments in the main house sold for $85,000. **********The entire project was done with subcontractors from the area and bank financing of only $310,000 in a short-term construction loan.  The Scherrs estimated that they put $800,000 to $850,000 into the project, mostly their own capital and personal borrowings. The deeper they got into the project, the more money it turned out they would need. ''The momentum carries you along,'' Mr. Scherr said. **********He managed to squeeze in time at the construction site early weekday mornings and on weekends, meanwhile holding down a full-time job at Ross Roy/ Compton New York Inc. **********From a financial standpoint, the Scherrs are agreed, the project is only partially a success. It will produce a reasonable return on the capital invested but hardly a ''killing,'' they said. About $40,000 was spent in correcting what they came to consider construction errors. **********But it certainly was a success in what Mrs. Scherr described as ''an exercise in tolerance.'' Every step of the way the Scherrs had disagreements - over how to lay out the apartments, how many to build, how to treat the exteriors, how to price them. Mr. Scherr had firm ideas on the construction. ''They would build the walls in the morning,'' Mrs. Scherr said, ''and I would come in the afternoon and have them tear them down.'' **********Mrs. Scherr, it seems, wanted to spend more, do more and charge more. Mr. Scherr felt it necessary to heed the prices recently obtained in City Island sales and not make the job so expensive that sales might be imperiled. **********''We disagreed on everything,'' Mrs. Scherr said, but not on the absorbing interest of real estate development. She intends to pursue condominium conversions of commercial property independently, and he is already involved in a joint venture with a contractor aimed at creating 90 new condominium apartments in City Island.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/09/busin.body_text: **********A composition for treatment of hemorrhoids by oral administration was patented this week by Joseph S. Breskman, president of the Sentry Paint and Chemical Company, Darby, Pa. **********Patent 4,265,887 reports that no previous oral medication for the condition is known, although pain-killing preparations are sometimes taken by mouth. **********The composition is made up of thiamin, riboflavin, pyridoxine, cobalamin, niacinamide and pantothenic acid, preferably in liquid form. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/09/busin.body_text: **********When Paul Desmarais was in business school some 30 years ago, he wrote a research paper on how someone could take over Canadian Pacific Ltd., the giant corporate conglomerate so intimately tied to Canada's history. **********Today, at the age of 50 and a highly successful French Canadian businessman, Mr. Desmarais may be well on the way to carrying out that research dream. For Mr. Desmarais, the head of and largest shareholder in the Power Corporation, a large holding company, has acquired almost 5 percent of Canadian Pacific with an option to buy another 5.6 percent. **********The moves have excited talk in Canadian corporate circles that this country could be on the verge of witnessing the largest corporate takeover in its history, an estimated $3 billion effort to own a sprawling corporate giant with vast North American holdings in ships, planes, trains, trucks, hotels, steel mills, paper plants, mines, forests, oil, agriculture, real estate and even chinaware. **********Vulnerable to a Takeover **********In an age of takeovers, Canadian Pacific has appeared incr easingly vulnerable. Its 71.7 million common shares ar e widely held, by 62,000shareholders, and until now no one owned more than 5 percent. The other large holder is the Clifford Fielding f amily of Sudbury, Ontario, where Mr. Desmarais began as a bus o perator. **********Mr. Desmarais's attempt for control, if that is what it becomes, could also set off a free-swinging bidding brawl among other potential buyers, a brawl the likes of which the gentlemanly world of Canadian business has never seen. And it could initiate the involvement of the Government, to protect the company it was responsible for creating 100 yea rs ago. **********''Canadian Pacific is Canada,'' said David Schulman, an analyst with Geoffrion Leclerc Inc. in Montreal, ''and Canada is Canadian Pacific.'' **********The company began as a railroad line that was given $25 million, 25 million acres and a monopoly to build Canada's first transcontinental railroad. Its rails were to be used to link Canada's isolated population into one nation. **********Sometimes loved, sometimes hated, but never forgotten, Canadian Pacific Ltd. grew to become Canada's largest non-Government company, consisting of 110 companies and 110,000 employees. In 1980 it reported final consolidated net income of $583.1 million, or $8.11 a share, on revenues of $9.98 billion, compared with a 1979 net of $508 million, or $7.06 a share, on revenues of $8.18 billion. Six-Month Net Declines **********But in the six months ended last June 30, the company's earnings have fallen slightly, mainly because of disappointing second-quarter results in CP Air, CP Ships and CP Enterprises Ltd., its nontransportation investment arm that has moved aggressively into the United States recently. **********CP Enterprises' holdings include Pancanadian Petroleum; Cominco Ltd.; Great Lakes Forest Products; Marathon Realty; CP Hotels; Syracuse China; Chateau Insurance; Algoma Steel; Dominion Bridge, now called AMCA International, and the Canadian properties of International Paper, acquired in July. **********CP Entreprises is run by Ian D. Sinclair, the blunt, brash 67-year-old business executive who gave up his chairmanship of the parent company in May, marking what many consider to be the end of an era when one man ran Canadian Pacific's entire empire. **********Mr. Sinclair is a friend of Mr. Desmarais, part of the fraternity of clans that controls Canadian business. Both companies have their headquarters in Montreal. Both men have also heard the rumors of a brewing takeover of Canadian Pacific by one of the financial forces in Canada. **********Names of prospective bidders mentioned by analysts include the British Columbia Resource Investment Corporation; the Alberta Heritage Trust Fund, the multibillion-dollar repository of much of that province's growing oil royalties; the Nova Corporation, formerly the Alberta Gas Trunk Line, and even the newly merged Hiram Walker-Consumers Gas entity. Seagram Activity **********The Seagram Company was also prominently mentioned when large blocs of Canadian Pacific stock traded early this summer. ''They'd buy around $50, back off when it rose to $52 or $53,'' one broker said, ''and then come in like gangbusters when CP fell to $49.'' **********Actually, the purchaser was Cadillac Fairview Ltd, the real estate company largely controlled by Cemp Investments. That company is an arm of the Bronfman family, which controls Seagram's. Cadillac Fairview took its 4.4 percent share of Canadian Pacific, some 3.7 million shares, to Mr. Desmarais, who paid $174 million. **********''Without talking to each other,'' Mr. Schulman said, ''these business families all think alike. They know the rules, the rumors, the goals of others. Cemp led the signals. They had some spare cash to fool with. So they assembled the bloc and went to Paul and made a deal. That's the way these things get started.'' **********Mr. Desmarais says he is simply making an investment in Canadian Pacific. But at the same time he sold for $195 million his transportation subsidiary - Canadian Steamship Lines, Canadian Shipbulding & Engineering, Kingsway Transport (trucking) and Voyageur Enterprises (buses) -which frees his company from possible conflicts with parallel Canadian Pacific interests. **********He also arranged an option to buy another 4 million shares, or 5.6 percent, of Canadian Pacific for $216 million from the Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec, the provincial pension fund manager.  Today, the Power Corporation announced that it had let that option expire without taking action, at least for the moment. Swap Called Possible **********A takeover of Canadian Pacific, especially by interests that might move its headquarters out of troubled Quebec, appears disas trous to many in Quebec. Analysts note that Mr. Desmar ais is a Quebecer with family ties to the federal Cabinet. He owns a lmost 40 percent of Consolidated-Bathurst, the paper company in Q uebec, where the provincial government and Caisse want to incr ease their resource holdings. A swap might be made, analysts say. **********They also note that Mr. Desmarais's remaining holdings - Great West Life Assurance, Montreal Trust and Investors Syndicate, a mutual fund - would fit nicely with the Canadian Pacific family and that the Power Corporation's units co uld borrow upward of $500 million. That would be suff icient for more than 20 percent of Canadian Pacific and effective con trol. **********The Power Corporation reported six-month earnings ending June 30 of $48.5 million, or $1.88 a share, on revenues of $197.4 million, compared with earnings of $47.6 million, or $1.85 a share, on revenues of $155.7 million in 1979. **********Mr. Desmarais has been an innovative entrepreneur, who has always sought control. ''Desmarais didn't buy CP at $54 just for its $1.90 dividend, a 3.5 percent yield,'' Mr. Schulman said. Canadian Pacific closed yesterday at 43 5/8, down 2 1/2, on the Toronto Stock Exchange. **********Officials at Canadian Pacific have been silent about Mr. Desmarais, which is widely taken as tacit approval. They expect him to join the company's 22-member board next May. Mr. Desmarais says that would be ''nice,'' that he just wants a say in the company and that control is not his goal. **********But others, aware of the binding securities regulations that begin once someone seeks control, remain skeptical.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/30/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WOLRD; Storms Compel Indonesians To Halt Hunt for Survivors
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/30/world.body_text: **********Monsoon storms forced the suspension today of the search for nearly 400 people missing from an Indonesian ship that sank in flames in the Java Sea, and officials said it was feared that there were no more survivors. **********''With such bad weather we now have only very little hope to find any more survivors,'' said a spokesman for the search operation for the Tampomas II. **********He said 355 passengers and 25 crewmen were still missing and ''there is little chance they could survive at sea without food or fresh water.'' Eighty-seven people are known to have died and there are about 670 confirmed survivors from among more than 1,000 passengers and a crew of 54.
