https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/25/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Professor Galbraith's article provided us with the socialist's view of supply-side economics. He began with the presumption that monetary stability and control of Federal budget expenditures must necessarily produce a decline in real output. **********That notion is clearly at odds with history and with common sense. **********In Professor Galbraith's world, economic leviathans (Big Business, Big Labor, OPEC and farm cooperatives ) struggle for control in a zero-sum system where the weak and powerless can only be protected by Big Government. Nowhere in the good professor's vision does economic growth, the only effective rejuvenator of our private capital system, and the primary thrust of the Reagan economic program, play more than a neutral role. Growth in production, employment, risk-taking and success can occur only from lower tax rates (not sales taxes versus income taxes) and stability in the purchasing power of the dollar. That course is the only hope for the weak and powerless.  GERALD W. BOLLMAN Morristown, N.J., Jan. 8, 1981

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/03/busin.main_headline: Business Digest; FRIDAY, APRIL 3, 1981; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/03/busin.print_headline: Business Digest; FRIDAY, APRIL 3, 1981; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/03/busin.body_text: **********The Republican-controlled Senate approved spending cuts of $36.9 billion, $2.8 billion more than recommended by the President. The cuts, passed by an 88-10 vote, would mean a major retrenchment in social welfare programs and a change in how the Government operates.  The measure now goes to the Democratic-controlled House, whose leaders have predicted passage of 75 percent of the legislation sought by the President. (Page A1.) **********The Federal Reserve said it may stop reporting money supply data each week. The move could relieve pressure on the Fed to adjust interest rates quickly in response to short-term changes in the money supply and thereby reduce rate volatility. (D1.) **********The F.T.C. should stop its investigation into the regulation of children's advertising on television, the F.T.C. staff recommended.  It said a full ban on questionable ads would be the only effective way to protect children, but called that impractical. (D1.) **********The White House said it would nominate an Oklahoma oilman and real estate developer, Edward E. Noble, as chairman of the Governmentsponsored Synthetic Fuels Corporation. (D2.) Companies **********R.J. Reynolds' disclosure of talks with Rothmans International was seen as an indication that Reynolds might acquire the British cigarette maker. A link between the world's third- and fourth-largest tobacco companies, respectively, would mean that Reynolds would lift its share of the overseas tobacco market and compete with Philip Morris for the role of the second-largest cigarette maker. (D1.) **********The General Public Utilities Corporation received a $106.7 million annual rate increase for its two Pennsylvania units. Analysts said G.P.U. may now have greater leeway to solve the financial problems that resulted from the Three Mile Island accident. (D1.) **********Intel agreed to form a joint venture with a French company, Matra-Harris Semiconducteurs, in a move intended to give it access to a large part of the French electronics market. (D3.) **********Volkswagen did not disclose potential engine problems in 1 million 1974- to 1979-model cars, the F.T.C. charged. (A1.) **********Two Brooklyn banks plan to merge. If Metropolitan Savings and Brooklyn Savings win approval, they would form the country's fourthlargest mutual savings bank, with assets of $3.9 billion. (D3.) **********G.E. said it would manufacture and sell a robot developed by an Italian company. It will also acquire the Calma Company, giving G.E.  the facility to move into the growing market in integrated systems for automated production. (D4.) **********Noranda Mines raised its offer for MacMillan Bloedel to the equivalent of $62 a share, or $626 million (Canadian). The offer came a day after the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation raised its offer to $56 per share cash. (D4.) International **********Bonn is seeking to cut its contribution to the Common Market budget for 1982. Citing unfair treatment in steel, fishing and other areas, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said that West Germany, the E.E.C.'s largest contributor, had French support for the move. (D3.) Markets **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.13, to 1,009.01, as investors cashed in profits made in the rally of the last two days and reacted to reports of a growing possibility of Soviet intervention in Poland. Big Board volume slipped to 52.6 million shares. (D6.) **********The S.E.C. told Congress its computerized system to detect violations in stock trading now covered 10 percent of stocks traded and had helped uncover deficient surveillance procedures at both the Amex and the C.B.O.E. The system, known as MOSS, will be expanded to include all stocks later this year, the agency said. (D13.) **********Investments in money market funds rose $3.2 billion in the most recent week, to $112.3 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported. Last week's growth figure was revised to $4.1 billion.  (D6.) **********The dollar gained in New York and overseas markets on rising interest rates. Gold prices advanced, with Republic National Bank quoting bullion at $517.50 an ounce, up $2. (D10.) Short- and longterm interest rates rose modestly. (D9.) Futures prices were up for grain, soybeans, gold and silver. (D10.) Today's Columns **********Sharp cuts recommended for economics research under the National Science Foundation budget have united economists of all stripes to battle the proposals. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********Con Ed is now drawing praise on Wall Street, and analysts predict further gains. But rising interest rates could dampen the rosy prospects - and those of other electric utilities. Market Place.  (D6.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/17/world.body_text: **********Few South Africans have ever heard of this black shantytown in Transvaal, northeast of Pretoria, or of the obscure little state of which it is supposed to be the capital. **********There is not even a sign on the nearest highway to indicate the turning, or along the 18 miles of rutted side road to show the boundary of KwaNdebele, which in April became the latest of the 10 black states to be given self-rule within South Africa. **********The ethnic enclave, comprising 210 square miles of rolling veld, the African grassland, was set up for the Ndebele people, a tribe of a few hundred thousand related linguistically to the Zulu, who have their own KwaZulu state. **********Now theoretically just a step away from independence, the land allotted to KwaNdebele was once divided among 30 white farmers. In the 1970 census its population was said to be 32,000. Now it is somewhere between 166,000, a figure furnished by census officials in Pretoria, and 299,000, a number provided by the Chief Minister of KwaNdebele, Simon Skhosana. **********20 New Families a Day Arrive **********Every day, Mr. Skhosana said in an interview, the South African authorities deposit about 20 families in his state.  They are brought here with their possessions in white government trucks with green canvas tops, having been ordered to leave adjacent rural areas to the south around the Transvaal towns of Bronkhorstspruit, Middelburg and Bethal, which were proclaimed white by South African legislation. **********White politicians have recently become self-conscious about the policy of sorting out the black population on an ethnic basis, but two years ago a junior member of the Government declared that more than 9,000 Ndebele-speaking families had been removed to their supposed homeland in only one year. **********The veld in KwaNdebele is now covered with widening patches of mudand-thatch hovels, metal shanties and green canvas tents that are standard government issue for resettlement sites. **********The only visible industry is the government of this new black state. The only housing programs are for Mr. Skhosana and his ministers, who live side by side in small ranch-style structures behind a high barbed-wire fence, and for government employees, who are given simple cinderblock homes with small solar-heating devices atop the bathrooms. Few Buildings of Significance **********If there is any building that is plainly worth more than the car parked in the Chief Minister's driveway - a BMW sedan that sells for $35,000 in South Africa - it is the gymnasium-style structure that houses an appointed legislature. **********Elsewhere in KwaNdebele, which lies astride the upper Olifants River, agriculture is in decline because the growing population is taking over the grazing land and competing for the water, which is in short supply. There are no jobs in commuting distance. Most ablebodied men end up working in Pretoria, 60 miles away along a dirt road with occasional bus service. Those who are conscientious return on weekends. **********KwaNdebele's newest settlements have the appearance of unplanned squatter camps but, under the supervision of white officials from the Ministry of Cooperation and Development, little stakes have been driven into the hillsides every 60 feet or so to indicate the plots that can be allotted to new arrivals. Shanties on a Former White Farm **********The Nduli family got theirs on what was an empty hillside on a farm that had belonged to a white family named Smit in an area known as Kwaggafontein, 10 miles from here. Now there are scores of shanties and hundreds of people, mostly women and children. **********Kleinbooi Nduli, the youngest of Rose Nduli's three grown sons, arrived on a truck with the family's possessions, which were now stacked inside and around a thatch hovel that was serving as a shelter until the oldest brother, Johannes, could return from Pretoria with metal siding to make a shack. **********Kleinbooi Nduli wore a brown shoe on his right foot and a black boot on his left; the boot was tied with bits of copper electrical wire. With a shovel he dug away at the veld grass to clear his plot. **********Until he was abruptly told that his services had been terminated, he was living on a white farm near Middelburg with his brother's wife and three children, his sister and her child and his mother. His brother Johannes and another brother, Paulus, worked as laborers in a construction gang in Pretoria, earning about $50 a week each, much more than the $34 a month the farmer had paid Kleinbooi. **********Kleinbooi Nduli was asked whether he minded being forced out of a job in Middelburg. He laughed in embarrassment and said the farmer had sometimes hit him. His mother was more direct. **********''The law is the law and we have nothing to say about it,'' she said in a matter-of-fact tone. Forced to Move Three Times **********Jim Masetlana, an old-timer at Kwaggafontein, having been deposited here in March, was matter-of-fact but also angry. He had been forced to move three times in 19 years, from one township to another, as the black settlements outside the white South African cities are called. **********Asked whether it mattered that he had finally come to reside in a homeland, he replied sharply, waving his hand at the encampment on the hillside. **********''This is no homeland,'' he said. ''It's just a township. Where I grew up was really a homeland. I had land. I could plough, Even the white farmers give you land to plough. This type of homeland I've never seen.'' **********Chief Minister Skhosana, who once worked as a driver in Johannesburg, laughed when he was asked whether he had asked the white authorities to stop bringing new people into his state. **********''It's impossible,'' he said, meaning apparently that it would have no effect. He had asked, however, for more land. ''When they give it to you, you say 'thank you' and ask again,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/03/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 3, 1981; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee began drawing up a new two-year tax relief bill in a challenge to the Reagan Administration. The committee's chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, indicated after a caucus of committee Democrats that they were preparing for a test of strength with the Administration on the House floor. The Democrats were said to be mapping a cut of 5 percent in the first year and a further 10 percent reduction in 1982. (Page A1.) **********New factory orders fell 0.8 percent in April to a seasonally adjusted $163.3 billion, the steepest decline since last May, the Commerce Department reported. Manufacturers' shipments also declined slightly in April, raising factory inventories and providing new evidence that the national economy is no longer booming. (D1.) **********Sales of new single-family houses plunged 13.5 percent in April, the biggest drop in a year, as rising mortgage interest rates continued to plague the housing industry, the Government reported.  Despite the sales decline, the median sales price for new single-family houses rose to a record $69,300 in April, up from $67,300 in March. (Page D7.) **********The move to a lower prime rate was joined by the Bank of America, Citibank and other major institutions, which dropped their key lending rate by half a point, to 20 percent. (D12.) International **********Mexico slashed its crude oil prices by $4 a barrel, the first major producer to do so since the OPEC countries froze prices last week in Geneva in the face of weakening worldwide oil demand. The move was viewed by industry analysts as dramatic evidence of the downward pressure on world petroleum prices because of oversupply. (D1.) **********China will borrow from the United States Export-Import Bank, the United States Embassy announced. The agreement will enable China to increase its imports from American manufacturers. (D2.) Companies **********The F.T.C. decided not to block the takeover of Kennecott by the Standard Oil Company (Ohio). In doing so, the panel rejected a staff recommendation to sue Sohio on antitrust grounds. The commission instead approved a settlement with the British Petroleum Company, ordering it to sell the 6.8 percent interest that it also owns in Amax Inc., another mining company, within 30 months. (D1.) **********Pan American Airways dismissed seven vice presidents in a bid to improve efficiency. (D1.) The move coincided with the disclosure that Pan Am had switched its $35 million advertising account to Doyle Dane Bernbach. For the last three years, the account had been handled by N.W. Ayer Inc. (D20.) **********International Harvester has little hope of turning a profit before the first quarter of 1982, according to an analysis prepared for the farm machinery maker by Booz, Allen & Hamilton, a consulting concern. (D5) **********Two F.D.A. officials conceded that they were entertained by executives of Burton, Parsons & Company, a maker of contact lens solutions, but they denied this influenced agency decisions that gave the small Maryland company a virtual monopoly. (D5.) **********New York State's small bankers called for rapid deregulation so they can increase rates they pay depositors. The plea came at a New York State Bankers Association convention. (D11.) Markets **********The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 987.48, down 10.48, as investors reacted to confusing signals on the direction of interest rates. (D8.) An unexpected move by the Federal Reserve to drain funds contributed to sharp swings in short-term rates, which rose slightly on the day. (D12.) **********Commodities generally closed lower, affected by mixed signals on interest rates and the economy. (D14.) The dollar soared in early trading but then slipped in New York to finish with mixed results.  The price of gold fell $5.50 an ounce in London, to $476, and later in New York was quoted at $474.60, down 10 cents. (D14.) Columns **********Monetarism is the core of the Reagan tax plan rather than budget and fiscal restraint. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********Basic Earth Science Systems drastically devalued the oil and gas reserves cited in a prospectus for a public offering that drew pension money from I.B.M. and Bankers Trust. Market Place. (D8.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/07/busin.main_headline: MISS WEINSTEIN TO HEAD M-G-M UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/07/busin.print_headline: MISS WEINSTEIN TO HEAD M-G-M UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/07/busin.body_text: **********In the latest shuffling of executive posts at the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Corporation, Paula Weinstein has been named president of the motion picture division of the United Artists Corporation. **********Miss Weinstein replaces Raphael Etkes, who went to M-G-M after being dismissed as chief executive officer of Filmways a year ago.  Early in her career, she was an agent at a talent agency founded by David Begelman, chairman and chief executive officer at United Artists. **********Second Woman to Head Studio **********The 35-year-old Miss Weinstein will be the second woman to head production at a major studio, nearly two years after Sherry Lansing took over the presidency of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation. **********Miss Weinstein starts her new job Monday with what she described in an interview as ''a sense of mission, a desire to make pictures I feel passionately about and that are about something.'' **********United Artists became a wholly owned subsidiary of M-G-M last May, with the provision that the two companies would be kept separate.  A little over a month ago, Mr. Begelman shifted from his position as president and chief operating officer of M-G-M to become chairman and chief executive officer of United Artists. Freddie Fields, Mr.  Begelman's long-time associate and former partner in the talent agency, was then chosen as head of M-G-M's film division. **********Industry analysts believe that these shifts were partly a response to what some insiders call a somewhat precarious financial position at M-G-M. **********Mr. Begelman, former head of Columbia, was brought in to revitalize M-G-M in January 1980. The company went from torpor to the busiest studio in Hollywood and now has $150 million tied up in a program of 17 movies to be released between September and next autumn. The purchase of United Artists from Transamerica for $380 million insured M-G-M total control over the distribution of those films, and also brought the company a film library valued at more than $300 million. **********Currently, M-G-M's total debt is $702 million, compared with a stockholder equity of $207 million, and the cost of slightly more than half its debt is tied to the prime rate. **********The company's stock was selling at $12 last May. The anticipated stock rise, which the company felt would help to finance the purchase, has, instead, become a decline of $6. M-G-M has also tried to raise money through a $50 million limited partnership in 12 of its 1981 and 1982 movies in a joint venture with SLM Entertainment Ltd.  Units of $5,000 in the 12 films are being sold by Merrill Lynch and Dean Witter, but analysts question how attractive such a package will be. Analyst Cites Assets **********Lee Isgur, a movie industry analyst for Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc., is one who feels that M-G-M's difficulties have been greatly overestimated. ''Just look at their assets,'' he said. ''The company could raise significant sums of money right now by selling its library to cable and video cassette. I haven't recommended M-G-M for two years, but the company is now beginning to look interesting to me.'' **********According to Frank Rosenfelt, M-G-M's chairman, the company has ''absolutely no cash crunch.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/busin.body_text: **********Indonesian oil officials said today that representatives of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were trying to resolve sharp differences among members over Saudi Arabia's proposals for a long-term pricing strategy. **********These officials, however, held out little hope that the differences would be narrowed before the next OPEC meeting, which is scheduled for May 25 in Geneva. Among the topics expected to be discussed are crude oil prices increases and the possibility of reduced production in the face of an oil surplus on the world market. **********''Differences persist among OPEC members,'' said Dr. Subroto, the Indonesian oil minister and current OPEC president, who traveled to Kuwait at the invitation of Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, the oil minister. **********The Saudi proposals were reiterated here yesterday by Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, during a one-day visit.  Sheik Yamani called on other OPEC members to approve a plan under which oil supply would be matched to demand while prices would rise slightly every three months, indexed to the West's inflation and economic growth. He said the formula would likely put the price of OPEC oil above $50 a barrel by 1985. **********The Saudis say they want to restore moderation to oil pricing.  Their view is that in the long run sharp increases not only hurt the economies of the West but also the oil-producing countries, because of the inflation they induce. **********Sheik Yamani has held a series of meetings in the last few weeks to try to persuade his Gulf state counterparts to accept the Saudi position. **********Saudi Arabia has privately told its OPEC allies that it is prepared to reduce daily production by up to two million barrels - but only if OPEC reaches a long-term pricing agreement for the decade. ''Saudi Arabia will not reduce oil production before OPEC agrees on unified prices,'' Sheik Yamani said here, at the headquarters of the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries, ''Price unity would lead to production reduction by all OPEC members.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/18/world.main_headline: Doctors' Strike Spreads To Miners in Peru
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/18/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Doctors' Strike Spreads To Miners in Peru
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/18/world.body_text: **********Copper miners and bank employees went on strike today, joining 13,000 physicians in a campaign for higher pay. **********The country's largest copper mines, Cuajone and Toquepala, were paralyzed when 6,000 workers walked out to demand a 25 percent raise and reinstatement of dismissed colleagues. **********A spokesman for the Southern Peru Copper Corporation, which operates the mines, said the strike would cost the country a million dollars a day in foreign currency earnings. **********Bank workers struck over similar demands. Doctors, who have been on strike for 10 days, threatened more radical action if the Government refused to grant a pay increase.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.main_headline: EAST MIDTOWN'S OFFICE TENANTS LEARN ABOUT INFLATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; EAST MIDTOWN'S OFFICE TENANTS LEARN ABOUT INFLATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.body_text: **********''Anyone paying $1,000 a square foot for land must rent for $40 a square foot to break even,'' a Manhattan developer with long experience remarked the other day. ''And I just heard of two sales at $2,000 a square foot! The market is overheated.'' **********What will happen, he wondered aloud, if inflationary expectations subside? Will those who are paying $2,000 a square foot for land, who are perhaps paying 20 percent or more for interim financing and who face greatly increased costs for the numerous nonconstruction services associated with new development decide not to go forward after all? **********''If you start building today, you've got to get average rents of $50 to $60 a square foot,'' the developer said. Space in new east midtown buildings is currently said to be commanding rents of $35 to $45 a square foot per year. Recent leases in the General Motors Building and the Pan Am Building are reported to have been written at more than $50 a square foot. **********But the figures do not show the extent of leasing activity at that rent level, and the developer confessed he was uneasy. People going ahead with new projects are ''counting on inflation to bail them out,'' he said. **********How broad will the market be for space at the new east midtown rents? ''Already we are beginning to find resistance to the rents between Third Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas,'' the builder said. **********Leasing brokers confirm that many tenants are leaving the east midtown area rather than pay rents that are $20 a square foot higher than they had paid on expiring leases. The departures are often companies that use perhaps 10,000 to 30,000 square feet of space, while big law firms, accounting firms and corporate headquarters have usually stayed and accepted the higher rents. **********John L. Dowling, executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield Inc., identified the departing tenants as service firms - among them advertisers, publishers and public relations concerns - that cannot easily pass on their sharply increased rent costs. The rent resistance has not caused a weakening in rent levels, the brokers say. But leasing activity in the early part of this year subsided from what one broker, Edward S. Gordon, called last year's ''frenzy.'' **********A large body of office tenants, still comfortable with older leases made at perhaps $10 to $13 a square foot, have ''not had to face the music yet,'' Mr. Dowling said. Average rents in one group of east midtown buildings stand at $16 a square foot, for example. **********S. Donald Friedman, executive vice president of Huberth & Huberth, gave an example of how one east midtown service firm was responding.  It has a lease east of Madison Avenue in the 50's at $13 a square foot. The lease has five more years to run. **********The space can command $35 a square foot. The firm has put it on the market for sublet and is moving into 50,000 square feet in a loft building south of 34th Street at $10 a square foot ''as is.'' It will spend its own money to renovate the new space. **********''The tenant in 10,000 to 30,000 square feet is resisting the new high rents,'' Mr. Friedman said. ''They are finding space in the 'marginal' areas.'' **********Accordingly, the ''marginal'' areas are gaining new strength. The Park Avenue South area with its side streets from 18th Street north to 33d Street is one example. It was not an office center until recently, but office tenants are replacing manufacturers in some buildings. They pay higher rents than former manufacturing tenants, thus slowing the move toward residential conversion so noticeable in the late 1970's. **********Also benefiting is the Times Square area and Broadway buildings south of 42d Street.  As one developer noted, rents in Manhattan are ''all over the lot.'' **********At 767 Third Avenue, a new building with 250,000 square feet of leasable space that the William Kaufman Organization is producing, Melvyn Kaufman describes most of the incoming tenants as ''squeezeouts.'' It is a 39-story building in which most floors have 6,500 square feet of usable space. There are 20 tenants so far, including governmental missions, advertising agencies, law firms and computer firms, and the building is ''over 75 percent'' rented. The first occupants are supposed to arrive in August. **********The average rents are about $35 a square foot, Mr. Kaufman said.  Leasing began last fall at several dollars a square foot below that and has moved higher. ''But there is a limit to how much a tenant will pay not to be overcrowded,'' he said. **********The rent requirements of the new buildings have had the effect of raising asking rents greatly in older buildings in the vicinity of the new buildings, Mr. Friedman said. ''There's not enough space available for a healthy give and take in negotiation on rents,'' he said. **********In part the current midtown situation was created by the collapse of new production in the mid-1970's. The post-recession buildings are only now becoming ready for occupancy: 4.6 million square feet this year in midtown and 5 million square feet more next year. Several of the buildings will be occupied fully by the corporations building them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/04/busin.body_text: **********The average price of houses sold in the United States rose to a record $80,600 in the final three months of 1980, two Government agencies reported today. However, a separate Government housing price index declined slightly in the fourth quarter and showed a lower annual increase than in previous years. **********The $80,600 average price for one-family houses represented a 4 percent jump from the third quarter and a 10 percent increase over the final quarter of 1979, according to the Commerce Department and the Department of Housing and Urban Development. **********A separate index for single-family homes prepared by Commerce and H.U.D., which measures prices against similar sales in 1974, rose 11 percent in 1980 after increases of 13.8 percent and 14.1 percent in 1979 and 1978.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/world.main_headline: NEW ENVOY FROM CANADA OFFERS FRESH APPROACH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/world.print_headline: NEW ENVOY FROM CANADA OFFERS FRESH APPROACH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/world.body_text: **********Canada is sending a new ambassador to Washington Tuesday with an enhanced role in handling what he calls his country's ''dominant bilateral relationship.'' **********Allan E. Gotlieb, who has been Under Secretary of State for External Affairs, will share with the recently named United States Ambassador to Ottawa, Paul Robinson, responsibility for coping with the controversies that have plagued relations in the last few months. **********Mr. Gotlieb, a 53-year-old legal expert who was educated at the Harvard Law School and at Oxford, will replace Peter M. Towe, who is returning to Ottawa, reportedly for a post with the Government oil company, Petro-Canada. **********New System of Consultation **********Ambassador Gotlieb said he hoped that a system of consultation devised a few weeks ago giving leading roles to the two Ambassadors would lead to better coordination and cooler tempers. Tensions had been created by United States complaints of Canadian investment policies and Canadian complaints of American environmental policies. **********Now, when a specific problem arises, there will be an attempt, Mr.  Gotlieb said, ''to get the right players into a small group to discuss it.'' Two such meetings have already been held. **********Mr. Gotlieb said he hoped that some of the heat in the relations between the two countries would be reduced by the recent Canadian Government decision to drop plans to give further powers to the Foreign Investment Review Agency, an arm of the Department of Industry, Trade and Commerce that passes on applications by foreign investors. The agency has been accused by United States businessmen of putting obstacles in the way of investment in Canada. **********''Canada is not insensitive to the views of its trading partners,'' Mr. Gotlieb said, adding that ''this doesn't mean that the Government of Canada acts in the direction the United States wishes on all occasions.'' **********Canada has up to now refused to abandon a basic policy of reducing United States and other foreign ownership in the oil and gas industry although it is discussing American complaints of unfair and discriminatory treatment. **********Canada says the United States is insensitive to Canadian environmental concerns, in particular the spreading of acid rain by American industry. Mr. Gotlieb said environmental issues involved ''sharing a continent'' and may be the most important issues to resolve.

The Chrysler Corporation has been offering rebates of $300 to $1,000 on certain models. The Ford Motor Company has a program that could mean customer savings of up to $1,000 a car, while the American Motors Corporation has been offering dealer incentives of $100 to $450 a car. It was not known if these automakers would extend their offers. **********The incentive programs apparently helped increase sales industrywide by 29 percent in the first 10 days of August and by 18.2 percent in the second 10 days of the month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/14/world.main_headline: MALTA'S COURSE, TO THE WEST OR 'UNALIGNED,' TIED TO VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/14/world.print_headline: MALTA'S COURSE, TO THE WEST OR 'UNALIGNED,' TIED TO VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/14/world.body_text: **********With vote counting from Saturday's election proceeding slowly, politicians from both Prime Minister Dom Mintoff's ruling Labor Party and the conservative Nationalist Party tonight predicted a close contest. **********A widespread sense that the election is a milestone in Malta's political life, determining whether this strategic Mediterranean island continues with its proclaimed nonalignment or moves back closer to the West, brought a turnout of about 95 percent of an electorate of 238,378. **********Ballots were being counted in a fenced-off former barracks near the airport, encircled by armed troops and roadblocks. Sixty-five legislators will be chosen under a system of proportional representation. **********In a decade in power, Prime Minister Mintoff has changed the nature of political life in Malta, which became independent from Britain in 1964. While at home he has built an increasingly costly welfare state, in foreign policy the Prime Minister has attempted to win from his Mediterranean neighbors diplomatic pledges and money to guarantee Malta's nonaligned position. The last British troops left here in 1979 at his insistence. Relations With Libya Sour **********This sometimes erratic quest for a varyingly defined nonalignment first led Mr. Mintoff into a close relationship with Libya, which for several years sold oil to Malta at concessionary rates. But relations soured last year when Libyan warships forced the closing of an oil rig drilling in contested waters, and Mr. Mintoff angrily expelled 50 Libyan military trainers in retaliation. **********Last year, Italy signed an agreement committing it to respect Malta's neutrality, backing this pledge with $95 million in grants and soft loans over a five-year period. This year, the Mintoff Government gave Soviet commercial ships the right to store oil in Malta's underutilized harbor installations, and on Oct. 8 the Soviet Union signed an agreement proclaiming its respect for Malta's neutrality. **********The opposition Nationalist Party, which lost the 1976 election by only 6,000 votes, has said it will seek closer economic and defense ties with the West if it wins. **********''We don't agree with this concept of neutrality,'' said Eddi Fenech-Adami, the party's 47-year-old leader, in an interview. ''We don't place the two superpowers on equal footing.'' **********While the election has important implications for Malta's foreign policy, the campaign has turned largely on domestic questions. ''The main issue is the preservation of democratic rights,'' said Mr.  Fenech-Adami, who accuses the Prime Minister of undermining the independence of the judiciary, wrecking Malta's ancient university with a student-worker program, subverting the independence of its broadcasting system and bullying his political opponents. **********The Nationalists seem to be counting on a feeling in some sections of the population that a decade of Mr. Mintoff has been enough, and they have promised to cut heavy taxes that have resulted from his ambitious social programs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/13/busin.body_text: **********ROONEY, PACE INC. marketed a million units of Inteleplex Corporation on Wednesday and in doing so may have brought back the concept of public offerings for unseasoned companies. **********It is a coincidence perhaps, but Rooney, Pace took over the New York offices of John Muir & Company when Muir went out of business last August after dominating the market for new issues for high-risk companies. **********In the second page of a preliminary offering plan, Inteleplex pictures a dazzling array of telephone and computer equipment. Apart from this, however, there seems little to inspire confidence in the 35-page document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********The company states that the equipment it uses will be supplied by others: Inteleplex is not a manufacturer and has no intention of becoming one, the prospectus says. **********The company also states that its contract revenues so far total $160,424. Inteleplex, which is based in Atlantic City, reports a negative net worth. Moreover, as stated in bold type on the cover, Inteleplex securities involve a high degree of risk and the offering means immediate, substantial dilution. **********The million units marketed Wednesday each consisted of one share of common stock and a warrant to buy another share at a unit price of $3. The underwriter said yesterday that the units were fully subscribed and had reached 3 1/4 bid in the aftermarket. **********Inteleplex was founded last February, two months after a similar operation, General Telecommunications Technologies, ceased doing business. G.T.T.'s president, John M. Sues, is now president of Inteleplex. He ceased being president of G.T.T. when it ceased being a company. General Telecommunications owes unspecified sums to creditors, and one major investor failed to recover an investment in the company, the prospectus says. **********Inteleplex states that the creditors and the investor could attempt to assert claims against Inteleplex, though the company is not aware of existing or threatened claims. **********Even so, the company will set aside $250,000 from the proceeds of the offer for ''extraordinary working capital purposes,'' including the defense of any such claims. **********In March the company issued 1.3 million shares to Mr. Sues and to John Voigt, executive vice president, ''in consideration of past services'' to the month-old business. **********That same month, Harold Charno and Marcus Finkle, the latter a director, purchased 306,350 Inteleplex shares for 24 cents each.  In June, Mr. Charno and Mr. Finkle each lent the company $75,000 at an interest rate of 20 percent. The loans were subsequently converted into notes and units at 50 cents a unit. The units are similar to those being offered to the public, though the exercise price on the warrants is $5 a share. **********After the offering, though, the warrant price will be adjusted to $3 a share and the notes will be repaid out of the proceeds.  In September, the company sold $125,000 of 20 percent notes to an Aarnel Funding Corporation defined-contribution pension plan and issued Aarnel 50,000 Inteleplex units at a cent each. The loan is to be paid back out of proceeds of the offering. Moreover, the Aarnel pension plan will receive units worth $150,000 at the proposed offering price - or more than the principal amount of the loan itself. **********Rooney, Pace purchased for $300 a total of 30,000 units as compensation for ''certain financial consulting services'' in the July private placement with Aarnel. Rooney, Pace is also receiving an underwriting fee. **********While there is always hope in a business enterprise such as this, the risk to the investor is heightened by a lack of operating history and Inteleplex's weak financial structure. Moreover, the history includes a chief executive who just discontinued a business in a related field. He will be paid $75,000 a year by Inteleplex. All officers and directors as a group will be paid $280,000 a year. **********Mr. Rooney was reached by telephone and asked about the apparent similarity between Inteleplex and some earlier Muir offerings. He said he felt strongly that Inteleplex was a better company than the information in the prospectus would indicate. **********Under the Inteleplex concept, he said, the company will wire buildings for telecommunication service at relatively little cost when the steel goes up - not when the building is complete. It will put a minicomputer on the premises to handle the communications, data processing, energy management and security needs of both tenants and landlord. **********''The prospectus shows that this new company has a $5.1 million backlog,'' Mr. Rooney said. ''That in itself is unusual for new company. If I were an investor, I would investigate the potential in this company in light of such a substantial backlog at this stage of its development.'' **********A spokesman for Inteleplex declined comment, citing S.E.C.  restrictions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/26/busin.body_text: **********WHAT Rena Bartos, senior vice president at J. Walter Thompson, calls ''the irritation factor'' in today's advertising has left her, if not exactly irritated, at least distinctly worried about its implications for the advertising industry. **********''A lot of advertising is very hard-hitting and very hard-sell,'' she said in a low-keyed, unirritating conversation the other day, ''and it's a lot of this kind of advertising which people find irritating.'' **********Before a brasher person could press for specifics, Mrs. Bartos gently cited a survey that the Gallup organization carried out some months ago on behalf of the National Advertising Review Board. She has analyzed it, and related research, in the July-August issue of Harvard Business Review. **********''That study asked consumers whether they ever wanted to complain about the advertising they saw, and roughly half of them said they thought of complaining,'' she went on, ''although, human nature being what it is, only 8 percent actually did complain.'' **********''When Gallup asked them what it was they wanted to complain about, most of them focused on areas of taste. They said advertising was 'distasteful,' 'offensive,' 'insulting to my intelligence.' '' **********Those findings, she said, give ''further evidence of the importance of the irritation factor in advertising,'' tying in ominously with the results of repeated soundings by William D. Wells, the director or research at Needham Harper & Steers. **********Mrs. Bartos keeps up with that sort of thing in her capacity as J.  Walter Thompson's director of communications development; her job includes following social trends and trying to make links back to advertising and marketing. **********One societal sea change in recent years, she said, has been that the public has become ''increasingly sophisticated and increasingly skeptical -skeptical about all institutions.'' ''And therefore,'' she added, ''they are very sensitive about condescension, stereotyping and so forth.'' **********Understandably, in that climate, Mrs. Bartos ascribes considerable importance to an upward creep in the percentage of Mr. Wells's respondents, in his yearly surveys, who agree with the premise that ''advertising insults my intelligence.'' Sixty-one percent of the men and 60 percent of the women felt that way in 1975, but by last year the figures had risen to 66 and 67 percent, respectively. **********Over the same five years, Mr. Wells's soundings have also traced a decline in consumers' partiality to brand products. In 1975, 80 percent of the men and 72 percent of the women agreed with the premise that ''I try to stick with well-known brand names.'' But by last year those percentages had fallen, respectively, to 64 and 56. **********That shrinkage, Mrs. Bartos said, ''is very worrying in view of the fact that we have recently seen the challenge coming from generic, or no-name, brands. After all, the essential role of advertising is to build consumer trust in advertised brands.'' **********Is there a causal relationship between the two trends that Mr.  Wells has traced, Mrs. Bartos was asked. Do irritating advertisements actually diminish peoples' confidence in advertised brands? **********''I personally believe yes,'' she said, citing an earlier survey, sponsored by the American Association of Advertising Agencies, which, she said, suggested ''that when consumers say an advertisement insults their intelligence, or is in poor taste, they may also be challenging the credibility of the advertising message.'' **********''At the moment, this is a hypothesis which has not been proved,'' she continued, ''but I think the inferential data are so strong that it behooves us as an industry to move very cautiously, to consider any action on our part which may be eroding consumers' trust in advertised brands.'' **********Elaborating on that, Mrs. Bartos gave a nod toward the traditional notion that irritating qualities help give advertising impact: ''Now clearly it would be foolhardy for someone in a business to advertise with advertising that doesn't move the public,'' she said, ''But I honestly believe we don't have to insult or alienate our customers in order to persuade them.'' **********What to do? ''I think that, in order to close this credibility gap, or to avoid further erosion, it would be prudent for advertisers to add a dimension to their copy-testing procedures,'' she said, to track the irritation factor.'' **********All right, but what to call the new irritation-factor-tracking technique? The Bartos test?

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/09/world.main_headline: AUSTRIAN CHANCELLOR AND ECONOMY ARE AILING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/09/world.print_headline: AUSTRIAN CHANCELLOR AND ECONOMY ARE AILING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/09/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Bruno Kreisky and the Austrian economy are ailing these days - not gravely, but enough to prompt renewed speculation here about a governmental succession or change. **********In the last few months Mr. Kreisky has suffered from an eye problem, an attack of pneumonia and gout. In the same period the economy has suffered from increasing trade and budget deficits and rising inflation. **********Mr. Kreisky, who is 71 years old, has served longer than any other Western European head of government, with 11 years behind him in the Ballhaus Palace, where Prince Metternich once ruled. In a career as a Social Democratic politician spanning half a century, Mr. Kreisky has achieved a renown that reaches well beyond Austria. **********He now relishes his role as an occasional middleman between East and West and, more recently, between North and South, as diplomats refer to the industrialized and developing countries. **********Last month, however, ill health prevented him from attending the Cancun, Mexico, conference of rich and poor nations, of which he was a principal architect. In a meeting with foreign journalists last week, Mr. Kreisky acknowledged that it was not always possible to square the circle between North and South and East and West. **********He said he had tried hard and failed to persuade the Soviet Government to send a high-level delegation to Cancun. He said the absence of the Russians ''was a great political error, although it is not my job to instruct them.'' **********Mr. Kreisky spoke of himself as ''Austrocentric'' in his internationalism. ''I would say that the epoch of detente,'' he said, ''began in essence with the Austrian state treaty'' of 1955, under which 100,000 Soviet and Western occupation troops were withdrawn and independence was achieved. **********''The 25 years without a war, without intervention, without pressure have been such a blessing for this country,'' he said. ''I'm a star witness for the fact that in these 25 years there were no interventions. That's true for us and is true more or less for all the frontline countries in Europe - Swedes, Norwegians, Finns, Austrians and Yugoslavs.'' **********It is generally believed here that Mr. Kreisky's reputation as an international middleman and spokesman for cooperation across ideological lines is what has kept him in office so long and makes him popular today among a majority of Austrians. **********They affectionately call him ''Kaiser Bruno,'' as if he were the heir of the Hapsburg emperors, and they gave him a comfortable 51 percent majority in a four-way race in the last federal election, in 1979. **********But the economy is limping, with inflation running at 6.9 percent, a trade deficit of $6 billion, a projected budget deficit of $4 billion and creeping unemployment in stagnant state-owned industries such as steel. Some Austrians believe that a worsening of the economy could force elections before the scheduled date, in the spring of 1983. **********Meanwhile, many Austrians have begun to worry about what would confront them when Mr. Kreisky is no longer around.  In the event that the Chancellor must step down, politicians here now expect that he would pass the baton to Deputy Chancellor Fred Sinowatz, a 52-year-old son of a worker family from Burgenland in easternmost Austria. **********Mr. Sinowatz, who has been Education Minister since 1971, was described as ''the reserve Chancellor'' in a cover story this week in Profil, a widely read conservative magazine that has no particular affection for Social Democrats. The magazine said previous Socialist pretenders to the chancellorship, Poldi Gratz and Hannes Androsch, had already canceled each other out. **********Although Mr. Sinowatz lacks Mr. Kreisky's international connections and experience, many politicians in the Government and the opposition plainly regard him as steady and sturdy enough to take over if called.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/09/busin.body_text: **********The economically ailing Concorde service of Air France to the United States and Latin America appears assured of at least three more years of life as a result of the French Government's decision this week to pay an increased share of the operating losses until 1983. **********Meanwhile, British Airways, the only other airline flying the Concorde, contends that its supersonic services from London to New York and Washington are finally operating at a profit. But this is only because of a huge investment write-off and the halting of routes to Singapore and Dallas, which had been losing money. **********French Transport Minister Daniel Hoeffel, saying France ''will not and cannot abandon Concorde,'' signed a new agreement with Air France this week. The French Government, which with Britain had spent more than $2 billion developing the world's first supersonic passenger aircraft, will pay 90 percent of the plane's estimated operating losses for the next three years, compared with 70 percent in the past. **********Under the new pact, the French taxpayer will contribute $66 million this year to the cost of Air France's champagne-and-caviar service linking Paris with New York, Washington, Caracas and Rio de Janeiro.  In 1982, when losses are expected to decline slightly, the subsidy will be about $64 million, and in 1983, $59 million. **********Defending the decision to keep Concorde flying despite its high consumption of costly fuel and declining demand for air service, Mr.  Hoeffel argued that two-thirds of the subsidy promised to Air France represented the cost of amortizing its seven airliners and would have to be paid in any event. **********Any further increase in Concorde fares, which are generally about 30 percent above normal first-class rates, would only drive away passengers and increase losses, he said. A one-way Concorde fare between New York and Paris is $1,526. **********Nevertheless, the Government's plan to continue subsidizing the Concorde was attacked by many members of Parliament during discussions on next year's budget a few weeks ago. **********The Government's decision represents a considerable victory for Air France, which in an unusual display of independence for a French state industry had threatened to stop service a few years ago unless its losses were subsidized. The Government insisted that Air France continue flying the Concorde, which it sees as a symbol of French prestige and engineering excellence, and agreed to foot most of the bill. British Also Subsidize Flights **********Britain has also effectively agreed to subsidize British Airways' Concorde flights by allowing the state-owned airline to write off the capital costs of its six planes as well as stocks of spare parts, at a total cost to the taxpayer of about $400 million. As a result of this, and after the halting last fall of unprofitable routes, British Airways says its service from London to New York and Washington is making money. **********Before these latest subsidies, Britain and France had also agreed not to charge airlines that want to buy the planes for the roughly $2 billion in research and development costs paid by the two Governments before the airliner was built. Air France and British Airways are the only lines that have bought the Concorde so far and, with skyrocketing fuel costs and mounting operating losses, the consortium of British and French Government-owned aircraft manufacturers that built the plane has given up hope of other orders. **********Although Air France sold, on average, 70 percent of the seats on its Concorde run from Paris to New York last year, the load factor was 55 percent on the Rio de Janeiro run, 45 percent between Paris and Washington and 36 percent on the route to Caracas. British Airways' Concordes were 75 percent full between London and New York and 55 percent full on the London-Washington route.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/04/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Reagan Policy: Protests Grow
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/04/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Reagan Policy: Protests Grow
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/04/busin.body_text: **********THE worsening recession, combined with the Reagan Administration's ''new federalism,'' is intensifying the economic and financial pressure on the nation's cities and states. At this week's conference of the National League of Cities, one conservative Republican, Gov.  Richard A. Snelling of Vermont, warned that the President's program was leading the nation toward ''an economic Bay of Pigs.'' **********The protests of mayors and governors, including even those with reputations for preaching and practicing fiscal austerity, reflect the deterioration of the financial position of many states and localities. **********The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, which has never been accused of advocating ''bleeding heart'' or spendthrift liberalism, has warned in its November Survey that people and businesses all over the country are going to feel pain as local budget problems force cuts in spending, along with higher taxes. **********The prospect of widespread deficits at the state and local level, which Morgan estimates will total $5 billion in 1982, has already had a depressing effect on municipal bond markets. **********Concern about the ability of cities and states to meet their costs drove yields on municipal bonds to record highs this year. The Bond Buyer's index of municipal yields reached a peak of 13.2 percent in early September. **********The financial squeeze could injure the American economy's ability to withstand a sharp downswing, Morgan warns. In earlier postwar downturns, state and local fiscal actions have been a countercyclical force as welfare and unemployment payments rose while income and sales tax collections dropped. But in the current slump, cuts in spending and increases in taxes are likely to aggravate the recession. Hard-pressed state and local governments, unlike the Federal Government, have no alternative to cutting spending and raising taxes, lest they be forced into bankruptcy. **********The recession is also stirring up strong opposition to the President's policies among labor leaders; workers anxious about their jobs; Social Security pensioners; farmers; religious leaders (such as the Christians and Jews from Baltimore who denounced the Administration's economic and defense programs this week as creating ''misery at home''), and voters generally who, according to public opinion polls, are growing increasingly critical of the President's ability to manage the economy. **********Mr. Reagan has been hustling to put out these fires - lest they become a general conflagration -by dropping in on the White House Conference on the Aging to make a speech; sending forth aides as peace doves to the mayors, the governors and the farmers, and inviting the labor leaders to the White House for some personal stroking. **********He hopes to soothe his critics without making significant changes in his economic policies, while offering symbolic gestures, like a willingness to consider the plight of the air traffic controllers. **********However, an unappeased Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, emerged from the White House meeting with the President on Wednesday and said icily that the Administration's economic policies had produced ''excessive and mounting unemployment and the waste of resources resulting from the deepening recession.'' Mr. Kirkland said he had urged a ''strong antirecession program'' upon the President but ''deep principled differences'' still separated labor and the White House. **********But deep principles do not divide all labor leaders from the President. The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, who supported Mr. Reagan's election last year, came out of the White House Tuesday with a lot more to show than the A.F.L.-C.I.O.: the President's opposition to trucking deregulation. **********The teamsters' delegation to the White House was led by their president, Ray Williams, who was indicted last May in Chicago for attempting to bribe Senator Howard W. Cannon, a Nevada Democrat, to gain votes against trucking deregulation. The Administration, a White House spokesman indicated, remains strongly opposed to Government regulations in general, but will handle deregulation on a ''case-by-case'' basis. **********However, Mr. Reagan shows no signs of compromising on macroeconomic policy to arrest the recession and rising unemployment. Having made inflation his main target, Mr. Reagan seems determined to slug it out with existing fiscal and monetary policy, despite the complaints of various interest groups, including business groups such as builders and auto dealers frightened of their own prospects. **********One interest group that could give him a much harder time if the recession drags on would be the Republicans in Congress, worrying about next year's election. But no sign of revolt is yet evident on Capitol Hill.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY EARNINGS; Reynolds Up 2.4%; Burlington Dips 7.7%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/17/busin.body_text: **********R.J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's leading producer of cigarettes, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter moved up 2.4 percent on a sales increase of 14.9 percent. **********The diversified Winston-Salem, N.C., company said that net income in the three months rose to $188.3 million, from $183.8 million.  Sales climbed to $2.77 billion, from $2.41 billion. **********J. Paul Sticht, chairman and chief executive of Reynolds, said that the small increase in earnings was achieved despite lower levels of investment tax credits and capitalization interest. He said that together these items were 12 cents a share less than in the first quarter of 1980. **********Consolidated earnings from operations were up 9.2 percent in the quarter to $367.4 million, from $336.3 million.  Mr. Sticht called earnings from operations ''a good measure of the strength of our operations,'' but added that ''the year-to-year comparison is difficult because the 1980 first quarter was so exceptionally strong.'' **********Domestic tobacco sales for the first quarter rose 14.1 percent, to $859.1 million, from $753 million. Earnings from operations rose 17 percent, to $216.8 million, from $185.3 million. **********International tobacco sales edged up 1.4 percent, to $551 million, from $543.5 million, while earnings from operations in that sector shrank 19.8 percent, to $51.9 million, from $62.2 million. **********Reynolds said that higher selling prices and excise taxes, combined with a favorable sales mix, offset the negative impact of a stronger dollar in translating foreign currency sales. **********Reynolds said that energy sales soared 66.2 percent to $364.3 million, from $219.2 million, primarily because of higher prices.R.J. Reynolds Industries is the parent of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the Del Monte Corporation, R.J. Reynolds Tobacco International, Aminoil USA Inc., Sea-Land Industries Investments and the R.J. Reynolds Development Corporation. Burlington Industries **********Burlington Industries Inc., the country's biggest manufacturer of textile products, announced that net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1981 ended March 28 dropped 7.7 percent, to $27.6 million, or 98 cents a share, from $29.9 million, or $1.06 a share, in the corresponding quarter of the preceding fiscal year. Sales increased 6.4 percent, to $799.5 million, from $751.4 million. **********''Apparel results were reasonably satisfactory considering the changing pattern of retail demand for our products,'' said William A. Klopman, Burlington's chairman and chief executive. ''The knit business, however, continued to perform poorly.'' **********Mr. Klopman said that several segments of Burlington's home furnishing group improved from the December quarter but that the domestics area was seasonally weaker. ''A lack of strength in housing, along with high interest rates, continued to impact this group,'' Mr. Klopman said. Gillette **********The Gillette Company, a diversified consumer products company, reported that net income in the first quarter dropped 12.3 percent, to $32.2 million, or $1.07 a share, from $36.7 million, or $1.21 a share, in the 1980 quarter. Sales increased 6.8 percent, to $588.2 million, from $550.9 million. **********Colman M. Mockler Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Andover, Mass., concern, said that both sales and earnings in the first quarter were hurt by exchange rates for foreign currencies, which were significantly below those in the first quarter of 1980. Weyerhaeuser **********The Weyerhaeuser Company, the country's largest wood products concern, announced that net income in the first quarter plunged 48.6 percent, to $57 million, or 43 cents a share, from $111 million, or 86 cents a share, in 1980's first quarter. Sales dropped 12.2 percent to $1.01 billion, from $1.15 billion. **********Like many other forest products concerns, Weyerhaeuser, based in Tacoma, Wash., was hard hit by the slowdown in the housing industry.  Analysts maintain, however, that sales should show progress in the second half, bolstered by firmer wood products and paper prices. ---- Earnings tables, page D4.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/08/world.print_headline: PARIS WAITING ANXIOUSLY TO SEE IF IRANIANS WILL ALLOW 116 FRENCH; NATIONALS TO LEAVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/08/world.body_text: **********The French Government will be spending an anxious weekend waiting to see whether the Iranian authorities will honor their promise to permit the departure of 116 French citizens starting Monday. **********Publicly, the Government put the best possible face on things.  Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said on television that there was no reason to doubt that the Iranians would keep their word and allow the departure of the French on two Iran Airlines flights, one on Monday and the other on Wednesday. **********''We have more than one reason for thinking that this will be carried out,'' Mr. Cheysson said. He did not say what the reasons were, but he stressed that the Iranians had been cooperative in their most recent talks with the French Ambassador, Guy Georgy, and a special envoy, Paul Depis. **********Privately, officials said they had no way of telling what would happen. One official said yesterday that there were signs of disagreement among the Iranians as to what to do, which also marked their handling of the 52 American hostages who were held for 444 days, Mixed Signals From Iran **********The signals out of Teheran were mixed. The Teheran radio, while denouncing the French as imperialists, stressed that the French in Iran were guests. But the radio quoted Ayatollah Meshkini, a leading clergyman in the city of Qum, as threatening reprisals against the French if France did not return former President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr and Massoud Rajavi, a leftist guerrilla leader, who were recently granted asylum here. The French in Iran, the Ayatollah was reported as saying, would suffer the same fate as the American hostages. **********A Foreign Ministry spokesman here said there was no reason to believe that Iran would link the extradition of Mr. Bani-Sadr and Mr. Rajavi with the departure of the French, who were urged to leave by President Francois Mitterrand because of growing anti-French sentiment in Iran. **********Iran has presented a formal extradition request to Ambassador Georgy, but it is being held up in Teheran along with Mr. Georgy and his 115 compatriots. France takes a strong position on granting asylum to political exiles, and there seems to be virtually no chance that the two men will be extradited. **********Mr. Bani-Sadr is not making things easy for his hosts, however.  Last night two Foreign Ministry officials went to his residence at Auvers-sur-Oise outside Paris to reiterate an official warning that the exiled leader must make no statements to the press. French Barred Interviews **********When Mr. Bani-Sadr and Mr. Rajavi flew here on a commandeered Iranian Air Force plane nine days ago, the French insisted as a condition for granting asylum that they give no interviews on political subjects. A flurry of interviews ensued, and officials were sent to try to stop the flow. **********Mr. Bani-Sadr has been silent for the last few days, but last night's visit was prompted by his renewed offers to talk to the press. **********Short of delivering up the exiles, the French have made an effort to appear conciliatory. Three corvettes, built here for the Iranian Government but embargoed during the American hostage crisis, which ended in January, were released for delivery this week. Today, the plane commandeered by Mr. Bani-Sadr and Mr. Rajavi flew back to Iran from Evreux Air Force base, where it landed July 29. **********Foreign Minister Cheysson said the release of the ships and the plane was a ''normal'' step and not related to the crisis.  Nevertheless, the moves were interpreted here as an effort to make it easier for the Iranian authorities to keep their promise. No Signs of Use of Force **********There are no signs of any significant contingency planning for the use of force to free the French if they are kept as hostages. An official here said there had been no discussion of such a thing and indicated that it did not seem feasible. **********The nearest French intervention force is stationed in Djibouti, 2,000 miles from Teheran. Apart from the distance, the official said, a commando operation was a poor way to get a large number of people out alive from what presumably would be scattered locations. **********If there is any strength that the French are counting on, it is political. As they see it, the logical interest of the Iranian Government is to preserve its ties with a Western European nation that is in a position to help it and that is governed by a Socialist President who is committed to taking a sympathetic attitude to revolutionary aspirations in the third world.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/busin.print_headline: OTHER BUSINESS; THE PENNY STOCK EXCAHNGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/busin.body_text: **********The Denver Stock Exchange has not a single floor broker. It has no specialists, no ticker, no trading posts, no trading floor. The Denver Stock Exchange is a 16-page tabloid newsletter that covers the news of the over-the-counter penny stocks traded in the lively Denver market. **********''As an investor in penny stocks,'' said Jack L. Stiegelmeier, 49 years old, a former financial consultant and the newsletter's publisher, ''I've been aware there was no clearing house, no medium for the distribution for news about Denver over-the-counter companies. And the only forum I could give to this need was a newspaper.'' **********''When it came to choosing the name,'' Mr. Stiegelmeier added, ''I knew that most Denver brokers abhorred the word 'penny.' So I stayed away from penny stock. I knew there was no Denver stock exchange and since an exchange of information about stocks was what I had in mind, that became the name of the publication.'' **********The Denver Stock Exchange printed the preview issue on Sept. 15, 1980, and the first regular issue on Nov. 10. Paid subscription has now reached the 5,000 level and Mr. Stiegelmeier says that new subscribers are signing up at a rate of 600 to 700 a week. Single copies are $1 with an annual subscription costing $36 until the end of February; $40 thereafter. **********The newsletter originally limited its coverage to energy, mining and high technology companies that went public in Denver, are traded by brokerage houses there or have headquarters in the region. Since then coverage has been expanded to include 20 Salt Lake City overthe-counter mining stocks. **********The name, not unexpectedly, causes some confusion among investors who, finding a listing for a stock exchange in the Denver phone book, call for information. ''Some have been led down a blind alley by someone who suggested they call the Denver Stock Exchange for information about penny stocks,'' said the editor, David Lewis. ''I have developed a standard reply to these calls. I tell them they are speaking with a newspaper; that there is no stock exchange when dealing with over-the-counter stocks since one excludes the other.'' **********Many calls produce subscribers, a point that Mr. Stiegelmeier is likely to exploit further. He has registered the names of a series of future ventures, such as the Colorado Stock Exchange, Rocky Mountain Stock Exchange and Mountain State's Stock Exchange.

Rockwell Jr., the retired former chairman of the Rockwell International Corporation, to end his second proxy fight for control of SCM, a major industrial complex with operations ranging from food to telecommunications equipment. **********Under the agreement, Mr. Rockwell would be reimbursed $1.4 million for expenses in the proxy effort and be paid $3.9 million, or $30 a share, for his 130,000 shares of SCM stock. **********Partners with Mr. Rockwell in the control battle, who retained 90,000 shares of SCM stock after the first proxy fight last year, are also to receive $30 a share, an amount only slightly more than the stock has been selling for on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/21/busin.body_text: **********Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Administration was considering increases in the excise taxes on liquor and tobacco, adding another set of items to a growing list of revenue-producing proposals intended to help reduce the budget deficit. **********''Its an obvious area for us to look at; it's a painless way,'' Mr. Regan said in a speech here to the American Business Conference, a recently organized group of growth-oriented businesses. ''So that is a possibility; we are looking at all types of things.'' **********But he added that no decision had been made and no package had been presented to President Reagan. **********Proposal 'Floating Around' **********Some Treasury Department sources said that the Administration was also considering the possibility of some sort of curb on the present tax deductibility of interest on consumer installment credit, excluding mortgages and auto loans. But a Treasury spokesman, Marling Fitzwater, said that, while a proposal had been ''floating around,'' the department was not considering such a change now. **********The effort to increase tax revenue reflects the realization on Capitol Hill and in the Administration that, even with huge budget cuts in the next two years, additional revenue would be needed if the budget deficit was to be eliminated by 1984. **********At the same time, the Administration is insisting that there be no reduction or delay in the 25 percent cut in individual income taxes over three years enacted by Congress this summer. The first phase of the tax cut, a 5 percent reduction, went into effect on Oct. 1. **********Secretary Regan repeated his pledge that the Administration would not support any delay or reduction in its three-year tax cut.  ''Without the tax cuts,'' he said, ''you don't get the economic recovery; you shoot yourself in the foot.'' **********''The right solution is the hard solution - to cut the budget,'' he added. New Cuts Were Proposed **********As part of a new effort to balance the budget, the President proposed in September a new series of budget cuts and also proposals to increase tax revenues by $3 billion through such measures as restricting energy tax credits, taxing payments to private contractors for Federal projects in progress and curbing tax exemptions on industrial revenue bonds. **********Mr. Regan said today that, while he had promised to present a package to Congress this week, that date would now ''have to slip a bit.'' **********Republican leaders on Capitol Hill have been talking about doubling the excise taxes on liquor and tobacco. The present excise tax on cigarettes is 8 cents a pack. The present tax on a barrel of beer is $9 and, on a gallon of distilled spirits, it is $10.50. If the current excise taxes on cigarettes, liquor, beer and wine were doubled, Treasury figures show, the new revenue raised would amount to about $3 billion in 1982. Questioned on Impact Dilution **********Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, at a news conference before his speech to the business conference, was asked if increases in excise taxes would dilute the impact of the Administration's tax cuts. **********Mr. Weidenbaum said that such increases would be small in comparison with the Administration's tax cuts and asserted that, over all, ''this will continue to be an unprecedented program of tax relief.'' **********Members of the business conference, who met with President Reagan at the White House, generally voiced strong support for the President's economic program. Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the conference and chairman of the American Stock Exchange, said that the Administration should ''very carefully consider every source of revenue'' in an effort to reduce the budget deficit now and in the future. **********In an earlier appearance before the conference, Senator Ernest F.  Hollings of South Carolina, the ranking Democrat on the Senate Budget Committee, said the President's tax cut would have to be reduced because the country was staring at a $100 billion budget deficit in 1984 that could not be wiped out just with budget cuts. Satisfied With Reserve's Policy **********In answer to questions from business executives and reporters after his appearance, Mr. Regan said that he now was satisfied with the Federal Reserve's present monetary policy. The statement was the first by the Secretary accepting the current growth rate in the money supply. Since August he had criticized the Federal Reserve for being too restrictive and not permitting M-1B, the measure of currency and all checking account deposits, to grow fast enough. **********''The Fed is trying to do the right thing but they are not getting the kind of response they anticipated,'' Mr. Regan said, adding that the Federal Reserve's current growth pattern ''is agreeable to us.'' **********In his speech to the conference, Mr. Weidenbaum said that the economy had fallen into a ''mild'' recession, as the President said Sunday, and that the unemployment rate would rise ''to the neighborhood of 8 percent'' in the immediate future. The unemployment rate in September was 7.5 percent. **********But he argued that the President's tax cuts in October and next July, the expected increases in defense spending and a hoped for drop in interest rates meant that ''there are powerful forces already at work to reverse current areas of weakness in a timely fashion.''
