https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/14/busin.body_text: **********Selected natural resource issues advanced yesterday, while stock prices generally edged lower as trading contracted.  The Dow Jones industrial average, after rising less than a point Monday, dropped by 3.67 points, to 965.10.  Volume declined to 40.9 million shares from 48.8 million in the previous session.  Superior Oil rose 10 7/8 points, to 203, responding to a report in yesterday's New York Times that the company holds an 80 percent interest in a major oil and gas prospect in Peru. **********Along with other energy stocks, Superior came under selling pressure in late December and early January. Last November, the stock sold at a record price of 251. Gold Find Spurs Stock Rise **********On the American Stock Exchange, Ranchers Exporation climbed 3 3/8 points, to 32 1/2, after the company reported a major gold find in Arizona. However, the Amex market-value index declined 1.31, to 338.86. **********Some leading energy issues on the New York Stock Exchange attracted buying late in the session. Gains of a point or more appeared in Exxon, Mobil, Atlantic Richfield and Standard Oil (Indiana). **********Schlumberger, a leader in the oil-service group and an institutional favorite, climbed 4 1/2, to 114 1/4.  International Business Machines, the volume leader, dipped 1/4, to 66 1/2. ''We are maintaining our earnings estimates of $5.80 a share for 1980 and $6.45 for 1981,'' E.F. Hutton & Company said in a recent appraisal of I.B.M. ''We rate the stock a hold.'' Damper on Investor Psychology **********Meanwhile, analysts said that the continued high level of shortterm rates administered in the money market by the Federal Reserve placed a damper on investor psychology. **********A brisk rally occurred Monday morning in the stock market in response to the large decline in weekly money supply figures announced late Friday. That rally was cut short later on Monday after the Fed showed no signs of easing credit conditions, and these same factors continued to affect the stock market yesterday. **********Moreover, there was some conjecture that the money supply to be announced this Friday could show an increase because of the timing of Social Security payments. **********Bond prices, responding to this same scenario, have failed to make any upward progress this week. After displaying weakness, bond prices improved slightly late yesterday following the announcement of a 1.3 percent drop in the nation's retail sales for December. **********Signs of a slumping economy, analysts explained, were generally regarded as bullish for the bond market, partly because of lower credit demand. **********Meanwhile, Alan C. Lerner, money market economist for the Bankers Trust Company, said that the Fed, in carrying out its open-market operations, must weigh ''the hiatus in power and policy in Washington.'' **********''President-elect Reagan's economic strategy is not yet in place, nor do the financial markets know very clearly what the policy will be,'' Mr. Lerner said. ''Federal expenditures are still soaring, and it will take more than rhetoric to bring them under control.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/21/busin.print_headline: Iran's Deposits Earned Interest of Nearly 17%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/21/busin.body_text: **********American banks paid an unusually high rate of interest on deposits in their foreign branches turned over to Iran as part of today's hostage settlement, Treasury officials reported. **********Iran held $4.7 billion in the overseas branches but received a total of $5.5 billion. **********The additional $800 million works out to an annual interest payment over 14 months of nearly 17 percent. **********According to Treasury officials, the American banks felt the rate that Iran demanded was far too high, but they did not use this issue to block the deal. They will have the opportunity to contest the rate before the claims commission that is being set up under the accord. **********Interest rates on overseas dollars during the 14-month period paralleled the movement in this country: rising last winter, plummeting in the spring and then rising again to new highs within the last month. **********But the Iranians received far more on their funds than the holders of bank certificates of deposit in this country.  An interest rate has not yet been agreed on the freshly unfrozen bank funds in this country that will be turned over to Iran over the next few months under today's agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/21/busin.body_text: **********Latin American tourists, who arrive with nothing but cash and leave with mountains of merchandise, may delight Florida shopkeepers, but at least two airlines are now saying enough is enough. **********Pan American World Airways, the nation's second-largest air carrier, with extensive routes to Latin America, has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to approve new systemwide restrictions on luggage, effective April 1. If Pan Am is successful, Eastern Airlines is likely to follow. **********The changes, which would reduce weight allowances and the number of suitcases that could be checked, are opposed by consumer advocates and by Miami officials and retailers worried about a downturn in the $2 billion these shoppers spend each year. **********''I've never heard of such an ill-conceived venture as far as Miami is concerned,'' said Lew Price, director of the Dade County Department of Tourism. **********''Shopping,'' said Tony Alonso, president of the Downtown Miami Business Association, ''is the No.1 reason South Americans come to Miami. Most of the downtown customers are not smugglers. They're families who come and buy a year's needs, or at least half a year's needs. This would really curtail their ability to take things back.  It wouldn't be fair to Miami.'' **********Two complaints have been formally filed with the C.A.B. to prevent the proposed luggage restric-tions, which would most affect the estimated two-thirds of Pan Am's passengers who travel on discount fares. The C.A.B. is required to act on these complaints by mid-March on domestic routes and to make a recommendation to President Reagan on the international routes at least 10 days before Pan Am's proposed changes would go into effect. **********This would not be the first time an airline found the problem burdensome. Braniff Airways, which has extensive routes from Miami to South America, studied the possibility of limiting luggage a year ago, according to Raymond Chanaud, vice president of public relations for Braniff, because ''wealthy South Americans come up and buy and practically want to put a refrigerator in the upper racks.'' **********Braniff decided not to ask for the restrictions, he said, because ''we felt it would be impossible to enforce without great distress upon many passengers.'' **********Under the proposed rules other than new tariffs, filed with the C.A.B. on Jan. 30, the rate limit for each piece of luggage would be reduced to 50 pounds from 70 pounds. Pan Am said this reduction had recently been started by Philippine Airlines. **********First-class and clipper-class passengers, who may now check two suitcases without charge and as much excess luggage as they are willing to pay for, will have no new restrictions. **********Passengers paying the full economy fares may still check two suitcases without charge but will be limited to one excess piece.  Any additional luggage will have to be taken to the cargo terminal and shipped as freight. **********Passengers on discount fares will be limited to one checked piece and one excess piece. The remainder must be sent as cargo.  Pan Am will try to transport luggage sent as cargo on the same plane with the passenger and will deliver it to the passenger terminal, but it will have only the same priority as freight and will not displace mail destined for the same flight.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/15/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON A DISPLAY device for use in an airplane cockpit is designed to instantly give the pilot information that formerly was available only from several instruments. A miniature aircraft on the screen discloses any flight errors, based on data from computers and other commercial devices that provide flight parameters and navigation signals. **********The inventor named in the patent, no. 4,283,705, is Robert James of Lancaster, Calif., who is a pilot. The patent was granted this week to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Research was done under a NASA contract with the inventor's firm, James & Associates. Mr. James made many test flights in southern California with the display, and said in a telephone interview that he had found it had performed excellently. **********The unit shows the plane's attitude, altitude and horizontal position, and provides information the pilot needs to control the aircraft en route and on approach to landing. The miniature aircraft and movable bars that show deviation from course or altitude are motor-operated. **********The patent emphasizes that it is well recognized that, under stress and adverse conditions, a pilot may be confused by factors that would not normally be overtaxing. The purpose of the invention is to concentrate needed data in a manner simple enough for the pilot to use and interpret under difficult circumstances. ---------------------------------------------------------------------  To get a copy of a patent, send the number and 50 cents to the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C., 20231.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/27/busin.body_text: **********The minority leader of the State Senate, Manfred Ohrenstein, has asked the State Banking Superintendent to block an effort by a group of Arab investors to gain control of Financial General Bankshares Inc., which owns two banks in New York state and is the third-largest banking enterprise in the Washington metropolitan area. **********In a letter to Superintendent Muriel Siebert, Senator Ohrenstein argued that the interests of the Arab investors, led by the former head of Saudi Arabia's central intelligence agency, ''are more closely linked to the governments of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates than to the communities served by the component banks'' of Financial General Bankshares. **********Senator Ohrenstein, a Manhattan Democrat, said that the Arab investors, ''as representatives of their governments,'' are in a position to ''draw upon resources and even laws that take them out of the realm of competititon with other banks.'' Awaiting Formal Application **********In an interview, Miss Siebert declined to commit herself, but she said Mr. Ohrenstein had ''made some very good points and some very valid points, which we are going to look at when we get an application.'' She also said the Banking Board would call a public hearing on the application if Mr. Ohrenstein requested one, as he said he would. **********Miss Siebert added, however, that ''I might not have an objection if they file the proper information.'' She noted that the holding company's two New York banks, the Bank of Commerce in New York City and the Commercial State Bank of Albany, do not ''have a significant share of their market.'' **********But Mr. Ohrenstein contended that, ''while relatively small, Financial General Bankshares could be one of the most valuable bank holding companies in the United States to a foreign investor who desired maximum influence on American banking and political institutions'' because the company has controlling stock ''in a concentration of banks in the Washington, D.C., metropolitan area.'' Service After the Takeover **********Robert A. Altman, the lawyer for the Arab group, said, ''We respectfully disagree with the views and opinions which have been expressed by Senator Ohrenstein.'' Mr. Altman argued that the proposed takeover would allow the holding company's banks to provide ''even greater service to the communities'' where they operate and could lead to an additional flow of capital to the banks, creating new business opportunities. **********Mr. Altman added that he found ''unfortunate'' Mr. Ohrenstein's references to the ''foreign character of the transaction.'' Mr.  Altman asserted that the minority leader's view ''is thoroughly inconsistent with our national policy to establish mutually beneficial relationships with the Middle East and to encourage the flow of investment capital into this country.'' **********The investors in the group include Sheik Kamal Adham, former director of Saudi intelligence; Faisal Saud al-Fulaij, a businessman from Kuwait, and Abdullah Darwaish, who manages the financial affairs of a member of the royal family of Abu Dhabi, one of the United Arab Emirates. 18% of Stock Bought in 1977 **********The group began its campaign to acquire the bank holding company, which has assets of some $2.5 billion, in December 1977. At that time it bought 18 percent of the company's stock with the help of Bert Lance, who had served as director of the Office of Management and Budget under President Carter. **********The group was later ordered by the Securities and Exchange Commission either to make a public offer for the holding company or to sell its shares. Mr. Lance is no longer involved in the matter, Mr. Altman said. **********The takeover effort was intially resisted by the management of the holding company, but it eventually agreed to the deal when the Arab group raised its offer to $28.50 a share. **********The proposed takeover is now before the Federal Reserve Board for approval. But even if the Fed sanctions the deal, Mr. Altman said, approval would still be needed from the New York Banking Board and Maryland banking authorities. The holding company has controlling interests in six banks in Virginia, two in Maryland, one in Tennessee and one in the District of Columbia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/17/busin.body_text: **********Interest on loans to help United States businesses export their products will be raised to 10 3/4 percent for everything except aircraft, the Export-Import Bank announced today. **********A separate announcement was promised soon on the aircraft industry, which has been one of the biggest beneficiaries of the cheap loans. **********The previous basic interest rate was 8 3/4 percent, closer to those offered by competitors such as France, Britain and Japan in the ''credit war'' for new international business. **********The decision was the first under the newly confirmed president of the bank, William H. Draper 3d, and drew criticism from Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, chairman of a subcommittee on international finance and monetary policy. **********''Unfortunately, today's action of the bank is more in the direction of unilateral disarmament than in the direction of building our arsenal,'' Senator Heinz said. ''In the trade area, I have yet to see a case of our competitors following our moral example.'' **********Mr. Draper said that the 10 3/4 percent rate, plus a one-time 2 percent fee on each loan, is designed to cut the bank's expected $120 million loss next year to $20 million or $30 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/20/busin.main_headline: Court Cites New Bar on Tax Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/20/busin.print_headline: Court Cites New Bar on Tax Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/20/busin.body_text: **********The Internal Revenue Service's long-running legal battle with a Washington State couple over the disclosure of tax audit criteria came to an end in the Supreme Court today because of a provision in the new tax law. **********The tax legislation that Congress enacted two months ago contained a section, little noticed at the time, designed to preserve the confidentiality of the data that the I.R.S. uses to decide how to select tax returns for audit. **********That data had been the object of several lawsuits filed under the Freedom of Information Act by Susan and Philip Long. Despite repeated assertions by the I.R.S. that disclosure of its audit criteria would undermine enforcement of the tax laws, the Longs kept winning because the material they sought did not come within any of the information act's exemptions. **********Last May, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit upheld a lower court's order and told the I.R.S. to give the Longs 58 computer tapes containing the information they wanted. A last-minute stay granted by Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist delayed the disclosure while the Justice Department prepared an appeal to the Supreme Court. **********Shortly before the Government filed its appeal, Congress acted on the new tax bill, a section of which specifically bars disclosure of the type of data the Longs were seeking. **********As a result, the Justices, without a written opinion, accepted the Government's suggestion today and vacated the Ninth Circuit's order.  The Justices told the appeals court to reconsider the case in light of the new legislation, a step that makes it unlikely that the Longs will ever get the computer tapes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/04/busin.main_headline: CORNING SEEKS TO SELL OWENS-CORNING INTEREST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/04/busin.print_headline: CORNING SEEKS TO SELL OWENS-CORNING INTEREST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/04/busin.body_text: **********The Corning Glass Works said yesterday that it would attempt to sell its 23.9 percent interest in the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation. The announcement came after Corning abandoned its previously undisclosed efforts to arrange a friendly merger with the Toledo-based building materials company. **********Analysts said that the divestiture should bring Corning more than $200 million and might lead to a takeover of Owens-Corning, the company that pioneered the widespread use of glass fibers after it was set up by Corning and Owens-Illinois Inc. as a joint venture in 1938. **********''We either wanted to get further in, or get out,'' said Amory Houghton Jr., Corning's chairman. ''They weren't terribly enthusiastic about a merger. It is a great company, and we would have loved to have been a part of it.'' **********Whether Corning would have been able to com plete a merger, even with Owens-Corning's support, is unclear. Cor ning faces an October 1986 deadline for disposing of 90 percent of its interest under the revised terms of a consent decree entered int o in 1949 in response toan antitrust complaint. The disposal date was set when the decree wasamended in 1978. **********The decree had prevented Corning from exercising any voice in the affairs of Owens-Corning or having representation on its board of directors. Premium Price Expected **********James Burt, Corning's vice president of investor relations, said that the company had proceeded with preliminary merger discussions after talks with the Department of Justice indicated that the decree would not necessarily bar a merger. **********Apparently because arbitragers now expect a takeover, Owens-Corning shares rose $1.75, to close at $26.625 a share in trading on the New York Stock Exchange following the announcement. At that price, the sale would be worth $195 million. Most analysts, however, expect Corning to command a premium price for its 7,332,575 shares, increasing the value of the sale, because the shares can easily be expanded into a controlling interest. **********The sale would result in a large capital gain for Corning, which carries the value of its Owens-Corning interest on its books at $2.2 million. **********Corning's announcement was a bit of a surprise. Corning had been expected to meet the terms of the amended consent decree by exchanging its Owens-Corning shares for Corning stock in a tax-free transaction. That was the strategy employed by Owens-Illinois Inc.  when it liquidated its remaining interest in 1973, 21 years after the joint venture went public. **********Mr. Burt confirmed that Corning may well return to the stock swap approach if Lazard Freres & Company, its adviser for the sale, cannot come up with a buyer or group of buyers willing to pay the premium Corning seeks during the next few months. ''It depends on what is best for our shareholders,'' he said. Corning's Aggressive Course **********Analysts took the move as another in a string of recent indications that Corning's management was on an aggressive course aimed at marshalling the company's resources to exploit its technological strength in several fast-developing businesses. The 130-year-old company has a pivotal position in the burgeoning fiber optics industry, whi ch is providing telephone companies with the materials they need to transmit messages with lasers. **********Corning also has a growing stake in biotechnology and a wellestablished reputation as the world's leading specialty glass producer. **********''In exposing Owens-Corning to a takeover bid, they have done something that some people might not think was nice,'' said Mark Hassenberg, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''It has not been their style in the past, but it shows a concern for maximizing their potential.'' **********The stock market apparently agreed. Corning's shares rose $1.75, to close at $55.50 on the New York Stock Exchange following the announcement. **********Some analysts have their doubts that Corning will find a buyer.  Although Owens-Corning is expected to show dramatic earnings gains when the economy picks up, earnings this year are projected at just $2.50 a share, and the company is a defendant in thousands of asbestos lawsuits. In addition, the stock's 26 5/8 finish yesterday was above the company's 1980 book value per share. Analyst Doubts Takeover **********''It seems unlikely to me that any company would want to buy into the aggravation and potential liability at these prices,'' said Timothy Jones, who follows Owens-Corning for Dean Witter Reynolds. **********''I expect that if there is any action, it will be quick,'' said Brian Fernandez, an analyst who follows Corning for First Manhattan.  Corning earned $124.9 million on sales of $1.53 billion last year.  Corning received $8.2 million in dividends from its Owens-Corning investment. **********Owens-Corning earned $54.3 million on sales of $2.29 billion in 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/06/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration gave enthusiastic support today to the Federal Reserve Board's latest increase in interest rates, with one senior economist, Beryl W. Sprinkel, saying, ''If it leads to short-run problems, it's well worth the price we're paying.'' **********In Congress, a senior Democrat, Representative Henry S. Reuss of Wisconsin, criticized the board for ''supinely accepting'' Reagan Administration policy advice. Otherwise, however, there was little unfavorable reaction to yesterday's increase in the Federal Reserve discount rate - affecting loans to commercial banks - from 13 percent to a record 14 percent. **********Comments by Mr. Reuss, the chairman of the Joint Economic committee, and by William D. Nordhaus, a Yale economist who was an adviser to President Carter, underscored a fundamental difference in economic policy between the Reagan Administration and the Carter White House. **********Mr. Reuss and Mr. Nordhaus, in separate interviews, both said that inflation is importantly influenced by such forces as oil prices, crop prices, American exports of grain to the Soviet Union and wages, which account for three-fourths of business costs. This was the view of the Carter Administration. **********Mr. Sprinkel, the Treasury's Under Secretary for Monetary Affairs, and other Administration officials have insisted that excessive expansion of the country's money supply by the Federal Reserve is the sole cause of inflation. Conversely, they argue that only steady, unvarying progress toward slower expansion can bring down inflation. 'Offsetting' Benefits **********In a telephone interview, Mr. Sprinkel said that the unswerving trend toward slower monetary growth that he and other Administration officials have urged on the Federal Reserve was likely to cause some slowdown in economic activity - production, jobs, income - for about a half year. But, he said, ''the benefits in the long run'' -the predicted slowing of wage and price inflation - ''are offsetting.'' **********Yesterday's action by a unanimous seven-member Reserve Board raised to 14 percent the interest rate that the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks charge on loans to commercial banks. Because such loans finance a very small fraction of commercial bank lending, the importance of changes in the discount rate is as much symbolic as anything else. **********When such changes follow the trend of money market rates, as occurred yesterday, they are the Federal Reserve's way of signaling that the market is moving in line with official intentions. **********At the White House, the deputy press secretary, Larry Speakes, said in reply to a question: ''We do support the Fed's decision on this.  We feel like it is an essential step that is needed at this time.'' **********Mr. Speakes rebuffed a suggestion that the rise of interest rates in the past several weeks was a vote of no confidence in the Reagan program. Noting that the Congress has yet to vote on the President's budget and tax proposals, Mr. Speakes said, ''Once we do have it in place we're hopeful that these kinds of situations will not occur.'' **********The Fed's action also was endorsed by Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, in a speech in New York City to the Society of American Business and Economic Writers. ''We support the Federal Reserve System's perseverance in restraining excessive money supply growth, notwithstanding any short-term repercussions on interest rates,'' Mr. Weidenbaum said. The text of his speech was released in Washington. 'Sophomoric and a Disaster' **********Mr. Reuss, criticizing the Federal Reserve, said it ''has not had the gumption to assert its independence, stand up on its hind legs and shout from the rooftops that the Reagan economic policy is sophomoric and a disaster.'' Mr. Reuss said the Fed should have retained in 1981 the money growth targets it had in 1980 instead of reducing them. **********Mr. Nordhaus, interviewed by telephone, said he thought that the latest tightening of credit could cause ''a significant, sharp drop'' in economic activity later this year and might drive the annual rate of housing starts below one million units. Mr. Weidenbaum said yesterday that the development of variable rate mortgages would help the housing industry cope with high borrowing costs. **********Charles L. Schultze, who was chief economic adviser to Mr. Carter, said the economy could not achieve the sustained, vigorous growth forecast by the Reagan Administration unless interest rate come down. ''On the other hand,'' Mr. Schultze said, ''you have got to be careful about predicting recession or catastrophe, because the economy has shown surprising resiliency to very high interest rates.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/world.main_headline: VISITORS TO IRAQI-IRANIAN FRONT FIND A STALEMATED WAR OF ARTILLERY FIRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/world.print_headline: VISITORS TO IRAQI-IRANIAN FRONT FIND A STALEMATED WAR OF ARTILLERY FIRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/world.body_text: **********A visit to the Iraqi-occupied Iranian oil port of Khurramshahr has provided new evidence that the war between the two countries continues in stalemate and is being fought largely through exchanges of artillery fire. **********A group of Western correspondents just returned from an escorted tour of the city reported that Iraqi forces there are still being subjected to artillery and mortar bombardment, more than four months after Baghdad announced its capture. They said Iranian troops and snipers remained on the palm-fringed southern side of the Karun River dividing Khurramshahr. **********The center of town was deserted, they said, as sporadic mortar fire continued across the Karun. Many houses were wrecked, steel shutters on shops damaged and windows shattered. Members of Iraq's reservist popular army in the town said, the journalists reported, that Iranian artillerymen had fired at them through the previous night. **********In the distance, big Iraqi guns could be heard still pounding the Iranian oil-refinery center of Abadan to the southeast. It has been under Iraqi siege since October. **********Last weekend, President Saddam Hussein threatened to order his troops to take more Iranian cities if Iran continued its refusal to negotiate. But so far, Khurramshahr is the only one of the main southern towns captured by the Iraqis, and they have shown no eagerness to try to force their way across the Karun on to Abadan Island for a drive to the oil-refinery city. **********An Iranian military communique said today that heavy artillery exchanges were continuing at Abadan and Khurramshahr. Palme Pursues Peace Mission **********A United Nations attempt to arrange a cease-fire and peace negotiations ended here today, and Olof Palme, special envoy of Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, flew to Teheran. As he did so, the Teheran radio was reiterating the Iranian position that there would be no negotiations so long as Iraqi troops remained in Iran. **********Mr. Palme, a former Swedish Prime Minister who is on his third peace mission to the two countries, said on arriving in the Iranian capital: ''The process toward peace is difficult, but I think we are making some headway.'' **********But the Teheran radio denounced all peace moves, saying they constituted the Iraqi President's only option.  The press agency of Saudi Arabia, however, quoted Habib Chatti, the secretary general of the Islamic Conference Organization, as saying that a group of Islamic leaders would arrive in Teheran Feb. 28 to press for peace and that Iran as well as Iraq had agreed to receive it. **********Diplomatic sources here reported, meanwhile, that some Kurds opposed to the Iraqi Government had taken nine foreigners hostage in the northeast of the country to back demands for the release of prisoners held by the authorities and for an end to a Government attempt to force them to participate in the war against Iran.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/world.main_headline: TALKS IN POLAND AVERT TWO STRIKES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/world.print_headline: TALKS IN POLAND AVERT TWO STRIKES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/world.body_text: **********The political mood in Poland improved today after late-night negotiations between the Government and the independent trade union Solidarity averted strikes against the stateowned airline and by dock workers at Baltic ports. **********The accords, reached just before midnight and early this morning, defused the first possible confrontations since the special Communist Party congress, which ended two days ago with an emotional appeal by the leadership for an end to ''threats to the motherland.'' **********It appeared that in both disputes the Government and Solidarity negotiators had given ground. The 40,000 dock workers had pressed for improved social benefits such as extra vacation for hazardous work. The union at LOT, the national airline, insisted on the right to name the general manager. **********Food Imports Were Periled **********A strike in the Baltic ports would have paralyzed imports at a time of shortages of many basic foods and other necessities. The dock workers' chapter of Solidarity declared today that it had consented to an agreement ''because of deep concern about the fate of the country and awareness of the difficult economic situation in Poland.'' **********Stanislaw Bejger, Minister of Marine Affairs, issued a similarly tactful statement, which seemed, however, to claim a small victory for the Government. **********''Our partners wanted to win the most for the dockers, but some demands went further than the privileges of other branches,'' he said. ''However, they understood this and together with us sought ways out of the impasse.'' **********On July 8, the port workers conducted an hourlong strike as a warning and said they would walk out today unless an agreement had been reached. The next day, about 6,000 LOT employees quit work for four hours, causing cancellations and delays of domestic and international flights. Airline's Military Role Stressed **********The airline workers' demand that they be allowed to elect their general manager was opposed by Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski, who insisted that the airline was an integral part of Poland's military system and that the state must have a say in the manager's selection. **********The Minister of Transport, Mieczyslaw Zajfryd, rebuffed the union's candidate and named instead Gen. Jozef Kowalski, former commander of the Air Force Academy. But a letter from General Jaruzelski to the LOT union promising it a voice in the management apparently persuaded it to call off the strike. **********Both sides reported that a new statute outlining LOT's management structure had been drafted and submitted to Parliament. Solidarity said that General Jaruzelski's letter had been accepted, ''despite the fact that the demands of the crews have not been satisfied.'' Senator Urge U.S. Food Aid **********WASHINGTON, July 22 (Reuters) -Seven Democratic Senators called on President Reagan today to provide immediate food aid and economic assistance to Poland. **********Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts drafted the letter, which was signed by the Senate Democratic leader, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia; Alan Cranston of California, Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland and Dale Bumpers of Arkansas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/23/busin.body_text: **********The Kennecott Corporation, engaged in a bitter struggle to acquire the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, announced yesterday that it had purchased an additional 498,100 shares of common stock in the aerospace and industrial manufacturer. **********A filing by Kennecott, a metals producer, with the Securities and Exchange Commission said the $21 million transaction took place on Wednesday. **********Curtiss-Wright was the most active stock in New York Stock Exchange trading that day, rising 1 5/8 points, to 42 5/8. **********In trading yesterday, Curtiss-Wright shares rose 1 7/8, to 44 5/8.  Kennecott gained about 25 percent of Curtiss-Wright stock in a $40-a-share offer that ended earlier this month. With Wednesday's purchases in the open market, Kennecott raised its total holding in Curtiss-Wright to 30.6 percent of the voting stock - about the same share of Curtiss-Wright as is held by Teledyne Inc. **********Curtiss-Wright continues to offer $46 a share for up to 1 million shares of its own stock in a tender offer that expires Jan. 30.  In 1978, Curtiss-Wright acquired 14.3 percent of Kennecott stock in an acrimonious takeover bid.  In a prepared statement, Curtiss-Wright accused Kennecott of acting ''in a reckless manner'' and of taking the position ''that it can best solve its own problems by using cash it badly needs in its own businesses to purchase Curtiss-Wright shares.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/08/world.main_headline: New York Political Notes; 3 NEW G.O.P. CHIEFS CITY UNLIKELY TO ALTER STATUS QUO
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/08/world.print_headline: New York Political Notes; 3 NEW G.O.P. CHIEFS CITY UNLIKELY TO ALTER STATUS QUO
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/08/world.body_text: **********In an unusual turnover of party leadership, three of the five New York City Republican leaders have been elected in the last month - Alfred S. Pantaleone in Brooklyn Thursday evening, State Senator Roy M. Goodman in Manhattan 10 days ago and George M. Hart in Staten Island three week ago. That leaves only State Senator John D.  Calandra of the Bronx and City Councilman Jack R. Muratori of Queens as "the old-timers" among the Republican county chairmen. **********But since the three new leaders generally reflect the stances of their predecessors, there are not likely to be any major ideological changes in the city Republican leadership. **********Mr. Pantaleone and Mr. Hart are considered conservatives, while Mr. Goodman is closer to the center of the political spectrum. **********However, the new leaders, except for Mr. Hart, are considerably more cautious and less colorful than were their predecessors, notably George L. Clark Jr. of Brooklyn, who will now concentrate on state affairs as state Republican chairman, and the late Vincent F. Albano Jr. in Manhattan.  As county chairen, Mr. Albano and Mr. Clark did not hesitate to speak out publicly and colorfully. **********In the race for the at-large seat on the City Council that goes to a non-Democrat in Brooklyn, Vito P. Battista, who has made a career of loudly battling City Hall, is making his latest political comeback as the Republican candidate.  His principal competition will be another vocal politician, Michael Long, the Conservative Party leader in Brooklyn and one of the leaders of the state party.  The seat must go to someone who is not a Democrat because no party may hold both at-large seats in a single borough.  The Democrat holding the other at-large seat is Robert Steingut. **********The Conservatives captured the seat that is now vacant four years ago when Vincent A. Riccio, a Republican, who ran on their line and defeated the Republican candidate, Donald Pemberton.  Mr. Riccio lost his seat last month when he was convicted of payroll padding while having served previously as a State Assemblyman. **********Assemblyman John A. Esposito, who is challenging Mayor Koch for the Republican mayoral primary, is not likely to get the endorsement of the Right to Life Party. **********Mr. Esposito said that he believed in the antiabortion goals of the party but would not sign "a loyalty oath" that the party requires of its designees.  The candidate must put in writing his agreement with such party goals as a constitutional convention to ban abortion.  Mr. Esposito lost the party's designation for the Assembly last year when he also refused to sign the "loyalty oath." **********Rabbi Balfour Brickner of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in Manhattan is assuming an influential role in the LIberal Party as the newly designated chairman of the party's national issues committee.  The rabbi has been active in national Jewish affairs and is a veteran of the civil rights movement and the actions against the Vietnam War.  Another clergyman, the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington, is state chairman of the party but he is nearing retirement age. **********Richard M. Nixon has accepted an invitation to be a guest at the Republican State Committee's $200-a-person fund-raising party June 15 in Manhattan.  Mr. Clark, the G.O.P. state chairman, said he had invited the former President despite a stir that resulted from a Nixon appearance at an Ohio Republican fund-raising event in February. **********Mr. Clark said that he had received only one protest, from Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, who had said he was reconsidering whether he would attend because mr. Nixon had been invited.  The state chairman said he hoped to have at least 1,000 paying guests at the cocktail party, where there will be no formal speeches. **********Suffolk County will seek a primary date all its own from the State Legislature.  The reason is that the county's bipartisan reappointment commission has been so delayed in drawing new boundaries for the County Legislature that there will not be time for circulating designating petitions to qualify for the Sept. 10 primary ballot. **********In that case, party leaders will designate candidates and very likely deprive two or three Republican incumbents who are at odds with their leaders of the opportunity to seek renomination through the primary process. **********Suffolk officials say publicly that they will ask the State Legislature to approve a primary date later than Sept. 10 for that county only. Privately, they doubt the Legislature will set such a precedent.  The reappointment delays are attributed to late census figures and last-minute disputes over district boundaries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/06/busin.body_text: **********In a windowless basement room of the Data General Corporation in Westborough, Mass., engineers worked feverishly to produce a powerful new minicomputer vital to the company's future. Its archrival, the Digital Equipment Corporation of Maynard, Mass., had already introduced such a machine - a super minicomputer -forcing Data General to embark on a crash program in 1979 to design a powerful new mini of its own. **********A book, ''The Soul of a New Machine,'' by Tracy Kidder, tells the story of two engineering teams of youthful computer designers - the Microkids and the Hardy Boys - who worked under high stress days, nights and weekends on what the company called project Eagle. **********Mr. Kidder was there and his book recounts the pressures, the motivations, the corporate gamesmanship and the formidable technical problems. The project, under Tom West, a tough and individualistic manager, was a free-wheeling, risk-taking cell in the bowels of a structured corporation. ''Data General comes across as one of the few places people coming straight out of college can get in and contribute to a major project,'' said Edson D. De Castro, president and a founder of Data General. ''Of course, there is the other side of the coin. Did the company exploit them? But I think Kidder shows that for the engineers, involvement was a personally satisfying experience.'' **********In the following excerpt, Mr. Kidder draws some conclusions about the characterisitcs of the kind of work that produced the MV/8000, which Data General introduced last year and successfully marketed. **********A DOPTING a remote, managerial point of view, you could say that the Eagle project was a case where a local system of management worked as it should: competition for resources creating within a team inside a company an entrepreneurial spirit, which was channeled in the right direction by constraints sent down from the top. But it seems more accurate to say that a group of engineers got excited about building a computer. Whether it arose by corporate bungling or by design, the opportunity had to be grasped. In this sense, the initiative belonged entirely to West and the members of his team. What's more, they did the work, both with uncommon spirit and for reasons that, in a most frankly commercial setting, seemed remarkably pure. **********In ''The Nature of Gothic,'' John Ruskin decries the tendency of the industrial age to fragment work into tasks so trivial that they are fit to be performed only by the equivalent of slave labor.  Writing in the 19th century, Ruskin was one of the first, with Marx, to have raised this now-familiar complaint. In the Gothic cathedrals of Europe, Ruskin believed, you can see the glorious fruits of free labor, given freely. What is usually meant by the term craftsmanship is the production of things of high quality; Ruskin makes the crucial point that a thing may also be judged according to the conditions under which it was built. **********Presumably the stonemasons who raised the cathedrals worked only partly for their pay. They were building temples to God. It was the sort of work that gave meaning to life. That's what West and his team of engineers were looking for, I think. They themselves liked to say they didn't work on their machine for money. In the aftermath, some of them felt that they were receiving neither the loot nor the recognition they had earned, and some said they were a little bitter on that score. But when they talked about the project itself, their enthusiasm returned. It lit up their faces. **********Many seemed to want to say that they had participated in something quite out of the ordinary. They'd talk about the virtues of the machine -''We built it right'' - and how quickly they had done it - ''No one ever did it faster; at least, Data General never did'' - and of the experience they had gained - ''Now I can do in two hours what used to take me two days.'' One of the so-called kids - kids no longer, but veterans now - remarked, ''Thi@s'll make my resume look real good.'' But, he quickly added, that wasn't what it was all about. **********Many looked around for words to describe their true reward. They used such phrases as ''self-fulfillment,'' ''a feeling of accomplishment,'' ''self-satisfaction.'' Jim Guyer (one of the Hardy Boys) struggled with those terms awhile with growing impatience. Then he said: ''Look, I don't have to get official recognition for anything I do. Ninety-eight percent of the thrill comes from knowing that the thing you designed works, and works almost the way you expected it would. If that happens, part of you is in that machine.''On this project, he had reached a pinnacle th e day when he finally expunged the ''last known bug'' from the boar d that he'd designed. **********Engineers are supposed to stand among the privileged members of industrial enterprises, but several studies suggest that a fairly large percentage of engineers in America are not content with their jobs. Among the reasons cited are the nature of the jobs themselves and the restrictive ways in which they are managed. Among the terms used to describe their malaise are declining technical challenge; mi@sutilization; limited freedom of action; tight control of working patterns. **********No one who made it through the Eagle project could in fairness have raised such objections. The work was divided, but it was not cut to ribbons. Everyone got responsibility for some important part of the machine, many got to choose their piece, and each portion required more than routine labor. The team's members were manipulated, to be sure, and the unspoken rules of their group were Darwinian, but many of those who made it through declared that they had been given as much freedom as they could have wished for. **********A great deal has been written on the question of how to motivate industrial workers. Presumably such literature arises because so many jobs have been made so trivial that few people can find any meaning at all in them. It may be that techniques of management alone can't cure the problem. But clearly, for even the most potentially interesting jobs to be meaningful, there must be managers who are willing to throw away the management handbooks and take some risks. **********Maybe in the late 1970's designing and debugging a computer was inherently more interesting than most other jobs in industry. But to at least some engineers, at the outset, Eagle appeared to be a fairly uninteresting computer to build. Yet more than two dozen people worked on it overtime, without any real hope of material rewards, for a year and a half; and afterward most of them felt glad. That happened largely because West and the other managers gave them enough freedom to invent, while at the same time guiding them toward success. **********West never passed up an opportunity to add flavor to the project.  He helped to transform a dispute among engineers into a virtual War of the Roses. He created a seemingly endless series of ''brushfires,'' and got his staff charged up about putting them out.  He was always finding romance and excitement in the seemingly ordinary. Engineering is not of necessity a drab, drab world, but you do often sense that engineering teams aspire to a bland uniformity. **********As for West himself, there is no doubt that he had experienced an odd, nervous kind of fun. The circumstances had been propitious.  There was a crisis. Solving it called for unorthodox procedures. He'd found, it seems to me, an opportunity to reconcile for a time two opposite ambitions - one conventional and quantifiable, the other unorthodox and vague. He was back in Cambridge, as it were, singing folk songs, while at the same time putting money on Data General's bottom line. He could be, for a little while, a balladeer of computers. **********''We're building what I thought we could get away with,'' West had said. But Eagle sufficed. ''With this machine we're going way beyond what any one person can do. I always wanted to build something like this.''  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  From ''The Soul of a New Machine'' by Tracy Kidder. Copyright c 1981 by John Tracy Kidder. Reprinted by permission of Little, Brown & Company in association with the Atlantic Monthly Press.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/world.main_headline: ARAFAT ASKS JAPAN'S LEADERS TO BACK STATE FOR PALESTINIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/world.print_headline: ARAFAT ASKS JAPAN'S LEADERS TO BACK STATE FOR PALESTINIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/world.body_text: **********Yasir Arafat met today with Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki and Foreign Minister Sunao Sonoda to seek Japan's backing for an independent Palestinian state. **********''You are an economic superpower,'' Mr. Arafat, who heads the Palestine Liberation Organization, told Japanese journalists after the meetings. ''You have a lot to do to implement peace in the Middle East.'' **********''I am sure that through the support of the Japanese people we'll be able to advance more and more,'' he said, Mr. Arafat is here on an unofficial four-day visit at the invitation of the Parliamentary League for Japan-Palestine Friendship, although the Foreign Ministry had a hand in arranging the trip. **********The Palestinian leader, wearing his black and white Arab headdress but without his pistol - he left it at the airport in deference to strict Japanese handgun-control laws - did not disclose details of his talks with the Japanese leaders. **********Taizo Watanabe, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official, said that Mr. Arafat asked at his meeting with Mr. Sonoda for ''more understanding on the part of Japan - spiritual, or I should say political, support.'' Request for Initiative **********Mr. Watanabe said that Mr. Arafat asked Japan to ''take the initiative in talks with the U.S.'' and that ''Mr. Sonoda emphasized our determination to try to continue our efforts to have dialogues with all the parties concerned, including the U.S.'' **********Japanese diplomats showed concern that Tokyo's stance in the talks might be misunderstood in Washington. Shohei Naito, a Foreign Ministry official, said, ''We will certainly convey what we get through the dialogue to the U.S., emphasizing the necessity to look at the heart of the question, the Palestinian people's situation.'' **********Mr. Arafat leaves tomorrow for Vietnam, after which he is to visit the Soviet Union, with an assurance, to judge by these statements, that Tokyo will try to act as an intermediary between the P.L.O. and the United States. It seems unlikely, however, that there will be any great impact on American policy or the Middle East soon. **********Japan's influence in the Middle East is almost negligible, according to Japanese diplomats. Moreover, Mr. Arafat, in answering journalists' questions, did not deviate from his previous positions. 'We Are the Victims' **********Asked whether he accepted Israel's right to exist, he bridled and said: ''Always you are looking from an angle, the Israeli angle. We are the victims.'' **********In response to queries about any message for the United States, Mr. Arafat said: ''Stop sending bombs, cluster bombs, fragmentation shells, napalm, F-4's, F-14's, F-16's, Phantoms, Lance rockets, laser weapons, rockets to the Israeli military junta. We are human beings and not an experimental field for the new weapons, and we have the right to live as human beings, not as rabbits for hunting.'' **********Mr. Arafat said the peace treaty between Egypt and Israel was ''a deep conspiracy against the Palestinian people.'' He said, ''They are offering to us, to my people, a new slavery.'' **********Mr. Arafat repeated his charge that Israel seeks to extend its dominion over an area ''from the Nile River to the River Euphrates.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/16/busin.main_headline: PALTRY '82 GROWTH FORECAST FOR INDUSTRIAL NATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/16/busin.print_headline: PALTRY '82 GROWTH FORECAST FOR INDUSTRIAL NATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/16/busin.body_text: **********As the American economy slips deeper into recession, and with only an anemic recovery expected in Europe next year, the industrial world appears to be slipping another step down from the high rates of economic growth and prosperity it enjoyed during the 1960's. **********This is the view of bankers, economists and other analysts who were interviewed in recent days.  The first pronounced decline in the economic growth of the industrial nations occurred in the 1970's, when rising inflation and the 1974 oil price shock helped shrink the average rate of economic expansion to only 3.5 percent a year from the 5 percent that prevailed in the 1960's. Down to a Lower Plateau **********Now economic growth rates appear to be dropping to a lower plateau, partly as a result of the second oil price shock in 1979-80 but also because of high interest rates. **********The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and most private forecasters now expect that the industrial economies - essentially, the United States, Canada, Western Europe and Japan - will follow the mild contraction in 1980 and probable stagnation this year by growing a paltry 1.5 percent or so on average during 1982. **********If realized, this means that the industrial world's growth will average well below 2 percent a year over the first three years of the 1980's - the worst three-year performance that has been turned in since the start of the 1960's. '1980's Are Opening Badly' **********''The 1980's are opening badly, with another downward lurch in growth and an upward lurch in unemployment,'' said Paul Nield, chief economist at Philips & Drew, a London stock brokerage concern. **********''Sustained growth is getting more difficult to achieve,'' said Ulrich Schroeder, chief economist at the Westdeutsche Landesbank in Dusseldorf. **********The second big decline in growth that began at the start of this decade is intensifying economic and political strains between the industrial nations. David Watt, director of the Royal Institute for International Affairs in London, sees ''a rough ride'' for the industrial allies ''so long as slow growth continues.'' **********With an economic growth rate of roughly 4 percent needed to stop unemployment from rising, the number of jobless in the industrial world rose during the 1970's, to 4.5 percent of the work force compared with 2.7 percent in the previous decade, as measured by the O.E.C.D.'s standardized figures for the 15 biggest countries in the organization, which has 24 members. 26 Million Jobless in 1982 **********As the 1980's unfold, unemployment in the industrial world is climbing steadily higher by roughly half a percentage point a year, rising from 6.3 percent of the work force in 1980 to 7 percent this year and probably 7.5 percent in 1982, meaning 26 million people without jobs, according to forecasters here. **********Rising unemployment is straining relations between the industrial nations by encouraging protectionist policies, as governments try to keep out foreign goods to safeguard jobs at home. Top Reagan Administration officials have warned Europe and Japan to limit sensitive exports to the United States or open their markets to more American goods if they want to prevent reprisals by a Congress increasingly worried by the influx of foreign goods. **********In the last three years, the nations in the European Economic Community have failed to make any new moves toward freer trade among themselves because none is ready to make sacrifices. **********Rising unemployment is also encouraging Europe's growing antinuclear movement to oppose President Reagan's calls for matching the Soviet Union's arms buildup by spending more on defense and trading less with Eastern bloc countries, with opponents saying that this will only accentuate the recession. Economics and Strategy **********''This is the first time that a major economic crisis has coincided with a serious strategic debate inside the alliance, and look at the way the peace movement is blossoming,'' said Gregory Flynn, assistant director of the Atlantic Institute in Paris. **********The latest slowdown in growth is also inducing a new mood of humility among policy makers and economists, who now ruefully acknowledge that many of the recovery strategies they advocated in the past are discredited. ''We can't honestly say we have any easy answers any more,'' said Sylvia Ostray, the O.E.C.D.'s new chief economist. **********An Oxford University economist, Peter Oppenheimer, who used to help coordinate monetary policy at the Bank for International Settlements in Basel, Switzerland, said that ''we're in a state of intellectual bankruptcy; all we know is that there isn't any single economic formula that will do the trick.'' **********A major victim of the second economic downturn in the industrial nations has been the O.E.C.D.'s ''locomotive'' recovery plan, which called for the stronger economies, such as those of the United States, West Germany and Japan, to pull the rest of the world back to prosperity by expanding demand and encouraging more imports. But as these nations tried to spend their way out of recession in 1978 and 1979, the result was exactly what critics had forecast - rising inflation, swelling budget deficits and the collapse of the dollar and eventually the mark. **********''We're not going back to the locomotive age,'' the West German Economics Minister, Count Otto Lambsdorff, quipped at a recent Atlantic Institute meeting in Brussels. Monetarist View Undermined **********Yet the deepening recession is also undermining support for the alternative monetarist strategy, which holds that economic growth will only revive when inflation has been squeezed out of the economies by rigorously limiting the supply of new money and credit. **********No government has tried to carry out this policy more strictly than the British Conservatives under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.  Yet halfway through Mrs. Thatcher's first term of office, British inflation is as high as when she came to power, while the Conservatives' tight money policy has helped push unemployment up to nearly three million from just over two million. **********After studying experiments with monetary policies, Alexandre Lamfalussy, chief economist at the Bank for International Settlements, said that he now thought the ''very high social costs'' of monetarism in terms of bankrupt industries and rising unemployment made it hard for any democratic government to persist with this approach long enough to yield lasting results. Causes Many and Complex **********As the disarray among policy makers suggests, there is still no real agreement over why growth rates are falling once again, except that the causes appear many and complex. **********Dr. Ostry of the O.E.C.D. estimates that the second oil price shock and the restrictive policies that governments imposed afterward to limit its inflationary impact have reduced the total output of the organization's members by 5 percent below what it would otherwise have been in 1980 and will cut it by another 8 percent this year. **********On top of this came the exceptional explosion in United States interest rates, likened by the French Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, to ''a third oil shock.'' The American increase is criticized as forcing other countries to raise their rates as well to protect the value of their currencies. **********Workers appear to be restraining wage demands more than they did after the first oil price explosion, offering the prospect of lower inflation and more room for expansion in the future. But the monetarists say unemployment is high because labor is still pricing itself out of jobs, and they are calling for greater flexibility in wages and labor markets. Only 'Moderate Success' **********As Mr. Lamfallusy notes, the industrial nations have still experienced only ''moderate success'' so far in curbing inflation through a prolonged recession, and fear of another price upsurge remains the principal reason governments will not adopt more expansionary policies. **********With Saudi Arabia committed to hold the world oil price steady until the end of next year, and the world oil surplus abetting that intention, the industrial nations at least appear safe from the threat of another oil shock for a while. But at recent O.E.C.D.  meetings, there have been warnings that, even if inflation dropped and oil prices remained steady, another threat hung over recovery chances. **********Just as the late Milton Gilbert, then chief economist of the Bank for International Settlements, argued after the first oil shock that every upturn might be damaged by a new oil price rise, so Dr. Ostry fears that any future upturn in the United States might lead to another interest rate explosion so long as the Federal Reserve sticks to its low targets for monetary growth. ''The interest rate cycle may replace the oil price cycle,'' she said. Stimulation Weighed **********Despite the many reasons for caution, there are now clear signs that several governments, appalled by the prospect of even lower economic growth in the 1980's than they experienced during the last decade, are toying with the idea of stimulating their economies. **********President Francois Mitterrand of France is publicly committed to trying to spend his way out of the recession by raising wages and public spending. But in West Germany, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt seems more tolerant of government deficits, while Mrs. Thatcher was forced by a Cabinet rebellion to increase public spending in Britain by 4.5 percent more than originally planned. **********Even President Reagan's failure to reduce the budget deficit as promised is being welcomed by many for the support it will give the weakening American economy. **********''There's a bit of reflation in the air,'' said Philips & Drew's Mr. Neild, ''You feel governments have taken a look into the future and have gotten scared.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/25/world.print_headline: A Polish Cellist Applies For Asylum in the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/25/world.body_text: **********A 31-year-old Polish cellist who has been studying at Yale University announced today that she had applied for political asylum in the United States. **********The cellist, Cecylia Barczyk, who gave her first American performance in New York last February, said, ''I can't live in a country without democracy.'' **********''My hopes have been with the Solidarity movement,'' Miss Barczyk added in an interview. ''To this end I have given many concerts in its support. And I want to continue my mission to assist the people of Poland in their struggle.'' She has been a student at the Yale School of Music since 1977.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/31/world.main_headline: TRUDEAU PRESSES HIS PLAN DESPITE LONDON SETBACK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/31/world.print_headline: TRUDEAU PRESSES HIS PLAN DESPITE LONDON SETBACK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/31/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today rejected all efforts to alter his constitutional plans despite a major setback in the British Parliament. **********The Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Commons in London recommended rejection of his plan today because it is opposed by a majority of Canada's provinces. Britain is involved because the present Canadian constitution is the British North America Act of 1867. **********At a news conference, the Prime Minister made clear that he was determined to end nearly 54 years of paralysis in trying to gain control of the constitution.  He noted that ''there is always some province that doesn't agree'' and declared, ''We cannot fail forever.'' **********The stand of the committee in London indicated increasing difficulty in having the constitutional plan approved. The plan includes a request to Britain to ''patriate'' the constitution to Canada with a bill of rights and a formula for amending it once Canada has control of it. Two Provinces Back Him **********Mr. Trudeau has the support of only two provinces, Ontario and New Brunswick. The bill of rights is the most disputed provision, and the London committee suggested that it would be easier for Britain to act if the provision on rights was eliminated from the request and was acted upon in Canada later. **********The same appeal has been made by the Progressive Conservative opposition in Canada's Parliament. But Mr. Trudeau said that removing the bill of rights from the package would not make things any easier. **********He looked back at the history of constitutional squabbling between Ottawa and the provinces and said the provinces would not support even simple patriation with an amending formula because they constantly sought to bargain for more powers and disagreed among themselves on what the amending formula should be. Consequences of Rejection **********Asked if Canada would declare independence on its own if Britain's Parliament did not approve the Canadian request, Mr. Trudeau answered: ''The British Parliament will act. I have the word of the Prime Minister.'' **********Mr. Trudeau said he got such assurances from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher last June. A federal-provincial constitutional conference ended in failure in September, however, and six provinces have taken Ottawa to court over the moves. Some of these provinces have lobbied extensively in London to defeat the moves there as well. **********Mr. Trudeau said he had warned Mrs. Thatcher that he might not have provincial support. He said it was ''her problem'' to deliver the votes and indicated that if the votes were not forthcoming, there would be trouble at the next Commonwealth conference, to be held in the fall in Melbourne, Australia. He said he had told Mrs.  Thatcher that ''Britain might find it difficult to justify its position'' if it refused to give one of its former colonies ''its complete and final independence.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/25/world.main_headline: LEADERS OF 37 NATIONS AND P.L.O. TO OPEN TALKS TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/25/world.print_headline: LEADERS OF 37 NATIONS AND P.L.O. TO OPEN TALKS TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/25/world.body_text: **********Leaders of 37 Moslem nations and the Palestine Liberation Organization converged on this resort city today for tomorrow's opening of the Islamic summit conference, which is expected to focus on collective action against Israel. **********The participants' hopes of negotiating an end to the Iran-Iraq war appear to have been dashed by Iran's refusal to attend the talks. A five-man delegation returned from Teheran today after having failed to persuade the Iranians to reconsider their boycott of the meeting. **********Four kings, four sheiks, 21 presidents, eight representatives of heads of state and Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, have accepted invitations to the conference, the group's third. Iraqi Leader to Attend **********Conference sources said the Islamic nations had hoped to mediate the four-month-old war between Iran and Iraq. But Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, said yesterday that Iran would boycott the conference because President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would be present. **********Saudi Arabia, the Persian Gulf's largest oil exporter and the host for the conference, has expressed concern that the war might spread to neighboring countries. **********A number of Moslem nations besides Iran will not be represented at the conference. Libya is boycotting the meeting to express its displeasure over the basing of United States radar surveillance planes in Saudi Arabia since the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war. Afghanistan and Egypt Banned **********Afghanistan was banned from the conference because its Sovietbacked Government is trying, with the help of Soviet troops, to put down Moslem rebels. Egypt was excluded because of its peace treaty with Israel. **********The summit meeting will hold its opening session tomorrow in the open-air courtyard of the Grand Mosque of Mecca, birthplace of Islam. Security was extremely tight in the area, the site of fighting a year ago between Saudi security forces and Moslem extremists who occupied the mosque. **********The work sessions will be held in this resort city 50 miles northeast of Mecca, at a $250 million convention center built for the occasion. Concern About East Jerusalem **********The agenda calls for talks on the Palestinian cause and ways of putting pressure on Israel to yield Arab territories occupied during the 1967 Mideast war. The Islamic nations are especially concerned about Israel's control of largely Arab East Jerusalem, which contains one of Islam's holiest shrines, the Al Aksa Mosque. **********The conference, including nations representing some 800 million Moslems, is calling itself the ''Palestine and Jerusalem summit'' and is expected to reach a rapid consensus on an anti-Israeli program, a Saudi delegate said. **********''While the aim of the summit is to put Islamic 'swords into plowshares,' resolutions on economic and political sanctions against the enemies of the Islamic nations are perfectly relevant,'' he said. **********No official indication was given of specific actions to put pressure on Israel. But political sources said the campaign would probably be directed against Israel's supporters in Western Europe and the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/20/world.main_headline: POLISH BISHOPS DENOUNCE OFFICIAL NEW MONOPOLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/20/world.print_headline: POLISH BISHOPS DENOUNCE OFFICIAL NEW MONOPOLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/20/world.body_text: **********Poland's Roman Catholic bishops, in a pastoral letter to be read from church pulpits tomorrow, said that limiting freedom of speech was ''inadmissible'' and that monopolizing the press and broadcasting was ''unacceptable.'' **********The bishops' statement was made available tonight and appeared to endorse the demands of Solidarity, Poland's independent union, for access to the press and braodcasting, a sore point with the Government here and with the Soviet Union. **********Solidarity's leader, Lech Walesa, has vowed to lead an attempt to break the Communist Government's monopoly over the state-run press, radio and TV. He held talks yesterday with Archbishop Jozef Glemp, Poland's Roman Catholic primate, union sources said. **********The bishops' letter said it was ''inadmissible to limit freedom of speech only because the proclaimed views may contain a truth that is uncomfortable for somebody or in discordance with the conceptions of a given group of people.'' **********It said that the monopoly of one ideological group to disseminate its views was ''unacceptable'' and that all ''social groups should make use of the mass media, which are social property and should serve the whole society.'' **********The le tter said the press and broadcasting should be subject to social control ''because there is a chance of abusing such freedom.'' The bishops said they based the letter on t he teachings of Pope John Paul II, the former Archbishop of Krakow . Solidarity Withholds Comment **********Solidarity withheld comment today on a Soviet letter to the Warsaw authorities calling for an immediate crackdown on what it called anti-Soviet activities by Solidarity. The union, the first labor federation free of Communist Party control in Eastern Europe, postponed until early next week a meeting on the Kremlin warning. **********At the same time, the state-run press published without comment a Polish press agency article repeating comment from Solidarity membersaround the co untry on last week's warning to the union from the Polish Politb uro. The Politburo said free union activities were leading towar d bloody confrontation and a new ''national tragedy.'' **********Solidarity's silence and the publication of its views by the Government press appeared conciliatory and strengthened the view of Western diplomats that both sides hoped for peace despite the recent conflict. **********Neither the state broadcasting or the press carried attacks on Solidarity today, and the union's Warsaw news bulletin refrained from commenting on the Soviet message, which was released here yesterday. **********Solidarity's presidium, its national executive, plans to hold a closed-door session here Monday, said Janusz Onyszkiewicz, its press spokesman. The session was originally scheduled for today. Moscow Sustains Attack  Special to the New York Times **********MOSCOW, Sept. 19 - The Soviet Union sustained its propaganda offensive on Poland today, giving prominence on the evening television news to a Polish news agency report suggesting that Poland's existence as a nation was at stake in the confrontation between the Government and Solidarity. **********The principal Government and Communist Party newspapers also carried summaries of the letter sent by Soviet leaders last week to the Polish Government demanding immediate action against Solidarity. **********The television report tonight consisted of a lengthy dispatch from Warsaw by the Soviet press agency Tass that summarized an account of developments in Poland put out by the Polish Government press agency, P.A.P. The Polish report repeated many of the charges made by Moscow in its letter to Warsaw. **********Among other things, it charged that Solidarity, after its recent congress in Gdansk, was set on a policy of ''fomenting anarchy and chaos.'' It said that the union's leaders had broken agreements with the Government limiting their activities to labor matters and were openly plotting ''to capture power.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/30/world.main_headline: DRUGS ARE AN ISSUE AT THE SOUTH POLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/30/world.print_headline: DRUGS ARE AN ISSUE AT THE SOUTH POLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/30/world.body_text: **********McMURDO STATION, Antarctica, Nov. 27 - The traditionally close cooperation between the United States and New Zealand in the study of Antarctica has been undermined in recent weeks. **********New Zealand customs officials have for the first time interdicted, opened and confiscated quantities of United States mail bound for Americans working on this isolated continent. **********And the officials say their sniffer dogs have detected 26 parcels containing marijuana and other illicit drugs. They say they will ''interview'' the addresees when they return later from Antarctica through New Zealand with a view to prosecuting them. **********Americans detained in New Zealand will have no right under law to refuse to answer questions. Penalties on conviction vary depending upon the amounts. Importation of large quantities of illegal drugs for distribution can bring up to 10 years' imprisonment. Anger and Depression **********This news has stirred anger and depressed morale among the 1,000 or so American scientists, support workers and Navy personnel on the continent this austral summer. They accused the New Zealanders of opening their first-class letters, seizing magazines, damaging goods and violating their privacy. **********The State Department has ordered American officials in Christchurch, New Zealand, where the United States keeps its Antarctic support base, to cooperate with the searches. But high officials of the National Science Foundation, which is responsible for maintaining the American presence here, are so infuriated that they have talked of moving their Antarctic operations to Australia, though the cost makes this unlikely. **********While American authorities here say they do not condone importation of illicit drugs, they fear the searches will retard work here, particularly if eagerly awaited Christmas parcels are delayed or damaged. Already about a dozen key construction foremen have declared they will quit and leave the continent if their letters are opened. **********The New Zealand action came as a surprise to American officials and raised some complex issues of international law.  The Antarctic mail is sent through the Navy and is considered domestic mail by the United States. In the past it has been treated as mail ''in transit'' and left untouched in New Zealand when transferred to military craft flying south. Violation of Rules Cited **********A legal memorandum by the Judge Advocate of the United States Naval Support Force, Antarctica, implied that the seizures violated Universal Postal Union Rules guaranteeing ''freedom of transit'' for parcels. **********However, the Assistant Collector of Customs in Christchurch, B.J.  Kearns, was quoted in The Christchurch Press as defending the searches on the ground that the mail entered New Zealand territory during its transfer between planes. **********''The goods are therefore subject to customs examination in the same way as any other goods entering New Zealand,'' Mr. Kearns was quoted as saying. He disputed the charges over unnecessary damage. **********A New Zealand official on a visit here said some Americans had taken advantage of the mail system to smuggle in goods.  The commander of the United States Naval Support Force, Capt. Jare M. Pearigen, said in an interview that the seaches had gone a long way toward reducing the use of illicit drugs at American Antarctic stations. It had been widespread in previous years. Mail and Food Important **********After food, probably nothing is more important than mail from home to the morale of these isolated Americans. They wanted to talk of little else during a recent visit by reporters to research stations scattered over the continent. **********At the South Pole station, the workers handed reporters a letter they had sent to The Christchurch Press, signed by 39 members. It accused customs of a ''gross and unwarranted breach'' of trust between the two countries.
