https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/01/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve announced yesterday afternoon that the nation's basic money supply was unchanged in the week ended July 22, a development that analysts said left the Fed with little reason to change monetary policy or short-term interest rates in the near future. **********''By itself the money number does not change anything, but it is part of a trend that, if continued for another half month, would set the stage for lower rates,'' said Maury Harris, an economist at Paine Webber Inc. **********William Melton, an economist at the Irving Trust Company, added that the Fed would ''continue to be very cautious'' about encouraging lower rates by making bank reserves more plentiful. Although growth of the adjusted M-1B money supply measure is about $8 billion below the Fed's target of 3 1/2 percent growth this year, growth of M-2, the other closely watched money-supply measure, has been very rapid.  Mr. Melton estimated that M-2 would increase at a 12 or 13 percent annual rate in July, which would put it above the top 9 percent growth rate that the Fed has targeted for 1981. **********When money supply growth is slower than the Fed would like, it tends to supply more credit to the banking system, which leads to lower short-term rates. When money supply growth is faster than the Fed would like, it makes credit scarcer, thereby encouraging higher short-term rates. Earlier Data Revised **********After revising the previous week's data downward by $200 million, the Fed said that M-1B was unchanged at $428.7 billion in the week ended July 22, or $100 million lower than the average for the month of June. M-1B consists of currency plus interest- and noninterestbearing checking accounts at banks and savings institutions. **********The Fed announces an average level for M-2 monthly, although some components, which Mr. Melton used to make his estimate, are published weekly. M-2 consists of M-1B plus savings deposits at banks, certain short-term bank borrowings in the domestic and off-shore money markets, and the rapidly growing money market mutual funds. **********After the Fed's announcement, short- and long-term interest rates rose and eliminated the declines of earlier trading. Traders stressed that the higher rates reflected the efforts of securities dealers to attract buyers to next week's Treasury bill, note and bond auctions, and not any disappointment with the money supply and banking data published by the Fed. **********''The Fed data could have been good news for the market, but it was far overshadowed by the volume of notes and bonds to be auctioned next week,'' one dealer said. On Tuesday the Treasury plans to sell $4.25 billion of new notes due November 1984, $2.25 billion of 14 1/4 percent notes due May 1991, and $2 billion of 13 7/8 percent bonds due 2011. Treasury Bills at 14.96% **********By late in the day, three- and six-month Treasury bills were bid at 14.96 percent, more than an eighth of a percentage point higher than early in the day. The Treasury announced yesterday a $4.5 billion auction of new one-year bills, and by late in the day the outstanding year bills were bid at 14.3 percent. **********Among outstanding Treasury notes and bonds corresponding to upcoming issues, the 15 3/4 percent notes due May 1984 were offered at 99 30/32 to yield 15.78 percent, the 14 1/2 percent notes were 99 to yield 14.68 percent and the 13 7/8 percent bonds due 2011 were 99 1/4 to yield 13.98 percent. Earlier in the day the bonds had traded at a price of 100. **********According to economists, a slowdown in business borrowing is a crucial component of any sustainable decline in short-term interest rates. The latest Fed data give a mixed picture of business credit demands. Total bank loans to businesses fell at large banks, while commercial paper outstanding continued to grow rapidly, rising by $1.7 billion. **********In the week ended July 22, total business loans extended by large banks nationally fell $265 million, which includes a $817 million drop at 10 large banks in New York City. Most of the drop was accounted for by a decline in bankers acceptances outstanding, which fell by $657 nationally. **********Data on bank reserves showed no large changes in the amount provided by the Fed or the amount needed by the banking system. Total borrowings at the discount window rose more than $200 million to more than $1.9 billion in the week ended July 29, but even so, the demand for overnight loans ebbed enough to allow the average rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market to fall to 18.54 percent from 19.05 percent the previous week. For the last two days the funds rate has averaged about 17 1/2 percent. **********Nonborrowed reserves fell by $108 million, to $39.075 billion, in the week ended July 29. Nonborrowed reserves declined during the March-June period as the Fed sought to slow money supply growth by making reserves scarcer in the banking system. **********The increase of $644 million over the lastest four weeks, compared with the four-week average a month ago, shows that the Fed is willing to allow some growth of nonborrowed reserves now that M-1B growth has slowed, although the Fed has not moved aggressively to push more credit at the banking system.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/01/world.main_headline: SALVADORAN OFFICIALS SAY A BODY MAY BE THAT OF AMERICAN PRIEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/01/world.print_headline: SALVADORAN OFFICIALS SAY A BODY MAY BE THAT OF AMERICAN PRIEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/01/world.body_text: **********A body believed to be that of an American Roman Catholic priest who disappeared from his hotel Sunday was found here today, Government officials said. **********The face was completely unrecognizable, they said, but the shoes and clothes indicated that it could be the corpse of the Rev. Roy Bourgeois, who was working as an interpreter for CBS News. **********Results of a fingerprint analysis were not immediately known. **********The body, found in a ravine in the western part of San Salvador, had a gunshot wound. But it was not known whether the disfiguration was caused by blows or by the fall into the ravine. **********Reports indicated that the victim had been dead for several days.Father Bourgeois was last seen Sunday morning when he left his hotel, saying he was going to a pharmacy. Woman and Sons Killed **********A female employee of a Government agricultural bank and two sons were shot to death in their home today by unidentified gunmen, the Government said. The bank has been a frequent target of leftist guerrillas. **********A large Government anti-insurgency campaign was reported in the eastern province of Morazan, where up to 1,000 soldiers were said to be scouring the mountains for guerrillas. Government sources declined to provide details. **********A bomb destroyed a downtown San Salvador hardware store tonight, but no injuries were reported. The police blamed the explosion on leftist guerrillas, who are fighting to topple the United Statesbacked civilian-military junta here.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Doubleday Appoints New Dell President
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/busin.body_text: **********Robin Smith, president of the Doubleday book clubs since 1974, has been named president and general manager of the Dell Publishing Company, also a unit of Doubleday & Company, effective April 1. Carl Tobey, Dell's president since 1976, will become chairman, a position vacant for several years. **********''Companies with chairmen and presidents have more management hours than companies with only presidents,'' said James R.McLaughlin, a vice president of Doubleday, which purchased Dell in 1976. But industry sources said that Miss Smith's appointment had been prompted by the parent corporation's disappointment with Dell's eroding profitability. **********Although Doubleday will not discuss financial details, Dell, a major paperback publisher that includes the Dial Press and Delacorte books, reportedly accounted for about 15 percent of the parent company's earnings in recent years. Dell's profit margins have slipped recently, according to the sources, mainly because of problems related to shipping, warehousing and data processing. **********Meanwhile, Doubleday's book clubs division has continued to prosper under Miss Smith, 42 years old, a graduate of Wellesley College and the Harvard Business School who joined the company in 1965. This division comprises the Literary Guild, the Doubleday Book Club, the Military Book Club and a dozen others. **********''It's reputed to be one of the super parts of the company's revenues and earnings,'' said John S. Reidy, publishing analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert. **********While some industry analysts are wary about what the move might portend for the publishing end of Dell, they acknowledge that the management changes might strengthen its financial performance. Dell is not only a book publisher, but also a complex of related companies that publish horiscopes and crossword puzzle magazines and distribute motion picture and detective magazines. **********''Robin Smith has a very strong financial background and she's extremely competent,'' said Charles Sopkin, general manager of trade books for PEI Books, which includes Playboy Press and Seaview Books.  ''And Doubleday does not ever promote people to run important entities unless they are very competent,'' he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/04/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Madison Unit Names Yeowell President
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/04/busin.body_text: **********Brian M. Yeowell, 43 years old, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Mass Marketing Systems International. This company, a newly created subsidiary of Associated Madison Companies, an insurance holding company, will be based in Encino, Calif., and sell insurance through the mail, underwritten by the National Benefit Life Insurance Company, another Madison subsidiary. **********''I would hope to attract to the company new clients, major corporations that are in retailing and petroleum and have a large consumer base,'' Mr. Yeowell said in a telephone interview. ''And I hope to diversify a little into auto clubs and publications. There are about 3,000 companies in the direct marketing industry, and if we could put together a central unit, we might try to to acquire some.'' **********Mr. Yeowell began his career with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company as an agent and spent the past 18 years with the Beneficial Standard Corporation. For the past six years, he has been president of its Direct Marketing Corporation of America subsidiary. **********Why did he leave Beneficial Standard? ''I will have an equity for the first time,'' Mr. Yeowell said, referring to his 10 percent interest in Mass Marketing Systems. ''And I was very impressed by Gerry Tsai.'' **********Mr. Yeowell was referring to Gerald Tsai Jr., chairman and chief executive of Madison, whose annual revenues exceed $40 million. Mr.  Tsai had been the portfolio manager responsible for investing the assets of the Fidelity Capital Fund and then the Manhattan Fund. For his part, Mr. Tsai said that Mass Marketing Systems would have financial flexibility and corporate flexibility that could not be achieved without a separate subsidiary. **********''The easy thing is selling the corporation on renting their customer lists,'' Mr. Yeowell said about the companies whose mailing lists are rented by his company in an effort to sell insurance. ''The consumer sale is by far the most important. But I'll be doing my own thing and I thing we're going to have a lot of freedom.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/busin.body_text: **********Millions of individuals with savings accounts are familiar with the certificates of deposit issued at banks, guaranteeing the depositor a specific interest rate for a specified length of time. **********Those certificates, however, are vastly different from the large negotiable certificates of deposit traded in the money markets and eligible to satisfy futures contracts. **********Those large, negotiable C.D.'s typically are issued and traded in minimums of $1 million, with maturities ranging from 15 days to several years - the recent average has been about two months. **********Negotiable C.D.'s can be issued with a minumum size of $100,000, and banks are willing to do so - though the buyer must be willing to accept a yield be as much as a percentage point less than the bank will pay to its bigger customers. **********Besides the C.D.'s sold directly to the public and large customers, such as businesses and money market mutual funds, banks often sell their C.D.'s to securities dealers, who, in turn, distribute them to their customers. The yields are bid by dealers who are willing to buy C.D.'s and are often cited by analysts as the price a bank would have to pay if it wanted to attract substantial sums of money. **********In the context of large, money-center banks, ''substantial'' can mean $100 million or more. Naturally, a large issuing program by one or more banks can cause noticeable changes in C.D. yields and other short-term interest rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/02/world.main_headline: POLICE ARE AMBUSHED DESPITE BASQUE TRUCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/02/world.print_headline: POLICE ARE AMBUSHED DESPITE BASQUE TRUCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/02/world.body_text: **********Less than a day after one branch of the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. announced an ''unconditional ceasefire,'' guerrillas in the troubled northern region today ambushed a police patrol car, wounding three policemen. A woman was also hurt in the shoot-out between the policemen and their attackers. **********The ambush, which occurred before dawn between the towns of Sestao and Portugalete, appeared to be the work of either E.T.A.'s hard-line ''military'' wing or the so-called ''autonomous commando,'' which has no connection with the separatist group's two branches. **********It was the first major act of violence since the unsuccessful coup last Monday by soldiers and Civil Guard members who wanted to install a military junta that would stamp out terrorism. **********The guerrillas detonated two remote-control mines, bracketing two police patrol cars; one car was hit, and one policemen, Francisco Torre Gil, was critically wounded. Two other policemen were slightly wounded, as was a woman in a third car, caught in the crossfire between the policemen and their fleeing assailants. Coup Attempt Scares Basques **********The attack took place only hours after E.T.A.'s relatively moderate ''political-military'' branch announced a truce because of the coup. It was not certain that the ambush was the hard-line ''military'' branch's ''answer'' to the appeal to lay down arms. **********The attempted coup has deeply frightened Basque politicians, aware that a military junta would immediately extinguish the degree of autonomy that the region has gained in the last five years. The ''poli-milis,'' as E.T.A.'s more moderate wing is called, made it clear yesterday that they feared that further terrorist violence at this time would increase the chances of another putsch. **********The split in E.T.A. - its initials stand for Basque land and liberty - occurred in late 1974. It was caused by a difference of opinion over the prospects for democratic change after the death of Franco. The ''poli-milis'' believed that it was necessary to link the ''armed struggle'' with above-ground political activity, while the hard-line ''military'' wing, taking a pessimistic view of the chances for change, pursued a solely violent strategy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/25/world.main_headline: SALVADOR TRIES TO RALLY SUPPORT FOR 1982 ELECTIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/25/world.print_headline: SALVADOR TRIES TO RALLY SUPPORT FOR 1982 ELECTIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/25/world.body_text: **********A grieving woman, lighting candles at the four corners of a body covered by a sheet, appeared on the television screen. It might have been her husband, daughter, son, or a friend killed by the political violence. A narrator asked viewers if they wanted the violence to continue. The bereaved woman said, ''El Salvador deserves your vote.'' **********The public service announcement has been taken off the air, to the relief of many Salvadorans who were troubled by the negative approach of associating elections and democracy with death. **********Now, with more positive radio and television announcements, the Salvadoran Government is energetically trying to inculcate the democratic spirit. **********The schedule calls for Salvadorans to elect a National Assembly in March 1982. The Assembly's most important undertaking will be to draft a constitution that will include a provision for the election of a president sometime within the next two or three years. U.S. Supports Elections **********The United States and the Christian Democratic Party, which now holds most of the posts in the civilian-military Government, are the major forces behind the electoral solution. But they have reservations about how democratic the elections will be. **********''Can we between now and next March create the conditions for elections that will be meaningful?'' the United States Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton, said in a recent interview. ''Difficult, but we don't despair. And we're sure going to try.'' **********''I have to admit the elections are not going to be perfect,'' the head of the Election Council, Dr. Jorge Bustamante, said in an interview. **********Most sectors of Salvadoran society, including the National Federation of Lawyers, the Roman Catholic Church and conservative business leaders, are stronger in their declarations that the conditions are not propitious for bringing democracy to their tiny country. Churchman Is Skeptical **********In his homily last Sunday, Msgr. Arturo Rivera Damas, the senior church official in El Salvador, reiterated that the level of violence and the lack of confidence in the Government make meaningful elections impossible. **********According to Dr. Bustamante, the violence will in effect disenfranchise most peasants in rural areas, where an estimated 60 percent of the population lives and where illiteracy is about 70 percent. **********The National Federation of Lawyers has refused to work with the Electoral Council in drafting an election law. One of their reasons is that there is a state of siege, which suspends constitutional rights such as freedom of speech and assembly. Mass demonstrations and political rallies are prohibited. **********''There can't be an election under these conditions, and the state of siege can't be lifted now,'' Rene Fortin Magana said in an interview yesterday. Mr. Magana is president of the lawyer's federation and was a member of a ruling junta in 1960. He is now organizing what he calls a pressure group, called Democratic Action, which might participate in the elections as a party to the right of the Christian Democrats. **********Only the Christian Democrats want the elections, Mr. Magana said, adding: ''We are not obligated to participate.'' Broadcasting Is Controlled **********The main objection to elections involves the advantages of incumbency enjoyed by the Christian Democrats, which under the state of siege includes their control of radio and television. Mr. Magana said more non-Christian Democrats must be brought into the Government before there can be elections. **********Two members of the civilian-military junta, including President Jose Napoleon Duarte, are Christian Democrats, as are most of the Cabinet members. The junta has appointed the country's mayors and members of the Electoral Council, three of whose six members are Christian Democrats. **********''It will be a media campaign,'' said Jose Eduardo Palomo, manager of an agricultural supply company and a member of Democratic Action.  It will have to be, he said, because fear of being assassinated will keep candidates from campaigning in public. **********The Christian Democratic Party's headquarters in the center of the capital has been bombed several times. ''We know that many of us will be killed during the campaign,'' said San Salvador's Christian Democratic Mayor, Julio Adolfo Rey Prendes. Leftist Participation Unlikely **********On the other side, it seems unlikely that there will be any significant participation by leftist groups, either because they will not be allowed to campaign or because their leaders fear they will be killed. **********The Democratic Revolutionary Front, a broad coalition united with the leftist guerrillas, should not be allowed in the elections, Mr.  Magana said, because it has ''Marxist-Leninist tendencies.'' **********The head of the Democratic Revolutionary Front is Manuel Guillermo Ungo, a Social Democrat. Ambassador Hinton said Mr. Ungo, who is in exile, should be allowed to be a candidate, and he expressed confidence that Mr. Ungo would not fare well. ''He has no future in this country,'' Mr. Hinton said. **********''Do you think the United States would ever permit Mr. Ungo to become president?'' asked a professor at the Jesuit-founded University of Central America. U.S. Playing 'One Key' **********''The United States is playing only one key on the piano,'' a senior church official here said. He was referring to Washington's promotion of elections and its rejection of negotiations as the way to settle the civil war. **********''Elections do not necessarily mean democracy,'' a businessman said. Like many Salvadorans, he doubts that the elections will be honest or that the army will honor the outcome. **********Nevertheless, the Government is continuing its drive. On office buildings in the capital and on the villages' mud huts, whose surfaces are blotched with white paint that barely conceal spraypainted revolutionary graffiti, neatly printed blue-and-white posters are being put up. ''In 1982 your vote can make the difference,'' the posters say. ''El Salvador deserves your vote.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/28/world.main_headline: 7 Die as New Typhoon Ravages Philippines
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/28/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 7 Die as New Typhoon Ravages Philippines
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/28/world.body_text: **********A typhoon that swept through the Philippines over the weekend killed seven persons, destroyed more than 5,000 homes and left about 26,000 people homeless, officials said today. **********Reports from relief and rescue agencies indicated that the most severely affected area was the coastal town of Calapan on Mindoro island just south of Manila, where two persons were killed and 5,000 houses were damaged or destroyed. **********The storm, designated Lee, was the 23d typhoon to strike the Philippines this year. The areas hit were virtually the same ones battered last month by a typhoon called Irma, the most powerful in 11 years, with 150-mile-an-hour winds at the center. **********The reports today said that the latest storm had left 20,000 people - 85 percent of Calapan's population - homeless.  Four persons were killed and three injured in Naujan, another coastal town on Mindoro only 10 miles from Calapan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/07/busin.body_text: **********The huge and mounting United States trade deficit with Japan, expected to hit a record $15 billion this year, is threatening to lead to a new round of trade frictions between the two nations. **********The Reagan Administration has delivered that message, in no uncertain terms, to Japanese Government and business leaders.  ''Japan must open its market much wider,'' William E. Brock, the United States trade representative, told his audience last week at the Shimoda Conference, a gathering of 80 top Government officials, business executives and academicians from both countries that was held in Oiso, a small town southwest of here. **********Because of the deepening trade deficit with Japan, Mr. Brock predicted that the Administration and Congress would ''face substantial pressure'' this year to restrict Japanese imports into the American market. He stressed that the Reagan team would try to resist this protectionist pressure, and said he hoped it would be ''containable.'' **********Aggravating the push for protectionism, Mr. Brock said, was ''the widespread preception in America that Japan does not play fairly in the international trading arena.'' **********In a later interview, Mr. Brock, as well as many of the other Americans at the conference, said that, while the notion that Japan had a closed economy might be overdrawn, the widespread perception is by no means groundless. ''They've got a lot of liberalizing to do here,'' he added. ''We've got to keep the pressure on.'' **********Mr. Brock spent most of his five-day trip to Japan at the Shimoda Conference. It is named for the town where Commodore Matthew C. Perry first came to port in Japan in 1853. It was the fifth such gathering; the last one was in 1977. Although other topics were discussed at the three-day conference, trade issues were dominant. **********The view that the trade deficit with Japan, particularly if it continues to swell, could become a serious political issue in the United States was the consensus among the Americans. **********''It's clear that this kind of trade imbalance between the two countries will create severe and rapidly mounting political strains,'' said Paul W. McCracken, a University of Michigan economist and a former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. **********The Japanese, too, are deeply concerned by the growing deficit.  Recently, the Japan Foreign Trade Council, a business group headed by this nation's powerful trading houses, urged quick action to increase imports, and Japan's Cabinet ministers will reportedly review possible methods fo r stimulating imports late r this month. **********However, the Japanese attribute much of the present deficit problem to the Reagan Administration's policy of high interest rates rather than to any impediments to imports in Japan. High interest rates in the United St ates strengthen the dollar, making American exports morecostly and im ports cheaper. **********''The United States complains, but at the same time you pursue a policy of benign neglect in terms of international exchange rates,'' said Naohiro Amaya, special adviser to the Minister of International Trade and Industry. **********Mr. Amaya added that ''much more should be done with United States monetary policy.'' Any easing of monetary policy that would reduce interest rates would weaken the dollar relative to other currencies. **********In addition, the Japanese business executives and Government officials said that American criticism amounted to what one described as ''yelling at us because the Japanese economy is so successful.'' **********During the first seven months of 1981, the United States ran a trade deficit with Japan of $8.6 billion, the Commerce Department has reported. By contrast, the deficit for the full year of 1980 was $9.9 billion, and the previous record was $11.6 billion in 1978. **********United States Government estimates of the deficit for the year have been steadily revised to higher levels in recent months. Earlier this summer, Government economists were saying the deficit with Japan could go as high as $13 billion. In July, however, the monthly deficit reached a record $1.35 billion, and at the Japanese conference, the projection used for discussion was $15 billion. **********The deficit with Japan on a current account basis - a broader measure of the economic relationship between two nations that includes services and some short-term capital movements, as well as merchandise - will be much less than the trade deficit. The current account with Japan will show a deficit of more than $2 billion, Mr.  Brock estimated. Still, the trade deficit or surplus is most widely followed and, thus, is more important politically. **********In the recent past, the contentious trade issues that resulted in curbs on Japanese exports to the United States centered on specific products or industries, such as the current ''voluntary'' limit on Japanese automobile shipments and the reduction in exports of color television sets to the United States in the late 1970's. **********Now, the situation is somewhat different. ''This time the deficit overall is the issue,'' said Robert D. Hormats, assistant secretary for economic and business affairs in the State Department. ''There''s no specific area to focus on.'' **********Today, the barriers to entering the Japanese market that the Americans mentioned are not clear-cut tariffs or quotas. For the most part, those have been removed in the wake of the Tokyo round of multilateral trade negotiations, which were begun in the early 1970's and were largely prompted by pressure from the United States for Japan to open its economy. **********Instead, the blocks that remain are mostly such nontariff impediments as special standards on imports and time-consuming and expensive customs procedures. Other problems cited by the Americans are even more subtle and less susceptible to quick change. These include the country's strong ''Buy Japan'' ethic and the complex distribution system that is highly dependent on long-standing social relationships. **********These are some of the ''powerful social and cultural forces,'' Mr.  Brock said, that ''make trade liberalization an excruciating process for Japan.'' **********Simple political influence is another problem. Americans continually argue that Japan should be more open to American agricultural products, and even the Japanese politicians at the conference said they would like to import more food products and that would probably lower consumer prices in Japan. In the next breath, however, most of them noted that the farmers' lobby in Japan was extremely powerful and many Japanese politicians would be ousted without farmers' support. **********But the Americans also face political strictures on trade liberalization. For example, the single step that could do most to narrow the trade deficit, most at the conference agreed, would be to sell Alaskan oil to Japan. By some estimates, that might slice $5 billion annually from the deficit. **********Indeed, because of the high transportation costs of shipping Alaskan oil through the Panama Canal, it would be much cheaper for American consumers to buy oil from Mexico or other nations. **********Though the Reagan Administration is trying to change it, United States law now mandates that the Alaskan oil be sold in the domestic market. **********Also by law, shipments going from one American port to another must be handled by American-flag ships and crews, which are more costly than foreign carriers.  ''So now you've built up a whole navy up in Alaska to deal with theregulations,'' said John W. Simmons, senior v ice president of international relations for th e Atlantic Richfield Company . ''If you change the law now, you're going to throw that whole navy out of work; you can bet there'll be plenty of resistance to that .''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/06/world.main_headline: U.S. ASKED TO TRIM WAR GAMES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/06/world.print_headline: U.S. ASKED TO TRIM WAR GAMES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/06/world.body_text: **********Oman has ordered the United States to reduce the size and scope of a United States Marine landing exercise in the Arabian Sea-Persian Gulf area, Reagan Administration sources said today. **********The planned landing on Oman's shores next month is designed to demonstrate American intentions to help safeguard the security of oil-producing nations in the region. **********The sources, who asked to remain anonymous, said they were not certain why the Omani Government balked at the original United States plan. **********However, they indicated that Oman might want to keep the exercise as limited as possible to avoid criticism from other Arab nations.  The Carter Administration reached agreements with Oman, Somalia and Kenya for ''access'' by United States military forces to ports and airfields in the three countries. **********The terms of of the accords have never been publicly spelled out.  But the Carter and Reagan Administrations proposed spending about $78.5 million this year to improve installations in Oman for use by the American Rapid Deployment Force. **********The Marine landing, planned for early December, is part of a wideranging exercise with the code name Bright Star. More than 6,000 Army, Marine, Air Force and Navy personnel are to take part in activities in Egypt, the Sudan and Somalia, as well as Oman. **********Bright Star, which has been in preparation for months, follows a small American exercise last year in Egypt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/26/busin.main_headline: Advertising; OLD TYME GINGER BEER PROMOTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/26/busin.print_headline: Advertising; OLD TYME GINGER BEER PROMOTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/26/busin.body_text: **********' 'What nut would come into the New York market and try to sell another soft drink?'' asked Alice O'Leary, president of Fearon/ O'Leary, as she began her lively tale about a new client who is about to try just that. **********The assignment is to promote Old Tyme Jamaican Style Ginger Beer, the flagship flavor of the Old Tyme beverages line out of Lou Scharf Inc., Alpine, N.J., which is moving from the sheltered enclave of the gourmet shop (where it has been available in this market for some 15 years) and into the hustle-bustle, big-time action of the supermarket. **********That, of course, requires advertising support, something that Old Tyme really has not been getting too much of. And, since as Miss O'Leary uniquely put it, ''You've got to walk before you can run,'' the campaign will begin Monday without dear old television, just radio and newspapers. And unlike most soft drinks, Old Tyme, although it will be pushed by a jingle in its marketplace incursion, is not aimed at the youth market, but rather the older crowd. That's the kind that listens to WOR. And they will be among the crew that will hear about the ''swashbuckling taste of ginger beer,'' which goes well with the picture of the pirate on both the old and new labels.  Besides, Robert D. Fearon, chairman of the agency, likes the word swashbuckler because it swishes around the mouth like a soft drink. **********The new client is Robert W. Tuckman, lawyer and one-time associate counsel to the former Assembly Speaker, Stanley Steingut, who tried his hand at original equipment manufacture before buying out Lou Scharf, now 80 years old. **********The radio commercials, with jingle music by the Radio Band of America, will also be running on WNBC-AM, WNEW-AM, WRFM-FM, WCBS-AM and FM, and WYNY-FM. **********Black-and-white or four-color print ads will run in The New York Times and its magazine, The Daily News, and New York magazine.  The ad budget just for the summer is about $250,000, Miss O'Leary said, noting that Mr. Tuckman's plans call for adding the Boston, Dallas, Houston, Philadelphia, Los Angeles and San Francisco markets by the end of the year and putting between $100,000 and $150,000 worth of advertising into each. **********The Old Tyme label is on about a dozen different soft drinks as well as on a number of spicy sauces and two kinds of marmalade. The soft drink line, which has a very good cream soda, also includes such unusual soft drink flavors as sorrel, champagne cola and apple. **********The ginger beer, up against such competing brands as Perry, A&J, Metro and Schweppes, will be promoted as a soft drink and also as a mixer for such old-time favorites as the Moscow Mule (with vodka) and the Shandygaff (with beer). **********And the Old Tyme Jamaican Style Ginger Beer has the extra cachet of being imported. While Lou Scharf Inc. owns the formula, the manufacture and bottling is done by an independent company in Toronto. It also has the cachet of carrying a premium price, and that is one way of popularizing something with a certain segment. **********Indeed, the ads will also be running in newspapers in the Hamptons, where the agency will be running tasting parties for the various exotic mixed drinks, like the introduction festivities last night at the Jim McMullen ''in spot'' on Third Avenue and 72d Street. **********''The question is who can spread the word-of-mouth?'' Miss O'Leary said. ''We need a few hundred good mouths out in the Hamptons.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/31/world.body_text: **********The first thing to strike a visitor's eye as he alights from the military plane are two huge signs that proclaim in bold white Chinese characters on a flaming red background, ''Recover the Chinese Mainland'' and ''Destroy the Communists.'' **********Military transport remains the only way of reaching Quemoy and its sister island, Matsu, because the offshore islands, just a few miles from the mainland, remain fully military areas and are customarily referred to by Nationalist officers as ''the battlefront.'' **********The last exchanges of gunfire took place 23 years ago, and the Communist gunners stopped their every-other-day barrages of shells loaded with propaganda leaflets in December 1978, a few days before the United States broke diplomatic relations with Taiwan. **********The Nationalist side, however, maintains its propaganda shelling of the coast of Fukien Province. The two sides continue to send each other balloons carrying either propaganda wrapped around cookies, soap or items of clothing, or propaganda stuffed into inflated plastic toys. Slogans, Music and News **********Moreover, both sides still fill the airwaves with propaganda slogans, propaganda music and propaganda news for as much as 20 hours a day. **********''We are soldiers and we obey our commanders,'' replied a psychological-warfare officer when asked whether after more than three decades of unceasing propaganda bellowed at the limited audiences on both sides of the Formosa Strait the words and music had not suffered from repetition. **********Quemoy, whose 52,000 inhabitants live in 5 towns and 35 villages, remains on a full war footing. The number of Nationalist troops stationed here is a secret, but they are everywhere. They guard every crossroads, they are huddled into camouflaged pillboxes, they swarm through the extensive network of tunnels and trenches. **********Sometimes they are seen patrolling in a field exercise; often they can be observed in such make-work projects as sweeping dried pine needles off the roadways with fresh branches cut from the same trees. Always they seem alert, their arms are at the ready, and discipline and combat enthusiasm appear high, although none of the young soldiers have had to test their fighting mettle. **********The language of the military and the signs that are everywhere are studded with the phraseology of the period when the United States appeared ready to go to war over Quemoy and Matsu if the Communists attacked. Defense Pact Abrogated in 1979 **********However, when a mutual defense treaty was signed in 1954, Washington excluded the islands from the treaty's applicability. The pact was unilaterally abrogated by the United States in 1979. **********''We are the sentry and the safeguard of Taiwan and the Pescadores,'' said a trim young women of the ''Self-Defense Corps'' who, armed with a pointer and standing at attention, briefed a visitor. **********She wore a tailored and tightly fitted camouflage jumpsuit, the trouser legs neatly bloused over high-heeled black boots, and emphasized her slim waist with a broad but empty cartridge belt. **********''So that we never forget that we are not at peace but at war,'' replied Col. Mao Dien-ping of the military spokesman's office when asked about the officially fostered belligerent air. ''The enemy can destroy our lives at any moment. We should work hard to fight against our enemies.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/22/busin.main_headline: NIGERIA SAID TO CUT OIL PRICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/22/busin.print_headline: NIGERIA SAID TO CUT OIL PRICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/22/busin.body_text: **********Nigeria yesterday offered to sell crude oil to its customers at $34.50 a barrel, according to Platt's Oilgram Price Report, or $1.50 below Nigeria's discount price. **********The reduction, Nigeria's second in two months, was viewed by market experts as evidence that reports that OPEC members were near a compromise on a unified base price of $34 might be premature. The reason is that the Nigerian price, because of quality and transportation surcharges of up to $5 a barrel that that country usually levies, would be too low to fit in with the accord. **********''The market is not saying there is an accord,'' said Halsey Peckworth, editor of Platt's Oilgram, a market newsletter.  His point was underscored yesterday by developments on the spot, or noncontract, oil market. Platt's reported that Saudi light crude, on which the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries bases its price, was selling for $32.75. Analysts reasoned that if OPEC's price were, in fact, about to move to $34, this quote would have been higher. **********Additionally, two grades of crude similar to Saudi light were also offered at less that $34 a barrel, Platt's reported: a tanker of Oman crude at $33, which drew no buyers, and a quantity of Dubai crude that sold for $32.40. **********Earlier this week, OPEC called an extraordinary meeting for Oct. 29 in Geneva to try to unify base prices that have ranged from $32 to $36 in recent months. A number of OPEC members said they believed the organization was on the verge of a price compromise that would have Saudi Arabia, the lowest-priced producer in OPEC, raise its basic quote by $2 while all other members, now using a base of $36 a barrel, would lower this $2 to the same level. **********The thinking of industry analysts was that the Saudis would not attend the session if the $34 base price were not already agreed to.  But numerous analysts said the Saudis would indeed attend. **********Although not definitive, the fact that the oil markets were reacting ambivalently to a $34 price was seen as evidence that oil traders, who follow the markets more closely than anyone, were not basing their calculations on a $34 base.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/31/busin.main_headline: DISNEY ATTEMPTS TO REVERSE MOVIE DIVISION'S PROFIT SLIDE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/31/busin.print_headline: DISNEY ATTEMPTS TO REVERSE MOVIE DIVISION'S PROFIT SLIDE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/31/busin.body_text: **********The executive offices of Walt Disney Productions are located along streets called Mickey Mouse Avenue and Dopey Drive, named for some of the studio's most famous characters. **********The street names, like the showcases filled with memorabilia, are reminders of Disney's golden age of movie making, when timeless movies with characters such as Snow White, Cinderella and Bambi set the standard for family entertainment. **********On these successes Disney built a profitable corporate empire of motion pictures, theme parks and consumer products, which earned the company $135.2 million on revenues of $914.5 million in fiscal 1980 ended last Sept. 30. **********But since Walt Disney's death in 1966, Disney films have not done particularly well, especially compared with the performance turned in by its parks, which generated more than two-thirds of its sales last year. Another park, the Experimental Prototype Community of Tomorrow, or Epcot, located near Orlando, Fla,. is scheduled for completion in 1982. **********Now, however, the company is apparently trying to rebuild its animation department, depleted two years ago, by recruiting new young talent and by rethinking its position in the market. Renewed Emphasis on Movies **********''They're trying to come back into the movie business,'' said George Novello, an assistant vice president of reseach for E.F.  Hutton. ''Recently, much of their effort has been going to Epcot.'' **********Its summer release of ''The Fox and the Hound'' represents what Disney hopes will be a new era in Disney films. It has taken four years to get the 83-minute film about the friendship of a hound puppy and an abandoned fox puppy to the screen. At least part of the delay was caused when 11 animators left two years ago to form a rival company after a dispute with Disney management about artistic control. **********''The art of animation wasn't growing. The studio was so encrusted with its original and traditional ways,'' said Don Bluth, 44 years old, the animator who led the walkout. **********Without Walt Disney's flair for capturing the attention of young moviegoers, Disney films lost their momentum. The company produced a series of comedy movies such as the four ''Herbie'' movies about an impish Volkswagon, which appeared to be a success. The first of these films, ''The Love Bug,'' posted impressive profits in 1970. **********But by the time the fourth picture in the series, ''Herbie Goes Bananas,'' was completed, it was apparent that the films were not attracting audiences. ''We were making nothing but comedies. We didn't have the diversity we needed,'' said Ronald W. Miller, president and chief operating officer. **********So, Disney turned to other movie-making methods, trying to produce ''a couple of pictures to make money,'' Mr. Miller said. Box Office Failures **********These efforts included hiring well-known screen personalities to star in Disney films. One such example, ''The Devil and Max Devlin,'' starred Bill Cosby and Elliott Gould. ''The film cost between $7.1 and $7.2 million to make,'' Mr. Miller said. ''We lost a considerable amount of money. We were lucky to make six and a half in the film rentals with a write-off of $4 million.'' **********The company also agreed to joint ventures with Paramount Studios on ''Popeye'' and ''Dragonslayer.'' Both pictures did poorly at the box office. ''Popeye,'' which cost $22 million to produce, earned just over $22 million domestically. ''It didn't do well in Japan or Taiwan. Germany and France are still question marks - if it does well there, we'll show a small profit,'' Mr. Miller said. **********So far, ''Dragonslayer'' has had an unprofitable domestic run.  Disney is unlikely to profit from the film unless it too does well in foreign markets. **********Another recent picture, ''Watcher in the Woods,'' has also been disappointing. The film was pulled from distribution after a brief premiere run in New York in April 1980. ''We made a terrible mistake visually. We hadn't really worked on the alien'' - a character who is not seen until a climatic moment at the film's end - said Thomas L. Wilhite, vice president of creative development for motion pictures and television. An additional $800,000 was spent to restore the set in England and re-shoot the end of the movie. The second version is scheduled for release in November. **********When faced with pulling ''Watcher in the Woods'' from distribution, Disney decided to re-release ''Mary Poppins,'' the popular and successful children's film, as a substitute. The film is a Disney classic, part of the company's vast library of proven money makers, which have in large part been responsible for keeping up corporate profits. Most of these films, such as ''Cinderella,'' ''Snow White'' and many others, are re-released about once every seven or eight years. Disney Resists Cable **********But Disney is not one of those studios looking forward to cable television as an aftermarket for its classics. None of its classic films will be released for play on cable systems or home video cassette sales, Mr. Miller said, until a scrambling method, which prevents the making of illegal copies, is perfected. **********To bolster its new movie efforts, Disney has been looking for young executives, like Mr. Wilhite, 28, who can bring to Disney a broader appeal. ''Since Walt died, you have to recognize that there have been changes in society. Kids do mature much earlier,'' Mr.Wilhite said. As a result, the studio is developing some projects such as ''Tex,'' the story of two brothers growing up in present-day Oklahoma without parents. **********Mr. Miller, who is married to Mr. Disney's daughter, Diane, and Mr. Wilhite both acknowledge some frustration in making production choices because of the Disney reputation for nonsexual, nonviolent family entertainment. **********''There's a lot of frustration in making pictures for Disney. There are a lot of areas we'd like to get into but can't,'' Mr. Wilhite said. ''I'd like to do something a little different, a little more earthy,'' Mr. Miller said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/31/world.main_headline: ISLAMIC PEACE MISSION IN TEHERAN MAKING A NEW CEASE-FIRE EFFORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/31/world.print_headline: ISLAMIC PEACE MISSION IN TEHERAN MAKING A NEW CEASE-FIRE EFFORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/31/world.body_text: **********Nine Islamic leaders arrived in Teheran today for another attempt to arrange an Iraqi-Iranian truce and began talks at once with the Iranians. **********(The Saudi Arabian radio said the mission was carrying a new peace proposal, United Press International reported. The broadcast quoted Habib Chatti of Tunisia, a mission member who is secretary general of the Islamic Conference Organization, as having said that the plan took into account points made by the two sides in written responses to an earlier proposal.) **********The Islamic group, which proposed earlier this month that a ceasefire be declared and that an Iraqi withdrawal from Iran begin a week later, met today with the Iranian Supreme Defense Council.  Shortly before the session, the head of the mission, President Ahmed Sekou Toure of Guinea, conferred with President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, who also is commander in chief of Iran's armed forces. **********The mission, which is due to confer with the Iraqis tomorrow, includes the Presidents of Pakistan, Bangladesh and Gambia, the Prime Minister of Turkey, the Foreign Ministers of Malaysia and Senegal, and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********The Guinean President has said that the written responses from Iraq and Iran to the mission's earlier proposal did not amount to an absolute rejection, but leaders of the two sides said again yesterday that there could be no negotiations unless the often-stated conditions were met. Iran wants Iraq to withdraw first, and Iraq wants that its territorial demands be met. These are recognition by Iran of Iraqi sovereignty over the Shatt al Arab waterway and the cession of other border areas to the north. **********---- Iraq to Aid Minorities in Iran **********BEIRUT, March 30 (Reuters) - President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has pledged ''full support for all nationalities and national movements in Iran'' in any efforts to overthrow the Islamic Government in Teheran. **********Diplomatic analysts here noted that the pledge, made yesterday in a speech to peasant families in northern Iraq, contrasted with his vow last month to order Iraqi troops to take more Iranian territory if the Iranians did not agree to peace talks, and they said it apparently reflected a reluctance within the ruling Iraqi Revolutionary Command Council to step up hostilities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/15/world.main_headline: Weinberger Sees Peril Of Conventional War
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/15/world.print_headline: Weinberger Sees Peril Of Conventional War
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/15/world.body_text: **********Secretary of Defense Caspar W.  Weinberger said tonight that there was no guarantee that nuclear balance between the United States and the Soviet Union would deter a major conventional war. **********He added that there was no guarantee a conventional war would be short. **********In a speech prepared for a conference at the National Defense University, a military school for senior officers, he said the United States had to improve its ability to fight prolonged ground wars, such as the Korean War. **********''We must improve our ability to respond to limited aggression, as we responded during the Korean War, by rapidly expanding our overall defense capabilities,'' he said. **********The Defense Secretary said that both the readiness of American forces and the ability of military industries to gear up quickly had to be improved. **********He added that the United States had to realize that a conventional war might spread and had to be ready to respond on more than one front. He warned the United States would not necessarily limit its response to areas attacked by the enemy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/20/busin.body_text: **********Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. has sued to overturn last year's higher tariff on imported small pickup trucks, the importer announced. **********Toyota said in an announcement from its headquarters in Torrance, Calif., that it had asked the United States Court of International Trade in New York for a ruling that the Treasury Department acted improperly last August when it reclassified the trucks. **********The move switched the Japanese-made vehicles from classification as ''cab-chassis,'' which are taxable at 4 percent to ''unfinished trucks'' - taxable at 25 percent. **********All importers, which include the Big Three auto makers, bring in the trucks without beds and attach the beds after the trucks have cleared customs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Israeli Fighters Shoot Down Syrian Jet Over Lebanon
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/world.body_text: **********Israeli jet fighters shot down a Syrian MIG today over the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon.  The clash was the latest incident in what appears to be increasing Israeli pressure on Lebanon in recent weeks. **********This has included several coastal raids, artillery barrages in southern Lebanon and reconnaissance flights over Beirut. **********The Israeli command described the incident as occurring during a ''routine flight over Lebanon'' when Syrian fighters intercepted an Israeli patrol. The Damascus radio said that the Syrian aircraft had encountered Israeli planes on a reconnaissance mission and that in the ensuing battle ''one friendly aircraft'' had been lost. **********The pilot bailed out, witnesses in the village of Ain Ata said.  Later reports said the pilot had been killed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/08/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON T HERE is an eerie hush on the fifth floor of the downtown office building that, only six weeks ago, was the headquarters of the Community Services Administration. Only a handful of people slip between the desks, tables, chairs and typewriters that are piled in the corridor. The walls are full of graffiti, mostly the giant signatures of the people who ran the nation's antipoverty program until it closed Sept. 30. The fish swimming in the tank outside the administrator's office are, as one former employee put it, ''the only signs around here that life goes on.'' **********But life does go on in the Federal bureaucracy, even if the C.S.A., once the beehive of Federal activism in social affairs, has now become the symbol of the Reagan Administration's determination to turn back programs to the states and to pare the Federal work force.  Other agencies, such as the Department of Energy and the Public Health Service, have experienced relatively heavy cutbacks. But despite the Sturm und Drang that accompanied the Reagan budget and program cuts, the latest figures indicate that only 4,006 nondefense employ- ees nationwide were, in the word that increasingly is being bandied about here, ''separated'' from the Federal payroll in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30. **********Although the toll has been relatively slight, the personnel reductions would likely become more severe if Congress goes along with Mr. Reagan's plan for an across-the-board 12 percent cut in discretionary spending. But for now, the figure is far lower than anyone - Reagan personnel experts and Administration critics alike - expected. **********The Federal Government employs 1.8 million full-time workers and 60,000 part timers, excluding the Postal Service and the Armed Forces. As late as midsummer some projections had put the number of reductions in force, or RIF's, at 16,056. Even the President's pledge to reduce the Federal work force by 75,000 by the end of fiscal year 1984 may not cause much of a ripple; an official at the Office of Management and Budget estimates that the rate of Federal employee turnover itself is more than 75,000 a year. **********''It's a shell game,'' said Representative Geraldine Ferraro, Democrat of Queens and the head of a House human resources subcommittee. ''They're talking about reducing Federal employees, but they haven't really done it. They're doing cosmetic things. It looks good, but if you look below the surface, the story is a lot different.'' **********The actual dislocations that will be caused by forthcoming efforts to reduce the payroll constitute only one of many mysteries in the Reagan Federal personnel program. **********Although the Administration has made its effort to reduce the Government work force one of the centerpieces of its drive to cut the budget, the amount of money it will save is still being debated here. The O.M.B. estimates that a Federal em- ployee costs an average of $25,000 a year, but the Government Accounting Office is still trying to determine how much the severance pay, overtime, lump-sum leave payments, productivity loss and, in many cases, unemployment compensation will tax the Federal treasury. **********''It's an awfully difficult calculation to make,'' said an official at the G.A.O. ''New budget decisions are being made every day. We don't know how long it will take us to figure this out, or how accurate we can be.'' **********The Administration, however, contends that, whatever the short-term costs of cutting the Federal work force, the effort will pay off in substantial savings in the long term. **********''There's no question that we'll eventu- ally have savings,'' said a high-ranking O.M.B. official who declined to be named. ''It's just that the savings don't occur immediately. It takes six to eight months before you start realizing the savings.'' **********The true impact of the President's program is further obscured by the quirks and byzantine operations of the bureaucracy itself.  One of the natural consequences of the reduction in force is a personnel practice known among Government workers as ''bumping,'' which occurs when a high-level employee faced with the loss of his job exercises his prerogative to take a job that is occupied by an employee in a lower level, and to collect his old salary for two years. ''You could have the bizarre possibility of somebody earning $50,000 occupying a job that pays $12,000,'' said Reginald M. Jones, chairman of the Task Force on Personnel Reductions (no relation to Reginald H. Jones, General Electric's retired chairman). ''It could happen. It does happen.'' **********That, along with another Federal personnel practice, known as ''retreat,'' which occurs when an employee retains his salary and job grade for two years but returns to a lower-level job he previously held, causes major disruptions in the life of Federal bureaucracy. **********Although no figures are available yet, an O.M.B. official acknowledges that the Government might find itself overloaded with high-paid executive-level employees and without the batteries of secretaries, technicians and mid-level professionals it needs to carry out its functions. **********Because the Reagan program has produced such anomalies in the bureauracy, the reduction in force has come under attack on Capitol Hill. ''It tends to have the most devastating effect on women, minorities and others with little seniority,'' said Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. **********I N addition, according to figures issued by the Office of Personnel Management, about three-fifths of all the reductions in permanent Federal employee levels between January and July came from part-time Federal workers. During that period, 5,105 part-time positions and only 3,330 of the full-time positions were eliminated. **********Reductions in force can sometimes bring about reductions in productivity. Personnel costs at the Internal Revenue Service were cut by $21 million in 1968, for example, but the resulting loss in revenues hit an estimated $700 million over three years.  Representative Ferraro, among others, has expressed concern that possible cuts in the Customs Service and the Immigration and Naturalization Service would reduce the effectiveness of their services and would produce long waits at air terminals and ports. **********In a report issued this summer, the G.A.O. questioned the use of personnel ceilings in Government, saying such policies have an ''adverse effect on the performance and distribution of the Federal workload'' and adding: **********''The use of personnel ceilings reinforces the misconception that containing the staffing level of the direct Federal work force controls the cost of Government.'' **********Few officials even here would argue that Government employment is without featherbedding and waste, but some critics of the Administration's reductions maintain that the savings produced by the personnel cuts are often chimerical. ''Wholesale RIF's do not erase the necessity for the work to be done,'' said Frank Taylor, a spokesman for the National Federation of Federal Employees. **********''Management then looks to the only source it has left - outside contractors. And outside contractors have to make a profit,'' he said. ''Since the bad blankets sold during the American Revolution, outside contractors have supplied the Government with shoddy products, indifferent service, huge cost overruns and various other tactics that make their service more expensive to the taxpayers than that provided by Federal employees.'' **********Others suggest that the reductions in force themselves are part of the Administration's effort to cut Government regulation. ''In some of the areas, they're using reductions as a policy weapon,'' said Robert W. Hartman, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution here. ''With fewer people to enforce regulations and laws, it means weaker enforcement.'' **********To accompany its effort at reduction in force, the Office of Personnel Management implemented programs to register displaced employees and to refer them to openings within and outside the Government. **********But, according to Jerry Klepner, director of legislation for the National Treasury Employees Union, the placement procedures are inadequate. ''The Administration has done an abysmal job,'' he said.  ''They have not devoted enough resources to developing outplacement services. Some Federal agencies are hiring, and many employees who are losing their jobs could be placed in other agencies. There is no effective system.'' **********If the implications and operations of the work force reduction program can only be spoken of in tentative terms, it is in part because the Government has had so little experience in laying off and firing its employees. **********Although union officials are fond of pointing out that the ratio of Federal employees to the national population has declined by about one-fourth in the past three decades, nearly all the reduction has come by way of attrition. Only in the Defense Department, which traditionally has reductions in force at the end of wars and during periodic base closings, and in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which pared its payroll after it reached its goal of a lunar landing in 1969, have RIF procedures received much use. **********''We have very little experience in doing this,'' said Mr. Jones, the chairman of the Task Force on Personnel Reductions. ''We didn't think the Government was ready to do this. So we assembled people, brought all our personnel material up to date, established training sessions and conducted thousands of briefings. **********''Even then,'' he continued, ''sometimes the word didn't get through. Or the word got through and the employees didn't want to believe it. Sometimes no matter how much you explained that they should begin their job hunting, they didn't believe it. I think more employees are inclined now to believe it is going to happen.'' **********Already some 927 have been separated from the Department of Energy, which suffered an unusually high toll in the first round of cuts.  The Government counts an additional 650 separations from the Community Services Administration, which ceased operations Sept. 30.  And the Fish and Wildlife Service of the Department of the Interior separated 204. **********The Federal Grain Inspection Service was among the first Government agencies to eliminate jobs in the fiscal year that began last month; it eliminated 77 jobs Oct. 3. The Public Health Service also separated about 2,100 employees Oct. 31. The Consumer Product Safety Commission is expected to dismiss 47 this week. At the Department of Labor, perhaps as many as 1,200 jobs may be cut by Dec. 31. **********Should Mr. Reagan prevail and win his second round of budget cuts, there could be many more layoffs. According to some estimates here, the Federal Communications Commission could lose as many as 375 positions, for example. **********A S rumors of personnel cuts -many of them unfounded - circulate through the Federal bureaucracy, employee morale tends to suffer.  Documents circulating within the Environmental Protection Agency indicate that the Administration is considering reducing the staff by nearly half. In hearings on Capitol Hill this month, Anne M. Gorsuch, the E.P.A.'s administrator, refused to confirm whether staff reductions are being contemplated for next year. **********The situation has caused much uncertainty among E.P.A.'s employees. ''The average worker has no idea what's going on,'' said Harold L.  Dodson, president of the Government employees' local at E.P.A.  headquarters here. ''With a little trust or cooperation, something could be worked out. Right now our people have zero morale. All they get are rumors. Productivity and efficiency are way down. We have chaos and confusion and not organization.''  ONE UNHAPPY DEPARTURE WASHINGTON **********Her title was Power Rate Analysis and Allocation Specialist in the Office of Power Marketing Coordination of the Department of Energy.  Now, after a quarter-century on the Government payroll, Marlene A.  Moody is unemployed. **********The Government lured her here four years ago from Boulder City, Nev., where she directed a three-state power-marketing program for the Western Area Power Administration. This autumn the Government told her that if she wished to remain in the Energy Department, she could retain her $41,657 salary at the Government's GS-14 grade but would have to take a lower-level job as a budget analyst in a GS-11 grade, which has a pay range of $23,566 to $30,640. **********''I found it very, very difficult to accept a GS-11,'' said Mrs.  Moody, who is 44 years old. ''It was an insult. It's been 10 years since I was a GS-11. A lot of effort and work and expertise has been accruing in that period. To have 10 years of my life erased like that made no sense.'' **********Instead, Mrs. Moody, who said she has never done the kind of budget job she was offered, decided to leave the Government. **********It was, in part, her story that led Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, to call the Reduction in Force process ''a costly tool in dollar and human terms.'' **********Mrs. Moody's departure has left a gap in the Energy Department.  ''She was the only one on the staff who could do that kind of work,'' said a lawyer with the department. ''Now she's been sideswiped and is out.'' **********Mrs. Moody and her husband, who is an education specialist at a home for mentally and emotionally disturbed children, have two grown children. Today, she sits in her Tacoma Park, Md., home, trying to assemble a battery of clients for her new career as a power-rate consultant. She is angry over what she believes are the implications of Mr. Reagan's effort to diminish the size of the Federal work force. **********''I try very hard not to be bitter about this,'' she said. ''But I don't think the process that's going on in Government now is a beneficial one. The Federal work force is being weakened. Maybe that's the Administration's goal. But the best people aren't being retained and the people who are being retained are being shuffled off to jobs where they aren't being productive anymore. There has to be a better way to reduce the Federal work force than this kind of chaos.'' **********When Mrs. Moody left the Government payroll Sept. 25, she was entitled to a year's salary as severence pay plus an additional six weeks' accumulated vacation pay. But, she said, the cost of the Administration's work force reduction plan cannot be measured only in dollars. **********''I just sat there and watched nothing being done by anybody,'' she said of her last days at the Energy Department. ''The whole organization is totally preoccupied by this mess they've created.  It's still going on. It's just tremendous turmoil, and there's a lot of work to be done.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/30/busin.body_text: **********Shareholders of the Dean Witter Reynolds Organization Inc., the large securities firm, approved a $607 million takeover of the company by Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer. **********Holders controlling 9.78 million shares - those shares not obtained by Sears through its original tender offer - accepted terms of the merger agreement, said a Dean Witter spokesman, Robert Stovall. **********That agreement calls for the remaining Dean Witter stockholders to receive 3.110 shares of Sears common stock for each share of Dean Witter common. **********Before Sears's tender offer for Dean Witter stock expired Nov. 10, Sears had acquired 4.55 million Dean Witter shares, or 40 percent of the common outstanding at the time, Mr. Stovall said. The original offer was for $50 a share for up to 45 percent of Dean Witter common stock. **********Dean Witter is the nation's fifth-largest securities company with capital of $297 million.  The vote came just one day after Coldwell, Banker & Co.  shareholders accepted the $215 million acquisition of their Los Angeles-based company by Sears. Coldwell, Banker is the nation's largest real estate brokerage company with 1981 revenue of $345.5 million. Both acquisitions take effect Thursday. Sears stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange at 15 7/8 yesterday, down 1/4. Dean Witter closed at 49 3/8, down 1/8, on the Big Board.
