The plant is located about 600 miles southeast of Moscow on the Volga River. **********Disclosure of the dispute was a rare admission of industrial trouble by the Soviet authorities, and was particularly embarrassing in the case of the Togliatti plant, which is promoted abroad as the standard-bearer of the Soviet auto industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/16/world.body_text: **********Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who said yesterday that President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr could remain in office, appeared today to set a condition for allowing him to continue. The Ayatollah demanded that the President broadcast an apology to the Iranian people for calling on them last week to resist the clergy-dominated Government. **********The President responded with one letter pledging loyalty to the revolutionary leader but complaining that he had been treated unfairly, then sent a second defending himself against charges that he had violated the Constitution by refusing to sign a bill empowering the Government to fill Cabinet vacancies and complaining that his first letter had not been broadcast. **********It was not clear what the next step would be in the running battle between the dominant Islamic fundamentalists and the President, who has been stripped of virtually all power. **********Parliament Debate Scuttled **********Parliament, which was called into session over the weekend, presumably to debate the competence of the President and whether he should remain in office, adjourned today without attempting to do so. A move yesterday by more than 120 members of Parliament to begin such a debate was blocked by the Speaker, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, who acted after conferring with Ayatollah Khomeini. **********The Ayatollah, in an address to Islamic clergymen today in a mosque near his home, said he was sorry that opponents of the Government of Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai had ''dug their own graves.'' **********Speaking of the President and the Western-educated people around him, the Ayatollah said: ''I have several times told this gentleman to beware of those who have rallied around him because some are wolves. I want them now to go on radio and television and announce their repentance and say that they have been wrong so far in inviting people to revolt.'' Call for Bani-Sadr to Apologize **********Then the 81-year-old revolutionary leader declared: ''The gentleman should go and apologize to the nation and say that he has not acted according to the votes of the people who have elected him but that he would henceforth do so. But this should not be just in words.'' **********Last Friday, the President issued a statement denouncing the policies of the Government of his political foe, Prime Minister Rajai, calling on the Iranian people to resist what he described as a dicatatorship and declaring that an attempt was under way to deprive him of the Presidency and his life. That statement was broadcast only when read to Parliament yesterday. **********In his first letter to the Ayatollah, which was telephoned to news agencies, Mr. Bani-Sadr declared: ''I emphasize that however you behave, I will not violate my responsibility toward you. However angry you are, my honesty toward you will not be diminished. I think that your treatment of me is not fair. I have not had a bad thought toward you and the country I have served honestly.'' Demonstrations in Teheran **********Mr. Bani-Sadr has not been seen in public since returning to Teheran last Wednesday night from the battlefronts of Iran's war with Iraq hours after the Ayatollah dismissed him as Commander in Chief of the armed forces. An aide said he was under his supporters' protection at a secret location. **********As the feuding continued, Iranians tonight climbed to Teheran roofs to shout ''God is great!'' as a sign of support for the Ayatollah.  The chanting rang out in every direction for at least 15 minutes while car horns blared in the streets. The state radio had urged listeners to demonstrate support for the Ayatollah. **********Earlier, Khomeini supporters by the tens of thousands poured into the streets to block a march in support of the President that had been scheduled by his leftist and nationalist backers. Many of the Presidents opponents were apparently members of the Islamic extremist group known as the Party of God. They demonstrated all last week calling for Mr. Bani-Sadr's trial and execution. **********As the supporters of Mr. Bani-Sadr tried to assemble, the state radio broadcast a warning by the revolutionary prosecutor's office that everyone taking part in the projected march would be treated as corrupt and a fighter against God.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/11/busin.body_text: **********Sales of existing homes will jump 20 percent in 1982, to 2,875,000 units, as mortgage rates fall below 14 percent, according to a forecast being released today by Multi-List McGraw-Hill. It also predicts that the average home selling price will increase 7 percent, to $84,100, from $78,400 this year. **********''A reduction in the inflation rate to 8 percent, a slightly more relaxed monetary policy, and recently enacted tax cuts and savings incentives will produce a better financial environment for home buying,'' said Phillip E. Kidd, who prepared the forecast. He is director of economic research for Multi-List McGraw-Hill, the real estate information unit of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company. **********Mr. Kidd predicted that mortgage rates would decline steadily in 1982, falling from a national average of 17.6 percent in the final quarter of this year to 13.5 percent a year from now. **********The sales surge will signal a rebound in the depressed market, where there is a ''huge, fundamental demand for home ownership among first-time buyers,'' his report said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/06/busin.body_text: **********Within the past month, a flurry of stock-trading scandals has tested the detective skills of a little-publicized team of analysts at the New York Stock Exchange. **********On Feb. 3, a former investment banker at Morgan Stanley & Company and three others were accused of profiting from the use of confidential information on prospective mergers. Just two weeks later, the Securities and Exchange Commission obtained a consent degree against Frederick Wyman 2d, a broker at L.F. Rothschild Unterberg Towbin, and his father, Frank Wyman, for violating insider trading rules. And last week the financier Edward M. Gilbert was convicted of 34 counts of stock manipulation. **********The detective work in each case originated in a small, noisy room several stories above the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange. There, amid the staccato clatter of printing machines that record stock trades, a team of 11 analysts and investigators, armed with computers, follows each transaction made in a trading session. **********Officials at the New York Stock Exchange are decidedly optimistic about their surveillance program, known as Stock Watch, which has monitored trading activity since the 1940's. The American Stock Exchange, as well as most of the regional exchanges, have similar systems. Hard to Detect **********Other market observers, while applauding the stock exchange's security efforts, are not so enthusiastic about its ability to protect against well-executed stock manipulation or insider trading schemes. **********''If a person has inside information, and tells a friend about it, and that friend tells another friend about it, and transactions are done through nominee accounts (in which the actual owners of the stock are not identified), detection becomes very hard, if not impossible.'' said Thomas A. Russo, a partner in the Wall Street law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. **********Another view comes from Harvey Pitt, former general counsel of the S.E.C., now in private practice in the Washington office of the New York-based Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Kampelman: ''I just don't think it's possible to create a system that can prevent every deliberate fraud, but I think these cases came to light because the trading activities were picked up by market surveillance programs which are becoming increasingly sophisticated as computer technology advances.'' A Trading Alarm Sounds **********In the insider trading scheme involving Morgan Stanley, for instance, the exchange's analysts were alerted by a computerized printer that issues a warning message whenever a transaction or accumulation of trades exceeds pre-determined price or volume guidelines. **********The warning parameters are based on the historic performance of the stock and are programmed into the computer's memory.  For instance, the blue-chip General Motors stock, currently trading around $49 a share, is programmed to flag price movement up or down more than three points in a single trading session, while I.B.M, trading at $60, will be flagged if it reaches $64. The same principle holds true for newer, more volatile listings. **********Most jumps in the price of a stock can be readily explained by an encouraging earnings statement, an independent research report, the introduction of a new product or the disclosure of a possible merger or acquisition. **********Companies routinely alert the exchange to events that may affect their stocks. In addition, the Stock Watch subscribes to several news services that provide information which may affect a company's market performance. Sifting for Clues **********The Stock Watch detectives step in when there is no apparent reason for unusual interest in a stock. **********''Sometimes I look back through the news service reports as far as 90 days,'' said Sheldon Richter, a wiry, bearded man who started at the exchange as a floor reporter, and now heads the staff of analysts. ''There are times when a company will be talking about preliminary negotiations toward a merger, and they haven't said anything for 60 days, and now the stock is kicking-out (showing up on the warning printer), so by looking back, we can track it down.'' **********An analyst who detects trading irregularities immediately calls a floor official - a member of the exchange, who may question a specialist or commission broker about the stock's activity. If no reasonable explantion is forthcoming, the brokerage firm handling the account is questioned. **********The corporation whose stock is being traded is also questioned.  ''The company might say they don't know what is going on, then we might ask them then to say so on one of the news wires,'' Mr. Richter said. The purpose, he said, is to quell rumors, ''reducing unwarranted speculation in the stock.'' Checking Transactions **********When there is still no rationale for the stock's volatility or high volume, the analyst retrieves the computer record of sales - frequently covering several months of trading. **********''Trying to relate little scraps of information to other scraps to build a case is a tough, hard job,'' said Richard Drew, a vice president of the exchange responsible for the Stock Watch program. **********Mr. Drew said analysts looked for concentrations of activity, such as large block trades. ''If a person is involved in several situations - phenomenally luck on one tender offer, then another, and a third and a fourth - after several such occurrences, we often find that there may be problems here,'' he said. **********If the analyst finds reasons for further inquiry, the broker or customer representative may be asked why this moment was chosen to trade heavily in the market. **********''If he says it was tape action - he was watching tape and the stock exhibited high volume and he decided that it's a good time to buy the stock and he wanted to join the bandwagon, then we say fine,'' Mr. Richter said. ''The investigator will look at the market, and if there was no tape action, the broker will be asked to come to the stock exchange, accompanied by counsel.'' A Pattern Emerged **********As Mr. Drew put it, ''It is out of this kind of detective work that the Morgan Stanley case developed.'' **********After examining the trading pattern of several stocks that had been flagged by the computerized warning system, the analysts determined that they were all involved in takeover bids, and that the unusual spurts in trading activity came just before public announcements - a classic case of insider trading. **********Among those stocks involved were Marshall Field & Company, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Monroe Auto Equipment Company. Because of the pending investigation, Stock Watch officials declined to be more specific about which stocks were spotted first or how high they had traded above normal. **********When wrongdoing is found, the exchange begins disciplinary action.  When the exchange lacks jurisdiction it calls in the enforcement arm of the S.E.C., which has jurisdiction over customers, lawyers, accountants or officials of the company whose stock is involved.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/09/busin.main_headline: EX-REAGAN AIDE'S FIRM IN PIPELINE FIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/09/busin.print_headline: EX-REAGAN AIDE'S FIRM IN PIPELINE FIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/09/busin.body_text: **********The top executive of the principal company that would build the Alaskan gas pipeline said that he hired the public relations company of a former adviser to President Reagan to help him win White House endorsement of a proposal that would make financing of the project easier. **********The executive, John G. McMillian, a large financial contributor to the Democratic Party, said in an interview that he had retained the public relations-lobbying firm, the Hannaford Company, to improve his image with Republicans and to gain access to the White House and key Republicans. **********The proposal that Mr. McMillian wants approved could shift some of the pipeline's $40 billion cost to consumers before construction is completed. A Former Reagan Speechwriter **********The Hannaford Company is run by Peter D. Hannaford, a speechwriter and adviser to Mr. Reagan before Mr. Reagan became President. **********''Being able to talk to people who make the decisions is vital,'' said Mr. McMillian, the chairman and chief executive officer of the Northwest Alaskan Pipeline Company. The company heads a consortium of pipeline companies that plans to build the Alaskan segment of the 4,800-mile system, which would carry natural gas from Alaska's Prudhoe Bay through Canada and into the United States. **********Mr. Hannaford's firm, which was just one of several concerns hired by Northwest Alaskan to lobby for the pipeline financing plan, is being paid $2,000 to $3,000 a month, according to Mr. McMillian. Mr.  Hannaford became the focus of controversy recently when it was disclosed that he had bought a consulting firm, on an installment basis, from Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser. **********According to the White House, Mr. Hannaford's company arranged for Mr. McMillian to meet in the White House on Sept.22 with Edwin Meese 3d, the President's counselor. **********The Administration was then studying proposals for waiving some provisions of the Federal laws that apply to the pipeline project.  Mr. McMillian and other sponsors said that the waivers were needed to encourage private financing of the pipeline project. **********In a candid interview, Mr. McMillian said he was not ''ashamed'' that he had hired Mr. Hannaford's firm and other lobbyists and public relations firms to help him. He said it was ''part of doing business'' in Washington. ''Everybody does it,'' he added. President Endorsed Waivers **********Mr. McMillian and the White House said that Mr. Meese, who could not be reached today, made no commitments to him. Mr. Reagan endorsed the waiver proposal on Oct.6. **********The waiver package has been consistently criticized by some consumer advocates, including Ralph Nader.  In 1977, President Carter approved the pipeline project, but stipulated that it was to be privately financed.  He also specified that gas consumers could not be charged for construction costs until the system was finished. Furthermore, for antitrust reasons, his decision prohibited oil companies that owned Prudhoe Bay gas from owning part of the pipeline. **********The project consists of three segments. Under the waiver mechanism, if the system is not finished as of a date to be selected by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, customers could be billed as each segment is completed. The sponsors acknowledged that consumers could be paying for the gas before the pipeline is finished. Such pre-billing, they contend, would assure their lenders that project debt would be repaid. **********The waiver also gives the Exxon Corporation, the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) - the companies producing the gas - the right to own an equity interest in the line. **********Mr. McMillian and his supporters originally wanted to begin billing natural gas users for pipeline construction costs immediately. But the Reagan Administration demurred. **********Mr. McMillian's Sept.22 meeting with Mr. Meese, the President's counselor, was arranged by Daniel T. Kingsley, an executive vice president of the Hannaford Company. Craig L. Fuller, an aide to Mr.  Meese, said that Mr. Kingsley had called him and asked for the appointment. Mr. Fuller worked for Mr. Hannaford before joining Mr.  Meese's staff in January. **********Mr. Fuller and Mr. Mcillian said that Martin Anderson, who is Mr.  Reagan's chief domestic policy adviser, sat in on the meeting. Mr.  Hannaford did not attend, although Mr. Fuller recalled that Mr.  Kingsley did. **********''They didn't promise me anything,'' said Mr. McMillian. ''They just listened.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/05/world.main_headline: HAIG OPENS TOUR WITH CAIRO TALKS, PLEDGES EFFORTS FOR A MIDEAST PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/05/world.print_headline: HAIG OPENS TOUR WITH CAIRO TALKS, PLEDGES EFFORTS FOR A MIDEAST PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/05/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. opened his Middle East tour today by pledging the Reagan Administration's desire to promote security and peace efforts in the region, but his attention was distracted by the situation in Poland. **********Arriving for talks with Egyptian leaders today and tomorrow before he goes on to Israel, Mr. Haig was prepared to return immediately to Washington if the Soviet Union intervenes in Poland, his aides told reporters on his plane. **********Although Mr. Haig delayed his departure from Washington by an hour and a half yesterday to attend a meeting on Poland at the White House, the decision was made to go ahead with the nine-day tour through four Middle Eastern countries and five countries in Europe. **********''We are here today to learn how best we Americans can participate in a partnership to enhance the security of this region, which will enable us to go forward with the peace process with Israel in the confines of the Camp David accords,'' Mr. Haig said in a statement at Cairo International Airport. **********Haig Has Cited Soviet Threat **********Mr. Haig has talked in Washington about trying to create a ''strategic consensus'' in the Middle East to oppose what he sees as a growing Soviet threat. **********Reporters were told on Mr. Haig's plane that the Secretary was aware of dissatisfaction in Egypt and Saudi Arabia that the Administration was too involved with strategic concerns and was not paying enough attention to traditional Arab priorities, such as resolution of the Palestinian issue. **********Security concerns involving the Soviet Union are important, Mr.  Haig is said to believe, but they should reinforce the efforts to bring about peace in the region. **********Reporters on the Air Force plane were told Mr. Haig wants to be ''very careful that the Arabs do not view this strategic consensus as an effort to put the peacekeeping process in a lower priority.'' **********''This is not the intention,'' they were told. The goal is to use the common concerns on strategic matters as a catalyst toward progress in peace talks. **********As to the situation in Poland, Mr. Haig was in touch with Washington throughout the 13-hour flight to keep up with the latest information. **********Mr. Haig indicated his concerns about Poland when he said on arrival: ''Unfortunately, my stop in Cairo this morning is clouded once again by growing tensions for peace and stability in Europe.'' **********The Secretary met early this evening with Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali. American reporters traveling with Mr. Haig were invited to the Foreign Ministry before the session to receive a ''preview'' of the Egyptian point of view. **********The Egyptian position, as explained by a Foreign Ministry official, is that the Reagan Administration, by its stress on strategic matters was causing problems for itself and some of its friends in the region. **********Of particular concern to the Egyptians is the composition of the peacekeeping force that must be set up by April 1982 to patrol the Sinai peninsula after Israel makes its final withdrawal. **********The United States had said it was prepared to supply up to half the force, but Egypt urged Mr. Haig today to withdraw that offer and instead try to fill the force with contingents from other countries.  If there is a large American force in the peacekeeping group, Egypt will be criticized for allowing the Americans to replace Israel as the ''occupying power'' in Sinai, the official said. Israel Wants Large U.S. Role **********Israel, however, wants a 4,000-member force, preferably with many Americans, to insure its security. Until now, the United States, recognizing that it will be difficult to find volunteers for such a force, had thought that by publicizing its own willingness to participate it could persuade others to participate. **********The Egyptians are also concerned over the talk in Washington about setting up a permanent American ground force in the Middle East. If the United States has troops in the peacekeeping force, this could add to speculation that they were the first in a Middle East combat force and that Egypt was allowing the United States a Sinai ''base,'' the official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/07/world.main_headline: French Force In a Vital Area; Sole Ally That Is Ready For Indian Ocean Move; Military Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/07/world.print_headline: French Force In a Vital Area; Sole Ally That Is Ready For Indian Ocean Move; Military Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/07/world.body_text: **********The French military presence in the Indian Ocean and adjacent regions has assumed a new importance as American strategic planning turns increasingly toward Southwest Asia. Alone among America's allies, **********France has substantial forces in the area.  French global strategic thinking agrees with that in the Pentagon on one important point: A Soviet attack on Western Europe is the most dangerous but at present least likely threat. The danger lies in proxy wars or limited Soviet interventions in the arc of land from Libya to Pakistan and in black Africa. **********Since 1973, French forces have intervened twice in Zaire and in Djibouti, Mauritania, Lebanon, Chad and the Central African Republic. The operations were small, but French officers say the troops were deployed rapidly and operated effectively. **********French officers and civilian officials consider such missions normal responses to help friendly African nations, to prevent the overthrow of friendly governments and to protect French economic and political interests. Indian Ocean Naval Forces **********France has 20 ships in the Indian Ocean area. The guided-missile frigate Duquesne and five dual-purpose frigates are this squadron's major surface ships. Five minesweepers in the squadron are, French sources said, the only Western ships of this type in the Indian Ocean. **********The 3,600 French troops in Djibouti are the largest Western land force within striking distance of the Persian Gulf area. The force has four infantry companies, 30 tanks in two squadrons and two batteries of field artillery and one of @antiaircraft artillery. Ten Mirage III-C fighters and 13 helicopters are the air component. **********Djibouti is across Bab el Mandeb from Southern Yemen, where there are Soviet and Cuban forces. In a crisis France could try to block the strait and prevent the Soviet naval squadron now using the anchorage in the Dahlak Archipelago in the Red Sea from reaching the Gulf of Aden through the strait. **********Smaller French forces of all three services are also on Mayotte in the Comoro Archipelago northwest of Madagascar and on Reunion. 3 Major Units for Intervention **********In a crisis, the American Rapid Deployment Force, which has headquarters at MacDill Air Force Base in Florida, would have to call on units scattered across the United States and perhaps on formations in Europe. French intervention forces, however, are already organized in three major units that Westerners say are notable for their flexibility and powerful antitank weaponry. **********The largest unit, with a strength of 12,000, is the 11th Parachute Division in Corsica and southwest France. The second largest is the 7,000-member Ninth Division of marine infantry in Brittany. The 31st Brigade of 2,000 has been formed and equipped with tanks and other heavy weapons to support the other units. **********France's two aircraft carriers, the Foch and the Clemenceau, with their escorts and supply ships, would provide naval support for a major intervention. Nine transports and landing ships would carry the seaborne forces. **********France, like the United States, is short of long-range air transports.  The intervention force would have to depend on 50 Transall transports, which are twin-engine planes, and three DC-8's. The Government has ordered 25 second-generation Transalls, and military sources believe that these will double the force's lift capacity.  The new planes' performance is said to be similar to that of the American C-130, a tactical transport. Described as Highly Trained **********A French military estimate that may be optimistic is that today's landing forces would suffice for an operation by several regiments 3,700 miles from France. **********American and other NATO officers who have watched the intervention force on exercises say it is highly trained and motivated. It has more long-service soldiers than the forces stationed in France and West Germany, where conscripts predominate. The weapons and vehicles, while somewhat outmoded, have been chosen with an eye to conditions of war in third-world countries. **********The extent of French cooperation with the United States in the event of a crisis in Southwest Asia is difficult to estimate. The consensus among other NATO military and diplomatic sources is that any French involvement in strength would come only if the Government perceived a serious danger to French interests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/30/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Canadian Voices Annoyance With U.S. Over Acid Rain
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/30/world.body_text: **********Canada's Environment Minister, John Roberts, said here today that his Government was growing ''increasingly impatient'' with the failure of the United States to control acid rain. **********Mr. Roberts, who spoke at an environmental conference at Tufts University, said acid rain was polluting Canadian lakes and rivers, affecting trees and killing or harming wildlife. The issue was dramatized in Ottawa this month when President Reagan was greeted by demonstrators carrying signs protesting the American role in causing acid rain. **********''About eight million tons of sulfur dioxide and close to four million tons of oxides of nitrogen are falling on Canada every year,'' Mr. Roberts said. ''At least half of that load is sent to us by the United States.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/25/world.body_text: **********An explosion at a beach resort killed three people today and injured an undetermined number of others. Some of the victims had been attending a Christmas party. **********Initial reports indicated that the blast might have been caused by a butane gas cylinder, but some witnesses said the explosion appeared to have originated in a parked car. **********The blast occurred in a parking lot in the basement of a building in the predominantly Christian suburb of Antilias. Main Gemayel, a Member of Parliament and oldest son of the leader of the right-wing Phalangist Party, was at the party, which was being held for a group of children on one of the building's upper floors. He was unharmed, but a number of children were hurt by flying glass.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/18/busin.main_headline: Market Place; The Quandary In Bond Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/18/busin.print_headline: Market Place; The Quandary In Bond Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/18/busin.body_text: **********THE current rally in bonds after the worst bear market in history puts investors in fixed-interest securities in a quandary. Should they cash in their money market fund shares to lock in high yields on long bonds or sit tight - accepting reduced yields as interest rates retreat? **********United States Treasury bonds maturing in 25 years are enticing at current prices. For example, the 13 7/8 percent United States Treasury bond of 2006 now sells at a premium - $10,400 per $10,000 bond for a current yield of about 13 1/4 percent. **********Meanwhile, municipal bonds, which appeal to individuals in top tax brackets, are even more attractive. For example, the Municipal Assistance Corporation 10 5/8 percent bonds of 2008 are selling at about 85 for a current yield of about 12 1/2. The taxpayer in the 50 percent bracket would have to find a taxable bond yielding 25 percent for the same net result. **********With money market fund yields already down to 14 1/4 percent, many investors may wish to consider locking in high long-term yields.  In addition, should interest rates retreat further, prices of long bonds would appreciate substantially. Still, many investors will shy away from this devastated market, concerned that interest rates may move up again. Higher interest rates would produce paper losses and substandard yields for those who buy and hold long bonds today. **********Paul W.H. Trevor, who heads Trevor, Stewart, Burton & Jacobsen, a money management firm in Manhattan with $100 million under management, favors long bonds for their high current yields and appreciation potential. **********He said that should prices weaken, he would buy more because his outlook was favorable for the longer term. However, anyone who fears a weakening is not ''locked in,'' he said, and can sell and redeploy assets. **********Mr. Trevor is a native of Britain. He attended high school in France and was graduated from the University of Virginia and the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. He has managed money since receiving his M.B.A. in 1951. **********Firmly convinced that inflation will moderate and that interest rates will ''trend downward'' over the next few months, Mr. Trevor is purchasing long-term Government bonds for his firm's pension accounts and tax-exempts for individual accounts. **********In a telephone interview he said that appreciation potential is greater in long bonds than it is in shorter maturities. If long-term interest rates decline by 100 basis points - one percentage point - the price of a 30-year bond would increase by roughly 8 to 9 percent, he said. By contrast, there is no appreciation potential in a money market fund, certificate of deposit or Treasury bill. **********Mr. Trevor acknowledged that a large Federal deficit might force the Treasury to issue so many securities that interest rates could be pushed up again. However, he said that the demand for credit in the private sector would probably go down more than it would rise in the public sector. **********''This happened in the 1974-1975 recession,'' he said. ''This was a period during which the deficit reached $100 billion, yet the interest structure came down. For example, the prime rate, which reached 12 percent in July of 1974, retreated to 6.75 percent by early 1976.'' **********He believes that a sharp recession would produce a deficit of $100 billion or more this time. Referring to the risks of long-term bonds - risks that have caused some to imply that long-term bonds are obsolete - he said that there were two basic problems. **********''If you buy long-term bonds today there is a risk that in the next two weeks they will go down on profit-taking,'' he said. ''The other and more fundamental risk is that we won't control inflation -that the Federal Reserve will become extremely expansionary and that therefore inflationary psychology will become rampant once again.'' **********Can the individual afford to take these risks? Mr. Trevor thinks so. ''I don't recommend bonds for their stability,'' he said. ''Bonds will continue to be volatile. I suggest bonds for those willing to take an equity-type risk for a higher relative total return over the next couple of years than they can expect in money market instruments, Treasury bills and even stocks. **********''As far as stocks are concerned, I believe they have more risk and less potential than bonds at present. I think that bonds are cheap relative to stocks. The yields on bonds are now about 25 percent higher than the yields on stocks in terms of earnings. That is, highgrade corporate bonds are offering yields of 13 3/4 percent while the earnings yield on Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks is about 11 percent. **********''This is close to the situation that existed before the big stock market break in 1974. This yield premium favoring bonds is justified only under one of two circumstances: one is a great fear of inflation, which I believe to be unjustified; the other is that you expect earnings on stocks to go up sharply, which I think unlikely in view of the recession.'' **********Mr. Trevor concludes that either bond prices will go up or stock prices will go down or, more likely, both will occur.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/02/busin.main_headline: TAXES COMPLICATED BY CHANGES IN LAW
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/02/busin.print_headline: TAXES COMPLICATED BY CHANGES IN LAW
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/02/busin.body_text: **********There is both good news and bad news for taxpayers who, with calculators and pencils at hand, are getting ready for the annual bout with their income tax returns. The 1980 forms are largely unchanged from last year's, which is something of a relief. But the task has been complicated by new legislation, including some bills enacted in the final days of last December, as well as by hundreds of court cases and rulings handed down last year that have clarified the tax treatment of certain issues and actually changed the rules in other cases. **********To be sure, the task was already complicated enough. The tax code runs to some 6,000 pages of fine print, and an industry of tax preparers, employing thousands of people, has sprung up to interpret its intricacies and help people through their tax returns. In addition, the Internal Revenue Service itself employs 85,000 workers, including almost 19,000 auditors, to monitor the system. **********With it all, the American tax system basically is one of voluntary self-assessment, in which the taxpayer is generally trusted to determine the money owed. **********And the system somehow manages to succeed. Despite grumblings over the millions of hours consumed in doing the returns - and concern over the estimated billions of dollars of revenue lost to tax cheating - the American tax system is nonetheless the envy of other industrialized countries. **********In the 1980 fiscal year, for example, the I.R.S. processed almost 91 million individual tax returns, levying $252 billion in taxes and refunding $34 billion. 'Bracket Creep' **********Individual tax rates for 1980 were not increased, which at first might seem to provide cause for rejoicing. But ''bracket creep'' - in which taxpayers are pushed into higher tax brackets solely because of wage increases they receive to keep pace with inflation -will increase the tax bite for many. **********To make matters worse, the latest increase in the Social Security levy will mean that middle-income workers will be paying an extra $387 each to the Government this year. Not only has the tax rate increased to 6.65 percent from 6.13 percent of earnings, but the amount of annual salary subject to the tax has risen to $29,700 from $25,900. The maximum tax is now $1,975. **********But there were many positive developments for taxpayers as well.  The Internal Revenue Service, for example, last year relaxed its position on outlays for weight control programs. It decided that such expenditures could be deducted as a medical expense as long as a person attends the program on a physician's orders, to cure or alleviate a specific ailment, such as hypertension. **********The I.R.S. also increased its mileage allowance for people who use their own cars for medical or charitable purposes. The allowance now is 9 cents a mile, up from 8 cents, retroactive to Jan. 1, 1980. The allowance for business use of a car was increased to 20 cents a mile from 18 1/2 cents for the first 15,000 miles, and to 11 cents a mile from 10 cents a mile beyond that. Reversal on Loans **********The revenue service also suffered a setback on its tough stance regarding interest-free loans. The courts rejected its contention that key employees who receive loans from their companies at low interest rates, or at no charge at all, must report the economic benefit as income. The court decisions, the latest in a string of defeats in this area for the I.R.S., strengthen the use of interestfree loans as a device for parents in high tax brackets to shift income to children in lower brackets. **********Although Congress passed no major tax legislation last year, it enacted several relatively narrow bills that may have great importance to taxpayers in special situations. Many people who sold property under deferred-payment arrangements, for example, may be able to postpone paying tax on the gain by taking advantage of liberalized new rules under the Installment Sale Revision Act. A prime candidate might be someone who sold a house last year and received part of the payment in 1980 and the rest in 1981. **********Previously, sellers could defer capital gains only if they received 30 percent or less of the selling price in the year of sale - a technicality that many sellers inadvertently overlooked. But **********This series was written with the assistance of Sidney Kess, who conducts a nationwide continuing education program on tax return preparation for the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. Mr. Kess, national tax partner in the accounting firm of Main Hurdman & Cranstoun, is adjunct professor of law at New York Law School. **********Under the act, which is retroactive to Jan. 1, 1980, anyone who does not receive payment in full can qualify for the installment method, regardless of the amount of the initial payment. **********In addition, Congress abolished the rule requiring that sellers receive at least two separate payments to qualify for the installment method. Now this treatment is available to those who receive one lump sum payment after the year of sale. **********''As a practical matter, for those who overlooked the tough previous rules, tax liability and ability to pay are synchronized,'' Sidney Kess, national tax partner with the accounting firm of Main Hurdman & Cranstoun, said in an interview. **********Furthermore, such treatment is now automatic. Previously, taxpayers who qualified had to elect to use the installment method. Now the presumption is that they will use the method unless they chose not to. Dividend Exclusion Doubled **********Although the Crude Oil Windfall Profit Tax Act of 1980 deals mainly with the nation's energy problems, it contains several provisions of importance to the general public. The amount of dividends that taxpayers can exclude from income has been doubled, to $200 from $100 for single persons, and to $400 from $200 for married persons filing jointly. In addition, the exclusion has been broadened so that interest income from banks and savings and loan associations can be excluded, as well as dividends. In short, the first $200 of interest in savings accounts of single people is tax-free. **********The new exclusion goes into effect for the tax years of 1981 and 1982, so it does not help taxpayers now toiling over their 1980 returns. The law is scheduled to revert to its less generous provisions after 1982, but the betting is that under the Reagan Administration the larger exclusion will be retained, if not expanded. **********The act also enlarged the size of the ''renewable energy source'' credit, for such things as solar heating systems, to $4,000 from $2,200. In addition, it clarified the treatment of joint ownership of energy items qualifying for the credit. Previously, there was confusion about how much credit could be claimed by owners of adjacent condominium units, for example, who installed a commonly owned solar heating system. **********People who inherit property will also benefit from the act, which abolished the ''carry-over basis'' provisions that had been the pride of tax reformers. Now the law reverts to where it had been before the Revenue Act of 1976, when heirs who sold inherited property were able to increase the basis, or tax cost, of the property to its value on the date of death or, alternatively, six months later. This enabled them to escape paying tax on any appreciation of the property that had occurred during the lifetime of the deceased. **********The reform act had attempted to tax the appreciation by requiring the heir to ''carry over'' the deceased's original cost of the property, but protests that the law was unworkable prevented it from taking full effect. The windfall profit tax act decisively disposed of the matter. Stock Refund Opportunity **********The Technical Corrections Act of 1979 (which was not passed until April 1980) has created a possible refund opportunity for people who own Section 1244 stock, which is stock issued by new businesses. **********The Revenue Act of 1978 doubled the amount of ordinary losses that stockholders in defunct companies could deduct - to $50,000 if single and $100,000 if married filing jointly - but only for stock issued after Nov. 6, 1978. **********The corrections act says that, beginning in 1979, stockholders can claim such increased losses no matter when the Section 1244 stock was issued, even if the issue date was decades ago. ''So if you had a large 1244 loss in 1979 that was limited by the previous ceiling, you may be able to claim a larger loss by filing an amended return,'' Mr. Kess said. Next: Filing status and dependents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/16/world.main_headline: TALKS GOING WELL. HAIG AND DENG SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/16/world.print_headline: TALKS GOING WELL. HAIG AND DENG SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/16/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, said today that the first high-level talks between the Chinese authorities and the Reagan Administration had gone ''very well.'' American officials said that Taiwan had not been a major issue of contention. **********At the start of the last day of talks, Mr. Deng, who is a deputy chairman of the Chinese Communist Party and in effect the nation's leader, told Mr. Haig through an interpreter in the presence of reporters: **********''I have heard that you had very good sessions with Foreign Minister Huang Hua.'' Mr. Haig said that the talks had gone ''very well'' and that the ''time was well used.'' The comments by the two sides were evidently meant to dispel speculation in some news reports that problems had arisen in connection with Chinese concern over United States policy toward Taiwan. **********Two aides to Mr. Haig were authorized to brief reporters in advance of the final round of talks today. They contended that, while the Taiwan issue had come up, it had not played a major part in the talks and had not given rise to any acrimony. **********As a result of the discussion about Taiwan, one American official said, ''the Chinese now have a richer understanding of our policy and that it is more sophisticated than they believed.'' **********The major focus in the talks, the official said, has been the global strategic positions of the United States and China and specific regional issues such as Cambodia and Afghanistan, in which both the Chinese and the Americans oppose what they call Soviet ''hegemonism.'' **********Yesterday, Mr. Haig's discussions concentrated on military and intelligence matters in what the American side said was ''a very friendly atmosphere.'' **********One of the participants in the talks said the Chinese side had been ''all hearts and flowers.'' The Chinese, he reported, were going out of their way to appear supportive on the strategic questions that Mr. Haig came to discuss and on seeking better coordination of policies against the Soviet Union. News Conference Scheduled **********Ever since Henry A. Kissinger made his first trip here in 1971 as President Nixon's envoy, there has been a custom of secrecy about the negotiations while they were going on, and this has rarely been breached. Mr. Haig, however, plans to hold a news conference before he departs for Manila tomorrow, and an American official promised that the Secretary would ''fill in some of the blanks.'' **********Other customs were also followed. While Mr. Haig was meeting with Chinese leaders, his wife, Patricia, made the two-hour trip to the Great Wall and climbed the steep path to the top. The Haigs and members of their party attended a ballet known as ''The Sword'' and many seemed to doze, a custom set by Mr. Kissinger, who once fell soundly asleep during another ballet. **********Mr. Haig began his day yesterday with a meeting of nearly four hours with Foreign Minister Huang, continuing the discussions that the two men began Sunday. Session Extended From 2 Hours **********The session was originally planned to last two hours, but was extended to give the two sides a chance for more detailed discussion of the issues, aides to Mr. Haig said later. **********Mr. Haig also met with Bo Yibo, a Deputy Prime Minister who is in charge of economic matters, to discuss trade, including the provision of technology that could be used for military purposes. **********Then Mr. Haig conferred with Defense Minister Geng Biao, who was accompanied by Zhang Zhunzi, a deputy chief of army intelligence.  Chai Chenwen, a senior official in the Defense Ministry, met with members of Mr. Haig's party, including Lieut. Gen. Vernon A.  Walters, former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency and now ambassador at large; Richard R. Burt, director of the State Department's Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs; Richard I.  Armitage of the Pentagon, and Gen. William Webb, military attache at the embassy here. Talks Reflect New U.S. Policy **********This is the first time a Secretary of State has held such militarily oriented talks with the Chinese, and it reflects a decision by the Reagan Administration to press forward as far as it can in cooperation with the Chinese against the Soviet Union. **********Mr. Haig's predecessors were always constrained by a desire for closer relations with Moscow and for progress in arms control issues, something not considered so crucial by Mr. Haig. **********He had said that he was ready to discuss the question of possible arms sales and cooperation in sharing of intelligence information with the Chinese if they expressed an interest, but it was not known whether such matters actually were discussed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/20/world.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; POLISH CHIEF: A PRAGMATIST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/20/world.body_text: **********When Stanislaw Kania was first named as Poland's Communist Party leader in the wake of last summer's labor unrest, his first speech was read on Polish television by a dapper young announcer. A ripple of excitement passed through Warsaw: the new party secretary was attractive and young. Then the error was discovered, and people crowded the news kiosks to see what the new chief really looked like. **********That he did not read his first televised speech as party leader, and that so few people knew who he was, proved to be an unintentionally appropriate introduction to Mr. Kania, a career party functionary and security chief who has led Poland through a year of unceasing crises and who last night achieved the distinction of becoming the first Eastern European party leader to be confirmed in his post by a secret-ballot vote. **********A 1,311-to-568 Victory **********Poland's first independent party congress chose Mr. Kania over his only opponent, Kazimierz Barcikowski, a fellow Politburo member who shares Mr. Kania's moderate views. The vote was 1,311 to 568. Mr.  Barcikowski was nominated by the congress only yesterday; several other prospective nominees declined requests that they run. **********That Mr. Kania survived the tumultuous year, to say nothing of his re-election at wide-open party congress, was probably as much a result of his image as a colorless and modest bureaucrat as of his reputed skills at back-room maneuvering - and of pure chance. **********As recently as two months ago, the common wisdom in Warsaw was that Mr. Kania was politically finished. Moscow had begun showing signs of a loss of confidence in his leadership, the economy was steadily sliding downhill, liberals and hard-liners alike were demanding action, lawlessness was on the rise, and Solidarity, the independent trade movement, was pressing for more concessions. **********In early June, Moscow sent a stiff warning letter to the Polish party that included a sharp attack on Mr. Kania. It seemed an open call for his ouster, and at the Central Committee meeting of June 9-10 the hard-liners in the Polish party went on the offensive. Challenge to Leadership Fails **********But in a deft maneuver, Mr. Kania called for an open vote of confidence. The Politburo asked the 140-member Central Committee for a vote of confidence in each Politburo member. The proposal was rejected, as the Central Committee seemed to shy away from dramatic changes at a time of crisis. The challenge to Mr. Kania's leadership then withered. **********Mr. Kania emerged from the episode with a new gloss. He had beat back the hard-liners, and his defiance of Moscow gave him a new tinge of nationalism. In the wake of the Soviet challenge, his middle-of-the-road approach began to seem safer than the radical proposals of the reformers. Started as a Blacksmith **********Stanislaw Kania was born on March 8, 1927, to a peasant family in Wrocanka, near Jaslo, in southeastern Poland. An apprentice blacksmith when World War II broke out, he joined the resistance movement. Soon after the end of the war, he enrolled in what was then the Polish Workers' Party. **********Rising steadily through administrative posts, Mr. Kania was chosen after the bloody riots in northern Poland in 1970 to replace the security chief, Mieczyslaw Moczar. The same riots led to the ouster of Wladyslaw Gomulka as party chief and to his replacement by Edward Gierek. **********Ten years later, it was Mr. Gierek who fell from power in a new wave of workers' disruptions, again over economic conditions. Mr.  Kania was named to the top post. **********Throughtout the last year of crises, Mr. Kania has remained largely out of public view, making few speeches or appearances. His predecessor, Mr. Gierek, led a conspicuously flashy life that ultimately aroused strong resentment and accusations corruption. Mr.  Kania, on the other hand, reportedly lives in the same modest flat that he had before becoming First Secretary. No Puns Concerning His Name **********Little is known of his family life. A bulky man who keeps his receding hair close-cropped, Mr. Kania has no known hobbies, and no anecdotes are told about him. His name in Polish is also the name of a popular edible mushroom, but even this has failed to generate any popular puns. At this year's May Day parade, Mr. Kania shunned the traditional grandstand and walked alongside ordinary marchers. **********In his politics, Mr. Kania is considered a conservative but pragmatic functionary who lacks imagination and creativity but believes in the basic doctrines of Communism. Although he is thought to have little sympathy for Poland's powerful Catholic Church or for dissidents, he has demonstrated an ability to compromise with both.  His political survival is attributed in large part to his success in staking out a middle ground and in seeking to forge a consensus. **********Mr. Kania's future will require more than political skills. His survival in office is likely to hinge on his ability to forge a functional economic program and then to push it through against the likely resistance of Solidarity and consumers. His struggle for reelection at the party congress suggested that he will have to work hard to achieve control over the party apparatus, and the Kremlin is not given to restoring lost confidences. **********But in contrast to his predecessors who raised great expectations on coming to office, Mr. Kania is returning to his post with few public illusions about the hardships ahead.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/world.main_headline: BAKER SUPPORTS ADDED ADVISERS FOR EL SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/world.print_headline: BAKER SUPPORTS ADDED ADVISERS FOR EL SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/world.body_text: **********Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader, said today after a discussion with President Reagan that he supported sending as many as 150 United States military advisers to El Salvador. **********Senator Baker said no combat advisers were being considered. He added, ''It is entirely appropriate to dispatch noncombat advisers to tell those people how to defend themselves against Cuba.'' **********In the House, the Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations opened hearings on the issue of increased assistance. **********Fear of 'Gunboat Diplomacy' **********Representative Clarence D. Long, Democrat of Maryland, chairman of the subcommittee, said the Administration wanted the current level of military aid, $10.4 million, increased by an amount between $25 million and $40 million. **********The United States now has 19 military advisers in El Salvador plus its regularly stationed military attaches. Mr. Long opposed sending the additional advisers, because he said the move would be seen in Latin America as ''gunboat diplomacy all over again.'' **********A debate over the Administration's plans to increase the military aid, particularly the issue of advisers, has intensified on Capitol Hill since the State Department began its campaign against what it describes as Soviet-bloc shipment of arms to left-wing guerrillas in El Salvador. **********Apparently because of a meeting between President Reagan and his economic advisers, the White House postponed a National Security Council discussion of plans for increasing military aid to El Salvador. The discussion may be rescheduled tomorrow or Friday. **********The Pentagon has prepared recommendations for sending new equipment, including patrol boats, helicopters, communications and radar, that would help El Salvador's armed forces cut off the flow of smuggled arms to the guerrillas. Former Ambassador Testifies **********Robert E. White, whom Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  dismissed earlier this month as United States ambassador to El Salvador, told the foreign operations subcommittee that social reform and ''political reconciliation'' were the means to defeat the leftwing guerrillas. He also said that he opposed a major increase in military aid, asserting that it would weaken El Salvador's civilian leadership, headed by President Jose Napoleon Duarte. **********Mr. White said that Salvadoran security forces, in their campaign against the guerrillas and their sympathizers, had been responsible for killing at least 6,000 people, ''often just on suspicion.'' **********''Are we really going to send military advisers in there to be part of that kind of machinery?'' he asked.  In response to questions from Representative Jack Kemp, Republican of Buffalo, who defended the Administration's plans, Mr. White said that the ''Marxist-Leninist guerrillas'' lacked popular support and could be defeated by the Salvadoran armed forces, with modest United States arms supplies. **********Mr. White, a career diplomat who has not accepted reassignment to the State Department's corps of inspectors, also said that in January, while he was still ambassador, he opposed a Pentagon plan to send 75 military advisers to El Salvador. **********Also appearing before Mr. Long's subcommittee was John Bushnell, acting Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American affairs, who said that both economic and military aid increases would be necessary to assist El Salvador's Government in its campaign to defeat the leftist insurgency. Preference for Economic Aid **********The Salvadoran Government has said that economic aid would be of higher importance than military aid in the struggle against the guerrillas. While conceding that helicopters and communications equipment were needed, the country's military leaders have said that they could defeat the insurgents on their own. Both civilian and military officials in El Salvador say that the battle with the guerrillas is centered on social issues and that economic aid would help them win. **********The Carter Administration had approved $10.4 million in military aid to El Salvador, including an emergency shipment of ammunition, rifles, food rations and combat gear in January, after the Salvadoran armed forces had quelled a general uprising by the guerrillas. **********For the current fiscal year, the authorization of economic aid for El Salvador, a country of 4.5 million people, is $63 million.  Mr. Bushnell said that economic assistance would have to be increased, with the additional amount dependent on ''the further damage to the Salvadoran economy which the guerrillas are able to inflict'' and the response from other international lenders to El Salvador's requests for funds ''to reconstruct its economy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/25/busin.main_headline: 450,000 TONS OF CORN BOUGHT BY SOVIET UNION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/25/busin.print_headline: 450,000 TONS OF CORN BOUGHT BY SOVIET UNION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/25/busin.body_text: **********The Soviet Union has bought 450,000 metric tons of United States corn for delivery after Sept. 30, the date a current five-year grain agreement between the two countries expires, the Agriculture Department said today. **********The disclosure came hours after an announcement that the United States and the Soviet Union would meet early next month in Vienna to talk over a possible new grain agreement between the two countries. **********Officials said the sales - the first to the Soviet Union since the curtailment of grain shipments was ended three months ago - were reported to the department by private exporters as part of the regular export reporting procedure. **********Although the five-year agreement expires Sept. 30, the United States told the Soviet Union at a meeting in London in June that it could buy, without more consultation, up to 3 million metric tons of corn and 3 million of wheat for delivery before Oct. 1. **********Also, the Russians were told then that they could buy ''reasonable quantities'' of grain for delivery on or after Oct. 1. The sales announced today were in that category. **********Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said the new purchases ''are consistent'' with the talks held in London.  ''The United States has worked hard to develop the Soviet market, as well as to expand farm product sales in other parts of the world,'' Mr. Block said. **********Mr. Block also said ''American farmers have invested their own labor and capital in producing for export,'' and added, ''It is right and fair that they have the opportunity to compete for those markets, including the Soviet Union, and to benefit in terms of income.'' **********After President Carter ordered a curtailment of grain shipments to the Soviet Union on Jan. 4, 1980, in response to its military intervention in Afghanistan, sales of wheat and corn were restricted to no more than 8 million metric tons a year - an amount specified in the five-year agreement. **********A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat or 39.4 bushels of corn.  President Reagan ended the curtailment April 24, raising hopes that the Soviet Union would soon be back in the market for significant amounts of United States grain. **********The five-year agreement resulted after the Russians began buying huge amounts of United States grain six years ago. It was put into effect Oct. 1, 1976, and covered only wheat and corn. **********In the first year of the pact, the Soviet Union bought 6.1 million tons of grain; 14.6 million in the second year, and 15.5 million in the third. **********The Russians were told in the fall of 1979 that they could buy 25 million tons of United States grain during the fourth year of the agreement. But 17 million of that was canceled under the curtailment, leaving the Russians to buy 8 million in the fourth year and -from the way it looks now - only 8 million in the fifth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Minolta Photo Shifted to Esty
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/busin.body_text: **********Following a competition between its old agency, Bozell & Jacobs, and three other shops, the Minolta Corporation has decided to switch its photographic division account to one of the three, the William Esty Company. Billings are put at between $12 million and $15 million. **********While Esty is doing advertising for the Japanese-made Minolta cameras, lenses, flash units and other accessories, B.&J. will continue to do public relations work for Minolta as well as advertising for Minolta business equipment, which has a $5 million budget. **********The other agencies in the running were Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample and Marschalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies.  In the market for 35-millimeter single-lens cameras, in which about 2.2 million units are sold annually, Minolta is second only to Canon Inc., according to James D. DeMerlier, director of marketing for Minolta, who also says that, over all, there are more Minolta cameras sold than any other brand. Esty is also the agency for the Datsun automobile, made by Nissan Motor in Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/09/busin.main_headline: HIGH COURT DECLINES ROLE ON IRAN ASSETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/09/busin.print_headline: HIGH COURT DECLINES ROLE ON IRAN ASSETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/09/busin.body_text: **********The Supreme Court today declined a chance for immediate involvement in the legal dispute over the President's authority to take control of billions of dollars of frozen Iranian assets. **********The money, much of it still tied up by Federal court orders, is scheduled to be transferred out of the country on July 19 under the terms of the hostage release agreement with Iran. **********The Court denied a request by a subsidiary of the Dallas-based Electronic Data Systems Corporation for an expedited review of Presidential orders designed to cary out the agreement. In 1979, before the American hostages were seized in Teheran, E.D.S. won a $19 million breach-of-contract suit against Iran. Four months ago, the company went back to the Federal court to protect that judgment against a transfer order. **********Enjoined by District Court **********A Federal District Court in Texas enjoined the Government from taking control of the $19 million. The Government has appealed that ruling to the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, but E.D.S., which is headed by H. Ross Perot, a Dallas financier, was asking the Supreme Court, in effect, to skip the mid-level appeal and take up the case itself. **********The Justice Department, in a memorandum filed last week, told the Justices that it did not regard as subject to the release agreement those Iranian assets that had been won in court cases by American companies before President Carter froze all Iranian assets on Nov.  14, 1979. For that reason, the department said, E.D.S. was not actually affected by the subsequent Presidential orders and its case did not raise those legal questions that might need resolution by July 19. **********However, the Supreme Court will still have a chance to review the underlying issues. Dames & Moore, an engineering and research company based in Los Angeles, told the Court last week that it planned to bring an appeal this week from an adverse Federal court decision in California. Unlike E.D.S., Dames & Moore has claimed Iranian assets that apparently are subject to the July 19 transfer. **********Two E.D.S. employees were jailed by the late Shah's Government on Dec. 28, 1978, several months after Iran stopped making payments under a contract with the company, apparently in connection with allegations of corruption involving American companies and Iranian officials. The Shah's Government demanded a $12.75 million payment, which it said was owed by the company. The employees escaped from the prison on Feb. 11, 1979, when a revolutionary mobbed stormed it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/18/world.main_headline: OUTCRY OVER FIRE IMPERILS MEXICO CITY'S SCAVENGERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/18/world.print_headline: OUTCRY OVER FIRE IMPERILS MEXICO CITY'S SCAVENGERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/18/world.body_text: **********As firemen aimed high-pressure hoses at deep piles of smoldering garbage, the scavengers, old and young, men and women, went about their chores, picking out bottles, cans, cloth, plastic bags and cartons for resale and ignoring the toxic fumes enveloping them. **********''I don't know what the fuss is about,'' Felipe Estrada Menendez, a heavily-built 44-year-old, said angrily. ''We live and work here all the time and the worst we have is a little sore throat. The complaints in the press are lies.'' **********For almost two weeks a fire in the Santa Cruz Meyehualco dump has spewed soot and smoke across this sprawling city, bringing a public outcry. **********But the scavengers, known locally as ''pepenadores,'' resent the attention suddenly being given to the problem of disposing of 7,000 tons of urban waste each day. Garbage is their livelihood and almost any solution, such as construction of a new processing plant, is a threat. Payments Bought Protection **********The 7,000 or so pepenadores, though, are not without friends. As in many major cities, garbage is a lucrative business here, creating small fortunes for the officials and political bosses who control it. And by paying for the right to scavenge, the pepenadores have bought themselves protection. **********A job among the flies and rats and rotting food of the Meyehualco dump hardly seems like a privilege. Yet access to the scavengers' union is eagerly sought by the unemployed and tightly controlled by its leader, Rafael Gutierrez Moreno, who is also a member of Congress from the governing party. **********A powerful figure who is feared by his followers and does not welcome inquiries into his affairs, Mr. Gutierrez Moreno not only decides who will work in the dump, he also monopolizes the resale business. He takes the earnings on all the tin collected in the dump and receives a commission on other sales. **********In the 150-acre dump, a team of sturdy ''cabos,'' or corporals, assign scavengers to specific areas, reserving the freshest piles of garbage for those who give them small tips. They are also in charge of chasing away outsiders. ''Do you have permission to be here?'' 12-year-old Jose Ruiz asked a recent visitor. ''If not, you're in trouble.'' A Sharp Eye for Valuables **********The scavengers, most of whom live in shacks on the periphery of the dump, usually earn 150 to 300 pesos a day - $6.25 to $12.50 - but are sometimes luckier. ''You can find watches, gold chains, rings and other valuables thrown away by mistake,'' a pepenador explained.  ''You have to know how to look. It takes experience.'' **********But they complain bitterly about the drivers of the municipal garbage trucks who, they claim, remove the best items from the trash before it arrives at the dump. ''When there's a good load, you can hear the clink of bottles, tin and metal as it's tipped out,'' Mr.  Estrada Menendez, himself a cabo, explained, ''but most of the time, they bring little.'' **********On top of that, he said, the drivers charge the equivalent of a dollar to unload in a specific place.  The drivers, however, form part of a profit-making chain that begins with the street cleaner and ends with the pepenador. Garbage collection, although theoretically a public service with an annual budget of $3 million, has many of the trappings of private enterprise. Long Line of Entrepreneurs **********The street cleaner, for example, often accepts trash from homes and stores in exchange for a tip. He must then pay the truck drivers who empty his load. The drivers, in turn, charge to collect garbage on their rounds but pick out all salable items before driving to Meyehualco or Santa Fe, the city's other open-air dump. **********The 11,500 sanitation workers have their own union to defend their interests and pay monthly dues of $4.25, part of which is reportedly distributed among municipal officials in charge of garbage collection. **********Even before the recent fire in the Meyehualco dump, however, dissatisfaction with the sanitation service was growing. While streets are kept clean and garbage is collected in more affluent or commercial parts of town, city trucks rarely visit poorer districts where trash is often strewn on streets or dumped in open lots. **********But the Meyehualco fire, which began mysteriously on March 12 and quickly engulfed 40 acres of the dump, not only drew angry protests from residents but also highlighted the environmental disaster that the city is becoming. To the exhaust of two million vehicles and the smoke of hundreds of factories were added the sulfur dioxide fumes from Meyehualco. Reports of Invading Rats **********Newspapers had a field day, reporting that millions of residents were in peril, that hundreds of thousands of huge rats had invaded the neighborhoods around the dump and that the remains of numerous murder victims had been found by firemen among the smoking rubbish. **********The city authorities tried hard to play down the risks to the population, announcing daily for more than a week that the fire was about to be extinguished. But environmental officials conceded that sulfur dioxide levels in the air had increased tenfold and that toxic substances in some parts of the city were double those considered safe. **********Out of the crisis, though, came a new pledge by the city government to close down the 35-year-old Meyehualco dump, which was once on the southeast edge of the city but is now surrounded by poor neighborhoods. A new garbage-processing plant will be opened by next year, officials promised, and Meyehualco will be turned into a park. **********But the worried pepenadores are already preparing to protest.  ''We've lost a lot in the fire,'' one young man said, waving toward an expanse of blackened garbage. ''Now they want to take our jobs.  Our families have worked here since before I was born. What else can we do?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/27/world.main_headline: SOLIDARITY OPENS THE SECOND PHASE OF GDANSK PARLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/27/world.print_headline: SOLIDARITY OPENS THE SECOND PHASE OF GDANSK PARLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/27/world.body_text: **********The Solidarity union opened the second phase of its national convention here today with invited American labor leaders absent, with Soviet reporters watching like hawks and with moderates and militants clashing over the issue of workers' participation in the management of industries. **********Solidarity had invited three representatives of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., including Lane Kirkland, president of the 15-million-member organization, but they were not granted visas by the Polish Government. The Government, which has protested the financial support given to Solidarity by the A.F.L.-C.I.O, wants to discourage such expressions of fraternity from the United States. **********A videotape of Mr. Kirkland delivering a speech was in hand but could not be played immediately because proper equipment was lacking. Instead, printed texts of the speech circulated through the cavernous hall of the Olivia Sports Stadium. **********Kirkland Cites Polish Influence **********In the text, Mr. Kirkland spoke of Solidarity as an inspiration for workers the world over. He retraced the influence Poles have had on the American labor movement and found that it was substantial; Polish glassblowers, he said, conducted the first strike in the New World, near Jamestown, Va., in 1619. **********''You have brought a renewal not only for Poland,'' he said. ''You have renewed the spirit of workers around the world. Polish workers still continue to teach the world.'' **********The American labor leader asserted that there was ''no task more urgent than unlinking human rights and freedom from the question of who owns the means of production.'' **********''Respect for workers' rights does not automatically flow from any economic system,'' he said. Pledges 'Solidarity Forever' **********The text ended with a promise of support: ''To Solidarity, the workers of Poland, we pledge - in the words of an old American labor song - solidarity forever.'' **********The first round of the congress ended 15 days ago, and in the interim there have been increasingly strident warnings directed at the union from the Government, the Communist Party and the Soviet Union. But when the 824 delegates assembled beneath the 30-foot-long banners hanging from the rafters, there was little sign that any of this had worked to mitigate the mood of militancy. **********During a debate on whether to allow local televsion to cover the proceedings - the national state tele vision has been barred - one delegate rose to exclaim how wonderful it was to have television asking the un ion for access instead of the other way around. **********''If the TV news wants to speak, let them speak with Tass language - t-a-s-s,'' he added, spelling out the Soviet press agency in an ironic drawl. The Tass correspondent looked around and took notes surreptitiously. The congress voted to keep the Gdansk cameramen out. **********After the delegates greeted one another, today's meeting fell into the procedural wrangling that is characteristic of Poland's nascent democracy. But underneath was a growing dispute that threatens to preoccupy this second session, expected to last nine days. Compromise With Government **********At issue was a compromise that the union's leader ship offered to the Government over workers' participation in the management of industries. Some delegates grumbled that the leaders had no right to reach such an agreement without the approval of the congress or at least of the governing national commission. **********Only four union people, including Lech Walesa, Solidarity's chairman, were involved in the decision to seek a compromise. The formula that they agreed upon overcame an impasse on the question of which side - the workers or the state - should be empowered to hire and dismiss managing directors. **********The solution, to allow both sides to offer candidates and to retain the right to appeal to a court, broke a logjam of legislation that might set economic recovery in motion. Yesterday Parliament approved two bills, one of them including the compromise. **********Some union leaders, however, wanted to hold to an earlier position in which the workers would have the sole right to make managerial appointments and wanted to insist on a national referendum on the whole issue of worker self-management. The first phase of the congress had called for a referendum. **********Parliament Resisted Lead- ers **********Andrzej Celinski, who is secretary to Solidarity's executive body and is close to Mr. Walesa, termed the new law a ''victory.'' Pointing out that members of Parliament had resisted the Communist leadership's effort to water down the bill, he said such a spirit of independence had not been seen in the legislature in the last 36 years. **********But another union leader, Mieczyslaw Gil, who was Solidarity's chief negotiator on the issue, said the law was clearly ''not satisfactory.'' He suggested that the authorities were out to provoke a confrontation. **********Another said that the congress was the union's ''supreme authority'' and that its earlier resolution should not have been violated - a position that many delegates seemed to agree with. **********Privately, top leaders in the union said they expected heated arguments in the coming days. But they were confident the compromise arrangement would stand. At least 49 delegates were scheduled to speak on the topic.
