https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/06/busin.main_headline: 16-BILLION HOME LOAN SUPPORT AMONG CUTS REAGAN ORDERED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/06/busin.print_headline: 16-BILLION HOME LOAN SUPPORT AMONG CUTS REAGAN ORDERED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/06/busin.body_text: **********The White House disclosed today that President Reagan had made a $16 billion cut in Federal support for loans to purchase homes as the centerpiece of a larger effort to curb the Government's appetite for credit. **********In all, the President sent orders to Federal agencies to curtail loan guarantees by $20.3 billion between now and Sept. 30, 1982. The list included cuts for small business, rural development, exports, fishing vessels, trade adjustment, merchant ships and rail rehabilitation. **********The White House also called for complete elimination of guarantees for biomass energy development, defense production and community development. **********In addition, the White House said that Mr. Reagan wanted to reduce guarantees issued for rural electrification and telephone service by $1 billion, or nearly 20 percent, but could not do so without legislation. Intention Stated Previously **********The White House list of cuts in loan guarantee commitment to be issued in the fiscal year 1982, which began Oct. 1, provided the detail to support the President's Sept. 24 statement of intentions. **********Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist of the Office of Management and Budget, told reporters that ''this is a first step'' and that further curtailments would be made for the fiscal years 1983 and 1984. **********The Administration wants to shrink Federal guarantees of private loans, Mr. Kudlow said, because such loans, no less than Treasury borrowing to finance the budget deficit, ''pre-empt private capital and saving.'' **********The Reagan Administration, like the Carter Administration, has said that so-called off-budget borrowing by the Treasury and the issuance of Federal loan guarantees as a substitute for Federal dollars had grown rapidly in the 1970's and gotten out of hand. Rapidly Growing Involvement **********The White House contended that by borrowing directly and by assisting private borrowing, Washington now was ''absorbing'' more than 40 percent of the supply of credit available to nonfinancial borrowers, against 5 percent from 1955 to 1969 and 15 percent in the 1970's. **********Mr. Kudlow asserted that by reducing its role in credit markets, the Government would help make credit generally more available and would contribute to a decline in interest rates, all of which would help home buyers and business borrowers. However, those who lose access to subsidized interest rates - or to all credit -were expected to reply that the disadvantages to them would far outweigh the benefits. **********The largest single curtailment was $16 billion, or 25 percent, for mortage guarantees issued by the Government National Mortgage Association, or Ginnie Mae. Its guarantees make blocks of mortgages more attractive to investors, thereby bringing fresh money into financial institutions that originate home loans. **********Jack Carlson, executive vice president of the National Association of Realtors, said the loss of Ginnie Mae guarantees would make it harder for buyers of existing houses to find financing. The White House said that the effect on construction of new houses would be slight because Ginnie Mae loans account ''for less than 5 percent of financing for new housing construction.'' **********Other large cuts included $1 billion, or a 20 percent reduction, for the Small Business Administration and $1.2 billion, or 14.6 percent less, for the Export-Import Bank. **********Officials said that they believed the President's authority to limit loan guarantees did not violate anti-impoundment provisions of the 1974 budget act but that the question had not come up before and might be tested in the courts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/08/world.main_headline: YOUNG U.S. JOURNALIST MISSING IN EL SALVADOR: A DETERMINED NOVICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/08/world.print_headline: YOUNG U.S. JOURNALIST MISSING IN EL SALVADOR: A DETERMINED NOVICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/08/world.body_text: **********John J. Sullivan, the 26-year-old Bogota, N.J., freelance writer reported missing in El Salvador, was described yesterday as a man with one purpose in life - to be a journalist. **********''He was so determined to succeed as a journalist he quit a wellpaying union job to look for work as a writer,'' Malcolm S.  Forbes, president and editor in chief of Forbes magazine said yesterday. **********''My guess is that if he had an opportunity to see the guerrilla side down there, he would have seized it without worrying about the danger.'' **********A letter from Mr. Forbes commending Mr. Sullivan was among personal papers found in Mr. Sullivan's hotel room in San Salvador after the freelance writer disappeared more than a week ago. ''I thought highly of him and admired his ambition,'' Mr. Forbes said yesterday. Investigation Into Disappearance **********United States Embassy officials in San Salvador fear that Mr.  Sullivan may have been the victim of political violence. He went to El Salvador on assignment for Hustler magazine and checked into the Sheraton Hotel in the capital on Dec. 28. He spent only one night there, according to hotel workers, leaving behind a camera, a tape recorder and a typewriter. The ruling civilian-military junta has ordered an investigation into his disappearance, a Salvadoran Government spokesman said today. **********Seven Americans have been killed in El Salvador in the past five weeks, including four Roman Catholic missionaries and two men working in the country's land redistribution program. The farm experts were killed Saturday night while eating dinner at the Sheraton Hotel in San Salvador. **********Mr. Sullivan tried various odd jobs after graduating from Bogota High School. Then he went to work in the composing room at The Daily News in New York, where his father, John J. Sullivan, is employed as a photoengraver. **********''But what my brother really wanted to do was write,'' Donna Igoe of Bergenfield, N.J., an older sister, said yesterday. ''He took different courses in journalism, and went to Brazil and taught himself Portuguese and freelanced in Nicaragua, and taught himself Spanish, and was always writing stories and trying to get on a paper.'' **********Mrs. Igoe described her brother as over six feet tall, with ''dark brown hair, full beard and, if I must say so myself, very handsome.'' He returned to his parents' home in Bogota about a year ago, she said, after spending a year in Brazil, and had spent the last year ''trying to get a journalism job on a more permanent basis'' in New York. **********In Rio de Janeiro, Mr. Sullivan wrote columns about local matters that appeared in an English-language newspaper and also did some work for Forbes magazine and ABC Radio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/24/world.main_headline: MEMOIRS BY SADAT FRIEND TIE FORMER OFFICIAL TO FINANCIAL MISCONDUCT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/24/world.print_headline: MEMOIRS BY SADAT FRIEND TIE FORMER OFFICIAL TO FINANCIAL MISCONDUCT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/24/world.body_text: **********Publication of the autobiography of President Sadat's closest friend has created an uproar here because it contains allegations of financial misconduct by a former Prime Minister and by two daughters of Gamal Abdel Nasser. **********The book, ''Pages From My Experience,'' is by Osman Ahmed Osman, a self-made millionaire contractor whose company built the Aswan High Dam. Mr. Osman is now a Deputy Prime Minister with broad powers and complete access to President Sadat. One of his sons is married to a Sadat daughter. **********The book, whose first edition of 65,000 copies sold out quickly, is now unavailable but the scandalous passages have been published in the Egyptian press. **********Mr. Osman's memoir named no names but his descriptions of the people involved in the financial mischief were such that Egyptians were able to indentify them almost immediately. **********Those identified have since written angry letters of denial to Cairo newspapers and threatened to sue Mr. Osman.  Mr. Sadat has ordered a special committee of Parliament to investigate the charges and denials. The committee, which one Government official said would be mired for a long time in closed hearings, is to begin its inquiry next week. **********One of Mr. Osman's charges was that President Nasser's daughters had paid only $8,600 for houses worth about $140,000. The charge has been denied by Ashraf Marwan, a former Sadat favorite who is married to one of President Nasser's daughters. Mr. Marwan, speaking for the Nasser family, said he planned legal action ''to stop all defamatory charges reflecting on our honor and reputation.'' **********Mr. Osman also charged that a former Prime Minister of Egypt was involved in a real estate scam in which Cairo property was sold at a fifth of its value to non-Egyptian interests in exchange for shares in business ventures. **********The former Prime Minister, Abdel Aziz Hegazi, has said he will document his innocence before the committee of Parliament investigating the matter. Mr. Hegazi served as Mr. Sadat's Prime Minister from 1974 to 1975, when he was dismissed without public explanation. **********Financial chicanery and skimming is not at all rare in Egypt. What makes this case interesting is that it is being given an airing in the Government-controlled press, which normally avoids reporting about scandal and corruption. **********Mr. Sadat commented on the book controversy in this week's edition of May, a newspaper the President created last month. Mr. Sadat said he had not read Mr. Osman's book until after excerpts appeared in the press. ''Then I ordered an investigation immediately,'' he said. **********Mr. Sadat said that ''agitators'' had erroneously informed the Nasser family that ''Sadat is the one who asked Osman to write what he wrote.'' **********''The Communists and agitators have not stopped rejoicing because they think Osman has fallen,'' the President went on, ''and they think it means the fall of the whole system because Osman is a relative of Sadat.'' **********In the interview, Mr. Sadat said he could not comment on his friend's book ''until the matter comes before the law-making authorities.'' He said he planned to ask the Cabinet to consider some sort of censorship of books written by public officials.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/world.main_headline: BLACK CLERIC BACK IN SOUTH AFRICA BUT BOTHA IS FIRM OVER PASSPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/world.print_headline: BLACK CLERIC BACK IN SOUTH AFRICA BUT BOTHA IS FIRM OVER PASSPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/world.body_text: **********Bishop Desmond Tutu returned here today from a 10-nation tour and declared, in a manner that was too ebullient to be described merely as unrepentant, that he regretted none of the remarks that provoked Prime Minister P.W. Botha to threaten to confiscate his passport. **********''Given the opportunity again, I will repeat precisely what I have said,'' the outspoken black cleric said. He then proceeded to do so at a news conference in which he said again that economic pressure from abroad was necessary if South Africa's racial conflicts were to be resolved by peaceful means. The Bishop, an Anglican, is General Secretary of the South African Council of Churches. **********Not long after Bishop Tutu's news conference, Mr. Botha appeared at a rally in Cape Town, where he reiterated his determination to lift the cleric's passport. **********''When you travel on a passport granted to you, you must behave,'' Mr. Botha said. ''You cannot use the privilege granted to you and then misuse it to organize boycotts against your country. I repeat, Bishop Tutu's passport will definitely be withdrawn.'' Favored for Peace Prize **********Six hours after his arrival at Jan Smuts Airport, Bishop Tutu still had his passport. Some Afrikaans-language newspapers have observed that the confiscation of Bishop Tutu's passport might help to enhance his chance of winning the Nobel Peace Prize, for which he has reportedly been nominated. **********But Mr. Botha's threat came in the midst of a political campaign - the all-white electorate goes to the polls in three weeks - and it seemed likely that it would have to be made good, if only to prevent right-wing opponents from declaring that the Government had backed down in the face of international pressure. Bishop Tutu's last stop was Rome. **********The encouragement of disinvestment by foreign companies or economic sanctions against South Africa can be defined as ''terrorism'' under South African law. Bishop Tutu has stopped short, therefore, of saying what sort of ''economic pressure'' he would like to see the West impose. Asked about the response he got from officials he met, he threw back his head and laughed. ''There was a fair degree of coyness,'' he said. Two Answers for Whites **********A reporter from the South African Broadcasting Corporation asked whether blacks would not suffer most in the unlikely event that the West heeded the kind of pleas that the Bishop has been making. He had been asked that question by a number of foreigners, Bishop Tutu said, and always replied that there were two answers that blacks give. **********''You benefited from black cheap labor, black migratory labor, black misery,'' he said, repeating the first of them. ''How can you so suddenly become altruistic and now suddenly worry about black suffering when you have benefited from them for so long? **********''That is the rougher answer,'' he went on. ''The nicer answer is to say that blacks are suffering now.'' Having a passport confiscated, the Bishop said, was not the worst thing that could happen to a Christian. Even getting killed was not the worst thing. ''For me one of the worst things would be if I woke up one day and said to people, 'I think apartheid is not so bad,' '' the Bishop said to general laughter. He was still laughing himself when he said, ''For me that would be worse than death.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/13/world.main_headline: CARTER SAYS POSSIBILITY THAT HOSTAGES WILL BE FREED NOW 'LOOKS BETTER'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/13/world.print_headline: CARTER SAYS POSSIBILITY THAT HOSTAGES WILL BE FREED NOW 'LOOKS BETTER'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/13/world.body_text: **********President Carter said today that the possibility of freeing the hostages in Iran before he leaves office ''looks better,'' but he cautioned that he was still unable to predict success in the negotiations. **********With only four days left before the Administration's self-imposed deadline for dealing with the crisis, the President's comments to reporters reflected the wariness of officials at the White House and State Department about the latest developments in Teheran, which have stirred hope among some officials here that a breakthrough might be near. **********In Teheran, the Government introduced two pieces of emergency legislation in Parliament to help expedite an agreement. One would authorize the Government to conduct binding arbitration regarding claims against Iran's frozen assets in the United States; the other would ''nationalize'' the wealth of the late Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and 53 of his relatives. This last bill was apparently drawn up with an eye toward United States court cases in which Washington has agreed to seek waivers of laws protecting the property of former monarchs. **********(On Tuesday, the Iranian Parliament was forced to postpone action until Wednesday because not enough members of Iran's Council of Guardians were present.) **********Several American officials said that the statements of the Iranian authorities today appeared to indicate a sincere desire to resolve the crisis by the time Mr. Carter leaves office a week from tomorrow. But virtually every official also reminded reporters of previous hopes raised during the 14-month crisis only to be dashed later. Christopher Remains in Algiers **********Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher remained in Algiers for the fifth day, keeping in contact through the Algerian Government with the three-man Algerian team of intermediaries in Teheran. **********Mr. Carter, outside a Washington restaurant, said he had spoken by phone earlier with Mr. Christopher. ''It looks better, but I can't predict success,'' he said. ''That depends on them. We made a reasonable offer.'' **********John H. Trattner, the State Department spokesman, repeated again today that Mr. Christopher still was reporting that ''serious problems remain.'' Intermediaries Are Praised **********In Algiers, Mr. Trattner said Mr. Christopher called on President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria to express American appreciation for the ''high sense of propriety, the impartiality and discretion'' of the intermediaries. Mr. Trattner said that the courtesy call did not signal a breakthough or an end to the negotiations. **********The almost daily repetition of ''serious problems remain'' has become the Administration's diplomatic shorthand for saying that Iran has not replied formally to the latest American proposals. Until a formal reply is received and until it becomes clear that the two sides are officially in agreement, officials say the United States has to regard the positions as being far apart. **********Various indirect signals, including the questions asked by Iran about the most recent American proposals, have led officials to believe that Iran has substantially altered its position to bring it closer into line with that of Washington. But until a formal response is received, Mr. Trattner said, this could only be regarded as conjecture. **********Crucial to any breakthrough would be Iran's formal agreement to free the hostages before it has gotten back all the money it has claimed was frozen by the United States. Earlier, Iran had sought $14 billion, but now, according to officials, Teheran seems to be willing to accept the American estimate that only $9.5 billion was frozen. **********Judging by the legislation introduced in the Iranian Parliament today, Iran also may be willing to free the hostages with only assurances of receiving $5.5 billion simultaneously and $1.8 billion within a week or so, making a total of $7.3 billion that would be promptly available to Iran. Claims Appear to Be Lower **********The legislation introduced in Parliament would allow Iran to agree to binding international arbitration of the remaining $2.2 billion in frozen assets that are claimed by Americans. Until now, Iran has said it would not free the hostages until all the money was returned or an equivalent amount placed in escrow. **********Timing is a problem. Unless Iran responds officially in the next four days in a way that is completely acceptable to Washington, officials say the Administration will not have enough time before Inauguration Day to assemble the necessary assets to send to Algiers for eventual transfer to Iran in return for the simultaneous release of the hostages. **********If Iran delays or introduces some new element it is likely that the crisis will have to be turned over to the Reagan administration. **********---- Christopher Awaits Decision Special to the New York Times **********ALGIERS, Jan. 12 - American negotiators and Algerian intermediaries here anxiously awaited the outcome today of the debate in the Iranian Parliament on proposals for solving the hostage problem. **********The American team, headed by Deputy Secretary of State Warren M.  Christopher, and the Algerian Government both maintained strict official silence on the progress of the negotiations, fearing that a statement might be misinterpreted in Iran and jeopardize a settlement. **********However, Algerian sources close to the negotiations expressed relative optimism that an accord was within reach, barring lastminute complications in the Iranian Parliament. On the American side, it was stressed that a decision by Mr. Christopher to postpone his return to Washington was ''an encouraging sign.'' ---- Reagan Gets Optimistic Report Special to the New York Times **********LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 - President-elect Ronald Reagan said today that he had received reports showing a ''reason for optimism'' regarding the hostages, and he said he thought President Carter was negotiating for their release ''on the basis that we can all agree to.'' **********But Mr. Reagan repeated previous comments that he would not automatically agree to anything Mr. Carter negotiated without inspecting it first. ''I hope and pray and I think that the President is negotiating on a basis that we can all agree to,'' Mr. Reagan said. ''On the other hand, I don't think anyone should be asked to sign a blank check.'' **********Asked to comment on President Carter's remark that things were looking up for the hostages, Mr. Reagan said: ''Well, I understand that there is optimism, and I have my fingers crossed, and hope there's reason for it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/12/busin.main_headline: THE RETURN OF THE RADIO NETWORK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/12/busin.print_headline: THE RETURN OF THE RADIO NETWORK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/12/busin.body_text: **********S OMEWHERE back in the murky days of yesteryear, decades before the advent of Laverne and Shirley and Archie and Edith, network radio ruled the air waves. Now, while much of the media world stands agog at the upheavals to be wrought by new video technologies, a curious radio revolution is occurring. The old radio networks are storming back, and new ones are being formed at an astonishing pace. **********Within just the last two weeks, four new networks were announced, two each by the RKO Radio Network and the Satellite Music Network.  Last November, the Wall Street Journal's 50-city radio network went on the air and in January a sports network called Enterprise Radio began. The impetus? Advertising. Network radio is one of the fastestgrowing large advertising media, having increased its billings 23 percent in 1980, to $157 million, and in the first quarter this by more than 25 percent. **********As yet, such spending isn't much of a threat to competing media - the advertising bill in the United States last year was $54.75 billion. But the amount of programming that radio networks offer their affiliates has grown enormously since the 1960's when the four existing networks - ABC, CBS, NBC and the Mutual Broadcasting System - were primarily news services. By the end of this year there should be 19 national radio networks, many of them feeding programming such as concerts, sports events, talk shows and dramas. **********Generally, radio networks send their affiliates programming that contains national commercials and free time to be sold to local advertisers. Networks usually pay affiliates ''compensation'' - an average 17 percent of billings -for airing their shows and commercials. **********''Network radio is exploding,'' says Ira Berger, network supervisor at the Needham, Harper & Steers ad agency in Chicago. ''Much of its increased billing is coming directly out of network TV because the price of TV has gotten so high that many advertisers are looking for ways to spend more efficiently. Network radio can be a very good, fairly cheap way of covering the whole country.'' **********There is something resembling irony here. Three of the radio networks luring dollars away from network television have initials that most television viewers would recognize. **********The new radio networks are appealing to advertisers much as magazines and cable television do, by cultivating particular demographic groups, which are hard to target through network television. Two radio networks cater to blacks and one is aimed at physicians. **********''In 1960 we were a terrible medium,'' says Robert M. Chambers, general manager of the ABC Radio Networks. ''In recent years we've put more emphasis on programming because the advertisers want it and the affiliates demand it. Stations want something from us - concerts, lifestyle features, etc., that will distinguish them from the guy across the street who's playing the same records.'' **********Indeed, the RKO Radio Networks' president, Thomas F. Burchill, contends that increased competition between radio stations has helped spur the resurgence of radio networks. **********''In 1968,'' he says, ''there were 4,000 radio stations. Ten years later there were almost 8,000, mostly because of the growth of FM.  Now stations need additional resources to compete effectively, and many things they can't afford to produce themselves.'' **********These days ''instant'' radio networks are often formed by program syndicaters in conjunction with advertising agencies. (Satellite transmission is making this much simpler.) These networks transmit programming only infrequently and their ''affiliates'' can vary extensively from week to week. Regional networks, such as what Phil Rizzuto calls ''the New York Yankees baseball network'' are also popular. Finally, many radio sales concerns will put together an unwired national network for advertisers willing to sponsor different shows in dozens of cities. **********Network executives have learned from the success of radio syndicators that concert specials invariably improve ratings. This year, RKO will present at least 12 of them and ABC, which aired just one in 1978, will broadcast 100. **********There's a special reason for RKO's entry into network radio. Mr.  Birchill says the company feared that Federal Communications Commission rulings might prevent it from growing in the stationoperating business. In the late 70's, RKO General was worried that the F.C.C. might strip it of all its television and radio stations as retribution for filing false financial reports with the commission and, more importantly, because its parent, General Tire & Rubber, had confessed to making many improper payoffs at home and abroad and had been accused by the F.C.C. of forcing its customers to buy commercial time from RKO. In January 1980, the commission refused to renew three RKO television station licenses. The case is now in the courts. **********Profits can flow very fast in the network business. Mr. Burchill says RKO I became profitable after just 10 months. Bill Rasmussen, creator of the Enterprise sports network and the ESPN Cable TV sports network, says his radio operation, featuring a daily sports talk show that lasts an astounding 13 hours, will be in the black by the end of this year. Industry sources say that most networks yield returns of 20 to 25 percent per year, which helps explain the new interest. Mr. Burchill projects network revenues of at least $330 million by 1985, and perhaps as much as $500 million. **********N O radio network sounds more futuristic than the Satellite Music Network, created by Kent Burkhart, an Atlanta-based radio consultant, in partnership with John Tyler & Associates of Dallas; Midwest Broadcasting, owner of WCCO Radio in Minneapolis, and United Video of Tulsa. This summer Mr. Burkhart plans to introduce two 24-hour-a-day networks, one playing adult pop (Barbra Streisand, Barry Manilow) and the other contemporary country (Dolly Parton, Kenny Rogers). The twist here is that the disk jockeys would chatter to an entire nation. **********''We'll get revenue,'' says Mr. Burkhart, ''by selling two minutes per hour to national advertisers and by charging stations for using the service. For a local station, the economies are striking. They can cut their payroll dramatically. Many radio stations are getting hurt badly by rising costs and they need help. I expect two or three competitors by the end of the year, and eventually I think half the stations in the country will get their programming this way.'' **********Mr. Burkhart is encouraged by two statistics. More than 1,000 radio stations already devote most, if not all, of their broadcast hours to playing syndicated tapes, most often containing what is called ''beautiful music.'' And, according to 1979 F.C.C. figures, only 60 percent of commercial radio stations are profitable. **********The Big Four radio networks have not been caught sleeping. With the exception of Mutual, all are contemplating the creation of new networks. At NBC, Chuck Renwick was just given the full-time job of developing new networks and network services. Having lost almost $15 million in the mid-70's on its News and Information Service network, NBC rebounded well in 1979 by successfully starting a second full network, The Source, a lively blend of news, features and occasional music aimed at the 18-to-34 audience. By the end of the year NBC will broadcast a five-hour block of talk shows and is trying to create a network for women. **********CBS has been aggressively adding affiliates, sports events and life-style features. Its ''Mystery Theater'' has not exactly brought a return to the golden age of radio drama but it is doing moderately well. **********ABC has been investigating country and ''beautiful music'' networks. With 1,750 affiliates, ABC is the most profitable radio network, largely because it had the good sense in 1968 to split into four demographic segments - FM, Contemporary, Information and Entertainment. **********''It took a long time to get our story across to advertisers and agencies,'' is how ABC's Robert Chambers explains some rough years.  ''That's not quite the way I see it,'' says Gene DeWitt, director of media services (U.S.A.) for the McCann-Erickson ad agency. ''The radio networks kind of lucked out. The gouging by the TV networks drove dollars into their pockets. Nonetheless I'm thrilled with all the new programming they're doing.'' **********But Mr. DeWitt and a spokesman for Mutual, which is owned by the Amway Corporation, believe this luck may now hold.  ''The radio programming market is about to break open,'' says the Mutual spokesman. ''Eventually, local stations will receive a vast cornucopia of quality programming from the networks, and it's conceivable that very soon a station might take programming from many network sources.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/27/busin.body_text: **********Wall Street leaders appeared divided about the recent wave of brokerage house mergers as they gathered here today for the semiannual convention of the Securities Industry Association. **********Executives of large brokerage firms expressed cautious optimism about the Prudential Insurance Company's purchase of Bache Group Inc. and the American Express Company's bid to acquire Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc. But most heads of smaller regional firms were sharply critical of such mergers. The move toward consolidation, most delegates agreed, portended a major reshaping of the way financial services are provided in America. **********''It's too easy to say that these mergers will create a great delivery system for a set of yet-to-be-born products or already existing products that fit,'' said William J. Kneisel, a principal on the syndicate desk at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''What it's really going to mean in terms of financial services and new approaches is going to take a while to sort out.'' **********Comments From Delegates **********Asked whether the emergence of large financial institutions was a threat to independent brokerage houses, Watson B. Dabney, president of J.J.B. Hillard, W.L. Lyons Inc., a large regional concern based in Louisville, Ky., said: ''It doesn't mean that it's the end of small brokerage firms any more than it means the end of small banks. That's like saying that if you went across state banking lines, there would be nobody left but Manny Hanny, Citicorp and Morgan and so on.'' **********H. Virgil Sherrill, president of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, which is owned by Bache Group, commented on the merger with Prudential.  ''All the reaction I've had from everybody has been extremely positive,'' he said. ''I would say that maybe most of my competitors are just being complimentary, but they've all been very encouraging.'' **********During interviews in New York and Bermuda, several executives, particularly from small and medium-sized regional firms, expressed skepticism about consolidation. Some Prefer Independence **********''I'm just glad nobody wants to take us over,'' said Peter Eichler, president and chief executive officer of Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., based in Los Angeles. ''I think there may be some others to follow, but most of the firms out here would prefer to remain independent. **********''Unfortunately, the financial strength in this country is so heavily concentrated in the large insurance companies and the banks - their economic muscle far outdistances anything we have in the securities industry - that we are prey to these large offerings.'' Mr. Eichler added, ''I think we would be just as well to keep the business for ourselves. I hope this doesn't constitute a trend.'' **********Sanford C. Bernstein, chairman and president of Sanford C.  Bernstein & Company, said, ''I think it's going to become a more dehumanized business for the people involved in the conglomerate mergers.'' **********Mr. Bernstein questioned whether reshaping the financial industry would ultimately lead to better service to the public. As a result of this ''dehumanized budget environment,'' he said, ''There's going to be a greater stress on profits: The firms that are involved in these mergers are going to be driven more by money than service.'' **********He cited his firm's experience with tax shelters, the sort of service that one-stop financial groups might be expected to offer.  ''Our firm has refused to sell tax shelters,'' he said. ''That doesn't mean that we've seen every one of them and that there aren't some good ones being sold, but a lot of the ones being sold are not products that we'd put our name to. Conglomerates are going to push these kinds of products.'' **********This sentiment was echoed by W. Leslie Douglas, vice president of Folger Nolan Fleming Douglas Inc., of Washington. ''If an insurance or finance company buys a brokerage firm, the customer will be deluged with the offering of more services, most of which he won't want or need.'' he said. Outlook for the Customers **********Donald B. Marron, president of Paine Webber, is typical of executives who regard the mergers as harbingers of a new competitive environment on Wall Street. ''I think it's a very good thing for the customers,'' he said. ''We have an oligarchy in this industry. A small number of firms have a dominant role in the marketplace, and to compete in this environment is to improve the quality of your services. What this ought to do is provide a wider range of services and quality organizations at fair prices.'' **********Many of the executives from smaller firms felt that some employees, particularly stockbrokers, would be reluctant to work in large financial institutions. **********William C. Roney Jr., marketing partner with Wm. C. Roney & Company in Detroit, said: ''There are a lot of people who are not going to want to work for a giant company because most good people in our business have a pretty high entrepreneurial spirit, and I think they're likely to feel somewhat submerged in that sort of environment. Maybe bigger isn't always best.'' **********The effect that such mergers might have on the working environment at large brokerage firms also stirred some skepticism from Mr.  Eichler of Bateman Eichler. ''I think a lot of people are not going to want to be joining Shearson or Bache because they are subsidiaries of American Express or Prudential,'' he said. ''It might help them in capital, and it might be an aid to the underwriting side of our business, but I don't think it will help them necessarily in the brokerage part.'' A Personalized Operation **********As a group, however, people at most of the smaller regional firms seem optimistic about their future as independent brokerage houses.  Warren H. Berl, chairman of the Sutro Group, with headquarters in San Francisco, said: ''I believe that there is a certain element out there that would prefer to do business with a more personalized kind of operation then with one of the major service stations such as appears to be forming. I think that will probably increase the potential for a big regional firm, such as we are, in doing business with the individual client.'' **********Mr. Berl predicted that ''some of the major firms will go the way of Shearson and Bache, and others will go in the opposite direction - the Dean Witters and E.F. Huttons could very well buy an insurance company, for example, rather than being absorbed.'' **********Stephen Putnam, president of F.L. Putnam & Company, Boston, said that the recent merger activity ''obviously brings a great deal of capital to bear behind the brokerage dealers involved, and from that point of view, it could strengthen the industry.'' He added, ''I don't think it changes the outlook for regional firms significantly.'' **********Benjamin F. Edwards 3d, president of A.G. Edwards & Sons, a St.  Louis house widely cited as a possible takeover candidate, said: ''We plan to continue in the brokerage business. If other people want to diversify out of other businesses, that's fine with us.'' Role of Specialized Firms **********Felix G. Rohatyn, a partner at Lazard Freres & Company, said, ''From the point of view of a small and rather specialized firm, I don't think those particular mergers are going to have that much of an impact, because the services that we render to corporate clients are fairly specialized and depend on a few individuals within the firm, and that isn't going to change in my judgment.'' **********But he and others believe that the acquisitions are likely to increase pressure on Congress to soften the Glass-Steagall Act, which in effect bars banks from underwriting corporate securities. **********''The next step, which may be much more threatening, will be pressure from the large banks to either amend or repeal the Glass-Steagall Act and come into our industry directly either by acquiring firms or setting up their own,'' Mr. Rohatyn said. ''That would probably change the nature not only of the securities industry but also of our underlying economic structure. That would be quite significant and probably would lead us toward the German and Japanese relationships between the banks and industry.'' **********John B. Madden, a partner with Brown Brothers, Harriman & Company, remarked: ''A lot of people say you should put reserves on money funds and that sort of thing. Rather than doing that, you ought to free the banking industry from the restraints under which they have been placed and let everybody get out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/26/busin.body_text: **********Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, accused the Chase Manhattan Bank today of ''paying lip service only'' to Federal regulations requiring lending institutions to answer credit needs of their communities. **********At a House hearing, Thomas J. Murray, a Chase vice president, defended the bank's loan strategy, citing Chase's role as a national bank. **********Mr. Murray declined to discuss specifics of its loans, however, standing by Chase policy not to release information without the customer's express consent. **********''I wonder if the people of New York would be offended if they found out, like I found out, that you are lending more money in mortgages in Bethesda than in Brooklyn?'' the Queens Congressman asked, referring to a bank action in suburban Washington. **********One loan, on the mortgage to convert rental apartments in Bethesda, Md., into condominiums for sale, amounted to $29.2 million, Mr.  Rosenthal said, comparing that figure with the $18 million total he said Chase lent for condominium and cooperative conversion within New York City for all of 1980. **********''I think we're going to pursue this matter with a little more vigor than we have so far,'' said Mr. Rosenthal, chairman of the Government Operations Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs. **********''We'll have to hold a hearing in New York City, either in executive session in which you may want to be more forthcoming, or by way of a subpoena,'' he said. **********Chase Manhattan Bank has not followed the letter of the Community Reinvestment Act, which requires lenders to consider credit needs of their community, Mr. Rosenthal contended. **********He said that Chase collected $2.6 billion in savings and time deposits from residents of the five buroughs in 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/03/world.body_text: **********More than 2,000 Arab high school and university students in the Israeli-occupied West Bank clashed with Israeli soldiers today, hurling stones and setting tires ablaze in the streets in six towns. **********Israeli troops dispersed them by shooting into the air and using tear gas. About 60 youths were detained by the Israeli authorities in Ramallah and Nablus and at Bir Zeit University, according to Palestinian sources. **********The demonstrations marked the 64th anniversary of the Balfour Declaration that led to the establishment of Israel in May 1948. They also protested Israel's installation of a civilian administration for the occupied area to replace military jurisdiction in civil affairs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/12/world.main_headline: NATO IS FACING PARALYSIS OF WILL, EXPERTS CONTEND
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/12/world.print_headline: NATO IS FACING PARALYSIS OF WILL, EXPERTS CONTEND
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/12/world.body_text: **********A wide range of European and American political leaders, diplomats and foreign-policy experts believe that the NATO alliance faces growing erosion of common outlook and paralysis of will in its ability to deal with the Soviet Union. **********Talking recently to a European audience, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, attributed the problems at least in part to clashing views on the benefits of detente with Moscow. ''Detente for you, for Berliners, for Germans, has made a difference,'' he said in Vienna, ''but for us, detente has been a failure.'' **********A high French official, who did not want to be identified and whose remarks were typical of those heard in Europe, spoke of a deeper security problem. ''The United States used to represent protection from risk,'' he said in an interview in Paris. ''Now you represent protection and risk - or, to many Europeans, just risk.'' **********In many interviews over several weeks in Bonn, Paris, London and Washington, no one predicted that the current situation would prove unmanageable if the alliance could adapt politically to changes that seem certain to take place, among them increasingly divergent views on how to manage relations with the Soviet Union and how to handle change in the third world. **********The Economist, an influential London weekly, said recently in an editorial that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was in ''the early stages'' of a ''terminal illness.'' Seymour Weiss, a key consultant to the Reagan Administration, said for quotation what several of his official colleagues would say only privately: ''If there were no workable NATO in three years, I wouldn't be surprised.'' **********To old hands of the Atlantic alliance, it is nothing new to have a yearly ''crisis'' over a problem: how to conduct relations with Moscow, the risks and morality of stationing nuclear weapons in Europe, the role of NATO outside the European theater, the possibility of American troops being withdrawn from Europe or whether NATO members are all paying their fair share of the common military burden. **********What is new this time is that nearly all these issues are back, all at once, and are far more difficult to cope with because of a new element of ideology. **********Ideological politics have been reborn on the left in Europe and on the right in the United States, making for sharply divergent world outlooks and generating deep mutual suspicions. **********The left in Europe - the British Labor Party, the left wing of the West German Social Democratic Party and the Socialist Party in France, for example -seemed to many of those interviewed to be returning to earlier ideological roots centering on issues such as disarmament, workers' solidarity across national lines, help to oppressed nations and peoples and peaceful resolution of conflicts.  In the Reagan Administration, the roots run to a fervent nationalism and a kind of traditional isolationism. Key figures such as Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser, have far less patience with and tolerance of European views than their predecessors did. They are much more prepared to pursue a steady anti-Soviet line with or without the Europeans. Tone of Statements at Issue **********Allied governments have been pressing the Reagan team to moderate its polemics, which European leaders see as needlessly militaristic and playing into the hands of Moscow's ''peace offensive.'' Their goal, like that of many people in the State Department, is to quiet things down, so that problems that predated the Reagan Administration can be addressed. **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. is known to be so concerned about these attitudes that he now plans to address the issues that concern the Europeans in a speech to the Foreign Policy Association in New York City on Tuesday. **********But there are powerful figures in the Administration who continue to fight any change in approach. In private, many of them call Europeans ''Vichyite'' in a reference to the French who collaborated with Hitler, ''neutralists'' and ''pacifists,'' and contend that ''shock treatment,'' not conciliatory language, is necessary to shape them up. **********Even Mr. Haig, a former commander of NATO known for his understanding of West European attitudes despite his harsh public statements about the Russians, has made clear in private that he, too, is worried about trends in European thinking. Unlike many people in the White House and Defense Department, however, he is against threats and shock tactics and prefers quiet pressures. Delay in Policy Toward Europe **********By all accounts, the Administration has not begun to prepare an overall plan for managing relations with the European allies. The reason for this, according to some senior Administration officials, is that the approach toward Europe needs to be derived from the approach toward the Soviet Union, and not the other way around, and nothing that could really be called a policy toward Moscow has been agreed upon. **********There have always been differences between Europe and the United States over dealing with Moscow. The Europeans have historically insisted on the moral ambiguity of diplomacy and have worked with and against adversaries as part of the same relationship. American diplomacy has often insisted on drawing lines between ''good'' and ''evil'' powers, the more so now with the Reagan team's belief that Moscow is the wellspring of international terrorism as well as a political-military challenge to Western interests. **********There was always the Janus-like worry that either Washington would use nuclear weapons to defend Europe and blow Europe up at the same time or would not use the weapons for fear of jeopardizing American territory and thereby abandon Europe to the Russians. By all accounts, these worries reached their most acute form with the NATO decision of December 1979 to deploy new medium-range Pershing and cruise missiles in Europe. The purpose was to counterbalance new Soviet missiles and, by deploying new missiles, to give added credibility to the threat that they would be used. But then the Europeans began to worry about just that -their use. Issues Outside of Europe **********There was always an issue over whether the Atlantic allies should help each other outside Europe, but the sides are now reversed on the issue. For the first 20 or so years of the alliance, Washington resisted anything that might smack of assisting former colonial powers. Now Washington wants European help in defending areas such as the Persian Gulf. Europe is enormously dependent on oil from the Gulf, but the Europeans are resisting anything that smacks of transforming what they see as essentially local disputes into East-West confrontations. **********Many Administration officials see this as Europeans wanting to preserve the peace in Europe even at the price of allowing leftist factions backed by the Soviet Union to come to power in the third world. They see Americans paying to defend European interests in the Persian Gulf. **********These officials think the situation could easily degenerate into serious disputes over an equitable sharing of alliance burdens both in the third world and in Europe. Ultimately, they believe, it will revive Congressional pressures to reduce the number of American troops in Europe. **********Some evaluations of the economic relationship between Europe and the United States are that it is not so bad as previous crises, such as the one in 1971 when the flexible exchange rate system collapsed.  Other evaluations of the relationship are that it is potentially worse. C. Fred Bergsten of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace said in an interview that the Reagan Administration was forcing high interest rates and tight money on Western Europe and depressing the economies there. ''The situation is not unmanageable, but it will require basic changes in Administration policy to cope with it, and so far they have shown no willingness to do this,'' he said. **********A high-ranking State Department official provided an even more somber estimate. He saw severe problems developing as the new Administration pressed Western Europe to restrict trade with the Soviet Union and pressed it over general economic relations with the developing world, where the Europeans want to be more forthcoming than Washington does. **********''The economic problems of today,'' he summed up, ''will last longer than before because they are based on underlying structural problems. European economies are less healthy, less vibrant and less able to adjust.'' A Repeated Theme **********This idea of underlying structural problems in the alliance was a repeated theme in interviews as officials and experts here and in Europe spoke of what was new or relatively new in the situation: not only French but also West German pursuit of an independent foreign policy, the deepening chasm between the big and little nations of Europe and the rebirth of ideologies in Europe and the United States making political compromises and trust harder to achieve. **********In the winter issue of The Washington Quarterly, the historian Theodore Draper wrote: ''French Gaullism by itself could be isolated and ignored. Franco-German Gaullism commanding the heart of Western Europe can neither be isolated nor ignored.'' Now, although France is still a member of NATO, its forces are not integrated into the alliance's military command structure. **********Virtually everyone interviewed stressed that the problems appeared in most acute form in West Germany. Pierre Lellouche of the French Center for International Relations said, speaking of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, ''The fact that Schmidt, in effect, has to tell the German people that their enemy is the Soviet Union and not the United States shows how serious the problem is.'' **********West German officials and experts are notably more restrained in evaluating their own situation. A high German official explained: ''We have faced three crises. After the war, we asked whose side are we on, Russian or American, and chose America. In the late 1960's, the question was what should our relations be with the East and we chose detente. Now, the question is what is our role in the world.'' By this he meant whether West Germany would serve itself and the prospects of world peace better by pursuing a more independent policy from the United States. **********The gap in perceptions between West Germany and the United States could be seen several weeks ago in Bonn at a conference sponsored by the Friedrich Ebert Foundation, which is close to the ruling Social Democratic Party. Assistant Secretary of State Eagleburger gave a speech to reassure the Europeans about the Americans. He spoke about the need for military strength against the Soviet Union and the need to negotiate with Moscow. He also severely criticized the Europeans for not taking at face value President Reagan's pledge to begin negotiations on missiles in Europe with Moscow before the end of the year. No One Seemed Reassured **********Willy Brandt, the former West Germnan Chancellor and leader of the Social Democrats, then gave a speech to reassure the Americans about German fidelity to the alliance. He said problems stemmed from young people who were unaware of the cold war and America's importance to Europe, and he contended that Germany was not pacifist, neutralist or anti-American. **********Both speeches were well received but nobody seemed reassured. Many of the Europeans simply did not believe Mr. Reagan would seriously negotiate with Moscow on arms control or anything else. Many of the Americans remained wary that Mr. Brandt was too tolerant in his attitude toward an antinuclear mass rally then in progress in Hamburg that had decidedly anti-American overtones. **********The debate in West Germany, particularly over the future stationing of medium-range American missiles in Europe, is reflected and magnified in its small neighbors. In the view of several American diplomats, countries such as the Netherlands, Belgium, Norway and Denmark show decreasing sympathy to almost any American world position, increasingly pick up the Russian position and have been unreliable in upholding their share of alliance military burdens. The feeling is that the big European countries also have problems with their political left wings, but that their leaders, such as Chancellor Schmidt and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, are willing to risk their political futures to keep their countries in line. **********''Elites in the big countries are opposing the mass movements, but not in the small countries,'' agreed Klaus G. de Vries, a member of the Socialist Party in the Dutch Parliament who sympathizes with the protest movements of the left. **********Some American and British officials see this as leading to an alliance with tiers of loyalty and reliability, a complicated and ultimately unworkable arrangement. **********West European leaders and diplomats are increasingly looking for more moderate language from the Reagan Administration to calm European public opinion. But the last thing Reagan officials say they want to do is calm public opinion. As several of these officials explained it, to calm public opinion in Europe and the United States would be to lull the people again into a false sense of security and undercut pressure for increased military spending. **********Some high-ranking officials in the Reagan Administration say that if the Russians did invade Poland, it would at least make clear who the good guys and bad guys were and would mobilize the West.  Europeans, almost without exception, look on this with horror and even believe the shock would have a disintegrating effect on the alliance. A Few Bright Spots **********Many Europeans and some State Department officials stressed some continuing bright spots: agreement in the alliance on what to do in the event of a Soviet attack on Poland, a growing consensus among leaders on the need for greater military spending, the reaffirmation of the NATO decision to pursue both deployment and negotiations on the new missiles for Europe and the preference of many European leaders for Mr. Reagan over former President Jimmy Carter. **********But to most of those interviewed, these bright spots are fleeting, and the task of managing differences is becoming overwhelming. This is because leaders on each side of the Atlantic increasingly take their own positions as givens and assume that for things to work, the other side must change fundamentally. **********President Francois Mitterrand made this point mildly but publicly in early July when he said, ''I still have faith in the capacity for reflection of American leaders.'' Christoph Bertram, director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, put it more bluntly: ''There will be no crisis this year. Europeans still think time will shape things toward pragmatism in Washington and that, in time, the Administration will adjust and see realities as Europeans see them.'' Need for Basic Changes **********But the point was that most of those interviewed talked of the necessity of basic changes in attitude, not the usual compromises that have kept the alliance together in the past. **********A British diplomat put it this way: ''No American President can afford politically to be responsible for the destruction of the Atlantic alliance. What will save the alliance will be repeated American failures. Only then will Mr. Reagan see realities and change.'' **********In the end, hardly any of those interviewed could imagine a world without the alliance, but hardly any could foresee its future without fundamental change.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/13/busin.body_text: **********More companies yesterday took advantage of the chance to complete retroactive tax leasing deals before tonight's deadline. In such transactions, corporations in effect sell tax credits and depreciation deductions they cannot use to corporations seeking tax shelters. **********Until the deadline, equipment purchased between Jan. 1 and Aug. 13 of this year is eligible for the tax benefits of these sale-leaseback deals, in which the equipment never changes hands. After tonight, only newly purchased equipment is eligible. **********These transactions were announced yesterday: **********- Pacific Southwest Airlines, based in San Diego, sold the International Business Machine Corporation about $200 million worth of DC-9 Super 80 aircraft and related equpment. The price was not disclosed. **********- The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation transferred tax benefits on equipment valued between $100 million and $150 million to Batus Inc. for a price between $25 million and $35 million. **********- IC Industries, the Chicago-based conglomerate, sold benefits from about $93 million of assets of its Illinois Central Gulf Railroad to an undisclosed buyer for approximately $28 million. **********Separately, the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, a subsidiary of the RCA Corporation, introduced a nationwide program to help smaller companies enter into tax leasing deals. Companies that finance equipment purchases through C.I.T. may participate in the program.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/16/world.body_text: **********Iran's revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, has canceled all his public appearances for 1O days, starting Thursday, the Teheran radio said. **********The radio, quoting a statement from the Ayatollah's office, said he had made the decision to observe the 4Oth day of the martyrdom of the Shiite third imam, who was killed about 14 centuries ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/14/busin.body_text: **********Three Chicago banks yesterday raised their prime lending rates to 17 1/2 percent, falling in line with a similar move last Friday by two industry leaders in New York. **********The First National Bank of Chicago, the nation's ninth largest, increased its prime by half a percentage point and was followed almost immediately by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, No. 28, and the Northern Trust Company, No.33. **********First National of Chicago's prime rate had been 17 percent for the last three weeks after dropping from 17 1/2 percent on March 16.  Observers did not view the increases as pointing toward significantly higher levels for the prime rate. The prime -the interest rate banks charge their top corporate customers - had been falling from December's record 21 1/2 percent, gradually reaching 17 percent at most banks in early April. **********Last Friday, the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, both based in New York, raised their prime rate to 17 1/2 percent from the 17 percent that had generally prevailed in the industry since April 1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/11/busin.body_text: **********The number of auto workers on indefinite and temporary layoffs dropped slightly this week despite a 26 percent decline in production, caused mostly by the Labor Day holiday, according to industry reports released today. **********Domestic auto makers said they had 158,350 employees on layoff without a recall date, down from 1 59,400 last week, and 47,255 workers on temporary furlough, down from 47,3 65. **********An industry journal, Ward's Automotive Reports, said auto makers planned to build 91,659 cars during this holiday week, down from the 124,364 cars made in the comparable 1980 week, which was a full workweek. **********Truck production is scheduled to reach 26,014 this week, down from 29,385 in the 1980 week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/04/busin.print_headline: WASHINGTON BUSINESS: KEEPING TRACK OF THE BUREAUCRATS; WASHINGTON
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/04/busin.body_text: **********T O have the right name and telephone number at one's fingertips can be an ''open sesame'' in this town where information, political power, grants and government contracts can often be found at the other end of the telephone. **********The question more often than not, however, is: Just whom do you call and where does he or she fit in the maze of the Federal bureaucracy? This kind of predicament will be compounded over the next few months as more than 4,000 jobs change hands with the arrival of the Reagan administration. **********One of the small businesses that has sprung up to provide this kind of information - for a price - is the Carroll Publishing Company. Thomas E. Carroll, its president, says that even when there is no Presidential change, the pace of power shifting is hectic enough. His company's Federal Executive Directory is updated every two months, with changes of one sort or another in one-quarter of the names and telephone numbers for the 30,000 key Federal officials it covers. And all this is available for $96 a year. **********A number of other Washington publications are also attempting to keep up with the ever-changing scene. Washington Monitor Inc.  publishes the Congressional Yellow Book, which is updated four times a year and sells for $85. Its Federal Yellow Book, selling for $120, lists individuals by department and is updated every two months through looseleaf page supplements. The Government Printing Office publishes the Congressional Directory each year, which comes out in the late spring, and another research tool used by many Washingtonians is the privately published Congressional Staff Directory, now in its 23d edition. **********A sizeable portion of the 350,000 people who make up the Federal workforce are continually on the move. Aside from the perennial reorganizations of departments, employees are frequently transferred from one building to another, or to different offices within the same agency with an accompanying shuffle in job titles and telephone numbers. There are some agencies that never stop reorganizing. **********Even the Federal Government has trouble keeping track of its own. A Washington columnist recently called the State Department information operator for Secretary of State Edmund Muskie's direct telephone number and was given 224-3121. It was the switchboard number for the Capitol, where Secretary Muskie had served as the senior Senator from Maine before his appointment as Secretary of State last April. **********And F. David Mathews, who served for 15 months as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Ford Administration never did get listed in the H.E.W. telephone directory, which is published spasmodically. **********''When I worked in the Department of Transportation, my name stayed in their directory until 1979, and I left in 1977,'' said Suzanne Hatcher, who handles sales for Carroll publications. **********Six-foot-two, of husky build and curly auburn and white hair, Mr.  Carroll, 52 years old, put his feet up, puffed at his ever-present pipe, and talked in a low key manner about his operation. **********A 1950 graduate of Yale with a degree from the University of Michigan's Law School, Mr. Carroll also earned a masters in business from Columbia University. For years he was associated with Time Inc., serving as assistant business manager of Time/ Life Broadcasting properties, as director of planning with Time/Life Books, and as vice president of planning for General Learning, a Time/General Electric joint venture in the field of education. **********Divorced, with two sons, he works out of the second floor of an 1807 brick building that he owns situated on the banks of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal in the Georgetown section of Washington. **********I N 1970, he joined the Environmental Protection Agency. ''It was one of the first sort of crosscutting agencies that involved every other agency,'' Mr. Carroll recalled.  ''And as we dealt with people from other governmental departments, we found ourselves asking continuously, 'Who are these people, where do they fit, which is the brass and who are the Indians?' - and no one knew.'' **********After going into the consulting business in 1975, Mr. Carroll bought for $1,000 a defunct publication based in Columbus, Ohio, called ''U.S. Government Organization Chart Manual,'' to sell as a sideline. For his money, he got 55 subscribers and, he discovered, a lot of obsolete information. **********Today, he heads a staff of six full-time employees and 15 parttime employees. There are 5,000 subscribers and he has current annual revenues of nearly $700,000. **********The Executive Directory lists individuals alphabetically as well as by organization and function, and all three sections are cross indexed. As a result one can find the direct telephone number of the Community Service Grants Office of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, or the head of the Afghanistan desk at the Department of State, or the Hydrocarbon Processing and Distribution Group at the Energy Department. **********''I spend most of my time on the Department of Energy,'' said Ann L. Friel, editor of the directory. ''It's a zoo.'' Since the establishment of the Department of Energy in August 1977, it has undergone 10 major reorganizations. Its 28 major departments are broken down into more than a hundred subdivisions, of which, Inventions and Small Scale Technology, MXRES Project, Uranium Resources and Enrichment, Coal Resource Management, Shale Oil Resource Applications and Electric Energy Systems are a few. **********T HE company also publishes a separate directory for governmental energy activities (''That's where the money is,'' says Miss Hatcher), and a State Executive Directory of all 50 state governments. A research service is offered to clients who subscribe to one of their three chart services that give a visual picture of the structure of the Federal Government (the military chart shows command centers and divisions within commands). There is another chart service showing the stucture and personnel of 110 of the top Defense Department contractors. **********Carroll clients include consulting firms, lawyers and law libraries, universities, lobbyists, and Washington representatives of major companies. **********Federal offices make up 20 percent of their subscribers and they include the Executive Office of the President, the United States Senate Library, the General Accounting Office, the Library of Congress, and several branches of the Department of Commerce and the Justice Department. The State Department subscribes to their military charts that sell for $375 a year. **********''The Carroll book is one way of getting a handle on the Federal Government,'' said Linda Neighborgall, deputy coordinator for the Federal Information Center Program of the General Services Administration. ''We have been very impressed with it. It's up to date, and he does a lot checking.'' The G.S.A.'s 91 information centers around the country are subscribers. **********The secret of Mr. Carroll's success is simple. Each entry is called every two months for updating.  ''People said it was impossible,'' said Miss Friel, who with Pauline G. Green, the associate editor, updates the organization charts and handles major governmental reorganizations. ''But we have this group of marvelous older women whose kids have grown, and they make phone calls for three hours each day from their homes. They never let you down, they're careful, conscientious and part of that old school -they're never sick on the job.'' **********For its staff of outside callers and their accumulated phone bills, Carroll Publishing pays about $2,000 a month. It also runs up a monthly in-office phone bill of $2,000. **********The January/February issue has asterisks denoting the positions that appear in the Plumb Book (the political jobs that Mr. Reagan can fill). It is expected that most of these appointments will not be made until February or March and even later. **********''In our experience, the bulk of the appointments come in late summer and early fall, because it takes that long for these new guys to get in place and effectuate change,'' Mr. Carroll explained. **********About 20,000 Federal employees move every year within the capital area alone, according to Joseph O'Hern of the General Services Administration, which has a mandate of sorts of trying to keep track of it all. G.S.A.'s consolidated Centix system with 170,000 lines feeds most of the Federal agencies and departments, but some departments like Treasury and Commerce have independent phone systems and publish their own directories. **********''Basically we try to publish a directory once a year or when things get so disorganized it needs doing again,'' said Richard Q.  Vawter of the G.S.A.'s Information Office. ''I don't think we are very professional about it, but it is very difficult. Carroll is very successful, but it obviously requires a lot of manpower, and it's the kind of thing that if you do it all the time it becomes easier, if you do it once a year it becomes cumbersome.'' **********The G.S.A.'s library, as well as its information office, subscribe to the Carroll directory. James E. Edwards, special assistant to the Commissioner of Automated Data and Telecommunications, explained: ''Our directory is only as good as the information we receive. We ask our customers to fill out a form whenever there is a move, or a telephone or position change, but offices are often negligent in reporting changes. We have to rely on them (Carroll) to provide the information, for we don't have the resources or manpower to obtain it ourselves.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/busin.body_text: **********A compromise by the Federal Communications Commission that, in effect, gave the Bell System an upper hand in marketing a new mobile telephone service now seems to be falling apart. **********The commission, after 13 years of deliberations, agreed last spring to authorize the use of a new technology called cellular radio. The technology, developed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, is expected to dramatically improve car phone service - and may have other, potentially lucrative, applications as well. **********But since the F.C.C. acted, the phone company's competitors have waged an intense lobbying campaign to overturn the ruling, and their work may very well pay off. The F.C.C., at a meeting Dec.17, is expected to reconsider its earlier decision and possibly open up the field to more competition. **********It appears that Mark S. Fowler, chairman of the F.C.C., leans strongly toward taking away the guaranteed entry of Bell's local phone companies in the cellular radio market. **********Other commissioners also indicate privately that they are reconsidering their stand, and William Baxter, the Assistant Attorney General for antitrust matters, has called for keeping Bell out altogether. Bell Officials Incensed **********To no one's surprise, Bell officials are incensed at the thought that the company and its affiliates might lose their guaranteed participation in cellular radio. At the time the new service was approved April 8, the company said that it could have some service in place by 1983 and could be in 70 cities by the mid-1980's. **********''This has been one of the bitterest experiences in the history of A.T.&T.,'' said Pickard E. Wagner, a spokesman for the company. ''We have been trying to get this service to the American people for over a decade, and any backsliding by the commission now will just put off the day when the service can get to market. Nobody but the telephone company is ready and capable of putting up a good cellular mobile system. If this is thrown up in the air, the whole business will just go to the Japanese manufacturers.'' **********The technology came from Bell Labs in the 1940's, but did not become a hot item until the late 1960's, when Bell brought it before the F.C.C. **********It stayed on simmer there until last April, when the commission gave its ''final'' authorization for the system. A Bonanza Expected **********What kept the commission hung up so long was the question of how to allocate the right to offer the service, expected to be a bonanza worth hundreds of millions of dollars to equipment makers and radio system designers. **********Cellular radio will give the nation superior car phones and may make possible very small wireless units for home and portable personal use. **********Under the present system, a single powerful transmitter services a city area. Even in New York, where 5,000 people were on a waiting list at one time, no more than 24 simultaneous conversations can take place. The system is often ''busy,'' and voice reproduction is of poor quality. **********With the cellular process, made practical by new computer technology, localities are divided into small geographic areas, or ''cells,'' each served on a two-way basis by a low-power transmitter. Special switching equipment makes it possible for a call made from a moving vehicle to be handed off automatically from cell to cell, from frequency to frequency, without interrupting the conversation. **********Such a system allows division of the available frequency into smaller parts and thus can accommodate more callers. Voice quality is vastly improved, making it possible to place a call to London from a car moving through the streets of Washington, for example, with sound reproduction equal to that of a local call. An F.C.C. Compromise **********The F.C.C. had to weigh arguments by those who thought cellular service should be a local regulated monopoly, like ordinary phone service, against those that said the phone companies should be excluded and wide open competition among mobile radio companies permitted. In April, the commission, in a self-proclaimed compromise, said that the phone companies could offer service in every market - along with only one other competitor. **********However, some potential applicants, such as Motorola Inc., said that the plan was unfair because the monopoly phone company, with capital already in hand, would be first out of the gate, while competitors battled for local operating rights. **********And Millicom Inc., a New York City-based company, complained that its competing technology was ignored.  Various parties, including the Washington law firm of Dean Burch, a former F.C.C. chairman, called for the commission to reconsider its final order. Lobbyists swarmed on Capitol Hill urging Congress to take the issue away from the commission. **********The F.C.C. may well be pre-empted by Congress. Staff members on the House Subcommittee on Telecommunications said that ''strong consideration'' was being given to putting into an emerging telecommunications bill a provision that would overrule the commission's plan. Far-Reaching Applications **********Barry Yampol, president of the Graphic Scanning Corporation, an Englewood, N.J., company that transmits data and messages electronically, and provides radio paging, says that the cellular technology can have far-reaching applications. **********''It provides not just mobile but portable two-way communication that will be competitive eventually with the local switched network or local wireline phone service,'' he said. **********''It will take the wisdom of Solomon to reach a good decision,'' said Stuart Crump, editor of Cellular Radio News, a trade publication here. ''But wait, they did the Solomon approach by dividing the frequencies.'' **********Joseph R. Fogarty, a leading supporter of Bell's position on the seven-member commission, said: ''I advise the American people to keep their walkie-talkies and CB radios, because they seem to be the only mobile service we'll have this decade. I'm keeping my batteries charged.''
