https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/world.main_headline: U.S. NUNS' DEATHS LAID TO SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/world.print_headline: U.S. NUNS' DEATHS LAID TO SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/world.body_text: **********A captured Salvadoran national guardsman said in a broadcast over a guerrilla-run radio station that the four American missionaries killed last year were slain by guardsmen who suspected that two of them were running messages between leftists in Nicaragua and El Salvador. **********The claim came yesterday as a critic of the Salvadoran junta's human rights policies, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, ended a three-day visit and left El Salvador without making any public statements. **********Senator Dodd, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, proposed an amendment to the $114 million aid package for El Salvador requiring President Reagan to certify twice a year that El Salvador is making progress in human rights, economic development and political liberalization. **********The proposal was made in part because of reported human rights abuses by Government forces against the civilian population. Church sources here estimate that most of the 24,000 people killed in El Salvador since Jan. 1, 1980 have died in execution-style slayings rather than in combat between the leftist guerrillas and Government troops. U.S. Missionaries Among Victims **********Among the victims were three United States nuns and a lay religious worker slain in December 1980, purportedly by six guardsmen now under arrest. The women had been en route from the international airport to San Salvador. **********The three nuns, Ita Ford and Maura Clarke, members of the Maryknoll Order, and Dorothy Kazel, of the Ursuline Order, and Jean Donovan, a lay missionary, were killed because the first two had just arrived from Nicaragua, the captured guardsman said in an interview broadcast by the rebel station Radio Venceremos. **********The guardsman, identified as Isidoro Guevara, 25 years old, said that he had taken part in a guard meeting last summer in which a major informed his troops that six guardsmen had been arrested for the Americans' slaying. **********According to the guardsman, the major had told the troops that the suspects knew the women had arrived from Nicaragua and could have been carrying messages between leftists in Nicaragua and El Salvador. **********The Salvadoran junta has repeatedly accused Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista rulers of smuggling weapons to the guerrillas in El Salvador. **********The six guard suspects were jailed in April but have yet to be brought to trial.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/22/busin.body_text: **********Japan today formally adopted its official outlook for the Japanese economy next year, placing far more reliance on domestic factors than on exports for its expected growth. **********The Japanese Cabinet endorsed projections by the Economic Planning Agency that real economic growth in the 1982 fiscal year, starting next April, would reach 5.2 percent, considerably higher than private forecasts of between 3.1 and 4.5 percent. **********The planning agency also lowered for the second time the likely growth in the real gross national product for this year, estimated now at 4.1 percent compared with an October estimate of 4.7 percent. **********But Japan, under severe criticism in the West where its booming exports are blamed for depriving workers of jobs, is expected to have a record trade surplus in the next fiscal year of $30.1 billion after a record $26.3 billion that is expected this year, the planning agency said. **********The agency calculated that exports in the 1982 fiscal year would rise only 5.8 percent when measured in yen after climbing 17.2 percent during the current year. **********Despite pressure from both the United States and the European Economic Community to increase imports quickly, the Government agency's projections showed that Japanese imports should rise by only 4.4 percent next year after increasing just 2 percent this year. **********Exports in 1982 should rise to $165.2 billion and imports to $135.6 billion compared with 1981 projections of $153.1 billion for exports and $126.8 billion for imports. **********Japan's 1982 current account surplus, which includes trade plus payments for shipping, banking and insurance, was put at $12 billion, up from a new estimate of $10 billion this year, revised sharply higher from an estimate of $7 billion made in October.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1981; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/23/busin.body_text: **********A half-point rise in interest rates on passbook savings accounts was cleared by Federal regulators. Under the new rule, described by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan as part of an effort to give the small saver a ''better break,'' thrift rates may rise to 6 percent, while commercial banks may pay as much as 5 3/4 percent. The move was sharply criticized by the savings industry. (Page A1.) **********President Reagan tentatively dropped plans to seek deferral of cost-of-living increases in Federal benefit p rograms. Mr. Reagan willgive a speech on his plan tomorrow at 9 P.M.  (A1.) Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said Mr. Reagan had assu red him that military budgets would not be reduced beyond present p lans. (A24.) **********Secretary Regan rejected any idea of deferring or modifying the 25 percent tax-rate cut to balance the Federal budget. He indicated before the House Budget Committee that the Administration would renew its effort to curtail Federal credit programs. (D1.) **********New orders for manufacturers' durable goods fell 2.5 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported. The drop, a sharp one, was the first since January. Analysts called it consistent with other signs that economic conditions are continuing to deteriorate. (D1.) Companies **********AM International announced it would report a loss of $175 million in its 1981 fiscal year. The company plans to sell its Addressograph and Jacquard divisions to relieve its debt-laden balance sheet. James R. Mellor, president, resigned following the announcement of the loss. (D1.) **********G.M. plans to give away new cars as a lure to prospective buyers of the several hundred houses it has bought from transferred employees who could not sell them on their own. (A16.) **********Commonwealth Oil is seeking concessions that would stem its losses and permit continued operation of refining facilities in Puerto Rico. It said there would also be further cost-cutting efforts. (D7.) **********Delhi International Oil asked the Amex to halt trading in its stock pending an announcement today. It would not disclose the nature of the announcement, but there was speculation on Wall Street that the company, which has major exploration interests in Australia, had received a takeover offer from CSR Ltd. of Australia. (D6.) **********Avon Products said it was involved in talks with Cooper Laboratories, a producer of medical and dental products, about a possible combination. The cosmetics company is seeking to diversify.  (D4.) **********Russell Stover Candies plans to make a tender offer of $20 a share in cash to buy all of its outstanding shares. The offer, if successful, would give control of the candy company to Louis L.  Ward, its chairman, and his immediate family. (D2.) **********Pan Am's unionized employees agreed to a wage freeze through 1982 and a 10 percent rollback in salaries in an effort to guarantee the company's profitability. (D7.) International **********Unemployment in Britain reached 12.4 percent this month, the Government reported. The figure is the highest since the start of detailed record-keeping in 1948, officials said, and may be the highest since the Great Depression of the 1930's. (D13.) Markets **********The stock market closed slightly lower, with some takeover candidates and transportation issues posting the biggest price moves. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.86 point, to 845.70. (D8.) Short-term and long-term interest rates rose amid concern that the recent drop in short-term rates had run its course. (D12.) The dollar rose against most major currencies, ending a two-week slide. Gold prices fell $6, to $461.50 a troy ounce, on the Comex. (D14.) Hog and pork belly futures prices fell. (D14.) Today's Columns **********Wall Street has gone through the looking glass into a topsy-turvy world where ''bad news'' is really ''good news.'' For in every sign that a recession is here the experts see hope that interest rates will decline. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) Most invest ment advisers expect stock prices to continue falling.  They cite hig h interest rates, the Federal budget deficit, cuts in corporate pro fit estimates, increasing margin calls and a new vulnerability of foreign markets. Market Place. (D8.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/08/world.print_headline: Around the World; Leader of Peasant Party In Poland Forced to Quit
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/08/world.body_text: **********Stanislaw Gucwa, head of the pro-Communist Peasant Party, resigned today after party members had attacked him for opposing an independent farm union. **********He has been replaced as party leader by Stefan Ignar, head of the Agricultural Policy Institute, according to the official Polish press agency. Mr. Ignar led the party from 1956 to 1962 and served as a Deputy Prime Minister under Wladyslaw Gomulka, the former Communist leader.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/28/busin.body_text: **********The Xerox Corporation yesterday introduced a product intended to overcome a major obstacle in the path toward the automated office - the reluctance of white-collar workers with no computer experience to use electronic terminals. **********The 8010 Star Information System, a video display terminal, can be used without the need for code words and special commands common to other systems, Xerox said. The terminal can be used to create and edit documents, as is done on a word processor, to create graphs and charts, retrieve documents stored in electronic files and send and receive electronic messages. **********Analysts said the product would help make terminals less intimidating in the corporate levels above secretaries. The new work station, they added, was ahead of the field in providing many functions in one terminal and in being simple to use. 'Easier and Easier to Use' **********''That capability will be important to both office automation and to Xerox,'' said Sanford J. Garrett of Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins. ''The whole trend in office automation for the next 10 years will be to make products easier and easier to use.'' **********Rather than having to type commands and code words, as is required on other terminals, the user can move a little pointer on the screen to symbols representing various functions. **********To retrieve a particular file, for instance, the user moves the pointer to a picture of a filing cabinet and presses one key. To print a document the pointer is moved to a little picture of a printer. **********''We're dealing with professionals, people who prefer pointing and selecting to typing explicit commands,'' said David E. Liddle, vice president of Xerox's office products division, at a New York news conference. Managers and top-level executives would need yet simpler terminals, Xerox officials said. **********Xerox has invested about $50 million in developing the work station since 1972, Donald J. Massaro, president of the office products division, said. It will be available starting in the fall for a single unit price of $16,500 with volume discounts available. **********The Star work station would increase the productivity of such professional workers as engineers and analysts, Xerox officials said, by speeding their ability to gather information and to compile it into reports and memos. **********''We've already seen some things that indicate that the professional wants help,'' said Mr. Massaro. He pointed to the growing use of personal computers by engineers and analysts. Vital Gap Filled In **********For Xerox the Star work station also fills in a vital gap in its product line. It is designed to be used with other products introduced by Xerox over the last three years, including an electronic filing system, a printer that can print out what appears on the work station screen, a communications device linking various machines, and Ethernet, a communications network to tie the office machinery together. **********But what Xerox sees as strong points could hinder sales of the Star work station, some analysts believe.  Harvey L. Poppel, senior vice president of Booz Allen & Hamilton, a consulting firm, said that productivity of professional and managerial office workers was less well defined and more difficult to measure than it was for typists or factory workers. Unless companies can be convinced of the savings, he added, they will be reluctant to spend the money needed to buy the terminals. **********In addition, the Star work station is really useful only when tied in with the electronic file, the printer and the Ethernet network.  Few companies have made commitments so far to buy the whole package, which might retard sales of the work station.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/busin.main_headline: A.T.&T. LIFTS EARNINGS 11.1%, CALLS FOR HIGHER LOCAL RATES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/busin.print_headline: A.T.&T. LIFTS EARNINGS 11.1%, CALLS FOR HIGHER LOCAL RATES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today reported an 11.1 percent increase in its first-quarter earnings, and it said local telephone rates would have to be increased sharply. **********A.T.& T.'s chairman, Charles L. Brown, also said at a news conference before the company's annual meeting here that no negotiations were under way to settle the Justice Department's antitrust suit. However, he said, the company would be willing to negotiate a settlement. **********A tentative accord made in the last days of the Carter Administration was rejected by the Justice Department under President Reagan. The Justice Department has vowed to push the effort to break up A.T.& T. despite requests by the Defense Department to drop the case because of what it describes as the vital role of the company's communications network in national defense. **********Earnings of $6 Billion **********A.T.& T., which earned $6 billion in all of last year, the most ever for an American corporation, said its profit in the first quarter of 1981 rose to $1.6 billion, or $2.05 a share, from $1.4 billion, or $1.98 a share, a year earlier. But Mr. Brown called the earnings ''essentially flat'' and said they underscored a need for higher telephone rates. **********The company's latest three-month revenues were $13.5 billion, up from $12.1 billion in 1980's first quarter.  A.T.& T. keeps its accounts on a calendar-year basis, but announces earnings for the three-month periods ending the last days of February, May, August and November so that a current earnings report can be mailed to shareholders with their dividend checks, which are payable on the first business day of each calendar quarter. The company had announced that, in the three-month period ended Feb. 28, earnings rose 8.6 percent to $1.52 billion, or $1.97 a share, from $1.4 billion, or $1.93 a share, in the similar period a year before. Details of Expansion Plans **********A.T.& T. released a ''statement of policy'' today that detailed its previously announced plans to cope with increased competition in the telephone business and to expand into data processing and related fields, most of them unregulated. A.T.& T. is seeking permission to operate in unregulated business areas. **********Increasing local telephone rates was described as the key to these plans. In the past, the company said, local rates have been held below costs, with the difference made up by relatively high longdistance rates. **********''Long-distance service must be relieved of the burden of contributing to the support of local service,'' Mr. Brown said in his speech to 1,398 shareholders gathered in the Houston Convention Center. ''Deprived of that support, local rates will have no place to go but up, further and faster than inflation would in any case make necessary.'' **********One aspect of the company's expansion is a plan to offer its yellow pages electronically so the directory can be read on home computers.  The first test, scheduled for Austin, Tex., has been delayed in court because of opposition from newspapers, among others. **********''I really don't think it helps very much for the American Newspaper Publishers Association to clothe its economic interests in First Amendment rhetoric,'' Mr. Brown said. ''The issue is advertising, competition for advertising, and nothing else.'' Conflicting Agency Views **********In its statement of policy, A.T.& T. said: ''Ours is the business of moving information - voice, video, data, graphics, etc. - from just about any place in the United States to just about any other place in the United States or, for that matter, the world.'' **********The company has won approval from the Federal Communications Commission to set up a subsidiary to offer such services, but the Justice Department contends that it would violate a 1956 consent decree limiting A.T.& T. to businesses where rates are regulated by governmental bodies. Mr. Brown said A.T.& T. was ''caught in the middle'' between two parts of the Government. **********Other, smaller phone companies are now offering long-distance service between major cities at rates lower than A.T.& T.'s. Mr.  Brown said the telephone company, which is to raise interstate longdistance rates by 16 percent within a few weeks, planned to fight that competition, partly by raising the charges those companies pay to connect to the Bell System. **********Stockholders elected the management's slate of directors and rejected seven shareholder proposals, as management had urged.  The most important of those proposals would have barred the company from making charitable contributions, required it to report to shareholders all political contributions by its political action committees and required it to report to shareholders where pension funds were invested.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/25/world.body_text: **********Here in the municipality of Penang, beside the busy Strait of Malacca in northwest Malaysia, is Butterworth, one of Malaysia's principal free-trade zones. Within a few miles are two industrial parks with nearly 100 factories producing everything from umbrellas to steel and sugar. **********''The combination of a major shipping lane and the industrial zones makes Penang one of the most industrialialized areas in Asia and one of the most polluted,'' said the head of a foreign-based pollution control company that has been carrying out studies in Southeast Asia. **********Malaysia, like other rapidly developing countries in the region, is beginning to feel the environmental effects of industrialization.  Rapid deforestation, indiscriminate mining practices, poor planning and accelerated expansion are taking a toll on the country and its resources. **********The Ministry of Science and Technology has designated 42 of the 50 Malaysian rivers as ''grossly polluted,'' the result of paper and palm-oil production, rubber processing, pineapple canning and mining.  Leaving Things Till Later **********''There is a tendency to promote development and then sort out the problems later,'' said K.J. Ratnam, director of the Center for Policy Research at the university here. ''At the beginning, countries seem to feel that the price of preserving the environment is too high.'' **********In 1974 Malaysia enacted an environmental quality act that recognized the priority of economic growth over environmental concerns and is toothless. In effect, the palm-oil and rubber industries have escaped because of their importance. Only after multinational companies, particularly the oil producers, began bringing in new technology did the glaring disparity between the new and the old practices become apparent. **********''Some of the multinationals, particularly the oil companies, were sensitive to their behavior abroad, and it just may have been easier to build their installations to the same standard everywhere,'' said Anthony Morrow, an industrial sociologist in George Town. ''Whatever the reason, people began to become aware that something could be done to save the fish in the rivers.'' **********In recent years the Government has begun talking about protecting the environment and, under pressure from an organized and increasingly active consumer movement, it has begun to tighten regulations despite opposition from the industrial sector. S.J.  Sundram, Director General of Environmental Quality, said, ''Malaysia's economy today and for a long time to come depends on the renewable-resources sectors and these, for a small country like ours, are limited, fragile and in urgent need of comprehensive protection and sustained production.'' **********Industrial developers have been able to avoid having to carry out the 1979 regulations on sewage and industrial waste that were to go into full effect this year. The 130 palm-oil plants, for example, were to build treatment facilities to reduce the 250,000 tons of effluent released annually. The deadline has been extended until July 1; the Government has promised that it will act then. Until 'Something Awful Happens' **********''We will have to wait and see,'' said Lim Teck Ghee, secretary of the Consumers Association of Penang. ''Enforcement is very lax until something awful happens.'' **********Penang has a double environmental threat. In addition to industry and the tin mines, the Strait of Malacca is one of the world's busiest waterways, with more than 4,500 ships, many carrying oil to Japan, passing through monthly. The strait is Japan's lifeline to the Middle East, and the ports along it are vital to regional trade. **********Neither consumers nor the Government can do much about the strait, which is an international passage, but on land the battle is intensifying. Through educational seminars and mailings to 40,000 individuals and groups a month, the consumer association is ''trying to bring consumerism and environmental concern out of the dark ages,'' said Khor Kok Peng, its research director. **********''We are trying to educate Malaysians and the Government,'' he said.  It is an uphill battle. For villages without modern conveniences, consumerism has no meaning. On the environmental issue the association has nevertheless found support in fishing villages where livelihoods are threatened by pollution. **********''We are far behind the United States,'' Mr. Khor said. ''We don't have the technology or the sophistication, but we are beginning to approach the problem that every developing country must face. We want basic things like clean air and water and the guarantee of a good fishing day tomorrow.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/18/busin.main_headline: S.E.C. IS CHIDED IN ST. JOE CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/18/busin.print_headline: S.E.C. IS CHIDED IN ST. JOE CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/18/busin.body_text: **********The president of a Swiss investment house yesterday accused the Securities and Exchange Commission of ''leaking partial information'' about his role in the purchase of securities last March in the St.  Joe Minerals Corporation before a takeover bid by the Seagram Company. **********But in a telephone interview, the executive, Guiseppe B. Tome, president of Cie. pour le Financement et l'Investissement in Geneva, also known as Finvest, refused to deny, on the advice of counsel, that he was involved in the Government case. **********Only a day earlier, on the basis of testimony from an official of Banca Della Svizzera Italiana, through which the securities had been purchased, the Government agency identified Mr. Tome and his firm as having placed the orders.'' **********In a statement released in Geneva yesterday, Mr. Tome maintained that by leaking partial information, the commission was ''using moral and material pressures on third parties'' rather than resorting to the courts. Tome and Finvest Named **********Last March, after it had uncovered evidence of insider trading, the commission sued the Swiss bank to force disclosure of its clients. After it had obtained waivers of Swiss secrecy laws, a bank officer subsequently identified four clients and named Mr. Tome and Finvest of Geneva as having placed the orders for those clients. **********''The alleged facts and consequent assumptions as leaked by the S.E.C. are not correct,'' Mr. Tome's statement continued.  Although Mr. Tome said he ''would be very surprised'' if the bank had provided such information, court papers dated Nov. 12 show that Claudio Nesa, the bank's assistant manager, named Transatlantic Financial Company, Nayarit Investments and Finvest Panama, all of Panama, as having purchased 1,055 St. Joe options a day before the Seagram takeover bid. Mr. Nesa said in an affidavit that he received a call from Mr. Tome, then in New York, at about 4:10 P.M. Lugano, Switzerland, time, instructing him to purchase the options and urging him to place the order quickly. **********Mr. Nesa related a series of telephone conversations with Mr. Tome during the next few days, including one asking him to transfer options from one Panamanian company to another for ''greater confidentiality within his organization.'' St. Joe Stock Purchased **********He said 3,000 shares of St. Joe stock were also purchased on March 10 but that he learned of it the next day when a telex arrived at the bank confirming the order through the Wall Street firm of Baird, Patrick & Company in the bank's name on behalf of Finvest Geneva. He testified that while he did not know who had instructed Baird Patrick, Mr. Tome was a representative of that firm and ''occasionally Tome or some employee of Finvest Geneva would instruct Baird Patrick's New York office to effect a security transaction in the name of the bank.'' **********The commission subpoenaed Mr. Tome last April at his Baird, Patrick office in New York but is understood to have received no formal reply. Mr. Tome, a 51-year-old Italian citizen who said he had lived in Switzerland since 1965, said in his statement that he has ''repeatedly offered full cooperation'' to the Government agency and that his lawyers were in New York for that purpose.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/11/busin.main_headline: MORGAN SEEKS TO SET UP A BANK IN DELAWARE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/11/busin.print_headline: MORGAN SEEKS TO SET UP A BANK IN DELAWARE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/11/busin.body_text: **********J.P. Morgan & Company formally filed an application yesterday with the Delaware Bank Commissioner for permission to establish a new bank in Wilmington, Morgan announced. **********Assets of the proposed bank, Morgan Bank (Delaware), are expected to grow to $2 billion by the end of the first year of operation, and to $5 billion at the end of five years, David B. Dyche Jr., senior vice president of J.P. Morgan, indicated in an interview yesterday.  ''We're going to build it slowly and carefully and walk before we run,'' Mr. Dyche said. **********J.P. Morgan, whose total assets averaged $51.6 billion in the first quarter, owns the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, which accounts for about 97 percent of its assets. That ratio is expected to change as the Delaware bank grows. Morgan is the fifth-largest banking organization in the United States after Citicorp, the BankAmerica Corporation, the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. Avoidance of Taxes Sought **********Morgan and Chase were primarily responsible for legislation passed last year by the Delaware Legislature that allowed out-of-state banks to form banking subsidiaries in Delaware. A major incentive is to avoid the relatively high taxes they must pay in New York State. **********Approval must be obtained from the Federal Reserve Board and from banking authorities in Delaware before the bank can open. Mr. Dyche said he hoped that the bank could be opened before year-end. **********Initially, Morgan Bank (Delaware) would have 60 employees, and this would be increased to ''at least 100'' within a year, the minimum stipulated by Delaware law. **********David D. Wakefield, a senior vice president in Morgan's national banking division, would be president and chief executive of the proposed bank. Mr. Wakefield, a native of Delaware, will be stationed in Wilmington. **********Others who are expected to move to Delaware include Edward Grebow, vice president of J.P. Morgan, and Bruce T. Prolow, treasurer of Morgan Data Services, which is based in Jersey City. Mr. Grebow would be general manager for operations, and Mr. Prolow would be manager of organization. **********Mr. Dyche said most of the staff would be hired locally. Morgan is negotiating to lease 45,000 square feet, or one and a half floors, in the Delaware Trust Building in downtown Wilmington. **********As does Morgan Guaranty, Morgan Bank (Delaware) would concentrate on doing business with corporations, governments and other large institutions in the United States and overseas. It is initially expected to rely heavily on participation in loans initiated by Morgan Guaranty and other banks. Over time, it it expected to develop its own business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/12/world.body_text: **********In a report disseminated today, a group of liberals charges that there is a danger that Poland's Communist Party will be taken over by conservatives who will frustrate the general desire for change. **********The report, written yesterday, comes just before the opening of an emergency party congress and clearly reflects concern on the part of radicals that their positions will not prevail. **********The report was compiled by an organization that calls itself Experience and the Future. It was founded in November 1978 and included more than 100 journalists, scholars and intellectuals, many of them from the Communist Party itself. The group has produced three other reports, including two published before the strikes last summer that predicted an explosion of social unrest. **********As the report was being circulated in the capital, Stanislaw Kania, the party leader, held a strategy session with 85 delegates from the central party apparatus who will be attending the congress as delegates. The congress opens Tuesday. An Agenda Is Discussed **********The meeting was a basic strategy session. Topics for discussion included the agenda for the congress, voting procedures and the lineup of candidates for higher office with official backing. **********The congress is crucial to the future of the Polish party and its attempts to grapple with the workers' rebellion that erupted in response to meat price increases a year ago. It will elect a new leadership, consider changes in the statutes governing the party and come up with an overall program of party ideology and action to combat the crisis. **********The Experience and the Future report said the political situation had changed dramatically since a Central Committee meeting June 9 so that ''the position of extreme conservatives has strengthened.'' **********It said that there had been ''manipulations'' against intellectuals and reformers by the party apparatus in the provinces, an apparent reference to the selection procedure for delegates to the congress. Victory for Kania Expected **********It is now widely predicted that Mr. Kania, who rose to power at the height of unrest in September, will easily win re-election as first secretary. Party sources predict that Mr. Kania will place his election before the 1,964 delegates on the opening day, an unprecedented event for a Communist Party congress and a move that would strengthen his ability to control the direction of the congress and keep it from becoming either too conservative or too liberal. **********There is also speculation that Stefan Olszowski, a ranking hardliner on the Politburo, may be elevated to a new position as chairman of a new party institution called the presidium. This organ, to be comprised of 40 members, would be responsible for guiding the work of the Central Committee, which will be largely transformed by new people. **********However, the creation of a party presidium, which would entail a change in the party's statutes, has not yet been fully agreed upon, party sources indicated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/22/busin.body_text: **********PARIS I n 1980, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, the huge French oil company that later paid $2.5 billion to take over Texasgulf Inc., hoped to make a far bigger, $5 billion acquisition of another American company, Kerr-McGee. It never happened, and the reason was that Elf's big and even more powerful brother, the French Government, took a look at the deal, didn't like it and quashed it. **********Elf's chairman, Albin Chalandon, maintains that the order to halt the transaction came directly from the Elysee Palace of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, and that Elf still doesn't know why it was given. **********The incident illustrates the way the decisions of a national company can be subject to government policy. The Prime Minister in the Giscard d'Estaing Government, Raymond Barre, acknowledged that it was he who ordered the Kerr-McGee plan aborted. He did so, he said in an interview here, for diplomatic reasons. Another former minister, who asked not to be identified, added that Mr. Chalandon, who has operated Elf first and foremost as a profit producer, had taken the bidding process too far without approval, exceeding the authority the state allowed. **********For all that, Mr. Chalandon and the Giscard d'Estaing Government were essentially on the same wavelength. The question now is how such companies will be run under their new master - the Socialist Government of Francois Mitterrand. Elf says it may well continue to initiate big takeover bids in the United States, such as the Texasgulf acquisition. Others see the company's assets put to use pursuing Government policy - propping up employment where necessary and buying up bankrupt French companies. **********In addition, there is the clash of goals and style. Mr. Chalandon was not available for interviews, but he told the company's annual meeting in May that ''Elf's dynamism and prosperity have aroused as much mistrust as satisfaction on the part of our supervisory authorities.'' The sources of friction between such a man and a left-wing government are liable to be legion, and it may be difficult for him to live with the objectives of a government that is bringing more business under the state's control. When the nationalization bill of Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy becomes law, an overwhelming majority of France's largest companies will be state-run. **********Perhaps most significant, the nationalization of most of the financial sector means that the allocation of credit will be statedirected to a far greater degree than that of any other Western country, and Paris banking circles are convinced that the Government will name a Communist to the chairmanship of at least one big newly nationalized bank. **********Sixty-seven percent of Elf Aquitaine is owned by the Government.  The company, put together from a number of small oil companies shortly after Charles de Gaulle's return to power in 1958, is a key factor in the economy and easily the largest company in terms of assets in France. It produces around a quarter of the country's petroleum needs from gas fields in southwest France and oil wells in Gabon, Nigeria, the North Sea and the United States. The 33 percent of the stock still in private hands is alone worth more than 10 percent of all the stock traded on the Paris Bourse. Elf last year earned 5.8 billion francs - well over $1 billion - up 250 percent since Mr. Chalandon became chairman in 1977. **********Elf's management regards the United States as one of the few places in the world where profit is not likely to become a dirty word. It may take some time to digest its recent takeover of Texasgulf - but it probably hasn't satisfied its appetite for American properties.  ''In principle, Texasgulf is the platform on which we'll build,'' says Jean-Yves Chereau, the Paris executive for Elf's North American operations, ''but Texasgulf is not the end.'' **********The Texasgulf takeover, in fact, came about almost coincidentally, rather than as the planned answer to Elf's strategic needs. The idea originated with the Canada Development Corporation, and its desire to acquire Elf's considerable assets in Canada. Elf was worried about its ability to develop these assets under Ottawa's National Energy Program and, says Mr. Chereau, some of its holdings offered only long-term prospects of profit. **********Texasgulf, by contrast, offered a relatively rapid payout, so Elf accepted a complex plan, structured by Salomon Brothers, under which its Canadian properties and those of Texasgulf passed under the control of Canada, while the United States properties of Texasgulf came under that of Elf - and thus, incidentally, of the French Government. **********The United States companies Elf had been considering give an idea of where it may make a new thrust. The most recent were certain subsidiaries of Diamond Shamrock. Negotiations over these, according to Elf's vice chairman, Gilbert Rutman, were abandoned for reasons that provide an intriguing pointer to possible moves in the future. **********''Our lawyers,'' he says, ''warned us that, if we accepted the data Diamond Shamrock was offering on these subsidiaries, we would have seen inside information that would prevent us, at some time in the future, from bidding for Diamond Shamrock itself.'' **********For the time being, therefore, all negotiations with Diamond Shamrock have stopped, as have those with another American company to come under Elf's active consideration, Ashland Oil. The Ashland negotiations, however, were broken off, Elf sources say, for ''insider'' reasons of a different type. Whereas few people were aware of the possibility of deals involving Texasgulf or Diamond Shamrock, dozens of Elf employees, according to one senior executive, knew about its interest in Ashland. The stock took off, and Elf backed off. **********As for Kerr-McGee, rumors about Elf's intentions had run rife in the spring of last year. One day in May the July 80 call option on Kerr-McGee jumped from 5 to 6 3/4 - a rise of 35 percent. **********The Kerr-McGee episode created an open breach between Mr. Chalandon and the Barre Cabinet. The Cabinet felt that the size of Kerr-McGee, and of the estimated $5 billion needed to take it over was at least three times what the Government had been led to expect that Elf might be planning. Mr. Barre said he felt that to make an unfriendly bid for an American resource company of that size, given the delicate state of French-American relations, would be undiplomatic. As a result, Mr. Barre stopped the bid hours before it was to be started, and a few weeks later he restructured the company in a way that would give the Government firmer control over broad policy decisions. **********Up to then, Mr. Chalandon had been chairman of the holding company, Erap, which votes the Government's stock, as well as head of the operating company, Elf. Now the Government removed him from the chairmanship of Erap, putting Pierre Alby, chief executive of Gaz de France, the state-controlled gas utility, in his place. **********Although Mr. Barre says he tried to calm Mr. Chalandon by telling him that the idea was to give him greater autonomy in the normal operation of Elf, Mr. Chalandon didn't see it that way: Elf views the reform as an attempt to weaken the Elf group ''and to humiliate its managers,'' he said at the May annual meeting. **********Working with the new master may be tricky for Mr. Chalandon because he is politically far to the other side -an ex-chairman of a rightwing party who was nominated to Elf's leadership by the right-wing leader, Jacques Chirac, when Mr. Chirac was Prime Minister under Mr. Giscard d'Estaing. **********W ITH France's unemployment soaring, one conflict between what Elf's management sees as best for the company and what the Government considers best for the country is likely to heat up rapidly. Prime Minister Mauroy says the creation of jobs is his administration's top priority. **********Elf has substantial overcapacity in its domestic refineries, and it needs to shut some of them down. Will its new Socialist overlords allow it to do so? Not if it involves cutting back on employment, says Mr. Rutman, the Elf vice chairman. **********''We think the agreement between us and the Government will be 'you eliminate 200 jobs, but you must replace them with 200 other jobs in the same area.' '' The company won't create ghost towns, he says: ''If we can't create jobs in a place where we want to shut an operation, we won't shut.'' **********Mr. Rutman willingly concedes that this sort of operational stricture is not going to do anything positive for Elf's earnings.  Another burden on them is likely to be a governmental requirement that Elf use its enormous financial resources to buy up failing French companies. Since Elf is a state-controlled enterprise, its acquisition of other companies will bring even more industry under the state - without making it necessary for the Government to pass additional nationalization bills. **********Another area in which the Socialists may intervene in Elf management may be most controversial of all. According to one top Government official (who, for obvious reasons, declines to be identified), Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Mauroy are already laying plans to move their own people into key jobs in nationalized companies. One senior Elf executive says the company is holding back from creating new management positions, for fear the Government will insist on filling them with Socialist Party members. **********Mr. Rutman denies that this sort of infiltration has taken place so far, but he says ''it would be naive'' to suppose there will not be pressure of this sort in the future. People can be ''recommended,'' he observes, and although he adds that ''officially the Government has no right to put its people into Elf, any more than any stockholder,'' the recommendation of the holder of 67 percent of a stock is likely to get attention. **********At Texasgulf, Richard D. Mollison, the chief executive, is 65 years old, and people in Paris are studiously noncommittal about who will succeed him. Mr. Alby, head of the holding company, says ''it's up to Elf to decide whether they name a Frenchman to take Mollison's place: As far as we're concerned, the question is the extent to which Texasgulf is responding to the wishes of the mother company.'' **********Gaston Rimarex, chief of staff at the Ministry of Energy, makes a similar point: He notes that while many French subsidiaries of United States companies are run by Frenchmen, many other United States companies put Americans in charge to insure that the strategy of the subsidiary ties in with that of the parent. **********The thought of tying in with the strategy of a parent that is, when all is said and done, a Socialist Government, may be somewhat daunting to executives of Texasgulf and of any other United States company on which Elf sets its sights. Mr. Chereau, the executive committee member, however, puts forward two faintly reassuring thoughts. **********''We've no intention of implanting the black beret and the baguette of bread in Stamford, Conn.,'' he says, speaking of Texasgulf's headquarters. ''We want to be viewed as serious business people,'' at least partly, because ''if the chance to make another acquisition comes up,'' the seriousness of Elf's work will have made it acceptable to the United States business community.   ---------------------------------------------------------------------  John Carson-Parker is a freelance writer specializing in the economics of foreign countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/06/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1981; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/06/busin.body_text: **********The Government will institute a trade action for the first time next week, accusing foreign governments of unfairly subsidizing steel exports to this country, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige announced. The move was viewed as increasing the dangers of a trade war. The countries that are expected to be cited are France, Belgium, Luxembourg, Rumania and South Africa. (Page A1.) **********President Reagan is inclined to maintain his economic package unchanged, despite advice from aides and Republicans in Congress that he raise taxes to balance the budget. The debate within the Administration on the course of economic policy was said to be growing increasingly bitter. (D1.) **********The prime lending rate was cut by the Chemical Bank for the second time this week. The new rate, down half a percentage point to 17 percent, matched the lowest rate of the year, set in March, but no other major banks followed Chemical's lead. Some economists predicted an industrywide move to the lower rate within days. (D1.) **********The F.C.C. moved toward dropping its ban on ownership of cable TV stations by broadcasters and major television networks. It approved publication of a staff report supporting that view, and after 30 days is likely to propose the new policy formally. (D1.) **********Most retail chain stores reported October sales gains were modest at best compared with the same month last year. Two retailers - Woolworth and Montgomery Ward - said sales for the month slipped from October 1980. Analyst warned that the Christmas season, when 40 percent of general merchandise is sold, could be bleak. (D2.) **********The White House issued its list of Federal loan guarantee cuts. The main item in the $20.3 billion reduction will be $16 billion cut from Federal support for home-purchase loans. Also included will be cuts for small business, rural development and trade adjustment. (D3.) **********Sugar price support loans that would increase sugar users' prices at least 2 cents a pound this year were accepted by a House-Senate conference committee working. The current market price for raw sugar delivered in New York is about 16 cents a pound. (A19.) Companies **********I.B.M. will pay Ford up to $200 million for the right to use Ford's investment tax credits and depreciation deductions on nearly $1 billion in machinery that the auto maker has bought this year, the companies said. The transaction is built around a new kind of leasing arrangement approved as part of the Reagan tax program. (D1.) **********Grumman reported its third-quarter earnings fell 17.2 percent, to $5.3 million. McDermott said its earnings in the second fiscal quarter of 1982 more than doubled. Blue Bell's earnings in its fourth fiscal quarter of 1981, ended Sept. 30, dropped 38.4 percent. (D6.) **********Dayton Hudson plans to expand by more than 750 stores in the next five years, the company said. (D5.) Energy **********Energy companies are starting to pour billions into shale oil.  Though some experts remain dubious of the future of this resource, Exxon and Tosco see their new plant in Colorado producing 50,000 barrels of shale oil a day in 1985, or about 1 percent of what the U.S. now imports. (D1.) Markets **********The stock market retreated amid profit-taking. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.71 points, to 859.11. (D8.) The Treasury sold $2 billion of 30-year, 14 percent bonds at an average yield of 14.10 percent, completing a heavy week of financing. (D11.) Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose a relatively slight $443.2 million in the week ended Wednesday. (D5.) The dollar was mixed, while gold prices dropped $2 an ounce, to $427.80, on the Comex. (D12.) Futures prices for oats soared. (D12.) Today's Columns **********How can the Administration cure ''stagflation'' without triggering more inflation or a severe depression? It seems to rely on the recession against the former, and tax cuts, arms spending and a rising deficit against the latter. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene.  (D2.) **********Central Louisiana Energy is spinning off its electric utility to become a regional energy company. Some analysts say that the energy segment may go from $4.25 to $5.15 a share by 1982, an even more impressive rate of growth than before. Market Place. (D8.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Carbocol, a Colombian state-owned coal corporation, has asked Japanese cement, electric power and steel concerns to import an unspecified amount of Colombian coal under a long-term agreement, Government sources said here today. Carbocol plans to develop the El Cerrejon coal field in northern Colombia jointly with Intercor, the Exxon Corporation's Colombian unit.  Production at the coal field is scheduled to start in 1986 and is expected to increase to 15 million tons a year by 1990.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of America said it would increase the annual percentage rate and change the late charge on its bank card accounts beginning in February 1982. **********Bank of America, which operates one of the nation's largest card program after Citibank, now charges its customers 1.5 percent a month, or an annual percentage rate of 18 percent. **********The increase, which will apply to BankAmericard, Visa and MasterCard accounts, will raise the monthly rate to 1.65 percent, or an annual percentage rate of 19.8 percent. **********Bank of America's late charge, which currently ranges from $1 to $5 on minimum payments that are 15 days or more overdue, will be changed to $5 regardless of the amount overdue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.body_text: **********Philip H. Dougherty Intermarco Looks Back **********A YEAR ago in the light, airy, dignified and sincere surroundings of the Plaza's Palm Court, Ramon G. Gaulke, just getting accustomed to being chairman of Intermarco-America, talked expansively about the newly formed shop and its breakthrough plan. **********Imagine an ad agency with no account executives to act as liaison with the client, having the creative teams doing that work themselves. **********Well, it seemed like a good idea at the time.  Back in the Palm Court for breakfast yesterday was the same Ramon Gaulke, one-time president of Marsteller, who as before was accompanied by Gerard Pedraglio, vice chairman of the Intermarco-Farner network of the Publicis group that is half owner of Mr. Gaulke's operation. **********Mr. Gaulke acknowledged that the original concept was a bum idea and Arlene Hoffman, his president and creative director who was not on hand a year ago, more than agreed with him. Having heard Mr.  Gaulke complain, ''I think we are begining to collapse physically,'' she added, ''Suddenly I have a warm spot in my heart for account people.'' **********''You can't grow big under this system and you have to grow big,'' added Mr. Gaulke, probably becoming the 9,784th ad agency founder to change his grand initial plans. **********''And besides, it takes too much time from the creative people,'' added Miss Hoffman, putting in a word for her discipline.  Luckily, Intermarco Advertising as it is now called, is in 5,600 new square feet at 4 West 58th Street (over the Paris Theater) that can more than accommodate an influx of account executives, quite a few account executives. **********And a few will be needed, since, according to Mr. Gaulke, the agency, as planned and hoped for in a first-year projection, is now billing at the rate of $10 million, which is coming from 11 regular clients and two more for special projects. **********One of the more fascinating aspects of Intermarco's client list is the presence of five different alcoholic beverage assignments with no client concerns about a conflict problem. **********One is Cointreau America, posters for which just went up in bus stop shelters, and the others are De Motal Armagnac; Buton Distillers for a new product from Italy; Mediterranean Importing for Fazi Battaglia, and Peartree Imports for Reynac aperitif. **********A number of these assignments are for the full marketing treatment, which means from point-of-sale material and up. Hence, Miss Hoffman's complaint about exhaustion. **********Since nothing goes better with a jug of wine than a bit of cheese and a piece of French bread, Intermarco has cleverly added a few calories to the client list with Boursin cheese and Bagettines de Paris, a baker. **********To go with the baker there is also a banker, the BNP Bank, a French institution, as well as Business Week International; Akwell Industries, the condom manufacturing subsidiary of G.D. Searle, and Flymo, which manufactures a lawn mower that rides on a cushion of air. **********That happens to be a lot of business to be handled by a dozen people in what Mr. Gaulke characterizes as ''a full-service agency except for a research department.'' **********As you have probably already noted, practically all of the client companies are either foreign or international in interest. The latter category would also include Mr. Gaulke and Miss Hoffman, who had also worked at Marsteller before setting up her own agency to handle the Jamaica Tourist Board. **********And one part of the European scene that particularly interests both is the look of the advertising - more emphasis on the graphics, especially in television, taking advantage of the medium. **********''In the U.S.,'' Miss Hoffman said, ''there's too much copy, too much hard sell, which is getting to be less and less effective.  Graphics get the message across quicker and better.'' **********In hopes of capturing the spirit, Intermarco is using European photographers for still and motion pictures.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/25/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Professor Thurow focuses on the most perverse, although probably the least discussed, procedural obstacle to feasible price stabilization: the scattered scheduling of major union contract negotiations and the overlapping maturities of multi-year agreements. **********As long as the practice is allowed to continue, the reciprocal escalation of costs and profits per unit of output, the only two components of price, is almost guaranteed to follow suit. **********Professor Thurow correctly identifies the urgent need as a common, equitable point of departure for annually negotiated compensation adjustments, with no interim indexing of benefits to the rate of inflation. The only way to bring this about is through legislation. **********If it is deemed unconstitutional, unfair or unduly divisive to abrogate the future adjustment clauses of outstanding contracts, an alternative would be to limit the maturities of all upcoming agreements to the most distant date covered by any major agreement already on the books when the legislation is passed. This would provide a three-year transition during which expiring contracts would be rewritten in the light of the nominal benefits achieved by the groups that preceded.  HUGH R. CHACE Nantucket, Mass., Jan. 13, 1981

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/23/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM A STATEMENT ON REAGAN AND SCHMIDT DISCUSSIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/23/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM A STATEMENT ON REAGAN AND SCHMIDT DISCUSSIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/23/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts of a statement issued at the end of talks between President Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany: **********The President and the Federal Chancellor welcomed and reaffirmed the results of the recent NATO ministerial meetings in Rome and Brussels as renewed proof of the political strength of the alliance and the continuity of alliance policy. **********They stressed the determination of alliance members to take the necessary steps to work with their NATO partners to strengthen the Western defense posture and to address adverse trends due to the Soviet military buildup. Together with deterrence and defense, arms control and disarmament are integral parts of alliance security policy. **********The President and the Federal Chancellor affirmed in this connection their resolve to implement both elements of the NATO decision of December 1979 and to give equal weight to both elements. **********The Federal Chancellor welcomed the U.S. decision to begin negotiations with the Soviet Union on the limitation of theater nuclear weapons within the SALT framework by the end of this year. Arms Talks Are Welcomed **********He also welcomed the fact that the U.S. Secretary of State has initiated preparatory discussions on theater nuclear forces with the Soviet Union, looking toward an agreement to begin formal negotiations. The President and the Federal Chancellor agreed that T.N.F. modernization is essential for alliance security and as a basis for parallel negotiations leading to concrete results on limitations of theater nuclear forces. **********The President and the Federal Chancellor assessed very favorably the close cooperation between the Federal Republic of Germany and the Three Powers in matters relating to Berlin and Germany as a whole.  The Federal Chancellor thanked the President for his reaffirmation of the pledge that the United States will continue to guarantee the security and viability of Berlin. **********Both sides noted that a serious international situation has been created by Soviet expansionism and armaments efforts. To meet this challenge and to secure peace, they are determined to respond with firmness and to maintain a dialogue with the Soviet Union. **********The President and the Federal Chancellor agreed that it is important for the stabilization of East-West relations that the current C.S.C.E. review conference in Madrid agree on a balanced substantive concluding document which includes enhanced respect for human rights, increased human contacts, a freer flow of information and cooperation among and security for all of the participants. No Interference in Poland **********In this regard, and as part of such a balanced result, the President and the Chancellor favor agreement on a precise mandate for a conference on disarmament in Europe, providing for the application of militarily significant, binding and verifiable confidence-building measures covering all of the continent of Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals. **********Poland must be allowed to solve its problems peacefully and without external interference. The President and the Federal Chancellor reaffirmed unequivocally their view that any external intervention would have the gravest consequences for international relations and would fundamentally change the entire international situation. **********Genuine nonalignment of the states of the developing world is an important stabilizing factor in international relations. The Chancellor and the President support the independence and the right of self-determination of the states of the developing world. They will, in concert with their allies and the countries affected, oppose any attempts, direct or indirect, by the Soviet Union to undermine the independence and stability of these states. **********The President and the Federal Chancellor reaffirmed their view that the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan is unacceptable. They demanded the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan and respect for that country's right to return to independence and nonalignment. Cooperation on the Middle East **********Both sides stressed the importance of broad-based cooperation with the states of the Gulf region.  The President and the Federal Chancellor agreed that the United States and the Federal Republic of Germany, the latter within the framework of European political cooperation, should continue the search for a comprehensive, just and lasting peace in the Middle East. Their efforts should continue to be complementary and build upon what has been achieved so far. **********Both sides reaffirmed the determination to strengthen further the open system of world trade and to oppose pressure for protectionist measures. **********They stressed the vital importance for political and economic stability of further energy conservation and diversification measures to reduce the high degree of dependence on oil. The pressing energy problems can only be mastered on the basis of worldwide cooperative efforts that strengthen Western energy security and reduce the vulnerability of the West to potential supply cutoffs from any source. **********The President and the Federal Chancellor agreed on the need in framing their economic policies to give high priority to the fight against inflation and to the creation of improved conditions for renewed economic growth and increased productivity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Spanish Police Kill F ugitive Rebel Leader
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/06/world.body_text: **********A leader of a Spanish guerrilla group was shot and killed in a gunfight today after he refused to surrender, the police said. **********The police said they surrounded the apartment of Enrique Cerdan Calixto, 31 years old, and called him on the telephone and ordered him to surrender. **********The police said he tried to escape through an apartment window and exchanged pistol fire with policemen for nearly an hour. **********Mr. Cerdan Calixto escaped 18 months ago from a prison in northwest Spain where he was serving a 30-year sentence for killing two policemen. **********The police said he was the leader of the Revolutionary Anti-Fascist Group of the First of October, and the last ''dangerous'' member of the group still at large.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.main_headline: A SOVIET ENVOY DENIES MOSCOW SUPPLIES ARMS TO SALVADOR GUERRILLAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.print_headline: A SOVIET ENVOY DENIES MOSCOW SUPPLIES ARMS TO SALVADOR GUERRILLAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.body_text: **********A senior Soviet representative denied today that Moscow was supplying arms to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador but conceded that the Kremlin was sending arms to Cuba and Ethiopia without putting any restrictions on transshipments to other countries. **********Vladilen M. Vasev, Minister Counselor of the Soviet Embassy in Washington, also suggested that the Reagan Administration was publicly talking tough toward the Russians in part to build up an ''ultrapatriotic'' mood that would accept large increases in military spending at a time of economic troubles and prospective cuts in domestic programs. Shift in Soviet Diplomacy **********Mr. Vasev's appearance in several radio and television interviews lately marks a significant departure for Soviet propaganda and diplomacy in Washington. It evidently reflects a Soviet decision to meet charges from the Reagan Administration quickly with public appearances in this country rather than relying purely on press commentaries and official statements in Moscow. **********Mr. Vasev rejected what he called a suggestion that the United Sates ''could impose on the Soviet Union'' a ''code of conduct'' for international relations, a subject reportedly raised by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. with the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F.  Dobrynin, at a private dinner on Feb. 5. **********In an interview on the Cable News Network ''Newsmaker'' program, Mr. Vasev said that the Soviet leadership might have to ''take countermeasures'' such as increasing its own military spending in response to steps now contemplated by the Reagan Administration. **********While he voiced uneasiness about the tough line of the new Administration, he said that Moscow would show ''patience and restraint'' and not jump to quick conclusions about its longer-term intentions. ''We're not going to escalate it,'' he said. **********Top Administration officials contend that tens of millions of dollars worth of Soviet arms are being shipped to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador, but Mr. Vasev said in the television interview and in later remarks to The New York Times that this issue had not been raised officially with the Soviet Union by the Reagan Administration. **********Asked whether official complaints had been made to the Soviet Government, he replied: ''You haven't, and had you made, I would have refuted it. The Soviet Union is not concerned with arms shipments to Salvador, and that's a statement of fact. The Soviet Union is not involved, and you can't pin it on us.'' **********Pressed to say whether Soviet weaponry was moving to Cuba and Ethiopia and from there to El Salvador, as the Administration has charged, he replied: ''We do ship armaments to Cuba as a matter of Soviet-Cuban relations. We do supply arms to Ethiopia as a matter of Soviet-Ethiopian relations. But I flatly deny that there is any Soviet supply of arms to the guerrilla forces in Salvador.'' **********He was reminded that the United States often required recipients of American weapons to agree not to transship them to third countries and was asked whether Moscow did the same. **********''Sometimes we do, sometimes we don't,'' he replied. ''If we trust the other side that the arms will not be used against Soviet interests, we don't.'' Later, asked by The Times whether Moscow imposed restrictions on Cuba and Ethiopia, he added, ''In the case of the Cubans and Ethiopians, no.'' **********The Soviet diplomat, the second-ranking member of the mission here, said that after ''unprovoked remarks'' toward Moscow by President Reagan and Secretary Haig, the prospect for Soviet-American relations ''doesn't look very promising.'' But he pointedly declined to predict that the two superpowers were heading back into a cold war period. **********The Soviet leadership, he said, can afford to wait to see what actual steps the new Administration will take in the months ahead, and he contended that some of the ''purely artificial'' sharpening of American statements was intended to create a better domestic climate for higher military spending. **********''This is working up a tough attitude toward the Soviet Union which helps ul@trapatriotism when the crunch of guns-versus-butter comes,'' he told The Times. ''We are not worried. You often waste money. We'll have to look where you spend your money. In order to shift the military balance, one needs a lot of time.'' **********In the present climate, Mr. Vasev asserted, Moscow is indifferent to whether the Reagan Administration lifts or continues the embargo on grain shipments to the Soviet Union or makes efforts to increase trade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/30/world.body_text: **********TEXT OF REAGAN'S ANNOUNCEMENT OF SANCTIONS **********LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 (AP) - Following is the text of President Reagan's announcement today of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union: **********LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 (AP) - Following is the text of President Reagan's announcement today of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union: **********The Soviet Union bears a heavy and direct responsibility for the repression in Poland. For many months the Soviets publicly and privately demanded such a crackdown. They brought major pressures to bear through now-public letters to the Polish leadership, military maneuvers and other forms of intimidation. They now openly endorse the suppression which has ensued. **********Last week, I announced that I had sent a letter to President Brezhnev urging him to permit the restoration of basic human rights in Poland as provided for in the Helsinki Final Act. I also informed him that, if the repression continued, the United States would have no choice but to take further concrete political and economic measures affecting our relationship. U.S. Concern **********The repression in Poland continues, and President Brezhnev has responded in a manner which makes it clear the Soviet Union does not understand the seriousness of our concern, and its obligations under both the Helsinki Final Act and the U.N. Charter. **********I have, therefore, decided to take the following immediate measures with regard to the Soviet Union: **********- All Aeroflot service to the United States will be suspended. **********- The Soviet Purchasing Commission is being closed. **********- The issuance or renewal of licenses for the export to the U.S.S.R. of electronic equipment, computers and other high-technology materials is being suspended. **********- Negotiations on a new long-term grains agreement are being postponed. **********- Negotiations on a new U.S.-Soviet maritime agreement are being suspended, and a new regime of port-access controls will be put into effect for all Soviet ships when the current agreement expires on Dec. 31. **********- Licenses will be required for export to the Soviet Union for an expanded list of oil and gas equipment. Issuance of such licenses will be suspended. This includes pipelayers. **********- U.S.-Soviet exchange agreements coming up for renewal in the near future, including the agreements on energy and science and technology, will not be renewed. There will be a complete review of all other U.S.-Soviet exchange agrements. Next Actions **********The United States wants a constructive and mutually beneficial relationship with the Soviet Union. We intend to maintain a highlevel dialogue. But we are prepared to proceed in whatever direction the Soviet Union decides upon - towards greater mutual restraint and cooperation, or further down a harsh and less rewarding path. **********We will watch events in Poland closely in coming days and weeks.  Further steps may be necessary, and I will be prepared to take them.  American decisions will be determined by Soviet actions. **********Secretary Haig has been in communication with our friends and allies about the measures we are taking and explained why we believe such steps are essential at this time. **********Once again, I call upon the Soviet Union to recognize the clear desire of the overwhelming majority of the Polish people for a process of national reconciliation, renewal and reform.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/06/world.body_text: **********A three-man military junta has assumed control of the country, but the two rebel generals who forced the resignation last night of President Luis Garcia Meza are holding out for further negotiations. **********The commanders of the army, the navy and the air force said they had formed a ruling triumvirate, the 190th Government Bolivia has had in its 156-year history. **********The country seems apprehensive but calm. People here in the capital crowded outside appliance stores that had televisions in their windows to learn of the latest developments. **********In Santa Cruz, 300 miles away, Gen. Alberto Natusch Busch and Gen.  Lucio Anez Rivero said they did not recognize the junta and were waiting for its members to come to talk to them. Junta spokesmen said the three service chiefs had no plans to go. **********The rebel coup was the fifth attempt to overthrow General Garcia Meza since he came to power in a coup more than a year ago.  The rebels accused him of being corrupt and linked to the country's drug traffic. They said that Bolivia's legitimate economy was in disarray and that the country had become internationally isolated. **********The United States and several other countries have cut all economic aid and never recognized the Garcia Meza regime.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/18/busin.body_text: **********TOKYO **********T WO years ago, Tatsuya Tamura, an employee of the Bank of Japan, decided that a new car might be in order. He and his wife, Miyuki, visited some showrooms, then retired home to ponder choices. **********One evening, a salesman they had talked to unexpectedly knocked at the door, interrupting the family supper. ''I was not very happy,'' Mr. Tamura recalled, ''but he waited outside about an hour until we finished. Then he came in and I was impressed with his eagerness to sell a car.'' **********This is the Japanese way. While winter afternoon sunlight gleams off the the polished red, gray and brown Toyota Corollas sitting in a glass-enclosed showroom that is headquarters to 350 new-car salesmen - and 60 used-car salesmen - the buyers are at home. Very much unlike the system in the United States, the salesmen follow them there. **********Situated near Shibuya Station, Tokyo's third-busiest commuter point, the Toyota Tokyo Corolla dealership sold more than 24,000 cars last year. Yet days at a time go by without a prospective customer walking through one of the three glass entrances. No salesmen patrol the floor, ready to spout mileage statistics, kick tires or cut deals for interested parties or reluctant buyers. **********''Japanese customers are timid compared to Western customers,'' says Toshio Sato, a section chief in the Toyota Tokyo Corolla headquarters. ''If they come into the showroom and the clerks try to explain about the cars, it scares them away. They want the salesmen to come to their home where they can decide in their own castle.'' **********Dickering, on the other hand, goes on in much the same way as in the United States (but no discount exceeds 10 percent of the asking price, said Mr. Sato of his dealership). Buyers haggle over the value of the old car to be traded in and about which accessories, such as a stereo or FM radio, might be added - as well as straight price. **********Indeed, Mr. Tamura, negotiating the eagerness of the salesman, got a cut price on his new Toyota Calina. ''Cars were selling very fast then, so a discount was not very easy to get,'' he said, with some satisfaction. **********About 60 percent of new Japanese cars are purchased on an installment plan - 15 percent down and 24 months to pay under current government guidelines - according to Mitsuya Goto of Nissan, makers of Datsuns. The rest are purchased for cash, sometimes borrowed from a finance company. **********Mr. Goto observes that the average length of car ownership in Japan is around 47 months, just under four years, but that an owner is likely to be more ready to trade in his current vehicle just before ''shaken'' time rolls around. Shaken is the mandatory inspection required of every car and truck in Japan every two years. **********Unlike the fairly casual American system, the shaken is a bolt-bybolt review. It accounts for the extraordinarily good condition of vehicles on Japanese streets. It also means many drivers would rather buy a new car instead of paying a mechanic to get everything up to snuff. **********Automobile salesmen know when each vehicle in their territory is due for a new inspection, and schedule visits accordingly. They also know other bits of personal information about their prospective customers, culled from local government files or the nearby residents' association. **********''He may know a housewife's birthday and will give her a small present then,'' explains Mr. Sato.  What sells best here? Mostly Toyota and Nissan models. Toyota put out six of the 10 top sellers here last year and Nissan, three. Only the Mazda, made by the Toyo Kogyo Corporation, dented the ToyotaNissan dominance. **********And what is the worst seller? The import. Registrations of foreign cars plunged last year to 44,900 -accounting for less than 1 percent of the national total - from 60,000 in 1979. A tradition of tariff barriers, although those are gone now, plus service problems given the low volume of sales, plus the very entrenched nature of the national industry, and a host of assorted other factors have made the import, in effect, a nonstarter. **********Last year was the second-best year on record for domestic sales, and Toyota Motor Company president Eiji Toyoda predicts that 1981 will be slightly better for the industry. ''This means, of course, that competition at home will also be more severe than ever this year,'' he says.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will hold an emergency meeting before the end of October, seeking an end to oil-pricing chaos before the group's December meeting in Abu Dhabi, a leading Kuwaiti newspaper said today. **********The daily al-Rai al-Aam said the meeting was originally scheduled for today but had been postponed because of undisclosed ''emergency circumstances.'' **********A Kuwaiti Government spokesman, Abdel Aziz Hussein, denied that any such meeting had been set for today, but he indicated that OPEC's oil ministers were holding private consultations and that an emergency session should not be ruled out. **********''Intensified contacts are under way between oil ministers of OPEC on the pricing issue,'' he said. ''If oil ministers consider holding an emergency meeting of OPEC necessary, the date and venue of the meeting will be agreed upon. But no agreement has been reached to convene such a meeting.'' **********The Kuwaiti newspaper also said that Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah, had persuaded Venezuela and Algeria to lower their prices to $34 a barrel in return for a Saudi price rise to the same level. Iraq has reduced its price by about $2 a barrel, to slightly more than $34. Algeria sells its oil for $40 a barrel, Venezuela for $36 and Saudi Arabia for $32. **********Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, has repeatedly refused to increase its prices unless others, particularly OPEC's North African states, accept a compromise and help close the pricing gap. **********During OPEC's last meeting, held in Geneva in August, the 13 member nations failed to agree on a common price for their crude, which varies from the Saudi low of $32 a barrel to the high of $40 a barrel for North African oil. **********The Kuwaiti newspaper said the current glut of about 3 million barrels a day, which is flooding the world oil market, had helped the Kuwaiti initiative gain momentum.
