https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company said today that it had been unable to reach agreement with the Toyota Motor Company for joint production of a Toyota-designed small car or van in the United States. **********Although the Ford announcement said that ''both companies share the belief that there is potential for a further business relationship,'' analysts said the Reagan Administration's imposition of restraints on Japanese imports had cooled Toyota's interest in working with the American company. **********A Ford official said that the chief problem was that vehicles suggested by Toyota for joint production either duplicated products already well along in development at Ford or were at design stages that could not be brought to market soon enough to be of any value to Ford. Talks Preceded Ruling **********Toyota initiated the talks last year, before the International Trade Commission ruled that imports were not the cause of the domestic auto industry's problems. **********''If you follow the status of the negotiations, you'll see they blew hot and cold depending on the status of trade negotiations,'' said Harvey Heinbach, an auto industry analyst with Merrill Lynch.  ''Toyota saw the joint venture as an option if it was shut out of the United States market.'' **********The Reagan Administration this spring rejected pleas from the automobile industry and labor for stiff restrictions on imports, opting instead for ''voluntary restraints'' to be administered by the Japanese Government. The restraints cut imports by 7.7 percent from their 1980 levels. Agreement Faded **********As recently as last autumn, top Toyota executives were saying that an agreement on the joint venture would be reached by the end of the year. However, earlier this month, Eiji Toyoda, president of Toyota, said that the two companies disagreed on the type of vehicle to be built. **********In the meantime, Saudi Arabia had warned Japan that Arab countries would boycott Totota products if the company started making cars in conjunction with Ford. Ford is on the so-called Arab blacklist of companies that do business with Israel. **********Analysts said that the agreement, had it been worked out, would have produced significant advantages for Ford, particularly if Toyota bore some of the costly process of designing a new model. Ford would also have been able to get the new model on the market more quickly than if limited to its own financial and engineering resources. **********Toyota, on the other hand, would have gained access to Ford's dealers and would have been spared the expense of building its own plant in the United States, since Ford has three unused assembly plants. **********Pressure on auto makers to manufacture in the United States came from another front yesterday as Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers Union, promised to ''launch a major effort'' to enact a law requiring companies that sell cars in the United States to do the bulk of the manufacturing here also. **********The objective, Mr. Fraser said, would be to force Japanese auto makers to make major investments and provide jobs and prevent American companies from shifting more of their operations to countries with lower wage rates. **********A union official said that even the possibility of such legislation would have an effect on automobile company investment decisions, even if it does not move quickly in Congress. He said the union hoped to have such a bill introduced by friendly legislators this summer. **********Mr. Fraser called for a law requiring companies selling more than 200,000 cars a year to have 75 percent of the value, or content, of the car performed in North America. For companies selling over 500,000 vehicles, the requirement would be 90 percent. Nissan and Toyota, the Japanese companies most successful in the United States would fall in the latter category. **********''Content legislation will not only address the savaging of the American economy by the Japanese,'' Mr. Fraser told an automotive industry meeting in Detroit today. ''It will also confront the exporting of American capital and jobs by General Motors and Ford.'' **********Both companies have been pressing the union to reopen the existing labor contract to extract concessions to lower their costs. Both have said they will import an increasing level of automobile components if the union does not cooperate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/busin.body_text: **********G IVEN the way inflation batters the dollar, why would anyone buy life insurance? After all, if one bought a $100,000 policy five years ago, it would only provide $55,000 of coverage in today's dollars, and the small return on whole-life policies doesn't even match the rates paid on passbook savings accounts. **********Yet the same inflationary forces that undermine the dollar make the average family ever more vulnerable in the event of the breadwinner's untimely death. The income of most families hasn't kept up with inflation, so most have taken on more debt than ever. And even without extra debt, a policy bought just a few years ago is unlikely to go far in helping a family maintain its existing standard of living. **********In such circumstances life insurance is still useful. Few insurance companies even pretend to promote life insurance as a way of building savings any more. But they stress the protective aspects of their product and have offered a slew of new policies designed to compensate for the effects of inflation. Those particularly targeted are in the 30-to-50 age group with dependent children or spouses. **********Essentially, life insurance falls into two broad groups - whole life (also known as permanent life) and term policies.  Most whole life policies require a fixed premium for a specified amount of coverage during a period of time. Often, part of the premiums are returned as dividends, increased coverage or as a form of savings as the years pass. **********There was a time when whole life policies were a form of savings account, with the policyholder looking forward to receiving a certain amount of cash after the insured period ended. Many whole life policies still have the cash-value feature, but in inflationary times one can earn a lot more on the same money invested elsewhere. Such policies come in a mind-boggling variety of forms, many of these custom-tailored to the policyholder's personal needs. **********By comparison, term policies are relatively simple. Usually, the coverage declines each year over the term of the policy - as does the premium. The idea is that the coverage should be highest when the policyholder's beneficiaries are most vulnerable. Sometimes, the burden of heavy early premiums is eased by charging an average payment each year. Coverage declines over the policy's life, but charges are fixed. **********Which is the best depends, of course, on the individual's needs.  But many insurance experts have come around to the view that term policies are the most practical for the average head of family. **********''The best policy for most people is one that provides pure protection, such as in a renewable, annual, term policy,'' said John T. McNamara, vice president and actuary at Alexander & Alexander Inc., a large international insurance brokerage house. While the premium will usually rise with each annual renewal, he explained, especially if the coverage is not reduced, the cost is actually less on a current basis than that on most whole life policies. **********''Forget about the fringes and other gimmicks,'' Mr. McNamara continued. ''In these inflationary times, one can also forget about cash values. There are far better ways to accumulate savings, such as money market funds.'' **********Those seeking protection, Mr. McNamara said, should make a preliminary study of their protection needs before discussing it with an insurance agent. **********''They should ask themselves what their dependents would need if they died today,'' he said. ''How long would they need it? What do they expect their economic situation to be until then? The insurance agent can help later on with the inflation and other factors.'' **********The problem with term policies comes when the policyholder passes 60 or 65 years of age, when insurers usually decline to issue these policies. **********''Ninety-nine percent of term policyholders outlive their coverage,'' said Julius Vogel, senior vice president and actuary at the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest.  This happens usually when the children are grown and the chief dependent is the policyholder's spouse. ''What happens next is that the term buyer is too old to afford such coverage, assuming he or she can get it.'' **********When the individual is wealthy and has large assets to protect, whole life policies are often necessary. ''Death duties have to be paid in cash, and if the estate is tied up because the assets are not liquid it could force distress selling of assets,'' said Mr.  McNamara. ''But people with important estates can usually afford whole life.'' **********Among the many variations of whole life policies, he continued, are those in which the policyholder can borrow some of the cash value of the insurance, and have the interest, which may range from 5 to 8 percent a year, as a tax-deductible item. **********This is done by buying the whole life policy and paying for it with a ''minimum deposit.'' By borrowing some of the future cash value many of these plans provide, one can work it so that in the first seven years only four annual payments are actually paid. The rest is borrowed at the cheap rates of interest, Mr. McNamara said. **********Mr. Vogel of Prudential offered a few other tips: ''We agree that these times demand the pure protection that is offered by term policies. But one can get the best of both. For example, one can obtain a whole life coverage at quite economic premiums by averaging the payments. This often involves paying somewhat more in the early years and using the dividends and cash value to offset inflationadjusted higher costs later on.'' **********Another of the many approaches involves a combination of whole life and term coverage in a policy that provides dividends. These usually cost more than simple declining coverage term policies. **********Under one such plan, Mr. Vogel said, a person aged 30 years could get a $100,000 term policy that decreases in coverage over a 20-year period for a first-year premium of $263. At age 35 the same policy would have a first-year cost of $340; at 40 years, $497. **********Assuming that a 35-year-old policyholder doesn't touch the dividends, ''the dividends would build as the coverage declines over the 20 years to the point where the premium in the final year would be $45'' and the coverage $20,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/23/busin.body_text: **********THERE were quite a few in the running for the job, but a consultant screened them and reduced the number to a manageable dozen. Then the client took over and further trimmed the competition to two and asked for presentations. The winner was the one that used the flip charts. **********Does this sound like an agency competition for a client? It wasn't. It was actually an agency looking for a new president.  The agency was David Deutsch Associates and the flip-chart user was Stephen R. Fajen, 40 years old. They were brought together by Robert S. Marker, former chairman of the executive committee of Needham, Harper & Steers and chairman of McCann-Erickson, now a consultant, who had known three of the Deutsch partners during his McCann phase and had Mr. Fajen as his assistant at Needham. **********The three partners, David Deutsch, 51 and chairman, who is giving up the president's title; Rocco E. Campanelli, 52, executive vice president, and Robert G. Kilzer, 44, senior vice president, are all from the creative side of the business - two art directors and a copywriter. **********They had called their old associate, Mr. Marker, in to develop a five-year plan for the agency because the partners felt they were overwhelmed with work. **********Mr. Deutsch recalled: ''One night Bob said to me, 'I know what you need, a new president.' And I said, 'Wait, that's my job.' ''Then he said, 'You need a fourth wheel.' That fourth wheel is Steve Fajen.'' **********The flip-chart presentation that tipped the scales came after Mr.  Fajen and his single competitor had already met with the agency partners four or five times, sometimes with their wives, and after Mr. Deutsch had put these questions to them: ''What would you do as president?'' And, ''Why do you want to be president?'' **********Mr. Fajen responded by saying that he did not want to shoot from the hip and asked if he could make a presentation instead.  One of the charts of particular interest was headed ''Agency Evolutions.'' In it, the presidential contender grouped agencies according to their size and labeled the six groups (starting at the bottom) as Survivors, Legitimates, Contenders, Vergers, Comfortables and Giants. **********Mr. Fajen plans that his new employer will be one of the Contenders, in there with the likes of Waring-LaRosa; Avrett, Free & Fischer; Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson; Ammirati & Puris, and Ally & Gargano. **********Those are the agencies, he explained, that, by virtue of their style and work, are frequently invited to compete against bigger agencies. **********Mr. Fajen would seem to have every reason to believe that he and his new associates belong with such a group. Collectively they have worked for 12 of the top 30 agencies and have gained experience with 70 advertisers, in every category. **********The new, pipe-smoking president, for example, having come out of the A.C. Nielsen Company, worked for Jack Tinker & Partners, the J.  Walter Thompson Company, McCaffrey & McCall and Needham, where he was general manager of the New York office and assistant to Mr. Marker. **********He is sure to find the atmosphere and clients different from the old homestead, since in his new agency, with its $12.5 million in annual billings, each of the 18 clients averages $400,000 in billings. Not exactly the big time, but everyone seems happy, and no matter how big an account, all ads have the same purpose: to sell. **********Mr. Fajen was given some stock and bought some more, but the man with his name on the door continues to be the man who is chief executive and has 51 percent of the stock. He insists on such control, Mr. Deutsch said, because he can then ''control the atmosphere -the people who come and go - and the quality of work that the agency produces.'' **********As to his motivation for joining a much smaller agency, the new president said, ''I decided to trade down for the fun of it and for the ability to make a difference in the place where I work.'' **********''While we never stop learning in this business,'' Mr. Fajen said at another point, ''there comes a time when you must trade in your mentors for partners, roll up your sleeves, then get your own coffee and your own accounts.'' Words to live by.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/busin.body_text: **********Among the biggest nonfamily fans of Campbell's new Backer & Spielvogel ''Soup is good food'' campaign are William and Carol Lewis and their client, Tabatchnick-Millburn, maker of Tabatchnick soup, a frozen food product in national distribution. **********They are planning to take a ride on the Campbell coattails by subliminally adding ''And Tabatchnick is good soup.'' **********That's not the theme, the theme is ''It's how people with taste say soup.'' The first TV campaign from the new Lewis agency starts today in the New York market.  Morrow Lewis & Kelley is the name of the agency but don't ask for Morrow or Kelley, they are merely family names added to the title since Lewis & Lewis would be too common to incorporate. **********President of the agency is William E. Lewis, formerly executive vice president of John Emmerling Inc., while Carol, a former partner in Jonson Pedersen Hinrichs & Shakery graphics design firm, is vice president and creative director. They have four clients all together and billings of $1.2 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/17/busin.body_text: **********Nearly 60,000 workers at BL Ltd., the former British Leyland, voted by a margin of 2 to 1 to walk off the job Nov. 2, defying threats by Sir Michael Edwardes, BL chairman, to close the ailing state-financed car company if the strike goes ahead. **********British Leyland employees, who earn an average of 112, or about $201, a week, want a $38 pay increase. **********The company says the introduction of a bonus plan has raised average earnings by 28 percent in the last year and has offered an increase of up to $7.20 on basic rates. **********Sir Michael responded by renewing his threat to liquidate the company. ''The people on strike will have their contracts of employment terminated without notice or redundancy pay and the plants will be closed,'' Sir Michael's spokesman said. He said there would be no more talks with the unions and the offer would not be increased.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/15/busin.body_text: **********The Gulf Oil Corporation said it will buy up to 10 million of its own shares from time to time, beginning later this month. **********The company said the shares will be bought in the open market or through privately negotiated transactions. **********Gulf said that the First Boston Corporation would act as exclusive agent to acquire the shares. Gulf Oil now has 195.2 million common shares outstanding. Based on today's closing price for Gulf stock, the indicated value of the repurchase would be about $375 million. **********The company also said that its directors had raised the quarterly dividend to 70 cents a share from 62.5 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/02/busin.body_text: **********The United States dollar, buoyed by higher interest rates, has shown greater and greater strength in recent months, in an upturn that began to pick up momentum last fall. **********It has not yet regained the lofty stature it held in the early 1970's, before the actions of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries plunged the American economy and the world financial order into disarray. But this week the dollar reached a 10-year high against the French franc, hit a record high against the Italian lira and has shown signs of strength relative to other currencies, including the West German mark. **********Yesterday, the dollar ended mixed in the United States and abroad after setting new highs against the French and Italian currencies. **********New Money Supply Signal **********Whether the dollar will continue to gain, currency analysts say, depends largely on the course of interest rates both here and abroad. The report yesterday of further strong growth in the money supply was a signal to many that interest rates are likely to be pushed up still higher next week, further strengthening the dollar. **********''For a year now, the broad movements in the dollar have closely followed what is happening to interest rates,'' said Anne Parker Mills, a vice president at the Irving Trust Company. ''We're now back in a period of rapidly rising U.S. interest rates and the dollar has been following suit.'' **********For the United States, the dollar's sustained climb represents the end -at least for the present - of a troubled four-year period, when there seemed to be nothing it could do to curb the use of costly foreign oil or stem the flight of investors from the dollar. **********Central bankers huddled, trade ministers parleyed, rescue packages worked for a while, and then faded away. The dollar might stage a recovery for a month or two, but then would plummet again. **********The turnabout in the dollar has seemed to parallel the fortunes of the Reagan camp. Things started looking up for the American currency, at about the time that the prospects of a Reagan victory seemed to take shape. The country had by no means defeated its inflation problems. But because of recession and energy conservation, it had had some success in slowing oil imports and narrowing the huge trade deficits. **********''The lesser oil imports and the more favorable trade balance are definitely a factor in the dollar's recovery,'' said Jonathan Francis, director of foreign exchange for Chase Econometrics. **********In recent weeks, the sharp upward swing in short-term interest rates has made dollar-denominated investments more attractive.  Increasingly, good balance-of-trade figures and widespread confidence in the Reagan economic program have also made the dollar more attractive. Other Economies Affected **********But the dollar's new momentum, though barely visible to most Americans, is setting off stunning reverberations in other countries. Their energy bills - paid in dollars - are climbing, which is touching off new inflationary tendencies in their economies. **********''What we are doing in fiscal and monetary policy has international implications,'' said Rimmer de Vries, senior vice president for international economics at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. ''Of course, none of these countries like a strong dollar, since they have been living off the weak dollar and lower oil prices. But it's a fact of life that they will have to live with for a while, since there are a lot of things going for the United States.'' **********Indeed, the higher American interest rates have put pressure on some European countries to raise their own interest rates to compete with the dollar, despite their generally weak economies and high levels of unemployment. Most have tried to resist, widening the differential between their interest rates and those of the United States. **********For the less-developed countries, already hard-put to pay for oil imports and their extensive borrowings, the stronger dollar is making their burden even greater. **********Currency experts say that some European countries may yet push interest rates higher to strengthen their currencies, but they do not expect that to happen soon. **********But if foreign rates do start to rise, the dollar could soften, even if American rates remain high.  ''It is really the differentials that push up the dollar,'' said Morris W. Offit, chief executive officer at Julius Baer Securities Inc., an international money management firm. ---- Dollar Ends Mixed By The Associated Press **********The dollar was mixed against foreign currencies here and abroad yesterday. Gold rose $6 an ounce in London and $6.50 in New York in moderate trading. **********The dollar lost ground against most currencies in early New York trading, due mainly to profit taking, but it gained strength late in the day after the Federal Reserve Board reported that the nation's basic money supply had surged by $4.2 billion in the latest reporting week. **********Trading was light in Europe where few markets were open because of the annual May Day holiday.  In London, the dollar gained against the French currency, reaching 5.2600 francs, compared with 5.2440 Thursday, when it posted its best performance against the franc in 10 years. But the dollar fell in New York to 5.2325 francs from 5.2535 Thursday. **********The dollar set another record high against the Italian lira in London trading, closing at 1,102.50 lire, up from 1,100.50 Thursday and 1,086.85 last Friday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 215.75 yen from 215 Thursday, before gaining in New York to 216.70 yen from 216.52 Thursday. **********After some strong gains against the British pound this week, the dollar retreated yesterday in London. In late trading, the pound was worth $2.1438, compared with Thursday's $2.1413, while in New York the pound fell to $2.1345 from $2.1367 Thursday. **********In Amsterdam, the dollar traded at 2.4590 Dutch guilders, up from Wednesday's 2.4566. Markets were closed Thursday for a holiday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/19/busin.main_headline: THE MONEY SUPPLY TAKES A SURPRISE JUMP
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/19/busin.print_headline: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS S; THE MONEY SUPPLY TAKES A SURPRISE JUMP
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/19/busin.body_text: **********The nation's money supply shot up by $6.9 billion in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve reported Friday. The report of the unexpectedly large rise prompted a sharp jump in both short- and long-term interest rates. Three-month Treasury bill rates increased more than 0.25 percent to 14.82 percent, and yields on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 13.58 percent from 13.4 percent. **********Most savings and loan associations, caught in the interest squeeze are losing money, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board warned earlier in the week, and one-third may not survive. **********U.S industrial output slipped an adjusted one-tenth of 1 percent in June, reflecting the effects of the national housing slump.  Manufacturers operated at 79.6 percent of capacity, a half-point decline from May while business inventories rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in May. **********Housing starts fell 11 percent in June and retail sales were up a slim 1.2 percent. New car sales, meanwhile, were off 17.4 percent in the first 10 days of July to the worst sales level since 1961. **********Regulations on A.T.&T. were lifted by the Senate Commerce Committee's 16-to-1 vote, giving the company free rein in information processing and distribution. The landmark bill, however, still keeps Bell from beaming classified ads into homes, or establishing its own electronic newspapers. **********CBS and RCA both requested Federal Communications Commission approval to beam television programs from satellites directly to homes and apartments, a move that would compete with cable television companies and local stations. **********The Food and Drug Administration approved an artificial sweetener, aspartame, for use as a food additive. Made by G.D. Searle & Company, aspartame is the only alternative to saccharin, which currently boasts $115 million in annual sales. **********International Paper said it would sell its Canadian subsidiary to Canadian Pacific Enterprises for $910 million in cash, making Canadian Pacific the world's second-largest newsprint maker behind Abitibi-Price. **********Prudential Insurance agreed to acquire Connecticut General Mortgage for $340 million in cash. The offer topped a $267 million bid by the British coal miners' union pension fund. **********To discourage foreign takeovers of American concerns, a House subcommittee voted to apply domestic borrowing ceilings on loans for that purpose. It was the first real response from Congress to a recent wave of bids from abroad. **********Pan Am set a 10 percent cutback in flights to ease its losses of more than $1 million a day. The airline, which employs 33,000 people, lost $127 million in 1980. **********Mobil Oil raised gas prices 3 cents a gallon because of new state taxes in New York. A day later it admitted to making an error, and reduced the increase to 1.3 cents. Exxon announced it was raising wholesale prices on most petroleum products. **********The Energy Department announced its third energy plan, under which the free market would be allowed to dictate the United States' use of energy resources. The plan, which must be submitted to Congress every two years, would remove Federal barriers to allow the free market to operate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/busin.main_headline: Business Conditions; RADIO ADS RIDE A COMEBACK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/busin.print_headline: Business Conditions; RADIO ADS RIDE A COMEBACK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/busin.body_text: **********Radio, the advertising medium many gave up for dead in the 1950's and 1960's, when television began to take over, is making a comeback. During the last 10 years, advertising revenues have more than doubled, to an estimated $3.6 billion in 1980. **********And, according to Miles David, president of the Radio Advertising Bureau, the industry's trade association, the surge is continuing: through the first four months of 1981, Mr. David estimates that national advertising is up 21 percent from a year earlier. **********High costs of other media and radio's ubiquitous place in American life are reasons why advertisers are rediscovering the air waves.  Mr. David says that between 1968 and 1980, radio advertising prices have risen 65 percent - the smallest increase of any major advertising medium. By contrast, magazine prices have gone up 71 percent, television 124 percent and newspapers 132 percent. However, Mr. David notes, the value received by advertising on radio ''wouldn't be worth much unless the medium worked.'' **********One reason it works is because so many people listen to radio.  Citing a variety of research studies, Mr. David spells out a series of impressive statistics: in an average 15-minute period, radio has an audience of more than 30 million. During a given week, 95 percent of all Americans will have spent at least 15 minutes listening to radio. On average, adults 18 and over spend almost as much time listening to radio as they do watching television - three hours and 27 minutes compared with three hours and 57 minutes. **********While local radio advertising remains the bread and butter of the business - in 1980 it accounted for more than 70 percent of total revenues -since 1975 revenues for spot advertisements have risen 183 percent while ads run on national networks have jumped 230 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/23/world.main_headline: HAIG WARNS TIME IS GROWING SHORT IN NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/23/world.print_headline: HAIG WARNS TIME IS GROWING SHORT IN NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/23/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that ''the hours are growing rather short'' to prevent Nicaragua under the leftist Sandinist Government from becoming a totalitarian state like Cuba. **********He refused to rule out any military action in the region, asserting that ''it serves no constructive purpose to draw fences around the limits of American policy when nations are proceeding to push against our fundamental values.'' **********In a separate interview today, Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, also expressed concern, saying that ''the hour is late in the sense that there has been a military buildup in Nicaragua'' through Cuban assistance. **********Both Mr. Meese and Mr. Haig noted that President Reagan had seemed to rule out the sending of American combat troops into Nicaragua when he said there were ''no plans'' to dispatch troops anywhere in the world. **********But they both stopped short of saying whether they thought any other military action should be taken to stop what they regarded as ominous trends in Nicaragua. Naval Blockade Held Possible **********In answer to questions on ''Face the Nation'' on CBS News, Mr.  Meese said that a naval blockade, or some joint action outside of Nicaragua, was a possibility. **********''Whether we'd utilize a naval blockade or not would depend on circumstances,'' he said, ''and at this point we wouldn't want to say what we will do or on the other hand rule out any particular action that might be appropriate.'' **********Mr. Haig, who has taken the firmest stand in the Administration against Cuban and Soviet-bloc involvement in Nicaragua, said that despite American offers of friendship there had been a steady ''drift toward totalitarianism'' there. **********He said that ''it is vitally important'' that the remaining ''forces of freedom'' in Nicaragua as well as the other governments in the hemisphere recognize that ''it is incumbent upon us to work in political, economic and security areas to try to prevent this drastic outcome.'' **********For many weeks there has been a behind-the-scenes debate within the Administration on what to do about the situation in Nicaragua, whose leftist Sandinist leadership has reportedly imported large amounts of Soviet-bloc military equipment through Cuba and steadily suppressed voices of opposition. There is said to be no disagreement on the seriousness of the situation in Nicaragua, but rather a major difference of opinion on whether military action even as limited as a blockade of Soviet-bloc arms should be contemplated by the United States. **********Mr. Haig is said to be the most outspoken in feeling that this country should not shirk from military action if necessary since to allow Nicaragua to become a Cuba-like bastion on the Central American mainland would be seen worldwide as a major Soviet-bloc victory, would endanger the security of the other countries in the region, and raise questions about American resolve in such areas as the Middle East. **********Defense Secreatary Caspar W. Weinberger and the Joint Chiefs of Staff were reported by a senior Pentagon official last week to be much more wary of even limited military action against Nicaragua.  They were said to fear that American public opinion would not support any American military involvement in the region and this could cause the Pentagon loss of support for key programs such as the buildup in strategic arms and the rapid deployment force for the Persian Gulf. **********Mr. Weinberger, appearing on ''Meet the Press'' on NBC News, said today that ''vital interests'' of the United States were involved in Nicaragua but steadfastly refused to discuss what military options were under consideration. **********''We are well away from the syndrome of drawing a line in the sand and saying thus far and no farther,'' Mr. Weinberger said. He said it was necessary to prepare a number of options for President Reagan to consider ''in a perfectly calm and reasonable fashion.'' **********Meanwhile, he said, the United States was taking steps to improve the economic and living conditions in the whole area through such initiatives as the economic plan for the Caribbean area announced last summer by the United States, Mexico, Venezuela and Canada. **********Mr. Haig, reflecting his own concerns, was considerably more dramatic than Mr. Weinberger and Mr. Meese in discussing Nicaragua.  Appearing on the ABC News program ''This Week'' with David Brinkley, the Secretary of State said that the Administration had made ''very dedicated efforts'' to make clear to the Nicaraguan leadership that ''we are prepared to have full, normal and complementary relationships.'' **********He was referring to a trip to Nicaragua last summer by Thomas O.  Enders, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.  Mr. Haig said that the Sandinists were told that if they remained ''a pluralistic, democratic society''they would be eligible for ''the full level of American assistance, aid and cooperation.'' **********Such aid was suspended earlier in the year by the Administration because of Nicaragua's support for the insurgents in El Salvador.  ''Unfortunately, the leadership has rejected those approaches,'' Mr. Haig said, ''and has steadily increased its drift toward totalitarianism.'' **********He cited the repeated closing in recent weeks of the newspaper La Prensa, the closing of opposition radio broadcasts, the arrest of leading figures in the private sector and ''the suppression of the free labor movement and the right to strike.'' **********Talking about the arms buildup in Nicaragua, Mr. Haig said that simultaneous with the political crackdown, ''we've seen a high influx of sophisticated armaments from the Eastern bloc, from the Soviet Union, directly through Cuba.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/world.main_headline: IN VIETNAM, TEARS AS THE PAST IS REMEMBERED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/world.print_headline: IN VIETNAM, TEARS AS THE PAST IS REMEMBERED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/world.body_text: **********Christmastime in Ho Chi Minh City is especially sad.  The warm air is scented with jasmine and incense, the stores drape silver papier-mache stars in windows, but the downtown streets are curiously lifeless. **********''Merry Christmas, poppa!'' shout swarms of begging half-American children to foreigners. They clutch a visitor's arm. ''You take me home, poppa?'' **********If the outcast urchins are searing and visible remnants of the war - many of them are blue-eyed and fair-haired -there are other haunting encounters on the downtown streets. Near the market, a young Vietnamese woman is shocked to see an American she once knew. She is eking out a living teaching English and hopes next year to join her parents who fled to the United States during the fall of this city, then called Saigon. 'It's So Difficult Now' **********She starts to laugh nervously. ''I've become so skinny, so ugly,'' she said. ''My face is old.'' Her eyes turn wet. ''It's so difficult now.'' **********She starts to speak but says conversation with an American is dangerous and starts to slip away. ''Life is hard,'' she whispers.  At the Majestic Hotel, a middle-aged employee looks up and watches a group of American Vietnam War veterans depart after their recent visit to discuss with Government authorities reports of American servicemen still missing after the war. ''Saigon is no more,'' he says. ''Saigon is dead.'' **********The city is certainly quieter and perhaps cleaner than it was a decade ago. Every symbol and sign of the American and South Vietnamese presence -building names, streets, billboards that once advertised Coca Cola - have been stripped away. **********Tu Do, the raffish main street, has been renamed Dong Khoi (General Uprising), which commemorates the Communist takeover in 1975. The famed Caravelle Hotel is now the Son Doc Lap (Hotel Freedom) and is filled with Russians. **********There are posters everywhere exhorting Vietnamese to work in the fields, pictures in shop windows of Ho Chi Minh smiling angelically, Vietnamese and Soviet flags linked.  Around the city, most well-known buildings are intact but seem a bit dilapidated.  The old United States aid headquarters, which spent billions assisting the South Vietnamese, has laundry drying on its windows.  Cercle Sportif, the last stronghold of French colonialism, is a workers club. The American Embassy is used by Vietnam's gas and oil authority. The landmark Continental Palace Hotel is shut down but may open soon as a barracks for foreign sailors. Peddlers Hawk Their Goods **********Changes are everywhere, yet the Christmas season has somehow stirred memories of the old Saigon. Outside the cathedral, peddlers hawk toys and cards and tinsel. There are holiday sweet cakes in Givral's and in La Pagode, the popular coffeeshop, which is still crammed with bored youths, wearing American sweatshirts and Adidas sneakers. They seem utterly untouched by the ''liberation.'' **********Yet the bulk of the city's residents seem bereft, hard pressed.  Officially there are 200,000 unemployed, but the figure is probably closer to four or five times that. **********A special hospital has been set up for malnourished children. Wages are low - civil servants earn the equivalent of $30 to $40 a month, about the price of a pair of shoes. Inflation Has Doubled **********Inflation of many basic staples has doubled over the past years.  The shops are crammed with black market goods - Heineken beer, Salem cigarettes, champagne, tubes of shaving cream, medical supplies - mostly sent as gift parcels from abroad. **********Especially poignant, somehow, are the ceramics - jade and porcelain that families sold to buy official exit visas.  It is unclear who buys these things: the Russians, the major foreign group, are known as ''Americans without money.'' Nonetheless the wheeling-dealing black market economy, now as before, lingers, with Communist officials turning a blind eye to it. **********In his office in the old French-built city hall, Le Quang Chanh, deputy chairman of the People's Committee of Ho Chi Minh City and a founding member of the National Liberation Front, said that his aim was to make ''hard work and production'' the dominant values of the city instead of ''luxury and entertainment.'' 'First Social Evil' **********Mr. Chanh, a man in a green bush suit and wearing eyeglasses, said that the ''first social evil'' he had found in the city was prostitution. ''We built schools for these women. We cured them of their disease and tried to make them human beings again.'' **********''We have resolved this problem,'' he said.  Unresolved, however, is the legacy of prostitution - the Vietnamese-American children who beg and prowl the city streets and are objects of scorn in socialist Vietnam. Their number is estimated at 8,000. Pathetically, some of them hold up photographs of their mothers and fathers, usually a G.I. with his arm draped around the young woman. **********During the visit of the four American Vietnam War veterans, the children touched their arms, besieged them with photographs and letters, struggled to speak English and gazed at the four with awe. **********The American group was led by Robert O. Muller, executive director of the Vietnam Veterans of America. His companions were Michael Harbert, a former Air Force sergeant; Tom Bird, a former infantryman, and John Terzano, who was a Navy seaman.  All are members of Vietnam Veterans of America. **********As the Americans boarded their van to leave the city, they handed out candy and gum and some money to the children, who waved feverishly and blew kisses. Two fair-haired little girls began to weep. It was heartbreaking.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/11/busin.print_headline: OTHER BUSINESS; THE GAS THIS DENTIST USES IS NEON
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/11/busin.body_text: **********Just a year ago, Dr. Shel Kupper started a store-front dental practice on West 10th where Sutters Bakery had stood. Like other professionals starting out, he hung a shingle. Dr. Kupper's shingle, however, is a $1,000 neon sign. ''Smile,'' it says. **********What the practice stresses is preventive dentistry - a simple cleaning by hygenists - but dentists are there to provide further treatment, too. ''If patients just want a cleaning fine, if they're happy with their own dentist for all their other work, that's fine too,'' said Dr. Kupper. **********It's not an entirely new idea; many dentists operate store-front offices offering preventive and cleaning services. What's different is that Dr. Kupper wants to sell dentistry like fast food. **********''I think what they are driving at with these logos is a series of franchises like Kentucky Fried Chicken and McDonalds,'' said Dr.  Martin Rubin of the New York State Board for Dentistry. Sure enough, Dr. Kupper says ''I'd like to have hundreds franchises across the country.'' **********''On Jan. 14, 1980, when we first opened we had 10 appointments, this Wednesday we'll have 41,'' Dr. Jeffrey Zwas, his associate said. He estimated that the practice would bring in $400,000 this year. **********Dr. Kupper and Dr. Zwas are planning to open a second office in the spring near Columbus Circle in Manhattan. It that one succeeds, they want to open branches elsewhere. Already though they have competitors who seem to have similar ambitions. **********Dentists unaffiliated with Dr. Kupper and Dr. Zwas have opened a shop in Cambridge, Mass., called ''Smiles,'' and others in San Francisco have started one called ''Smile, America.'' **********Dr. Kupper schedules 45-minute appointments per patient, so there is rarely a wait. He charges $28 for a cleaning, $23 for a follow-up visit, $65 for a three-time-a-year plan and $85 for four visits a year. **********A preventive dental treatment costs $40. Smile accepts credit cards and offers patients gift certificates toward a cleaning for a friend. **********Dory Munder, vice president of worldwide services at American Express, discovered the Smile office while shopping one day. ''I feel so relaxed here,'' she said.''I grew up with a dentist who hummed morbid tunes and always had a crowded waiting room.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/08/world.main_headline: WEINBERGER EXHORTS ALLIES TO SHARE BURDEN OF DEFENSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/08/world.print_headline: WEINBERGER EXHORTS ALLIES TO SHARE BURDEN OF DEFENSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/08/world.body_text: **********Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger turned a routine meeting today with Western Europe's Defense Ministers into a strong advertisement for the Reagan Administration's military policy, and he made it clear that the Europeans were expected to do their full share. **********Senior American officials said Mr. Weinberger gave the Defense Ministers a graphic and detailed intelligence briefing on the Soviet military buildup in and around Poland and presented a sweeping analysis of the steady growth in Soviet nuclear and conventional arms. **********On his first trip to Europe in his new position, the Secretary described a new mood among Americans on national defense and outlined the Administration's plans for rearming America, the official said.  Finally, he laid out his message for the Europeans. **********''Our people will not want to march alone,'' Mr. Weinberger said, according to an official. ''If our effort is not joined by all who are threatened, by all who face the common danger, we in the United States could lose at home the critical public support for which we have labored long and hard.'' Ministers Appear to Agree **********The response was surprisingly agreeable from European leaders who had been expected to insist on an American commitment to resume negotiations with the Soviet Union on arms control, a subject barely mentioned today. **********After Mr. Weinberger's long presentation this morning, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, the host, told the delegates at lunch: ''We Europeans know that the United States can meet its responsibility as an international power only in league with its partners in Canada and Europe.'' **********He added that ''in the long run we can maintain our security only if all partners mobilize their capability for the common cause.'' A senior American official said that a communique scheduled to be issued Wednesday would capture the tone of Mr. Weinberger's remarks and would warn the Soviet Union to be aware of a new resolve in the United States and the Atlantic alliance. A Reminder About the Opposition **********But an antiwar demonstration reminded the delegates that sizable segments of the public in Europe oppose their plans. The demonstrators shouted ''Disarmament!'' and pelted soldiers, officials and reporters with eggs and tin cans. **********About 300 protesters sat down in front of the gate to the Defense Ministry where the meeting was held, but they were carted off by the police. One of the few tense moments occurred when West German soldiers tried to prevent an American television crew from filming the demonstration. **********The Defense Ministers' meeting, a regular conference which supposedly was to be devoted to discussing plans for deploying nuclear weapons in Europe, gave Mr. Weinberger the opportunity to infuse the European allies with the necessity of much greater efforts on defense, the American official said. **********The Secretary's report on Poland, including aerial photographs taken from satellites and flashed on a giant screen, provided far more intelligence than many of them had received before, according to a European minister. 20 Divisions Surround Poland **********He said the briefing showed that 20 Soviet divisions around Poland in the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and East Germany had been steadily built up since last summer, with some of them going from 15 percent of their assigned manpower to 80 to 85 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/06/busin.body_text: **********''I'm sorry to say that the last Easy Access statement you received was incorrect. Since they're programmed by people, computers are only human...'' Thus began an early November letter from Citibank vice president Russel A. Herz. **********Somewhat ominously, there was no explanation of the error. **********Easy Access is one of the many marvels inspired by computerized banking, and like many such marvels the computers - or the people who run them - can make a banking transaction more of a hassle than it ever was with a flesh-and-blood teller. **********With Citibank's Easy Access, customers can keep a savings account and a checking account, and borrow money by writing checks for more than they actually have in checking. The year-and-a-half-old service is so involved, said Peter Cullum, a Citibank spokesman, that there are many chances for mistakes. **********Indeed, from Oct. 15 to Nov. 1, a flaw in the computer program for Easy Access accounts caused some incorrect notations on interest on some customers' statements. No money shifted accounts, but some of the bank's customers received statements showing that it had, Mr.  Cullum explained. Letters were sent to everyone who had an Easy Access account, he added - even those with correct statements. **********''What it comes down to is a minor error, and no one got hurt by it,'' Mr. Cullum said.  Maybe so, but at least one customer, claiming yet one more in a series of Citibank frustrations, is still grousing. His corrected statement on Easy Access was speedily sent, but to the wrong address. However, people being people, rather than computers, it was safely forwarded by the recipient.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/05/busin.body_text: **********The House today approved a bill that would encourage retail merchants to offer sizable discounts to customers who pay cash instead of using credit cards. The vote was 296 to 43. **********The House had overwhelmingly approved a similar bill in February, but final passage was stalled in the Senate when an unrelated amendment concerning the age of the surgeon general was attached to the banking bill. House and Senate conference committee members agreed last week to reintroduce the bill without the amendment. **********The bill encourages merchants to offer discounts to cash-paying customers by lifting restrictions requiring retailers to comply with cumbersome disclosure regulations if they offer discounts that exceed 5 percent of the purchase price. **********Opponents had no problem with the cash discount provision, but objected to a section of the bill that extended for three years a ban prohibiting merchants from imposing a surcharge on credit card purchases to offset the added costs of accepting credit cards. A similar ban expired Feb. 27. **********Opponents argue that the ban is a form of price control since it prohibits merchants from charging customers to offset the 3 percent fee that credit card companies charge retailers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/23/busin.body_text: **********In this holiday-shortened week, underwriters have scheduled $1 billion of new corporate issues, but they said that the volume could be much larger if market conditions are good. **********Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said in the latest issue of Comments on Credit that last week's record volume of new corporate issues ''provided only a glimpse of the huge corporate funding needs.'' **********The United States Treasury will be the largest single borrower this week, first at the regular Monday auction of three- and six-month bills, followed by Tuesday's auction of $3.25 billion of new notes due in five years, two-months. Late Friday, three- and six-month bills were bid at a rate of 10.15 percent and 10.7 percent respectively. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/04/world.main_headline: ARMY OF PICASSO AFICIONADOS PAINTS A LITTLE SPANISH TOWN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/04/world.print_headline: ARMY OF PICASSO AFICIONADOS PAINTS A LITTLE SPANISH TOWN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/04/world.body_text: **********Until recently, few people had heard of Caltojar, a village in the north-central province of Soria with one telephone and 207 inhabitants. Then Angel Nuno, the secretary of Caltojar's Town Hall, got the idea of painting imitation Picassos on its white walls and low adobe buildings. **********''At first we thought of paying homage to Velazquez,'' related the energetic Mr. Nuno. ''But then we realized that it was the year of Picasso and that 'Guernica' was about to be brought to Spain. And most of the older students in the village knew who Picasso was.'' **********Mr. Nuno got the idea last Easter and soon - well before Madrid's official cultural establishment had begun its observances of the 100th anniversary of Pablo Picasso's birth - the walls of Caltojar began to sprout Picasso doves, harlequins, guitar players, demoiselles of Avignon and self-portraits. And Caltojar inaugurated its own, full-size ''Guernica'' two weeks before the original painting, after returning from New York, was unveiled in October at an annex of Madrid's Prado. **********People in Caltojar live by raising sheep and growing wheat on the hard Soria plain, now cracked by drought, but they took eagerly to painting Picassos. Angel Molina, the 32-year-old Mayor, was so tickled with his portrait of the poet Antonio Machado, painted on a building facing his home, that he added a copyright mark and his signature, ''Sr. Alcalde,'' or Mr. Mayor. Children Do the Most **********Teen-agers and schoolchildren did most of the work. At night, with a movie projector, they cast images of the Picassos of their choice on the walls and traced them. By day, they painted. A sign on the country highway that runs through Caltojar warns: ''Caution: children painting.'' **********A total of 51 paintings and a huge free-standing copy of ''Guernica'' have been finished. Others are planned.  Collective effort is not always the hallmark of Soria villages, from which young people are fleeing to the cities. The province is dotted with deserted villages and others where only the old remain. **********Caltojar is unusual in the province in having enough children to merit an elementary school of its own. Many rural children are bused long distances to school. Village Priest Demurs **********The local reviews have been fairly positive.  ''We people who have lived all our life in the country don't understand these things,'' said Wenceslao Galan, an 81-year-old farmer in a tattered beret. ''But we think they're pretty, and it makes people talk about our village.'' **********One mild dissenter is the village priest, the Rev. Hernan Larena, who was found busily cleaning stones and dirt from a pile of beans at the doors of Caltojar's 12th century church. **********''The people here are a little cold,'' said Father Larena. ''They do not exactly fulfill their Christian duties. And the men - the men here are a little revolutionary.'' **********Others scoff at the priest's assertion, saying he is simply upset because a lot of people have been painting on Sundays instead of going to mass. **********''Some people want to give this a political interpretation,'' said Julian Andres, a 26-year-old teacher at the one-room school.  ''Someone even asked if all the kids here were Communists. But it is a cultural thing.'' Village's Renown Spreads **********There is so little politics in Caltojar that all seven members of the municipal council, including the Mayor, are independents. In national elections, the villagers have mostly voted for the centerright Government party, with others voting Socialist. **********Caltojar's painting spree has brought the village renown well beyond the boundaries of Soria Province. At official invitation, Mr.  Nuno has taken delegations of children to Barcelona, the home of the Picasso Museum, and to Madrid, where they were invited to the ''Guernica'' opening. **********Almudena Ayuso, a 10-year-old girl and occasional painter, was impressed by the glass and metal cage that surrounds the original ''Guernica.'' **********''They put it there so that no one will steal the painting,'' she said. ''But I like ours better. It is new and clean.'' Now Mr. Nuno is organizing a trip to Paris, with help from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. And he is looking farther. The Allure of New York **********''I have heard about things happening in America that for us are utopias,'' he said. ''Maybe there is some American millionaire who would like to bring us over there so we could see the skyscrapers and 'Les Demoiselles d'Avignon.' We will go to the Museum of Modern Art.  Write that down. I'm sure we will go.'' **********Other villagers seem to find Caltojar's sudden fame a bit too much to handle.  ''It's so noisy,'' said a woman dressed in black. ''Every weekend people coming to look at the paintings. And during the week, I bet there are at least four cars every day. It makes you afraid to be in the streets.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/27/busin.body_text: **********Texas International Airlines, which has been seeking to acquire Continental Airlines, said yesterday it would cut the salaries of about 600 management employees by between 5 percent and 15 percent starting Nov. 15 and increase their workweek to a minimum of 48 hours. Texas International also said it would try to increase management productivity by allowing managers of one department to work in other areas. The airline, which said these and other efficiency measures were aimed at offsetting effects of the air controllers' strike, said the cuts would be effective through March 31.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/04/busin.body_text: **********Banks and savings and loan institutions said yesterday that they would continue to offer consumers accounts yielding high interest as a lure to sell savings certificates on Oct.1. But they said they would protect the tax-exempt status of interest on the certificates by making their purchase optional. **********Hundreds of thrift institutions across the nation had been offering the bonus accounts on condition that the consumer invest the money on Oct.1 in a savings certificate. Most agreed to modify their bonus packages in reaction to an Internal Revenue Service ruling yesterday that disqualified the savings certificates from tax exemption if they were bought as part of a bonus package that made the ''rollover'' mandatory. The I.R.S. ruling was announced in Washington. (Page D4.) **********The interest on the savings certificate will be equal to 70 percent of the yield paid on one-year Treasury bills at the most recent auction. The latest monthly auction, held yesterday, fixed the Treasury bill yield at 18.01 percent, which means that certificates sold during the first two days of October will carry an interest rate of 12.61 percent. (Page D5.) **********The I.R.S. ruling came after hundreds of thousands of dollars had already been invested in the bonus deposits offered by commercial banks and thrift institutions in advertisements that promised interest rates as high as 50 percent on an annual basis. The financial institutions can accommodate these customers by rewriting the terms of their agreements to make the tie-in optional, according to the I.R.S. ruling. **********Bankers and savings and loan officials accused the I.R.S. yesterday of having created confusion over the bonus packages, but in interviews they seemed eager to assure customers that the tie-ins would be made optional. Most Say Program Is Useful **********The optional feature will not assure banks and thrift institutions that the money put into the high-interest accounts will stay with them beyond Oct. 1. A spot check, however, showed that most of the financial institutions still regarded the bonus accounts as an effective way to attract depositors for the one-year savings certificates. **********''The way the I.R.S. went about this was quite unfair to the consumer,'' said Gerald McEvoy, a senior vice president of the Lincoln Savings Bank. **********''We will be talking to all the people who have signed up here and assure them that they will be able to withdraw their money on Oct. 1 without a penalty.'' How Plan Would Work **********He added that Lincoln would begin to advertise a new program next week, but he was unsure if it would offer consumers the same 35 percent interest that it advertised last week. **********Under the new ruling, a consumer who invests $2,000 now in a bonus program at 35 percent would earn $57.53 in interest during a onemonth period. On Oct. 1, the consumer can either withdraw the $2,057.53 or invest it in the one-year savings certificate created under the tax law passed by Congress in July. **********An individual can earn up to $1,000 in interest tax-free on the new certificate, while a married couple filing a joint return can earn up to $2,000 tax-free. Tax experts have said that the certificates make the most sense for a person who is in a tax bracket above 30 percent. Comments From Banks **********''We're going to start our ads running immediately,'' said Greg Sullivan, assistant vice president of the Dime Savings Bank of New York. His institution offered consumers an 18 percent interest rate with a 1 percent bonus until Oct. 1. **********The Chase Manhattan Bank said it would honor the 40 percent interest it promoted last Friday and yesterday. However, a Chase spokesman said the bank had not decided whether it would offer a 40 percent rate in the future. **********The Dry Dock Savings Bank said it would free depositors, who had already signed up for their bonus package, from the mandatory tiein. However, the savings bank will discontinue its bonus program. **********The savings and loan institutions began to promote bonus packages last month to compete for some of the $250 billion that is expected to flow into the savings certificates. The bonus accounts introduced by the banks and thrift institutions in the competition for this money are actually repurchase agreements - loans made to the institutions - that are generally sold only to corporate customers at market rates of about 17 percent. Advertising Interrupted **********Most financial institutions stopped advertising the bonus packages after the I.R.S. said over the weekend that it had ''substantial doubts'' about the tax-exempt status of the bonus packages. **********''The whole thing is an outrage,'' said Paul A. Schosberg, president of the Savings Association League of New York State. ''The way they handled it will have a chilling effect on the 'All Savers' certificates.'' **********He added that he expected most New York banks to resume their offers for the repurchase agreements in an attempt to draw potential customers for the one-year savings certificates. **********''The underlying rationale - to position the largest possible number of depositors for the 'All Savers' - is still there, and I would expect a whole new round of ads to be hitting the papers by the weekend,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/12/world.main_headline: AT LEAST 1,000 PEOPLE ARE KILLED AS NIGERIA CRUSHES ISLAMIC SECT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/12/world.print_headline: AT LEAST 1,000 PEOPLE ARE KILLED AS NIGERIA CRUSHES ISLAMIC SECT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/12/world.body_text: **********At least a thousand people, and possibly many more, were killed here over the last two weeks as members of an Islamic cult attacked the local authorities, and Government forces were sent to quell what Nigerian officials said they believed to be a Libyan-backed insurrection. **********There is no evidence in this northern town of a million people to suggest Libyan interference. But a high-ranking assistant to Nigeria's President, Shehu Shagari, said in an interview earlier this week that ''we have every reason to believe Libya was involved.'' Nigeria has expelled Libya's diplomats from the capital of Lagos, 800 miles to the south, and has called home the Nigerian envoy in Tripoli. **********Cult Is Annihilated **********The full story of what happened here is still unclear. What is known is that a fanatic cult, led by a man from Cameroon named Alhaji Mohammadu Marwa, started the violence. In the end, the cult was annihilated by a Government that painfully remembers the Biafran war in which more than a million Nigerians lost their lives in the 1960's. **********Nearly every Nigerian lost a relative or a friend in the civil war over Biafra. The killings here have reminded the Government how easily the situation could get out of hand in Nigeria. As a result, it is likely that the authorities will step up security measures. **********Despite the absence of proof, Western diplomats in Lagos tend to believe that Libya had a hand in the troubles here, if only in providing financial assistance to the cult. Alarm Over Libyan Plans **********The authorities in Lagos, as well as in other African capitals, have been alarmed by Libya's announced intention to merge with Chad after helping the Government in Ndjamena defeat insurgent forces in a civil war. **********Islamic scholars said that Mr. Marwa, the head of the cult, had been expelled from here twice in the last 17 years for disruptive activities. He and nearly all his followers were killed on Dec. 30 and 31, according to some reports. **********Kano is a center of Moslem worship and trade in Nigeria. The old section of the city is ringed by a crumbling mud wall. The new section is made up of tens of thousands of mud tenements and alleys just wide enough to be negotiated by people and goats. Into an area right between the two, where the city's major markets stand, came Alhaji Mohammadu Marwa last year to establish a settlement for his 3,000 to 5,000 followers. **********According to the head of Islamic studies at a nearby university, who did not want to be identified, Mr. Marwa first seemed to espouse relatively harmless Islamic fundamentalist beliefs. He condemned materialism, prohibiting his followers from wearing watches or owning bicycles. They were forbidden from going to bed at night in possession of more money than they would need to get through the following day. **********However, Mr. Marhwa's beliefs eventually began to deviate from Islamic tradition. He told his followers that they did not have to face Mecca during prayer, as Moslems do the world over, and he reduced the number of daily prayers from the traditional five to three. **********Later, there were reports of kidnapping of young boys and girls, and the taking over of nearby houses by force.  ''He would ask, 'Is this God's house or yours,'' said a professor who requested anonymity. ''If the occupant said God's, then they as God's representatives would claim it. But if they said it was not God's, then they would would still claim it for God from the infidels.'' Reports of Black Magic **********Then came reports that the cultists were practitioners of juju, or black magic. Juju, although still prevalent in the south, is not seen here very often. However, superstition is entrenched in many parts of Nigeria. For example, human eyes are used used in a charm that is said to make a thief invisible and impossible to catch. **********The prevalence of superstition in Nigeria enabled Mr. Marwa to convince his followers that they were invincible. Armed with only bows and arrows and a small number of stolen automatic weapons, they charged Nigerian forces who were firing mortars, machine guns and bazookas. **********In October, there was a clash between the cultists and the police here. Although a policeman was killed, Kano's Governor, Abubakar Rimi, did not take any public action against the cultists at that time. **********On Dec. 18 and 19, about 50 policemen were killed in a battle with the cultists. Some residents of Kano said the fighting started because Mr. Marwa's son had been killed in a confrontation with the police. Others said it started because the Government had privately given the cultists a deadline to leave Kano. Mr. Rimi's press secretary refused to allow journalists to interview the Governor earlier this week. Governor Delays Acting **********The police asked the Governor to request federal intervention, but he did not act.  The police also appealed to citizens to help contain the fanatics.  Vigilantes set up roadblocks to catch members of the cult. Each of the cultists was said to have a tattoo, a cross in a circle, on the abdomen. People were stripped and, when a tattoo was found, often summarily executed. **********On Christmas Day, as the Governor was preparing to leave for a conference in Lagos, a mob attacked his house. That was apparently the final straw. He stayed in Kano and called for federal assistance. **********Last week, two days before New Year's, the army moved in. People in the quarter occupied by the cult were warned to leave the area or be shelled. Then the army opened fire. 'It Was Unfortunate Really' **********''You should have have seen it,'' said Muhammad Hassan Ali, a journalist for the the state television here. ''They were killing them like goats, like donkeys even. It was unfortunate really, but they were given a warning.'' **********Another journalist, Tunde Amao, a reporter for The Daily Times, was killed by a stray arrow.  After the troops had collected all the bodies, the official death toll was put at 1,000. However, Mr. Ali said that it was at least 10,000. Half a dozen other witnesses said the figure was about 7,000. The bodies were piled on garbage trucks and buried in mass graves. **********For the next few days, prisoners were summarily executed, according to witnesses. One businessman saw 80 people, including children, gunned down in a field near his house. Only piles of shoes remained in the field.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; France to Continue Study Of Neutron Arms Project
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy said today that the Government ''has decided to continue studying'' development of a neutron warhead tested by France last year. **********In a speech before the Higher Institute for National Defense, Mr.  Mauroy said the warhead was a tactical weapon ''which can increase our deterrent potential.'' **********He went on: ''This capability remains to be developed and that's why the Government has decided to continue studying'' the project. **********France tested a neutron warhead in June 1980 but has not yet decided whether to add it to its arsenal. A decision to do so could cause friction between the Socialist Government of President Francois Mitterrand and the French Communists, his party's allies. **********Outlining the military policies of the new Government, Mr. Mauroy declared that France wanted nothing to do with neutralism and intended, through the ''nuclear deterrent,'' to preserve autonomy in military decisions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/06/world.main_headline: REFUGEE AGENCY TO ASSIST 193,000 NEXT YEAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/06/world.print_headline: REFUGEE AGENCY TO ASSIST 193,000 NEXT YEAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/06/world.body_text: **********An agency formed by 16 governments in 1951 to assist World War II refugees and displaced persons in Western Europe has approved plans to move about 193,000 victims of the world's continuing turmoils to new homelands next year. **********The decision came Wednesday at the end of a two-day session that marked the 30th anniversary of the formation of the agency, now known as the Intergovernmental Committee for Migration. **********The present global scope of its activities was not foreseen in 1951 when the United States, Canada and Australia joined 13 Western European and Latin American nations at the founding conference in Brussels. **********By 1963 the agency was helping the first waves of Cubans fleeing the regime of Fidel Castro and Tibetans fleeing the Chinese takeover of their homeland. But it was not until 1980 that the member countries struck the world "European" from the original title of the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration. **********Though independent of the United Nations, the agency was established to render assistance that would complement the primarily legal protection provided by the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. **********Last July the number of people the migration agency had assisted since 1952 passed the three million mark. **********The first major new refugee crisis that the committee was called on to face after its founding was the outpouring of Hungarians in 1956-57 when Soviet tanks ended their revolt. The agency helped 180,000 of them move on to permanent homes, mostly overseas, after they had reached asylum first in Austria and Yugoslavia. **********Although some of the founder nations withdrew from the committee over the years, the number of member governments expanded steadily without changing its basic Western and Latin American composition.  Even with the departure of Malta at the end of this year, the member nations will number 29. Thirteen other countries, including former members, hold observer status and collaborate closely with the organization. Much of the Budget Given by U.S. **********The United States has played a major role since the start and underwrites one-third of the budget. All but one of the six directors the committee has had to date have been Americans. **********Now holding the top position is James L. Carlin, a 60-year-old former State Department official long experienced in refugee and migration affairs. **********Although the committee's efforts on behalf of refugees fleeing their homelands have captured the most attention, the agency also has the important function of helping find the skilled workers and professionals willing to migrate to the third world, mostly to Latin America, where they are needed to speed development. **********Vietnamese and other Indochinese refugees are expected once again to form the largest group, 135,000, among the worldwide total of 193,000 asylum-seekers that the committee expects to help in 1982. **********The organization estimates at 45,000 the number of Soviet Jews, who first reach the West in Austria, and other migrants from the Soviet bloc who will require aid in 1982 to move on to countries or resettlement. This is 10,000 more than in 1981, mainly because of the growing number of Poles who want to start a new life abroad because of the unsettled conditions at home. **********The committee's budget for 1982 has been set at $133 million, but the member countries are due to provide through their annual assessments only $7.4 million, a figure unchanged from 1981, covering the costs of administration by a regular staff of 300. **********The balance of nearly $126 million in expenditures on operational programs and the special staff they require is covered by voluntary contributions from governments and private sources.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/29/world.main_headline: EGYPT AND ISRAEL POSTPONE PALESTINE TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/29/world.print_headline: EGYPT AND ISRAEL POSTPONE PALESTINE TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/29/world.body_text: **********Egypt has agreed to an Israeli request for postponement of the talks scheduled for next week on self-rule for Palestinians in Israeli-occupied lands, a senior Foreign Ministry official said today. **********The official, Boutros Ghali, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, said that Israel requested the postponement because members of its low-level working group were scheduled to be in Washington at the time set for the meetings. **********He did not elaborate. The meetings were scheduled to begin in Israel next Wednesday. **********''It is perfectly normal,'' Mr. Ghali said of the postponement. He said that the delay was not related to Israel's objections to having West European nations serve in the multinational peacekeeping force that will police the Sinai peninsula after Israel's final withdrawal in April. European Role Opposed **********Israel has opposed inclusion of the Europeans because of a declaration issued by the Common Market in Venice in June 1980. The declaration said the Palestine Liberation Organization should be ''associated'' with the Middle East peace talks. **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met with Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel on Friday, attempting to convince him that his Government should drop its objection to European participation.  The Israeli Cabinet is expected to meet Sunday to discuss the issue. **********Mr. Ghali said that the autonomy talks would be rescheduled for mid-December. The official press agency said that Taher Shash, a Foreign Ministry official who heads Egypt's working group, was to set a date. **********Israeli officials have said they were seeking an agreement on the scope, jurisdiction and powers of a self-governing authority to be elected for the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
