https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/12/world.print_headline: CLOSER TIES SOUGHT BY LONDON AND BONN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/12/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany sought closer links between their countries today at a meeting made more urgent by the election of Francois Mitterrand as President of France. **********In both the West German and British delegations there was an unmistakable sense of excitement and apprehension at the prospect of a fundamentally changed political map of Western Europe, with France moving to the left and West Germany, if the Social Democrats' defeat in West Berlin yesterday was any indication, moving to the right. **********Mr. Schmidt arrived here for two days of talks only 15 hours after it became clear that the French Socialist leader had defeated President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, a close ally of Mr. Schmidt but a frequent adversary of Mrs. Thatcher despite their parallel conservative economic views. The French election supplanted Common Market and other international questions as the main item on the agenda. **********Participants in the discussions this afternoon and evening, which took place here at the Prime Minister's country residence, Chequers, 40 miles northwest of London, said that bad feeling between Mr.  Schmidt and Mrs. Thatcher appeared to have eased. Sharp Clash at Last Meeting **********The two clashed sharply at their last meeting seven weeks ago in the Dutch city of Maastricht, particularly over the question of fishing rights within the European Economic Community. A West German official said tonight that ''the same problems remain but the climate has changed.'' **********British sources said that Mrs. Thatcher, who found Mr. Giscard d'Estaing an aloof and haughty figure, saw in the election of Mr.  Mitterrand an opportunity to improve British relations not only with France but also with West Germany. In recent years, an informal Paris-Bonn entente has tended to dominate the community to the exclusion of Britain. **********Mr. Schmidt spent much of the flight from Bonn analyzing the results of the French election, his aides said. He was reported to have concluded that there would be fundamental changes in French economic and social policies but that continuity could be anticipated in the field of foreign affairs. **********A senior official traveling with the Chancellor emphasized the importance of the French-West German treaty of 1963, which, he said, should guarantee good cooperation between Mr. Schmidt and Mr.  Mitterrand. The official also called attention to warnings by Mr.  Mitterrand about the seriousness of the Soviet threat to European security, arguing that these showed that the French President-elect shared the views of the entire Western alliance. Personal Friendship Aided Ties **********But Mr. Schmidt has met Mr. Mitterrand only twice, and the German official conceded that he could not hope, at least at first, to establish with Mr. Mitterrand - even though both are Socialists - the kind of relationship that he has enjoyed with Mr. Giscard d'Estaing.  The Paris-Bonn entente rested to a considerable degree on their friendship. **********It is this situation, Mrs. Thatcher believes, that gives Britain its opportunity.  At the same time, there was some apprehension in the West German camp, and even more in the British, about the consequences of a French President's having been elected with Communist help and possibly being compelled to include Communist ministers in his Government. The Chancellor said on the airplane this morning, according to one aide, that Western Europe faced an unsettled period during which it would be difficult to calculate the probable course of French foreign policy. **********Similar views were expressed in Brussels, where the defense ministers of the European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization met today. They were said to have agreed that the victory of Mr. Mitterrand was ''not disquieting'' but to have expressed some concern about the degree of influence Communists would be able to wield over his administration. **********Both Mrs. Thatcher and Mr. Schmidt voiced hope that they would be able to see Mr. Mitterrand soon. The first meetings, officials here suggested, will probably come at the next Common Market summit meeting in Luxembourg at the end of June - about the same time that Mr. Mitterrand is expected to call parliamentary elections in the hope of winnng a left-wing majority. Brezhnev Sends Congratulations Special to the New York Times **********MOSCOW, May 11 - Leonid I. Brezhnev today congratulated Francois Mitterrand on his election to the French Presidency, saying he hoped that France would continue to cooperate with Moscow in promoting detente and disarmament. **********The Soviet leader's cordial telegram to Mr. Mitterrand, who has often been critical of Soviet policies, was reported by Tass, the Soviet press agency. ''I express the hope that the Soviet Union and France will continue to promote mutual understanding between East and West in the interests of restraining the arms race and achieving disarmament,'' Mr. Brezhnev wrote. **********The Soviet media, which had shown preference for President Valery Giscard d'Estaing during the election campaign, reported Mr.  Mitterrand's victory today with strong emphasis on the support given him by the French Communist party. **********Both Tass and Izvestia, the Soviet Government daily, depicted the Socialist candidate's victory as a demand by French voters for major economic and social changes. **********In this context, the Soviet commentators quoted a statement by Georges Marchais, the French Communist leader, declaring readiness to join hands with the new Government. **********Despite the portrayal of the Socialist election victory as a mandate for social change and as a potential opportunity for French Communists, there seemed little doubt that Mr. Giscard d'Estaing'r defeat was regarded as a setback for Soviet policy objectives in Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Venpub, a new company formed by Joseph D. Girraputo, founder and publisher of Venture, The Magazine for Entrepreneurs, has acquired the majority equity in the magazine from the Christiana Companies. **********According to Mr. Girraputo, this prevented Bertelsmann, the German publisher, from doing the same.  Venpub got the money (''several million'') from the Arthur Lipper Corporation, a venture capital investment banking firm. Mr. Girraputo says that now he is the majority stockholder. **********The monthly magazine, started May 1979, carried 230 advertising pages in the first half, which is a 43.9 percent increase from the same period last year. In all of 1980 it carried 385 pages. **********Paid circulation, begun at 75,000, is now at 150,000. Turner Ads Placed **********McDonald & Little, the biggest ad agency in Atlanta that is soon to be bought by Ted Bates & Company, has just been tapped by Ted Turner to do advertising for Turner Broadcasting and the Cable News Network. The two previously had their promotion done by Communications Trends which will continue with a couple of projects, while the McDonald shop spends the next three months getting up a long-term marketing and communications plan for the client. La Quinta Account **********Cunningham & Walsh will be opening an office in Dallas to service the La Quinta Motor Inns account just landed by its Chicago office and also Lenox Industries of Dallas, a long-time client. La Quinta, based in San Antonio, has 103 locations in 24 states. The ad budget may exceed $1 million. People *********** Fergus O'Daly has been named president of Poppe Tyson Inc., succeeding Fred C. Poppe, who becomes chairman and chief executive officer, a new position. *********** O. Burtch Drake rejoines Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc. as president and general manager of the DFS/San Francisco office. Addendum *********** Creamer Dickson Basford Inc., a subsidiary of Creamer Inc., has opened a Washington office.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.main_headline: SHOSTAKOVICH'S SON SAYS MOVES AGAINST ARTISTS LED TO DEFECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.print_headline: SHOSTAKOVICH'S SON SAYS MOVES AGAINST ARTISTS LED TO DEFECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.body_text: **********Maxim Shostakovich, the Soviet conductor and son of the composer Dmitri Shostakovich, said in a magazine interview that he decided to defect to the West because of the demeaning treatment of artists and musicians in the Soviet Union. **********In an inteview with the West German magazine Stern, to be published tomorrow, Mr. Shostakovich, also defended his father against suggestions that he was a supporter of Stalin and the Soviet Communist system. **********But he denied, as he has in the past, the authenticity of a book published in the West in 1975, after his father's death, that characterized his father as being highly critical of the Soviet Union. **********Mr. Shostakovich, who turned himself over to the police in West Germany, along with his son, Dmitri, a pianist, during a concert tour last month, is now living in New York. Shostakovich Accuses Bureaucrats **********In the interview, Maxim Shostakovich accused Communist bureaucrats of demeaning Soviet artists by trying to prescribe what is acceptable art and by treating them in an arbitrary way against which there was no appeal. **********''Everything that sounds pessimistic is rejected,'' he said of Soviet attempts to define art.  ''Even a woman who is painted as carrying a hundred pounds of potatoes on her back has to be depicted as smiling optimistically.'' ''That applies to music, too,'' the conductor continued. ''The party wants to express through culture that everyone is satisfied.'' Mr. Shostakovich said his monthly salary of 600 rubles, about $900, made him the Soviet Union's second highest paid conductor. But, he added, a suit costs 200 rubles. Musicians Denied Exit Papers **********The chief reason for his defection was the humiliating treatment at the hands of cultural bureaucrats, he said. Two days before leaving for the recent tour of West Germany, for example, the authorities refused exit papers to five of his best musicians. **********''I had to find substitutes within two days,'' Mr. Shostakovich said. ''If he was a talented Jew I couldn't take him along.  Of the five musicians who were refused papers, he said, ''one had a brother in America.'' He added: ''Another was a close friend of Yuri Aronovich, my predecessor, who also defected to the West. The third behaved in a way functionaries disapproved of during his last trip abroad. The fourth once got drunk at an inopportune time.'' **********Mr. Shostakovich was the conductor of the Symphony Orchestra of Central Television and Radio at the time of his defection. Questioned Before Travels **********Mr. Shostakovich said that Soviet musicians were regularly examined before going abroad by a travel commission on questions such as the difference between capitalism and Communism, or on current events, such as who were the political leaders of the country they were to visit. **********Asked about the authenticity of a book published in the West after his father's death, and described as his memoirs, Mr. Shostakovich replied: ''These are not my father's memoirs. This is a book by Solomon Volkov. Mr. Volkov should reveal how the book was written.'' **********Mr. Shostakovich said language in the book attributed to his father, as well as several contradictions and inaccuracies, led him to doubt the book's authenticity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/28/busin.main_headline: FREEZE ORDERED ON PROFIT MADE ON ST. JOE OPTIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/28/busin.print_headline: FREEZE ORDERED ON PROFIT MADE ON ST. JOE OPTIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/28/busin.body_text: **********Judge Milton Pollack of the Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday ordered the Irving Trust Company to freeze assets placed in three accounts by a Swiss bank after the Securities and Exchange Commission alleged the use of insider information in a recent purchase of St. Joe Minerals Corporation options. **********The commission charged in a civil suit filed yesterday in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York that customers of a Swiss bank, Banca Della Svizzera Italiana, made $1 million by the purchase of St. Joe options prior to the announcement of a $45-a-share tender offer by Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, and their subsequent sale. **********Named in the suit are Irving Trust, the Swiss bank, and purchasers whose identities and addresses are ''unknown,'' according to the commission, which had sought a temporary restraining order barring the defendants from trading in St. Joe options and from disposing the proceeds of any options sales. **********The suit charges that on March 10 the Swiss bank ordered the purchase of more than 1,000 call options, which gave the purchaser the right to buy more than 100,000 shares of St. Joe common stock for $25 to $30 a share. **********On March 11, Seagram announced its $45-a-share tender offer, causing St. Joe common to rise $15.375 a share, to $45.25 a share.  The following day the defendants liquidated their positions, yielding a profit of about $1 million. These proceeds were deposited in Irving Trust by the Swiss bank. **********The S.E.C. charged that the unnamed defendant purchasers caused the Swiss bank, Irving Trust and A.G. Becker Inc. to trade on their behalf while in possession of ''material nonpublic information'' that had been ''misappropriated from Seagram and certain entities'' retained by Seagram. **********The commission's complaint also noted that, the day after Seagram disclosed confidential nonpublic information to its legal counsel, forwarding agent, financial printer and publisher, the price of St.  Joe's common shares rose by $1.625 in trading that was 10 times higher than normal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/11/world.main_headline: REAGAN WORLD VIEW: IS A SPEECH NEEDED?
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/11/world.print_headline: REAGAN WORLD VIEW: IS A SPEECH NEEDED?
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/11/world.body_text: **********For a month, President Reagan's critics have been calling on him to make a speech on foreign policy. Some of these critics say that either he does not have a foreign policy or it is in disarray. **********Tuesday night in Chicago, the President answered that a speech was not ''necessary'' and might even be ''counterproductive,'' and that anyway, international relations was just ''common sense.'' **********Defenders of the President argue that there are clear lines of policy, but good political reasons for not making a speech yet.  These charges and explanations are standard fare for the early months of any Administration.  Those who like what Mr. Reagan is doing say he has a policy, and those who do not like it say he does not have one.  William G. Hyland, a national security adviser to President Ford and now with the Carnegie Endowment, thinks that there is a sound policy. He said: ''The basics are pretty obvious, flowing from the Presidential campaign: Contain Soviet expansionism through a major defense buildup and tough rhetoric without actually closing any doors to negotiations. And until there is a clear direction to Soviet-American relations, everything must be subordinated to this.'' **********Political Reasons Cited **********Some senior officials in several different departments maintain that the President has political reasons for not laying out a detailed policy now. The most important reason given at this time is that Mr. Reagan wants nothing to get in the way of Congressional approval of his economic programs. **********In this view, a major foreign policy address is bound to raise a political storm. As several White House aides explained the dilemma: If Mr. Reagan gave a very conservative speech, as his instincts would dictate, many foreign countries, the foreign policy establishment in the United States and much of the news media would be irritated with him; if he gave a middle-of-the-road speech, conservatives would criticize him. **********A measure of what some in the Administration see as the political problems from the right was a report issued several weeks ago by the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research organization. Even after the Administration urged increases of several billion dollars in military spending, the foundation report said, ''Thus far the new Administration has given few signs that it understands the urgency of correcting the vulnerabilities of U.S. strategic forces.'' **********Representative Les Aspin, a Wisconsin Democrat who finds much of what the President is doing excessive, does not think he has a policy. Mr. Aspin commented: ''Saying that he's not giving the speech because this will create political problems just doesn't wash. He already has political problems with his foreign policy, and these won't go away until he personally enunciates a position and stops the bickering in his own Administration.'' 'The World Is Too Complicated' **********Robert E. Osgood, a professor at Johns Hopkins University and an adviser to Mr. Reagan in the Presidential campaign, said the President was correct in resisting pressures to give ''an overarching speech and state some grand design, because the world is too complicated and it would mislead more than inform.'' Mr. Osgood also thinks that the direction and single theme of the Reagan foreign policy are quite clear, but that they do not constitute ''a policy.'' A policy to Mr. Osgood entails explaining what priorities are and how pieces fit together, obtaining the support of America's allies and showing how it is all going to work. **********Mr. Osgood, like many other foreign policy specialists, also contends that common sense is not enough. ''The world is uncommon and unpredictable, with too many variables and conflicts to be resolved by common sense without knowledge and a conceptual framework,'' he said. **********While Mr. Osgood is not critical of the time Mr. Reagan has taken so far, he, like others who hold similar views, maintains that the President will soon start paying a price in Congress, in his own bureaucracy and in foreign countries. So far, Mr. Osgood said, they are getting ''mixed signals, and they would respond better if they knew what we were doing.'' **********Richard M. Scammon, a public opinion expert, says that while the President's failure to give a major speech on foreign policy might be hurting him among some people in Washington, it has done him no harm with the American people in general. ''The polls show solid support for his foreign policy,'' Mr. Scammon said. ''Media complaints won't hurt him with the public in the short run, but if the press continues to hammer on the issue, it will begin to hurt him in the long run.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/busin.main_headline: U.S. CAR MAKERS ADDING MORE ALUMINUM, PLASTIC
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/busin.print_headline: U.S. CAR MAKERS ADDING MORE ALUMINUM, PLASTIC
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/busin.body_text: **********American auto companies, in an effort to increase fuel efficiency by making lighter cars are using more parts made of aluminum and plastic.  "The most exciting development programs currently under way in Detroit include doors, hoods and trunk lids made from reinforced plastics," said Gregory Galagher, transportation market manager for PPG Industries' Fiber Glass division in Pittsburg. **********"In addition structural parts made of composite will include wheels, rear springs, bumper systems and similar components." **********At General Motors, the nation's largest auto maker, "lightweight materials are going to play an important role," James Sines, manager of purchasing, forward planning and research, said in a telephone interview from Detroit. **********"It's going to depend not only on what the steel people do, but on what their competitors do.  It is definetely an opportunity for those suppliers who are creative and innovative," Mr. Sines added. **********The auto industry has traditionally been steel's largest single customer, until recently buying about 22 percent of annual output.  But steel shipments to Detroit have slowed because of slumping sales and shrinking cars. **********SHIPMENT DOWN 40% **********The American Iron and Steel Institue, and industry group, has estimated that automotive steel shipments in 1980 fell by 40 percent from the year before. **********Steelmakers, who realize that heavy luxury cars have gone the way of cheap gasoline, are striving to make lighter and stronger materials. **********The average net shipping weight of a General Motors four-door sedan in 1970 was 3,895 pounds.  In 1980 it was 3,228 pounds.  In 1970 car steel accounted for 2,443 pounds, or 63 percent of the weight.  Last year, steel in the average car totaled 59 percent, or 1,919 pounds. **********While steel content dropped 4 percentage points over 10 years, the use of plastic and aluminum in cars roughly doubled, plastic to more than 6 percent from less than 3 percent, and aluminum to nearly 4 percent from 2 percent. **********The plastic industry, which began a big development program after the 1973 oil embargo, appears ready for a major breakthrough in the auto market, with high-strength reinforced materials. **********PPC recently rebuilt a Cadillac Seville almost entirely out of fiberglass composites, shaving about 700 pounds from the car's weight. **********Plastic, however, must overcome production problems - auto makers are still geared for steel, with huge capital investment in steel stamping and assembly facilities. **********Aluminum, which might more easily be used as a steel substitute, also has its problems.  Marvin Gantz, a vice president for mill products at the Aluminum Company of America, recently told securities analysts that the passenger-car market "is less than thriving at the moment. **********PLANT CONSTRUCTION CANCELED **********Alcoa abandoned a multimillion-dollar plant-construction project in Davenport, Iowa, last year after losing promised orders from the auto industry. **********Aluminum's price has risen more than 50 percent in the last three years, but Alcoa contends that aluminum has a long-term advantage. **********"When taking into account fuel savings present with use of light materials such as aluminum, we believe the cost is actually cheaper in the long run," said Gordon Wangersheim, an Alcoa spokesman. **********Mr.Wangersheim uses the example of a car hood.  He estimates it would weight 42 pounds and cost $12.40 if made from steel, 16 pounds and $24.70 if made from aluminum.  But the lower weight would save 42 gallons of gasoline over 1000,000 miles, giving aluminum a cost advantage over steel. **********But since the mid-70's, the steel industry has been working to develop thinner, stronger steels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/02/busin.body_text: **********Kurt Waldheim, Secretary General of the United Nations, today sharply criticized what he termed ''too exclusive reliance'' on monetary policy in the fight against inflation because of its impact on interest rates. **********Opening the annual summer session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, Mr. Waldheim named no country as he echoed Continental European criticism of the monetary policy now being followed by Washington and London. **********France and West Germany, for example, contend that their currencies are being weakened because investors are buying dollars to profit from the higher American interest rates resulting from Washington's tight monetary policy. **********Mr. Waldheim first criticized what he saw as excessive reliance on monetary policy in the fight against inflation because, he said, the ''causes of the inflationary process are too varied for it to be effectively countered by any one type of action.'' Factor in Instability **********Then he added that the high interest rates that such a policy engendered caused instability because ''partner countries have to adjust their financial policies to prevent large outflows of capital.'' **********Deploring the ''erosion of the system of multilateral cooperation'' in the economic field, Mr. Waldheim said that unilateral measures in financial markets and new trade barriers did not augur well for the International Development Strategy for the third world adopted by the General Assembly. **********For the developing countries, he said, the higher interest rates cause a very large increase in debt-carrying costs. Mr. Waldheim added that new protectionist trade measures, or even the threat of them, similarly discouraged the investment that was necessary, ''if production structures are to be adjusted and new jobs created.'' **********Earlier at a news conference, he said he took ''strong exception'' to the statement by a third world journalist that in proposing ''zero growth'' the United Nations budget was putting into practice ''Reagan-Thatcher'' economics,'' a reference to the tight monetary policies put into effect by President Reagan in the United States and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Britain. **********The reporter, Chakravarthi Raghavan of the Rome-based Inter Press Service, asked Mr. Waldheim why he had presented the $1.5 billion budget for the two years 1981-82 without an express mandate from the General Assembly when ''it is going to have a devastating effect on the United Nations system's capacity to respond to the development strategy.'' Sharp Reaction **********Reacting sharply, the Secretary General said the newsman's ''completely unfounded'' statement had ''completely distorted'' the budget proposal. **********More than 80 percent of the United Nations budget, as distinct from the budgets of the related United Nations agencies, goes ''exclusively for personnel'' and less than 20 percent for other expenditures, he said. **********By ''reorganization'' and by ''redeployment of personnel'' that affected the 80 percent part of the expenditures, it was possible to present a ''zero growth'' budget, Mr. Waldheim said. **********''Let me say with extreme clarity,'' the Secretary General stressed, ''not one program of development has been touched by this restraint, not one program.''

Appliance Park employees would be furloughed for two weeks, beginning on Monday. **********A G.E. spokesman, Jim Allen, attributed the layoffs to growing inventories of unsold refrigerators, ranges and dishwashers. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/26/world.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia's economic planners believe they can successfully link the West's technology and the Islamic faith without rending society, but acknowledge they face a challenge. **********The text of the country's economic plan recognizes that there is concern in the Government and among the populace that ''alien values and the spirit of materialism'' may threaten religion, adding that this is a difficult problem. **********''I am an optimist,'' Deputy Planning Minister Faisal Bashir said in an interview. ''I think we came out of the 1970's very well. But we must not compromise our basic principles. I would call those Islam and our belief in the family.'' **********Saudi officials privately acknowledge that the world has a legitimate interest in how the kingdom will progress, as fabulous oil wealth and the technology that this is buying rub against ancient piety and ingrained traditionalism. The Birthplace of Islam **********The vast desert land was the birthplace of Islam, so what happens here has meaning to all the world's 600 million Moslems.  The Government understands the West's concern over a safe flow of Saudi oil, they said, but it resents ill-informed Western criticism of the stricter practices of Islam, as observed here, such as stoning of adulterers and the veiling and seclusion of women. **********Comparisons with the experience of Iran anger Saudi officials who contend that Saudi Arabia has a different style of monarchy with a tradition of consultation. King Khalid does not wear a crown or sit on a throne. **********''There are also not very many Saudis - perhaps not more than five million -so it is easier to spread the wealth around,'' a West European diplomat remarked. **********The 1980-85 economic plan envisages investments of about $300 billion for social improvements, defense, agriculture and gas-based petrochemical plants to earn foreign exchange when oil income eventually tapers off. **********A recent visitor, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, heard the Minister of Planning, Hisham Nazer, declare that all Saudis were entitled to free education and health care, unemployment and injury benefits. Prices for some essentials are subsidized. **********''It may sound as if the Saudi Government is following a policy of handouts,'' he told Mrs. Thatcher, who is a vigorous champion of self-reliance and free enterprise. ''But the policy is to insure a minimum standard of living and beyond that the good life will have to be earned.'' **********The Saudis have a flair for doing that. The opulence of some is legendary. Yet even the remaining shacks and shanties of Riyadh and the commercial city of Jiddah have cars outside and television antennas on the roofs. Saudi Partners Are Required **********Jidda business executives said non-Saudi companies could only operate if they had Saudi sponsors or partners, who swap expertise in mastering local conditions for a share in the profits that are made as Saudi Arabia rushes to spend its oil dollars. **********Islam does not discourage making money, provided that the prosperous give alms to the poor.  As conservative religious authorities see it, Islam is liable to be at risk when wealthy young Saudis fly off for the summer to London, Paris or Bangkok and cultivate a taste for permissive ways, a diplomat said. **********Spiritual values are perceived as further threatened by the presence of many non-Moslems in a foreign work force of at least 1.5 million, required because so far too few Saudis have the technological skills to run a modern economy and very few are inclined to undertake manual labor. 'I Love My Kingdom' **********In turn, young technocrats may be irked by the restrictions that prevail in Saudi Arabia, although Saudis themselves say too much stress should not be put on this. ''I have been to England,'' a 22-year-old minor official said. ''I like it for the summer months.Then I am happy to return to my kingdom. I love my kingdom.'' **********Foreign diplomats said that close links between the religious authorities and the 4,000-member royal House of Saud aided social cohesion. The Sauds emerged as a power in the Arabian Peninsula during the 18th century, in alliance with the purist Wahhabite movement that sought to cleanse Islam of what it saw as sacrilegious and idolatrous practices. **********King Khalid regularly consults with the Islamic authorities.  Officials say the strength of the Sauds has been that it has held fast to the fundamentals of Islam, while very gradually encouraging change in some attitudes that owe more to customs that have secured religious sanction than to strict Koranic injunction. A Girls' School Succeeds **********An example often cited is the introduction of education for girls.  Islam does not forbid this but has been invoked as an ally against it. The first girls' school opened in 1956, at the initiative of Princess Iffat, wife of the late King Faisal. She obtained her husband's backing for the project -evidence for the behind-thescenes influence of Saudi women. **********For about a year pupils could not be found for the new school. By 1960, royal patronage had made girls' education sufficiently acceptable for state-run girls' schools to open. **********Some resistance was encountered and in one town King Faisal sent troops to keep its new school open. He declined, however, to coerce parents into sending their daughters there and for some months the only occupants were the headmistress and her own child. Then resistance waned. **********Among problems to which Saudi planners now seek a solution is that of enabling many of the thousands of women who have been educated to work, which would trim demand for immigrant labor. Islam does not bar women from working but Saudi custom requires that they may not do so in the company of men. **********Jobs as nurses and airline attendants are among those done in Suadi Arabia by foreign women brought in on contract.

The big chemical concern said the action would not affect corporate earnings but would allow it to reassign its resources to more profitable products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/01/busin.body_text: **********T HE bond market has been a painful place for investors in the last two years as soaring interest rates chopped a fourth or more off the value of fixed-rate bonds. As the single-digit bond yields of the 1970's were overtaken by double-digit inflation, many bondholders fled the market entirely. **********Issuers, caught between their need for long-term money and the investor's demand for a decent return and preservation of capital, scratched their heads and came up with the floating-rate note. These are issues where the stated interest rate, or coupon, is adjusted periodically. Introduced in this country by Citicorp in 1974, there are now about $3.9 billion of them outstanding in the corporate market, with another several hundred million worth in the tax-exempt sector. **********If interest rates increased, the theory went, the price of the floating-rate issues would stay near par because of the periodic raising of the note coupon. Now, the question is whether the innovative floaters will become a real marketing alternative, or will disappear should interest rates decline and become more stable. **********''The traditional fixed-coupon, long-term bond will return to its favored position among investors if the Reagan Administration can wring out the inflationary psychology,'' said Richard Wilson, a vicepresident at Merrill Lynch who has specialized in floating rate issues. **********Not everyone agrees.  ''I expect further permutations on the floating rate idea'' as investors learn more about living with double-digit inflation and interest rates, explained Robert Henry, an investment banker at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''We have not gone nearly as far as the Europeans in developing more standardized versions of long-term floating rate securities.'' **********With new, fixed-rate, Aaa-rated, 40-year telephone company bonds yielding over 14 3/4 percent, there is ample evidence that investors are expecting high inflation and interest rates to persist. ''You still see a lot of people today who are uncertain about where inflation is headed, and are only too well aware that they have underestimated it in the past,'' said Mr. Henry. **********James L. Sullivan, senior vice-president in charge of $3 billion of investments at the American General Insurance Company, said his new bond holdings are all in the floating, or adjustable-rate securities, which he expects to account for a third to a half of the his portfolio within three to five years. **********''The adjustable-rate issues help keep the yield of my portfolio near current market levels,'' he explained. ''Even if I swing $100 million of bonds in and out of the market with perfect timing, the improvement for the entire portfolio is small.'' **********E VEN if interest rates do decline sharply later this decade, Mr.  Sullivan plans to stick with floaters. ''A lot of investors who think they are locking in high yields with long-term, fixed-rate bonds will have to reinvest that money in five to seven years because the companies will refund those old, high-coupon issues,'' he said. **********The shortcomings of floaters became apparent shortly after the groundbreaking Citicorp issue of 1974, a $650 million offering of notes due 1989, with a coupon adjusted every six months, to a slight premium over the equivalent yield on three-month Treasury bills. In 1975-76, the yield on the notes dropped below 6 percent, or less than what could be earned with other short- or long-term issues. Investors began to redeem their notes in bunches. Today, only about $160 million of the issue is still outstanding. **********Other deficiencies in the floating rate issues of Citicorp and a host of imitators became apparant in 1980 when interest rates changed rapidly. The semiannual changes in the coupon where not frequent enough to keep pace when six-month Treasury bills, for example, jumped from about 12 percent in early February to 15.7 percent in late March. And rates on Treasury bills, because they are considered the safest and most liquid of all investments, rose far less than other alternative investments, including bank certificates of deposit or commercial paper. **********A subsequent Citicorp issue in 1980 attempted to correct those ills by adjusting the coupon monthly. Also, the new issue, which was sold in minimums of $100,000 due to Federal regulations, set the coupon according to a formula that included the yield of bank C.D.'s as well as Treasury bills. **********Another type of floating rate issue, also pegged to Treasury bills, allows the investor to convert his holdings into a long-term, fixed-rate bond. There are about $1.6 billion of such issues outstanding - from companies ranging from Chase Manhattan to Beneficial Finance - and most specify that the investor has the option to convert to a long-term, fixed-rate issue with a coupon of about 8 1/2 percent. **********''The convertibility does not seem to be worth much today because bond yields are so much higher, but the jury is still out since the right to convert does not expire for several years,'' one investment banker said. **********Yet another variety of floater calls for the new coupon to be adjusted according to the yield on 10-, 20-, or 30-year Treasury bonds. (Since yields of long-term issues are more closely linked to expected inflation than short-term issues, many investors prefer the long-term link.) So far, the only companies to publicly offer such issues are General Motors Acceptance, where the yield is adjusted according to the yield on 10-year Treasury issues; Gulf Oil, with 30-year issues, and General Felt, 20-year issues. **********The latest wrinkle, this time playing on the price potential, is in the $75 million, B-rated General Felt issue. Far from aiming at par, the notes came out at a price of 70 to yield 17.42 percent for the first two years, after which the rate will be changed quarterly.  Michael Milken, a senior vice-president at Drexel Burnham Lambert, the issue manager, explained that the idea was to offer investors the potential for hefty price gains, as well as an adjustable interest rate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/01/busin.body_text: **********President Francois Mitterrand's Socialist Government today introduced a proposed 1982 budget aimed at cutting unemployment by increasing Government expenditures. **********The Government also announced that it was paring France's ambitious nuclear energy program. Both moves reflected promises made during last spring's election campaign. **********The 788.1-billion-franc budget proposal - equal to $143.3 billion - contrasts sharply with budgets being planned in the United States, Britain, West Germany and most other Western industrial countries, all of which are committed to conservative economic polices aimed at reducing inflation by limiting public spending. **********The proposed budget will be submitted to the French Parliament where the Socialists have a majority. No substantial changes are expected. Government Plans Biggest Deficit **********Although most French citizens would pay more taxes next year and the rich, for the first time, would pay a wealth tax, the Government still planned to run the biggest budget deficit in French history - 95 billion francs, or $17 billion. **********Today, Pierre Beregovoy, the presidential chief of staff, described the new budget as a step toward ''fiscal justice'' and an expression of the Government's will to ''fight for employment by stimulating the economy calling for national solidarity.'' **********Government spokesmen stressed that next year's budget deficit would be relatively small compared with those of many other Western countries, and therefore should not promote inflation or undermine the franc. **********But the Government's revenue projections assume the economy would grow by 3.3 percent next year because of the stimulus it was administering. That forecast is higher than many private projections. **********Moreover, next year's planned deficit would follow an anticipated budget deficit of about 75 billion francs this year that has already helped push the inflation rate to 15 percent and gravely weakened the franc on currency markets. **********Selling pressure on the franc mounted today following announcement of the proposed budget. The currency closed in European trading at 5.5570 francs to the dollar, up from 5.53 yesterday. 65,000 New Jobs Planned **********Under the proposed budget, the Government plans to create 65,000 new public sector jobs, in order to reach its target of 125,000 new jobs during 1981 and 1982. The Government also has increased by 45 percent incentives, such as subsidies for training, that it would give companies to encourage them to hire more employees. A total of 18.6 billion francs has been budgeted for such incentives. In addition, the Government would increase spending on public works program by 30 percent and on housing by 34 percent. **********Inexpensive loans and other subsidies to industry, such as grants for research or energy conservation investments, are due to rise 54 percent. **********Military spending would also increase by 18 percent, reflecting President Mitterrand's tough anti-Soviet stance and frequent warnings about the rapid buildup of Soviet nuclear weaponry. The overall military budget is expected to equal 3.89 percent of total economic output next year, compared with 3.85 per cent this year. **********To help raise money for its spending sprees, the French Government plans to impose a wealth tax ranging from five-tenths of 1 percent to 1.5 percent on fortunes of more than 3 million francs. In order to combat evasion of the tax, the Government also announced yesterday that henceforth the names of both buyer and seller will be recorded in all gold transactions on the Paris market, thus eliminating the well-established practice of anonymous tradin g. Income Tax Increases Scheduled **********In addition, French income taxpayers paying more than 15,000 francs next year would have their tax increased by 15 percent in an exceptional step intended to help finance the soaring cost to the state of unemployment compensation. Banks and oil companies would conti nue to p ay this year's ''windfall profits'' tax, while taxes on gasoline, tob acco and motor vehicle licenses would all be sharply raised. **********The cutback in the nuclear program would eliminate about one-third of the nuclear generating capacity the defeated Gaullists had planned to build during the next two years. It came in the form of an announcement that the Government had decided to build just five 1,300-megawatt reactors and one 900-megawatt reactor over the twoyear period. **********During the election campaign, President Mitterrand sought to win the votes of environmentalists by saying that France's civil nuclear program was ''excessive, even dangerous '' and promising to review it. But the cutbacks ordered today also reflected a decline in France's projected electricity needs as a result of the economic downturn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Noranda Increases Bid for MacMillan
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/03/busin.body_text: **********The battle for control of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. of Vancouver, Canada's largest forest products company, intensified today as Toronto-based Noranda Mines Ltd. raised its cash-and-shares offer for the company to the equivalent of $62 a share, or $626 million (Canadian). **********The offer, which would raise Noranda's holdings in MacMillan to 49 percent, from 8 percent, follows by one day the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation's offer to raise its stake in MacMillan from 20 percent to 49 percent by paying $56 a share cash, or $347.2 million. **********According to William Procter, a forest-products analyst for Gardiner Watson Limited, a Toronto investment concern, ''the Noranda offer is clearly better and is up in the realms of a very fair offer.'' **********The bidding war was begun by B.C. Resources March 12 by offering $46 for each of 6.2 million common shares. Noranda countered with a $565 million cash-plus-shares bid that, in the case of the common stock, was equal to $56 a share. **********MacMillan Bloedel is the last major forest products company whose control is not locked up. Last month Olympia and York Investments Ltd., a company privately owned by the Reichmann family of Toronto, bought 91 percent of the stock of Abitibi-Price Inc. of Toronto, the world's largest newsprint producer, in a takeover offer. **********More than a third of the shares in Canadian forest products companies would be taken out of the hands of the public in a little more than a month if the 49 percent of MacMillan shares is acquired.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/26/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: **********Burton Malkiel's article, ''Here a Yield, There a Yield...'' (July 5), gave an amusing example of why economics always seems so confused. In a most convoluted mathematical calculation, Mr. Malkiel attempts to show that an investor lending at 13 percent, with a prevailing 10 percent rate of inflation, will receive a net yield of 3 percent. He reasons as follows: An investor lends $1,000 for one year at 13 percent, receiving $130 in ''interest.'' But at the end of the year the investor receives back a devalued principal which Mr.  Malkiel somehow concludes is now worth $900 in year-one dollars. He then goes on to calculate that $900 (adjusted for inflation) plus $130 (inflated, unadjusted) minus $1,000 (not inflated) equals $30. **********Let's try to get an answer in real dollars. First, $1,000 at 10 percent inflation is devalued in one year to 1000/@ 1.10 equals $909, not $900. We might forgive Mr. Malkiel for casually ''rounding off,'' but suppose our investor moves overseas where we now find her investing $1,000 at 110 percent a year with an annual inflation rate of 100 percent. She gets $1,100 in ''interest'' and a devalued principal back which is now worth, not zero, but $1,000/2.00 equals $500. Using the dubious ''Malkiel Equation,'' we might conclude $500 plus $1,100 minus $1,000 equals $600, or a whopping rate of return of 60 percent. **********Tsk, tsk, professor, it's really all so simple. Remember, interest also gets hit by inflation. To get net, we take $1,000 (principal) plus $1,100 (interest) equals $2,100. Since inflation is 100 percent, $2,100 buys only half that, or $1,050 of goods at last year's prices. Thus, net equals $1,050 minus $1,000 equals $50, or 5 percent. Only if the investor receives the interest immediately upon investment, and reinvests it at the prevailing inflation rate, will she receive, in this example, a net yield of 10 percent. (This is something I've never quite gotten my bank to do.) **********Mr. Malkiel's example will be left as an exercise for the reader.  However, for the still perplexed investor, the correct answer is $27.27, or (if you'll forgive the rounding) 2.7 percent. Be sure to try and work this out though because next week we will cover compounding. VLADIMIR DROZDOFF New York, N.Y., July 7, 1981  Phillipsburg, N.J., July 9, 1981  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.  Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Business Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/18/busin.print_headline: SEAGRAM'S NET UP 113% IN QUARTER; EARNINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/18/busin.body_text: **********The Seagram Company yesterday reported record operating results for the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 1981, ended July 31.  Net income rose 113 percent, to $92.3 million, or $2.63 a share, compared with $43.3 million, or $1.23 a share, in the final quarter last year. **********The company's quarterly revenues increased 11 percent, on sales of $611.2 million, from $548.3 million a year earlier. **********Net income for the year, before unusual credits and currency translation effects, doubled, to $285.6 million, or $8.14 a share, compared with $142.4 million, or $4.06 a share, in the fiscal year 1980. **********Sales for the fiscal year increased 9.4 percent, to $2.77 billion, up from $2.54 billion in 1980.  Contributing to the gain was $180.2 million in after-tax interest income, which resulted from the interim investment of the proceeds of the sale of the company's oil and gas properties in the United States. In August 1980, Seagram sold the properties to the Sun Company for $2.3 billion in cash and notes. The proceeds were the basis of Seagram's unsuccessful bid for Conoco last summer, as well as its unsuccessful bid for the St. Joe Minerals Corporation earlier this year. **********In addition, annual operating income in Seagram's spirits and wine business rose 14.1 percent, to $98.6 million, on a 9.4 percent sales gain for the fiscal year. ''We had a very solid year in our basic spirits and wine business,'' said Edgar M. Bronfman, chairman and chief executi ve officer. The company reported that premium brands, including Chi vas Regal Scotch whisky, Crown Royal Canadian Whisky and Myers's R um, were a significant factor in the earnings increase. **********Seagram, based in Montreal, is the world's largest producer and marketer of distilled spirits and wines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/world.main_headline: BEGIN DENIES A LINK BETWEEN AWACS AND U.S. STRATEGIC TIES WITH ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/world.print_headline: BEGIN DENIES A LINK BETWEEN AWACS AND U.S. STRATEGIC TIES WITH ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that in his talks with President Reagan and other American officials, no hint was given that any link existed between the sale of surveillance aircraft to Saudi Arabia and broad strategic cooperation with Israel. **********''In all my con versations with the President and his advisers,'' Mr. Begin sai d, ''I never heard, not a single hint, nor did my colleagues. T here is no link between these things.'' **********He was replying to a reporter's question, after the weekly Cabinet meeting, about statements in Washington that Congressional rejection of the sale would disrupt plans to strengthen United States military ties with Israel. **********The growing emphasis on a link has been interpreted here as a reflection of the Reagan Administration's increasing concern over the developing Senate opposition to the deal, and an inclination to hold the pro-Israel lobby responsible for any defeat. Charge of Interference Rejected **********Mr. Begin rejected an accusation by Senator John Tower, Republican of Texas and chairman of the Armed Services Committee, that the Prime Minister had intervened in domestic American politics by opposing the sale of Airborne Warning and Control System planes, known as Awacs, to the Saudis. **********''There is no basis to this accusation, but I do not want to enter into an argument with a U.S. Senator,'' Mr. Begin said. ''In the debate between the two arms of government, the executive and legislative, we won't intervene.'' **********Israel's tactic, in an effort to avoid antagonizing the Reagan Administration, has been to try to walk a careful line, stating its opposition while staying out of the conflict between Congress and the White House, hoping that the sale will be defeated but that Israel will not be blamed for a defeat. **********The Israeli press has reported that the Israeli Embassy in Washington, for example, has been directed to keep a low profile in the debate. Mr. Begin has even drawn criticism at home, with newspaper editorials and opposition Labor Party leaders accusing him of weakening the fight against the Saudi arms deal in exchange for the vague and dubious notion of ''strategic cooperation.'' 'A Totally New Situation' **********The cooperation being considered would include stockpiling American weapons in Israel for use by American troops in an emergency, and joint air and naval maneuvers. **********Shimon Peres, the Labor Party chairman, said last week: ''We in the Labor Party would not have agreed to pay the price which Begin paid for his strategic agreement. That price was the Awacs. We always had a constant agreement with the U.S. that since we are at a numerical and quantitative disadvantage, we should enjoy qualitative superiority, including in armament. Now, with the sale of Awacs to the Saudis, we are for the first time facing a totally new situation.'' **********In fact, Mr. Begin has argued forcefully against the proposed sale of five Awacs to Saudi Arabia, and against the provision of extra fuel pods, bomb racks and missiles for F-15 fighters that the Saudis are purchasing. **********''I spoke to the President for an hour and a half and expressed our opposition to this double sale,'' Mr. Begin said. ''I told the President explicitly, illustrating with maps - we brought maps - to prove how these Awacs could view almost all of Israel, and out of the seven airfields, five of them, and so forth.'' Awacs Could Be Targets The Israeli apprehension is based on the fact that Saudi Awacs co uld detect Israeli aircraft, and direct Saudi fighters against th em, long before the Israelis could spot the Awacs or the Saudi fi ghters. The Awacs has radar and computerized command equipment su perior to the instruments aboard the Hawkeye E-2C, which the Is raelis fly to direct their fighters into combat. **********Some Israeli officials have said that a Saudi Awacs would be a first target in any warfare, but one American expert, who asked not to be identified, doubted that the surveillance plane would be so easy to shoot down. **********''Israel would lose in excess of a dozen aircraft trying to shoot this down,'' the American said. ''It sees you 200 miles before you see it. It would call up Saudi F-15's, which would fly just outside the Israeli perimeter and wait, and they'll enter from a difficult angle and ambush the Israelis.'' **********He noted that in proposing the original procurement of the expensive planes -each one costs about $1 billion - the United States Air Force argued in 1976 that the Awacs could ''survive sufficiently well'' against the Warsaw Pact, which has 2,000 fighters, and that ''survivability in other, less demanding environments is unquestioned.'' 'What Are You Worried About?' **********The idea of shooting down planes that would have, at least initially, American crew members aboard has bothered Israeli officials. Prime Minister Begin commented on it in a speech to P arliament la st May 11. **********''Some respected and important Americans gave us some simple advice,'' he said. '' 'What are you worried about? You have a marvelous air force. If they are stationed near the Israeli border instead of in the eastern part of Saudi Arabia, you simply shoot them down.' **********''And at the same time, they tell us that for many years to come, there will be Americans and Saudis in those planes after the Awacs are sold to Saudi Arabia. What strange advice we get from Washington. We are supposed to shoot down the planes and kill not only the Saudis, who are our enemies, but also the Americans, who are our friends. Very strange advice indeed. We cannot accept it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/06/world.body_text: **********Two Afghan MIG jet fighters twice strafed a Pakistani border post today, injuring two civilians, the Pakistani Defense Ministry said. **********The ministry said the two MIG-17's violated Pakistani airspace three times during the morning, opening fire the second and third times at Domandai, north of Quetta. The post building was damaged, the announcement said. **********The reported violations were believed the first in eight months.  The last major incident occurred in 1980 when Afghan helicopters strafed a border post in Northwest Frontier Province, killing a Pakistani officer and one other person.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/06/busin.main_headline: Commodities; Traders Find Safety In Pooling
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/06/busin.print_headline: Commodities; Traders Find Safety In Pooling
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/06/busin.body_text: **********MOST commodity futures speculators need not be reminded that they lost heavily during the first half of the year, when prices declined sharply in most markets. As usual, the losers were long the market because most small traders do not sell short. They are fearful of selling goods they do not own in the hope that prices will decline before they have to deliver them. **********But there was one kind of small speculator that actually made money in the first half without making any decisions at all. Nor did they spend one night worrying about a morning call for more cash margin from their brokers. The reason: they were members of commodity pools, which are similar to the mutual funds involving securities. **********Commodity pools have been proliferating at a rapid rate in the past year or so to serve small speculators unable or unwilling to trade on their own. Most of the major pools are sponsored by leading brokerage houses and managed by independent professionals who receive a fee and portion of the profits. **********''The growth of the pools is indeed astounding, particularly in light of the lackluster performance of most markets in the last 18 months,'' said Andrea Cocoran, chief counsel of the trading and markets division of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, during an interview in her office in Washington last week. **********''Our agency began registering commodity pool operators on April 1, 1979, when the total was some 600.'' she said. ''In 1980, the number grew to 786, and as of last April, there were 1,084 registered operators and the number is growing.'' **********Barbara Stern, special counsel of the C.F.T.C. division, said in the same interview: ''Thus far there have been few problems with the pools sponsored by brokerage houses. The troubles have been confined to swindlers pretending to run legitimate pools.'' **********As a result, the C.F.T.C. is tightening its regulations governing commodity pools. Oddly, one of the agency's reforms instituted last Wednesday exempts pools with less than $200,000 in assets as well as those with fewer than 15 members, while supervision of the large pools have been inexplicably tightened. **********Another oddity is that the only private monitor of the performance of commodity pools is Norwood Securities Inc., a Chicago brokerage house that does not handle commodity business. Jay Klopfenstein, president of Norwood, said in a recent interview: **********''We began to monitor the pools some two years ago because we knew they were going to become a very important element in the financial services business. Besides, many of our securities customers also trade commoditiies and only knew the results of their own pool's performance from monthly reports. They didn't know how the others were doing.'' **********But Mr. Klopfenstein emphasized that he only records the performance of pools that provide him with detailed data each month.  He also has devised the Norwood Index, which has become the Dow Jones of pool watchers. **********The index showed that the assets of the 26 pools rose 3.8 percent in May compared with a gain of nine-tenths of a percent the month before. The index for June is expected to be published later this week. **********According to his information, the following brokerage houses are forming commodity pools as a first venture or ''clone'' to existing ones: Merrill Lynch, $30 million; Thomson McKinnon Commodity Partners I, $10 million; Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Heinhold, $15 million; A.G. Becker's LaSalle Street Futures Fund, $15 million; Piper Jaffray (Minneapolis) Midwest Commodity Fund I, $10 million. **********Again, Mr. Klopfenstein stressed that the list only contained pools that brokerage houses had told him about.  ''We still can't make year-to-year comparisons because they are being created at a fast pace,'' Mr. Klopfenstein said. ''What we can state is that most did quite well during the price slump in the first half because most of them followed their computer instructions and were short the market during this period. Now it looks like commodity prices in general may have reached a bottom for the time being.'' **********Thomas A. Russo, a specialist in commodities at the New York law firm of Cadwalader Wickersham & Taft, observed yesterday: **********''The next big step in commodity pools will be taken later this year, when the big and not-so-big brokerage houses run their own pools, instead of just underwriting them. After all, they have the sales force and their in-house commodity research.'' **********Most important, Mr. Russo said, the reservoir of commodity traders is relatively small, numbering perhaps 200,000 active accounts. Given the heavy losses sustained by small speculators in the past 18 months, many are now unable or unwilling to risk their capital in these highly volatile markets. **********''If the brokerage houses want to keep their commodity departments as profit centers,'' Mr. Russo said, ''they will need more than new products such as financial instruments. They will need safer methods to trade futures. The proliferation of futures markets in recent years has not really increased the number of traders. For many houses it has just increased the overhead. That's why everyone is forming pools.'' **********While this may run counter to the glowing trading statistics furnished each month by the Futures Industry Association, many brokers and exchange officials concede that the sharp rises in volume increasingly represent trading among floor traders and other professionals, rather than the public's participation. **********This week, the F.I.A. will report that futures trading in June soared a further 27 percent, to 8.5 million contracts, with the total for the first six months up 24 percent from the 1980 level, to 47.5 million. Last May, the monthly volume rise was 21 percent, while volume in the first five months rose 23 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/26/world.body_text: **********More than 50 policemen were injured in street clashes in West Berlin last night when demonstrators temporarily occupied two town halls in protest at police action against squatters. **********A police spokesman said demonstrators smashed the windows of 30 banks and department stores in the protest, which was prompted by the eviction of squatters from three houses. A firebomb attack on local government offices caused minor damage. He said 18 people were detained and that legal proceedings were started against five of them. **********According to police figures, squatters are occupying more than 120 houses in West Berlin, which has a serious housing shortage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/27/busin.main_headline: Other Business; PROTECTING YOUR SECRETS - AND YOURSELF
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/27/busin.print_headline: Other Business; PROTECTING YOUR SECRETS - AND YOURSELF
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/27/busin.body_text: **********''Maybe I'm just paranoid, but I think someone's tapping my phone.'' The speaker was a contractor who was making half a million dollars a year - until a competitor began stealing job after job out from under his nose. The listener was Carmine O. Pellosie, president of CCS Communications Control Inc. in New York, a maker of antiespionage devices. **********''He wasn't paranoid,'' Mr. Pellosie recalled. ''There was a little transmitter in his phone.'' (Which the police removed, but not before the contractor sent his competitor chasing false leads across the state.) **********Last year CCS, the largest company in the $400 million-and-growing surveillance and monitoring industry, said it had $32 million in sales and more than $12 million in pretax profits, de-bugging offices and boardrooms and supplying individuals with James Bond-like gadgetry. The price includes secrecy, and Mr. Pellosie won't breathe a word about his clients. But he says he has enrolled 200 of the Fortune 500 companies. **********Still, most customers buy their own protection. Witness the trionic briefcase, which sniffs out bombs and electronic bugs, hides a built-in lie detector and tape recorder, can temporarily blind an attacker with a beam of light, reveals its whereabouts through an electronic transmitter, and can shield its owner against a shot from a .357 magnum. Grab it - or try to - and it sounds a piercing alarm seconds after the theft. CCS says it sold 2,500 of these cases last year. **********The CCS counterintelligence catalogue - which at $25 is the company's cheapest item - offers many other novelties: *********** Bug Alerts, $500 to $3,000. Disguised as a pack of cigarettes (''your favorite brand''), a leather-bound notebook, digital wristwatch or pen set, these bug detectors beep, light up or vibrate when the wearer nears a hidden transmitter. *********** Supercar. In 1979, the Shah of Iran ordered one, a $250,000 bullet-proof, bomb-proof Cadillac, but ''by the time we were ready to deliver it, he was in Mexico,'' says Mr. Pellosie. (CCS kept his $50,000 deposit.) This is the car that leaves oil slicks in its wake and emits clouds of tear gas. Mr. Pellosie sells 30 armored roadsters a year, most of them more modestly equipped than the one ordered by the Shah. *********** The Communication Control Center, a telephone in an attache case that can change a woman's voice into a man's, and a man's voice into something altogether different. There's a voice scrambler, and a device to detect wiretaps - unless, of course, one wants to ''feed the eavesdropper misinformation.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.main_headline: TAX RISES VOTED BY 30 STATES TERMED LARGEST IN 10 YEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.print_headline: TAX RISES VOTED BY 30 STATES TERMED LARGEST IN 10 YEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.body_text: **********Thirty state legislatures have already moved to rais e taxes a total of $2.5 billion this year, the highest annual increa se since 1971, according to a study released yesterday. **********The study said that $860 million, or slightly more than one-third of the increase, would come in higher general sales taxes. It also said that another sizable portion, $750 million, would be made up in higher tax rates on motor fuel. **********The study was made by the Tax Foundation In c., a nonprofit researchand public education organization.  Twenty-four states and the District of Colu mbia agreed to raise motor fuel taxes, the study said, ''reacting to the continuing squeeze on highway funds brought on by rising costs and declining gasoline usage.'' **********At least 12 states put into effect new or higher taxes on minerals taken from the earth, while six states raised cigarette taxes and eight raised taxes on alcoholic beverages, the study said. New York enacted the largest single tax package with a five-year program for mass transit. **********The tax increases agreed on this year by 30 states are the largest since 1971, when 30 states raised taxes by a record of more than $5 billion annually, the study said. **********Last year the increase was $420 million, the study said.  Substantial reductions were recorded in the taxpayer revolt years of 1978 and 1979. **********William J. Wilson, a spokesman for the Tax Foundation, said the the Reagan Administration's cutbacks in funds for state and local governments had a minimal effect because most of the legislative actions were started before the Administration made its proposals. **********''Generally, the states are having to cope with the increased costs brought on by inflation and higher interest rates,'' he said.  Joe McLaughlin, a spokesman for the National Governors Association, noted that Federal aid to state and local governments had been declining in terms of real dollars, calculated after discounting for inflation, for the last three years. **********He also suggested that some states were feeling the aftereffect of the tax revolts of 1978 and 1979, when taxpayers demanded relief from state and local taxes. ''Sooner or later the pressure starts rebuilding'' for more money, Mr. McLaughlin said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/14/busin.body_text: **********The Internal Revenue Service estimates that it has been unable to deliver income tax refund checks to nearly 88,000 people who have moved and left no forwarding address, according to a report released today. **********A partial breakdown made by the General Accounting Office for Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, shows that at least 33 of the checks are for $10,000 or more apiece. **********Mr. Rosenthal's Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs released a G.A.O. report saying that as of Dec. 31 the tax agency was holding $24.5 million owed to 87,760 taxpayers who could not be found by the Post Office. **********Ellen Murphy, a representative of the I.R.S., said the money is earning 12 percent interest. The refunds can be claimed regardless of how many years have passed, she said. Taxpayers should telephone or write to their nearest I.R.S. office, she said, giving the name or names on the return, Social Security number or numbers, old address, new address and the year for which the return was filed. Companies Also Sought **********In addition to the refunds for individuals, Miss Murphy said, there is also a backlog of refunds for business taxpayers that can not be located. One New York company's undelivered refund check is for ''many tens of thousands of dollars,'' she said. **********A breakdown for the three tax years of 1976-78 shows 358 undelivered refunds for people who filed from Connecticut, 1,171 from New Jersey and 4,183 from New York. **********On returns filed for 1979, the I.R.S. sent out a total of 72.3 million refunds, adding up to $44.4 billion. The deadline for filing Federal income tax returns for 1980 is midnight Wednesday. **********The G.A.O. report, in the form of a letter to Mr. Rosenthal from the agency's acting chief, Milton J. Socolaw, said the I.R.S. asked the Social Security Administration more than two and a half years ago to use its benefit files to help locate people who did not get their refunds. Social Security officials expressed concern that to do so might violate the Privacy Act, Mr. Socolaw added. **********He said that issue had been sidetracked pending the outcome of a trial computer run this summer to determine whether the Social Security's computer files can help deliver the refund checks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/27/busin.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; NOMINEE AS F.T.C. HEAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/27/busin.body_text: **********James Clifford Miller 3d, who was named by President Reagan today to be the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, brings to the post a strong commitment to the free-market system, energy and a dash of humor. **********Mr. Miller, who learned of his nomination yesterday, on his 39th birthday, has helped lead the Reagan Administration's drive to shrink Government regulation, first as head of the transition group that studied regulations and currently as a top staff member of the Office of Management and Budget and executive director of the Presidential Task Force for Regulatory Relief. His appointment to the F.T.C. is expected to have a strong impact on the way the regulatory agency works. **********''My basic philosophy reflects the President's own,'' Mr. Miller said in a telephone interview. ''I have, like most economists, a great appreciation for the marketplace, which needs regulatory relief. It's not that we need to cut the pie smaller, we need to make the pie grow larger.'' Government regulations, Mr. Miller feels, represent one of the chief negatives in the equation - an equation that started out to redress inequities but has since become part of the problem. ''Simple changes have ramifications beyond the original scene, and there ain't no such thing as a free lunch,'' Mr. Miller said. **********Under Mr. Miller, the commission is likely to find itself working within a very narrow mandate. Remarking that he still faced confirmation hearings, Mr. Miller declined to discuss his plans for running the F.T.C. **********The F.T.C. has encountered hard times in the last several years, as the mood of the country shifted to one of regulatory caution. In the early and mid-1970's, the commission broke new ground in the area of antitrust law and consumer protection, as it operated under new powers from Congress and broad interpretations of old mandates. Crackdown by Congress **********But last year, Congress cracked down on the agency's powers. The Reagan Administration has already cut the commission's budget and attempted to remove its antitrust authority. Most of the antitrust cases that brought it into the limelight during the last decade have quietly died since January or have been severely curtailed. **********''Jim has the talent of focusing on what are the important things that need to get done and not getting sidetracked,'' said one budget official who has worked closely with Mr. Miller. **********As an example of that focus, others cite the swiftness with which Mr. Miller was able to get a coalition of support behind President Reagan's Executive Order 12291, which requires executive branch departments and regulatory agencies to do cost-benefit analyses of new regulations and submit the results to the Office of Management and Budget before issuing new regulations. Research Aide With Two Groups **********Mr. Miller received his undergraduate degree in economics from the University of Georgia in 1965. He received his doctorate, also in economics, from the University of Virginia in 1969 and afterward served as a senior staff economist with the Department of Transportation. During 1972, he also worked as a research associate at the Brookings Institution and the American Enterprise Institute, both Washington-based economic research organizations. **********From 1972 to 1974 he was associate professor of economics at Texas A & M University, as well as a consultant to the Department of Transportation and the National Bureau of Standards. **********From 1974 to late 1975, he was a member of the senior staff of the Council of Economic Advisers, as well as being an adjunct scholar with the enterprise institute. In October 1975, he served as assistant director for government operation and research on the Council on Wage and Price Stability. Resident Scholar at Institute **********Beginning in 1977 and until his budget appointment this year, he was an enterprise institute resident scholar and co-director of its Center for the Study of Government Regulation. **********Mr. Miller was born on June 25, 1942, in Conyers, Ga., the eldest of six children. His father, James C. Miller Jr., is a retired Delta Air Lines pilot; his mother, Annie, is a real estate broker. **********Mr. Miller married the former Demaris Humphries and they reside in the District of Columbia and have three children: Katrina, 11 years old;, Felix, 10, and Sabrina, 8. **********Mr. Miller relaxes by riding his motorcycle, backpacking with his family and operating his ham radio set. ''His absolute favorite hobby, though, is playing Dixieland trumpet, which he plays with records,'' Mrs. Miller said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/26/busin.body_text: **********Aside from worries about environmental hazards, participants at this week's U.S.-Canadian conference on acid rain are likely to focus on a growing body of information about the costs created by what analysts call an external diseconomy. **********Although many claim that more research is needed before costs and benefits of regulation can be assessed, economists like Thomas Crocker of the University of Wyoming disagree. **********Damages from acid rain are rising, Mr. Crocker says, and may soon become uncontrollable. **********Industry officials who burn and sell high-sulfur coal, seen by many as the major source of the acid rain which falls in the northeastern U.S. and Canada, say the cost of placing pollution-control devices in older plants, burning lower-sulfur coal, or both, could run into billions. **********Mr. Crocker agrees the cost to industry would be high, but estimates that damages to materials, forests, lakes and agriculture attributable to acid rain amount to $5 billion annually. Moreover, since power plants generally have a life of 40 to 50 years, he thinks it will be another two decades before the older plants are phased out.
