https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/23/world.print_headline: Pope Says Catholics Have a Duty To Fight Legalization of Abortion
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/23/world.body_text: **********Declaring that abortion is the ''killing of an innocent creature,'' Pope John Paul II said today that Roman Catholics had a duty to work against laws legalizing the practice. **********Speaking to about 25,000 people gathered in St. Peter's Square for his weekly blessing, the Pope praised a statement by the Italian Bishops Conference last week that called for abortion laws ''to be overcome with all legitimate means and opportunities.'' **********''The image of God is present in every human creature from the first instant of conception,'' the Pope said, reaffirming traditional Roman Catholic teaching. ''It is in this context that one places the effort to inscribe divine law in the daily life of the earth so that beyond any equivocation the value of motherhood and the full defense of human life is guaranteed.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Consumer prices in the 10 countries of the European Economic Community jumped 1.6 percent in April, the most in a year, the Common Market's statistical office reported today. **********The inflation rate for the community as a whole was 12.4 percent in the 12 months ended April 30. **********The biggest rise in prices in April was 2.9 percent in Britain, partly because of tax increases. In other Common Market countries, prices went up 2 percent in Greece, 1.4 percent in France and Italy, 1.2 percent in Denmark, 1 percent in the Netherlands and six-tenths of 1 percent in West Germany and Luxembourg. In Belgium, where the Government froze prices in April, there was a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent. Figures for Ireland were not released. **********West Germany had the community's best inflation record in the 12-month period, with a rate of 5.5 percent. Elsewhere, the Netherlands had inflation of 6.3 percent; Belgium, 7.4 percent; Luxembourg, 7.5 percent; Denmark, 11.8 percent; Britain, 12 percent; France, 12.8 percent; Italy, 20.2 percent; Ireland, 21 percent, and Greece, 24.3 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/25/world.main_headline: WHITE HOUSE SAYS MRS. KIRKPATRICK DIDN'T KNOW SOUTH AFRICAN'S ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/25/world.print_headline: WHITE HOUSE SAYS MRS. KIRKPATRICK DIDN'T KNOW SOUTH AFRICAN'S ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/25/world.body_text: **********Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, met last week with a high-ranking South African military intelligence official without knowing the full role of the official, the White House said today. **********Lieut. Gen. P.W. Van der Westhuizen, chief of South African military intelligence, and three of his aides met with Mrs.  Kirkpatrick on March 15 in New York. Initially, the State Department denied that the meeting had taken place. In trying to explain it today, the White House press secretary, James S. Brady, said that Mrs. Kirkpatrick did not have full knowledge of the general's position in the South African Government. **********''Had Jeane known that,'' Mr. Brady said at a press briefing, ''she probably would have had second thoughts about meeting them.'' Under United States policy, members of the South African armed forces are not permitted to visit this country on official business. This is rooted in a ban on the sale of military equipment to South Africa. **********''I don't think she was aware that the people she was meeting with were military,'' Mr. Brady said.  According to his account, the meeting was arranged by ''third parties'' whom he did not identify. Diplomatic sources have indicated that the South Africans were assisted in their visit to this country by the American Security Council, a conservatively oriented political group based in Boston, Va. **********Mr. Brady said that others were in attendance at the meeting and that fuller details were being sought by State Department officials.  He was asked why Mrs. Kirkpatrick attended the meeting. **********''It was represented to her that these were people who were knowledgeable on the South African question,'' he replied.  Initially, State Department officials had insisted that no members of a South African military delegation had met with policy-level officials of the Reagan Administration and that the department had not known in advance of the South Africans' identity. These public reassurances were contradicted yesterday by State Department and South African officials. ---- Change in Policy Seen at U.N. Special to the New York Times **********UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 24 -Diplomats here said today that the meeting between Mrs. Kirkpatrick and General Van der Westhuizen was indicative of a disturbing change in United States policy toward South Africa. **********''From what we've seen, there is a pattern emerging that is not a coincidence,'' said B. Akporode Clark, the head of the Nigerian mission here. ''Everybody is prepared to give a government the benefit of doubt when it's just been installed but this points to a pattern of behavior.'' **********The United States mission here refused to comment on Mrs.  Kirkpatrick's meeting with the South African officer.  There is anxiety over the meeting, said Bishop Desmond Tutu, the general secretary of South Africa's Council of Churches, ''not as an isolated thing but in relation to the whole tenor that appears to be emerging in Washington over policy on South Africa.'' **********Bishop Tutu said he had been told of the meeting by Mrs.  Kirkpatrick yesterday, during a half-hour visit he made to her office, which was arranged before his arrival in New York Saturday, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/26/world.main_headline: FOR MARGARET PAPANDREOU, A 'QUIET RAGE' OF FEMINISM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/26/world.print_headline: FOR MARGARET PAPANDREOU, A 'QUIET RAGE' OF FEMINISM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/26/world.body_text: **********Margaret Papandreou believes her husband's new Socialist Government will mean a breakthrough for Greek women, who she says ''have been largely suppressed through our capitalist system and our patriarchal mentality.'' **********The American-born wife of Greece's new Prime Minister is a dedicated feminist, a Socialist and the guiding inspiration behind the Women's Union of Greece. **********''Women's problems are the same in Greece as in most countries, though maybe to a greater degree,'' Mrs. Papandreou said in a recent interview. She emphasized the need to open more jobs to women, set up more child care centers, change the education system, revise family laws and legalize abortions. **********Greece's new First Lady is tall and blond with the unpretentious charm of a Midwestern farm girl. She comes from Elmhurst, Ill., and studied journalism and public health at the University of Minnesota. Papandreous Met in Minnesota **********It was there that she met and married an economics professor, Andreas Papandreou, in 1951. He had left Greece in 1940 before the invasion of Mussolini's troops, and had gone to Harvard University, where he obtained a doctorate in economics in 1943. **********Mr. Papandreou became an American citizen in 1944. He served in the United States Navy for two years before going to the University of Minnesota to teach. In 1955, the Papandreous moved to the University of California at Berkeley, where he served as chairman of the Department of Economics. **********Their four children were born in America. George Jeffrey, 29 years old, has just been elected to Parliament from the district of Patras, where his father and grandfather ran before him. Gayle Sophia, 27, who has just finished her master's degree in economics in Sussex, England, recently married and expects to get a job soon.  Nicholas, 25, is studying for a doctorate in Princeton and Andreas Jr., 23, is studying at the London School of Economics. **********It was in 1959 that Andreas Papandreou decided to return to Greece, his wife recalls. Mr. Papandreou, who had gone back with Fulbright and Guggenheim grants, was asked by Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis to set up the Center of Economic Research in Athens. He resumed his Greek citizenship, won a seat in Parliament and was given a Cabinet post in the 1964 Government headed by his father, Prime Minister George Papandreou. Colonels Arrest Father and Son **********The rapidly growing influence and Socialist ideas of Andreas Papandreou were said to be among the main factors that prompted the 1967 colonels' coup. Both father and son were arrested. **********George was released six months later and died the next year.  Andreas was charged with high treason, kept in solitary confinement for eight months, then released under a Christmas amnesty and expelled. **********Andreas spent his seven years of exile as a professor of economics, first at Stockholm University, then York University in Toronto.  During his exile, he organized the Pan Hellenic Liberation Movement, a coalition of groups opposed to military dictatorship. **********Mr. Papandreou and his family returned to Greece in 1974 when the junta collapsed after the Turkish invasion of Cyprus. He then founded the Pan Hellenic Socialist Movement, called Pasok. It grew in seven years from a small group with 13 percent of the vote and 12 seats in Parliament to become the major political force in the country with 48 percent of the vote and 172 seats in last Sunday's election. 'Margaret Taught Us Everything' **********His wife started to build up the women's movement in 1975.  ''Margaret taught us everything, how to make a modern organization,'' says Titina Pantazis, a young woman who has just been elected on the Socialist ticket as deputy to the European Parliament. ''She is the brains behind the women's union and has been elected president several times, but always refuses, preferring the post of vice president.'' **********Mrs. Papandreou says her main activity has been to mobilize women, wherever they are - in the marketplaces, beauty shops, hospitals and particularly in the villages. There are now chapters of the Women's Union all over Greece. **********''But there's still a strong belief that women belong at home,'' she said. More Women Candidates **********She is pleased that there were more women running in the last election - 205 compared with only 103 in 1977 - but she is disappointed that there were not many more. And only 12 women - 8 of them Socialists - were elected to the 300-seat Parliament, just two more than in the last Conservative-dominated legislature. **********Mrs. Papandreou rarely appeared with her husband during the election campaign, preferring to take part in women's rallies. She went to Piraeus to show support for the actress Melina Mercouri, who later won a seat in Parliament and has been named Minister of Culture and Sciences. **********Miss Mercouri arrived at the rally late with a dramatic flourish, wearing the party's green colors and stealing the show with slogans, ''No to American Bases!'' and ''Out With NATO!'' Mrs. Papandreou showed up quietly and on time. In a correct, if stilted, Greek she made a strong plea for women to vote Socialist. **********''We've had enough of high prices and high cost of living of this archaic educational system, the lack of child care centers,'' she said. ''We've had enough of living in areas where our relatives or friends die because of lack of doctors, of hospitals, of emergency treatment. We've had enough of Government bureaucracy and corruption, of getting improper and dangerous abortions.'' 'Second-Class Citizens' **********She went on, ''We've had enough of being second-class citizens, always pushed to the margin, never listened to, never given rightful positions in decision-making bodies.'' **********Militant men in the Socialist ranks generally approve of Mrs.  Papandreou's discretion and say she has played ''an appropriate role,'' concentrating on the Women's Union. **********In a recent interview with a Greek newspaper, Mrs. Papandreou said she had been interested in women's rights ever since her high school days, when she wanted to play on the school basketball team, but it accepted only boys. **********''Since then, a quiet rage developed in me over the unfairness of the system,'' she said.  Almost wistfully, she expressed the hope that one day she would be seen by Greeks as not only the wife of Andreas Papandreou but also as Margaret Papandreou, a woman with her own personality and political activities, particularly her work with women. **********Several years ago, she began writing children's books with a message - in Greek ''with some help.'' She has written ''an antiimperialist book'' and a ''women's lib book'' for children aged 5 to 8. **********''Children's fairy tales are political,'' she says. ''All the books we read as children talk of kings, princesses, poor and rich, strong and handsome men, pretty women made for the home. This is the children's version of the capitalist system's ideology.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/world.main_headline: LIBYAN VOWS NOT TO DENY U.S. OIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/world.print_headline: LIBYAN VOWS NOT TO DENY U.S. OIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/world.body_text: **********Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today in a television interview that he would not retaliate with an oil embargo for the expulsion by the Reagan Administration of Libyan diplomats in the United States. **********''I am sorry to see this childish behavior by the American Government, which is not suitable for a big power,'' said Colonel Qaddafi, whose country supplies 5 percent of United States oil imports. **********He was interviewed by satellite from his office outside Tripoli on ''The MacNeil-Lehrer Report'' on PBS.  The Libyan leader said that 2,000 Americans living in his country, most of whom are employed by American oil companies, would be safe unless ''the situation deteriorates'' because of further United States actions against Libya. Warning to Libya on Terrorism **********The expulsion of 26 members of the Libyan diplomatic mission here was described by United States officials as a warning to Libya against support for terrorist groups around the world and for Libya's military intervention in Chad with Soviet-supplied arms. **********Colonel Qaddafi denied that Libya had used its oil wealth to finance an attack by Palestinian terrorists on Israeli athletes at the Munich Olympic Games in 1972 or that Libya had provided money or arms for guerrillas in Ireland, El Salvador or Italy. **********He said Libyan relations with the Soviet Union were good because Soviet arms sold to his country helped it maintain its defenses against ''enemies.'' But he said that Libya would not allow its territory to be used by the Soviet Union to store arms that could be used against African countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/05/busin.body_text: **********Directors of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company today recommended that the company's minority shareholders accept a merger proposal, valued at more than $1 billion, announced last night by the company's 52.9 percent owner, Dome Petroleum Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta. **********Under the proposal, which has the support of the Hudson's Bay Company of Winnipeg, Manitoba, owner of 10.1 percent of the shares, Dome would offer one preferred share in a Dome subsidiary, plus a warrant to purchase one and a third more shares, for each share of Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas. **********Wilfred Gobert, oil analyst with Peters & Company in Calgary, said today that the proposal had a potential value of $1.13 billion (Canadian). **********The merger, which would not have a cash component, would give Dome access to Hudson's Bay's cash flow of about $500 million, he said, and represented ''a significant accomplishment for Dome in resolving its finances.'' Dome is heavily in debt after its $1.43 billion acquisition of 52.9 percent of Hudson's Bay Oil from Conoco Inc. last June. **********Mr. Gobert also said that Dome's announcement last night of its Beaufort Sea drilling results indicated that Beaufort's oil potential ''ranks with the North Sea.'' **********Dome said one of the structures it was working, the Kopanoar, had an indicated potential of 1.8 billion to 4.5 billion barrels of oil and another, the Koakoak, could yield 2 billion to 5 billion barrels. The company estimated, however, that only 15 percent to 40 percent of the total was recoverable. **********Mr. Gobert cautioned, however, that there were still two uncertainties: If the low end of recoverable reserves was assumed, the Beaufort wells so far add up to less than the 400 million-barrel level that Dome had said was the commercial threshold. In addition, Dome had still not been able to provide ''exhaustive testing data,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/30/busin.body_text: **********T HERE isn't just Conoco, which after fending off Seagram and Mobil has disappeared into Du Pont.  Cities Service is fretting over the flirtations of Nu-West and Mesa Petroleum. Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads is on the run from Allied Stores. Nowadays executives of even the largest corporations are whispering among themselves: How do we defend our company when a corporate raider tries to snatch it up? **********''A takeover attempt is the single most important thing that will happen to the management of a corporation,'' said Martin Lipton, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz and a well-known specialist who has aided such companies as McGraw-Hill, St. Joe Minerals and United Technologies to repel unwelcome suitors. Displayed on a shelf in his Park Avenue office are miniature ''tombstones,'' newspaper ads announcing earlier takeover offers. **********Conoco couldn't do it, but there are ways of thwarting a raider.  Once an offer has been made, the odds of eluding a suitor are about 1 to 4, and, understandably, takeover specialists believe a company's first line of defense is to even refuse to play the game. **********When an executive gets a call from a person he spots as a likely raider, he should make himself scarce and tell him nothing, said several takeover advisers. The slightest insight the raider might glean into the state of the company can become lethal ammunition. Several investment bankers believe that Conoco's undoing began when Ralph E. Bailey, the chairman, agreed to sit down and talk with Edgar Bronfman, the chairman of the Seagram Company. **********''Problems always start to arise when a company agrees to talk and the raiding company begins to commit its prestige to an offer,'' said Mr. Lipton. **********After an offer is made the time constraints the target must work under are enormous. When a company makes an offer for the shares of another, the target has 20 business days to respond, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission regulations. In that 20 days, takeover specialists, including investment bankers, lawyers and public relations advisers, are called in to direct the management in what often turns into around-the-clock work. **********''It was not unusual to get a call at 2 A.M. on Sunday morning asking me to go to the printer,'' said one young man who worked for a public relations firm that specialized in takeover work. He has since left that job for one that is less nerve-wracking. **********The investment banker analyzes the financial adequacy of an offer and may suggest such strategies as making a tender offer for the company's own shares as a way to raise the value of those shares and at least make the company more expensive. The lawyer culls the offer for antitrust problems, regulatory conflicts and securities violations, and the public relations adviser concentrates on the public-interest issues. **********Just last week, Cities Service tried to discourage Mesa and Nu-West by filing lawsuits charging that the two companies manipulated its stock. Garfinckel officers called Allied's bid ''inadequate'' and also approved lucrative management contracts for the company's executives. **********While both of these defenses may prove helpful, a survey completed by Goldman, Sachs & Company that traced the outcome of 114 takeover attempts showed that 72 percent of the companies were eventually taken over and the defensive tactics proved most helpful in delaying the process long enough for 39 percent of those taken over to find a more desirable partner. **********How have some of the companies that managed to escape the clutches of another company beaten the odds?  A public relations expert, Richard E. Cheney, a vice chairman of Hill & Knowlton, has made a career out of trying to defend companies from takeovers. He recalled the 1967 case of Federal Paper Board. **********''I got a call from the president of Federal Paper to come down to the law offices of White & Case,'' he said. The day before, the president of Federal Paper had lunched with the president of Simkins Industries, a small paper company and learned that he was ready to make a cash offer for more than 50 percent of Federal's stock on Monday morning. **********John Kennedy, the president of Federal, called the board and its advisers to meet and by Sunday afternoon Federal's board had split the stock, raised the dividend, announced record earnings for the current year and projected even better earnings for the following year. **********Even before it was out, the bid had been beaten back. On Monday morning, when the offering was made, the price of Federal's stock opened higher than the price Simkins was willing to pay and it retreated. **********When Harold W. McGraw Jr. learned that American Express had made an offer for McGraw-Hill in 1979, the grandson of the publishing giant surprised even employees by the vehemence of his attack on James Robinson 3d, chairman of American Express. **********Gershon Kekst, president of Kekst & Company, a firm that specializes in advising clients on the public relations aspect of a takeover, credits Mr. Lipton with recognizing after a weekend of strategy sessions that in this case, the public relations effort would be crucial. **********''To convince the shareholders and public that the conflict-ofinterest problems in this case just weren't a ruse, we wanted Harold McGraw himself to express publicly the same sense of outrage that he expressed privately with Marty and I,'' Mr. Kekst said. **********Mr. McGraw had several reservations, such as whether some of its publications like Business Week would be able to cover topics thoroughly in which American Express had some interests. **********At a news conference and later in full-page advertisements that ran in several major papers, Mr. McGraw recounted the contents of a fiery letter to Mr. Robinson in which he called the offer illegal and improper, and accused American Express of lacking integrity and corporate morality. **********McGraw-Hill sued, American Express countersued and McGraw-Hill cried ''unjust'' to the Federal Communications Commission, the Federal Trade Commission and Congress. Mr. Robinson soon realized that the company he might end up with would be quite different from the one for which he had bargained - he not only wanted the publishing business but the executives and writers that worked for it - and he let his offer expire without purchasing a single share. **********In the battle between the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Mead Corporation that began with Occidental's bid in August 1978, a little-used specialist, Stanley Pottinger, a partner in the Washington law firm of Troy, Malin & Pottinger, was called in by Mead's outside counsel, Joseph Flom, an attorney for Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. **********Mr. Flom has distinquished himself as one of the best takeover lawyers in the field, and Mr. Pottinger's expertise is litigating on liabilities that the raider may have, such as a huge product liablity suit that could cost millions or a problem with toxic chemical liabilities. Because his research can result in some complicated and serious lawsuits, he will only work on a case when the client's outside counsel requests his services. **********The skeletons that Mr. Pottinger unearthed in Occidental's case exposed the oil company to millions of dollars in potential liability, and forced the company to make new disclosures to the S.E.C. **********Lawsuits brought by other parties, Mr. Pottinger said, later resulted in some out-of-court settlements, but before that the whole affair became embarrassingly bitter for Occidental, and by Dec. 20 the directors of the oil company had voted to withdraw their offer. A statement issued at the time said that one reason for the decision to drop the bid was ''the ferocity of the Mead management opposition.'' **********''The two companies have to be in a clear adversarial position before we are called in,'' said Mr. Pottinger. ''The target company doesn't want to loosen boulders at the top of the hill on the raider unless it is very sure. Once you begin to go to court and discover liabilities you can't simply shake hands after the tender dispute comes to a close. That litigation goes on.'' **********Managements worried about covering their flanks from raiding companies can take some security in knowing that a bitter battle can sour an acquiring company from ever again making an unsolicited offer. **********Northwest Industries lost out in a bid for B.F. Goodrich in 1969 after the tire company bought a trucking concern to complicate the antitrust issues. **********The defense team topped the strategy off by Mr. Cheney's discovery that Northwest's chairman had been attributing several quarters of poor earnings on bad weather. The press releases with the weather excuses were collected and pasted up in an advertisement that ran under the headline: ''It only snows on Northwest.'' **********''What we carried away from that was to never enter an unfriendly bid again,'' Paul J. Weir, Northwest's chief financial officer, said. ''When you buy a company you are looking for the management and even after a battle is over it becomes difficult to retain and work with the management.'' **********Mr. Weir contends, however, that in hindsight it would have been better for Goodrich shareholders to accept the Northwest offer. ''If they would have accepted the offer they would have been 750 percent better off today,'' said Mr. Weir. ''They are the real losers.'' **********Mr. Lipton used to believe that the most effective defense strategy was to litigate on the basis of antitrust issues. These issues at least delayed Mobil's bid for Conoco, which was higher than Du Pont's, long enough to make Conoco's shareholders believe that final clearance for Mobil was iffy and it was better to go with Du Pont. **********With the Reagan Administration taking a more liberal view toward big mergers, however, Mr. Lipton said that at least for the next four years antitrust litigation might not be as effective. When antitrust issues aren't applicable, Mr. Lipton said that he then goes through the panoply of defense options. **********These include possible regulatory conficts, disclosure questions, breech of fiduciary responsibility and just watching closely, hoping to catch a mistake that the raider might make. If a raider can be nabbed on just one offense it may be enough to squelch the attack. He cautions, however, against, overkill. **********One of his colleagues in another firm went down Mr. Lipton's list of defenses and used them all. ''In certain circumstances,'' writes Mr. Lipton, in an outline of takeover practices, ''more may turn out to be less.''  TAKEOVERS:THE PLAYERS **********When an executive finds that he wants to buy another corporation or someone is trying to buy his, one of the first things he will do is assemble a strategy team of lawyers, investment bankers and public relations and shareholder advisers. Here are some of the people and firms that have figured in recent major battles: **********Lawyers: The two best-known takeover lawyers are Joseph Flom of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, and Martin Lipton of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. Some of the Washington firms that help out on antitrust issues are Howrey & Simon and Covington & Burling. **********Investment bankers: Carl Ferenbach, Merrill Lynch White Weld; Stephen Friedman, Goldman, Sachs & Company; Robert Greenhill, Morgan Stanley; Ira Harris, Salomon Brothers; J. Tomilson Hill 3d, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company; Joseph Perella, First Boston; Mark Millard, Shearson Loeb Rhoades, and Felix Rohatyn at Lazard Freres **********Public relations and shareholder advisers: Hill & Knowlton; Georgenson & Company; Kekst & Company; the Carter Organization, and Morrow & Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.main_headline: DART & KRAFT AND HOBART IN $460 MILLION MERGER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.print_headline: DART & KRAFT AND HOBART IN $460 MILLION MERGER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.body_text: **********Dart & Kraft Inc., confirming widespread speculation on Wall Street that it was considering the purchase of the Hobart Corporation, disclosed yesterday that it had reached a $460 million agreement to merge with Hobart, the manufacturer of Kitchen Aid and other foodrelated equipment. **********Responding to the move, in the wake of the decision of Dart & Kraft's directors to offer $40 a share for Hobart stock, Hobart climbed $6.38 a share on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $39.50. It was the day's most-active issue on the Big Board. **********Canadian Pacific Enterprises, which is attempting to take over Hobart against its will with an offer to pay $32.50 a share, had no comment. It is understood to be reviewing the offer but is regarded as too unpredictable for Wall Street analysts to say what it might now do. Some analysts felt that Dart & Kraft's offer was so favorable that Canadian Pacific would find it difficult to improve upon. **********For the first time in many months, professional arbitragers found that they were unable to penetrate the secrecy normally imposed in merger talks. Even so, Wall Street analysts had heard reports that not only Dart & Kraft but also American Brands Inc. and the Raytheon Company had looked at the company. **********Before its merger with Dart Industries last year, Kraft Inc., then a food company, reviewed a number of diversification steps, including the purchase of Hobart, but did not pursue them. In explaining why it was now seeking Hobart, a spokesman said yesterday that it was ''not experienced'' then in managing a number of different companies but felt that it was now, since its merger with Dart. **********The bid for Hobart is understood to have developed in mid-January, at the suggestion of the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets group, soon after Hobart's directors rejected the Canadian Pacific proposal. Financial Data Studied **********The Merrill Lynch group, as financial adviser to Hobart, showed Dart & Kraft executives enough of Hobart's internal financial data to prompt a closer look. By the end of last month, at a meeting in Troy, Ohio, Hobart's headquarters, John M. Richmond, chairman of Dart & Kraft, and David B. Meeker, chairman of Hobart, discussed the matter privately but issued no statements. **********Wall Street arbitragers, convinced the merger was set, bid up the stock in heavy trading to around $35, feeling certain the plan would be approved at a regular Dart & Kraft board meeting on Feb. 5 and announced shortly thereafter. But no word came, convincing arbitragers that they had guessed wrong and the stock sagged to around $33. A Dart & Kraft official said the subject was not on the agenda then because more work remained to be done on the venture. **********Despite Hobart's assertions that it preferred to remain an independent company, its board of directors is known to have authorized Merrill Lynch to approach Dart & Kraft, among others, as a white knight to rescue it from a takeover it viewed as hostile. By next Friday, Canadian Pacific would have been free to buy Hobart at $32.50 and the only possibility of rescue - except for Dart & Kraft - would be a court decision in New York, due soon but very much in doubt. **********Even while seeking a white knight, Hobart has been waging a major campaign to enlist legislative support, convincing a number of Senators and Congressmen, mostly from Ohio, to call for hearings directed at the Canadian Pacific takeover bid. In hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Monday, W.J. Stenason, president of Canadian Pacific Enterprises Ltd., testified that if it won Hobart, the company would remain a good citizen under Canadian control. Mr.  Meeker testified that he was offered a top job and threatened with a takeover when he turned down the offer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/03/busin.main_headline: Business People; Schenuit's Nelson Unit Is Sold to Its Officers
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/03/busin.print_headline: Business People; Schenuit's Nelson Unit Is Sold to Its Officers
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/03/busin.body_text: **********Last year when Allegheny International Inc. bought Schenuit Industries, a small conglomerate based in Baltimore, A.P. Caltrider, the president of one of Schenuit's subsidiaries knew that his company would not fit into the new family of businesses that Allegheny was building. **********His concern, the Nelson Company, makes wooden pallets used to ship tinplate, mostly from the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Sparrows Point plant near Baltimore and the large wooden wheels used to ship cable and cord. **********So he and three officers began to put together a plan and raise money. Yesterday they bought their own company, which has annual sales of $10 million, for an undisclosed amount from Allegheny. **********There was a strong possbility, Mr. Caltrider said in a telephone interview, that if they had not come up with their own plan, the company, which employs 170 workers, would have been forced into liquidation. **********''We're not a glamorous business,'' he acknowledged, and Allegheny management made it clear that they would seek to dispose of it. Given present high interest rates, he added, and the fact the business was not highly profitable, ''there were not that many buyers out there.'' **********For Mr. Caltrider, who is 46 years old, Nelson has provided a place to use his talents and to work with people who, he said, ''were willing to put in a good day's work and have been here a long time.'' **********He recalled that he began as a clerk at the company in 1958, doing many odd jobs. He was promoted to vice president in 1967, when the company was taken over by Schenuit, then promoted to president two years later. **********Mr. Caltrider said that high interest rates made it tough to get together the financing but that he and three other officers, J.K.  Williams, the vice president and secretary-treasurer; R.F.Burman, the vice president of sales, and D.E. Weckesser, the vice president of manufacturing, were finally able to put together a package from their own funds and from borrowing.  Agis Salpukas

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/busin.body_text: **********The United Technologies Corporation, a Hartford-based conglomerate that is one of the nation's biggest defense contractors, announced its entry into the telecommunications field with the introduction of a telephone system that simultaneously transmits voice and data signals. **********The system, known as the Lexar Business Exchange, or LBX, will be offered through the Lexar Corporation, a Los Angeles-based concern acquired by U.T.C. earlier this year. **********Essentially, the LBX allows one party to talk to another party and transmit data at the same time. For example, a company official in New York could talk to a colleague in Cleveland and simultaneously transmit print-form information over the same telephone. **********Although the technique is not new, Lexar's president, William L.  Salway, said the advantage to his company's technology was that it involved much less equipment and wiring than older systems that had been refitted for this type of transmission. **********Mr. Salway said the market for such equipment was nearly $2 billion in 1980 and is expected to reach more than $4 billion by 1986.  Pricing information was not disclosed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.main_headline: MANDATORY PENSIONS ASKED IN U.S. STUDY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.print_headline: MANDATORY PENSIONS ASKED IN U.S. STUDY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.body_text: **********A high-level Federal commission, appointed by former President Carter, will urge in a report to Congress today that all private employers provide a minimum income for their retired workers. **********That and several other recommendations in the 10-member commission's final report are expected to get a mixed response in Congress, where interest nonetheless has grown in recent years for the establishment of a national retirement income policy. **********A source at the White House said that the Reagan Administration would not back mandatory pensions, or many of the other recommendations made by the President's Commission on Pension Policy, named after authorization by Congress in 1977. **********''We have nothing to do with this,'' he said. ''It doesn't represent Reagan Administration pension policy.'' He noted that nine of the panel's 10 members had been affiliated with the Democratic Party when President Carter appointed them in 1979. No Reagan Policy Yet **********The Reagan Administration has not yet framed its policy on retirement income, the White House source said. **********Representative Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, who endorses many of the panel's recommendations, is chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging. C. Peter McColough, the chairman of the President's commission, and also chairman of the Xerox Corporation, is scheduled to testify today before Mr. Pepper's committee on the recommendations. The New York Times obtained a copy of the commission's final report. **********In addition to mandatory pensions, the commission has also endorsed a voluntary reduction by employers to five years in the length of employment required for workers to qualify for pensions. This is known as the vesting provision. Under current law, the vesting minimum is 10 years. **********Other major recommendations include the following: **********- Raising the age of eligibility for full Social Security retirement benefits to 68 from 65, beginning in 1990. **********- Allowing retired persons to earn an unlimited amount of income without losing Social Security benefits. However, Social Security benefits would become taxable along with earned income. **********- Allowing employers a 46 percent tax credit for pension contributions of 3 percent of total payroll. **********- Extending Social Security coverage to all Federal, state and local government employees.  The commission rejected proposals to abolish the indexing of Social Security payments to the Consumer Price Index. Shorter Vesting Period Sought **********Also, in asking that vesting requirements be lowered to five years from the 10 years required in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, the commission stopped short of demands from some lobbying groups for shorter vesting periods. **********''We're tremendously disappointed,'' said Karen W. Ferguson, director of the Pension Rights Center, in Washington. She said that while some 60 percent of the nation's workers were employed by companies with pension plans, only one worker in five qualified for the benefits at retirement. **********Lobbyists representing a variety of business organizations opposed a lowering of vesting requirements.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/busin.main_headline: S.E.C. TOLD OF TALK TO AMAX INSIDER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/busin.print_headline: S.E.C. TOLD OF TALK TO AMAX INSIDER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/busin.body_text: **********Thomas C. Reed, a former Air Force Secretary, has testified before the Securities and Exchange Commission that one of the persons he talked to in advance of a $4 billion takeover bid for Amax Inc., the giant mining company, was Ian MacGregor, a prominent Wall Street investment banker and a member of the Amax board of directors. **********Only one day before the takeover bid became public, Mr. Reed, now a West Coast businessman, placed an order for a substantial amount of Amax call options and subsequently sold them at a profit of several hundred thousand dollars. **********Mr. Reed has denied that he acted on inside information or otherwise acted improperly, and so has Mr. MacGregor. If the S.E.C.  concludes otherwise, however, both Mr. Reed and any Amax insider who guided him could be charged with violations of Federal securities law. **********According to Wall Street sources who have read Mr. Reed's deposition, the gist of his testimony was that Mr. MacGregor had told him that the Standard Oil Company of California was trying to organize itself for another takeover bid for Amax, with Mr.  MacGregor's encouragement, but that Socal might not go ahead because of opposition by Amax's management. Fear of a Controversy **********Mr. Reed, these sources said, also maintained in his testimony that he did not act on anything Mr. MacGregor had told him because Mr.  MacGregor's remarks suggested that a takeover might not occur. **********One Wall Street investment banker, who has substantial holdings of Amax stock, said he feared that a public controversy over Mr.  MacGregor's comments, however innocent they might have been, could be enough to prompt Socal to abandon its offer. **********Amax stock jumped 4 points, to 68 1/2, last Thursday, the day of a regular Amax board meeting. Then it slid 3 points on Friday, to 65 1/2, when Amax had nothing to say about Socal. Wall Street professionals had been hoping Socal might sweeten its offer. **********Reached by telephone in California last Friday, Mr. MacGregor, who is now chairman of the financially troubled British Steel Corporation, acknowledged that he had discussed the takeover situation with Mr. Reed on the phone in January. He denied, however, that he had given Mr. Reed inside information. He also said he had not had any subsequent conversations with Mr. Reed. **********''I told him the same as I've told everybody else,'' Mr. MacGregor said, ''that Socal already had 20 percent of Amax, had made one offer for the company and had been rebuffed. They stayed with the 20 percent, so they must have been happy with it. I said now they'd have to make up their mind what they wanted to do among the three things they might do: nothing, sell what they have or make another tender offer. A Conversation's 'Acid Test' **********''All I told him,'' Mr. MacGregor continued, ''was that one of these days Socal should be doing something about Amax - pursue it further or retire from the situation. That's the same thing that almost any Wall Street observer would say. I didn't tell him to buy any stock, and I didn't buy any stock myself. That's the acid test, isn't it? **********''Lots of people have asked me about it in the last six to nine months, and I give them exactly the same answer,'' he went on. ''It would enable Mr. Reed to make up his own mind what gambling he wanted to do - but there were three outcomes.'' **********Mr. MacGregor was asked if he, as an Amax director, felt that the comments had disclosed confidential information. He replied: ''There's nothing confidential about that. That's purely speculation. I don't believe there's anything damaging about it.'' **********Mr. MacGregor, currently a limited partner of Lazard Freres, said he used to see a lot of Mr. Reed and regarded him as a close friend, ''a friend of the Amax family.'' **********According to Mr. MacGregor, when Mr. Reed discovered he was back in the United States on business, Mr. Reed phoned him to discuss other matters. Mr. MacGregor said the conversation dealt mainly with Mr.  Reed's interest in politics abroad and Mr. MacGregor's interest in the new Reagan Administration. Mr. Reed raised the Socal question only at the close of the conversation, Mr. MacGregor said. Outlook for S.E.C. Questioning **********Mr. MacGregor also said that he had already been told that any Amax director whose name turned up in the S.E.C.'s investigation could expect to be called in for questioning. He said, however, that he had not heard directly from the commission and that he had not retained an attorney. **********A spokesman for Amax said the company was aware of Mr. Reed's deposition but was not aware of any of its contents.  Mr. Reed's testimony before the S.E.C. was part of the agency's continuing investigation into unusual trading patterns in Amax call options before Socal's March 5 announcement that it would pay about $78.50 a share for the 80 percent of Amax stock that it did not yet own. **********As part of that investigation, California employees of the brokerage firm of Dean Witter Reynolds were reported last month to have purchased 538 Amax call options for $3,750 the day before the Socal offer and to have sold them later for $500,000. **********Mr. Reed, who is the son of Gordon W. Reed, another Amax board member, acknowledged in a formal statement at the time that he had purchased a total of 500 Amax options on Jan. 30 and Feb. 2 plus 500 on March 4, the day before Socal's offer, reportedly through Dean Witter's San Rafael, Calif., office. Mr. Reed denied at the time that his purchases were based on advance knowledge. Agency Remaining Silent **********Mr. Reed's lawyer said last Friday that he would not comment on the situation because of pending litigation. **********The S.E.C. is widely known to be investigating, but it declined to comment in any way, as is its policy.  Mr. MacGregor, interviewed by phone while he was visiting a West Coast Amax plant, said Mr. Reed called him, possibly on a visit to Houston. '' 'Is there anything happening between Socal and Amax?' '' he recalled that Mr. Reed asked toward the end of a short conversation. **********''One of these days, I said, Socal has to move forward or backward.'' Mr. MacGregor recalled. ''I said I don't think management has been moving forward, so they might have to move backward. Socal might have to do something else, like selling its 20 percent interest.'' He said he told Mr. Reed that it seemed to him that the situation ''has to come to a head sooner rather than later.'' Mr.  MacGregor maintained that the remarks about Socal lasted ''a minute or less at the tail end of a short call.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/03/world.main_headline: REPRESSION IN GUATEMALA INCREASES AS U.S. IS SEEKING TO IMPROVE TIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/03/world.print_headline: REPRESSION IN GUATEMALA INCREASES AS U.S. IS SEEKING TO IMPROVE TIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/03/world.body_text: **********Violent Government repression of leftist and moderate groups in Guatemala is increasing at the very time that Reagan Administration officials are looking for a way to repair relations with the military regime of Maj. Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia. **********On the night Ronald Reagan was elected President, fireworks filled the skies of this capital city of 1.3 million people and marimba bands played in front of the United States Embassy. **********The nation's leaders expected the Reagan Administration to resume military assistance suspended since 1977 and otherwise deal more sympathetically with them. **********United States law prohibits arms aid to countries guilt of continuous violations of human rights. In Guatemala, there have been more than 5,000 killings of people in opinion-making positions since 1978, decimating university faculties, moderate and left-of-center political organizations and other groups. There have been no arrests or investigations. **********Officially, Guatemalan leaders say they want nothing more than to be left alone by the United States. More telling of their mood, however, were the welcome-back parties thrown for Lieut. Col. David W. Patton of the United States Army, a military aide from before the Carter Administration who has just returned for a new assignment. **********''It was like the second coming of Bolivar,'' a participant said.  Although the Reagan White House has been clear in its shifts from Carter strategies on El Salvador and Nicaragua, it has given no signal as yet of what it intends to do in Guatemala. The post of Ambassador, vacated last summer with the removal of Frank V. Ortiz Jr., is still open. **********State Department officials have told inquiring Republican members of Congress eager to re-establish links with Guatemala that a decision will be made in May. **********''It is very important to our interests in the region to reestablish relations with the Government of Guatemala, and we are actively pursuing ways in which to do so,'' said a high-ranking State Department official. **********Besides wanting to halt the spread of political convulsion in Central America, Washington would like to bring stability to a country that has recently turned up evidence of oilfields that could supply 10 percent of United States needs. **********Complicating the State Department's task is a terror campaign being conducted by the Lucas Garcia Government not only to combat the 2,000-member guerrilla movement that is having increased success in the countryside but also to eliminate centrist politicians that Washington could ultimately identify with. **********Seventy-six leaders of the Guatemalan Christian Democratic Party, which is associated with the Christian Democratic Party of President Jose Napoleon Duarte in El Salvador, have been slain in the last 10 months. Ten officials of the left-of-center Social Democratic United Revolutionary Front have been killed. **********The two parties have been terrorized into not participating in elections scheduled for next year. The field will be left to six right-wing parties. The current front-runner is Mario Sandoval Alarcon, an extreme rightist who has said that he has a 3,000-member private army. **********This will almost certainly reduce voter participation to less than the 35 percent turnout that was estimated in 1978, when President Lucas Garcia was elected. 'In Guatemala We're Adrift' **********A foreign visitor to Guatemala who met with a wide range of national leaders said that within two months of his trip the five most impressive people he had met had been killed. **********''At least in El Salvador the United States had a tiny little island to cling to,'' he said. ''In Guatemala we're adrift.'' This has occurred under a President who was elected on a platform pledging change and who has been delivering modestly on his promise.  Guatemala spends more on public housing and health than any other Central American nation, and the Lucas Garcia Government has been dividing up large farms confiscated from Germans after World War II and giving title to workers now sharecropping them. **********Despite promotion campaigns on radio, in newspapers and on highway billboards, these achievements have attracted little notice.  Two developments account for the Guatemalan Government's reluctance to steer a more moderate course. One is the fear generated by reports that Indians, who make up more than half of the population of nearly seven million, are starting to abandon their traditional isolation and join the opposition forces. The other is the belief that the same influences that provoked uprisings in Nicaragua and in El Salvador are at work in Guatemala. 'We Are in a War' **********''We are in a war, and in a war atrocities happen on both sides,'' a businessman said. ''We think the new Administration recognizes that this area has been marked for conquest by the Soviet Union.'' **********The show of faith that Guatemalan leaders are awaiting from the United States is resumption of military aid and training for their 18,000-member army. The assistance was suspended four years ago in a dispute over human rights abuses and indications that Guatemala might use force in its territorial dispute with neighboring Belize. **********The Guatemalans have been resourceful since then, turning to France for aircraft, Argentina for antiguerrilla strategy, South Korea for uniforms and Yugoslavia for howitzers. But Guatemala's fleet of UH-1H Huey helicopters, an essential ingredient in its campaign to flush out rebels, will only be able to fly for several more months unless the Guatemalans can obtain spare parts currently blocked in the aid suspension. **********Even holdovers from the Carter Administration in the State Department have accepted the notion that past policy toward Guatemala did not succeed in reducing human rights violations. The State Department now reasons that the army runs the country and that the army is therefore the sector that American diplomacy must engage. Restrictions Under U.S. Law **********To resume military aid, the Administration must come to terms with restrictions in the foreign military assistance law, which prohibits shipments of arms to nations that commit ''gross and consistent'' human rights violations. Guatemala initiated the rupture in military cooperation with the United States, so the law has not been formally invoked. But the language in the law regarding human rights precisely describes the situation in Guatemala today. **********Killings of people in opinion-making positions have decimated university faculties, student groups, moderate and left-of-center political organizations, rural cooperatives, newspaper and radio staffs, peasant leagues, unions and churches. In recent weeks there have been massacres in Indian villages aimed at frightening residents into ignoring guerrilla calls for support. **********Every day newspapers carry pictures of new kidnapping victims, with assurances from their families that the person was not involved in any political activities and pleas that the victims be returned to their homes. **********The number of killings in the Lucas Garcia years now exceeds 5,000, but there have been no arrests or investigations. The only people to survive the kidnappings have been members of wealthy families abducted by leftists for ransoms that have reached as high as $4 million. **********The pace of the guerrilla kidnappings has quickened, too, as the polarization of Guatemalan politics further radicalizes the left.  Henrique Roesch, head of the Guatemalan Coffee Association, was interrupted three times in a one-hour conversation with a visitor recently to take calls reporting abductions of planters. **********From the evidence, killing alone does not satisfy the vengeful motives of the security forces. The coroner in one of the city's four morgues said that two of every three bodies bore signs of torture.  Virtually all of the murder victims found in the countryside are manacled and indicate beatings, facial disfigurements or violence to sexual organs. **********Leftist guerrilla tactics include ambushes of army convoys and killings of suspected informants, business leaders and doctors who refuse to treat wounded rebels. Victims of the guerrillas are usually not tortured. The insurgents often occupy villages briefly, explain their cause and then melt back into the hills before the security forces arrive. **********During Easter Week there were 152 killings. Eleven of the victims were soldiers. Others included the secretary general of the Christian Democratic Party in the western department of Huehuetenango and the leader of Social Democratic United Revolutionary Front in Escuintla, Guatemala's second largest city. **********In the same period, 15 social action groups, including international organizations such as the Church World Service and local assistance groups that grew out of relief efforts after the 1976 earthquake, received letters warning them to deport foreigners and disband local staffs or face ''elimination.'' Most foreigners working in such organizations have already left Guatemala. Letters Linked to Regular Army **********The letters were signed by the ''Secret Anti-Communist Army,'' a designation that is so openly associated with the regular army that one recipient simply called a general he knew to inquire whether the threat against him was genuine. The officer said it was, and the man left Guatemala for Mexico last weekend. **********Elias Barahona y Barahona, a former press secretary to President Lucas Garcia who went into hiding in September, told Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, that stationery with the letterhead of the Secret Anti-Communist Army was stocked in the office of the Minister of the Interior, who is responsible for internal security. ''Hit lists,'' according to Mr. Barahona, were drawn up by the Army Chief of Staff in an annex to the National Palace, an aquamarine, Art Deco compound that is shuttered and under heavy guard. **********Foreign diplomats say that the hard-line approach of the Lucas Garcia Government is strategically counterproductive. The best evidence is that the terror campaign, in claiming so many noncombatants as its victims, has not diminished the ranks of the guerrillas but has instead helped their recruiting efforts. Tourists Are Staying Away **********Tourists, in response to reports of the violence and to several organized boycotts, are staying away in such numbers that hotel occupancy has fallen to 50 percent from 80 percent in 1979. **********Guatemala has become diplomatically isolated in the region and abroad. Its economy, the most robust in Central America, has suffered from the flight of capital and the reluctance of foreign investors to put any more money into such a strife-torn country. Its relations with Mexico, Costa Rica, Panama and Venezuela are strained, and two recent Guatemalan trade fairs in France and West Germany were disrupted by protests. **********These developments appear to have only reinforced the Government's resolve to stick to its present course. ''Are not these people violating our human rights when they interfere in Guatemala and not let us have the government we want?'' asked Roberto Alejos Arzu, a prominent industrialist and presidential candidate in the 1982 elections on whose farm some of the Cuban exiles who invaded the Bay of Pigs 20 years ago trained. **********Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, touched this nerve in Guatemala City last week when, during a fact-finding mission, he said that he wanted to find out about human rights violations in Guatemala. **********''No country and no state can intervene in our affairs,'' responded Foreign Minister Rafael Castillo Valdez. ''This would be like Guatemala trying to resolve the problems that the United States has in Atlanta, where barbarous acts have been committed, or the Government and society of Guatemala trying to protect President Reagan from assassination attempts.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.main_headline: JUNE TRIAL DATE IS SET IN MERGER DATA CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.print_headline: JUNE TRIAL DATE IS SET IN MERGER DATA CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.body_text: **********Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. of the United States Court for the Southern District of New York yesterday set June 15 as the trial date for the Government's case against a former investment banker at Morgan Stanley & Company and three others who allegedly profited from the use of confidential information on prospective mergers. **********The trial date was set some months off to allow Arthur Christy of Christy & Viener, the attorney for one of the four, to move for charges against his client to be dismissed. **********His client, James Mitchell Newman, the only one of the four defendants yet arraigned, has pleaded not guilty. **********The three others, Edmond Jacques Courtois Jr., a former vice president at Morgan Stanley, and Franklin Carniol and Constantine Spyropoulos, both charged with using the confidential information, are still being sought, and warrants have been issued for their arrests. The trial of Mr. Newman would proceed without the others if necessary. **********Lee S. Richards, the Assistant United States Attorney, told Judge Haight yesterday that efforts were being made to arrest Mr.  Spyropoulos, a Greek citizen, in California, where his wife is believed to be living. Mr. Richards agreed with Judge Haight's observation that, if Mr. Spyropoulos were in Greece, obtaining his extradition would be quite difficult. **********Extradition is considered more likely, but by no means a certainty, for Mr. Carniol, now reported in Belgium, and Mr. Courtois, who is living in Colombia. Mr. Richards said that any efforts to extradite Mr. Courtois would wait for a new and stronger extradition treaty with Colombia that was recently drawn up but has not yet been signed in Washington. ''If we go down the road to extradition in any country, it will be a relatively lengthy road,'' Mr. Richards said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/11/busin.body_text: **********The handicapped occupant of a motorized wheelchair can steer it and control its speed by chin movements, using a system that was patented this week by two staff members at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, Laurel, Md. **********John H. Loveless and Woodrow Seamone, who were granted patent 4,260,035, have arranged for quadriplegics to operate half a dozen prototypes. **********A small control arm is suspended in front of the patient's chin.  Nudging it up and down controls the speed, and swings to the left or right control the steering. The user can move the chair backward or forward by pushing a switch with a slight forward movement of the chin. **********The patent explains that the invention, which was developed during research under a Navy contract, avoids the use of the large rubber caps that fit over the chin in previous control equipment. The university is willing to license manufacturing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/05/world.main_headline: BEGIN ANNOUNCES NEW COALITION AFTER CONCESSIONS TO MINOR BLOCS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/05/world.print_headline: BEGIN ANNOUNCES NEW COALITION AFTER CONCESSIONS TO MINOR BLOCS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/05/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Menachem Begin tonight announced the formation of a fragile new coalition Government that involves major concessions to Israel's three minority religious parties. **********The Prime Minister, who is embarking on a second term of office with a bare majority - 61 members in Israel's 120-member Parliament - also announced the appointment of some members of his new Cabinet.  Many are holdovers from his previous administration. **********A major appointment was the elevation of former Gen. Ariel Sharon, a conservative hawk in what is expected to be a very conservative Government, as Minister of Defense, one of the nation's key posts.  Mr. Sharon served as Minister of Agriculture during Mr. Begin's first term and oversaw the development of Israeli settlements on land captured from the Arabs in the West Bank during the 1967 Middle East war. **********Five-Week Battle for Key Posts **********Mr. Begin made his announcement to reporters tonight, flanked by members of his new Government, many of whom had battled for five weeks to insure their jobs and obtain perquisites for the interests they represent. **********As late as this afternoon, the bitter infighting continued and there were indications even as Mr. Begin announced his new Cabinet appointments that the feuding was far from ended. **********Mr. Begin said he would formally present his new administration, dominated by members of his Likud bloc, to Parliament tomorrow. A 12-hour debate, probably consisting mainly of bitter denunciations from the opposition Labor Party, is expected. **********In the new administration, Yitzhak Shamir is expected to continue as Foreign Minister and Yoram Aridor as Finance Minister. Yosef Burg will continue as Minister of Interior and will also serve as Minister of Religious Affairs. **********In recent days, the concessions made by Mr. Begin to the small religious parties have been the subject of intense debate here and a topic of bitter criticism in some of Israel's press. **********Mr. Begin tried to smoooth over some of the controversy tonight, telling reporters that Likud had not had to be pressed into accepting the demands of the religious blocs because ''this is a Jewish state.'' Stronger Discipline Foreseen **********The Prime Minister also tried to put the best possible construction on the narrowness of his majority in Parliament, asserting that it would enhance discipline in the coalition because ''all members will know they must be wanted so the Government can serve all four years and three months of its term.'' **********As Mr. Begin spoke, speculation intensified that the new Government was such a patchwork and had such theocratic tendencies that it would not last long and that new elections were in the offing. **********The three religious parties made sweeping gains in the negotiations for the new Government despite their having lost seats in Parliament in the elections on June 30. The power of these blocs increased because the opposition Labor Party came close to defeating Mr.  Begin's Likud, getting 47 seats to Likud's 48. Because both major groups were well short of the needed minimum of 61 seats, the minority parties became crucial once again in forming a majority Government. **********At tonight's ceremony held at Mr. Begin's office, a coalition agreement containing 83 clauses, written in Hebrew, was signed by the participating factions. Just about all of the clauses dealt with the religious concessions that had been wrested from Mr. Begin by the National Religious Party, the ultra-orthodox Agudat Israel Party and a new religious party called Tami that is a factional offshoot of the National Religious Party. **********The new Government is expected to be tougher on such issues as autonomy for the Palestinians of the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip than the one headed by Mr. Begin since 1977 because of the departure of more moderate elements that held positions of power.  Composition of New Coalition **********The new coalition will consist of the 48 members of Likud, which is composed of several factions; six members of the National Religious Party, which lost six seats in the last election; four members of Agudat Israel and three members of Tami. **********Many of the religious concessions were made to the Agudat Israel Party, which is essentially an anti-Zionist religious entity responsible to a group of rabbis called the Council of Torah Sages.  The party professes to have no political ambitions, seeking only religious benefits for its members. Some of the criticism here has focused on the fact that Mr. Begin, an ardent Zionist for decades, has made concessions, particularly concerning exemption from military service, to a group that professes no interest in the governance of the state's affairs. **********These are some of the concessions: **********- Greater financial aid to students in yeshivas, or religious schools. **********- Eventual cessation on the Jewish Sabbath of flights by Israel's national airline, El Al, which would cost the state as much as $50 million a year. **********- Cessation of activity on the Sabbath in the port city of Haifa, where many cruise ships dock during the weekend, bringing much-needed tourist dollars. **********- An end of work on the Sabbath in Government-owned companies, such as the rail system and oil-drilling organizations. **********- Abolition of university dormitories occupied jointly by men and women. Exemption Pledge Causes Furor **********A furor has already erupted over a pledge by the Government, not specifically contained in the coalition agreement, to exempt for up to three years from military service ''newly observant'' Jews who wish to study Orthodox theology. **********The idea of military exemption is extremely touchy in this nation where women are subject to the draft. Mr. Begin said tonight that details on this issue, which has aroused anger among members of his own party as well as the National Religious Party, which is Zionist, would be worked out in a separate letter to Agudat Israel to be sent by the new Defense Minister, Mr. Sharon. **********''Nothing will be kept secret from the public,'' Mr. Begin said in response to questions about the special exemptions for those who might suddenly decide to pursue Orthodox Jewish studies. **********The last clause of the coalition agreement also touches on a very controversial concession to the Agudat bloc. It contains a pledge to amend the Law of Return, under which anyone who is a Jew is granted Israeli citizenship automatically, to exclude conversions to Judaism made by any but Orthodox rabbis. **********This has provoked a great outcry not because the number of conversions is high - experts here say it is minimal -but because it is seen as a blow against the validity of the rabbinate of Reform and Conservative Judaism. These two groups are the predominant branches of Judaism in the United States, and members of both provide extensive funds and services to Israel.
