https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.main_headline: U.S. ACCUSED OF FAVORING CURBS ON FREE PRESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.print_headline: U.S. ACCUSED OF FAVORING CURBS ON FREE PRESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.body_text: **********The chairman of the International Press Institute charged today that the United States, while publicly criticizing a United Nations-backed campaign for a so-called ''new world information order,'' was moving toward support of projects contrary to the aims of a free press. **********Cushrow Irani, chairman of the Zurich-based organization, which monitors challenges to journalists and news organizations around the world, said that American support for the newly created International Program for the Development of Communications was ''naive'' and mistakenly based on a fear of ''interfering in the internal affairs of other countries.'' **********The communications development program, now being organized within the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, would provide financial and professional support for press and broadcasting projects in developing nations. **********U.S. Seeking to Curb Criticism **********The development program was largely a United States initiative, which the State Department's Bureau for International Organization Affairs has supported in the hope that material aid to poorer nations would dampen criticism that Americans remain insenstive to the needs of the third world's press. **********Mr. Irani, who is publisher of the Indian daily The Statesman and one of the third world's most outspoken critics of the Unesco campaign, said today that the United States was preparing to make a financial contribution to the international develoment program through the Agency for International Development. Mr. Irani is in Washington to argue at the State Department against such a move. Any contribution, Mr. Irani said, would finance only ''propaganda.'' **********''Of the 14 or 15 detailed programs the I.P.D.C. has already proposed,'' Mr. Irani said, ''each one of them concerns itself with strengthening government news agencies. They call themselves news agencies, but they are in fact propaganda agencies and not one of them will help in any way to further our objectives of a free press working independent of government.'' No Comment by State Dept **********The State Department declined to comment today on Mr. Irani's assertion that the United States was about to contribute money to the program. But State Department officials have said that no money from the United States would be contributed to projects that were found to be unacceptable by American standards. **********Beginning at a communications development program meeting in Acapulco next January and thereafter, United States delegates intend to examine each project individually, officials said. **********The Reagan Administration has gone on record in support of an amendment to the State Department budget that calls for a cutoff of contributions to Unesco if that organization persists in any attempt to regulate the world's press. The amendment, which was backed by the White House but not, initially, the State Department, was adopted by the House of Representatives, though the bill to which it was attached was subsequently defeated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; CHICAGO MILWAUKEE HAS NEW CHAIRMAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/busin.body_text: **********Emory Williams, 69 years old, has been elected chairman of the Chicago Milwaukee Corporation, the holding company whose subsidiaries include the financially troubled Chicago, Milwaukee, St Paul & Pacific Railroad. Effective June 1, he will succeed Donald F. Hunter, 50, who resigned his post at the Chicago-based company to concentrate on his law practice in Minnesota. **********"One of my first goals is to see the railroad reorganized and returned to the stockholders," Mr. Williams said. "Nineteen eighty-one is the year of decision for the company." **********Last week, the trustees of the railroad, which has been in receivership since 1977, asked a Federal bankruptcy court for permission to discontinue commuter service in the Chicago area because a funding source, the Regional Transportation Authority, had run out of money. **********Earlier this month, the line laid off 300 workers, mostly in its equipment repair shops, and put off planned track improvement. **********Mr. Williams, a director of Chicago Milwaukee since 1974, will redtire at the end of this month from Sears, Roebuck & Company, which he joined in 1933 as a manager at a catalogue order plant.  Twenty-five years later, he became president of Sears' Brazilian operations. **********Two years after returning to the United States in 1960, Mr.  Williams was appointed vice president and chief financial officer of Sears. For the last six years, he has been chairman and chief executive officer of the Sears Bank Insurance Company. **********Mr. Williams said that he hopes to search for nonrailroad acquisitions to add to those that the Chicago Milwaukee has in the manufactoring, food distribution and highway paving fields. In addition to the railroad, the parent corporation owns the Vulcan-Hart Corporation, the Aslesen Company and the Southern Boiler Company. **********But Mr. Williams is not losing sight of improving the railroad's operations. "It's possible to operate much more profitably as part of a larger system," he said. Then he added that the railroad is also "capable of independent operation."

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/13/busin.main_headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Various Views Of Coca-Cola
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/13/busin.print_headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Various Views Of Coca-Cola
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/13/busin.body_text: **********AVE a Coke and a smile.'' So runs a current advertising theme for the Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft drink company and a recurring investment favorite on Wall Street. But some brokerage houses are restraining their enthusiasm this hot summer as far as Coke's stock is concerned. **********In mid-June, when the stock was selling at $40 a share, Lawrence Adelman of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. informed clients: ''We have lowered our investment rating for Coca-Cola stock to Hold/ Sell from Hold.'' He went on to suggest that ''profit-taking in the issue be considered once again.'' **********Last Friday the stock closed at 34 on the New York Stock Exchange.  Within the last 12 months, its price has ranged between 40 1/4 and 29 1/8. **********In his comments, Mr. Adelman cited the outlook for ''disappointing'' trends in both earnings and volume for Coca-Cola, reflecting the impact of foreign currency transactions as well as sluggish economic activity in important overseas markets. **********Oppenheimer & Company, sounding basically the same theme, removed Coke from its recommended list of stocks on June 23. Its analyst, Joseph C. Frazzano, also expressed disappointment that Coke's earnings momentum was lagging during a period of plummeting sugar prices, when profits ordinarily could be expected to accelerate. **********Coincidental to the lowered ratings, both brokerage houses also reduced their earnings estimates for Coke, which showed a profit last year of $3.42 a share. Mr. Frazzano revised to $3.75 a share his previous earnings projection of $3.90 for 1981. The 1982 estimate was cut to $4.35 a share from $4.45. **********At Dean Witter, estimates for Coke's earnings this year were lowered to between $3.70 and $3.80 a share from $3.90. Projected earnings for next year were reduced to $4.30 a share from $4.50. **********But opinion on Wall Street runs two ways much of the time, and attitudes toward Coke's shares are no exception. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., for example, carries Coke on its current ''Buy'' list, along with higher estimates for the profit picture. It projects earnings at $4 a share this year and $4.70 a share in 1982. **********And, as if to underscore this difference of opinion, Drexel rates Pepsico Inc. - the archrival of Coke in soft drinks - as neutral, while Oppenheimer carries Pepsico not only on its roster of recommended issues but also on its ''emphasis'' list. **********In a time period of up to one year, meanwhile, Merrill Lynch's research department regards both stocks as ''O.K. to buy.'' Assessments at the Value Line Investment Survey, however, tilt in favor of Pepsico. In its latest appraisal, the advisory service said: ''Pepsico continues to carry our highest rating for relative price performance over the next 12 months.'' **********Value Line expects Coke's shares to show only average market performance during this same period. It noted that, unlike the Coca-Cola Company (whose impressive array of soft drink products includes such other brand names as Tab, Sprite, Fresca and Fanta), Pepsico derives considerably more than 50 percent of its operating profits from operations outside the soft drink business. In fact, Value Line regards Pepsico's snack foods division - said to enjoy an annual growth rate of more than 20 percent - as virtually certain to edge out beverages as the prime profit center for the company by 1983. **********As for Coke's earnings prospects for 1981, there appears to be no disagreement among Wall Street houses that the improvement will top the prior year's performance. Profits edged higher by less than 1 percent last year from $3.40 a share in 1979, a year that reflected poor results in some key foreign markets and an eight-week strike at a Mexico City bottler. **********Traditionally, Coke's profits have shown a yearly growth rate of about 12 percent, according to some followers of the company. Between 1975 and 1980, its common stock traded as high as 47 5/8 and as low as 26 5/8. During the late 1960's and early 1970's, Coke's stock became one of the ''Nifty Fifty'' darlings favored by bank trust departments and other institutions. But soon afterward the stock plunged, along with other glamour favorites. From a split-adjusted peak price of $75 a share in late 1973, the stock fell as low as $22.25 a share the following year. **********Present-day bulls on the stock, such as Drexel Burnham Lambert, point to Coke's new top management as one of the things they like.  Earlier this year, Roberto C. Goizueta became chairman and chief executive officer. Under his leadership, some analysts say, Coca-Cola is looking for new worlds to conquer by diversifying its operations.  Possible areas of acquisition are believed to include entertainment, leisure or food companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.print_headline: U.S. DEAL EMBROILS TINY ISLAND NATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.body_text: **********With an election scheduled for Sept. 8, the Prime Minister of this tiny, impoverished South Pacific island nation is in serious political trouble over an investment deal with a California businessman involving more than $640,000 in Government funds. **********Not long after this former British colony just south of the Equator became independent in 1978, Prime Minister Toalipi Lauti handed over the Government funds, equivalent to about one-fifth of the country's annual budget, to a visiting American businessman, Sydney Gross of Encino, Calif., to be invested at a promised 15 percent annual interest. **********Around the same time, associates of Mr. Gross in a west Texas real estate venture collected about the same amount from individuals, local government bodies and the Church of Tuvalu for plots of land that promoters advertised as having a rich agricultural potential.  The Church of Tuvalu is a Protestant denomination to which most of the 9,000 or so Tuvaluans belong, **********Hundreds of Tuvaluans, who are members of the Polynesian group found on Pacific islands extending from Hawaii to New Zealand, bought into the Texas development, expecting that ''future generations could live and work in the United States,'' Pulekai Alofa Sogivalu, the editor of the Church of Tuvalu's newspaper, said in an interview. **********American Sounded Alarm **********Then another American, Dr. Richard Finney of Lexington, Ky., who once lived on Nanumanga, a remote Tuvalu atoll whose island council had invested heavily in the Texas promotion, heard of the deal and sounded an alarm. **********Dr. Finney sent a letter to Prime Minister Lauti that began, ''I do not know your name, but I am writing to you to help the people of Nanumanga.'' This was followed by highly critical comments on the Texas property, quoting state and Federal officials. **********Later the Parliament of Tuvalu demanded that Prime Minister Lauti retrieve the money given to Mr. Gross for investment. According to Tuvaluan officials, the Californian had paid the promised interest meticulously but had asked for more time to send back the principal. **********''We don't even know where the principal is invested,'' Henry Naisali, a Member of Parliament and a leading critic of the transactions, said in an interview. Secretary to Government Iotana Iotana added, ''The Government is very concerned.'' 'Barren and Mountainous' **********Meanwhile, according to Mr. Sogivalu, the editor, many of the Tuvaluans who had contracted to purchase the Texas land have defaulted on their installment obligations and fear that their downpayments have been forfeited. Earlier, a news release by the Federal Trade Commission in Washington had described the plots, which are in Culberson and Jefferson counties, as ''barren in parts and mountainous in others.'' **********Prime Minister Lauti, apparently undaunted by the political storm over his investment activities, was hopeful for his young nation's economic future when interviewed recently in Suva, Fiji, where he had stopped en route to London for the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer. **********''The problem is a lack of natural resources,'' he said of the nine verdant but economically unproductive coral atolls in the Tuvalu group. The name of the country, formerly known as the Ellice Islands, is translated loosely as ''eight standing together,'' apparently not counting the isolated and uninhabited ninth atoll, Niulakita. **********Funafuti, the main atoll and national capital, was an American logistics base during World War II, as were the outlying atolls of Nanumea and Nukufetau. **********Tuvalu, which is part of the British-aligned Commonwealth of Nations, has hardly been touched by Western influence except on Funafuti. Here the Government offices, an eight-room hotel and other service facilities are housed in simple one-story buildings that provide a faint patina of urbanization in an idyllic post-card setting of palm trees fringing a serene lagoon. Content With Simple Life **********Prime Minister Lauti estimated that 80 percent of the Tuvaluans subsist in traditional fashion, living off coconuts, other fruits, a few easily cultivated root crops and fish. Their meager cash - per capita income is estimated at $240 a year - comes from a modest output of coconut products, handicrafts and remittances from the hundreds of Tuvaluans working aboard foreign ships, on the phosphateproducing island of Nauru and elsewhere outside the country. **********Foreign specialists working on various improvement projects in the chain agree that most of the Tuvaluans are content with their simple way of life, bereft of such modern amenities as electricity except on the two main atolls of Funafuti and Vaitupu, where the country's only high school is situated. **********''People are happy, and you see nothing like the grinding poverty of Asia,'' said Arthur Dahl of Carmel, Calif., who is making an environmental survey for the South Pacific Commission, an intergovernmental development group. **********Since independence came nearly three years ago, Prime Minister Lauti said, Tuvalu's top money earner has been the sale of colorful postage stamps produced in a joint venture with a British company.  Last year, he said, the stamps brought in $700,000 in Australian money, which is Tuvalu's national currency, and sales are expected to go well over $1 million this year because of a new series commemorating the British royal wedding.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/28/busin.print_headline: The Week in Business; BRONFMAN'S SURPRISE BID FOR CONOCO
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/28/busin.body_text: **********Seagram, the company that Edgar M. Bronfman (right) heads, is known for its whisky. **********But it also has a taste for oil. Last week it offered $2.55 bilion for almost 41 percent of Conoco, the ninth-largest oil company in the United States. Seagram has been flush since its sold its United States oil properties to the Sun Company last August for $2.3 billion. A recent bid for St. Joe Minerals failed. The surprise offer for Conoco caused Conoco talks with Cities Service to collapse. Cities Service is seeking to block a threat from Nu-West of Calgary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/11/busin.body_text: **********The nation's businesses plan to increase their spending on new plants and equipment 1.8 percent - after adjustment for inflation - in the first half of 1982 over the last half of this year, the Commerce Department said today. **********A survey, conducted in late October and early November, put the inflation-adjusted advance in capital spending this year at a slim three-tenths of 1 percent. Planned spending increased eight-tenths of 1 percent in 1980 and 7.7 percent in 1979, after adjustment for inflation, the report said. **********In the third quarter of this year, inflation-adjusted capital spending rose 1.8 percent, following a 1.6 percent drop in the April-June quarter, the report said. **********It estimated that spending for the current quarter would decline eight-tenths of 1 percent, Long-Range View **********Deputy Commerce Secretary Joseph Wright said the figures on planned spending for the first half of next year were ''not surprising, since we expected business decision-makers to stick to their long-range investment goals and to view the current downturn as short-lived.'' **********He also said the Administration's new tax law should provide businesses with enough incentives to ''offset and prevent any serious decline'' as operators reassessed their investment plans in light of the current economic slump. **********''Here we are going into a recession and plans for the first half of 1982 appear to be pretty buoyant,'' said Robert Ortner, the department's chief economist. ''They are certainly not collapsing.'' **********But Thomas D. Thomson, senior vice president and chief economist at San Francisco's Crocker National Bank, said the health of the economy had worsened considerably since the survey was done. Less Ambitious Plans **********He said the survey had indicated that business executives ''weren't very ambitious in their plans and one has to believe they would be even less ambitious'' now after seeing the turn the economy has taken in the weeks since it was conducted. **********He predicted that lower interest rates and tax law changes would provide incentives in the second half of 1982 resulting in ''a quicker snapback'' in investments than is normally the case after a recession. **********The Commerce Department survey found business operators estimating that their capital investments in the first half of next year would be at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $350.1 billion - or a 6.1 percent increase - before adjustment for inflation, from the last half of 1981. **********The department said its latest estimate of spending for 1981 was $322.6 billion, a 9.1 percent gain, before inflation, over the previous year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/18/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission voted unanimously today to end the monopoly of the Western Union Telegraph Company over telegram and teleprinter service in the United States. **********The vote authorized the five American companies that now specialize in international service to begin providing telex and telegram services between the various American cities in which they operate.  The agency's action parallels a similar Congressional authorization in a bill passed Wednesday that President Reagan is expected to sign shortly. The bill also repealed a 38-year-old law that has prohibited Western Union from offering international cable and telex services. **********The legislation sets specific procedures to be followed by the commission in authorizing domestic competition. Thus, it will likely be some months before the international carriers offer domestic service. 'A Jump on Congress' **********''The bill doesn't directly authorize each of these international carriers to provide domestic service; that's something we have to do,'' explained Gary Epstein, the chief of the commission's common carrier bureau. ''We've just gotten a jump on Congress by finding that it is in the public interest for the international carriers to compete in the domestic market.'' **********For years, the international carriers were barred from relaying messages from abroad to any customer outside New York and other ''gateway'' cities. Recently, however, this restriction has been eroded and the carriers have delivered overseas messages to domestic customers without using Western Union. With today's commission ruling and the bill passed by Congress, the carriers would be able to originate messages as well as deliver them, and to transmit freely within the country. **********The five companies are RCA Global Communications, International Telephone and Telegraph, TRT Telecommunications, FTC Communications and Western Union International Inc., which has no relationship with Western Union Telegraph. F.C.C.'s Initial Action **********The commission first tried to spur competition among Western Union Telegraph and the five international carriers in December 1979, when it adopted an order expanding the number of American cities in which the international concerns could operate and authorizing overseas links for Western Union. **********A United States Court of Appeals subsequently ruled, however, that the agency had exceeded its authority in opening the international market to Western Union.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/17/busin.main_headline: About Real Estate; HOME MORTGAGES WITH AN INTEREST RATE THAT CAN CHANGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/17/busin.print_headline: About Real Estate; HOME MORTGAGES WITH AN INTEREST RATE THAT CAN CHANGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/17/busin.body_text: **********It will come as no surprise to most home buyers these days that lending institutions are starting to offer alternatives to the fixedrated, long-term mortgage. **********What many may find surprising is that borrowers, given a choice, frequently take the alternative to the fixed-rate loan - especially when the initial monthly payments are pegged lower as an incentive. **********This was the experience in Toledo, Ohio, for example, of the People's Savings Association. This savings and loan association with assets of $443 million introduced what it called a one-year rollover loan and a five-year rollover loan in November 1979. Fixed-rate loans were also available at an interest rate one percentage point higher than the rollover loan. It developed that 94.4 percent of the borrowers chose the rollover loans. That represented 1,205 loans totaling $51 million. **********''People hope and expect that the rates will go down,'' said James Petty, senior vice president. ''And we priced it right. You must price it below the fixed rate.'' **********It is also likely, some real estate specialists say, that buyers planning to move within a few years are less worried about ''locking in'' their monthly repayments over the life of the loan. **********A confusing new language is developing to describe subtly different forms of home mortgage loans. In the savings and loan industry, the most frequently heard terms are rollover mortgages or renegotiablerate mortgages. One savings and loan officer described the word ''renegotiable'' as poor use of language. ''There is no renegotiation after the term of the loan ends,'' he said, ''only adjustment of the interest rate.'' **********Accordingly, even the thrift institutions may come to adopt the term that the Comptroller of the Currency has used in recent regulations authorizing national commercial banks to make such loans. The Comptroller calls them adjustable-rate loans, and this may ultimately become the generally accepted term. **********The basic principle is the same -periodic adjustment of the interest rate during the life of a long-term loan to reflect changes in the cost of money as reflected in some index. Under the Comptroller's regulation, the rate cannot change more than 1 percent every six months, and there is no total limit in the life of the loan. This is more liberal for lenders than rules of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board for federally chartered savings and loan associations and savings banks, but that may change. **********In the metropolitan New York area, experience with flexible-rate mortgages is in the early stages. Market activity is hardly brisk with interest rates above 15 percent, and some hard-pressed lenders are out of the home mortgage market entirely. **********On Long Island, a mortgage office at the Suburbia Federal Savings and Loan Association, which has been offering what it calls threeyear rollover loans since last September, said that many people take it, even though there is no spread in rates with conventional loans, because they ''think the rates will come down.'' The volume of lending has been low. **********An example of what different pricing can mean in dollars was provided by an officer of the Westchester Federal Savings and Loan Association, which has been offering what it calls renegotiable-rate mortgages. The buyer can get such a mortgage at present with a 15 percent interest rate and a 30-year repayment schedule for principal and interest. Alternatively, the buyer can choose a fixed-rate mortgage at 15 1/2 percent based on a 25-year repayment period. **********On a $50,000 loan the initial monthly payments would be $632.23 for the renegotiable mortgage. Rates can change every three years. On the fixed-rate mortgage, monthly payments would be $659.88. **********Mortgage terms vary among lenders. Some are said to have priced conventional loans at 17 percent or to have stopped making them altogether. There does not seem to be a widespread use of ''spread'' between the cost of flexible-rate and fixed-rate mortgages as a way of stimulating business. **********When interest rates are adjusted in mortgages, the borrower's monthly payments do not necessarily change. Amortization, or principal, payments can be lowered to hold monthly debt payments steady. But the Comptroller's rule guards against excessive use of ''negative amortization,'' in which the home owner piles up debt and never comes to own equity in the house, a situation that caused many to lose their homes in the Depression. **********To promote its rollover loans, People's Savings in Toledo also offered the features of assumability or portability. Assumability means that a loan can be taken over by a new purchaser at whatever point it is in its five-year cycle. Portability means that the borrower who has a loan can get a new loan for a house at the same rate for the rest of the five-year cycle. **********Edward O. Knowles, president of People's Savings, is a forceful advocate of the flexible loans. Last January the association introduced still another option, a one-year loan convertible to a five-year or a fixed-rate loan. It was offered at 12 1/2 percent, which was two percentage points below the fixed rate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/12/busin.main_headline: THE ITKINS RIDE THE 'WORK STATION' BOOM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/12/busin.print_headline: THE ITKINS RIDE THE 'WORK STATION' BOOM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/12/busin.body_text: **********Almost half a century ago, three brothers from Brooklyn joined forces as office furniture repairmen, pushing dolleys laden with freshly repaired goods along New York city's trolley tracks.  Canvassing skyscrapers floor by floor, the Itkin brothers ventured into sales, and gradually succeeded in unravelling the tight-knit fraternity of office furniture dealers. **********Today, ''The Itkins,'' boasts a bustling Madison Avenue showroom, a sprawling warehouse and a fleet of snappy green trucks. It is also the largest retailer of office furniture in the nation. **********Indeed, despite a folksy image and a philosophy of ''servicing the hell out of clients,'' the second generation approach to doing business is a far cry from the family's earlier days as ''cold call'' salesman. **********And at a time when many sectors of the economy are reeling from high interest rates and general investor malaise, first cousins Lewis and Leonard Itkin have managed to capitalize on one area that has been hot - office space -and used the accompanying boom in high technology (and high fashion) corporate enviroments to their advantage. Pacing his unprepossessing office overlooking the gleaming showroom edownstairs, Lewis Itkin - the ''outside man'' or go-between for some 550 manufacturers and 3,000 new clients annually - seizes an array of glossy catalogs. Leonard - the administrator or ''inside man'' in Itkin parlance -sits down unobtrusively on a well-worn sofa. The pitch about the changing officegeer territory begins: **********''When our fathers first started the product was very simple: a desk, a chair and a filing cabinet,'' declared Lewis Itkin, who entered the family business in 1963, in good time to be trained in the art of salesmanship by his relations. (At one time, as many as 7 Itkins worked together; the number dwindled to two at the beginning of 1980, when the last senior Itkin retired.) **********''Now, as manufacturers have gotten into panel office systems with anywhere from 400 individual components, things just aren't so simpleany more,'' c ontinued Mr. Itkin. ''This market is exploding and everyone from the guy with one room to an organization like ours is after it.'' According to the Business and Institutional Furniture ManufacturersAssociation, manufacturers in the office furn iture market garnered sales of $3.4 billion last year, up from $1.2 billion in 1975. The figure this year is expected to climb to $3.7 5 billion.  Of this sum,fifty percent of the installations are curren tly in so-called systemsfurniture. In contrast, ten years ago, the sy stems market - work stations composed of panel partitions and mod ular components such as electronic computer printout files - held a l ess than 5 percent sliver of the market. **********But in a business so rough and tumble that suppliers will not disclose a client's name for fear of sending scores of contractors scurrying to its door, (the Itkins eschew specificity beyond claiming to have made deals with 69 Fortune 500 companies in New York), the two cousins have carved out a comfortable financial niche. **********This year, the Itkins, who describe their relationship as ''symbiotic,'' predict sales of more than $10 million, an increase of 25 percent over last year's revenues. The company's average fee for an contract job is roughly $300,000, representing a 10-30 percent markup over manufacturers' costs. The reason for their success? It may lie in their advertising agency's story boards.  Smith and Greenland's, high visibility and low cost campaign ($300,000 annually) deflates the ego of unchic office dwellers through full page newspaper advertisments that read: ''Does your office look so bad that instead of going public you go private,'' or ''Do even pigeons avoid sitting outside your office.'' **********Predictably, some competitors sniff at the Itkin's romance with the Madison Avenue hardsell. ''The Itkins was built on advertising and selling to the street trade,'' noted Lawrence Glasow president of the New York based Empire Office Equipement Company, the largest contractor on the East Coast with $30 million in sales last year.  ''We have a solid corporate base.'' **********And the company does not appear to top every architect and interior designer's roster of furniture dealers. '' We use a great many furniture dealers, and they are not one of them, remarked Richard Carlsen, director of interior design at Swanke, Hayden, Connell Architects, a leading corporate architure and interior design firm. **********''The Itkins deal very strongly in specific product lines and are very agressive in terms of their client relations,'' Mr. Carlsen explained. ''In our view, a furniture dealers' main contribution is as a middleman, coordinating dates between a manufacturer and client. But the Itkins are less interested in this, than in getting clients to buy everything offered by the Itkins.'' **********But many clients beset by architects, interior designers and manufacturers are reasssured only too eager for the headache-free solutions the Itkins promise, not to mention their unflappable image. **********''The Itkins are very fine and honorable gentlemen. More than the product, they are selling confidence,'' observed a senior vice president at the Seamans Bank for Savings where the Itkins have had a hand in opening some 8 branches. The executive who requested anonymity paused and added, ''Occasionally they have promised furniture when they were really only keeping their fingers crossed, but in this business something always fall through the cracks.'' **********As part of the continuing scramble to convince clients that their empty office space - an estimated 4.5 million square feet this year - will be more speedily filled under Itkin supervision, the company has just installed an intricate computer system. The system tracks the progress of orders as they wend from manufacturer to freight carrier, from warehouse to Itkin truck to customer and also monitors the $500,000 warehouse inventory roster. **********''You can live in an empty apartment, but you can't work on the floor,'' says Leonard Itkin adding ''If you're paying $50 a square foot, God help you if you don't move in on time.'' end

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/14/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON A VERY productive inventor, who received a patent this week for a patient-monitoring device, announced that he had just licensed the International Business Machines Corporation to use more than a score of his earlier inventions that concern information handling. **********Jerome H. Lemelson got patent 4,299,233 on apparatus for detecting body sounds, chiefly from heartbeats and respiration. **********The patient lies on a water-filled mattress. Attached to the mattress is an electronic sensing device that changes the sound vibrations transmitted by the liquid to electrical signals. These are analyzed by a mini-computer. Buzzer alarms can be sounded, and a record kept. **********Mr. Lemelson, who has more than 360 earlier patents, has granted nonexclusive licenses to I.B.M. under his patents on information storage, communication systems, facsimile transmission, magnetic recording, industrial robots, light pens used to read printed codes, and video terminals and displays. In a telephone interview, he described the arrangement as ''a very good deal.'' **********The inventor is president of the Licensing Management Corporation, New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/01/world.main_headline: GREEKS SEEM READY TO VEER LEFTWARD THIS MONTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/01/world.print_headline: GREEKS SEEM READY TO VEER LEFTWARD THIS MONTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/01/world.body_text: **********Public opinion polls suggest that Greece will turn left in the general elections of Oct. 18 and install the Socialist lead er Andreas Papandreou in power. But Prime Minister George Rallis insists that his conservative camp is an ''awakening giant'' that will prevail. **********Mr. Papandreou has sought during the campaign to counter the Government's attempt to portray him as a revolutionary Marxist.  Tempering his more radical earlier views, he is competing with the Prime Minister for the backing of Greece's centrist voters, who have remained largely uncommitted since the breakup of the center parties following their poor performance in the last elections, in 1977. **********''We are the party of change, of national and social rejuvenation, not of upheaval as our opponents want to portray us,'' the 62-yearold Socialist leader said at one of his huge rallies. **********For Mr. Papandreou, son of the centrist Prime Minister, the late George Papandreou, this will be the third attempt to gain power since the rule of the Greek colonels was ended in 1974. His meteoric rise has followed his success at the 1977 elections, when his Panhellenic Socialist Party doubled its share of the votes, reaching 26 percent, and tripled its representation in Parliament, raising it to 94 out of 300 seats. Papandreou Predicts Victory **********Mr. Papandreou, a former professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley, predicts victory this time with more than 50 percent of the vote and promises ''reforms which the country has not experienced since Greek independence in 1821.'' **********He continues to say that it is ''preposterous'' for Greece to belong to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization because doing so ''means deploying our forces in a way that makes us naked toward the east, toward Turkey,'' also an alliance member. **********But sources close to him maintain that Mr. Papandreou has decided, if elected, not to move quickly to pull Greece out of NATO or close down the four American bases in the country. They say that he is wary of possible displeasure in the military and of upsetting the international balance of power and that he realizes there is no easy alternative source of arms supplies. The United States supplies Greece with 90 percent of its military equipment. **********His associates describe Mr. Papandreou as preparing the ground with his remarks for a tougher negotiating stance with the West. They also say that he has abandoned earlier plans to seek the outright withdrawal of Greece from the European Economic Community and has decided to move instead for a renegotiated special relationship or a referendum on Greek membership. Domestic Policy Is Basic Appeal **********He insists that Greece's foreign policy cannot only be Westernoriented but must also take account of the nation's ''position as a European, Balkan and Mediterranean country.'' **********His party's principal appeal, however, derives from its domestic policy. He has called for a strict separation of church and state, the institution of civil marriage, changes in education and improved health care. Avoiding the term ''nationalization,'' he has called for ''socialization,'' or increased worker participation, in 12 key fields, among them banking and insurance, shipbuilding, energy production, mining and defense-related industries. **********Prime Minister Rallis, a mild-mannered 63-year-old lawyer who has been in office since May 15, 1980, cannot match the crowd-pleasing campaigning of his rival and privately concedes that he detests campaign rallies. But he is seeking to present his party, which polled 42 percent of the vote in 1977, as the guarantor of stablility and steady progress in the face of growing demands for quicker change. **********''Voters have the tendency to regard our existing achievements as natural,'' he said in an interview. ''But when the danger appears that these achievements will be abolished, won't they defend them with their votes? We are the only ones who can guarantee an untroubled course toward progress and stability.'' Return to Democracy Cited Mr. Rallis presents the main successes of his ruling party, known as New Democracy, as being the restoration of democracy after the fa ll of the military dictatorship in 1974, the achievement of po litical stability and membership in the Common Market. **********He says Greek per capita income has more than doubled in the last seven years, reaching $4,380 in 1980, outstripping that of Yugoslavia and Portugal and approaching the levels of Spain and Italy. He predicts that the inflation rate - the nation's most persistent economic problem - will be reduced this year from 25 to 20 percent.  He maintains that inflation is a necessary price to pay for continued economic development and full employment. **********Countering oppposition charges that New Democracy has neglected social improvements, he says, for example, that more schools have been built since 1974 than in the century and a half before then. **********On foreign policy, he says New Democracy is responsible for improving Greece's international prestige and for broadening relations with neighboring Communist countries and the Arab world.  He defends Greece's nine-month-old membership in the European Common Market as a ''privilege,'' one that he says Spain and Portugal would like to have, and he charges that the Socialists ''want to render Greece a third-world and nonaligned country'' - a development that he says would benefit Turkey since it would cut the Greek armed forces from their basic sources of supply. Third Vote Since 1974 **********''I have no doubt,'' he says, ''that the majority of our people reject this combined anti-American, anti-Western and anti-European policy, and that is perhaps why the Panhellenic Socialist Party has modified its policy of late.'' **********While the October election will be the third since 1974, it will mark the first time that New Democracy will be led by someone other than Constantine Caramanlis, now President. A victory for Mr. Rallis, who has been accustomed to being regarded as an underdog, would go far toward establishing him as a leader who was no longer in the shadow of Mr. Caramanlis. **********New Democracy has been attempting to broaden its appeal - beyond its 1977 showing of 42 percent of the vote - both by competing with the Socialists for the centrists and by absorbing supporters of the far right. Mr. Rallis claims credit for uniting the two wings of the divided party he inherited when he became Prime Minister, succeeding Mr. Caramanlis. **********Mr. Rallis first entered politics in the 1950's, burdened with the background of being the son of a man who was Prime Minister during the Nazi occupation of Greece and who was later sentenced to life imprisonment. The current Prime Minister's own political credentials were firmly established when he was imprisoned three times for outspoken criticism during the colonels' rule in 1967-74. **********He says he expects his party to confound the experts on Oct. 18 by polling more than 50 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/17/world.main_headline: ISRAELI SAYS FRIENDSHIP WITH U.S. HAS BEEN DAMAGED BY SALE TO SAUDIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/17/world.print_headline: ISRAELI SAYS FRIENDSHIP WITH U.S. HAS BEEN DAMAGED BY SALE TO SAUDIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/17/world.body_text: **********Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir accused the Reagan Administration today of damaging the friendship between Israel and the United States by agreeing to sell sophisticated weapons to Saudi Arabia. **********He said that Israel could not afford an extensive arms race and warned that the arrival of new weapons in the Middle East was creating an explosive situation for which the United States shared responsibility. **********It was Israel's first sharp criticism of the new Administration, and it reflected rising concern in Jerusalem over the emerging American policy of arming pro-Western Arab countries. **********Speaking in Parliament, Mr. Shamir hailed the ''deep sense of friendship which binds our two peoples and countries.'' But he denounced the recent decisions on Saudi arms. **********Israel is heading for parliamentary elections June 30, and Abba Eban, a former Foreign Minister in a Labor Government, also denounced the sales, saying that sophisticated military hardware did not insure the stability of a regime. Saudis Will Get Gear for F-15's **********The Administration has notified Congress of its plan to supply the Saudis with detachable fuel tanks and Sidewinder air-to-air missiles to increase the range and firepower of about 60 F-15 jet fighters slated for delivery. The added equipment could make the planes effective against Israel. **********In addition, officials in Jerusalem have been in an uproar over press reports that Washington would also sell the Saudis four Awacs intelligence-gathering and command aircraft. **********Deputy Defense Minister Mordechai Zipori said that with the planes, Saudi Arabia could monitor all of Israel's military activities, locating troops, aircraft, tanks and artillery pieces. They would ''expose all of Israel's secrets,'' he said. ''We would not be able to take even one move without them knowing about it.'' **********Mr. Shamir had originally sought to mute Israel's protest over the Saudi sales to avoid a confrontation with the new Administration on an issue that seemed a lost cause. But the climate in Jerusalem has developed into one of heightened anxiety, especially over the reports of the Awac aircraft being offered, and in that context, Mr. Shamir told Parliament: **********''The friendship and understanding between the United States and Israel have been marred recently by the American decision to supply Saudi Arabia with sophisticated auxiliary equipment for F-15 airplanes as well as with four Awac aircraft, as has now been reported in the media.'' Promises to Israel Are Dismissed **********He dismissed American promises to keep Israel ahead in weapons technology. ''The President, the Secretary of State and the Secretary of Defense believe that it is possible to redress the damage by supplying weapons systems to Israel under special conditions,'' Mr.  Shamir said. ''To our regret, we must state that we do not see this as a solution, or as a way out. **********''The state of Israel will not be able -even from the economic point of view -to withstand such an arms race.'' Israel has also been fighting tentative West German plans to sell Saudi Arabia advanced Leopard tanks.  Mr. Shamir deplored what he called ''a massive flow of all types of weapons, including the most advanced, into this region from every possible source: the United States, the Soviet Union and the European countries. These massive quantities of weapons do not strengthen the West in this region; they do not serve any positive purpose, but they do jeopardize peace and endanger Israel.'' He Scoffs at Label of 'Moderate' **********The Foreign Minister scoffed at the American portrayal of Saudi Arabia as moderate and pro-Western. ''This state has participated in all the wars against Israel,'' he said. ''It orchestrated the conference which declared jihad against us. It is the major financier of the P.L.O.'s terrorism. It works persistently and aggressively against the peace process. Any additional military equipment given to it will ultimately serve all of the extremist elements in the region that oppose peace and stability.'' **********A less-concerned voice was heard from the military ranks, however.  In a radio interview, the former air force commander, Gen. Binyamin Peled, said the Awacs could be shot down with ease. ''An air force like ours, with F-15's and some other things, will find it relatively easy to bring down big buses like these,'' he said. ''These aircraft are practically defenseless if anyone really intends to bring them down and has the range to reach them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/17/world.main_headline: A POWER LINE ACROSS ZAIRE NEARLY READY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/17/world.print_headline: A POWER LINE ACROSS ZAIRE NEARLY READY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/17/world.body_text: **********After seven years and many delays, the construction of the Inga-Shaba power line, the longest and most powerful in the world, will be completed this month. **********The line runs 1,100 miles from the Inga Dam near Kinshasa on the Congo River to this remote copper-mining town in the heart of the southern, mineral-rich Shaba Province. It cuts through forest and bush and stalks over rivers, its 8,500 120-foot-high towers posing a striking contrast to the villages of straw-roofed huts in their path. **********When it comes on stream next year, carrying half a million volts across a great swath of Africa, the line will stand as a monument to engineering tenacity, and as a symbol of a developing country's vulnerability to market forces beyond its control. **********For critics it will also represent a lasting, large-scale reminder of the hubris of the country's leader, President Mobutu Sese Seko. Copper Boom and High Hopes **********Work on the line by an American-led consortium began in 1974 when the price of copper - the mineral that fuels Zaire's economy - was high. The copper boom, economists say, swelled state coffers, individual pockets and presidential visions of grandeur. General Mobutu took credit for the idea of a line that would build a new unity between the north and south of his vast country and provide Africa with power. **********Then, the price of copper fell drastically, oil prices went up and the cost of foreign technology rocketed. Critics say the line is just one of a number of projects that were conceived in the boom years on a scale that has now outstripped the nation's resources. **********Its original purpose was to link the Inga Dam complex with Shaba Province in order to fuel a 200 percent expansion of the copper mines. It was also, critics say, a matter of presidential prestige. **********Shaba already had its own hydroelectric resources, which are still, experts say, enough for present production. When the bottom fell from the copper market, the plan to expand production was dropped too, so the power needs of the industry could have been met at lower cost by rehabilitating Shaba's own aging hydroelectric system. Cost Overruns and Invasions **********Initially planned for completion in three years at a cost of $350 million, the line will now cost over $800 million. Delays have been caused by problems with financing, invasions of Shaba from across the Angolan border in 1977 and 1978, the soaring price of imported equipment and Zaire's inability to pay its debts. America's Export-Import Bank is guranteeing the loans for the project. **********The line has brought some employment and improved roads to the areas its crosses, but it does not provide power for these regions.  For instance, halfway down its length at Kananga, the railways run on diesel fuel and electric power is provided by fuel-oil generators and hydroelectric equipment. A switch to power from the Inga-Shaba system would sharply reduce local bills. However, the line marches straight past Kananga and, according to officials, a spur into the town would cost a further $80 million. **********There are those who defend the line. An official from Morrison-Knudsen International of Boise, Idaho, the concern that leads the construction consortium, said that sooner or later towns like Kananga would be connected to the Inga-Shaba line. In addition, the official said, Shaba's own hydroelectric equipment, some dating back to the 1920's, is in poor shape, so the completion of the line will be timely. Potential for Development **********In the long term, an American official said, the vast power resources of Inga-Shaba - the great waters of the Congo River basin contain enough power potential to light up all of West Africa -could play a central role in Africa's development, a process that has been slowed in this region by high oil costs, low mineral prices and falling agricultural production. **********Morrison-Knudsen, which has 280 Americans and 2,000 Zairians working on the line, has faced mammoth logistical problems.  Equipment is imported by sea, unloaded at Matadi on the Atlantic, sent by road or rail from there to Kinshasa, loaded onto barges for a river trip and then put back onto the railways or onto trucks for onward transport, often to places where there were no roads before the line crews moved in. One hundred and forty thousand tons of equipment has been moved this way. **********The line crews, some American, some Italian, have cut 4,000 miles of roads through inhospitable land. In some places, large trees have grown up around sections of the line built only three years ago.  Tropical storms whip the shield wire with lightning. Local people, engineers say, have found uses for the steel from which the towers are made and have taken to unbolting sections and carrying them off.  Maintenance is thus a never-ending job.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/10/world.main_headline: Israel Officially Rejects Saudi Peace Proposals
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/10/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Israel Officially Rejects Saudi Peace Proposals
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/10/world.body_text: **********Israeli officials today dismissed Saudi Arabia's Middle East peace proposals as a plan to destroy Israel.  Officials said the plan outlined yesterday by Crown Prince Fahd in an interview with the official Saudi press agency ultimately envisaged an all-out attack on Israel by Arab nations led by the Palestinians. **********In an interview with the Tel Aviv daily Yediot Aharonot, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said there was nothing new in the plan. He rejected the contention of some politicians and analysts that the Saudis had made concessions by suggesting that they would accept Israel's right to live in peace if the Israelis allowed the creation of a Palestinian state. ''Even the suggestion of Saudi recognition of Israel is not new,'' he added. **********Former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin said the very publication of a plan conceding Israel's right to exist as a sovereign country in the region was politically significant. The Labor Party leader, Shimon Peres, agreed but said the conditions put forward by the Saudis would jeopardize Israel's survival.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/18/busin.main_headline: 3 TRADERS SUING BEAR, STEARNS ON KENNECOTT TRADING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/18/busin.print_headline: 3 TRADERS SUING BEAR, STEARNS ON KENNECOTT TRADING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/18/busin.body_text: **********Three local market makers in Kennecott options on the Chicago Board Options Exchange have filed suit in Federal court here against Bear, Stearns & Company, charging that, because of improper activites by insiders, the three suffered losses of more than $5 million. **********It was the second lawsuit in a week charging improper use of insider information in options trading. The three traders asserted that the losses had eroded their capital position and had resulted in their suspension from the exchange. **********Last week, O'Connor & Associates, another Chicago firm, sued Dean Witter Inc. and A.G. Becker, charging that the firms ''aided and abetted'' insiders in the purchase of options to buy shares of Amax.  In an amended complaint, filed yesterday in Federal court in New York, O'Connor asked for a jury trial and named Thomas C. Reed, a former Secretary of the Air Force and the son of an Amax director, as one of the alleged insiders. **********''Nobody around here can remember a time when there've been two suits like this,'' an official of the Chicago board said. Options trading began eight years ago on the Chicago board. **********Several traders said privately they doubted the suits would have much impact, terming them acts of desperation on the part of people who got caught on the wrong side of the market, people who got caught writing so-called naked options - without owning the underlying stocks - and who did not hedge their exposure. Each call option, the type in dispute, represents a contract to purchase 100 shares of stock at a given price before a specific expiration date. **********The options had given the purchasers the right to buy the underlying stock in coming months at prices well above the levels at which Kennecott and Amax were traded before the Standard Oil Company of California arranged to buy Amax for $4 billion, and Standard Oil (Ohio) offered $1.77 billion for Kennecott. Immediately after the offers were announced in the last 10 days, the Kennecott and Amax stocks shot up in price, increasing the value of the options many times over. For example, some Amax call options to purchase Amax stock at $45 or more in March multiplied in value more than 70 times as Amax stock doubled to $58. **********The Chicago board, the Amex and the Securities and Exchange Commission have said that they have their own investigations pending in the Amax and Kennecott cases. And the brokerage houses have denied any wrongdoing. **********The three plaintiffs in the suit filed here yesterday said, however, that the exchanges' self-regulatory efforts, made up of daily surveillance of trading to spot irregular patterns, would not compensate them for their losses. **********''The object of this suit is to get back some lost money,'' said Lawrence Rubin, a lawyer with Avery, Hodes, Costello & Burman, attorneys for the plaintiffs in the suit involving Kennecott options. ''The exchanges and the S.E.C. have generally taken a long time to reach conclusions and the trial may have grown cold by that time.'' **********Mr. Rubin contended that his clients - Robert Lechman, David Harris and 3-S Board Brokers - sold many of the options to buy 200,000 shares of Kennecott in June at prices of $30 and $35 in the days before Sohio announced that it would pay $62 a share for Kennecott.  Kennecott shares, selling for around $27 before the deal, soared to more than $50 a share after the announcement and closed today at 53 1/8, up 3/4. **********Caught off guard by the merger news and not owning the shares covered by the options they had sold, the traders were then obliged under the options contract to buy the stock at more than $50 a share and sell at $30 and $35 to cover their options commitments. **********Alton Harris, an attorney for O'Connor at the firm of Coffield, Ungaretti, Harris & Slavin, said he did not believe that O'Connor owned all the shares on all the options that it sold. **********Attempts by telephone to reach Bear, Stearns for comment were in vain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/19/busin.body_text: **********The United States Treasury is scheduled to sell $4.5 billion each of new three- and six-month bills at its regular auction today, followed on Wednesday by a $4.75 billion auction of new two-year notes. The minimum purchase is $10,000 for the bills and $5,000 for the notes. **********While this week's Treasury sales are in maturities with proven popularity among investors, dealers are already beginning to worry about the first week of November, when the Treasury is expected to sell up to $9 billion of notes and bonds, including 10- and 30-year issues that are harder to sell. **********In advance of this week's sales, outstanding three- and six-month bills were bid late Friday at 13.60 percent and 13.86 percent, respectively. The outstanding 16 percent notes due Sept. 30, 1983, were offered at 100 26/32 to yield 15.51 percent. Because the Treasury needs to raise as much as $35 billion of new cash this quarter, some experts say weekly bill sales might increase to $10 billion, while monthly auctions of two-year notes rise to $5 billion.  Corporate Offerings Light **********In the corporate market, the volume of new notes and bonds continues to be relatively light, because interest rates are too high for most borrowers. **********After a week when revenue bonds dominated the tax-exempt calendar, several highly rated states are scheduled to sell general obligation bonds this week. **********New York City investors, who can earn special benefits from local issues that are exempt from Federal, state and city taxes, might want to wait until next week, when the New York State Mortgage Finance Agency is scheduled to sell $125 million of revenue bonds and the New York State Dormitory Authority, $112 million. **********The following new fixed-income securities are scheduled this week: TAXABLE TUESDAY **********San Diego Gas and Electric, 1.3 million preference shares, $25 par value, rated Ba by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
