https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1981; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/19/busin.body_text: **********The nation's economy stagnated in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said. Its preliminary figure for the G.N.P., after adjustment for inflation, shows a decline at an annual rate of 0.5 percent. The G.N.P. declined at a revised 1.6 percent rate in the first quarter. Officials expect the rate of inflation, as measured by the G.N.P.'s fixed-weight price index, to hold at 7.9 percent. (Page 29.) **********A sweeping approach to deregulation of financial institutions was outlined by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. He would let banks open branches across state lines and would gradually erase the distinction between commercial banks and savings institutions. He would also permit commercial banks to move further into securities underwriting, in competition with brokerage houses. (29.) **********President R eagan promised a meeting of G.O.P. women in Denver that he would ''fi ght to the last blow'' for further spending cuts. (1.) The Senate re jected his free-market approach to agriculture and moved toward approval of a farm bill that would cost at least $10.8 billion in th e next four fiscal years. (1.) G.O.P. Congressional leaders, dubi ous of the White House plan to squeeze benefit programs,began draftin g their own alternative package of budget cuts. (9.) **********The Federal Reserve is adding funds to the banking system and thus encouraging lower short-term interest rates, new data indicated. The Fed said the nation's basic money supply rose $1.1 billion in the week ended Sept. 9. (35.) **********The Gold Commission began considering whether the nation should return to a gold standard, but after four hours it could agree on little. Europe's bankers regard the idea as risky. (32.) Companies **********G.M., Ford and Chrysler are again offering performance as an option to buyers. While switching to smaller models, the auto makers are fine-tuning their engines in an effort to match foreign competitors and overcome consumer resistance to their subcompacts. (29.) **********Nathan's Famous hot dogs seem to have lost their hold over New Yorkers. The company has had to shut down 23 restaurants in the metropolitan area in the past year. It now operates 13, franchises 10 others and is seeking to develop a new market in the Sun Belt. (29.) **********Air Oregon, a major part of the commuter airline empire that Justin Colin, a New York financier, is attempting to put together, withdrew from his attempt to suspend operations. The airline also acted to disassociate itself from a request for C.A.B. subsidies to offset losses from the air traffic controllers' strike. (29.) **********An option to buy 17 percent of Kaiser Steel for $50 a share, or about $59 million, was acquired by a California investor, Stanley Hiller Jr., who is also chairman of Bekins. He represents a group of investors who are negotiating to acquire the rest of the company's 7 million outstanding shares. (31.) Markets **********The stock market continued to retreat. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 3.90 points, to 836.19, its lowest closing since May 21, 1980. For the full week, the Dow fell 36.62 points. Analysts noted that since June 15, the Dow has plunged 175 points, one of the sharpest sustained declines in the past 12 years. (33.) The dollar fell for the eighth consecutive session, while gold prices rose $8.80 an ounce, to $450.90, on the Comex. (36.) Coffee futures prices rose sharply. (36.) Energy **********Bonn and Moscow are near accord on an exchange of West German coalprocessing plants for Soviet energy supplies, Bonn officials said. The project is expected to cause concern in Washington, which opposes allied energy dependence on Moscow. (29.) **********Amoco, the nation's No.3 gasoline marketer, raised wholesale prices as much as 1 cent a gallon while Exxon U.S.A., No.2, lowered prices a similar amount. Several other refiners announced price changes, both up and down. (31.) Today's Columns **********G.M.'s cut-rate auto loans are among the most imaginative of the auto makers' ploys to bolster sagging sales. G.M.A.C. rates are as low as 13.8 percent for certain models. Your Money. (30.) **********A new cylinder was patented this week for use in ''Dixy,'' or dipole xerography, a new method for developing patterns in the copying process. It was the 125th American patent for the inventor, Robert W. Gundlach of Xerox. Patents. (32.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/world.main_headline: SOVIET PROMPTLY REPORTS MOVES BY POLISH REGIME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/world.print_headline: SOVIET PROMPTLY REPORTS MOVES BY POLISH REGIME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/world.body_text: **********In a clear signal of Moscow's approval, the Soviet news media today announced the declaration of martial law by the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, one hour after Poles heard the news themselves. **********The Moscow radio carried the announcement as a flash on its news broadcast at 9 A.M. (1 A.M., New York time), just one hour after General Jaruzelski's speech was aired in Poland after a night of light music. **********The press agency Tass, listing Mr. Jaruzelski's three principal portfolios as the Communist Party leader, the Prime Minister and the Defense Minister, said his radio address ''announced the introduction of martial law in the country and the setting up of a Military Council of National Salvation.'' **********The announcements were brief, but the quick relay of General Jaruzelski's announcement of a ''state of war'' in Poland indicated that Moscow approved of the Polish Prime Minister's actions. **********Communications Links Cut **********Telephone and telex links between the Soviet Union and Poland were cut at about the time of a blockade by riot policemen on the Warsaw headquarters of the Solidarity union, just as the links were cut between Poland and Western nations. **********The Tass announcement said that General Jaruzelski ''announced that martial law was introduced in the country by a decree of the Council of State of Poland at 00.00 hours, Dec. 13, in the face of anarchy threatening the country, in the face of irresponsible actions by Solidarity's extremist forces, which openly strain after power.'' **********It continued: ''A Military Council of National Salvation has been set up and military commissioners have been appointed. The commissioners are given a right to exercise control over the activities of the bodies of state administration.'' It said they were ''given a right to remove from leading posts, as a disciplinary action, persons who do not fulfill their duties.'' Internment of Some Poles Cited **********The statement said that it had ''been decided to intern Solidarity's extremist leaders as well as members of illegal antisocialist organizations.'' It went on, ''A group of persons who bear responsibility for the socio-political and economic crisis in Poland has also been interned,'' including Edward Gierek, the former Prime Minister. **********The broadcast said General Jaruzelski ''pointed out that the party and Government consistently come out for the establishment of a front of national accord and for the unification of all the patriotic forces of the people in the name of salvation of Poland.'' It said that he had ''called for public tranquility to set in the country, the national economy to start functioning normally, and trust in and respect for the state power bodies to be restored.'' **********Earlier in the day, Radio Moscow broadcast charges that some factions of the Solidarity trade union were ''preparing to seize power'' in Poland. **********''Patriotic forces in Poland are calling more and more decisively for rebuffing the enemies of socialism,'' Radio Moscow said in its 6 A.M. (10 P.M. EST Saturday) news broadcast. 'Confrontation Is Inevitable' **********It quoted a Solidarity official in Bydgoszcz as saying that ''military confrontation is inevitable'' and added, ''Solidarity leaders are blocking Government measures to supply the population with necessities.'' **********Neither Soviet officials nor diplomats at the Polish Embassy in Moscow were available early Sunday to discuss events in Poland.  Radio Moscow's broadcast repeated charges against Solidarity originally made in a Tass news agency commentary Saturday in one of the strongest Soviet statements on Poland in recent months. **********''Renouncing the solution of the crisis by political means, the trade union Solidarity and counter-revolutionary elements operating within it are preparing for direct seizure of power,'' Tass said. **********After weeks of relatively restrained comments about Poland, the Soviet news media sharpened the tone of their reports noticeably last week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/04/world.main_headline: TRUCE IS REPORTED IN LEBANESE TOWN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/04/world.print_headline: TRUCE IS REPORTED IN LEBANESE TOWN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/04/world.body_text: **********A cease-fire was reported tonight in the eastern Lebanese Christian town of Zahle after two days of artillery duels between Syrian troops and Christian militiamen. **********The state-controlled Lebanese television indicated that the guns were silent because of intervention by President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. President Elias Sarkis of Lebanon had telephoned Mr. Assad and also sent an envoy, Elias Herawi, to Damascus to ask his help in ending one of the worst outbreaks of violence since the 1975-76 civil war. **********The Lebanese television reported, however, that tension remained high in the area. There was also tension in Beirut as sporadic exchanges of rockets and machine-gun fire continued along the line dividing predominantly Christian East Beirut and the predominantly Moslem West Beirut. **********Syrian forces are in Lebanon as members of the Arab force sent in 1976 to police the truce that ended the civil war in which Christian forces fought Moslem militias and their Palestinian guerrilla allies. For the last three years, however, the 22,000-man force has clashed intermittently with Lebanese Christian militias whose leaders are demanding the removal of both the Syrians and the Palestinians from the country. Israelis Raid Southern Lebanon **********Israel, in a Foreign Ministry statement, denounced the bombardment of Lebanese Christians but indicated that it would not intervene now. Prime Minister Menachem Begin pledged earlier that Israel would not stand by while Lebanese Christians were killed, but Israeli officials, in condemning the attacks this week on Zahle and in Beirut, said the commitment applied only to the border area next to Israel. **********Naphtali Lavie, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said, ''We don't intend to interfere in the domestic affairs of any country unless they affect us directly or indirectly.'' **********Israeli seaborne commandos, however, landed on the Lebanese southern coast early today, ambushed a Palestinian guerrilla vehicle and killed two of its occupants. It was the third Israeli attack on Palestinian positions in Lebanon this week, but officers at the Israeli military headquarters in Tel Aviv said the raids were not related to the fighting in Zahle and Beirut. **********The predominantly Lebanese Moslem port of Sidon came under artillery fire today from positions of the Israeli-backed Christian militias in southern Lebanon, the state-controlled Beirut radio reported. It said four people were killed and nine wounded. A Lebanese Christian broadcast said the attack on Sidon was in retaliation for the Syrian bombardment of Zahle. 72 People Reported Killed **********As the Zahle truce was reported, police sources said 72 people were killed and about 300 wounded in the two days of violence. They said 60 percent of the casualties were in Zahle. **********Lebanese Christian militiamen were said to have rushed more men and artillery to Zahle during the day from strongholds in nearby mountains. A Lebanese Christian broadcast said the Syrians had also brought up more men and tanks. **********The Damascus radio accused the Lebanese Christian militias of serving Israeli aims and said Syrian troops would deal firmly with any provocation. A Syrian communique said yesterday that the fighting at Zahle began when Christian militiamen tried to build a road to link the town with other Christian districts and encircle Syrian forces. **********The Lebanese Cabinet remained in session tonight, and there were reports that Christian members were pressing for moves to replace the Arab force with the regular Lebanese Army. This was reportedly opposed by Moslem members and the leftist grouping known as the National Movement, an ally of the Palestinian guerrillas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/busin.body_text: **********Federal financial regulators have refused to reverse themselves and put an interest ceiling on new retirement savings accounts scheduled to go into effect on Dec. 1, an official said today. **********They did, however, agree to impose early withdrawal penalties on individuals who transfer money out of existing Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh plans to the new ones, said Richard T. Pratt, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. **********Mr. Pratt, who had asked the regulators to reverse themselves out of concern for the ailing savings and loan industry, said he was ''disappointed'' in the vote not to put a cap on the accounts. **********William B. O'Connell, president of the United States League of Savings Associations, said, ''The bank regulators' decision to go ahead with the wild-card account was irresponsible and arrogant.'' **********The Depository Institutions Deregulation Committee, set up by Congress last year to phase out interest rates on deposits by 1986, had unanimously agreed in September to create a new category of I.R.A. and Keogh plans with a maturity of 1 1/2 years or longer and with no limit on interest rates. **********It also agreed that individuals could shift their money from existing retirement accounts to the new ones without early-withdrawal penalties. **********But Mr. Pratt, the chief Federal regulator of savings and loan associations, had requested the panel to overturn its decisions because he said he was concerned that the uncapped accounts would spark a price war. **********Millions of Americans will be able to put money into Individual Retirement Accounts on Jan. 1 when the new tax law greatly expands eligiblity to people now covered by private pension plans. The Dec. 1 starting date is for people already eligible to have I.R.A.'s under existing law. **********The banking industry, represented by the American Bankers Association, opposed any move to put interest ceilings on the accounts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/20/world.main_headline: A STYLISH HOTEL LIVES TO MIRROR UGANDA'S FATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/20/world.print_headline: A STYLISH HOTEL LIVES TO MIRROR UGANDA'S FATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/20/world.body_text: **********The Swahili word for finished, over, ended, out or no more is kwisha, pronounced kwee-sha. The word is heard everywhere in Kampala, where food is kwisha, water is kwisha and gasoline is kwisha. Kampala is all but kwisha. **********There was a time when the crusty old colonialists of Kenya came here for holidays in a more benign climate and, more important, to buy goods that could not be found at home. Uganda was wealthier. The fifth largest exporter of coffee in the world, it had the foreign exchange to import luxury items. The stores were jammed. **********The other morning, at the Apolo Hotel, the grandest hotel in the region when it was opened in 1965, coffee was kwisha. That night, beer was kwisha. All day, water was kwisha. **********The Apolo, in fact, is the tallest testament in town to Uganda's sad slide. It has 15 stories and 300 rooms and it stands on the highest of the seven lovely green hills that comprise Kampala. When it was opened, the President of the newly independent nation was Apolo Milton Obote, and thus the name. A Fine Wine Cellar **********In those days, great ivory tusks formed a parenthesis through which guests entered the lobby, where the stuffed magnificent heads of Cape buffalo gazed dully over carefully tanned lion and zebra hides. Profiteers took the rooms up top, looking down from their balconies on the manicured lawns - here and there the name ''Apolo,'' spelled out in bursting blossoms - that sloped away into a capital where building cranes were busy raising commercial buildings. The capitalists availed themselves of the 24-hour room service. In the cellar was a million dollars in wine. **********Idi Amin overthrew Milton Obote in 1971. Some conquering armies behave more badly than others, but nearly all like to make command posts of the poshest hotels. The Apolo, renamed the Kampala International, got through Mr. Amin's occupation by yielding up its cellar, its silverware and a few hides and tusks. It still functioned, though. **********The Amin dictatorship lasted eight years. Uganda had no economy when Tanzanian troops marched into Kampala in 1979 and set up temporary headquarters at the Kampala International, which they tore apart at the seams. Two coups later, an election was held and Apolo Milton Obote regained the presidency. **********The hotel's new general manager, Ron Hermer, a Briton, then received, in his words, ''a rather strong indication from a high authority that the hotel should be renamed.'' Life at the Apolo: A Nightmare **********Life at the Apolo today is a nightmare, and Mr. Hermer admits it.  If he has any reason to be thankful, he says, it is that he does not have the foreign exchange to have the signs made that would proclaim, from four sides of the top of the hotel, ''Apolo.'' Such is the tenuousness of Mr. Obote's hold, and such is the plethora of rebellious groups around that, according to the manager, ''The signs would just be shot out.'' **********Such is Mr. Hermer's candor that he told a first-time guest ''poor you'' and explained, ''I'm just here until they can con somebody else into the job.'' **********For all its problems, the hotel enjoys -or suffers, to use the manager's word -100 percent occupancy. Two years ago, Tanzanians filled it and the bills piled up on the cashier's desk because no one had the courage to ask the troops to pay. As the soldiers moved out, taking the room keys with them, civil servants whose houses had been looted and other city residents who simply felt safer up high moved their families in. Now the few phones that work ring ceaselessly as the hotel staff tries to collect the rents. **********Booking in is tough, but nothing that a big enough bribe will not take care of. Recently, while parting with money for the favor, a first-time guest took note of the deteriorative evidence in the lobby. Moths had gotten to the hides and something had left the Cape buffalo head with a stupid, cross-eyed look. A receptionist, who had first said, ''rooms kwisha,'' found an unoccupied room on the 12th floor. Cold Brown Baths Available **********From that point on, a certain amount of resourcefulness and stamina was required. The elevators did not work, the room had no key. A man with a credit card and a deft touch can release a locked door, and he did. A dirty man with a sharp eye will have remembered, upon finding dry taps, that he passed a fire hose 50 yards back down the corridor. Speculating that the hose was connected to rain barrels on the roof, and finding himself right, a man can have a cold brown bath. **********Toward evening, as kites, maribou storks, pied crows and bats fill the air above Kampala, the town looks pleasant enough from a 12thfloor balcony. A little later the sky gets filled with garbage raining down from rooms above in which families have cooked their dinners. Still later, about the time the hotel dining room opens, a guest must learn to ignore the sounds of gunfire outside. **********An Apolo waiter will courteously wipe a previous diner's dirty plate and cutlery on his sleeve and serve the next guest a piece of meat as tough as hippo. Then, if the guest is the sort who can sleep in a bowling alley, repose can be gained after flicking a bedbug off the pillow. Some time in the night the phone may ring. That would be the front desk demanding five days advance payment on the room, in hard currency. **********After a dark walk down and up, a man can end his day, his spirit kwisha, and he did.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/16/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration expressed concern today that the rise in ''tensions and rhetoric'' since President Anwar el-Sadat's assassination could produce ''an outbreak of hostilities'' in the Middle East. **********Dean Fischer, the State Department spokesman, read a statement asserting that the United States was trying ''to defuse'' the situation. **********Officials said that there were no signs of imminent hostilities, but that senior American officials thought it prudent to issue the statement in light of the volatile history of the region. **********'Confidence-Building' by U.S. **********Mr. Fischer said American military moves in the last week - including the dispatch of two Awacs radar surveillance planes to Egypt - were ''confidence-building and deterrent in character.'' The planes arrived in Egypt today and immediately began patrolling the western desert region along the Libyan border. (Page A10.) **********A senior Defense Department official said this afternoon that equipment would be taken directly from the United States armed forces and shipped to the Sudan to buttress Sudanese forces against threats posed by Libya. The equipment includes 20 M-60 tanks, tank transporters and a dozen 155-millimeter howitzers. **********In addition, the United States Air Force will provide the Sudan with two F-5F trainers, the first in the contemplated shipment of a dozen F-5's. **********Since Mr. Sadat's death, military forces have been placed on heightened alert in Libya, Egypt, the Sudan and Chad. So have American forces in the region. **********Mr. Fischer said the two Awacs, which are manned by United States Air Force crews, would be free to operate wherever necessary, including the Sudan. **********His statement took note of ''increased tension and state of military alerts in the area of Egypt and the Sudan.'' He went on to say that ''all of the security-related activities'' that the United States was taking with Egypt and the Sudan had ''the purpose of helping to defuse the tensions through deterring possible hostilities directed against them.'' 'An Outbreak of Hostilities' **********There have been reports that the Sudan was preparing, with Egypt's aid, to invade Chad and strike at Libyan forces there. In addition, the United States has been worried about a possible Egyptian attack across the border against Libya, even though publicly most of the American concern here has been about Libyan activities. **********When asked why the statement was made, Mr. Fischer said the United States was concerned that ''an escalation of tensions and rhetoric could feed on itself and lead to the precise thing we are trying to avoid, an outbreak of hostilities.'' **********After Mr. Sadat's death Mr. Haig and other officials issued a series of statements, addressed principally to Libya and the Soviet Union, warning them that the United States would take whatever steps were necessary to protect its friends in the region. **********Those warnings, the dispatch of the Awacs to Egypt and the reports of large-scale American military exercises next month with Egypt, Somalia, the Sudan and Oman have tended to create some tension, officials have conceded. **********Pentagon officials said that in recent days both Oman and the Sudan have indicated that they might decide to withdraw from the joint maneuvers. The officials attributed their apparent reluctance to propaganda from Libya. **********Some officials said the Libyans might regard the exercise as a sign of American support for an invasion of Libya. The said the Fischer statement was supposed to ease that concern and deter a possible Libyan attack.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/14/busin.body_text: **********First, there was Jell-O, a gelatin dessert, and its sales were good. Then General Foods created Jell-O pudding.  Now, if the giant food company has its way, there will be Jell-O Pudding Pops, frozen pudding on a stick. **********Conceived four years ago, test-marketed since 1978, Pudding Pops promises to be one of the most successful products to emerge in recent years from the General Foods kitchens. The company refuses to say when it will be introduced nationwide. But General Foods, which has already sunk millions of dollars into the new product, clearly has great hopes for Pudding Pops. **********''It's potentially a very large business,'' said Peter Rosow, general manager of the company's desserts division, who predicts that it will make major inroads on the lucrative ice cream market. **********Pudding Pops is only one new product at General Foods, which introduces several each year. Currently, it is also testing Jell-O Slice Creme, a freezer cake mix, and Jell-O Gelatin Pops, whipped gelatin on a stick. The Unfilled Niche **********These are just a few of hundreds of new products on which consumer goods companies annually gamble as they seek that increasingly elusive, but immensely profitable, unfilled niche in the marketplace. **********It is difficult to give a precise measure of the new-product business. According to Martin Friedman, editor of New Product News, 682 new food, household, beauty and health care products were introduced in the first six months of this year, an exceptionally high figure. However, other marketing experts quibble with Mr.  Friedman's criteria - he lists old products in new flavors and colors - and some even dispute the upward trend he detects, arguing that newproduct introductions reached a peak in the expansionist 1960's. **********But there is no dispute that the introduction of a new product is a high-risk venture. According to Mr. Rosow, only one in 10 consumer products that get to the test-market stage succeeds nationally. ''A lot of products go national and never get their original investment back,'' said Alden Clayton, managing director of the Marketing Science Institute, a Harvard-affiliated organization. **********General Foods takes more such gambles than most companies. The reason, apart from the company's sheer size and concentration on food, is that its volume comes from ''many mature food categories - coffee, gelatin,'' said Lawrence Adelman, a first vice president of Dean Witter Reynolds. ''So it has a greater need to launch new products.'' He added that General Foods outspends any other packaged food company on research and development: $79 million in 1980, $96 million budgeted for 1981. **********Jell-O pudding was a prime example of the ''mature'' food category. Although its business is large and highly profitable, the vast base was a barrier to major volume growth, which General Foods recently declared to be a key corporate objective. ''To grow dramatically, you have to introduce new products,'' Mr. Rosow said. A Snack-Time Problem **********At the same time, eating patterns had changed, to the detriment of Jell-O pudding. While mothers still wanted its ''wholesome goodness'' for their children, Mr. Rosow said, afternoon snacks such as ice cream and packaged cakes were usurping the place of conventional desserts that were not readily portable and required preparation time. ''The question was, 'How can we put pudding in the path of the afternoon snack opportunity'?'' said Mr. Rosow. ''What we did was to freeze it and put it on a stick.'' **********Even its flavors were borrowed from traditional Jell-O pudding: chocolate, vanilla, banana and butterscotch. The reason, Mr. Rosow said, is that ''its credentials are pudding credentials.'' **********General Foods scientists say that the development of Pudding Pops was not quite that simple, but the technology involved was certainly less sophisticated than that of other new General Foods products such as Lean Strips, a textured protein substitute for bacon, or frozen Crispy Cookin' french fries. The dessert division does have some higher-technology products under development, but with Pudding Pops, Mr. Rosow conceded, ''it is hardly the Manhattan Project.'' **********The big financial outlay, therefore, began with the marketing of Pudding Pops. In the preliminary stage, known as pre-test-marketing, General Foods researchers circulated a drawing and description of the product to households around the country. Encouraged by the response, the company manufactured and distributed door-to-door a limited sampling of Pudding Pops. The Best-Laid Plans . . . **********''However sophisticated the research, it's hard to rely on the information you get from consumers,'' Mr. Rosow said. ''People sometimes say things because they want to please you.'' Partly as a result, the best-laid marketing plans have sometimes gone awry. ''The company that brought you Pampers also brought you Pringles,'' he said, referring to the troubled history of Procter & Gamble's processed potato chip. **********Encouraged by consumer reaction, however, General Foods decided to test-market - a costly if cautious decision. In test-marketing, ''You have all the inefficiencies of small scale, in manufacturing and distribution,'' Mr. Rosow said. In 1978, Pudding Pops were introduced into stores in Cincinnati and Denver. Minneapolis and Salt Lake City followed a year later. Sales are said to be ''extremely good'' in all four test markets, where a box of a dozen Pudding Pops sells for $1.99. **********Another favorable sign is that Pudding Pops are being imitated by competitors, according to Mr. Rosow. Shortly after General Foods began test-marketing Pudding Pops, Popsicle Industries introduced Good 'n' Puddin'. The product is selling very well nationwide, said Eugene Welka, Popsicle's marketing director, who refused to comment on Mr. Rosow's view. **********The proliferation of rival products, as well as the expense of test-marketing, puts some pressure on General Foods to ''roll out'' Pudding Pops nationwide. ''The objective is to get a product national as quickly as possible,'' Mr. Rosow said. He refused to confirm or deny a suggestion by a competitor that Pudding Pops will roll out next month, or even to acknowledge that a decision has been made. **********It is important to get it right. ''By the time a product like Pudding Pops goes national, the up-front investment is really enormous, running into the tens of millions of dollars.'' Mr. Rosow said. **********Furthermore, ''it takes five to seven years to break into the black,'' he added, so General Foods must be sure that the product has enduring consumer appeal. ''All of us in this industry worry about the product that is a fad,'' he said. ''You never get your money back.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/world.print_headline: APARTHEID IS CRUMBLING ON BEACHES IN SOUTH AFRICA; The Talk of Cape Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/world.body_text: **********No country has gone further than South Africa in relying on statutes to shape society and social custom. But after decades of legislating on every conceivable aspect of race relations, the lawmakers are starting to find that changes occur spontaneously, without having been entered on their agendas. **********An example is the crumbling of apartheid on the glorious beaches of the Cape peninsula, which extends like a tiny comma from the bottom of a vast continent. **********It took plenty of lawmaking and law enforcement to get the various racial groups segregated on their various beaches, with the most handsome spots, the least windswept, going by scant coincidence to the people who picked the lawmakers. Apartheid did not come to the Cape's beaches until the 1960's and it was not until the 1970's that the great work of separation seemed to have been finally achieved. **********One can still see ''Whites Only'' signs and scent the fragrance of coconut oil, which indicates that the browning torsos in the vicinity were once of a paler hue. But wherever you look you are bound to see family groups that are obviously ignoring the signs. **********Mostly they belong to the people of mixed race who are classified here as coloreds and who account for a clear majority of the peninsula's population. There is no suggestion of a political act in their refusal to confine themselves any longer to what a white South African would describe as ''their own beaches.'' Indeed, they seem to think that they are on their own beaches, whatever the signs say. White Beaches Overwhelmed **********However, on certain days - major holidays like Christmas or New Year's Day, which fall in the summer here, -blacks as well as coloreds now overwhelm the white beaches. An Afrikaner editor of relatively liberal attitudes who was on such a beach last Christmas acknowledged that he found the experience disturbing enough to make him wonder how liberal he really was. A colored professor reacted differently. ''It was a good sight to see in Cape Town,'' he said.  ''This part of the country is one day going to wake up to the fact that it is part of Africa.'' **********On a typical weekend it is not an invasion so much as an infiltration, with colored families clustering at the edge of the white beaches. At St. James Beach on False Bay, the nonwhites mostly stayed on a rocky outcropping, going to the beach only when they were ready to face the pounding surf. But some set their canvas chairs up on the sand. **********Whites nearby seemed not to notice or care. A colored constable, who is technically supposed to enforce apartheid on the beaches but doesn't, looked on approvingly. The municipality of Cape Town, for which he works, has given up on apartheid on the beaches, he explained, leaving it to the provincial police, who remain unyielding. **********If whites complain to him, the constable said, he refers them to the provincial police and then goes to warn the coloreds in the vicinity that there is likely to be a scene. The penalty for being a nonwhite on a white beach is a fine of 50 rands, the equivalent of about $75, or 50 days in jail. **********''But the people are getting brainy,'' the constable said. ''They know there's safety in numbers.'' If there are enough of them, he said, the officials can either call out the riot policemen or leave the offenders alone. ''If they call out the riot police,'' he added, ''they'll have a riot and that's bad for the country's image.'' So gradually beach integration creeps up, like the tides. **********Looking for a new basis for exclusion, some white communities on the peninsula have decided to put up turnstiles and charge admission, shifting the standard from race to class. **********It is hard, sometimes, not to speak of a colored professor or a colored constable, because in almost any South African situation the category of race makes itself felt and words have to be found to express it. But politically alert people who carry identity cards that classify them as colored no longer use the word except ironically. **********As a political statement, expressing a sense of solidarity among all the disenfranchised, they prefer to call themselves blacks, but that leaves them without a convenient word for referring to Africans who are also called blacks. One circumlocution when distinctions become necessary is to refer to brown blacks and black blacks.  Another is to refer to so-called coloreds or to accompany the word colored with a plunking two-fingered gesture to indicate that quotation marks have been attached. ''It's so cumbersome,'' said a faculty member of the University of the Western Cape, an institution that is officially colored but ''so-called colored'' to most of its students. ''You have to define your terms every time you use them,'' he said. **********Though Richard van der Ross, rector of the university, said he was comfortable using ''black'' or ''colored,'' depending on context, ''so-called colored'' struck him as an absurdity because, he said, it seems to imply that those being described are not really coloreds and that there are some other people, somewhere else, who are. **********The term most offensive to Richard Rive, a novelist and critic, is ''nonwhite'' because it defines people negatively. ''But one does speak in terms these days of nonblacks,'' he said. **********Another man with a sense of political and linguistic nuance said the only tolerable circumlocution was to refer to ''those people classified as coloreds.'' Although he is happy to be called black, he said, ''the ideal is to achieve a common identity.'' **********One of the great lost causes of the apartheid era has been the fight to save District 6, a colored neighborhood in the center of Cape Town that was exuberant and often bawdy before the need for any redefinition was felt. District 6 was the closest thing to a ''homeland'' that the coloreds had in South Africa, but in 1966 it was proclaimed white under the Group Areas Act. **********What ensued was the 15-year bureaucratic equivalent of a guerrilla war between the functionaries of the Ministry of Community Development - a euphemism in this context since its purpose was removal, not development - and the local population, which evaded and resisted eviction notices. **********That struggle is nearly over now and the bureaucrats have plainly won. The population of the district, once 40,000, has fallen in the past year from more than 10,000 to barely 3,000; this time next year it will probably be zero.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/28/busin.body_text: **********Although shoppers were much in evidence on Saturday, many of the nation's merchants, after a difficult Christmas season, are facing the final month of their last 1981 fiscal quarter with discomfort. **********More than a few believe it will show the scars of erratic sales and the costly markdowns taken during the first four weeks of December.  The outlook for the fourth quarter, which for retailers ends on Jan. 31, is cloudy, a special source of concern since the period normally provides more than 50 percent of the year's profits and 30 percent of sales. But most analysts see the quarter's results as unchanged or down from the 1980 quarter. They also see it as an uncertain harbinger for the early months of the new fiscal year. **********'Still Cause for Concern' **********In addition to the spotty holiday sales, industry analysts say, the quarter may well end up suffering from weak January sales. **********''Sales volume for Christmas 1981 was ahead of last year for most retailers, with some companies showing healthy sales gains while most others were slightly ahead,'' said Robert M. Zimmerman, director of retail industry services for the Coopers & Lybrand accounting concern. ''Nevertheless, there is still cause for concern over fiscal 1981 retail performance figures.'' **********The accounting executive, noting that, ''for most retailers 1980 was a marginal year,'' said that any 1981 sales gain must be evaluated against that weak base. Extensive Price-Cutting Cited **********''In addition, price-cutting and price-shopping were extensive during this Christmas season, so that gross margin dollars will not increase in proportion to sales,'' he added. ''There is also a strong possibility that many of the off-price purchases made in December will reduce the traditional bargain shopping in January.'' **********One of the major hindrances to improvement in the final quarter, compared with a year earlier, is the inventory remaining.  Post-Christmas stocks are higher than most retailers would like, and it is likely that this will be so at the end of January as well. **********Over the weekend, stores from New York to Los Angeles and from Maine to Texas began their post-Christmas clearances in a sweeping effort to pare inventories and take advantage of the normal January bargain-hunting. Cuts of Up to 60 Percent **********The offerings, which carry price reductions of up to 60 percent from the original cost, represent the residue of unmoved holiday goods, seasonal merchandise and also new purchases committed for sale during the post-Christmas period. **********On Fifth Avenue in Manhattan on Saturday, sidewalks were almost impassable much of the morning and afternoon as hordes of family shoppers turned out. The Christmas windows at Saks Fifth Avenue drew waiting lines of onlookers three and four deep. Lord & Taylor had crowd directors to guide its window watchers, who wound around the block. **********In the stores, aisles were crowded and cash registers were ringing.  In the 34th Street area, the shopper stream was steady most of the day. Gimbels, Ohrbach's, Lerner's and particularly Macy's Herald Square were busy. The main floor at Macy's, with its overhanging wreaths and ''Nutcracker Suite'' music, and especially its crowds, resembled a typical day at the height of the pre-Christmas season. 'Expecting Big Things' **********At Gimbels, M. Ronald Ruskin, chairman of the 10-store Gimbels New York chain, said: ''We are expecting big things over the next few weeks. The break in the calendar will help, with Saturday, normally a big shopping day, being the first day after Christmas, against Friday last year, and the same for the New Year's weekend. Our attitude after our Christmas experience is that the consumer is being very selective, as shown by the fact that it was not the usual freefor-all Christmas. We intend to operate in the future convinced that that will be a major factor in consumer psychology.'' **********In Houston, Robert T. Sakowitz, chairman of Sakowitz Inc., an apparel specialty store chain in Texas and Arizona, said, however, that while consumers were being very selective they were also interested in advancing the seasons by seeing early selections. ''We brought in early spring goods in November and got a strong reaction that will help us on color and silhouette selection,'' he added. **********But Mr. Sakowitz, while savoring his company's strong 20 percent year-to-year sales gain in December thus far, also reflected views of other retailers by saying in a telephone interview: **********''The inventory turnover rate is the key to the business today, in a time of high inflation and high interest rates. In men's clothing, for example, it has been traditional for major suppliers to insist that retailers buy for the entire season and take delivery as it develops. But we decided not long ago to buy four to five times a year, with individual delivery each time. This gave us a chance to create new excitement with each arrival and it has improved our inventory turnover rate about 30 percent in that type of goods.'' Interested in Value **********Both retail executives observed that the recent holiday season showed that the public was especially interested in items with recognizable value and quality as opposed to entire lines of merchandise or storewide promotions. ''It's no more a matter of just filling up the selection to take space,'' Mr. Sakowitz said. **********Mr. Ruskin said, ''We cannot expect the consumer to get excited about advertising blouses at a third to a half off; it has to be a nationally branded blouse, with which the shopper can identify, and at values that she knows are real.'' **********In the meantime, the remainder of the all-important fourth quarter lies ahead. ''Basically, I think that the final quarter's earnings for most retailers will be from flat to down compared to 1980, but not disastrously,'' said Monroe H. Greenstein, senior analyst for Bear, Stearns & Company. **********''This year's Christmas was very promotional, but so was 1980's,'' he added. ''So we are not comparing poor gross margins with good gross margins a year ago; this year's final period, though, might be worse.'' **********The quarter's profits will be aided by lower last-in, first-out charges in inventory accounting than had been originally estimated because inflation has slowed in general merchandise, Mr. Greenstein added. ''Most estimates had been that the inflation rate would be between 6 and 7 percent,'' he went on, ''but my feeling is that it could come in the next reading and be applied to the final quarter at about 5.5 percent.'' Difficult Comparison Seen **********The Bear Stearns analyst predicted that retail earnings for the first 1982 fiscal quarter, which will begin Feb. 1, would be ''poor.'' He added: ''The recession will continue, with the consumer remaining very selective, while the comparable quarter in 1981 was much stronger than anyone expected. So the comparison with the prior year will be difficult, probably leading to small sales gains and a trend to declining earnings.'' **********Mr. Zimmerman, of Coopers & Lybrand, said, ''The 1981 fourth quarter will not be a disaster for most retailers but neither will it be the salvation of a generally mediocre year. And the first half of 1982 promises no relief. Sales demand is not expected to be strong and tight inventory control will continue to be mandatory.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/09/world.main_headline: MORE OIL PRICE CUTS SEEM LIKELY AS GLOBAL OVERSUPPLY CONTINUES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/09/world.print_headline: MORE OIL PRICE CUTS SEEM LIKELY AS GLOBAL OVERSUPPLY CONTINUES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/09/world.body_text: **********Day after day, reductions in the price of crude oil have been shaking the already unsettled world petroleum markets. And further price erosion seems inevitable, oil analysts and oil company officials said yesterday. **********As an indication that major oil producers will announce further price cuts soon, traders reported yesterday that spot prices for crude oil sold on a noncontract basis had plunged as low as $32 a barrel, roughly equal to the lowest official price charged by any member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. **********''This thing is really a zoo,'' said a top official of one international oil company. ''We have entered a totally new environment.'' **********Actions Taken Abroad **********Britain offered last Friday to drop the official price of its North Sea crude by $2 a barrel, an offer that refining companies rejected as not enough. And African oil producers, among those most aggressive on pricing in OPEC, are said to be offering discounts of as much as $4 a barrel from their official prices, which exceed $40 a barrel. **********Mexico, a major oil producer, has already announced a $4-a-barrel price cut, and Persian Gulf producers have eliminated the surcharges they formerly attached to official prices. Saudi Arabia, which accounts for 40 percent of OPEC production, charges $32 a barrel, and the price range among the other members of OPEC is from $36 to $41 a barrel. **********The present situation, oil analysts say, could give way to a wholly different kind of chaos. Speculation was rampant yesterday that Israel's surprise attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor might cause a retaliatory oil embargo, similar to the one in 1973, by Arab oilproducing states against the United States and other supporters of Israel. Some analysts also fear that Iran and Iraq, both of which have substantially increased oil output in recent months, may resume their war and be forced to cut production again. **********For the present, however, the price cuts are working to reduce the retail price of gasoline in the United States and to stir conjecture that OPEC's grip on the industrialized world may be weakening. The price cuts also demonstrate the power of the cartel's biggest producer, Saudi Arabia, to force its will on the other members by flooding the market with 10.3 million barrels of oil a day. **********Saudi Arabia's official production ceiling is 8.5 million barrels daily, but it increased the output to put downward pressure on prices. This rise in production created the current worldwide oil glut, with the oversupply estimated at 2 million to 3 million barrels daily. **********The Saudi goal is to force high-priced producers - Libya, Algeria and Nigeria in particular - to bring prices down. Most oil analysts think such moves are imminent. **********''Something has got to give on prices and give pretty quickly,'' said Ian Sanderson, coordinator of foreign crude oil supplies for the Phillips Petroleum Company. Saudis' Long-Term Plan **********Rumors persist in the oil industry that after such price reductions, or even before, the Saudis would raise their price to $34 from $32 in an attempt to unify their price with those in the rest of OPEC, where the current base price is $36 a barrel. This would provide a basis for introducing a long-term pricing plan that the Saudis favor, a plan that oil industry experts estimate would increase inflation-adjusted crude oil prices by approximately 2 to 3 percent annually. **********All the petroleum price reductions so far, as well as those expected to occur, will probably not be entirely passed on to consumers, who nonetheless have already seen gasoline prices decline by nearly 10 cents a gallon over the last few months, to an average national price of $1.35 a gallon. Pump prices might go down another 5 cents, analysts suggest. **********For every $1 change in the price of a barrel of crude oil, the price of a gallon of gasoline changes slightly more than 2 cents if all of the changes are passed along to motorists. Filling Strategic Reserve **********The Reagan Administration is taking advantage of the present soft prices to step up buying for the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve. By the end of this month, the reserve is expected to total 160 million barrels, a 40-million-barrel increase during the last four months. **********''Obviously we're doing our best to take advantage of things,'' said Danny Boggs, White House energy aide. ''We don't want to miss the turn in the market.'' **********In less than a week, following OPEC's inability to assert control over the situation at its meeting in Geneva, the new weakness of oil prices has been underscored by these developments: **********- Mexico, which exports about 700,000 barrels of oil a day to the United States, cut the price of its two principal grades of crude oil by $4 a barrel, an amount equivalent to 9.5 cents a gallon. **********- The British National Oil Company, which sets the price of the high-quality, low-sulfur crude produced in the British sector of the North Sea, offered to cut its price by $2 a barrel. A major oil company planner, calling the offer ''clearly inadequate'' to spur sales of North Sea oil, predicted it would have to be further reduced, perhaps by $5 a barrel. **********- Several smaller oil-producing countries have cut prices - Malaysia by 70 cents a barrel yesterday and Ecuador by $3.80 a barrel on Friday. **********- Oil traders say Libya, Algeria and Nigeria have been offering special discounts of as much as $4 a barrel on their oil. **********- Spot prices of almost every variety of oil in the world continue to fall. Industry officials reported yesterday that some Saudi crude, the least expensive in the world, was being offered on a spot basis for $32 a barrel, its official price. This represents a drop of $7.25 in the spot market so far this year. Fee on Imports Debated **********Talk is being heard in Congress that the time may be right to consider such measures as imposing a fee on imported oil. Such a step would increase prices in the United States, thereby continuing to dampen demand and lessening this country's dependence on foreign producers. **********Although such a move would be inflationary, it could benefit the Federal Treasury by billions of dollars. ''If the Saudis raise the price, they get the money,'' argued an aide to a Democratic Senator.  ''If we raise the price, we get the money.'' **********''We should accelerate moves to make the glut a permanent fixture,'' said Elihu Bergman, executive director of Americans for Energy Independence. He urges taking advantage of the producers' current lack of power to push rapid conversion to alternative fuels and to encourage energy conservation efforts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today formally appealed a regulatory decision that raised its profit margin to 10.87 percent, instead of the 13 percent it had requested. **********In a filing with the Federal Communications Commission, the telephone company charged that the Feb. 5 decision by an administrative law judge was ''grossly inadequate to reflect the level of earnings necessary under today's economic and financial conditions'' and said the decision could hinder its efforts to raise capital for modernization and expansion. **********As a regulated utility, A.T.& T.'s profits are not allowed to exceed a specified percentage of its rate base, or total investment.  That percentage is calculated on the basis of the company's capital structure and what it costs to raise money on the stock market and pay off debts on bonds. **********A.T.& T. announced earlier this month that its 1980 profit margin was 9.91 percent. It is the first United States company ever to post earnings of more than $6 billion in a calendar year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/busin.main_headline: BIG THREE AUTO SALES UP BY 8.5%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/busin.print_headline: BIG THREE AUTO SALES UP BY 8.5%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/busin.body_text: **********Despite one of the most lucrative customer rebate programs in the auto industry's history, the Big Three auto makers reported today that sales rose only 8.5 percent in early March from the comparable period last year. Some analysts attributed the slow sales to continuing problems in the general economy. **********''Sales are not as strong as I would have expected, given the rebates,'' said Harvey Heinbach of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. ''The rates of sales are much slower than what we had in February, when rebates were kicked off,'' he added. The costly rebate programs have been beneficial to the dealers, however, he said, because increased sales help reduce costly inventories that require high-interest loans to carry. **********The rebates, which range from $500 to more than $1,000, are scheduled to expire at G.M., Ford and Chrysler by March 21.  Another analyst, Arvid Jouppi of John Muir & Company, said he was not disappointed in the sales levels. ''There is a latent demand for cars,'' he said. ''If the consumer is given any incentive at all, he'll go for it, as is evidenced by the most recent periods.'' Slowdown Is Expected **********Both agreed that, because of the increased sales resulting from rebates, a period of slower sales would follow, probably in April.  This is the traditional beginning of the spring selling season, when sales levels usually increase. **********Total industry sales in the March 1 through 10 period, including those at Volkswagen of America and an estimate of sales for the American Motors Corporation, were 204,031, up 8.6 percent from last year, when sales were off sharply as a result of the recession, rising gasoline prices and the attraction of smaller, fuel-efficient foreign cars. There were eight selling days in both periods. **********The Chrysler Corporation, which has been offering a 7 percent rebate, showed the most significant increase in year-to-year sales gains - up 51.2 percent, to 25,900 new cars this year, from 17,128 last year. Chrysler's rebate program began Dec. 4 and was extended recently to run through March 17. Chrysler has also held prices steady, while the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company had recent increases. **********General Motors, which is offering $500 to $700 rebates on most of its smaller models, reported an increase of 7 percent in the period, to 125,549 new cars, from 117,296 last year. G.M. sold 61.5 percent of all domestic cars sold in the early March period; Volkswagen's market share was 1.9 percent, while Ford held 21.7 percent, and Chrysler 12.7 percent. **********Ford was the only domestic producer to show a year-to-year decline in the latest period - down 3.6 percent, to 44,227 new cars this year, from 45,871 last year. Ford was also the only company to have rebates at this time last year. The Ford rebate program of shaving 10 percent from the base price of some models allows the customer a rebate on cars ordered now for future delivery, but whose sale will not be reported for several weeks. Neither G.M. nor Chrysler has this rebate provision. Optimism at Ford **********Ford officials remained optimistic about future sales: ''The consumer cash programs are breaking up the industry's sales logjam,'' said Philip E. Benton Jr., vice president of sales for Ford's North American operations. **********Volkswagen sales increased 5.4 percent on sales of 3,855 cars, compared with 3,657 last year. Industry estimates put American Motors' sales in the period at 4,500 units, up 14 percent from 3,943 sold in the period last year. The company reports sales on a monthly basis only. **********For the year to date, in which there were 58 selling days, compared with 59 last year, General Motors sales were down 12.3 percent and Ford sales were down 12.7 percent. Chrysler sales were up 14.1 percent. **********The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for the first 10 days of March was 8.7 million cars, which would be total sales for the year if the most recent rate were typical of the entire period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/busin.main_headline: I.T.T. EARNINGS OFF 50% IN FIRST QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/busin.print_headline: I.T.T. EARNINGS OFF 50% IN FIRST QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/busin.body_text: **********Earnings by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation tumbled 50.1 percent in the first quarter, the company disclosed at the annual meeting here today. **********The company said its net income was $173 million, or $1.17 a share, for the first quarter of this year, down from $347 million, or $2.38 a share, in the first quarter of 1980. Revenues were $5.5 billion in both quarters. **********Rand V. Araskog, chairman, president and chief executive officer, attributed the downturn to losses on translating foreign currencies into dollars. In addition, he said, the quarterly earnings figure was reduced because of I.T.T.'s settlement of a lawsuit brought by the Internal Revenue Service over its 1970 acquisition of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company. In the settlement, announced last week, I.T.T. agreed to pay the Government $17.8 million. Operating Improvement Expected **********The company said that its revenues and operating earnings would be higher for 1981 than they were in 1980, with the gain experienced largely during the second half of the year. However, because of Federal accounting requirements covering the translation of foreign currencies, Mr. Araskog said, reported earnings may be lower. **********Mr. Araskog described as ''frivolous and silly'' the ruling by a Federal Trade Commission judge yesterday that the Continental Baking Company, an I.T.T. subsidiary, had engaged in anticompetitive practices, adding that I.T.T. would appeal the ruling by Miles J.  Brown, an administrative law judge in Washington. **********''It would be ridiculous for us to try and run a business in the mode set by some administrative judge,'' he said.  Yesterday, Mr. Brown recommended that the Federal Trade Commission consider ordering the huge communications and manufacturing conglomerate to divest itself of Continental, which is said to be the world's largest baker of bread. He ruled that Continental, which makes Wonder Bread, Hostess cakes and other well-known products, had engaged in unfair price competition for nearly 15 years. Defends Fees for Directors **********Mr. Araskog also responded to several questions regarding his own position and the compensation given to the company's top executives. **********The executive, who is 48 years old, defended his company's policy of paying $6,000 annual fees to the six I.T.T. officials who also sit on the company's board of directors. He asserted that the fees ''are really inadequate'' because board membership is considered entirely separate from executive duties, and because the I.T.T. employees sit on no other boards of directors. **********Mr. Araskog also asserted that the I.T.T. board had no immediate intention of restructuring the company's top management by separating the positions of chairman, chief executive officer and president. **********I.T.T., which is based in New York, reported net income of $894 million last year on sales of $23.8 billion. In addition to its huge telecommunication operations, it produces automotive products, consumer food products, semiconductors and other electronics equipment and home appliances and owns the Sheraton hotel chain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/28/busin.main_headline: Business People; New President of Todd To Stress Ship Repair
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/28/busin.print_headline: Business People; New President of Todd To Stress Ship Repair
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Hans K. Schaefer, 45, has been elected president of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, effective July 15. He will succeed Arthur W.  Stout Jr., 60, who is taking early retirement. J.T. Gilbride, 65, continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the New Yorkbased company. **********Although new ship construction is the largest segment of the corporation's business, Mr. Schaefer said that he intended to concentrate primarily on ''expanding our commercial and Navy repair activities.'' He added that ''in the market of the future, we see an increase in repair and overhaul of foreign ships coming to our shores as well as Navy ships being reactivated.'' **********Todd, the largest independent shipbuilding company in the United States, has seven yards: in Brooklyn, Seattle, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Galveston, Tex., Houston and New Orleans. **********Mr. Schaefer, who was born in Germany, served an apprenticeship at the Deutsche Werft shipyards in Hamburg. ''I think it is a prerequisite of our type of business to know the hardware and what is required to get an understanding of the complexities of the job,'' he said. **********Mr. Schaefer emigrated to Canada in 1956 and subsequently worked for three shipbuilding companies there. He came to Todd in 1968 as an engineer and was named two years ago to his present posts of vice president of the Todd Pacific Shipyards subsidiary and general manager of the Los Angeles division. **********Mr. Stout joined Todd in 1937, but left in 1955 to work first for the Avondale Shipyard Corporation and then for the New York Shipbuilding Company. He rejoined Todd in 1967 as general manager of the Houston division and became president eight years later. **********Mr. Shaefer observed that the company currently had a backlog of $1.6 billion, its largest in history. ''I have to get to know the other divisions,'' he said. ''So I'll be doing a little bit of traveling and touching the hardware.'' Leonard Sloane

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/16/busin.body_text: **********The failure of Federal regulators to share information or react quickly enough permitted speculators in silver to build large holdings and drive up market prices for the metal during 1979 and early 1980, according to a Congressional report released today. **********The soaring prices, which eventually led to the virtual collapse of the silver futures market, had a detrimental effect on consumers of products like film, X-rays, hearing-aid batteries and electrical conductors, a report by the House Government Operations Committee said. **********Despite what it called a disorderly market situation, the report said the Commodity Futures Trading Commission took no preventive or emergency action, even though it had the duty and the information to do so. **********None of the Federal regulatory agencies responsible for financial markets exchanged information on the situation until the week silver prices collapsed, the report said. **********A summary of the report, prepared by the Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs Subcommittee, laid the cause for the increase in silver prices to actions by W. Herbert and Nelson Bunker Hunt, billionaire brothers from Dallas, and ContiCommodity Services Inc., a commodity futures brokerage. **********Silver prices rose to more than $50 an ounce in January 1980 before plummeting to less than $11 an ounce by April.  ''In fact, by December of 1979, the two groups owned outright and controlled through futures contracts, more than 250 million ounces, almost 100 million more ounces of silver than the United States used during all of 1978,'' the report said. **********But in a statement, W. Herbert Hunt described the committee report as being only ''about half right.'' ''It brings out the conflict of interest positions of several exchange board governors who changed the rules of the market,'' Mr.  Hunt said. ''But the allegation that my brother and I attempted to corner the silver market is false. **********The report called for Federal regulations to be changed to emphasize prevention of market manipulation rather than reaction to it, to place strict limits on the number of futures contracts one speculator can control, to review the ''self-regulatory'' structure of market exchanges, and impose strict minimums on futures trading margins, the amount of cash down payment required to order a futures contract.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/world.main_headline: STACKS OF MAIL AWAIT ARRIVAL OF U.N. CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/world.print_headline: STACKS OF MAIL AWAIT ARRIVAL OF U.N. CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/world.body_text: **********Stacks of mail - more than 1,000 letters, cards and telegrams bearing postmarks from around the world - await Javier Perez de Cuellar on Jan. 1 when he moves into his new office as Secretary General. **********The mail contains everything from congratulations to advice on how to run the world to the promotion of pet projects. The letters come from presidents, prime ministers, diplomats, United Nations staff members and concerned citizens. **********Vice President Bush, Fidel Castro of Cuba, Prime Minister Surya Bahadur Thapa of Nepal and Juvenal Habyarimana, the President of Rwanda, have written. But letters from world dignitaries are outnumbered by those from untitled correspondents. **********The mail is collected by Emilio de Olivares of Peru. He works on the staff of the outgoing Secretary General, Kurt Waldheim, and will move to a job with the inner cabinet of Mr. Perez de Cuellar, his longtime Peruvian friend. 'Greater Peace and Justice' **********''Freeze the arms race,'' reads the cover of a red-and-white Christmas card from a North Manchester, Ind., resident. Inside, he wrote, ''Our fervent wish is that your office will guide the world to greater peace and justice through a strengthened United Nations.'' **********Mr. de Olivares withheld the name of the author of this letter, as he withheld those of others that have not been answered.  A former pilot from Ohio suggested building a railway around the world to promote global harmony. Two New Yorkers, perhaps upset over the stock market, sent a mailgram that read, ''Thank God you are not an economist.'' **********Letters from third-world countries frequently expressed pleasure at the selection of a Secretary General from a developing nation. The writers said they hoped that Mr. Perez de Cuellar would devote his attention to improving their lot. **********''God Almighty has chosen you not only as the spokesman for the superpowers but an Ambassador (a messenger) to tell the superpowers of their responsibility to poor, illiterate, backward peoples of Latin America, Africa and Asia,'' said an engineering professor from Dacca, Bangladesh, in a typewritten, three-page letter. Hobbies and Interests Cited **********Some of those writing Mr. Perez de Cuellar appeared to be trying to drum up business. A partner in a Syracuse law firm sent his congratulations. He also enclosed a brochure extolling his firm's work for third-world clients. **********Some correspondents wrote of their hobbies and interests.  A man from Skokie, Ill., proposed a musical dictionary substituting notes for words. For example, he wrote, the note A could mean ''all'' or ''beginning;'' A-sharp could stand for ''humans;'' B for ''other,'' and what he called a ''B quartersharp'' could mean ''love.'' How this might improve communication he did not say. **********''I wish for Mr. de Cuellar to carry out total success for our Negro Catholic Society,'' an elderly man from Jacksonville, Fla., said in his letter, written in a shaky scrawl across six pages. A 72-year-old Canadian wrote to complain that his country still owed symbolic allegiance to a British monarch. Not All Letters Are Friendly **********A family from Newton, Mass., sent a privately printed, illustrated and bound copy of two original Christmas tales in rhyme. The inscription read, ''Best wishes for your important work toward collaboration and world sharing and peace.'' **********Not all of the mail was friendly. An Atlantan wrote: ''It is time for the U.S. to resign from the U.N. and get the U.N. out of our country. The U.N. is a luxury and we can no longer afford luxuries.  We are sick and tired of carrying your burden.'' **********But a man from Hyderabad, India, voiced the most common sentiment.  His letter said, ''Let flowers shower on you for every spectacular deed and let you be the pearl in the eyes of people of the world.''
