There was no explanation on when or why the offer was later increased.  Adobe is active in the United States, Canada and in the Dutch sector of the North Sea. Last year it earned $21.4 million on sales of $154.4 million. **********Francana, an oil and gas exploration company with operations mainly in Canada, earned $32.7 million (Canadian) last year on sales of $133.8 million. It is 58 percent owned by the Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company, whose principal shareholder is the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa. **********A Williams spokesman said his company had not raised its offer because ''we didn't want to get in a bidding war'' with Francana. He said the company had not decided what action, if any, it would take.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.main_headline: BREZHNEV REBUTS REAGAN VIEW OF U.S.-SOVIET RIVALRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.print_headline: BREZHNEV REBUTS REAGAN VIEW OF U.S.-SOVIET RIVALRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Embassy released a letter today from Leonid I. Brezhnev to President Reagan, challenging Mr. Reagan's picture of Soviet-American global competition but urging that the two leaders augment their correspondence with a personal meeting because ''private conversation is better.'' **********''We do not seek confrontation with the U.S.A. nor do we wish to infringe upon legitimate American interests,'' Mr. Brezhnev said. He echoed President Reagan's comments that a meeting between the two ''should be well prepared'' and suggested that ''we could yet return to the questioning of its timing, I believe, at a moment acceptable to both of us.'' **********The Soviet leader wrote to Mr. Reagan on May 25 in response to the President's letter of April 24, written during Mr. Reagan's stay in the hospital after he had been shot. In his speech Wednesday, Mr.  Reagan quoted extensively from his April letter, and Soviet officials said this was what prompted the release of the Brezhnev response. **********No New Political Initiatives **********The portions of the Reagan-Brezhnev correspondence disclosed by both sides in the last 72 hours have revealed no previously unknown diplomatic or political moves. Instead, they contain fairly familiar political debate and disagreement between Moscow and Washington, much of which has been reflected in public statements by the two Governments. **********The Soviet leader blamed the United States, specifically the Carter Administration and, by implication, even Mr. Reagan himself during the years he was out of office, for the deterioration in Soviet-American relations. **********Then, as if warning the President of the political risks in letting a chill fall over Soviet-American relations, Mr. Brezhnev commented that ''in the final analysis, let us be frank, it brought no laurels to Carter.'' **********''Isn't it so, Mr. President?'' he asked.  He took the Reagan Administration to task for expanding on the Carter Administration's efforts to revitalize the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, for seeking to extend the American military presence into the Persian Gulf region and for throwing the mantle of American protection over that area. 'Through Our Eyes' **********''Try, Mr. President, to see what is going on through our eyes,'' Mr. Brezhnev wrote. ''Attempts are being made to revitalize the U.S.- made military and political alliances; new bases are being added to those which already exist thousands of kilometers away from the U.S.A. and are aimed against our country; the American military presence abroad, in general, is being increased and expanded; large areas of the world are being declared spheres of 'vital interest' to the U.S.A.'' **********In response to Mr. Reagan's earlier objections to the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, Mr. Brezhnev argued that ''there should be no double standards,'' evidently implying that Soviet action there was no different from other American interventions abroad. **********Moreover, he complained that the United States intention was being ''openly announced in Washington to go on supplying arms'' to what he described as the ''the bands'' raiding Afghanistan ''from the outside.'' He seemed to imply that anti-Communist insurgency in Afghanistan was entirely a matter of incursions from beyond Afghan frontiers. An Appeal for Negotiations **********While he acknowledged ideological ''differences of opinion'' with Mr. Reagan, Mr. Brezhnev included in his lengthy letter an appeal for ''honest and constructive negotiations'' on ''practically all major questions existing between us - be it restraining the arms race, eliminating the most dangerous sources of tension in various areas of the world, or measures for confidence-building and developing a mutually beneficial cooperation.'' **********He closed with another push for the summit meeting that he first suggested in a speech to the 26th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party on Feb. 23. **********Although Mr. Reagan and his top policy advisers have responded positively, they have not wanted to seem overly eager for a Reagan-Brezhnev meeting and have repeatedly insisted on the need for adequate and lengthy preparations. **********The Reagan Administration took office convinced that Mr. Carter had displayed too great an eagerness for negotiations and top-level meetings with the Soviet Union and that Moscow had used this as leverage to gain negotiating concessions. **********In his letter, Mr. Brezhnev also seemed at pains not to be in too much of a rush for a meeting with Mr. Reagan, a topic that he reportedly raised in another letter sent in October that has not yet been released.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/19/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; THE TURNAROUND AT U.S. STEEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/19/busin.body_text: **********It was a dramatic turnabout at the United States Steel Corporation - a return to a profitable year. But surprising to industry analysts was the report that even the company's steel division, despite a decline in shipments, was in the black. **********The company, which reported 1980 earnings of $504.5 million, following a loss of $293 million the year before, has attributed the improvement to sharp manpower reductions, more efficient use of plant and equipment and a high level of capital spending, and stresses that it will continue along this course. **********The turnabout in the steel division, during a period when industry shipments declined 16 percent, to 84 million tons, and most of U.S.  Steel's plants operated at 50 percent capacity, was a dramatic one, analysts said. They recalled that in 1979, when steel shipments had climbed to a robust 100 million tons, the steel division of the nation's largest steel company had lost money. **********''Considering the operating rate,'' said Charles A. Bradford, the steel industry analyst for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., ''that's a monumental achievement.'' **********Even if the company announces in its annual report, when the operating profit of each segment will be broken out, that steel showed only a small profit, he said, ''that's still a hell of an improvement.'' **********He shared the view of David M. Roderick, the company's chairman, however, that U.S. Steel still has a long way to go in improving its steel business. ''It's gone from a bad company,'' Mr. Bradford said, ''to an average company.'' Plant Closings a Factor **********Mr. Roderick, who took over as chairman in 1979, has brought the company through a period of consolidation and a redeployment of its assets. Interviewed in the company's Washington office, he cited a number of reasons for the turnaround in steel, but emphasized that the permanent closing of 15 older plants with the loss of 12,500 jobs in November 1979 was one of the most important steps. That drastic action resulted in a loss of $561.7 million in the fourth quarter of 1979. **********''Thank God we did it,'' he said. He estimated that if the closed plants had been in operation last year, the company would have run up a loss of more than $100 million. **********The closings permitted management to concentrate on turning around more viable plants. It was also an incentive to the remaining problem plants such as Fairfield in Alabama, the Gary and South Works in the Chicago area and the works in Beaumont, Tex., to work hard to turn their plants around. 'The Clock Was Running' **********''Let's face it, when you do what we did in '79, I think you create a sense of urgency,'' Mr. Roderick said. Local management and the rank and file, he added, realized that ''the clock was running.'' **********Thoughout 1980 Mr. Roderick reminded them of the clock with repeated warnings that such plants would be closed unless cuts in manpower and more efficient use of equipment brought considerable improvement in productivity. **********Mr. Roderick noted that there would be a continuing drive to increase yield by using less manpower.  The number of blast furnaces, which are used to make iron from which steel is smelted, has been reduced to 27 from 46. The company's capacity to produce raw steel, however, is expected to shrink to about 34 million tons from the 38 million produced in 1978. Spending Remains High **********Mr. Roderick emphasized, however, that it was too simple to point only to manpower reductions. Another major reason for the the greater efficiency in steel, he explained, was that the company kept capital spending at a high level even though orders for the steel industry were low in three of the last five years. **********''We've spent $6.8 billion, much of it in the last five years,'' he said, seated on a beige couch in his office.  Only a part of the money went into steel, however, with a major share spent for diversification into chemicals.  Mr. Roderick still maintains, however, that new spending will go to those businesses that provide the highest rate of return. Chemicals, oil and gas and coal thus may be given precedence over steel in the competition for capital investment. Cash Reserve Increased **********Not that U.S. Steel is short of money. For most of the year, it has been building up its cash reserves, which will stand at about $1.5 billion at the end of the first quarter. **********The purpose of increasing its cash, Mr. Roderick said, was to prevent borrowing under current high interest rates and to have money on hand should an attractive acquisition in chemicals, coal or natural gas and oil come along. **********As for steel, he predicted that investment would be directed toward rapidly expanding segments such as goods for oil countries. Such goods are in heavy demand as a result of increased oil drilling. **********Though capital spending will increase to about $1.3 billion this year, compared with $975 million last year, most steel plants will have to try to increase their efficiency with existing equipment. **********Frank M. Hogan Jr., superintendent of the Fairless Works, for example, dreams of the time he can replace his outdated open hearth furnaces with modern basic oxygen furnaces that produce steel faster and cheaper. **********Such a shop, however, would cost more than $300 million, an investment that the company is unlikely to make under the present return. Mr. Hogan is optimistic, however, that the investment eventually will be made. Japanese Technology Studied **********Thus he has put emphasis on increasing quality and efficiency.  Several of his managers have gone to Japan to study technology and production methods there. **********Mr. Hogan said that on a scale of 1 to 10, the Fairless Works operated at a level of ''about 3'' in production efficiency, compared with what he would like to see. ''We've just scratched the surface,'' he said, ''But we have started.'' **********He is also exploring the possibility of adopting the idea of quality circles used in Japanese plants under which groups of workers and immediate superiors are made responsible for meeting certain standards of quality. **********The frank acknowledgement of the superiority of Japanese methods is the result of a more pragmatic attitude of Mr. Roderick and William R. Roesch, the president. In the past, the company sought to develop much of its own technology; now its executives emphasize that U.S.  Steel will turn to whomever has the best. While the Japanese could not be copied exactly, Mr. Hogan said, ''You can take the principles and improve things.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/13/busin.body_text: **********Philip H. Dougherty Filling A Niche With Beer **********NEAL W. KAYE Jr., a young man with big ideas, was in town from New Orleans last week to see about getting his beer sold in Europe. He does not have a brewery but that has not stopped him so far. **********Mr. Kaye has been selling Coy International Private Reserve down home since February. And down home they know where the beer's name comes from. They know that the Kayes pronounce their name Coy. That goes for both Junior and Senior, who are president and chairman, respectively, of Neal W. Kaye Inc., a major beer wholesaler that sells about 40 brands of beer in the New Orleans market, including Schlitz, for whom the father worked from 1947 to 1968. The senior Mr. Kaye is also president-elect of the National Beer Wholesalers Association. **********What has the industry watching the Kayes is their historic move of separating the manufacturing function from the marketing function in the beer business. **********Having perceived a niche in the market, the Kayes had a formula concocted by a brewmaster and are now lining up independent brewers to turn out Coy with their excess capacity with the goal of becoming a national and international brand. **********In a visit here the other morning, Neal Kaye Jr., who is 33 years old, made it all sound possible. Coy is already selling in six states and Mr. Kaye was about to go to his second meeting with Henry Verbruggen, a Brussels business consultant, who, he said, was instrumental in getting Wrigley's and Mars candies into European distribution. **********Mr. Kaye thinks that while the American brewing industry, led by Philip Morris' Miller, prefers light beers, the products of the baby boom (like himself) have matured enough to desire more flavorful brews. To fulfill such a desire, he maintains that they must turn to something like Heineken, the Dutch import. **********''I know the public is in the market for taste,'' Mr. Kaye said, ''and they can't get it in an American beer, at least for a decent price.'' **********That's the niche.  And with filling it in mind, the Kayes went to the brewmaster at the Pearl Brewing Company in San Antonio who brewed a combination of beer and ale. The junior Mr. Kaye is expecting the taste to do much of the selling because, comparatively speaking, Coy does not get that much of an advertising boost. **********''Beer,'' he remarked, ''doesn't have to be high-spending. There have been some that weren't, like Heinekin and Moose Head.  ''Spontaneous combustion occurs when all the elements are right,'' he said.  The brand has gotten some advertising, like the billboard that says, ''The first great international beer brewed in America.'' And then there is the themeline, ''The world belongs to you.'' **********The agency is Watts Wall & Associates, New Orleans, through which the Kayes spent about $50,000 for initial advertising - radio beginning in mid-April and running through Memorial Day, and billboards up for the month of May. **********Mr. Kaye also said that he believes that a wholesaler can motivate retailers to recommend a brew to consumers. He seems also to believe that anyone can sell well at a low price because that is what he has been doing in his own territory. Coy is in sixth place after Schlitz and Dixie, fourth and fifth best sellers in New Orleans. But it is ahead of Heienken, Pabst and Old Milwaukee. **********All the beer is coming from Pearl Brewing and is moving through wholesalers in Texas, Arkansas, Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia, where the advertising programs are co-op and where, unlike New Orleans, the brand is generally selling at premium prices. Young Mr.  Kaye is talking to other brewers to line up manufacturing and distribution in the rest of the country. **********''The brewers love the idea,'' he said, ''and the wholesalers want a number of products so that they can hedge their bets.'' Now let's wait to hear from the beer drinkers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/23/world.body_text: **********President Hafez al-Assad of Syria flew to Saudi Arabia today in the first stop of a tour of the Arabian Peninsula to work out a common Arab strategy in response to Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights. **********The Syrian President, who heads the hard-line Steadfastness Front, began his journey in Riyadh in what seemed to be an attempt at reconciliation with the leaders of the moderate Arab camp. **********It was largely Syria's boycott that led to the failure of the recent Arab League meetiing at Fez to back the Saudi peace plan for the Middle East. **********Damascus hopes to win broad Arab backing for concrete action if Israel fails to heed the demand of the United Nations Security Council that it rescind the annexation of the Golan Heights, according to official Syrian sources. The Security Council unanimously adoped a resolution last week declaring Israel's action ''null and void'' and threatening to take ''appropriate measures'' if the decision is not reversed. **********Considering the annexation a violation of earlier Security Council resolutions, the United States supported the Syrian-proposed resolution. It also suspended the new strategic cooperation accord with Israel. **********Nevertheless, the United States Embassy in Damascus has informed the Syrian Government that the United States would not vote for any Security Council resolution calling for sanctions against Israel, American sources said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.main_headline: 2 Hurt and Property Attacked In Sri Lankan Ethnic Violence
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.print_headline: 2 Hurt and Property Attacked In Sri Lankan Ethnic Violence
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.body_text: **********Two people were seriously hurt and shops and vehicles were set on fire yesterday in fresh outbreaks of violence between two Sri Lankan ethnic groups, a Government spokesman said today. **********The disturbances between the nation's majority Sinhalese and the minority Tamils occurred mainly in Ratnapura, a rich gem mining and rubber producing district 40 miles southeast of Colombo. Fourteen people were arrested. There were sporadic incidents in other areas, where security forces also made several arrests, the spokesman said. **********The Government-run Ceylon Daily News said most of the violent incidents involved arson and looting. President J.R. Jayewardene called out troops on Wednesday night and gave them special powers to quell the violence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/01/busin.body_text: **********Compact Passat cars designed by Volkswagenwerk A.G. of West Germany will be built in Japan by the Nissan Motor Company, the No.2 Japanese auto maker announced in Tokyo. **********Nissan, which makes Datsun cars, said production is expected to begin in the spring of 1983, at the rate of about 4,000 to 5,000 cars a month. **********The auto makers would not provide further details about the location and size of the project. **********The cars will be front-wheel-drive models, powered by 1,500-cubiccentimeter engines. The two companies had already agreed to build West German cars in Japan and negotiations on the project had been under way since late last year. **********The talks that led to the agreement were viewed as part of VW's strategy to meet what it considers a greater threat from United States auto makers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/21/busin.main_headline: A MAKER OF MIRRORS FINDS A NEW PLANT IN BROOKLYN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/21/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; A MAKER OF MIRRORS FINDS A NEW PLANT IN BROOKLYN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/21/busin.body_text: **********It would not insult Seldon Barlow to be accused of achieving his success with mirrors.  Quite the contrary. He and a partner founded Marsel Mirror & Glass Products with $1,900 in 1947. Now it is a $25 million-a-year business, making the decorative mirrors that K mart, Woolworth's, Sears and other chains and houseware stores sell for $5 to $20. Some bear legends such as ''Home Sweet Home'' or ''Drink Pepsi-Cola.'' Some show scenes of nature or cuddly puppies. Some are merely mirrors. **********The company had only six employees in its first five years. It was using vacuum-formed plastic frames - the first in the industry to use plastic rather than metal, Mr. Barlow said -and toodled along with a handful of products for a few years until someone thought of rounding the tops and bottoms of long rectangular door mirrors.  Plastic was just right for that. **********''People thought it was a joke, making an oval mirror,'' he said, ''but it went over like the Hula-Hoop.'' **********In three years, sales went to a million dollars from $300,000 on that item alone. The oval door mirror, Marsel's bread-and-butter product, now retails for about $12. **********Oval mirrors are only one of 180 mirror products Marsel makes now.  In recent years it has outgrown the space it occupies in a handful of multilevel industrial buildings at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, where it has a tenant for 10 years. So two years ago Marsel began what has been a periodic undertaking since it came into being in the back of a knitting store on South Fifth Street hard by the Williamsburg Bridge. It began to look elsewhere. **********One by one the company rejected, among other possibilities, the College Point Industrial Park, the former Rheingold brewery and the former Brooklyn Army Terminal. New construction was deemed too timeconsuming. The Army Terminal property, which the Koch administration hopes to see rehabilitated as industrial space, Mr.  Barlow described as unacceptable because of low ceilings and not enough clear space between support columns on the floors. ''The basic structure is unsound for industry,'' he said. **********Eventually he chose an eight-year-old building at 101-01 Foster Avenue in the Flatlands Industrial Park, which the Board of Education's central repair shop had occupied on a lease. In a contraction of its repair operation, the ''shop'' was moving from the immense two-level building. It has 320,000 square feet of clear space on two floors. **********Marsel signed a 12-year lease at about $2.50 a square foot last September with the Rentar Development Corporation, the developer of the Flatlands Industrial Park, and is refitting the interior itself.  Production operations are gradually moving in. The move is to be completed next month. George Sachs of the State Commerce Department coordinated the relocation. The lease arrangements were handled by R.B. Miller Realty and J.B. Greiner Realty. **********Marsel Mirror is the kind of company that officials strive to hold in the city, sometimes successfully, sometimes not. It is laborintensive. Of the 600 employees, 500 are production workers who are unskilled when they start. Soon, they are spraying or wiping paint onto frames, or affixing plastic framing on glass, or air-gunning fittings onto mirrors for hanging. Of the 500 workers, about half earn under $10,000 a year. **********The products are hand-assembled. ''It's very hard to automate this,'' said Jack Feldman, the plant manager, as gloved employees wrapped the pliable plastic frames around mirrors. **********About 60 percent of the workers live within a mile of the plant.  The availability of this labor pool is a big factor keeping Marsel in Brooklyn, Mr. Barlow said. The subway stops almost across the street from the new plant, but also there is more parking space there. A larger number of workers are expected to drive to work. **********In the new location, Mr. Barlow expects to expand to about a thousand employees within two years.  At the Navy Yard, Richard J. Aneiro, president of the Commerce Labor Industry Corporation of Kings, known as Click, which manages the yard for the city, said that 100,000 square feet of the Marsel space had already been leased by the expanding Cumberland Packing Corporation, makers of Sweet 'n Low, a big Navy Yard tenant. A company from Manhattan is taking 60,000 square feet. **********Rents at the yard range from about $1.50 to $2.50 a square foot, with separate billing for steam. The Navy Yard has 4.3 million square feet of industrial space in addition to its drydocks and piers. **********In the Flatlands, Rentar built 12 buildings with about two million square feet of industrial space in the 1968-72 period on 96 acres of urban renewal land leased from the city. But now it is negotiating to turn back the five remaining sites to the city, which is doing its own industrial development on city-owned land through the Public Development Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/busin.main_headline: GAF HEAD STEPS DOWN AFTER 10 MONTHS IN POST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/busin.print_headline: GAF HEAD STEPS DOWN AFTER 10 MONTHS IN POST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/busin.body_text: **********The GAF Corporation announced yesterday that Jay R. Olson, president, chief executive officer and a director, had resigned those posts ''to pursue other interests.'' **********Last January, Richard Fleming also resigned as president, just five months after joining the company in that position. The same reason was cited for his departure. Mr. Olson was then named to the post. **********''The position of president will not be filled at present,'' the diversified producer of chemicals and related products said in a statement. Mr. Olson could not be reached for comment at the company nor would GAF elaborate on the reasons for his resignation. **********Before assuming his latest positions, the 48-year-old Mr. Olson had been executive vice president and a member of the management committee. He joined GAF in 1970 as treasurer and became a vice president in 1972. Before coming to GAF he was an assistant vice president at Continental Group Inc. Company Restructured **********In December 1980, GAF announced a major restructuring of its operations to improve its return on investment and reduce debt. The restructuring encompassed nearly half of GAF's business, leaving the company primarily as a producer of specialty chemicals and roofng materials. **********GAF has discontinued businesses with sales of $553 million - 45 percent of total sales in 1980 - and a book value of $392 million, and has a $244 million reserve for losses on the program. **********The discontinued businesses include vinyl siding, graphic arts, pictorial products, paper and millboard, a latex plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., and its entire vinyl flooring businesses. **********Upon his appointment as president and chief operating officer, Mr.  Olson had appeared to many analysts as the likely successor to Jesse Werner, GAF's longtime chairman, who will be 65 years old in December and had said that he was looking forward to retirement. **********Mr. Werner, however, has recently signed a five-year agreement ''to continue to serve GAF through 1986.'' It was not specified whether this would be as chairman, as a consultant or in some other capacity. **********A spokesman for GAF said yesterday that GAF's restructuring program had been extremely successful and that Mr. Olson had played a major role. **********For the first nine months of this year net income of GAF rose 81.1 percent, to $23 million, from $12.7 million in the first nine months of 1980. The 1981 period included earnings from discontinued businesses and other extraordinary items. Income from continuing operations, however, was $2.3 million, down 81.3 percent from $12.3 million in the first three quarters of 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/07/world.body_text: **********Increases of up to 55 percent in the prices paid to farmers for their products were announced tonight by the state radio. **********The increases for animal products, including meat, milk and wool, went into effect April 1, the radio said, and crop prices will go up on July 1. **********The official press agency said that the Government wanted to speed up talks with labor unions aimed at increasing retail food prices, which are far below those paid to farmers. **********The price of milk went up to 43 cents a liter from 28 cents. The retail price is 12 cents. A liter is a little over a quart.  Attempts to raise retail food prices without raising wages brought on last summer's labor revolt, which led to the formation of the independent union, Solidarity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/16/busin.main_headline: Washington Watch; Reagan to Drop An Export Curb
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/16/busin.print_headline: Washington Watch; Reagan to Drop An Export Curb
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/16/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON PRESIDENT Reagan is about to reverse the order President Carter signed shortly before the new Administration took office restricting the export of hazardous products that are banned or controlled in the United States. **********To Reagan aides, who are already moving with dispatch to ease regulatory burdens on industry estimated at $125 billion a year in administrative and compliance costs, the Carter order represents another example of excessive Government involvement in commercial affairs. **********The President intends to commission a new study on the subject of hazardous products. Meanwhile, he will dismantle the cumbersome administrative machinethat had been set up by the Carter order. **********The State Department, for example, was to notify foreign Governments of all American regulatory actions on substances to be exported. Products deemed ''extremely hazardous'' were to be placed on the State Department's commodity control list. The Commerce Department was to grant an export license only if the importing country, when fully informed, had no objection to the product. **********Industry attacked the order as an unnecessary hindrance to exports. It will ''insure that sales go to foreign firms,'' said Lewis A. Engman, president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association. **********To Mr. Carter, however, it was an act of benevolent self-interest - showing other countries that ''they can trust goods bearing the label 'Made In U.S.A.' '' **********Reagan aides had tried to get the Carter White House to delay the controversial order, which had been two and a half years and five drafts in the making. **********But Mr. Carter's consumer affairs assistant, Esther Peterson, prevailed against the Secretary of Commerce, Philip M. Klutznick, who opposed the order, and got the President to act just five days before the Reagan inauguration. **********The order was formulated after controversies over the export of children's sleepwear treated with Tris, a flame retardant, and of Leptophos, a pesticide. **********Tris-treated garments are banned in the United States because the substance is suspected as a carcinogen The pesticide, also banned here, was linked to the death of domestic animals in Egypt. Other pesticides as well as some drugs, aerosol sprays and X-ray equipment are also banned here but sold abroad. Enterprise Zones **********Up to 10 years of tax relief for companies that set up shop in such economically depressed urban areas as the South Bronx or Watts in Los Angeles are offered in a new bill just introduced by two members of the House of Representatives from New York. **********The measure, co-sponsored by Representative Jack Kemp, a conservative Republican, and Representative Robert Garcia, a liberal Democrat, is being reviewed by a White House task force and could become the centerpiece of the Administration's urban policy.  President Reagan supported the concept of enterprise zones during the election campaign. **********Property taxes would be cut 20 percent in the designated areas.  Business tax rates would drop 15 percent. Social Security payroll taxes on employers and employees would plummet 90 percent for workers under 21 and 50 pecent for those who are older. **********To Representative Kemp, who believes that tax cuts are critical to restoring prosperity, the measure is the ''pragmatic, utilitarian'' answer to urban deterioration, and to Representative Garcia it means ''jobs, jobs, jobs.'' **********But there's little enthusiasm from urban interest groups who see only the immediately lower tax receipts. In the spirit of the times the bill makes no provision for Federal grants. The National Urban Coalition, which is seeking to redraft the measure, finds the whole thing ''rather unimpressive, notwithstanding the appeal of its broad develoment theme for cities.'' Iran Found Short of Funds **********The International Chamber of Commerce has been taking a hard look at Iran's balance sheet, and according to its Middle East Affairs director, John Sarpa, finds Teheran ''falling considerably short of its revenue needs.'' **********The message being passed on to American companies is to be very cautious about any resumption of trade until the precise method of payment is nailed down. **********''There isn't a company in its right mind that would deal with Iran right now,'' he adds, ''given the revelations of the former hostages and the state of bankruptcy. Last week the Bank Markazi, the Iranian central bank, went from bank to bank in Europe trying to raise $15 million. It finally got the funds, but only after being turned down a number of times. **********Helping to deplete reserves is an $800-million-a-month bill for imported food, which may explain why the country is now so eager to build up its oil production. House Prices Falling **********Don't look now, but your house may be depreciating in value. The National Association of Realtors reports that the median price of an existing home decline in December by $1,300 to $63,000. **********''It's largely because of high mortgage interest rates, which are keeping sales down, encouraging purchases of smaller homes, and causing sellers to ask lower prices for their homes,'' says the association's chief economist, Dr. Jack Carlson. Data Sought on the Prime Rate **********Representative Fernand J. St. Germain, a Rhode Island Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, has just asked the nation's banks to provide his panel with a detailed analysis of how banks arrive at their prime rate. **********Mr. St. Germain wonders how good a gauge of interest rates the prime really is, since, as he notes, at times last year two-thirds of the business loans made by large commercial banks in New York were made at rates below the prime. **********He thinks the misleading nature of the prime is unfair to consumers and small business. ''Perhaps your more sophisticated borrowers are well aware that the prime rate is not the prime rate, but the small business and the consumer are none the wiser,'' he wrote in a letter to chief executives of the 10 leading banks. Briefcases *********** Befitting his Texas heritage, Robert S. Strauss, one of the most influential advisers during the Carter Administration, likes to throw a chili party every year. And all this city's notables crave invitations. This year the invitation list is so long that he's had to move the party from his home to a more spacious private club. ''I am pleased to advise that after working and reworking the list,'' he told one friend, ''you are still included.'' *********** Herbert E. Harris 2d, who lost his Virginia House seat last November, is joining the Washington law firm of deKieffer, Berg & Creskoff. Donald E. deKieffer, one of the partners in the firm, is expected to be named shortly as general counsel at the Office of the United States Trade Representative.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.main_headline: NORWAY CUTS OIL PRICE BY 10% ADDING TO PRESSURE ON AFRICANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.print_headline: NORWAY CUTS OIL PRICE BY 10% ADDING TO PRESSURE ON AFRICANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.body_text: **********Norway's state-owned oil company announced yesterday that it was reducing the price of its North Sea crude oil by 10 percent, another indication of the intense downward pressure on world oil prices. **********This widely expected price cut brought Norwegian crude into line with the price of Britain's North Sea oil and put additional pressure on the high-priced African oil producers to lower their prices. **********Although Norway and Britain are not members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, until now both of them had pegged their crude oil prices to those of OPEC's African members - Libya, Nigeria, Algeria and Gabon. On Tuesday these four producers vowed to hold their prices at $40 to $41 a barrel even though their oil is almost identical to the North Sea's low-sulfur crude. **********The Norwegian company, Statoil, said yesterday that its 10 percent cut would drop the average price of its North Sea crude to just below $36 a barrel, from $40 a barrel. The new price is retroactive to June 20. **********On June 15 the British National Oil Company lowered the price of its most plentiful grade of North Sea crude by $4.25 a barrel, to $35. 'A Major Departure' in Pricing **********Norway produces about 510,000 barrels of oil a day in the North Sea. Most of Britain's daily output of 1.8 million barrels of oil comes from the North Sea. **********''The Norwegian and British reductions signify a major departure in world oil pricing,'' said Charles A. Mink, manager of worldwide crude supplies for the Phillips Petroleum Company, a large North Sea producer. ''This time instead of following the lead of the Africans, Norway and Britain have recognized the significant changes in the market and have decided to base their prices on the $32-a-barrel rate charged by Saudi Arabia instead.'' **********Oil economists say the differential between Saudi light crude and the oil from Africa and the North Sea should normally be about $3 to $4 a barrel. The African and North Sea oil is regarded as worth more because of its proximity to the marketplace, low sulfur content and dependability of supply. During the oil shortages of the late 1970's, however, the differential grew to nearly $10 a barrel. **********It was partly to force the African producers to restore the traditional differential that Saudi Arabia, with its production of 10.3 million barrels a day, has been helping to create a worldwide oil glut of 2 million to 3 million barrels a day in excess of consumption. Impact on Demand Analyzed **********''If the African OPEC countries do not lower their prices,'' said Barry Good, oil analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company, ''they are not going to have any demand. If they do come down, they are going to put tremendous pressure on the middle-level OPEC producers such as Kuwait, Venezuela and Iraq to lower their prices accordingly to stay competitive. It is at that point the Saudis should be able to dictate the unified price they want.'' **********Mr. Good said the Norwegian move would make it much more difficult for Mexico to raise the price of its crude oil, as it has threatened to do. **********Only three weeks ago Mexico reduced its oil price by $4 a barrel, to $30.60, to hold onto its share of shrinking world oil demand. The director general of Mexico's state-run oil enterprise, Petroleos Mexicanos, was forced to resign in the political furor raised by the price cut. Since then Mexican officials have said they want to bring the price back to, or near, its former level. **********United Press International reported from Mexico City yesterday that Mexico was considering raising its prices and reducing its petroleum production to help counteract the worldwide glut of oil. Cutback in Exports Hinted **********Quoting sources close to Pemex, as the state oil enterprise is generally known, the news agency said Mexico was weighing a cutback of 15 to 20 percent in its exports of 1.5 million barrels a day.  Roughly half of Mexico's oil exports go to the United States. **********Mexico was also reportedly studying the possibility of raising its prices as much as 20 percent.  A Pemex spokesman, Miguel Tomassini, said that ''we cannot confirm or deny'' the reports.  ''The oil companies have been putting the squeeze on all the North Sea producers to lower their prices,'' said Mr. Mink of Phillips Petroleum. ''They argue that they can't buy it for $40 a barrel, put it through their refineries and make money in today's motor fuel market.'' **********The prices oil companies are willing to pay for petroleum produced in the United States continue to decline. The Ohio-based Marathon Oil Company announced yesterday that it was reducing the price it will pay for Wyoming and Montana high-sulfur crude by $1 a barrel, to $33. The day before, Marathon had reduced the price it would pay for low-sulfur crude by $1 a barrel, to $35.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/02/world.main_headline: AMERICAN-OWNED CARS SET AFIRE IN WEST GERMANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/02/world.print_headline: AMERICAN-OWNED CARS SET AFIRE IN WEST GERMANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/02/world.body_text: **********Arsonists destroyed automobiles belonging to United States military personnel and set an office building afire today in incidents that West German investigators said had a clearly anti-American character. **********The burning of seven cars at an Air Force housing unit in Wiesbaden, and the partial gutting of facilities of the Social Democratic Party in Frankfurt, accompanied by the painting of anti-American slogans, followed a major explosion yesterday at Ramstein Air Base, the American Central European Air Force headquarters near Kaiserlautern. **********Twenty people were injured in the explosion yesterday, which the police said appeared to have been caused by a bomb, although the Air Force continued to maintain that the cause was undetermined. There were no injuries in the incidents today. **********Reagan Is a Frequent Target **********The attacks come at a time of many anti-American statements by leftist West German politicians. The Reagan Administration has become an almost daily target of segments of the Social Democratic Party that suggest that the United States is trying to force West Germany into confrontation with the Soviet Union. **********The central theme of this movement, which has several million West German supporters, is resistance to NATO's plan to begin deploying new American medium-range nuclear missiles in West Germany in 1983.  But since the Reagan Administration announced its intention to start production of neutron weapons, the anti-American tone has sharpened.  Washington's statement that it does not intend to station the weapons in Europe now has been largely ignored. **********In a speech on Sunday, Willy Pieczyk, the chairman of the Social Democrats' national youth group, called Mr. Reagan a ''terrifying President.'' **********Egon Bahr, the party's spokesman on disarmament matters, has said that the United States is behaving as if Western Europe was ''its protectorate,'' and Willy Brandt, the Social Democratic Party chairman, was reported to have complained that West Germany was being treated ''like a colony.'' **********Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has said that high American interest rates were holding back the West German economy.  For some Americans, the remarks seemed to be intended in part to take attention away from the highest unemployment rate in West Germany in 20 years and from a tangible weakening in the governing coalition. **********There has also been continued resistance since the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan to any American policies that would seem to endanger the profitable relations West Germany has built with the Soviet Union over the last 10 years. Plan for a Protest **********In light of the attacks, leaders of the opposition Christian Democratic Party called on the young Socialists to abandon a plan to protest the visit in two weeks of Secretary of State Alexander M.  Haig Jr. to West Berlin. The young Socialists, although criticized by party newspapers, said they planned to go ahead with the demonstration. **********Other newspaper editorials condemned the attacks. The Westdeutsche Allgemeine, the country's largest provincial newspaper, said today: ''The terrorists want to fan the emerging anti-Americanism and exploit it for their purposes. They want to drive a wedge between Germans and Americans. We hope they will fail.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/07/busin.body_text: **********Things could have been a lot worse in home textiles last year. The economy posted declines in personal income and housing construction, two components that ordinarily generate demand for textiles, and those declines could have hurt sales severely. **********But sales of products ranging from pillowcases to bath and kitchen accesories rose between 5 and 6 percent, to nearly $9 billion.  However, as participants in the recently completed Bath, Bed and Linen Show at the New York Coliseum were quick to point out, the industry has been regrouping to combat negative economic developments and redefine a mature domestic market. Thus far, the transformation has been successful: Since 1975, retail sales of home textile products have risen nearly 180 percent. **********Manufacturers and retailers now emphasize fashion, not utility.  ''We have to give the consumer a reason to buy these products,'' says Janet Morgan, managing editor of the Home Textiles Section of Home Furnishings Daily. ''Our stuff doesn't wear out very fast, which cuts into the replacement market, and the industry is extremely price-competitive.'' As a result, she adds, ''more and more manufacturers are adopting a concept selling approach, where the consumer is shown a package of color coordinated articles for the bath, bedroom or kitchen.'' **********A burgeoning home improvement market and rising interest in foreign sales are also important. According to Donald H. Roberts, executive director of the National Bath, Bed and Linen Association, consumers spent nearly $45 billion on remodeling and home additions last year, up 75 percent from 1975.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/26/world.main_headline: FRANCE'S PRESIDENT FACING 9 OPPONENTS IN TODAY'S ELECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/26/world.print_headline: FRANCE'S PRESIDENT FACING 9 OPPONENTS IN TODAY'S ELECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/26/world.body_text: **********The 10 candidates in France's presidential race were silent today for the first time in weeks as the nation entered the one-day campaign recess that precedes tomorrow's round of voting. **********The balloting, for which 36 million citizens are registered, will be the first of a two-part election to choose a president for the next seven years. The two candidates drawing the most votes will qualify for the runoff on May 10; the other eight will be eliminated. **********There are no firm indications about the results, either for tomorrow's preliminary or for the runoff two weeks later. By law, no polls have been made public in the last week, and the polls published a week ago gave no clear leads. **********Giscard Expected to Lead **********The general expectation is that the vote will be close and that President Valery Giscard d'Estaing will probably face Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist candidate in a runoff election on May 10. **********However, Jacques Chirac, the Mayor of Paris and the candidate of the Gaullists, is believed to have advanced dramatically in recent weeks, drawing the votes of conservatives who are fed up with Mr.  Giscard d'Estaing but do not want a Socialist president. There was a flurry of rumors a few days ago that Mr. Chirac would outpoll Mr.  Mitterrand, though this now seems unlikely. **********Such an upset, if it occurred, would pit the two conservative candidates against each other in the final round and would leave the half of France that normally votes for the left without a candidate. Importance of Communist Vote **********The fourth important contender is Georges Marchais, leader of the Communists. The most recent polls put him in third or fourth place, slightly ahead of or behind Mr. Chirac. Mr. Marchais is given no chance to win, but the size of his vote will be important. A decline of much more than 20 percent would mark an important decline for the French Communist Party and might produce a change in its leadership and tactics. **********Mr. Marchais has conducted a vigorous and lively campaign, however, and he seems to have bounced back after earlier signs that he was in trouble. **********It has been a quiet campaign by French standards, producing more irritability than passion. Only a handful of the thousands of teams that glue posters onto walls, trees and public toilets - and onto rival posters - have been beaten or shot at. Swiss Tourist Killed in Blast **********A bomb was set off at a Corsican airport when Mr. Giscard d'Estaing landed there, and a Swiss tourist was killed, but it was not thought to have anything to do with the campaign except for subsequent charges that the President was using it to get a sympathy vote. **********In addition, the financial markets have been quiet.  By all indications, the voters feel less strongly about their choice than at any time in 20 years, yet the turnout is expected to reach the usual level of about 85 percent. Whatever happens, the French do vote. Expressing an opinion is of the utmost importance in this country, even when people do not have one. **********None of the issues proposed by the candidates seem to have seized the public imagination. All the candidates are offering to do something about the 1.6 million unemployed. Mr. Mitterrand proposes to create 200,000 public-service jobs; Mr. Chirac proposes to stimulate the economy; Mr. Giscard d'Estaing is holding to a modulated version of austerity in hopes that the economy will pick up. **********Mr. Mitterrand's program includes the nationalization of private banks and some of the large industrial companies, but he has not been stressing it in his campaign. On foreign policy, although the candidates have been swiping at each other, there is not much variation from the traditional French position: go with the West, and take time out for side trips. Skepticism About the Future **********Certainly, polls and interviews show little public awareness of the particulars of each candidate's program. They find, on the other hand, considerable skepticism that things will look up much, either in France or the rest of the world, no matter who wins. **********And yet, in a relatively low-key fashion, the campaigns have addressed the traditional French tendency to polarize into right and left at election time. The voting will show whether the messages have been received, but with the end of the first round of campaigning, two basic themes had emerged. **********The nine candidates seeking to unseat Mr. Giscard d'Estaing have stressed the need for change. Mr. Chirac attacks the President for growing stale, for lacking vitality and for being out of touch with the mood of the country. He offers himself as a fresher replacement, telling the voters that by supporting him they can have change without the dangers of Socialism. Same Governors for 20 Years **********Mr. Mitterrand's principal theme is not so much the policy changes he has proposed as the need to provide alternation in a democracy.  His point, and it is a popular one, is that the same political clan - the Gaullists and their divided heirs - have held power for more than 20 years. The processes of government, he charges, have become stratified and corrupt because of this continuity in power. **********Mr. Giscard d'Estaing has defended his record vigorously, and he does have things to defend. Even Le Monde, which opposes him bitterly, noted several achievements in a front-page editorial this week. He has regularly been telling his audiences that during his first seven years in office he built the foundations of French prosperity. Now he would like another seven years ''to construct the upper floors.'' **********But increasingly, and this theme will undoubtedly dominate the runoff campaign if he faces Mr. Mitterrand, Mr. Giscard d'Estaing has been playing on most Frenchmen's distrust of the Communist Party. He argues that Mr. Mitterrand can only win the runoff with the support of the Communists and that such support will make him dependent on them. Difficult to Reject Argument **********The Socialists, who are bitter rivals of the Communists, reject the argument. But since it is true that they would need the votes of Communists in the second round, they find it difficult to reject in full cry. Mr. Mitterrand asserts that if he is elected it is because the nation endorses his democratic version of Socialism and that such support will allow him to build a democratic majority for change in the elections he would call for the National Assembly. **********Underneath the programs and proposals, the rhetoric and debate, the French are trying to sort out conflicting feelings. There is a desire for change. There is also a concern about its dangers, and the question of whether Mr. Mitterrand or Mr. Chirac can be trusted with it. **********Today's Le Monde carried a cartoon that summed it all up.  Marianne, the symbol of France, stands with a ball and chain fastened to one leg, a hacksaw held hesitantly in one hand, and a look of bafflement on her face. ''What do I do?'' she wonders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/09/busin.main_headline: Chairman Is Named At British Unilever
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chairman Is Named At British Unilever
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/09/busin.body_text: **********The Unilever Group, the huge British-Dutch conglomerate, has elected Ken Durham, 57 years old, chairman of Unilever PLC, the British component of the organization. In keeping with the usual pattern at the world's largest consumer goods producer, Mr. Durham was also named a vice chairman of Unilver NV, the Dutch arm based in Rotterdam. **********Mr. Durham will succeed Sir David Orr, who will retire at the age of 60, after 33 years with the company. F.A. Maljers, a 49-year-old Dutchman and longtime Unilever executive who is now a director in charge of edible fats products, will succeed Sir David as a member of the worldwide organization's special committee - the three-member body that acts as Unilever's chief executive office. **********Reached at his London office yesterday, Mr. Durham noted that he had been a member of the special committee for the last four years.  ''I've been involved in all of the major policy decisions and I can't hide behind saying that I'm going to change this or that,'' he said. **********Mr. Durham, a physicist, joined Unilever's research operations in 1950 and moved into its general management in 1970. He has been a director of the corporation for the last eight years and became one of the two vice chairmen of Unilever PLC when he was appointed to the special committee four years ago. **********Sir David, who came up through the marketing ranks, seved with Lever Brothers, the company's American subsidiary, from 1963 to 1967, successively as vice president, administrative vice president, president and chief executive officer. He has been a director for 15 years and was chairman of Unilever PLC for eight years. **********''The real heart of our business is in Europe and I intend to emphasize that particular aspect,'' Mr. Durham said. ''In North America, there is a market very kind to the free enterprise system, so we clearly have to see if we can expand our business there. And in the overseas markets, there are some very high growth areas - like Indonesia, Brazil, Thailand and Malaysia -and I think we have to make certain we put the resources there to gain from it.'' **********Mr. Durham added: ''It seems to me that people wash and use goodquality detergent products even in difficult times. Business hasn't yet been affected too much by the general recession, but I'm touching wood.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/02/world.print_headline: SOVIET PAPER SAYS GOOD WEATHER SPEEDS SPRING SOWING IN SOUTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/02/world.body_text: **********Good weather in the south of the Soviet Union's European areas has enabled farmers to begin sowing grain earlier than usual, raising hopes for a good crop, the Government newspaper Izvestia said today. **********Izvestia said sowing had begun almost as far north as Volgograd and Poltava. **********A wet fall last year and a mild winter created good conditions for grain, but also encouraged weed growth, the newspaper said.  It said conditions were similar to those in 1978, when a record grain crop of 237 million tons was harvested.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/world.main_headline: JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA MOVING TO RESOLVE THEIR DISAGREEMENTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/world.print_headline: JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA MOVING TO RESOLVE THEIR DISAGREEMENTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/world.body_text: **********Japan has agreed to sell more than 400,000 tons of surplus rice, valued at close to $200 million, to South Korea following the failure of much of the 1980 Korean rice crop, officials announced here last weekend. **********The agreement, which was apparently held up by political differences last year, was seen here as a sign that the two nations are moving cautiously to patch up their disagreements. Since January the Japanese have also offered to resume economic aid to South Korea, and last week Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ito went to Seoul in an effort to improve relations. **********Tamio Amau, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said that ''whether we like it or not,'' there had been a difficult atmosphere in relations with Seoul in the last few months, but he said the difficulties had been ''at least somewhat smoothed out by Mr. Ito's visit.'' **********The improvement is likely to be welcomed by the Reagan Administration, officials said, as evidence of timely Japanese support for the newly established regime of President Chun Doo Hwan. Case of Dissident Hurt Relations **********Japanese relations with Seoul were strained because of the death sentence given to the South Korean opposition leader Kim Dae Jung by a military court last year. President Chun's commutation of Mr.  Kin's sentence to life imprisonment in January was followed by the lifting of a temporary suspension of $92 million in Japanese economic aid to South Korea. **********Foreign Minister Ito represented Japan in Seoul last week at the inauguration of President Chun for a seven-year term. During his visit he met with Foreign Minister Lho Shin Young and agreed to resume regular meetings at the foreign ministers' level that were suspended in 1978. **********Meanwhile, a meeting between Mr. Chun and the Japanese Prime Minister, Zenko Suzuki, is under consideration. ''It's possible,'' said Mr. Amau, ''though not probable as yet.'' **********Only three months ago an effigy of Prime Minister Suzuki was burned in Seoul before a cheering crowd of tens of thousands, assembled by South Korean military intelligence agents under martial law. Remark by Suzuki Protested **********The rally, accompanied by anti-Japanese meetings throughout the nation and by demonstrations outside the Japanese Embassy in Seoul, was organized by the authorities to protest a reported remark by Mr.  Suzuki to South Korean diplomats that there would be pressure here for closer ties with North Korea if Mr. Kim was executed. **********Mr. Ito appears not to have been warmly received in Seoul last week, judging by the small amount of coverage his visit received in South Korea's Government-controlled press, presumably because he has visited North Korea twice and is considered sympathetic to the Communist Government there by right-wing advisers close to Mr. Chun. **********The rice deal, with payments to be made over 15 years, was announced after Mr. Ito returned here last Friday.  The United States supplied most of the rice obtained from abroad by South Korea after the 1980 crop fell some 30 per cent below the normal annual level of 6 million tons. **********''They bought practically the entire California rice crop,'' said a high United States official in Seoul. Korean purchases of American rice were close to one million tons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/28/busin.body_text: **********The United Auto Workers union will not renegotiate its current contract with the Allis-Chalmers Corporation despite the company's claim that it needs wage and benefit concessions, U.A.W. officials said. **********Citing weak economic and market conditions, Allis-Chalmers asked the union last week to reopen the three-year pact, which is not scheduled to expire until Nov. 1, 1982. **********In a letter to the company, Stephen P. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/30/world.main_headline: ISRAELIS CLAIM SYRIAN MIG-25 IN CLASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/30/world.print_headline: ISRAELIS CLAIM SYRIAN MIG-25 IN CLASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/30/world.body_text: **********An air battle erupted over Lebanon today as Syrian jets scrambled to intercept Israeli reconnaissance planes. A Syrian MIG-25 was shot down, the Israeli military command reported. **********A claim by the Syrians that they downed an Israeli plane was denied by a military spokesman in Jerusalem.  It was the first serious clash since a cease-fire in Lebanon took effect last Friday. Palestinian forces have carried out scattered rocket attacks on Lebanese Christian villages along the Israeli border, but Israel has not returned the fire. The region remained quiet today. **********The air battle came a day after Syria contended that the terms of the cease-fire barred Israeli flights of any kind over Lebanon, reconnaissance or otherwise. Israeli officials had made clear, in agreeing to the truce, that reconnaissance flights would continue. **********''We have to carry out the overflights,'' Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today, ''to know what is going on and to find out where there are the P.L.O.'s bases so we can attack them without hurting the civilian population.'' Israel Bars a P.L.O. Buildup **********Israel has said that it would not tolerate the P.L.O.'s use of the cease-fire to build up its military presence in southern Lebanon, from which northern Israeli towns were shelled in the weeks preceding the truce. **********Mr. Begin mocked a Syrian threat, broadcast yesterday on the Damascus radio, to shoot down Israel's reconnaissance planes.  ''If a Syrian representative says so,'' the Prime Minister declared, ''I will say to him: 'It is easier said than done, because today we have shot down a MIG-25.' '' **********He was applauded by his audience at the Fifth International Conference of Jewish Lawyers and Jurists.  The MIG-25 is one of the Soviet Union's top interceptors, capable of flying up to three times the speed of sound and reaching an altitude of 80,000 feet. **********Since April 1979, a military spokesman said, Israel has shot down 15 Syrian planes over Lebanon, including the MIG-25 downed today. The Israelis say they have not lost any piloted aircraft, although several unmanned reconnaisaance aircraft have been downed over Lebanon. Sensitivity on Beirut Raid **********Mr. Begin's reference to civilians and the Palestine Liberation Organization reflected a growing sensitivity here to international condemnation of the July 17 air attack by Israel on a heavily populated quarter of Beirut. Mr. Begin announced at the time that P.L.O. installations would no longer be spared even if they were in civilian areas. **********Today, however, he stressed Israel's commitment to minimizing civilian casualties and he tried to draw a distinction between attacking Beirut and attacking P.L.O. headquarters that happened to be in Beirut. **********''We did not attack Beirut,'' he said. ''We attacked the command and headquarters of the P.L.O. terrorist organization which gives an oath that this country is going to be destroyed, that this people is going to be destroyed. Never again will Jewish blood be shed with impunity.'' Israel Makes Gesture to U.S. **********Israel appears interested in maintaining the fragile truce to demonstrate its good will to the United States, where angry reaction to the Beirut bombing caused further delay in suspended shipments of 10 F-16 fighter-bombers. Washington's resumption of deliveries is expected to hinge partly on a restoration of calm in the border region. **********David Kimche, director general of the Foreign Ministry, said in a radio interview today that accepting the cease-fire had been a ''difficult decision.'' **********''For us, the obvious thing would have been to have carried on an really once and for all, to have finished off this problem. And we didn't. We stopped, we agreed, because we took the United States interests into consideration. This is understood, and I do believe that this will lead to an improvement in relations.'' **********However, Mr. Kimche's assertion that continued air strikes could have finished off the problem ''once and for all'' was not bolstered by any military evidence, and military sources said they had no such impression. **********Mr. Kimche also said that the P.L.O. had begun to move equipment into the area since the cease-fire, but military officers said they were unable to confirm this. **********Despite occasional Syrian attempts to intercept Israeli aircraft, the Israelis say, there has been no movement of Syrian antiaircraft missiles, which were deployed last April in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon, toward P.L.O. bases or Beirut. **********Palestinians and Lebanese leftists, who have asked that Syrian missiles be emplaced around Beirut, have been told that Syria has too few batteries to do this, according to reports from Beirut, but that it would assist the shipment of weapons from other Arab countries into Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/23/world.print_headline: REAGAN WAR OVER WORDS; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/23/world.body_text: **********The dispute in Western Europe over President Reagan's comments about the possibility of a battlefield nuclear exchange reflects no basic differences over nuclear strategy but rather the acute state of political nervousness in the Atlantic alliance. The President's remarks did not signal any shift in either American policy or the doctrine of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********But West European diplomats explain, and privately American officials concur, that the European press fastened on Mr. Reagan's comments because many Europeans are deeply uncertain about the general direction of the Reagan Administration's policies and they do not share Washington's sense of peril about a Soviet attack in the mid-1980's. **********''From Europe, Reagan looks to be extremely aggressive, more than in Washington,'' said a veteran European diplomat just back from a trip to the Continent. ''The other day he touched a sensitive European nerve on the nuclear issue and he seemed to reinforce his image as a tough guy. And that caused trouble.'' **********''The problem in Europe,'' added an experienced American official, ''is that we're dealing with a postwar generation which thinks detente was good for them, that the Soviet threat can be contained and the real danger now comes from Reagan and these gung-ho guys in Washington. They don't believe we're serious about disarmament and arms control. They're nervous and this Administration has not done a whole lot to reassure Europeans on this score.'' Leftward Pull in Europe **********According to this view, Europe is being pulled to the left politically at a time when the United States has taken a more conservative turn. Specialists here point to Socialist victories in France and Greece, with the new Greek leader, Andreas Papandreou, talking of pulling his country out of NATO and removing American military bases. **********In Britain, the left wing of the Labor Party also favors withdrawal from NATO and disarmament. In West Germany, the Netherlands and other northern European countries, the growing neutralist movement has been pressing those Governments to forswear plans to deploy a new generation of tactical nuclear missiles like the Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Europe in 1983 to offset 250 or more Soviet SS-20 missiles in Eastern Europe. **********It is pressures like these that caused NATO defense officials, meeting in Scotland yesterday, to override the objections of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and approve what is known as ''the zero-level option'' - that is, scrapping plans to deploy those American missiles if the Russians withdraw their SS-20's from Eastern Europe. **********Because the Russians are expected to refuse any such pullback, practically no one here considers the ''zero-level option'' very practical. But it is taken as a measure of the need West European governments feel to appease the sentiment for arms control in their own countries. Wishes of the People Involved **********As Hans van Mierlo, the acting Dutch Defense Minister, was quoted as saying yesterday: ''We see ourselves as suppliers of security, but we often forget that we are supposed to respond to the wishes of the people. It's important that the Europeans see that we are striving for their goal. Then if that goal is not reached, it won't be because we didn't try.'' **********But European attitudes are complex and pose a problem for American administrations. Such European leaders as Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany want American protection and have asked for American tactical nuclear weapons to be stationed on their soil, but they are then confronted with a public opinion that dislikes the risks entailed. **********Plans for the deployment of Pershing 2 and cruise missiles have brought about acute political anxieties in Europe, as Mr. Schmidt himself explained, because people in crowded regions of Central Europe fear that this will increase the Soviet tendency to target their homeland. ''Ask more Europeans if they support NATO and they say yes,'' said an American official. ''But ask them if they want NATO missiles in the next neighborhood, and they get very, very nervous.'' **********The problem is compounded because now, as for nearly two decades, many Europeans have been fearful that Washington would answer a Soviet attack in Europe with tactical weapons rather than turning quickly to all-out nuclear retaliation with strategic forces based in the United States. For nearly 20 years the NATO doctrine of a flexible response has been to try to deter attack, meet it at the lowest level, and then proceed to global war. **********But there has been a persistent European fear that Europe would have to bear the brunt of a nuclear war while the United States was spared. It is this ''European nuclear allergy,'' as American officials term it, that President Reagan set off last weekend. **********Against a backdrop of political unease about Mr. Reagan, resentment of high American interest rates and worry about the prospects for arms control, his comments were a flashpoint. ''Technically, the President really didn't say anything new,'' said one official. ''But the problem is that anything we say on this issue now is a problem for the Europeans. So once again, this Government has shot itself in the foot and had to scurry around to try to cure the wound.''

Jepsen, Republican of Iowa, vice chairman of the Joint Economic Committee; Harrison H. Schmitt, Republican of New Mexico, a member of the Banking Committee; Christopher J. Wylie, Republican of Ohio, a member of the Joint Economic Committee; Ronald E. Paul, Republican of Texas, a member of the Banking Committee, and Stephen L. Neal, Democrat of North Carolina, a Banking Committee member. **********Also, J. Charles Partee, Emmett J. Rice and Henry C. Wallich, Federal Reserve governors; Murray L. Weidenbaum, chariman of the President's Council of Ecnomic Advisers; Jerry Jordan, a council member; Paul McCracken, a professor at the University of Michigan; Arthur Costamagna, a Santa Rosa, Calif., lawyer; Herbert Coyne, executive vice president of J. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.body_text: **********The British Petroleum Company and Nigeria have agreed in principle on a plan to allow B.P. to resume operations in the African country for the first time since its Nigerian interests were nationalized in 1979, industry sources said today. **********B.P. had been banned from operating in Nigeria on the ground that it was selling oil to South Africa. **********The sources said that, under terms of the accord, Nigeria would supply $138 million worth of oil to B.P. as compensation and would permit the company to begin business operations again in the country. **********At the current price for Nigerian crude, the pact would be worth about 3.5 million barrels of oil, although the figure was not disclosed. **********A B.P. spokesman said that ''we have not signed any formal agreement,'' but declined further comment.  B.P.'s assets taken over by Nigeria in July 1979 included a 50 percent share in a joint company with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group; a 20 percent stake in a joint project with the Nigerian National Petroleum Company, and a 60 percent share in an oil marketing concern.
