https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/14/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Scaled-Down Bid on Phoenix
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/14/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Scaled-Down Bid on Phoenix
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/14/busin.body_text: **********THE scaled-down offer by the Texas International Company for the Phoenix Resources Company has piqued some holders of Phoenix's remaining shares. Texas International already owns 52 percent of Phoenix and is offering half a share of its stock for each Phoenix share still in public hands. **********An earlier share-for-share exchange plan between the two oil and gas exploration and production companies was withdrawn last January, about a week before Texas International announced a wildcat discovery in the Eloi Bay off Louisiana. **********Texas International has justified the revision of the terms on the ground that the new find doubled the company's value. But some minority stockholders are skeptical and the reserves are as yet unproven. **********The scaled-down offer for Phoenix was presented to that company's board a week ago. Now several Wall Street sources and a former director argue that Texas International is using its control position to acquire Phoenix at a bargain price. **********Last week's offer is in lieu of Phoenix's liquidation. Phoenix employed Morgan Stanley & Company to arrange a buyout but the investment banker has been unable to obtain an offer acceptable to the Phoenix board. Texas International, which needs capital, had hoped to use its share of Phoenix's liquidation proceeds to finance the development of a number of promising oil and gas properties, including Eloi Bay. **********Phoenix's $30 million annual cash flow apparently is not enough to develop the company's own 700,000 acres of oil and gas properties in the United States, Canada and abroad. Phoenix's proven reserves comprise 6.2 million barrels of oil and 162 billion cubic feet of natural gas. **********Wall Street critics argue that Texas International is moving too easily from one side to the other in efforts to consolidate its interest in Phoenix. Last week, for example, Morgan Stanley was hired to defend Texas International in case an unfriendly takeover bid should materialize - an unusual arrangement in view of the fact that the investment banker is serving Phoenix in its ongoing liquidation program. **********Moreover, three members of the Phoenix boardwork for Texas International while another is an employee of the controlled company. Arthur Lipper 3d was the fifth member of Phoenix's fivemember board until he resigned following the announcement of the new merger proposal. **********In a telephone interview Mr. Lipper said that ''Texas International has a meaningful burden of fiduciary responsibility to Phoenix minority shareholders which is yet to be understood or accepted'' by it. **********One close observer of the takeover scene commented that, once a company owns a controlling interest in another company, it does owe a fiduciary obligation to the minority holders. There would be no such duty if the pre-existing management of the controlled company agreed in advance to a two-step takeover, as happened in Du Pont's takeover of Conoco. But when a company first obtains a controlling interest and then negotiates for the balance, questions of fairness are often raised. **********As for the offer itself, Mr. Lipper said: ''I would be surprised if an investment banker could find the present proposal to be fair. To do so would, in my opinion, require a finding that Texas International was selling at a price of less than half of what its market value should be.'' **********Texas International closed on Friday at 39 3/8, off 3/4. Phoenix Resources, which traded on the over-the-counter market as high as 44 1/2 shortly after announcing promising results from an Arctic oil discovery in midyear, closed on Friday at 18 3/4 bid. The last quotation before the exchange offer was announced was 25 bid, on Dec. 4. **********Ward Holliday, the senior vice president of Texas International, reached at the company's Oklahoma City headquarters, was asked about Mr. Lipper's comments. **********He said: ''It is our view that as directors we have an obligation to treat all shareholders fairly. We believe that we have done so in the past and will continue to do so in the future. Texas International has made what we believe to be a fair offer and the Phoenix board has taken the offer under consideration and has employed Morgan Stanley to advise it on the fairness of that offer. I don't believe that Texas International nor the Phoenix board members who are employed by Texas International would have further comment.'' **********Mr. Holliday did not see a conflict of interest in Morgan Stanley advising Phoenix as to the fairness of the Texas International offer on the one hand and counseling Texas International with regard to potential takeover bids on the other. **********Asked about any potential conflict, Fabianne Gershon, a Morgan Stanley vice president and spokesman, said, ''No comment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/14/world.main_headline: U.S. PANEL SAYS INDOCHINA REFUGEES MAY INCREASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/14/world.print_headline: U.S. PANEL SAYS INDOCHINA REFUGEES MAY INCREASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/14/world.body_text: **********The United States must be prepared for continuing and possibly increased flows of refugees from Indochina, particularly Vietnam, according to a State Department report released today. **********In the report to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., a fourmember panel that has just completed a 25-day tour of Southeast Asia endorsed the general direction of United States refugee policy, saying that most of the Vietnamese ''boat people'' were legitimate political refugees. **********But the report said many of the people from Cambodia and Laos, especially the lowland Lao, appeared to be fleeing for economic reasons, to improve their basic living conditions, rather than from a fear of persecution. **********The panel, headed by Marshall Green, former Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs, foresaw ''a long-term continuation of the exodus of boat people from Vietnam'' and ''the potential for increased land refugee flows from Laos and Cambodia, in view of worsening conditions of life and the threat of widening hostilities.'' **********The State Department commissioned the study in part because of a widespread belief that those trying to leave Indochina today were much different from those who fled five years ago. **********In addition, there is a growing debate over the wisdom of maintaining refugee programs at current levels while the United States cuts back on domestic social programs. In Congress, Senator Walter D. Huddleston, Democrat of Kentucky, has charged that ''the great majority of those claiming to be political refugees are, in reality, economic refugees'' and that the State Department was recruiting refugees to fill unused quotas set by Congress. **********The panel rejected such allegations, but it warned the Administration not to ''stretch the concept of refugee beyond its proper boundaries, lest the term itself be debased.'' Lists 'Worrisome Aspects' **********There were several ''worrisome aspects of our Indochinese resettlement program'' listed in the report: **********- Charges that an increasingly large proportion of the refugees are motivated primarily by such factors as economic betterment rather than by persecution. **********- The fact that more and more of the refugees have neither immediate family connections in the United States nor ties dating from the period of American involvement in Indochina. **********- Charges that there is a growing tendency among refugees to exploit the welfare system and complaints about the high costs of resettling refugees. **********- The fact that as other countries resettle fewer refugees, the United States is absorbing an increasingly large proportion of them.  Since the end of the Vietnam War in 1975, the panel said, 1.4 million refugees have come by boat and by land from Vietnam and across Thailand's borders from Cambodia and Laos. About 1,060,000 Indochinese refugees have been resettled outside Southeast Asia since 1975. Of that number, 504,000 have come to the United States, according to the report. **********''The Vietnamese constitute the hard core of the long-range refugee problem,'' the panel said. The flow of Vietnamese boat people continues at the rate of 8,400 a month, an increase of one-third over last year, while the flow of Lao and Hmong refugees has decreased significantly, the panel said. **********There could be an upsurge of refugees at any time because of the continuing turmoil in Indochina, the panel said. Definition of Term Cited **********''All of those who fled their homeland are generically referred to as 'refugees,' '' the panel said. ''In the strict sense of the term, however, it appears that some number of them, difficult to ascertain with accuracy, may not qualify as a 'refugee' within the meaning of that term.'' **********Under the United Nations definition accepted by the United States, a refugee is a person who is unable to return to his or her homeland because of a ''well-founded fear of persecution'' because of race, religion, nationality or political beliefs. **********The panel found it ''disturbing that some refugees in Southeast Asian camps are fully aware of the United States welfare program.'' The other members of the panel, besides Mr. Green, were Rita E.  Hauser, a New York lawyer; James F. Greene, former Deputy Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, and Richard W. Wheeler, senior vice president of Citicorp.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/29/world.body_text: **********West Africa, Oct. 28 - With South Africa's ostensible blessing, nearly all the political parties in South-West Africa appear ready to subscribe to a Western-sponsored set of ''constitutional principles'' leading to an independence settlement. **********The principles, which were presented to the parties here on Monday, call for a one-man, one-vote election, a bill of rights and the elimination of the last vestiges of racial discrimination in all private as well as public ''cultural, social, health and educational institutions.'' **********A delegation of senior diplomats from the five Western nations that are seeking to revive a long-stalled initiative on the future of Namibia, as this vast, sparsely populated territory is also known, arrived here this evening from Cape Town after cordial discussions with Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha and Defense Minister Magnus Malan. **********South Africa's readiness to negotiate seriously on the constitutional questions, after months of insisting that thorny procedural issues involving the role of the United Nations had to be resolved first, represented a gain for the Reagan Administration, the main sponsor of the revived initiative. But the intentions of Prime Minister P.W. Botha in the many-sided negotiations remain as much of a riddle as ever, in part because of the political risk he would run if he decided to push through with a settlement that would be seen on all sides as a significant white retreat. **********Enormous Turnout of Whites **********The possibility of a white backlash here and in South Africa was shown last night in the turnout of more than 1,000 whites - an enormous crowd for Windhoek, where the white population is only 30,000 - for a rally at which Prime Minister Botha was accused of betrayal for even considering the Western proposals. **********The rally was sponsored by the Herstigte Nasionale Party, the only party in the territory, which is now said to have a plethora of 46 parties and would-be parties, to register an outright rejection of the proposals. Speakers including Jaap Marais, the party's leader in South Africa, called for resistance to a United Nations force if it finally arrives here next year to carry out the Western plan. **********The diplomatic exercise that will take place here tomorrow and the next day, when the Western representatives meet local political leaders, seems designed to allay the fears of minority ethnic groups and parties that the South-West Africa People's Organization, an insurgent movement that has kept up a low-level guerrilla war on the country's northern border, might be able to achieve an unquestioned dominance in a pre-independence election. **********But political leaders across the spectrum here all agree that the central question remains the attitude of the South African Government, which appears to have two objectives that are nearly mutually exclusive. These are to avoid charges, such as those made by Mr. Marais last night, that it was ''selling out'' the territory's 100,000 whites, most of whom are Afrikaans-speaking South African citizens; and to avoid, at the same time, any appearance that it was sabotaging the Reagan Administration's effort to redeem its policy of ''constructive engagement'' with South Africa by bringing Namibia to internationally recognized independence. Little Room to Maneuver **********Having argued for years that a victory by the insurgent movement would represent an unacceptable danger, because it would bring Soviet influence to South Africa's borders, Mr. Botha and his colleagues appear to have left themselves little room in which to maneuver if they really mean to take the political risk in order to reap whatever rewards they think they might get from a grateful Administration in Washington. **********Black political leaders here who have been consistently skeptical of South Africa's motives in the protracted negotiations now say they believe Mr. Botha may have embarked on a course that could end in a settlement. So do some whites who have gone along with the diplomatic maneuvering of the last four years in the confident faith that it was all a charade. **********Particular note is taken of an interview with Foreign Minister Botha that was broadcast three times in Namibia last week. In it he said that South Africa had to put its own interests first and that the cost of sustaining the guerrilla war - especially since the economy here is now visibly running down as a result of prolonged uncertainty over the territory's future - might be too great for South Africa to bear. **********''My frank opinion is that they're committed,'' said Jannie de Wet, a leader of the National Party here, the largest of the three white parties and an offshoot of the governing party in South Africa. Nationalists' Reaction in Doubt **********The National Party, which cloaks a demand for segregated schools and hospitals by calling for ''ethnic rights,'' is the one party whose reaction to the Western plan was seriously in doubt this evening. Since it represents a majority of Afrikaaners in the territory, it is also the party whose reaction is most important to South Africa. **********Acceptance of the constitutional plan would not be enough to insure the carrying out of the Western plan, for a mine field of negotiations lies ahead on the issue of how the United Nations might now show itself to be an impartial executor of the independence plan after having declared its support for the insurgents in a series of General Assembly resolutions. The issue is a highly emotional one here and in South Africa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/09/busin.main_headline: 2 IN MIDEAST SAID TO LIFT OIL PRICE $4
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/09/busin.print_headline: 2 IN MIDEAST SAID TO LIFT OIL PRICE $4
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/09/busin.body_text: **********Oil price increases of $4 a barrel yesterday by Qatar - and apparently by Kuwait as well - provided mounting evidence that consumers would be paying more for petroleum products than analysts had expected just after the meeting last month of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. **********Qatar increased its crude oil price to $37.42 a barrel, according to an official notice received by a major United States oil company.  In addition, reports were circulating that Kuwait had increased its price by $4, to $35.50, although buyers had not yet received official word. **********Oil analysts said the developments were ominous because they indicated that Persian Gulf countries had decided to take full advantage of the maximum price increase approved by OPEC, despite widespread expecations these nations would be more moderate. In addition, prices of the big Middle East producers tend to set the tone for oil prices everywhere. Non-OPEC oil exporters such as Mexico, China and Canada have also raised prices in recent weeks, and Britain and Norway are expected to follow suit. **********Effects on Gasoline Prices **********Thus, one major oil company official calculated yesterday, if the Qatari and Kuwaiti actions set a new world price standard, and if the decontrolled prices of domestic United States oil rose accordingly, the price of gasoline could rise as much as 10 cents a gallon. **********Immediately after the OPEC meeting, most analysts predicted gasoline price rises of 4 cents to 7 cents a gallon.  But if the big Persian Gulf producers, particularly Saudi Arabia, decide to match their neighbors' prices even partly, the impact would be considerably greater than these earlier estimates, analysts said. **********Currently, Saudi Arabia is selling its basic crude for $32, more than $5 less than Kuwait and Qatar could receive if they applied the various surcharges that they have in the recent past. **********''There is no question that Saudi Arabia will eventually try to close that gap,'' said John H. Lichtblau, the director of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. **********Saudi Arabia sends the United States about 1.3 million barrels of oil a day, about 21 percent of total American imports.  The prices attributed to Qatar and Kuwait startled some observers, because refiners can not currently make a profit on Middle East oil that sells for much over $36, due to softness in the products market. **********The impact of the actions will have a ''profound effect'' particularly in Europe, because refineries there are geared to run on the heavier Middle Eastern crudes, one analyst said. **********Moreover, the moves appear to disrupt earlier efforts by Venezuela, Indonesia and several other producers to keep increases below the sanctioned $4. **********Qatar produces about 500,000 barrels of oil a day, exporting about 35,000 to the United States. Kuwait produces about 1.2 million barrels daily, sending less than 5,000 to the United States. **********Despite the lack of official word from Kuwait, Oil Buyers Guide, a weekly trade journal, said it was certain the Kuwaitis went up by $4. Moreover, some buyers of Kuwaiti crude said they expected to be informed of a $4 increase soon. **********Because of various surcharges, the new prices are higher than they seem at first. Kuwait, for example, has been charging an extra $5.50 for half its oil. Thus, on average, its new price is expected to be about $37.75. This is still below a spot price of about $40, according to industry sources. **********Qatar has been adding as much as $6 a barrel to some of its sales, but analysts were uncertain if and how this would be applied to the new price. **********The speed with which crude price increases work through the system was evident yesterday in separate announcements by the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Oil Corporation that they were increasing heating oil prices by about 2 cents a gallon. Exxon's wholesale price in the New York City area is now 91.8 cents; Mobil's is 93.8 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/20/world.main_headline: REAGAN AND MITTERRAND OBSERVE 200TH ANNIVERSARY OF YORKTOWN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/20/world.print_headline: REAGAN AND MITTERRAND OBSERVE 200TH ANNIVERSARY OF YORKTOWN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/20/world.body_text: **********In speeches marking the bicentennial of the British surrender at Yorktown, President Reagan and President @Francois Mitterrand of France today hailed that Revolutionary War campaign as the event that established the tradition of free, representative government in the West. **********But the two leaders, in careful, polite language, also revealed their differing views of how the ideals of the American Revolution apply to the present world situation. **********As he did last night in his toast at a state dinner in his honor, Mr. Mitterrand suggested that the United States play a more supportive role in the developing nations - a view he has pressed with increasing vigor with the approach of a conference in Cancun, Mexico Thursday of developing and industrialized nations. **********Mr. Reagan, for his part, linked the battle to his efforts to reduce the size of government, cut taxes and build up the military.  ''The men and boys who fought on this field somehow understood that government must be close to people and responsive to them,'' Mr. Reagan said. ''Today in our country those concepts are threatened by government's bloated size and the distortion of its true functions.'' **********One area of agreement between the two leaders did emerge, however.  At a breakfast meeting with reporters, Mr. Mitterrand said his Government would be willing to contribute troops to a peacekeeping force in Sinai (Page A5.) **********Mr. Reagan and Mr. Mitterrand arrived at the battlefield at about 11 A.M., under heavy security that limited their activities and prevented most of the crowd of 60,000 from seeing them. The two chief executives spoke from behind a 32-foot-long expanse of dark, bulletproof glass. **********The grandstands flanked the speakers' stand, rather than facing it, so Mr. Reagan and Mr. Mitterrand could not see most of the people they addressed. The chief executives' view was of the camera stand and of the troops assembled on a grassy ridge several hundred yards away. **********Security agencies had canceled earlier plans for Mr. Reagan and Mr. Mitterrand to review the troops from an open jeep. Instead, soldiers from the United States, France, Great Britain and Germany marched by the speakers' stand, as did hundreds of civilians dressed in the costumes of the soldiers who fought the campaign that insured the success of the Revolution. British troops under Lord Cornwallis surrendered to a combined American-French force here on this date in 1781. **********Personal feelings between Mr. Reagan and Mr. Mitterrand are said to be positive. But private talks yesterday at Williamsburg, the reconstructed colonial village near here, failed to resolve key differences between them. **********At Cancun, Mr. Mitterrand wants to lay specific plans for a world energy system, while Mr. Reagan favors more generalized talks. Also, Mr. Mitterrand's Government is planning arms sales to Libya, over American objections. Finally, Mr. Mitterrand believes the United States should provide more generous foreign aid to poor nations and should encourage movements for social change in those nations. **********For example, he has recognized the leftist insurgents in El Salvador as a legitimate political force, while the Reagan Administration supports the ruling junta there. **********Mr. Mitterrand today raised the subject of social and political change by saying that the American revolutionaries provided an example for the modern world. Remarks by Mitterrand **********''Let us listen together to the voices which come from all continents,'' the French President said in a part of his address.  ''The aspirations of the peoples of the world today are just as legitimate as those of our forefathers,'' he continued, speaking through an interpreter. ''They are loyal to their example and let us understand them, those of us who have the responsibility of governing the places of our countries in these difficult times, and let us act so that their message be heard before it is too late.'' **********Mr. Reagan's remarks were more narrowly focused, dealing mainly with the domestic economy, the military buildup and patriotic themes. Asserting that ''we have come to this field to celebrate the triumph of an idea,'' Mr. Reagan called for a rededication to the original principles of American government that, he said, are now jeopardized. **********''Our people are struggling under a punishing tax burden many times heavier than that which ignited our first rebellion,'' Mr.  Reagan said. ''Regulations that inhibit our growth and prosperity would be incomprehensibke to the colonists who revolted because of the Stamp Act.'' **********''But of equal concern to me,'' Mr. Reagan added, ''is the uncertainty some seem to have about the need for a strong American defense.'' Contending that weakness invites attack, Mr. Reagan said, ''We are rebuilding our defenses so that our sons and daughters need never be sent to war.'' **********Despite their differing emphasis, Mr. Reagan's and Mr. Mitterrand's speeches contained no direct criticisms. Both called for continuation of the French-American alliance under which French naval and land forces, joining with Continental soldiers under George Washington, dealt the British the decisive defeat of the Revolution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/22/busin.print_headline: RAY OF HOPE ON OIL PRICES; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/22/busin.body_text: **********Gasoline prices in the United States are expected to remain generally stable and possibly dip slightly over the next few months because of the failure yesterday of the oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to agree on a uniform pricing policy. **********The result is particularly good news in view of the widespread expectation before and during the ministers' meeting in Geneva that OPEC would agree to a range of prices between $34 and $37 a barrel, rather than the current $32 to $40. **********Had the new range been adopted, with its $34 minimum price, it would have increased gasoline prices in the United States, many of which are tied to the $32 price that Saudi Arabia charges for its basic crude. OPEC's indecisiveness thus, in effect, saved American drivers 3 cents or more a gallon, oil analysts calculate. 'Good News for the Consumer' **********''Obviously this is good news for the consumer,'' said John H.  Lichtblau, executive director of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. **********If, as expected, some African and Middle Eastern countries that now charge $36 or more unilaterally reduce their crude oil prices, consumers would save more. Several OPEC nations are talking about such price reductions because the worldwide oversupply of oil has made it difficult for them to sell their crude at their current prices. Nigeria, Algeria and Libya, all oil exporters to the United States, charge $40 a barrel. **********The price of regular unleaded gasoline in the United States now averages $1.34 a gallon at self-service stations and $1.41 at fullservice stations. **********The long-range implications of the OPEC meeting may prove considerably more important than any immediate financial savings, according to analysts, academics and company officials interviewed after the oil ministers adjourned yesterday without reaching an agreement. **********Most important, Saudi Arabia proved that it was indisputably the first among equals in OPEC, which has 13 members. Virtually every OPEC member was arrayed against the kingdom, but the Saudis' stubborn resistance to a price increase of more than $2 a barrel prevailed. **********The meeting sought a single base, or benchmark, price from which each member might add premiums or offer discounts, depending on the quality of their oils and their proximity to markets. The Saudis now use a $32 benchmark, while all the other OPEC members use $36. Failure of a Compromise **********Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister, said his Government was prepared to raise its benchmark to $34, but the meeting broke up after an unsuccessful attempt to convince Sheik Yamani to increase the Saudi price by another dollar, to $35. **********''Fundamentally, one has to say it is the Saudis, and the Saudis alone, who will determine how things will go in the future,'' said Walter J. Levy, a noted oil economist. Added Theodore R. Eck, chief economist of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), ''There's only one vote in OPEC that counts.'' **********But the hastily called meeting also provided other insights.  Analysts noted that OPEC had now held six top-level meetings over the past two years without agreeing on a single price for oil, calling into question the organization's effectiveness. In particular, OPEC again demonstrated a glaring inability to lower prices officially despite the weak oil market. Domestic Political Questions **********Analysts suggested that this inflexibility, largely the result of domestic pressures within the producing countries, could severely hamper OPEC's ability to deal with always changing circumstances. **********''We're closer to a breakup of OPEC than at any time since it was formed in 1960,'' said Robert LeVine of E.F. Hutton & Company.  This view was reinforced by a number of oil company officials who said that OPEC was embarrassed by the apparent collapse of an agreement by Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Venezuela that was forged in the days before the full ministerial meeting began on Wednesday. **********In particular, they said that Sheik Yamani would not have attended the meeting unless he was fairly sure of a consensus on a $34 benchmark. Prices Have Doubled in 2 Years **********In part, OPEC appears to be at least a temporary victim of its own success. **********Following a doubling in oil prices over the past two years, demand for OPEC oil has fallen by nearly a third, to about 21.5 million barrels a day. **********This has called into question OPEC's evident need to devise an effective system to curtail production in order to raise prices, in effect to divide a smaller pie. This is something it has never been able to accomplish. **********''What this demonstrates is that OPEC has difficulties in coordinating not just prices, but production,'' said Morris A.  Adelman, an energy expert at the Massachussetts Institute of Technology. ''They have to do something about market shares.'' Oversupply Will Continue **********The Geneva stalemate will most likely mean a continuation, and perhaps an expansion, of the abundance of crude oil that has prevailed most of this year. **********Saudi Arabia's announcement yesterday that it would reduce its daily oil production of about 10 million barrels a day by 10 percent, at least for one month, was viewed by analysts as insignificant and by other OPEC countries as sort of a bone that Riyadh had arrogantly deigned to toss them. **********The current weak market for oil has been caused in large part by high Saudi production, which has been running almost two million barrrels daily over its usual level. The oversupply of oil is generally reckoned at just about two million barrels daily, too. **********A top planner for one of the world's largest oil companies suggested that a Saudi cut of at least two million barrels daily would be needed to tighten the market sufficiently to strengthen prices. Nigerian Output May Rise **********The kingdom's reduction in output will be minimal if Nigeria fulfills a widespread expectation that it will soon cut its prices in order to sell more of its oil, which is considered overpriced at $40. Mr. Lichtblau of the research foundation estimated that a 10 percent cut in Saudi exports could increase Nigeria's by 30 percent to 40 percent. **********Such a move, analysts believe, would almost certainly be followed by Algeria and perhaps by Libya. Then, several Middle Eastern countries, including perhaps Iran, would be under heavy pressure to cut prices. With falling prices, an insufficient cut in Saudi output and growing production elsewhere, analysts concur, the oversupply would persist with a vengeance. Chronology of Prices **********Following is a chronology of the major pricing decisions taken by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and its individual members over the past three years that have led to the current wide range of OPEC prices. All prices are for 42-gallon barrels. **********Dec. 31, 1978: OPEC announces a four-stage price increase to lift the base price from $12.70 to $14.54 by Oct.1, 1979. **********February 1979: Abu Dhabi, Qatar, Libya and Kuwait raise their prices beyond the planned levels. **********March 27: OPEC members agree to apply immediately the $14.54 price that had not been due until Oct.1. **********March 28: Nigeria announces a $4 surcharge. **********June 28: OPEC votes to raise their minimum price to $18 and to allow a maximum of $23.50. Some free-market prices reach $40. **********October: Kuwait, Libya and Iran raise their prices beyond the planned maximum. **********Dec. 20: OPEC meeting ends without an agreement on uniform prices, with members being allowed to set their own. Subsequent listed prices vary from Saudi Arabia's $24 to Libya's $30. **********May 14, 1980: Saudi Arabia raises its prices to $28. **********June 10: OPEC sets a minimum price of $32 and a maximum price of $37. But Saudi Arabia refuses to budge from $28. **********Sept. 18: At an OPEC meeting, in a partial compromise, Saudi Arabia agrees to raise its price to $30, while other members agree to freeze prices until the end of 1980. **********Dec. 10: After an OPEC meeting, Saudi Arabia increases its base price to $32, while other members use a benchmark of $36. This price, with premiums added, means some members can charge up to $41. **********May 26, 1981: OPEC members meet but are unable to agree on a single price schedule. Saudis keep price at $32, but other members range from $36 to $41. Aug. 21: OPEC fails again to unify prices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/22/busin.main_headline:
OTHER BUSINESS;
HOT AIR IN ADVERTISING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/22/busin.print_headline:
OTHER BUSINESS;
HOT AIR IN ADVERTISING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/22/busin.body_text: **********It was 3 A.M. when it appeared, flying over Cambridge and along the coast of eastern England. Local police switchboards got alarmed calls from otherwise sober Britons reporting the sightings. A bird? A plane? An unidentified flying object? No, a gigantic, illuminated light bulb, emblazoned with the trademark of Osram, a leading British light bulb maker. **********There are among its critics those who allege that advertising involves nothing more substantial than hot air. True or not, one advertising man in Britain is, in effect, building a thriving business on nothing more. **********Colin Prescot is chairman and chief executive of the Hot Air Balloon Company, one that specializes in aiding companies to advertise their goods with balloons that often resemble the products they promote. The company has made 25 balloons in all and currently has a list of 15 clients including, besides Osram, British American Tobacco, Smirnoff vodka and Ricard Pastis, the French beverage. **********Mr. Prescot, a 30-year-old balloon pilot, started the company a little over four years ago on the theory that the hot air balloon, more so even than the the Goodyear blimp, was a promising promotional medium. Last year the privately owned company recorded sales of about $11 million. **********''This was rather inflated by 100,000 ($223,000) we were paid for our stunt work in a major feature film,'' said Mr. Prescot. ''But nontheless we're still hoping for slightly higher sales this year.'' **********Mr. Prescot figured that unlike a page in a magazine or a 30-second spot on the radio, a great big balloon is a difficult object to ignore. **********''We're not trying to tell the public that Brand X baked beans have the best-tasting tomato sauce. We're trying to create an image, a presence, a style,'' explained Mr. Prescot, a banker's son who was educated at Britain's top boys' boarding school, Eton, went on to J.  Walter Thompson and spent seven years in advertising. **********In 1978 an independent media company quantified the value of a balloon campaign through coverage in the press and television at an average of seven times its cost. For example, it was estimated that British American Tobacco's State Express 555's cigarettes had a total of 30 minutes free exposure on television from its balloon campaign, something that is of particular value since television cigarette advertising is banned in Britain. **********Almost invariably, Mr. Prescot and his team work directly with clients, rather than through advertising agencies. Indeed, the agencies tend not to be overwhelmingly enthusiastic about balloons.  ''You do it as part of a promotion and it can never equal the usefulness of the major media,'' said Bill Muirhead, a director of the advertising agency Saatchi and Saatchi. **********So, said Mr. Prescot, ''Whenever I have a good idea that I think might interest a specific client, I will approach him and explain about what we do.'' **********One idea was the light bulb. ''With such a boring product,'' Mr.  Prescot said, ''most advertising money will be spent on the trade trying to get your particular brand stocked in the shops. But when our company discovered the technology to make a bulb-shaped balloon and to light it up, we approached Osram.'' **********Another Prescot brainchild was the ''Cloudhopper'', a one-man, basketless, harness balloon. ''Everyone said this wouldn't work. But when we found this new polyester-based, silicone-proofed material that can withstand internal temperatures of up to 200 degrees Centigrade (twice the recommended capability of a normal hot air balloon) it seemed like a possibility,'' he said. **********He approached vodka makers Smirnoff, since their advertising slogan is, ''Well, they said anything could happen.'' The flying machine, which is light enough to be carried by the pilot and allows for approximately one hour's flying time, was developed by a Swedish aeronautical engineer, Per Lindstrand, and made by his company, Colt Balloons Ltd., in Oswestry, as are all Hot Air Balloon products. **********The Smirnoff Cloudhopper was launched from Tower Bridge with Colin Prescot as pilot dressed in a suit and tie with a bowler hat and umbrella. ''This attracted instant media coverage all ove the world,'' Mr. Prescot said. **********Other Prescot products include a balloon shaped like a bottle of Ricard Pastis, another fashioned after British Telecom's merchandising character, Buzby, and another in the blue-flamed shape of Mr. Gas, a figure used by the Gas Board. **********On the other hand, Mr. Prescot said, ''Some companies feel a sophisticated image is better conveyed without using an unusuallyshaped balloon.'' For example Lambert and Butler decided that twin balloons with an integrated livery of Range Rovers and trailers and ground crew uniforms all in silver and black indicated most clearly an impression of style and elegance for their cigarettes. Similarily, a special gold fabric was found for the otherwise conventional balloon that promotes Terry's All-Gold chocolates. **********For an annual operating fee of $15,000 his team supervises the design and construction of the balloon. Each client buys his own balloon and basket, costing from $16,000 to $36,000 and boasting a three-year life for advertising purposes. **********Each time the balloon flies, and most manage about 50 flights a year, it costs the client $580 a day, plus expenses, payable even if bad weather forces cancellation of the flight. **********Most clients spend upwards of $50,000 a year in ballooning, Mr.  Prescot said, ''which is a very small proportion of a normal advertising budget and highly cost-effective.'' **********The weather, and most notably the very seasonal nature of the work, poses staffing problems too. The Hot Air Balloon company has just four full-time employees; the rest, and that includes an additonal 30 in the summer, are paid on a daily rate. **********How do clients feel about the service?  ''We've learned that one cannot build up a whole crowd-gathering promotion solely on the expectation of a balloon going up,'' said Jacques Martin, British representative of Ricard. ''There are too many days when the weather is not good enough, expecially with an unusually shaped balloon such as ours. **********''Secondly, the price structure was intended for companies wanting to fly a balloon periodically, but having a daily rate is clearly a very expensive business if you want to use your balloon every day for six months as we did. We'll have to change that.'' **********'' But,'' he added, ''on balance, we're certainly pleased enough to want to continue doing it again this year.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/04/world.main_headline: SCHMIDT'S ARMS POLICY SUFFERS SEVERE SETBACK AT A REGIONAL MEETING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/04/world.print_headline: SCHMIDT'S ARMS POLICY SUFFERS SEVERE SETBACK AT A REGIONAL MEETING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/04/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's policy of supporting a 1979 NATO decision to deploy additional nuclear missiles in Western Europe, if arms control talks fail, suffered a serious setback today when a regional conference of Mr. Schmidt's Social Democratic Party voted overwhelmingly for a review of the decision. **********A regional party conference in the state of Baden-Wurttemberg voted to petition that the Social Democratic Party review its commitment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization decision at a national party conference in early 1982, to see whether the ''official basis'' of the decision still existed or whether a ''revision is necessary.'' **********The conference delegates called for the ''immediate start'' of arms control talks and said that a ''moratorium, limited in time, regarding the stationing of strategic weapons in Europe can be a reasonable part of the talks.'' **********Mr. Schmidt used his influence at a national party conference in West Berlin in 1979 to win support for the NATO decision, despite strong opposition from the left wing of his party. Resistance in Party Grows **********The vote today is seen as a measure of the resistance to the 1979 decision that has grown in the party in recent months.  Bonn and Washington have rejected the idea of a moratorium on plans to station missiles. Russian officials, including Leonid I.  Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, have suggested such a delay in recent months. **********Reflecting the degree of Social Democratic dissatisfaction, the party's chairman, former Chancellor Willy Brandt, said the resolution was ''an important and weighty contribution'' to the party's discussion on arms control. **********In an oblique reference to recent remarks by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that Bonn should spend less for social programs and more for defense, Mr. Brandt said that it was unacceptable that ''people not far from the U.S. President take it upon themselves to determine the federal republic's budget spending.''

They represent 75 percent of the Common Market's annual steel imports of between 10 million and 11 million tons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/13/busin.body_text: **********The Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill today that would allow companies to recover losses incurred from a Government ban on the production of children's sleepwear treated with the chemical Tris, a suspected cancer-causing agent. **********Without objection or a roll-call, the committee sent to the Senate floor the bill, which allows the companies to seek recovery before the Federal Court of Claims. **********Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, who had earlier raised questions about the measure, dropped opposition after the committee approved amendments aimed at preventing manufacturers from reaping a windfall from sales of Tris-treated sleepwear, which was banned in the United States in 1977. **********The amendments are intended to prevent a company from being reimbursed by the Government if it sold Tris-treated products abroad. The companies would be required to show proof that they had not sold the goods for export.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/24/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Danish Politician Convicted of Tax Evasion
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/24/world.body_text: **********Mogens Glistrup, who built up a powerful political party in Denmark by advocating the abolition of taxes, was convicted today of tax evasion. He received the maxiumum sentence of four years in prison and a $1 million fine. **********The Copenhagen High Court also stripped Mr. Glistrup, who had one of Denmark's largest law firms, of the right to practice law for life. **********Mr. Glistrup, who is 55 years old, said he would appeal. He came to prominence in 1971 when he announced he had not paid taxes for years and ''only idiots pay tax.'' **********The next year he formed his Progress Party, whose motto was ''tax evasion is patriotism.'' It also advocated the firing of all civil servants. **********In 1973 the Progress Party won 28 seats in the 179-member Parliament, to become the nation's second largest political party.  It dropped behind the Liberals, the Social Democrats and the Conservatives in subsequent elections. Polls show the party may lose more seats in national elections Dec. 8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/10/busin.main_headline: Chairman of Comdial Given Additional Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chairman of Comdial Given Additional Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/10/busin.body_text: **********Ted E. Westfall, the 62-year-old chairman of the Comdial Corporation, has been elected to the additional position of chief executive officer. He succeeds Don G. Hoff, 45, who continues as president of the San Francisco-based telecommunications terminal company. **********Mr. Westfall, who is both a lawyer and certified public accountant, started at Price Waterhouse & Company and later worked for the General Accounting Office and the Grace Lines. He joined the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in 1960 as a vice president and was an executive vice president when he resigned 14 years later to become a consultant. Mr. Westfall came to Comdial as chairman last September. **********Mr. Hoff was a civilian employee of the Navy who went on to found two companies, Vemco Inc. and General Teletronics, that were later bought by larger corporations. He established Comdial in 1977 and has been its head ever since. **********''I think telecommunications, both transmission and terminals, is perhaps the largest growth area ahead,'' Mr. Westfall said in a telephone interview. ''The deregulation of the telecommunications industry has opened it up to new products. It's something to be expected when you get rid of a monopoly.'' Leonard Sloane

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.main_headline: DUPONT'S CONOCO BID BUOYS STOCKS OF OTHER OIL TARGETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.print_headline: DUPONT'S CONOCO BID BUOYS STOCKS OF OTHER OIL TARGETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.body_text: **********Middle-tier oil stocks advanced sharply yesterday in heavy trading in the wake of the record-breaking $7.3 billion offer by E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company on Monday to buy Conoco, as analysts speculated on which oil company might be the next acquisition target. **********The general conclusion on Wall Street was that the next major candidate would be the nation's 20th-largest oil company, Cities Service - likely to bring a price approaching $4 billion. **********Other oil companies mentioned prominently as targets, although one or more were also considered possible buyers, included Marathon Oil, Phillips Petroleum, Louisiana Land, Pennzoil and Diamond Shamrock. **********Responding to market sentiment, oil issues moved ahead sharply, with Cities Service up 3 5/8, Marathon up 2, Pennzoil up 2 5/8, Louisiana Land up 4, Pennzoil up 3 1/4 and Diamond Shamrock up 3 1/4. **********Conoco, Texasgulf, Cities Service and Mobil led the list of mostactive issues. 'Logical Buyers' **********Among the long list of ''logical buyers'' - all described as ''capable of doing something but not necessarily involved'' - were Getty, Phillips, Texaco, Mobil and Allied, all regarded as possible bidders for Cities Service. **********Potential bidders for other oil company included Tenneco, Pennzoil and even General Electric, which already has vast coal and other natural resources interests through its ownership of Utah International. Still other possibilities mentioned were Sohio, through British Petroleum, its majority stockholder; Gulf, Standard Oil of California and Union Oil. **********Even foreign buyers, such as Deminex of West Germany and Petrofina of Belgium, were thought to be interested in picking up an American company. **********Because premature disclosure of actual negotiations would make prices move sharply higher, dozens of normally approachable executives, along with Wall Street lawyers and investment advisers, refused all comment. **********And despite strong market feeling that the $87.50-a-share Du Pont bid for 100 percent of Conoco seemed almost unassailable by competiting bidders, the Seagram Company, which had earlier offered to pay $73 a share for 40 percent, refused yesterday for the second day to disclose what its next move might be. ' **********A Seagram spokesman said late yesterday that ''the situation is still under study.'' Its advisers are Shearson Loeb Rhoades and Lazard Freres. **********One Wall Street analyst who asked not to be identified maintained that if Seagram attempted to ''stay in the game'' for Conoco it would have to raise its price to somewhere around $90 a share and at the same time increase the amount of shares it would to buy from 40 percent to around 51 percent, a step that would increase the cost to Seagram from $2.5 billion to around $4 billion in cash. 'Another $1.5 Billion?' **********''Will Edgar write a check for another $1.5 billion?'' this analyst asked. **********Edgar Bronfman, Seagram's chairman, is widely regarded as ''an unemotional buyer,'' that is, one who buys companies on the basis of underlying values. **********Other Conoco watchers note, however, that the oil company has been valued by independent analysts at substantially more than $100 a share. **********Moreover, Texaco and a secret bidder are also known to have shown serious interest in Conoco.  Conoco disclosed that it had received an all-cash offer for $85 a share from an undentified bidder, and, to clear the air, Texaco said yesterday that it had not made a firm merger offer. This raised the possibility that the secret bidder was Seagram itself or, possibly, some other big oil company. **********As for Cities Service, informed sources said that whichever company or companies emerged as bidders would first have to deal with Nu-West Group Ltd., a Canadian real estate company with oil and gas interests -and some 8 percent of Cities Service stock. **********In such a situation, these sources said, the buyer and Nu-West would decide how much Cities Service's properties in Canada were worth. Then Nu-West would buy enough Cities Service stock so that it could then swap the stock in exchange for the Canadian properties. **********This, the sources explained, would guarantee that the increasingly nationalistic Canadian Government would not raise objections to the takeover of Canadian operations because, under this arrangement, the Canadian holdings would remain with Nu-West. Cities Service has been vigorously opposing such a plan in the courts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/11/world.body_text: **********A year after sei zing power, Turkey's armed forces are taking the first steps towar d eventually restoring civilian rule. Although no timetable has been given, the expectation is that general elections may be held in 1983 . **********But anxiety appears to be growing among Turkish politicians and intellectuals over the form that the new democracy might take. One reason is that politicians have been barred from any role in the preparatory moves. Other factors cited are increased curbs on the press and greater Government control of the system of justice. **********A prominent figure in the Republican People's Party of former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit said recently that he and his associates were ''very worried about the leadership's concept of the new democracy.'' **********''How can they achieve democracy without politicians and a free press?'' asked the party figure, who declined to be identified. 'Assembly Without Politicians' **********Turker Alkan, a professor of political science at Ankara University, was openly critical in a recent interview of the military rulers' plan for ''an assembly without politicians'' to prepare a constitution for future politicians. **********Politicians and intellectuals are reported generally agreed, however, that the military takeover last Sept. 12 was necessary to restore security in the country. Since then, most of the activists and supporters of the principal extremist organizations have been arrrested; the others have gone underground or fled abroad. Political killings, which averaged 30 a day before the military takeover, have been reduced to under one a day. **********With its gains against political terrorism, the military leadership has begun drafting rules for a constituent assembly to convene on Oct. 23. Sources close to the ruling National Security Council say the assembly's first task will be to draw up a constitution, which in its final form is to be submitted to a referendum, probably late in 1982. **********The sources said, however, that the National Security Council will retain the power to accept or reject the recommendations of the assembly. Former Politicians Barred **********The second task of the assembly, from which members of political parties that existed at the time of the military takeover are to be barred, is to prepare laws governing future parties and elections.  These reportedly are to be ready by the spring of 1983, with general elections expected to follow in the fall of that year. **********The great majority of the Turkish people appear to support the five-member National Security Council, headed by Gen. Kenan Evren, because it has largely succeeded in achieving its immediate aims - the restoration of the authority of the state and the virtual ending of the ''political terrorism'' stemming from clashes between extremist groups. Although many people are suffering from austerity measures, they seem inclined to blame past politicians for the economic problems. **********The restrictions introduced over the last year by the junta, however, have tarnished Turkey's relations with its closest partners in Western Europe. **********While the military rulers have stressed from the outset that they remain committed to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and their goal of membership in the European Common Market, the Market has discouraged a ny application now. The European Parliament has suspended Tur key's membership, and the European Council threatens itsouster. Washington Gives Support **********Of its Western partners, only the United States appears constant in its support of the military regime and has increased its economic and military aid. **********General Evren said recently that the council was determined to restore power to civilians ''once political terrorism is totally eradicated, the economic development of the country is set on firm foundations and a democratic parliamentary system is reestablished.'' **********Trials are under way involving groups of extreme rightists, leftists, Communists, Kurdish separatists and Islamic fundamentalists on charges of terrorism and subversion. The accused reportedly number in the thousands; so far there have been 10 executions. **********''Despite the extraordinary circumstances,'' said Attila Sav, president of the Ankara Bar Association, ''the military authorities are trying to preserve the due process of law.'' **********Mr. Sav added, however, that lawyers had complained to the military authorities about reports of ill treatment of some prisoners and difficulty of access to defendants. **********The restr ictions that have caused uneasines s among politicians and intellectuals were announced in June and were added to the measures taken a year ago when the military assumed po wer. Union Activities Curbed **********Those initial measures included the disbanding of Parliament and the Government, the proclamation of martial law and a ban on trade union activities such as strikes. Although the regime refrained from imposing direct press censorship, it demanded strict self-censorship and closed many small publications considered to be of the radical left or right. Politicians were barred from holding any political meetings or making any public statements. **********The future popularity and stability of the military regime are generally regarded as depending largely on the state of the economy.  Inheriting a disastrous situation with inflation running at an annual rate of more than 100 percent, the generals subscribed fully to a stabilization program launched nine months earlier and made its architect, Turgut Ozal, a Deputy Prime Minister.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Morgan Stanley Appoints Director
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/busin.body_text: **********Edwin H. Yeo 3d, 46 years old, who resigned from the First National Bank of Chicago 15 months ago, reportedly because of personality clashes with other top executives, has been appointed a managing director of Morgan Stanley Inc., effective April 2. He will be concerned with the New York investment banking concern's fixed-income activities, particularly in such matters as government securities and money markets. **********''The areas I hope to be helpful in at Morgan Stanley are very much in line with what I've done in recent years,'' Mr. Yeo said in a telephone interview from Chicago. Reluctant to forecast the trend of interest rates over the next year, he asserted that the fixed-income markets should be ''interesting and tumultuous.'' **********Mr. Yeo began his career in 1959 as a management trainee at the Pittsburgh National Bank, where he rose to vice chairman 14 years later. He was Under Secretary of the Treasury for monetary affairs from 1975 to 1977, when he joined the First National Bank of Chicago as chairman of the asset and liability committee and executive vice president. **********The management of First Chicago was turbulent during much of Mr.  Yeo's tenure there and he resigned in January 1980. For the next 10 months, he was chief financial adviser to Mayor Jane M. Byrne of Chicago. **********Since then, Mr. Yeo has been a consultant, spending most of his time with Morgan Stanley. His new position, he observed, ''evolved from that.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/15/world.main_headline: COMMON MARKET TIES BRING MEAT SHORTAGES IN GREECE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/15/world.print_headline: COMMON MARKET TIES BRING MEAT SHORTAGES IN GREECE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/15/world.body_text: **********Greece is facing meat price increases and scarcities as the first direct problem of membership in the European Common Market. **********The so-called ''meat war'' has seen brawls in marketplaces, arrests and trials of merchants, and a Government attempt to prevent meat from becoming a political issue. **********The problem stems from the fact that under Common Market regulations national subsidies for the production of meat and other goods have had to stop. This has pushed production costs up, forcing wholesalers and then retailers to raise their prices. **********Ioannis Paleokrassas, the Minister of Economic Coordination, said yesterday that the Government had applied to the Common Market for subsidies for imports of frozen meat as a means of keeping down prices. **********The problem began soon after Greece joined the market on Jan. 1 when meat dealers raised their prices as much as 20 percent. Several wholesalers who were arrested maintained in court that market membership meant that prices should be allowed to find their own levels based on supply and demand. The Government insisted that antiinflationary controls would continue and meat prices not be allowed to rise more than 4 to 5 percent. Butchers Fight for Share **********The Government has sent policemen to force compliance and keep order, while butchers have fought for a share of the dwindling supplies. **********''There are ample supplies of meat available both within Greece and from abroad,'' said Nikos Hajipantazis, one of Greece's largest meat producers and importers, who was among those arrested and charged with price violations. ''But the Government must first allow free competition and the laws of supply and demand to operate, so that prices will find their own natural levels. With present soaring production costs it is impossible to stick to the prices prevailing before community membership.'' **********Retail merchants, however, charge that through political connections Mr. Hajipantazis holds a monopoly on supplies. ''We are killing ourselves at the central market to get some of his meat,'' said Dimitris Koukas, a retail butcher. ''Most of us in Athens have closed down our shops because we have little else but chickens to sell.'' Inflation Upsets Public **********Wholesalers have demanded a Government-approved wholesale price for veal of $4.17 a kilo, or 2.2 pounds, and $2.65 for pork, similar to Common Market levels but in both cases 15 cents more than the Government's last offer. When the producers and importers sharply reduced their supplies last week in an attempt to force compliance, the Government countered by placing large meat orders directly with Common Market producers. **********With elections scheduled for November at the latest, the Government's uphill drive to keep prices down is also political.  Inflation has been running at 26 percent annually and has been a major cause of discontent. New increases in fuel prices are expected to be announced in the next few days, which may further aggravate inflation. A rise in the price of basic foods, however, would be directly linked by the consumer to membership in the Common Market and would play into the hands of the opposition Socialists, who have criticized Greece's entry and consistently warned of a price explosion. **********While Mr. Hajipantazis says acceptance of the wholesaler' demands will not affect retail prices, Government officials say it will mean an increase of up to 32 cents a kilo of meat for the consumer. Mr.  Koukas says the increase will be at least 43 cents and will bring a sharp public reaction since meat prices have already been raised 12 percent since Jan 1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/06/busin.body_text: **********''By taxing estates heavily at death, the state marks its condemnation of the selfish millionaire's unworth life.'' - Andrew Carnegie, 1889, industrialist, multimillionaire, philanthropist, advocate of estate taxes. **********''Current estate and gift tax law imposes almost impossible burdens on the most productive sector of the economy.'' - Testimony to Congress, 1981, by Robert L. Spence, chairman of the National Committee to Preserve the Family Business. **********WASHINGTON, July 5 - The problem of heeding both Mr. Carnegie and Mr. Spence is before Congress this year as it considers how much to relax the Federal tax on transfers of wealth by inheritance and giftgiving. **********It is a problem of line-drawing. President Theodore Roosevelt recommended to Congress in 1906 a progressive inheritance tax on ''fortunes swollen beyond all healthy limits.'' Then and now, the legislator's task is to define the limit. **********Two weeks ago, after a quarter-hour of debate, the Senate Finance Committee voted, 17-0, to raise the present $175,000 estate tax exemption in stages to $600,000. That was portrayed as a belated - and equitable - adjustment to inflation. A driving element has been the appreciation of farm land values of the 1970's. Some analysts say that rising land prices represent an income to farmers that escapes income tax. Benefit to Spouse **********The committee also voted to permit an unlimited deduction for a surviving spouse, effectively deferring any estate tax during his or her lifetime if the survivor is the sole heir. The present exemption is 50 percent or $250,000, whichever is more. **********''There's going to be a powerful incentive for people to remarry,'' quipped Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine.  If the provisions approved by the Finance Committee are part of the final 1981 tax bill, as seems likely, the number of taxable estates would fall by 90 percent. However, there may be less here than meets the eye. Only 2.8 percent of all persons who die in 1981 will leave a taxable estate, according to Congressional analysts. Those 56,000 taxable estates will owe $7.3 billion of taxes, a lot of money, but only 1.2 percent of all Federal revenue. Fewer Taxable Estates **********The Treasury has estimated that the annual revenue loss would climb from $1.9 billion in the 1983 fiscal year (which will start Oct. 1, 1982) to $4 billion by the 1985 fiscal year. The committee provision would apply to estates of people who die after Dec. 31, 1981, and would reduce the number of taxable estates to 6,500, according to the Treasury. The Finance Committee would make no change in the present estate tax rates, which range from 18 percent to 70 percent on taxable transfers (bequests or gifts) above $5 million. **********Nominally, the committee adopted the Reagan Administration's proposal on estate taxes. But the underlying reality was that the Administration had embraced legislation sponsored by Senators David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, and Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, both members of the Finance Committee. **********Reducing estate taxes fits in with the Administration's preference for tax changes to encourage saving, investment and the accumulation of wealth. In addition, there was a tactical motive - to win the support of conservative Democrats in the battle over taxes that is likely to occur on the floor of the house of Representatives later this month. A Grass-Roots Issue **********To such pro-Reagan Democrats as Representative Kent Hance of Texas and Dan Daniel of Virginia, easing the estate tax is an important grass-roots issue. **********Advocates of lower estate taxes contend that the issue is the preservation of family farms and businesses. A Republican member of the Senate Finance Committee from Minnesota, David Durenberger, said that in his state ''the average farm is $1 million.'' Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, retorted that ''the average farm is 40 acres and a mule when we're talking about wheat subsidy.'' **********Senator Moynihan, himself a champion of lower capital gains taxes, purported to be perplexed by the proposal to ease estate taxes. ''Why are we doing this?'' he asked, tongue in cheek. Two or three such interjections seemed to say that the New York Democrat felt that the legislation had not been persuasively presented. But Senator Moynihan did not vote against the amendment. No Senator did. Nor did any witness oppose it at hearings early in June. **********As seen by liberal Democrats such as Donald C. Lubick, who was the Treasury's assistant secretary for tax policy from 1977 to 1981, the issue is one of preserving a progressive Federal tax system, one in which rates rise with income. ''If the income tax is not hitting large amounts of income, then the estate tax is a back-up to get some progressivity,'' Mr. Lubick said. Further Cuts Seen Likely **********Mr. Lubick said that reduction of the estate tax should be seen in a wider context. He noted that Congress in 1980 reinstituted law that makes it possible to escape capital gains tax by holding an appreciating asset until death. Mr. Lubick also noted that Congress reduced the maximum income tax rate from 91 to 70 percent in 1964 and this year is likely to cut it to 50 percent. **********Jay Angoff of the Tax Reform Research Group asserted that a graduated estate tax promotes democratic equality of opportunity. ''I don't think it's fair for some people to be born into the world rich as Rockefeller and some people with no money,'' he said. **********Senator Wallop argued that ''estate taxes force farmers or familyowned businesses to sell out to large corporations.'' But the Senator's office was unable to offer supporting evidence. Said a Wallop aide, ''I don't really think you'll find hard statistical evidence.'' Farms Sold to Farmers **********As far as anecdotal evidence goes, some long-time observers of farm life say that when a piece of a farm must be sold to pay estate taxes, the buyer is usually a nearby farmer. **********For years, President Reagan has said that he favored repeal of the estate and gift taxes. Considering that position, the Finance Committee Chairman, Senator Robert Dole, Republican of Kansas, said the Administration had taken ''a rather mild approach.'' **********The second-ranking Democrat, Harry F. Byrd Jr. of Virginia, himself an heir to extensive land holdings, said he thought that an approach that left unchanged a maximum estate tax rate of 70 percent did not go far enough, although he applauded the larger exemption. No Revision Since 1976 **********First enacted in 1916, the estate tax was last revised in 1976, the first change since 1942. As several witnesses reminded the committee, the exemption for gift taxes of $3,000 a year to each recipient has been unchanged since 1942 despite inflation. The pending bill would raise the exemption to $10,000. That would make it possible for a husband and wife to each give each of their children $20,000 a year tax-free. **********Although enacted in 1916 to raise revenue to help finance a military build-up, an estate tax had been used temporarily to help finance the Civil War. Its ideological roots were in the progressivism of the 1880's and 1890's. **********''Its roots and later history are both bound up with the Democratic dream of equal opportunity for all,'' according to Boris I. Bittker and Lawrence M. Stone in their law school textbook on taxes. United in Professed Sentiment **********Such sentiments may be swept aside in the present climate in which both parties profess to favor greater saving and capital formation. **********A Republican member of the Finance Committee, Senator Steven D.  Symms of Idaho, said that the estate tax should be repealed because ''the estate was built with money that already has had tax paid on it.'' **********That prompted Senator Dole to say that repeal might come after 1984, the year President Reagan has set for balancing the budget.  As for protecting equal opportunity, Senator Symms told a reporter, ''if it worked out like that'' the tax would be worth keeping. But, he argued, its principal effect is to cause forced liquidation of family-owned businesses, such as the sale of independent newspapers to large corporate chains. **********Although a few academicians and tax specialists may favor the estate tax, no constituency for keeping it has come forward. If that continues to be true, repeal may not be far off.
