https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/world.body_text: **********IRAQ VOWS TO PUSH NUCLEAR PLANS DESPITE ISRAELI THREAT **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 (UPI) - The Iraqi Government vowed today to press ahead with its nuclear program despite the threat by Israel's Prime Minister, Menachem Begin, to order a new attack if the nuclear reactor raided last Sunday was rebuilt. **********'Iraq will not be deterred by enemy plots,'' Information Minister Latif Nusayyef Jassem wrote in an article printed today in the state-run Baghdad newspaper Al Jumhuriya. He said that Iraq was ''capable of establishing new and better nuclear installations.'' **********Mr. Jassem wrote that the Israeli air strike on the French-built nuclear research plant on Sunday showed that Israel knew its ''real and decisive danger'' came from the forces of Iraq. **********However, Iraq has denied Israeli charges that it was building a nuclear bomb.  The Information Minister's article followed an announcement from Paris that the French Government had made clear it would consider a request to rebuild the shattered 70-megawatt Osirak reactor. **********However, the French concerns working on the reactor said that they were summoning home all but 12 or so of the 150 technicians working at the plant east of Baghdad. Those staying behind were assigned to operate an earlier and much smaller reactor supplied by France. ---- One Bomb Reported Unexploded **********PARIS, June 10 (UPI) - A French worker who witnessed the Israeli raid on the Iraqi nuclear plant said here today that cleanup work at the reactor site was impossible for the present because one of the bombs dropped there did not explode. He called the accuracy of the Israeli bombing ''stupefying.'' **********''The central building is entirely collapsed,'' said Jacques Rimbaud, a construction worker of Bouygues S.A., a French company working on the project. **********''The atomic reactor is unreachable and the antiradiation shield has disappeared,'' he said.  Mr. Rimbaud said that before the plant could be rebuilt, ''you will have to destroy everything that remains.'' One French technician, Damien Chaussepied, 25 years old, was killed in the attack. Israeli officials have said, without elaboration, that no more than three persons were killed in the raid. Site Surrounded by Defenses **********Another French witness to the raid, Jean-Francois Masciola, an electrician, said that the site was surrounded by military defenses and antiaircraft weapons but that they were apparently caught unprepared by the attack. **********''It seems one of the bombs did not explode,'' Mr. Rimbaud said.  He gave no indication whether the Israelis might have intentionally dropped a delayed action weapon to hamper damage-control efforts. **********Mr. Rimbaud said that he had had a perfect view from a compound about 550 yards away as the Israeli jets made two runs above the reactor building to drop bombs. He said that ''the Israelis chose their hour perfectly'' to minimize casualties. Nearly all the French technicians had finished work and left the site before the attack began, he said. **********Mr. Rimbaud was one of the first French technicians to leave Iraq after the attack. Employees of two Italian companies also worked at the Iraqi plant and a spokesman for one of them said in Rome yesterday that about 25 of the company's 100 employees were returning to Italy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; WARM RESPONSE TO BUDGET PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/busin.body_text: **********Corporate America yesterday welcomed President Reagan's economic program - particularly his proposals to encourage investment - as a long-needed change in Government policy. **********Many of the nation's top business executives said that they expected the President's economic plans, if approved by Congress, to lead to increased investment in new plant and equipment. They also believe that his proposed tax revisions will put the consumer in a better buying mood. **********But as the businessmen passed from near-euphoria after the President's address Wednesday night to a more analytical mood, many were unable to cite the definite effects the proposals might have on their companies. **********''The total program will encourage us to increase our capital expenditures program, but we aren't prepared at this moment to say how,'' said Marshall Hahn, president of COMPANY NEWS: Reagan Impact the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, a leading forest products company.  ''We're pleased to see the efforts to control inflation by cutting federal spending and by accelerating the depreciation allowances.'' **********The J.C. Penney Company expects that the President's proposals for improved depreciation allowances for businesses will stimulate retailers' returns on their investment in stores and other facilities. ''That, in turn,'' said Donald V. Seibert, chairman, ''will help to increase cash flow and stimulate additional investment.'' **********But Mr. Reagan's forecast that his three-year slowdown in income tax rates would put $500 billion in consumers' hands over the next five years drew some skepticism from Mr. Seibert. ''Tax cuts, in helping to improve the economy, will of course mean that retailers will get their share. But tax cuts do not have the immediate effect of tax rebates.'' **********However, Henry H. Henley Jr., chairman of Cluett, Peabody & Company, said he believed the Reagan program ''will stimulate the economy right off because of an improved public attitude.'' The chairman of the apparel company said he expected retailers to receive a prompt stimulus in sales: ''Our business should respond positively.'' **********But there were also caveats from other executives. Irving S.  Shapiro, chairman of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, noted that improved depreciation policies were needed because ''industry has been decapitalized.'' But Mr. Shapiro, while agreeing on the Federal budget cuts, observed that the total Reagan program might prove inflationary. **********''All we've got to rely on is an economic theory,'' Mr. Shapiro said. ''No businessman can run his company on an untried business theory. I expect Congress to go ahead with the depreciation proposals and the first-year tax cut, and then sit back on the tax cuts for the other years to see how the initial phase works.'' **********Reginald H. Jones, chairman of the General Electric Company, said, ''We endorse the concept of a smaller public sector, and achieving it by simultaneously lowering taxes and expenditures. **********''But it seems to me that there is considerable confusion about the role of the Export-Import Bank, which is primarily a lending, not a spending agency. Cutting its lending authority has minimal impact on the budget but will have significant negative impact on United States exports. Reducing the lending authority of the Export-Import Bank thus cripples our international competitiveness.'' Stronger Credit Markets **********In the financial community, the mood also was one of hope, and at Dillon Read & Company, a prominent investment banking house, there was ''cautious optimism.'' Charles A. Ballard, managing director, said, ''For the first time in at least a decade, the President will not be part of a creation of a fiscal policy based on social programs.'' **********Regarding his company's position if the President's proposals go through, he said: ''We see a trending of improvement in the capital markets. We don't necessarily anticipate wild rallies in the debt or equity markets, but rather a trend to more stable markets. That could amount to our ox being gored, because the return to stability away from market volatility may mean fewer opportunities for investment bankers.'' **********At the General Motors Corporation in Detroit, Roger B. Smith, chairman, said that he was ''heartened'' by the President's intention to pursue significant reductions in projected government spending, tax changes geared to promote savings and investment and reductions in the costs of government regulation. Textile Makers Enthusiastic **********The textile industry also greeted the Reagan program with enthusiasm. **********David W. Johnston Jr., chairman of Dan River Inc., said that he particularly welcomed those portions of the budget designed to provide incentives for capital formation and investment. **********Whitney Stevens, chairman of J.P. Stevens & Company, called it all ''very encouraging,'' while Otto Stolz, chairman of Cannon Mills Inc., said that, on balance, ''the program merits substantial support.'' **********In San Francisco, Karl Slacik, senior vice president and chief financial officer of Levi Strauss Inc., said: ''The accelerated costrecovery system should have a beneficial effect upon our expansion of existing facilities and our addition of several new facilities within the next year. The tax reductions on investment income and capital gains will stimulate savings and productive investments.'' Comments on Medicaid Cuts **********In the medical services field, Karl D. Bays, chairman of the American Hospital Supply Corporation in Evanston, Ill., observed: ''I don't think the cutback in Medicaid will affect us. It's true, there is a lot of abuse in the Medicaid program, and I think it's a good idea to move more authority back to the states where it belongs.'' **********And Morris Yoffe, president of American Medical Affiliates Inc., Jenkintown, Pa., which operates nursing homes, said that the President's program would trim ''a lot of waste and duplication - eliminating the health system bureaucracy will allow the free enterprise system to take effect.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/03/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Agency Is Right On Track
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/03/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Agency Is Right On Track
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/03/busin.body_text: **********STANLEY RAPP thinks his agency is on a winning streak. He has every right to. Rapp & Collins, since 1976 the direct marketing subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach, ended last week by picking up its third piece of new business for the month, a short month at that. **********It is to do circulation promotion for Geo, the slick, generalinterest, monthly magazine from Gruner & Jahr, the German publishers, which is expected to have billings of more than $1 million. **********The month's biggest account was won the earliest - the RCA Record and Tape Club, which could bill $6 million or more. Then came the W.  Atlee Burpee Company, seed sellers and the country's biggest catalogue house, which will probably spend in the $2 million neighborhood. **********Each of the accounts is coming from an agency that is a subsidiary of a major agency, as is Rapp and Collins. Geo was handled by Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam. **********Bigness, you see, is the direction in which the direct marketing segment of the advertising agency is heading. **********As the bearded, 52-year-old Mr. Rapp said of the 1975 period: ''It was becoming apparent that Fortune 500 companies and other major marketers were becoming very interested in getting additional business by direct marketing.'' **********Slightly later, he added, ''An important consideration for being acquired is that a $20 million agency is not in a league to be considered by a $1 billion corporation as a source for meeting their needs.'' **********That was the feeling he and his associates had when D.D.B., Needham, Harper & Steers, and Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, all big boys, came calling as suitors. That was about five years ago, a year after Young & Rubicam had acquired Wunderman, the largest agency of its kind. Since then almost all of the larger independent direct marketing specialty agencies have become part of the giant general agencies, a number of which have also acquired capabilities in health-care and recruitment advertising, sales promotion, and public relations fields, and become total communications companies. **********It is ironic, however, that the agencies with acquired direct marketing subsidiaries do not include Foote, Cone & Belding, because it was that international agency that was far ahead of the field when it decided late in 1964 to found a direct marketing agency and sent a headhunter after a couple of people to do it. **********As Mr. Rapp remembers it, when he was asked if he was interested in estabishing such a division, he said he would be willing if they could get Tom Collins, the copy chief at Wunderman, who he knew only by reputation. It turned out that Mr. Collins was presenting the same conditions about Mr. Rapp. **********''It was a marriage made in heaven; we've been together 16 years,'' Mr. Rapp recalled, noting that the writer decided a couple of years back to step out of management and spend more time at his farm in Liberty, N.Y. At the agency he has discovered the three-day week. **********R.&C. had begun as a division of F.C.&B. in 1965 with the Cleveland Institute of Electronics as its first client. In 1969, when it was billing a respectable $9 million, its client Capitol Records, billing $5 million, was acquired by Longines Symphonette, which decided to do the advertising in-house. **********''We became a much smaller agency,'' Mr. Rapp said, ''but problems are opportunities. And we made Foote, Cone an offer it couldn't refuse.'' It was a three-year buy-out. **********A couple of years later, however, the two were ready for a little more action and merged with Stone & Adler of Chicago, same specialty, same size. This marriage lasted until D.D.B. came along and its client list had too many conflicts with those of Stone & Adler. So they split, and Stone & Adler later became part of Young & Rubicam, the Jaws of the agency business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/05/busin.body_text: **********The Soviet Union has bought another 400,000 tons of American grain.  The Agriculture Department said yesterday that the sales - 300,000 tons of wheat and 100,000 tons of corn -counted against the sixth year of the recently extended grain agreement, which begins Oct.1. **********Soviet purchases planned in the sixth year now total 3.45 million tons, 2.05 million in corn and the rest in wh eat. In the current year, the Soviet Union has purchased 9.55 mil lion tons of grain, 5.9 million in corn and the rest in wheat. **********The new agreement calls for a minimum purchase of 6 million tons, and up to 8 million without consultation.  In a related development, American and Chinese negotiators wrapped up two days of talks this week on the second year of a four-year grain pact. **********Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said that the United States had told the Chinese they could buy more than the current limit of 9 million tons in the year beginning Jan.1, but that the Chinese had been noncommittal. **********Under the agreement signed last year, China is required to buy at least 6 million metric tons of wheat and corn, and may buy 3 million additional tons without further consultation. China has bought more than 6.5 million tons of wheat and 214,300 tons of corn for delivery in 1981; purchases for 1982 include about 450,000 tons of wheat.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/world.main_headline: GRAHAM GREENE DOUBTS HOLLIS WAS SOVIET AGENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/world.print_headline: GRAHAM GREENE DOUBTS HOLLIS WAS SOVIET AGENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/world.body_text: **********Graham Greene said today that he believed the world's secret services were riddled with traitors, but he discounted allegations that the late Sir Richard Hollis, Britain's counterintelligence chief, was a Soviet agent. **********The 76-year-old author and former intelligence officer told reporters that spies ''begin to feel a game rather than a cause and begin to play the game both sides.'' **********He called a report that Sir Richard, who was for nine years the head of MI-5, Britain's counterintelligence agency, might have been a Soviet spy ''an obvious piece of disinformation originating probably in Russia.'' He offered no explanation to support his statement. **********Chapman Pincher, a British reporter, said in a book excerpted last month in The Daily Mail of London that top-level investigators had looked into the possiblity that Sir Richard was a double agent. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told Parliament there was no evidence to incriminate Sir Richard, who died in 1973, but she ordered a new investigation of Britain's security services. **********Mr. Greene confirmed that he had received letters recently from H.A.R Philby, known as Kim, a Briton serving the Soviet Union who infiltrated the upper echelon of British intelligence before defecting to Moscow in 1963. **********Mr. Greene said that Mr. Philby, his former superior, apparently was trying to mislead him with information on the situations in Iran and Afghanistan. He did not disclose further details of Mr. Philby's letters. **********''We were friends,'' the writer said of Mr. Philby. ''I knew he was left-wing, but I didn't know he was Communist. I respect his Communism. He didn't do it for money.'' **********Mr. Greene is in Israel to receive the $2,000 Jerusalem Prize, a biannual literary award.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/16/world.body_text: **********Supporters of Nicaragua's ruling leftist Sandinist movement seized parts of the town of Nandaime and prevented what would have been the opposition's first public meeting since the leftists came to power in 1979, opposition spokesmen said today. **********The spokesmen said that leaders of the Democratic Movement decided to postpone the meeting in Nandaime, 40 miles south of Managua, after Sandinist militiamen set up barricades in the main streets of the town. **********The postponement of the rally followed violent clashes yesterday between Sandinist supporters and their political opponents on the outskirts of Managua, in which two people were killed, Government officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/03/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; AMPLE VARIETY DUE AT AUCTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/03/busin.body_text: **********The words ''peak'' and ''record high'' have become worn with overuse in the credit markets, but the weight of this week's Treasury financings could provoke several more rounds of headlines proclaiming high rates. **********Predictions of declining interest rates are common, but investors are cautious buyers and seem to require yields well above recent inflation rates. Dealers acknowledge that their market remains quite volatile, and the pattern of sharp swings with successively higher peaks in rates is one reason why investors are cautious about buying long-term issues. **********''Long-term yields have just established record highs for the fifth time in the last 16 months,'' analysts at Salomon Brothers observed in the July 31 issue of Comments on Credit. **********May Revive Speculators **********While investors are wary, many market participants said this week's Treasury auctions should attract investors and speculators who have been dormant for the last month or so. ''There are no numbers to prove it, but I've got a strong feeling that this market will do all right,'' commented George Hester, vice-president at Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis's government dealer subsidiary. Along with others, he noted that some foreign interest is evident for upcoming issues, as are trading accounts at the thousands of securities firms and money managers across the country. **********There will be an ample selection of new Treasury issues in many maturities. **********- Today the Treasury sells $4.3 billion each of three- and sixmonth bills in minimun denominations of $10,000. **********- Tomorrow the Treasury sells $4.25 billion of 3 1/4-year notes due November 1984 in minimum denominations of $5,000. **********- On Wednesday the Treasury sells $2.25 billion of 9 3/4-year, 14 percent notes due May 1991 in minimum denominations of $1,000. **********- On Thursday, the Treaury sell $2 billion of 29 3/4-year, 13 7/8 percent bonds due May 2011 in minimum denominations of $1,000. **********- On Friday, the Treasury sells $4.5 billion of one-year bills in minimum denominations of $10,000. Reminiscent of May **********If buyers do appear in force, it would resemble the early May Treasury financing, which was the catalyst for a six-week buying spree that carried the 13 7/8 percent Treasury bonds due 2011 to a price of 110. Since mid-June, however, prices have been mostly lower until late Friday when the same bonds were offered at 99 1/4 to yield 13.98 percent. **********Yields in the Treasury market this week would look very familiar to an investor who participated in the May refunding and then went on a long vacation. The 3-year, 10-year and 30-year issues sold then correspond to this week's note and bond offerings, and late Friday the outstanding issues were offered with yields of 15.78 percent, 14.68 percent, and 13.98 percent. **********Whether or not interest rates are higher than last May's comparable issues, salesmen will try to convince buyers that this is an opportunity to buy before interest rates decline. Besides a high yield from interest payments, a large capital gain would result. If for example, 30-year Treasury bond yields fell to 12 percent, their prices would rise about 14 points, or $140 per $1,000 bond. Inflation Incentive **********In a report analysts at Merrill Lynch pointed out that buyers have even more reason to buy now than they did in May, when yields were about the same. ''Economic activity posted a decline in the previous quarter and could continue to decline in the present quarter, several more months of favorable inflation numbers are now under out belts.  M-1B growth remains exceedingly sluggish and the Fed is easing -not tightening - its credit reins,'' the report said. **********If the uncertainty of investor demand and financing costs were not enough, securities dealers may find another yet another obstacle between them and a profitable underwriting of the Treasury's debt. **********The air traffic controller's strike could interrupt the Federal Reserve's transportation system, and cause a huge multibillion-dollar increase in the float, or checks in transit between banks. Increased float results in additional bank reserves, which the Fed will have to offset with temporary sales of securities that it owns. Unfortunatly, the Fed will not have perfect knowlege of reserves being added to the banking system by float, or any other aberrations. **********''It's the lousiest setting for a Treasury refunding I can think of,'' said William Melton, a money market economist at Irving Trust.  He explained that rates on overnight loans in Federal funds might fall during the week, which would cause aggressive buying of new issues even though the drop in the funds rate would be a result of the excess float, rather than any easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve. **********Alernatively, Mr. Melton said, the funds rate could be unusually high if the Fed overestimated the reserves it must drain to offset the increase in float. The result then would be higher interest rates as dealers worried about higher financing costs while investors waited until the smoke cleared.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM ENGLISH VERSION OF THE POPE'S ENCYCLICAL 'ON HUMAN WORK'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM ENGLISH VERSION OF THE POPE'S ENCYCLICAL 'ON HUMAN WORK'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from the official English version of the encyclical of Pope John Paul II ''On Human Work'': **********Through work man must earn his daily bread and contribute to the continual advance of science and technology and, above all, to elevating unceasingly the cultural and moral level of the society within which he lives in community with those who belong to the same family. **********And work means any activity by man, whether manual or intellectual,whatever its nature or circumstances, it mean s any human activity that can and must be recognized as work, in t he midst of all the manyactivities of which man is capable and to whi ch he is predisposed by his very nature, by virtue of humanity itself . Man is made to be in the visible universe an image and likeness of God Himself, and he is placed in it in order to subdue the earth. Fr om the beginning therefore he is called to work. **********Work is one of the characteristics that distinguish man from the rest of creatures, whose activity for sustaining their lives cannot be called work. Only man is capable of work, and only man works, at the same time by work occupying his existence on earth. Thus work bears a particular mark of man a nd of humanity, the mark of a person operating wit hin a community of persons. And this mark decides its interior char acteristics; in a sense it constitutes its very nature. Introduction **********Since 15 May of the present year was the 90th anniversary of the publication by the great Pope of the ''Social Question,'' Leo XIII, of the decisively important encyclical which begins with the words ''Rerum Novarum,'' I wish to devote this document to human work and, even more, to man in the vast context of the reality of work. **********Man's life is built up every day from work, from work it derives its specific dignity, but at the same time work contains the unceasing measure of human toil and suffering, and also of the harm and injustice which penetrate deeply into social life within individual nations and on the international level. **********While it is true that man eats the bread produced by the work of his hands - and this means not only the daily bread by which his body keeps alive but also the bread of science and progress, civilization and culture - it is also a perennial truth that he eats this bread by ''the sweat of his face,'' that is to say, not only by personal effort and toil but also in the midst of many tensions, conflicts and crises, which, in relationship with the reality of work, disturb the life of individual societies and also of all humanity. Work as Merchandise **********In the modern period, from the beginning of the industrial age, the Christian truth about work had to oppose the various trends of materialistic and economistic thought. **********For certain supporters of such ideas, work was understood and treated as a sort of merchandise that the worker -especially the industrial worker -sells to the employer, who at the same time is the possessor of the capital, that is to say, of all the working tools and means that make production possible. This way of looking at work was widespread especially in the first half of the 19th century.  Since then, explicit expressions of this sort have almost disappeared and have given way to more human ways of thinking about work and evaluating it. **********The interaction between the worker and the tools and means of production has given rise to the development of various forms of capitalism - parallel with various forms of collectivism -into which other socioeconomic elements have entered as a consequence of new concrete circumstances, of the activity of workers' associations and public authorities and of the emergence of large transnational enterprises. Nevertheless, the danger of treating work as a special kind of merchandise or as an impersonal force needed for production (the expression work force is in fact in common use) always exists, especially when the whole way of looking at the question of economics is marked by the premises of materialistic economism. **********Everybody knows that capitalism has a definite historical meaning as a system, an economic and social system, opposed to Socialism or Communism. But in the light of the analysis of the fundamental reality of the whole economic process - first and foremost of the production structure that work is - it should be recognized that the error of early capitalism can be repeated wherever man is in a way treated on the same level as the whole complex of the material means of production, as an instrument and not in accordance with the true dignity of his work - that is to say, where he is not treated as subject and maker, and for this very reason as the true purpose of the whole process of production. **********The development of human civilization brings continual enrichment in this field. But at the same time, one cannot fail to note that in the process of this development not only do new forms of work appear but also others disappear. Even if one accepts that on the whole this is a normal phenomenon, it must still be seen whether certain ethically and socially dangerous irregularities creep in, and to what extent. **********It was precisely one such wide-ranging anomaly that gave rise in the last century to what has been called ''the worker question,'' sometimes described as ''the proletariat question.'' Burst of Solidarity **********This question and the problems connected with i t gave rise to a just social reaction and caused the impetuous emergence of a great burst of solidarity between workers, first an d foremost industrial workers. The call to solidarity and common ac tion addressed to the workers - especially to those engaged in narr owly specialized, monotonous and depersonalized work in industr ial plants, when the machine tends to dominate man - was important and eloquent from the point of view of social ethics. It was the re action against the degradation of man as the subject of work and against the unheard-of accompanying exploitation in the field of wag es, working conditions and social security for the workers. This rea ction united the workingworld in a community marked by great solidari ty. Following t he lines laid down by the encyclical ''Rerum Novarum'' and many late r documents of the church's magisterium, it must be frankly recog nized that the reaction against the system of injustice and harm that cried to heaven for vengeance and that weighed heavily upon workers in that period of rapid industrialization was justified from the poin t of view of social morality. This state of affairs was favored by th e liberal sociopolitical system, which in accordance with its ''ec onomistic'' premises, strengthened and safeguarded economic init iative by the possessors of capital alone, but did not pay sufficien t attention to the rights of the workers, on the groundsthat human wo rk is solely an instrument of production and that capital is th e basis, efficient factor and purpose of production. Injustices Persist **********From that time, worker solidarity, together with a clearer and more committed realization by others of workers' rights, has in many cases brought about profound changes. Various forms of neocapitalism or collectivism have developed. Various new systems have been thought out. Workers can often share in running businesses and in controlling their productivity and in fact do so. Through appropriate associations, they exercise influence over conditions of work and pay and also over social legislation. But at the same time various ideological or power systems, and new relationships which have arisen at various levels of society, have allowed flagrant injustices to persist or have created new ones. **********There must be continued study of the subject of work and of the subject's living conditions. In order to achieve social justice in the various parts of the world, in the various countries and in the relationships between them, there is a need for ever new movements of solidarity of the workers and with the workers. This solidarity must be present whenever it is called for by the social degrading of the subject of work, by exploitation of the workers and by the growing areas of poverty and even hunger. **********The church is firmly committed to this cause, for she considers it her mission, her service, a proof of her fidelity to Christ, so that she can truly be the ''church of the poor.'' Conflict Between Labor and Capital **********The encyclical ''Rerum Novarum,'' which has the social question as its theme, stresses the issue of ownership or property, recalling and confirming the church's teaching on ownership, on the right to private property even when it is a question of the means of production. The encyclical ''Mater et Magistra'' did the same. **********The above principle, as it was then stated and as it is still taught by the church, diverges radically from the program of collectivism as proclaimed by Marxism and put into practice in various countries in the decades following the time of Leo XIII's encyclical. At the same time it differs from the program of capitalism practiced by liberalism and by the political systems inspired by it. In the latter case, the difference consists in the way the right to ownership or property is understood. Christian tradition has never upheld this right as absolute and untouchable. **********On the contrary, it has always understood this right within the broader context of the right common to all to use the goods of the whole of creation: the right to private property is subordinated to the right to common use, to the fact that goods are meant for everyone. Nature of Ownership **********Furthermore, in the church's teaching, ownership has never been understood in a way that could constitute grounds for social conflict in labor. As mentioned above, property is acquired first of all through work in order that it may serve work. This concerns in a special way ownership of the means of production. Isolating these means as a separate property in order to set it up in the form of capital in opposition to labor - and even to practice exploitation of labor - is contrary to the very nature of these means and their possession. **********They cannot be possessed against labor; they cannot even be possessed for possession's sake, because the only legitimate title to their possession -whether in the form of private ownership or in the form of public or collective ownership - is that they should serve labor and thus, by serving labor, that they should make possible the achievement of the first princip le of this order, namely the universal destination of goods and the right to common useof them. **********From this point of view, therefore, in consideration of human labor and of common access to the goods meant for man, one cannot exclude the socialization, in suitable conditions, of certain means of production. **********If it is true that capital, as the whole of the means of production, is at the same time the product of the work of generations, it is equally true that capital is being unceasingly created through the work done with the help of all these means of production, and these means can be s een as a great workbench at which the pre sent generation of workers is working day after day.  Obviously we are dealing here with different kinds of work, not only so-called man ual labor but also the many forms of intellectual work, including whi te-collar work and management. Protecting Ownership **********In the light of the above, the many proposals put forward by experts in Catholic social teaching and by the highest magisterium of the church take on special significance: proposals for joint ownership of the means of work, sharing by the workers in the management and/or profits of businesses, so-called shareholding by labor etc. Whether these various proposals can or cannot be applied concretely, it is clear that recognition of the proper position of labor and the worker in the production process demands various adaptations in the sphere of the right to ownership of the means of production. **********Therefore, while the position of ''rigid'' capitalism must undergo continual revision in order to be reformed from the point of view of human rights, both human rights in the widest sense and those linked with man's work, it must be stated that, from the same point of view, these many deeply desired reforms cannot be achieved by an a priori elimination of private ownership of the means of production.  For it must be noted that merely taking these means of production (capital) out of the hands of their private owners is not enough to insure their satisfactory socialization. They cease to be the property of a certain social group, namely the private owners, and become the property of organized society, coming under the administration and direct control of another group of people, namely those who, though not owning them, from the fact of exercising power in society manage them on the level of the whole national or the local economy. **********The princple of the priority of labor over capital is a postulate of the order of social morality. It has key importance both in the system built on the principle of private ownership of the means of production and also in the system in which private ownership of these means has been limited even in a radical way. Labor is in a sense inseparable from capital, in no way does it accept the separation and opposition with regard to the means of production that has weighed upon human life in recent centuries as a result of merely economic premises. When man works, using all the means of production, he also wishes the fruit of this work to be used by himself and others, and he wishes to be able to take part in the very work process as a sharer in responsibility and creativity at the workbench to which he applies himself. Rights of Workers **********While work, in all its many senses, is an obligation, that is to say a duty, it is also a source of rights on the part of the worker.  These rights must be examined in the broad context of human rights as a whole, which are connatural with man, and many of which are proclaimed by various international organizations and increasingly guaranteed by the individual states for their citizens. Respect for this broad range of human rights constitutes the fundamental condition for peace in the modern world: peace both within individual countries and societies and in international relations, as the church's magisterium has several times noted, especially since the encyclical ''Pacem in Terris.'' The human rights that flow from work are part of the broader context of those fundamental rights of the person. **********Experience confirms that there must be a social re-evaluation of the mother's role, of the toil connected with it and of the need that children have for care, love and affection in order that they may develop into responsible, morally and religiously mature and psychologically stable persons. It will redound to the credit of society to make it possible for a mother - without inhibiting her freedom, without psychological or practical discrimination and without penalizing her as compared with other women - to devote herself to taking care of her children and educating them in accordance with their needs, which vary with age. The Need for Unions **********All these rights, together with the need for the workers themselves to secure them, give rise to yet another right: the right of association, that is to form associations for the purpose of defending the vital interests of those employed in the various professions. These associations are called labor or trade unions. The vital interests of the workers are to a certa in extent common for allof them; at the same time however each type o f work, each profession,has its own specific character which should f ind a particular reflection in these organizations. **********In a sense, unions go back to the medieval guilds of artisans, insofar as those organizations brought together people belonging to the same craft and thus on the basis of their work. **********However, unions differ from the guilds on this essential point: The modern unions grew up from the struggle of the workers - workers in general but especially the industr ial workers - to protect their justrights vis-a- vis the entrepreneurs and the owners of the means of production. T heir task is to defend the existential interests of workers in al l sectors in which their rights are concerned. The experience of history teaches that organizations of this type are an indispensable element of social life, especially in modern industrialize d societies. Obviously, this does not mean that only industrial wo rkers can set up associations of this type.  Representativ es of every profession can use them to insure their own rights. 'For' but Not 'Against' **********Catholic social teaching does not hold that unions are no more than a reflection of the class structure of society and that they are agents for a class struggle which inevitably governs social life.  They are indeed advocates for the struggle for social justice, for the just rights of working people in accordance with their individual professions. However, this struggle should be seen as a normal endeavor ''for'' the just good: in the present case, for the good which corresponds to the needs and merits of working people associated by profession, but it is not a struggle ''against'' others. **********Even if in controversial questions the struggle takes on a character of opposition toward others, this is because it aims at the good of social justice, not for the sake of ''struggle'' or in order to eliminate the opponent. It is characteristic of work that it first and foremost unites people. In this consists its social power: the power to build a community. In the final analysis, both those who work and those who manage the means of production or who own them must in some way be united in this community. Limits to Union Demands **********In the light of this fundamental structure of all work - in the light of the fact that, in the final analysis, labor and capital are indispensable components of the process of production in any social system - it is clear that, even if it is because of their work needs that people unite to secure their rights, their union remains a constructive factor of social order and solidarity, and it is impossible to ignore it. **********Just efforts to secure the rights of workers who are united by the same profession should always take into account the limitations imposed by the general economic situation of the country. Union demands cannot be turned into a kind of group or class egoism, although they can and should also aim at correcting - with a view to the common good of the whole of society - everything defective in the system of ownership of the means of production or in the way these are managed. Social and socioeconomic life is certainly like a system of ''connected vessels,'' and every social activity directed toward safeguarding the rights of particular groups should adapt itself to this system. **********In this sense, union activity undoubtedly enters the field of politics, understood as prudent concern for the common good. However, the role of unions is not to ''play politics'' in the sense that the expression is commonly understood today. Unions do not have the character of political parties struggling for power; they should not be subjected to the decision of political parties or have too close links with them. In fact, in such a situation they easily lose contact with their specific role, which is to secure the just rights of workers within the framework of the common good of the whole of society; instead they become an instrument used for other purposes. **********One method used by unions in pursuing the just rights of their members is the strike or work stoppage as a kind of ultimatum to the competent bodies, especially the employers. This method is recognized by Catholic social teaching as legitimate in the proper conditions and within just limits. **********While admitting that it is a legitimate means, we must at the same time emphasize that a strike remains, in a sense, an extreme means.  It must not be abused, it must not be abused especially for ''political'' purposes. Furthermore, it must never be forgotten that, when essential community services are in question, they must in every case be insured, if necessary by means of appropriate legislation.  Abuse of the strike weapon can lead to the paralysis of the whole of socioeconomic life, and this is contrary to the requirements of the common good of society, which also corresponds to the properly understood nature of work itself. Elements for a Spirituality of Work It is right to devote the last part of thes e reflections about human work, on the occasion of the 90th anniv ersary of the encyclical''Rerum Novarum,'' to the spirituality of wor k in the Christian sense. Since work in its subjective aspect is always a personal action, an actus personae, it follows that th e whole person, body and spirit, participates in it, whether it is manual or intellectual work. It is also to the whole person that the word of the living God is directed, the evangelical message of salva tion, in which we find many points which concern human work and whic h throw particular lighton it . **********These points need to be properly assimilated: An inner effort on the part of the human spirit, guided by faith, hope and charity, is needed in order that through these points the work of the individual human being may be given the meaning which it has in the eyes of God and by means of which work enters into the salvation process on a par with the other ordinary yet particularly important components of its texture. **********The truth that by means of work man participates in the activity of God himself, his Creator, was given particular prominence by Jesus Christ - the Jesus at whom many of his first listeners in Nazareth ''were astonished, saying, 'Where did this man get all this? What is the wisdom given to Him? ... Is not this the Carpenter?' '' For Jesus not only proclaimed but first and foremost fulfilled by His deeds the ''gospel,'' the word of eternal wisdom, that had been entrusted to Him. Therefore this was also ''the gospel of work,'' because He who proclaimed it was Himself a man of work, a craftsman like Joseph of Nazareth. **********And if we do not find in his words a special command to work - but rather on one occasion a prohibition against too much anxiety about work and life - at the same time the eloquence of the life of Christ is unequivocal: He belongs to the working world, He has appreciation and respect for human work. It can indeed be said that He looks with love upon human work and the different forms that it takes, seeing in each one of these forms a particular facet of man's likeness with God, the Creator and Father. Is it not He who says, ''My Father is the vinedresser,'' and in various ways puts into His teaching the fundamental truth about work which is already expressed in the whole tradition of the Old Testament, beginning with the Book of Genesis?

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/28/busin.main_headline: Executives Move Up At Superior Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/28/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Executives Move Up At Superior Oil
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Fred C. Ackman, 50 years old, took over yesterday as president of the Superior Oil Corporation at the organizational meeting of the board of directors. He succeeds Joseph E. Reid, 52, who became chairman of the exploration and production concern, while continuing as chief executive officer. **********The moves follow the retirement of Howard B. Keck as chairman of the big Houston company at the age of 67. **********Mr. Ackman came to Superior last February as executive vice president and chief operating officer and will retain the latter title. Previously he spent his career at the Exxon Corporation, starting as a production geologist in 1952 and working his way up to executive vice president and member of the management committee 26 years later. **********Mr. Reid, who played professional football for the Los Angeles Rams, worked for the Cabot Corporation and the Trunkline Gas Company before joining Superior as president of its international operation in 1972. He became a senior vice president in 1974, president in 1978 and chief executive last year. **********Mr. Keck - the longtime head of Superior, which was founded by his father, William M. Keck, in 1921 as a drilling contractor - had held the posts of president, chairman and chief executive at different times. He will assume the positions of chairman of the executive, compensation and nominating committees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/world.main_headline: ISRAELI CABINET AFFIRMS STAND ON AUTONOMY TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/world.print_headline: ISRAELI CABINET AFFIRMS STAND ON AUTONOMY TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/world.body_text: **********The Israeli Cabinet, signaling an interest in reviving the talks on Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, today reaffirmed its longstanding proposals on the issue. **********Prime Minister Menachem Begin and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt are scheduled to take up the autonomy question when they meet Tuesday and Wednesday in Alexandria. **********Mr. Sadat broke off the autonomy talks a year ago to protest Israel's formal annexation of Arab East Jerusalem, captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war, as part of what Israel has declared as its capital city. **********Commenting on today's Cabinet session, Aryeh Naor, the Cabinet Secretary, said that Mr. Begin and his key ministers had discussed the coming meetings with Mr. Sadat in the framework of a ministerial defense committee. which is an Israeli device for not having to divulge any of the contents of the discussion. **********'Plans, Thoughts and Ideas' **********Asked whether Israel had any new initiative to help revive the stalled autonomy talks, Mr. Naor said the question had come up repeatedly and that he had perfected a standard reply: **********''The Israeli Government has plans, thoughts and ideas,'' he said.  ''I don't know if they are new, but they are good.'' Essentially, the existing Israeli autonomy proposal interprets autonomy in an ''administrative'' sense, with Israel continuing to be responsible for the security of the West Bank and Gaza. **********In addition, the Israeli plan bans the creation of a Palestinian state or any other self-governing entity remotely resembling a separate nation. The plan also bars the inclusion of East Jerusalem and calls for a Palestinian administrative council, numbering between 11 and 15 members, that would handle purely local matters. **********So far, no West Bank or Gaza leaders, most of whom support the Palestine Liberation Organization, have indicated any interest in the Israeli plan. There were reports here today that Ariel Sharon, who as Defense Minister is in charge of the occupied West Bank and Gaza, has been meeting quietly with moderate Arabs in rural areas, apparently in an effort to gain some support for the plan while bypassing the recalcitrant mayors of the larger municipalities. Call for Renewing Talks **********The other day, Dr. Yosef Burg, the Israeli minister in charge of autonomy negotiations, said of the existing autonomy plan put forward by Israel, ''There is no need for new decisions. What is required is the renewal of the talks.'' **********Mr. Naor refused to either confirm or deny a report in today's Jerusalem Post, the English-language daily, that said Mr. Begin would present to Mr. Sadat a proposal that Israel abolish its current military government in the West Bank and Gaza in return for Mr.  Sadat's approval of Israel's definition of autonomy. **********The proposal, the newspaper said, was recommended by Defense Minister Sharon, who will accompany Mr. Begin to Alexandria along with other key ministers. **********There were no details in the newspaper account on what was meant by abolishing the current military structure.  The issue of autonomy for the 1.3 million Palestinian Arabs of the West Bank and Gaza who have been living under Israeli military rule since 1967 has been a stumbling block ever since the Camp David agreements between Egypt and Israel. Sadat Hopes for Accord in '81 **********Mr. Sadat said some weeks ago in a number of speeches and interviews that he wanted some sort of autonomy plan agreed to by the end of the year. The topic was one he brought up in his recent meeting in Washington with President Reagan. **********The issue of autonomy will also be discussed between Mr. Begin and Mr. Reagan when the Israeli leader meets the American President for the first time in Washington early in September. **********But reports from Egypt indicate that the Sadat Government does not foresee a quick resumption of the autonomy talks - something that Israeli leaders said today they wanted. Egypt's Foreign Minister, Kamal Hassan Ali, was quoted in the weekly October magazine published in Cairo as saying that the talks may not be resumed until December. **********Mr. Ali was quoted as saying that a gulf existed between Egypt and Israel on the very definition of ''autonomy'' and that there were differences, as well, over the construction of Israeli settlements in the occupied lands and over the annexation of East Jerusalem. **********Mr. Sadat is known to want a workable autonomy plan, or at least one that indicates that Egypt is fulfilling its commitment to the Palestinian Arabs, before the scheduled return of the last portion of the Israeli-occupied Sinai Peninsula to Egypt next April. **********Meantime, in a development related to East Jerusalem, one of Mr.  Begin's Cabinet members, Yitzhak Modai, Minister Without Portfolio, quietly moved his office to East Jerusalem on Friday in a step that came to light today. Mr. Begin caused a furor a year ago when he said that he would move his office to East Jerusalem, a move that was eventually deferred.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/17/busin.main_headline: Patents; Thermal Storage Tanks For Daytime Cooling
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/17/busin.print_headline: Patents; Thermal Storage Tanks For Daytime Cooling
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/17/busin.body_text: **********A thermal storage system patented this week by Calvin D.MacCracken, president of Calmac Manufacturing Corporation, Englewood, N.J., is described as making it possible for the first time for ice to be frozen solid in a tank without damaging the tank. **********The company, to which patent 4,294,078 is assigned, is manufacturing the equipment and plans to begin mass production soon in a new plant. Mr. MacCracken says the principal use will be to shift air-conditioning loads in buildings by making ice at night and using it for daytime cooling. **********He foresees savings of as much as 50 percent in operating costs. **********Plastic tanks up to four feet in diameter are used. They were tested in 50 Long Island homes under an Energy Department award.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/23/world.main_headline: Around the World; Spanish Parliament Votes To Legalize Divorce
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/23/world.print_headline: Around the World; Spanish Parliament Votes To Legalize Divorce
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/23/world.body_text: **********After several years of heated public debate and opposition from the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy, the Spanish Parliament approved a bill tonight that will permit civil divorce in Spain for the first time since Gen. Francisco Franco overthrew the republic in 1939. **********The law, one of the most nettlesome issues tackled by the Parliament since Franco's death in 1975, permits divorce by mutual consent following a period of legal separation. It had become a test of the willingness of the center-right Government of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo to liberalize Franco-era laws in the face of conservative opposition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; A Reagan Plea For Self-Help
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; A Reagan Plea For Self-Help
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.body_text: **********PRESIDENT Reagan, in his address to the International Monetary Fund and World Bank yesterday, told the developing countries that unless they put their own financial and economic houses in order, no amount of foreign aid would produce progress. However, he assured them that the people of the United States were ''as compassionate and caring as any on earth'' and would remain so. **********He conceded that the United States has made mistakes of its own in the past, declaring that ''we have overspent, overtaxed, and overregulated,'' mistakes that his Administration would undo. Those past mistakes, he contended, had been responsible for slow growth and soaring inflation -stagflation. **********Thus, in his maiden speech to the I.M.F. and World Bank group, Mr.  Reagan voiced the deeply felt free-market philosophy of his Administration. He declared that the nations that had made the most progress in the world were those that trusted in ''the magi c of the market.'' **********It seems unlikely that in speaking of the magic of the market, Mr.  Reagan had Wall Street in mind. In recent weeks he has been extremely critical of the Street for its lack of comprehension, particularly of his economic program. Nevertheless, it was that market known as Wall Street that came through for Mr. Reagan in the clutch this week and warded off what might have been a financial and economic disaster, here and abroad. **********Wall Street appears to have redeemed its reputation as the most efficient of markets - a huge and speedy accumulator, processor and evaluator of information. **********If Wall Street had not stood up and rallied, in the face of panic selling around the world from London to Tokyo, the worldwide sell-off might have turned into another Great Crash. **********The heavy volume of margin debt overhanging Wall Street had created conditions for a plunge in prices that might have made what Joe Granville advertized as ''Blue Monday'' rival ''Black Tuesday'' in 1929. **********That it instead became ''Green Monday'' was evidence, at least this time, of the Street's collective cool, realism and intelligence. **********This was a rallying cry heard round the world. Indeed, the strengthening of other markets yesterday signified the continuing financial dominance of New York, even though the United States economy has lost relative position in the world economy in terms of share of world output, share of foreign trade, rate of productivity growth and technological progress. But Mr. Reagan was at pains to remind those attending the I.M.F. and World Bank meeting that they should not underestimate the continuing economic importance of the American market to their well-being. He pointed out that the United States imports half of all manufactured goods from the oil-poor third world countries. **********The foreign financial markets were really waiting to see what New York would do, and when it rallied, the panic was dispelled.  Nevertheless, the financial markets remain wary of economic and financial troubles to come. Yesterday, while most foreign markets were rallying behind New York, Hong Kong - the truest of true believers in the magic of the market - remained skeptical. Should Mr. Reagan criticize its doubts or, applauding the cleverness of markets, pay heed to what Hong Kong is saying? **********Certainly there is still doubt, not only in Hong Kong but in Wall Street and European money centers that the Reagan Administration has yet found the answer to stagflation. Anxieties persist that its combination of huge tax cuts and tight money will continue to mean high interest rates and sluggish growth, or even slump, at home and abroad. **********Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, has called for undoing the damage of the tax bill, which he charges has devastated the revenue posture of the Government, with tax cuts that will cost $93 billion in 1983, $150 billion in 1984, $199 billion in 1985 and $268 billion in 1986. ''The only outcomes guaranteed by that kind of revenue loss,'' says Senator Hollings, ''are budgeting in the red, high interest rates and continued inflation.'' **********Besides trimming the tax bill sharply in the coming three years, Senator Hollings also proposes the immediate repeal of ''the illconsidered and hastily enacted provision for indexing the income tax'' and repealing the new oil tax breaks. **********Some of his colleagues, including moderate Republicans as well as Democrats, together with a remarkably large number of businessmen, would put heavier emphasis on scaling back military expenditures, in line with carefully developed strategic policy decisions. **********In his talk to the world's financiers yesterday, Mr. Reagan coupled his call for free-market ideology with a plea for pragmatism. The unresolved question about the Reagan Administration remains whether it will in the end be more ideological or more pragmatic.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/03/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Olin to Raise Prices of Its Caustic Soda
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/03/busin.body_text: **********The Olin Corporation said it would raise its prices of liquid caustic soda by $30 a ton, for both spot and contract customers. The company also said that there would no longer be a price advantage for shipment from Acme, N.C. **********Liquid caustic soda is used in papermaking, textile manufacture, water and waste treatment and aluminum processing.  The new prices of 50 percent commercial grade liquid caustic soda will now range between $250 and $290 a ton, depending on the origin of the shipment, Olin said. The company attributed the increases to higher labor and transportation costs

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/20/busin.body_text: **********The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the nation's seventh-largest bank, said today that it was reducing its prime lending rate a half-point, to 16 percent, matching a level established earlier in the week. **********The move follows an earlier reduction by the No.12-ranked Crocker National Bank of San Francisco, which cut its prime rate to 16 percent Monday, the lowest level for the key business-borrowing rate since Nov. 17, 1980. **********Other major banks left their prime rate at 16 1/2 percent. **********The prime rate, the base upon which banks compute interest charges on short-term loans to their most creditworthy corporate customers, has been falling sharply as a deteriorating economy has reduced demand for business loans. **********The prime rate stood at a record 21 1/2 percent in December 1980 and fell to 17 percent in March before rising to 20 1/2 percent in July, a level it held until the latest downturn began in mid-September.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/19/world.main_headline: Mexican Students Reported To Free Last of 7 Hostages
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/19/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Mexican Students Reported To Free Last of 7 Hostages
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/19/world.body_text: **********Three preparatory school students who had taken over the rector's office at the University of Mexico freed the last of seven hostages today after the Government agreed to fly them to Cuba, a university spokesman said. There was no immediate confirmation from the Government. **********Witnesses said the three burst into the rector's office on the sixth floor of the 12-story rectory building and began smashing furniture. The rector, Octavio Rivera, escaped through a back door, the campus police said. Seven people in the outer office were taken hostage, witnesses said. ---- **********MEXICO CITY, Feb. 18 (UPI) - Mexican peasants protesting alleged repression in the state of Oaxaca seized the Guatemalan and Indian embassies today, but the police soon evicted them, witnesses said.  About 30 protesters seized the Indian Embassy, holding 10 people as hostages, an embassy spokesman said. Half an hour later, 40 protesters seized 19 hostages in the Guatemalan Embassy, according to witnesses.
