https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/15/busin.body_text: **********Honeywell Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income rose 27.5 percent, to $71.4 million, or $3.15 ar share, from $56 million, or $2.51 a share, in the second quarter of 1980. **********The company said 4 cents a share of the quarter's earnings resulted from extraordinary gains, compared with 2 cents in the period a year earlier. **********Revenues in the second quarter increased 10.2 percent, to $1.30 billion, up from $1.18 billion a year earlier.  Despite the large surge in the latest period, Honeywell's chairman and chief executive officer, Edson W. Spencer, was cautious about the remainder of the year. **********''The rate of increase in second-quarter earnings will probably not continue for the second half, but the company still hopes to match 1980 earnings for the year,'' he said. **********The company said all major control system businesses showed improved orders. Worldwide computer orders were down from the second quarter of 1980 but increased from the first quarter of this year. **********The company said CII Honeywell Bull, the French computer company 47 percent owned by Honeywell, had an operating loss for the first half and that loss in francs was magnified when translated into dollars because of the current strength of the dollar. But Honeywell said that effect was more than offset by an earnings gain resulting from translating Honeywell Bull's balance sheet into dollars. North American Philips **********Because of a large gain from the sale of its industrial chemicals subsidiary, the North American Philips Company's earnings for the second quarter were $34.2 million, or $2.54 a share, compared with $16.3 million, or $1.26 a share, in the second quarter of 1980. **********However, excluding the one-time gain from the June sale of the Thompson-Hayward Chemical Company, Philip's net income from continuing operations rose 12.2 percent, to $18.4 million, or $1.36 a share, from $16.4 milion, or $1.26 a share, in 1980. **********Pieter C. Vink, chairman and chief executive officer, said earnings increased in the consumer electronics area and for professional equipment, which includes electronic devices used in medicine, science, television and business. Those gains were offset by reduced earnings in electrical consumer products and by higher interest rates, Mr. Vink said. **********Sales for the second quarter rose to $790.5 million, up 36.2 percent from $580.5 million last year. Sales were bolstered by $136 million by the purchase of the Sylvania and Philco television set and components business from the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation in January. **********North American Philips is 62 percent owned by the Hartford National Bank and Trust Company as a trustee of the United States Philips Trust. The beneficiaries of the trust are the shareholders of N.V.  Philips, the Dutch electronics giant.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/26/world.main_headline: REAGAN REAFFIRMS HAIG AS TOP ADVISOR ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/26/world.print_headline: REAGAN REAFFIRMS HAIG AS TOP ADVISOR ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/26/world.body_text: **********President Reagan reaffirmed today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. is his ''primary adviser on foreign affairs,'' but White House advisers said that the strain between Mr. Haig and Mr. Reagan's senior staff was much more severe than had been publicly acknowledged. **********According to a Presidential adviser, Mr. Haig has threatened to resign eight or nine times since Mr. Reagan took office. Had he done so again yesterday, the adviser said, the acceptance of the resignation might have not have been opposed by Edwin Meese 3d, the counselor to the President, and James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff. **********The White House was uncertain until late last night whether Mr.  Haig might make good his earlier threats, some of which were regarded as mere mutterings of discontent, with a formal resignation. The question was not laid to rest, for the time being at least, until Mr. Haig met at 6 A.M. today with Michael K. Deaver, the deputy White House chief of staff, and later in the morning with the President. **********Haig Still Reported Disgruntled **********Even after the meetings and Mr. Reagan's subsequent statement of support, Mr. Haig was described by associates as disgruntled and uncertain about his future in the Administration. White House aides were telling political associates today, however, that they expected Mr. Haig to stay. **********Mr. Meese and Mr. Baker were described as infuriated by Mr. Haig's public criticism yesterday, before a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee, of Mr. Reagan's plan to put Vice President Bush in charge of the White House situation room during foreign or domestic crises. The Reagan inner circle regarded this criticism as another example of Mr. Haig's creating public controversies that have disrupted the Administration's plan to keep public and Congressional attention on Mr. Reagan's demand for quick passage of his economic program. **********Mr. Reagan tried to end the divisiveness as he left the White House for an afternoon of horseback riding by reaffirming Mr. Haig's role as ''chief formulator and spokesman for foreign policy'' and then blaming reporters for the controversy over Mr. Haig's remarks. **********''I don't know whether you'd like my reaction,'' Mr. Reagan said.''My reaction was that maybe some of you were trying to make the news instead of reporting it.'' Then, the President, clad in navy windbreaker, tan riding britches and knee-high boots with gleaming spurs, strode to the Marine helicopter for the 30-minute trip to the stables at the Marine base at Quantico, Va. **********It was unclear whether the President's carefully worded departure statement went far enough to lay to rest Mr. Haig's misgivings over the crisis-management arrangement, which was regarded, even by senior State Department officials, as a clear victory for Mr. Bush in the competition with Mr. Haig for primacy in the Reagan hierarchy. **********Just over an hour after Mr. Reagan's departure, Mr. Bush made a conciliatory statement toward Mr. Haig, saying that he would leave to the Secretary of State ''the day to day problem areas of foreign policy,'' such as El Salvador. **********But Mr. Bush added at his 3 P.M. press conference, ''When the President is not there, not on hand, I will be in the situation room, in charge until the President is available.'' **********As for Mr. Haig, the Vice President continued, ''To the degree there is some misunderstanding or reservation on his part, I refer you to him on it, really, because I just don't want to exacerbate things.'' **********The White House press secretary, James S. Brady, tried to draw a veil across what other White House officials described as discordant events in the West Wing after Mr. Haig's expression of discontent with the crisis-management plan yesterday morning. Mr. Brady insisted, despite Mr. Haig's remarks to the contrary, that the Secretary of State had been ''fully consulted'' on the plan. He also asserted that Mr. Haig had not threatened to resign and that any problems between Mr. Haig and Mr. Reagan were of ''external making.'' **********But other White House officials characterized Mr. Meese, in particular, as increasingly exasperated with Mr. Haig's attentiongetting statements and his drives for influence, dating back to his memorandum on Inauguration Day asking Mr. Reagan for broad authority over foreign affairs. **********Mr. Meese's patience was ''severely tested,'' one White House source said. Mr. Baker was said to have shared Mr. Meese's anger yesterday. Both men, another source added, had grown weary of Mr.  Haig's hints that he would resign unless he got his way. **********''He's threatened eight or nine times to resign,'' the official added, although he did not specify what issues had provoked the threats. **********Mr. Baker, Mr. Meese and Mr. Deaver conferred with Mr. Reagan in the Oval Office yesterday about Mr. Haig's remarks. Mr. Brady and David R. Gergen, the White House staff director who helps plan the Administration's publicity efforts, were also called in. There were also consultations with Mr. Bush, according to Mr. Brady. **********Mr. Meese's and Mr. Baker's anger was such that for the first time it seemed possible that they might not oppose Mr. Haig's resignation. ''At one point it was a flip of a coin'' as to which way Mr. Meese and Mr. Baker would go on such a question, the official said. Faced with a decision, he added, ''I don't think they would have gone to the mat to stop it.'' **********Mr. Reagan said the matter never went that far. ''He never once threatened to resign,'' the President said.  Mr. Deaver reportedly emerged as the peacemaker, making the telephone call in which Mr. Reagan told the Secretary of State of the forthoming announcement of Mr. Bush's new assignment and assured Mr.  Haig that he was still needed in the Administration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/03/busin.body_text: **********The Sunshine Mining Company, a leading silver producer, announced that its plan to merge with the Silver Dollar Mining Company, Silver Syndicate Inc., Sunshine Consolidated Inc. and the Big Creek Apex Company had been approved by directors of the four companies, all silver-mining concerns based in Wallace, Idaho. **********Under the agreement, valued at about $66 million, one share of Sunshine Mining common will be traded for 1.15 shares of Silver Dollar stock, 0.75 share of Silver Syndicate stock, 0.715 share of Big Creek Apex stock and 0.55 share of Sunshine Consolidated stock.  Sunshine Mining said that shareholder meetings on approval of the mergers are expected to be held in November.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/busin.body_text: **********P ETER RABBIT Nursery Ware.  Peter Rabbit's Natural Foods Cookbooks. Peter Rabbit and Family Serving Trays. Beatrix Potter's Coloring Book Featuring Peter Rabbit. Beatrix Potter Wallpaper. The Beatrix Potter Lift-Out Jig-Saw Puzzle ... **********Proliferating like bunnies, as it were, books and wares written and inspired by Beatrix Potter have been best sellers for generations and the products of a multimillion-dollar, globe-girdling empire. **********In these pre-Christmas weeks, sales of Potter merchandise have been cheeringly brisk despite the recession, Miss Potter's longtime New York publishing house, Frederick Warne & Company, reports.  Roughly 30 percent of its Potter book sales come in the fall-and-Christmas season - and this year, they have been running 15 percent higher than in the comparable period last year. **********That performance is especially envied in the competitive children's book industry because it comes fully 80 years after the shy Miss Potter, a British amateur artist and naturalist, brought out the first edition of ''The Tale of Peter Rabbit.'' The first 250 copies appeared in December 1901 in Britain, with illustrations she did herself. **********That trickle of books has swelled to a mighty stream of merchandising revenue: In the United States alone, sales of Warne's Potter books, and revenues from other Peter- and Potter-related merchandise it has licensed, will come to an estimated $7 million or more for in this, the 38th year after Miss Potter's death. And Potter book proceeds worldwide dwarf those recorded in this country, according to the Warne company, a 100-year-old subsidiary of the London publishing house of Frederick Warne, which looks after Miss Potter's literary estate. **********The British company's stock is closely held - the majority is owned by the Warne family and a connected clan, the Stephenses - and it does not discuss its operating results. But Potter books have been translated into a dozen languages and do surprisingly well in such unlikely bailiwicks as Japan, where more than 500,000 copies, in Warne-authorized Japanese translations, are sold each year. **********It was in 1902 that Warne, after earlier turning ''Peter'' down, brought out its own first edition of the book, which is about the adventures of a naughty young rabbit who lives with his family in a sandbank. Warne's large-scale printing was a quick commercial success, and there followed 22 other children's books, which have become classics. These include ''The Tale of Benjamin Bunny,'' ''The Tale of Squirrel Nutkin,'' ''The Tale of Johnny Town-Mouse,'' and ''The Tale of Mrs. Tittlemouse.'' **********With ''Peter Rabbit'' and some other Potter titles in the public domain in this country, other houses have joined the rabbit wagon.  The Outlet Book Company, for instance, says that two collections of Potter tales, published under its Derrydale and Avenel imprints, are among its best-selling children's books. **********Miss Potter's will gave the Warne parent company control of rights to publish the Potter books and license the use of her characters.  Which is only natural, considering her close professional and personal ties to the Warnes: They published most of her works, and she became engaged to a member of the family, Norman Warne, who died of leukemia only weeks afterward. **********Warne executives in Britain do not say what their company does with the revenues from the Potter literary estate, but in knowledgeable publishing circles it is suggested that she evidently bequeathed all or most of its earnings to the Warne family, its London house, or both. She married late and died childless, and her attorney-husband, William Heelis, died not long afterward. **********As for profits, Richard Billington, chairman and president of Warne's American subsidiary, said the Warne companies have been in clover for many years. The parent concern has been doing well since World War I and the New York house for decades, he said. All told, Mr. Billington calculates, Warne has sold about 20 million Potter books in this country, including more than three million copies of ''The Tale of Peter Rabbit.'' **********Unit sales and revenues of Warne's Potter books in this country have been increasing from year to year, Mr. Billington reports, except for 1980, when the economy's woes kept them flat. This year they will be up about 5 percent, he says, amounting to more than 300,000 copies, including roughly 100,000 of ''Peter Rabbit.'' **********What's the secret of the appeal of Peter Rabbit, Squirrel Nutkin, Jemima Puddle-Duck, and the other Potter animal-characters?  ''Beatrix Potter was one person who managed to dress animals up while still retaining their true animal likenesses,'' says Mr.  Billington. ''Peter Rabbit is really a rabbit; he just happens to have a jacket on - he's not a Bugs Bunny, is he?'' **********Publishing experts add that grownups generally buy the children's books they liked when they were young.  Mr. Billington, who is 58, agrees. He raised his son, now 29, on Potter books. But he argues that the underlying reason the works live on is that once children are introduced to them, ''they love them, and ask for them to be read over and over.'' **********Part of the charm of the books, he says, is their dimunitive size - about four by five inches. Miss Potter, he reports, ''said they should be 'little books for little hands.' '' He also stresses her choice of names and words: ''Jemima Puddle-Duck. Is there a better description for a duck?'' he asks. ''Beatrix Potter had a great sense of the sound of words; she knew how to make them interesting to children.'' **********At the Outlet Book Company, Alan Mirken, president, emphasizes the Potter illustrations. ''There's a warm tone to them that makes people of all ages feel comfortable looking at them,'' he says. ''There's an extraordinary ability, apparently, for different generations to spend time reliving the tales.'' **********The opposition is particularly impressed. ''The success of the Beatrix Potter books is incredible,'' says John Briggs, president of Holiday House, a rival children's book publishing company. It puts out two books that have come to be known as modern classics - ''The Shrinking of Treehorn'' and ''Treehorn's Treasure'' - both written by Florence Parry Heide and illustrated by Edward Gorey. **********''It's encouraging that books of outstanding quality can survive from one generation to another,'' says Mr. Briggs. ''The Beatrix Potter books have a special appeal that's universal; they sell all over the world.'' **********The American Warne company's Potter books generally sell all over this country, says Mr. Billington, who is a British-born American citizen. They have been doing best in California and in the Northeast, but have been faring better lately in the South and Middle West. **********His company has nourished sales in recent years by packaging the 23 $3.50 Potter books in $75, maroon-wrapped sets, and marketing fourbook Potter sampler sets at $11.95. It has also begun publishing $1.95 paperback editions of Peter Rabbit and three other books. **********In addition, the house purveys a number of books that are about, or related to, Miss Potter. And it has licensed 19 manufacturers to turn out merchandise that is identified with her and her characters.  All told, American sales of the licenced products amount to $5 million or more a year, Mr. Billington says, and revenue from licensing is particularly welcome to his company since almost all of it flows straight down to the bottom line. **********The licensee companies range, rather spectacularly, from the C.R.  Gibson Company (birth announcements, jigsaw puzzles and the like) and the Quiltex Company (snowsuits, crib sheets and whatnot) to Josiah Wedgwood & Sons Inc. (earthenware nursery sets, children's tea sets etc.) and Eden Toys Inc., which makes stuffed animals depicting Peter Rabbit and 14 other Potter critters. **********Eden doesn't divulge sales figures for the animals, but it says Peter Rabbit does best, and good sellers include Benjamin Bunny, Jemima Puddle-Duck and Jeremy Fisher, which is a frog. In January, stores will begin selling a new addition to the Eden-Potter line: Samuel Whiskers, which is a rat. **********''These are more than just children's toys,'' says Barbara Goldberg, the company's product promotion manager. ''They appeal to all ages. They have a certain style to them. They're whimsical.  They're collector's items!''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/28/busin.body_text: **********A three-judge Federal appeals panel denied a request by two Penn Central Corporation stockholders to delay the company's Thursday meeting at which shareholders are to vote on its proposed merger with Colt Industries. **********The two-page decision, written by Judge Arlin M. Adams of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, said that Howard L. Terry of Houston and W. Herbert Hunt of Dallas failed to prove that they would win their appeal of a lower court judge's decision to dismiss the suit. **********A Penn Central Corporation spokesman said the company will proceed with the shareholders meeting as planned.  The judges also scheduled a Nov. 5 hearing on the full appeal.  Mr. Terry and Mr. Hunt, former directors of Marathon Manufacturing Inc. of Texas and representing a group of holders of Penn Central preferred stock, filed suit Sept. 30, claiming the proposed Colt deal violated promises made by Penn Central when it bought Marathon pledging not to weaken the worth of Marathon stockholders' shares in Penn Central. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/07/world.main_headline: CHINA'S INNER MONGOLIA IS FOUND 'SERIOUSLY AFFECTED' BY DROUGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/07/world.print_headline: CHINA'S INNER MONGOLIA IS FOUND 'SERIOUSLY AFFECTED' BY DROUGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/07/world.body_text: **********One-third of Inner Mongolia's 18 milllion people and nearly one half of its livestock have been ''seriously affected'' by the drought that has parched the North China Plain, according to agriculture officials here. **********A relief program has averted starvation and curtailed livestock losses, the officials said. **********Recent rains, the first since early 1979, have sprouted 80 percent of the spring wheat crop. **********But more rain this summer is necessary to break the drought, which last year killed 1.5 million head of sheep, goats, horses and camels, they said. **********Although China has turned for the first time since 1949 to international agencies for aid to cope with droughts and floods, it limited the appeal for help to two hard-hit provinces. Inner Mongolia, which is a relatively sparsely populated autonomous region of China on the border of Mongolia, a Soviet ally, was not included. **********Nevertheless, millions of people in Inner Mongolia are receiving emergency food supplies and the region has received $15 million in direct subsidies to aid drought victims. **********''Our Government has made a commitment that it will not allow a single farmer to die of hunger,'' said Har Di, a Mongol who heads the production division of the region's Agriculture and Animal Husbandry Commission. **********He said nearly half of Inner Mongolia's range lands have been rendered barely usable for grazing. Some 1.52 million head of livestock, mostly sheep, had to be sold and five million head had to be moved distances of up to 500 miles to find suitable grazing areas. **********Meanwhile, one-fourth of the region's cultivated cropland produced little or nothing last year, he said. In several districts, he said, farm family incomes dropped by 60 to 70 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/23/busin.main_headline: Talking Businesswith Olmer of the Commerce Dept. U.S. Trade With Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/23/busin.print_headline: Talking Businesswith Olmer of the Commerce Dept. U.S. Trade With Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/23/busin.body_text: **********When Lionel H. Olmer stood up to address last week's meeting of the Japan-United States Businessmen's Conference, the Japanese executives in the audience seemed to adjust their translation headsets a little tighter, while the American businessmen leaned forward that extra inch. Mr. Olmer is the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, and his comments were of more than passing interest to these high-level industrialists. **********Mr. Olmer, 46 years old, is familiar with the wall of obstacles that Japan has built against American imports. While he was at Motorola Inc., he helped it break into the lucrative Japanese public telecommunications market. In an interview last week, he discussed the state of American-Japanese trade. **********Q. How would you characterize America's trading relationship with Japan today? A. A number of people have observed that even at present we have become a developing country with respect to the Japanese. We ship them raw materials, and they send us manufactured goods. **********Our imports from Japan are now 50 percent larger than our exports to Japan. We find ourselves having to run faster just to prevent backsliding. Since 1970, our exports to and imports from Japan have each been growing at about 17 percent a year. If this trend continues, our deficit with Japan will be $22 billion in 1985 and $48 billion in 1990. **********Q. What American products do you think could be competitive in Japan but are being kept out? A. Citrus fruits, certain kinds of semiconductor and telecommunications devices, computers, petrochemicals, machine tools, auto parts, furniture, cosmetics and health care products. **********They have trouble penetrating for a number of reasons. Tariffs, for instance. A glass of American orange juice costs $5 in Japan.  There is also a whole area known as ''performance requirements.'' It is very difficult for a U.S. supplier of telecommunications equipment to go to Japan and say: ''I build a fine product. Try it.'' They don't want the product. They want to see how you build it, and they want to test it at every step of the manufacturing process. They also want to know the extent to which you provide a happy home and recreational activities for your employees. **********Q. Do American companies continue to hold a substantial competitive lead over the Japanese in high technology? A. The Japanese are in every area that is the wave of the future. They are not dominant in the leading edge of semiconductors and computers, but they are in those areas, and it would be absolutely foolish to underestimate their competence. **********I have asked this rhetorical question of a number of people: Would it be a matter of concern if by the end of this decade the U.S.  Defense Department had to rely on imports from Japan for substantial quantities of computers, semiconductors and telecommunication devices? I think there is at least a 50 percent probability that is going to happen. **********Q. How can American industry keep from conceding more ground to the Japanese? A. We can't let the Japanese have a protected home environment with assured sales from which to launch overseas competition. Selling in the Japanese market will help American companies learn more about the nature of competition. **********We have to make absolutely sure we are competitive, which means doing everything we can domestically to satisfy our American customers here. If we do that, I think it is going to be very difficult to keep us out of the Japanese market. **********Also, we have to train more engineers. **********Q. What is the Reagan Administration doing to improve the competitiveness of U.S. business? A. The President's economic recovery program and deregulation will help foster a healthy economy and our ability to compete. You can't be internationally competitive if your domestic economy is sick. **********In addition, we are going to make a sustained effort on a comprehensive basis to address the Japanese market-access problem.  It would be very helpful if we could find a way to cooperate with the Japanese Government at the highest level to help alter attitudes - not to change the fabric of Japanese society but to change fundamentally the way Japanese consumers look at foreign products.  Thomas L. Friedman

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/31/busin.main_headline: BELL DATA PLAN HALTED PENDING HEARING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/31/busin.print_headline: BELL DATA PLAN HALTED PENDING HEARING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/31/busin.body_text: **********A Texas district court judge has ordered the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company to stop preparations for consumer testing of its Electronic Information Service, a computerized home information retrieval system. **********Southwestern Bell, a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said today that its lawyers were studying the March 20 decision by Judge Charles Mathews and had not yet decided whether to appeal it. **********Judge Mathews agreed with the Texas Public Utility Commission that Bell should take no further action with regard to testing of the electronic service until the commission could hold a public hearing.  He said the commission had the authority to grant or deny a certificate to carry out the project. **********In Washington, meanwhile, the American Newspaper Publishers Association announced it was joining a legal battle to keep A.T.& T., the world's largest telephone company, out of the information business. **********The association said it would seek to intervene formally April 13 when A.T.& T asks for United States District Court permission to enter the field of electronic news delivery. **********The Texas Daily Newspaper Association challenged the Austin experiment and won the utility commission's decision to hold full public hearings before allowing it to proceed. 700 Participants **********More than 700 homes and businesses would take part in the experiment, free of charge, if the commission approves it, Bell said. **********Computer terminals would be installed in businesses and homes, and users could call up on their screens such information as telephone numbers and advertising by about 2,400 merchants. **********The Texcas newsapaper group contends Bell's monopoly control over telephone lines and equipment would give Bell an unfair advantage over possible competitors in the fledgling computerized home information business. Among the possible competitors are Reader's Digest, American Express, H.& R. Block and the A.H. Belo Corporation, parent company of The Dallas Morning News. **********During the hearing before Judge Mathews, Dennis Sullivan, an assistant vice president of A.T.& T., said the company had no intention of producing news, weather and sports. **********Mr. Sullivan said ''billions of dollars'' in revenue would be realized if the home information service succeeded.  He said Bell had invested $20 million testing the service, including $6.2 million preparing for the Austin experiment. A.T.& T has also run tests in Albany, N.Y., and Coral Gables, Fla.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/28/world.body_text: **********Baluchi emigre leaders have decided to press for independence, possibly through guerrilla war in western Pakistan and eastern Iran, according to a study made public tonight by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, a nonprofit foundation. **********The study by Selig Harrison, ''In Afghanistan's Shadow: Baluch Nationalism and Soviet Temptations,'' asserts that 7,500 guerrillas are ready for combat in Baluchistan and that 15,000 to 20,000 more could be fielded within ''a matter of weeks.'' **********He said the rebels would resume the insurgency of 1973-1977 if they had a steady source of arms from the Soviet Union, India or Arab countries. Baluchistan is a sparsely populated mineral-rich region between Afghanistan and the Arabian Sea.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/busin.body_text: **********CBS Inc. said yesterday that its profits for the first three months this year rose 6.9 percent, to $14 million, and another major communiations company, Warner Communications Inc., reported a 41.4 percent increase in its earnings, to $49.5 million. **********CBS said its first-quarter earnings amounted to 50 cents a share, up from 47 cents a year earlier, when the company earned $13.1 million. **********Revenues rose 2.3 percent, to $990.8 million, in the latest quarter, up from $968.9 million. **********CBS had earlier predicted a decline in first-quarter earnings but said higher ratings for the CBS Television Network had resulted in a smaller than expected decline in pretax income. **********In the quarter, CBS said, pretax income dropped 8 percent primarily as a result of an increase in start-up costs for the company's new operation in the cable television, theatrical, film and home video fields. **********Warner said its per-share earnings were 81 cents, compared with 62 cents@ in the 1980 quarter. Warner earned $35 million in the first three months last year. Revenues rose 41.1 percent, to $602.6 million, from $427 million in 1980. **********Steven Ross, Warner's chairman, said the profit increase was due in part to growth in the company's Atari line of consumer electronics and toys.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/29/world.main_headline: INDIA AND CHINA ANNOUNCE TALKS ON BORDER ISSUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/29/world.print_headline: INDIA AND CHINA ANNOUNCE TALKS ON BORDER ISSUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/29/world.body_text: **********India and China announced their intention today to hold early negotiations on their long-deadlocked border dispute. **********Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and the Chinese Foreign Minister, Huang Hua, said after a 70-minute meeting that they had agreed on talks at an ''appropriate level'' to try to resolve the issue. Indian officials said that the talks would be held in September with a visit by an Indian delegation to Peking. **********Mrs. Gandhi also said that she had accepted an invitation to visit China at a mutually convenient date. **********First Visit by Top Aide Since '60 **********Mr. Huang's visit here was the first by a top-ranking Chinese leader since Prime Minister Zhou Enlai came to India in 1960. During his three days of talks, he appeared to have concentrated on building new friendship and getting India to agree to seek an early negotiated settlement of the border dispute. **********The two nations went to war in 1962 over a Chinese claim to vast Indian territories along the 2,500-mile Himalayan border. The Chinese seized, and still hold, a large piece of territory in Ladakh in the western sector but they later withdrew from the eastern sector in India's northeastern frontier region. **********The border dispute long kept the two Asian giants at loggerheads, but in the last few years both have tried to establish normal contacts and resolve their differences by negotiations. Initiative Taken by India **********The first major initiative was taken by India in 1979 when Atal Bihari Vajpayee, who was then Foreign Minister, visited Peking. Mr.  Vajpayee was received well by the Chinese but his trip ended in failure because of the sudden attack carried out by the Chinese against Vietnam, a friend of India. **********Last year Mr. Huang was scheduled to return the visit but he canceled his trip after Mrs. Gandhi's Government recognized the Soviet-backed regime of Heng Samrin in Cambodia. **********Mr. Huang spent many hours in discussions here, talking mostly with Foreign Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao on Soviet involvement in Afghanistan and the Vietnamese presence in Cambodia. The views of the two sides on these matters were sharply at variance, according to officials, but these questions were relegated to the background. **********Mr. Huang said at a news conference that he was ''optimistic and positive'' about a ''fair, comprehensive and reasonable'' settlement of the boundary question. **********He was asked whether the settlement he envisaged would include any return of territory to India. ''The question involves a controversy and I would not like to address myself to it,'' he replied. **********Mr. Huang was also blunt in stating that the Chinese had not changed their attitude in disputes over Kashmir and Sikkim. China has sided with Pakistan on the longstanding Indian-Pakistani dispute over Kashmir. Peking has also denounced the merger of Sikkim, formerly an autonomous Himalayan kingdom, with India in 1974 and has refused to recognize it. **********Nevertheless, Mr. Huang said that both sides had adopted ''a forward-looking attitude'' during the discussions and had agreed that the ''dispute and differences should not be allowed to stand in the way of developing our bilateral relations.'' 'Friendship and Peace' Stressed **********He said that the exchange of views had a ''major significance'' against the background of the ''turbulent, tense, complex and volatile international situation of the 80's.'' The development of friendly relations between China and India, he declared, will be beneficial to peace and stability in Asia and the world at large. **********''Both our peoples need friendship and peace so that we may concentrate our energies on developing our respective national economies at a relatively fast pace,'' he said. **********The Chinese official said that his country favored a nonalignment policy and the establishment of a new international economic order.  China will ''always belong to the third world,'' he asserted. **********An Indian spokesman said it had been decided during the talks to draw up programs for annual cultural, scientific, technological and economic exchanges. **********As a gesture of good will, Mr. Huang readily granted an Indian request for access to Manasarovar Lake and Mount Kailash, both in Tibet, which are regarded by Hindus as the abode of Shiva, the god of destruction. Mr. Huang said that his country would make temporary arrangements for visits by Indian pilgrims to the holy places pending agreement on long-term facilities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/18/world.main_headline: CRIME SUDDENLY PRESSING TOPIC FOR CANADIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/18/world.print_headline: CRIME SUDDENLY PRESSING TOPIC FOR CANADIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/18/world.body_text: **********Canada, a country that views itself as far less violent than the neighboring United States, has suddenly seen one policeman slain and four wounded in separate shooting incidents since Christmas, and this has led to demands that all officers be equipped with bulletproof vests. **********The surge of public emotion over the shootings has already prompted one major law-enforcement department, in Hamilton, one of Canada's largest cities, to appropriate funds for the vests. Elsewhere, private citizens, perhaps inspired by the success of a similar drive in New York City, have begun fund-raising efforts to buy the vests for officers. **********Homicide Rate Is Down **********The shootings and the public outcries have come after a year in which Canada's homicide rate fell for a third straight time since capital punishment was abolished. According to Statistics Canada, in 1979 Canada had 579 homicide incidents, down from 616 in 1978 and 637 in 1977. For the first six months of 1980 violent crimes were up 4.8 percent over the same 1979 period, but homicides were down 9.1 percent. **********The death penalty was abolished in Canada in 1976, although some private groups, notably policemen, have since sought its reinstitution. First-degree murder is now punishable by a 25-year prison term without parole. Second-degree murder draws a 10- to 25-year sentence without the possibility of parole. **********The flurry of activity over the vests followed the recent incidents that left one policeman and a filling-station attendant dead and four other officers seriously wounded. One officer, Constable Larry Johnson of Hamilton, owes his life to a thick notebook that stopped a bullet headed for his heart. **********The most dramatic recent shooting occurred during the New Year's weekend when a gun store was broken into in Mattawa, about 180 miles north of Toronto. Shortly afterward, about midnight New Year's Day, Chester Blackmore, a service-station attendant in Burk's Falls, Ontario, was shot and killed after pumping $14 in fuel into a car.  The car then sped away. A witness, believing it to be a hit-and-run accident, alerted Ontario Provincial Police. Constable Is Shot 8 Times **********Apparently suspicious of a passing car, Constable Rick Verdecchia stopped the vehicle to check for a dented fender or other damage. Not finding any, he radioed an all-clear message. He was then shot eight times and dumped in a snowdrift, and his cruiser was moved off the road. **********Later that weekend, farther south, another constable, Neil Hurtubise, stopped a speeder and, as he approached the car, was shot five times in the face and chest. He managed to radio a call for help, however, and his accurate description set off an all-night manhunt with helicopters and dogs. Mr. Hurtubise is recovering. **********The assailants' car was found abandoned. After tracking them for three hours through snow-covered bush country, officers found a parked van. Inside, the officers found two heavily armed but unresistant suspects, Gary Fitzgerald, 18 years old, and Joseph Schoenenberger, 17, both from Windsor, Ontario. Both were charged with murder. **********The next day in Hamilton, a port city of 312,000 on the western end of Lake Ontario, Constable Johnson's notebook saved his life during a backyard struggle with a suspected housebreaker. And on Christmas Eve two patrolmen were shot and wounded by a murder suspect in Toronto, which has seen six officers fatally shot in recent years. **********The funeral of Constable Verdecchia, who was 35 years old, drew more than 1,200 fellow officers from the United States and across Canada. They exchanged vows of solidarity and pledged new efforts to force their Governments to buy the vests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/05/busin.main_headline: A Magazine for Travelers To Atlantic City's Casinos
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/05/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; A Magazine for Travelers To Atlantic City's Casinos
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/05/busin.body_text: **********There are magazines for passengers in commercial airplanes; there is a magazine for people bound for New York airports by bus from Fairfield County, Conn.; there is a magazine for guests at a certain motel chain, and there is a magazine for people taking the Gray Line sightseeing tours. So why shouldn't there be a magazine for folks taking the bus to Atlantic City for a little gambling? **********Well, now that you mention it, there will be. And it will be a fine change of pace for Patrick Mandarano, president and publisher of Atlantic City Express, who is entering the field from a stint at Harcourt, Brace, Jovanovich Publishing, where he ran the five dental publications. **********The new magazine is due out in April, and it will be promoted with about $500,000 worth of advertising by KSW&G, which is also the agency for Psychology Today. **********Mr. Mandarano has research to show that of the 15 million visitors to Atlantic City last year, one-third came by bus, some 230 of which arrive each day. **********The initial circulation rate base of the Atlantic City Express will be 450,000, which Mr. Mandarano said is ''rather modest. But its growth potential is mind-boggling.'' **********A black-and-white ad page is going for $10,350 while a four-color carries a $13,350 price tag. Costs per thousand, the publisher notes, are similar to in-flight magazine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/19/busin.main_headline: U.S. TO EASE SOME ENERGY-SAVING RULES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/19/busin.print_headline: U.S. TO EASE SOME ENERGY-SAVING RULES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/19/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration indicated today that it would discard elaborate proposals made by the Carter Administration to impose mandatory standards for the fuel efficiency of home appliances. **********The controversial plans, which have been opposed by manufacturers, would have brought eight kinds of appliances under the standards by July 15; regulations for five more would have been set by the end of the year. **********In another action, the Administration today abandoned most elements of a plan that would force gasoline conservation on the public in case of an emergency. This included provisions for a shortened workweek and a sticker system to keep vehicles off the road on designated days. **********The moves followed the abolition earlier this week of yet another Carter energy measure: requirements that the temperature of many buildings be kept below 65 degrees in winter and left to rise above 78 degrees in summer. **********The previously proposed appliance standards, the Department of Energy said, would not be imposed until it conducted a new economic analysis of them. But the Administration's economic recovery plan, presented to Congress today and outlined by the President in his address this evening, made it clear that the standards were unlikely to survive. 'Massive Burdens' Feared **********''If undertaken as planned,'' the Administration said, ''they would impose massive regulatory burdens on the private sector'' and would be ''a nightmare to administer and enforce.'' **********The eight appliances for which proposed standards were issued last June are refrigerators, freezers, clothes dryers, water heaters, stoves, furnances and air conditioners. Standards for dishwashers, televisions, clothes washers, humidifiers and heat pumps were to have been put forward early this year and set by year's end. **********A second, presumably stricter, level of specifications would have come at the beginning of 1986. Estimated Savings Disputed **********When the first standards were proposed, it was estimated that consumers would save up to $29.4 billion in energy between 1982 and 2005 at a cost in higher appliance prices of up to $10.2 billion.  But since then, two Government agencies have questioned whether the implied net savings of $19.2 billion would actually have occurred. **********A recently initiated program of mandatory labeling of appliances to indicate their energy efficiency was cited by the Energy Department as another reason that it could adopt an overall energy strategy ''free of arbitrary and counterproductive restraints.'' **********As for the standby energy-conservation plan, the department also revoked, or proposed revoking, various measures that had called for employer-sponsored commuting, employer subsidies for mass transit, odd/even-day gasoline purchase restrictions and more vigorous enforcement or reduction of the national 55 mile-an-hour speed limit. **********Only an information program and a minimum purchase rule for gasoline remain among steps states could be required to take should they fail to meet the Federal emergency gasoline-conservation targets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.main_headline: CUBA IS MOVING TO BROADEN TRADE IN BID FOR DOLLARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.print_headline: CUBA IS MOVING TO BROADEN TRADE IN BID FOR DOLLARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.body_text: **********It intends, for the first time under the present regime, to share with foreign corporations both the ownership and management of a luxury tourist resort on the island of Cayo Largo, off Cuba's southern coast, where a free port comparable to those in the United States Virgin Islands is to be set up. **********It also quietly established, about a year ago, a fast-growing commerical trading company, Commercial Muralla, which is trying to buy and sell products ranging from frozen cattle embryos to cement for cash, bypassing Cuba's usual state trading channels. **********And, according to reliable sources, one Cuban official told Canadian executives in March that Havana was so eager for hard currency - not available from Communist-bloc trading partners - that artificially low production figures were being reported to Moscow, so undeclared surpluses could be sold to the West for cash. Need for Access to West **********These developments, according to some Western diplomats in Havana, underscore Cuba's determination to put more flexibility in its own economy and to gain better access to Western products, markets and financial resources, despite the United States trade embargo, which was imposed in February 1961 in response to Cuban confiscation of United States property and growing hostilities between the two countries. **********The drive for improved economic ties with the West, which now accounts for about 20 percent of Cuba's foreign trade, may also explain, these sources say, why President Fidel Castro's public responses to the Reagan Administration's harsh criticisms have been relatively restrained, leaving the door open for improvement in trade relations. **********According to Lawrence H. Theriot, Cuban desk officer in the United States Department of Commerce Bureau of East-West Trade, Cuba has $2.9 billion in external and hard-currency debt, of which $1.9 billion is to commercial banks at interest rates that float with current high market rates.  The other $1 billion is to official export credit agencies.  The interest alone on these loans creates a strong demand in Cuba for hard currencies - currencies that can be freely converted under rules agreed to by the International Monetary Fund. **********Mr. Theriot and Amadeo Blanco Valdes-Fauly, the Cuban Deputy Minister of External Commerce, said 1980 was a very good year for Cuba in the world marketplace.  Sugar, which accounts for 83 percent of Cuba's exports, reached a peak at 40 cents a pound and, although the harvest was poor, helped give Cuba a $500 million hard-currency trade surplus, against a $70 million deficit in 1979. **********Sugar prices, however, have dipped this year, and another significant source of dollars, visits home by Cuban exiles, seems likely to continue to dwindle.  These visits, which in 1979 yielded between $100 and $150 million by Mr. Theriot's estimate, this year will bring only $40 million, according to Jesus Jimenez, vice president of Intur, the Cuban state tourism organization. **********The Cayo Largo tourist project, which is expected to be under way by 1985, is an effort to attract the big-spending luxury trade, which now goes elsewhere in the Caribbean to beachcomb, relax and shop.  Cuban hotels are generally clean, but hot water and good service range from sporadic to nonexistent, and there is little to buy. **********On Cayo Largo, which lies in an archipelago east of the Isle of Youth, Mr. Jimenez hopes that 5,000 rooms in hotels, villas and cabanas can be developed in partnership with private foreign investors. **********Depending on how much they invest, these would go into partnerships with one of the 25 companies run by Intur, and these partnerships would take over the management and share the profits from the resort developments. **********There are more than 10 miles of wide beaches on the island, coral reefs and sunken ships nearby for scuba divers.  A golf course is planned, along with shopping and restaurants.  The accommodations will be low-density: "We don't want to make it a Miami Beach," Mr.  Jimenez said. **********No casino gambling will be allowed, and it is unlikely that Cuban citizens will be able to shop in the stores for foreigners, which will ask for payment in foreign exchange or credit cards.  (MasterCard and Diners Club are already accepted at hotels in Havana.) **********According to Mr. Jimenez, Intur is now negotiating with a Japanese group, a Canadian company and Club Mediterranee, which he said wants to build a resort on the island and helped design the finishing touches on a 71-room Cuban hotel, the island's first, which will open next month. **********The Cubans are finishing a two-mile runway to accomodate jumbo jets at the island's airport, but there is as yet no tower and no terminal building. **********The Canadian group, negotiating to build the Hotel Lindamar, is CR International, which is based in Ontario and linked to the business empire of Cyrus Eaton Jr., who since the 1960's has arranged the construction of 11 major hotels in five Soviet-bloc countries and who withdrew from a 1978 project ot build a resort complex elsewhere in Cuba. **********Clara Reece, a British subject, is president of both CR International and Tower International, an Eaton enterprise, and she suggested that Transfer Embryo of Canada, an Ontario concern that freezes cattle embryos for transplants, send the Cuban Government a proposal. **********The Cuban dairy industry is successful and highly developed, and Fidel Castro's older brother, Ramon Castro, takes an active interest in it.  The Cubans replied to the Canadians that they would like to send five veterinarians and four others to see the project.  Two of those in the delegation were officials of Commercial Muralla. **********Dr. Barry Callaghan, technical director of Transfer Embryo, said the name Commercial Muralla meant nothing to him - he thought he was to deal with a delegation from the Cuban Ministry of AGriculture and from Ramon Castro's farm. **********His unfamilarity with the firm is not unusual.  Requests for information about Commercial Muralla were declined by Cuban authorities in Havana. United States officials, who suspect that Commercial Muralla is another in a series of Cuban companies that have been set up to get around the United States trade embargo, know little about the company, other than that it was organized in the summer of 1980 to sell products to the West and to make a profit.  It is organized outside of the usual foreign trade channels and reports directly to high officials in the Cuban Government. It seems to be growing quickly. **********In Havana, before the revolution, Muralla was a street where businessmen of European descent started small "hole-in-the-wall" enterprises that often grew into huge concerns. **********According to State Department officials, Commercial Muralla has been corresponding with many American companies.  And it was Commercial Muralla that handled Cuba's sales of cement to Mexico, which needed it for construction projects. **********For Cuba, more hard currency means more access to foreign technology, which, in turn, can generate more production.  Sometimes, as in the case of the cattle embryos, the increase would be for domestic consumption. At other times, it could generate more output for export. **********Cuba's second major export, for example, is nickel, and the country is now renovating its two existing plants and building a new plant at Punta Gorda. **********In March, during a visit by Canadian experts, Cuban officials said they were having difficulty with Soviet-made equipment and thought they could increase the output of nickel as much as 20 percent if they had Western technology.  An improvement of 1 percent, they said, would raise profits $4 million. **********Production increases, which are not reflected in official statistics, they explained, can and are being sold in the West for hard currency. Reports of this conversation come from reliable non-Cuban sources close to the discussions, but the truth of what the Cuban officials said could not be confirmed. **********Lorne C. Varcoe, president of the Canadian company, Dorr-Oliver Canada Ltd., would not comment in a telephone interview other than to say, "You're on target" and to observe that such a report "could cause problems" for the Cubans, with whom his company still wants very much to do business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/busin.main_headline: CONGRESS AIMS TO CUT U.S. CREDIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/busin.print_headline: CONGRESS AIMS TO CUT U.S. CREDIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/busin.body_text: **********In handing President Reagan a resounding budget victory, both the House of Representatives and the Senate also acted in accordance with the President's wishes to check the rapid growth of Federal borrowing, which many economists consider a major contributor to the rise in interest rates. **********While most attention has been focused on the Government's direct spending and receipts, the less visible off-budget deficit, incorporating Federal credit demands, has been cut back significantly in the parallel versions of bills from both chambers. **********For the 1982 fiscal year, beginning in October, the House and Senate both voted to trim more than $3 billion from the credit, or off-budget deficit, projected for the current fiscal year, an amount of nearly $23 billion. **********Perhaps more significant, Congressional budget aides noted, the total direct and indirect Federal credit requirements next year would fall to 28 percent of all the credit in the financial system, from 33.5 percent envisaged in fiscal 1981. **********Private Economists Encouraged **********Although problems could still arise, for example, in financing to build up oil stocks in the strategic petroleum reserve, the budget monitors in the private sector have been encouraged by the Congressional action. **********''It is the vast amounts of credit pre-emption by the Federal Government, including guarantees and off-budget financing, that is placing excessive inflationary pressure on our system,'' said economist Alan Greenspan, a former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. **********''That Congress is now acquiescing to the cutbacks represents a very important change in overall policy,'' he continued.  Both chambers restricted direct loans and Federally guaranteed loans, and accepted many of the restrictions sought by the Administration on the total lending of the Federal Financing Bank, an institution set up at the request of the Treasury in 1973 to streamline Federal credit operations. It borrows from the Treasury and uses the funds to finance a score of programs run by other agencies. Cuts From Both Houses **********Both houses voted to reduce Federal Financing Bank lending by more than $3 billion in 1982, compared with the $4.7 billion reduction that had been sought by the Administration. The Federal Financing Bank accounts for most of the approximately $85 billion in Federal lending guarantees. **********They also sought to check two activities of the bank that have led to increasing off-budget lending activity in previous years: the ability of the bank to convert loan guarantees of an agency to an off-budget direct loan; and the purchase of loans from the agencies, again to remove the spending from the budget accounts to an offbudget item. **********As an example of the former, the Farmers Home Administration would guarantee a mortgage for a farmer who would in turn take that guarantee to the Federal Financing Bank, which would make him an offbudget loan at a favorable interest rate. **********The budget resolutions of both Houses seek to check the growth of these so-called loan originations of the bank by holding their total to $11.7 billion in 1982, compared with $11.3 billion in 1981. In 1977 the total was $5.3 billion. **********As an illustration of the latter practice, known as a loan asset sale, the Rural Electrification Administration would make a loan to a rural electric cooperative, which in turn would sell the note to the Federal Financing Bank. In this way the transaction would again be neatly erased from the budget. **********The budget resolutions of the two chambers would sharply reduce loan asset sales to $6.3 billion in fiscal 1982 from a projected $14 billion in 1981. Signs of Credit Restraint **********The overall figures for direct lending and loan guarantees are further indications of the degree of restraint that Congress wants to apply in the Federal credit activities. **********Although there are small accounting differences in the two legislative proposals, the overall direct lending figure for fiscal 1982 has been trimmed to a bit over $50 billion from the $73.5 billion for fiscal 1981 projected in the latest estimates of the Office of Management and Budget. **********Loan guarantees - in which the Federal Government underwrites a loan in the private sector, as in mortgage loan guarantees to veterans, or as was done recently to prevent the collapse of the Chrysler Corporation - are to be kept at $85 billion in 1982, roughly the same level as that projected for 1981. **********That the total would stay unchanged is still considered a victory for restraint in light of the 50 percent increase in guaranteed loans between fiscal 1980 and 1981. **********Most loan guarantee programs are financed directly in the securities market, giving rise to the belief that they are substantially different from direct loans and involve less Government intervention in traditional borrower-lender relationships. **********But according to Roger W. Mehle, the new Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance, such a belief is a ''myth.'' ''Every dollar of Government-guaranteed debt financed in the public marketplace,'' Mr. Mehle observed, ''is like a Treasury borrowing and has a similar negative impact on private-sector rates.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/20/world.main_headline: SWEARING-IN OF PAPANDREOU EXPECTED TO COME TOMORROW
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/20/world.print_headline: SWEARING-IN OF PAPANDREOU EXPECTED TO COME TOMORROW
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/20/world.body_text: **********Andreas Papandreou, whose Socialist party surprised even its most militant members with the extent of its election victory yesterday, is expected to be sworn in as Prime Minister on Wednesday. **********With the defeat of the pro-Western New Democracy Party, Prime Minister George Rallis is due to submit the resignation of his Cabinet to President Constantine Caramanlis tomorrow morning. The formal request to Mr. Papandreou to form a new Government will follow. **********The Socialist triumph, ending 35 years of conservative rule in Greece, produced no marked effect on financial circles here. Some New Democracy sources had predicted that panic would ensue. **********However, Georgios Kolitsa, the general director of the Athens Stock Exchange, said there was no indication of unusual movement.  There was a 15 percent increase in banking activities, according to banking sources, but they said there was nothing like any run on the banks. A Commanding Majority **********Campaigning on a platform of radical change in both foreign and domestic policy, the Socialists won a commanding majority in Parliament, capturing 174 of the 300 seats. New Democracy was limited to 113, and the pro-Moscow Communist Party won 13. **********According to final returns announced tonight by the Ministry of the Interior, Mr. Papandreou's Panhellenic Socialist Movement received 2,629,870 votes, or 48.06 percent of the total. New Democracy received 1,966,516 votes, or 35.94 percent, and the Communist Party, 594,532, or 10.87 percent. **********In his victory speech last night, Mr. Papandreou pledged to carry out his party's program ''to the letter,'' but, in an apparent move to assure the public, he also said he would not ''lead the public on any adventure.'' **********This was viewed as evidence that he was not preparing any dramatic foreign policy moves in the near future despite his party's opposition to Greece's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Economic Community and its denunciation of the American bases that are on Greek soil. Reagan Sends Congratulations **********President Reagan today sent Mr. Papandreou a message congratulating him on his election triumph but also reminding him, according to a Socialist party statement, of the close ''dedication to democracy'' shared by the two countries and the ''common ideals represented within the Western alliance.'' **********Mr. Papandreou replied that Greece was indeed dedicated to democracy and that he would do everything possible ''to promote the close bonds of friendship between the Greek and American peoples.'' **********Diplomats here said they felt Mr. Papandreou would proceed cautiously with his program, taking special care not to perturb the military. He is expected to concentrate on the extensive proposals for social and economic change included in the program of his party.  It calls for higher wages and pensions as a result of inflationary pressures, effective price controls, the reorganization of the education system, a new socialized health system as well as the ''socialization'' of various sectors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/06/world.main_headline: U.S. TELLS SUZUKI SUBMARINE DID NOT REALIZE JAPANESE SHIP HAD SUNK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/06/world.print_headline: U.S. TELLS SUZUKI SUBMARINE DID NOT REALIZE JAPANESE SHIP HAD SUNK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/06/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan was given a preliminary report today on the collision between an American submarine and a Japanese freighter that said the submarine did not search for survivors because it did not know the ship had sunk, Administration officials said today. **********The officials said that the report on the accident that occurred April 9 in the East China Sea was given to the Prime Minister in New York today by Mike Mansfield, the United States Ambassador to Japan.  Mr. Suzuki is in the United States for meetings later this week with President Reagan and other Administration officials. **********The officials said the brief report said that a Navy watch officer had failed to avoid the collision after sonar instruments detected the freighter Nissho Maru and that American naval authorities in Tokyo had delayed reporting the incident to the Japanese Government because they did not know the ship had sunk. Two persons aboard the freighter died in the sinking. **********The United States Navy last month accepted liability for the accident, which has already led to lawsuits in Japan for financial damages. **********The incident provoked sharp criticism in Japan, where there is strong antimili- **********In New York, the Prime Minister met with business executives and leaders of the Japanese community. Page B1. tary and antinuclear sentiment. United States officials said that the interim report given to Mr. Suzuki would allay some of the tension while a more complete investigation goes on. **********The officials said that the warship involved in the collision, the George Washington, the oldest United States submarine that carries nuclear missiles, put to sea again early today under a new commander after minor damage from the crash was repaired in Guam. **********They said that Comdr. Robert Woehl had been transferred from the submarine in order to participate in the Navy investigation, which includes interviews with the submarine's officers and crew and with Japanese survivors. The 13 survivors were rescued by passing Japanese warships that came upon them by chance after they had spent 18 hours adrift in lifeboats. **********Officials said that these were the main points in the preliminary report: **********- The submarine's watch officer was notified that sonar had picked up a freighter in the area, but he failed to respond by monitoring the cargo ship's course. **********- The submarine tried to determine after the crash whether the freighter was in danger, but no distress calls were received and the ship appeared to be steaming normally before it disappeared from sight into a fog bank. **********- A United States Navy plane also attempted to make contact but its crew did not see the freighter or its lifeboats and did not realize the ship had sunk. **********- The submarine reported the crash as a seemingly minor incident to Navy authorities in Japan an hour and 37 minutes after it occurred, but the authorities delayed many more hours and did not notify the Japanese Government until after the survivors had been rescued. **********''There was no sense of urgency'' on the submarine or among the United States officials in Tokyo, an official in Washington said. He said that Navy officials in Tokyo had not responded properly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/busin.body_text: **********Advance summer bookings for domestic travel on trunk airlines are generally weak, airline analysts report, and passenger traffic has been sluggish this month. **********Several possible causes have been suggested. Michael Derchin, vice president and airline analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, cites the state of the economy, the recent threat of an air traffic controllers' strike, fare increases, aggressive competition from new and regional airlines and fare discounting in May, which probably induced some travelers to fly then instead of later. **********Mr. Derchin predicted that domestic passenger traffic on the trunk carriers, as 10 of the nation's large airlines are known, would turn out to be 5 to 8 percent less this month than it was in June 1980 - or maybe even less than that. The trunk airlines are American, Braniff, Continental, Delta, Eastern, Northwest, Pan American, Trans World, United and Western. **********Amid flight uncertainty surrounding the controllers' threat to walk out on June 22, many travelers chose not to fly. As a result, the country's scheduled airlines lost more than $40 million in ticket sales, the Air Transport Association, the main industry organization, estimated last week. Impact of Fare Changes **********Airline passenger traffic in May was relatively strong. But Robert J. Joedicke, an airline expert and first vice president at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, described domestic airline operations as an area of ''pernicious weakness in travel demand as a result of fare increases'' last winter. **********May's domestic and international travel on scheduled airlines was 3.6 percent higher than in May 1980, the Air Transport Association reported. It was the first year-to-year increase for any month since February 1980. For the first five months of this year, however, passenger traffic was 5.8 percent below the level of a year earlier. **********In appraising this summer's outlook, analysts declared that precise predictions were not feasible. ''It's very difficult to quantify,'' said Mr. Derchin of Oppenheimer. ''It's hard to read the booking patterns for the trunk airlines. Restrictions on discount fares have loosened up, and it's a lot easier for travelers to make last-minute arrangements.'' **********On the positive side, Mr. Derchin said: ''International traffic has been the bright spot this year, and advance international bookings look very strong, probably because of the strengthening of the dollar abroad. Travel is getting a lot cheaper.'' August Surge Expected **********Sally C. McElwreath, T.W.A.'s director of public affairs, said: ''On the international side, we expect a strong surge of passenger traffic in August as Americans realize the growing strength of the dollar, and the outlook for the rest of the summer domestically looks slightly higher than last year for us.'' **********For his part, Mr. Joedicke said the prospects for airline travel demand during the summer vacation period were enhanced by ''the extremely low promotional fares being offered in this peak season for some of the major travel markets.'' **********The airlines' efforts to attract additional passengers have been taking many forms. Last week United Airlines decided to match the new fare to Hawaii introduced by Western Airlines and Trans World Airlines. Both United's new fare and the joint Western-T.W.A. fare slash as much as $216 off existing discount round-trip tickets. But the carriers are offering their deep discounts for somewhat different sets of cities in the continental United States, and other provisions of their offers differ.

Molybdenum is a soft silver-white mineral used to harden metal alloys. **********If Exxon proceeds with the venture, it will be the second major molybdenum mine in Nevada. The Anaconda Copper Company is developing a major mine in the San Antonio mountains in Nye County, about 25 miles north of Tonopah.
