Porter of the department's Agricultural Marketing Service said it had become ''a source of concern'' to the agency that the cash quotations were so widely used in the grain industry despite the small volume. **********''It's our position that we should not continue to issue quotations when changing market patterns have resulted in only limited activity in the market,'' Mr. Porter said. The quotations will continue until April 1, he said, to give the industry time to adjust.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/31/busin.body_text: **********H AVING started the debate about the economic impact of President Reagan's military spending in the New York Review of Books last month, let me respond to the points made by the economic defenders of the Reagan military budget. **********The President plans to raise military spending to $343 billion a year in fiscal year 1986, from $162 billion a year in fiscal 1981.  In that earlier article, I contended that, ranked in descending order of their probability, this increase in military spending would severely weaken this country's high-technology civilian industries as materials, equipment and skilled personnel are moved from civilian to military pursuits; produce shortages of materials, equipment and skilled personnel that will create ''bottleneck'' inflation in the sectors where the shortages occur, and stimulate general excess demand inflation in the rest of the economy just as it did during the Vietnam War. **********Perhaps because there is no counterargument, the economic defenders of the Reagan Administration's defense budget have been completely silent when it comes to the first point. Since our high-technology civilian industries exist in the same regions of the country and demand the same equipment and personnel as our military industries, a rapid military buildup can only occur by taking resources out of the high-technolgy civilian sectors. **********The effects are going to be particularly severe in the semiconductor industry since it is going to be facing a Japanese onslaught during the next three years. Since our military allies but economic competitors - mainly West Germany and Japan - are not planning to increase their defense spending, our computer industry will be hemorrhaging personnel just when it needs its best brains to survive. **********Engineers and skilled blue-collar workers will be moving from civilian computer companies, such as Wang Laboratories, to military contractors, such as the Raytheon Company, in the Boston area. **********The economic defenders of the Reagan Administration's defense budget also concede that bottleneck inflation will exist, but argue that it will be small. Bottleneck inflation added 1.2 percentage points to the nation's inflation rate during the first two years of the Vietnam War. Although it is true that 1.2 percentage points looks larger relative to a 1.7 percent inflation rate in 1965 than it does relative to 12.4 percent in 1980, it is still important. **********There is also every reason to believe that the economy has become more inflationary-prone with the experience of the past 15 years and that the same bottleneck would create more inflation in 1982 than it did in 1966. **********Bottlenecks depend upon how fast resources are being transferred from the civilian to the military economy. In the Reagan defense budget, military spending is to rise 9.1 percent a year after correcting for inflation. Given the time it takes to train new skilled blue-collar workers and engineers, there is no way that the supply of skills can keep up with this growth rate. **********There is also every reason to believe that the President has underestimated his defense budget. Whatever happens in the rest of the economy, demand will push up prices for military hardware. It will take more money than is now estimated to buy the equipment that the Defense Department wants. In addition, the President's budget has not allowed for the increased training and personnel costs that will be necessary to man all this new equipment. **********V IEWED as the fraction of the gross national product that must be reallocated to defense, the size of the burden depends upon whether you do or do not believe in the President's supply-side miracle - a much higher rate of growth in the G.N.P. According to the President's economic projection, the economy's real growth rate will average 4.4 percent from 1982 through 1986. If this occurs, the higher military budget will rise from 5.7 to 7.1 percent of the G.N.P. **********But in order for the economy to grow at 4.4 percent a year, productivity has to grow 3 percent. But productivity growth has been below 3 percent for the last 16 years, and actually falling in the last three years. Productivity will not recover quickly. New factories, better-trained workers, and new management techniques will all be necessary. **********Suppose that productivity were to stop falling but did not rebound, leaving the economy's growth rate at only 1.4 percent a year. In this case, the military budget would rise an extra 2.4 percentage points, to 8.1 percent of the G.N.P., from 5.7. At its peak, Vietnam required an extra 1.8 percent of G.N.P. **********The economic defenders of the Reagan military budget are correct in saying that general inflationary pressures can be controlled if we raise taxes and cut civilian spending enough. But is Mr. Reagan planning to do so? **********In President Reagan's projections, the Federal budget is to be balanced in 1984, with a $28 billion surplus in 1986. But this movement toward a balanced budget depends upon the supply-side miracle and that instantaneous recovery in productivity growth. If productivity does not recover and the economy's real growth rate is 3 percentage points less than Mr. Reagan predicts, there will be a $55 billion deficit in 1984 and an $86 billion deficit in 1986. In addition, the Congressional Budget Office estimates that the President is underestimating 1982 expenditures by $25 billion. Add $25 billion to spending and you have a deficit of $111 billion in fiscal 1986. **********President Reagan's economic defenders also point out that unemployment is higher and capacity utilization lower in 1982 than it was in 1965. Those unemployed resources could be absorbed to expand defense production. **********But there is a problem. Those unemployed resources are not in the right geographic areas, industries or occupations necessary to expand defense production. There is also a question whether there is a lot of excess capacity on an inflation-adjusted basis. More than 7 percent of the population is unemployed, but up to now we have been told that more unemployment was necessary to stop inflation. **********I have a lot of sympathy for the view that America's inflation was not caused by excess aggregate demand and that more unemployment will not cure inflation, but it is interesting to note that those who just a few months ago were arguing that more unemployment was necessary to stop inflation are today arguing that the unemployed can be put to work in defense industries without creating inflation. **********One wonders what conservatives would be saying about inflation if President Reagan were planning to expand nondefense spending by $181 billion a year by 1986. ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Lester C. Thurow is Professor of Economics and Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and author of ''The Zero-Sum Society.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/15/world.main_headline: FRANCE'S SOCIALISTS WIN BY LANDSLIDE IN ASSEMBLY VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/15/world.print_headline: FRANCE'S SOCIALISTS WIN BY LANDSLIDE IN ASSEMBLY VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/15/world.body_text: **********The Socialist Party won a landslide victory today in the first round of elections for France's National Assembly. Its showing was so strong that, barring an unexpected upset, it should hold a majority in the Assembly after the second round of voting next Sunday. **********Today's vote confirmed the major shift in France's politics that began with the election as President last month of the Socialist leader Francois Mitterrand, and it confirmed it more decisively than the Socialists themselves had expected. **********The voting seems to guarantee that Mr. Mitterrand will be able to introduce without serious parliamentary opposition the economic and social changes he has promised. It also seems to guarantee that he will be able to do this, if he chooses, without including Communists in his Cabinet. **********Almost 50 Percent Increase **********In France's two-round system, today's voting decides the two toprunning candidates for each Assembly seat. In next week's election, voters will make a final choice for each seat. **********Computer projections gave the Socialist candidates for the Assembly's 491 seats between 37 and 39 percent of the vote, an increase of almost 50 percent over Mr. Mitterrand's total in the first round of the Presidential vote. Communist Party candidates won a projected 16 percent, thus failing to make any significant progress after their big setback last month. **********Indeed, a significant result of today's vote was the confirmation that the Communist Party has been seriously weakened. After averaging a bit over 20 percent of the vote over the past decade, the party had slipped to just over 15 percent in the first round of the presidential elections. **********It was unclear, however, whether many Communists voted for Mr.  Mitterrand out of a new-found loyalty or because they thought their own candidate, Georges Marchais, had no chance to win. The fact that these lost voters have remained lost, despite the party's urging that a strong Communist delegation to the Assembly was necessary if real change was to take place, means that the party is in serious trouble.  Support for Front-Runners **********Because the Communists and Socialists have agreed to support in the second round whichever of their candidates leads after the first round, and given that the Socialists are mostly the front-runners, next Sunday's vote is expected to give them between 280 and 320 seats. At present the Socialists hold 117 Assembly seats. The number of Communist seats is expected to fall from 89 to about 50. **********Against what is both the biggest victory of the French left in this century and the biggest victory for the Socialists, the candidates of the right have won a projected 44 percent of the vote. **********The Gaullists, followers of Jacques Chirac, have taken about 21 percent of that, the followers of former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing about 19 percent and the rest has gone to splinter groups.  Projecting the Gaullist vote would produce about 75-80 seats; the supporters of Mr. Giscard d'Estaing might win 65 or 70. Complex Electoral System **********The figures may vary next Sunday; the mathematics of the French electoral system are too complex for precise projection in the second round. In addition, the electorate could vote differently. Finally, only 70 percent of the electorate voted today, the lowest figure in 20 years, and if many of those who abstained decided to vote next Sunday the figures could change. **********Tonight, leaders of the conservative groups were calling on those who stayed at home to came out and vote, figuring that more of them would suport the right than the left. **********The Communists' troubles were confirmed indirectly tonight by Mr.  Marchais, who admitted that it was a ''difficult'' time and indicated that a period of self-examination was likely. **********The virtually certain ability of the Socialist Party to dominate the National Assembly for the next five years along with its ally, the small, centrist Radical Left Movement, raised the question here tonight about whether the Socialists would continue their negotiations with the Communists on a common program that would permit the appointment of a few Communist Cabinet officials. **********Socialist spokesmen were ambiguous on the subject, but Interior Minister Raston Defferre stressed that although talks would continue it was still necessary for the Communists to accept a stiff list of Socialist policy conditions. Among these are condemnation of the Soviet Union for its military presence in Afghanistan and approval of the Western stand on nuclear missiles in Europe. **********Today's low voter turnout intrigued French commentators. It was the first warm and sunny Sunday in a cold and rainy spring, but, perhaps more important, the French have already been called on to vote twice in the past month and will have to vote again next Sunday. Fairly Lethargic Campaign **********The campaign over the past two weeks was fairly lethargic in comparison with the one that preceded the Presidential voting. The basic argument of the Socialists was that the French had decided on major changes in their social and economic life by electing Mr.  Mitterrand, and that the only consistent and intelligent thing to do was to confirm the decision by giving him the legislative majority he will need. **********The Gaullists and the Giscard d'Estaing followers argued, without much enthusiasm, that the French should do precisely the opposite.  Having gone out on a limb by electing a Socialist President, they asserted, the French should hedge their bet by electing a conservative Assembly, thus preventing Mr. Mitterrand from going too far. **********Mr. Mitterrand is expected to choose his Cabinet after next Sunday's election, which will choose, generally speaking, from among the two top-runners in today's vote. The present Cabinet was chosen more for symbolic and electoral purposes than for efficiency, and a number of officials are likely to be replaced. **********Although the French President has strong powers, and although Mr.  Mitterrand has been able in the past months to take a number of steps, such as raising minimum wages, he needs an Assembly majority to make the major changes he has promised. Among these are a readjustment of the tax system, a decentralization of the Government and the nationalization of a number of enterprises.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/10/busin.body_text: **********The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, which slid to fourth place from third among brewers in total beer sold last year, said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings for 1980 were $2.2 million, or 8 cents a share, compared with a loss of $44.8 million in the same period last year. Gross sales fell 2.9 percent, to $217.8 million from $224.3 million. These sales figures included excise taxes of $27.9 million in the 1980 quarter and $29.5 million in the period a year earlier. **********Profits for the year amounted to $27 million, or 93 cents a share, compared with a loss of $50.6 million for 1979. Sales slipped 1.4 percent, to $1.03 billion from $1.04 billion. The sales figures included excise taxes of $131.1 million and $148.4 million, respectively. **********Frank J. Sellinger, vice chairman and chief executive, attributed the showing to a price rise, a reduction in plant capacity and continuing cost controls. **********Wall Street analysts were not impressed by the Schlitz performance and Schlitz shares fell yesterday to 9 3/4, off 3/4, in heavy trading. **********In New York, Richard E. Ozaroff, brewing analyst for the Value Line Investment Survey, said that Schlitz's beer volume for 1980 - 15 million barrels, down 11 percent from the 16.8 million reported for the year before - was ''about 500,000 barrels higher than we expected.'' However, he added, Schlitz's results for the year ''still have to be considered weak.'' **********In Chicago, Roger W. Spencer, brewing analyst for Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins, said it was uncertain whether Schlitz could achieve a turnaround. ''It's been going down since 1976 and unless you can turn it, sooner or later you'll wind up with nothing,'' he said. **********Once the world's largest brewer, Schlitz lost that title to Anheuser-Busch many years ago and now, according to Mr. Ozaroff, could slide from its No. 4 spot to sixth position in the industry as both the Adolph Coors Company, No. 5, and the G. Heileman Brewing Company, No. 6, press for further sales. **********After Anheuser-Busch, Miller Brewing, the Philip Morris subsidiary, ranks second, with the two accounting for roughly one-half of all beer sales. Pabst is No. 3. Anheuser-Busch **********The Anheuser-Busch Companies Inc. reported that fourth-quarter net income rose 23.2 percent, to $35.1 million, or 78 cents a share, from $28.5 million, or 63 cents a share, in the same period last year. Net sales for the quarter rose 15.2 percent, to $800.5 million from $695.1 million. Beer shipments rose 9.3 percent in the final quarter, to 12,067,000 barrels from 11,040,000 the year before. Gross sales in the quarter, which include Federal and state excise taxes, rose 14 percent, to $925.2 million from $811.5 million. **********The company, which reported earlier that sales for 1980 had jumped 8.5 percent, to 50.2 million barrels, said this was the 24th consecutive year of industry leadership. It said its volume was 27.8 percent of total industry sales. This would place the industry's sales at 180.5 million barrels. **********On the New York Stock Exchange, Anheuser-Busch shares fell a point, to 32 3/4, in brisk trading. The company brews Budweiser, Michelob and Busch and imports Wurzburger beer from West Germany.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/busin.print_headline: NEW YORK AIR PLANS TWO BOSTON ROUTES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/busin.body_text: **********New York Air said today that it would begin daily service from both Washington and New York to Boston at discount prices beginning Feb. 15.  New York Air said it would offer a one-way Boston-Washington fare of $59, compared with a normal coach fare of $103. **********The fare from Boston to New York would be $39 on weekdays and $29 on weekends. **********The airlines said it would have five round-trip flights between Boston and Washington and ten between Boston and New York each weekday, with eight flights to New York and four to Washington on Saturday and Sunday. **********The company, owned by the Texas Air Corporation, challenged Eastern Airlines' dominance in the Northeast air commuter business Dec.14, when it began a Washington-New York service at fares 20 percent below Eastern's.  Eastern has since lowered some fares and started a coupon campaign in efforts to meet the competition. **********New York Air reported yesterday that it carried 37,676 passengers on its New-York-Washington route in January, its first full month of operation, for a load factor of 58.1 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/busin.main_headline: DOW CLIMBS BY 5.40 IN HEAVY TRADING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/busin.print_headline: DOW CLIMBS BY 5.40 IN HEAVY TRADING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/busin.body_text: **********The stock market finished moderately higher yesterday in heavier trading with the glamour, blue chips and airlines issues posting the largest gains. **********Analysts attributed the market's upswing to an increasing belief among investors that interest rates may have peaked and that the Polish crisis is easing. Stock prices generally rise when interest rates decline. **********However, they cautioned that if the Federal Reserve Board reports a sharp rise in the latest money supply after the market closes today, it would probably spark further credit tightening by the Federal Reserve Board and another rise in interest rates. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range throughout the session, closed up 5.40 points, to 998.83. At 2 P.M.  the blue chip barometer was off almost 5 points. **********In the general market, advancing issues led decliners by 901 to 637. The main casualties were the energy issues, which fell as traders worried whether the Mexican and Ecuadorean oil price cuts announced late Wednesday would spread to other petroleum-producing countries and reduce oil companies' profits. **********Volume on the New York Stock Exchange expanded to 59.5 million shares from Wednesday's 48 million shares, as institutional participation increased. Turnover yesterday was the largest since March 26, when 60.3 million shares changed hands. **********Charles Jensen, chief technical analyst of MKI Securities, commented that the market was showing good support at the 990 level of the Dow. He said that this suggests ''that in the coming weeks the Dow could test the 1,020 level.'' **********Mr. Jensen said that he regarded the reduction in oil prices by Mexico and Ecuador as ''a good omen in the battle against inflation and for the market.'' He said that investors had been hoping for a concrete sign for an abatement in the inflationary spiral, and the reduction in oil prices ''is a big move in that direction.'' A.T.&T. Leads Active List **********American Telephone and Telegraph led the active list and climbed 1 1/4, to 55 1/8. The stock has benefited from the recent disclosure that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger had urged that the Government's six-year old antitrust case against the company be dismissed. Howagainst the company be dismissed. However, yesterday, William Baxter, the new head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said he would ''litigate the case against A.T.& T. to the eyeballs.'' **********In the stronger glamour and blue chip category yesterday, Eastman Kodak rose 2, to 82 7/8; International Business Machines 1 1/2, to 61 1/2 in heavy trading; General Telephone 1 3/8, to 28 1/2; Texas Instruments 3 3/8, to 118; Tandy 4 1/2, to 62 and Hewlett-Packard 1 3/4, to 96. **********The larger gainers in the transportation group included Delta Air Lines, which rose 2, to 71 1/4; American Airlines 1 5/8, to 17 1/2; UAL 2, to 26 7/8; Northwest 1 1/2, to 31 1/8, and Pan American 1/2, to 5 1/4. The airlines would be big beneficiaries of a cut in oil prices. **********One of the biggest movers was the Chicago Milwaukee Corporation, which jumped 7, to 57 3/8, after a 1 1/2-point gain on Wednesday. The company said it did not know of any special circumstances to account for the rise. U.S. Steel Gains **********United States Steel advanced 1 1/8, to after Sohio agreed to purchase some of U.S. Steel's properties for about $700 million. **********Ford Motor added 1/2, to 22 3/8, after directors voted the regular 30-cent dividend, although the auto producer said it expected the first-quarter loss to exceed the $316 million deficit of the fourth quarter of last year. **********In the weaker energy group, Superior Oil lost 3 1/4, to 212; Atlantic-Richfield lost 1, to 49 1/4; Phillips Petroleum 1 1/4, to 43 3/4; Getty 1 1/4, to 69; Standard of California 1, to 38 1/4, and Mobil 1 1/8, to 64 7/8. **********Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended higher with the market value index up 2.54, to 367.72. Niagara Frontier Services, a food retailer and franchiser, was up 4 3/8, to 31 1/2. On Wednesday, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, said it was negotiating to acquire Niagara Frontier. A.& P.'s stock, which is traded on the Big Board, rose 1/4, to 6 3/8. **********Also on the Amex, Valle's Steak House gained 1 3/8, to 6 3/8, and The New York Times class A stock rose 1 5/8, to 34 1/4.  In the over-the-counter market, the Joseph Dixon Crucible Company soared 9 points, to 37 bid. The company on Wednesday said its directors had agreed in principle to be acquired by a newly formed company to be owned by Wolsey & Company, a New York investment banking firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/21/busin.print_headline: Oil Price Cut By Iraq Cited
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/21/busin.body_text: **********Iraq has officially notified Japanese buyers that it will cut the price of its Basrah light crude oil by 50 cents a barrel, to $34.21, effective Jan. 1, industry sources said. **********The Basrah crude is of slightly better quality than Saudi Arabia's best export crude, which sells for $34 a barrel and serves as the benchmark for all OPEC prices. **********The United States does not import Iraq's Basrah crude, but the reported price concession was seen by industry analysts as a strong indication that other crude prices may fall in the weeks ahead as demand remains depressed worldwide. **********Earlier this month in Abu Dhabi, the oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cut prices on some lower-quality grades of crude, but left almost unchanged the prices for higher-quality oil. The price reductions are to take effect Jan.  1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.print_headline: STOCKHOLM DEVALUES CROWN TO AID ECONOMY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.body_text: **********Sweden devalued its currency by 10 percent today and presented a tough economic package to revive the flagging economy. The crown was last devalued in August 1977. **********Along with the devaluation, the Government announced an immediate price freeze to help slow domestic inflation and a planned reduction in the national value-added sales tax to spur Sweden's beleaguered industry. **********The minority center-liberal Government of Prime Minister Thorbjoern Faelldin has been under pressure to restore the competitive position of Swedish industry and stimulate exports. But, according to economic analysts, the devaluation will bring mixed blessings to the economy. **********While the cheaper crown will help exports of Swedish products manufactured by such giants as Volvo, Electrolux and L.. Ericsson, the devaluation will also raise the price of imported crude oil and other products vital to Swedish industry. **********Today's devaluation is against a basket of 15 currencies most important to Sweden's trade.  The basket is made up of a complex system of weighted currency components that are proportional to the average share of each of the 15 major countries in Sweden's foreign trade over the five years since the 1977 devaluation. The countries include such major trading partners as the United States, West Germany, Britain, Norway and Denmark. **********If the dollar rises against the crown, as it has over the past few months, the currency basket's index will automatically compensate for the increase by permitting the crown's value against other currencies in the basket to appreciate, financial analysts said. **********Sweden's value-added tax, to be lowered from 23.46 percent, to 20 percent, pending parliamentary approval in the fall, has been one of the highest sales taxes in the world. This, according to analysts, has pinched industry's competitiveness against major currencies like the United States and Japan. **********The price freeze and value-added-tax cut are intended to curb inflation, which the government estimates at 13.5 percent this year.  ''We must have a slower rate of expenditure if we are to resolve the problems of imbalance in Sweden's economy,'' Mr. Faelldin told a news conference. **********Flagging production, swelling imports, slackening investment and gaping budget and current account balance of payments holes have been the hallmarks of the Swedish economy over the last two or three years, the economic analysts said. **********As part of today's measures, the Government also announced a $115 million employment program calling for more construction projects in the public sector, housing and road building.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/busin.main_headline: PUSHING THE MAXWELL PRODUCT AT GENERAL FOODS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/busin.print_headline: PUSHING THE MAXWELL PRODUCT AT GENERAL FOODS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/busin.body_text: **********WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.  JOHN SUSKO, as the photographs papering his office attest, has played on the Maxwell House football team. Also the softball team, the tennis team, the basketball team and the baseball team. At one time or another, he has captained them all. **********Off the field, Mr. Susko is being judged on both the qualities thus represented: leadership and teamwork. The sandy-haired, sunburned 30-year-old is a brand manager for Maxwell House instant, which is the best-selling instant coffee in the United States and part of the coffee division of General Foods, critically important to the company. As such, he must tread the line between pushing his own product and playing in the larger context of corporate wellbeing. **********''We're fighting Maxwell House regular, Sanka, Brim,'' he said, citing some of the division's leading brands. But at the same time, he added, ''we look at ourselves as part of the Maxwell House Coffee Company.'' **********Such ambiguity is the lot of the brand manager, a low-level but key position and a well-trod rung to the top at many consumer goods companies. In brand management - a system elevated, if not invented, by packaged goods giant Procter & Gamble - an individual such as Mr.  Susko manages the market for his brand, participating in advertising, packaging and even production decisions, as well as overseeing promotion through trade discounts and consumer couponing. **********The brand manager is expected to vanquish all comers, notably Nestle's Nescafe and P.& G.'s Folger's. At the same time, his objectives - and his budget to achieve them - are defined by a multitude of bosses, who must weigh his needs against those of other General Foods coffee brand managers. **********Furthermore, recent trends at corporations have curbed the brand manager's freedom. ''Marketing has become more specialized, leading to development of separate corporate departments for media and promotion,'' Stephen Greyser, a marketing professor with the Harvard Business School, said. Indeed, at General Foods there is a separate consumer promotions department in coffee that comes up with coupon ideas, there are advertising specialists within the division, and all the Maxwell-brand coffees are advertised under one umbrella. **********''Also, the greater use of formal strategic planning models at the corporate level puts restraints on what individual brands are all about,'' Professor Greyser said. On General Foods's product strategy matrix, for example, Maxwell House instant has been classified as a ''maintenance'' product. That is better than a ''sell-off'' product, but less exciting than a ''grow'' product. **********Nonetheless, ''there's still a lot of responsibility, a lot of visibility in brand management,'' Mr. Greyser added. ''For a relatively young person, particularly in a consumer goods company, it is still an excellent first step to understanding what's going on.'' In short, it's an excellent showcase for up-and-coming managers, whatever the position on the matrix. **********The giant foods company had sales in the fiscal year ending last March 28 of $6.6 billion, of which $2.7 billion came from grocery coffee. Admittedly, General Foods has a host of well-known products, including Birds Eye, Kool-Aid, Jell-O and Minute Rice, and has lately been trying to broaden its business base, notably through the acquisition last May of Oscar Mayer. But the company was built on coffee, and most of its top executives have served time in the coffee division. James L. Ferguson, the current chairman and chief executive officer, is the first in that position who did not come up through coffee. (His experience was mainly in Birds Eye.) **********''If you can market coffee, you can market anything,'' observed Mr. Susko, explaining the product's importance as a training ground.  ''Coffee is a big-selling, heavily-marketed product. There's local competition. Commodity prices change constantly. You almost learn the business in a building-block kind of way,'' he added. **********The job does not demand personal brand loyalty - Mr. Susko, who does@n't even like the taste of coffee, drinks Tab and beer. It does demand a quick grasp of a wide variety of factors affecting any product thrown at the manager, and, Mr. Susko insists, it is ''fun.'' **********''These packaged goods companies have lots of young, interesting people,'' he explained. (The average age in his division is 30 years.) At a relatively early age, he added, ''You get pretty good responsibility.'' **********So far, his path has been fairly typical of brand managers. After studying economics at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, Mr. Susko went to work for Procter & Gamble, peddling Tide, Cheer and P.& G.'s newest detergent, ERA, in Philadelphia. He left to acquire an M.B.A. at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Alfred P. Sloan School of Management, with a summer break in marketing at Coca-Cola. **********In 1978, at the age of 27, Mr. Susko joined Maxwell House as an associate brand manager.  In the past three years, he has: marketed regular and instant coffee, mainly through trade promotions, west of the Mississippi; managed Yuban, General Foods's premium-priced brand; served as the main advertising agency contact on Maxwell House regular and instant, overseeing the transition in television commercials from Cora, the shopkeeper who harangued young couples, to ''that good-to-the-lastdrop feeling,'' crooned by Ray Charles. **********Three months ago, he took charge of Maxwell House instant, at the $40,000 to $50,000 salary range for brand managers at General Foods.  Such mobility is also typical of brand management, and Mr. Susko does not expect to stay for more than a year with Mick, as his product is called. Next on the agenda, in all likelihood, is decaffeinated coffee, and possibly a stint in new product development. **********As brand manager, Mr. Susko said, ''My most important priority is to meet the volume objectives for the year.'' This may not be easy, especially in a declining market. Annual coffee consumption in the United States has been slipping steadily since it peaked in 1962 at 40 gallons per capita, according to John Maxwell, first vicepresident, Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. It fell to 27.8 gallons in 1980, and the decline is expected to continue, said Mr. Maxwell, noting that cold drinks are more compatible with the American lifestyle. **********F URTHERMORE, Mr. Maxwell noted, regular coffee, which had lost market share in recent years to instant coffee, is making a modest recovery - due perhaps to the new generation of cheap, fast electric drip coffee-makers. Instant coffee has leveled off, at less than 20 percent of the total market. **********Maxwell House instant has suffered from not only the declining market but also a surge in competition. Last year, P.& G., whose Folger's regular coffee outsells regular Maxwell House, brought out a new instant, High Point, that immediately captured 2.5 percent of the instant market; instant Folger's also gained share, to 11 percent. **********Mr. Susko's Maxwell House instant, which had peaked in 1972 with a 27 percent market share, slipped to 23.4 percent in 1979 and to 22.2 percent last year. Each market point is worth an estimated $12 million. **********In the long term, ''instant coffee's growth will come mainly from decaffeinated coffee,'' predicted Bruce Bramen, a category manager who is responsible for all Maxwell House-brand coffees. Still, Mr.  Bramen said, ''managing a business in a declining category is extra challenging.'' **********To manage his brand, Mr. Susko keeps his finger constantly on market's pulse. He confers almost daily with the four regional managers for the coffee division about promotions, arguing the best rates to give the trade, the wisdom of distributing a certain package size in a given market. He may talk to the consumer promotions department about ideas for coupons - will it be a 50-cents-off coupon? or a free coffee mug for three labels? - and discuss advertising strategy with the agency, Ogilvy & Mather. **********Up to half of Mr. Susko's time is spent in allocating his marketing budget. (He will not disclose its size, but General Foods' marketing budgets ''are huge,'' he said. ''I could probably retire on the rounding errors alone.'') The money is distributed two ways: through the trade - ''the products you see at the end of the supermarket aisle'' - and through consumer coupons. **********Nothing could sound more obvious, but in fact there is a delicate balancing act. ''You must look at external factors in the market,'' said Mr. Susko, citing the different regional methods of retailing.  Because there are many regional brands of coffee, and regional brands tend to market through trade promotions rather than coupons, Maxwell House and other national brands must try to match their specials.  ''Anything on the end of the aisle sells,'' Mr. Susko said. **********That is the policy in such markets as Chicago, where supermarket owners tend to feature and underwrite such promotions, offering a loss-leading ''$2.99 special,'' for example, placed prominently in the aisles rather than on the shelf, to lure shoppers into the store. **********But specials are avoided in other markets, such as Los Angeles, where groceries are sold heavily through discount stores. A General Foods trade promotion at 20 cents per jar there, for example, would produce only a modest markdown on the shelf; Folgers and Nescafe would be forced to follow suit, and ''all you've done is increase the cost of doing business,'' said Mr. Susko. **********In discount markets particularly, Mr. Susko said, ''consumer promotion is a more effective way to price differentiate,'' thus undercutting the competition through attractive coupon offers. But marketing directly to the consumer rather than via the trade can also be tricky. **********For one thing, while trade promotions virtually guarantee sales, consumers ignore most coupons (and thus the product). For another, the country has lately been swept by a wave of illegal coupon redemptions that costs couponers dearly. To prevent such abuses, General Foods, one of the nation's leading couponers, is issuing more coupons through the mail rather than as newspaper inserts. **********Mr. Susko allocates money for trade and consumer promotions at the start of each quarter, but the decision-making is anything but static. A change in the price of green coffee, an important factor in the price of the final product, can have a major impact on marketing decisions, and ''prices have been all over the place this year,'' he said. First, a glut brought prices tumbling down, then, last month, came news of a frost in Brazil. The cost of beans jumped 50 percent overnight. ''We look at different marketing scenarios all the time,'' said Mr. Susko. **********Every Monday morning, he pores over data from the A.C. Nielsen Company, measuring the previous week's sales against the targets set by the division. ''We're a little behind in volume now,'' he said, ''but we'll make it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/world.main_headline: U.S. ADVISERS TAKING CARE IN EL SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/world.print_headline: U.S. ADVISERS TAKING CARE IN EL SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/world.body_text: **********uf881 By EDWARD SCHUMACHER **********SAN SALVADOR, March 9 - The military advisers here live cautiously, avoiding publicity with almost as much care as they avoid the Marxist guerrillas who might want to shoot them. **********They have tried to blend in, but a group of several hundred journalists here has been hounding them for pictures and interviews.  The fear among the advisers is that they might become walking targets if pictures are published. **********At a news conference arranged by the United States Embassy today, one adviser, a helicopter maintenance instructor, said: ''What makes you nervous - and I'll be honest with you guys - is the press. We have more problems with the press than with these people we are supposed to be aware of.'' Salvadorans Called Capable **********More than 30 of the 45 noncombat advisers assigned to El Salvador have arrived and their presence is a major world issue. But until today, the commanders of the United States Military Group, their formal organization, had refused interviews even under tightly controlled conditions. **********The two officers who met with the press today at Ilopango Air Force Base on the outskirts of San Salvador declined to give their names, ages or places of birth or to speak of their families.  Nonetheless, in 15 minutes they painted a picture of apprehensive but patriotic American volunteers training capable and highly motivated Salvadorans. **********The maintenance instructor, a veteran of the Vietnam War, said there was ''no comparison'' between the Salvadoran soldiers and the South Vietnamese he had trained. He said the Salvadorans were superior in discipline, organization and motivation. **********''The Salvadorans' problem is not their capability,'' he said.  ''It's their support, their equipment. They are very capable. Their ingenuity is amazing.'' Helicopter Pilots Retrained **********The two officers are part of a helicopter training team of 14 that came here a month ago. The pilot said his job was mostly a matter of training Salvadorans to fly the 10 American Bell Huey transport helicopters on loan from the United States. The Salvadorans are already experienced in flying El Salvador's French-made helicopters.  The pilot said he trains four Salvadorans every five weeks. **********''The pilots are extremely capable, willing and eager to learn,'' he said.  The training, he said, takes place near the air base and the international airport. The helicopters are sometimes taken away for combat missions, but the pilot said no American goes along. **********Among the other advisers who have arrived or are on the way are five specialists in ship maintenance, five specialists in planning and operations who will work with the senior command, and 15 who will teach small-unit tactics, including intelligence, interdicting weapons traffic and helicopter assault. In addition to the 45 advisers, seven men are also being temporarily assigned to provide support, bringing the headquarters and administrative staff to 12. Weekends at the Beach **********United States officials said they hope that the advisers will be able to complete their work in six months, though there is no firm time limit. One of the officers said today that he had a month to prepare before coming; the other said he had just three days notice. **********The advisers live off base in private accommodations and are free to move about the city. On weekends, some go to El Salvador's unspoiled beaches. **********They said they always carry a pistol. Their orders are not to get involved in any combat, but they are authorized to shoot in selfdefense or to protect a fellow adviser. **********''If another one of our members is about to get killed, I will take action,'' one said today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/12/world.main_headline: GISCARD ROLLS OUT RED CARPET FOR SADAT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/12/world.print_headline: GISCARD ROLLS OUT RED CARPET FOR SADAT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/12/world.body_text: **********After years of diplomatic chilliness, the French Government went all out today to welcome President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, who is here on a campaign to encourage Western European involvement in a Middle East settlement. **********President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, who measures out protocol like an expensive medicine, went to the airport, along with his wife, Anne-Aymone, to meet Mr. Sadat, who arrived from Luxembourg with his wife, Jihan, and one of his daughters. Such attention is rated as exceptional here, for Mr. Sadat's visit is technically a private one. **********Yesterday Mr. Sadat said at a session of the European Parliament that he welcomed a plan approved in December by the Common Market.  The plan called for continued diplomatic efforts by the market to explore proposals that would guarantee Israel's security, gain Israel's withdrawal from occupied Arab territories and provide for Palestinian self-determination. **********This morning, at a news conference before leaving Luxembourg, Mr.  Sadat suggested that European involvement might go so far as to provide troops for enforcing any security guarantee worked out in an eventual settlement. Talks Through the Afternoon **********The meeting between Mr. Sadat and Mr. Giscard d'Estaing included a lunch and talks through the afternoon at the President's official residence, Elysee Palace. Mr. Sadat will remain here until Friday, when he will hold a news conference, but no further talks are scheduled. **********Mr. Sadat's visit marked a noticeable shift in the strained relations that have existed between Egypt and France in the recent past. **********Of all the Western European countries, France has tended to be the most critical of the Camp David accords and among those most favorable to recognizing the Palestine Liberation Organization. In recent years, furthermore, the French concentrated on cementing relations with the hard-line Arab countries, such as Iraq and Libya. **********All these things tended to put them at odds with Mr. Sadat, who was offended by the criticism of the Camp David agreeement and, more specifically, by the diversion of French political and economic efforts to Arab countries that were not only more radical but had more oil as well. Diplomatic Effort Complicated **********A number of recent developments have inclined the French to alter their course. The Iran-Iraq war, and other splits among the more radical Moslem nations, have complicated the French diplomatic effort. The P.L.O., weakened by the quarrels among its supporters, seems less of a sure thing, at least in the short run. France's relations with Libya have deteriorated steadily, most notably with the recent Libyan push into Chad. **********All this has made the French Government more interested in a rapprochement with Mr. Sadat. Furthermore, France's effort to rally Chad's neighbors against further Libyan expansion finds a natural ally in Mr. Sadat, an old enemy of Libya's leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi. **********In addition, French officials studying the Middle East situation see possibilities for diplomacy that were not previously apparent to them. For one thing they are betting that the Labor Party will come to power in Israel in this summer's elections. **********Although Israel's relations with France have been far sourer than those of Egypt, Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, visited Paris a few weeks ago. 'More Reasonable' Attitude **********Not long after this, some French officials began talking about a ''more reasonable'' attitude by Israel. They suggested that what they had seen of Labor Party attitudes, and what they had learned from their contacts with the P.L.O., suggested a degree of mutual softening. **********At the same time the French began to talk of better relations with Egypt, and of the prospect that in the course of this year the atmosphere for negotiating might improve. One well-placed official suggested that France might find itself strategically placed to use its good offices in getting indirect or even direct talks going between the Israelis and the P.L.O. **********It is expected that this summer there will be a reawakening of the European efforts to find a Middle East peace formula. And the French effort to improve relations with both Egypt and Israel is undoubtedly designed to give Paris a more effective role in any plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Specter of Crisis In Global Debt
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Specter of Crisis In Global Debt
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/busin.body_text: **********THE shock wave from the attempt on the life of President Reagan spread through the world financial system within minutes. Panic was forestalled by the quick closing of the New York Stock Exchange and by the news that, following surgery to remove the bullet from his lung, the President was not in danger. **********Nevertheless, anxieties stirred by the assassination attempt will not quickly vanish.  Some threats to world financial stability come not from individual assassins or bands of terrorists but from governments themselves. A recent report by the heads of the four major foreign-policy research institutions of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany warns of three great dangers to the West: **********First, in contrast to a decade ago when the prospects were for detente and successful arms negotiations with the Soviet Union, the period now beginning ''is marked by increased tensions between East and West and enhanced Soviet military threats both in Europe and in third-world regions.'' **********Second, the West is facing an increasingly unstable third world, especially in the Persian Gulf, upon which it depends for economic survival. ''In effect,'' says the report, written by Karl Kaiser of West Germany, Winston Lord of the United States, Thierry de Montbrial of France and David Watt of Britain, ''the new importance of the third world for Western security is such that an extensive and prolonged interruption of oil supplies today would provoke a world economic crisis of a greater magnitude than the Great Depression of the 1930's.'' **********Third, the period ahead will be one of prolonged economic crisis worldwide, characterized in the West by very low growth rates, high inflation and high unemployment. These economic troubles, the report says, ''can be expected to sharpen North-South tensions, increase competition among Western nations themselves (including Japan) and produce dangerous social tensions within Western democracies.'' **********But there is a fourth potential crisis, stemming from those named above: the danger of a breakdown in the world banking and financial system. While this danger receives scare treatment from some profitseeking promoters, it is scarcely discussed publicly by government or central-bank officials or private bankers. **********However, a new study, ''Financial Disorder and International Banking'' by Jack Guttentag and Richard Herring of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, concludes that ''a crisis in international banking has become increasingly probable.'' **********The rapid growth of international banking activity, at a much faster rate than domestic activity, has exposed the banks to growing risks of borrower defaults and foreign-exchange losses. Light regulatory controls have allowed the banks doing huge amounts of business internationally to assume huge risks without challenge. **********''The most likely crisis scenario,'' say the Pennsylvania economists, ''would begin with a development that substantially raises the expenses or reduces the revenues of one or more countries with heavy outstanding indebtedness to banks.'' **********Climbing interest rates, as well as oil bills, are increasingly burdening poor countries.  Using floating-rate loan contracts in making Eurocurrency loans, Western banks have tried to protect themselves against interest-rate loss by shifting the risk to the borrower. But this, Mr. Guttentag and Mr. Herring warn, ''could lead to a credit shock to lending banks, to a loss of confidence in such banks and to a run by creditors of such banks including other banks.'' **********United States banks have taken big risks in covering the deficits of the oil-importing countries of the third world. The latest lending-exposure survey of the Federal Reserve Board, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Comptroller of the Currency shows that, as of last June, American banks were owed $42.9 billion by nonoil-producing Latin American countries and $19.9 billion by nonoil-producing countries in Asia. The risks are compounded by the heavy lending done by West German, British, French and other foreign banks. **********Total foreign debts of the developing countries that do not produce oil have climbed to about $500 billion in the last decade, according to estimates by the Dresdner Bank of West Germany. **********The probability of an actual shock powerful enough to wreck the world banking system stemming from an inability of the poor countries to meet their debts may be low, as the great majority of private and central bankers insist. The loans are rolled over again and again, and the International Monetary Fund, with growing help from Saudi Arabia, will help the oil-importing countries meet their debts. **********But, according to Professors Guttentag and Herring, the probability of a major shock is growing, along with the diminished capacity of banks to withstand such a shock. This, they say, raises serious questions about the adequacy of existing ''lender of last resort'' facilities - that is, the existence of a plan and sufficient resources among Western governments for rescuing the international banking system in the event of a major crisis, like the one that wrecked it in 1931, plunging the world into the worst depression in history.. **********Even with a low probability of a major shock, the potential damage to the world economy is so enormous that it seems irresponsible not to be prepared to deal with such a shock promptly and strongly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/30/world.main_headline: POLAND SAYS ARTICLES BY AMERICAN CONCOCTED TALES OF 'UNDERGROUND'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/30/world.print_headline: POLAND SAYS ARTICLES BY AMERICAN CONCOCTED TALES OF 'UNDERGROUND'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/30/world.body_text: **********The Polish Foreign Ministry and the Solidarity trade union have denounced as a fabrication articles by an American who visited Poland four months ago. **********The visitor, Harley Lippman, a former exchange program student in Poland, said he had a close relationship with Solidarity leaders that enabled him to meet secretly with Polish soldiers who said they would fight against a Soviet invasion. The articles also purported to describe his experiences traveling ''underground'' for 27 days, accompanied by Solidarity activists, to evade a police deportation order. **********Mr. Lippman wrote about a week's stay in the apartment of Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, whom Mr. Lippman claimed to have known while he studied in Poland from 1975 to 1977. 'Article Lacks Any Hard Facts' **********Janusz Onyszkiewicz, Solidarity's national spokesman, speaking on behalf of Mr. Walesa, said ''the article lacks any hard facts that can be verified.'' . **********''The only statement that can be verified is Mr. Lippman's claim that he spent a week living with Lech Walesa in his apartment,'' Mr.  Onyszkiewicz said.  ''I must say that this is totally untrue, as well as some other statements that may give a false impression that Mr.  Lippman is Mr. Walesa's friend. **********''I would like to strongly deny that Solidarity runs a network of secret safe houses to help people unpopular with the police. Our union is strong enough to protect, if necessary, our members, activists or guests using legal means, as we have shown in the past.'' **********Mr. Onyszkiewicz's repudiation came in a letter to The Times of London, made public here today. On May 11, the London paper printed an article by Mr. Lippman headlined: ''On the Run in Poland With My Friends in Solidarity.'' **********The Onyszkiewicz letter termed that article ''a great distortion of the real situation in Poland.'' Distributed From New York **********The Times of London received the article from the Special Features division of The New York Times Syndication Sales Corporation, which sometimes distributes work by freelance journalists. It erroneously bore a New York Times copyright. But Mr. Lippman is not employed by The New York Times nor did his article appear in The Times. In a note to editors, it was marked ''Not from The New York Times.'' **********Jesse Levine, executive vice president of the Syndication Sales Corporation, said the special features division withdrew Mr.  Lippman's work, a two-part series of 1,800 words each, from circulation several weeks ago after questions about its veracity had been raised by The Boston Globe. **********Mr. Lippman also wrote an article for The Chicago Sun-Times that appeared March 15.  The current issue of Life magazine contains a series of photographs taken during 1970 labor disturbances, along with a photograph of Mr.  Walesa and Mr. Lippman seated at a table. The text says Mr. Walesa gave the ''previously unpublished pictures'' to Mr. Lippman. **********The photographs have circulated widely throughout Poland since December and have been reproduced in numerous Polish publications and exhibits. 'Bad Faith for All Americans' **********Officials in the Press Department of the Foreign Ministry have been in touch with resident Western journalists to express concern over the articles. **********''They are clearly untrue,'' an official said today. ''Journalists like Mr. Lippman create bad faith for all American journalists. Many journalists who live here and know the situation write accurately.'' **********Mr. Lippman visited Poland from Jan. 22 until Feb. 19 on a tourist visa. He wrote that he was stopped at the airport upon entering the country and interrogated by an officer of ''the Ministry of Internal Security,'' an apparent reference to the Ministry of Internal Affairs, while Solidarity friends were ''waiting apprehensively'' in the terminal lobby. **********Three days later, he asserted, the police called for him at the apartment where he had been staying and he then went into ''hiding underground'' with Solidarity activists who smuggled him ''through a bewildering network of safe houses and secret rendezvous points.'' A Meeting With Paratroopers **********On one occasion, he wrote, he was blindfolded and taken to a barn outside Warsaw where he met a platoon of smiling Polish paratroopers who told him they would fight the Russians ''no matter what the odds.'' His description of the paratrooper uniform is inaccurate. On another occasion, he asserted, he had a clandestine meeting with a nationalist Polish general in a forest outside Lodz. **********Mr. Lippman wrote that he had numerous narrow escapes from the police. One time, he wrote, he avoided arrest on a train when his escort shouted out, ''Help us, we have an American friend!'' and ''the aisle suddenly filled up with people'' who blocked the police. **********Another time, he said, he eluded pursuers by slipping into a farmhouse where a young boy took his hand and took him to safety in the back of a horse-cart, driven by an old man whose last words were: ''Be safe. Remember us. Do not forget us.'' **********''Mr. Lippman described Solidarity as if it were an undergound organization in Poland during World War II,'' said Mr. Onyszkiewicz in his letter. ''This is not at all the reality of presentday Poland. During the time in which he was allegedly ''underground,'' Mr.  Lippman was seen in public by many Western journalists. **********He appeared at a seminar for Polish journalists in Warsaw and spoke there, presenting himself as a correspondent for The Washington Post. He also interviewed Marian Dobrosielski, a Deputy Foreign Minister, presenting a letter from Senator Edward M. Kennedy that asked for routine assistance to Mr. Lippman as a ''constituent.'' Mr. Lippman lives in Boston. **********During his stay in Poland, Mr. Lippman variously purported to be representing half a dozen American newspapers.  Solidarity members and American Embassy officials said that Mr.  Lippman also said he had an association with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., but the American labor organization has denied any present connection with him. **********Stephen M. Dubrow, press officer at the American Embassy, said that Mr. Lippman got in touch with the embassy after his arrival and was advised not to work as a journalist without a press visa because to do so would jeopardize other journalists. ''He wouldn't listen,'' Mr. Dubrow said. 'An Incredible Story' **********''Then he came back with an incredible story of having visited an arms cache in the woods,'' Mr. Dubrow added. ''We tried to point out to him how serious these stories were.'' Mr. Dubrow said that Mr.  Lippman was known to the embassy from his student days in 1976, when he claimed to have been taken by students into a forest to view arms allegedly for use against Soviet soldiers. **********Mr. Lippman used mostly first names in his articles, many of them misspelled, except for that of Mr. Walesa. Mr. Lippman had an interview with Mr. Walesa scheduled for Feb. 4, but it was canceled because of a crisis in southern Poland, according to the union. **********Mr. Lippman has shown editors in the United States photographs of himself with Mr. Walesa taken in different places. Solidarity's national spokesman said that such photographs were easy to come by, since Mr. Walesa customarily poses with scores of visitors who drop in on him at his office and home. A Haven in Walesa's Home **********Mr. Lippman suggested that he avoided arrest during the week he allegedly slept in the room of Mr. Walesa's son only because the police feared to serve a deportation notice on him there. **********Many aspects in his accounts do not ring true. The Solidarity union operates above board, and Polish Army officers do not easily grant interviews to Westerners. Parts of the articles are potentially damaging to Polish-Soviet relations, including Mr. Lippman's assertion that at a gathering of intellectuals he heard a discussion on the need to spread the workers' movement throughout Eastern Europe. **********Mr. Lippman also said that Solidarity smuggled tapes and photographs for him by ship to the Netherlands and from there to the United States. Solidarity denies this. The American Embassy said that Mr. Lippman had sought to send materials by the diplomatic pouch and that the request was rebuffed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/17/busin.main_headline: REAGAN MOVING ON U.S. EXPORT BARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/17/busin.print_headline: REAGAN MOVING ON U.S. EXPORT BARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/17/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration, having organized a team of officials to deal with international trade issues, is now moving to speed up a drive to eliminate Government hindrances to exports. **********At a White House meeting last Thursday of the Trade Policy Committee, which is headed by Bill Brock, the United States Trade Representative, decisions were made to press for relaxation of the following trade disincentives: **********- A kind of double taxation of Americans working abroad, who are hit by both the host country's tax collectors and the Internal Revenue Service. **********- Antitrust and banking laws that prevent American companies and financial institutions from banding together in foreign sales activities. **********- The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which puts American companies at a disadvantage with rigorous controls over commissions paid to foreign representatives and stiff penalties for violations. **********Baldrige to Take Lead **********The Commerce Secretary, Malcom Baldrige, will take the lead in the legislative campaign to open the door to the foreign sales groupings of American enterprises, the Trade Policy Committee decided. **********This division of authority worked out in the early strategy session illustrates the way efforts are being undertaken now to reduce the almost inevitable interagency frictions over oversight. **********When the same legislative proposals came up last year, the former trade representative, Reubin O. Askew, and the former Commerce Secretary, Philip M. Klutznick, both sought leading roles and failed to synchronize. **********''Mr. Brock is re-establishing the trade office as a central clearing house for trade issues,'' said Howard Weisberg, director of international trade poiicy at the United States Chamber of Commerce.  ''Rather than act as an advocate, he is the coordinator.'' **********Friction between the Commerce Department and the trade office arose from a reorganization last year, which gave the Commerce Department much greater clout in the trade field. **********The Commerce Department, which had already managed exort promotion and controls, got enforcement authority over imports from the Treasury Department and took responsibility for commercial attaches away from the State Department. A Matter of Chemistry **********Much of the way the trade team functions will depend on the chemistry between Mr. Brock and Mr. Baldrige. From reports so far, the chemistry is good. Both are from the same moderate wing of the Republican party. Mr. Brock, a former Senator from Tennessee, had been chairman of the Republican National Committee. Mr. Baldrige, a former business executive from Connecticut, had been a supporter of Vice President Bush. **********Significantly, Mr. Baldrige has appointed Mr. Brock's former executive assistant, William H. Morris Jr., to be the new Assistant Secretary of Commerce for trade development. **********''I think the team is shaping up very well,'' said Alan W. Wolff, a former Deputy United States Trade Representative now practicing law in Washington. ''Strauss (Robert S., the former trade representative and former chairman of the Democratic Party) proved how highly political the job was. **********''You have to understand domestic forces and work with the Congress. Brock qualifies on both counts.'' A key Congressional staffer who follows trade issues added: ''Brock has grasped the immediate issues. I think he'll be much clearer in the signals he gives to other countries. There will be more of an America-first approach. But I don't think there will be any change in basic liberal trade philosophy.'' Beefed-Up State Department **********While Mr. Brock is trying to cement a close relationship with the Commerce Department, he also faces a large repository of trade expertise at a beefed-up State Department. **********The Secretary of State, Alexander M. Haig Jr., in efforts to make the State Department more influential in the international economic area, brought in Myer Rashish, an economist with long experience in trade matters, and Robert D. Hormats, the former Deputy Trade Representative. Mr. Rashish is the new Under Secretary for economic affairs, and Mr. Hormats the new Assistant Secretary for economic affairs. **********Another key person will be Lionel H. Olmer, an international economic problem-solver for the Motorola Inc. who was brought over to the Commerce Department by Mr. Baldrige as Under Secretary for international trade. **********The hottest issue before the new trade team is what, if anything, to do about imports of small, fuel-efficient Japanese cars, which have been embraced by American consumers but which the domestic industry now wants to check. **********The Administration has taken no position yet on legislation proposed by Senators John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, and Lloyd M. Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, placing quotas for three years on the Japanese imports. **********But Mr. Brock said in a recent interview that he was opposed to any kind of legislatively mandated quotas. The Administration position is being prepared by a task force under the chairmanship of the Transportation Secretary, Drew Lewis, which should have a report ready by April.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/26/world.body_text: **********The Mayor of Peking, who has been criticized for lavish municipal spending, was dismissed by the city council today, the New China News Agency reported. **********The move against Mayor Lin Hujia followed press reports that economic leaders had criticized lavish municipal spending in the city. **********Mr. Lin, who has been Mayor since 1978, was also relieved of his post as the city's Communist Party chief.
