https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/25/busin.print_headline: Other Business; HUMAN EVENTS: THE WHITE HOUSE GETS 24 COPIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/25/busin.body_text: **********For most of its 37 years, the magazine Human Events was everything you'd expect of a small right-wing Washington tabloid. It lost money. It was vilified by liberals. It never made much of an impact. **********Today, however, the man in the White House reads Human Events.  Fifteen fresh-off-the-press copies are delivered there by messenger every Friday. A long list of Congressional sources talk to its writers regularly now because they know who is reading the magazine.  And it it even gets written about in other, far better-known publications. **********As yet, however, Human Events has found more success in its influence than in its revenues. According to Alan H. Ryskind, Capitol Hill Editor and co-owner, the magazine is merely breaking even - but that is much better than it has done. A few years ago, facing bankruptcy, it was bailed out by wealthy subscribers. It also cut back drastically its discount subscription offers, reducing its circulation from 150,000 to 60,000. And the magazine's new blueribbon audience has done little to attract Madison Avenue sales.  ''We have had more interest from advertisers lately,'' said Thomas S. Winter, editor and co-owner, ''but most agencies just will not pay attention because the numbers aren't there.'' **********Human Events is still a target of liberal attack. ''They're just numb,'' says Jeffrey Stein, Washington editor for the Progressive, of Mr. Ryskind and Mr. Winter. ''They're the old right: anti-gun registration, pro-gold standard. They see a conspiracy in every corner and think the major newspapers are all dupes for the Communists.'' **********But it pulls no punches. Whether questioning the affiliation of America's college political science teachers (''Do you know who's teaching your kids?'') or haranguing Congress on behalf of the Reagan budget, Human Events is never subtle. **********''Frankly, we have been somewhat surprised that so many Republican lawmakers have begun to crawfish on Reaganomics,'' reads one recent issue, ''As soon as things weren't working perfectly, they began to run from the field of battle. Dagwood Bumstead has displayed truer grit.'' **********At the White House, press aides could not confirm that Human Events is Reagan's favorite magazine. According to one, Human Events and the National Review are either No. 1 and 2, or 2 and 1. ''I've seen Human Events at the top of the list,'' the aide said, ''but I personally don't think you can rank them.'' Last year, Mr. Reagan was more explicit. ''Not a week goes by during the campaign,'' he said, ''that I don't take time to read Human Events from cover to cover.'' **********What has that kind of exposure done for Mr. Ryskind and Mr. Winter?  ''Well, for one thing, we're certainly accorded more respect than we used to be,'' Mr. Ryskind said. ''I, personally, am given more respect at press conferences and things - I've certainly felt that.'' **********On the other hand, both men say they feel that fewer people may be listening. ''When you're out of power, when you're on the outside criticizing, people tend to think they need your information because they're not getting it,'' Mr. Winter said. ''But when you have a Ronald Reagan in the White House, they might not need you as much.  They say, 'well, now we know what's going on.' '' **********But he quickly added: ''Don't get me wrong. God knows we're glad he's in.'' Kirk Johnson

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/24/busin.main_headline: MOBIL MERGER OPPOSED BY OFF-BRAND DEALERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/24/busin.print_headline: MOBIL MERGER OPPOSED BY OFF-BRAND DEALERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/24/busin.body_text: **********Companies that sell so-called off-brand gasoline at prices 2 to 8 cents a gallon lower than the major oil companies would be hurt by the Mobil Corporation's proposed takeover of the Marathon Oil Company, opponents of the merger told Congress today. **********Marathon supplies gasoline to the independent service stations that sell the cheaper off-brands. Mobil, by contrast, generally declines to deal with independents. **********''The nonbranded independent station is at the cutting edge of price competition,'' Jack A. Blum of the Independent Gasoline Marketers Council said at a joint hearing of the Senate and House Commerce Committees. ''Because low prices attract customers and build volume, nonbranded independents constantly test the pricevolume relationship by selling at the lowest price at which they can operate profitably.'' Downward Price Pressure **********The competition of these stations also forces down the prices charged by the brand-name stations, he said.  Mr. Blum predicted that, if Mobil succeeded in the takeover, ''there will be a wave of other mergers in the industry.'' The Federal Trade Commission is investigating antitrust aspects of Mobil's tender offer to acquire Marathon for $5.1 billion. Marathon management strongly opposes the move but has welcomed a bid by the United States Steel Corporation to acquire the company for $6.3 billion. **********The head of the F.T.C.'s bureau of competition did not testify because of President Reagan's veto of an emergency budget appropriations bill to provide money for the F.T.C. and other Government agencies to continue operations. In addition, Mobil officials declined to appear, a move criticized by Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, chairman of the Senate committee and a foe of the takeover. Offer Called Inadequate **********Thomas H. Barre, vice president of Marathon, said his company opposed the merger because Mobil's offer was inadequate and because of antitrust concerns. ''Mobil's hostile offer drove us up the wall,'' he said of the Marathon board meeting that considered it. **********Ohio's Attorney General, William J. Brown, who has opposed the merger in an antitrust suit brought by Marathon, said the takeover would drive up prices in areas of the Middle West where Marathon, which is based in Findlay, Ohio, was active. **********''Off-brand gasoline serves as an important check against the major oil companies,'' Mr. Brown said.  Representative John Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the House committee, said that, if Mobil was prevented from acquiring Marathon, ''it will simply look for another company to prey upon.'' he added, ''The result, no matter what, will be one less independent competitor.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/30/busin.body_text: **********Poland has resumed limited payments of its commercial bank debt for the first time since the declaration of martial law on Dec. 13, West German and American bankers reported today. **********The bankers suggested that Poland sought to signal through the payments its willingness to comply with an agreement to pay $500 million in overdue interest to avoid being declared in default. **********But some German bankers cautioned against drawing the conclusion that the Poles would be able to complete payment of the $500 million in the next six weeks. They had originally promised to pay off the $500 million by Thursday. **********Extension Called Possible **********The bankers said that, if the partial payments continued, they probably would be willing to extend the year-end deadline into early next year. **********The Dec. 31 deadline for payment of the $500 million has been a crucial issue. Failure to meet it has carried the possibility that one of the 460 Western banks holding Polish debt might insist on declaring Warsaw in default. The entire bank consortium would be required to consider Poland in default if one of its members insisted on such a move. **********The bankers interviewed today -West Germans in Frankfurt as well as Americans in both Frankfurt and Vienna - requested anonymity because they are involved in the negotiations over rescheduling payments of Poland's $16 billion debt to the Western banks. In telephone interviews, they described the amounts transferred to Western banks as ''small,'' although they would not divulge the actual figures. 'Trickles All Along' **********''It would be wrong to overdramatize the fact,'' one German banker said. ''There have been trickles all along.'' He added that the first transfer by the Polish state bank, Handlowy, since the military takeover on Dec. 13 came in the middle of last week, and there had been several transfers since then. In addition, several payments were made to the banks earlier this month, before the military takeover. **********The most recent payments were made by transferring small amounts of funds held on deposit in Frankfurt and in New York banks to agent banks for the syndicated loans, the bankers said. **********The 460 Western creditor banks had reached an agreement on Dec. 4 to postpone for several years the payment of $2.4 billion in debt principal that was scheduled to have been paid this year. But the postponement carried the condition that the Poles pay the $500 million in interest by year's end. The interest had originally been due in the first three quarters of 1981. **********The rescheduling agreement, after weeks of negotiations, was the first involving the $16 billion bank debt. Because of Poland's deteriorating economy, both the Western banks and Polish officials had agreed that Warsaw would need a grace period of several years before resuming payment of the principal. Bid for New Loan Was Denied **********Last week, a committee of eight creditor banks, representing the total group, met in Zurich and agreed to deny a request from the new military government for a $350 million loan to help pay the $500 million in back interest. Banking sources said that the loan was denied partly on the theory that the Soviet Union would come to Poland's assistance rather than let an Eastern-bloc country go into default. **********Today's report that some payments had been made was the first public indication that Poland was trying to comply with the Dec. 4 rescheduling agreement, if not by the year's end then by early next year. **********The bankers interviewed today said a meeting would be held in London on Jan. 8 to complete the final wording of the agreement to reschedule the $2.4 billion in principal.In setting the meeting, the bank consortium indicated that it would go along with final payment of the $500 million in interest early next year. **********The bankers said that they did not know where the Poles could obtain funds to meet their debt payments, given the sharp decline in export income resulting from the nation's prolonged crisis. But they noted that the price of gold had fallen on European markets in recent days. Some gold dealers have attributed the drop to heavy sales of gold by the Soviet Union, possibly to obtain hard currency with which to help Poland make the interest payments. Germans Hold Biggest Part **********Poland owes an estimated $10 billion to Western governments in addition to the $16 billion bank debt. Payment of some of the government debt was rescheduled earlier this year. Among the creditor banks, the West Germans hold the biggest portion of the debt, a total of about $4.5 billion, with $2.7 billion not covered by Government guarantees. American banks hold $1.3 billion of the Polish debt. **********(Leland S. Prussia, the chairman of the Bank of America Corporation, said in San Francisco in a telephone interview that he had not yet heard any reports of resumed interest payments from Poland. Several other bankers in the United States, all of whom refused to comment for the record, also said that they had not received any direct confirmation from Poland that interest payments had been resumed.) **********The news of the bank transfers came as it was announced in Bonn that Poland's Deputy Prime Minister in the last civilian Government, Mieczeslaw Rakowski, would come to West Germany on Wednesday to discuss with Bonn's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the Polish events. The talks are expected also to cover economic questions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/03/busin.main_headline: Six-Month Bill Rises to 14.13%; Three-Month Rate at 14.46%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/03/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Six-Month Bill Rises to 14.13%; Three-Month Rate at 14.46%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/03/busin.body_text: **********Short-term and long-term interest rates rose yesterday as traders adjusted to higher overnight interest rates and light investor demand for issues due in more than two years. **********In the short-term market, the Treasury sold new three-month and six-month Treasury bills at average rates of 14.46 percent and 14.13 percent respectively, up from 14.1 percent and 13.61 percent at last week's auction. **********After adding a quarter of a percentage point to the six-month bill average, banks and savings institutions may offer a top rate of 14.38 percent on new six-month savings certificates starting Thursday, up from 13.86 percent currently. Exceeds 13 Percent **********While Treasury bill rates are still well below their highest level of the year, the yield for long-term Treasury bonds exceeds 13 percent - a level reached only briefly last December and again in mid-February. The Treasury's 12 3/4 percent bonds due 2010 closed at about 96 3/4 to yield 13.18 percent. **********''The traders did not like the increase in the Federal funds rate, and investors are just not buying,'' explained one Treasury securities dealer. **********Prices also moved lower for other recently issued Treasury securities, with the new 13 7/8 percent notes due in two years offered at 99 1/4 to yield 14.32 percent while the 13 3/4 percent notes due in 1986 closed at 99 1/4 to yield 13.99 percent. **********In the Federal funds market, where banks and others arrange overnight loans, the rate climbed above 16 percent late in the day - a sharp contrast from the 14.96 percent average in the week ended Feb. 25. Sign of Expansion **********Besides the higher rate for Federal funds, dealers said news of a 5.4 percent rise in construction spending for January also encouraged lower prices during the day. They reasoned that the construction spending was a sign that the economy was continuing to expand, signaling greater credit demands and higher interest rates in the future. **********Some analysts also cited the recent growth in the nation's money supply as a reason for the weaker prices yesterday. Although money supply growth for the latest quarter is still a slow 1.1 percent, economists at Merrill Lynch said in yesterday's money market newsletter that the $2 billion increase in the basic money supply for the week ended Feb. 18 helped ''dash any hopes that the Fed would allow the funds rate to ease any further over the near term.'' Without further declines in the funds rate, traders say that yields are unlikely to drop for other securities. **********In general, most analysts say that the Fed's internal target for the credit it wants to supply to the banking system should result in a funds rate of 15 to 16 percent. **********The Chrysler Corporation's latest issue of Government-guaranteed notes increased in price yesterday even though other note and bond prices have declined since the issue was offered last week.  Originally priced at 98 to yield 15.31 percent to maturity in 1991, the issue was offered late yesterday at 98 5/8. Underwriters said that demand from yield-conscious individual investors grew after the issue was brought to market. New Jersey Issue Due **********The tax-exempt market was beset with the same lack of buying interest as the government securities market, dealers said. In advance of today's $150 million of Aaa-rated New Jersey general obligation bonds, traders said that prices of other high-grade state issues were reduced enough to raise yields about 10 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Trading in the Aaa-rated Illinois bonds sold last week was not heavy yesterday, but one trader estimated that current prices for the bonds would result in yields about 10 basis points higher than the original scale. Last week the Illinois bonds were offered to yield from 7 percent in 1982 to 8.45 percent in 1991, 9.7 percent in 2001 and 9.85 percent in 2004-06. **********Among negotitated tax-exempt issues planned for sale this week, underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation said that a $150 million sale of A-rated Kentucky Turnpike Authority bonds was postponed because of market conditions. Sebring Bonds Priced **********Negotiated issues still planned this week include $91 million of A/BBB-rated Sebring, Fla., utility revenue bonds that a Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb group has tentatively priced to yield from 7.75 percent in 1981 to 11 percent for term bonds due 2001 and 11 3/8 percent for discount priced term bonds due 2011. An issue of 10 3/4 percent term bonds due 2010 priced at par has a lower yield than the other term bonds, underwriters explained, because it is insured by the American Bond Assurance Corporation and is thus AAA-rated. **********Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb also plans to sell a $36.4 million issue of A-rated pollution-control revenue bonds guaranteed by the National Rural Utilities Cooperative Finance Corporation. The 9 percent bonds due 1984 are tentatively priced at par. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/03/busin.body_text: **********The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether American subsidiaries of foreign corporations are required to abide by the Federal law that forbids discrimination in employment, despite trade treaties that appear to give the companies discretion in hiring. **********The case involves a New York company, Sumitomo Shoji America, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of a Japanese import-export company. The New York company hired only male Japanese nationals for management positions, and was sued by a group of women secretarial employees on the ground that the policy violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. **********The company argued that it was exempt from Title VII on the basis of the Treaty of Friendship, Commerce and Navigation between the United States and Japan. This 1953 treaty, similar to other trade treaties, allows companies of one country doing business in the other country to hire ''technical experts, executive personnel and other specialists of their choice.'' **********Referred to Appeals Court **********The Federal District Court in New York referred the legal question, without ruling on it, to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The appeals court ruled that Title VII covered the company's employment practices regardless of the trade treaty, but that, at a trial, the company could try to prove that it had a special need to hire Japanese nationals. **********In agreeing to hear the company's appeal, Sumitomo Shoji v. Avigliano, No. 80-2070, the Court asked the Justice Department today to file a brief ''expressing the views of the United States.'' **********The Justices also agreed to hear the women's appeal from the aspect of the Second Circuit's ruling that gave the company the opportunity to defend its Japanese-only policy. **********Other business-related action at the Court today included the following: Antitrust Suit **********The Court agreed to decide whether a subscriber to a prepaid health care plan could bring an antitrust suit to challenge the plan's refusal to cover specific types of health care. **********The case, Blue Shield of Virginia v. Mccready, No. 81-225, is an appeal by both a state Blue Shield plan and a statewide organization of psychiatrists. The two were accused of conspiring against clinical psychologists by refusing to provide coverage for their services. **********The United States District Court dismissed the suit on the ground that the plaintiff, an individual subscriber who sought reimbursement for care by a psychologist, lacked standing to bring the suit. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit ruled that the Clayton Act, which provides triple damages for plaintiffs injured by antitrust violations, entitled the subscriber to bring the case. **********The appeal argues that the Fourth Circuit opened the door too widely to consumer antitrust suits by not following the precedents of other appeals courts that restrict Clayton Act suits to plaintiffs who are themselves the victims of the alleged antitrust conspiracy.  In this case, the alleged boycott was aimed not at subscribers but at the psychologists. Diesel Emissions **********The Justices refused to hear a challenge by the General Motors Corporation to the Environmental Protection Agency's limit on exhaust emissions from diesel-powered cars and light trucks. The company argued that the regulations, which were upheld by the United States Court of Appeals here and are scheduled to take effect with the 1985 model year, are so infeasible that production ''will cease'' in 1985 if the standards are not modified. **********The Justice Department urged the Court not to hear the General Motors appeal, G.M. v. Gorsuch, No. 81-201, both because the appeals court decision upholding the standards was ''a proper application of relevant law'' and because the environmental agency has recently begun a review of the standards. ''Petitioner may well obtain administratively all the relief it requests from this Court,'' the department said. Oil Cleanup **********The Court refused to hear an appeal by the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, operator of the Trans-Alaskan Pipeline, from a ruling that it was not entitled to Federal reimbursement for the costs of cleaning up a 1978 oil spill that was due to sabotage. The company spent $1.2 million cleaning up the 14,000-barrel spill after an unknown vandal blew a hole in the pipeline. **********A Federal law provides reimbursement for oil spills that are the fault of ''third parties'' rather than the fault of the pipeline operator. But another Federal law, the Trans-Alaska Pipeline Authorization Act, explicitly eliminates the reimbursement provision for the Alaska pipeline. On that basis, the United States Court of Claims dismissed the pipeline's suit for reimbursement. **********The Justice Department urged the Court to deny the appeal, Alyeska Pipeline v. U.S., No. 81-231. The department argued that, in enacting the no-reimbursement provision, ''Congress recognized the extraordinary environmental risks associated with the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System venture and concluded that those who undertook that venture in search of profit, not the taxpayers, should also bear the burden of those risks.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/04/busin.body_text: **********After eight years of planning and an investment of $200 million, the much-publicized DeLorean sports car is finally in production. But the car's price tag will be much higher than was at first planned and, according to industry analysts, the design has been substantially modified. **********The sleek, stainless-steel autos, now rolling off an assembly line here at the gentle rate of 18 a day, are to go on sale in the United States, for about $25,000 each, some time next month. **********''Every phase of successful enterprise has now been completed,'' says John Z. DeLorean, the former General Motors Corporation executive who conceived the car and persuaded the British Government to finance it. ''What remains now is the all-important test in the marketplace.'' **********Concern About Market **********Mr. DeLorean concedes that the marketplace for his car - almost exclusively the United States, at least at the beginning - is not in ideal economic shape at the moment for the introduction of a very expensive two-seat auto, one that has almost doubled in price since it was first conceived. **********But he maintains that the kind of buyers he is appealing to are not feeling too much of a pinch.  ''The market for these cars is far more quality-sensitive than it is price-sensitive,'' says Mr. DeLorean, a tall, elegantly groomed entrepreneur who exudes the breezy self-confidence with which he talked the Government into a financing deal that his critics find far too generous. Initial Sales Goal **********Mr. DeLorean readily concedes that a car that costs $25,000 has to be ''perfect,'' but he thinks this one is. He hopes to sell 11,000 of them this year, 20,000 next year and perhaps 30,000 a year thereafter. He also talks hopefully of introducing a DeLorean sedan, with four or five seats, later in the 1980's. Such a project, the company said, may be financed by a general public stock offering in the United States. **********The last new sports car to reach the market amid great publicity was the $10,000 Bricklin, developed by Malcolm Bricklin, a millionaire promotor from Philadelphia. The car was assembled in Canada but production was halted soon after it began in 1975 because of manufacturing and financial problems. Only about 3,000 were built. **********But the DeLorean Motor Company says it has lined up more than 300 American dealers, each of whom has a $25,000 equity interest in the company, and they are said to have 7,000 to 10,000 firm orders for the car. **********Mr. DeLorean, who said his relations with General Motors had become increasingly strained since he left the company, says he sees signs that G.M. may be putting pressure on its dealers not to handle the new car. **********Mr. DeLorean left General Motors in 1972, when he was vice president and group executive in charge of all car and truck divisions in North America. He said he left because the company had been unenthusiastic about his determination to build smaller and sportier cars. G.M. seemed to feel that the executive's exuberance contrasted too much to the company's conservative management style. Conflicts With G.M. **********General Motors, in fact, has told Cadillac dealers who handle small-car imports and who plan to sell the DeLorean that they will not receive initial shipments of the Cimarron, a small ''J'' car scheduled to be introduced in early May. **********The DeLorean car has undergone rather extensive modification at the hands of Lotus Cars Ltd., which did much of the preproduction engineering, added a frame, changed the body molding processes and altered the car's character. **********Mr. DeLorean's auto is low (45 inches) and fast (maximum speed, 125 miles an hour) and is available only in silver, the color of its unpainted stainless steel body. But its most distinctive feature is its gull-wing doors, which are hinged at the top, rather than on the side. Critics say that the doors are just an attention-getting gimmick. But they do make it easier to settle down in the car than it would have been if it had had conventional doors. Steel, Glass and Plastic **********The stainless-steel panels, which the company says are completely corrosion-proof, are fastened to a glass-reinforced plastic underbody, molded here into two halves and set onto a conventional metal chassis. Much of the work is done by hand, in a cavernous new factory that DeLorean built over the past two years. **********The reason for building the plant in Belfast was that the British Government was willing to offer such generous terms here. And the reason for that, of course, is that this province, scarred by more than a decade of constant sectarian violence, is by many economic standards the most depressed corner of Britain. **********But since DeLorean will depend almost entirely on sales in the United States, at least at the beginning, the project has suffered from the sharp appreciation of the British pound, which has helped to drive up the retail price of the car. Company officials say that about 54 percent of its supplier costs are in pounds, 31 percent in French francs, 7 percent in German marks and 6 percent in dollars. Critics of Government Aid **********The plant, on a 70-acre site that was a bog three years ago, employs 1,200 people and expects to employ 2,000 by the end of the year. **********Since the Government has paid out more than $160 million in grants, loans and equity for the company, critics in Parliament have complained that this is very expensive job creation. **********But Mr. DeLorean, who likes to remind critics that he put $4 million of his own money into the company too, says that not many investors would even consider coming to Belfast. **********''Northern Ireland is the most serious single problem that Britain has,'' he said in an interview. ''We are in the most hostile area of it. The M.P.'s who are screaming about giving us a few more bucks would be afraid even to come visit the plant.'' Tories Less Enthusiastic **********The company has also suffered from a change of government. The deal it negotiated in 1978 was with the Labor Party of Prime Minister James Callaghan. But soon afterward Margaret Thatcher and the Conservatives came to power, with a promise of rigid controls on public spending. Although the contracts are being honored, the mood of some of the company's dealings with the Government has changed, officials report. **********Even so, at the age of 56, Mr. DeLorean has finally achieved the dream he had been talking about for years: the neat rows of silvery sports cars bearing his name parked in the factory yard here on their way to the Belfast port. **********But his critics are as vociferous as ever.  ''They used to say that we'd go broke before ever making a car,'' he said good-naturedly. ''Now that we have actually begun making cars, they are saying that we'll go broke in a year or two. I guess as long as they keep on predicting my demise two years in the future, rather than tomorrow, I'll be O.K.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia will not raise oil prices or reduce production until other OPEC members lower their prices significantly, its oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said. His statement is seen as the opening round in what could be a tough struggle within OPEC when its members meet May 25 to discuss oil prices. (Page A1.) **********Japan is prepared to limit auto exports to this nation to 1.7 million units a year. American proposals for a ceiling of 1.6 million over a three-year period are considered too low by Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry. (D1.) **********Nissan plans to introduce highly acclaimed Japanese production techniques at its new Smyrna, Tenn., plant, which will produce about 180,000 light trucks a year. (A1.) **********Noranda's move to acquire MacMillan Bloedel, Canada's biggest paper manufacturer, highlights the vertical and horizontal diversification of the mining company. (D5.) The Economy **********First-quarter earnings are surprisingly strong on balance in the face of a generally dull economy. Economic forecasters project a 4 to 6 percent gain in profits for the period, despite poor auto, oil, semiconducter and nonferrous-metals results. (D1.) **********A trading link between national stock exchanges and the O.T.C. is expected to be ordered by the Securities and Exchange Commission despite industry and political opposition. (D7.) Companies **********National Singing Telegrams sang $800,000 worth of customer tunes last year in a highly competitive market. The San Francisco-based company charges $17.50 for a phone rendition and $35 for a personal performance. (D1.) **********Household Finance's rush to diversify has slowed its earnings growth. Analysts now question whether its moves to hedge against a potential collapse of consumer financing were justified. (D1.) Today's Columns **********Tax breaks for auto, steel and other depressed industries are alive in Washington, although the Treasury opposes them and other detractors view them as rewarding losers. Washington Watch. (D2.) **********Drought still imperils the winter wheat crop now entering its final development stages. Despite recent rains over the main farm belt, concern is also voiced over spring crops. Commodities. (D8.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.main_headline: S.& P. Lowers B raniff Rating
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.print_headline: S.& P. Lowers B raniff Rating
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.body_text: **********The Standard & Poor's Corporation, a major debt-rating service, said it had lowered the ratings on Braniff Airways' long-term de bt obligations because of the airline's recent p oor financial performance. **********''Given the severity of the cash drain and the consequent reduction in financial flexibility to minimal levels, Braniff's debt obligations must be regarded as highly speculative,'' S.& P. said. **********Braniff's 11 1/8 percent bonds due 1987, its 10 percent notes due 1986 and its 9 1/8 percent bonds due 1997 all were lowered to a CCC rating from B. Both the CCC and B ratings are in a range that S.& P.  considers ''speculative,'' with CCC being slightly more speculative than B . **********S.& P. also lowered to CC from CCC Braniff's subordinated debentures, or promissory notes, due 1986. The CC rating is the lowest in S.& P.'s speculative range. **********Moody's Investors Service Inc., the other major debt-rating organization, rates Braniff's obligations at the equivalent of Standard & Poor's previous ratings. **********The S.& P. rating changes reflect Braniff's continuing losses, which by June 30 had resulted in a $52 million retained-earnings deficit, S.& P. said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/11/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki visited Japan's northern island of Hokkaido today in what seemed to be an effort to dramatize a long-running dispute over islands seized by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II in 1945. **********Moscow has dug in its heels on this issue and has refused to consider returning the islands. They are Iturup and Kunashir in the southern part of the main Kuril chain, as well as a parallel, subsidiary chain, the Lesser Kuriles, from Shikotan through the Habomai Islands to a seaweed-strewn rock called Kaigara, only 2.2 miles from Hokkaido. **********But the Japanese are not giving up. Today Mr. Suzuki became the first postwar Japanese leader to view the area, flying by helicopter to Cape Nosappu to peer through a telescope at the Soviet-held territories where naval vessels rode in the water barely a mile away. **********''The Russians do not gain by this, but they do not lose either,'' said a Foreign Ministry spokesman. ''It is a question of endurance.''  Sonoda to Confer With Gromyko **********Although Foreign Minister Sunao Sonoda hopes to meet his Soviet counterpart, Andrei A. Gromyko, at the United Nations in New York next week, the dispute is not likely to be resolved soon. **********In 1855, a treaty between Japan and Czarist Russia assigned the northern Kuriles to Russia and recognized that the southern, now disputed, islands had always been Japanese. Under a second treaty, in 1875, the Russians gave up the northern Kuriles in exchange for the southern half of Sakhalin, whose northern part was already in Russian hands. The Russians were forced to return southern Sakhalin after their defeat in the Russo-Japanese War of 1905. **********This was the situation until Japan's defeat at the end of World War II, when Soviet forces seized both southern Sak@halin and all of the Kuriles. **********The issue was revived in 1956 when the two countries re-established diplomatic relations and the Russians seemed to indicate flexibility, at least with regard to the Lesser Kuriles. In a communique, they promised to hand back Shikotan and the Habomais, ''whose actual accession to Japan will be subject to the conclusion of a peace treaty between Japan and the Soviet Union.'' Dispute Lon g in Abeyanc e **********For years the dispute was in abeyance. Japan was not strong enough to fight for return of the islands by diplomatic and economic arguments alone. Once the United States returned Okinawa in 1972, Japan's only territorial dispute was with the Soviet Union. **********Talks began in earnest in 1973 between Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader. The outcome was that Moscow conceded the existence of ''yet unresolved problems,'' a formula for the island dispute. **********Attempts to negotiate a peace treaty, with the Japanese demanding the return of the islands as a precondition, failed.  In 1976, the Russians refused to allow visits by Japanese to the graves of relatives on the Kuriles unless they came with Japanese passports. But the Japanese Government declined to issue passports for such trips on the ground that this would be admitting that the islands were no longer Japanese territory. Soviet Announces 200-Mile Zone **********Later the Soviet Union announced a 200-mile economic fishing zone off shore. The move was disputed by Japan, a major fishing nation.  Eventually Mr. Suzuki, then Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries, went to Moscow in 1977 for 30 days of talks that ended in a compromise. It allowed Japanese ships to fish inside the 200-mile zone, provided that they stayed out of the Soviet Union's 12-mile territorial waters. **********Other grievances abound. The police at Nemuro, a Japanese port near Cape Nosappu, say that the Russians, in return for promising access to rich fishing grounds, seek to induce Japanese fishermen to spy on the movements of armed forces on Hokkaido, which is home to four of Japan's 13 infantry divisions. **********More recently the Soviet Union increased the size of its forces in the Kurils to close to a full division or 10,000 men, according to Japanese officials. Militarization of Islands Noted **********These were first confined to Iturup, known in Japanese as Etorofu, a long, scenic island dotted with dead volcanoes and picturesque, mostly deserted coves, with some forces on Kunashir. A new airstrip on Iturup is said to be adequate for the latest jet fighters and transports. Even tanks, which would not be of much use on the islands, were reported there. **********By late 1979, army reinforcements were also reported on the Habomai Island. The militarization of the islands was thought to be a reaction to the peace treaty Japan signed with China in 1978 while rejecting a simultaneous treaty with the Soviet Union. **********A map appearing in newspapers today showed the course of Mr.  Suzuki's helicopter as it approached Cape Nosappu. The chopper kept close to the shore, hugging the land most of the way, well back from the line between Hokkaido and the Soviet-held islands. **********''A couple of years ago I was up there taking pictures,'' a Japanese reporter said. ''We went as close as we dared and then we got a message from the ground that Soviet fighters had scrambled. We beat it back at once.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/busin.body_text: **********The Fokker Aircraft Company has been feeling the pressure lately. Its civil aircraft production has not been large enough to increase profits, and its military output - Fokker makes F-16 fighters under license - is scheduled to taper off in the mid-1980's. **********To complicate matters, a 12-year-old merger with Vereinigte Flugtechnische Werke, a small West German aircraft company, broke up earlier this year because of conflicting German and Dutch aviation policies. **********But Fokker, trying to put its house in order, has embarked on a strategy that some industry analysts consider risky. In an effort to increase output and compensate for the maturing F-16 program, the company has joined forces with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to build a 150-seat aircraft. **********''We think we can make it go,'' Francois Swarttouw, Fokker's 48-year-old chairman, said. Before joining Fokker in 1978, he helped transform the Rotterdam harbor into Europe's busiest port. Airline Stagnation Noted **********Other people are not so sure about Fokker's outlook. A securities analyst at a major Amsterdam bank cited the airline industry's general stagnation. Many major carriers are suffering from high interest rates, soaring fuel costs and a recent slump in the passenger-mile growth rate. Fokker and McDonnell Douglas, the analyst added, are sure to face tough competition from American aircraft makers, such as the Boeing Company, and European manufacturers, such as the Airbus consortium, which has had surprising success with its wide-body A-300 and smaller A-310 planes. **********The aircraft Fokker plans to make, the MDF 100, is a modified version of a model called the F-29 that Fokker spent nearly $79 million developing. Essentially the MDF 100 is intended to replace the present generation of Boeing 727's and McDonnell Douglas DC-9's.  Major airlines in the United States, including United and Delta, plan to purchase hundreds of such planes, worth billions of dollars, beginning in the late 1980's. **********An advanced airframe and a new wing designed by the Dutch national aerospace laboratory are expected to reduce fuel consumption and noise levels. Rolls-Royce (1971) Ltd., the Pratt & Whitney group of the United Technologies Corporation and CFM-International (a joint venture of America's General Electric Company and France's Snecma) are submitting designs for engines. Fokker says the aircraft will be ready by 1986 and will cost $20 million to $25 million. Heavy Development Costs **********Amsterdam bankers note that the new plane's design details are less of a problem than its financing. Development costs are estimated at $2 billion. The Dutch Government, troubled by the recession and soaring unemployment, is eager to see the 2,000 to 4,000 jobs that production of the MDF 100 is expected to generate in the Netherlands. So the Government has assured Fokker of $711 million in development credits and guaranteed commercial bank loans if Fokker can find partners, demonstrate the project's feasibility and get enough orders. **********Even with aid from the Government, the MDF 100 project is beyond Fokker's financial range, the company's executives acknowledge. That is why it has linked up with McDonnell Douglas in a joint venture to build the plane in the Netherlands and at Long Beach, Calif. After 275 persons died in the 1979 crash of a DC-10 at Chicago, McDonnell Douglas's airliner sales slumped, and the company is hoping for a rebound. **********Mr. Swarttouw said Fokker needed at least 50 pre-production orders, some from major airlines. He estimated the market over the next 25 to 30 years at about 3,000 units and said Fokker hoped to get one-third of that market. Japanese Aid Also Sought **********Fokker is also talking with a Japanese industrial group representing Mitsubishi, Kawasaki and Fuji to see if it is interested in a 20 percent stake in the project. If so, Fokker executives envision 40 percent for Fokker and 40 percent for McDonnell Douglas.  Any participation by the Japanese, Mr. Swarttouw said, depends partly on Japan's willingness to purchase the aircraft after it is built. **********''KLM and Martinair, a charter airline owned by Dutch shipping interests, are interested,'' a banker in Amsterdam said, ''but there is no indication how large the interest is. Fokker needs the market in the States, and if Japan said yes they would likely have a market in Japan.'' **********Fokker's best-selling aircraft is the F-27 Friendship, a twinengine turboprop that carries as many as 60 passengers or seven tons of cargo and costs $6 million to $7 million. Fokker has sold more than 750 of these planes since it began making them in 1958. **********The F-28 Fellowship, a jet version of the F-27 that seats up to 85 and costs $9 million to $10 million, has had less success, perhaps because of greater competition in its class. The F-28 was designed 13 years ago, and 185 units have been sold. Most Sales in Civil Sector **********Military aircraft account for roughly 25 percent of Fokker's sales, and civil aircraft account for 70 percent. The rest comes from space activities, such as satellite construction. **********Fokker's net income nearly doubled last year, to $3.9 million, from 1979's $1.9 million. Revenues rose to $446.2 million from $381.4 million. **********The company sold only 19 planes in the first half of this year, but the six-month earnings were $2.3 million, up from $1.9 million a year before. **********Mr. Swarttouw remains sanguine. ''Our sales target is 50 aircraft for the year and improved earnings,'' he said. ''If you look at the shape of the aircraft industry, that's ambitious.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/06/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Moore of Lang, Fisher & Stashower; For TV Ads, A New Era
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/06/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Moore of Lang, Fisher & Stashower; For TV Ads, A New Era
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/06/busin.body_text: **********As vice president and account supervisor at Lang, Fisher & Stashower, a Cleveland advertising agency, Thomas A. Moore handles advertising for a wide variety of products, ranging from soap to hardware to baby bottles, among the 49-year-old agency's $22 million a year in billings. **********In addition, Mr. Moore, a graduate of Northwestern University and its Medill School of Journalism, has written articles in the business press about the image of advertising men and women in society as a whole and was co-author of an article in the Harvard Business Review about the new video technology. In a recent interview, he discussed what today's rapid technological change might mean for television advertising. **********Q. What does the future hold for the television commercial? **********A. The notion of a consumer sitting back and watching the same laundry detergent commercial for the 10th time will become an anachronism.  The basic notion of television advertising, as it is practiced at present, is that you can position an advertisement adjacent to programming and therefore get exposure to the message. Tha t will be changed, I fe el, because it will become a lot easier to avoid commercials.  That doesn't mean that marketers will find it impossibleto get their messages in front of consumers. But it does mean that the methods w ill have to change dramatically. The challenge to advertisers will be to get the messages in front of the appropriate consumers and to make the messages such that the consumers will be less inclined to change the channel. **********Q. How will advertisers go about this? **********A. It's possible that, within the next 20 years, if a consumer is interested in learning about the latest stereo equipment, he will order a video cassette which has advertisements from the top five stereo marketers, each maybe five minutes in length, about their equipment. **********Q. What about toothpastes? Will consumers bother to make that kind of comparison study about them? **********A. What we call low-involvement products -such as toothpaste, soap and household cleaners, which are less likely to be of great interest to consumers - will face a tougher environment in terms of building awareness and brand preference. **********A. What could a manufacturer of a low-involvement product do under those circumstances? A. Your best advertising would become in-store placement - in other words, being on the shelf. And the things a manufacturer does, other than consumer advertising, to get the product on the shelf, will become far more important. **********Q. What can advertisers do with their commercials to try to keep viewers from tuning them out? **********A. More messages and different kinds of messages will probably be in order. The technique of repeating a commercial over and over again, which has been very successful in the past, will be less so, since the consumers are more likely to change channels the moment they recognize a familiar commercial. And I think commercials are going to have to be both more entertaining and more informative. **********Q. Given the prospects for change, what else will advertisers and advertising agencies need to do? **********A. I think that as video technologies change, we are going to have to pay very close attentionto consumer viewing and buying habits - and to be quick to change, too. **********In the past, we have felt that we could throw our message out there and that people would get the message, whether they intended to or not. I think that is going to change, and we are going to have to start with the assumption that the consumer is going to pay attention to what he wants to. We can only get his attention if and when he is interested. And we had better be there when he is ready to hear about us, as opposed to when we are ready to talk to him.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/17/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Ethnic Ad Budgets Holding Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/17/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Ethnic Ad Budgets Holding Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/17/busin.body_text: **********THE traditional cutting of ethnic advertising budgets during recessions does not seem to be happening this time around, according to the leaders of the nation's few black-owned advertising agencies.  That news comes from both New York and Chicago, where most of the half-dozen full-service companies operate. **********What appears to have happened is that there has been a shakeout in the past among both advertisers and agencies. The advertisers who are still directing specific advertising to the black market are those who believe in it and see the economic benefits from it. **********''They think the black market is very important to them,'' said Keith E. Lockhart, president of Lockhart & Pettus. ''It's gotten down to marketing versus social dollars. My experience is that, once the advertiser makes a commitment, they only cut in relation to their total budget.'' **********''Those that are still advertising to the market,'' said Byron Lewis, president of the UniWorld Group, which works in both the black and Hispanic markets, ''are in it for business reasons. They are the residue that know the value of the market.'' **********Last July, his agency crossed an important bridge when one of his clients, Heublein, gave UniWorld a general market assignment for Rhum St. James. Similarly, Mingo-Jones, New York, handles Omni cigars for Liggett & Myers, and Proctor & Gardner, Chicago, handles the professional division of Alberto-Culver worldwide, a nonethnic assignment. **********Although the recent program for the fourth annual Communications Excellence to Black Audiences awards presentation lists 21 companies under ''advertising agencies,'' Barbara Proctor, president of Proctor & Gardner, said that only about seven are full-service, that is, equipped to do the whole job of planning, creating and placing advertising. Others in the business - on the media side - confirm the number. **********The three others are Vince Cullers Advertising, the oldest of them all, and Burrell Advertising, both in Chicago, and the recently formed Vanguard Advertising in Minneapolis. **********For the most part, these are the second-generation black agencies, most of the first generation having disappeared, victims sometimes of their own ineptitude, although there are those in the black community that have charged that the big white agencies helped destroy them. **********Some black agencies in the 1960's were started by people, who, Mr.  Lewis said, had earlier been hired by general agencies under pressure to seek more racial diversity, but who were never really thoroughly trained and were rarely trained on the creative side or in media. **********Another problem, as Miss Proctor noted, was that each time one of the specialty ad agencies was invited by a major advertiser to seek a black marketing assignment, it would cost the agency about $3,500 to prepare, even through it was fighting for only the 15 percent commission a $500,000 piece of business. **********''We couldn't play the presentation game,'' she said. ''We killed ourselves.'' **********A former copywriter at Post-Keyes-Gardner, a major Chicago agency now part of Cunningham & Walsh, she says that the problems of the first-generation agencies included a lack of sophisticated management, fiancial controls, management controls and sophisticated marketing concepts. **********''And,'' she said, ''you have to understand research and market segmentation. Too many of us were relying on what we knew about black people, gut feelings. **********''And the industry doesn't give a damn about gut feelings.'' Meanwhile, a big interest of the entire black advertising agency community is the search under way by Coca-Cola USA that will end with one of their number getting the assignment of a brand for advertising to the general market, not an ethnic account. **********According to Carlton Curtis, Atlanta-based director of media relations, this account could grow in size to around $8 million in billings. **********The assignment will come as the result of a minority participation plan agreement reached last August with the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Operation PUSH, People United to Save Humanity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/world.main_headline: WEINBERGER TELLS OTTAWA REAGAN PLANS TO GO AHEAD WITH THE F-18
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/world.print_headline: WEINBERGER TELLS OTTAWA REAGAN PLANS TO GO AHEAD WITH THE F-18
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/world.body_text: **********Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger reassured Canadian officials today that the Reagan Administration supports development of the F-18 fighter jet, a program in which Canada has a large financial stake. **********Mr. Weinberger, on a half-day visit to Ottawa, met with Canada's Defense Minister, Gilles Lamontagne, and later told a news conference that the United States Government would stand by its plan to buy 1,366 of the F-18's, although ''how many we purchase will depend on the Congressional appropriation.'' **********There had been reports that Washington might cut its initial purchase to 1,044 of the McDonnell Douglas planes, whose development has encountered some technical problems and large cost overruns. **********Canada announced last year that it was buying 138 of the planes, and since then Mr. Lamontagne has had to deal with domestic criticism that Canada was buying a ''$4 billion white elephant.'' **********In addition, McDonnell Douglas has promised Canadian subcontractors billions of dollars in business as part of the F-18 program, and a reduction in the Pentagon's purchases would cut into those contracts. **********Mr. Weinberger, who was joined at the news conference by Mr.  Lamontagne, also said that the United States was interested in buying more Canadian-made military products in order to help balance the defense trade between the two countries. The Canadian deficit in that trade has totaled $394 million over the last 20 years. **********An Air Force spokesman said in Washington yesterday that the Air Force was looking at Canadian-made planes as replacements for some executive jets and training planes. **********Canada and the United States have sold each other equipment worth $10 billion under the Defense Production Sharing Agreement of 1959.  Mr. Weinberger said he was convinced that Ottawa and Washington would settle on an ''agreed-upon upgrading of the whole warning system'' across northern Canada and Alaska. **********A United States Defense Department policy paper proposes a reduction from 31 to 13 Distant Early Warning line radar sites. Mr.  Lamontagne has said he favors technical improvements to the radar systems, but is concerned about the economic impact on northern Canadian communities of such a cutback in the number of sites.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/29/busin.body_text: **********The board of Texasgulf Inc., a leading chemicals and minerals concern, failed to decide yesterday whether to accept Friday's takeover offer from France's Elf Aquitaine group. **********Eight board members met for three hours at headquarters here, but reached no decision on the $2.5 billion offer, a company spokesman said. Another meeting was set for July 2. **********Under the offer, Elf Aquitaine said it wanted to obtain Texasgulf, excluding the 37 percent share owned by the Canada Development Corporation. Canadian Development would get Texasgulf Canadian assets and a cash adjustment and would agree to buy 75 percent of Elf Aquitane's Canadian oil unit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/22/busin.main_headline: Chief Executive Named At L'Oreal's U.S. Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/22/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief Executive Named At L'Oreal's U.S. Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/22/busin.body_text: **********Lindsay H. Owen-Jones, 35, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Cosmair Inc., the United States licensee of L'Oreal, a large French cosmetics company. He succeeds Jean Caste, 51, who became president and chief executive of the Nestle Company, an American subsidiary of the giant Swiss Nestle organization, which owns a minority interest in L'Oreal. **********''It's a L'Oreal tradition to have a feel for what's going on in the stores and that's true here too,'' Mr. Owen-Jones said from his New York headquarters. ''My background is in marketing, but as much of my time will be spent in industrial operations and financial planning as in marketing or sales.'' **********Mr. Owen-Jones, a Welshman, started with L'Oreal in France in 1969, was placed in charge of its Belgian retail operation three years later and rose to vice president for marketing at the parent company in 1976. For more than three years, he has been president of its Italian subsidiary. **********Looking at the hair products, cosmetics and fragrances produced by his company and others, Mr. Owen-Jones observed that this industry ''has suffered less than most from inflation and recession.'' He said, ''There is a deep psychological need for women and men to appear as best they can.'' **********Mr. Owen-Jones acknowledged that the American market was new to him. ''I think we have an incredible potential in the United States,'' he said. ''We have gotten to a size where we can make a determined go for the big markets.'' Leonard Sloane

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/world.main_headline: LIBYANS ARE WILLING TO HELP IN FREEING HIJACKERS' CAPTIVES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/world.print_headline: LIBYANS ARE WILLING TO HELP IN FREEING HIJACKERS' CAPTIVES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/world.body_text: **********Libya agreed today to receive the prisoners to be released by Pakistan at the demand of three hijackers who are holding more than 100 passengers and crew members aboard a Pakistani airliner here. **********The hijackers said yesterday that they would free their hostages after they had received notification that 55 prisoners held in Pakistani jails had arrived in Libya. The hijackers also asked to be flown to Libya, and this demand was accepted as well. **********A Pakistani diplomat at the airport told reporters early this evening that 49 prisoners who had been held in four different provinces in Pakistan were being gathered in Karachi and would be leaving Pakistani airspace ''in the direction of Libya.'' (A plane carrying the prisoners left Karachi for Syria Saturday, Reuters reported from Karachi.) **********No Record of 6 of 55 Prisoners **********The diplomat repeated earlier statements that the Pakistani Government had no record of 6 of the 55 prisoners whose names the hijackers had submitted in a list of people to be freed. The hijackers contend that all 55 are political prisoners. **********The issue of the six prisoners could still lead to a collapse of the agreement.  One of the hijackers was heard telling the Syrian and Pakistani negotiators in the control tower by radio that he wanted to know whether the six prisoners were alive. He added that all 55 on the list had to be released and that members of the prisoners' families had to be flown to Libya as well. Stopover in Syrian City **********Tonight the Syrian Government announced through its press agency, Sana, that the plane taking the released prisoners from Pakistan to Libya would make a stopover at the northern Syrian city of Aleppo. **********Although the statement did not say so, Syrian officials in Aleppo were expected to check the identities of the people aboard the plane and advise the hijackers, who were then to release the hostages in Damascus. **********At one point this afternoon the hijackers seemed to be making new demands. They said that the agreement between them and the Pakistani Government had to be underwritten by Syria, the United Nations and Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group. Safe Passage for Families **********The hijackers also demanded that members of their own families be allowed to leave Pakistan unharmed and that one member of each family be permitted to stay behind to liquidate their possessions. **********There was a report from Pakistani sources that the hijackers had demanded that the Pakistani Government give $40,000 to each of the three families. But this report could not be confirmed. **********Another report said that the hijackers did not ask for payment but for Government permission for each family to take the proceeds from the sale of its possessions out of Pakistan in hard currency. **********Shahrayat Khan, the Pakistani Ambassador to Jordan, one of the two Pakistani diplomats who have been negotiating with the hijackers through Syrian intermediaries, told reporters that he did not think these demands constituted a major problem. Other diplomats said that they understood that the hijackers continued to bargain today but had not raised any ''real new conditions.'' **********The diplomats pointed out that Syria came close yesterday to underwriting the agreement between the Pakistani Government and the hijackers. The statement by the Pakistani President, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, that his Government was ready to release the prisoners was not made to the hijackers but to President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, who had it transmitted to the hijackers along with a message of his own urging them to accept the Pakistani moves and to refrain from violence. Pakistan to Afghanistan to Syria **********The procedure chosen by President Assad amounted to a Syrian guarantee to the hijackers that the Pakistani message was genuine, diplomats here said. **********The Pakistan International Airlines Boeing 720 was hijacked on a domestic flight in Pakistan on March 2 and flown to Kabul, Afghanistan. The hijackers released most of the women aboard but on Friday they killed a Pakistani diplomat, Tariq Rahim, one of the passengers. While in Kabul the hijackers also acquired explosives, pistols and at least one automatic weapon. The plane arrived in Damascus early Monday morning. **********Hygienic conditions on the plane are known to have become appalling. Syrian airport workers who have been handing food and soft drinks for the hostages to one of the hijackers three times a day are reporting that each time the door of the plane is opened the foul air inside can be smelled, even at a distance. **********The septic tanks of the toilets have been removed and replaced regularly only for the last three days. Early this morning Syrian cleaning women were allowed aboard the plane for the first time. The hijackers agreed to let them in after Islamabad's decision to free the Pakistani prisoners was announced yesterday. **********Western diplomats here said today they had the impression that the turning point in the drama came with the hijackers' threat yesterday to kill the three American citizens aboard the plane. Less than 20 minutes before the hijackers' deadline expired, President Zia notified Syria of his decision to accept the hijackers' demands.Until then the Pakistanis had said that they would free only about a dozen prisoners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/world.main_headline: JOINT PATROLS SEEK TO END FIGHTING IN BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/world.print_headline: JOINT PATROLS SEEK TO END FIGHTING IN BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/world.body_text: **********Clashes between Syrian troops and Christian militia forces gave way today to sporadic shooting here and in Zahle, but all efforts so far to maintain an effective cease-fire have failed. **********Brig. Sami al-Khatib, the Lebanese liaison officer with the Syrian peacekeeping force in Lebanon, said that contacts had been established between the factions in an effort to stabilize the situation in Zahle, a mainly Christian city of about l50,000 people situated 30 miles east of here, and that joint patrols of Syrian and Lebanese soldiers were being set up along truce lines in Beirut to end the four days of fighting that have left 136 people killed and 500 wounded. **********Units of the Lebanese army were involved in the exchanges here, and a military communique said that four soldiers had been killed and 12 wounded in the last 24 hours. Twenty-two other people also lost their lives in the same period, according to police estimates. **********While the state-controlled Radio Lebanon said there had been a noticeable improvement in security conditions in the capital and in Zahle, the Voice of Lebanon, the private radio station of the Christian Phalange Party, reported that Syrian troops had pounded Zahle with rockets. Four Tanks Reported Knocked Out **********The radio report said that Christian militiamen had knocked out four Syrian tanks. There has been no confirmation of the report from other sources. **********The Phalangist Party is Lebanon's principal rightist paramilitary organization, providing the bulk of the anti-Syrian militia forces.  Syrian troops have been in Lebanon for the last five years operating under an Arab League mandate. **********Ghassan Tueni, Lebanon's delegate to the United Nations, was quoted today as having said that it would be better if the Syrians were replaced by a combined force representing other Arab countries and the United Nations. In an interview with the English-language magazine Monday Morning, Mr. Tueni said that Lebanon had never been so close to partition as it was now. **********A number of Christian members of the Cabinet are known to favor adding to the United Nations troops here and deploying them at trouble spots in place of the Syrians. **********Six thousand soldiers from eight nations comprise the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon, known by its initials, Unifil.  They are stationed in southern Lebanon. **********President Elias Sarkis is said to be reluctant to ''internationalize'' the Lebanese crisis, however, for fear that this would provoke an irreparable split in the Government. The Moslem Prime Minister, Shafik al-Wazzan, and other Moslem officials are opposed to such a move. Message Sent to the Pope **********The Grand Mufti of Lebanon, Sheik Hassan Khaled, the spiritual head of Lebanon's Sunni Moslems, has sent a cablegram to Pope John Paul II asserting that the current conflict here is political and not religious. He urged the Pope to advise Lebanese Christians to cooperate with the Moslems. **********The Pope had expressed concern over the deteriorating situation in Lebanon. A majority of the Christians here are Maronite Catholics who follow the Vatican. **********The overwhelming majority of the population of Zahle are Greek Catholics, or Melkites, who also adhere to Rome. The Maronite militiamen of the Phalangist Party gained control of the city in December after fighting Syrian troops. **********Syria has told Lebanese officials who visited Damascus in the last two days that the Phalangists must leave Zahle and that the task of maintaining order can be taken over by the Lebanese army. **********Two Syrian brigades of about 1,500 men backed by tanks have had Zahle under siege for five days. Damascus reportedly has said that the siege will be lifted as soon as the Phalangist forces have left. ---- Israeli Leaders Discuss Crisis **********JERUSALEM, April 5 (Reuters) - Israel's leaders met today to discuss the crisis in Lebanon. The Cabinet heard briefings from the chief of staff and the head of military intelligence, but no statement was issued. **********In a radio interview, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said that Israel would not stand by and let Syrian troops massacre Lebanese Christians. He said that the Government was pressing the United States to use its influence to end the fighting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/09/world.main_headline: MUBARAK PLEDGES TO IMPROVE LIVING FOR ALL EGYPTIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/09/world.print_headline: MUBARAK PLEDGES TO IMPROVE LIVING FOR ALL EGYPTIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/09/world.body_text: **********In his first major address since taking office, President Hosni Mubarak called today for economic changes to better the lot of the average Egyptian and affirmed that Egypt was committed to a policy of nonalignment in foreign affairs. **********Mr. Mubarak's nationally televised address before a session of Parliament emphasized his commitment to the policies of the late President Anwar el-Sadat. But he outlined what could become his own versions of directions charted by the assassinated leader. **********The speech began with a brief eulogy for Mr. Sadat, who was killed by gunmen in uniform as he watched a military parade on Oct. 6. It then dwelled on Egypt's internal problems, particularly the country's perennially precarious economy. Near the end, Mr. Mubarak discussed foreign policy, affirming his support for the Camp David peace treaty with Israel. **********'Neither East Nor West' **********But the new President deviated from Mr. Sadat's position somewhat when he said that Egypt was ''fully committed to nonalignment and positive neutrality.'' **********''Egypt is an African state,'' Mr. Mubarak said. ''It is neither East nor West. Egypt, a great country, will never be within the orbit of this or that country, of this bloc or that bloc.'' **********In recent years, Mr. Sadat, while emphasizing Egypt's independence in foreign affairs, also emphasized the link he had forged with the United States, which is Egypt's chief supplier of military and other aid. **********''Our relations with the superpowers,'' Mr. Mubarak said, ''we gauge by the good intentions shown to us'' and by the noninterference of these nations in Egypt's internal affairs. **********The area around the Parliament was dense with uniformed and plainclothes security men as Mr. Mubarak entered the legislative chamber on schedule at 11 A.M. Mr. Mubarak's address lasted 45 minutes, far shorter than the average speech by Mr. Sadat, who often spoke for up to three hours. **********The PresidentHe proceeded to read his speech from a prepared text, another departure from Mr. Sadat, who often spoke extemporaneously.  After eulogizing Mr. Sadat, Mr. Mubrak spoke of the need for renewed efforts to improve the economy.  ''The time for work has come,'' he said, adding that ''Egypt is for all - it is not a community of the privileged few who would monopolize influence and impose a guardianship on the people.'' **********This remark was viewed here as a criticism of the nouveaux riches who have reaped windfalls from Mr. Sadat's so-called open-door economic policy, designed to lure foreign investors to Egypt. **********At the same time, Mr. Mubarak said there was to be no retreat from the policy because ''this is the ideal form of economic and social development in this country.'' **********''The open-door policy should be productive,'' Mr. Mubarak said, adding that it ''should come within the framework of what the grass roots in this country need and not the luxury commodities limited to the few.'' **********He said he was distressed at Egypt's penchant for importing enormous quantities of food, some of which, he said, could be raised at home. **********''In all and every field of economic endeavor, we have to bear in mind the interests of the grass roots,'' he said.  Referring to Egypt's program of subsidies of such basic commodities as tea, sugar, cooking oil and bread - a program long criticized by leading economists as a severe drain on the country's investment reserves - Mr. Mubarak said, ''The subsidies should go to the people who really need them.'' **********Turning to the 1979 peace treaty with Israel, Mr. Mubarak referred to those who feel that Egypt might withdraw from the pacts after Israel's scheduled withdrawal from Sinai next April. Peace 'A Strategic Commitment' **********''Peace, as far as we're concerned, is a strategic commitment and not a tactical position,'' Mr. Mubarak said.  ''We should not listen to those voices that are trying to impede the withdrawal by raising doubts,'' he said, adding that the return of Sinai was ''a foregone conclusion.'' **********He said: ''The peace for which Egypt strives is not partial or limited, but a just and comprehensive peace for the whole of the Middle East. A peace that will realize a major historic reconciliation between Israel and the Arab world and eradicate the roots of their conflict.'' **********Mr. Mubarak extended an olive branch to Egypt's legal political opposition parties, which were the target of Mr. Sadat's scorn in his last days, and urged them to work with him as he tried to achieve his domestic and foreign goals. **********Referring to the Moslem fundamentalists the Government has said killed Mr. Sadat and planned to topple his regime, Mr. Mubarak said, ''Recently, we found our life has been infiltrated by bloody terrorism, terrorism which wanted to destroy everything that we built.'' **********He alluded to the recent arrests after Mr. Sadat's killing, numbering 700 to 1,500, saying, ''Every national of this country should know that the home front is quite safe, and the institutions of this country are quite on the alert and dedicated to protect this country.'' **********At the end of his speech, Mr. Mubarak said that he had given only the ''broad outlines'' of his foreign and domestic policies and that the details of those policies would be forthcoming. **********When he concluded, the normally dour-looking President broke into a broad smile as applause filled the chamber and the members of Parliament chanted three times ''Long live the Arab Republic of Egypt!'' ---- Egyptian Trial to Begin **********CAIRO, Nov. 8 (AP) - The Cairo newspaper Al Akhbar reported today that the four men who have been accused of shooting President Anwar el-Sadat at a military parade would be indicted on Wednesday. It also reported that supreme military court trials began yesterday for an undisclosed number of officers charged with ''not fully carrying out their duties'' by allowing the attackers to infiltrate the parade with weapons and ammunition.
