https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/world.main_headline: REAGAN ARRIVES IN CANADA TO HECKLING AND APPLAUSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/world.print_headline: REAGAN ARRIVES IN CANADA TO HECKLING AND APPLAUSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/world.body_text: **********President Reagan heard more heckling than applause today as he began an official visit to Canada with a pledge of cooperation on issues dividing the two neighbors. **********It was Mr. Reagan's first foreign trip as President, though he visited Mexico while he was President-elect.  Unlike the hundreds of demonstrators who gathered outside the Parliament to denounce what they consider United States intervention in El Salvador and negligence on pollution, Canadian officials said they were satisfied with the way the visit was going. **********After several hours of discussing both world issues and Canadian-American problems, Mark MacGuigan, Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, told reporters that ''an excellent rapport'' had been established between the President and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau. **********Fisheries Treaty Scuttled **********But Mr. MacGuigan indicated that though confrontation had been avoided, no problems had been settled. The United States, he reported, had promised its best efforts to control cross-border pollution, notably acid rain, and to protect fish stocks endangered by the Reagan Administration's decision last week to scuttle a fisheries treaty because of the Administration's inability to obtain approval in the United States Senate. **********The feeling that the United States was not doing enough to protect either the environment or fish resources had been two major grievances of the Canadian Government and had created an anxious, even angry, mood in the capital before Mr. Reagan's arrival. Mr.  MacGuigan said it was still not clear how the United States will protect fish stocks off the East Coast from overfishing or what it will do on environmental questions. **********American officials said it would take time to settle such problems as the fisheries but agreed that a good atmosphere had been created.  In an effort to contribute to this atmosphere, it was learned, Washington withdrew a strongly worded note it had sent on Friday attacking Canada's policy of reducing the domination of American and other foreign companies over the domestic oil and gas industry. Some Consider Note 'Insulting' **********The note, characterized by some Canadian officials as ''insulting,'' was understood to have been sent without the knowledge of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who is part of the American party here. There was discussion of Canada's energy policy but with officials here showing no sign of backing down, the talks on that point were inconclusive. **********Eager to establish a friendly atmosphere, the Canadians avoided any confrontation over El Salvador despite the clamor raised in the streets, and both Mr. Haig and Mr. Trudeau indicated later that the two nations' differences on El Salvador are small. **********''There was complete agreement,'' Mr. Haig told reporters tonight, ''in the sense of what we're there to do and the need to keep foreign intervention out and to work for a pluralistic and moderate society.'' **********Asked whether Mr. Trudeau approved of the United States decision to send military aid to El Salvador, Mr. Haig said, ''Well, I will leave that for him to speak to, but we didn't have any disagreements on that subject.'' **********Later, during a dinner for Mr. Reagan at the home of Governor General Edward R. Schreyer, Mr. Trudeau stopped short of endorsing the aid to El Salvador but said the Canadian press ''just got it wrong'' in reporting his criticism of the American action. **********''We support the middle in El Salvador,'' Mr. Trudeau said. ''We don't want either the fascists or the Marxists to triumph and we believe that's the aim of the United States Government.'' **********Pressed on whether there were @disagreements in today's talks, Mr.  Trudeau said: ''Believe it or not, I can't think of any. The Administration has really made a great effort to solve the problems of concern to the environmentalists about acid rain. It depends on what they do, but insofar as projects and intentions, we're in agreement right down the line. It depends on how much they can do.'' **********Asked whether he and Mr. Reagan had gotten along personally, Mr.  Trudeau said, ''I think we're both a bit of a ham. He's a good actor and I'm a bad one.'' Landing at Military Airport **********The visit got off to a staid and well-regulated start shortly after Air Force One, with the President, his wife, Nancy, and Cabinet officials aboard, touched down at Ottawa's heavily guarded military airport shortly before 9:30 this morning. Governor General Schreyer greeted the Reagans, and after a short ceremony they drove to the Governor General's residence. The Reagans were to spend the night there. **********Things became unruly when the President was greeted at the Parliament building by Mr. Trudeau. Hundreds of sign-carrying and shouting demonstrators were allowed to cross the broad lawn to within 50 feet of the microphones where the President and Prime Minister greeted each other. They were easily heard above the speeches. **********''Canadians like Americans,'' Mr. Trudeau started to say, and the crowd chanted, ''Acid rain, go home!'' Some demonstrators suggested that Mr. Reagan could go home as well, while others told him to get out of El Salvador. **********Mr. Trudeau continued to express his confidence that the two countries would find answers to their problems ''because we have faith in the people of the United States.'' **********Mr. Reagan then noted the ''warm words of welcome'' while the heckling continued. ''The people of the United States do not merely value your friendship, we cherish it,'' the President said over the shouts. **********Schoolchildren clutching American and Canadian flags cheered. But apparently annoyed by the continued heckling from the rest of the audience, Mr. Trudeau returned to the microphone and shouted: **********''Hey guys, when I go to the United States, I am not met with these kinds of signs. You know, the Americans have some beefs against us too, but we receive them politely, so how about a great cheer for President Reagan?'' The schoolchildren cheered. Reagan Takes Jeers in Stride **********As the two leaders went into the building to start their talks, Mr. Reagan was heard to say of the heckling, ''It made me feel right at home.'' **********By the time the morning meetings ended, about 20 minutes behind schedule, the crowd on the lawn had grown to several thousand. It booed as the Presidential motorcade passed, and later an American flag was burned. Two arrests were reported. **********At Mr. Trudeau's official residence, the leaders lunched on lobster and quail while talking mainly about economic policy. Outside other demonstrators tore up an American flag. Although Mr. Reagan's economic philosophy of minimum government intervention is not shared by Mr. Trudeau, there was agreement on the importance of controlling inflation. **********Canadian-American issues occupied the rest of the afternoon.  Tomorrow morning Mr. Reagan will address a joint session of Parliament before returning to Washington.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/28/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; PENNZOIL ECONOMIST WINS AS FORECASTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/28/busin.body_text: **********James L. Pate, the 46-year-old vice president and treasurer of the Pennzoil Company, may be the hottest economic forecaster of all. At least he will get an award and $5,000 today for his forecasts of the gross national product and inflation rate from 1978 through 1980. **********The first annual Silbert Economic Forecasting Award and check will go to Mr. Pate at a Washington seminar luncheon sponsored by the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company, of which Theodore H.  Silbert is chairman. Mr. Pate is one of the panel of 42 economists whose forecasts are published monthly in a newsletter called Blue Chip Economic Indicators. He is the winner because he had the lowest average differential from the actual statistics, as authenticated by Columbia University, the consultant for the award. **********In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Pate was not shy when it came to talking about the outlook. ''I think the economic outlook has deteriorated in recent weeks,'' he said. ''The depth and severity of this downturn is going to be very much dependent on what happens to interest rates.'' **********Mr. Pate added, ''I think the Federal Reserve should permit interest rates to decline from the present excessive levels, which are in direct conflict with the Administration's economic policies.  High interest rates are dragging the economy down.'' **********Mr. Pate, chief economist of the Houston-based oil company, was previously a speicial adviser to the White House and an Assistant Secretary of Commerce. He also was director of business research of the B.F. Goodrich Company, a senior economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and an economics professor at Monmouth College. **********And what are Mr. Pate's predictions for 1981 and 1982? The real gross national product will advance 1.9 percent this year and 1.1 percent next year, he responded. As for inflation, as measured by the G.N.P. deflator, he forecast that it would be 9.1 percent in 1981 and 8.2 percent in 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/world.print_headline: PAPAL VIEW OF WORK; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/world.body_text: **********The encyclical letter that Pope John Paul II issued yesterday on the subject of work and human dignity is the Pope's third major statement relating Roman Catholic doctrine to modern problems. **********Like the earlier two encyclicals - one on the ''moral disorder'' of the arms race and another on the dangers of materialism - ''Laborem Exercens'' (''On Human Work'') is a nuanced document that reveals both the Pope's scholarly background and his pastoral concern for the way the modern world affects the life of the Christian. **********The Polish-born Pope's diplomatic tact is also evident in the balanced critique of both capitalism and Marxism. By stressing the theological aspect of work as humanity's ''specific dignity,'' he gives a spiritual dimension to labor at a time when economic and technological developments tend to downgrade the worker, making him merely a unit of production or operator of machinery. **********In the introduction to the 30,000-word encyclical, Pope John Paul refers to the first social encyclical of the modern papacy, issued by Pope Leo XIII in 1891, and an early chapter in the new encyclical analyzes in detail the biblical and theological foundations for work. By the time the encyclical has closed with a chapter titled, ''Elements for a Spirituality of Work,'' the Pope has surrounded his social critique with a theology explaining that work contributes not only to earthly progress and welfare but to the development of the kingdom of God. Work Not a Penalty Religious thinkers have sometimes concluded that work is a penalty laid upon the human race as punishment for di sobeying God, but the encyclical stresses the more common Christian view that God ordered the man and woman he had created to ''be frui tful and multiply, and fill the earth and subdue it.'' **********''Even though these words do not refer directly and explicitly to work, beyond any doubt they indirectly indicate it as an activity for man to carry out in the world,'' the encyclical says. Several tim es the Pope warns against regarding humanity as tools for industria lization or profit. Sometimes ''heavy toil'' is requiredof workers, s ays the Pope, who worked in a factory as a young man.  But he warned that in economic systems where productivity and profit ''gain in nob ility,'' the worker should not lose human dignity. **********Because work is a biblical mandate, the use of the world's resources placed at the disposal of humanity is a theological issue, the encyclical states. About 40 percent of the encyclical is devoted to questions of work and ownership of the means of production, rights of workers to earn just wages, pensions and vacations, their right to form unions and the responsibility of governments to maintain just labor policies. Deplores Adversary Relationship **********Roman Catholic theology, the papal letter states, champions the rights of the worker above all else, and it will take issue with any aspect of a social system - capitalist or Marxist - that depersonalizes human beings. But the Pope deplores the adversary relationship between labor and capital. **********When it speaks of these issues, the encyclical breaks no new ground for Roman Catholic social policy but reaffirms earlier statements and re-emphasizes concerns Pope John Paul II has expressed in the past. There is no direct reference to Poland, where a labor union campaign has rocked the country in the last year. The encyclical acknowledges that the struggle for worker's rights will touch the political arena, but it says that ''unions do not have the character of political parties struggling for power.'' **********On this point, the Pope's description of the role of labor unions parallels his concerns about political activism in the church. He warns that when unions are too closely linked with political parties ''they easily lose contact with their specific role, which is to secure the just rights of workers within the framework of the common good.'' **********For the same reason, he has often asked that the church and its clergy stay clear of partisan politics.  In a section on ''social benefits,'' the Pope says wages should be high enough so a man can support a family and so a mother will not have to work to help the family survive. On Role of the Mother **********''It will redound to the credit of society to make it possible for a mother -without inhibiting her freedom - without penalizing her as compared with other women - to devote herself to taking care of her children,'' the encyclical states. ''Having to abandon these tasks in order to take up paid work outside the home is wrong from the point of view of the good of society.'' **********While that small section is likely to anger some Catholic feminists because it regards the primary role of woman as that of wife and mother, the Pope says in another section, ''Women, sometimes without proper recognition on the part of society and even of their own families, bear the daily burden and responsibility for their homes and the upbringing of their children. **********''The true advancement of women requires that labor should be structured in such a way that women do not have to pay for their advancement by abandoning what is specific to them and at the expense of the family,'' the encyclical says. **********Catholics are likely to read the encyclical according to their own social situation, said the Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, S.J., editor of America, a Catholic weekly magazine. Poles, he said, are sure to notice that the word ''solidarity'' - the name for the Polish union - appears prominently in the encyclical. American Catholic women, he added, will say that the encyclical is critical of a situation that requires a woman to leave home to support her family but leaves open the possibility that she might choose to do so.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/busin.print_headline: CHRYSLER SAID TO GET $140 MILLION IN CANADIAN LOAN GUARANTEES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/busin.body_text: **********A Canadian cabinet committee has given approval in principle for about $140 million (Canadian) in loan guarantees for Chrysler Canada Ltd., Government sources confirmed today. **********Final cabinet approval, however, is not expected until Tuesday. **********The settlement, after weeks of talks between Chrysler Canada, the Government and the union involved, may clear the way for Chrysler to receive $400 million in loan guarantees from the United States Government. Canadian aid to Chrysler is an essential part of the total financial package the United States is attempting to work out. **********Final details on the financially-troubled United States auto maker's loan guarantee agreement are expected to be completed next week in Washington. **********The Canadian guarantees are less than the $200 million which Chrysler negotiated last spring, and presumably reflect the Government's response to plans by Chrysler to reduce its investment committment in Canada from $1 billion to $700 million over the next four years. Employment Levels **********The Canadian package is believed to include an agreement that employment levels in Canada will be about 12 percent of the North American total by 1985. **********The major sticking point in the recent negotiations has been Chrysler's proposal to drop car production in Canada. However, it now appears that the Chrysler package in Canada includes production of a front-wheel drive car starting in the 1985 model year, which would be later than previously scheduled. **********The car will be built at the company's existing Windsor, Ontario, truck plant, with about 100,000 units produced a year - about half of an original plan for about 260,000 units.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/22/busin.main_headline: G.N.P. UP AT 5% RATE IN QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/22/busin.print_headline: G.N.P. UP AT 5% RATE IN QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/22/busin.body_text: **********The Commerce Department reported today that the nation's economy grew at a 5 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter. The report demonstrated once again that the economy was stronger than economists had expected. **********The fourth-quarter results bring to a close an extraordinarily turbulent year for the economy, which posted a record drop in the second quarter but still managed to end 1980 with a gross national product almost exactly the size it was 12 months earlier, after adjustment for inflation. **********For the future, economists said that today's news made a decline in the first quarter of 1981 unlikely, a prospect that had been widely forecast in the wake of record interest rates. **********Beyond the first quarter, economists said that the outlook was uncertain, but they took today's figures as a reminder of the danger of underestimating the strength of the economy. Doubt on Contraction **********''There is not a clear picture of weakening emerging that some observers were thinking we might see,'' Courtenay M. Slater, chief economist at the Commerce Department, said at a briefing. Although Mrs. Slater, who expects to be leaving the department shortly, said she still expected the growth rate to slow, she added that she was a ''little doubtful'' that the economy would contract. **********The growth in the gross national product, the total value of goods and services produced, in the fourth quarter promised to intensify the debate over when a tax cut should be made effective. President Reagan's advisers are currently debating between his original plan for cutting individual taxes as of Jan. 1 and the possibility of delaying it until summer or fall. **********''This calls into question the necessity of a tax cut now,'' said Robert Gough, an economist with Data Resources, a consulting firm. In his final days in office, President Carter proposed delaying his tax cut for individuals until 1982 in part because of the apparent economic strength. **********However, Alan Greenspan, a Reagan economic adviser, said that today's figures would not affect the thinking in the White House because the Republicans had already been assuming that the economy would grow at a rate of 4 percent or faster in the quarter. Inflationary Expectations **********Mr. Greenspan and other economists said that, although the pace of expansion in the fourth quarter was not large by historic standards for a post-recession period, it was large compared with what was expected in a period of peak interest rates. **********''The economy has basically been stronger at these levels of interest rates than we would have assumed,'' Mr. Greenspan said.  ''The level of interest rates required to cut off expansion is higher than it was six months ago.'' **********To Mr. Greenspan, this phenomenon suggested that ''underlying inflationary expectations are higher,'' meaning that consumers have continued to spend in the face of the high rates on the theory that the goods will only become more expensive. **********As part of its report today, the Commerce Department said that a G.N.P. price measure, a broadly based index known as the deflator, increased at an 11.2 percent rate in the quarter, up from increases of less than 10 percent in the previous three quarters. **********Mrs. Slater and Mr. Greenspan both said that the number reflected a Federal pay rise and not an acceleration of inflation. Over 1980, prices as measured by the deflator rose 9.9 percent. **********According to today's figures, the growth in the fourth quarter was due principally to continuing high spending by consumers. The housing industry also showed strong improvement, and Government purchases were up modestly. Business investment and net exports declined. **********The increase in the fourth quarter followed a growth at a 2.4 percent rate in the third quarter. The decline in the second quarter was at a 9.9 percent annual rate. In the fourth quarter, the G.N.P., after adjustment for inflation, totaled $1,490.1 billion, compared with $1,490.6 billion in the fourth quarter of 1979. Sales to Consumers Cited **********''In the fourth quarter, real G.N.P. was still about eight-tenths of 1 percent below its first-quarter peak,'' Mrs. Slater noted.  ''Growth during the second half was entirely in final sales to consumers and private businesses.'' **********Although economists have predicted that the economy would weaken under the strain of higher interest rates, the only major indication of broad weakness has been retail sales, which declined 1.3 percent in December. **********Meanwhile, industrial production rose by 1 percent in December, housing starts were virtually unchanged rather than declining as expected, and new claims for unemployment insurance have not been growing. **********Most forecasters were expecting G.N.P. to grow slightly faster than a 4 percent rate. But those recent predictions represented a substantially more optimistic view than was prevalent a few weeks earier. And economists who until today had been expecting a decline in the first quarter indicated they would probably revise their forecasts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/09/world.main_headline: IRAN GETTING ADVICE FROM U.S. LAWYERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/09/world.print_headline: IRAN GETTING ADVICE FROM U.S. LAWYERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/09/world.body_text: **********Iran's American lawyers have quietly been helping Iranian leaders evaluate the apparent legal obstacles to compliance with some of Teheran's demands for the release of the hostages. **********These lawyers have not always agreed with one another or with Carter Administration lawyers on the extent of the President's legal authority to meet Iran's demands. But the concern of Government officials close to the hostage negotiations about the legal advice that Iran was receiving has apparently ebbed after a secret meeting a few weeks ago. **********Some significant legal disagreements persist, however. As a result, the Iranian leaders' skepticism about the legal obstacles may have been reinforced by differences between what President Carter has offered to do to obtain release of the hostages and what some lawyers say he has the power to do. **********Some Say Demands Can Be Met **********Leonard B. Boudin, a New York lawyer who represents Iran's central bank, and his partner, Eric Lieberman, have said in interviews over the last two months that most of Iran's conditions ''can easily be met'' under ''clear-cut precedents'' and laws if President Carter wants to meet them. **********They have recently qualified those statements by acknowleding that court challenges could delay the carrying out of any Presidential orders transferring frozen Iranian assets or the property of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi out of the United States. They have continued to assert, however, that the President has broader powers to do what Iran has asked than the Administration has been willing to concede. **********On the other hand, Thomas G. Shack Jr., the principal Washington lawyer representing the Iranian Government, has said that some of the Iranian demands might be ''legally and politically impossible'' for any President to satisfy. But he has also said the President could do much of what Iran has demanded. Moral and Ethical Issues **********In interviews, lawyers who represent Iran, and other sources close to the hostage negotiations, expressed the moral and ethical questions they have had in providing advice to a regime that is using 52 American hostages as its bargaining point. **********Mr. Boudin, Mr. Shack and other lawyers emphasized that they had not advised Iran about what conditions to set for release of the hostages or acted as intermediaries between Iran and the United States. **********But Mr. Boudin and Mr. Shack acknowledged that in advising their respective Iranian clients they had dealt with issues that are central to the hostage negotiations. Among those issues are President Carter's legal powers to free frozen Iranian assets and cancel the claims of American companies. Lawsuits have tied up as much as $14 billion in frozen Iranian assets. **********Advice given for one purpose could possibly be used for another, and the Iranians might find the litigation advice equally relevant in framing their conditions for release of the hostages. **********''We cannot refrain from giving advice on the litigation out of fear of that happening,'' Mr. Shack said. ''It is our ethical obligation to advise our client as to what is legally and technically feasible in this area.'' A Secret Meeting **********Administration lawyers, apparently concerned that lawyers representing various Iranian leaders might be giving their clients the false impression that their demands could easily be satisfied, held a secret meeting with Mr. Boudin and Mr. Lieberman in November or December. Those who attended the meeting, including Lloyd Cutler, President Carter's counsel, and Roberts Owen, the State Department's top lawyer, have refused to discuss it. **********Since the meeting, Administration officials have discounted reports that Iran's lawyers have been a significant problem in the hostage negotiations, and Mr. Boudin and Mr. Lieberman have said that they agreed with the Administration's position that international arbitration would be the best way of resolving the claims against Iran. **********One potentially important disagreement, however, was suggested by Mr. Boudin's assertion that the President is authorized by the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 to order all the frozen Iranian assets, as well as the Shah's wealth, transferred to Iran or Algeria even if no agreement had been reached to protect companies with claims against those assets. **********The United States has told Iran that only the courts can lawfully transfer the property of the Shah. And American officials have said that the President could order transfer of the frozen assets only after Iran had agreed to ''some fair substitute mechanism'' for settling the claims against those assets. **********Although Iran and the United States have agreed in principle to international arbitration of claims by American companies, they have apparently not resolved such issues as what guarantees the two Governments would provide each to insure performance of their promises.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/14/busin.main_headline: AILING CAR INDUSTRY CALLED PERIL TO U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/14/busin.print_headline: AILING CAR INDUSTRY CALLED PERIL TO U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/14/busin.body_text: **********The Transportation Department warned today that the current difficulties of the automobile industry posed a threat to national security, and it urged the Government to negotiate an agreement with Japan setting ceilings on shipments of Japanese vehicles to this country. **********Such an agreement would be a key part of a combined effort by industry, labor and government to fight foreign competition, which in the past two years has nearly doubled its share of the American auto market. **********Meanwhile, Treasury Secretary G. William Miller said the Chrysler Corporation's survival plan must include a greater financial cushion before the Government could approve more loan guarantees for the company. (Page D1.) **********The Transportation Department's grim assessment came in a report on the domestic automobile industry that Congress ordered last year when it authorized a rescue of the Chrysler Corporation. Essentially the department's plan is intended to buy time for the American car industry while it retools over the next few years to make smaller, more fuel-efficient cars. **********In its report, the department said that the ''alarming'' trends and developments it had identified had been long in the making and that blame should be apportioned widely. **********Management, it said, neglected production efficiencies, quality control and development of new products. Labor, it said, grew accustomed to annual improvements in wages and fringe benefits without regard to productivity or business conditions. And the Government, it said, ''has loaded the cost of social and environmental regulation onto auto makers without a careful examination'' of costs. **********All this, the department said, combined with surging fuel prices and recession to cripple an industry that accounts for 8 1/2 percent of America's gross national product and, directly and indirectly, for one-sixth of its jobs. **********Transportation Secretary Neil E. Goldschmidt said the decline, if allowed to continue, could spread with disastrous consequences. ''If this report says one thing,'' he said at a news conference, ''it is that Chrysler is just the tip of the iceberg if we don't move on this problem.'' **********Moreover, he contended, the nation's security could be placed in jeopardy by an erosion of the industrial base accompanying the decline of automotive business. **********''In the past this industry's production capacity has been a vital mobilizing force in our defense capability,'' he told President Carter in sending the report to the White House. ''Just as important is the role our industrial might plays in defining our position in the world. Our strategic position could be gravely undermined were we to depend on others for our basic manufactured goods.'' **********The idea of limiting imports of Japanese cars - of which 1.8 million were sold in the United States last year -has been raised before. The International Trade Commission, a Federal agency, rejected the auto industry's demands for protection last year, and just last month Congress failed to pass a resolution that would have authorized the President to negotiate the issue with the Japanese. **********It is possible, however, that today's report will add to the pressures for import quotas, although trade restrictions in general are said to be opposed by the incoming Reagan administration. **********Mr. Goldschmidt, in response to a question, said he had no commitment from Reagan aides to pursue the idea, but he noted that the Transportation Secretary-designate, Drew Lewis, had put the auto industry at the top of his list of subjects to discuss at department briefings. **********In recent years Britain has limited imports of Japanese cars to about 10 percent of its market, and France has imposed a 3 percent ceiling. **********Today's report calculated that Japanese cars, 78 percent of the imports sold in this country, have a price advantage over domestic models ranging from $1,000 to $1,500 even after shipping costs and American duties are paid. **********---- G.M. Chairman Comments **********WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (Reuters) -The chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Roger B. Smith, said today that he saw merit in the proposal by Transportation Secretary Goldschmidt that the United States and Japan negotiate an import-restraint program.The chairman of the nation's largest automobile maker told reporters at the National Press Club that the United States industry needed breathing space from Japanese competition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/21/busin.main_headline: Other Business; DAD'S DAY GETTING AHEAD, AS RETAILERS CHEER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/21/busin.print_headline: Other Business; DAD'S DAY GETTING AHEAD, AS RETAILERS CHEER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/21/busin.body_text: **********The liquor will flow, the steaks will sizzle, the neckties are already out of the box. Father's Day, that early summer homage to the gods of retailing, has by and large caught up with Mother's Day, despite the latter's long headstart. (Mother's Day was authorized by law in 1914, a status Father's Day only acquired in 1971.) **********''Nearly $3 billion in total retail sales are expected from this Father's Day, virtually the same amount as for Mother's Day,'' said Ted Kaufman, executive director of both the Father's Day and Mother's Day Councils, which are non-profit groups whose members include such top corporate names as Sears Roebuck and J.C. Penney. **********''Until about 1940, Mother's Day was the more dominant holiday for retailers, but since then the gap has closed steadily. Now if anything, the median amount spent for a Father's Day gift is a bit higher,'' Mr. Kaufman said. That median cost of a gift for either holiday is now $65, he said, and Dad gets an average of 2.5 gifts. **********Three out of four Father's Day gifts are clothes, from the predictable necktie to outfits with more flair. ''A wife tries to upgrade the clothing that her husband wears,'' Mr. Kaufman said. ''If he usually wears Arrow, she'll buy him Van Huesen or a designer shirt.'' **********Major New York stores, while declining to break out figures because graduations and weddings also contribute to volume this time of year, declare the current holiday a success. **********''There are double-digit increases over last year,'' said Paul Leblang, senior vice-president for marketing at Saks Fifth Avenue.  ''All of our active sportswear is selling exceptionally well.'' **********''Business is fabulous, almost equally, for Father's and Mother's Day,'' a spokesman for Bloomingdales said, noting strong growth in men's accessories - small leather goods and cufflinks. **********''As Father's Day becomes more of a tradition, people try to outdo what they did the year before,'' added Arthur H. Grodd, general merchandising manager at Paul Stuart, a Madison Avenue men's shop at which cotton sweaters and knit shirts are hot items. **********Liquor is the second most frequently given gift for Dad. Citing a Harvard Business School research report, done for the Father's Day Council, Mr. Kaufman said ''26 percent of those surveyed admit to giving liquor. I say 'admit,' because people tend to understate purchases of liquor. It might be 50 percent.'' More liquor is sold for this weekend than at any other time except the Christmas season. **********The Harvard study found that people between the ages of 18 and 25, and wives, are the most likely gift-buyers. Twice as many women as men gave gifts for Father's Day, while women matched men in giving on Mother's Day. **********Separate holidays for parents stress the old sex roles. Mother's Day typically liberates Mom from the kitchen. (Restaurants are more crowded than on any other day except Thanksgiving.) Father's Day is for cooking out. The Beef Industry Council reports that 70 million to 80 million pounds of beef are sold for the Father's Day weekend, 10 million more than usual. **********Telephone volume is also up, but Father's Day is a loser in that catagory. Today, 18 million phones are expected to ring with interstate callers as opposed to the 21 million which sound on Mother's Day, according to A.T.& T. (Ordinary Sunday volume averages 15.3 million interstate calls.) This year, MCI communications, one of A.T.& T.'s competitors, is offering a freebie that Ma Bell doesn't concede on any holiday - 10 minutes of free calling over Father's Day weekend, similar to its past promotions for Christmas and Mother's Day. **********On Madison Avenue, the June holiday has already moved ahead, generating $17 million worth of advertising, against Mother's Day's $12 million. Both are growing, however, and at whose expense?  Easter's, retailers say. **********The trend to less formal dress and the hop-about date of Easter, which frequently means it falls too early for light clothes, have cut into sales. Mother's and Father's Day arrive dependably in the warm months when shoppers need to shed their winter wool. ''We are heading towards the development of a parents' season which will run from the end of April through July,'' Mr. Kaufman said. Now, what about the in-laws? Type for eisner Who Gets a Gift Mothers receive far more often than fathers, except in the highestincome category. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/26/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; SONY TO BUILD TV PLANT IN SOUTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/26/busin.body_text: **********The Sony Corporation said it will build a $19.7 million color TV plant early next year in the suburbs of Columbia, S.C., with an initial output of 20,000 sets a month when production begins in late 1982.  Sony said the plant would employ about 500 workers. **********The Sony Corporation of America, the wholly owned United States subsidiary of the Japanese consumer electronics concern, was the first Japanese TV maker to build a United States facility when it opened a plant in San Diego in 1972.  It employs 1,800 in San Diego and this year will produce about 750,000 Trinitron sets there, the company said. **********The Columbia plant will be Sony's third in the United States; it opened a magnetic tape manufacturing plant in Dothan, Ala., in 1977, which now employs 1,750.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/12/busin.body_text: **********Corporations seeking to reduce their tax bills are rushing to meet tomorrow's deadline for completing special tax leasing deals that could cost the Treasury billions of dollars in lost revenue. **********The benefits, part of the Administration tax program approved by Congress in August, permit money-losing corporations with tax credits and depreciation deductions they cannot use, in effect, to sell them to profitable companies seeking tax shelters. **********Tomorrow midnight is the deadline for trading tax benefits related to equipment that was purchased between Jan. 1 and Aug. 13 of this year. To transfer the benefits, the previously purchased equipment must be ''sold'' to a company willing to pay cash for the tax benefits and then lease the equipment back to the original owner using the equipment. In fact, the sale is for tax purposes only. The company using the equipment retains title and possession. After tomorrow, such deals can be entered into only for newly purchased equipment. **********Estimate of Total Involved **********Tax experts expect that by the deadline, the tax benefits on equipment valued at $10 billion to $20 billion will have been sold, resulting in a loss to the Treasury of at least 10 percent of the total. **********''There's a great deal of frantic activity,'' said William P.  Casey, of the investment firm bearing his name. ''There's never been anything like this before.'' **********Peter K. Nevitt, president of the BankAmeriLease Group, the Bank of America's leasing subsidiary, added, ''A tremendous amount of deals are getting done or are in the late stages.'' But he noted that some deals had ''fallen out of bed'' because of last-minute complications. **********One of the biggest buyers of tax benefits has been the International Business Machines Corporation, which purchased tax credits and depreciation deductions from the Ford Motor Company, the B.F. Goodrich Company and the CSX Corporation for more than $300 million. I.B.M. is expected to announce still another deal tomorrow. **********In the past couple of days, the Marsh & McLennan Companies announced the purchase of tax benefits from the Occidental Petroleum Corporation for an undisclosed sum, and Ideal Basic Industries sold tax benefits to an unnamed buyer for $77 million. **********Other sellers of benefits have included United Airlines, Conrail, Burlington Northern, Bethlehem Steel and Inland Steel. Bankers say that buyers are more reluctant to disclose their identity since many of them fear they will be criticized for tax avoidance. **********''It's very unlikely, unless you have both parties lined up, that you could still get a deal done,'' said Donald R. Kendall Jr., a vice president at Morgan Stanley & Company, which estimates it will negotiate leases for some $2 billion in equipment. ''One of the biggest constraints is finding a good law firm that isn't busy with these.'' **********''We have been working 16- and 17-hour days on these deals,'' said Richard J. Bronstein, a lawyer at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. ''We are trying to close everything now. No one wants to leave this for the last minutes.'' How Tax Benefit Works **********Participants in the transactions are closely guarding their exact terms in order to maintain bargaining room for future deals. Here is an example used by some experts to describe how a typical deal is structured: **********Equipment valued at $1 billion that is owned by a financially troubled company is ''sold'' for tax purposes to a profitable company for $200 million in cash and an $800 million note. The seller retains title to the equipment and possession of it, but for tax purposes the profitable company is declared its owner. This allows the buyer of the benefits to depreciate the equipment over its life and to get a one-time investment tax credit of 10 percent of the value of the equipment. **********The right to possession is gained by a lease, which is for $800 million, the amount the buyer happens to owe on the note. Except for the $200 million cash payment, the deal is a ''wash.'' **********As a result, the buyer of the benefits gets a tax benefit it would not otherwise have and the seller gets cash. Payment Is Postponed **********The 10 percent tax credit is subtracted from the buyer's tax bill and is permanently lost to the Treasury. The depreciation allowances are deducted from current tax bills but must be paid in later years.  Their value is that they free capital to be employed sooner rather than later and that, in inflationary times, they are eventually paid in less valuable dollars. **********Another tax effect of the deal is that the purchaser of the tax benefits must report the $800 million in lease payments as income over the life of the lease and is taxed on them, even though the payments are not actually received from the equipment user because they are offsetting what the benefit purchaser owes the user on the purchase note. **********''There's a number of companies that are interested in becoming buyers of benefits,'' said C. Daniel Tyree, a vice president at Saloman Brothers. ''But they just haven't been able to react aggressively before Nov. 13. They may be in the market in the future.'' Chrysler's Situation **********One open question is whether the Chrysler Corporation, which has some $200 million worth of equipment it purchased during 1981, will be able to find a buyer of its tax benefits before the deadline. **********Yesterday the Treasury Department issued new regulations that, in effect, allow a tax benefit purchaser to keep the benefits if the seller goes bankrupt - provided that creditors with a secured interest in the equipment have agreed in advance of the bankruptcy.  Otherwise, the creditors can claim the equipment and the benefits. **********Some experts doubt that such agreements could be obtained from Chrysler's secured creditors by the deadline.  Chrysler's controller, Christopher J. Steffen, has noted that the cash that could be obtained from such a sale -perhaps $50 million - would be ''very important to the cash flow'' of Chrysler and that the troubled auto company planned to sell other tax benefits after tomorrow's deadline.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/06/busin.main_headline: Company News; CRUDE SPOT PRICES OFF SHARPLY; '81 DROP MORE THAN $5 A BARREL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/06/busin.print_headline: Company News; CRUDE SPOT PRICES OFF SHARPLY; '81 DROP MORE THAN $5 A BARREL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/06/busin.body_text: **********The price of the basic grade of crude oil from the Middle East has slipped more than $1 on the spot market in the past week, a direct result of an oversupply of oil worldwide, traders report. **********Since early April, the price of this oil on the spot market, where oil not under contract is traded, has dropped more than $3.50 a barrel, for a total decline of more than $5 a barrel this year - an unusually steep decline. **********The price for this medium-quality oil is now $34 a barrel, but even at the lower prices buyers are refraining from large purchases in the belief that prices will fall still lower. **********Spot prices of the light, low-sulfur, high-quality African crudes have fallen even more sharply than for the Middle East ones.  According to a cable received by one major oil company, the African spot price has now fallen as low as $35.50 a barrel, almost $5 below official prices. **********Profit Margins Seen Disappearing **********The new lower prices ''are the kind of prices at which people are failing to sell oil,'' said Marshall Thomas, markets and pricing editor of Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, an influential trade publication. **********The spot market, which usually accounts for only about a tenth of oil in world trade, has become even thinner as a result of the lack of sellers. Indeed, Mr. Thomas estimates that even with the decline in crude prices, companies are having trouble breaking even on refining oil because of the growing oversupply. **********Further, companies are refusing to accept oil that they are guaranteed under previous contracts, an action that was unthinkable in the much tighter markets that existed just several months ago.  Industry sources say that the Ashland Oil Company recently refused some heavy crude from Mexico, while the Atlantic Richfield Company earlier acknowledged that it had rejected contract deliveries from Nigeria. **********Numerous other companies are said to be taking the less drastic step of telling producing countries they have logistical problems, such as refinery difficulties, that force them to delay purchases. Forcing Gasoline Prices Down **********The falling spot prices have already helped reduce gasoline prices about 2 cents a gallon in recent weeks, have facilitated the United States Government's accelerating spot crude purchases for its Strategic Petroleum Reserve and have damped the prospect that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will raise prices at its planned meeting in Geneva May 25. **********Energy analysts note that the major force behind the current glut and the steep drop in spot prices is Saudi Arabia, which is flooding the world with less expensive oil to force OPEC to reduce prices. **********This strategy appears to be based on growing fears in the kingdom that the price of oil is rising so fast that it will force Western countries to develop alternative energy sources and improved conservation well before the Saudis run out of oil. Other oil producers, with far less oil, have a greater interest in seeing prices rise as much as possible. Now at Saudi Arabia's Level **********Oil industry officials note that a spot price of $34 a barrel coincides with the $34 for which the Saudis recently decided to sell so-called war-relief crude. This oil, believed to total about 550,000 barrels daily, is being supplied to customers who had been purchasing crude from Iraq before the onset of its war with Iran. Analysts have suggested this is about the level the Saudis consider appropriate. **********As such, the $34 price would represent a compromise between the basic $32 that Saudi Arabia charges for most of the 10.3 million barrels it produces daily and the $36 base used by the rest of OPEC.  The significance of the $34 price, for which the Saudis seem clearly to have been responsible, is that the 13-nation group often uses spot prices as a basis for official prices. **********Perhaps the biggest beneficiary of the decline in spot prices has been the United States Government, which has increased its strategic oil purchases from 100,000 barrels a day in the fourth quarter to 300,000 barrels currently. The stated basis for the speedup has been national security. **********Recently, industry sources say, the Government has turned down 19 offers from sellers of crude oil. ''Effectively, what they are doing is gambling that the price will be lower later on,'' said a pricing expert with a major international oil company. U.S. Purchases Important **********If it were not for the United States Government purchases, spot prices would be even lower. That program has been almost the only factor working to keep prices up in the thin spot market, oil analysts say.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/24/world.main_headline: EVEN IN MEXICO, REAGAN TURNS HIS ATTENTION TO AWACS ISSUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/24/world.print_headline: EVEN IN MEXICO, REAGAN TURNS HIS ATTENTION TO AWACS ISSUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/24/world.body_text: **********President Reagan met with Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia here today, but by prior agreement both men reportedly refrained from mentioning the sale of Awacs aircraft to the Saudis. **********Representatives of the two nations have already discussed the Awacs issue ''to the limits of tolerance,'' a White House spokesman said.  Nonetheless, the President increasingly turned his attention from the conference here of 22 developing and industrialized nations to the coming Senate vote on the sale of the radar surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia. **********Mr. Reagan interrupted his participation in the conference today to telephone Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, to ask for his support on the Awacs issue. But Mr. Bumpers told Mr. Reagan that he was about to announce his opposition to the sale. **********Mr. Reagan's advisers insisted that the Administration came here determined not to press Prince Fahd for concessions granting the United States greater control over the Saudis' use of the planes in an effort to overcome Senate opposition to the sale. **********James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, also said that Mr. Reagan did not expect Prince Fahd to offer such concessions voluntarily to clear the way for Saudi purchase of the five Airborne Warning and Control System aircraft at a cost of $8.5 billion. **********The Senate is scheduled to vote on the sale Wednesday. A vote of 51 senators can block the sale, and the White House has acknowledged that it does not yet have enough committed votes to push it through.  The House has already voted against the sale. A Vow to 'Keep on Fighting' **********This morning, in his suite at the headquarters hotel for the conference, Mr. Reagan vowed ''to keep on fighting'' for votes in the Senate. ''I look forward to getting back Monday morning and going to work some more,'' he added. **********In the meeting with Prince Fahd, Mr. Reagan said Philip C. Habib, the President's special envoy, would return to the Middle East in the second week of November. Mr. Habib visited the area earlier this year to try to defuse the crisis over Syrian missiles in Lebanon and helped negotiate a cease-fire between Israeli and Palestinian forces along the Israeli-Lebanese border. **********David R. Gergen, the senior White House spokesman, said that the mission would involve maintaining the cease-fire in southern Lebanon and that Mr. Habib's trip was being timed to begin shortly after an Arab League meeting in early November. White House officials said the timing did not reflect concern about any renewed crisis in Lebanon. **********In addition to Prince Fahd, Mr. Reagan conferred today with two other leaders at the conference.He and President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania discussed their differences on seeking independence for South-West Africa, also called Namibia, which is administered by South Africa in defiance of United Nations resolutions. In another meeting, Mr. Reagan thanked President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria for that nation's help in freeing the American hostages in Iran. **********Mr. Benjedid told Mr. Reagan that Algeria intended to ''remain a truly nonaligned nation,'' Mr. Gergen said. Mr. Reagan pledged to continue United States economic assistance to Algeria, Mr. Gergen said. **********Since arriving here Wednesday, Mr. Reagan has had private meetings with leaders of 12 nations, and three more such meetings are scheduled before he leaves for Washington tomorrow morning. He has also participated in the four full sessions of the conference, which is seeking ways to narrow the economic gap between rich and poor nations. **********White House aides, faced with predictions from key senators that Mr. Reagan is losing the Awacs fight, worked hard today to protect the privacy of the President's meeting with Prince Fahd. **********Initially, Mr. Reagan's advisers planned to bar photographers from the President's sixth-floor suite while the Prince was there. Then it attempted to impose a ground rule that reporters at the photo session could not ask questions of the two leaders. **********A White House official said before today's meeting that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was opposed to placing restrictions on the sale. Some senators want the Saudis to agree to some American control over the use of the planes to insure that the classified equipment aboard does not fall into unfriendly hands and to insure that the planes are not used against Israel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.main_headline: Advertising; TIME TEAM PLANS CABLE MAGAZINE; ¸
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.print_headline: Advertising; TIME TEAM PLANS CABLE MAGAZINE; ¸
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.body_text: **********TIME INC., which is both the country's largest magazine publisher and cable systems operator, is apparently planning a new magazine to serve the nation's growing number of cable subscribers. **********It has assigned to the project the same team that brought out the highly successful People magazine - Richard B. Stolley, People's managing editor, and Richard J. Durrell, its publisher. **********Time, which also has interests in forest products and book publishing, may thus join a long list of publishers who have tried to cater both to consumers using electronic media and to the trade. Some have failed. **********Decisions on the makeup, content and publication frequency of Time's new product are still far down the pike. As Mr. Durrell said, ''We're starting at ground zero.'' **********A number of executives in the company were notified of the plans June 18 in a memo from Henry A. Grunwald, editor in chief, and Kelso Sutton, group vice president for magazines. It said that the the new project would be a joint research and development effort of the magazines division and the video groups. **********The former is made up of Time, Life, Fortune, Sports Illustrated, Money and Discover; the later mostly of Home Box Office and American Television and Communications. **********The cable portion of the business is proportionately more profitable than the print, according to the 1979 annual report, which shows that the magazines had $70 million in profits on $680 million of revenue, while video did almost that well - $69 million in profits - on revenues of $299 million. **********Another publisher, On Cable Publications in Norwalk, Conn., is already serving Time's Manhattan Cable system, and is contracted to serve building franchises with its monthly guide, On Cable. **********According to Peter Funt, On Cable's editor and publisher, he has contracts serving certain Time systems that preclude the distribution of other magazines. His publication is a local cable program guide in a national wraparound taking both national and local advertising. Its circulation is 290,000 and Mr. Funt believes it will be 1.5 million by the end of next year. **********Mr. Funt thinks that his is the only purely cable consumer magazine, but notes that there are others like Home Video and Video Review that cover the whole spectrum, games and all. **********One recent casualty in this field was Panorama. A classy magazine for regular TV viewers, it began with the February 1980 issue and closed with this month's. Triangle, its publisher, said that it was a success with advertisers but not with readers, gaining a circualtion of only about 100,000. Cable TV was another consumer magazine that died after three issues. Triangle introduced a cable/pay TV guide into New Mexico and El Paso, Tex., in February 1980, and is still ''refining'' it. **********On the trade side, there are such publications as Multichannel News, Cablevision, TVC, View, Cable Marketing and Cable Age.  People magazine, by the way, carried an estimated $106 million in advertising revenues last year and is ahead of projections for the first half of 1981. It stands sixth in ad revenues and fourth in ad pages among American magazines. It is delivering 2.4 million copies a week.

Take an outspoken, Budapest-born securities analyst and stock promoter named Andrew G. Racz. **********Roughly five feet six inches tall - it is hard to judge because of his obstreperous hair - Mr. Racz has no trouble standing out in a crowd.  His style might be called dishelveled flamboyance; his rumpled clothing gives him a scholarly air, while his cherubic face flashes with wry grins and startling pronouncements. When he flourishes one of his Don Diego cigars to make a point, Mr. Racz looks like a symphony conductor whose oboes are in revolt. "All Hungarians are 'Mad Hungarians,' don't you know that?" he says in a thick paprikash accent. **********Mr. Racz (rhymes with "cats") has the Street buzzing because of two controversial deals in which he has played behind-the-scenes roles.  One is the struggle over control of the Bache Group Inc., one of the nation's largest brokerage firms. The other is a struggle for control of the Hardwicke Companies, a New York-based enterprise with interests in a resort hotel, two safari parks, and such restaurants as Maxwell's Plum and Tavern on the Green. It also has hopes of building a casino in Atlantic City. **********Mr. Racz currently runs a division of Philips, Appel & Walden. But now, at age 42, he plans to set up his own brokerage and portfolio management operations. **********All three developments are related.  Mr Racz writes provocative, insightful studies of undervalued stocks. The reports are based on tape recordings of interviews he has with a company's management and tend to be enthusiastically bullish. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/busin.print_headline: Peru Lifts Price Of Fuel, Food
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/busin.body_text: **********The Peruvian Government increased the price of fuel and basic foodstuffs today by an average of 48 percent as part of a policy to eliminate subsidies. **********Gasoline prices rose 29 percent, although Peru exports oil. **********Other increases covered the price of gas and electricity, and the cost of staple foods such as bread, rice, milk and sugar. **********The price of loans also rose sharply, in an effort to bring the cost of credit in line with the rate of inflation.  In a television address last night, Prime Minister Manuel Ulloa said the food and gasoline subsidies would have cost almost $900 million this year. He said the Government would continue to subsidize some products and would institute a system of food coupons for the poorest classes. **********Mr. Ulloa partly blamed a disastrous three-year drought that has slashed agricultural production for the price increases.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/15/busin.main_headline: F.T.C. IS ASSAILED ON MOBIL STRATEGY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/15/busin.print_headline: F.T.C. IS ASSAILED ON MOBIL STRATEGY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/15/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Trade Commission has taken an unprecedented step in an antitrust suit filed Friday by listing in detail the terms under which the Mobil Corporation could take over the Marathon Oil Company without antitrust problems, a Congressman charged today. **********The F.T.C. petition, filed in Federal District Court in Cleveland, asks for an injunction against the takeover unless Mobil divests itself of the transportation, storage and marketing assets of Marathon ''in such a manner as to maintain the divested entity in viable competition.'' **********At a hearing today, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, challenged Thomas J. Campbell, director of the commission's Bureau of Competition, to show that the commission had ever offered such an alternative in past antitrust suits. **********Mr. Campbell, appearing before a joint meeting of the House and Senate Commerce committees, said there had been similar cases involving other industries but that he knew of none in the oil industry. **********Giving 'Green Light' Charged **********Representative Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, charged that the commission and the Justice Department had given industry a ''green light; you have played a role in the extraordinary wave of merger activity.'' **********Mr. Gore said the provisions outlined by the commission in its suit against Mobil would be the key to a Mobil takeover.  ''The public should be aware the blueprint was written at the F.T.C.,'' he said. Mr. Gore said the alternative outlined by the commission ''says to the middle-tier oil company it's O.K. to buy up reserves as long as you sell off other assets.'' (In New York, Herbert Schmertz, Mobil's vice president for public affairs, said, ''We fail to understand why Congressmen Dingell and Gore would be critical of a Government agency which encourages compliance with the law.'') **********Mr. Campbell said the commission had determined that the only aspects of the merger that would be considered an antitrust violation were in the areas cited for divestiture. Overlaps in 18 Areas **********In marketing of wholesale gasoline, Mr. Campbell said the commission found significant ''overlaps'' between Mobil and Marathon in 18 metropolitan areas, mainly in the Middle West. **********He said the commission would insist that any company taking over Marathon's marketing, transportation and storage assets be capable of continuing those operations. **********Mobil, which faces other court obstacles in its pursuit of Marathon, has announced an greement to sell these Marathon assets to the Amerada Hess Corporation in the event Mobil wins the takeover battle against the U.S. Steel Corporation, the rival bidder for Marathon. U.S. Steel's bid, endorsed by Marathon, is valued at $6.3 billion, and Mobil's at $6.5 billion. **********Witnesses at a House subcommittee hearing last week questioned whether Amerada Hess, a New York-based oil company, had the crude oil sources to supply the Marathon network. Yates Field Key Target **********Mobil's primary target in its proposed takeover is Marathon's nearly 50 percent stake in the Yates oilfield in west Texas, whose oil and gas reserves are Marathon's most valuable asset. **********Last week, stymied in its takeover attempt by U.S. Steel's apparently more successful bid, Mobil announced plans to buy up to 25 percent of U.S. Steel stock, a move that industry analysts viewed as a way for Mobil to gain bargaining power in a bid to acquire Marathon indirectly. **********In answer to a question from Mr. Dingell, Mr. Campbell said that, if Mobil tried to get control of U.S. Steel, the commission ''would be faced with all the overlaps we already face in the Marathon takeover as well as possible overlaps between Mobil and U.S. Steel.'' **********William F. Baxter, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said such a move would touch off another investigation by his department, but he declined to say whether such an investigation had already begun. Reconsideration Sought **********In Cleveland, attorneys for Mobil today asked Judge John M. Manos of the United States District Court there to reconsider his decision that Marathon's takeover by Mobil would violate antitrust laws, particularly in the sale of gasoline in the Middle West. Mobil is also appealing Judge Manos's ruling to the United States Court of Appeals in Cincinnati, with hearings scheduled before the appeals court on Thursday. **********Marathon, meanwhile, said that it had asked the appeals court to dissolve a temporary restraining order imposed last Friday against U.S. Steel's purchase of Marathon stock. The appeals court granted the order while it considered another appeal sought by Mobil, this one objecting to a ruling by Judge Joseph P. Kinneary in United States District Court in Columbus. **********Judge Kinneary had upheld the legality of two options that Marathon had given to U.S. Steel to encourage it to bid for Marathon. Marathon said that it asked the appeals court to dissolve the restraining order on the completion of a hearing this Thursday of Mobil's arguments in the case. **********Terms of the appeals court decision provide that Marathon's stockholders have the right to take back their shares of either U.S.  Steel or Mobil for five business days after the appeals court rules.  U.S. Steel, which already has received 90 percent of Marathon's shares in response to its offer to pay $125 a share for 51 percent of Marathon, might therefore be unable to buy the shares at least until Dec. 24, if the court rules the day of the hearing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/16/world.main_headline: 2 U.S. AWACS IMMEDIATELY BEGIN PATROLS IN EGYPT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/16/world.print_headline: 2 U.S. AWACS IMMEDIATELY BEGIN PATROLS IN EGYPT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/16/world.body_text: **********Two United States airborne surveillance planes arrived over Egyptian airspace today and immediately began patrolling Egypt's vast western desert, which borders on Libya. **********A scheduled reception for the arrival of the two Awacs, or Airborne Warning and Control System aircraft, did not take place because the planes were immediately put into service. **********Officials of the Ministry of Information had invited the press to attend the reception, and the American Embassy here also sent a delegation for an arrival ceremony that included a small Egyptian honor guard. **********There was no immediate explanation of why the ceremony was canceled. Speculation ranged from a contention that it should never have been called in the first place to assertions that there might be a problem on the border that separates Egypt from its foe, Libya. **********On Loan to Egypt **********The Awacs are on loan to Egypt and are manned by American military personnel. They were offered to President Hosni Mubarak, who yesterday assumed the office of Anwar el-Sadat, who was assassinated nine days ago. **********The offer was meant as a demonstration of the Reagan Administration's support of Mr. Mubarak.  After the funeral of Mr. Sadat on Saturday, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said American arms deliveries to Egypt would be stepped up.  But Egypt is not scheduled to receive the Awacs radar surveillance planes. **********Five of the Awacs are scheduled to be sold to Saudi Arabia in a deal that is strongly opposed by Israel and by many members of Congress. No Objections From Israel **********According to reports from Tel Aviv, Israel has no objection to the presence of the two planes in Egypt, with which it has a peace treaty. **********An Israeli Government official was quoted by Reuters as saying, ''We have no objection to the use of the Awacs in Egypt because they are to be operated by American crews, remain in American ownership and we understand will only remain there for a limited time.'' **********During Mr. Haig's visit here, the Secretary and Mr. Mubarak discussed the situation in the Sudan, where Libya has been making sorties into towns on the border with Chad. Mr. Haig also met with the Sudanese President, Gaafar al-Nimeiry, who was in Cairo to attend the Sadat funeral. **********Mr. Haig told newsmen then that the United States would also speed up arms deliveries to the Sudan. Weizman Visits Mubarak **********Mr. Mubarak began his second day as Egypt's President with a heavy schedule that included a visit from Israel's former Minister of Defense, Ezer Weizman. Mr. Weizman, like Mr. Mubarak a former commander of his country's air force, became a close friend of Mr.  Sadat after they met during the President's historic visit to Jerusalem in 1977. **********In a brief interview before he returned to Israel, Mr. Weizman said his visit was a private one ''to pay my respects to Mr. Sadat, to the memory of a great man.'' He laid a wreath at Mr. Sadat's grave. **********A report from Israel said Mr. Weizman had been barred from the official Israeli delegation that attended Mr. Sadat's funeral on Saturday because of a strong dislike between him and Prime Minister Menachem Begin. **********Mr. Mubarak has reappointed all the members of Mr. Sadat's Cabinet and has retained the governors of Egypt's 26 governorates as part of his attempt to insure continuity. For the time being the post of Vice President, which Mr. Mubarak held, is vacant. Questions Still Unanswered **********A Government investigation into Mr. Sadat's assassination during a military parade is continuing, and there are several major questions still unanswered. One is whether the security around Mr. Sadat was lax in responding to the sudden departure from the parade of men dressed as soldiers who began firing and throwing hand grenades at the reviewing stand. Another is whether the attack was the work of a small group of Moslem fundamentalists or whether the attackers were part of a broader consipiracy to bring down the Sadat regime. **********A ranking Egyptian official said that for the time being Mr.  Mubarak would concentrate on insuring continuity in the Government but that in time he would assert his own style. **********Mr. Mubarak has said several times that he will continue Egypt's strong links with the United States and will pursue a comprehensive Middle East peace as outlined in the Camp David accord with Israel.  Yesterday in his inaugural speech, Mr. Mubarak said he was strongly committed to carrying out the policies of Mr. Sadat.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; The Thatcher Plan's Failure
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; The Thatcher Plan's Failure
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.body_text: **********A SPECTER is haunting the Reagan Administration: Thatcherism. The riots in Liverpool this week, stemming partly from the worst unemployment Britain has experienced since the Depression of the 1930's, are grim evidence of the failure of what was once regarded as a brilliant innovation in economic policy. **********When Mrs. Thatcher became Prime Minister in May 1979, she was the darling of conservatives on both sides of the Atlantic. Today, she faces a revolt in her own party and has been disowned by the Reaganites in Washington, who say she departed from and made a mess of what initially was a correct solution to the twin problems of inflation and industrial stagnation. **********But was her fault one of execution or were there inherent inconsistencies and contradictions in the Thatcher program that the Reagan Administration is on the way to repeating? **********The Thatcher plan certainly began with close parallels to the Reagan program: **********- A commitment to ''monetarism,'' the doctrine that holds that the way to stop inflation is to reduce the growth of the money supply to a rate equal to the potential growth of the economy. Mrs. Thatcher elected to do this gradually: The Bank of England, under the domination of her Government, would reduce the rate of growth of the chosen monetary aggregate called ''sterling M-3,'' currency in circulation plus sterling-denominated demand and time deposits in British commercial banks, to an annual rate of 9 percent in 1980-81 and to 6 percent in 1983-84. **********- The real value of Government spending - total outlays corrected for inflation - was to be cut. The money the Government needed to borrow from the public to cover its debts and those of local authorities and public corporations would be scaled down to 7 billion in 1980-81 for openers. **********- Marginal income tax rates would be cut sharply to spur savings and productivity growth, with the biggest cuts both absolutely and proportionately going to those in the higher income brackets. **********How faithfully did Mrs. Thatcher carry out her plan? On monetary policy she has striven to tighten up the money supply. It is true that sterling M-3 overshot its target but this resulted largely from removing the so-called corset from the commercial banks, the special deposit regulations that had limited the extent to which the banks could increase their interest-bearing deposits. However, the money supply narrowly defined, M-1, consisting of currency and demand deposits, was held to a mere 3 percent rate of growth during the first 12 months after Mrs. Thatcher took office and an 8 percent rate thereafter. **********The clearest indication of tight money was the sharp rise in interest rates. The outflow of funds from London to New York, attracted by still higher interest rates, helped tighten money further, despite Government plans to make more funds available by bringing down public-sector borrowing. **********In this Mrs. Thatcher failed. She quickly put through cuts in marginal income tax rates, bringing down the top rate on compensation income to 60 percent from 83 percent and the bottom rate to 30 percent from 33. And she cut the top rate on investment income to 75 percent from 98 percent. At the same time, to promote the shift from consumption to savings, the Government nearly doubled the value added tax, a kind of sales tax, to 15 percent from 8 percent. **********Sharply rising interest rates pushed the economy into a deep slump, and the budget fell deeper into deficit. To curb the growing public borrowing requirement, the Government raised excise taxes on tobacco, alcohol, gasoline, diesel fuel, road vehicles and other items. **********Government spending kept climbing, despite Mrs. Thatcher's efforts at belt-tightening. She imposed her steepest cuts on public-sector investment items, thereby aggravating the problem of inflation. But instead of realizing her initial plan to bring down public borrowing to 7 billion in 1980-81, the Thatcher Government ran its borrowing requirement up to 13.5 billion, or 6 percent of the gross national product, one of the highest in the world. **********Thus, Mrs. Thatcher's fundamental mistake has been to try to cure stagflation by combining a tight monetary policy with a loose fiscal policy. She has incurred big deficits that forced the Government to be a heavy competitor for scarce private savings, forcing up both nominal and real interest rates. **********This has produced an extraordinary slump in production and employment. The jobless rate has doubled, to more than 11 percent, from 5.4 percent when Mrs. Thatcher took office two years ago. **********With the slump, inflation has fallen to low double-digit numbers, but the high interest rates on both Government and private bonds reflect the pessimism of the financial markets about the prospects for solving the problem of British inflation. . **********The recent behavior of interest rates and the securities markets in New York reflect similar apprehension that the Reagan monetary and fiscal policies have more in common with those of the Thatcher Government than the Administration here is willing to acknowledge.  Whether the Administration can still benefit from the mistakes of the Thatcher Government will be examined in a second column.
