https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; New Talent Is Hired At Muller Jordan Weiss
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/busin.body_text: **********A lot has been going on at Muller Jordan Weiss that could affect the future of the agency. There is new business, about $3 million worth of it, but mostly there are two new people, young or youngish packaged-goods hot shots. **********The most recent arrival, who came in last month to the $32-millionclass agency, is Robert E. Polansky, 35-year-old self-confessed entrepreneur, whose agency hopping after Tufts and Columbia Business School was aimed at experience more than money. He is senior vice president and managing director. Some say he could be the next president, but James T. Jordan is not among them. **********Mr. Polansky joins George H. Hanley, 43, who was a November arrival and is a senior vice president for account services.  According to William Nightingale, 49, senior vice president-media director, who was in on the search, young Mr. Polansky, a Bay State native, is ''a tiger, a fighter, a demanding Young Turk.'' Mr.  Nightingale, who helped found Smith & Toback and Nakano, McGlone, Nightingale, is convinced that he helps fill the agency's need for ''young, big-agency marketing guys.'' **********''I would think we would be at $50 million in two years,'' said Mr. Polansky, who thinks big.  ''But I'm not going to do it all myself,'' he said later, ''I'm only the cutting edge.'' He worked on General Foods business at Benton & Bowles, his first agency, then switched to the William Esty Company for Colgate-Palmolive experience, next went to Ogilvy & Mather for insights into the way Lever does business. Still more marketing expertise was supplied by General Foods during a tour at Young & Rubicam, and finally a little spirits aid came from Southern Comfort at McCann-Erickson. **********Mr. Hanley is a veteran of two Colgate shops, Ted Bates & Company, where he worked for 12 years, and Norman, Craig & Kummel.  The two will find the accounts at M.J.W. a change of pace. It has such clients as McGraw-Hill for corporate advertising; Chubb & Sons insurance, Levolor Lorentzen for window blinds, and Monsanto. Also Stroehmann Bread, ABC Radio, John Blair and Stanley Blacker apparel. **********The way Mr. Nightingale and Mr. Polansky have it figured - and they explained it yesterday morning in the Plaza's Palm Court - they and their new associates should bring in a lot of new business, which will lead to increased compensation, which will allow them to buy the agency from the three partners at that future time when the partners decide to step out. **********In addition to Mr. Jordan, 55-year-old president of the 27-year-old shop, they are Frank B. Muller, 54, executive vice president, and Andrew M. Weiss, 56 and also an executive vice president. They are also the board of directors. **********The new 1980 business is Penfield Retail Services, a chain of apparel stores in 13 states in the South, Middle West and Southwest; Oleg Cassini National Consumer Program for an umbrella campaign to cover all men's wear and leather goods produced by licensees; Wallachs Surgical Devices; more business from Monsanto, and, to prove things are looking up, Levolor ceilings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/14/world.main_headline: IMQUIRY IS PALNNED ON LONDON RIOTS AS VIOLENCE FADES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/14/world.print_headline: IMQUIRY IS PALNNED ON LONDON RIOTS AS VIOLENCE FADES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/14/world.body_text: **********As a measure of calm returned to the Brixton section of south London today, the Government set up a judicial inquiry to investigate the causes of the weekend of looting, firebombing and violent clashes with the police. **********But at the same time, Home Secretary William Whitelaw declared sternly in Parliament that ''the police will continue to do their duty to maintain the law on the streets of London.'' **********In two nights of rioting in the area, which has one of Britain's greatest concentrations of blacks, 200 people were arrested and several dozen people were injured. Nine policemen were still hospitalized today, recovering from their injuries. **********There were renewed but very sporadic outbreaks of violence in the district tonight. In two incidents youths hurled bricks and bottles at policemen, but the disorder was not in any way comparable to that of Saturday or Sunday night. **********With more than 100 buildings and several dozen vehicles damaged over the weekend, it was one of the worst disorders that Britain had experienced in years, and to a people unaccustomed to street violence, it was deeply shocking. 'Absolutely Stunning News' **********''Stunning news, absolutely stunning,'' murmured a schoolteacher who watched the weekend television reports in horror. ''To think of this happening in London.'' **********Although most of the rioters were black, there were also white youths among them, and community leaders insisted that economic depression and general hostility toward the police, rather than race, had been the principal underlying causes of the violence. **********Brixton, which was the destination of waves of immigrants from the West Indies 30 years ago, has more recently been a focus of Britain's worsening race problem, and relations between young black men and the police, almost all of whom are white, have been particularly tense. **********A dilapidated residential neighborhood two miles south of central London, Brixton has a rate of unemployment much higher than the national average of 10 percent, and for many of its young people, white as well as black, the job future seems bleak. **********But Mr. Whitelaw said, ''Unemployment is very serious but it never can be and never should be made an excuse for violence.'' Retired Jurist to Conduct Inquiry **********The inquiry he set up, after extensive consultation with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, will be conducted by Lord Scarman, a distinguished retired jurist. Its mission will be ''to inquire urgently into the serious disorder in Brixton, and to report, with the power to make recommendations.'' **********The opposition Labor Party generally welcomed the inquiry, but it said the hearings should also consider ''the breakdown of the relationship between the police and public'' in the area. **********In a grim round of post-mortems on the disorders, a number of Brixton leaders, including white people, said that there had been a sharp increase in the police presence in their community in recent years, heightening violence. **********In response, Sir David McNee, the metropolitan police commissioner, said that Brixton had, increasingly, ''a very bad record of crime, particularly street robbery,'' which could only be combated by a stronger police presence.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/05/busin.body_text: **********The price of silver dipped below the $10-an-ounce mark yesterday for the first time in almost two years as the metal continued to be buffeted by high interest rates, a strong dollar and the impression that inflation was moderating. **********Silver for current delivery on the Commodity Exchange Inc. in New York at one point fell to $9.95 a troy ounce before closing at $10.10, down 15 1/2 cents from Wednesday's close. **********Gold and many other commodities also fell because of higher interest rates and the strong dollar, which make it expensive either to finance commodity holdings or to borrow money to speculate in commodity futures. **********''The background in terms of a strong dollar just makes it extremely difficult to want to hold precious metals in which there is no return,'' said Jack Boyd, a silver analyst with the investment firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. **********Some analysts also cite the threat that large silver supplies might be dumped on the market, which would depress prices.  The $9.95-an-ounce silver price was the lowest on the Comex since August 1979. Amid frenetic speculation, the price peaked at $52.50 an ounce on Jan. 21, 1980, then began to fall amid high interest rates and a general slump in the commodities markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/world.main_headline: HIJACKERS FORCE INDONESIAN PLANE WITH 57 TO THAILAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/world.print_headline: HIJACKERS FORCE INDONESIAN PLANE WITH 57 TO THAILAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/world.body_text: **********Seven armed assailants demanding the release of 20 Indonesian prisoners hijacked an Indonesian airliner yesterday with 57 people aboard and forced the pilot to land here. Early this morning Thai officials announced that President Suharto of Indonesia had agreed to the hijackers' demand. **********They said his message was received by telephone from Indonesia.  There was no immediate word of a response from the hijackers.  (United Press International reported that the hijackers had stiffened their terms and had demanded that Indonesia free a total of 80 prisoners. U.P.I. said they made the new demand after hearing the report that President Suharto had agreed to free the original 20.) **********Indonesian airline officials said their country's chief negotiator with the hijackers, Air Marshal Sugiri, had been told that President Suharto was also prepared to provide a DC-10 with long-range flight ability to take the hijackers to Sri Lanka, as they had demanded. **********Charn Angsuchote of the Thai Prime Minister's office said that Mr.  Suharto had asked negotiators to tell the hijackers that he would release the prisoners but that he would need time to assemble them from various prisons and find a country that would accept them. **********Three Americans were reported to be among the hostages. One was identified by Thai officials as an employee of the Milchem Company in Indonesia with the last name of Schneider. The names of the other Americans were not immediately known. Plane Seized Over Indonesia **********The hijackers commandeered the Garuda Indonesian Airways DC-9 jet on a domestic flight and forced it to Penang, Malaysia, where they demanded and received food for 60 people, fuel and maps. **********Malaysian officials said the hijackers had freed one of their captives, a young woman who had become ''very sick.'' She was not identified. **********The hijackers, reportedly armed with grenades and small arms, at one point threatened to blow up the plane if the prisoners were not freed. They also demanded passage to Sri Lanka. **********Officials in Sri Lanka said hours before Mr. Suharto's announcement that they did not want to get involved in the hijacking.  As soon as the plane landed in Thailand, troops with machine guns surrounded it and isolated it in the airport cargo area.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.main_headline: A World to Feed:; First article of a series appearing from time to time.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.print_headline: DEMAND OUTPACES WORLD FOOD SUPPLY; A World to Feed:; First article of a series appearing from time to time.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.body_text: **********The world food situation is like a basket half empty, half full.  On the bountiful side, for the last three decades global food production has steadily increased, slightly outstripping population growth and enabling more people to eat better than at any time in history. **********This year, world grain production is expected to set historic records, permitting some rebuilding of world food stockpiles. India, once written off as a hopeless case, has almost tripled its food production in the last 30 years. Laborers in the Soviet Union expect a regular portion of meat, and Chinese peasants no longer fear the killing famines that in the past have swept over the land. 500 Million Suffer Malnutrition **********Despite the real progress, however, there are still more hungry people in the world than ever before - both in absolute numbers and as a percentage of total world population. The rising cost of food has contributed to this situation. **********By most estimates, more than 500 million people - roughly one out of every nine - suffer from serious malnutrition today, compared with 100 million to 200 million - one out of every 14 to 25 people - in the 1950's. Mismanagement Adds to Woes **********Refugee camps are still filled with wide-eyed children with swollen bellies. Millions of malnourished adults in Asia and Africa are still doomed to live and work far below their normal capabilities. And even in relatively prosperous countries such as Poland, economic mismanagement has produced shortages of food so severe that the population has taken to the streets. **********The coexistence of bounty and want is, in short, as stark as it ever was. The reason is that food production has not kept up with rising incomes around the world and those income gains are not being equitably distributed. **********As more countries - particularly the rapidly developing middleincome countries - and wealthier people in those countries gain in purchasing power, they consume more food. This in turn puts pressure on food prices, and means that poorer people everywhere have a harder time buying enough to eat. **********''There has been significant progress in a few developing countries,'' John Mellor, head of the International Food Policy Research Institute in Washington, said in a recent interview. ''But the gains do mean that the poorest people will be worse off. It's a good development, but it is increasing inequalities.'' 'Ghost of Malthus Not Buried' **********''The ghost of Malthus,'' as Shahid J. Burki of the World Bank recently put it, ''is not buried yet.'' But the fact remains that the doomsday theorists who warned only a few years ago that a ''human tidal wave'' would swamp the world's capacity to produce food have so far been proved wrong. Between 1960 and 1980, thanks to the Green Revolution's new seeds and fertilizers, global corn and wheat yields have jumped by 50 percent, and rice yields by 30 percent. **********As a result, by the late 1970's global per-capita food consumption had increased to 108 percent of the minimum essential for good health, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, compared with slightly below 100 percent in the early 1950's. Many Uncertainties Remain **********What are the chances of extending these gains, and more important, of translating them into food for the millions with empty stomachs?  Will the 1980's bring a more secure world food system and more equal distribution of food, or a recurrence of the periodic shortages, price instabilities and inequities of the 1970's? **********The answers to these questions are as uncertain as the weather.  But most international food experts agree that in the next decade the world will be entering a new era, characterized more by food shortages than food surpluses, by widely fluctuating prices, and by a steadily widening gap between those who have plenty and those who go hungry. At worst, a disaster to dwarf the food crisis of 1973-74 is seen as a possibility. **********A number of new stresses on the world food system are responsible for the insecurities that lie ahead. The most important structural changes are these: **********- Agricultural productivity in the United States seems to be leveling off, and idle cropland in this country has virtually disappeared. Because the United States now supplies more than half of the grain in world trade, this could mean less food available in the future for deficit countries. **********- The United States may also be forced to curtail its food exports because of accelerating soil erosion and the pressure of foreign demand on domestic food prices. Some experts, such as Walter P.  Falcon, director of Stanford University's Food Research Center, believe that ''the 1980's will almost surely see a reduction in the rate of growth of export supplies from the United States.'' **********- Even if exports of food from North America could continue expanding indefinitely, many believe that the very dependence of the rest of the world on a single region is a danger. According to the World Bank's Mr. Burki, if a drop of more than 10 percent in the North American grain crop coincided with a shortfall somewhere else, the result would be ''disaster.'' **********- World food prices now rise much faster in times of scarcity, because of the spreading tendency of food-importing countries, notably Japan, the European Economic Community and the Soviet Union, to keep their domestic grain prices fixed. This means that, even when global food supplies shrink, consumers in these countries can continue to purchase the same amount of food and producers have no incentives to hold stocks or increase production. As a result, supplies do not adjust, international prices go higher than they would otherwise and the poorest food importers suffer. **********- The improvement in living standards and the growing demand for food around the world have put pressure on food prices, making it harder for the poorest countries to import their food needs. Many Eating More Meat **********Rapidly developing, middle-income countries such as Mexico, South Korea and Thailand are eating more meat than ever before. The Eastern European bloc - with the exception of hard-pressed Poland - has decided to maintain levels of food consumption through good years and bad. And the Middle East oil producers have adopted Western diets with abandon, increasing their food imports from 3.1 million metric tons, valued at $350 million, in 1970 to 15 million tons, valued at $3 billion, in 1980. **********Behind these new consumers looms the enormous shadow of China. Its food imports tripled in the period from 1961 to 1977 and are still growing. In all, these purchasers are putting great pressures on the international grain markets and, consequently, on prices. **********As a result of these trends, world grain prices are increasingly unstable. In the 1970's, world wheat price fluctuations were more than seven times greater than in the 1960's, and swings in rice prices were more than twice as extreme. Virtually all the authorities expect prices in the 1980's to be even more unpredictable, adding to the insecurity of the poor importing countries and of food producers and consumers in the United States, one of the few countries that allows international grain prices to be fully reflected in its domestic market. **********Since the World Food Conference in 1974, a major goal of the antihunger movement has been the establishment of an international wheat reserve system to stabilize prices, so that poor countries could be assured of affording food imports in cases of emergency. But negotiations on a global grain reserve were adjourned without success in 1979, and the prospects for such a system being established now appear to be nil. A Modest Wheat Reserve **********In late 1980, the United States did act to guarantee that a modest Government-held wheat reserve of 4 million metric tons would be established to backstop shipments of food aid in cases of severe food shortages. The United States is also committed to a minimum annual level of 4.47 million tons of food aid under the Food Aid Convention of 1980, which guarantees that at least 7.6 million tons of food aid a year will be available from exporting countries as aid. **********Current food aid levels are about 9 million tons a year, of which about 6 million tons are from the United States. That amount is negligible compared with the needs of the food-deficit areas, however. According to the F.A.O., 72 low-income, developing countries received some 8.1 million tons of food aid in 1980, compared with import requirements of some 17.7 million tons of wheat, 4.6 million tons of coarse grain, and 4.8 million tons of rice over the 1980-81 crop year. **********The poorest countries will obviously have to go into the commercial markets to cover their food deficits. To enable them to afford emergency purchases, the International Monetary Fund recently established a criterion for lending that would enable poorer countries to receive additional financing from the fund when their food imports rose above a base level. This could make an additional $500 million to $700 million available to food-short countries. **********To keep such an influx of funds from pushing prices even higher, and to guarantee that the poorest countries would have access to grain purchases in tight periods, several international food groups, including the F.A.O., the International Fund for Agricultural Development and the World Food Council, have proposed an international food security reserve. A 9- to 18-Million-Ton Reserve **********The reserve, which could be from 9 to 18 million tons in size, would assure developing countries that they would not be squeezed out of the world food market if prices skyrocket during a shortage.  Grain exporters would promise to make available to the poorest countries in times of scarcity an amount of wheat based on their normal commercial import purchases. The sales would be at roughly commercial rates, although a ceiling on the price, based on long-term market trends, would be set. **********Over the longer run, however, the only real world food security is an increase in food production in the deficit countries. The World Food Council, a United Nations policy group set up in 1974 to monitor international food security, is working with some 50 developing countries to establish national food plans. **********Food experts agree that greatly increased investment in technical assistance, irrigation networks and agricultural research will be necessary in the coming decades if the world is ever to achieve freedom from hunger. The World Bank, the chief international lending agency for such projects, is now putting 30 percent of its resources into agriculture, 80 percent of which is going directly into food production. The $1 billion International Fund for Agricultural Development, based in Rome and heavily financed by the Arab oil producers, is also devoting all of its resources to agricultural development. **********These investments are only a drop in the bucket compared with the world's need, however. World Bank calculations indicate that an investment of $600 billion in developing countries, largely in expensive irrigation systems, will be required over the next 10 years just to maintain food supplies at present levels of hunger. **********No one is sure where that vast sum will be coming from, or whether the agricultural development that is necessary will be accomplished before the next poor harvest years. **********''Say the economic policies in the United States don't work, and we get heavy inflation here, and then a bad crop year or two,'' Mr.  Mellor of the International Food Policy Research Institute speculated recently. ''Food prices here soar, and the Government decides to slap on an export embargo, sending global food prices through the roof.  What would a Tanzania or a Bangladesh - which already spends 80 percent of its export earnings on food imports - do then? That's the disaster scenario, and it's a perfectly possible eventuality.'' **********Next: The human cost of worldwide malnutrition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/24/world.main_headline: U.S. APPLAUDS SEOUL FOR SPARING OPPOSITION LEADER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/24/world.print_headline: U.S. APPLAUDS SEOUL FOR SPARING OPPOSITION LEADER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/24/world.body_text: **********The United States welcomed today the decision by President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea to commute to life imprisonment the death sentence imposed last fall on Kim Dae Jung, the opposition political leader. **********''We believe this action will contribute positively to the strengthening of relations between the United States and South Korea,'' William J. Dyess, the acting State Department spokesman, said. **********President Chun's commutation took place early today shortly after the South Korean Supreme Court had affirmed the death penalty for sedition against Mr. Kim, who was convicted last September. The fate of the 56-year old political figure became a major issue between the Carter Administration and President Chun. **********Shortly after Ronald Reagan won the Presidential election, his aides disclosed that they had also advised President Chun that Mr.  Kim's execution could harm future relations between Seoul and Washington. Chun to Visit Washington **********Two days ago, as one of its first actions, the Administration announced that Mr. Chun would be Mr. Reagan's guest for talks on Feb. 2. **********State Department officials said then that while there was no firm pledge from Mr. Chun to commute Mr. Kim's death sentence, they assumed that the South Korean leader would not have asked to be received in Washington unless he was prepared to resolve that issue. **********Under the Carter Administration, the State Department had described as ''farfetched'' the original charges against Mr. Kim, who was a presidential candidate in 1971. **********But Mr. Dyess, speaking under instructions from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., said he would not comment on the charges or on South Korean court procedures. **********Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, praised the commutation decision but said he felt life imprisonment for Mr. Kim was still too severe. Expected To Be Freed Later **********Some South Korean political opponents of Mr. Chun said today that they expected Mr. Kim would be freed later this year and permitted to accept invitations to live in the United States. **********Mr. Chun, a former general, assumed the presidency last August and is seeking to be elected President in voting late next month.  President Chun had summoned South Korea's State Council, the equivalent of a Cabinet, to discuss the Supreme Court's verdict.  He said, according to his spokesman in Seoul, that Mr. Kim had ''endangered national security by violating the laws of this country, especially by forming an antistate organization and conspiring for insurrection.'' Those charges, he said, had been proved in previous trials. **********But he said the State Council should approve clemency ''to end confrontational politics'' in South Korea and because of requests from ''friendly nations and persons,'' a reference to public statements in the United States, Japan and Western European countries. Kim Said to Be Repentant **********Mr. Kim had also submitted a petition in which he expressed repentance, apologized to the South Korean people and appealed ''for magnanimous and generous consideration'' for himself and 11 co-defendents, the President said. **********''The basic policy of this Government is to treat magnanimously anyone who repents of his wrongdoing, regardless of the gravity of the crime or his previous ideology,'' he said. **********Mr. Chun also reduced the prison sentences of the 11 other defendents.  State Department officials said that Mr. Chun, who seized power in the aftermath of the assassination of President Park Chung Hee in October 1979, is striving to improve his image at home and abroad. **********Mr. Chun last week called for talks with President Kim II Sung of North Korea, but North Korea rejected the invitation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/01/world.body_text: **********The Labor Party voted by a large majority today in favor of a policy of unilateral nuclear disarmament, including the shutdown of all American nuclear bases on British soil or in British waters. **********Although a resolution to that effect fell narrowly short of passage by a two-thirds margin, and thus failed to become part of the party's formal program, the vote was an indication that such an action continues to dominate Labor thinking despite the comeback staged by the right wing at this week's annual party conference. **********In the event of a Labor victory in the general election expected in 1983, a broad disarmam ent program now appears to be a distinct possibility. Michael Foot, the party leader, who would become Prime Minister if Labor won, is a longtime supporte r of unilateral disarmament and restated his conviction in ri nging terms here yesterday. **********The Labor decision came at a time of mounting resistance to nuclear weapons in a number of other countries of Western Europe, including Norway, Belgium, the Netherlands and West Germany. U.S. Role Questioned **********As in other European countries, opposition to nuclear weapons in Britain stems in part from the view that the United States wants this continent to take all the risks. Alex Kitson, the party chairman, said in a speech to the conference on Sunday, ''When they talk of a limited nucle ar war, they mean limited to us.'' **********In addition, many members of the Labor Party fear that a nuclear conflict could be started in Europe through a miscalculation or a technical malfunction 3,000 miles away. A delegate from southwestern England, who lives near two military bases, said she could not bear to tell her children that ''a nuclear attack is likely to be only a few miles away.'' The only sane course, she added, was for a future Labor government ''to tell President Reagan to pack up his bases and leave our shores.'' **********What the party's activists are demanding is that the Conservative Government's plan to acquire Trident missiles to replace the aging Polaris missiles be canceled, that American cruise missiles be banned, that military spending be cut sharply and that this country work for the creation of a European nuclear-free zone - all regardless of what other nations do. **********However, the conference rejected a second resolution calling for the withdrawal of Britain from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, after first seeming to approve that as well. On a show of hands, the measure passed, but on a ''card vote,'' in which the big trade unions were able to make their weight felt, it was defeated easily, 5.2 million votes to 1.6 million. 'This Is Mass Suicide' **********Advocates of withdrawal from NATO said it made no sense to ban nuclear weapons and remain within the Atlantic alliance. One, Stephen Ratcliffe, a delegate from the Midlands, said NATO's policy was to use conventional weapons until it was losing, then to try tactical nuclear weapons ''and then to blow up the world.'' **********''This is mass suicide,'' he told the 1,300 delegates. ''We must get out of the game before it kills all of us.'' Joan Lestor, speaking against withdrawal for the party's National Executive Committee, said it was perfectly consistent for a partly disarmed Britain to remain in NATO. She argued that this country could play a role like those of Canada, Norway and Denmark, all members of the alliance that have forbidden the deployment of nuclear weapons on their soil. **********It was a rowdy and confusing day of voting in the Brighton Conference Center. The chairman, Mr. Kitson, failed to call on Brynmor John, the party's parliamentary spokesman on defense, to state the case for multilateral disarmament, and Mr. John stalked out of the hall without waiting for Miss Lestor's summing up. Later he and Mr. Kitson exchanged recriminations on television.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/08/busin.main_headline: EFFORTS TO REHABILITATE CROWN HEIGHTS APARTMENT HOUSES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/08/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; EFFORTS TO REHABILITATE CROWN HEIGHTS APARTMENT HOUSES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/08/busin.body_text: **********The architectural quality of the houses of Crown Heights in Brooklyn are generally believed to rival any in the city. But many of the imposing six-story English Tudor apartment buildings of the community have a look of faded glory. **********The population of 230,000 is mainly moderate-income and middleincome blacks, largely from Caribbean islands, and Orthodox Jews. Many of the blacks are from households that earn $15,000 to $25,000 a year. New tenants are often ''moving up'' from poorer housing in Bedford-Stuyvesant or other neighboring communities. **********The buildings need money. In recent years they have gotten a good bit, $14.5 million of it lent or committed by the New York City Community Preservation Corporation, a private company financed by a consortium of commercial and savings banks. It has financed the rehabilitation of 2,200 housing units, mainly apartments. **********The city has contributed to many rehabilitations through the federally funded participation loan program. The Settlement Housing Fund has also done rehabilitation work. **********From time to time rehabilitation work attracts new entrepreneurs. A case in point in Crown Heights is Norwood Campbell.  Mr. Campbell is a 42-year-old black who graduated from the City University of New York, worked in the real estate finance department of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and went into real estate development on his own in the early 1970's. **********In 1977 Mr. Campbell joined Alex Shapiro, owner of a plumbing business in the Bronx, to form the NCAS Realty Management Corporation and the NCAS Construction Company, based in Mount Vernon, N.Y. They began with a building with 110 apartments on Garden Street near the Bronx Zoo. **********Now the Campbell-Shapiro partnership is far advanced in the subsidized rehabilitation of a 178-apartment building at 769 St.  Marks Avenue, close to the Brooklyn Children's Museum in the Brower Park neighborhood. It is a street lined with apartment buildings that have gotten or are soon to get moderate rehabilitation financing, the level of funding usually depending on the state of decay. **********No. 769 was far gone, as developers would say, when Mr. Campbell entered the picture. It had paid no taxes since 1975. Fifty apartments were occupied by squatters paying no rent. ''There were some concerned tenants,'' Mr. Campbell said, ''but conditions were so bad that they could not remain.'' **********So the building was emptied and boarded. When rehabilitation finally came a year and a half later, vacancy had taken its toll. The water-damaged roof needed replacement, as did all the walls and flooring. **********Since the rent-paying capacity of the incoming tenants in that area would be only about $60 a room per month, rehabilitation required a so-called deep subsidy, only possible under the Federal Section 8 program for totally rehabilitated or new housing. The project finally approved by the the Department of Housing and Urban Development called for construction outlays of $37,000 an apartment, or $6.6 million. **********''We intend to see this work over the long haul,'' said Mr.  Campbell, who will continue to manage the project.  But what of the other buildings in the neighborhood? For other owners, management is a struggle. One owner of a nearby 35-family building conceded, ''The future doesn't look good.'' His building would need an overall 30 percent rent increase just to keep up with fuel and repair bills, he said. **********The future accordingly appears to depend on the extent of moderate rehabilitation. Withdrawal or reduction of Federal subsidies could be devastating. The city itself, at the same time, may have the power to smooth the road to more rehabilitation. **********Housing officials are trying to work out a faster route to rent restructuring, typically stalled for eight months to a year and a half when approval is needed for new rents in rent-stabilized apartments from the Conciliation and Appeals Board, the appeals arm of the rent-stabilization system. **********But as matters stand, rigidity in the rent-stabilization system works against rehabilitation efforts. Rent restructuring is a critical component of renewal of older multifamily housing and neighborhoods. Ironically, the problem for the city has not been rent-controlled apartments but rather rent-stabilized apartments, where rent restructuring is not under the direct control of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. **********What rehabilitation of occupied buildings also accomplishes is to take moderate-income housing accommodations off the tax rolls through the J-51 incentive. Tenants could not afford the new rents that rehabilitation requires if taxes were built into the rent structure. **********Would vacancy decontrol have helped if it had not been repealed by the State Legislature in 1973? ''You would have had a higher income mix of tenants in rent-controlled buildings,'' in Mr. Campbell's view. ''The institutions would have had a different attitude about lending.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/25/busin.main_headline: By Leoanrd Sloane; BUSINESS PEOPLE; The Seamen's Bank Elects a President
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/25/busin.print_headline: By Leoanrd Sloane; BUSINESS PEOPLE; The Seamen's Bank Elects a President
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/25/busin.body_text: **********Steven H. Rice, 38 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Seamen's Bank for Savings, the New York savings bank founded in 1829. Effective Dec.1, he will succeed E.  Virgil Conway, 52, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer of the bank, which has six offices and $1.8 billion in assets. **********''When Virge brought me aboard seven years ago, he did it on the basis that we would work as a team,'' Mr. Rice said yesterday. ''I'm sure we will continue on that basis.'' **********Mr. Rice, a lawyer who once served as the assistant counsel to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, was previously with the New York State Banking Department, where he rose to first deputy superintendent before joining the Seamen's as a vice president in 1975. He became senior vice president the following year and has been executive vice president since 1978. **********Mr. Conway is also a lawyer and former first deputy superintendent of the New York State Banking Department. He was executive vice president of the Manhattan Savings Bank for two years before coming to the Seamen's as chairman and president in 1969. **********Mr. Rice said that the savings bank industry ''has certainly been through a difficult time, but the recent downturn in interest rates is a positive development.'' He continued, ''We quite frankly feel that, assuming these lower short-term rates continue for an extended period of time, we can look towards a more favorable earnings picture for the thrifts, including Seamen's.'' **********He added: ''One thing that we hope for is that we have a deregulatory framework that is more conducive to the long-term stability of all kinds of financial institutions. There are so many people out there now who would very much enjoy to purchase a home and are unable to because of high short-term rates. There just has to be a balance between our asset structure and our liability structure.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/02/busin.main_headline: Real Estate; West Street Lofts Made Into Co-ops
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/02/busin.print_headline: Real Estate; West Street Lofts Made Into Co-ops
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/02/busin.body_text: **********''T HERE are people who come to New York City with one thing in mind for a profession,'' said John Waggaman, an established fine-arts photographer, ''but end up doing something entirely different. That's what makes it so interesting.'' **********Mr. Waggaman, who has worked for the Whitney Museum of American Art, among other institutions, recently became a part-time real estate developer. He went into partnership with three other people to form Agadaz Inc., the sponsoring group for the conversion of an imposing eight-story building at 288 West Street, built as a warehouse in 1885, into 14 cooperative apartments designed to sell for more than $175,000 apiece. **********''After living in San Diego for nearly 30 years, I had just moved back to the city and was only looking for a loft to live in,'' Mr.  Waggaman said. ''I saw this rugged old black brick structure and I knew it was just what I wanted.'' **********He was impressed with the location, he added, and the quality of structural sturdiness in the building. It has massive maple wood columns as big as 10 inches square, with as many as 23 per floor, or eight or nine in each apartment. The apartments will range in size from 1,200 to 1,900 square feet. The building itself is 46 feet wide by 100 feet deep. **********It was in the spring of 1979 that Mr. Waggaman returned to the city and began his search for real estate. He scoured Tribeca, the trapezoidal wedge of a commercial district just below Canal Street, once best known as a commodity center. Nowadays it is closer to a New Bohemia - a phenomenon best observed on weekends and evenings when its resident painters, actors, musicians and writers fill the streets and cafes. Meryl Streep and Robert De Niro, the actors, are Tribeca residents, and so is Bette Midler, the singer **********Through a friend, Mr. Waggaman met John Enck, who two years earlier had bought 288 West Street with Linda Patton, his business associate, from Abner Levine for about $100,000. Previously the building had been used as an office furniture warehouse by Umberto Bros. **********The photographer joined the ownership group and with an investment of about $145,000 the mortgage was paid off. **********Mr. Enck had come to Manhattan in 1971 to study architecture, though he gave that up to try a career as a writer. To support himself he worked on loft renovations, specializing in plumbing work. Miss Patton ran a business importing rugs from North Africa. **********For herself, she said, the prospect of living in an apartment that offered sweeping views of the Hudson River was the primary attraction of the building. ''A big city feels different if you are near the river,'' she added. **********To take advantage of the river views, the old windows were enlarged and some new ones punched out of walls that are some places as thick as two feet. Relying chiefly on the designs of a fourth partner, Max Scott, a British-born artist, the partners started the renovation themselves. They cleared space to install new wiring and copper plumbing and put in three new gas furnace heating units, housed in a special area on the roof, near a fenced-in patio. **********There were more extensive changes: a new elevator shaft was built near the front of the building and an automatic self-service cab provided. Flooring has been constructed through the old shaft, adding to the usable floor space of the building. There is a new steel staircase, a sprinkler system and smoke alarms for fire safety, and new kitchens and baths. Other features include thermal windows and more-than-usual insulation in the floors for soundproofing. **********''We learned from our earlier renovations of other people's places that tenants like making some changes themselves,'' said Mr. Scott, who has been a contractor for various loft owners. **********The building's 14 units will be sold for prices ranging from $175,000 to $195,000, according to Mr. Enck, who said an offering plan had recently been accepted by the New York State Attorney General's office. **********As a cooperative, the building will have a $500,000 25-year permanent mortgage at 14 1/2 percent interest. A $10,000 emergency reserve fund has also been set aside. To enhance the offer, Mr.  Waggaman said, cooperative buyers will be given at least $18,000 a year in earnings from the leasing of commercial space to which the property is entitled because of appropriate zoning. A restaurant or an architectural concern are considered possible lessees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/27/busin.main_headline: NATIONALIZATION TARGETS RALLY ON PARIS BOURSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/27/busin.print_headline: NATIONALIZATION TARGETS RALLY ON PARIS BOURSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/27/busin.body_text: **********Shares of companies and banks that France's new Socialist-Communist coalition Government plans to nationalize rallied on the Paris stock exchange today, following yesterday's announcement that the Government would pay a record interest rate of 16.75 percent on its first state borrowing. **********Investors conclude that the bonds the Government is expected to offer shareholders as compensation for taking over their property will carry similarly generous yields. **********Rhone Poulenc, the troubled French synthetic fiber and chemical group, led the rise on the Bourse, as the exchange is known, gaining 14.3 percent. Compagnie Financiere de Suez, the bank and industrial holding company, was up roughly 8.5 percent, as was St.  Gobain-Ponta-Mousson, the diversified industrial company. **********Banque de Paris et des Pays Bas, Pechiney and other companies to be taken over also moved sharply ahead, wiping out some of the big losses they have suffered since the Socialists gained power earlier this year. 'Fair' Compensation **********So far the Government has said only that it plans to start nationalizing privately owned French banks and 12 large industrial companies later this fall, beginning with the banks and the Frenchowned companies on the list. It has said only that the compensation will be ''fair.'' **********If, as is widely expected, the bonds the Government offers shareholders as compensation have a life of 15 years, the interest rate could be as high as 17.50 percent, according to one broker's calculation. The state borrowing announced yesterday has a six-year term. **********The Government could offer a bond with a floating interest rate tied to the general level of interest rates to protect itself if the cost of money falls. But many French brokers believe it will choose a fixed-rate issue to preserve public confidence in its bonds at a time when it faces a heavy borrowing requirement to finance the big budget deficits that will result from its plans to stimulate the economy. **********Another argument, frequently made by brokers, is that the nationalized French insurance companies are already big investors in many of the companies to be nationalized. ''The Government has no interest in ruining their portfolios,'' one broker says. **********Meanwhile, France's private banks are maneuvering to limit the impact of their impending nationalization. The Rothschild interests are trying to save their bank's $75 million portfolio of industrial shares, which is heavily concentrated in mining, metals and tourism, by separating it from their relatively small banking business. Approval in Question **********It has been only three years since the Rothschilds deliberately brought their industrial investments into the family bank by arranging for it take over Compagnie du Nord, the industrial holding company that they also controlled. **********Sources close to the Rothschilds say that the move was planned before the Socialists came to power. They also point out that the Government has said it does not want to keep the industrial holdings of banks it nationalizes and plans to sell them back to private investors. However, it is still unclear whether the Government, which has already put representatives into all the banks it plans to take over, will approve the Rothschilds' plan. **********If the Rothschilds suceeds in their plan, other big banks on the nationalization list with extensive industrial holdings may well try a similar maneuver, bankers believe. At present they are arguing strongly that their extensive foreign operations should be spared nationalization.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/20/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation will pay off depositors of the Economy Savings and Loan Association, a Chicago institution that was closed earlier this week by the state authorities for having exhausted its net worth. This is the first time in nearly a decade that the Federal agency has taken such action. **********Economy Savings, which has $88 million in assets, was closed Monday, the same day the Federal agency stepped in as receiver and began preparations to pay an estimated $60 million to insured depositors. All deposits are insured up to $100,000 by the Federal Government. **********William Schilling, Illinois Commissioner of Savings and Loan Associations, said the state had ''made a decision'' that Economy ''had exhausted its net worth and was unable to continue operations.'' **********The last time the Federal agency was required to pay depositors occurred in October 1971 when the Northwest Guaranty Savings and Loan in Seattle closed. The Federal agency has been forced 14 times in its 45-year history to make such payments. **********Robert Hughes, deputy director of the Federal agency, attributed Economy's problems to the high interest rates it has to pay for funds and to the low yield on its outstanding mortgage portfolio. **********Insured depositors will receive their funds by mail, a process that has already begun and will continue through the week. Access to the bank is being given only to customers with safe deposit boxes, pending a Federal inventory of Economy's accounts. **********Generally, the Fedeal loan insurance agency attempts to seek merger partners for ailing thrift units. These partners generally take over the deposits and assets of the weak institutions. But, in the case of Economy, no partner could be found. According to Federal officials, Economy is in a neighborhood economically unattractive to other thrifts. **********A spokesman at the Federal agency explained that it was required to apply a ''cost test'' to determine the fate of ailing thrift units, before recommending merger or liquidation. The alternative with the least cost is to prevail. **********Since the start of 1981, the Federal agency has assisted in the mergers of five ailing thrift units, according to the spokesman.  The $60 million to pay off Economy's depositors will come from a $6.5 billion fund set up by the Federaal agency for this purpose. The agency said that it expects to recover nearly all of the $60 million by liquidating Economy's loan portfolio, a process that should take about a year. **********Uninsured funds will receive a pro rata share from the liquidation proceedings, according to H. Brent Beesely, the Fereral agency's director. Economy also has two branches, one on the city's Southwest Side and the other in Carpentersville, Ill., a Chicago suburb.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/29/world.main_headline: IN RIOT AREA, HARD TIMES SPOIL BRITAIN'S PARTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/29/world.print_headline: IN RIOT AREA, HARD TIMES SPOIL BRITAIN'S PARTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/29/world.body_text: **********Like many thousands of other shops all over Britain, the Bhikbro delicatessen here is decorated with two large pictures of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer, with a message of congratulations on their marriage tomorrow. **********But the heart-shaped color photographs are pasted not onto plate glass but onto sheets of plywood that were nailed up to protect the tiny shop two and a half weeks ago, when rioters ripped through the center of this industrial city 100 miles north of London. **********''There were mobs throwing petrol bombs and bricks all over this neighborhood,'' said A.Y. Bhikhu, an Indian immigrant who owns the store and now worries about it constantly. ''Without the plywood, I am sure that the glass would have been broken. I do not know when I will take it down.'' **********As Britain celebrates the royal wedding, Mr. Bhikhu's sheets of plywood are a reminder of what will still be a troubling reality long after all the red, white and blue bunting has been taken down - the urban disorders that so shocked a nation long proud of its lawfulness and civility. **********''The Government can make whatever fuss it wants to about Charles and Diana,'' said a 22-year-old unemployed man who said he had taken part in the rioting here but had not been caught. ''But sooner or later, it's going to have to think about us.'' **********He and a group of friends who were whiling away a sunny morning in a littered playground outside a public housing project said they had not heard about the emergency youth-employment program that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced yesterday, partly in response to the rioting. But when told about it, they were skeptical. **********''What future will it bring to Leicester?'' one of them asked.  ''I'll believe it when I see it.'' A textile center that was once prosperous, Leicester began declining even before the current recession, largely because of competition from cheap imports. Then the general economic downturn, in which Britain's manufacturing output has fallen by 17 percent in the past year and a half, added to its miseries. **********But despite the obvious contrast between the splendor of the royal wedding and the plight of the city's unemployed, there were few overt signs of resentment toward Charles and Diana. **********''I expect that even in the riot areas you'd find everybody watching the wedding on television tomorrow,'' said Peter Lowman, an official of the National Union of Hosiery and Knitwear Workers.  ''Remember, we in Britain don't have an antiroyalist or republican tradition.'' **********Downstairs in the union headquarters, the receptionist shyly disagreed. Although the office, like most offices in Britain, will be given a holiday tomorrow, she will not watch the wedding, she said, ''because it doesn't seem right, such an elaborate occasion with so many people out of jobs.'' **********The cities are now peaceful except for Liverpool, where gangs of youths have again clashed with the police this week. The police chief there warned today that he planned to ''get tough'' in his effort to bring calm to the streets. **********''But even when they do crack down, it may bring peace for only a little while,'' said Mr. Bhikhu, staring bleakly at the inside of his plywood panels as if he could still see through the window. ''These are very bad times, and very bad things are happening. I don't know when things will ever be right again.'' ---- Liverpool Riots Continue **********LIVERPOOL, England, Wednesday, July 29 (AP) - Two hundred young rioters hurled gasoline bombs and rocks at the police in this port city's third straight night of violence. The authorities said the situation was ''quite severe'' early today, with 20 officers and some of the rioters hospitalized.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/24/busin.main_headline: FINDING THE PRODUCTS FOR FAMOUS NAMES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/24/busin.print_headline: FINDING THE PRODUCTS FOR FAMOUS NAMES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/24/busin.body_text: **********LEO GORE never asks, ''What's in a name?'' He knows precisely, in dollars and cents, what is - in Sasson, Oscar de la Renta, Gloria Vanderbilt and a handful of other illustrious designer names. **********His own name does not exactly come trippingly off the public tongue, but, in the fast-growing business of designer licensing, Mr. Gore is a Very Important Person. He is one of the biggest and most successful of the licensing agents, the middlemen who make the vital connection between the designer and the manufacturer who wants to put that designer's name on his line of dresses, panty hose, sunglasses, wallets, bedsheets or what-have-you. **********''We've been responsible for putting together licenses worth $1 billion in retail sales,'' said Mr. Gore, a quiet-spoken man probably in his late 50's (he declines to give his age) who is himself discreetly branded with other people's marks - a YSL tie, a Sasson tie clip. (No Sasson briefs, however. As he conceded, ''they're not designed for a 36-inch waist.'') **********In an industry that thrives on trendiness, flash and hype, Mr.  Gore is almost startlingly low-key. Even now, the name-dropping that he likes best involves his children: Lesley Gore, the singer and songwriter, and Michael Gore, the composer who won two Academy Awards this year for the score and song of the movie, ''Fame.'' **********While agents are often unloved, people speak suspiciously fondly of Mr. Gore. ''I love him,'' said Paul Guez, founder and president of Sasson, the jeans company.''We have a beautiful relationship.'' **********''He's a soft man, a nice man,'' said John Pomerantz, president of Leslie Fay, a large apparel company that was licensed a year ago to manufacture suits, dresses, jackets and raincoats under the Sasson name. **********He is also a deal-maker par excellence. In an industry that exists on contacts, ''we pretty much know everyone in the apparel and accessories business,'' Mr. Gore said. That range reflects a career devoted to apparel. **********Until a decade ago, Mr. Gore was running Peter Pan Swimwear, a small, New York-based manufacturer of bras and girdles as well as swim suits, founded by his brother-in-law in 1942. When the company was sold to U.S. Industries in 1968, Mr. Gore went along, then quit shortly before the conglomerate shut it down in 1973. **********Having peddled the Peter Pan name in 27 nations, Mr. Gore amassed a stock of information about licensing and apparel manufacturing. In 1975, he founded Leo Gore Associates in an office on the Avenue of the Americas and began putting his experience to work. Now, with offices in Paris, Tokyo and Mexico, his network is again worldwide. **********In New York, behind a desk piled high with telephone messages, Mr.  Gore is continually on the line to his 10 sales representatives, his licensees and some would-be licensees around the world. **********A caller proposes introducing a hosiery line under a designer's name. ''It could be strong enough,'' Mr. Gore muses. ''Are we talking underwear?'' he queries another caller. ''Are we talking swimwear?'' **********In a pause between telephone calls, Mr. Gore explained that designer initials and logos are popular with consumers because ''they give credibility to products. These are today's trade names, like Maidenform years ago.'' Social historians offer more profound explanations. According to Daniel J. Boorstin, who is now Librarian of Congress, as traditional ties to church and region fade, Americans define themselves, and find a sense of community, in the material items they share. Winston smokers and Mustang drivers ''share their illusions, hopes, and disappointments.'' Of late, this has become the more explicit, with Lord & Taylor shopping bags, Sony hats and someone else's initials on your shirt. **********But whatever psychic or practical needs it fills, designer merchandise has unquestionably proliferated in recent years, despite prices that are often two or three times those of nondesigner wares of equivalent quality. While there is no accurate statistical measure of this sales catagory, Mr. Gore estimated that designer licenses generate $7 billion to $8 billion in store sales each year. **********In return for the design and the right to his or her name or insignia, the designer collects a royalty - ranging from 5 percent to 7 percent, depending on the item - on the manufacturer's sales to the stores. Mr. Gore, in turn, collects 10 percent of that royalty as his commission. **********Many of the top designers, such as Calvin Klein or Bill Blass, as well as some of the top trademarks, such as Jordache, sell their licenses directly to manufacturers. In fact, some tend to be a touch condescending toward the independent agent. **********''I don't need a broker,'' said Joseph Nakash, president of Jordache Enterprises, the fast-growing jeans company that now has 35 licensees in the United States and 20 abroad. ''Good manufacturers come to me.'' **********In the view of Nicholas De Marco, a former agent who is now the full-time coordinator of Pierre Cardin's licenses in the United States, licensing agents primarily benefit less-established names.  Noting that most of the designer names have their own lacensing staff, Mr. De Marco asserted that ''independent agents don't give you the best arrangement. The agent is a compromiser. He gets paid only when a deal is made.'' Too often, an agent is mainly interested in closing a deal and moving on to the next one. **********Indeed, for all his admiration for Mr. Gore, Mr. Guez did say that the licencer has sometimes been ready to settle for a $50,000 royalty guarantee while his client, Sasson, insisted on holding out for $150,000. **********(The way Mr. Gore works, the manufacturer must guarantee of a minimum of $1 million in sales, meaning at least $50,000 in royalties for the designer and $5,000 for Mr. Gore. Typically, Mr. Gore said, ''We'll negotiate a two- or three-year contract with a $1 million guarantee and the option to renew at $1.5 million.'') **********On the other hand, Oscar de la Renta, for one, has concluded that it can pursue licensing opportunities more aggressively through an agent. ''It would be hard for me to go out and flaunt Oscar de la Renta,'' Gerald Shaw, the company's president, said. ''We're not that kind of company.'' **********And Mr. Gore is much more than a broker for his clients, he says.  ''We could sign hundreds of contracts, but our job is to search out the best potential licensees, with the best manufacturing, marketing and financing ability,'' he said. ''We get involved in coordinating the different licensees, in approvals, advertising, product development and quality control. We don't just make the deal and walk away.'' **********Since he signed a contract four years ago with Sasson, for example, he has helped transform the jeans-and-T-shirt manufacturer into an industry. Under Mr. Gore's guidance, the company has added dresses, suits, scarves, fake furs, leather goods, swimwear, men's sports underwear, bras and panties, children's sportswear, belts, hosiery and dolls. **********One Gore inspiration was Sasson maternity jeans. ''Young women are good Sasson customers, and when they become pregnant, they'll still want to wear Sasson jeans,'' he said. Today, $250 million worth of merchandise annually sells under the Sasson label, of which only $80 million - in jeans and some sportswear - is actually manufactured by the company. By 1985, Mr. Guez said, he expects a three-fold increase in total Sasson sales. **********Admittedly, Mr. Gore's loftiest designer names retain him for only part of their business. One of his first clients was designer Oscar de la Renta, for whom Mr. Gore arranged a deal with Cannon Mills for bedding and put together a highly successful perfume line. He also licenses the designer in furs, scarves, eyeglass frames, jewelry and swimsuits. **********BUT Oscar de la Renta men's wear is handled by Kayser-Roth, while the designer's own company sells licenses to manufacture women's jeans, some sportswear, coats and small leather goods under his name. **********For Gloria Vanderbilt, Mr. Gore handles home furnishings only. When she embarked on her career, Mr. Gore said, he made the initial connection with a Hong Kong-based company called Murjani International, which started manufacturing blouses under her name.  Now, through its Gloria Vanderbilt division, Murjani manufactures Vanderbilt sportswear and licenses shoes and leather products. **********''Gloria's a natural for other products - flatware, tableware, paper goods, small leather goods,'' Mr. Gore said. As the designerhome furnishing business grows, he predicted, ''She will become very strong in furniture, lamps, rugs.'' **********The choice of licensee and of products to license can be critical elements in this business.  Mr. De Marco of Pierre Cardin, for example, recalled the time that the designer lent his name to a wine. When the wine promptly sold out, ''the bottler, because he was greedy, put out inferior wine under the same label,'' he said. Mr. Cardin withdrew the license.  ''He didn't really belong in that realm anyway,'' Mr. De Marco said.  ''He designs for the living environment.'' **********Mr. Gore, to protect his designers' names, rejects manufacturers who might sell the wares to discount outlets. ''We want to build a name,'' he observed. Also rejected are licensees who come in with inappropriate products. He cited one manufacturer who approached him recently about putting one of his best designer names on a new line of chewing gum in champagne and sangria flavors. Mr. Gore unhesitatingly vetoed the offer. **********Where will it stop? Mr. Gore conceded that it would be a mistake to attach the trendy Sasson logo to some products, such as housewares. But for some licensers, the model - in volume, at least - is Pierre Cardin. According to one source, the French designer collects $50 million annually in licensing royalties by putting his name on a vast range of products, including cars, jet airplanes, computers, clocks and backgammon sets as well as apparel and accessories. Mr. Cardin ''just goes on, like Old Man River,'' said Mr. Gore. **********Although he confessed that he wearies of some of the more ubiquitous initials, such as Vuitton, Mr. Gore said that he believed the designer syndrome has not yet run its course. ''We don't think it's reached the saturation point, even in clothing,'' he said. As initials proliferate in the future, ''it will just shake out the weak.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/31/world.main_headline: CONFLICTS EMERGING IN NIGERIA'S 21-MONTH CIVIL REGIME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/31/world.print_headline: CONFLICTS EMERGING IN NIGERIA'S 21-MONTH CIVIL REGIME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/31/world.body_text: **********A crowd went on a rampage here two weeks ago, burning down the state radio station, the assembly building and other institutions and setting fire to half the state's files. At least two people were killed, and the damage was estimated at $300 million. **********Since then, five local polititians have reportedly gone into hiding, fearing assassination, and the Governor of Kano State, Mohammed Abubakar Rimi, the target of much of the violence, has reported receiving death threats. Many of the official buildings are now smoke-blackened hulks amid the palm trees of Kano, where other riots took place last December. **********The disturbances on July 10, according to Nigerian officials, resulted from strains that have emerged in the 21 months since the end of military rule in Nigeria, which is Africa's economic giant and America's second largest foreign supplier of oil. **********They coincided, too, with realignments and fissures in Nigerian politics, which seem to underscore a mounting, formal opposition to President Shehu Shagari among the country's political parties and growing divisions within those parties. What the Rioters Left Alone **********For anyone who seeks omens, those that emerged from the Kano rampage lay as much in what the rioters left alone as in the targets of their wrath. **********While the institutions of Kano State came under attack, the riot left unscathed the outposts of the federal Government in Lagos, 700 miles to the south. The mob called for the blood of Governor Rimi, but did not direct its attack at the political party in which he leads a maverick faction. ''It was a controlled rampage,'' one official said. **********Ostensibly, the cause of the unrest was a peremptory note that Governor Rimi delivered to the emir of Kano, the traditional ruler.  The emir's powers, on paper, have been greatly diluted over the years, but his influence among the Moslem majority is still great. **********The Governor's note asked the emir to show cause why he should not be removed from office for supposedly displaying disrespect to the state government. Political Motive Suspected **********''The official explanation was that the rampage was caused because the crowd wanted to protect the emir,'' a high state official said.  ''Others feel the riot was politically inspired.'' Kano State is one of 19 such administrative regions in Nigeria and has a reputation for volatility. **********Governor Rimi belongs to the Eagle Faction, a group within the People's Redemption Party, a minority, socialist-leaning group that is regarded by Nigerian and Western analysts as the most ideological of Nigeria's five main parties. In general, these analysts say, ethnic affiliation and personalities play a major role across the political spectrum. **********The Eagle Faction, the analysts say, favors confrontation with symbols of traditional rule, like the emir, whom it accuses of ''oppressing the masses.'' **********But the masses, the high state official said, tend to like their emir. ''Most of the masses are uneducated - they are illiterate,'' he went on. ''They need education. They do not understand the Governor's policies.'' Faction Seen as a Target **********The Eagle Faction has sought unsuccessfully to wrest the leadership of the People's Redemption Party from its chairman, Aminu Kano. The state official and other authoritative sources said the riot on July 10 seemed to have been inspired, in part at least, by members of the party mainstream intent on crushing the Eagle Faction and using the slight against the emir as a pretext. Other groups, these sources said, may also have been involved or have had foreknowledge of the event. **********Nigeria returned to civilian rule in October 1979 after 13 years of military administration. It did so on the basis of a Constitution, modeled on that of the United States, permitting presidential rule and abandoning the parliamentary system bequeathed by Britain, the colonial power that ruled here until independence in 1960. **********Five parties contested the presidency. President Shagari's National Party of Nigeria won enough votes to obtain the leadership, but not an absolute majority. So it entered into a loose and often fractious alliance with the Nigerian People's Party. **********Earlier this month, the People's Party announced that it was withdrawing from the alliance, called The Accord, and the withdrawal caused divisions within the party. Six of its 77 deputies announced that they would continue supporting President Shagari. Two of the party's ministerial appointees are still in President Shagari's Cabinet. A Sense of Vulnerability **********The withdrawal reflected a sense of vulnerability among minority groups, analysts said. A Nigerian official said that the People's Party, like other parties, feared that the President's men were using the coalition to make inroads into its power base and thus strengthen Mr. Shagari's position before the next election in 1983. **********The party also felt, a Western diplomat said, that The Accord was not yielding enough of the ''patronage and largesse'' on which much of Nigerian politics operates. A senior official in President Shagari's party, rubbing his thumb and forefinger together in a universal financial gesture, said, ''They said they wanted more lolly. We said: 'No more lollipop.' '' **********The withdrawal of the People's Party nonetheless meant that formal opposition to President Shagari had solidified, with four parties now ranged against him. Nigerian and foreign analysts expect, however, that he will be able to muster enough votes from the divided opposition to prevent a parliamentary stalemate. As the senior official put it: ''You patronize them rather than align them with others, and they play ball.'' **********Dr. Chuba Okadigbu, President Shagari's senior political adviser, said the apparent disarray was part of a process in which Nigeria was coming to terms with the new presidential system. **********''The presidential system normally operates within a two-party system, with other groups as spoilers,'' he said, adding that such an alignment now seems to be taking shape in Nigeria. **********Opponents of the President, however, see events as part of a sustained campaign by his party to use the power, influence and wealth of office to foment division in - and win supporters from - other parties, thereby enhancing its prospects in the 1983 election and diverting attention from the uncertainties within its own ranks.
