https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/busin.body_text: **********Alden Winship Clausen, who will take over Wednesday as president of the World Bank, stresses that it is in the ''vested interest'' of the United States to support the institution, which lends to the third world, and warns that the reluctance of Congressional conservatives to provide adequate financing threatens its survival. **********''If we can help the third world countries expand their economies, ours will also expand, and there will be more jobs in the United States,'' said Mr. Clausen, who is leaving his job as the chairman of the Bank of America to succeed Robert S. McNamara as the World Bank's sixth chief executive. **********He stressed that one-third of American exports were bought by developing countries. ''That's the vested interest I'm talking about,'' he said in a recent 90-minute interview at the Bank of America office in Washington. 'Makes So Much Common Sense' **********He added that the World Bank ''makes so much common sense that it seems that other reasonable people with like common sense will see what we're trying to do.'' **********He said he was concerned not about Reagan Administration support for the World Bank, but about the reluctance of conservatives in the House of Representatives to back Administration financing proposals. **********Without United States support, he added, the institution, which is more formally known as the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and is owned by 139 nations, was in danger of unraveling.  Talks With Officials Cited **********He said that, contrary to popular belief, the Reagan Administration was ''very supportive'' of the bank, a conclusion he has drawn from talks with high Administration officials including the President, with whom, Mr. Clausen observed, ''my relations, I believe, are good.'' **********The 58-year-old banker, who as chief executive of the 36-year-old multilateral lending body will receive about one-third of his present $600,000-a-year salary, described the new job as a ''step up on challenge'' and himself as acutely sensitive to the ''voracious'' needs of the third world for development assistance. **********He left little doubt, however, that he would proceed on a course somewhat different from that laid out by his predecessor - for example, by trying to marshal more of the resources of the private sector into the business of development. ''I'm a private sector person,'' he said. ''I'm biased to maximizing. I'm biased to help starting at home. I'm biased to bailing in. I don't want to bail out anything.'' **********He conceded that the job of running the bank, just as he was about to put his ''foot in the stirrup,'' looked a lot bigger than it did last October when he was appointed under a pre-election agreement between Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter. ''The horse is bucking a bit harder than I had anticipated, but my job is to get on it and try to ride it.'' Lent $12 Billion Last Year **********It was a reference to the troubles the bank faces as it seeks support of the United States, its largest stockholder, for a mission that is to make loans, some at practically no interest, to nearly 100 developing countries. The bank lent some $12 billion last year on transportation, power, agricultural and other development projects in the poorer countries. **********In taking over from Mr. McNamara, in whose 13-year reign the bank's lending expanded twelvefold, Mr. Clausen said that he saw ''both consolidation and further growth'' but added that continued growth of the dimensions of the last 12 years would be ''unsustainable.'' **********''If it is true that there is growing reluctance of supporter nations to support multilateral aid, then that aid may have to slow down,'' he added. ''But the need is not diminishing in any way; the appetite is voracious.'' **********One way to address that need, he said, might be to attract more private sector capital to World Bank-supported projects. He noted that, for every $1 the bank put into a project, it now attracted $3 to $4 from outside. ''Can we make that $5 and $6?'' he asked, adding, ''I think that clearly I want to explore that.'' Salesmanship Stressed **********Mr. Clausen made it clear that he considered his main job to be salesmanship. ''I think that the people of the United States don't know anything about the World Bank,'' he said. ''Even the large commercial bankers of the United States don't know much about the World Bank, and they should. We have to get people to understand what the World Bank can do, and what it means to them in their own communities. Then this will translate itself to Congress. And Congress needs to know.'' **********The Bank of America's chief executive said that ''the President was for a number of years my Governor in California, and a good one; I know the media has said that the Reagan Administration is anti-World Bank.'' Mr. Clausen declared, ''I don't believe that.'' **********But the Administration has so far had trouble getting its recommended financing for the bank's soft-loan affiliate, known as the International Development Association, accepted by the House. The association makes loans to the world's poorest countries that are repayable over 50 years at no interest and only a small service fee.  The Administration is seeking a $3.24 billion appropriation to cover an American commitment, made during the Carter Administration, for a $12 billion I.D.A. lending program over this year, 1982 and 1983. **********The Senate has approved the recommendation, but the House has stretched appropriations out over the next five years. 'The Very Minimum' **********''The Administration recommendation is the very minimum that Congress can do,'' Mr. Clausen said, adding that ''if it goes below that, we are in danger of going back to square one. I know from my travels around the world over the last 90 days that, if the United States does not support the World Bank, then other countries will not support it.'' **********In addition to I.D.A. soft loans, the World Bank makes about $8 billion a year of more conventional loans at close to market rates to support a variety of development projects. **********''In a way I'm a United Way freak,'' Mr. Clausen said. ''I believe that those that have ought to help those that don't have because those that have will be stronger and better off in the longer run.'' **********''I don't believe in transferring wealth,'' he continued, ''but I believe in helping those that want to help themselves.'' Citing recent economic successes of Argentina, Chile, Peru, South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong, he said that ''getting the econonic momentum going for the private sector is a good way to achieve economic development.'' Matches Reagan Priorities **********The stress on the private sector coincides with what are understood to be the priorities in the still evolving Reagan Administration policy toward the third world. **********Some conservatives have charged that the World Bank has supported socialist causes. ''The World Bank is not perfect,'' Mr. Clausen said. ''I know those charges. My job will be to try to do a better job. The World Bank has done a tremendous amount of good, far more good than bad, and hopefully we'll continue the good and avoid the inefficiencies and errors.'' **********He continued: ''You can write that Clausen is going to make mistakes. But I'm not a socialist. I'm for the private sector. I want to develop people. I want to develop economies of nations. I want to be part of the solution, not part of the problem.'' **********Although he has yet to develop a policy for the bank, Mr. Clausen said the next two or three years would be ''absolutely critical'' because of projected slower world economic growth and high inflation. **********Noting the huge drain on the resources of developing countries because of energy imports, he said that energy credits must continue to be a ''very strong'' focus of the bank, and added that he believed that Mr. McNamara's idea for an energy subsidiary of the bank had a good deal of merit. The Reagan Administration has been cool to the idea on the ground that the World Bank would enter into competition with private industry. In a Complementary Way **********Mr. Clausen said that, instead of working competitively against private industry, such an affiliate would be using the private sector in a complementary way to ''help explore where there are opportunities.'' **********But he added that, if the Administration was adamantly opposed to the idea of a separate affiliate, he would continue, nevertheless, to press for an energy thrust in other ways. ''I may lose a battle here and there, but I'm not going to lose the war,'' he stressed. **********He said that agriculture would be another priority area to help developing countries become more self-sufficient in food production. Open Mind on Decentralization **********Asked about reports that he would decentralize the World Bank as he has the Bank of America, he said he still had an open mind on that question. ''I'm not in love with decentralization just for the sake of decentralizing,'' he added. **********He said he believed in the ''squeeze box or accordian theory'' in which, if an institution has been compressed over a long period, ''you decentralize to make beautiful music.'' **********He noted that, from the outside, the World Bank appeared to be a very centralized oganization. Decentralization, which has been pressed by many in the third world, would mean that some operations would shift from Washington to points of major lending activity. ''I don't know yet what I will do,'' Mr. Clausen said. ''I don't want to prejudge.'' **********He said that, in his 11 years as the Bank of America's chief executive, he had tried to make that bank ''more socially responsible.'' In terms of assets, the Bank of America is the biggest bank in the United States. Its parent holding company, however, the BankAmerica Corporation, slipped into the No.2 place at the end of 1980, having been edged out by Citicorp, the parent of Citibank.  Citicorp's total assets, including those of its banking and nonbanking activities, are greater than those of the BankAmerica Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/10/busin.main_headline: CHANGE IS A DU PONT TRADITION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/10/busin.print_headline: CHANGE IS A DU PONT TRADITION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/10/busin.body_text: **********First, there was Du Pont. And then Du Pont begat gunpowder, and the gunpowder business begat chemicals.  Chemicals begat nylon, and the nylon business begat fibers. Fibers begat diversification, and the diversification begat Conoco. Conoco? **********''I have heard people use the term mishmash,'' said Edward G.  Jefferson, chairman of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, commenting on his corporation's takeover of Conoco Inc. ''Well, you know, that is all good sport for the morning paper, but it really doesn't describe this at all.'' **********Whether mishmash or synergism, the marriage of the venerable lord of Delaware to a giant wildcatting oil company out of Ponca City, Okla., has left more than a few people wondering about the future of Du Pont. **********The Questions to Be Faced **********What becomes of this 179-year-old institution that got its start selling black powder to the Government during the War of 1812, and for decades grew by the motto, ''Better things for better living through chemistry''? **********Can it be that the people who brought you nylon, Teflon and Lucite are now running the corner gas station?  To all of his doubters on Wall Street and elsewhere, Mr. Jefferson has a simple answer: If you can't see where we're going, it's because you don't know where we've been. **********''Du Pont has changed all through its history,'' said Mr. Jefferson in his baritone British accent. ''It started out as an explosives business, it matured into a chemicals business and got into plastics, paints and fibers. If you look back a little more than a decade, it set its sights on diversification, into electronics and pharmaceuticals. Now we are adding energy. Just 'Another Diversification' **********''What we can do,'' the 60-year-old executive continued during an interview, ''is to bring some of the talents of our engineering department and our research laboratories to the problems and opportunities that exist in the energy field. So although this is a large diversification, it is but another diversification in a company that has been doing this for a long time.'' **********Glancing over his shoulder at a portrait of three of his predecessors, Pierre, Irenee and Lammot duPont, who stare down on his polished table-desk, Mr. Jefferson says confidently: ''The current management have got to run what they've got well, and they've got to do something for the future management. That is our tradition. **********''I suspect,'' he adds, ''that my successors in the 1990's will be very glad that we acquired Conoco.'' The excitement with which Mr. Jefferson discusses the Conoco merger has infected the entire Du Pont company, and the city of Wilmington as well. With the baseball players on strike, following the contest between Du Pont, Joseph E. Seagram & Sons and the Mobil Corporation for control of Conoco became the most talked about sport in this company town. And when it was clear that the home team had won, people amused themselves thinking up new names. How about Du Ponococo? Or Cu Donopo? Or maybe Du Ponocont? Wide Personal Involvement **********''This is the first time I remember something as complex and distant as a corporate merger - which is not your man-in-the-street kind of issue -being the topic of conversation everywhere in the city,'' said Pierre S. du Pont 4th, Delaware's governor and the great-great-great-great-grandson of the founder of Du Pont. ''The community feeling was, we're really going somewhere. People here have so much confidence in the Du Pont management, that if this is what it decides to do, then it must be right. **********''I think it fits in with the same kind of business judgments that my great-great-great-great-grandfather was making in 1802,'' added Governor du Pont during an interview in his mahogany-paneled office. **********''He took a big risk in starting up a brand new gunpowder business. Now they are going into another area they have not been into before.  If they are right, they will be rewarded; if they are wrong, they will pay the price. But it's a risk in the spirit in which it all began.'' Explaining the Logic **********Edward Jefferson would not quibble with that assessment.  When you examine the way the chemical business is evolving, he argues, Du Pont's paying $7.57 billion for Conoco's cornucopia of coal, oil and natural gas reserves seems perfectly in character with its basic business of applying engineering and research to upgrade raw materials into specialty products. **********''If you don't get a very high percentage of oil out of the ground with the present methods of recovery, then there are opportunities for new approaches,'' said Mr. Jefferson, ''particularly at today's prices of hydrocarbons.'' **********Du Pont will soon apply its engineering talent to the problem of recovering the billions of barrels of crude underground that cannot be pumped using current conventional techniques. **********With Conoco's enormous oil reserves of 1.5 billion barrels, Du Pont can be assured of a secure supply of this crucial raw material, even as supplies tighten and the nature of competition in the world petrochemical business changes. Gaining a Competitive Edge **********''The thing that is going to happen in the next decade,'' said Mr.  Jefferson, ''and already is happening, is that more and more chemicals and plastics will be made by the resource-producing countries. You'll find polyethylene, for example, is already made by Middle Eastern oil producers. Conoco gives us a position to compete against the producing countries.'' **********What Conoco's oil does for Du Pont today, its 15 billion tons of coal reserves will do for Du Pont in the future, Mr. Jefferson believes. **********''We have no plans to sell the coal,'' said Mr. Jefferson, scotching speculation that it would be swapped to Seagram for the big block of Conoco stock that Seagram was left with after the takeover battle ended. **********''You know, back in the time when nylon was being presented to the world, it was described as coming from coal, air and water. It wasn't until the mid-1950's that cheap natural gas appeared to replace coal. There is a great deal of coal-based chemistry, and its time will come again. We have a competence to reign in that field.'' **********Conoco describes its total energy reserves in the United States, of oil, coal and natural gas, as the largest of any American company. Du Pont depends on such raw materials to make 70 percent of its products. 'A Confusing Company' **********But while it all seems to fit together on paper, many analysts wonder how the merger will work in real life. **********''It's become a much more confusing company,'' remarked Emily Plishner, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company. ''To them it looks like they have added a new division, but to Wall street it looks like they have become something different.'' **********Analysts question how Du Pont will be able to continue its new commitment to the life sciences, or maintain its traditionally generous dividend payout, when so much capital and talent will have to be devoted to running an oil company. **********Mr. Jefferson said the basic plan was for Conoco to operate as a separate, wholly owned subsidiary. Its chairman, Ralph E. Bailey, will join the Du Pont board, along with three other Conoco executives. Beyond that, Du Pont is still studying the question of integration, and has consulted with the Exxon Corporation and other major companies about how they have digested large acquisitions. **********''I think they'll fit rather well,'' said Mr. Jefferson, ''into a framework which is used to the idea of delegated operating resposibility and a corporate management that mainly concerns itself with the adequacy of planning, people development and overall financial management.'' Self-Financing by Conoco **********As for the potential diversion of capital to the cash-hungry energy field, he said that Conoco was capable of satisfying its own needs.  True, he acknowleged, top management would be stretched. But Du Pont has a long tradition of going in a lot of different directions at once. People forget that it was between 1917 and 1960, when Du Pont held a major stake in the General Motors Corporation, that it made its greatest innovations, the chairman noted. **********One irony of the battle for Conoco is that Du Pont will not only be digesting a new company but a new stockholder as well - the Bronfmans of Canada. They control Seagram, which has acquired at least 25 million Conoco shares. **********On Aug.17 Du Pont, according to its own tender offer, will exchange each of those shares for 1.7 Du Pont shares. That will give Seagram at least 18 percent of Du Pont. The large duPont family, which has eight representatives on a board of 25, will own about 22 percent.  But their holdings are fragmented among 2,500 persons, who, incidentally, spell the family name in various ways. **********How does the family view the Seagram prospect?  ''I almost stopped drinking V.O. for a couple of weeks,'' Governor du Pont said with a smile, in reference to a popular Seagram whisky.  ''It does of course reduce the proportion of the company shares held by the family. But I think the family crossed that bridge a long time ago. It really ceased to be a family company 15 or 20 years ago. **********''This is all part of the trend of the company becoming a large corporation, with professional managers and a wide range of investors,'' the Governor said. **********''I have other large institutional shareholders,'' said Mr.  Jefferson diplomatically. ''We try to serve them all.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/24/busin.body_text: **********The IU International Corporation, parent of two of the nation's leading motor carriers, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of last year increased 13.7 percent on a sales gain of 6.5 percent. **********The Wilmington, Del., concern said that net income in the latest three months rose to $15.8 million, or 71 cents a share, from $13.9 million, or 38 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1979. **********Revenues climbed to $590.1 million from $554.2 million. **********IU, with operations that include Ryder Truck Lines and Pacific Intermountain Express, said that, for the full year, earnings more than doubled to $144.7 million, or $5.25 a share, from $67 million, or $1.88 a share, in 1979. Revenues advanced 6.1 percent, to $2.26 billion, from $2.13 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/07/busin.body_text: **********American business and economic leaders expressed fears yesterday that the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat could further shake the Middle East's fragile stability. Concern over the shooting of the Egyptian President drove up the price of gold, the dollar and domestic oil stocks. **********''Clearly this tragic event does create additional uncertainty in an area fraught with uncertainty,'' said Edward G. Jefferson, chairman of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. ''While Sadat played a constructive role toward peace, events of this kind can be unsettling and destabilizing, although I'm ho ping that this won't.'' **********Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the American Stock Exchange, called the assassination ''clearly a destabilizing force.'' But he added that a lot depends on what happens in the next 30 days, especially regarding the succession to Mr. Sadat. Several executives commented that the presence of a large professional class in Egypt should help assure the nation of security. Sense of Loss Expressed **********Above all, businessmen felt the void left by Mr. Sadat's death.  ''He was one of the great leaders who has emerged in the 20th century,'' said David Rockefeller, retired chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''His visit to Jerusalem will go down as one of the dramatic moments in history. One cannot exaggerate the importance of our loss. It raises the question of what will happen to the whole Camp David process.'' **********In the stock market, reports of the assassination sent up prices of oil companies with holdings outside the Middle East but did not drastically affect other issues. Edward Yardeni, chief economist at E.F. Hutton & Company, said the market took the news ''quite calmly.'' The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 856.26, down 3.61. At 2 P.M., when Mr. Sadat's death was confirmed, the average was up 4.29 points. **********The dollar opened weak in Europe's currency centers, partly in response to lower United States interest rates. Then came word of the shooting. The dollar responded to conflicting reports on Mr. Sadat's condition by rising. After drifting throughout the day, the dollar stabilized at a level higher than Monday's close, in part because of purchases by investors seeking a stable currency. Gold's Trading Pattern **********Gold, which has traditionally been seen as an international haven at times of crises, rose $16.40, to $451.70 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Earlier it had risen in London and Zurich before retreating amid profit-taking. Prices of other metals, including silver, also rose. **********But the uncertainty over what the death of Mr. Sadat would mean to the already shaky political situation in the Middle East was foremost in the minds of businessmen. **********A. Nicholas Filippello, chief economist of the Monsanto Company, said that in the Middle East ''political instability can lead to economic instability.'' He added that business would have to wait and see whether Mr. Sadat's successor follows his path of peace with Israel. **********''The direction of Egypt without him will be uncertain, and uncertainty is a negative factor given the delicate balance in the Middle East,'' Mr. Filippello said. ''The potential for economic disruption is there.'' **********Frank P. Popoff, president of Dow Chemical Europe, a subsidiary of the Dow Chemical Company, said Egypt's well-educated professional people, who work in other Middle Eastern nations as well as their own, would help maintain stability in the region in the days ahead. Economic Momentum Seen **********''I don't think everything in Egypt will be paralyzed as it would be in other countries where the loss of a leader would create dissension.'' Mr. Popoff said. ''I don't think Sadat's death will derail the economy. There is a tremendous amount of positive Egyptian influence in the Middle East that will help bridge this period until Egypt can readdress itself to the issue of leadership.'' **********The stability implied by the presence of an educated cadre of Egyptian businessmen was also cited by Alfred Brittain 3d, chairman of the Bankers Trust Company. ''We are encouraged,'' he said, ''that the country's economic affairs are in the hands of people whom we know to be hi ghly professional, thoroughly experienced and unusually competent.'' **********Many businessmen expressed sadness and shock at the sudden death of a political leader who had tried to bring peace to his troubled region. Sanford I, Weill, chairman and chief executive officer of Shearson/American Express, said he hoped that what Mr. Sadat ''was trying to do would be magnified by his untimely death.'' **********James E. Burke, chairman and chief executive officer of Johnson & Johnson, said Mr. Sadat was ''one of those rare individuals whose humanity had a positive impact on the world.'' **********And Edson W. Spencer, chairman of Honeywell Inc., described Mr.  Sadat's death as ''a great loss for the cause of peace in the Middle East.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/06/world.body_text: **********Former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany urged developing countries yesterday not to reject out of hand the insistence of the Reagan Administration that future international aid to them be linked with their own economic reforms and austerity. **********At a news conference in New York, the former West German leader also expressed hope that when 22 leaders from developed and developing countries, including President Reagan, meet in Cancun, Mexico, this month, they would ''come closer'' to recommendations on encouraging increased agricultural production and stimulating the exploitation of energy resources in developing countries. **********The Cancun gathering, formally called the International Meeting on Cooperation and Development, grew out of a report last year by a commission on international development issues headed by Mr. Brandt.  The report warned of the danger of starvation in the third world and called for a meeting of government leaders to discuss a broad range of economic problems. **********The 14 poor countries who will attend the meeting have made it known that they would like increased economic concessions from the industrialized nations. But the Reagan Administration has made it clear that it will resist those efforts and that it is not sympathetic to beginning so-called ''global negotiations'' on international development and cooperation. **********''I hope very much that as a result of Cancun the blockade on global negotiations could be lifted,'' Mr. Brandt said.  The former Chancellor, who received the Gold Medallion for Humanitarianism of B'nai B'rith International on Saturday, also said that as a result of the Cancun meeting he hoped the World Bank would develop an ''energy affiliate,'' a proposal previously blocked by the United States. Such an affiliate, Mr. Brandt said, could ''pick up a couple of billion dollars a year which is necessary in order to explore and develop energy resources in those developing countries where natural r esources exist but where the m oney doesn't exist to do that exploration and development.'' **********Describing a meeting he had earlier in the day with ambassadors from third world countries, Mr. Brandt said, ''They were not too enthusiastic about President Reagan saying everyone must bring his own house in order.'' Nonetheless, the former Chancellor admonished them that ''it is absolutely fruitless to have this passion about bringing one's house in order because that as a general position is a right position.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/18/busin.body_text: **********A bipartisan panel of regulatory experts today assailed Reese H. Taylor Jr., chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, and his agency's application of the new trucking bill. **********Alfred E. Kahn, who introduced airline deregulation three years ago and helped to complete the Motor Carrier Act of 1980 as a member of the Carter Administration, said that developments at the commission had upset him. **********''I'm not sad; I'm mad,'' he told theJoint Economic Committee.  Mr. Kahn, two former members of the I.C.C. and Thomas Gale Moore, a conservative economist, criticized the new chairman for maintaining restrictive policies that run counter to the mandate to promote increased competition in the vast national trucking industry. **********'Clear Evidence of Retreat' **********Recent decisions by the commission on applications by truckers to introduce service indicate ''clear evidence of retreat from free market principles,'' Mr. Kahn said. **********He criticized what he saw as tendencies to restrict, in truck operating licenses, the distance over which the applicant can operate and the customers he can take on, as well as the ability of the companies to set prices more freely and competitively. **********Marcus Alexis, a Democrat who served as interim chairman before Mr. Taylor's arrival, labeled his successor as ''an inveterate regulator'' who was ''bent on a deliberate, calculated policy to reimpose regulations'' at the commerce commission. **********Mr. Taylor defended his actions, saying that he was carrying out the law as he thought Congress intended.  Under terms of the Motor Carrier Act, the trucking business was to be open to all those who are ''fit, willing and able,'' and want to offer service to meet a ''public need.'' **********Mr. Taylor's critics said that he takes the terms too literally, and applies the fitness rules too rigidly. Chairman Cites Approvals **********In his defense, Mr. Taylor introduced statistics that he said showed that, since he took over this summer, from 91 percent to 95 percent of the trucking applications in various categories have been granted. **********However, Dr. Alexis said that his information indicated that many of the ''approvals'' provided operating authority that was in many instances less than was sought. **********As evidence of pent-up demand for operating licenses in recent months, Mr. Moore, an economist with the Hoover Institution at Stanford, said that truck operating licenses were once again obtaining a market value. Late last year, as the previous Administration threw open the entry gates, the once valuable licenses fell to zero, he said. **********''In other words, the I.C.C. has again created monopoly profits in the industry,'' he stated.  Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, chairman of the committee, chided Mr. Taylor, saying that his policy seemed to be at odds with the deregulatory attitude of the Reagan Administration. **********In reply, the commission chairman said that, contrary to various reports, he had received no guidance or criticism of his policies from the White House, even though he had tried to get advice from Martin Anderson, the White House economic adviser. **********With regard to the commission's restrictions on entry, Mr. Taylor said that an adverse ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in New Orleans, upholding a complaint by the American Trucking Associations, seemed to underline the requirement to scrutinize new applicants closely. He said that the commission had not yet decided whether to appeal the ruling.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/04/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union accused the United States today of seeking to ''torpedo'' the United Nations conference that has been working since 1973 on a treaty setting global rules on use of the oceans and their resources. **********Semyon P. Kozyrev, a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, said that the Reagan Administration's decision to review the the conference's tentative compromises was only a ''pretext'' for rejecting work accomplished on the treaty. **********Speaking at the first meeting of the new session of the Law of the Sea Conference, Mr. Kozyrev said the American goal was to scuttle a ''whole series of compromise agreements'' on how nodules containing cobalt, copper, manganese and nickel would be mined under the supervision of an international authority. **********This could lead to the ''pirating of the seabed resources that are the common heritage of mankind,'' the Soviet delegate said. Protection for U.S. Companies **********Delegates have reached unofficial agreement on most of the 440 articles. But a seven-week session in New York last spring could not finish substantive work because American officials had just begun reviewing the text. **********The Reagan Administration has said that its concerns about the treaty center on the issue of mining on the deep seabed. Officials say they are worried that American companies that have already invested in developing deep seabed mining technology could be put at a serious disadvantage under the proposed international treaty. **********When the conference of about 150 nations reconvened today, its President, Tommy Koh of Singapore, said that Assistant Secretary of State James L. Malone, head of the American delegation, would make a statement ''as comprehensive as possible'' on Wednesday on the results of the Administration's review. **********Upset by the delay, officials from third world nations said they were anxious to get a commitment that Washington intended to seek an accord acceptable to all. Awaiting the U.S. Explanation **********Mr. Koh said that he hoped that the statement by Mr. Malone would explain the Reagan Administration's difficulties with the tentative agreements and how the problems might be resolved.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.body_text: **********United States mineral production increased 3.5 percent in 1980, the smallest annual gain since 1977, the Bureau of Mines said today. **********Domestic production of copper, iron ore and other nonfuel minerals was up $800 million, to $24.8 billion, according to bureau statistics. **********Government economists attributed the slowdown to reduced demand in the automobile and construction industries. The Government also said that a 20-week strike in the copper industry caused copper production to drop 18 percent, to 1.2 million tons. **********The rising price of gold continued to stimulate exploration in Western states, but total domestic production declined 4 percent, to 930,000 ounces. Iron ore production totaled 69 million tons, down 20 percent from 1979, which the bureau attributed to a slowdown in the steel industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/21/busin.body_text: **********With demand appearing for precious-metals stocks, the market moved higher yesterday to finish an erratic week on a note of optimism.  The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.22 points, to 992.80. It had closed above 1,000 on Monday, but promptly sank 10 points Tuesday, then bobbed up and down the rest of the week. **********The American Stock Exchange's market value index, a more speculative barometer of stock prices, gained 5.77 yesterday, to 352.39, its best advance of the week. Kirby Exploration, which does not pay a cash dividend, jumped 7 points, to 300, on the heels of an 11-point advance Thursday. **********Trading on the New York Stock Exchange remained active, with a turnover of 62 million shares, compared with the previous day's 62.4 million. Favorable Market 'Breadth' **********Advances ran ahead of declines by a 2-to-1 ratio. To technical analysts, this meant that market ''breadth'' remained favorable. **********''Stocks showed a very healthy tone today,'' commented John A.  Conlon Jr., who heads block trading for E.F. Hutton & Company.  ''Also, we saw some sophisticated institutions nibbling at utility issues, a group that stands to benefit from declining interest rates.'' **********Consolidated Edison, now yielding 11 percent, edged ahead 1/4, to 26 3/4. On Thursday, the stock hit 27 during the day, its best price since 1972. **********Among the savings and loan issues, Fidelity Financial and Northern California Savings and Loan scored gains of better than 1 point each.  Digital Equipment, climbing 3 1/4, to 87 3/8, erased its 2 5/8-point loss on Thursday.  Precious-metal issues reflected the sharp rise in the price of gold bullion. Analysts said this stemmed from renewed international tensions in Poland. **********ASA Ltd. jumped 4 1/8, to 56 1/8. In turn, its May 60 call option advanced 1 9/16, to 3 1/4, on the Amex. A contract of 100 calls allows holders to buy 100 shares of ASA at 60 until the options expire in May. **********Meanwhile, put and call options for all stocks in the March series expired after the close of trading yesterday. Dome and Homestake Climb **********Elsewhere in the precious-metal group, Dome Mines and Homestake Mining also climbed more than 4 points each. **********But Newmont Mining slipped 1 1/4, to 60 1/2, after jumping 6 5/8 points on Thursday in response to unconfirmed rumors of a possible takeover. **********Yesterday's takeover conjecture, brokers said, helped to send City Investing ahead 1 1/8, to 26 3/4.  Mattel, reporting a fourth-quarter loss, fell 1 3/8, to 8 1/2.  The Chesapeake Corporation of Virginia rose 3 1/4, to 35 1/2. The company, a producer of linerboard and corrugated containers, said it could not explain the activity in its stock. **********Prices also improved for photography, steel and brokerage issues.  Brokerage stocks benefited from two factors, according to analysts. The stepped-up trading pace means more commission income for brokerage houses. Secondly, this week's agreement whereby the Prudential Insurance Company of America would acquire the Bache Group has touched off conjecture that other brokerage Zirms might receive similar overtures. **********A.G. Edwards rose 1 7/8, to 25. Gains of 1 point or better appeared in Shearson Loeb Rhoades, E.F. Hutton and Merrill Lynch.  Teledyne and Litton Industries were standouts among the conglomerates.  Energy stocks, which have undergone severe selling pressure in recent weeks, showed relatively small price changes yesterday.  But Marathon Oil fell 1 1/2, to 52. One analyst recently reduced 1981 and 1982 earnings estimates for the company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/23/busin.body_text: **********The Hecla Mining Company has offered to acquire Day Mines Inc. in an exchange of stock valued at about $165 million. Completion of the transaction would make Hecla the nation's largest silver producer. **********Under the merger proposal, Day shareholders would receive 1.65 shares of Hecla common stock for each of their shares. The action would come after a 3-for-2 Hecla stock split planned for Tuesday. **********''The proposed combination of the two companies' operations, employees and land holdings would create a larger, stronger and more efficient entity, which would be the premier silver mining company in the United States,'' said W.A. Griffith, the president of Hecla, after the merger proposal was made Saturday. Sunshine's Bid for Hecla **********Hecla's move comes about a month after the Sunshine Mining Company announced that it had purchased 370,206 common shares, or about 5.3 percent, of Hecla's outstanding stock. Sunshine, one of the largest silver producers in the country, had also said that it might seek to gain control of the silver, zinc and lead producer. **********In its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Sunshine reported that in 1979 it had proposed to Hecla that the two merge, but that Hecla did not respond. No further discussions were held, Sunshine said. **********Responding to the Hecla bid, Bob Mullen, a spokesman for Day Mines, said: ''We have just received the proposal. Of course, we take all proposals of this nature very seriously. We are analysing it and when we finish that, we will issue our own news release.'' Premium Offered on Day Shares **********The Hecla proposal offers Day shareholders a 46 percent premium for their shares, based on Thursday's closing price, and an 85 percent premium based on the closing price on Feb. 26, the day before Hecla filed notice that it had purchased 5.7 percent of Day's outstanding common stock. Hecla now owns 327,400 shares, or 7.51 percent, of Day Mines. Day Mines closed Friday at $27 a share, up $1, on the American Stock Exchange. **********In 1979, Hecla was second nationally to Asarco Inc. in silver production. Hecla, which will have 10,483,071 outstanding shares after the Tuesday split, had 1980 earnings of $55 million on revenues of $78.7 million. Hecla's Past Problems **********However, things were not always so bright for Hecla. Three years ago, battered by a long copper slump, low silver prices and a hefty bank debt, the company faced bankruptcy. A further complication was caused by a copper project that did not prove successful; Hecla took a $101 million write-off on this in 1978. But a subseqent rise in silver prices helped strengthen the companyand its stock, which has since risen from $5 to reach $35.875 last Friday, a gain of $1.375 on the day. **********Day, with 4,357,268 shares outstanding, had 1980 earnings of $10.3 million on revenues of $36.4 million. Its main operations are in Idaho and Colorado.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/13/busin.body_text: **********The Household Finance Corporation announced on Friday that it intended to acquire a bank in California by taking advantage of a loophole in Federal law. Through the bank, Valley National of Salinas, the finance company could establish a deposit-taking banking operation throughout the state. **********The only restriction would be that the bank could not grant business loans. By not making commercial loans, the bank no longer would be considered to be a ''bank'' by the Federal Reserve, and, therefore, Household would be allowed to acquire it. But, through its other subsidiaries, Household could continue to extend loans to businesses. **********Eighteen percent of Household's consumer loans are made in California, where the company has 250 branches, more than twice the number it has in any other state. A Household spokesman said last Friday that some of these branches might be turned into branches of the bank. Wider Application Feared **********Following the announcement, some bankers expressed fears that many other companies might also use the loophole to establish banking operations not only in California, or in a single state, but throughout the country. Earlier this year, by using the same loophole, a subsidiary of the Gulf and Western Corporation acquired the Fidelity National Bank of Concord, Calif. **********Banks, however, are prohibited from accepting deposits outside their own states and from engaging in businesses that the Federal Reserve considers not ''closely related'' to banking. **********The Bank Holding Company Act prohibits corporations that are not banks from acquiring banks. But, according to a spokesman for the Federal Reserve Board, the law defines a bank as an institution that accepts demand deposits and that makes commercial loans. Sidestepping Definition **********To avoid coming under the Bank Holding Company Act, Household Finance plans to have Valley National divest itself of its commercial loan portfolio. As a result, it would no longer be a bank, as defined by the Bank Holding Company Act. **********Household is offering to pay $20.3 million for all 310,000 outstanding shares of Valley National, which has $100 million in assets. The offer is equivalent to $65.15 a share, more than three times the bank's year-end book value of $20.65 a share. **********''This is our entry into the banking market in California,'' said the Household spokesman. To Household, he said, the $20 million is almost an insignificant figure compared with the opportunity the acquisition would provide. ''The key thing is having the entry vehicle,'' he said. Deposits Possible **********Household already has about $600 million of consumer loans in California. A bank would make it possible for the finance company to accept consumer deposits in the state, an activity in which only banks and thrift institutions may engage. **********''We've been the dominant independent bank in this area,'' said Edward L. Evans, president of Valley National. The bank's management welcomed the bid by Household, he said, because the finance company planned to retain the bank's management and because the 18-year-old bank would retain its identity. **********D. Vernon Horton, 40 years old, is executive vice president and chief executive officer of the bank, and Dennis Foss, 34, is senior vice president and chief administrative officer. **********At present, Valley National, which is in an agricultural area, has about $20 million in commercial loans. It also has about $22 million in consumer loans, $16.5 million in mortgages, $2.5 million in loans guaranteed by the Small Business Administration, and about $2 million in credit-card loans, Mr. Evans said. **********In 1980, the bank earned $927,000 on an equity base of $6.34 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/02/world.main_headline: TEXTS OF JUSTICE DEPARTMENT STATEMENT ON ALLEN AND SUMMARY OF FINDINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/02/world.print_headline: TEXTS OF JUSTICE DEPARTMENT STATEMENT ON ALLEN AND SUMMARY OF FINDINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/02/world.body_text: **********Following are the texts of the statement issued by the Justice Department today on the investigation of Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, and the summary of the findings of the department's Criminal Division on the matter: The Statement **********The Attorney General has decided to close the Department of Justice inquiry centering on the discovery of an envelope containing ten $100 bills in a safe in an office previously occupied by Richard V. Allen, Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs. **********The Federal Bureau of Investigation has interviewed all those who observed this envelope and its contents before its discovery as well as others possessing relevant information. Thirty-six people were interviewed in the United States and Japan. The Department's Criminal Division has carefully reviewed the F.B.I. report on this matter and concluded that it does not present any evidence that Mr. Allen violated Federal criminal law. **********The Attorney General has further concluded that the special prosecutor provisions of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 are not triggered because as to this matter the Department has not ''received'' or discovered any ''specific information'' that Mr.  Allen violated Federal criminal law. The Criminal Division recommended that this matter be closed without appointment of a special prosecutor or report to the Special Prosecutor Court. The Deputy Attorney General and the Associate Attorney General concurred in this recommendation. **********Because of the public interest in this matter and in order to answer some of the inquiries that the department has been unable to comment upon while this matter was still under review, the Attorney General authorized release of a report summarizing the Criminal Division's findings and conclusions. **********During the course of this inquiry two additional matters regarding Mr. Allen came to the department's attention: that Mr. Allen received watches from certain Japanese persons and that Mr. Allen's financial disclosure form incorrectly stated the date he sold his interest in Potomac International Corporation. Both of these matters came to the department's attention within the past 10 days. The applicability of the special prosecutor provisions to those matters has not yet been determined. At this time it would be premature and inappropriate to comment further. The Findings **********On Sept. 21, 1981, Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to the President, after having been told of this matter by White House employees, turned over copies of documents to the Attorney General that were found in a safe in an office used by Allen in the Old Executive Office Building. The documents consisted of a large outer envelope bearing Oriental characters; a smaller inner envelope with $10,000 written on it containing ten $100 bills; a piece of paper resembling a receipt with Oriental writing, including the figure $10,000; a business card of a Japanese Chamber of Commerce official and a faxgram dated Jan. 14, 1981, from the offical to Allen. No explanation or criminal allegation was furnished with the documents. Summary of Investigation **********Through interviews of 36 individuals in the United States and Japan1 and analysis of documentary evidence and forensic examinations, the investigation has yielded a complete, coherent and materially uncontradicted account of how the cash came to be found in the safe. On Jan. 21, 1981, an envelope containing ten $100 bills was intercepted by Allen when Japanese journalists attempted to hand it to Mrs. Reagan as an honorarium for a brief interview Mrs. Reagan had given to the journalists. Allen gave the envelope to his secretary with instructions to turn it over to the appropriate officials. The secretary placed the envelope in a safe and, through oversight, the cash was never officially reported or turned over to the appropriate officials. The envelope was discovered on Sept. 15, 1981, in a safe in an office used by Allen in the Old Executive Office Building by individuals moving into the office. Arranging the Interview **********Sometime in December 1980, Kamisaka Fuyoko, a writer for a Japanese women's magazine called Shufu-no-Tomo (translated: Friends of the Housewife or The Housewife's Friend, hereinafter referred to as the Magazine) discussed with Mrs. Takase Chizuko in Japan the possibility of interviewing Nancy Reagan for the Magazine. Mrs.  Takase knew Allen through her husband's business and personal relationship with him and she undertook to arrange such an interview. Mrs. Takase telephoned Allen and sought his help in arranging the interview. Allen, in a memorandum dated Dec. 8, 1980, wrote to Charles Tyson, then a scheduling official for the transition team, passing on Mrs. Takase's request and stating that he supported the request if time for a short interview could be arranged. Allen recalls referring the request for an interview to Peter Hannaford, who at that time was in the process of taking over Allen's private consulting business, Potomac International Corporation. Mrs. Takase states that she called Allen on Jan. 15, 1981, prior to departing Japan and that Allen told her there was almost no possibility of obtaining an interview because of the Reagans' busy schedule. **********Mrs. Takase, Mrs. Kamisaka and Kimoto Yoshiko, an editor of the Magazine, departed Tokyo for Washington, D.C., on Jan. 15, 1981, in hopes of obtaining an interview with Mrs. Reagan. Prior to departing, they discussed the subject of an honorarium for Mrs.  Reagan and decided on $1,000, which was withdrawn from the Magazine's accounting section in Japan. Mrs. Kimoto placed the $1,000 in a ''ceremonial pouch'' (the envelope) in Washington, D.C., prior to the interview. None of the women knew who wrote $10,000 on the envelope or the receipt form, but each stated that only $1,000 was put in the envelope.2 Accounting records obtained from the Magazine indicate that $1,000 was vouchered and dispensed for the honorarium.  The records also indicate that a total of $10,000 in cash was disbursed by the accounting office to the women to cover their expenses for the trip. **********Upon arriving in Washington on Jan. 16, 1981, the three women went to Hannaford's office where they told Hannaford that they were still seeking a response to their interview request. Shortly thereafter, Hannaford called Mrs. Reagan's chief of staff to request an interview of Mrs. Reagan for the three women. Hannaford did not contact Allen regarding the request. Neither Hannaford nor Potomac International Corporation received any compensation from the Magazine for the assistance provided. Mrs. Reagan's chief of staff had only a faint recollection regarding the request but believes that he passed on Hannaford's request to Mrs. Reagan. Both Mr. and Mrs. Takase contacted Allen regarding the interview during the three-day period before the Inauguration. There is no indication that Allen provided any assistance during that time period. **********On Jan. 20, Mrs. Takase received a phone call from the transition office informing her that an interview might be possible and she should stand ready. The following day, on Jan. 21, the women received a message from the transition office to come to the White House at 5:45 P.M. The Interview **********White House records and interviews indicate that Mrs. Reagan met with the three Japanese women for between 5 and 10 minutes at around 6 P.M. in the living quarters of the White House. In addition to Mrs. Reagan and Allen, at least five others were present. In the course of the session, Mrs. Kamisaka presented Mrs. Reagan with a lacquer box that she had purchased in Japan. The box was immediately turned over by Mrs. Reagan to the Government through appropriate White House channels. **********Allen states that one of the women also attempted to present Mrs.  Reagan with an envelope and some news clippings. Allen stepped in and took possession of the envelope and the clippings before they could be passed to Mrs. Reagan. One of the women asked Allen to sign a receipt but he refused ''since he had not accepted it for himself.'' Allen stated that he did not return the envelope to the women because he thought it would offend them. Allen did not recall from which of the women he took the envelope; Mrs. Kamisaka believes it was Mrs.  Takase, Mrs. Kimoto recalls that she gave the envelope to Mrs. Takase at the end of the interview but did not see what Mrs. Takase did with it, and Mrs. Takase cannot recall who had the envelope. get first add ALLEN TEXT Storage of the Envelope **********Allen states that after the interview he returned to his office where he opened the envelope while sitting at his desk. He recalled that it contained ten $100 bills. In his first interview, Allen said he recalled seeing the receipt, but in a later interview he said that he had not seen the receipt or a notation showing $10,000. In any event, he immediately turned the envelope over to his secretary, advising her that the money should be turned over to the appropriate officials. His secretary placed the envelope in a four-drawer safe in her office located next to Allen's former office in the Old Executive Office Building. Allen did not thereafter see the envelope. Peter Hannaford, Secretary of the Navy John Lehman, and Allen's wife have all told the F.B.I. that they recall Allen telling them sometime shortly after Jan. 21 about the incident, including the fact that he had intercepted an envelope contaning cash that one of the women had attempted to hand to Mrs. Reagan. **********Allen told the F.B.I. that he should have made sure the envelope was turned over in the proper manner; however, due to the confusion of moving into the White House, his secretary did not get around to cataloguing the money and properly disposing of it. Allen's secretary corroborated these facts and has told the F.B.I. that she wanted to accept full responsibility for the money since it was her responsibility to dispose of it properly. **********In February, Allen's secretary moved to new office space in the West Wing of the White House. At about the same time, another National Security Council secretary also moved out of the Old Executive Office Building office previously occupied by Allen's secretary. In the process of moving, she checked the safe in the office to make sure it was empty. In one of the drawers she discovered a gift package and an envelope with Oriental writing. She opened the envelope and observed ten $100 bills. She immediately summoned yet another National Security Council secretary to the office and showed her the envelope. The second secretary remembers seeing ten or eleven $100 bills. **********The second secretary then notified Allen's secretary that they had found an envelope with $1,000 in the safe. She was instructed by Allen's secretary to notify an assistant to Allen, who was occupying Allen's former office. She gave the envelope and package to the assistant who says he received the envelope from her, opened it and counted ten $100 bills. On his own initiative the assistant put the envelope and packages in the two-drawer safe in Allen's former office ''for safekeeping.'' He left the National Security Council in March 1981 with the envelope still in the safe and without notifying Allen of what he had done with the envelope. The envelope was next discovered in the two-drawer safe on Sept. 15. Discovery of the Envelope **********On Sept. 15, 1981, three military officers on special detail to the White House were moving into Allen's former office in the Old Executive Office Building when they opened a two-drawer safe they had presumed was empty. In the safe were several gift-wrapped packages, the receipt form and the envelope containing $1,000. The $1,000 was observed by two of the officers and a secretary. The secretary turned the envelope and packages over to Barbara Diering, the head of the Administrative Office of the National Security Council. While in Diering's office, the items were inspected by Jerry Jennings, the chief of security for the National Security Council staff. A business card of a Japanese Chamber of Commerce official was taped to one of the packages. In an effort to locate any related documents which might bear on the envelope, Jennings found in another office a faxgram from the Japanese Chamber of Commerce official to Allen requesting assistance in obtaining an audience with Ronald Reagan.  Jennings mistakenly believed that this faxgram was related to the envelope because of the proximity of the envelope containing the ten $100 bills to the gift box which had the business card attached.3 On Sept. 21, Jennings turned over to Meese the envelope, the faxgram and the business card. Later the same day, Meese turned over copies of the documents to the Attorney General. Analysis Facts **********The facts uncovered in the investigation of this matter involving the envelope containing $1,000 are consistent on all material points. These points are: **********1. The $1,000 received by Allen was intended as an honorarium for Mrs. Reagan. Each of the three Japanese women and the Magazine records are consistent on that point. There is no evidence that the cash was intended for Allen. **********2. Allen did not intend to keep the money for his personal use.  Both Allen and his secretary agree on Allen's expressed intent to turn the money over through proper channels. The fact that Allen wholly parted with dominion and control over the money, left the envelope in a safe accessible to others, and told several people, including the present Secretary of the Navy, about the cash, is inconsistent with an intent to keep the money for personal use. There is no evidence to indicate Allen intended to keep the money for himself. **********3. There was only $1,000 in the envelope turned over to Allen.  Although the receipt and envelope contain the figure $10,000, all the evidence indicates that only $1,000 was given to Allen. The three women and the Magazine's records indicate $1,000 was given and everyone who saw the envelope and money, a total of eight people, observed only $1,000 with one exception and that person recalled observing ten or eleven $100 bills. Relevant Criminal Statutes **********The bribery statute, 18 U.S.C. 201(c), requires that Allen receive something of value in return for being influenced in the performance of an official act. In this matter, the money was not given to Allen for anything he had done; rather, it was intended as an honorarium for Mrs. Reagan and simply intercepted by Allen. It was neither given nor received to benefit Allen or to influence him in any way. Indeed, he was not even aware of the contents of the envelope until after the meeting was completed. **********For the same reason, the gratuity statute, 18 U.S.C. 201(g), is inapplicable. That statute proscribes the receipt of something of value by a public official ''for himself for or because of any official act performed or to be performed by him.'' In this instance, Allen was not given the $1,000 for himself and it was not intended by Allen or the women to thank Allen for anything. **********18 U.S.C. 209 proscribes receipt of compensation by an official for his services as an official from sources other than the Government.  Again, there is no evidence that the money was either given to or received by Allen with an intent to compensate him. Similarly, 18 U.S.C. 203, proscribing compensation to a Government official for services in relation to a Government proceeding, is inapplicable because the money was not intended to compensate Allen for anything. **********In sum, when the uncontradicted facts are analyzed in the context of possibly applicable criminal laws, it is clear there was no criminal violation by Allen regarding the $1,000. Applicability of the Special Prosecutor Provisions of the Ethics in Government Act **********The special prosecutor provisions of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, 28 U.S.C. 591, et seq., are triggered by the receipt of ''specific information'' that a person covered by the act committed a Federal criminal offense. As an employee of the Executive Office of the President with a salary above Executive Level IV, Allen is a person covered by the act. With regard to the $1,000 matter, the act would thus be triggered if the department had received, at any point, specific information that Allen committed a Federal crime. **********Neither the initial documents nor subsequent investigation has provided specific information regarding a criminal violation and, thus, the statute has not been triggered. The initial referral, insofar as it involved a sum of cash found in a White House safe, was sufficiently suspicious in nature to warrant an inquiry into the surrounding circumstances. At the beginning of the inquiry there was no allegation or information that Allen committed any crime. Thus, strictly speaking, this was not a preliminary investigation under the act which commences only after the department receives specific information of a crime. Rather, this was an inquiry to determine whether the ''suspicious circumstances'' amounted to specific information. Instead of uncovering specific information regarding a crime, the subsequent investigation has, without contradiction, yielded a detailed and innocent explanation of how the money arrived in the safe. There is no evidence that the money was intended for Allen or was kept by Allen for a corrupt purpose. **********In brief, the Attorney General has never received nor has the investigation revealed specific information of a Federal crime by Allen regarding the $1,000 and, thus, the Ethics in Government Act is inapplicable. It would, therefore, be inappropriate to appoint a special prosecutor or to file a report with the Special Prosecutor Court. ----1. The F.B.I. is not permitted to conduct interviews in Japan.  Thus all interviews in Japan had to be conducted by the Japanese National Police Agency. ----2. Forensic examination of the documents revealed that there were no differences in the ink used to write the figure ($10,000) and the ink used for the rest of the Japanese handwriting on the envelope and the receipt form. ----3. Jennings believed that the business card was somehow related to the envelope because it was attached to a box proximate to the envelope when he inspected the items in Diering's office. The individuals who opened the safe, however, stated that the envelope fell out from among the packages when they removed them from the safe. They did not know where the envelope had been placed among the boxes and when the envelope and boxes were given to Diering, no effort was made to duplicate the original position of the envelope.  Jennings' assumption that the envelope's position among the boxes had some significance when he later inspected them was thus incorrect.  The faxgram and business card are wholly irrelevant to the envelope.  The gift boxes were opened and inspected by the F.B.I. with Allen's permission. They contained gifts of nominal value. Allen does not remember precisely when he received the various gifts, but he says they will all be properly catalogued. None of the gifts has any relationship to the envelope or the Magazine interview.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/25/busin.main_headline: TOP POSTS TO ENGINEER AT HATZEL & BUEHLER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; TOP POSTS TO ENGINEER AT HATZEL & BUEHLER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/25/busin.body_text: **********Hatzel & Buehler Inc., one of the nation's oldest and largest electrical construction concerns, has elected Bernard Finkelstein, 55, as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Robert A.  Goeller Jr., 53, who was named chairman of the New York-based corporation. **********Referring to business conditions in his industry, Mr. Finkelstein said that ''the Midwest is horrible and we're looking to go into new areas of the country.'' One such area that he mentioned is the Southwest, because ''that's where the future is.'' Hatzel & Buehler, founded in 1884, has branch offices for electrical contracting and subcontracting work in Delaware and Michigan, as well as Long Island and New Jersey. **********Mr. Finkelstein, a professional engineer, has worked for electrical construction companies his entire career and previously spent 22 years with the Forest Electric Company, rising to the top operations position. He joined Hatzel & Buehler in 1978 as executive vice president. **********Mr. Goeller, son of a former chairman and president of Hatzel & Buehler, started working full time at the corporation in 1949 and became a vice president 21 years later. He was elected president in 1974. **********''I'm looking to get into the mechanical end of it,'' Mr.  Finklestein said, referring to the plumbing and heating components of commercial and industrial structures. ''This way, you're able to offer an owner a complete package. And especially the way the buildings now are going, the heating and the plumbing have a big impact on the electrical.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/18/busin.body_text: **********The Itel Corporation, the company that went bankrupt leasing computer equipment, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to settle all remaining claims with Lloyd's of London, its principal insurer. **********Since 1978, Itel's maximum potential liability relating to its computer transactions insured by Lloyd's has been reduced to $100 million from $300 million, according to Catherine Manz Compton, a spokesman for Itel. **********The claims were made against an insurance policy that Itel purchased to cover its losses from computer equipment that it financed through other institutions and then leased to customers. **********Under the agreement signed yesterday, Lloyd's will continue to settle directly with the banks and other institutions that financed the computers. In addition, Itel will receive $4 million from Lloyd's and an escrow account of $2 million will be released by Lloyd's. Procedure Formalized **********The settlement made yesterday formalizes an arrangement that Lloyd's has been following for the past year. Before that, Lloyd's had challenged many of the claims filed by Itel. **********Itel filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act last Jan. 19. The proposed agreement with Lloyd's must be approved by the bankruptcy court. **********The agreement applies to an insurance policy that Lloyd's wrote on the computer equipment. Itel leased I.B.M. 370 computers to customers for seven years, the period of time required to pay for the computers. Lloyd's insured Itel against losses that resulted when a customer chose to terminate a lease after three or four years. **********But an unexpected number of leases were broken after 1979, when I.B.M. introduced the 4300 computer, which was faster and less expensive than the 370. When Itel began to file claims with Lloyd's in 1979, the two concerns became entangled in a dispute over the extent to which the Lloyd's policy covered Itel's losses. **********James H. Maloon, Itel's chairman, said in a prepared statement that the agreement with Lloyd's was ''a major milestone in the company's efforts to reorganize following the collapse of its computer-related businesses in 1979.'' **********John C. Kingery, president of Itel's lease finance division, said in a telephone interview that the company's liablity had been reduced in various ways, including expiration of its obligations to buy equipment; payments between Itel and the parties that financed the equipment, and claims payments by Lloyd's. **********Mr. Kingery declined to comment on the amount of money Itel had paid in settlements.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/14/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Neil Orloff's ''Rethinking Environmental Law,'' (May 10) points out an important problem of environmental policy: the myriad laws and regulations that have to be satisfied for energy development projects. It was concerns such as his that led to Congressional consideration of ''fast-track'' legislation and President Carter's proposal for an energy mobilization board. **********During the debate over the mobilization board one example of delay and frustration stood out: the PACTEX pipeline proposed by Standard Oil of Ohio. Professor Orloff also uses PACTEX as his sole example supporting regulatory change. While such changes may be desirable, the pipeline is not a solid basis for support of that argument; indeed, one could make the claim that the pipeline's history argues the necessity for careful consideration of energy development projects. **********The pipeline example suffers from two problems.  First, there was testimony developed during Congressional hearings on the board proposal that Sohio was somewhat less than responsive to regulatory requests. Some of the delay, therefore, appears to be attributable to Sohio's inaction. **********Second, there is the history of the Alaskan pipeline.  Environmentalists wanted the pipeline to be built through Canada to the United States Middle West. By building the pipeline to Valdez and then shipping the oil to California, as was decided, excess crude was available on the West Coast. PACTEX's purpose, then, was to move the excess crude to Midwest refineries. Had the pipeline been built to the Midwest in the first place, PACTEX would not have been necessary. Had Congress not cut off debate, the other route might have been chosen. **********Changes in environmental laws and regulations may be necessary, as Professor Orloff states, but PACTEX does not support that case.  MARK RUSHEFSKY Assistant Professor University of Florida Gainesville, Fla., May 15
