https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/31/busin.main_headline: Patents; A Method for Carving Jack-o'-Lanterns
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/31/busin.print_headline: Patents; A Method for Carving Jack-o'-Lanterns
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/31/busin.body_text: **********Jack-o'-lanterns are traditionally made for display on Halloween.  By coincidence, Christopher A. Nauman of Frederick, Md., was granted a patent this week for his method of forming them from pumpkins and for the tools to be used in shaping their facial features. **********The procedure outlined in patent 4,296,659 includes the use of specially shaped cutters to form eye, nose and mouth apertures in the pumpkin wall. After the features have been formed, the top of the pumpkin head can be sheared off, the interior cleared and a lighted candle inserted for display. **********The whole operation takes about four minutes, according to Mr.  Nauman, and youngsters won't cut themselves, as they might with knives.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/25/world.body_text: **********Egyptian security units have arrested more than 350 Moslem ''terrorists'' belonging to the organzation that is believed responsible for the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat, the semi-official newspaper Al Ahram reported today. **********Egyptian security sources indicated that the police were still searching villages and cities across the country in the hutn for more members of the underground Moslem network that reportedly engineered the slaying of Mr. Sadat at a military parade 18 days ago. **********President Hosni Mubarak said in an interview published in Al Ahram today that the conspiracy to kill Mr. Sadat involved a coalition of secret Islamic societies, with the leading role being played by a group called Takfir Wahigra, or Atonement and Repentance. **********Mr. Mubarak said the assassins and other members of the network, which reached inside the armed forces, had planned to annihilate the entire Egyptian political, religious and military hierarchy in preparation for establishing an Islamic republic like that of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in Iran. Higher Figures Reported **********Al Ahram quoted security officials as saying that 356 terrorists involved in the assassination and the planned coup had been arrested. The latest official number of arrests marked an increase of 126 from the figures released last week by the Interior Ministry, an indication that the nationwide roundup was continuing. **********Other Egyptian security sources, however, said that the number of arrests disclosed by the Government was too low and that about 1,500 people -both religious militants and political extremists - have been detained since the assassination on Oct. 6. **********Al Ahram said arms caches discovered in the terrorists' hideouts contained machine guns, automatic rifles, homemade grenades, gelignite, TNT, pistols and hundres of rounds of ammunition. **********Mr. Mubarak said the Moslem terrorists were also found to have a mufti, an adviser on Islamic law, who provided spurious religious legitimization for their acts of assassination and theft. The mufti has been arrested and during his interrogation demonstrated no academic or religious credentials, the President said. Education Campaign Planned **********The authorities appeared to be taking every opportunity to emphasize the extremism of the assassins, as well as the wide scope of their plot, in an effort to create a national consensus for the crackdown. **********In a related development, the Ministry of Education announced a campaign to counter the teachings of the Islamic fundamentalist societies, particularly among the young. Half of Egypt's population of 43 million is under the age of 15. **********The Ministry said new Islamic curricula would be introduced in all public schools next year to explain the basic tenets of the faith and the role it can play in facing the problems of the age. **********In addition, a team of professors from the state-run Islamic university, Al Azhar, will be touring campuses to outline authentic religious concepts and ''correct the ideas of youth,'' the ministry said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/jobs/.main_headline: WORD PROCESSORS SPELL OUT A NEW ROLE FOR CLERICAL STAFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/jobs/.print_headline: WORD PROCESSORS SPELL OUT A NEW ROLE FOR CLERICAL STAFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/jobs/.body_text: **********T HE growing business reliance on word processors, those small computers with typewriterlike keyboards designed to complete routine reports and other rote clerical chores, has barely begun, but it already is having a profound effect on the office of the present as well as the future. **********Authors, including the novelist John Hersey and Jimmy Carter, working on an autobiography, have abandoned their typewriters in favor of them. Instead of employing secretaries to retype drafts, complete footnotes and number pages, authors are accomplishing these chores by touching a few keys. **********Where there was one word processor for every 10 clerical workers last year, by mid-decade the figure will be one for every three.  However, the machines, experts believe, are not likely to lessen the demand for clerical workers in the 1980's. The use of the processors by small as well as large employers is expected to give secretaries more time and opportunity to perform duties now completed by managers. If this happens, experts believe, the serious shortage of secretaries may subside and the gap in wages between executives and secretaries may narrow. **********''Secretaries are an executive perk and no businessman or professional wants to be without one,'' said Bruce Richardson, a market analyst with the Yankee Group, a Boston consulting firm.  ''They are in no danger of being replaced by word-processing machines, as some people had feared when the machines were introduced in the early 1970's,'' said Larry Drake, an economist in the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics. **********But experts do predict a radical restructuring of work, including a devaluation of current work skills and the creation of new ones.  ''Filing skills will be far less important, because these machines can store vast amounts of information that can be retrieved at the touch of a key,'' Mr. Richardson said. ''Many word processors come with spelling verification so that secretaries won't have to spend their time verifying the boss's spelling.'' **********''The emphasis on typing speed also will decline because these machines make it possible for secretaries to handle more work in less time,'' said John J. Connell, executive dire ctor of the Office Technology Research Group, a Pasadena, Calif. , organization of managers from 44 foreign and domestic compani es concerned with managing change in the office. ''Instead of s pending 20 percent of her day typing, the typical secretary will sp end only 10 percent in the years ahead. Secretaries will have more t ime to devote to intellectual tasks that are now don e by their bosses and o ther managers.'' **********Mr. Connell cited the example of a secretary who was given responsibility for preparing a proposed budget, a task that had previously been assigned to a manager. She queried the department heads about their requirements for the coming fiscal year, fed the information into the word processor, and came up with a proposed budget that was critiqued by her boss and other top managers. **********''If more secretaries were given duties like that, their morale would improve and more women might be attracted to the field,'' Mr.  Connell said. ''Secretarial salaries also might rise. The typical manager now makes three to four times what the typical secretary earns, but if she starts assuming some managerial duties this gap may lessen.'' **********The salaries of secretaries with word-processing skills are already higher than those who lack such expertise, according to Mr.Richardson. ''The typical secretary earns from $250 to $300 a week while the secretary who has skills in word-processing earns at least $50 more,'' he said. **********Acquiring skills in word processing will be easier in the decade ahead because more high schools and colleges are offering instruction. Several temporary-help agencies also have adopted shortterm training programs because more than a million word-processing units have been installed in offices and another 1.5 million are expected to be installed by 1985. Some of the 50 manufacturers of word-processing equipment also have developed disks and other selfteaching aids. **********One of the biggest problems to be overcome is worker resistance.  ''The use of word processors has meant a slight improvement in the working lives of some clerical workers because it has removed the drudgery of repetitive typing,'' said Karen Nussbaum, director of Working Women, a group representing female office workers. ''But for millions of others, it has meant that they are assigned to centers where they do nothing but baby-sit machines for eight hours. **********Bernard Schwartz, director of communication of the International Information/Processing Association, Willow Grove, Pa., believes that this atmosphere will be changed because the lower price of machines will allow companies to disperse them throughout their organizations, rather than restricting them to a single center. **********''Word processing is a good field for career-minded people,'' Mr.  Schwartz said. ''Many of our 14,000 members started out as secretaries, and today some of them are earning as much as $50,000 a year, because word processing was a career path to management. In the 1980's, more secretaries will have such opportunities.''  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Sharon Johnson is a freelance writer - who still uses a typewriter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/13/busin.main_headline: WHEN UNCLE SAM IS THE BABY SITTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/13/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; WHEN UNCLE SAM IS THE BABY SITTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/13/busin.body_text: **********A LTHOUGH the Reagan tax bill provides generous tax breaks for the wealthy, it also contains several provisions that could substantially trim taxes for the average American family. One is an easing of the marriage penalty. Another is a provision that could greatly aid many two-income households with children, but is still virtually unknown outside a tight coterie of tax experts. **********That provision would permit companies to set up tax-favored ''dependent-care assistance programs'' to help pay for employee child-care expenses, a much sought-after fringe benefit now that more and more mothers are working. Effective Jan. 1, 1982, companies can set up and pay for the costs of on-site day-care centers, directly pay the outside providers of such services, or reimburse employees for the costs of home day care provided by housekeepers and babysitters. **********Within certain limits, employees will not have to report the reimbursement as taxable income, just as they now do not have to report medical reimbursements. In addition, companies will be able to claim a tax deduction for their share of the bill, so long as the program is a formal written plan and is not limited to highly paid workers. **********''It may be one of the most signifi cant items in the entire tax act,'' said R ichard W. Hutson, a partner in Hewitt Associates, an employee bene fits consulting firm in Lincolnshire, Ill. **********The program offers generous savings to families that have to spe nd up to $6,000 a year and more for their childr en's day-care arrangements. ''If you could get that same su m on a tax-free basis, you'd be ecstatic,'' Mr. Hutson said. ''It wo uld mean a $1,200 tax savings for someone in a 20 percent tax brack et and a $3,000 tax savings for someone in a 50 percent bracket.' ' **********But Mr. Hutson and other consultants are most interested in the impact that the provision may ultimately have on a new kind of compensation arrangement, called salary reduction, that is still in the drawing-board stage. **********Under such an arrangement, a company would reduce a worker's salary by the amount of tax-free fringe benefits received. Despite the pay cut, the Hewitt consultants say that in the short run, the worker is better off because he or she wrings more after-tax use out of the total compensation package. The employer also benefits because its total employee compensation package is more tax-effective and the wage base on which it must pay Social Security taxes is reduced. **********There are long-term drawbacks, however. An employee may suffer because his wage base for retirement benefits is reduced. Clearly, workers are best off if companies add a day-care assistance program to their existing fringe benefits without a salary reduction plan. **********So far, there has been little movement by managements to embrace the idea, according to Mr. Hutson. ''It's a sleeper, and the typical reaction has been one of surprise,'' he said. ''Most people say, 'Gee, I don't believe that. I want to read it for myself.' '' **********In any case, there are still many sticky questions about day-care assistance plans. It is unclear, for instance, how companies will be able to monitor a reimbursement program for home day care to insure that those providing the service do not inflate their fees and kick back some of the excess to the parents. And some consultants are concerned that day-care assistance may favor employees with children over those without. For this reason, they say, such a plan may be best suited to companies with ''flexible'' benefit plans. **********Such plans have a core group of common benefits, such as basic medical insurance, and then permit workers to choose among a laundry list of supplementary benefits that best suit their lifestyles. Some people may opt for extra vacation days, while others choose dental insurance. **********The other provisions of the tax bill that deal with family tax matters are more straightforward. For example, the easing of the marriage penalty, which taxes a two-earner couple more heavily than if both parties were single, will be gradually phased out starting next year. Effective in 1982, such couples will be able to claim a deduction of $1,500, or 5 percent of the lower-paid spouse's earnings up to $30,000, whichever is less. In 1983, the deduction doubles to $3,000, or 10 percent of the lower-paid spouse's earnings up to $30,000, whichever is less. **********Sidney Kess, national tax partner with the accounting firm of Main Hurdman, notes that only a spouse's earned wages and salary qualify for this tax break. The deduction is not applicable to interest income, dividends, distributions from Individual Retirement Accounts, pension or annuity payments, deferred compensation or salary paid by a taxpayer to his or her employee-spouse. **********Mr. Kess also suggests some marital tax planning to take maximum advantage of the provision. A unmarried couple currently living together would be well advised to postpone marriage until 1982. ''In some cases, they could save enough in taxes to pay for their honeymoon.'' Conversely, he said, two-career couples in the middle of a divorce proceeding might be better off to complete their break before the end of the year. **********However, David A. Berenson, a partner at Ernst & Whinney, said the provision, enacted to provide relief to one taxpayer group that felt disadvantaged, will now penalize women who drop out of the labor force to raise their children. He gave the example of a wife who earns $40,000 and a husband $30,000. If the husband's salary rises to $70,000 and the woman quits to raise their child, ''they will lose out on a $3,000 deduction.'' **********The new law also offers a retroactive tax break to parents who adopt children, but it has limited applicability. People who adopt starting this year can claim a deduction of up to $1,500 for such expenses as adoption fees, court costs and legal fees. But to qualify for the deduction, they must adopt a child who is handicapped or a member of a minority group. **********Finally, the law liberalizes the credit that working parents can claim for child-care expenses. Currently, the maximum credit is $400, or 20 percent of the first $2,000 in expenses for one child, and $800, or 20 percent of the first $4,000 in expenses for two or more children. Effective f or 1982, the credit will be increased and changed to a sliding scale , depending on a family's income. For couples with adjusted gros s incomes of $10,000 or less, the credit for one child will be a max imum of $720, or 30 percent of the first $2,400 in expenses. For two or more, it will be $1,440, or 30 percent of the fir st $4,800. The credit decreases by one percentage point for each additional $2,000 in income. Thus, for families earning mo re than $28,000, it is only $480 for one child and $960 for two or more. **********Despite its advantages, the provision has come under criticism. Its impact is miniscule compared with relief the bill has granted to high-income taxpayers by retroactively reducing the capital gains rate and by cutting the maximum tax rate next year to 50 percent from 70 percent. **********''Sure a credit of $1,440 looks good, but how many people who make $10,000 a year can afford to spend $4,800 on child care,'' said Mr.  Kess. ''For the typical middle class couple, the increase is peanuts.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/24/busin.main_headline: A ROSY OUTLOOK FOR OIL, BUT CROSS YOUR FINGERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/24/busin.print_headline: A ROSY OUTLOOK FOR OIL, BUT CROSS YOUR FINGERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/24/busin.body_text: **********A S the oil ministers' customized jets swoop toward Geneva for the mid-year meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that begins tomorrow, a consensus has taken shape among Western economists, oil analysts and government policymakers that the cartel has never been in shakier shape. **********Maybe. But lurking in the shadows is a nagging suspicion, founded on hard experience, that the world oil situation could turn nasty overnight. The industrialized nations' dependence on OPEC oil, while somewhat diminished, is by no means a bygone worry. Nor is the pricing history of this commodity, even pre-OPEC, a cause for much celebration. **********But the optimists do have some strong arguments: Demand for petroleum products in the industrialized world is plummeting, the world oil market is soggy with excess supplies, and the most significant OPEC member, Saudi Arabia, is running its wells at unusually high levels, aiming at freezing prices or even forcing them lower. **********''Consuming nations, for the first time in years, are gaining the upper hand,'' Business Week pronounced this week. ''Never before on the eve of an OPEC meeting has the cartel's hold on consuming nations been so tenuous.'' **********''The chances of an oil price increase for the remainder of the year are very, very slim,'' said John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. Moreover, he predicts the inflation-adjusted price of foreign petroleum will remain stable through 1985. **********The reasons for this more cheerful outlook are rooted in some familiar sour news - the 20-fold increase in the price of oil over the past decade, and particularly, the doubling of prices in the last two years. **********As a result of the painful price hikes, the Western world's demand for petroleum plunged by 2.5 million barrels a day last year, and by another 2 million to 2.3 million barrels in the first quarter of 1981. Moreover, some optimistic forecasts, such as that of the Mellon Institute of Energy Productivity, have suggested that more efficient use of energy could totally eliminate the need for oil imports to the United States by 2000. **********The higher prices are also encouraging oil exploration in non-OPEC nations. Over the past two years such output, chiefly from Mexico and the North Sea, has increased by nearly 2 million barrels daily and further increases seem certain. Additionally, the current level of oil prices is finally beginning to make synthetic fuels look economically attractive, if soaring interest rates come down, Mr.  Lichtblau suggests. **********Unquestionably, all these developments have weakened the roar of the OPEC lion, and represent cause for hope. But it would be a serious mistake to consider the oil cartel a meek pussycat. The precarious nature of the West's dependence on OPEC petroleum is evident from the following factors: *********** Since the days of John D. Rockefeller, the oil business has been characterized by periods of price-depressing glut, followed by periods of shortage and sharply higher prices. The market forces that are now limiting OPEC's power could quickly reverse themselves, particularly when Western economies recover from the doldrums and regain momentum. *********** One major producing country, say Libya, could be shut down by internal or external events. The danger of a repeat of the disastrous price leapfrogging that followed the Iranian revolution two-and-a-half years ago would then arise. *********** Saudi Arabia could cut its 10.3 million barrel daily production by 2 million or 3 million barrels. Although current world inventories - some 600 million barrels above normal - are ample, oil analysts suggest a Saudi cutback would inspire enough nervousness to quickly firm up today's weak market. Certain oil analysts insist this is true despite the fact it would take more than six months for a Saudi cutback to 8.5 million barrels to have much of an effect on world stocks. Simply put, Saudi Arabia is that important. **********Essentially, the message behind today's headlines, oil analysts say, is that the happier view of oil should be taken with at least a small grain of salt. ''No matter how the price goes, whenever it stops rising, there is a tremendous sigh of relief and life is beautiful again,'' Morris A. Adelman, an economist at the Massachussetts Institute of Technology, said. The Economics **********I N essence, the oil business is just like any other commodity business. Higher prices bring on more supplies - until the market is saturated, and the cycle repeats itself. Because of oil's importance in driving overall economic activity, such cycles tend to be even more dramatic. **********This, of course, has been the impetus behind repeated efforts in the oil business to stabilize prices by setting limits on production. Oil historians point out that it was only a small step from the Texas Railroad Commission and the Oklahoma Corporation Commission, which early on regulated production in those states, to OPEC's efforts on a world scale. **********But even with such self-imposed production curbs, market forces often fight their way to the surface and emerge as dominant factors.  After the initial quadrupling of crude oil prices in 1973-74, the industrialized nations plunged into a recession, one that was on the way anyway, many economists think, albeit in less severe fashion.  This had the effect of cutting demand, and thus preventing increases in the real, or inflation-adjusted, price of foreign petroleum until revolution wiped out Iran's production in 1979. **********United States demand in the post-recession recovery responded expectedly. It surged by nearly 7 percent in 1975-76, as large gasguzzling cars were again embraced, and by more than 3 percent in each of the next two years. The net result was that the American public was nicely set up for 1979's big price hikes. **********Could it happen again? ''If economies suddenly revive as oil is getting a little cheaper and taking less of the paycheck, we could see the same thing,'' a top oil analyst said. **********Arguing against a re-occurrence of the old pattern is the view that today's high level of petroleum prices is itself enough to curb demand, even without real increases. Arguing in favor of a demand spurt, with the accompanying temptation on OPEC to jack up prices, would be a quick and dramatic econodic improvement resulting from President Reagan's budget and tax proposals. The Flashpoints **********J AMES SCHLESINGER, who was Secretary of Energy at the time, said in the midst of the Iranian revolution that that crisis ''underscored the fragility'' of the world oil system. That fragility is still woefully apparent. **********As Syria and Israel are taking each other's measure in the lush hills and valleys of Lebanon, top planning officials of the international oil companies are muttering that the Arab nations may again employ the oil weapon against the United States if war breaks out. Moreover, spring has come to Iran, and with the good weather, the threat of a resumption of hostilities. **********''My God, you have a war,'' said Walter McDonald, former top energy analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency. ''You've got Iran and Iraq sitting and waiting to shoot at each other again.'' **********Mr. McDonald contradicts a number of optimistic reports that peace between the two countries is imminent, saying ''chances are the fighting will start up again.'' **********Bolstering this view, in recent days, several Japanese tankers have elected not to take loadings from Iran's Kharg Island terminal, for fear of being attacked, a major oil company official said. **********Oil analysts note that the biggest increases in crude prices have come as a result of supply disruptions that have thrown markets into pandemonium, rather than specific pricing decisions by OPEC. The two biggest have been those following 1973's Yom Kippur War and 1979's Iranian revolution. But smaller incidents, and even fears of disruptions, have also occasionally sent oil markets spinning. **********Experts cite two factors that might make future supply interruptions worse than earlier ones. First, the Iranian cutoff proved it now only takes one country to send prices spiraling upward; in 1973 it had taken 10 Arab countries acting in concert to have any appreciable effect. Iraq's new importance as OPEC's secondbiggest producer in times of peace makes this an especially worrisome point. **********Second, the amount of oil controlled by international oil companies outside North America has shrunk from 19 million barrels a day in 1973 to only 7 million barrels in 1978, and it has shrunk even more since then, according to analysts and company officials. **********As governments have wrested control from the companies, they have also increasingly favored government-to-government sales, often with strict condions attached, such as ones limiting resale. This significantly reduces the flexibility with which the world oil system can respond to crises, analysts point out. The Saudis **********I N times of oil abundance, ''Saudi Arabia is OPEC,'' Mr. Lichtblau said. By its own production decisions, it can almost singlehandedly determine the price of petroleum.  Currently, the desert kingdom produces 10.3 million barrels of oil a day, nearly 2 million barrels a day above its official ceiling of 8.5 million barrels. But Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Oil Minister, said in New York last month that production of only 5.2 million barrels would ''give us what we need'' in terms of revenues. And in January, in a speech delivered at the University of Petroleum and Minerals in Dammam, Saudi Arabia, he said Saudi Arabia ''may have to reduce its production to four, or even three, million barrels a day'' to keep the price of oil at a level acceptable to the cartel in the face of tumbling demand. **********Production cuts of this magnitude would come in the face of Sheik Yamani's own pronouncements that the price of oil may be rising too fast, damaging Western economies where the Saudis have invested billions of dollars and forcing more conservation and fuel switching than would occur if price rises were more restrained. Moreover, Saudi Arabia hopes to receive F-15 fighters and AWACs surveillance planes from the United States, as well as expand its trade with the West. **********But powerful minorities in the kingdom are said to be pressing for drastic cuts in oil output, a move that would have the immediate effect of solidifying prices for the entire cartel. **********''If Saudi Arabia wants a strong OPEC, they can have it any time they want,'' said James Tanner, an international oil expert with the Petroleum Information Corporation. Added Mr. Adelman: ''The Saudis could be the cartel enforcer. If you put their backs to the wall, I haven't the slightest doubt what they're going to do.'' The Upshot? **********F OR the present, tumbling demand and the world's enormous inventories of oil are expected to militate against any price increase and keep oil prices relatively stable. If OPEC's goal of unifying prices is achieved, it will lay the way for the cartel's adoption of a long-term plan for gradual price increases, probably of 9 percent to 12 percent a year in real terms. But even that is substantial: Real price increases of only 5 percent annually would push the price of oil above $100 a barrel in 1981 dollars by the year 2000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/22/world.body_text: **********White House sources in Washington said last night that President Reagan was expected to nominate Maxwell M. Rabb, a New York lawyer active in Jewish affairs, as ambassador to Italy. **********Mr. Rabb, a 70-year-old native of Boston with a law office at 61 Broadway, had served in various capacities in the Eisenhower Administration. **********There have been reports in the press in Italy that some Italian-Americans were unhappy with the choice because of a preference for an Italian-American in the post and because of Mr.  Rabb's age. **********Mr. Rabb was a key figure in the Reagan campaign in New York. He was active in fund-raising and promoted the Reagan candidacy in the Jewish community.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/06/world.main_headline: 22 COUNTRIES AVAIL THEMSELVES OF PAKISTANI SOLDIERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/06/world.print_headline: 22 COUNTRIES AVAIL THEMSELVES OF PAKISTANI SOLDIERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/06/world.body_text: **********With two divisions of troops now reported to be assembling for deployment to Saudi Arabia, Pakistan is becoming the third world's leading supplier of military manpower after Cuba. **********There are Pakistani military missions in 22 countries, with the largest contingents in Saudi Arabia, Jordan, Libya and Abu Dhabi. In all, analysts here believe, there are nearly 10,000 Pakistanis serving on foreign soil in addition to the contentent for Saudi Arabia, which is said to involve up to 20,000 men. The military missions, part of Pakistan's large and well-trained army, are already becoming a factor in the increasingly tense maneuvering around the Persian Gulf. **********Some Western sources say that a Pakistani military group has already been dispatched to Saudi Arabia to prepare cantonments for men and equipment to be assembled later. Others say that relatively small numbers of men will actually move to Saudi Arabia, with the bulk of the force serving as a rapid deployment unit, based at home but on a virtual standby alert. Indian defense specialists report that the commander is Gen. Shams ur-Rahman Kallu, who is said to be in Saudi Arabia. Reports of Troop Assembly Denied **********Pakistani officials continue to deny the reports of their troop assembly for Saudi duty. In an interview last November, President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq said he thought that negotiations then going on with Saudi Arabia would result in the dispatch of no more than 600 or 700 additional Pakistani soldiers, airmen and sailors. Even after that Pakistan's Government-controlled newspapers and its diplomats repeatedly insisted that no Pakistani troops were going to augment the Saudi Army. **********K. Subramaniam, a former Indian defense official who heads the Institute of Strategic Studies, a Government-supported research organization in New Delhi, said he regarded the 20,000-man figure as reasonable and said the formation and deployment were being carried out within the context of a five-year-old technical assistance agreement under which Saudi Arabia had obtained the services of pilots, plane mechanics and tank technicians as well as military instructors. The negotiations last year involved completion of the arrangements. **********Mr. Subramaniam said that according to his understanding the Pakistani forces would not technically be attached to the Saudi Army but to the Saudi National Guard, a military force recruited from loyal tribes that is primarily responsible for protecting the royal family. Bodyguard Duty Not New **********Such essentially bodyguard duty is not new for the Pakistanis.  President Zia ul-Haq commanded a Pakistani brigade in Jordan and played a key role in suppressing the challenge to King Hussein from Palestinian guerrillas in 1970. The brigade, according to Indian military strategists, is still in Jordan and may number 3,000 troops. **********Similarly, Pakistani contingents in Libya and Abu Dhabi have been there for many years.  In Libya, the air force's many Mirage jets are maintained and flown by Pakistanis. Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, who had established close ties with Zulfikar Ali Bhutto when he was President, ordered the Pakistanis to leave after President Zia endorsed the execution of Mr. Bhutto in April 1979. The Libyan order was later rescinded, however, and there are said to be several thousand Pakistani troops still in the country. **********In Abu Dhabi, Pakistanis have for some years flown and serviced many of its 52 combat planes, including 26 Mirages.  Clearly it is the Pakistani military ties to Saudi Arabia that are the most important. The need for efficient and trustworthy troops was brought home to the Saudi leaders by the capture of Islam's holiest shrine by religious fanatics 14 months ago and by the difficulties encountered in subduing the occupiers. From the Saudis' perspective, the Pakistani forces they are getting provide them with professional and disciplined troops that have no interest in the tribal disputes and family jealousies that have imperiled Saudi leaders. Sorely Needed Funds for Pakistan **********What debt-ridden Pakistan gains from the arrangement is, first of all, money. While there is no way of knowing how much it is receiving for supplying manpower, the informed speculation of Asian attaches here in New Delhi is that at the very least Saudi Arabia, in addition to paying for equipping, paying and transporting the two divisions, will underwrite the expenses for raising and equipping two divisions to remain in Pakistan. **********Even before the Pakistani forces were to be sent to Saudi Arabia, it was clear that the Government in Islamabad had sought and received aid of all sorts from the Saudis and that as United States aid withered with the revelations that the Pakistanis were developing atomic weapons, the Saudis were taking up the slack. Some Indian military analysts suggest that the relationship with the Saudis may become an effective means of permitting the Pakistanis to acquire the expensive and sophisticated weapons they seek -either more of the Mirage fighters they have bought from France or the F-15 and F-16 aircraft they want from the United States on a strictly cash deal on which there are no encumbering Congressional riders. **********These Indian sources, supported by a few Western ones, say that whatever the details, the sending of troops serves the interests of the United States as well as those of Pakistan and Saudi Arabia.  According to this argument the presence of skilled and disciplined Islamic soldiers and airmen from Pakistan is far less provocative to Saudi society than an American or other Western presence would be.  The net result, furthermore, is the immediate strengthening of the Saudi leadership and the concomitant reassurance of the West about the security of a vital source of oil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/08/busin.body_text: **********Small breweries have been folding almost since anyone can remember. The growing national brands have swallowed them as acquisitions or have made it impossible for them to survive financially. **********Now the country is left with about 40 brewing companies, most of them small. Two rapidly expanding giants, the Miller Brewing Company, owned by Philip Morris Inc., and Anheuser-Busch Inc., control 50 percent of the market. Six smaller companies of national stature - Coors, Heileman, Schlitz, Pabst, Stroh and Olympia -seem bent on trying to get back into the race through mergers. Most of them are now suffering from financial setbacks. **********''The consolidation of the industry seems to be approaching its final stages,'' said Peter Coors, vice president of marketing for the Adolph Coors Company. He refused to confirm or deny reports that his company was looking for a merger candidate. **********Deal Valued at $494 Million **********Last week the G. Heileman Brewing Company of La Crosse, little known outside the Middle West, agreed to buy the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company in a deal valued at $494 million in cash and stock. This week the Pabst Brewing Company raised the ante by making a $588 million offer for Schlitz in cash and stock. **********The offer drew immediate speculation from Heileman's president that Pabst's bid ''may be significantly less than its stated value'' because of the tax implications to Schlitz shareholders of accepting Pabst debentures. **********Earlier this year the Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit took over the F.& M. Schaefer Corporation. Industry experts expect other brewery mergers to follow if antitrust officials offer no objection. Speculators Attracted **********The prospect of a shakeout in the $27 billion-a-year beer industry has attracted the interest of speculators. Irwin L. Jacobs, Pabst's largest stockholder, made a fortune liquidating W.T. Grant assets, and last week he won a seat on Pabst's board of directors. Industry analysts expect him to raise a strong voice for merging or liquidating the company. **********Pabst seems to attract a lot of interest from outsiders. Since July 2 it has been under the temporary leadership of Thomas N. McGowan, a lawyer and formerly an outside director. Mr. McGowan became president when Frank DeGuire, the chairman, was forced to give up the title of chief executive officer after Pabst suffered a $1.8 million loss in the first quarter. Mr. Jacobs, before his election to the board, had asked to be named chairman and had threatened a proxy fight. **********Miller and Anheuser-Busch have been as effective as yeast in all this fermentation. Both companies have increased beer prices only slightly over the last year and half, preventing sizable increases by other companies and squeezing their profit margins. All of the six smaller companies except Heileman have shown lackluster earnings and weak sales growth over the last several quarters. Expansion of Capacity **********Miller and Anheuser-Busch are adding production capacity at a brisk rate while beer consumption is growing less than 4 percent a year.  Busch, now spending $100 million to convert a former Schlitz brewery near Syracuse, will increase its production capacity by 27 percent, to 70 million barrels a year, by the end of 1982. Miller, with a $413 million plant under construction at Clinton, Ohio, will add more than 20 percent to capacity, making a total of 62 million barrels a year, by early 1983. **********''Somebody has to lose in this game,'' said Russell T. Clary, Heileman's chairman. ''If some capacity doesn't come offstream, there's going to be big overproduction in a few years.'' **********Schlitz recently announced that its old brewery in Milwaukee, capable of producing more than six million barrels of beer annually but at high cost, would close permanently. The plant had been idled by a labor dispute since June 1. **********Just whose capacity will be reduced is now a big question in the industry. The financial performance of the second tier of companies over the next several months will probably determine the new pecking order. Profits for the group have been disappointing despite the fact that beer sales are regarded as recession-resistant. New Marketing Methods **********But that was before Miller's corporate parent, Philip Morris, changed the game in the early 1970's by throwing big advertising dollars into the fray and discounting prices to increase its market share. Over the last year, Miller and Anheuser-Busch have increased prices by 5 to 6 percent although production costs have gone up significantly more than that. **********''You're in real trouble if you're a regional brewer and get caught in a national price squeeze,'' said Heileman's Mr. Cleary.  His company has responded, he said, by belt-tightening and by measures to improve productivity -using double-forklift trucks and increasing the speed of can lines. **********But he added, ''You've got to have good efficient facilities and a broad product line, and advertising has to be effective in its appeal.'' Operating plants near their capacity is extremely important to profitability in the beer industry. And Heileman thinks it can improve Schlitz's operating rate - 60 percent before the closing of the Milwaukee plant - by brewing some of its 24 brands in Schlitz breweries. **********Although the marketing thrust of the industry's giants has put pressure on the also-rans, some of their problems have resulted from their own actions. That Different Formula **********Schlitz, for instance, changed its formula in 1976. Beer drinkers promptly accused the company of marketing ''green beer,'' a product not aged enough. After its market share plummeted, Schlitz went back to the original formula, but many of its old fans continued to stay away. Last fall Schlitz created a stir with its comparative taste tastes. In the second quarter of this year, Schlitz won its first small sales increase in five years. **********Coors is another example. At one time the Coors management flaunted its dedication to conservative causes, and the company became the target of several boycott campaigns. **********''Coors got everybody mad at them,'' said John A. Tauer Jr., an analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis. ''They alienated women, labor, the Government and environmentalists.'' Coors has since tempered its advocacy. **********For years Coors, with all of its production coming from a single plant in Colorado, has been considering building another plant in the East. Some analysts think Coors may be in the market to acquire another brewery, but Mr. Coors said: ''We would have a difficult way making beer the way we like to make it in someone else's brewery. Our strategy is to survive as a very strong regional brewery.'' A Multitude of Brands **********Coors, like Pabst and Olympia, has been slow to follow the industry's trend toward brand proliferation. These days there are popular-priced and premium-priced brands for light beer, regular beer, malt liquor and imported beer. The fastest-growing items are light beer, imports and expensive brands such as Miller's Lowenbrau or Anheuser-Busch's Michelob. **********Miller and Busch are continually developing and introducing new brands. Heileman has managed to offer a full line by adding brands, such as Colt 45 and Blatz, through acquisitions. All three companies also distribute imported brands. **********Brewing companies that have vast production capability but lack full product lines may find that time is running out for them as independent concerns. ''They are going to have to merge themselves into bigger barrelage to survive,'' said Roger Spencer of Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.main_headline: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.print_headline: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/25/busin.body_text: **********Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday as traders continued to worry about the heavy supply of new corporate and Treasury issues and their financing costs. **********Even though prices have dropped in recent days, salesmen say that there has been modest buying of bonds. Nevertheless, it is continuing as some buyers follow the old dictum of ''buy on weakness.'' Since June 16, the price of 30-year Treasury bonds has dropped about 4 1/2 points, or $45 per $1,000 bond, as the 13 7/8 percent issue due in 2011 closed yesterday at 105 14/32 offered to yield 13.14 percent. **********Over all, however, the debt markets' performance has not been so dismal, since dealers have successfully distributed a heavy volume of securities. More than $2 billion of corporate issues have been sold, including deep-discount securities, while Treasury dealers are distributing $3.25 billion of new 14 percent four-year Treasury notes and $1.75 billion of 20-year bonds to be auctioned today. Lower Yields Expected **********Despite the move to higher yields during the last week, many economists say bond yields will drop again. ''The rally is by no means over,'' said Arnold X. Moskowitz, an economist at Dean Witter Reynolds, who estimated that Treasury bond yields could fall to 11 percent, about 3 1/4 percentage points below the peak yields of early May. **********''The fundamentals of inflation, a slower economy, and Federal Reserve control over money supply overwhelmingly favor lower bond yields,'' said Robert Parry, senior economist at the Security Pacific National Bank. By the fourth quarter, he estimated, the prime rate could be 15 percent, Federal funds 13 percent or less, and triple-A bond yields 12 percent or less. **********''There is enough slack in the economy to avoid a resurgence in inflation,'' Mr. Parry said, even if the economic growth resumes after a flat second quarter. **********''My primary doubt concerns the Fed and short-term rates,'' Mr.  Parry said, acknowledging that economic growth could cause a pickup in money supply growth that would require the Fed to tighten policy and cause short-term rates to rise again. ''We might avoid that problem,'' he explained, ''since high interest rates are changing the way the public handles its money.'' Traders Cautious **********Uncertainty about the Federal Reserve continues to make traders cautious. Yesterday the overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market opened at 16 percent, dropped to 15 1/4 percent, and then climbed to 19 percent by late afternoon. Although financing costs were 15 percent or even less, analysts said they were worried that the low rate would not endure. **********In advance of today's auction of $1.75 billion of new 20-year Treasury bonds, analysts estimated the issue might carry more than 30 basis points of additional yield compared with the 13 7/8 percent Treasury bonds. A basis point equals one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Additional supply is also coming from the agency sector, where the Federal National Mortgage Association plans to announce the interest rate today for $600 million of debentures due in May 1985. **********Securities dealers said that the lower prices had come recently as they tried not to accumulate large holdings of bonds in the face of a heavy supply of new issues and erratic financing costs. **********Although some proposed new issues, such as International Business Machines' $250 million of 25-year debentures, have not come to market, many other borrowers have grown tired of waiting for rates to fall. For example, Gulf Canada's $200 million of Aa/AAA-rated 30-year debentures were priced by a Merrill Lynch group for sale today at par with a 15 1/2 percent coupon. The company initially announced plans to sell the debentures last October. **********As securities firms successfully sell new issues, they explain that downward pressure on secondary market prices can still develop, since many of the recent issues are sold in swap transactions where a dealer accepts an older, outstanding note or bond as part of the payment for the new issue. The result helps sales of new issues but encourages lower prices in the secondary market as dealers try to attract buyers for the securities they accepted in the swap. **********In the tax-exempt market, notes of Nassau County, L.I., due in December 1981 were offered by Bankers Trust to yield 8.5 percent, while notes due in July 1982 were offered by Chemical Bank to yield 8.6 percent. Elsewhere, a $41.1 million issue of Houston general obligation bonds was offered by the First Boston Corporation to yield from 7.5 percent in 1981 to 9.1 percent in 1991 and 10.4 percent in 2000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/27/world.main_headline: Around the World; Atomic Energy Agency Considers Ousting Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/27/world.print_headline: Around the World; Atomic Energy Agency Considers Ousting Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/27/world.body_text: **********The International Atomic Energy Agency voted today to consider suspending Israel next year if it does not open its nuclear facilities to inspection. The agency also suspended immediately all technical aid to Israel under agency programs. **********The Israeli delegate called the decision ''arbitrary and discriminatory,'' and said that it made the agency ''an instrument of political warfare.'' **********The vote, 51 to 8, with 27 abstentions, was taken in response to the Israeli bombing of Iraq's nuclear reactor in June. The United States was the only Western nation to vote no. **********Under the resolution, which was submitted jointly by Algeria, Saudi Arabia and 16 other countries, the agency will consider expulsion at a general conference in September 1982 unless Israeli nuclear facilities are opened by then.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/18/busin.main_headline:
Patents;
Pigeons For Use in Sea Search
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/18/busin.print_headline:
Patents;
Pigeons For Use in Sea Search
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/18/busin.body_text: **********THE Navy has found a method of using pigeons to trace persons or objects lost at sea. The birds are to be carried in an aircraft and peck electric signals when they see a downed pilot or piece of equipment floating below. **********James V. Simmons Jr. of the Naval Ocean Systems Center in Kailua, Hawaii, was granted patent 4,261,284 this week for the sea hunt system. **********The Coast Guard plans to make operational tests of the hunt system to find out how well it works. The equipment will be installed in a helicopter and used in rescue operations at an air station, probably beginning next December. **********According to the patent, the accepted method of searching for a person lost at sea is to use aircraft with human lookouts, but their main limitation is the capability of their eyes. Many birds are said to have vision far superior to that of human beings. **********A transparent observation chamber in the bottom of a helicopter has several compartments, each containing a cradle to support a bird with its head facing outward and a peck key nearby. The peck keys serve as push buttons to show by light flashes which pigeon is operating them and how many times. **********The equipment may be adjusted to alert an operator when the pecks reach a preset total within a preset time. According to the patent, in an operating model it was found desirable to require from four to eight pecks within four to seven seconds to meet the detection requirement. **********A tray containing food can be slid into a compartment to reward a bird when it makes a pecking report that is confirmed by human observation.Solar Electric Cell To Cut Conversion Costs **********A solar electric cell, patented for Ametek Inc., a diversified manufacturer with headquarters in Paoli, Pa., is described as promising to reduce sharply the cost of converting sunlight directly into electricity. Thin films of common semiconductor materials are used rather than expensive silicon. **********Patent 4,261,802 was granted this week for the production method to Gabor F. Fulop, a nuclear physicist who is director of the company's applied physics laboratory, and three associates. A related patent for the structure of the photovoltaic cell was obtained last week by the same inventors. **********The Ametek photovoltaic program is still in the laboratory stage, but the company is preparing a pilot plant. Ferenc J. Schmidt, a vice president and technical director of the company, said in a telephone interview that production should begin within a year and a half. **********The photovoltaic compound used in the new cell is composed of cadmium and tellurium, both of which are reported to be common byproducts of metal refining and readily available in the United States.Process to Make Space Shuttle Resist Fires **********The edge-lighted instrument panels on the space shuttle Columbia were photoengraved with fire-resistant materials by a process that was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Patent 4,262,080 was obtained by Wolfgang Fuhr of North Haledon, N.J., an employee of a NASA subcontractor. **********The recordings on the panels give flight information, and have been compared to the miles per hour shown on a speedometer. For space use, the recordings must be fireproofed.New Method Devised To Produce Interferon **********A method of producing interferon, a substance used in the treatment of a variety of disorders and malignancies, has been invented for the Cetus Corporation, Berkeley, Calif. Clarence Colby Jr. and Dan W. Denney Jr. were granted patent 4,262,090 this week. **********According to the patent, the primary source of interferon is in Helsinki, Finland, where it is obtained from donated blood. Because of the limited source of interferon and the difficulties of purification and concentration, the cost is said to be prohibitively high, and production in useful amounts holds great promise. **********As explained by a patent examiner, the new method of producing interferon involves a technique wherein mammalian cells, including the human variety, are fused.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/08/busin.main_headline: Chock Full o'Nuts Gets New Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chock Full o'Nuts Gets New Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/08/busin.body_text: **********Jerry Finkelstein, the 65-year-old publisher and industrialist, has acquired about 5 percent of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, the coffee and restaurant company with headquarters in New York. Mr.  Finkelstein, father of Manhattan's Borough President, Andrew Stein, was joined in the stock purchase by his other son, James Finkelstein, publisher of The National Law Journal. **********Jerry Finkelstein said, in a telephone interview, that he was impressed by both the wholesale and retail aspects of the Chock Full o'Nuts business. **********''The reason I did it is they have leases that are very good and they have the third-largest coffee company in the United States,'' he said. ''I think there's good value there.'' **********The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation derives more than 80 percent of its sales, and more than 90 percent of its profits, from processing and distributing coffee and frozen cakes. It has a chain of 26 company-owned and franchised counter service restaurants, primarily in New York City. It also operates a nine-unit chain of fast-food Beef Corral Restaurants, based in Cleveland. **********In the world of business, Mr. Finkelstein has had an unusually diversified career. A former reporter on The Daily Mirror and a public relations consultant, he later co-founded The Civil Service Leader and is now publisher of The New York Law Journal. **********His dozens of other ventures have included the ownership of real estate, operating an antiques show and serving as executive vice president of Gray Line Motor Tours. Since the 1960's, Mr. Finkelstein has been chairman of the Struthers Wells Corporation, a manufacturer of equipment for power industries. **********Mr. Finkelstein, a lawyer, has also been active in politics for many years. A former chairman of the New York City Democratic Committee, he has long been a national Democratic fund@raiser of note. In public life, he was on the staff of Thomas E. Dewey, when Mr. Dewey was a special prosecutor, and was chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, and a director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. **********Mr. Finkelstein said that he and his son had been buying Chock Full o'Nuts stock for about a year and had recently made a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, as required when their holdings passed the 5 percent level. **********He added that he had not been in contact with William Black, chairman and president of the company and its largest stockholder.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/busin.main_headline: Groups Ask U.S. to Bar Mobil's Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/busin.print_headline: Groups Ask U.S. to Bar Mobil's Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/busin.body_text: **********A coalition of small business, consumer and union groups today urged the Reagan Administration to block the Mobil Corporation's bid for the Marathon Oil Company, calling the proposed merger clearly illegal. **********Representatives of the groups told a news conference that Mobil's attempted takeover of Marathon violated antitrust laws because it was anticompetitive. **********They said if the merger was approved it would result in higher gasoline prices for consumers and loss of business for small independent gas companies. **********The Federal Trade Commission is investigating Mobil's announced intention to acquire Marathon for $5.1 billion. The F.T.C. last week asked the companies for additional information, thereby imposing a moratorium on the acquisition. Once the information has been provided the F.T.C. has an additional 10 days to review it. **********Jack Blum, a lawyer for the Independent Gasoline Marketers Council and a spokesman for the coalition, said the Mobil-Marathon merger would be an invitation for major oil companies to swallow up independent companies. ''If this merger is allowed, it will signal that the Reagan Administration is unwilling to enforce the antitrust laws,'' he said. **********An F.T.C spokesman said one of the commission's options would be to seek a preliminary court injunction to bar the acquisition while it studied the issue. Another would permit the acquisition only under certain conditions, such as an agreement by Mobil to hold Marathon's assets separate for a specified time to allow easy divestiture if the merger is disapproved. It could also issue an administrative complaint challenging the acquisition after it takes place. **********A hearing has been scheduled in Federal District Court in Cleveland tomorrow on a suit by Marathon to block the takeover.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/12/busin.main_headline: John Hancock Mutual Elects New Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; John Hancock Mutual Elects New Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/12/busin.body_text: **********John G. McElwee, 59, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, effective next Jan. 1. He will be succeeded as president and chief operating officer of the Boston-based insurer by James Morton, 54. **********The changes will follow the retirement of J. Edwin Matz, who will become 65 later this year. **********Mr. McElwee has been with John Hancock for his entire career, starting in 1945 in the administrative training program. He became a vice president 20 years later, a senior vice president and secretary in 1971 and executive vice president in 1974. **********Mr. Morton came to the corporation as an actuarial student in 1949 after graduating from Yale University. He became senior vice president for technical operations in 1971 and executive vice president for corporate operations about seven years ago. **********Mr. Matz worked for 10 years in the actuarial department of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company before joining John Hancock in 1949 as research associate and corporate controller. He was named president and chief operations officer and later vice chairman in 1974 and chairman and chief executive in 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/world.main_headline: SALVADOR LEADER, IN THE U.S., OPPOSES ADDITIONAL ADVISORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/world.print_headline: SALVADOR LEADER, IN THE U.S., OPPOSES ADDITIONAL ADVISORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/world.body_text: **********The head of El Salvador's ruling military junta said today that what his Government needed most was communications equipment to wage more effective war against guerrillas in the countryside and $300 million in economic assistance to bridge a balance of payments gap. **********Jose Napoleon Duarte, the junta president, who arrived in Washington today to ''talk to the American people,'' said he did not want additional United States military advisers or American troops. **********Sp eaking on the CBS News television program ''Face the Nation,'' Mr. Duarte sa id he rejected the idea of American troops entering El Salvador just as he rejected the idea of any other foreign combat units - he me ntioned Cubans, Nicaraguans and Russians -on the side ofthe insurgent s battling the junta. ''Of course,'' he said, ''I wouldn't like to have the Marines, either.'' **********The Salvadoran leader, who will meet with President Reagan at the White House tomorrow, reiterated that the purpose of his visit to the United States was not primarily to make specific requests for assistance. No Military Aircraft **********When pressed by questioners, however, Mr. Duarte described the American equipment he said his technical advisers would be seeking - ''radar, radios, trucks, helicopters, things that we can move around and protect the country, protect the crops.'' **********He said that the junta was not seeking American military aircraft.  Mr. Duarte intends to meet with members of congress early in the week. A $114 million aid request for the next fiscal year will come up for Congressional action this fall. That figure was recently increased from $101 million. El Salvador is receiving $161 million in economic and military aid this year. **********The State Department has said on several occasions that increased aid to El Salvador has been under discussion within the Reagan Administration. **********The Administration, in a spech in July by Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, committed itself to a political solution to the El Salvador civil strife. But Mr. Enders said that increased economic and military aid would be necessary. **********The Administration, echoing the argument of the El Salvador Government, has described the insurgency in El Salvador as a campaign of terrorism, and has charged that there has been Soviet and Cuban involvement in supplying rebel forces. ---- Priest Urges Investment in Nation **********SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 20 (AP) - A Roman Catholic priest celebrating mass in a packed cathedral said today that it was necessary that ''all Salvadorans who have capital place it at the service of the country.'' **********In a homily punctuated by applause from the worshipers, the Rev.  Jesus Delgado also said that the Catholic Church favored elections in the country, but voting alone could not end the strife.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/07/busin.body_text: **********Dr. Samuel Bogoch, a New York physician who is also associate research professor of biochemistry at the Boston University School of Medicine, received this week another of his series of patents in the field of cancer detection. **********Patent 4,298,590 covers preparations called Anti-Recognins, which attach themselves to cancer cells in the body and can be pinpointed by a radioisotope or other signal emitter. **********According to Dr. Bogoch, they may make it possible to provide early identification of cancer for treatment before it has grown to the point of producing symptoms. **********Dr. Bogoch got patents last year for a preparation called Malignin, first introduced as a diagnostic for brain cancer and later recognized as effective for other types. Malignin is marketed for medical use by Brain Research Inc., a New York company of which the inventor's wife, Dr. Elenore S. Bogoch, is president.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.main_headline: BASQUE'S DEATH IN JAIL BRINGS CALL FOR MASS STRIKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.print_headline: BASQUE'S DEATH IN JAIL BRINGS CALL FOR MASS STRIKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.body_text: **********Basque nationalists called today for a general strike in their region to protest the death of a suspected Basque terrorist while he was being held by the Madrid police. **********The death of Jose Ignacio Arregui Izaguirre, a 30-year-old truck driver who was captured in a gun battle Feb. 4 and who had been held incommunicado for 10 days under a new antiterrorist law, seemed certain to galvanize partisans of the Basque terrorist organization E.T.A. just when it had openly split and been thrown on the defensive by popular sentiment against it in the troubled north. **********Mr. Arregui, whom the police accused of several assassinations, died yesterday afternoon in a Madrid prison hospital. According to official reports, his eyes were badly bruised, one lung was full of liquid, his body was covered with hematomas, or swollen areas full of blood, and the soles of his feet had been burned. Such injuries would tend to confirm a recent report by Amnesty International that said torture was still practiced by the police in Spain. **********Even before an autopsy was performed, Interior Minister Juan Jose Roson dismissed the head of the police medical department and the Madrid plainclothes officer who supervised Mr. Arregui's detention.  Five police officers, who presumably were implicated in the death, were placed at the disposition of an investigating magistrate. **********Mr. Arregui's death could generate renewed support for E.T.A., which has become increasingly isolated from the mainstream of Basque public opinion. Last week, there were demonstrations in the Basque region against terrorism after E.T.A.'s ''military'' wing murdered a kidnapped nuclear engineer. **********Then, in a bitter open split rarely seen since E.T.A. was founded in 1959, the organization's so-called political-military wing denounced the military branch and accused it of committing ''constant errors'' and, more seriously, said it was resorting ''every day more and more to Fascist methods.'' **********The political isolation of E.T.A. - its initials stand for Basque Homeland and Liberty - has grown as Madrid has conferred home-rule powers on the region. **********Calling Mr. Arregui's death a ''brutal murder,'' the heavily middle-class Basque Nationalist Party, the Socialists and the Communists called a general strike in the Basque region for Monday.  Last Monday, a similar general strike paralyzed the north after the E.T.A. killed Jose Maria Ryan, a 39-year-old nuclear engineer. **********''We who condemned the death of Ryan,'' declared Xabier Arzallus, president of the Basque Nationalists, ''have the right to condemn, too, this death.'' **********''One cannot justify one death and condemn another,'' he added, speaking of the above-ground political arm of E.T.A.'s military branch, which called Mr. Arregui's death a ''state assassination'' and also called for a general strike Monday. Criticism by Rights Group **********The death focused attention on the Law of the Suspension of Fundamental Rights, which was adopted in December to help the police fight terrorism. The statute permits a terrorist suspect to be held by the police for 10 days before being allowed to see a lawyer. **********Amnesty International, in a report in December, criticized such Spanish legislation and said it contributed to patterns of police mistreatment of prisoners. Torture is specifically banned under the country's two-year-old Constitution. **********An autopsy report this evening mentioned bronchial pneumonia and fluid in the lungs among the causes of death. It also listed the many bruises without saying how they had been caused. **********''The thing is very clear,'' said Enrique Galavis, director general of prisons, who left no doubt that Mr. Arregui had been tortured to death.
