https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/05/world.main_headline: Around the World; Kuwait Gets New Cabinet In the Wake of Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/05/world.print_headline: Around the World; Kuwait Gets New Cabinet In the Wake of Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/05/world.body_text: **********Kuwait's Crown Prince and Prime Minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, formed a new 15-member Cabinet today to guide the desert oil state on its return to parliamentary life. **********The Kuwaiti Emir, or ruler, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah, announced his approval of the new Cabinet in a decree issued today.  The previous Government, which also served under the premiership of Sheik Saad al-Abdullah, resigned Feb. 24 following the election of a 50-seat Parliament. **********The parliamentary elections marked the return of Kuwait to a democratic system. The previous assembly was dissolved by the Emir in 1976 during the turmoil generated by the Lebanese civil war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/16/world.print_headline: PONTIFF FEELS PAIN BUT GAINS STRENGTH; DOCTORS OPTIMISTIC
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/16/world.body_text: **********Although suffering piercing pains from his bullet wounds and surgery, Pope John Paul II continued to gain strength today as the Italian police sought to establish whether the attack on the Pope resulted from an international conspiracy. **********A medical bulletin said the 60-year-old Pope, who was shot in the stomach, the right arm and the left hand, allegedly by an escaped murderer from Turkey, was running a mild temperature. But he was described by Father Romeo Panciroli, the Vatican spokesman, as ''serene,'' and he was strong enough to recite prayers and impart blessings to his doctors and nurses. **********His doctors were optimistic because of the progress he has made in the 48 hours since the attempted assassination, but they warned that there was still a risk of peritonitis or other infection. Newspapers Charge Conspiracy **********Major Italian newspapers carried large headlines announcing that the head of the Roman Catholic Church had been the victim of a conspiracy. **********The Milan newspaper Corriere della Sera said the shooting of the Pope was an ''international plot.'' The headline on the left-wing Rome newspaper Paese Sera was, ''Plot from abroad.'' But none of the papers cited evidence of a plot or produced any details. **********The suspected assailant, Mehmet Ali Agca, 23, insisted under prolonged official interrogation that he had acted alone. The Italian authorities do not believe him, because they think he must have had help with documents, money and other matters during his travels through Europe in the last year and in Italy in the last five months. Magistrate Quoted on Plot **********Without elaboration, La Stampa of Turin quoted Luciano Infelisi, one of the magistrates in the case, as saying, ''As far as we are concerned, documents prove that Agca did not act alone. He is a killer enlisted by an international group with subversive aims.'' **********But authoritative police and judicial sources said that they had no hard evidence of a plot. They said they were looking into the network of connections between the Mr. Agca and other persons here and abroad, more because they thought he must have had help than because they were confident of proving a conspiracy. **********Magistrate Infelisi, who is not one of the ranking figures in the investigation, could not be reached for comment, and it was impossible to confirm independently that he had made the statement attributed to him by La Stampa. **********The police denied published reports that the 9-millimeter Browning pistol with which the Pope was shot had been purchased by Mr. Agca in Bulgaria. They were working to trace the weapon, which they believe was bought in Western Europe and brought into Italy by train from Switzerland about April 20. Mr. Agca reportedly left it in the checkroom at the main railway station in Rome, reclaiming it just before he went to St. Peter's Square Wednesday. **********A painstaking check of hotel records established that the suspect had been in Italy as early as last Dec. 13, when he spent the night at the Hotel Liguria in Palermo, Sicily. One theory under exploration is that he picked up money in Sicily and on other trips, including his recent two-week holiday in Palma, on the Spanish island of Majorca. **********The police have been unable to break down Mr. Agca's story that he is a ''pro-Palestinian Communist comrade,'' even though they say he has extensive ties to right-wing extremist organizations in Turkey.  Questioned by Italian magistrates and Turkish detectives until 2 o'- clock this morning and then again throughout the day, he maintained ''a cold, very controlled attitude,'' a police official said. Suspect Ends His Fast **********Mr. Agca, who began eating again today after refusing food yesterday, reportedly answered fully all questions requiring responses that could be checked. But he refused to reply to inquiries about his friends or sources of income. **********Tonight, two young Turks who talked briefly to Mr. Agca in April when he registered at the University for Foreigners in Perugia, in central Italy, were brought to Rome for questioning. The two - Osman Tancu Celik, a man, and Endican Aytul, a woman - have said they never saw him before or after the morning of April 9, when he registered. **********The Pope talked this morning in his room at Gemelli Hospital with his chief aide, Agostino Cardinal Casaroli, the Vatican Secretary of State, and with Carlo Cardinal Confalonieri, the Deacon of the College of Cardinals. He also chatted frequently with his doctors and his two secretaries. **********He was awakened during the night by sharp pains, members of the hospital staff said. His dosage of sedatives had been reduced because it was important for his recovery that sources of pain be identified, doctors said, and in those circumstances the reaction was normal. Pain Is Said to Subside **********The pain subsided during the day, according to Dr. Emilio Presalti, the chief physician and a spokesman at the hospital.  A 7 P.M. medical bulletin, read by Dr. Luigi Candia, one of the Pope's surgeons, said John Paul's health had continued to improve.Another of the surgeons, Dr. Gianfranco Finschi, said the Pope would need two more operations - one to close the partial colostomy created during more than five hours of abdominal surgery on Wednesday and another to repair the damage to the index finger on the Pope's left hand. **********John Paul asked to be kept informed about the health of the two women wounded in Mr. Agca's attack during the Pope's weekly general audience in St. Peter's Square. Ann C. Odre, 60, of Buffalo, was reported to be recovering well from a chest wound. Rose Hall, 21, a Jamaican married to an American and living in Wiesbaden, West Germany, suffered only a minor wound in the arm. Turkish Detectives Have Role **********The interrogation of Mr. Agca was in the hands of Achille Galluci of the Rome chief magistrate's office and Domenico Sica, an aide, along with the Turkish detectives. The prisoner was attended by his attorney, Pietro d'Ovidio, one of the best-known and highest-paid criminal lawyers in Rome. He was appointed by the court. **********The lawyer is regarded as a conservative, even a right-winger. He has often represented Arabs, including several Palestinians. But other lawyers said it would be a mistake to deduce Mr. Agca's politics from those of Mr. d'Ovidio. **********Investigators said the key to Mr. Agca's ability to move around Europe freely was the documents he carried.  His false passport, in the name of Farouk Osgun, protected him from the warning bulletins that were circulated by Interpol, the international police organization, at the request of the Turkish Government. For six months his real name was on Italian Interior Ministry's bulletins of dangerous persons, but he was untouched as he crossed and recrossed the Italian border because ''Farouk Osgun'' was not on the list. **********The passport also enabled him to register at the Perugia university. That, in turn, got him a matriculation card, which made it possible for him to pass as a foreign student. Blank Passport Was Stolen **********According to Turkish diplomatic sources, the passport was stolen from the Government printing office in Turkey while still blank and was then filled in with the false name and Mr. Agca's photograph.  That fact was just one suggesting links with Turkish political groups, since there was no indication that Mr. Agca himself stole the document. He escaped from prison near Istanbul in November 1979 after having been convicted of murdering a Turkish journalist. **********Another, more important factor in the suspicion that he had allies was his access to money. When seized, he was carrying 100 Swiss francs and 400,000 Italian lira - more than $600. He had enough money to eat in the costly Biffi Restaurant in Milan on at least one occasion. The Italian police believe it must have cost him at least $100 a day while traveling through Eastern and Western europe. **********But the police were no closer to discovering where the money came from. Mr. Agca told them it was his own. Turkish Students Interviewed **********In an effort to cover every possibility, detectives interviewed all the Turkish students at Perugia, every witness to the shooting they could find and dozens of other persons. They prepared composite photographs of persons seen leaving the square just after the attack. But Alfredo Lazzarini, head of the antiterrorist squad at Rome police headquarters, said there was nothing to indicate the presence of accomplices at the scene of the crime. **********''The pictures were made to be scrupulous,'' he said. ''If more than one killer had been present, they would have shot simultaneously.'' **********One of the witnesses interviewed was Father Martino Siciliani, a Benedictine who directs the seismic observatory at Perugia. He told the police that outside St. Peter's about 30 minutes before the attack Mr. Agca had asked him what route the Pope would follow. The priest pointed it out to him.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/31/world.main_headline: URUGUAY EDITOR IS TAKING LEAD AS ARMY CRITIC
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/31/world.print_headline: URUGUAY EDITOR IS TAKING LEAD AS ARMY CRITIC
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/31/world.body_text: **********"To avoid risk, most newspapers here do not say anything," an opposition spokesman remarked. **********"Well," the spokesman, Enrique E. Tarigo, went on, speaking of his weekly newspaper, Opinar, "we tried to say something, then said a little bit more and a lttle bit more, until..." **********His voice trailed off.  Mr. Tarigo, who is 53 years old, was recounting his experiences since he emerged as the most popular opposition leader during the constitutional plebiscite of last Nov.  30.  That vote overwhelmingly rejected a proposed charter that would have given the country's armed forces a permanent share of power. **********"The plebiscite showed," he said in an interview, "that the majority of the people do not agree with the armed forces and their solutions.  You would think they would move faster now." **********His weekly began publication just before the plebiscite with an issue that was banned, but it was then allowed to continue until last month, when it was closed for four weeks. Two Articles Are Cited **********The Government cited as the reason two articles by contributors calling for elections and criticizing the armed forces' scheduled designation of a new President in September.  The articles reportedly did not bother the generals, who have the power here, but they wre said to have upset the civilian President, Aparicio Mendez. **********On the same day that the newspaper was closed, its managing editor, Luis Antonio Hierro, was jailed for 18 days under an executive order for publishing a photocopy of an internal document from the National University dealing with payments for 30 people who had helped prepare entrance examinations. **********Mr. Hierro questioned the appropriateness of the payments; the military went further, overruling them, but took action against the managing editor for publishing an internal document.  He said he was treated "rigorously but correctly" while in jail. **********Opinar is a tabloid that usually has about 30 pages, almost half of them devoted to cultural news.  Its forte is national and international analysis and opinion articles, written mostly by contributors and Mr. Tarigo. Permanent Staff of Four **********The weekly has a circulation of 25,000, and its newsstand price is the equivalent of one dollar.  It has a permanent staff of four, whose work is mostly a labor of love, as the pay is sporadic.  Advertisers steer clear of the paper. **********Mr. Tarigo divides his time running between the dimly lit apartment where he does most of his writing, the bare law office with peeling linoleum floor where he earns his living, and a small room rented from a pro-Government newpaper where he is engrossed with Opinar. **********A square, broad-shouldered man with gray hair and a direct manner, he was a law professor at the National University when the military moved bloodlessly into power in 1973.  It was during a crisis of urban terrorism and an unraveled economy, and the takeover was widely welcomed. **********Soon, however, Mr. Tarigo began finding the university an uncomfortable place, and he joined El Dia, one of the country's two major dailies, as an editorial writer.  The newspaper partly represents the Colorado Party, one of the country's two major centrist parties. **********He served as an editorial writer and columnist for five years until, he said, the Government began to press the owners to tone down its political views, even though they had been largely muted under the strict self-censorship here. Out of a Job Again **********Voluntarily leaving El Dia, Mr. Tarigo went to work for a popular magazine, writing the same sort of columns.  One year later, he was out of a job.  This time, he decided to start his own weekly. **********"Everything is magnified outside the country," said Mr. Tarigo, who keeps a copy of the United Nations Declaration on Human Rights on the wall beside his desk in his law office. **********"The situation here has improved, one reason being the lack of subversion, strikes and protests.  The number of prisoners is diminishing." **********Human rights leaders here say that the Government still has 1,154 political prisoners and that they are subject to such psychological pressures as interruptions in their daily exercise and sleep routines and the imposition of solitary confinement. **********On the question of political rights, generals have been making statements in the last week promising an "opening" at some unspecified future time to the country's two dominant political parties, the Colorados and the Blancos.  However, all the country's old civilian political leaders remain banned from political activity. **********These bans allowed a previous unknown like Mr. Tarigo to rise to prominence.  He said he had always considered himself a man more of politics than of journalism.  If a political opportunity should arise, he said, he would be a "coward" if he did not take up the challenge after his years of criticism. **********In the meantime, Opinar has resumed publication.  "I am at peace with my conscience and sleep well at night," Mr. Tarigo said of his renewed criticisms.  "I just worry about finding the ways to lead the country back to democracy."

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/busin.main_headline: GULF CANADA BLOCK HAS CHANGED HANDSZ
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; GULF CANADA BLOCK HAS CHANGED HANDSZ
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/busin.body_text: **********A 1.2-million-share block of Gulf Canada Ltd.  stock that traded on the American Stock Exchange this morning may represent an attempt to increase Canadian ownership in the company under Ottawa's National Energy Program, market analysts suggested here today. **********The block, representing slighlty less than 1 percent of Gulf Canada's outstanding, was crossed at $21 by Goldman Sachs and Company in New York. **********The stock closed at 20 7/8.  Gulf Canada, the country's second-largest oil company, after the Exxon Corporation's Imperial Oil unit, is 60 percent owned by the Gulf Oil Corporation of Pittsburgh. Under the energy program, a company must be 50 percent Canadian-owned to qualify for attractive exploration incentives that increase along with domestic ownership. **********Gulf Canada is close enough to this threshold so that such an attempt may be in the offing, analysts said.  Gino Blink, director of research at Moss, Lawson and Company Ltd., a Toronto investment concern, said he understood that ''the selling (of the shares) was entirely American and the buying entirely Canadian.'' **********Robert Vallance, a Gulf Canada spokesman, said he had no information on who the purchaser might be.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/18/world.main_headline: IRAN MAY OUST 3 OFFICIALS TO EASE STRIFE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/18/world.print_headline: IRAN MAY OUST 3 OFFICIALS TO EASE STRIFE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/18/world.body_text: **********A senior Islamic cleric, who is Speaker of Parliament, and two legislators are likely to be ousted from Iran's Supreme Defense Council under Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's new formula for ending strife among Iranian leaders, the Ayatollah's office said today. **********A spokesman said that Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker, a founding member of the dominant Islamic Republican Party, and two members of Parliament faced removal from the defense body headed by President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr. **********Yesterday, the Ayatollah set forth a plan for ending 11 days of conflict between the President and the fundamentalist Islamic Republican Party, which controls the Government and most of the country's legal bodies. **********Ayatollah Khomeini said the Supreme Defense Council ''will be administered in the manner stipulated in the Constitution,'' which limits it to seven members. **********A spokesman for the Defense Council said nothing had been decided about the membership and declined to discuss the implications of Ayatollah Khomeini's plan. Mr. Bani-Sadr said that it was likely to have a crucial effect on morale and ''to enhance law and order and disappoint foreign enemies.'' Reconciliation Panel Planned **********The plan calls for a three-member reconciliation panel to resolve disputes. Mr. Bani-Sadr said in a message to the Ayatollah, reported by the official Pars press agency, that he would nominate his representative to the proposed committee in a day or two. **********Ayatollah Khomeini proposed that the commission be formed of a representative of Mr. Bani-Sadr, one from ''the other side'' and one from his own office. **********The two other members of the Defense Council who are likely to be dropped are Hojatolislam Mohammed Montazeri, son of Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, religious leader of the holy city of Qum, and Mohammed Ali Akbar Parvaresh, the Islamic Republic Party's deputy from Isfahan. **********They were included in the Defense Council at Ayatollah Khomeini's request soon after the start of the war with Iraq last September so Parliament could receive first-hand information on the Defense Council's activities. **********The council took on a foreign affairs role in addition to directing the war effort. But political sources said foreign affairs would now be under the control of Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai. Counterweight to Islamic Party **********The Defense Council changes were seen as an indication that Ayatollah Khomeini wanted to support the President as a counterweight to the Islamic Republican Party, particularly since his plan permitted the President to decide whether to carry out the Defense Council's decisions. **********After the Ayatollah's action, the state radio announced that a planned televised debate between the President and his rivals in the Islamic Republican Party and the clergy had been called off. **********The leaders were to debate events at a rally held by Mr. Bani-Sadr on March 5, during which 45 people were injured, but the peace formula called on top leaders not to make speeches until the war with Iraq was over. Former Official Put on Trial **********In another development, former Deputy Prime Minister Abbas Amir Entezam went on trial today before an Islamic revolutionary court on charges that included collaboration with the Central Intelligence Agency. **********Mr. Entezam, who is 47 years old, was official spokesman of Iran's first Government after Islamic revolutionaries deposed the Shah early in 1979. **********Smiling and appearing relaxed, he walked into the courtroom at Evin Prison, 15 months after his arrest at Teheran Airport on the basis of documents seized by the militants who overran the United States Embassy Nov. ber 4, 1979. **********Mr. Entezam listened carefully as a prosecutor read out an indictment.  If convicted of espionage, Mr. Entezam could be executed.  The trial was the first of a senior member of the former Government, headed by Mehdi Bazargan, that resigned two days after the embassy was seized by militants demanding extradition of the Shah from the United States.

Sharpe, president of East-West Trade. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/19/world.main_headline: A 'Solidarity in Exile' Not Seen as Likelihood
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/19/world.print_headline: A 'Solidarity in Exile' Not Seen as Likelihood
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/19/world.body_text: **********Those members of Poland's Solidarity labor union who were abroad when the Warsaw Government decreed martial law will decide Saturday whether to give themselves a formal structure, a spokesman for the group said tonight. **********''But I do not think we will form a 'Solidarity in exile,' '' Piotr Naimski said, when reached by telephone at the group's meeting place in Zurich. **********''Since Solidarity is still functioning in Poland there is no reason to form a 'Solidarity in exile,' '' Mr. Naimski said.  A member of the executive board of Solidarity's Center for Social Studies in Warsaw, Mr. Naimski flew to Zurich from New York to meet with about 30 members of Solidarity. A biochemist, Mr. Naimski has been at New York University's medical center on a research fellowship since last March. **********''We want food and medical supplies to be sent to the Polish people, but we want its distribution to be under strict international control by an agency such as the International Red Cross so that it is not diverted,'' Mr. Naimski said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/07/busin.main_headline: CHANGE OF STRATEGY FOR TALON ZIPPERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/07/busin.print_headline: CHANGE OF STRATEGY FOR TALON ZIPPERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/07/busin.body_text: **********The mechanics of making zippers haven't changed much. Coils of monofilament polyester spew from machines looking like miniature Slinkys. The endless coils are sewn onto a continuous tape and a slicing arrangement chops them into appropriate-sized pieces. Bottom stops define the zipper lengths, and sliders, the things that go up and down, are slipped on and zipped up. **********While the technology has stayed the same, the rest of the business has not.  Talon, which used to have a firm grip on the zipper market, now is trying to defend and consolidate its shrinking market share. Ten years ago, chances were seven out of 10 that a zipper's slider would be marked Talon. Today, industry experts say, Talon has little more than 35 percent of the $393 million a year American zipper market, and they give YKK (USA) Inc., a Japanese-based company that entered the American market two decades ago, a slight edge. **********Nucon Holdings, a privately held venture capital company that purchased Talon from Textron Inc. last April, would like to change all that. Nucon paid Textron $66 million for Talon and two other divisions, which make foam manufacturer and hearing aids. According to Textron's annual report, Talon was suffering from intense and increasing foreign competition. A New Strategy **********Sidney Merians, Talon's new president, described the company's new strategy as a retrenchment plan that included cutting excess costs while maintaining market share. **********''We've eliminated millions of dollars of overhead,'' Mr. Merians said in an interview. ''We have closed losing facilities in Seymour, Ind., and Canada, and there are others that will come.'' **********Under its new owners, Talon continued to lose money in May and June. But in July, the company began to show a profit, Mr. Merians said, though he declined to divulge figures. And he predicted that results would improve further as more pruning took place. **********For Mr. Merians, the challenge comes down to becoming more competitive with YKK. For many years the Japanese company has cast its shadow not only over Talon, but over the rest of the American zipper industry as well. Trade Complaint Rejected **********In 1975 the industry trade group, the Slide Fastener Association, sought relief from the foreign imports - most notably YKK - by appealing to the International Trade Commission in Washington. **********But an investigation of the charges concluded that changing fashions and the declining economy were the most important causes of the industry's decline, not imports. In the meantime, many smaller independent zipper companies eventually went bankrupt, while Talon held on but lost money. **********Mr. Merians predicted that Talon's new position as a privately held company would giving the company more freedom to maneuver and make it a stronger competitor to YKK. **********''YKK is a private company,'' Mr. Merians said. ''They only have their own stockholders to answer to. We're in a similar position today. We don't have to worry about our earnings per share for the next two or three quarters.'' Opinion Is Mixed **********Talon's new approach is drawing mixed reviews in the industry.  Ralph Lundquist, counsel to YKK (USA) Inc. and a former director of the company, said that Talon might have a better competitive position now than it did previously. ''Textron had placed impossible burdens on Talon,'' he said. ''They expected the same sort of profits from the Talon division as they did from the helicopter division. It didn't work.'' **********The owner of another zipper company, who asked not to be named, also applauded Talon's new moves.  ''Talon needs a street fighter,'' he said, but a fighter who understood and realized Talon's shortcomings. He contended that Talon had found just that person in Mr. Merians. Where Talon once supplied every segment of the zipper market, this executive said, it could no longer afford to do so, and was acting accordingly. **********But not everyone thinks the new Talon strategy will build a stronger company. Ralph Gut, president of the Ideal Zipper Company, an independent manufacturer based in North Carolina, said he felt that Talon's new investors were merely trying to liquidate their assets and walk off with more money. In his estimation, Talon has lost a tremendous amount of business and ''is no longer a viable source in the marketplace.'' Talon's Defense **********Mr. Merians defended the company's strategy, however. He said there were no plans to sell Talon. Furthermore, he explained, it was necessary to get rid of marginal product lines and to gain the maximum from the company's potential. **********''In this industry, a discontinued zipper is worth exactly that: Zip,'' he said. ''So there are no assets to sell. We knew that when we bought Talon, and we bought this company to run it. '' **********In another move that Talon expected to help profits, the company raised prices. Scoville Inc., another zipper manufacturer, did the same. But, as Mr. Merians noted, ''Everyone is waiting for the other shoe to drop as to what YKK will do.'' **********Even with these improvements in place, Mr. Merians conceded, not all of the company's problems had been solved. As he assessed the zipper market, Talon's weakest link was still nonapparel fasteners for luggage, knapsacks, sleeping bags and the like. And while Talon had the predominant market share, he felt, in the fashion area, that area had a somewhat questionable future. Zippers are simply not as fashionable as they once were, in the thirties, when the French designer Elsa Schiaparelli used shiny metal zippers in couture clothing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/12/busin.print_headline: Japanese Expect Steel Output to Fall in '81
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/12/busin.body_text: **********The Japanese steel industry, after strong production last year, is projecting a gloomier outlook for 1981 because of declining demand. **********''In general, this will be a rather stagnant year,'' said Eiro Iwamura, president of the Kawasaki Steel Corporation. ''I don't think we will be able to show as good a profit and sales record as last year.'' **********According to the Japan Iron and Steel Federation, Japanese mills' crude steel output this year is expected to decline 9 percent, to 104 million metric tons. A metric ton (1,000 kilograms) equals about 2,205 pounds. **********''Exports will be at the same level as in the previous year, about 32 million metric tons,'' said Torao Okumura, president of the federation. ''At one time we exported as much as 40 million tons, but we have voluntarily reduced exports, especially to the United States, in order to cooperate with its industry and Government.'' **********Last year Japan replaced the United States for the first time as the non-Communist world's No. 1 steel producer. (Biggest of all is the Soviet Union, which produced 152 million metric tons of steel in 1980.) Japan's steel output totaled 111.4 million metric tons last year, according to the trade federation. This was down three-tenths of 1 percent from the 1979 level, but American production meanwhile fell 18.2 percent, to 108 million metric tons. 'A Statistical Aberration' **********''This was a statistical aberration,'' said Eishiro Saito, president of the Nippon Steel Corporation, in an interview. ''We hope very much the United States will regain its dominant position by fully displaying its latent strength.'' **********The Japanese steel industry is now operating at about 72 percent of its 140-million-ton capacity. It has begun paring expenses to cope with uncertain demand and surging costs. **********Japanese steel mills have spent much of their capital funds on energy-saving measures. Mr. Okumura of the federation estimated that Japanese mills consumed about 99.1 million barrels of oil in 1973, just before oil prices began to soar. Last year the total was down to 37.7 million barrels, and this year it is expected to be only 25.2 million barrels. Coal and coke are being substituted for expensive oil. Demand From Oil Industry **********Sumitomo Metal Industries has 10 blast furnaces and is operating six of them, three without oil, said Shigeto Yamada of the company's business research department. **********Ironically, the global oil industry promises to be one of the few sectors showing brisk demand for Japanese steel. Analysts say 3,200 drilling rigs will be operating in the United States this year, up from 2,850 in 1980. **********The technological level of Japanese steel mills helps their efforts to make steel more cheaply. S.J. Janow, president of a metals consulting firm in Tokyo, recalled that after World War II Japanese steel mills had to use imported equipment. ''Today there's not a single piece of imported equipment,'' he declared. ''It's Japanese, and it's superior.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/22/world.main_headline: U.S. PRESSES JAPAN ON MILITARY ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/22/world.print_headline: U.S. PRESSES JAPAN ON MILITARY ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/22/world.body_text: **********Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger urged the Japanese today to acquire enough military power to defend their nation up to 1,000 miles offshore. **********It was the most specific and forceful public statement yet from the Reagan Administration that Japan should pick up a greater share of the burden of its defense. **********The request seemed certain to generate even more resistance from the Japanese, who have steadily opposed efforts by successive United States administrations to have their country assume more responsibility in the defense of the Western Pacific. **********But senior officials in the Pentagon said that the Administration had assigned high priority in 1982 to getting Japan and allies of the United States in Europe to increase their military strength. U.S. Public Opinion Stressed **********Mr. Weinberger, who was interviewed by the Japan Broadcasting Corporation for an hour by satellite, said he was concerned ''that we not get a situation in which public opinion in the United States would feel that there was not sufficient effort being made.'' **********The Defense Secretary, in laying out the Administration's desire for a greater military contribution from Japan, appeared to be trying to meet a common Japanese complaint, that the United States is not specific in the defense contributions it wants from Japan. **********In the interview, the transcript of which was made available in the Pentagon, Mr. Weinberger said: ''The allocation of Japan's defense expenditures is clearly a matter for the Japanese Government and the Japanese people.'' He said that ''what we are talking about is the allocation of proper roles.'' **********''How Japan fulfills its part of the cost-sharing, its portion of the defense burden, is very clearly a matter for the Japanese Government to decide itself,'' he said. ''But it may well require an additional defensive expenditure, just as our additions to our defensive strength are clearly requiring a substantial increase in American total expenditures.'' Defense of Airspace and Sea Lanes **********In stating what the Reagan Administration wants from Japan, Mr.  Weinberger said, ''That would be to provide for the self-defense of the Japanese islands and defense of the airspace and the sea lanes up to a thousand miles from the shoreline.'' **********This would include the entire Sea of Japan through which the Soviet surface and submarine fleet must pass from its base at Vladivostok to reach the open Pacific. The Japanese could bottle up the Soviet fleet by closing four relatively narrow exits. A fifth, north of the Soviet island of Sakhalin, is difficult to navigate. **********Mr. Weinberger also said that the United States ''will be increasing, without any question, in a substantial way, our Pacificbased naval strength - carriers, aircraft, submarines - and this will of course be a direct, immediate benefit to the defense of Japan.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/26/busin.main_headline: MID- AUGUST AUTO SALES UP BY 20.3%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/26/busin.print_headline: MID- AUGUST AUTO SALES UP BY 20.3%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/26/busin.body_text: **********Sales of new cars by the nation's Big Three auto makers, spurred by industrywide rebate and incentive programs, increased 20.3 percent in mid-August over the comparable 1980 period, the manufacturers reported today. **********''It was specifically a reflection of the number and generosity of the campaigns,'' said Maryann Keller, an auto industry analyst with Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins & Company. She predicted that sales would drop in September when the incentive plans end. **********The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation reported sales of 194,836 units for the Aug.  11-20 sales period, compared with 161,889 units sold in mid-August of 1980, when sales were at their lowest level in 13 years. **********Highest Since Mid-March **********Based on the results for Aug. 11-20, the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for the Big Three and the two other domestic auto makers, Volkswagen of America and the American Motors Corporation, reached 7.9 million vehicles - the highest since mid-March, the last period of broad rebate campaigns. **********By comparison, the annual selling rate was 6.1 million vehicles in all of July. The rate rose to 7.4 million vehicles in the first 10 days of August as the new incentive programs went into effect. **********Industry analysts said they were pleased, but not surprised, at the results. ''They look pretty good,'' said Harvey Heinbach of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. ''This does indicate that there's a market out there, given the right price.'' 'It's the Rebates Coming In' **********Michael Ward, an auto analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds, agreed, saying that the sales looked strong. ''It's the rebates coming in,'' he added. **********While Chrysler showed the most improvement on a year-to-year basis, up 42.9 percent, General Motors again increased its share of the domestic market, to 66.6 percent for the middle 10 days of August, on a daily selling rate that was G.M.'s best since mid-March. **********Analysts and company spokesmen attributed the rise to G.M.'s unusual financing program. The company is offering low-interest loans on its cars when financed through the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, its consumer finance subsidiary. **********''Customers in the second 10 days of August continued to show their willingness to buy new cars and trucks when they can get favorable financing,'' said Robert D. Burger, vice president in charge of G.M.'s sales and marketing staff. Other Incentives Offered **********Chrysler offered rebates of $300 to $1,000 on certain models, and Ford had a dealer incentive program in effect that could result in customer savings of up to $1,000 on a car. A.M.C. conducted a summer sale that offered reduced prices on some models. **********Speaking of the industry in general, Mr. Ward said: ''You get the interest rates down and sales will take off. Until then, they're just bumping along.'' **********G.M. dealers reported sales of 134,949 cars in the period, which had nine selling days this year and last; sales were 19.8 perecent higher than sales last year of 112,688 cars. Ford Market Share Slips **********The Ford Motor Company said its dealers sold 37,034 cars this year, up 11.5 percent from sales of 33,212 cars in the comparable 1980 period. The growth in G.M.'s market share seemed to come primarily at the expense of Ford, which held 18.3 percent of the market in the period. **********Chrysler sold 22,853 cars in the period this year, compared with 15,989 cars last year, for its 42.9 percent increase. Chrysler's market share was 11.3 percent. **********In the mid-August period, Volkswagen of America sold 4,842 domestically built cars, down 14.7 percent from 5,676 cars a year earlier.  Including an estimate of 2,900 cars sold by the American Motors Corporation, sales for the five major domestic producers totaled 202,578, up 18.2 percent from sales of 171,381 cars last year. **********Sales for the month to date were also up for the Big Three, by 25.4 percent at G.M., 17.1 percent at Ford and 34.4 percent at Chrysler, largely because the incentive programs began at the first of the month. Volkswagen sales were down in the month-to-date period, by 8.9 percent. While American Motors reports its sales only once a month, estimated sales were down 21.1 percent for the month to date. Chrysler Up 22.9 Percent **********For the year to date, with 196 selling days this year and 197 days last year, Chrysler remained the only major domestic manufacturer to show improved sales, climbing 22.9 percent, based on its daily selling rate. On a daily selling rate basis, Chrysler sold 499,087 new cars, or 2,546 a day, this year compared with 407,926, or 2,071 cars daily, last year. **********G.M. sold 2,537,271 cars, or 12,945 units daily, for the year to date, down 3.8 percent from sales of 2,650,5l6 cars, or 13,454 units a day, last year. **********Ford sold 927,052 cars, or 4,730 daily, in the period, a 2.3 percent decline from last year's sales of 953,633 cars, or 4,841 units daily. **********Volkswagen sales slumped 15.2 percent, to 104,324 cars, or 532 units daily, this year, compared with 123,566 cars, or 627 units daily, last year. A.M.C. sales, including the estimate, were down 2.5 percent for the year to date, to 93,396 cars, or 477 units daily, compared with 1980 sales of 96,322 cars, or 489 units daily.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/18/busin.main_headline: MOBIL SAYS ITS BID MEETS U.S. CRITERIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/18/busin.print_headline: MOBIL SAYS ITS BID MEETS U.S. CRITERIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/18/busin.body_text: **********The Mobil Corporation, anticipating a major antitrust investigation of its $7.7 billion offer to buy Conoco Inc., yesterday vigorously defended its bold takeover move for the nation's ninth-largest oil company as one that ''meets existing merger guidelines of the Department of Justice.'' **********But Ralph E. Bailey, chairman of Conoco, said that the Mobil bid ''raises substantial antitrust and other public policy issues of national importance, which will require intensive examination and which make the acquisition of Conoco by Mobil subject to serious question.'' He said, however, that he would not respond to the Mobil offer until Conoco directors reviewed it early next week. **********Moreover, less than a week ago, without naming any of the companies interested in Conoco, William Baxter, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, signaled that all big bidders would face a tough fight. **********'In for a Big Surprise' **********''If,'' he said, ''they think we're generally soft on mergers, that they can slip significant horizontal aspects past us, they're going to be in for a big surprise.'' Horizonal mergers are those between companies selling the same products in the same geographical markets. **********In bidding for Conoco, Mobil is competing with Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, the big Canadian liquor company, which has offered $85 a share for 51 percent, and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the chemical producer, which has offered $95 a share for 40 percent and 1.7 shares of stock for each of the rest. Based on Du Pont's closing price yesterday of $46.25, that would be $78.625 a share for the remaining 60 percent. **********Both Seagram and Du Pont declined comment on the Mobil bid.  Regarding its own bid as higher because of Du Pont's market price, Mobil placed a combined value on the Du Pont offer of $85, and Du Pont did not dispute it. **********Sources friendly to Du Pont noted, however, that the chemical company still had $700 million of its $4 billion loan for the Conoco deal. This, he said, could be interpreted as meaning that Du Pont - if it chose to do so - already had the funds on hand to increase its $95 bid to as high as $115 a share. There was no indication so far that Du Pont had any such plans. 'Extreme Disfavor' From Dubai **********In a separate development, Conoco said in a statement that it had received a letter from Dubai in which the Middle Eastern state expressed ''extreme disfavor'' over the Seagram move and said that Conoco's operations there would be ''in grave jeopardy if Seagram interests gain substantial control of Conoco.'' It did not explain its view, except to say it would be placed in an ''embarrassing'' position. **********Conoco added that it had also received a communication from the Petroleum Ministry of Norway, where Conoco has North Sea oil interests, approving of a Du Pont takeover but noting that one by Seagram ''would require re-examination of Conoco's Norwegian North Sea licenses.'' **********Conoco denied, in answer to a question, that it had sought the views. Seagram said it was ''skeptical'' that the statements reflected the positions of these states. It noted that it had cordial relations with Dubai and that its formerly owned Texas Pacific Oil Company had drilled for oil there, relinquishing rights when it found no oil. **********Mobil, the No.2 oil company, following the Exxon Corporation, asserted in a five-page position paper that ''the fact that Mobil and Conoco are both big oil companies is not, of itself, determinative'' under the Justice Department's ''guidelines or the antitrust laws.'' Far Smaller Than Exxon **********Should Mobil succeed in taking over Conoco, the two would still be far smaller than Exxon. Mobil's $32.7 billion in assets, when added to Conoco's $4 billion, would be nowhere near Exxon's nearly $57 billion. **********Conoco has already signed a $7.4 billion merger agreement with Du Pont. And Mobil's emergence had been widely forecast on Wall Street, although the way in which it came - in an advertisement in the late editions of Friday morning newspapers - took other bidders by surprise. **********The company, as a result, was flooded with phone calls asking for particulars. A Mobil spokesman said the company deliberately waited until yesterday morning to make its official announcement to prevent competing bidders from trying to block Mobil in the courts. **********The advertisement said that Mobil was offering $90 a share for 43.5 million shares of Conoco, which would total $3.92 billion.  Efforts on Thursday evening to obtain further information about the ad were unsuccessful. But Mobil said yesterday, in its formal announcement, that the cash portion of the offer would be followed by a merger. Consequently other Conoco shareholders would be paid in Mobil securities ''intended to have a value substantially equivalent to $90 a share.'' Biggest Takeover in History **********Thus, in a battle that, if successful, would result in the biggest takeover in history, regardless of the winner, stockholders are faced with three multibillion-dollar bids amid signs that Texaco Inc., generally regarded as cautious, might still decide to become a bidder.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/05/world.main_headline: Around the World; Tanzanian to Try Again For Waldheim's Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/05/world.print_headline: Around the World; Tanzanian to Try Again For Waldheim's Job
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/05/world.body_text: **********Salim A. Salim, Tanzania's Foreign Minister, said today that he would make one more effort to overcome the United States veto against his candidacy for Secretary General of the United Nations. **********He indicated that if the effort failed he would follow the lead of Kurt Waldheim, the incumbent, who said on Thursday that he would step aside from the balloting and open the door to other candidates. **********Mr. Salim said he reached his decision after a meeting with African delegates. He said he had been told by Olara Otunnu of Uganda, President of the Security Council, that there ''is no evidence of change on the part of the UnitedStates.'' The United States has voted against him 16 times, just as China has vetoed Mr. Waldheim 16 times.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/28/busin.body_text: **********The Government gets back more in taxes than it pays out for a small-business program, so it should be spared the Reagan Administration's budget ax, an industry group asserted today. **********''In these economic times, why cut back on assistance to small businesses, especially when the program is doing such an effective job for everybody?'' said Barry Davis, chairman of the National Association of Small Business Investment Companies. **********A recent study, the association said, found that in 1979 the program generated $110 in tax revenues for every dollar spent on it by the Government. **********Peter McNeish, deputy associate administrator for investment at the Small Business Administration, said the program was originally budgeted for $160 million in the present fiscal year but was reduced to $145 million. **********Under the program, the S.B.A. licenses privately owned Small Business Investment Companies. They provide financing for about 2,500 new growth-oriented enterprises a year. The investment companies borrow money from the Government at less than prevailing interest rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/22/busin.main_headline: New York Air to Add Television Commercials
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/22/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; New York Air to Add Television Commercials
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/22/busin.body_text: **********New York Air, the recent arrival in this town that has been troubling Eastern and its Washington shuttle, will branch out from newspaper and radio advertising, which it has had since going into business, and next month try television. Ketchum/New York, already the agency for Air Jamaica and B.W.I.A. International, does advertising for New York Air as well. **********Before leaving for the inauguration of President Reagan the other day, James V. O'Donnell, senior vice president-marketing of New York Air, which is an affiliate of Texas International Airlines, said: ''In the two cities of Washington and New York we now have a high level of awareness among the target audience, but there are a lot of people who have not had an opportunity to try us. **********''We're not out to put Eastern out of the shuttle business, just fill our own seats. And one thing is certain to us, the consumer will end up the beneficiary.'' **********The agency has created a 30-second commercial and a 10-second spot. They will begin to run in mid-February in news shows and during early fringe time. The target is those with above-average incomes and education. **********The television commercials, Mr. O'Donnell said, are intended ''to work on attitudes, show what we look like with professional people and good equipment.'' **********Although New York Air will soon have five DC-9's serving the two markets, it currently has only three, making a total of 20 flights a day. Unlike Eastern, New York Air requires reservations, but it also has liquor and other refreshments, which the Eastern Shuttle does not have. **********Eastern is fighting back with a campaign that rewards the shuttle passenger with a coupon for reduced transcontinental tickets. New York Air was delighted and retaliated with some gag coupons of its own. **********It is the plan of the carrier to offer service eventually between New York and 31 markets within two hours of our town. As for this year's ad budget, Mr. O'Donnell would only say that it would be at least in seven figures. ''But how much?'' he asked himself. ''We don't know how much it will take to get the job done.'' **********He had already noted that New York Air was ''an airline built on productivity'' and that that certainly applied to its advertising and marketing techniques. Highly successful Texas International has the same attitude. ''If the industry averages 1.5 percent of gross sales in advertising, then we'd be delighted to cut it by a third,'' Mr. O'Donnell said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/22/busin.main_headline: U.S. STEEL TO BUILD SEAMLESS TUBE MILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/22/busin.print_headline: U.S. STEEL TO BUILD SEAMLESS TUBE MILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/22/busin.body_text: **********David M. Roderick, the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, is expected to announce today that the company has decided to build a new seamless tubing mill to supply the boom in oil drilling that began several years ago, according to company sources. **********Industry sources said that oil companies would help finance the project and that under the plan the plant would be built by U.S.  Steel and then, in effect, leased to the oil companies. **********The site of the new mill, company sources said, will probably be its plant in Fairfield, Ala., which has modern steel-making facilities but lacks modern finishing mills. Company sources said that other sites were still under consideration, however. **********Steel analysts estimated that a new pipe mill would cost about $500 million .  Oil country goods, which are steel products used in oil drilling, have been in tight supply and several steel companies such as Armco Inc. and the C.F.& I. Steel Corporation, a subsidiary of the Crane Company, announced new tube mills last fall. **********These companies have sought assurances from oil companies and other major buyers of oil country goods that they would buy certain levels of the products in an effort to protect themselves in the future. **********There is the risk that the current oil drilling boom could sputter. Some steel executives have warned that this could leave their companies with large amounts of new pipe capacity coming on stream and demand dropping. A venture that would include oil companies would therefore help to protect U.S. Steel from becoming stuck with a new mill and low demand for its products. **********On April 1 U.S. Steel announced that it would spend several hundred million dollars to rehabilitate its old plant, the South Works in Chicago, as part of an effort to strengthen its older mills.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/01/world.print_headline: Soviet Carrier Enters Baltic, Joining a Major Navy Buildup
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/01/world.body_text: **********The largest ship in the Soviet Navy, the aircraft carrier Kiev, sailed into the Baltic today, adding to a naval buildup puzzling Western military and diplomatic analysts. **********''I really think it's for an amphibious exercise and not any kind of action involving Poland or anything like that,'' said one Western diplomat. **********''It might, of course, be a political demonstration -just as such things always are - but I really believe it's a maneuver.'' **********A West German admiral said the Kiev had been in the Mediterranean, taking part in landing exercises with Syria.  Monitors in Britain said the Soviet Union's largest amphibious landing ship, the Ivan Rogov, was heading north from the English Channel. Danish intelligence officers said they believed it, too, was headed for the Baltic. **********The arrival of the Kiev and two missile-carrying destroyer escorts in the western Baltic raised to at least 10 the number of ships joining the Baltic Fleet in recent days, said Lieut. Col. Preben Broberg, spokesman for the Danish Defense Intelligence Service. **********Colonel Broberg said he thought it was a landing exercise, probably planned for the Baltic coast.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/busin.main_headline: BELGIUM IN WORST SLUMP SINCE WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/busin.print_headline: BELGIUM IN WORST SLUMP SINCE WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/busin.body_text: **********At the edge of this city, on the site of a former railroad yard, Banque Bruxelles Lambert just moved into a gleaming concrete and glass building. But all around it in a sprawling urban renewal area are empty lots, reflecting a wait-and-see attitude among other builders. **********At the bank, Belgium's second largest, there is a feeling that maybe Bruxelles Lambert should have waited, too.  Like many Belgian businesses, Bruxelles Lambert cut its dividend last year, and the empty lots reflect the investment contraction caused by the country's toughest postwar economic crisis. **********''There's been no orthodox financial policy, nothing like an income policy, and the budget has gotten totally out of hand,'' said a top economist at a major Brussels bank, commenting on the Government's failed attempts to set the economy straight. ''We've had crises in steel, textiles and mechanical engineering. Office building has slowed since 1975, and now it's homes, with building costs up and mortgages at 14 percent.'' Further Economic Shrinkage **********In a recent report, published by Belgian newspapers, the national bank forecast that the economy would shrink this year by 1.7 percent, business investment would drop 3.8 percent and the currentaccount deficit would balloon to $6.8 billion. It also projected that unemployment would swell by 100,000, to 477,000, about 10 percent of the work force, which would push Belgium past Ireland into the dubious distinction of having Europe's highest jobless rate. **********As the economist from the Brussels bank explained, ''To avoid deterioration of the labor market, the Government got into subsidizing industry. That would have been all right had it helped improve the companies, but in many cases it only breached the gap, helped them pay the salaries. Our decision-makers didn't recognize the financial situation. Over the last six years we've borrowed the equivalent of $10 billion.'' **********Finding solutions to these problems is complicated by Belgium's smoldering strife between French-speaking Wallonia and Flemishspeaking Flanders. Wallonia, once the cradle of Belgian heavy industry thanks to coal and iron ore, has lost ground to Flanders, where modern industries such as electronics and machinery settled after World War II. **********Now, Wallonia's aging industries, like the steel mills around Liege and Charleroi in the south and east, are getting heavy portions of Government revival aid, giving the Flemish a sense of satisfaction that the Walloons, long Belgium's overlords, are now the country's poor cousins. Oil Shock Felt Strongly **********Belgium's problems arose, many here say, because the country never really recovered from the energy price shock of 1973-74. Old industries like steel, textile and glass had little cash left after paying their oil bills to develop much-needed new products and plants. To worsen matters, plummeting revenues and expanding social security expenditures spawned a huge public debt. **********The recovery of 1978-79 brought some respite, but when Europe's economies swung down again in mid-1980, it was evident that Belgium's structural problems - aging industries, high labor costs and paper-thin profit margins -remained. Efforts to revive industry by Government spending only widened the state's deficit. **********The language strife between Wallonia and Flanders was pushed into the background, at least temporarily, last August when a six-party coalition Government granted partial autonomy to the Flemish and French-speaking regions. That feat accomplished, Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, a 44-year-old Christian Democrat from Flanders, moved forward to tackle the economy's problems. **********Wage restraint is the keystone of Mr. Martens's revival plan, according to Jacques Van Ypersele, his top economic adviser and one of the architects of Europe's monetary system. The plan's first installment came in January, when labor and employers agreed to a two-year wage freeze. **********The second stage, including spending cuts in the bloated social security area, is expected to be ready by next month. And the final stage - to be initiated by a coalition of Government, industry and labor - involves a rethinking of revival plans for such key sectors as steel and textiles. 'How to Spread the Burden' **********''There is definitely more need for fiscal belt-tightening,'' Mr.  Van Ypersele said. ''We must try to cut down public-sector borrowing, which is driving interest rates up. **********''There is a growing awareness that adjustments must come,'' he added. ''Six months ago a wage agreement such as we passed in January would not have been possible. The question now is how to spread the burden in an acceptable fashion.'' **********One way the Belgian Government has hidden its problems from its citizens is by artificially raising the value of the Belgian franc by maintaining high interest rates, and through central bank intervention in currency markets. Thus, Belgians have not felt the brunt of price increases for such imports as French cheese and Japanese television sets. **********Economists say that, in effect, Belgian industry has been footing the bill, first by paying the difference in currency fluctuations to the oil-producing countries, then by raising wages to meet consumer price increases. **********Some economists recommend devaluating the franc as a means out of the bind, to shift the cost of maintaining the standard of living onto the shoulders of consumers, who would have to pay more for imports as the power of their currency dropped abroad. **********''We are quite against any kind of devaluation,'' Mr. Van Ypersele said. ''We are a small open economy, where exports and imports account for about 50 percent of the gross national product. We are a very indexed economy, so that devaluation would have an immediate effect on domestic prices and wages. In a one-year period, we reckon, we would have lost 80 percent of the supposed advantage.'' **********To foot the bill of currency support, the Government has been borrowing increasingly abroad - in West Germany, Switzerland and other European countries - after virtually drying up the domestic lending market. **********By all accounts, however, Belgium can continue to support the franc almost indefinitely, if at an ever greater cost. Belgium has considerable gold reserves, economists said, and it was the Belgians who wisely pushed for a partial gold backing to the European currency unit, the yardstick within the European Monetary System that Belgium now uses increasingly for collateral.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/05/busin.body_text: **********About a year ago, on the fifth floor of what was then a rundown humanities and science building on the campus of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, two 22-year-old former R.P.I. research associates started a computer graphics company called Raster Technologies. **********Shortly thereafter, on the first floor, four former graduate students went into business building large ''point focusing'' solar collectors, founding a company called Power Kinetics Inc. **********A few classrooms remain in the R.P.I.'s Russell Sage Laboratory Annex - there are, after all, about 5,000 students at this school.  But it is the entrepreneurs on campus, with eight such organizations at present, including Raster and Power Kinetics, that have lately been getting most of the attention. **********''I don't think it's a very traditional role for a university,'' said Michael Wacholder, one of the coordinators of the R.P.I.  Incubator Space Project, which houses private companies in university buildings at very low rents, and also allows them access to the school's teaching staff and facilities. ''Essentially what we are doing is taking fledgling businesses and putting them into tax-exempt schools.'' **********The businesses in or near the annex, according to R.P.I., the country's oldest engineering college, are the heart of the program, which is intended to strengthen the ties between business and education in general, and high technology and R.P.I. in particular. A Broad Redefinition **********R.P.I.'s attempt to fuse business and industry more fully is, to many minds, part of the broad redefinition of the relationship between industry and academics occurring in this country. The transformation of a research park built by Stanford University in the 1950's into northern California's Silicon Valley was an early example of the phenomenon. More recent attempts by several universities to set up genetic engineering firms are more contemporary examples. **********While other universities have built industrial parks, or taken equity positions in companies, R.P.I.'s program is as yet the only venture designed to bring private companies completely onto campus. **********R.P.I's program was established for a number of reasons. To begin with, it draws attention, and potential business, to the university's Capital District Technology Program, instituted under the auspices of George M. Low, president of R.P.I., in an effort to increase upstate New York's ''synergism'' among business, industry and government. (Mr. Low, who is a former acting head of National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the director of the manned moon landings, is also an R.P.I. alumnus.) **********Specifically, according to Mr. Wacholder, the Incubator program will bring business to nearby Troy, N.Y., and also to a 1,200-acre industrial park now being built by R.P.I. ''As companies grow,'' he said, ''it is expected that they will leave the incubator space and remain in the community.'' **********Further, according to R.P.I., the program gives life to ventures that might otherwise never get off the ground, for reasons ranging from the complexities of funding to the lack of a Xerox machine. In addition to low rents, companies in the program are granted access to R.P.I.'s extensive computer facilities, consultation rights with its faculty, and privileges at the school's libraries. They also get venture capital advice from the university management. **********In the case of Raster Technologies, in fact, R.P.I. took an minority equity position in the young company in lieu of charging rent. (Jay Morley, vice president for finance and administration at R.P.I., is on Raster's board of directors.) Benefits to Students Seen **********R.P.I. believes the Incubator project will benefit its students tremendously. Mr. Wacholder, for one, believes that the ''entrepreneurial tinge'' of the program complements an academic environment nicely. ''It gives them a feel for the practical side of the thing,'' he said, adding that students no longer go ''way out of town'' to get job experience in fields that might be related to their studies. **********Both landlord and tenants believe the companies involved in R.P.I.'s new program stand a good chance of profiting.  ''Our plans are to be extremely successful,'' said Lou Doctor, the now 23-year-old president of Raster, which will soon begin marketing a computer graphics terminal that allows its operator to produce color pictures as well as more traditional blueprint-like images.  Although Mr. Doctor notes that Raster ''tries to avoid'' estimating its earnings, an engineering magazine has reported that the company hopes to do $25 million to $30 million in sales within two years. **********Mark Rice, president of Power Kinetics, adds that his company, which did $300,000 in sales last year, has a ''75 percent chance'' of being awarded a Saudi Arabian contract for a desalinization project requiring 31 solar collectors. Companies Are Diverse **********Although the Incubator project is primarily made up of businesses run by people with connections to R.P.I. -former students, researchers, or professors - there are no restrictions of this kind.  Of the concerns now in the program, one is a spinoff from a local high-technology company, and another was formed after an established architectural firm merged with a local consultant. Currently, discussions are under way with a ''Canadian company connected with computers'' that wants to move into the New York State area, Mr.  Wacholder said. **********The companies in the Incubator program have little in common beyond newness and a potentially innovative technology. Besides Raster and Power Kinetics, other participants include QC-3 Associates, which biologically validates the results of private water testing laboratories, and Stenson-Dale, a consulting firm concentrating on chemical process design. **********While everyone connected with R.P.I.'s program appears to be happy with its intentions, there are those who are concerned about some of its possible implications. **********''I think the university knows it is treading a thin line here,'' Mr. Rice of Power Kinetics said, referring to a belief that education and industry are ''two distinct entities that should not be combined.'' Mr. Rice added that the ''outer limits of this kind of thing are not very far from where we are now.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/08/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Emery of Emery Air Freight; Balancing Act For Air Cargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/08/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Emery of Emery Air Freight; Balancing Act For Air Cargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/08/busin.body_text: **********The air cargo industry is currently trying to balance a pattern of expansion, on one hand, against an air traffic controllers' strike, a weakening national economy and a changing regulatory atmosphere, on the other. Emery Air Freight is the largest of the major airforwarding companies, as well as a major factor in the international air cargo field. Revenues in 1980 came to $533 million, while net income was $21.6 million. **********John C. Emery Jr., chairman and chief executive officer at Emery, attended Dartmouth College and served as a Navy pilot during World War II. Recently, he discussed the effects of today's complex business conditions on Emery, in particular, and the air cargo industry, in general. **********Q. So far, much of the air cargo industry says it has been unaffected by the flight controllers' strike. Is this the case at Emery? And if the strike is protracted, is there a point at which the air cargo industry will feel it? A. We haven't anticipated any problems, as long as the Federal Aviation Administration continues to provide coverage to the national airways. **********If Emery was still operating as it used to, as an air freight forwarder with 100 percent of its cargo in the bellies of scheduled airlines, today we'd be in very tough shape. Thankfully, however, 80 percent of our cargo is in Emery airplanes now. **********Our big opportunity is really to convince the shipping public that some of the problems that they've seen with the short-haul airlines cutting back on their service is not carrying over on the air cargo side. **********Q. Air cargo is still mostly unexplored territory. How long will it be before the industry ''matures''? A. I don't think we're anywhere near that point. I look upon the air cargo industry as being at aboutthe same poin t the plastics industry was at back in the 19 40's. Rightnow, the state of the art is, you take the equivalent of a Pullman car, whether it's a DC-3 or a 747, and pull the seats out and make itinto a freight car. **********If the CXX is developed for the Air Force, and if the airlines and companies like Emery get behind this, so that there is a commercial derivative of a military-purpose airplane, so that the two forces join together on the future production run of, let's say, 500 rather than the 300 we're talking about -then I think we can see the cost of air cargo substantially decline. **********Q. Emery's real growth declined for the first time last year. How is the generally weakening economy affecting your business? A. Last year it was dull in automotive and retail. So all right, we avoided that. We hit technology in our selling efforts, we hit the graphic arts business, we hit the Government agency business, and we got from those areas a response that offset some of the low points in the automotive and retail thing. **********We are putting a 26 percent increase in our sales force as of the end of last year. We think that by investing more in the sales side today, even with the generally weak market conditions, we can increase our share of the existing market. **********I expect that by 1984 we will be a billion-dollar business. **********Q. If the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978 were yours to rewrite, would you change it substantially? We'd make a couple of changes. The public needs to know and have copies of official tariffs from a rules standpoint. People should understand what liabilities companies like Emery do not assume. **********Number two, there's no longer any collecting agency, as the Civil Aeronautics Board used to be. I think that we can do a better job with better information, and therefore I would urge again the Department of Transportation to bring back the good old days in terms of data collection. **********Q. Other than that, is the airline industry deregulated to your liking? A. Very much so. We hope very much to see the Interstate Commerce Commission bending in the same way the C.A.B. did. It may well be that soon we might want to use trucks up to 1,000 miles. We are filing with the I.C.C. for rights to have traffic surface freight forwarding rights, to be used in times of inclement weather, or on the short haul. We would like to have 48-state rights to do this.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Deere & Company, the world's largest producer of farm equipment and a major manufacturer of construction machinery, said yesterday that net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1981 slipped 2.4 percent as sales fell 4.5 percent. **********''Operating results for the second quarter were affected adversely by lower physical volumes, particularly of industrial equipment,'' said William A. Hewitt, Deere's chairman. **********''The lower production volumes have resulted in underutilization of manufacturing facilities, thereby causing higher costs per unit of production.'' **********Mr. Hewitt added that interest expense was ''much greater due to high interest rates and additional borrowing required to finance increased levels of assets.'' **********The Moline, Ill., concern said that earnings in the three months ended April 30 fell to $90.7 million, or $1.38 a share, from $92.9 million, or $1.52 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales dipped to $1.47 billion from $1.54 billion. **********The company said that worldwide farm equipment sales were 2 percent above the second quarter but that construction equipment sales plunged 37 percent in the period. For the second quarter of the 1981 fiscal year foreign-exchange gains rose 27.8 percent, to $11.5 million, from $9 million in the second quarter of the 1980 fiscal year.
