https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/19/world.main_headline: POLISH PARTY GIVES HIS POST TO PREMIER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/19/world.print_headline: KANIA IS REPLACED; POLISH PARTY GIVES HIS POST TO PREMIER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/19/world.body_text: **********Stanislaw Kania, the Communist leader who gained power at the height of labor unrest nearly 14 months ago, was dismissed today and replaced by his Prime Minister, Wojciech Jaruzelski, a general. **********The Central Committee of Poland's Communist Party, which accepted Mr. Kania's resignation in the third day of a stormy session, also issued demands for stronger action to overcome the economic crisis and for a tougher line against ''antisocialists'' in Solidarity, the independent union. **********The committee also passed a resolution that, citing ''existing dangers to the existence of the state,'' called upon the Government to invoke if necessary ''its constitutional prerogatives to guarantee peace in the country'' - a reference to the imposition of martial law. Cooperation Is Offered **********The resolution asserted that the party was willing to work with all patriotic forces ''who are not against socialism.'' But at the same time it called for a renegotiation of the agreements signed with striking workers last summer, a resumption of the six-day work week and a ''temporary'' suspension of the right to strike. **********Any one of these proposals, if imposed by the authorities, could provoke a major confrontation with the 9.5-million member Solidarity union. **********The ouster of Mr. Kania, a 54-year-old career party official who replaced Edward Gierek Sept. 6, 1980, followed months of deteriorating economic conditions, with food increasingly scarce, long lines in front of shops and a dwindling supply of gasoline.  Politically, the party appeared divided and unable to move in any direction. **********General Jaruzelski, Western diplomats and Polish observers felt, was an attractive choice to be Mr. Kania's sucessor. He is politically moderate and appears to be acceptable to the Soviet Union, the Solidarity union and most of the Polish people. Career Military Officer **********A 58-year-old career officer with ramrod posture and a chest festooned with medals, the general probably owes his selection today to his military uniform more than anything elese. He became Prime Minister in Februray and has not been an activist head of Government. **********His appointment to be first secretary of the Polish Communist Party means an unusual concentration of power in the hands of a military man. It was not immediately known if he would continue as Minister of Defense. The vote to unseat Mr. Kania was 104 to 79, according to P.A.P., the Polish press agency. **********In an acceptance speech, General Jaruzelski asserted that the first priorities were to overcame the economic crisis and strengthen the state. He stressed the ''priceless importance'' of the alliance with the Soviet Union and maintaing the integrity of the Soviet bloc, according to the news agency. Military Role Growing **********Poland has not had a military leader since the inter-war dictatorship of Marshal Jozef Pilsudski. Nowhere else in Eastern Europe does a military officer serve as a party leader, since Communist parties traditionally keep military commanders to one side in the power structure. In recent months, the military has become highly visible in the political landscape. Soldiers have been interviewed on television denouncing ''counterrevolutionary'' forces. Patrols of helmeted troops in open jeeps have become a common sight in Warsaw. Two days ago it was announced that some 40,000 ground troops would have their tours of duty extended by two months. **********Mr. Kania had come under increasingly strident attack for vacillating and being too conciliatory in dealing with Solidarity.  The day before the Central Committee meeting the powerful Warsaw party organization held its own caucus and passed a resolution condeming the leadership. **********Indicative of the mood of the Central Committee meeting was a speech by Zofia Grzyb, a Politburo member, who said: ''Things are going from bad to worse. Production is falling. The shelves in shops are now almost totally empty. The party is in disarray and many party organizations are stagnant. Our people feel no support from the party governing bodies and they cease to believe that overconing the crisis is possible.'' **********Mr. Kania was reported to have offered his resignation to the 15-member Politburo, but several key figures on the Politburo were said to have opposed his removal. He is then reported to have placed it before the 200-member Central Committee. A majority of the committee voted to accept it, according to Interpress, the Government information service. Jaruzelski Gets Big Margin **********A motion for General Jaruzelski to move up to the top position was approved overwhelmingly, winning 180 votes out of 184 cast, the Polish news agency reported. It was not immediatedly known if the General would also continue to serve as Prime Minister. The appointment of a prime minister usually awaits convocation of Parliament. **********Should General Jaruzelski hold on to both psoitions - as both head of the party and head of Government - he would have accumulated a degree of power unprecedented in postwar Poland. But most observers did not expect this to happen. **********Mr. Kania, a heavyset man with closely cropped hair, was a party insider who sought compromises behind the scenes and the comfort of collective rule. In his very first speech as party leader, which was read to the nation by a television announcer, he served notice that he would not be in the limelight. **********He never managed to capture the esteem or the affection of the general public, but he won a kind of grudging admiration for his tenacity, as he steered a delicate course avoiding both open, violent confrontation with Solidarity and military intervention by the Soviet Union. 'A Great and Growing Need' **********He reluctantly went along with the union's drive for a more open society, often opposing it verbally but stepping aside at the last moment to avoid conflict. He was not an architect, but at least not an opponent, of what came to be called ''socialist renewal.'' His promise of a new order was summed up in a sentence he included in many of his speeches: ''Democracy is not a gesture of the ruling power toward society but a great and growing need of the society.'' **********Mr. Gierek's grip on power was loosened quickly by two months of labor turmoil kicked off by meat price increases. Mr. Kania's grip weakened slowly and progressively, as the economy deteriorated day by day and the hopes that the party would move to meet the aspirations of the working-class revolt against its rule gradually turned cold. **********Mr. Kania's single most attaractive feature, for many Poles, was the simple fact that under his leadership security forces were not called out against strikers. It was a fact that lost much of its appeal as the union and the party drifted farther and farther apart, leading many to conclude that his policies would lead ultimately to catastrophe. **********The Soviet Union gradually became disillusioned with Mr. Kania, whom it regarded as weak, and made no secret of its dislike. Soviet leaders held at least four meetings with Mr. Kania, in which they counseled him to move forcefully to head off what they contended was a growing '' counterrevolutionary'' threat. Soviet Message Backfires **********Finally, in June, the Soviet Central Committee sent a harshly worded warning letter that struck most analysts as a call to Polish party members to overthrow their leader. The move, however, backfired, as Mr. Kania rode out a challenge from hard-liners at a Central Committee meeting. His popularity was boosted by a sense of Polish anger at what was viewed as open interference from next door. **********In July, he was overwhelmingly re-elected against only token opposition at the party's national congress. It was the first time in the history of the Soviet bloc that a Communist Party leader was chosen by a secret ballot from the entire congress, and not simply by acclamation by the central committee alone. **********In view of that victory, Mr. Kania's departure today was further proof of how deep the frustrations run in the party's middle-level leadership. It was presaged by a number of actions - including the explusion from the party of a prominent liberal, Stefan Bratkowski, the firing of a newspaper editor who had printed an interview with a well-known political dissident , and a call for party members who also belong to the union to give up one or the other. **********Meanwhile, the Soviet Union has been signaling its dissatisfaction with Mr. Kania in recent weeks, notably by omitting all mention of him in commentaries. By contrast, Stefan Olszowski, a hard-line member of the Politburo, and General Jaruzelski have been praised in some recent Soviet publications.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/busin.print_headline: Toyota and Nissan Set Output Record
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/busin.body_text: **********Japan's top two auto makers today reported record output for March but slower exports.  The Toyota Motor Company, the nation's largest auto maker, said its output of passenger cars and trucks surpassed 307,162 units, an increase of 6 percent over March 1980. **********The Nissan Motor Company, the maker of Datsun cars, reported an output of 223,835 units, up 1.4 percent.  Both output figures are the highest ever for the month of March, the two companies said. Toyota and Nissan account for about half of the total auto output in Japan. **********Meanwhile, Toyota Motor Sales, Toyota's sales unit, said exports for March were down 3 percent, to 148,447 units, and Nissan reported overseas sales of 127,507 units of passenger cars and trucks in the month, down by 9.5 percent. **********A breakdown of exports to individual countries was not immediately available, but industry sources said Japan's car exports to the United States fell 24.7 percent in March to 127,699 units. Total Japanese auto exports to the United States in the first quarter of 1981 were 445,325 units, down 3.5 percent from the first quarter of 1980, the sources said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/30/world.print_headline: AIDE TO KHOMEINI WOUNDED BY 2 GUNMEN IN SOUTH IRAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/30/world.body_text: **********Ayatollah Rabbani Shirazi, the personal representative of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in the southern province of Fars, was slightly wounded by two gunmen in the city of Shiraz yesterday, according to official reports today. **********The assailants, who fired at the Ayatollah from a motorcycle as he sat in his car, escaped. Ayatollah Shirazi's bodyguard was quoted as saying that the attackers, men in their twenties, covered their heads with woolen hats as they fled. **********Ayatollah Shirazi suffered only a slight neck wound, but said in a radio statement from his hospital bed that the bullet ''just missed my jugular vein.'' **********The evening newspaper Ettelaat reported from Shiraz that responsibility for the attack had been taken by Forghan, a shadowy group that is apparently dedicated to killing prominent members of the Moslem clergy, which has played a dominant role in Iran since the overthrow of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi two years ago. Bombing Attack in December **********The attack was the first reported attempt to kill a leading clergyman since last December, when Forghan said it had planted a bomb intended to kill Ayatollah Moussavi Ardabeli, the Prosecutor General. The bomb, placed under a bridge near Teheran University, shattered windows but caused no casualties. **********In a statement expressing concern over political violence, President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr termed the murder attempt ''a clarion call of danger, a warning to society about the spread of terrorism.'' **********(Mr. Bani-Sadr, asked about Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's ability to deal with the political unrest in Iran, told The Associated Press in a telephone interview from Teheran that ''a human being is not God.'' He added: ''Man has limited means considering the problems, barriers and so on. He can act to a limit.'') **********Ayatollah Khomeini sent a message to Ayatollah Shirazi, his longtime associate, calling the two gunmen ''deviate elements'' intent on removing clergymen from the political scene. **********Ayatollah Shirazi, a veteran of the fight against the late Shah, is a member of the 12-member Council of Guardians, which was established by Iran's Constitution to insure that legislation passed by the Parliament is in keeping with Islamic concepts. **********---- Arafat in Teheran on Peace Mission **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 29 (AP) -Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived in Teheran today as part of an effort by a 42-nation Islamic organization to persuade Iraq and Iran to end their war, now in its seventh month. **********Military communiques from both Iran and Iraq indicated that sporadic clashes were continuing along the 300-mile-long front, but that no major battles were under way. **********The 42-nation Islamic Conference established a nine-member commission at a summit meeting last January to mediate the Persian Gulf conflict. The commission put forward a plan earlier this month calling for a cease-fire to be followed by a staged Iraqi withdrawal from Iranian territory over a one-month period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/22/busin.body_text: **********The Union Pacific Corporation, a diversified transportation, natural resources and land development concern, said yesterday that its railroad and some of its energy interests helped increase secondquarter earnings 8 percent from the similar period in 1980. **********Net income was $85.6 million, or 89 cents a share, in the second quarter, compared with $79.2 million, or 82 cents a share, a year earlier. **********Second-quarter revenue rose to $1.6 billion from $1.1 billion. **********The company said refinery earnings ''were under pressure due to market conditions that prevented the full recovery of higher crude oil costs,'' so that sales of refined oil products - affected by falling demand and oversupply - were ''more than offset by increased costs.'' **********Union Pacific also said its manufacturing, marketing and petrochemical operations reported a $31.8 million operating loss in the second quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/01/world.print_headline: New Delhi Suspends Legislature In Manipur After Party Stalemate
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/01/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government has suspended the legislature in Manipur State and imposed central rule in the region following the collapse of her party's government there. **********The orders came after 10 legislators left her ruling Congress Party, forcing the resignation of the chief minister, Rishang Keishing. The 60-member legislature was then unable to form a new government. **********Manipur, a remote northern region, has been troubled since 1978 by armed tribal insurgents demanding independence. Scores of people have died in clashes between security forces and the rebels.

Vehicle registrations fell to 272,456 units last month, down 24.9 percent from April and down 15.9 percent from a year before.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/09/world.print_headline: CHINA TO ISSUE FIRST BONDS SINCE 50'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/09/world.body_text: **********The Government announced plans today for the sale of up to $3.3 billion in treasury bonds this year, the first such bonds issued in China since the 1950's. **********Purchases of the bonds will be dictated by Peking authorities and will be compulsory for selected state-owned factories, local governments, army units and wealthy communes and production brigades, according to the Ministry of Finance. **********Mandatory bond purchases will sharply curtail the amount of fiscal freedom given to various factories and regional administrations in the last two years to develop and invest as they saw fit. With their profits siphoned off by the central Government bonds, some production units will undoubtedly have to curtail expansion plans, as well as profit-sharing and other incentives to workers. **********The New China News Agency said that the Finance Ministry had authorized bonds with face values ranging from 10 yuan, equal to about $6.67, to 1 million yuan, or about $667,000, carrying an annual interest rate of 4 percent and repayable in installments beginning in 1987 and to be completed by 1990. Inflation at Double-Digit Rate **********The Finance Ministry said that some local governments had more money than they could usefully spend. Rather than let them spend it, the authorities intend, through the bond sales, to funnel the excess money into the central coffers in Peking. **********With inflation running into double digits - the official estimate is 5.8 percent a year but officials concede that rates are three times that high in some urban areas - the 4 percent bonds are no bargain. That is why the Government made their purchase voluntary only for individual citizens and overseas Chinese and for foreigners living and working in China.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/31/world.main_headline: SHOULD REAGAN HONOR DEAL WITH IRAN?
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/31/world.print_headline: ISSUE AND DEBATE; SHOULD REAGAN HONOR DEAL WITH IRAN?
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/31/world.body_text: **********As the national celebration over the safe return of the 52 Americans held hostage by Iran draws to a close, the debate over whether to revoke or honor the complex agreements that led to their release may only be beginning. **********Some members of Congress, lawyers for many of the more than 350 companies and individuals that have sued Iran, and publications as diverse as The Wall Street Journal and The New Republic have asserted that President Reagan could and perhaps should renounce as extortionate and illegal all or part of the dollars-for-hostages deal negotiated with Iran by the Carter Administration through Algerian intermediaries. **********Several claimants have gone to court to challenge the constitutionality of efforts to transfer out of the country Iranian assets against which they have filed claims and to terminate their lawsuits in favor of the international arbitration provided in the agreements. Appeals From Carter Aides **********On the other hand, several former senior officials of the Carter Administration have urged their successors to scrupulously enforce the agreements, which they say are highly favorable to the United States and to Americans with commercial claims against Iran. **********President Reagan, at his first news conference, said yesterday that ''I think that the United States will honor the obligations'' under the accords, but he said Administration lawyers had not yet determined ''whether they are in keeping with international and national or our own laws.'' **********The Reagan Administration has postponed regulations implementing President Jimmy Carter's 11th-hour executive orders under the agreements. The carefully hedged statements by Mr. Reagan and other high officials suggest that they have not ruled out the possibility of declaring all or part of the accords illegal under international law and the United States Constitution. The Background **********As the months passed the fate of the hostages released Jan. 20 had become increasingly interlocked with that of the $11 billion to $12 billion in Iranian assets that President Carter froze on Nov. 14, 1979, 10 days after the seizure of the embassy in Teheran. **********The Algiers accords represent a complex set of compromises on the four conditions for release of the hostages announced last September by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian revolutionary leader: return of the frozen assets to Iran, cancellation of American claims against Iran, return of the late Shah's wealth and a pledge of noninterference in internal Iranian affairs. Three of the five documents that embody the details of the financial agreements are still secret, but the general outlines are clear. **********Iran agreed to release the hostages, to submit to binding international arbitration of commercial claims and to pay all claims found valid by a special arbitration tribunal. In return the United States agreed, among other things, to return the frozen assets (including accrued interest), except for about $5 billion set aside to pay off bank loans to Iran and $1 billion that would go into a special escrow account to insure payment of the projected arbitration panel's awards on claims by companies other than banks. **********Iran received $2.9 billion soon after the hostages were released.  A further $3.7 billion was used to repay syndicated loans by American and European banks and $1.4 billion was set aside to repay individual bank loans after resolution of questions about the amounts owed. **********The central issue posed by the Algiers accords now that the hostages are free is whether President Reagan should or legally can honor those of his predecessor's agreements that have not yet been carried out. These include pledges to return within seven months the $3 billion to $4 billion worth of Iranian assets that are still tied up by court orders in the United States; to nullify the court orders and terminate lawsuits in favor of international arbitration; to guarantee Iranian immunity from liability to the hostages and their families and certain classes of commercial claimants, and to provide largely symbolic but still controversial assistance to Iran's efforts to recover property of the Shah and his close relatives. For Renunciation **********Some advocates of renouncing the agreements in whole or in part maintain that such a step is necessary to erase a dangerous precedent no matter how good a deal the Carter Administration lawyers may have achieved for the banks and other claimants. Kidnappers, terrorists and governments that join with them should be put on notice that the United States has no obligation or intention to submit to extortion or to pay ransom in any form, it is argued. **********Critics of the agreements also say that they would prevent the United States from punishing Iran or exacting compensation for the illegal detention and maltreatment of the hostages and the occupation of and damage to the embassy and its contents. **********Enforcement of the agreements might also lead to a kind of deferred ransom for the hostages, some say, by rendering the United States liable to compensate the former hostages and those commercial claimants who cannot obtain just compensation through arbitration. **********Renunciation of the agreements, on the other hand, would free the United States to punish Iran and compensate both commercial claimants and the former hostages by confiscating the $3 billion to $4 billion in Iranian assets still in the United States. **********''To let Iran off not merely scot-free but actually profiting from its obscene conduct would establish an odious and dangerous precedent,'' George W. Ball, a former Under Secretary of State, wrote in The Washington Post. The New Republic editorialized: ''Helping Khomeini get his hands on the Shah's wealth, however ill-gotten it may have been, is rewarding the Ayatollah for seizing our diplomats.'' A Respectable Basis **********A Harvard law professor, Detlev F. Vagts, and other experts on treaty law say that there is a respectable basis in international law for renouncing the accords or for asking the International Court of Justice to declare them void, although Professor Vagts said he would not necessarily advocate such a course as a matter of policy. He cited Article 52 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, which provides that treaties are void if ''procured by thethreat or use of force in violation of the principles of international law embodied in the Charter of the United Nations.'' **********Lawyers representing many companies and individuals with commercial claims against Iran are critical of portions of the agreements that they fear would put their claims at risk or underminethem while insuring the banks full repayment of loans that became bad risks long before the hostage crisis. **********Precedent does not resolve constitutional doubts as to the President's power to nullify court orders and terminate lawsuits in order to remove from the country billions of dollars' worth of foreign assets claimed by American citizens and corporations. Lawyers for companies that would apparently be excluded from access to the arbitration tribunal, such as those suing under contracts that provide for Iranian court jurisdiction over all disputes, say they have a particularly strong constitutional argument for continuing their lawsuits against Iran or for exacting compensation from the United States. **********Even some claimants who would clearly have access to arbitration consider it a risky and inadequate substitute for lawsuits. Against Renunciation **********The former Carter Administration officials and others who have argued that the United States must keep its word insist that this is essential to retain the respect and trust of other nations, especially since the accords were negotiated through the good offices of the Algerian leadership. **********Warren M. Christopher, former Deputy Secretary of State, who spent the last days of the hostage crisis in Algiers, said in a television interview with CBS News: ''The word of the United States is a very important commodity, and I want to keep it pure.'' **********Mr. Christopher and others warn that reneging would further antagonize Iran and insult Algeria and would damage the reputation of the United States in other Islamic countries and around the world.  Renunciation could also undermine the more rational elements in the fragmented Iranian leadership, they maintain, and increase the already grave danger of Soviet influence and penetration in the vital oil-producing region. Full Repayment of Bad Loans **********Supporters of the agreements also argue that they insure full repayment of bank loans that had already become bad risks by the time the Shah fell and would leave most or all other American commercial claimants with better chances of obtaining compensation than they would have had if the hostages had not been seized. **********Many of those claimants would have had difficulty obtaining compensation through lawsuits against Iran, according to Lloyd N.  Cutler, who was President Carter's counsel, because of a variety of rules limiting the liability of foreign governments in United States courts. The international arbitation provisions agreed to by Iran, on the other hand, would be free of many of the technical defenses it could raise in the United States, would at least in theory provide full compensation to all claimants that have access to the arbitration panel and would make awards not paid by Iran enforceable against Iranian assets in other countries. **********The former Carter Administration officials say that they were forced to accept Iranian demands that certain classes of claims be excluded from the arbitration agreements, but that they drafted the exclusions so narrowly that they would apply only to claimants who would have had little chance of obtaining compensation in any event. **********Renunciation of the agreements, they say, could also cost the banks the $1.4 billion in Iranian deposits now held in a special fund pending resolution of disagreements. The Outlook **********The tone of the recent statements by President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. suggests that they are inclined to honor the agreements to the extent that they can under United States law and to the extent that Iran honors its obligations. **********Those are important qualifications. It is not clear whether some aspects of the agreements could survive the expected court tests, and Mr. Haig's stress at his news conference Wednesday on the importance of what he termed ''the Iranian regime's post hostage return attitude'' may presage an effort to challenge Iran's willingness to settle claims and to pay arbitration awards before the remaining assets are moved out and before any lawsuits are terminated. **********It is clear that the Reagan Administration does not plan to do any favors for Iran. Mr. Haig said that ''there will be no military equipment provided to Iran'' even though some was bought and paid for before the hostages were taken. He discouraged American businessmen from traveling to Iran to renew trade even though Mr. Carter lifted formal trade sanctions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/01/busin.body_text: **********APPOINT/ Names 2 Officers Lance Primis, advertising director of The New York Times, and John M. O'Brien, the newspaper's controller, have been elected vice presidents of The Times, it was announced yesterday. **********Mr. Primis, 34 years old, has been advertising director of The Times since December 1979. **********He joined the newspaper in 1969 as a classified advertising sales representative and has moved up through a variety of sales and management positions. **********As advertising director, Mr. Primis has been responsible for all display, classified, production, promotion and research functions of the newspaper's advertising department. **********Mr. O'Brien, 38, became controller of The Times in December 1978.  He joined the newspaper in 1960 and in 1966 was promoted to assistant manager of general accounting. Three years later he became controller of the Microfilming Corporation of America, a Times Company affiliate. He returned to the newspaper in 1971 as assistant controller. **********As controller, Mr. O'Brien has been responsible for the operations of the newspaper's general accounting, budget planning, advertising accounting, credit and customer service departments, and the cashier's office. **********The New York Times is published daily by The New York Times Company. The company's operations also include magazines, books, regional newspapers, broadcast facilities, a news service and an information retrieval service. end

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/25/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 'Easy' Marriage Annulments Are Denounced by the Pope
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/25/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II today denounced ''easy and hurried'' marriage annulments granted by Roman Catholic Church courts. **********He noted that there had been ''an alarming increase'' in annulments in recent years. Latest Vatican figures show that church tribunals, mostly at local levels, granted 55,450 annulments worldwide in 1978, up from 11,120 in 1973. Most of the cases were reported in the United States, where 43,470 couples obtained annulments in 1978, up from 9,654 in 1973. **********The Pope, addressing the Sacred Roman Rota, a Vatican tribunal, said annulments tend to weaken the institution of marriage, particularly in the minds of young people. The church does not accept divorce.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/18/busin.body_text: **********Rejecting President Reagan's approach to business tax relief, the Democratic majority on the House Ways and Means Committee today adopted a plan centered on cuts in corporate tax rates, starting in 1984. **********By a largely party-line vote of 20 to 14, the committee also endorsed the principle of letting business take a full write-off for investments in equipment and vehicles in the year the investment is made. Mr. Reagan had proposed letting business deduct from taxable income the cost of vehicles in three years, most equipment in five years and buildings in 15 years. **********The Democrats proposed to reduce the corporate tax rate in stages from its present 46 percent to 43 percent in 1984 and then down by three percentage points a year to 34 percent in 1987. The lower rates now paid on profits of less than $100,000 would also be reduced, aides said. **********The combination of general corporate rate reduction and first-year write-offs of investments was intended to appeal to the business community. Although Washington business lobbyists have maintained a solid front in support of the Reagan proposal, which originated with big business several years ago, small business and service companies may find the Democratic alternative even more attractive. 'Scatter-Shot Scheme' **********In a statement tonight, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan denounced the Democratic proposal as ''a last-minute, scatter-shot scheme which falls short of addressing the economic needs of the country.'' He said the Administration proposal had the merit of linking tax relief ''to job-creating investments that help modernize American industry.'' **********Mr. Regan's point was that the Democrats would give tax relief through rate reduction to all corporations, whereas the Administration's approach would deliver tax write-offs only to companies that invest in plant and equipment. **********The votes in the Ways and Means Committee late this afternoon were the first of many that must occur in committees and on the House and Senate floors before a 1981 tax-relief bill becomes law. **********Although Mr. Reagan continues to exhort Congress to pass a tax bill by Aug. 1, there is little belief in Congress that this target date can be achieved. A few days ago, Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said he thought the House could complete floor action by the end of July. **********The Senate Finance Committee is scheduled to start drafting a bill of its own tomorrow. It is expected to be much closer to Mr.  Reagan's proposals, including a 25 percent cut in individual taxes over three years, than the Ways and Means bill. A floor fight in the House between the Democratic leadership and the Administration appears certain. **********Mr. Reagan's approach to business tax relief has been criticized as giving benefits almost exclusively to capital-intensive industries, such as oil refining, steel, chemicals and paper, and offering little to labor-intensive and advanced-technology companies. By definition, capital-intensive industries excludes small business. Strategy a Surprise **********The Democratic strategy, developed in the last few days and a surprise to most of the capital, was to offer tax relief to all corporations, regardless of industry, and to dangle before business the attractive possibility of simple, first-year writeoffs for investments in equipment and machinery. **********Representative Sam Gibbons of Florida, the second-ranking Democrat on the committee, said the Democratic plan was intended to cost the Treasury roughly the same revenue as the Administration's approach.  Estimates prepared by the nonpartisan staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation showed the Democratic plan costing a little less than Mr.  Reagan's until the fiscal year 1990, when it would cost $92.2 billion, or $1.5 billion more. **********The senior Administration representative at the committee's session, John E. Chapoton, the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Tax Policy, was cool to the Democratic proposal, arguing that its phase-in feature would make it less an incentive to near-term business investment than the Administration's plan. He noted that the Administration had dropped its original intention to phase in its own tax depreciation plan on the ground that a phase-in may give a company an incentive to delay a new investment to take advantage of more generous write-off terms later. **********In the Ways and Means Committee vote, three of the 23 Democrats voted with the Republicans. They were Kent Hance of Texas, who is a co-sponsor of the Administration tax bill; James R. Jones of Oklahoma, a principal author in 1979-80 of the depreciation approach adopted by the Reagan Administration, and J. J. Pickle of Texas, one of the more conservative Democrats on the panel. **********Mr. Rostenkowski said at the start of today's two-hour-and-20-minute session that he hoped the committee would finish with business tax relief this week and deal with savings incentives and estate and gift taxes next week. With a Congress recess scheduled for the week of June 29, the committee would reach individual tax relief - the most politically contentious facet of the bill - in the week of July 6. **********Mr. Rostenkowski said that the committee was voting only on ''concepts'' today, not on blueprints, and that there would be an opportunity to revise today's decisions. Nevertheless, it appeared that decisions in principle had been taken in the Democratic caucus that preceded the committee meeting and that revisions would be minor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/04/world.main_headline: Three London Robbers Take $2 Million in Gems at Cartier
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/04/world.print_headline: Three London Robbers Take $2 Million in Gems at Cartier
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/04/world.body_text: **********Three robbers broke into Cartier today and fled with nearly $2 million in jewels, just missing a $7.52 million shipment in gems that arrived minutes after they escaped, the police said today. **********Leonard Williams of Scotland Yard said that there was ''no doubt'' that the men were waiting for the larger shipment. **********But the thieves could not wait for the Cartier gems, which were on their way back to the store from a society charity exhibition, the police added. **********One of the store's two guards broke away and raised the alarm during the robbery, but the police would not say if that was why the thieves fled. **********Guards on a security truck returning the gems saw the police and a commotion round the store and sped off to their company's headquarters, where the gems were locked up for the night. **********The police said the robbers, armed with a handgun and a sawed-off shotgun, beat up two security guards on duty inside the Cartier showrooms at New Bond Street in London's Mayfair district.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/30/world.main_headline: U.S. HOSTAGE IS SHOT ON INDONESIAN JET AT BANGKOK AIRPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/30/world.print_headline: U.S. HOSTAGE IS SHOT ON INDONESIAN JET AT BANGKOK AIRPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/30/world.body_text: **********The hijackers of an Indonesian jetliner shot and wounded an American hostage today as he tried to flee the sweltering plane hours after a British passenger managed to escape. The American was in serious condition at a nearby hospital. **********Forty-nine passengers and crew members were still aboard the Garuda Airlines DC-9 at the Bangkok airport today as Indonesian officials negotiated with the hijackers. **********The hijackers, said to be armed with submachine guns, pistols, dynamite and grenades, seized the plane yesterday during a domestic Indonesian flight. **********Indonesia Sends Negotiators **********The hijackers originally demanded the release of 20 ''political prisoners'' in Indonesia, but raised the number to 80, and then 84. A team of Indonesian officials that arrived here last night agreed to the final number. **********(A Thai spokesman said Indonesia had agreed to all the hijackers' demands, but would only disclose one -freedom for the 84 prisoners, according to The Associated Press. The spokesman said the nature of the others was an internal Indonesian matter. **********(Thai officials said the hijackers also demanded punishment for the Indonesian Vice President, Adam Malik, ''for taking kickbacks from a United States aircraft company,'' and ''the expulsion of all Jewish officials and Israeli militarists from Indonesia,'' United Press International reported.) Briton Uses Emergency Exit **********A 27-year-old British hostage, Robert Wainwright, escaped through an emergency exit earlier today while the hijackers were in the cockpit. The beaming Briton, waving a clenched fist, told reporters after his escape that the hijackers ranged from 20 and 40 years old. **********Hours later, a 47-year-old American, Karl Schneider, bolted through a front exit while ground mechanics were attempting to refuel the plane. **********The hijackers, increasingly impatient and irritable, opened fire.  Mr. Schneider was shot twice in the side and fell to the tarmac. He was taken to the nearby Royal Thai Air Force Hospital and was listed in serious condition. The Texas-born American underwent surgery for a bullet ledged near his spine. **********The American and the Briton work for the Indonesian branch of the Milchem Company, a New Orleans-based concern that supplies drilling fluids and chemicals to the oil industry. **********The United States Embassy here said that Mr. Schneider was one of three Americans aboard the plane. A spokesman refused to reveal the names of the other two. **********There were 44 passengers and five crew members still aboard the plane. Throngs of onlookers and food vendors were camped beside the airport's chain-link fence. Military policemen armed with Israelimade Uzi submachine guns watched the crowd. **********Indonesian and Thai officials, sequestered in a third-floor office at the airport, negotiatied via radio with the hijackers.  The hijackers initially demanded that they be flown to Colombo, but Sri Lankan officials refused to accept them. The hijackers have yet to propose a new destination. **********It was the second international airline hijacking since Friday.  The first, involving 50 hostages, eight of them Americans, ended last night without injuries when the four hijackers of a Honduran jetliner surrendered in Panama. The Honduran Government had acceded to the demand for the release of a group of prisoners. ---- Hijackers Held in Panama **********PANAMA, March 29 (UPI) - Four hijackers who held 50 hostages aboard a plane for two days were in military custody today awaiting the arrival from Honduras of 13 prisoners who were to be released in order to end the hijacking. **********The hijackers, who seized a New Orleans-bound Honduran jet Friday, freed the hostages, including eight Americans, when the plane flew here late last night from Managua, Nicaragua. **********A Panamanian Government communique said that Honduras had agreed to free the 13 leftist prisoners whose release had been demanded by the hijackers in order to end the 32-hour standoff. **********The communique said the four Honduran hijackers would remain under National Guard custody until the Honduran Government gave the prisoners safe conduct out of Honduras and a third Government granted them entry. **********Unconfirmed reports said that the hijackers, members of the Cinchoneros Popular Liberation Movement, and the released prisoners would fly to Cuba.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/07/busin.main_headline: Business People; New President Named At Jordache Subsidiary
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/07/busin.print_headline: Business People; New President Named At Jordache Subsidiary
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/07/busin.body_text: **********Stanley Schwarz, 41, has been named to the new post of president of Jordache Licensee Promotions Ltd. The new unit, a subsidiary of Jordache Jeans Inc., will be responsible for the 32 apparel and accessory licensees of the Jordache label and its horsehead symbol. **********''The way I see the thing, we have an orchestra right now and we need a conductor,'' said Mr. Schwarz in a telephone interview. ''I want to bring it all together and bring up the quality of the licensees.'' **********Born in Israel, Mr. Schwarz attended Temple University in Philadelphia and served as a United States Army officer in Korea. His business experience has been in retailing; he started at Alexander's in New York in 1963 and moved on to Burdine's and Jordan Marsh in Miami. Since 1976, he has been associated with Goldwater's in Phoenix, most recently as senior vice president and general merchandise manager. **********In moving next week to Jordache -whose total retail sales of its own and licensed products amounted to about $300 million last year - Mr. Schwarz knows exactly what he would like to accomplish. ''I'm a very structured guy and I'm going to first of all concentate on the business that we have,'' he said. ''Then I'll venture out into other areas, like fragrance, men's dress shirts and men's neckwear. The kids who have bought the jeans are graduating into other products.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/01/world.print_headline: Around the World; U.S. Is Advocating Freeze in U.N. Budgets
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/01/world.body_text: **********Elliott Abrams, President Reagan's choice for Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations, said today that the United States had called on the United Nations and its agencies to hold budgets for 1984 and 1985 to the same dollar level as those being set for 1982 and 1983. **********There is ''much too much fat'' in the budgets of international organizations, he told a news conference, adding that the Reagan Administration could not accept any further budgetary expansion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/26/world.body_text: **********Israel is currently juggling three dilemmas.  It must decide whether or not to accept European participation in a Sinai peacekeeping force under terms it finds abhorrent. It must decide whether or not to accept American notions of ''strategic cooperation'' far more limited than those originally sought. And it must decide whether or not to accept American appeals for continued restraint in the face of a Palestinian arms buildup in southern Lebanon. **********If taken literally, the unequivocal statements by the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin would guarantee rejection on all three questions. But no available option seems free of disadvantages for Israel, and officials are now weighing the choices in search of those that do the least damage. **********In large measure, the issues have been complicated by ultimatums.  In recent months, Mr. Begin and his key advisers have told the Europeans that they can stay home if they base their Sinai participation on anything outside the Camp David accords. They have told the United States it can do without Israeli cooperation if anything short of a comprehensive, broad-based strategic agreement develops. They have warned of military action against Syrian missiles and P.L.O. bases in Lebanon if American diplomacy fails to get results. **********In each case, in Israel's view, the worst possibility has been realized.  The Europeans, in offering troops for Sinai, divided the Camp David agreement in half, endorsing only part of it, and linked their role to the Common Market's 1980 Venice declaration on Palestinian self-determination and P.L.O. legitimacy, an approach vehemently rejected by israel. Stockpiling of Medical Supplies **********In Washington, Pentagon officials have reportedly limited their interest in military cooperation to the stockpiling of medical supplies in Israel, and a few joint maneuvers, far short of the Israeli hopes for extensive stockpiling of heavy weaponry. **********In Lebanon, American diplomacy has come to naught - Syrian missiles are still there after nearly seven months, and the Palestine Liberation Organization is said to be stronger than ever militarily. **********Some of Mr. Begin's credibility is in jeopardy. After making such categorical threats, he risks seeing his demands become nothing but bluffs, with consequences for his Government's standing at home and abroad. **********More durable interests are also at stake. The Sinai force, for example, has turned out to be a double-edged diplomatic sword for Israel. Because the force is is the creation of the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty, it has been rejected by those countries that oppose the pact. It could not be formed under United Nations auspices, as prescribed by the treaty, because the Soviet Union said it would veto the plan in the Securty Council. U.S. Seeks Broad Participation **********Therefore, the Reagan Administration has argued to Israel, Western European participation would broaden international acceptance and legitimacy of the Camp David process. **********The trouble for Israel is that, in announcing their participation, Britain, France, Italy and the Netherlands diluted the significance of Camp David by stating, ''We regard our support for the arrangements associated with the implementation of the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty as quite distinct from and independent of the rest of the Camp David process.'' **********This meant that they were dissociating themselves from Camp David's other aspect, the provisions for limited Palestinian selfadministration in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********The 10 European Economic Community countries also reaffirmed the Venice declaration, calling for the ''Palestinian people to exercise fully its right to self-determination,'' meaning the establishment of a Palestinian state. They also declared that the ''P.L.O. must be involved in the process leading to a comprehensive peace.'' Israel Balks at European Role **********These words have made the European role difficult for Israel to accept. The Begin Government does not want to weaken the Camp David accords, which it regards as a buffer against a Palestinian state and the legitimization of the P.L.O. **********Officials here are therefore inclined to reject the Europeans, as Mr. Begin was reported to have indicated today to the United States Ambassador, Samuel W. Lewis. A final decision is expected after the Israeli Cabinet meets next Sunday. **********Israel is also distressed by the narrow scope of military cooperation being proposed by Washington. Defense Minister Ariel Sharon is reportedly considering canceling a trip to the United States scheduled for next week to show his displeasure at American reluctance to enter into a broad-based partnership with Israel. Last month, he told a United States delegation to stay home after it had become clear that the Americans wanted to investigate only medical facilities. **********The disagreements extend into the Lebanon situation, where the United States, according to an American official here, has taken the position that the P.L.O. has not violated the cease-fire by deploying additional heavy weapons within range of Israeli settlements. The Begin Government, which agreed to the cease-fire last July on the explicit condition that the Palestinians not use it to enhance and fortify their positions, are anxious to convey a sense of alarm to Washington.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/07/busin.main_headline: TAX SAVING SEEN KEY TO DOME'S BID
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/07/busin.print_headline: TAX SAVING SEEN KEY TO DOME'S BID
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/07/busin.body_text: **********An offer by Dome Petroleum Ltd. of Canada to pay $915 million for a minority stake in Conoco Inc. was made, without prior consultation with Conoco, as a way to avoid payment of capital gains taxes, insiders said yesterday. **********Dome's unusual approach would enable the Canadian oil company to swap the 14 million Conoco shares it wants to buy, at $65 a share, for Conoco's 53 percent block in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company. It was devised to get around a tax problem that would arise for Conoco in the exchange for the shares of Hudson's Bay, headquartered in Calgary, Alberta. **********The Dome proposal grew out of a problem that developed last year after Esmark Inc. sold its Vickers oil properties to the Mobil Oil Corporation. In that case, Mobil first agreed to pay Esmark $715 million for Vickers and then bought $715 million worth of Esmark stock to pay for Vickers. That ostensibly made the transaction taxfree for Esmark. **********Some tax lawyers said privately that the Internal Revenue Service was expected to attack the Esmark-Mobil approach and that, if it did, it would probably win. **********''It might take 10 years to find out who's right, and in the meantime Esmark has the use of the funds that it might otherwise have to pay in taxes,'' one Wall Street insider said. **********The tax that Esmark might have to pay is estimated at roughly $100 million or more, while the tax impact on Conoco in the Hudson's Bay deal could be more than twice that amount. **********As explained by insiders close to the transaction, the I.R.S.  takes the position that a tax-free deal in such a proposal is possible only when the buyer is a stockholder. But Mobil, these sources said, did not become a stockholder of Esmark until after it had reached agreement with Esmark about the price it would pay for Vickers. **********Dome, on the other hand, will take the position that its plan to swap the Conoco block for Hudson's Bay is tax-free because it will be a Conoco stockholder when, and if, it makes the swap. **********Early yesterday, Conoco declined comment on the Dome tender offer, saying it had not seen the documents. By late in the day, a spokesman said Conoco had subsequently obtained a copy of the Dome proposal and that it was arranging a directors' meeting for ''next week sometime'' to prepare a response. **********Although Conoco sources maintained that the Canadian bid had come as a complete surprise, sources close to both companies contended that top executives of the two oil concerns had discussed the possible sale of Hudson's Bay, particularly in light of Canada's growing efforts to bring Canadian oil companies under domestic ownership. May Seek More Conoco Stock **********As proposed by Dome, the Canadian company's tender offer, which began yesterday and runs through June 3, would establish Dome's standing - for tax purposes - as a stockholder of Conoco, with a 13 percent holding. However, in what was described by insiders as ''protection if Conoco says no,'' Dome's offer provides for an eventual purchase of 22 million Conoco shares, or 20 percent, a deal that would cost Dome more than $1.4 million in cash. **********More importantly, it would enable Dome to add 20 percent of Conoco's profits to its own, something it could not do under current accounting procedures with less Conoco stock. **********Wall Street investment bankers, meanwhile, speculated that the Securities and Exchange Commission and the American Stock Exchange, where Hudson's Bay stock is traded, would almost certainly start investigating the heavy trading that took place in that stock in advance of the Dome offer announced Tuesday. **********''The buyers had the wrong facts but the right stock,'' one Wall Street professional said yesterday. Heavy Trading in Hudson's Bay **********Trading in Conoco on Tuesday, prior to the Dome offer, showed no unusual movement, but Hudson's Bay stock jumped $3.325 points in heavy trading on the Amex, to $23. By yesterday's close, Conoco had jumped $6.625, to $56.50, on a volume of about 1.5 million shares.  Hudson's Bay did not trade here yesterday. A Hudson's Bay spokesman had said early Tuesday that it had no explanation for the price rise in its stock. **********The company was formed in 1926 by Conoco and the Hudson's Bay Company, with Conoco getting 75 percent. This stake has fallen to 53 percent, worth about $925 million, through sales to stockholders and acquisitions using stock. Hudson's Bay owns 21 percent; the rest is publicly held. **********Dome's proposal, stressing that it was not to get control of Conoco but ''to enable Dome to negotiate with Conoco'' on the stock swap, was pictured as ''consistent with the aims of'' Canada's energy program.
