https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/02/world.main_headline: FOR PARTY LEADER FROM SIBERIA, 'CAREER IS AN ALIEN NOTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/02/world.print_headline: FOR PARTY LEADER FROM SIBERIA, 'CAREER IS AN ALIEN NOTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/02/world.body_text: **********Among the delegates to the 26th Communist Party Congress here, a special bustle surrounds the men in their 40's and 50's who have made their way to key positions in industry, agriculture and the party apparatus. It is they who constitute the talent pool from which the next generation of Kremlin leaders will most likely emerge. **********One such man is Pavel S. Fedirko, first secretary of the party committee for Krasnoyarsk Territory in eastern Siberia, 2,500 miles from Moscow. It is a fast-developing industrial and agricultural area sprawling over 928,000 square miles from the Arctic Ocean in the north to the fertile steppes in the south. **********In a political system that concentrates ultimate power in the party and subordinates all economic, social and governmental institutions to the party's will, Mr. Fedirko is in effect the region's boss. He and his committee in Krasnoyarsk, the territory's principal city, are deeply involved in all local decision-making to see to it that Moscow's policies and plans are carried out. Politicking in Corridors **********The other day, between the formal speeches at the party congress and the informal politicking in the corridors and lobbies, Mr.  Fedirko consented to sit down with a Western reporter and talk about himself. **********At 48, he is a powerfully built man -more than six feet tall, beginning to spread around the midriff, and with a puffiness about the face that suggests long working hours, irregular meals and too little exercise. He is soft-spoken. His manner is attentive and responsive; he seems quick to catch the essence of a question and impatient to dispose of it and proceed to the next one. **********''I get up early in the morning to be in the office by half past eight,'' Mr. Fedirko said. ''I try to get away by 9:30 in the evening, but sometimes I can't manage it until 10 or 11. On Saturdays I can usually leave by 8:30 P.M.; Sundays are supposed to be free, but half the time there's work to be done.'' **********Mr. Fedirko appears to have been working these grueling hours most of his life, from the time he graduated from engineering school in Rostov, in European Russia, at the age of 22 and went to work in a metallurgical plant in Norilsk, in Krasnoyarsk Territory above the Arctic Circle. His wife and infant daughter accompanied him to that harsh terrain. Rise Through Party Ranks **********Mr. Fedirko specialized in nonferrous metallurgy, but to the party committee in the plant his leadership qualities must have seemed better fitted for political responsibilities, for three years later, in 1957, he was elected to party membership and his rise began. By 1970 he was first secretary of the city committee of Krasnoyarsk and by 1972 he headed the party organization for the entire territory. **********How, he was asked, is a party career made? Do young men rise through association with a superior who makes it to the top?  ''We don't use the word 'career' or even think it,'' Mr. Fedirko replied. ''That connotes something individual. But if you mean 'How do people advance in their work?' we watch people constantly, and when we see someone who is especially conscientious and talented, we pick him for promotion or a more important assignment. It's a collective decision.'' **********Mr. Fedirko said his first marriage ended in divorce years ago, and the daughter who was taken to Siberia as an infant is now married.  His second wife, Lidiya, teaches at an institute and has a heavy work schedule of her own, ''so it works out all right.'' They have a 12-year-old son, Viktor. Trips 'All Over Soviet Union **********''What we do is take a month's vacation together every year,'' he said. ''I try to put it to good use by going to places where I can learn more about the world. We have been all over the Soviet Union, and also in Italy, Cuba and the German Democratic Republic.'' **********Asked about his special interests, Mr. Fedirko spoke of Krasnoyarsk Territory - its coal, nonferrous metal, lumbering and other industries, its rich mineral deposits, the giant hydroelectric station, and plans for an even more powerful station. **********''We must improve living conditions so we can continue to attract people into our area in sufficient numbers to carry out our industrial development plans,'' he said. **********''The problem is not becoming any easier, because the manpower situation is getting tighter all over the country. We must solve it by creating both social and professional advantages, so people will know that they have wide perspectives, interesting work, a chance to do something new and important. **********''We have not done badly so far. We have learned to build better housing. The region was a backward province, a place of exile, in czarist times. Krasnoyarsk is a beautiful city now.'' **********An aide to Mr. Fedirko came up and said, ''It's time.'' Mr. Fedirko, explaining that he was late for an appointment, said goodbye and added: ''Visit us in Siberia.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/16/world.main_headline: FOR THE CARIBBEAN, A NEW APPROACH TO ASSISTANCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/16/world.print_headline: FOR THE CARIBBEAN, A NEW APPROACH TO ASSISTANCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/16/world.body_text: **********The islands and countries of the Caribbean Sea, from the Bahamas 1,500 miles south to Venezuela and from Belize 2,000 miles east to Barbados, share the memories of empire but now speak only the common language of poverty and desperate, largely unfulfilled longings. **********Last weekend, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met in the Bahamas with the Foreign Ministers of three other nations that are among the richest in the hemisphere - Mexico, Venezuela, and Canada - and agreed that something had to be done to help the region. **********In a joint press conference afterward, the four said they would set up working groups to consult with governments seeking assistance.  Then Mr. Haig will meet with Foreign Ministers Mark MacGuigan of Canada, Jose Alberto Zambrano of Venezuela and Jorge Castaneda of Mexico before the end of the year. **********There were no other promises, no price tag on the possible cost of this undertaking and no speculation on how it might be financed. The Causes of the Problems **********The problems of the 52 million people in the region have been multiplied by skyrocketing oil prices but are rooted, according to many economic analysts, in unequal terms of trade: the cheap sale of their agricultural products and natural resources and the expensive purchase of food, manufactured products, petroleum and technology. **********Meanwhile, their populations and unemployment soar, their cities attract rings of slums and land is wasted. Education, housing, sanitation and medical care range from inadequate to miserable.  People with talent, skills and ambition often leave. **********''So far from God, so close to the United States,'' they say in the Dominican Republic in an expression of the love-hate feeling of admiration and resentment that one finds in many countries of the region. **********Past United States administrations have analyzed the region's problems and announced their intention to do something, but inevitably their attention has been detoured elsewhere unless a crisis arose. What's Already Being Done **********''Our attention span is too short,'' said a member of the group accompanying Mr. Haig last weekend.  Nonetheless, United States economic involvement in the region is significant: $350 million a year in foreign aid, according to the State Department, and investments of $20 billion to $25 billion, according to the Department of Commerce. Annual exports to the region, including Mexico, are $22.7 billion and imports from it are $25.9 billion. **********The other countries at last Saturday's talks also have been helping the region: Canada has announced it will double its annual foreign aid to $100 million, and Mexico and Venezuela each gave $350 million in aid last year. **********Part of the reason for the failure of past aid programs in the region, as Prime Minister J.M.G. Adams of Barbados said during a visit to the United States last fall, has been been the perception that they are anti-Communist measures and nothing more. **********The United States emphasis on private investment, he said, has also been criticized as a form of economic imperialism and an excuse to ignore the need for development assistance to the less profitable projects. Differences Are Accepted **********The United States, Mexico, Canada and Venezuela still have different opinions about the role of private capital in economic and social development plans. **********A senior State Department official at last weekend's conference said the term mini-Marshall Plan ''is not apt either in its implications of an exclusive emphasis on foreign aid or in its unilateral, made-in-Washington sense'' for what the Reagan Administration now has in mind. **********William E. Brock, the United States trade representative, said he hoped other industrialized nations such as Japan and Germany could be persuaded to join in trying to ''weave together aid, trade and investment.'' **********Foreign Minister Castaneda, on the other hand, said Mexico, with fewer potential private investors, would place less emphasis on the private sector. **********The four nations also have different opinions about aid to Cuba, Grenada and Nicaragua and about military aid to El Salvador. In a communique after their meeting, they agreed that ''there are signifiant advantages to an economic and social development approach without military considerations or political preconditions.'' Mexico's Conditions **********This statement, Mr. Castaneda said, reflected three conditions set out by Mexico before the conference: that there be no military component, that no country be automatically excluded from participation and that the conference not become a political platform for an anti-Communist campaign. **********In this framework, assistance could go to Cuba, although the United States would not be obigated to participate. ''We are giving no red lights,'' Mr. Haig said, ''and we are giving no green lights.'' **********''The fact they would agree to ignore their differences is significant,'' said a high-ranking member of the Canadian delegation. ''The most impotant thing,'' said Mr. MacGuigan, ''is that they have begun something new here with the promise to proceed.'' **********''It's a great step forward,'' said Mr. Castaneda.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/25/world.main_headline: WARSAW CUTS THE MONTHLY MEAT RATION BY 20 PERCENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/25/world.print_headline: WARSAW CUTS THE MONTHLY MEAT RATION BY 20 PERCENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/25/world.body_text: **********The 7.7-pound monthly meat ration for Poles was cut by 20 percent today. **********Before sunrise, even before the news had reached all the city, long lines had formed.  There are lines for almost everything in Poland. Lines at kiosks for newspapers in the morning become lines for cigarettes later in the day. There are lines for bread, lines for vodka, lines for plane tickets, linoleum and detergents. Lately, lines for gasoline have meant waits of one to two hours. **********But meat in Poland is politics, so the meat lines are the ones that worry the authorities the most. A sudden rise in meat prices last July was one of the things that touched off labor disturbances that culminated in the emergence of the independent union Solidarity. **********According to Solidarity, the Mayor of Lodz, the second largest city in Poland, has been bombarding Warsaw with telegrams demanding more meat supplies. Next week, Solidarity plans to stage ''antihunger'' marches in Lodz, including one by women. **********Another protest march will be conducted in Kutno, a railroad junction town west of Warsaw, where the meat made available is said to have fallen about 30 percent short of the specified ration. Truck's Arrival Produces a Line **********Warsaw is still relatively privileged. But this morning a line developed quickly at Meat and Sausage, a state store on Pulawska Street, soon after the arrival of a meat delivery truck. ''Now we'll see what they're bringing,'' said a women in a checked dress, clutching a shopping bag. **********''I was driving along and I saw the truck so I stopped,'' remarked a tall man, one of the few males in the line. ''All of us Poles have been turned into hunters. I spend my life in lines now - sometimes eight hours a day. You know, today is supposed to be a holiday for me.'' **********The air of expectancy collapsed when a box of chickens was dumped onto the empty display case. Chicken supplied to Poland's state stores, the housewives remarked, is usually of low quality. Buy Whatever Is Available **********Even so, no one quit the line. The rule is to buy whatever is available, even if the shopper doesn't need it. It can always be exchanged for something else. The tall man, who said he was an economist, chatted as the line inched forward. As it was, he said, he could not find enough meat to fill his monthly ration for his pregnant wife, his 11-year-old son and himself. **********''This new ration is going to be impossible,'' he added. ''But the worst thing is not the ration. When you stand in line like this you expect to get something at the end. But. ...'' He made a despairing wave toward the chickens. **********Warming to larger themes, the man explained that since the special Communist Party congress this month, Poles had a new confidence in the Government and hoped the food situation might improve. **********By the time the man neared the head of the line, a half hour had passed. A woman said brightly: ''It's the first time they've brought chicken in a month. Maybe it will be good chicken.'' **********A look of panic suddenly seized the man. He fumbled with his ration tickets, and looked as if he might weep.  ''I've brought the wrong ration tickets,'' he said numbly, shaking his head, and left the barren store.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/02/world.main_headline: IN SOVIET, MAY DAY REMAINS FESTIVE HOLIDAY BUT THE SPONTANEITY IS GONE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/02/world.print_headline: IN SOVIET, MAY DAY REMAINS FESTIVE HOLIDAY BUT THE SPONTANEITY IS GONE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/02/world.body_text: **********Leonid I. Brezhnev and his colleagues in the Communist Party leadership, sporting red ribbons on their heavy overcoats, mounted the Lenin Mausoleum just before the Kremlin chimes began to ring. At the stroke of 10 o'clock, a recorded voice boomed out across Red Square: **********''Hail the First of May - the Day of International Solidarity of Workers in the struggle against imperialism, for peace, democracy and socialism!'' **********Thus began the Communist rite of spring in the Soviet capital, a demonstration as carefully orchestrated and controlled as the Chicago event it commemorates was chaotic and unforeseen. **********Ninety-five years ago, a strike by workers in Chicago demanding an eight-hour workday led to the Haymarket Square bombing and a battle between workers and policemen. Three years later, the Second International proclaimed May Day as International Workers' Day. **********Since then, May Day has become a primary holiday in every Communist-ruled country. In the Soviet Union it has evolved into a national festivity second only to the Nov. 7 celebration of the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. Flags, Bouquets and Balloons **********And so today on Red Square, in cool weather under a clear sky, thousands of young athletes in flawless ranks cheered and waved red flags in unison. Girls with large bows in their hair trotted up the mausoleum steps to hand bouquets to the Soviet leaders. Balloons soared. **********Then hundreds of thousands of workers, ranked by regions, streamed in from assembly points throughout the city and flowed briskly across the vast square, moving between crowd-control lines under a red sea of paper flowers, banners, floats, slogans and portraits of Communist leaders - past and present. **********Loudspeakers around the square alternated between patriotic songs and May Day slogans intoned in the melodramatic, excited cadences that have become customary on such occasions. The Spontaneity Is Gone **********May Day, like so many official Soviet holidays and public events, has become increasingly standardized and ritualized in postwar years. In a reflection of a society whose rulers firmly adhere to the policy that all power and direction must come from the center, most manifestations of spontaneity have been carefully deleted from mass celebrations. **********Access to Red Square was by printed invitation only, and the center of the city was sealed off to traffic. Cordons of policemen and security officials checked documents on all streets to the center. **********Along the marchers' routes and in Red Square, organizers with walkie-talkies kept the demonstrators moving in brisk and orderly fashion. For anyone lacking proper accreditation, the only recourse was to watch the marchers assemble outside the center or to stay home and watch the parade on television. **********It was not always so. Older Muscovites nostalgically recall May Day 1946, after the German invaders had been repelled and defeated, when Muscovites flooded freely across Red Square for more than seven hours. Shifting Fates of Leaders **********The Red Square parades have also lost most of their excitement for Kremlinologists since the days when Western observers tried to assess the shifting fates of Soviet leaders by their varying positions atop the mausoleum. **********Today, the fact that Mr. Brezhnev, the party's General Secretary, stood between Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov and Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov was of little consequence. **********Western reporters shifted their attention to the diplomatic stand next to the Lenin Mausoleum to determine which Western ambassadors would adhere to the boycott of Red Square parades started last year after the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. Ten heads of embassy stayed away, including the United States charge d'affaires, Jack F.  Matlock Jr. Last year, 16 stayed away. **********There was also the annual attention to placards carried by demonstrators for clues to political emphasis. Among those noted were placards proclaiming ''No to the Aggressive Nuclear Strategy of the United States!'' and ''No to Medium-Range Nuclear Missiles in Europe!'' **********To most of those chosen to march in the parade it all seemed to be great fun. As they flowed from the distant assembly areas to merge into one river in Red Square, many sang, linked arms and waved cheerily to passers-by. ---- In Cuba, Anti-U.S. Placards **********HAVANA, May 1 (UPI) - Red flags vied with anti-American placards today as hundreds of thousands of Cubans paraded past President Fidel Castro in a May Day celebration. ---- Chinese Stress National Unity **********PEKING, May 1 (AP) - China's leaders today appeared together at a May Day celebration in an apparent effort to show that the nation had solved its most divisive problems and to deny reports of a power struggle in the hierarchy. ---- West Germans Jeer Schmidt **********BONN, May 1 (Reuters) - Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, trying to cope with recession and growing unemployment, was shouted down by demonstrators at a May Day rally in Duisberg.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Lawyer New Lukens Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/17/busin.body_text: **********Frederick M. Myers, 58, a partner in the Pittsfield, Mass., law firm of Cain, Hibbard & Myers, has been elected chairman of the Lukens Steel Company. Lukens, with headquarters in Coatesville, Pa., - 1 hour 15 minutes by corporate jet to Pittsfield - is an old-line corporation that specializes in plate steels. **********Mr. Myers's election follows the retirement of Charles A. Carlson Jr., 62, as chairman and chief executive officer after 42 years with the company. William R. Wilson, the 53-year-old president and former Inland Steel Company official, was appointed to the additional post of chief executive officer. **********''I will be the liaison dealing with the board,'' said Mr. Myers, who has been a Lukens director since 1957. Formerly associated with Cravath Swaine & Moore and then with another Pittsfield law firm, he first joined the Lukens board of directors because of a friendship with a member of the company's founding Huston family. **********''In the next six to 12 months, I think we will have a difficult time,'' Mr. Myers said. ''There has been a slowdown, particularly in the capital goods market, and Lukens is heavily dependent on the capital goods market. But demand is going to be expanding, clearly for defense-related items, and as business demand picks up, demand for steel plate tends to pick up,'' he added. **********Mr. Myers called his new job ''a mid-age change of life.'' He added: ''I've enjoyed the law and think it's exciting, but I think there are other areas to work in and this is one of them.'' Leonard Sloane

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/28/world.main_headline: SIBERIA A REFUGEE OF TRAMPS, TRADERS AND TALL TALES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/28/world.print_headline: SIBERIA A REFUGEE OF TRAMPS, TRADERS AND TALL TALES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/28/world.body_text: **********This was once the Klondike of Siberia, a boom town built on gold, fur and trade with Asia, with gambling and boozing to match. **********Waves of cultivated exiles, including thousands of Polish nationalists and some of the Decembrists, aristocrats who bungled a coup in 1825, once gave the city a touch of culture and breeding, and even today Irkutsk takes pride in having one of the few organs in Siberia. **********The city is now an attractive administrative center of about half a million residents, several institutions of higher education, an assortment of industries and a lovely park along the banks of the Angara River. **********But a touch of the ''Wild East'' still lingers. A frequent sight at the airports and railroad stations here, like elsewhere in Siberia, are the tramps known as bichi. The name derives from ''beachcomber,'' but the popular explanation is that it comes from the Russian initials for ''former intelligent person.'' **********'Nobody Asks Where You're From' **********Valentin Rasputin, the popular Siberian writer, described bichi as heavy drinkers, vagabonds who fled from the law, from grief, from alimony, or in search of freedom. ''People always ran here seeking freedom and escape,'' he said. ''In the taiga, nobody asks where you're from.'' **********The taiga is that great stretch of forest and swamp across the Eurasian continent, that despite the rapid advance of civilization remains a wilderness where only two years ago newspapers reported that geologists stumbled across a tattered family of Old Believers - sectarians persecuted at every stage of Russian history - whose progenitor had fled into the bush during the civil war. The aged patriarch, his two ragged sons and two daughters had subsisted on the fruits of the forest and what they could scratch from the soil for more than 50 years. **********A touch of the past died in Irkutsk on Nov. 29, when the authorities ordered the legendary barakholka, or clothing flea market, shut. ''We closed it because it fired speculative passions,'' the deputy chief of the regional Communist Party organization, Leonid G. Pinko, said. **********On the last day, only about 50 peddlers remained in the acre of outdoor stalls on the outskirts of Irkutsk. But their wares suggested what Mr. Pinko meant: here were precious furs, including sable marked with Government stamps, thick homemade fur boots, imported shoes and sweaters, salves, jewelry and every variety of clothing, homemade or state-supplied, despite a well-worn board warning that only used clothing could be sold. A Lithuanian Woman's Diatribe **********An old Lithuanian woman, asked why the place was being dismantled, broke into a distinctly subversive stream of invective. ''Just ask yourself who benefits from this,'' she said. ''They want only the Government to get all the sales. Back in Lithuania when I was growing up it was all private shops and you could buy anything you want. Now you even have to sell the berries and nuts you gather to the Government.'' **********Rationing, known as the coupon system, went into effect in Irkutsk and some other Siberian cities in May after years of deteriorating supplies. Coupons issued by the housing authorities entitle each resident to 2.2 pounds of meat and two-third of a pound of butter each month. **********The system caused some grumbling at first. But it also simplified life for working people who could never get to the store until late in the day, by which time old women had stripped the stores bare. **********In food shops along Karl Marx Street, the main avenue, the food and butter counters were the only ones without lines, and the products lay repackaged in the authorized amounts. In restaurants and cafes, meat seemed plentiful and unrationed. A Contrast With Moscow **********The scene contrasted with that in shops in Moscow, where the arrival of meat or butter spawns instant lines. The contrast extended to the official approach to the problem - in Moscow, officials rarely acknowledge any shortages, no matter how obvious.  Here, Mr. Pinko met the problem head-on: ''Yes, we're on a coupon system because we don't produce enough meat and milk. Local farms supply only 60 percent of the meat we need, and 80 percent of our milk, and we don't get enough from outside.'' **********Such candor is frequently encountered across Siberia, and Mr. Pinko said it remained an integral component of the Siberian character.  ''European traits are slow in reaching us,'' he said, showing obvious distaste for whatever weaknesses he found in his Western cousins. His own grandfather, Mr. Pinko said, was a political exile under the czars, and a true Sibiryak was a man unafraid of hardships, persistent, taciturn and honest. **********Siberia is a big land, and tales told here are correspondingly tall. There's the hunter who developed appendicitis and operated on himself, using deer gut for sutures. Or the builders of the Bratsk dam whose heads froze to their pillows at night and whose eyes bled from mosquito attacks. Or the year that berries grew badly and bears turned to eating meat, devouring 15 or 20 people in the process. **********The latter tale was told by no ordinary hunter - Nikolai S.  Sveridov has been an instructor in the lore of the hunt for almost 30 years at Irkutsk's Institute of Game Management, combining work with the pleasure of expeditions for deer, moose or bear. Repositories of Legend **********Though properly collectivized and duly assigned five-year plans by the Soviet authorities, hunting and trapping remain staunch repositories of the romance and legend of siberia. It doesn't take much to get the Sibiryak to talk about his dog, his game and the lure of the taiga. **********The serious hunting these days - for sable and other fur-bearing beasts - is left to professionals who spend weeks tracking and trapping the precious predators. But there's hardly a bureaucrat in Irkutsk who in early winter can resist donning his heavy fur boots, collecting his ax, kettle, skis, gun and dog, and heading into the taiga. **********The ax is the main tool, Mr. Sveridov said. Only that and dry matches will get you through a Siberian night in the open. He recalled one time when he spent a week in the bush. The main thing is to leave enough time to build a nodya, a Siberian bonfire made by putting one log atop another in such a way that the crack between smolders all night. The hunter sleeps beside it - ''only if it's cold, like today, you sleep a little less,'' said Mr. Sveridov. It was 25 degrees below zero outside. **********The hunters turn in their pelts at regional collecting depots, and from there they come to the Irkutsk fur center, the biggest of seven such warehouses in the Soviet Union. **********Siberia's premier pelt is, of course, the sable, whose fur ringed the medieval crown of Muscovite grand princes, and whose pelts were carried by early Russian ambassadors to Europe instead of money and gifts. About 120,000 pelts are processed a year, most headed for the West in exchange for hard currency. But rare is the hunter who turns in all the precious pelts, and those withheld from the state turn up on Irkutsk women's heads, giving the city's streets a touch of class beyond its visible means.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/27/busin.body_text: **********When Lawrence Kamm, founder and president of the Mobot Corporation, sets out to sell his industrial robots, he is likely bring up the legend of Pygmalion. **********The Greek mythological tale of the king of Cyprus, who sculpted a statue of a woman and then pleaded with the goddess Aphrodite to bring it to life, embodies the age-old desire to create artificial humans. As Mr. Kamm sees it, that desire has influenced the thinking of industrial robot designers and users alike, with the result that industrialists are investing heavily in unnecessarily complicated and expensive robots. **********''Management has been snowed,'' he said. ''Companies like Unimation and Cincinnati Milacron have mistakenly tried to emulate the human arm,'' he added, referring to the two leading manufacturers in the rapidly expanding industry, which last year topped $100 million in sales. **********Mr. Kamm said that such ''arms,'' which typically are tubespangled, multi-jointed appendages that twist about on a solid base, are not needed to fulfill the tasks robots are assigned, from materials handling to welding and painting. Those jobs can be done more accurately and inexpensively by combining small devices that move in straight or circular motions, and placing them on metal mounts that run over the work station, he said. **********He likened the approach to building an erector set. Mobot describes these amalgamations as ''modular robots.'' In addition to being less expensive to start with, they also are easier for workers to understand and straightforward enough for the user's own engineers to perform most maintenance, he said. **********Although the robot business has been flooded with new entrants in recent months, Fibro Gmbh., a West German firm, is the only competitor that builds a wide variety of units out of standard modules, according to Mr. Kamm. But the Versatran line of Prab Conveyors Inc., the third largest American robot producer, also relies on motion modules to a lesser extent and RCA has reported that a picture tube plant in Finland was built around a modular robot line designed by Rosenlew Tool Works, a Finnish company. **********The key difference between modular robots and the standard robots marketed by the companies currently dominating the industry is that the latter are intended to be multi-functional. A painting robot, for example, is made so that it can be converted into a welder. **********''That's a total waste,'' Mr. Kamm asserted. ''Robot purchasers buy a unit on its ability to economically perform a given task. They never switch it and, in fact, it is complicated and expensive to do so.'' **********Analysts who follow the robot industry regard Mobot's approach politely but skeptically. They say that versatility is important for machines that may someday be integrated into fully-automated, computer-controlled manufacturing. And they point out that Mobot units have yet to prove themselves on complicated tasks. **********''So far, all they have really done is pick-and-place machines,'' said Jean Fine, an analyst at Gruntal & Company, referring to devices that move materials on and off assembly lines or in and out of other machines. **********Pick-and-place machines cannot paint, weld, or otherwise process pieces. Many experts do not think of such devices as robots.''We don't have the capital yet to offer the special electronics needed to control processing jobs,'' Mr. Kamm conceded. But, he said, there is no technical barrier to equipping modular robots with electronic controls that allow them to compete favorably with the''anthropomorphic'' robots that do such work. One Mobot customer has made a Mobot-built skeleton into a robot painter, he said. **********Mobot's desire to develop its own electronic controls for its modular robots is one reason the company is planning a second stock sale this autumn, just a year after it changed its name from Modular Machine Company and first went public. However, the first priority for the $4 million to $5 million Mobot hopes to raise with the sale is expansion of its marketing efforts. **********Marketing, especially sales support, has been crucial to the success of the leading robot companies. ''One big difference between a company like Unimation and someone like Mobot is that Unimation can provide you with all kinds of consulting services and mock-ups,'' said a robotics expert on the technical staff of one of the nation's largest consumer products manufacturers. ''If you wind up investing a lot of your own staff and engineering time, a modular robot might be no bargain.'' **********Robots cost anywhere from $5,000 to hundreds of thousands of dollars. Although Mr. Kamm says that Mobot's machines, which can rest on a tabletop or be more than 30 feet long, perform the work of competing robots that cost one-third more, sales have not come easily. **********Sales rose to more than $909,000 for the year ending March 31, 1981, compared to $251,000 for the year earlier. But the growth rate slowed considerably during the first quarter of the current fiscal year, when sales totaled $255,000, compared to $206,000 in the yearearlier quarter. **********The company's efforts to rapidly expand its production capability and marketing efforts have also hurt the bottom line. Neither Mobot or its predecessor, founded by Mr. Kamm in 1973, has ever recorded a profit for the year. Losses in the last fiscal year were almost $168,000. And losses in the recently completed quarter were $169,000. **********Robotics experts at such consulting firms as Booz-Allen & Hamilton, Inc., and stock analysts doubt that modular robots will supplant the more sophisticated models marketed by the leading companies. They also dismiss Mr. Kamm's assertion that experienced machine tool makers like Cincinnati Milacron are suffering from a Pygmalion complex. But that does not mean they are discounting Mobot's prospects of finding a profitable niche in the materials handling end of the robot business. **********''The Japanese have proven that there is a market for less sophisticated robots,'' said Eli Lustgarten, an analyst at Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins, referring to widespread use in Japan of pick-and-place devices. 'In an industry that's evolving, there's room for a variety of concepts and several levels of sophistication.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/29/world.main_headline: West Germany Implicates 2 In Attack on U.S. Commander
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/29/world.print_headline: West Germany Implicates 2 In Attack on U.S. Commander
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/29/world.body_text: **********The police have found fingerprints of two of West Germany's most wanted terrorist suspects during investigations into a grenade and gun attack on the commander of the United States Army in Europe, the federal prosecutor's office said today. **********A spokesman said forensic tests also showed that a submachine gun fired in the attack was one of the weapons used to kill the driver and three bodyguards of Hanns-Martin Schleyer, a leading industrialist abducted four years ago and later murdered. **********The two suspects were identified as Christian Klar, 29 years old, and Brigitte Mohnhaupt, 32, both of whom are thought to be among the approximately 20 hard-core members of the extremist Red Army Faction who are at large. **********The left-wing group claimed responsibility for the Sept. 15 attempt on the life of Gen. Frederick J. Kroesen, who escaped with minor injuries. **********The man's fingerprints were also found in the investigation of the bomb that exploded Aug. 31 at the United States Air Base at Ramstein.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/27/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Jones of G.E.; How to Improve Management
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/27/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Jones of G.E.; How to Improve Management
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/27/busin.body_text: **********American management is undergoing a period of critical scrutiny within the board rooms and the classrooms.  Its indictment contains the following elements: managers are obsessed with short-term profits, ignoring long-range investments; the entrepreneurial spirit seems scarce among executives; top positions are often filled with financial types, who have little hands-on experience with the businesses they oversee; managers have not focused enough on overseas markets, and business schools are a seedbed for these deficiencies. **********The General Electric Company is often held up as an example of a corporation that has avoided these shortcomings. Its chairman, Reginald H. Jones, 63 years old, will retire on April 1, in keeping with the tradition at G.E. of making way for the next generation.  Recently Mr. Jones was questioned about the state of the art of management in America. **********Q. Is the indictment against American management justified? A. I think that in many cases it is. It is something that should be taken very seriously. **********Q. People say corporations are less entrepreneurial than in the past. Do you agree? A. There's an element of truth in that. But the ability to take risk is partly a function of expected returns.  Today, the real return on investment for industry is about 3 percent, which makes it very difficult to take the risks of our forebears. **********Q. Aren't corporate managers largely responsible for the poor performance - paying now for their failure to make longer-term investments? A. Unquestionably there's some of that. But you've got to bear in mind that during the 1960's and 1970's, the corporation had much wider responsibilites forced upon it. Beyond economic requirements, costly social and environmental demands have been placed on corporations. At the same time international competition has increased tremendously. **********Q. What evidence is there that managers are overly concerned with short-term profitability? A. I think that the most damning thing is that nearly two-thirds of the inventory of U.S. industry is still accounted for on a FIFO (first-in, first out) basis, which increases both reported earnings and tax payments. The reason for that is the unwillingness of management to face up to the lower reported earnings that would result under LIFO (last-in, first-out) - perhaps because most top executive contracts are tied to reported earnings.  For G.E., the net effect of LIFO is roughly $1 billion that is not taxed and can be used for internal investment. **********Q. American management has been called too parochial. Does that appears to be changing? A. Yes. And Washington seems to have finally recognized the need for more international trade. There hasn't been a piece of legislation in the past 20 months that has been a disincentive to exports. That certainly was not the case in the previous 17 years. **********Q. Doesn't the increasingly global nature of business force managements to take a longer-term perspective? It seems the consensus that we've entered an era of protracted battles for survival in global markets. Strategic planning was supposed to provide the blueprint for that competition. Yet many companies give it lipservice for a few days and then forget it in the heat of day-to-day problems. A. More and more, strategic planning is no longer just a buzz phrase or paperwork exercise. At G.E., we entered the 1970's getting 80 percent of our earnings from electrical equipment. By 1979, that was down to 47 percent. If you take this longer-term strategic approach, it will get you more capital investment, increased productivity and take you out of dying industries and into ones that are growing. **********Q. Business schools have been the target of a good deal of criticism lately. Is it warranted? A. I think the top business schools do a good job. But they could do better at teaching communication skills. And if the schools could concentrate on a little instruction in humility it would be helpful. You just don't come fresh out of business school ready to run a large corporation. Steve Lohr

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/30/world.main_headline: MARSHALL ISLANDERS PRESS CLAIMS AGAINST U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/30/world.print_headline: MARSHALL ISLANDERS PRESS CLAIMS AGAINST U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/30/world.body_text: **********Marshallese families have begun repossessing islets in the Kwajalein Atoll, which they had relinquished for American missile tests, in a move foreshadowing a confrontation with the United States over claims for millions of dollars. **********According to Imada Kabua, president of the Kwajalein Atoll Corporation, an organization representing the landown@ers, the move back to the islands is a protest against a delay by the Marshalese authorities in the payment, due last month, of $2.4 million received from the United States for distribution to the displaced islanders. **********Mr. Kabua, who has extensive land rights in Kwajalein as a highranking traditional chief, is in Honolulu to consult legal counsel in connection with larger claims that go back to 1944. **********Under an agreement between the Marshall Islands and the United States in 1979, the islanders have received slightly over $6 million a year for lands taken over by the United States for the missiletesting program. That operation involved missiles fired from Vandenburg Air Force Base in California, some 5,000 miles to the east, which are then shot down by other missiles fired from a billion-dollar installation on Kwajalein, the main island in the atoll. **********Earlier Arrangement Superseded **********The 1979 agreement superseded a 1964 arrangement under which the Marshallese received from the United States Government a one-time payment of $750,000, or $1,000 an acre, for rights to use the land for 100 years dating from 1944. In that year, American forces seized Kwajalein from the Japanese in an amphibious attack. **********The 1979 agreement expires at the end of next month. The Kwajalein Atoll Corporation notified the Marshallese authorities in June that its members would refuse to permit use of their land by the United States after Sept. 30 unless they received satisfactory assurances of ''full and fair compensation'' for such use between 1944 and 1979. **********In principle, Mr. Kabua said, the landowners want to extend the terms of the 1979 agreement backward to 1944, a formula that would cost the United States $177 million if accepted by Congress, which would have to appropriate the money. However, there are indications that the islanders might scale down their demands sharply in actual negotiations. **********Meanwhile, American attorneys for the Kwajalein landowners, who number about 5,500, have a suit pending in the High Court of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands, which includes the Marshalls, seeking to nullify all agreements made between the United States and the Kwajalein people before the 1979 arrangement to pay $6 million annually. Islands Self-Governing Since '79 **********The Marshall Islands and several other groups in the trust territory became self-governing in internal affairs in 1979. The islands, known collectively as Micronesia, were taken from Japan by United States forces as a result of World War II. They were made a United Nations trusteeship, with the United States as the administering power, in 1947. **********The Reagan Administration is reviewing a series of tentative agreements with the Marshalls, the Palau group and a new entity called the Federated States of Micronesia, comprising Yap, Truk, Ponape and Kosrae, that would make these entities independent states upon termination of the trusteeship, with the proviso that the United States retain military rights in the area. A fourth chain, the Northern Mariana Islands, has voted to become a commonwealth of the United States. **********The reoccupation of the Kwajalein islands that had been surrendered for the missile project was prompted, Mr. Kabua said, by the needs of numerous families that plan to send younger members to Hawaii to resume their schooling in coming weeks. **********Prompt payment of the $2.4 million now due to the displaced islanders would no doubt end the present protest campaign, Mr. Kabua said, but not the campaign for compensation for the use of the lands from 1944 to 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/07/busin.body_text: **********Fiat, Italy's largest private employer, announced it would lay off 70,000 workers for one to two weeks in October because of declining auto exports. **********The decision, announced Friday, had been expected. But it was feared that the layoffs could trigger severe social tensions in this northern city, which has been a center of terrorist activities. Fiat employs about 120,000. **********The state-owned Alfa Romeo, which ranks second, and Nuova Innocenti, which makes small cars, also are expected to decide on temporary layoffs before the end of the year because of falling demand domestically and abroad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/11/busin.main_headline: A Lawyer Is Appointed To Key Piedmont Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/11/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A Lawyer Is Appointed To Key Piedmont Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/11/busin.body_text: **********William R. Howard, a 58-year-old lawyer who learned to fly at age 16, has been named president and chief operating officer of Piedmont Aviation Inc., a regional airline based in Winston-Salem, N.C. He succeeds Thomas H. Davis, the carrier's 63-year-old chairman, who continues as chief executive officer. **********''We have been working very hard in succeeding under deregulation,'' said Mr. Howard in a telephone interview.'' **********Certainly the industry is in the doldrums, but we've had the reverse results.'' **********Mr. Howard, who was an Army Air Force pilot during World War II, said that he had decided early to combine his interest in law and aviation. **********He was associated for 12 years with the Atlanta law firm of Gambrell, Russell & Forbes, where he worked on the Eastern Airlines account. Mr. Howard joined the client in 1967 as a staff vice president and was a senior vice president when he left for Piedmont three years ago. For the last year he has been executive vice president-marketing and customer services. **********Mr. Davis joined the Camel City Flying Service, the predecessor company to Piedmont and then a distributor of small aircraft, in 1939 with a $14,000 investment. He was appointed vice president and treasurer in 1940 and president three years later. **********''We have looked very carefully at routes where we could see a genuine need for additional air transportation,'' Mr. Howard said.  ''And we've been setting up complexes where our short-haul flights feed our long-haul flights.'' **********As for his own background in aviation, Mr. Howard observed: ''When I was a kid, I was fascinated by the local airport in west Nebraska.  I wanted to fly and my dad bought me an airplane for $999 - brand new.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/24/busin.body_text: **********The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company, yesterday announced a nationwide 2-cent-a-gallon increase in wholesale gasoline prices. **********The Exxon Corporation, the nation's largest oil company, said it had raised wholesale prices for gasoline a cent a gallon in the Far West, and industry sources said the Standard Oil Company of California, No. 4 in the industry, was likely to announce a gasoline-price increase today. **********Socal, which increased wholesale gasoline prices 1 to 2 cents a gallon last week, would not comment on its intentions. On Wednesday, Texaco, No. 3, increased wholesale prices for gasoline 1 to 2.5 cents and those for gasohol nine-tenths of a cent to 2.25 cents a gallon in many areas. **********Wholesale price increases may be passed on to consumers. Exxon, which attributed its move to rising crude oil prices, said its wholesale increase had averaged 4 cents a gallon since Jan. 1. **********The average price of crude oil from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has risen 10 percent since early December. In the United States, the gradual lifting of Federal crude oil price controls is raising refiners' oil costs 1.5 cents a gallon each month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/busin.body_text: **********About 35 men in blue and gray business suits convened here last week in a spartan room at the United States Naval Research Center to gather the technical information about a new Coast Guard procurement program. **********They came from aerospace subsidiaries of companies like Goodyear and Westinghouse Electric, from the aerospace subsystems divisions of leading military contractors like Grumman and Northrup and from a slew of smaller concerns with expertise in the particular problem at hand. That problem, all but ignored for several decades, is how to build a blimp. **********The goal of the meeting was to make sure that all potential prime contractors for the Coast Guard program, which is to design a blimp with wide-ranging patrol, surveillance and rescue capabilities and then build and test a scaled-down model by 1985, have the information they need to get their bids in by Nov. 17. **********Already the blimps have bureaucratic abbreviations comprehensible only to the initiated - MPA (Maritime Patrol Airship for the fullscale system) and PAD (Patrol Airship Demonstrator for the scaleddown version, which will be almost the size of the blimps Goodyear uses for publicity). **********The Coast Guard's project is one of the most tangible indications yet that descendants of the huge, energy-efficient airships of yesteryear may indeed take to the skies by 1990. This year the service is spending only $1 million on the notion, but that amount will rise dramatically as the project progresses. Earlier reports have estimated that the service will have to pay $25 million to $46 million a blimp. **********The Navy, which is administering the Coast Guard project, is also spending millions, along with the Department of Transportation and the United States Forest Service, on another project that will study the feasibility of joining helicopters to a blimp so that timber, and presumably other heavy loads, can be transported to and from wilderness areas. **********The Piasecki Aircraft Corporation, a Philadelphia-based specialty helicopter firm, has a $10.7 million contract to deliver by next May a demonstrator model built largely with Navy-furnished materials. **********And in Britain, Airship Industries is reported to have tentative orders for a new blimp, the first model of which flew briefly last year before being destroyed on the ground during an unexpected storm. **********''The people who attend the technical conferences are not the 'flakes' any more,'' said Dale Williams, chairman of the technical committee on lighter-than-air craft of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics. **********An airship renaissance has been predicted by a devout band of lighter-than-air vessel supporters ever since the Navy phased out its last airships in 1962. At least pa rt of the reason for the airship's exile wa s a series of spectacular accidents during the 1930's in which famous dirigiblessuch as the Hindenburg and the Akron were lost. These airs hips had rigid metal skeletons and were many times larger than toda y's blimps,but their demise left a lasting - and experts say unfair - impressionon the public that airships were unusually hazardous. Toda y, Goodyear's fleet of four blimps and a similar ship in West Germany make up the world's airship population. **********Mindful of this, comments here about the significance of the Coast Guard's program were cautious. ''This is a good sign,'' said one of the four Goodyear executives attending the meeting, ''but it is still too soon to announce the rebirth. It is not clear anyone can make money producing them.'' Privately, officials at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and other companies that have maintained an interest in blimps are more confident that the forces pointing toward a comeback are strengthening. Need for Wider Surveillance **********In the Coast Guard's case, vastly expanded surveillance and rescue requirements have resulted from the expansion of the nation's fishing boundary to 200 miles, increased concern with problems such as drug smuggling and offshore oil development from Alaska to the Atlantic. **********Airships can cruise for days on end, move at low speeds, hover near the water and in general operate in a wide range of weather with small crews and low energy consumption. **********In assessing the market for coastal patrol airships, executives that the Navy used 150 of them during World War II and that nations around the world are claiming expanded coastal jurisdictions. An even larger market may exist for the airships linked to helicopters, known as hybrid vertical lift systems. Mating Blimp and Helicopter **********Scheduled for completion next year, the Piasecki hybrid blimp is a million cubic feet, nearly five times the volume of the Goodyear blimps, and will be attached to four helicopters. The Heli-Stat, as the craft has been dubbed, is over five stories tall and more than six times as long. **********A study for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in 1976 forsaw a long-range market of 1,000 vertical lift airships in logging alone. **********Foreign interest extends well beyond Canada. Indeed, analysts of the Coast Guard project say that Goodyear, the acknowledged favorite for the prime contractor's job, faces its stiffest competition from Britain's Airship Industries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/world.body_text: **********By demolishing much of the Chanel couturier shop here with a bomb yesterday, separatists from Guadeloupe served notice that they would no longer be ignored. **********Just a week ago today, President Valery Giscard d'Estaing arrived at Guadeloupe's airport to fly back to Paris from a six-day holiday in the sun. Driving his own car - it was, he kept saying, a private trip - he studiously ignored the shattered passenger terminal where, the day before, separatists had exploded a 12-pound time bomb in a baggage locker. **********The bombing was the 15th case of violence in Guadeloupe, an overseas department, or state, of France, in nine months, all claimed by a group calling itself the Guadeloupe Liberation Army. On the eve of the President's arrival, another bomb destroyed a studio of the Government-owned television system and, two days after his departure, a prominent island businessman narrowly escaped injury when his car was fired upon by a hidden rifleman. Last Sept. 17, a policeman was killed removing a bomb from the wing of an Air France Boeing 727, also at the airport. The plane was destroyed. **********Campaign Began in March **********The campaign of violence began in March when a wealthy businessman and the only white member of the City Council of Pointe-a-Pitre, Guadeloupe's largest city, was wounded by unseen gunmen. The separatist group claimed responsibility and said it was opening a ''campaign of harassment'' against ''French colonialism'' and warned all French living on the seven islands in the Caribbean to ''pack their bags and leave before Dec. 31, 1980.'' About 30,000 of Guadeloupe's 385,000 people are white, 12,000 of them born there and the rest born in mainland France or in Algeria. **********On Dec. 10 an anonymous letter to Le Monde in Paris warned that President Giscard d'Estaing should abandon his proposed vacation because ''we will consider it a provocation and an act of bravado. **********''Moreover,'' the letter said, ''we assume sole and complete responsibility for whatever the consequences may be. The Vietnamese killed French colonialism, the Algerians dug its grave and the Guadeloupians will bury it.'' **********The unrest on Guadeloupe is particularly annoying to the French because they have long prided themselves on the attention they have paid to their three Caribbean departments, Guadeloupe, Martinique and French Guiana. The French say that these possessions, along with Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean, are not colonies but departments, which means they are as much a part of France as Normandy or the Cote d'Azur. To the French, the relationship is the same as that between Hawaii or Alaska and the rest of the United States. **********As such, they are eligible for all French social services: medical and unemployment benefits and pensions. The standard of living there is 5 to 20 times what it is on neighboring islands, most of which have gained their independence from Britain since World War II. The French Contribution **********Ten years ago, a visitor to Guadeloupe drove from the airport to the center of Pointe-a-Pitre through one of the Caribbean's largest and foulest slums. Today, long before the plane touches down, the visitor sees the high-rise, low-income apartments provided by Paris, which have replaced all but a few of the thousands of tin shacks. **********The French authorities do not know who belongs to the terrorist group. A moderate separatist group, the Union for the Liberation of Guadeloupe, denies any connection with it. Local elections on Guadeloupe have indicated that the majority of voters oppose independence. **********The political unrest that swept through the Caribbean in the 1960's and 70's came late to the French islands, mostly because of their higher standard of living and because, according to French officials, free access to the French mainland siphoned off social and poltical pressures. As many as 50,000 young people from Guadeloupe and Martinique went to France each year and found jobs. No longer. Like the equally angry Corsicans, who used to find jobs in the army and civil service, young people in the French Antilles see little future at home or in France. Unemployment on Guadeloupe among working-age people is about 40 percent. **********Despite the problems of Guadeloupe's black population and the fears of the whites, the French Government is continuing an ambitious development program that is to include an irrigation program, a program to develop hydroelectric and solar energy and the modernization of the island's sugar industry. Another venture will try to revitalize the island's fishing and farming industries.  Guadeloupians, whose waters teem with fish, according to the French Government, and whose growing conditions are ideal, import most of their vegetables and leave their commercial fishing to the Japanese.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/02/world.print_headline: KANIA'S ROLE BUTRESSED BY POLISH PARTY ELECTIONS; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/02/world.body_text: **********With the election of all 1,967 delegates to attend a special Communist Party congress in two weeks, Stanislaw Kania, the party's leader, has strengthened his position, increasing a likelihood that the gathering will reaffirm his policies of moderate change. The election process ended Monday night at a local party conference in Warsaw. Although the majority of the delegates are new and their political leanings are not totally clear, a number of known conservatives and more radical reformers were eliminated. **********The middle ground - Mr. Kania's political area - seems to have emerged triumphant. This is the message read by both Polish and Western analysts as they pore over the results of scores of party conferences in the provinces and thousands of earlier elections in the basic cells. **********Significantly, despite the pressures for change from the party's rank and file, most of the party's top leadership was elected as delegates to the congress, which begins July 14. This, too, was seen as something of a victory for Mr. Kania, since he had appealed to party members to allow the leadership to attend the congress intact so its members could be judged by the full party assembly. 'Passive Election Right' **********For the leaders to be elected, they had to employ what is called the ''passive election right'' - entering their candidacies at the provincial party conference level in ''safe'' constituencies instead of undergoing elimination elections in smaller party organizations. **********This device, used liberally in the past to insure control over congresses, touched off opposition in some regions this year.  Three cities - Torun, Slupsk and Lublin - refused to accept the ''central'' delegates as candidates. In other cities - such as Katowice, Poznan and Byd-goszcz - the ''central'' candidates were allowed to run but some of them were defeated. In all, about 55 such delegates were approved, in contrast with several hundred in earlier elections. **********Among those attending the congress will be three leading hardliners on the 11-member Politburo, Stefan Olszowski, chosen at the Warsaw conference; Tadeusz Grabski, representing Konin, and Andrzej Zabinski, from Katowice. Mr. Olszowski narrowly squeezed through, getting 246 votes out of the 429 cast. **********But a number of other party officials went down to defeat, under new and more liberal election rules that provide for secret ballots and more candidates than positions. **********Two Politburo members who were not elected were Gerard Gabrys, a former coal miner, and Zygmunt Wronski, a former worker at the Ursus Tractor Plant in Warsaw. Both were elevated to the Politburo in April, in what the leadership depicted as a move to bring real workers into the leadership. **********But both were disowned by their former workmates. At Ursus, Mr.  Wronski was called a party hack who had not been an the assembly line in years. Mr. Gabrys was initially involved with the Katowice Forum, a hard-line group that won praise from Moscow but little support at home, although he later disassociated himself from the group. **********All the other Politburo members were chosen as delegates, although two candidate members, Jerzy Waszczuk and Jozef Masny, were not.  There were other casualties among the Central Committee and the Government, including Leslaw Tokarski, the committee's new head of press, radio and television; Mieczyslaw Wojtczak, head of the committee's cultural section; Mieczyslaw Glanowski, Minister of Mines, and Adam Krzysztoporski, Deputy Interior Minister. The rejection of these candidates is considered a victory for the reformers. **********Past congresses were so dominated by the party's central apparatus that they were conclaves of the faithful. This year, there will be only three ministers and three heads of sections in the Central Committee. The inablity of the others to gain admittance cast doubts on their political future. **********The business before the congress includes a revision of its statutes, approval of an overall ''program'' to deal with the country's economic and political crisis and the election of a new Central Committee, Politburo and first secretary. **********It has not yet been decided whether the first secretary will be chosen by the congress as a whole, which the reformers would like, or by the Central Committee that emerges from the congress. That decision will be made by the delegates. **********The surge in support for Mr. Kania can be traced to a letter sent on June 5 by the Soviet Communist Party that was intended to undercut him. He rode out a subsequent challenge from hard-liners at a Central Committee meeting and seemed to gain strength as a comfortable and known quantity, acceptable to all factions. **********''The psychological effect of the last Central Committee meeting was that Kania became the defender of national dignity,'' remarked a professor at the Higher School of Social Sciences run by the Central Committee. **********Mr. Kania's strength was readily seen in the provincial conferences in which he participated. He untangled a bitter procedural wrangle in Poznan, arranging a compromise by telephone, and he personally presided over the conference in Warsaw and put his prestige on the line to insure the re-election of Stanslaw Kociolek as Warsaw first secretary. **********Mr. Kociolek, whose reputation was tarnished by his suppression of workers' demonstrations in Baltic cities 11 years ago, retained office. **********As a result of all this, predictions that Mr. Kania will be swept aside as party leader at the congress are no longer being heard. It is even possible, some Polish and Western analysts theorize, that a few hard-liners will be left in place, as window dressing to assuage Moscow's fears that Poland is treading the path of revisionism. Major Changes in Committee **********Most analysts believe that the major changes will be in the Central Committee, which is still largely unchanged from precrisis time. Most predictions are that less than 25 percent of the 140 committee members will be re-elected. Such a turnover would bring an unalterable shift toward liberalism in the basic decision-making body. **********Over the next few weeks, analysts, including those in the Soviet Embassy, will undoubtedly be examining the roster of delegates to try to fathom their political inclinations. **********According to preliminary statistics from the Central Committee's Department of Organization, among the 1,873 delegates chosen up until the Warsaw conference, 20 percent are workers and 10 percent are farmers. Only 5 percent are women. The average age is 30 to 40. **********About 1,521 of the delegates belong to trade unions. Of those, a vast majority - 59 percent - are in party-dominated ''branch unions.'' Only 21 percent are members of Solidarity, the independent labor movement that emerged from disorders last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/20/busin.body_text: **********The Phibro Corporation, a leading international commodity trading concern, said yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter fell 28.1 percent, to $78.8 million, or $1.15 a share, from $109.6 million, or $1.61 a share, in the third quarter of 1980. Sales advanced 20 percent, to $6.6 billion, from $5.5 billion in the 1980 period. **********Earlier this year, the company agreed to buy Salomon Brothers, the Wall Street brokerage firm. Earnings of the new subsidiary, however, will not be included in Phibro's results until the fourth quarter.  The company was a unit of the Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation until last May. **********Phibro's earnings, like those of other traders, are tied to cyclical swings in world commodity markets, and the company said it had suffered throughout most of the year from sluggishness in those markets as well as a slowdown in the industrial sector and high interest rates. **********Analysts speculated that the decline in Phibro's earnings also reflected the worldwide surplus of oil. Trading in crude and refined petroleum products accounted for half of the company's revenue last year, although the contribution of petroleum to profits is relatively smaller because margins on oil often run as low as 1 percent. **********David Tendler, co-chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement that while commodity markets remained in a depressed state, ''net earnings for the third quarter were higher than for the first two quarters of the current year.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/03/world.main_headline: IN THE FAR SEYCHELLES, A TALE OF INTRIGUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/03/world.print_headline: IN THE FAR SEYCHELLES, A TALE OF INTRIGUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/03/world.body_text: **********For a down payment of $1,000 and a slice of the action, Aubrey Brooks, a 38-year-old father of two, and Roger England, 26 and single, came here, they say, to overthrow a President. The two would then fade away, along with 50 other mercenaries. **********They were led, according to the socialist authorities of the ''Island of Love,'' as the Seychelles calls itself, by Mike Hoare, a mercenary of renown. **********The plot was discovered at the airport soon after they arrived, and after a long gun battle 44 of the mercenaries were forced to retreat aboard a hijacked Air India plane to South Africa. Today, South Africa freed 39 of those men without charges. The other five, including Mr. Hoare, were charged with kidnapping and released on bail. (Page A9.) **********Paraded Before the Press **********Mr. Brooks, a bearded man with a pocked and battered face, and Mr.  England, a sandy-haired man whose cheeks are badly cut, were not so lucky. They stayed behind to act as a rear guard and were captured with three others. **********While their comrades tasted freedom in South Africa today, the two were brought from green-doored cells, with manacles biting their wrists, and paraded before reporters at the central police station here to confess in the dazzling humidity of a small Indian Ocean island a long way from home. **********Reporters, the first to arrive on the island since the coup attempt, were allowed to ask two questions, which the authorities insisted on approving in ad-ju vance: Who paid and hired you? What was your mission? **********The two men, dressed in sports shirts and shorts, spoke in a small courtyard of green grass outside the cells, surrounded by a 12-foot wall topped with barbed wire. Seychelles soldiers kept assault rifles trained on them. **********''I received $1,000 down payment,'' Mr. Brooks said. ''I never met the person who paid us, but I believe it was done on behalf of the ex-President.'' Here, he faltered and turned for assistance to his captors, who gave none. ''Was it Montgom? I think it was Montgom,'' he said. **********Former President James R.M. Mancham, a flamboyant right-winger and former disk jockey was overthrown four years ago and replaced by the Seychelles' present leader, President France Albert Rene. **********''I'm not sure of his name,'' Mr. Brooks said. ''My answer is the same,'' Mr. England said, shuffling slightly.  Mr. Brooks and Mr. England, according to the Seychelles authorities, were part of an advance unit of mercenaries who arrived before the other 44 touched down here in a Royal Swazi Airlines Fokker F-28 plane a week ago. **********Five of the advance men, the authorities say, have been captured, but three, including a man named Charles Dukes, who is identified as an American, are still on the run in the jungles of Mahe, the principal island among the 92 in the Seychelles archipelago. **********Mahe is 17 miles long and 5 miles wide. Its hills are steep and craggy beneath the dense jungle, and girded by narrow, serpentine roads. It lies a thousand miles from the nearest mainland. ''Those on the run have nowhere to go; they will be caught,'' a Seychelles Information Ministry official said. **********Mr. Brooks said his mission was ''to put on two tapes at the radio station once the so-called bloodless coup was over.'' He continued: ''One was to tell the people what to do. The other was to announce that the ex-President ... Montgom, I think it was Montgom ... had now taken power again.'' **********Mr. England, a Briton, said: ''It was a coup attempt. We would supposedly take power bloodlessly, and once we had taken power we would disappear and the local Government would come and run the place.'' **********Mr. Brooks, who had been wounded in the leg, volunteered the information that he was married, had two children, one 17 years old, the other 4 1/2, and was a Rhodesian who had lived in South Africa for two and a half years. Mercenaries to Be Tried **********Reporters were not allowed to ask further questions, so Mr. Brooks was not given an opportunity to say why he had risked all for $1,000 up front and the promise of altering a bit of history. An unidentified police official prevented the two mercenaries from talking to one another. Then they were led away to separate cells, their moment of celebrity fading, along with the myth, that mercenaries cultivate, of invincibility. **********At a news conference earlier, President Rene said the captive mercenaries would be tried on charges including murder because one Seychellois officer was killed in the fighting. One mercenary died, too, and his body was taken to South Africa aboard the hijacked plane. **********President Rene, a short man in a cream-colored, open-neck tropical suit, said South Africa's action in freeing the mercenaries who escaped had convinced him ''that the South African Government was involved in this attempt.'' The statement was the most forthright that Mr. Rene has made on South Africa in connection with the attempted coup. **********''We all know that South Africa is one of the countries that has been destabilizing foreign governments,'' he continued. ''We are not surprised that they have done so here.'' He acknowledged that ''one or two'' Tanzanian troops, who have been training the 1,000-m@ember Seychelles military force, were ''attached to our men at the time of the fighting.'' **********He accused former President Mancham of having ''surreptitiously'' approached both the mercenaries and the South African authorities to set up the coup attempt. Mr. Mancham said in New York on Tuesday that he recorded the message that Mr. Brooks planned to play on the Seychelles radio but said he did not know for whom he had recorded the tape and when it would be used. **********''What is obvious,'' President Rene said of the 44 mercenaries, including Mr. Hoare, ''is that this was mainly an advance party. They came to act from inside with a follow-up at some time or other. We suspect that a yacht would arrive in early December to be part of this operation.'' The coup attempt, he said, would have then coincided with a visit to France that he had planned. **********The mercenaries arrived in the guise of rugby players, attending a drinking fest in the Seychelles called the ''Ancient Order of Foam Blowers 1981 Congress.'' They carried bags with false bottoms hiding Bulgarian-made assault rifles of Soviet design, walkie-talkies and other weapons. On top of the false bottoms, they piled toy cars, toy boats, Christmas candy, badminton sets, all adorned with tags from a Johannesburg toy shop called Clicks. **********At the airport, the Seychelles authorities said, one gun muzzle poked through the toys, which were marked as gifts for disabled children, and a customs officer spotted it. In the 20 hours of firing that followed, the 44 escaped, leaving others as a rear guard, who held Seychellois hostage as a shield. **********The fighting left the airport, seven miles from Victoria, the capital, scarred. The Seychelles military force, a Government official said, put two rocket-propelled grenades through the Royal Swazi Airlines plane to prevent the mercenaries from escaping on it.  The tactic has left the twin-engine passenger jet eviscerated, its electronics dangling messily in the flight deck, and oxygen masks hanging down in the cabin. The plane represents the entire Swazi fleet. **********According to a list released by the authorities today, the 44 who arrived Nov. 25 included 23 South Africans, 9 Britons, 5 Zimbabweans, 2 Germans, one Australian, one Austrian, one Irishman and an American identified as Barry Gribein. The eight who had come earlier comprised three South Africans, one American, two Zimbabweans and two Britons, the authorities said. Government Displays Booty **********The Government also displayed its booty: at least 14 stockless rifles recovered from false-bottomed bags, tracer ammunition, a ''Foam Blowers'' T-shirt with bloodstains and American-made walkietalkies. **********The Seychelles radio broadcast an appeal today to an American and three South Africans who have been reported missing from hotels to come forward. By nightfall, none of them had surrendured, and a dusk-to-dawn curfew settled on the island. **********Two Soviet warships, which arrived three days after the coup attempt in a show of support for Mr. Rene, and a day after a French destroyer arrived on a similar mission, lay at anchor just offshore. **********To the sighing of turquoise waves, night eased down on beaches that by daylight are as palm-fringed and coral-white as the brochures say.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/31/busin.body_text: **********T HE limited nature of the city's economic revival is mirrored in the labor markets. Although the unemployment rate in 1980 was basically unchanged in New York City while rising sharply in the rest of the country, joblessness continued to be much higher in the city. The stability of the city's jobless rate was largely the result of a reduction of the size of the city's labor force and not because its job market was substantially stronger than the nation's. Indeed, if the city's labor force had grown in 1980 at the same rate as the nation's, all other things being the same, the city's unemployment rate would have risen to 10.9 percent instread of remaining unchanged at 8.6 percent. **********Actually, the city's civilian labor force has been declining for several years now. This decline is partly the result of the city's shrinking population. According to the 1980 census, the city's population has fallen by about 10 percent since 1970. **********The size of the labor force also depends on what fraction of the population is at work or actively looking for work - the labor force participation rate, as measured by the ratio of the civilian labor force to the civilian noninstititional population aged 16 years or more. It is now widely appreciated how much lower participation rates are in New York City, compared with the rest of the country.  The difference (55.3 for New York, 63.8 for the nation) is striking.
