https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/28/busin.body_text: **********The triangular shape of a 12-story brick and limestone Greenwich Village loft building recently converted into condominiums has resulted in plans of unusual angular design for its 44 apartments. **********An offering plan for units in the building at 2 Cornelia Street has been accepted for filing by the Attorney General's office and subscription agreements are being processed, according to Robert Fisher, who developed the project in partnership with his twin brother, Roger. **********''Our desire was to create homes that were different from most new apartments being built,'' Roger Fisher said. ''We believe that people interested in settling in Greenwich Village are looking for something other than a typical high rise, the brick-on-brick, boxlike unit, whether they are lawyers, physicians or architects. '' **********In the opinion of the developers, the ''old image'' of the Village as a Bohemian enclave has changed - ''even though our clients are looking for a more relaxed environment than in some other areas of the city,'' Robert Fisher added. **********One of the earliest steel-frame structures built in the city, 2 Cornelia Street was designed in the Beaux Arts style by the architect Fred Eberling and erected in 1907. **********Several small retail businesses and La Groceria Ristorante continue to lease shops fronting on the Avenue of the Americas, although renters of loft space on the upper floors moved out before acquisition of the property by the Fisher brothers in May 1980. **********The developers will retain ownership of the retail space.  The Fisher brothers, who are in their early 30's, renovated an office building at 6 East 46th Street in Manhattan. They own it along with other commercial properties in the metropolitan area. The Cornelia Street venture marks their entry into the residential market. **********''In commercial development, we began to feel we were at the beck and call of banks who usually are looking for some form of equity participation,'' Roger Fisher said. **********''We wanted to do something more creative than commercial projects allow.'' In its residential reincarnation, according to the plan by the Stephen B. Jacobs architectural concern, the building has maintained its many windows and high-ceilinged rooms, which the builders hope will enhance a perception of spaciousness. **********''When you develop an office building you create space, but the tenant makes the final decisions about how the space is going to be used,'' Roger Fisher said. In an apartment building, he continued, ''whether it's renovation or new construction, the developer creates the interior space and the whole environment, even down to considerations such as layout and decor and hardware for the doors.'' **********The Fisher brothers chose white circular staircases with oak treads to connect the upper and lower levels of the duplex units; brasscolored fixtures - instead of chrome - and sliding thermal-glass windows that are fitted with screens even though the windows have sleeves for air-conditioners. **********Despite some objections from the architects, they decided the fully equipped and ventilated kitchens would be left without partitions while other units were demarcated by the cabinet arrangement. **********Looking north, residents of the second floor and above have unobstructed views of the Empire State Building and the Manhattan skyline. Though views beneath the sixth floor on the Cornelia Street side are obstructed by residential buildings, tenants on the sixth floor south and above have access to sweeping scenes of Lower Manhattan, the towers of the World Trade Center and the Hudson River. Some apartments have roof terraces. **********By offering their units as condominiums, perhaps the first in Lower Manhattan, the developers hope to lure buyers seeking fewer restrictions on resale and lower monthly charges -features they believe are not as attractive in cooperative offerings, which are more common in New York City. **********Cooperative owners buy shares in a corporation owning the property, while condominium owners buy their units and lease space in common areas shared with other residents such as the lobby and hallways. **********Though a condominium board made up of owners may decline to sell to a prospective apartment buyer for any reason, in that case the board must at least match the offer of the prospective buyer. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/16/world.body_text: **********Former Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan today sharply criticized Iran's President, Prime Minister and Chief Justice, saying that a struggle for power had grown into a dangerous feud. **********Mr. Bazargan, who headed a provisional government in 1979 and is now a member of Parliament, said that President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr paid ''too much attention to his post'' and Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai ''uses his efforts to block the way of the President.'' **********He accused the head of the Supreme Court, Ayatollah Mohammed Beheshti, of misusing his post to spread propaganda and of exceeding his jurisdiction. Mr. Bazargan made the comments in a speech to Parliament. **********The Teheran radio meanwhile broadcast an account of a formal meeting between Prime Minister Rajai and the Soviet Ambassador, Vladimir M. Vinogradov, in which Iran made one of its sharpest criticisms of Moscow since the revolution two years ago. During a 45-minute session, according to the radio's account, Mr. Rajai accused the Soviet Union of losing its revolutionary ideals and of adopting policies similar to those of the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/20/world.main_headline: MARCOS YIELDS SOME POWER TO CONGRESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/20/world.print_headline: MARCOS YIELDS SOME POWER TO CONGRESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/20/world.body_text: **********President Ferdinand E. Marcos opened the session of the National Assembly today by formally transferring to it the legislative power that he had exercised during eight years and four months of martial law. **********But Mr. Marcos told the legislators that he is retaining the right to issue decrees whenever, in his judgment, there is a grave emergency or imminent threat of one, or whenever the National Assembly ''fails or is unable to act adequately on any matter for any reason that in his judgment requires immediate action.'' **********Mr. Marcos described this power as a safety valve that would allow him to meet an emergency without again resorting to the extreme of declaring martial law. **********In proclaiming the end of martial law Saturday, the President, who has been in power since his election in 1965, declared that the orders and decrees by which he had governed for more than eight years would remain in force unless modified by him or by the regular National Assembly. Election of Assembly Set for 1984 **********This provision, as well as Mr. Marcos's retention of standby power to issue decrees, is viewed by opponents of the regime as greatly reducing the real significance of the lifting of martial law. Mr.  Marcos has issued more than 1,000 decrees. **********Nonetheless, opponents and diplomats concede that the gestures represent an opening for change toward liberalization. A new National Assembly, replacing the present interim legislature, is to be elected in 1984. **********So far, the organized opposition, led largely by elected officials from the days before martial law was declared, has made no move to test the new climate. They are deliberating on whether to hold political meetings and publish anti-Marcos newspapers. **********Mr. Marcos affirmed, in an addition to the prepared text of his speech today, that he had not lifted martial law in response to pressure from the United States. The change of American administrations, with the new one believed likely to be more favorable to Mr. Marcos than that of President Carter, is frequently mentioned here as a factor dictating the timing of the President's action. Pope John Paul II's visit next month to this predominantly Roman Catholic country also is mentioned as a factor. He Says U.S. Did Not Know Plan **********Mr. Marcos also said that the United States had not been informed of his decision to impose martial law in 1972. Many opponents have asserted that the United States connived in the martial-law regime in return for assurances by Mr. Marcos that American military and economic interests would be unaffected. **********Mr. Marcos's formal cession of legislative powers to the assembly is not viewed here as creating a threat to his authority. Of its 184 members, 169 belong to the President's New Society Party; many of the others generally support it. A maximum of five deputies are firm opponents. **********After the proclamation of martial law, the assembly was moved from the old Congress Building in the center of the city, and it was transformed into the national museum. The assembly was moved to a new structure in a remote suburb, and its deliberations are held before sparsely filled public galleries. The legislators are bused there from the park on which the old Congress faces. Critics of Mr. Marcos view this as symbolic of the legislature's status.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/busin.main_headline: U.S. Files Suits On Gasoline Pricing
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; U.S. Files Suits On Gasoline Pricing
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/busin.body_text: **********The United States Department of Energy said it had begun legal action to recover $34 million from the Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation and $25.9 million from the United Refining Company for alleged violations of Federal pricing regulations. **********The Government agency alleged that between August 1973 and December 1974 Quaker State improperly calculated selling prices for gasoline and general refinery products. The agency also contends that United Refining miscalulated its selling prices during the period from August 1973 through December 1974. **********United Refining said the Government complaint contained a number of factual and legal errors that it intended to contest vigorously.  Quaker State said it had turned over the Government complaint to its legal counsel for response.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Interest rate jitters touched off a sharp decline in the stock market yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 10.48 points, to 987.48. Energy, technology, fast-food, railroad and airline issues joined blue chips in showing weakness. **********''Price declines in the technology sector, where many issues had run ahead recently, contributed to the market's vulnerability,'' said Donald I. Trott, research director for A.G. Becker & Company. **********The broad retreat, gaining momentum in the final hour, was underscored by these statistics on the New York Stock Exchange: 478 advances against 1,134 declines. **********Volume contracted to 53.9 million shares from Monday's 62.2 million, which had marked the heaviest turnover in five weeks.  The Dow transportation average plunged 10.29 points, to 420.63, producing a percentage decline more than twice that of the industrials. The utility average, which is sensitive to interest rate developments, also lost considerable ground. **********Faced with conflicting signals, many investors and traders apparently chose to pare their portfolios. On the one hand, additional banks cut their prime lending rate by half a point, to 20 percent. But short-term rates gyrated wildly in the money market before finishing slightly higher. **********Continued weakness in energy stocks - Wall Street favorites in 1979 and 1980 - proved unsettling, according to analysts.  The Mobil Corporation, for example, fell 1 5/8, to 54 3/4, and sold at its lowest price within the last 12 months. Last year, Mobil traded at a record price of 89 1/2. Some issues, such as Wainoco Oil, an aggressive exploration company, sold yesterday at less than onehalf of their 1980 highs. Drilling Stocks Hit Hard **********Oil-service and drilling stocks also were hit hard. Such former favorites as Schlumberger, Halliburton and Parker Drilling displayed losses exceeding 2 points. **********Just as energy stocks rose in the two previous years in tandem with climbing petroleum prices, so have an abundant supply of crude oil and the recently invoked price freeze by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries applied pressure to this sector. **********Also reflecting the price pullback in natural-resource issues, the American Stock Exchange's market value index dropped 7.04 points, to 363.40, registering its largest decline since an 11-point loss on Feb. 2. Retreating more than 3 points each were Dome Petroleum, Felmont Oil and Delhi International Oil. **********In citing price erosion in the technology group, Mr. Trott of Becker mentioned Texas Instruments, which plunged 11 5/8 points in the previous two sessions. On Friday, the company announced a permanent layoff of 2,800 workers because of weakness in its semiconductor business. Yesterday, Texas Instruments eased 3/4, to 107 3/4. **********Elsewhere, Prime Computer, Hewlett-Packard and Teledyne dropped more than 3 points each.  Despite yesterday's pronounced setback in the market, some Wall Street analysts continued to express optimism for a recovery. Mr.  Trott, for example, said he believes the Dow industrials this summer will surpass their record closing of 1,051.70 on Jan. 11, 1973. **********The Big Board's most active stock, Kennecott, moved against the general trend, advancing 1 7/8, to 61 3/4, on a turnover exceeding 1 million shares. This followed the report that the Federal Trade Commission had voted in a closed session against opposing the proposed acquisition of Kennecott by the Standard Oil Company (Ohio). Sohio dropped 1 7/8, to 43 3/8. Its high last year was 91 1/2. **********Walt Disney Productions, reaching its loftiest price in eight years, climbed 1 1/8, to 64. David J. Londoner of Wertheim & Company attributed this gain primarily to recently improved attendance at Walt Disney World near Orlando, Fla. **********The Mead Corporation fell 3 1/4 points, to 28. On Monday, the Supreme Court refused to block a proceeding that potentially could force Mead to pay up to $1 billion for fixing prices on corrugated containers. **********Prices also fell sharply in the over-the-counter market. The Nasdaq composite index declined 3.43, to 219.59. MCI Communications, the volume leader, dropped 2 3/8, to 21 3/8 bid. Apple Computer retreated 1 5/8, to 31 1/2 bid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/world.main_headline: MOSCOW SAYS THE PENTAGON BOOKLET IS UNBALANCED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/world.print_headline: MOSCOW SAYS THE PENTAGON BOOKLET IS UNBALANCED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union said today that a Pentagon booklet on Soviet military might was designed to ''confuse, intimidate and misinform public opinion in the West'' about the relative strengths of Soviet and Western forces. **********A commentary by the Government's press agency, Tass, said the booklet was part of a propaganda campaign to justify ''the sharp turn in United States foreign policy from negotiations to confrontation and the unprecedented increase in military expenditures'' under the Reagan Administration. **********Details of the booklet first became available on Saturday, and it was officially presented today in Washington at a news conference by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. **********The Tass commentary said Mr. Weinberger, who has supplanted Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. as the prime villain in Soviet attacks, had set out to disprove previous United States acknowledgments that there was approximate military parity between the two sides. **********This position, Tass said, was taken by high-ranking officials in the Carter Administration, including Defense Secretary Harold Brown, Gen. David Jones, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and even by Mr. Haig while serving as commander of Atl antic alliance forces in Wes tern Europe. **********''Washington's new propagandistic trick with the publication of the booklet about the 'Soviet military threat,' '' Tass said, ''obviously pursues the aim of lulling the suspicions of the Western European allies that the United States is more interested in an unbridled arms race than in negotiations with the Soviet Union on strengthening European security, and it simply fools its NATO partners.'' **********The reference to negotiations on European security appeared to allude to the agreement to begin talks in Geneva on Nov. 30 on medium-range nuclear forces in Europe. The agreement came out of talks last week between Secretary of State Haig and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union. Tass said the Pentagon pamphlet showed sign s of having been produced in a hurry. It said: ''No attempt has been made to analyze in an y serious way the correlation of military might of the sides in the world or in Europe.The authors resort to the dishonest device of snatching individual elements of the Soviet armed forces from the overall balance and comparing them in a deliberately distorted wa y with United States forces.'' **********''The pamphlet does not mention the geographical proximity of a huge number of United States military bases to the territory of the U.S.S.R., United States aircraft carriers with planes carrying nuclear warheads that constantly cruise near the shores of Europe, United States nuclear-powered submarines that carry hundreds of nuclear warheads in the Mediterranean, near the shores of the Far East, in the Indian Ocean and in the Persian Gulf.'' **********The commentary closed with a warning.  ''The Soviet Union,'' it said, ''has never sought and does not seek military superiority. But it will not be indifferent to the emergence of still more formidable types of weapons in the United States arsenal. If that happens, the Soviet armed forces will possess an appropriate counterweight.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/09/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Philip Verleger's, ''All Gluts Are Not Created Equal...'' (July 19), missed the point as a response to Daniel Yergin's article, ''Lulled to Sleep by the Oil Glut Mirage'' (June 28). **********Mr. Yergin's argument was straightforward: The current easing of oil market pressures is not cause for complacency and selfcongratulation and the problem of United States vulnerability to supply disruptions remains unsolved. **********Mr. Verleger offers strong evidence that in the short run, crude oil prices will likely decline further, but he fails to address the vulnerability issue. **********Demand for oil includes not only immediate consumption, but inventory change as well. The expectation of a decline in prices fosters the decline of oil company stocks, the oil companies not wanting to be stuck with high-priced inventory. These stocks were at unusually low levels at the time of the Iranian shutdown, and the ensuing scramble to rebuild them was in part responsible for the devastating price increase which took place over the following six months. In contrast, at the outbreak of the Iran-Iraq war, inventories were at record levels as a result of the previous build-up. Their release served to moderate upward pressure on prices. **********Oil prices have shown themselves extremely sensitive to loss of supply, and sharp price increases can wreak havoc in the economy, causing more inflation and lost output. As Mr. Yergin emphasized, the current ''glut'' psychology is a dangerous and potentially costly illusion.  ROBERT WEINER Harvard Business School  GLENN HUBBARD Department of Economics Harvard University Cambridge, Mass. July 28, 1981

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.body_text: **********The RLC Corporation and Waste Management Inc. of Oak Brook, Ill., said they had reached an agreement in principle for Waste Management to acquire Rollins Environmental Services, RLC's chemical waste operations, for preferred stock worth $53.2 million. **********In the tax-free transaction, holders of RLC common stock will receive 8 percent cumulative preferred stock convertible into shares of Waste Management common stock at $42.50 a share. **********RLC's chemical waste operations include chemical waste incineration facilities in Bridgeport, N.J., Baton Rouge, La., and Houston, as well as deep-well injection facilities in Plaquemine, La. RLC's chemical waste operations had revenues of about $31.5 million for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/busin.main_headline: CHAPTER 11 PETITION IS FILED BY SAMBO'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/busin.print_headline: CHAPTER 11 PETITION IS FILED BY SAMBO'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/busin.body_text: **********Sambo's Restaurants Inc., the financially ailing food chain, said yesterday that it had filed a voluntary petition under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in the United States District Court in Los Angeles. **********The filing was prompted by the service of a notice of default from its 17 lenders on Wednesday, according to Arthur Dowd, Sambo's vice president for administration. **********The chain's creditors include the Prudential Insurance Company of America, First Interstate Bank of California, Bank of America, Crocker National Bank and Citibank of New York. **********Mr. Dowd said that the petition would ''have absolutely no effect on the company's operations'' and described it as an attempt to buy time from lenders. **********On Sept. 30, the California-based restaurant chain, once one of the nation's most prosperous franchising operations, failed to pay $4.8 million that it owed as the first installment of a $100 million loan-restructuring arrangement. Under terms of the original arrangement, the 17 lenders could demand immediate payment if there were a default. Earlier this week, it asked its lenders to again restructure the debt. **********Mr. Dowd said that Sambo's would continue to operate its remaining restaurants under supervision of the court.  ''We will continue to operate 667 restaurants nationwide under our present supervision and employees,'' Mr. Dowd said. ''The company will continue to do business as before. We want to stress to our employees and vendors that they will be paid as usual, as will shareholders.'' **********Earlier this week, Sambo's announced that it had closed 447 restaurants since Nov. 9, resulting in layoffs of up to 10,000 employees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/25/world.main_headline: Marcos Opponents Decide Not to Contest Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/25/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Marcos Opponents Decide Not to Contest Election
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/25/world.body_text: **********The main political opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos decided today against entering a candidate in the June 16 presidential elections, thus virtually assuring Mr.  Marcos a new six-year term. **********Their decision came on the eve of a party convention of the President's followers, who are expected to nominate him unanimously as their candidate. Mr. Marcos has ruled the Philippines since 1965. ---- **********DAVAO CITY, the Philippines, April 24 (AP) - About 300 demonstrators staged a protest march today against terrorist bombings in this southern city, where a grenade attack killed 16 people in a Roman Catholic church on Easter Sunday. The military said the attack was made by Communist guerrillas of the New People's Army.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/busin.main_headline: DOW OFF 9.80, TO 924.66, ITS LOW FOR THIS YEAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/busin.print_headline: DOW OFF 9.80, TO 924.66, ITS LOW FOR THIS YEAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/busin.body_text: **********The stock market failed yesterday to sustain a rally attempt and prices then plunged abruptly, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest closing this year. The indicator tumbled 9.80 points, to 924.66, bringing its combined loss this week to 34 points. **********Once again, analysts cited the high level of interest rates - both short-term and long-term - as the critical factor in turning investors away from the stock market when lofty yields are available elsewhere. Some money market funds, for example, return upwards of 17 percent. **********''I think the stock market will catch hold so that the Dow can recover somewhere above 900,'' stated Charles S. Comer, a technical analyst for Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. ''However, I don't foresee any sustained rally for stocks until interest rates show some sign of easing.'' **********Mr. Comer noted that a critical test for the Dow - if it sinks that low in the current sell-off - could develop in the area of its close last Dec. 11 at 908.45, which marks the indicator's lowest closing over the last 12 months. Volume Stable **********Trading volume, totaling 47.5 million shares, was virtually unchanged from Tuesday's 47.3 million. Declines outpaced advances by nearly 2-to-1. **********Meanwhile, in the recently battered credit market, most prices displayed little change yesterday.  During July, companies involved in actual or rumored takeovers have accounted for as much as 20 percent of daily turnover on the New York Stock Exchange. As a result, analysts said, this excitement has masked price deterioration in many other sectors of the market. **********For example, Conoco Inc., which has received acquisition offers from three major corporate suitors, traded more than 1.8 million shares yesterday. Conoco's stock eased 1/2, to 84. **********Several stocks that posted large gains Tuesday amid takeover rumors finished lower yesterday. Cities Service dropped 4 1/4, to 55, while Kerr-McGee fell 2 1/4, to 77 1/2. Getty Oil and Amerada Hess retreated more than 2 points each. **********Minnesota Mining, a component in the Dow industrial average, fell 2 1/2, to 50 7/8, as the second most active issue. The company reported lower earnings for the June quarter. **********Cox Broadcasting, however, climbed 2 points, to 63 1/4, after announcing improved profits. Metromedia, another broadcasting company, also announced higher earnings. But its stock swung widely, finishing at 145 3/4, down 4 3/4 points, after selling as high as 153 3/4. Various Factors Cited **********In attempting to explain the stock market's abrupt decline this week, analysts cited reasons other than the competitive pressure of near-record interest rates. These ranged from the steadily declining cash resources of large institutional investors to the uncertain impact of any business slowdown on corporate earnings. The debate in Congress over proposed tax cuts also has served to confuse or disappoint some investors. **********Other negative factors, as Rudolf Hauser of Oppenheimer & Company has pointed out, include the large number of common stock offerings recently and the high level of margin debt. **********But interest rates, it is generally agreed, hold the key to future movements in both the stock and bond markets. On this score, Paul A.  Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, served notice Tuesday of the Fed's intention to pursue a policy of ''sustained monetary restraint'' until inflationary expectations abate. **********With leading natural resource issues generally holding steady, the American Stock Exchange's market value index slipped only 0.02, to 362.95. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index fell 1.01, to 206.16. **********On the Amex, Adobe Oil and Gas rose 1 3/8, to 36 1/4, after announcing a discovery in Billings, Okla.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/31/world.main_headline: COSTA RICA BUFFETED BY REGIONAL UNREST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/31/world.print_headline: COSTA RICA BUFFETED BY REGIONAL UNREST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/31/world.body_text: **********Long held up as proof that democracy can prosper in Latin America, Costa Rica is suddenly being buffeted from abroad by political and economic forces that it cannot control. **********The main threat to the country's stability comes from an economic crisis provoked by high oil prices and low coffee prices beyond its borders. But two recent terrorist bombings here, in which three United States Marine guards were injured and the Honduran Embassy was damaged, also announced the arrival of Central America's political problems in Costa Rica. **********''The boat is ours to steer,'' President Rodrigo Carazo Odio said in an interview, ''but the storm is all around us and the water is rough.'' **********In reality, the ''boat'' still seems strong. Although the Carazo administration is unpopular and economic hardship is growing, the majority of Costa Ricans, including leftists and conservatives, recognize that the democratic system installed here 33 years ago has brought them a tranquillity and welfare that are the envy of the rest of the region. **********'Pro-Americanism' Is the Norm **********Yet, with no security apparatus trained to deal with terrorism and no industrial base able to cushion the impact of unstable world commodity prices, Costa Rica's political and economic structures seem more vulnerable today than at any other time in recent memory. **********A rare Latin American country where ''pro-Americanism'' is the norm, an alarmed Costa Rica is naturally looking to the United States for help in riding out the storm. So far, though, the Reagan Administration's attention has been narrowly focused on El Salvador, and it has barely noticed the crisis brewing a few hundred miles to the south. **********''Washington must help us today or face problems here tomorrow,'' said Oscar Arias Sanchez, an opposition member of the Legislative Assembly. ''The U.S. is rushing to help Jamaica, but if it can't see that we're as important to Central America as Jamaica is to the Caribbean, then we might as well as switch off the lights and leave.'' **********One irony is that although successive United States Administrations have offered Costa Rica as a model to the rest of Latin America, Washington's $10 million aid program to Costa Rica this year is just one-tenth of the amount of its planned assistance to El Salvador. 40 Percent Inflation Expected **********Even without the violence elsewhere in Central America, many Costa Rican politicians have been predicting that the economic crisis will soon bring social unrest. Since last September the country's currency has lost half its value, feeding inflation, which is expected to exceed 40 percent this year, and forcing the Government to hold down both imports and public spending. **********Although the Carazo administration has been criticized for reacting slowly to the crisis, the rise in the country's current accountpayment deficit to $661 million last year was largely attributable to the 28 percent increase in its oil import bills, to $206 million, and the 22 percent decrease in its coffee earnings, to $244 million. **********''In 1970, one bag of coffee bought 100 barrels of oil,'' said Jose Miguel Alfaro, the Minister of Economy. ''Today, one bag of coffee buys just three barrels of oil.'' **********To find a way out of the crisis, Costa Rica has now turned to the International Monetary Fund, which is demanding a severe austerity program, including a $225 million cut in the budget deficit. In exchange, Costa Rica is hoping for a so-called Extended Fund Facility of $330 million over three years, which should enable it to continue investments in energy and agricultural programs aimed at strengthening the economy's resistence to the vagaries of world prices. Plan for Alternative Energy **********''The deterioration of the terms of trade is totally beyond our control,'' explained Hernan Saenz, the Finance Minister. ''If we don't carry on our structural investments and reforms, we'll be in exactly the same position of vulnerability when the monetary crisis is overcome.'' **********In a country with no hydrocarbons of its own, the major problem involves alternative energy, with plans to phase out oil-fired thermoelectric plants by developing Costa Rica's huge hydroelectric potential, and to substitute alcohol for all the gasoline used by automobiles by 1989. **********Nontraditional exports - anything but coffee, bananas and meat - are to be stimulated. In the short to medium term, the slump - the economy is expected to grow by only 1 percent this year, compared with a recent annual average of 6 percent - could spark labor unrest and increased dissatisfaction with the Carazo administration. **********With general elections due next February, however, local politicians hope that political dissent will be channeled into the campaign. Mr. Carazo cannot seek re-election, and the candidate of the opposition Social Democratic National Liberation Party, Luis Alberto Monge, is the strong favorite to become the next president. Bombings Introduce Uncertainty **********But the unpredictable political variable here, introduced abruptly by the terrorist bombs, is a cause for concern for all political parties. **********Officials believe that the bombings were the work of foreign leftists linked to Salvadoran guerrilla groups. But local leftist sources insist that young Costa Rican radicals, inspired by the revolutionary fever in the region, were responsible. **********A communique signed by the ''Commander Carlos Aguero Echeverria Command'' said the bombings were in reprisal for United States and Honduran support for El Salvador's junta, and it called for the formation in Costa Rica of a ''political-military organization,'' the leftist euphemism for a guerrilla group. **********The Costa Rican Army was dismantled in 1949, and the shock caused by the bombings was soon followed here by the nervous recognition that the country's poorly equipped 7,000-member Civil Guard was ill prepared to deal with terrorism. Because the guard is considered a police force, United States law prevents Washington from providing it with assistance. Carazo Rejects 'Militarization' **********President Carazo was among the first to insist that the bombings would not lead to ''militarization'' of the society. ''That is out of the question,'' he said. ''Terrorism is repudiated by everyone, and the best ally of the Government in fighting it is the people.  When the country has an army, it expects the army to defend it.  Because we have no army, the people are ready to defend the country.'' **********Although Costa Ricans were always ready to volunteer as reservists during the frequent border crises with Nicaragua under the Somoza regime, some security analysts here recognize that terrorism is more difficult to combat. ''The extreme left's objective is to polarize society by provoking the extreme right to resort to the same tactics and by forcing the police to become more repressive,'' one police expert said. ''That is, of course, a greater danger than the terrorism itself.'' **********Conscious of the risk that this country might be sucked into the Central American vortex of violence, President Carazo is indirectly trying to protect Costa Rica by actively promoting a political solution to the Salvadoran conflict and by warning that ''excessive'' military aid to El Salvador could weaken President Jose Napoleon Duarte and other civilians in the Government. **********Having assisted Nicaragua's Sandinist guerrillas in ousting the Somoza regime, President Carazo is also alarmed by the Reagan Administration's hostility toward the left-wing Managua Government. **********''The intelligent thing would be to adopt a friendly and constructive policy toward Nicaragua,'' he said. ''We have to help Nicaragua a great deal and keep it on the side of democracy. We must not repeat Cuba and force Nicaragua to be a friend of Moscow. In this polarized world, a country expelled from one side goes automatically to the other.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/14/world.body_text: **********Italian and French Communists at the East German party congress here warned today against any outside intervention in Poland and said they were convinced that Warsaw could settle its own affairs. **********Addressing the conference as the representatives of the two largest Communist parties in Western Europe, Gaston Plissonnier of France and Giovanni Cervetti of Italy spoke of widespread concern in the West at the events in and around Poland. **********''For the past six months the media in France have reported that a military intervention is imminent,'' said Mr. Plissonnier, who is a member of the French politburo. ''Naturally this has led to violent attacks against the Communist Party.'' **********He said his party was ''deeply convinced it is the affair of the Polish party, the Government and the Polish people to solve their problems through realization of economic, social and democratic reforms that will enable them to go forward on the road to socialism.'' Affair for Poles Themselves **********Mr. Cervetti, a member of the Italian party's national leadership, used even stronger language, saying his party firmly believed ''that the respect for independence and sovereignty of every country and every nation is an unrenounceable principle for every socialist force, for every progressive force, and is also a basic condition for the continuation of detente.'' **********The Poles themselves, he said, should ''solve and overcome the crisis and the tensions by political means, with their own strength and without outside interference.'' **********Mr. Cervetti said that the Polish events had caused ''fear and concern'' in Europe. Italy's Communists, he said, ''are following the process of renewal in Poland and the work done by the Polish comrades with hope and good will.'' **********While the Italian Communists have never left any doubt of their opposition to any military threat by Soviet and Warsaw Pact forces against Poland, the French Communists, closer to Moscow's fold, have so far been quiet about the Polish developments. Mr. Plissonnier's statement was seen to reflect worry lest the events influence the French presidential elections next month. **********In light of widespread fears in Europe of military interference in Poland, France's Communists evidently fear their prospects at the elections may be hurt unless they speak up. Both the French and Italian parties condemned the Soviet intervention in Czechoslovakia in 1968. Concept of 'Renewal' Attacked **********The East German leader, Erich Honecker, signaled official restraint at the opening session of the congress Saturday when he pledged ''brotherly solidarity'' with Polish Communists striving to defend and strengthen socialism. But other East German delegates were given leeway to express discontent and suspicion at the pace and the manner in which the Poles were handling the situation. **********At this morning's session a high-level official attacked the concept of ''renewal,'' the term used by the Poles to describe their party's reform movement. Egon Krenz, the head of the East German Communist youth organization, said ''anti-Communists, revisionists and so-called renewers'' must all be grouped together and fought as enemies of socialism. **********East German youths, he said, know the difference between revolution and counterrevolution and had ''long accepted leadership of the party as an inviolable principle of socialism.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/05/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates on home loans for new single-family houses soared to an average of 16.1 percent last month, the highest since the all-time record of 16.59 percent in April of last year, the Government reported today. **********The Federal Home Loan Bank Board report seemed to be in line with recent complaints by numerous housing industry spokesmen that rates have risen so high that few Americans can afford loans for new houses. **********The average rate fell to 12.52 percent last August, but has been rising since then along with interest rates in other parts of the economy. **********The bank board's average is based on a survey of loan commitments of large savings institutions offering 25-year mortgages covering 75 percent of the purchase price. **********The average for early May was more than one-half percentage point higher than the 15.53 percent average recorded one month earlier, the board report said. **********''The sharp advance in rates reflected both substantial withdrawals of funds from thrift institutions, which are typically large mortgage lenders, and the general rise in long-term interest rates,'' the report said. **********The bank board had reported earlier that the nation's federally chartered savings and loan associations suffered a record $4.63 million ''outflow'' of new savings deposits in May.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/26/busin.body_text: **********NO sooner has the world been treated to the personal desktop computer than along comes the portable computer. Now everyone can have a computer - not only in the home or office but also in the briefcase or pocket. **********The new portable machines range from the hand-held computer, which looks like an overgrown calculator, to the briefcase-sized computer, which looks like a miniature version of a desktop machine. **********Several such devices are already on the market and more are coming. Two days ago, Japan's Casio Computer Company announced plans to introduce this summer a $250 computer small enough to fit in a coat pocket. **********In function and price, the portable computers fill the gap between programmable calculators and desktop computers. Indeed, there is now a continuum in computing devices from the $10 wallet-sized calculator to the multimillion-dollar, room-sized mainframe. **********The portable devices achieve their size by a combination of technical advances, compact packaging and omission of some of the features of the larger computers, such as television-screen displays and full-sized keyboards. **********The first hand-held computer to reach the market was the $250 Radio Shack model introduced last summer and manufactured by Japan's Sharp Corporation. Sharp intends to market a similar device under its own name. **********The computer is similar to a programmable calculator except that it can be programmed using a conventional programming language rather than by punching function keys as on a calculator. It has a one-line display, allowing the user to read the program one line at a time.  The computer can also prompt the user through written messages to punch in certain data. But without a typewriter-like keyboard and a television display screen, the device is somewhat inconvenient to use. **********''I have a real question as to the acceptability of hand-held computers in the market,'' said Ed Faber, president of Computerland, a chain of more than 150 computer retail stores. Nevertheless, Computerland will soon offer the Sharp computer. **********A more powerful device will be offered by Panasonic and Quasar later this year. Developed by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and Friends Amis Inc. of San Francisco, the device is the successor to the ill-fated electronic translator, which was more limited in function and lasted two years on the market. **********The computer uses the same powerful microprocessor as in some of the desktop computers that require household current. To allow the hand-held computer to run on batteries, a sophisticated internal program constantly turns off the microprocessor when it is not in use. The computer also uses several methods to cram more data onto less memory than in many other computers. **********The computer comes with special attachments that give it the capabilities of a desktop computer. It can connect over the telephone, for instance, to access data banks that provide everything from stock quotations to airline schedules to newspaper articles.  That information can be read one line at a time on the computer's display, which is rather cumbersome. Or the computer can be hooked to a television screen, providing a bigger display. The hand-held computer can also be hooked to a tiny printer, additional memory blocks or a larger keyboard. **********Of course, with all those attachments, the computer is no longer a hand-held device but a briefcase-sized one. And its price, which will be $600 for the basic computer, will jump to $2,000. **********That brings it up against other competition. Britain's Sinclair Research Ltd. has developed a book-sized computer weighing 12 ounces and selling for $200. The device has a keyboard that is almost the size of a typewriter keyboard. The user must provide his own television set for display. **********Perhaps the ultimate in packaged portable computers is the one that will be brought out by the Osborne Computer Corporation of Hayward, Calif., next month. It contains a typewriter-like keyboard, a five-inch diagonal display screen and two disk drives for additional memory, and can connect to larger screens or telephones.  All will fit in a briefcase small enough to put under an airplane seat. It will sell for $1,800. **********Industry officials and analysts think it is only a matter of time before several other companies jump in with hand-held or portable computers. **********Frequently mentioned as candidates are Texas Instruments and Hewlett-Packard, whose programmable calculators are likely to feel increased competition. Hewlett-Packard already seems to be moving in that direction with its HP-41C, the first programmable calculator that can display letters as well as numbers. It can also be attached to printers and plotters. **********''I think the portable computers will take off like gangbusters,'' said Portia Isaacson of Future Computing, a Dallas-area consulting firm. **********Dr. Isaacson predicts businessmen will soon be carrying entire electronic offices with them, consisting of microcassette recorders, tiny printers, tiny televisions and small keyboards all attachable to a small computer. **********Businessmen will be able to dictate letters, type and edit reports, have access to company files and send data to the main company computer while on the road. Dr. Isaacson has a name for it: The Swiss Army Pocket Computer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/20/busin.body_text: **********Housing starts declined 1 percent in December, to 1.56 million at an annual rate, the first loss since May, and permits for future building plunged 9 percent in a possible indication of more trouble ahead, the Commerce Department reported today. **********The department also released figures showing that Americans' personal income rose nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, a pace almost certain to be less than the inflation rate. (Page D12.) **********Noting the building-permit decrease, an economist for the National Association of Homebuilders said he expected new construction ''to drop substantially'' in coming months as high interest rates made a national housing recovery difficult. **********The economist, William Young, predicted a ''very, very slow'' seasonally adjusted annual housing start rate of 1.2 million units through the first six months of this year. **********That would be about halfway between December's rate and the 906,000 annual rate reported in the midst of the recession earlier last year.  November Figure Revised **********The Commerce Department had originally reported a drop of fourtenths of 1 percent in housing starts for November, but the figures released today changed that to a slight increase. **********Single-family housing starts declined 6 percent in December, the third straight monthly drop for that category. But that decrease was almost balanced in the overall figures by a 19 percent increase in the rate for units in buildings designed for five or more families, the department said. **********Over all, housing starts for all sizes of buildings have changed little for several months, rising slightly in October and November after increasing rapidly through the summer from the year's low in May. **********A department statement accompanying the new figures cautioned against interpreting month-to-month changes in seasonally adjusted statistics too closely because ''it may take three months to establish an underlying trend for total starts and two months for total building permit authorizations.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/23/world.body_text: **********The leader of the South-West Africa People's Organization accused the Reagan Administration today of undermining efforts by the United Nations to bring about a settlement for the territory that would lead to its independence under the name of Namibia. **********Sam Nujoma, the head of the organization that is waging a guerrilla war against the South Africans in the territory, said that it appeared to his organization that President Reagan had decided to throw the weight of the United States behind South Africa. South-West Africa is administered by South Africa under a mandate given by the League of Nations after World War I. **********''We denounce the recent American diplomatic missions to Namibia because this is tantamount to recognizing the puppet regime created by South Africa there,'' Mr. Nujoma said at a news conference. He was referring to a visit to the territory recently by Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark, who also traveled to South Africa and Zimbabwe. **********Mr. Nujoma called for new sanctions by the West against South Africa. ''We urgently call on the West to support comprehensive sanctions against the racist regime of South Africa,'' he said. **********Foreign ministers from the 50 member nations of the Organization of African Unity, which is meeting here, have supported the idea of asking the West, and particularly the United States, to institute new sanctions against South Africa. **********Mr. Nujoma said that if the West, in particular the United States, failed to heed this call, his organization would ask the O.A.U. to call for economic sanctions against major Western powers like the United States. In response to a question, he said that one possibility would be to ask Nigeria, which is the second-largest supplier of crude oil to the United States after Saudi Arabia, to stop its oil shipments to the United States. **********He said that his organization, known as Swapo, along with the Organization of African Unity, held that the ''only basis'' for a fair settlement in Namibia was Security Council Resolution 435, which calls for United Nations-supervised elections. **********In a related development today, Randall Robinson, head of TransAfrica, a Washington-based lobbying group, disclosed to the African foreign ministers what he said were details of an American proposal for a constitution for Namibia. **********According to the outline disclosed by Mr. Robinson, the Reagan Administration's plan calls for a federal system with state boundaries that would be based on the territories inhabited by the ethnic groups of Namibia. ---- Zimbabwe Rules Out Embargo **********SALISBURY, Zimbabwe, June 22 (Reuters) - Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe said today that his country could not participate in trade sanctions against South Africa. **********Zimbabwe's economic dependence on its white-ruled neighbor was such that it would be senseless for it to pretend it could join in an embargo, Mr. Mugabe said in an interview.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Lexicon Gets Second Wind
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Lexicon Gets Second Wind
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/busin.body_text: **********IN the beginning the Lexicon Corporation manufactured a hand-held language translator. Although this product was the first in the field when it was introduced in November 1978, the company lacked the financial strength to compete after the translator market grew hot. **********The $500,000 that Lexicon raised in early 1978 dwindled to nothing, and the Miami-based company avoided bankruptcy only by selling its one important asset - the rights to its translator - for $1.5 million. **********The good news is that, unlike so many faltering start-up companies, Lexicon survived. The proceeds from the translator sale reduced the corporate debt to $1 million and paid for research and development on an advanced 5-pound portable computer terminal with a thermal-process paper tape. Lexicon believes that this terminal, which can send and receive, has even more promise than the translator did. **********The diminutive machine - two could fit inside a standard briefcase - can be hooked into any or all of the many data banks now available through the nearest telephone. For example, a subscriber could draw information from The New York Times Information Bank, Reader's Digest Source, the United Press International wire, the Dow Jones broad tape and Microquote, which provides current prices and their histories for over-the-counter and listed stocks, among other financial data. **********Lexicon's machine, called Lex 21, can reach the corporate data bank by telephone so that field people ''can get computerized information from wherever they happen to be,'' as Michael Levy, president of the company, explained in New York this week. For example, salespeople could ask the home office computer for updates on orders in process. **********Moreover, assuming Lexicon makes a deal with one of the half-dozen real estate multiple-listing data bases, the would-be seller of a private home would be able to obtain from his broker all current listings in the neighborhood, including features of houses on the market along with details and prices obtained in recent sales. Thus the householder reading a Lexicon printout could price his house with a sharp eye on the real estate market. **********To get this new terminal into production, Lexicon tapped the public capital market a second time, offering (through Blair & Company) 3,000 units priced at $1,000 each. A unit consisted of 100 convertible preferred shares, 400 common shares and warrants to purchase an additional 100 common shares. **********The offering, made in February, was a success. After the underwriting costs, the company kept $2.6 million of the $3 million proceeds. Now, Mr. Levy insists, Lexicon is ready to market its terminal and take its place among high-technology companies that have succeeded despite formidable odds. **********Does this mean that Lexicon is a shoo-in to participate in the growing market for portable computer terminals and become another glamour stock? **********Perhaps. But it is by no means certain. The company must still demonstrate that it is capable of marketing a promising product against some of the toughest competition in the world. **********As the prospectus issued for the recent offering notes, the venture involves ''significant risks.'' The company has experienced sizable losses in every year of its existence, and it had a working capital deficit before the offering. Mr. Levy said the company had about $1.5 million in working capital now. **********''Our fiscal year ends Aug. 31, and we should do about $1 million to $1.2 million in sales, and we should break even,'' he said. **********Among other risk factors, the company will depend on a Hong Kong manufacturer to build certain component parts for the terminals.  The company describes its major competitors as Texas Instruments Inc. and the Computer Devices Corporation, but Mr. Levy says, ''Their units are much heavier than ours. **********Wall Street speculators have heard about Lexicon and evidently are impressed with it. The over-the-counter shares began trading on March 3 this year. They were quoted at 1 1/4 bid that day and have since moved up. They reached 3 3/4 bid on May 7, when the trading volume was 135,500 shares. On Monday of this week the shares were 2 3/4 bid, and 14,600 shares were traded. The units that were issued at $1,000 rose to $3,500 in May and are now trading at about $3,000. **********In all, there are 3.3 million shares outstanding, of which insiders own about a third. So here is a high-technology company of promise. High among its attributes is a demonstrated ability to hold its important technical people, most of whom were originally at Racal-Milgo Inc. Mr. Levy takes pride in the fact that virtually no one has left his research and development department over the years despite the company's hard times. **********Will the Lex 21 terminal be a success and will Lexicon itself thrive? Only time will tell. If it does, it will join a tiny group of companies - such as the Intel Corporation, Tandem Computers Inc. and Prime Computer Inc. - that have survived and grown after near-fatal adversity in their early years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/17/world.main_headline: REAGAN MEETS WITH 8 SENATORS IN PUSH FOR SUPPORT ON AWACS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/17/world.print_headline: REAGAN MEETS WITH 8 SENATORS IN PUSH FOR SUPPORT ON AWACS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/17/world.body_text: **********President Reagan met with eight Senators today to urge them to support his proposal to sell Saudi Arabia five Awacs radar surveillance planes. **********Senator J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Alabama, announced after seeing the President that he would definitely vote to support the President and against a resolution of disapproval aimed at blocking the sale. Senator Johnston had been reckoned by several vote counters and journalistic polls as leaning in favor of the sale. **********Of the seven other Senators who went to the White House today, none announced what position he would take in a vote scheduled for early in the week of Oct. 26. But at least two Democrats, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and David L. Boren of Oklahoma, indicated they were prepared to listen to more arguments from the White House. **********The House of Representatives voted this week to disapprove the sale, and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 9 to 8 for a disapproval resolution yesterday. Outcome Difficult to Predict **********The outcome in the full Senate is difficult to predict. Most vote counts continue to show a small majority against or leaning against the sale, but White House officials say publicly that they see ''momentum'' working in the President's favor, although privately Administration lobbyists say they still have fewer than 40 firm votes. **********David R. Gergen, the senior White House spokesman, said the White House was ''encouraged'' by the closeness of the vote in the Foreign Relations Committee. He also said the President was continuing to work on the text of a letter that will be sent to senators sometime before the final vote. **********The letter will apparently contain some sort of pledge by Mr.  Reagan that before the first Awacs planes are delivered to Saudi Arabia in the fall of 1985, he will inform Congress that he has negotiated certain terms and conditions that are now said to be in the form of ''understandings.'' **********The lack of written and signed agreements on many aspects of the use and protection of the equipment in the Airborne Warning and Control System has troubled many senators. Explanations Have Differed **********The understandings with Saudi Arabia have also been explained in a number of different ways that have left confusion among some senators. Yesterday, for instance, Under Secretary of State James L.  Buckley told the Foreign Relations Committee in its last hearing on the sale that ''while there will not always be U.S. personnel on the aircraft themselves, there will be an essential continuing involvement of the U.S. military and contractor personnel in operating the Awacs system.'' **********This wording seemed different from an Oct. 1 statement by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who said that ''there will be an American presence in the aircraft'' well into the 1990's. **********The other Senators who visited the President Reagan at the White House today were Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont; Quentin N.  Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota; Howell Heflin, Democrat of Alabama; John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana. **********The White House said this brought to 24 the number of senators who had come for conversations with the President.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/08/busin.main_headline: The Week in Business; THE UNEMPLOYMENT RANKS GROW
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/08/busin.print_headline: The Week in Business; THE UNEMPLOYMENT RANKS GROW
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/08/busin.body_text: **********The unemployment rate soared to 8 percent of the work force in October from 7.5 percent the month before, the Labor Department said. The figure means that more than 8.5 million people were out of work. **********President Reagan abandoned his long-standing goal of a balanced budget by 1984. He also said he would consider new taxes in 1983 and 1984. **********New-car sales plunged 19.7 percent in the last 10 days of October and 27.2 percent for the month, the Big Three auto makers reported.  The results mean that 1981 sales will probably come in lower than 1980's. **********G.M. delayed plans to start up a $500 million assembly plant in Hamtramck, Mich. The company also declared its regular quarterly dividend of 60 cents. **********International Harvester is temporarily suspending operations next month at 16 plants in the United States and three in Canada. **********Polaroid plans to cut 1,000 from its 17,000-member work force early next year. **********Steelmakers in five foreign countries will be accused of unfair trade practices, the United States said. **********I.B.M. will pay Ford up to $200 million for the right to use some of Ford's investment tax credits and depreciation deductions. **********Marathon Oil rejected a $5 billion bid by Mobil, and a Federal judge in Ohio, citing antitrust considerations, temporarily restrained Mobil from proceeding. **********Dome Petroleum said Beaufort Sea oil drilling indicated potential recoverable reserves of 3.8 billion barrels, disappointing many analysts. Dome also plans to buy the 47 percent of Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas it doesn't already own. **********Beatrice Foods plans to purchase the beverage opertions of Northwest Industries for $600 million in cash. **********Chemical Bank was selected by Florida National Banks, a bank-holding company, as its proposed merger partner in a move toward interstate banking. **********Greenwich Savings of New York was merged with Metropolitan Savings, averting possible failure of Greenwich. **********The prime rate was cut by some major banks to 17 percent. Earlier in the week, most of them had reduced the key lending rate a half point to 17 1/2 percent. **********Retail chain stores reported meager October sales gains. Sales at Sears were up 2.1 percent. Woolworth and Montgomery Ward sales for the month slipped from October 1980. **********New orders for manufactured goods fell nine-tenths of a percent in September. **********The trade deficit on a balance-of-payments basis grew to $7.2 billion in the third quarter despite a drop in oil imports. **********The money supply fell sharply, by $3.3 billion, in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve said. **********Stocks marked time. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 852.45, off 0.10 for the week. Bond prices surged in heavy trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/26/busin.body_text: **********China has agreed to compensate Japan's Mitsubishi industrial group for scrapping a $369 million contract to build a steel rolling mill at Baoshan, near Shanghai, Mitsubishi said today. **********Mitsubishi would not specify the amount of compensation but trade sources said it would be about $39 million, around half of what the company had sought. The compensation was agreed to after seven months of talks between Mitsubishi and Chinese officials. **********China initially proposed canceling the order as part of its policy of curtailing foreign industrial contracts while it adjusted its economy. It later sought a five-year suspension but Mitsubishi insisted on the cancellation. **********Several other claims, from West German and Japanese companies, remain outstanding.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/29/busin.body_text: **********The Vulcan Materials Company, a producer of chemicals and construction aggregates, announced a major $67 million expansion of its facilities in Wichita, Kan., to increase production of chlorine, caustic soda and hydrochloric acid - three basics used widely in a variety of industries. **********Chlorine helps in water purification, caustic soda is used by the oil refining, detergent and cellophane industries, and hydrochloric acid has many users including the oil industry. **********The company said the expansion, which will be completed by late 1983, would use new technology developed by the Diamond Shamrock Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/13/world.body_text: **********Two Iranian policemen were killed outside the Soviet Embassy in Teheran today in a gun battle that brought differing explanations from the police and the official Pars news agency. **********Pars said that counter-revolutionaries were involved in the incident. It said that leaflets published by the semi-clandestine Fedayeen-e-Khalq organization had been found in a nearby building together with documents concerning the Armenian Secret Army, a guerrilla group little known in Iran that has claimed responsibility for killing Turkish diplomats in Europe. **********The police said, however, that the attackers were would-be bank robbers stopped after policemen had become suspicious of false number plates on their van. Two of the assailants were arrested and one escaped, the police added.
