https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/15/busin.body_text: **********Interest Rates Up Modestly By MICHAEL QUINT **********Short-term and long-term interest rates rose modestly yesterday, despite a decline in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market. Many analysts had expected the drop to encourage declines for other interest rates as well. **********In the money markets, dealers said that the downward pressure on rates came from the Federal Reserve's willingness to let the Federal funds rate drop to about 17 3/4 percent. But upward pressure on rates came from the increased issuing by banks of negotiable certificates of deposit, they added. **********Some dealers and investors were concerned that yesterday's bank borrowing in the C.D. market could be the harbinger of even greater borrowing in the future. ''Everybody wants to stand back and see how the banks handle the loan demands that could emerge from all the merger financing,'' one investment banker commented. Return to Markets Seen **********Other analysts contended that the bank borrowing to finance corporate mergers might not put as much upward pressure on rates as some market participants seemed to think. ''It is a zero sum game,'' one analyst said, since the money borrowed from one bank would quickly return to the financial markets as shareholders of the acquired company deposited their checks. **********Donald Miller, vice chairman at the Continental Illinois National Bank, said that ''market participants might have got a little overexercised'' about the volume of credit facilities being arranged. He added that not all the companies arranging credit lines would need to use them since several were trying to buy the same company, Conoco Inc. He said that, when the loan demands were spread over the banking system at some unknown date in the future, ''the amount needed by any one bank need not be disruptive.'' **********Yesterday, specialists said that about half of the 10 largest banks in the country were actively raising money in the domestic C.D.  market, and were paying rates as high as 17.9 percent for one-month certificates and 16.875 percent for six-month C.D.'s. As recently as last week, some banks were paying more than 18 percent for one-month certificates. As Low as 16 3/4 Percent **********Yesterday, the Federal funds rate averaged about 17 3/4 percent after being as low as 16 3/4 percent. The Federal Reserve supplied reserves to the banking system for the fifth consecutive day when it arranged temporary two-day purchases of securities. The Fed also bought $150 million of seven-year securities for its customer account. **********Investors continued to be reluctant buyers of long-term bonds yesterday, even though overnight and other short-term interest rates fell modestly. **********In the corporate bond market, investment bankers found that record yields for new triple-A rated issues of American Telephone and Telegraph subsidiaries were enough of an inducement to attract buyers for all of New York Telephone's 40-year debentures or 10-year notes.  Underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation said the 15 5/8 percent debentures due in 2021 were about three-fourths sold with a yield of 15.725 percent, while $150 million of 14 5/8 percent notes due in 1991 were about two-thirds sold at a yield of 14.749 percent to maturity. **********Among bond issues outstanding, prices were lower all day, for taxable and tax-exempt issues. The bellwether 13 7/8 percent Treasury bonds due in 2011 traded as low as 102 7/8 before closing at an offered price of 103 1/8 to yield 13.43 percent, down about seveneighths of a point on the day. Record Electric Utility Yield **********A record yield for new Baa-rated 10-year electric utility debt was established yesterday when underwriters led by Morgan Stanley said they would be selling Ohio Edison's $75 million of 16 7/8 percent bonds at 99.395 to yield 17 percent to maturity. As recently as June 30, a similar issue of Long Island Lighting bonds was sold with a 16.75 percent yield. **********In the tax-exempt market, underwriters said sales were slow for several new issues, with the notable exception of New York City. The city's bonds were priced with a top yield of 12 percent for bonds due from 1998 to 2001, a level that attracted strong demand. **********Among the proposed issues that were selling slowly, underwriters said that the terms of the Michigan State Building Authority's Arated revenue bonds might be revised to attract more buyers. Earlier this week, they proposed a top yield of 12 percent for bonds due in 2001. **********Underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb said the size of a Harris County, Tex., housing revenue bond issue was reduced to $57 million from $100 million. The bonds have a top yield of 11 percent for the 1994 maturity. **********In United States Government agency financing, the Federal Home Loan Banks announced an interest rate of 15.9 percent for $1 billion of new one-year bonds, 15.55 percent for $1 billion of three-year bonds, and 15.35 percent for $500 million of five-year bonds. All the issues are for sale today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/01/world.main_headline: ITALIAN ANTITERRORIST GENERAL IS SHOT AND KILLED IN ROME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/01/world.print_headline: ITALIAN ANTITERRORIST GENERAL IS SHOT AND KILLED IN ROME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/01/world.body_text: **********Two terrorists masquerading as delivery boys shot and killed a general in the Carabinieri paramilitary police today as the general and his wife returned home from mass in Rome, the police reported. **********A group calling itself the Communist Fighting Unit claimed responsibility for the assassination of Enrico Calvaligi, deputy commander of the Carabinieri antiterrorism force in northern Italy.  General Calvaligi, 61 years old, was also in charge of security in the maximum security prisons where convicted and suspected terrorists are held. **********A woman who telephoned the news agency ANSA indicated that the attack was a reprisal for Monday's storming by the police of a maximum security prison in Trani that had been held by the inmates.  About 70 convicts seized 18 guards as hostages, and 4 prisoners and 23 hostages and policemen were injured in the assault. **********Government sources said General Calvaligi worked closely with the Rome magistrate Giovanni D'Urso, a leading official in the national prison system who was kidnapped Dec. 12 by the Red Brigades. The Red Brigades, a leftist group that kidnapped and killed former Prime Minister Aldo Moro, have not set specific conditions for Mr. D'Urso's release, but have demanded the closing of some of Italy's penitentiaries. Police Account of Shooting **********The police gave this account of the shooting of General Calvaligi: The gunmen, in their late teens, rang the bell to the general's apartment, announcing through an intercom that they were delivering a package. After being told that the general was not home, they opened the outside gate of the apartment building and waited in the passageway leading to the front door. **********Five minutes later General Calvaligi and his wife got out of their car and entered the passageway, where one of the terrorists presented him with a basket containing eight bottles of wine. As the general handed a tip to one of the youths, the other drew a pistol and shot the general three times in the head and chest, killing him instantly. **********The killers fled in a waiting green Fiat 128, which was found abandoned an hour later about two miles north of the scene of the slaying in southern Rome. **********It was not immediately clear where the general's bodyguards were at the time of the attack.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/03/busin.main_headline: CONGRESS SET TO GIVE ADMINISTRATION TAX BILL FINAL APPROVAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/03/busin.print_headline: CONGRESS SET TO GIVE ADMINISTRATION TAX BILL FINAL APPROVAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/03/busin.body_text: **********Congress is expected to give final approval this week to an Administration-sponsored tax bill that is replete with a wide variety of special tax breaks for individuals and business, including three years of cuts in individual income tax rates. **********House and Senate tax writers reconciled differences between their respective bills in a conference that started at 4 P.M. Friday and ended at 8 A.M. Saturday. The White House pronounced President Reagan pleased with the bill and ready to sign it. **********The Senate is expected to give final approval to the conference report tomorrow. Leaders of both parties were prepared to do so in a pro forma session Saturday evening but Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, sent word from his summer home on Cape Cod that he felt the concessions made to oil producers were too generous and he wanted an opportunity to say so before the Senate acted. **********Senator Kennedy is expected to ask the Senate tomorrow to send the bill back to conference and the Senate is expected to turn him down, then vote final passage. The House meets Tuesday and is expected to approve the bill and send it along to Mr. Reagan. **********The Economic Recovery Act of 1981 is notable because for the first time Congress authorizes three rounds of reductions in individual tax rates - 5 percent on Oct. 1, 10 percent on July 1, 1982, and 10 percent on July 1, 1983. These cuts, the core of the Administration's supply-side strategy for stimulating the economy, were adopted by both houses and were not at issue in the conference. **********As passed by the House and Senate, the bill also created a new, more simple system of depreciation for business. It applies to investment made in 1981 and later. It will reduce business taxes by $10 billion in fiscal year 1982, which starts Oct. 1, and by increasing amounts every year thereafter as the pool of covered investment in buildings and equipment grows. **********In a television interview today, the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, gave this capsule assessment of the bill: ''What we are doing is really a riverboat gamble. We are gambling that this new economics will work - and it will, in my judgment.'' Following is a summary of the principal issues resolved by the House-Senate conference: Capital Gains **********The conference dropped a House provision to shorten to six months from 12 months the period an asset must be held for profits to qualify as long-term capital gains. The maximum 20 percent capital gains tax will apply to assets sold after June 9, 1981. Estate Taxes **********Broad relief from estate and gift taxes was adopted. It will affect the estates of people who die after 1981, as well as their gifts and bequests. The present $175,000 exemption for transfers (bequests and gifts) will rise to $225,000 for 1982 and an annual increment thereafter to $600,000 in 1987. The maximum tax rate on estates and gifts was reduced from 70 percent now to 65 percent for 1982, 60 percent for 1983, 55 percent for 1984 and 50 percent for 1985 and later. Tax rates in excess of 50 percent now apply to taxable transfers in excess of $2.5 million. Amounts paid for someone else's school tuition or medical care will not be taxable as gifts.  Both Houses had voted to raise the annual exclusion for gifts to any one person to $10,000 from $3,000. Stock Option **********Both Houses voted to repeal the 1976 law that imposed ordinary income tax on executive stock options if there was a gain when the option was exercised. Both Houses voted to return to prior law under which profits on stock options were taxed only when the stock is sold. For existing options issued after 1975, executives will be allowed to exercise up to $200,000 of such options under the new law but no more than $50,000 worth in one year. For options issued after 1980, executives will be allowed to exercise up to $100,000 worth a year. Of unused amounts, half may be carried over for up to three years. Options may be good for up to 10 years. The option price must equal or exceed the value of the stock at the time the option is issued. Shareholder approval is required. Interest Exclusion **********A new 15 percent exclusion of interest income will go into effect in 1985 with limits of $450 for a single tax payer and $900 for a couple filing a joint return. However, in calculating the exclusion interest, income must first be reduced by interest payments - except for payments on a home mortgage or on business borrowing. Congress adopted this ''net interest'' approach because of the growing conviction that the law should not encourage the use of credit cards and other installment credit. Such interest payments remain deductable. The present exclusion of $200 of interest and dividend income ($400 for a couple) will revert in 1982 to the old exclusion of $100/$200 for dividends only. Commodities Straddles **********The conference adopted the tougher Senate version of a provision to apply new, tighter tax rules to speculation and commodities, including the profits of professional traders. The House bill would have exempted the professionals from the tougher language. Contributions **********The 70 percent of taxpayers who take the standard deduction would be allowed a special deduction for charitable contributions. In 1982-83, they would be allowed to deduct 25 percent of contributions up to $100 each year. In 1984, taxpayers would be allowed 25 percent up to $300. In 1985 they would be allowed to deduct 50 percent of contributions with no upper limit and in 1986 they would be allowed to deduct 100 percent without limit. The authority would lapse after 1986 unless renewed by Congress. Child-Care Credit **********The law now permits a credit for child care of 20 percent of expenses up to $2,000 for each of two or more children. The conference, working from a Senate provision, increased the credit to 30 percent for families with income under $10,000, with a reduction of one percentage point for every $2,000 of income from $10,000 to $30,000. The limits against which the credit may be applied are $2,400 of expenses for one child and $4,800 for two or more. Thus, the maximum credit for a family under $10,000 is $1,440. For a family above $30,000, the maximum credit is $960. Transit Bonds **********Public transit authorities such as the Metropolitan Transit Authority in New York may issue tax-exempt bonds to finance the purchase of buses and subway cars. By leasing the equipment from private companies, the transit authorities - themselves not Federal taxpayers - receive the cost reductions that flow from the 10 percent investment tax credit and the new, more generous depreciations. House Sales **********The conferees lengthened to 24 months from 18 months the period before or after the sale of a house or apartment in which the seller can avoid taxes on any profit by buying another residence of equal or greater value. The conferees also increased to $125,000 from $100,000 now the one-time exemption of profits on the sale of a home by persons aged 55 or older. Retirement Savings **********The maximum amount that may be paid into individual retirement accounts will rise in 1982 to $2,000 from $1,500 now. In addition, workers who are covered by an employer's pension plan will be allowed to make deductible contributions to an I.R.A., or may claim the deduction for money paid into the pension plan. Americans Abroad **********The conferees agreed to let Americans living and working abroad exclude up to $75,000 of wage and salary income in 1982, with the exclusion rising by $5,000 a year, to $95,000 in 1986. Eligibility is confined to persons who spent ll of 12 months outside the United States, or who had established a bona fide residence abroad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/02/world.main_headline: PEKING STRESSES ECONOMIC GAINS AS PARTY PRIORITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/02/world.print_headline: PEKING STRESSES ECONOMIC GAINS AS PARTY PRIORITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/02/world.body_text: **********The Chinese Communist Party has published a platform of party goals that appeal to almost everyone except people opposed to continued Communist rule of China. **********The platform calls for slow but steady economic development and improvement of living standards, gradual extension of democracy under party control, a loose mix of public and private enterprise, a legal system that guarantees people's rights, a commitment to intellectual achievement, protection of religious freedom, a modernized army as the economy improves and more autonomy for ethnic minorities. **********At a rally in the Great Hall of the People today, the new party chairman, Hu Yaobang, said that China would stress the role of competent managers in a new era of orderly economic development and would no longer tolerate a single all-powerful ruler like Mao Zedong. (Page A12.) **********Problem of 'Degenerate Elements' The party platform calls for ''weeding out degenerate elements who oppress and bully the people.'' But, the platform warns, ''any word or deed which denies or undermines'' the party's leadership and its commitment to Communism ''cannot be tolerated.'' **********The statement of goals and policies is contained in a book-size assessment of the party's successes and mistakes being made public on the 60th anniversary of the party's founding in Shanghai in July 1921. The party assessment acknowledges major errors by party officials, including Mao, and pledges never allow them to happen again. **********Endorsed Saturday by the Central Committee, the platform amounts to an official endorsement of the policies that Deng Xiaoping, the party's senior deputy chairman and China's most powerful leader, set forth in December 1978, declaring political struggle to be subordinate to the goal of upgrading the living standards of China's one billion people. **********Political struggles have continued since then. Mr. Deng has forced supporters of radical Maoism out of power and shunted others aside in a systematic campaign to put supporters of his policies in leadership roles. That struggle reached a watershed of sorts on Monday when Mr.  Hu, a protege of Mr. Deng, was named party chairman replacing Hua Guofeng, a staunch supporter of Maoist policies that are now officially declared to have been wrong. **********The party's platform affirms Mr. Deng's goal of modernizing China ''systematically and in stages'' without resorting to unrealistic campaigns that in the past resulted in ''colossal waste and losses.'' **********It says that anyone who opposes Communism for China ''is wrong,'' but it calls for modifications to suit China's conditions.  Without the Communist Party in control, the platform says, ''our country, for a variety of reasons, both internal and external, would inexorably fall apart.'' Although the party will make mistakes, ''in no case should one use the party's mistakes as a pretext for weakening, breaking away from or even sabotaging its leadership,'' the document says. **********The platform says the biggest mistake the party made in the past was dwelling on class struggles against exploiters when they had long been basically wiped out, and not shifting in the 1950's to the goal of economic development. Private Enterprise Encouraged **********Although state enterprises and planning will predominate in China, the report said, private enterprise and market forces must complement and help government-run efforts to increase production. It urges flexibility, saying, ''There is no rigid pattern for the development of socialist relations of production.'' **********The party's political goals, the report says, include ''gradual establishment of a highly democratic socialist political system'' that will ''gradually realize direct popular participation'' in grassroots democracy. The neglect of democracy in the past, it says, helped foster the feudal-like rule of individuals like Mao and his wife, Jiang Qing, during the Cultural Revolution. **********On the rule of law, the platform says: ''We must turn the socialist legal system into a powerful instrument for protecting the rights of the people, insuring order in production, work and other spheres, punishing criminals and cracking down on the disruptive activities of class enemies. The kind of chaotic situation that obtained in the Cultural Revolution must never be allowed to happen again in any sphere.'' Appeal to Intellectuals **********In an appeal to intellectuals, who were punished during the Cultural Revolution simply because they were educated, the party platform says: **********''We must firmly eradicate utterly fallacious views that denigrate education, science and culture, and discriminate against intellectuals.'' **********The party, it says, needs people who are both ''red and expert.'' In the past, being red meant being a good Communist and that was thought better than being an expert. **********The platform says that China's ethnic minorities, made up of 60 million people spread over half of the nation's territory, were gravely wronged during the Cultural Revolution by party leaders who attempted to force them to give up customs and traditions and adher to Communist practice. **********''We did not show due respect for their right to autonomy,'' the platform says. ''We must never forget that lesson.'':

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/world.main_headline: SOVIET JEWS FOUND TO RETAIN IDENTITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/world.print_headline: SOVIET JEWS FOUND TO RETAIN IDENTITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/world.body_text: **********An unusual opinion survey of 1,500 Jews in the Soviet Union has found a high degree of Jewish identity and interest in Jewish culture, even among those who oppose emigration to Israel. **********An analysis of the results, issued recently by an Israeli research institute, reported that most of the Soviet Jews who condemned emigration said that they would nevertheless like thier children to learn Yiddish or Hebrew. They also said that they would like to be able to buy books on Jewish history and that they would frequent Jewish cafes and dining halls if they existed. **********The survey was privately organized by Jewish dissidents in 1976 to test the feelings about Jewishness among the large majority of Soviet Jews who had not taken steps to emigrate. Anyone who had applied for an exit visa was excluded from the poll. **********Data Analyzed Only Recently **********The data, smuggled out of the Soviet Union in 1977, was not processed until recently, when a private organization that does research on Jewish affairs, known as the Center Jewish Community, ran it through a computer and presented it to Israeli experts for analysis. **********The organization's report concluded that the study's main weakness was its sample, which could be neither random nor scientifically selected because of the Soviet Government's opposition to polling outside official auspices. **********Benjamin Fain, a physicist now at Tel Aviv University who organized the survey when he still lived in Moscow, said a questionnaire had been developed with the help of a Soviet anthropologist, Mikhail Chlenov, and a sociologist, who asked to remain anonymous. About 100 volunteer interviewers collected responses in different parts of the Soviet Union from Jews they knew or happened to meet. **********The polling method may have produced a bias in the sample toward those among the Soviet Union's 1.8 million Jews counted in the last census who felt their Jewishness more keenly than others. Most aspects of Jewish culture are suppressed by Soviet authorities, including Hebrew language instruction, religion, Jewish holiday celebration and the like, and many Jews regard themselves as assimilated into Russian culture. Material Escaped K.G.B. Searches **********Nevertheless, the Israeli report said, the study produced ''the only systematic data on Soviet Jews collected outside of Government sources.'' The K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence agency, confiscated all the response sheets, Mr. Fain said, but duplicate copies of 1,216 of the 1,500 had already been made and escaped the searches. **********The 1,216 responses reflected a spread of ages, economic levels and educational backgrounds approximating the Jewish population as a whole. Most answered affirmatively to questions on their sense of Jewishness: 77.8 percent said they would have an aversion to a close relative marrying a non-Jew, and 85.3 percent wanted their children or grandchildren to learn Yiddish or Hebrew. **********On similar questions, 55.7 percent said they would be willing to choose a Jewish name for a son; 86 percent said they would like their children to go to Jewish schools; 81.6 percent thought it would be desirable to establish a Russian langauge periodical on Jewish subjects; 59.3 percent observed some or all of the Jewish holidays, and 61.3 percent said they felt some connection with Jews abroad. **********The attitudes toward emigration divided along lines of region and age, with the small number opposing departure for Israel - 7.2 percent of the sample - being generally over 60 and from the Crimea and central Byelorussia, near Poland. Fifty-eight percent of the respondents said they believed emigration to Israel was a method of relating to Jewish life, and 34.8 percent saw it as a way to flee discrimination and improve living standards. **********The respondents were split on the desirability of having ''nationality'' listed on Soviet internal passports, which now label citizens as ''Russian,'' ''Jewish,'' ''Ukrainian'' and the like.  Sixty percent wanted the nationality deleted from the passports, 40 percent did not. **********A rule that would allow Jews to list themselves under any nationality would be welcomed by 47.8 percent, but only 17.3 percent said that they would want their children listed as other than Jewish. Even of those who would not list their children as Jewish, 93 percent said they would like to buy books on Jewish history. And 89 percent of those opposing immigration expressed the same inclination. **********''This points to the conclusion,'' the report said, ''that even the many Jews in the Soviet Union who would register their children as non-Jews and who condemn immigration to Israel probably want more opportunities for Jewish culture and association than are now available to them. That finding contradicts some of our earlier notions about Soviet Jews and clearly suggests that we should increase our efforts to prepare appropriate materials and find ways to get them to Jews behind the Iron Curtain.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/21/world.main_headline: SENATE TO MOVE ON STATE DEPT. NOMINATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/21/world.print_headline: SENATE TO MOVE ON STATE DEPT. NOMINATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/21/world.body_text: **********The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will begin confirmation hearings tomorrow on a number of key State Department appointments that have been delayed by political opposition from Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. **********After three months in office, President Reagan's White House advisers and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. have decided that further delays in confirmation of senior State Department officials would weaken United States foreign policy. **********The Senate has yet to confirm White House nominations for such major posts as undersecretary of state for economic affairs and the assistant secretaries of the regional bureaus for Europe, East Asia and the Pacific, the Near East and South Asia, Africa and Latin America. **********The delay in confirmation of the regional assistant secretaries has held up the Reagan Administration's nomination of new ambassadors, with the exception of John J. Louis, an Illinois Republican who was named ambassador to Britain. **********Envoy to Saudi Arabia Named **********Today, Mr. Reagan nominated Robert G. Neumann, a former Ambassador to Afghanistan and Morocco, as ambassador to Saudi Arabia. Mr.  Neumann directed the Reagan transition team at the State Department. **********Senior advisers to Mr. Haig who have been designated but not confirmed have had to carry out missions abroad without the full authority of Senate confirmation. One of them, Chester Crocker, nominated to be assistant secretary of state for Africa, is scheduled to complete a tour of 11 African countries tomorrow. **********Mr. Crocker has been criticized on his trip by black African Governments as well as by South Africa, which is strongly supported by Senator Helms. The black nations are pressing for a United Nations Security Council meeting to consider South Africa's resistance to a Security Council plan for internationally supervised elections in South-West Africa, also known as Namibia. **********Mr. Crocker, who came under sharp questioning from Senator Helms during an initial hearing on April 6, will go before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee again next Monday. Democrats Predict Approval **********Senate Democratic sources said that they expected the State Department appointments to be approved by the committee, with liberal Democrats lining up with moderate Republicans behind Mr. Reagan's nominees. **********Senator Alan Cranston, the Senate Democrtic leader from California, said during the first hearing for Mr. Crocker that it was a ''disservice'' to United States foreign policy for the confirmation to be delayed ''by a barrage of questions from one Senator,'' a reference to Mr. Helms. **********The Senate Democratic minority refused to begin discussion of the Administration's foreign assistance authorization bill for the 1982 fiscal year before the White House sent up the names of key State Department nominees for confirmation. **********Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, the committee chairman, then joined senior State Department officials who have been confirmed, such as the Deputy Secretary of State, William P. Clark, in urging the White House to send in all nominations with completed security checks. Panel to Question Trade Expert **********The confirmation hearing schedule announced by the committee opens tomorrow with Myer Rashish, a Washington trade expert who has been named to be undersecretary for economic affairs, and Robert D.  Hormats, a career diplomat chosen to be assistant secretary for economic affairs. **********Next Monday, in addition to Mr. Crocker, the committee will question John H. Holdridge, a career diplomat named to be assistant secretary for East Asian and Pacific affairs. **********These hearings will be followed next week by committee questioning of Lawrence S. Eagleburger, a senior adviser to former Secretary of State Henry A. Kis-singer and a nominee to be assistant secretary for European affairs. Nicholas A. Veliotes, a career dioplomat whose last post was Ambassador to Jordan, will be questioned on his nomination as assistant secretary for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs. **********The White House has not yet nominated an assistant secretary for inter-American affairs, although Mr. Haig has indicated that his choice is Thomas O. Enders, United States representative at the European Economic Community in Brussels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/world.main_headline: ISRAELI AND P.L.O. RAIDS DISTRESS MANY U.S. JEWS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/world.print_headline: ISRAELI AND P.L.O. RAIDS DISTRESS MANY U.S. JEWS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/world.body_text: **********Widespread distress among American Jews over the increased fighting in the Middle East, including the Israeli bombing of Beirut, was indicated by an informal survey yesterday, with a number of spokesmen urging a cease-fire and negotiations. **********Howard M. Squadron, chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations and president of the American Jewish Congress, said ''the ultimate solution is to be found'' when Arab countries accept Israel's right to exist and ''give up on the notion of erasing it.'' **********According to the Lebanese authorities, 300 people were killed and 800 wounded in last Friday's bombing by Israeli jets of sections of Beirut said by the Israelis to contain Palestinian guerrilla headquarters. The bombing was followed by rocket attacks on Israel, and the two sides have continued fighting since. **********In Boston, Leonard Fein, editor of Moment, a Jewish monthly, contended that the Beirut bombing was ''utterly without redeeming social or strategic value and an absolute violation of community standards.'' He asserted that Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel did not seem to acknowledge ''the urgent need for a political solution.'' 'Moral Outrage' at Bombing **********In Los Angeles, Rabbi Leonard I. Beerman of Leo Baeck Temple said that many people felt ''moral outrage'' at the bombing. He said Mr.  Begin's ''policy represents a danger'' to Jewish ideals and ''plays into the hands of Israel's enemies,'' giving them ''sympathy which they desperately need.'' **********The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations has invited Ephraim Evron, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, to give it a briefing today. Its meeting was originally scheduled to oppose a planned Reagan Administration arms package for Saudi Arabia. **********Rabbi Israel Miller of Orange, N.J., past chairman of the conference, expressed ''sincere sorrow'' over the civilian losses in Beirut, but noted that the Palestine Liberation Organization was ''conducting a war'' that resulted in civilian casualties in Israel. **********''I still don't think we have all of the facts about why Israel did what it did,'' Rabbi Miller said. But he said that talks in the Camp David process begun by Israel and Egypt must continue to ''arrive at an equitable solution to enable peace.'' Schindler Blames the P.L.O. **********Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, said responsibility for civilian casualties must be shared by Palestinians who ''put their military deliberately in civilian quarters.'' He asserted that the P.L.O. had ''consistently refused to come to the negotiating table'' and that it had killed Palestinians who desired peace. **********Bertram H. Gold, executive vice president of the American Jewish Committee, said there was ''deep anguish over the loss of innocent civilian lives, be they Lebanese, Palestinian or Israeli.'' He saw ''unanimous hope that our country's efforts to obtain a sustained cease-fire in the area meet with success.'' **********In Philadelphia, David Tulin, president of the 3,000-member Americans for Progressive Israel, noted two issues: ''How to stop terrorism and how to protect the Jewish value system.'' Israel, he said, should declare that it would ''negotiate with any Palestinian group that recognizes the right of the Jewish state to exist and that ends all terrorist acts.'' **********Rabbi William Berkowitz, president of the Jewish National Fund, said the P.L.O. was operating out of southern Lebanon with the collusion of Syria and with increasing supplies of Soviet-bloc and Libyan weapons. He said the United States' suspension of the delivery of F-16 planes to Israel should be reversed because it slapped Washington's most ''reliable Middle East ally'' and sent ''misleading signals.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/17/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge lifted a temporary restraining order against Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. yesterday, allowing the brokerage firm to distribute profits made by customers who bought Amax Inc. options. **********Judge Morris E. Lasker acted after apparently receiving information he had sought from the brokerage firm regarding the transactions in which Amax call options were bought by clients in the days preceding a takeover offer on March 5 from the Standard Oil Company of California. **********Dean Witter and A.G. Becker Inc., another brokerage firm, were among the defendants in a suit filed by O'Connor & Associates, a Chicago options trading firm, which alleged that some purchasers of the options had inside information about the offer. **********Judge Lasker lifted an identical order against Becker last week after receiving information about trades by its clients.  The action, which did not end O'Connor's suit, enabled clients to collect the profits they made by trading Amax options.  Socal offered $4 billion to buy the 80 percent of Amax stock it does not already own, and the price of the stock soared. The price of options also rose. An option to buy Amax at $50 a share this month, for example, rose from 12.5 cents to $9. **********In a related development yesterday, Dean Witter said that a weeklong internal investigation into the O'Connor charges had ''discovered no evidence to indicate the knowlege or use of any 'inside' information by anyone employed by our firm.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/09/busin.main_headline: COST OF 'DUMB' TERMINALS FALLS AS IMPORTS INCREASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/09/busin.print_headline: COST OF 'DUMB' TERMINALS FALLS AS IMPORTS INCREASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/09/busin.body_text: **********Computer terminals, which resemble television sets in outward appearance, are beginning to resemble them in another way as well: The terminal industry, like the television industry before it, faces competition from low-priced products made in the Far East, and American manufacturers are starting to move their own operations to stay competitive. **********At the National Computer Conference, an industry show held here this week, manufacturers displayed several new terminals with list prices of $650 to $700, about $200 lower than prices of equivalent terminals a year ago. Many of the new products were partly or completely made overseas. **********"The advent of offshore manufacturing has created a whole new threshold of pricing," said Edward Jeran, director of computer terminal sales for the Hazeltine Corporation.  His company is one of the largest American terminal makers aside from computer manufacturers such as the International Business Machines Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation. **********Behind Mr. Jeran, in the center of Hazeltine's booth at the conference, were streamers proclaiming the introduction of the company's $695 Esprit terminal, which was designed and manufactured in Taiwan. **********There are some discrepancies in the terminal/television parallel. A flood of low-priced television imports from Japan and elsewhere in the Far East in the 1970's led American manufacturers to move assembly operations overseas.  With terminals, the major manufacturers have been South Korean and Taiwanese companies, not Japanese, and rather than export under their own names, the makers are selling components or entire terminals to United States companies to market. **********The fiercest competition is in the low end of the market, the so-called dumb terminals.  These are used to enter data and instructions into a computer and to display the output of a computer, but they have no capabilities to operate when not attached to a computer. Industry officials and analysts say that with few special features, the dumb terminals compete mainly on the basis of price in a crowded marketplace.  There are about 25 independent manufacturers of dumb terminals, and they shipped 250,000 to 300,000 units last year, according to Gnostic Concepts Inc., a Menlo Park, Calif., market research firm. (The company's name comes from the Greek word gnosis, meaning knowledge.) **********"The dumb terminal is almost a commodity item," said Robert H.  Katzive, program manager for computer projects at Gnostic Concepts.  "The more commodity-like it becomes, the more likely it is for production to move offshore." U. S. Concern Started Price Cuts **********The latest round of price reductions was started by an American company, Applied Digital Data Systems Inc., which introduced a $650 terminal in March.  The Hauppauge, L. I., company, was acquired last year by the NCR Corporation, invested heavily to integrate vertically, building a plant in Utah that manufactures and assembles virtually all the components of a terminal. **********The competition was not far behind.  In addition to Hazeltine, Televideo Systems Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., introduced an unsophisticated terminal this week with some components made in Korea. **********Televideo, which is headed by K. Philip Hwang, a Korean-born engineer, was actually the first company to take advantage of low-cost parts made in Korea.  Two years ago the company introduced a low-cost smart terminal--one that allows the user to edit what is on the screen-- and quickly became an industry leader in the sector. **********The Ampex Corporation, which has had Far Eastern manufacturing operations for 20 years, has also started to make terminals in Taiwan. **********Lear Siegler Inc., which in l979 was the largest independent supplier of dumb terminals, according to estimates by Gnostic Concepts, has not responded to the price reductions yet.  Suddenly, however, Lear Siegler finds itself with a product that costs $200 more than many comparable models, and it is debating its next move. But the company feels that its size will help protect its market, at least for a while. Adding Features **********Company officials say Lear Siegler has tried to cut manufacturing costs and has been buying more components overseas in the past two years. The company has also tried to add special features to its terminals, like the ability to recognize voices.  But those steps are not sufficient, the officials believe.  William A. Terry, president of Lear Siegler's data products division, said the company would respond to competition more vigorously in the next few months.  There was speculation that Lear Siegler would buy a complete low-end terminal from a foreign manufacturer and market it in the United States. **********Falling prices have made the terminal market an inhospitable one for some companies.  Just last week, the Perkin-Elmer Corporation announced it was halting sales of terminals for use in its own computer systems. "It was a profitable operation, but we feel the margins aren't there," a company spokesman said. U. S. Retains Some Advantages Those in the industry say American companies will remain competitive in more sophisticated terminals, where much of the value is in software and special features, rather than hardware. **********A big question is whether the Japanese will enter the market in a big way.  Some, like Mr. Terry of Lear Siegler and Richard DuBridge, executive vice president of Televideo, do not expect that, arguing that the market is not big enough to interest the Japanese. **********Others, however, note that Japanese companies already make video display tubes that are used in terminals, including one made by I. B. M.  The Japanese companies also make sophisticated color display tubes, and since more and more terminals are being made with color capability, the Japanes stand to benefit. **********A French company, Alcatel-Electronique, is also gearing up to export terminals selling for a few hundred dollars or less, but companies in the market now say those terminals are aimed primarily at the home information-retrieval market, not the data-processing market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/03/world.main_headline: PREMIER OF FINLAND GAINS AMID CRITICISM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/03/world.print_headline: PREMIER OF FINLAND GAINS AMID CRITICISM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/03/world.body_text: **********To the consternation of his political foes, Finland's Prime Minister has survived a clash with President Urho Kekkonen, and has pulled even further ahead in opinion polls as the most likely successor to the President. **********''They made him Prime Minister in the hope that he would fail,'' a Finnish diplomat remarked the other day, ''and they are trying to topple him.'' **********For the moment, however, Mauno Koivisto, a 57-year-old Social Democrat on leave from his regular post as governor of the Bank of Finland, appears to have won the latest round of what is known in Finland as the ''presidential game.'' While no presidential election is scheduled until February 1984, the ''game'' has taken on urgency for Mr. Koivisto's rivals because the Prime Minister's popularity has continued to grow as the attacks on him increase. **********'Rises Above Party Politics' **********One reason was suggested last month by the Helsinki newspaper Uusi Suomi, which said that Mr. Koivisto managed once again during a television appearance to impress his viewers as a ''good-natured conciliator who rises above party politics.'' **********Although leading politicians, including even some Social Democrats, oppose him, the Prime Minister, with a quiet manner and the rugged appearance of an outdoorsman, has attracted wide support from rankand-file members across party lines. **********President Kekkonen, who is 80 and in his 26th year in office, is generally regarded as in his last term. He would apparently like to be succeeded by someone from his agrarian Center Party. However, public opinion polls show Mr. Koivisto outdistancing even President Kekkonen in popularity. The President has told visitors privately that he views Mr. Koivisto as a man who is unable to make a decision. **********The clash between the President and Prime Minister erupted April 2 when Mr. Kekkonen summoned Mr. Koivisto and reportedly accused him of holding up legislation dealing with budget matters. The next day Mr.  Kekkonen was described as wanting a change in Prime Ministers. Dispute Over Social Welfare **********The President's attitude was made known by Aarne Saarinen, the chairman of the Communist Party, upon emerging from the presidential residence, where he had gone to discuss a Cabinet problem. The Communist-dominated Finnish People's Democratic League, a member of the Koivisto-led coalition of Social Democrats, Centrists, Swedish People's Party members and an independent, had been balking at a proposal affecting social welfare. **********The Saarinen statement that Mr. Kekkonen had denounced the Prime Minister caused a storm in Finland but was not disavowed by the President. Finnish newspapers reported for days that the Koivisto coalition's days were numbered. But Mr. Koivisto refused to resign, creating what some experts described as a constitutional crisis unheard of in Finland, where a clash between President and Prime Minister had usually led to the Prime Minister's resignation. A Settlement Worked Out **********As the crisis appeared to be creating anti-Kekkonen feeling while adding to Mr. Koivisto's popularity, a settlement was worked out.  Officially, it was announced that the budgetary dispute would be left to Parliament to decide. It was generally understood, however, that Mr. Koivisto had won a round. **********The attacks on Mr. Koivisto apparently are continuing. Foreign Minister Paavo Vayrynen, who is chairman of the President's Center Party, stressed in a recent speech that it was absolutely necessary for Finland's President to have foreign-policy experience, since the chief of state conducts the nation's foreign policy in accordance with the Constitution. **********This was interpreted as an attack on Mr. Koivisto, who has served as Finance Minister twice and who is now in his second term as Prime Minister. His first term as head of government lasted from 1968 to 1970. **********Last Sunday, Mr. Vayrynen, in another apparent jab at Mr. Koivisto, said that the Center Party would continue to back Mr. Kekkonen for re-election as long as the President was willing to run.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.body_text: **********A judge has been appointed to the court that will hear charges against six soldiers accused of the murders of three American nuns and a Roman Catholic lay worker, officials said today. **********Justice Ministry officials said Mario Adalberto Rivera Lazo had been appointed to the judgship in the southeastern province of Zacatecoluca, the legal jurisdiction where the four missionaries were killed Dec. 2. The Zacatecoluca provincial judgeship had been vacant since mid-April, when Judge Hector E. Jimenez, who began a preliminary investigation into the slayings, was transferred to San Salvador to work on another case involving assassinated Americans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/13/busin.body_text: **********Giant Food Stores Inc. said that it had entered final negotiations for the sale of the company to Ahold, the Netherlands' largest food retailer. **********No purchase price was disclosed and the acquisition is subject to a final agreement, said Lee Javitch, chairman of Giant.  Giant Food Stores, a privately held company, operates 29 stores in Pennsylvania, Maryland and West Virginia. The company had $266 million in sales in the 1981 fiscal year ended last April. **********Ahold, with 700 stores in the Netherlands and 28 in Spain, has 38,000 employees and had 1980 sales of $2.8 billion. It operates food manufacturing and restaurant divisions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/03/busin.body_text: **********J. Terrence Lanni has been elected president and chief operating officer of both Caesars World and its Caesars New Jersey subsidiary, it was announced by the two companies. **********The companies also said that Mr. Lanni, 38, would act as chief executive officer of the two corporations until a New Jersey court determines whether Clifford S. Perlman, who has been on leave from the posts of chairman and chief executive officer, can return to the positions. **********The New Jersey Casino Control Commission ruled last October that it would grant a permanent gaming license to the company's Boardwalk Regency Casino in Atlantic City only if the company offered a plan for the orderly disposal of the 16 percent ownership of Caesars World held by Mr. Perlman and his brother Stuart Z., who took a leave of absence from his post as vice chairman. **********The Perlmans have appealed the ruling but have taken unpaid leaves of absence pending the court decision.  Mr. Lanni is replacing William H. McElnea Jr., who resigned as president and chief executive of the two companies last week. Mr.  Lanni joined Caesars World in January 1977 as treasurer and chief financial officer. **********Mr. Lanni said in an interview that his appointment ''does not signal any change in the direction of the company.'' Some analysts have suggested that Caesars may decide to sell its casino in Atlantic City. Mr. Lanni said that such a matter was ''purely for the board of directors to decide. '' **********The boards of both companies also selected Harold D. Berkowitz to take on the functions of chairman and M. Peter Schweitzer those of vice chairman until the courts resolved the positions of both Perlman brothers.

About 350 workers will be given notice this week and the remainder will be released over the next three months, the company said. McDonnell Douglas Canada said employment at its Toronto plant, where wings and other components for the parent company's DC-10 airliners are built, is more than 3,800.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/30/busin.main_headline: REAGAN REPORTED PARING $30 BILLION FROM 1983 BUDGET
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/30/busin.print_headline: REAGAN REPORTED PARING $30 BILLION FROM 1983 BUDGET
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/30/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan has reportedly approved cuts of more than $30 billion in his projected 1983 budget but has been told by the Office of Management and Budget that there still will be a deficit of roughly $110 billion unless there are tax increases. **********The deficit for the 1982 fiscal year, now three months old, was projected by the budget office at about $99 billion, Administration officials said today. They emphasized that this figure was subject to re-estimation of revenue and spending. In any case, officials say that there is little the Administration can do now to affect 1982 outlays. Mr. Reagan has ruled out flatly any tax increase before the fiscal year ends on Sept. 30, 1982. **********As for 1983 and beyond, the Office of Management and Budget said in a memorandum to the President before he left for California last weekend that unless additional revenues are raised the budget deficit will persist in the range of $100 billion to $120 billion each fiscal year through 1986. Campaign for Tax Increases **********The memorandum appeared to be part of a continuing campaign by David A. Stockman, the budget director; James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, and Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, to persuade Mr. Reagan that fiscal prudence and a declining deficit trend require some selective tax increases. **********Federal health and budget officials also said today that the President wants Congress to authorize a modest charge for care given under the Medicaid program and will seek further reductions in the Federal subsidy for school lunch programs. (Page D14.) **********Mr. Reagan is determined to make no change in the three-year tax cut he sponsored and signed earlier this year and has otherwise professed to be deeply opposed to any form of tax rise. Yet, he has several times signaled that his view might be changed. **********For example, in an interview with several reporters on Dec. 23 he left open the possibility of an increase in excise taxes on tobacco, alcoholic beverages and possibly gasoline. **********''I don't think that consumption taxes are in direct opposition to the tax pro-gram we have instituted,'' Mr. Reagan said in the interview. In the past, the Administration has stressed its view of the importance to economic activity of reduced income tax rates. **********Pressed on excise taxes, Mr. Reagan added, ''If necessity could convince me that they had to be put into effect, I'd be more tolerant of those.'' Then he added, as he often does, ''I would not look kindly on any tax increase.'' **********Administration officials said that the White House has delayed submission of the budget for the fiscal year 1983 from Feb. 1 to Feb. 8 to give the budget office more time to prepare material that will explain proposed cuts in ''entitlements,'' which are expected to run to roughly $14 billion. **********Entitlements are benefits that individuals meeting certain criteria receive automatically. Under present law, such spending in the fiscal year 1982, which began Oct. 1, will total $200 billion for programs other than Social Security. **********The entitlement cuts will affect Medicare, Medicaid, food stamps, school lunches and the formula for annual cost-of-living increases in civil service pensions, an Administration official said. Rather than a uniform across-the-board slash, each program will be narrowed and trimmed in particular ways. The White House evidently plans to take pains to explain these proposed changes to Congress, interest groups and the news media in hopes of softening opposition. Protected Benefits **********Omitted from the proposed list of cuts will be Social Security, unemployment insurance and black-lung benefits for miners, officials said. Congress tightened up on jobless benefits last summer and has just passed a bill revising black-lung benefits. Social Security payments of old-age, survivor and disability benefits are expected to climb from $158 billion in the fiscal year 1982 to $176.5 billion in the fiscal year 1983. After taking a political battering on his proposed Social Security cuts of last spring, Mr. Reagan has put off any further such effort until after the 1982 elections. The budget office estimated that under present law these outlays would reach $215 billion in 1986. **********Before leaving for his California ranch, Mr. Reagan resolved pending budget appeals, leaving for January decisions on whether to seek additional revenue and, if so, how. His proposed cuts were described by an Administration source as being ''in the low thirties.'' Some experts said this figure could be revised for a variety of reasons before the budget goes to the Government Printing Office. **********The President's decisions would reduce spending in some cases, particularly for entitlements, not from present levels but from the level spending would climb to if the law were unchanged. In such cases, 1983 spending could be ''cut'' and still be higher than in 1982. These proposed reductions would be in addition to the $35 billion of cuts Congress made last summer in the Budget Reconciliation Act. **********A bit more than half the budget cuts were in so-called discretionary programs, where Congress can cut spending without revising basic law. For example, spending for most energy programs would be cut by roughly one-third from 1981 levels to $2.8 billion in 1983. All major energy programs except the strategic oil reserve and nuclear weapons would be hit. **********The deficits projected in the memorandum to the President were based on an economic forecast described by an official as ''reasonable but on the optimistic side'' as well as an assumption that Congress would make all of the proposed entitlement and spending cuts. Because of the upward trend of some benefit programs under present law, the annual savings attributable to the proposed benefit cutbacks would in some cases increase over time. The budget office projected those savings at roughly $50 billion a year for 1984-86. **********Untouched in the budget exercise so far has been military spending. Under a decision by the President in late summer, Defense Department spending for military functions (a category that excludes nuclear weapons, now under the Department of Energy) must not exceed ceilings of $181.8 billion for 1982, $214.9 billion for 1983 and $242.6 billion for 1984. **********Mr. Stockman, it was understood, would be happy to see those levels reduced but has thought it unwise to reopen the campaign for retrenchment he waged publicly last summer with limited effect.  Moreover, there is some feeling in budget-making circles that it is more important to cut back not the 1983-84 spending rates but the spending authority for later years provided in the annual military appropriations. By 1986, according to some experts, military spending will reach $325 billion, a rise of one-third above the 1984 level.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/14/world.main_headline: FRENCH BEGIN VOTE FOR ASSEMBLY TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/14/world.print_headline: FRENCH BEGIN VOTE FOR ASSEMBLY TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/14/world.body_text: **********Having elected Francois Mitterrand as President a month ago, the French will begin a two-stage vote tomorrow to determine the composition of the National Assembly. **********All indications are that the Socialist Party will take control of the legislature, replacing the present conservative majority. It may not be clear until a week from tomorrow, after the second stage of the vote, whether the Socialists will obtain a majority. Short of this, they are generally expected to win a plurality sufficiently strong to allow passage of Mr. Mitterrand's legislative programs. **********Although the Socialist Government has already used its decree powers to take a number of steps toward economic and social change, it will require parliamentary approval to achieve the kind of national transformation it aims at. **********The National Assembly, the lower but actually the effective house in the bicameral French Parliament, has 491 seats, all of which are at stake in the elections. At present the two conservative parties, the Gaullist Rally for the Republic and the Union for French Democracy, hold 274 seats; the Socialists hold 117, the Communists 86 and assorted independents 14. Polls Show Gain for Socialists **********Recent polls have given the Socialists, who obtained 24 percent of the vote in the 1978 legislative elections, anywhere between 32 and 36 percent. These percentages, if they hold through the two rounds of the voting, would give the Socialist Party and its small centrist ally, the Radical Left Movement, anywhere between 200 and 250 seats. **********The Communists, whose predicted percentage has ranged between 13 and 16 percent, could drop to somewhere between 40 and 60 seats. The two conservative parties, which are for the most part putting up a single candidate in each district but have otherwise failed to heal their deep splits, could get 200 to 230 seats, according to these estimates. **********In the two-stage system here, a candidate must obtain a majority of the votes cast tomorrow to win a seat. If there is no majority, the vote eliminates all but the two top-running candidates. The second vote chooses between the two and decides the seat. Because the right has managed to run a joint list, for the most part, its candidates, if they do not win outright, should make it to the finals in almost every district. The Socialists and the Communists, on the other hand, are running separate lists. **********Because of this, the main significant result of tomorrow's vote, aside from establishing percentages for the left and right, will be to determine the number of districts in which the Socialists displace the Communists as the front-runners on the left, thus qualifying as finalists in the second round on June 21. Plans for Cabinet Unclear **********The Communists seem likely to support most of the Socialist legislation, whether or not Mr. Mitterrand decides to name two or three Communist ministers to his post-election cabinet. His intentions in this question - one of strong interest to Washington and Bonn - are unknown, even to close associates. **********Still, the relative strength of Socialists and Communists is important, since it will affect the degree to which Mr. Mitterrand will be dependent on Communist support. The indications are that he will be able to do without it, if necessary. Even if the Socialist-Radical Left alliance is short of an Assembly majority by 20 or 30 seats, it should be possible to pick up needed votes from some elements among the conservative groups. **********After the intensive and emotional campaigning that preceded the presidential elections, the Assembly campaign has aroused relatively little interest. The Socialists' theme has been that by choosing Mr.  Mitterrand, France has decided for genuine change. Appealing to logic - one of the good appeals to make in a French election - the Socialists argue that the voters should now give Mr. Mitterrand the legislative means to make the changes. Limited Nationalization Planned **********Some areas, such as foreign and defense policy, do not require significant legislation. In any case, major changes are not under consideration in these areas, for the most part. But many of the social and economic changes do require parliamentary approval. Among these are a program of limited nationalization, a change in tax laws aimed at increasing the contributions of the wealthy and of large businesses, government decentralization and regionalization, and increased public supervision over private and religious schools. **********The Communists' theme has been that the voters should choose Communist deputies to keep the Socialists honest and discourage them from sliding to the right. **********The conservatives have had the most trouble in working out a line of attack. Mr. Mitterrand's Government, which has taken a series of modest but generally popular measures, has not yet done anything to cause it to be attacked very hard. There are accusations, some of them fairly plausible, of confusion and unclear purposes, but by and large the French seem inclined to grant a new Government the right to be confused for a month or two.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/busin.body_text: **********The Madison Fund Inc., acknowledging what appeared to be a major investment miscalculation, said yesterday that it would attempt to sell its 16 percent stake in ailing AM International Inc., the moneylosing maker of engineering graphics and information processing systems. **********Madison, a prosperous Wall Street investment management concern based in New York added, however, that it ''anticipates difficulties'' in finding a buyer. AM International has said it is on the brink of default on $106 million in revolving credit agreements with 19 banks. The company expects to report a loss of $175 million for the fiscal year 1981. **********In a lawsuit filed against five former AM International executives and directors, plus its former investment house and auditing concern, Madison charged that the company's prospects were seriously overstated early this year when Madison agreed to become AM's largest shareholder. Madison invested $28 million. **********In its suit, filed last Thursday in the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York, Madison charged that AM ''has suffered massive losses, is financially incapable of carrying out its business plans'' and that it ''is struggling to maintain its very existence.'' Richard B. Black, chairman and chief executive of AM, said through a company spokesman that he would not comment on the suit. **********Madison is seeking ''not less than $27 million'' in damages from its ill-fated involvement with AM. The defendants in the suit are four former executives, including Roy L. Ash, the company's deposed chairman, and John P. Birkelund, a director who is now president and chief operating officer of Dillon Read & Company. Other defendants include the New Court Securities Corporation, the investment house headed by Mr. Birkelund at the time of Madison's investment; and the company's auditor, Price Waterhouse & Company. Mr. Black, who replaced Mr. Ash last February, was not named in the suit. A $20 Million Loss **********As it now stands, Madison has lost on paper approximately $20 million of the $28 million invested in AM stock, or about 16 percent of its common shares, which it acquired last winter. Its arrival in AM's camp was resisted by Mr. Ash and was the flash point in the dispute that brought about his dismissal. Mr. Ash was director of the Office of Management and Budget from 1972 through 1975, before taking the reins at AM in 1976. **********Most of Madison's stake in AM, 1,475,000 shares, was purchased at an average price of $17.33 a share. It later purchased 161,000 shares at a lower cost of $15 to $16.50 a share in the open market. Last Friday Madison valued the stock at $3 a share, or roughly $5.2 million of Madison's $572 million in total assets. AM shares closed at 3 3/4 yesterday, off 1 1/4, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The Madison Fund, which reported a market value of $24.93 a share on its investments last Friday, also lost ground. It closed at 18 1/4, off 1/4 on the Big Board. **********The AM ''common stock purchased by Madison Fund is now substantially worthless and unsalable,'' the fund charged in its legal brief. Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, a prominent Wall Street law firm, is Madison's adviser in the suit. **********The document charged the former AM officers and agents with ''fraud, deception, concealment, suppression and false pretense'' in soliciting the Madison investment. It said ''a very substantial portion'' of the $158 million loss reported by AM in the first six months of 1981 actually was caused by problems in the last two quarters of 1980 (and the first half of AM's fiscal year), prior to Madison's investment. Those recently reported losses were ''concealed by overstatements'' of assets and profits, ''and understatements'' of losses and debts. **********William B. Breed Jr., Madison's executive vice president, said in an interview that the fund was on solid financial footing despite the apparent setback with AM. Indeed, Madison reported $31 million in profits last week on the sale of its 18.5 percent holding in General Portland Inc., which it had acquired for $30 million in the last 18 months. In Default Nov. 4 **********AM International was placed in technical default on Nov. 4 on $106 million in revolving credit agreements with 19 banks. It has received a 45-day reprieve from its lenders. **********Warren Beck, an analyst with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., in Los Angeles, said a survival plan for AM was expected to be presented by Mr. Black, perhaps by the end of this week. An audit by Arthur Andersen & Company must be completed before the new AM plans can be disclosed. **********The Andersen firm, with headquarters in Chicago, was named by AM directors to replace Price Waterhouse as the company's independent auditor after Mr. Black's appointment. Mr. Black, formerly chief executive of the Maremont Corporation, in Chicago, moved AM's headquarters from Los Angeles to Chicago on Sept. 1. **********Mr. Black has already announced his intention to sell or write off $175 million of AM International's business, slashing shareholder investment to about $80 million, from $225 million, in the process. **********''This has to go down as one of the biggest writedowns, on a percentage basis, in the annals of corporate history,'' Mr. Beck said. ''I think you do have a value of roughly $200 million here. But it could be that they have just a fire sale in mind.'' Some analysts have said they believe that Mr. Black's plan will be to sell the remaining AM operations and distribute the equity to shareholders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/18/world.main_headline: IN BOGOTA, REBEL DARING VS. THE CLUB
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/18/world.print_headline: IN BOGOTA, REBEL DARING VS. THE CLUB
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/18/world.body_text: **********Only months after being pronounced ''virtually annihilated'' by Colombia's Defense Minister, guerrillas have rejected an amnesty offer and renewed fighting with such ferocity that the country's army commander warned that the conflict could reach a ''point of no return.'' **********Casualties are the highest since a civil war 30 years ago, and concern over what to do about the insurgency is overshadowing all other issues as the country's two political parties prepare to choose presidential candidates for next year's election. **********President Julio Cesar Turbay Ayala is being urged by critics to extend a more ample amnesty than the recently expired one that brought only 20 rebels in from the field. The army is being accused of torturing and killing peasants and dissident politicians who have no connection to the guerrillas. **********Speaking at the inauguration of a rural clinic Saturday, Mr. Turbay called proposals for an unconditional pardon ''diabolical.'' At issue are the fates of leftist militants now serving prison sentences for crimes like arson and murder in a noncombant situation. 'One Can Think as One Wants' **********''In Colombia, one can think as one wants, one can disagree with the Government as much as one wants, but always within the confines of the law,'' he said. ''What one cannot do, especially under my administration, is to violate the Constitution and the law with impunity.'' **********Gen. Luis Carlos Camacho Leyva, the Defense Minister, who is often accused of exercising more authority than a democracy should allow, was even more emphatic. ''Either the rebels submit themselves to the law and the courts or they will be exterminated by the armed forces, who will not give them a moment's rest,'' he said. **********Some Colombians have likened the struggle here to those occurring in Central America, but the comparison is simplistic and only serves to cloud the uniqueness of the Colombian situation. The repression that exists here is far less than in countries like Guatemala and El Salvador, and the tradition of elected government is far stronger here. **********The issue in Colombia is how a democratic nation can deal with armed internal opposition. The specter frequently summoned up by critics is Uruguay, where a representative government faced with guerrilla attack ceded more and more power to the military until the armed forces finally took over the country. Theatrics vs. Predictability **********M-19, the dominant group, has never clearly articulated its prescription for Colombia's 26 million people. But it has attracted support and capitalized on the numbing predictability of Colombian politics through daring theatrics like embassy takeovers and the theft of Simon Bolivar's sword from a museum. **********Two days before the July 22 expiration of the four-month-long amnesty offer, M-19 guerrillas lobbed three 60-millimeter training mortar shells into the grounds of the presidential palace in downtown Bogota and kidnapped the country's leading television star for 20 hours to gain publicity for a counter proposal. Photographs published the next day showed the talk show host, Fernando Gonzalez Pacheco, conversing over a drink with Jaime Bateman Cayon, the M-19 leader and Colombia's most-wanted man. **********By contrast, delegates at regional Liberal Party conventions on Friday were busy promoting the candidacy of former President Alfonso Lopez Michelson for the coming race, in which the Conservative Party candidate will be one of two men who have run for President before and lost or a third who was President immediately before Mr. Lopez. **********In terms of illustrating the clubbishness of Colombian public life, the contest could end up rivaling the 1974 vote, in which the three final candidates were all sons of previous presidents. Colombia's Political Immobility **********''News of political changes occurring in the great democracies seem to come from another planet,'' said Alfredo Vazquez Carrizosa, a former Foreign Minister who is now a newspaper columnist. ''The characteristic phenomenon of Colombian political life is immobility.'' **********The indifference bred by this has angered military leaders, who feel it has cost them the popular support they deserve. At the end of an impassioned four-hour debate in the Senate Wednesday night, General Camacho Leyva eyed a group of critical young legislators who call themselves ''New Liberals'' and said bitingly, ''One of the reasons my men are falling in combat is to protect your right to say the things you're saying here.'' **********In his ''point of no return'' speech, General Fernando Landazabal Reyes, commander of the army said, ''It is necessary that the leading social, political and economic classes understand in its full dimension the threat to the country of the subversion and that they exercise their influence so that the armed forces will be respected in their efforts to bring peace to the country.'' **********Neither of the two political parties has been able to make substantial headway in improving the uneven distribution of income, one of the most uneven in South America. The middle class is being particularly squeezed by inflation, which has been running at 30 percent a year during the Turbay administration. Sympathy for Rebels **********To the extent that the rebel groups draw attention to these conditions, they attract the sympathy, if not the support, of large parts of the population. **********In two open letters, a group of prominent Colombians, including a former President, called on President Turbay to accept talks proposed by Mr. Bateman. The rebel leader has vowed to try to sabotage next spring's elections in the absence of an agreement with the Government to sit down and talk. **********Msgr. Dario Castrillon Hoyos, Bishop of Pereira, said in a magazine article that the Government was portraying such peace talks as ''a meeting between dirty criminals and clean cassocks.'' **********''It isn't only those in arms who are violent, but also those official elements who commit violence against people like peasants who can't defend themselves,'' the church leader said. Resurgence Surprises Generals **********The resurgence of the rebels has surprised military leaders, who thought they eliminated them in a seven-week jungle campaign four months ago. Two columns of guerrillas, trained in Cuba and infiltrated through Panama, were almost wiped out by the army at that time, prompting General Camacho Leyva to say the insurgents were ''virtually annihilated.'' **********In recent weeks, however, rebels have inflicted significant losses on army troops. In addition, they have left behind propaganda messages indicating that individual groups like M-19 and the pro-Soviet Colombian Armed Revolutionary Forces were overcoming ideological differences that had long kept them at odds. **********''This is very disturbing,'' said an officer who requested anonymity. ''The FARC have a well-disciplined underground structure and long experience as fighters, but without much support. The M-19 has caught public imagination and sympathy with the dramatic style of making the Government look foolish. The mixture is dangerous.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/29/world.print_headline: z; U.N.'s Council Assails Killing of 2 Fiji Soldiers
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/29/world.body_text: **********The Security Council has condemmed the killing on June 19 of two Fijian soldiers in the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon. **********The council, in a statement issued Thursday through its president, Porfirio Munoz Ledo of Mexico, identified the assailants only as ''armed elements.'' United Nations officials said that Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas who were attempting to infiltrate the United Nations zone in southern Lebanon were responsible. **********A statement by the president is the mildest form of Council declaration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/03/world.main_headline: 31 Arms and Poison Caches Are Found in West Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/03/world.print_headline: 31 Arms and Poison Caches Are Found in West Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/03/world.body_text: **********The police said today that they had discovered huge quantities of arms, explosives and poisons in 31 buried caches that had been described in a register kept by a neo-Nazi. **********A spokesman said 88 containers of arms were found in Luneburg Heath in northern West Germany. **********They had been meticulously described in a register kept by Heinz Lembke, a right-wing extremist who committed suicide in jail yesterday. **********The caches contained 340 pounds of explosives, 240 bombs, fuses and detonators, 50 antitank grenade launchers with 70 antitank grenades, 258 hand grenades and more than 13,000 rounds of ammunition, he said. **********The police also found 13 guns, including a machine gun, and cyanide, arsenic and strychnine.  Mr. Lemke, a 44-year-old forester and member of the neo-Nazi National Democratic Party, hanged himself with a radio cord in his cell.
