https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/busin.main_headline: SPREAD OF 'MIRACLE' RICE LAGGING IN ASIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/busin.print_headline: SPREAD OF 'MIRACLE' RICE LAGGING IN ASIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/busin.body_text: **********In parts of Asia, the shift from the use of hand knives called ani-ani to sickles during the 1960's brought a major technological revolution. The number of workers for each rice paddy was reduced. The time of harvesting was shortened.  The community structure changed. **********So when a new rice - a sturdy, fast-growing, high-yielding variety called IR-8 - was introduced in 1966, it promised something called a Green Revolution in Asia. With its introduction came the promise of eventual self-sufficiency in rice and a new way of life. This hope was stirred despite some initial controversy. In some of the countries of the Indochinese peninsula, for example, the grains were considered ''American,'' and therefore subversive, and the seed was sometimes planted there surreptitiously. **********Fifteen years later, countries like Malaysia, Indonesia, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh are within reach of the goal of self-sufficiency.  And the Philippines, a rice importer until 1976, is now an exporter, with overseas sales of 250,000 metric tons in 1980. ''It was a victory,'' said a spokesman for the Ministry of Agriculture. Developed for Ideal Sites **********But one shortcoming of the Green Revolution has been that IR-8 and other varieties based on that strain were developed for planting under the best circumstances: irrigated paddies where fertilizers could be used. Under those conditions, the new rice strains tripled production. But the conditions exist only for a small percentage of rice farmers. **********''More than three-fourths of the world's farmers still do not grow the new rices,'' said Nyle C. Brady, director general of the International Rice Research Institute, an institution supported by the United Nations, the European Economic Community, the Asian Development Bank, the Ford and Rockefeller Foundations and several nations, including the United States. **********''The reason is too little or too much water for the strains we have developed,'' he said, ''or the soil is too salty, acid or sandy. Our research is now focused on helping these farmers who have not had the benefit of the Green Revolution.'' Luzon Output Rises Sharply **********Nevertheless, in the past 10 years under a Government-sponsored program called Masagana 99, rice production in the Philippines' fertile Luzon area has climbed from 2.2 metric tons of rice from a hectare to an average of 3.3 tons, or a rise from just under one ton an acre to one and a half. **********''If there had not been a Green Revolution, most of the countries of Asia would be short, maybe desperately short, of rice,'' said Surajit K. Da Datta, an agronomist at the research institute. ''Now they are keeping up with their population gains, making up the difference that a slightly higher standard of living has on rice demand and in some cases moving from importer to exporter.'' **********It takes five or six years to develop and test a new rice that will produce guaranteed results. Grain by grain, under sterile conditions, the rices are catalogued and indexed for size, color and shape, so farmers can request by number the rice that meets their needs. The most popular rice now being grown in Southeast Asia is IR-36. Resistance to Pests **********IR-36 combines the characteristics of IR-8 with a high resistance to pests. But it does not grow well in deep water or in drought areas. ''In Bangladesh, for example, two million hectares of land are under deep water,'' said Gurdev S. Khush, a breeder at the institute. ''India needs rice that will take long periods of drought. Ideally, what we need is a rice that will tolerate both floods and droughts, since most of the world's farmers rely on monsoons for their water.  If we can solve this problem, we will have a truly miracle rice.'' **********What the new rice promises is a new way of life for rice farmers, greater employment opportunities and development of local subsistence economies. ''There has been a lot of talk about who wins and who loses,'' said Robert W. Herdt, an agricultural economist at the institute. **********''It takes so little to influence the structure of subsistence economies. The introduction of a new rice can do that. With each variation, we create ripples in the local economy,'' he said. **********The impact of the Green Revolution on the Philippines has been the development of rice barter and trade and a general increase in the income of rice farmers. **********Since most of the farmers grew rice primarily for their own families, extra rice crops were cash crops. With ample rice and additional money, farmers became consumers. Health improved. The standard of living increased. **********''Our studies show that hired labor in central Luzon earned 320 kilograms of rice per hectare in 1966 and 543 kilograms per hectare in 1979,'' Mr. Herdt said. ''Much of our work in this phase of rice development is aimed at insuring that more, not less, employment is created by the new technology.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/world.main_headline: Soviet Says U.S. Seeks Military Edge at Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/world.print_headline: Soviet Says U.S. Seeks Military Edge at Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/world.body_text: **********As Soviet-American talks opened today in Geneva on the reduction of medium-range nuclear arms in Europe, Soviet leaders issued a statement accusing the United States and its NATO allies of entering the negotiations with a plan to obtain ''military advantages.'' **********The statement dismissed President Reagan's proposal two weeks ago that both sides renounce land-based nuclear missiles in Europe, calling it an attempt to obtain ''the Soviet Union's unilateral disarmament.'' **********It added, ''The Soviet Union will not agree to this.'' **********The statement, made by the Communist Party's Politburo, appeared to be aimed at public opinion in Western Europe.  It demanded that the Reagan Administration and other NATO governments give ''full and objective consideration'' to proposals put forward in West Germany by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, which envisaged a moratorium on NATO's deployment of missiles in return for a ''unilateral'' reduction of missiles deployed in the European part of the Soviet Union. The Soviet document took the form of an appraisal of Mr. Brezhnev's trip to Bonn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/22/world.main_headline: LONDON POLICE SEIZE 8 AS BLACK TEEN-AGERS GO ON A NEW RAMPAGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/22/world.print_headline: LONDON POLICE SEIZE 8 AS BLACK TEEN-AGERS GO ON A NEW RAMPAGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/22/world.body_text: **********A mob of young blacks rampaged through the streets of East London late today, breaking shop windows, overturning a car and threatening policemen in the second straight night of racial violence, a police spokesman said. **********No one was injured in the rampage, but the police arrested eight persons, who will appear in court tomorrow charged with threatening behavior, the spokesman said. **********The spokesman said that a mob of 60 to 70 black teen-age boys and girls had run through two streets in the Forest Gate area of East London, breaking windows and shouting at the police. **********''It was vandalism more than anything else,'' said a Scotland Yard official. Extra Police on Patrol **********''There were extra police in the area after the events of last night,'' said the official, referring to the three clashes between the police and black youths yesterday in which 16 policemen, including two senior Scotland Yard officers, and 27 bystanders were injured. **********One of the clashes took place in the Forest Gate area at Wanstead Flats. Twelve policemen were hospitalized and 15 youths arrested during the fighting in the area. **********Yesterday's violence, in three separate areas of London, was the worst since rioting broke out in Brixton 10 days ago, causing millions of dollars damage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/30/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; BOND YIELDS SET NEW HIGHS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Rising short-term interest rates and a lack of investor demand combined yesterday to raise yields in the credit markets to record levels for securities due in more than three years. **********''Investors were shocked by the market's recent declines,'' said Peter Karchis, a vice president at Morgan Stanley & Company, ''and they have pulled back into a shell where they do not want to do anything.'' **********George Johnston, president of the investment advisory firm of Scudder, Stevens & Clark, explained that bond yields were rising to new levels because ''buyers are not yet convinced that money supply growth will slow, and the economy is still growing at a good pace.'' **********''It seems hard to suppress the economy and inflation by monetary policy alone,'' Mr. Johnston said, adding that many people thought the Reagan Administration's proposed tax cuts would only stimulate the economy and aggravate inflation. **********Prices for Treasury notes due in two to 10 years recovered a portion of their losses late in the day after the Treasury announced plans to sell next week $3 billion of three-year notes, $1.75 billion of 10-year notes and $2 billion of 30-year bonds. The $6.75 billion financing package and the size of the note offerings were slightly less than traders had expected. How Similar Maturities Did **********Among actively traded Treasury issues with maturities similar to the new issues, the 13 1/4 percent notes due in August 1984 closed at 97 2/32 to yield 14.38 percent, the 13 percent notes due in November 1980 were at 95 to yield 13.96 percent and the 12 3/4 percent bonds due in 2010 were at 94 3/4 to yield 13.47 percent. **********Besides a lack of investor demand, securities dealers said, prices drifted lower because of uncertainty about how high short-term interest rates might go as the Federal Reserve seeks slower growth of the money supply. **********''We are fairly certain that the Fed is trying to make reserves scarcer, but nobody knows just how scarce,'' one dealer explained.  Securities dealers are sensitive to bank reserve positions because overnight financing costs will tend to rise if bank reserves are less available and as the rate on Federal funds rises. **********Bank reserves were exceptionally scarce yesterday, despite a variety of moves by the Federal Reserve and the Treasury to inject credit into the banking system temporarily. Overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market were as high as 24 percent and averaged 19 percent, but analysts said the Fed and Treasury actions were a signal that reserves were scarcer than authorities wanted. They pointed out that reserve availability is often abnormal on Wednesday, the last day of the banking system's statement week. Temporary Transactions **********To supply reserves, the Fed arranged one-day purchases of securities and then told dealers it would consider more such transactions. The Fed was unable to supply as much credit to the banking system as it wanted, dealers said, because firms did not have enough securities to sell to the Fed temporarily. **********The Fed also bought $375 million of Treasury bills for a customer account, which analysts said showed that the Fed did not want to drain credit from the banking system. It also helped reduce Treasury bill rates, while other money market rates moved higher. **********The Treasury, in another move to ease the squeeze on bank reserves, arranged large transfers of money into special tax and loan accounts it has with banks. **********Amid extreme uncertainty about interest rates, traders in the money markets said, most investors were not willing to buy paper due in more than 30 days. At 15 1/2 percent, top-quality 30-day commercial paper attracted a good flow of funds, while the 10 largest banks were said to be issuing 30 day certificates of deposit with a yield of about 15 3/4 percent. The commercial paper rate has increased about a percentage point since Monday. High Yield but Weak Demand **********In the corporate bond market, a record yield of 15.93 percent for triple-A Bell System debentures was not enough to attract strong investor demand. Michigan Bell's $250 million issue of 15 3/4 percent issue due in 2020 was allowed to trade freely, and by late in the day the issue was offered at about 97 to yield 16 1/4 percent. **********Among new issues, the New Brunswick Electric Power Commission's $100 million of A-1 15 percent debentures, being offered through a First Boston Corporation group, were priced for sale today at 97 3/4 to yield 15.45 percent. **********Elsewhere in the corporate bond market, the Alaska Housing Finance Corporation postponed a proposed issue of mortgage revenue bonds that would have made it the first housing authority to issue taxable bonds. In the past, state and local authorities have issued taxexempt bonds, but their volume has declined this year since the Federal Government set limits on the amount and structure of such bond issues.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/24/world.main_headline: RESTORATION SCANDAL: ANNE HYDE AND JAMES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/24/world.print_headline: RESTORATION SCANDAL: ANNE HYDE AND JAMES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/24/world.body_text: **********Not for 321 years has an heir to the British throne married an Englishwoman. The last time it happened, there was little talk about the bride's youthful innocence. **********The Duke of York, who later became James II, was the younger brother of Charles II, whose reign followed the English Civil War and Oliver Cromwell's Protectorate. **********The woman was Anne Hyde, who was born here and whose family devoted much time to ingratiating itself with royalty. As a result, in 1654, Anne, then 17 years old, was made a maid of honor to Princess Mary, James's older sister. **********James and Anne met several times during his exile in Europe. The young Duke was quickly attracted to the daughter of a key political adviser to his family. A Written Promise of Marriage **********''He gave Anne gladly the written promise of marriage for which she stipulated, and their love was consummated,'' the historian F.M.G.  Higham said in 1934. **********In 1660, a few months after the document was signed, the Restoration placed Charles II on the throne and the Royal Court returned to London. **********Mr. Higham wrote that James viewed his affair with Anne as ''a happy episode,'' adding, ''In the summer of 1660, he forgot it.'' However, Anne did not, particularly because she was pregnant. A few weeks later, she reminded James of the document he had signed. The Duke, who had just had an unhappy affair with a married aristocrat, decided it was best to fullfill his promise. They were secretly married in September, preparing a backdated contract. **********In October, the child was born, only to die in infancy. James was King from 1685 to 1688. Anne Hyde, who did not live to be Queen, died in 1671. James and Anne had two surviving children. One ruled as Queen Mary II beside King William III; the other ruled alone as Queen Anne.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/24/busin.main_headline: Continental Air Chief Backs Worker Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/24/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Continental Air Chief Backs Worker Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/24/busin.body_text: **********Alvin L. Feldman, the president and chief executive officer of Continental Air Lines, emphasized yesterday that he prefers a workers' proposal to gain control of the carrier to that of Texas International Airlines, which owns 49 percent and is seeking a merger.Mr. Feldman made his comments in a speech to security analysts in New York and in an interview. **********''You can't predict'' what the Continental directors will do, Mr.  Feldman said. **********But he added that ''the employee plan looks much more beneficial.'' **********Mr. Feldman announced commitments for the $185 million that the proposed Employee Stock Ownership Plan will need to buy the 15.4 million new shares of Continental that would give it 51 percent control. But he declined to identify the banks, noting only that there are ''a number of'' them and that the proposed deal ''is oversubcribed.'' **********The response by the banks, according to Mr. Feldman, ''sets the stage for a viable alternative to the Texas proposition.'' He said, ''With the employee willingness to make the financial sacrifice to acquire a stake in the company and the willingness of the banks to help finance it, it looks like there's a very good business proposition that benefits all the shareholders.'' **********Earlier this week, the Continental Employees Association said that the airline's workers had voted 8.982 to 359 to support the stock ownership plan. As for Texas International, its Continental stock is being held in a trust while the Civil Aeronautics Board reviews its merger proposal. **********Mr. Feldman suggested that both proposals would be presented to the board of the Los Angeles-based Continental. The Texas International plan ''is not a fair shake either for the other shareholders or for our employees,'' he asserted. ''Frankly the employee plan appears to be substantially more favorable to Continental and its shareholders.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/19/world.print_headline: WARSAW REPORTS HOARDING OF FOOD; TIGHTENS PATROLS JAILINGS ASSAILED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/19/world.body_text: **********The United States publicly called upon Poland's military Government today to free its political prisoners and to let Lech Walesa, the leader of the Solidarity movement, ''speak to his countrymen and to the world.'' **********The State Department said the Administration was ''deeply concerned for the leaders of Solidarity and the thousands of other prisoners being held in Poland.'' **********Elsewhere, there were these developments: **********- The West German Parliament called on Chancellor Helmut Schmidt to put off any action on further economic aid for Poland as long as ''repressive measures'' are in force against the Polish people. (Page 7.) **********- The leader of Italy's Communist Party, Enrico Berlinguer, denounced the crackdown in Poland, saying the authorities there did not know that ''socialism and democracy are inseparable.'' (Page 7.) **********- Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria called the Polish situation the most dangerous threat to global peace since the end of World War II. (Page 7.) Inhumane Treatment Charged **********Dean Fischer, the State Department spokesman, said that many of the prisoners in Poland ''are being held in inadequate facilities and are not being accorded humane treatment.'' **********''It is also extremely disturbing that the leader of Solidarity is being held under de facto house arrest and that he has not been allowed to make a public statement to reassure the world about his welfare,'' Mr. Fischer said. **********''We call on the Polish Government to release the prisoners, whose only crime has been their attempt to exercise those civil and political rights enshrined in many international documents to which that country is party, and to allow Lech Walesa to speak to his countrymen and to the world,'' he said. Reagan Meets With Kirkland **********President Reagan met today with Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., to discuss the Polish situation. Speaking to reporters before the meeting, Mr. Reagan said, ''We want a return to the negotiation stage, an end to martial law and the release from confinement of those people who have been unjustly arrested and an end to violence.'' **********The State Department reiterated today that the United States would permit the continued supply of food aid being distributed to the Poles by private American organizations such as Care and Catholic Relief Services. Such aid is funnelled directly to individuals. **********But the United States has put in abeyance a Polish Government request for more than $730 million in credits for next year to purchase feed grains and other agricultural products. **********Mr. Reagan, at a news conference Thursday, caused some confusion by suggesting that all aid might be halted. Weinberger Cites Caution **********Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, in an interview with The Boston Globe published today, said the United States was trying to avoid turning Poland into ''another Hungary.'' In 1956 Soviet-led forces invaded Hungary to crush a liberalization movement, and thousands of Hungarians died or fled to the West. **********''There's a worry that if too much is said,'' Mr. Weinberger said, ''the Soviets will feel that they have to go in and there will be a bloodshed that could otherwise be avoided, and there's a great desire not to have another Hungary on our hands.'' **********He ruled out military involvement by the United States in any event ''because of the logistics of the situation - supply lines of 5,000 miles or whatever and that kind of thing.'' Military action, he said, is ''not what's contemplated.'' **********''What's contemplated are attempts to dissuade the Soviets from taking action that could harm the Polish people and delay their reach for freedom,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/world.main_headline: MURDOCH, IN 'CHALLENGE OF MY LIFE,' BUYS LONDON TIMES FOR $28 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/world.print_headline: MURDOCH, IN 'CHALLENGE OF MY LIFE,' BUYS LONDON TIMES FOR $28 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/world.body_text: **********Rupert Murdoch bought The Times of London and its affiliated publications today for $28 million, making him one of the most powerful Fleet Street publishers of the 20th century. **********Mr. Murdoch, a 49-year-old Australian whose international newspaper empire includes The New York Post, said after the complex transaction had been completed that he regarded the acquisition of The Times, which is widely regarded as one of the world's best newspapers, as ''the most exciting challenge of my life.'' **********The price he paid for The Times, The Sunday Times and three weekly supplements was something of a bargain, in the opinion of some publishing sources here. The Times building alone is worth more than $40 million. **********On the other hand, not one of the publications is making money, and the Thomson Organization, which sold the properties, has lost more than $100 million on them in its 14 years of ownership. Moreover, Mr. Murdoch's company will have to pay $15 million or more in severance pay for the hundreds of employees he plans to dismiss in an economy drive. Another provision of the sale agreement is that if the papers start making a big profit, Thomson will share in it, at least during the first 10 years. Labor Contracts Announced **********The Times publications are losing $30 million a year, but Mr.  Murdoch hopes to turn all five of them into profitable publications within a few years. He already owns the largest daily and Sunday newspapers in Britain, The Sun and News of the World. **********''The best guarantee of editorial independence is financial independence,'' he has said before and in the three weeks since the purchase was conditionally arranged. The sale depended upon new contracts, announced last night, with all the unions representing the company's 4,000 employees. **********One of the features of the contracts is the introduction at The Times and The Sunday Times of so-called cold-type printing, an electronic process, to replace the traditional lead-type method. **********In 1976 the Thomson Organization bought several million dollars worth of cold-type equipment, including 200 video display terminals for a computer system. System Remained in Storage **********But the company, which had an increasingly troubled relationship with its unions, was unable to work out a contract that would allow the new system to be used, and it has stayed in storage, unused, on the third floor of the company's building here. **********According to Mr. Murdoch, the switch from hot type to cold type will begin almost immediately and be completed at the daily in 24 weeks and at the Sunday paper a few months after that. **********Only one major London newspaper, The Daily Mirror, is fully produced by the new technology, but the managers of all the others are interested, and there was hopeful talk up and down Fleet Street today that ''Rupert is paving the way for some important changes,'' as one newspaper executive put it. **********The terminals are intended to be operated by journalists and adtakers, but under the new agreement at The Times, they will be operated by members of the printers union, whose work force is being cut from more than 350 to 180. Mr. Murdoch hopes eventually to eliminate these printers from the process, but their union made it clear today that that task would not be easy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/04/world.main_headline: PERU ACTS TO STEM TRADE IN STOLEN ARTWORKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/04/world.print_headline: PERU ACTS TO STEM TRADE IN STOLEN ARTWORKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/04/world.body_text: **********The Peruvian Government is waging an urgent campa ign to halt a billion-dollar trade in st olen art treasures that is ravaging the country's cultural heritage. **********Diplomatic efforts culminated in the signing of an agree ment with the United St ates in mid-September to facilitate the return of stolen works of art recovered by United States authorities. **********At the same time, the Public Prosecutor's Office has launched an investigation into the activities of Peruvian dealers and collectors who are said to act as the agents for foreign buyers. **********The export of artwork has been prohibited since 1929. But the law has failed to stop a boom in the trading of gold and silver objects, colonial-era paintings and centuries-old pottery. **********''In the past 10 years, the illegal trade has flourished, especially toward the United States and Europe,'' a senior official of the National Institute of Culture said recently. **********''Most of our best pieces are already abroad and if it continues, Peru will be left with only a mediocre collection of its own antiques,'' he said. **********Clients are wealthy, cultured and demanding. ''They want only the best,'' he said, ''which is why the finest pieces disappear.'' Furious at the appearance of Peruvian treasures in foreign auctioneers' catalogues, the Government decided earlier this year to take action to halt the trade. **********It achieved an immediate success when the New York branch of Sotheby Parke Bernet, the art auctioneers, withdrew from a sale of seven colonial paintings that the Peruvian Government charged had been stolen from Peruvian churches and museums. **********Six were returned to Peru after the Government presented documentary evidence to back its claim. It is now seeking to recover 46 more earmarked for auction. **********Cultural officials said the recovery marked an important precedent and had apparently already discouraged some collectors from buying Peruvian works. **********A longer-term achievement was the signing of the agreement with the United States Government to speed up repatriation of stolen antiques.  The agreement, similar to one signed between the United States and Mexico in 1970, will allow the Peruvian Government to bypass the courts and obtain quick recovery of treasures if they can prove they have been stolen. **********''Legal proceedings are lengthy and costly,'' one cultural official said. ''While they go on, the antiques deteriorate because they are not properly stored.'' **********The Institute of Culture said more than 5,000 works of art were stolen last year, and the main targets were churches in the region of Cuzco, the ancient capital of the Incas 365 miles east southeast of Lima. The Incas dominated the region at the time of the Spanish conquest in 1532, and the area is filled with Incan and colonial relics, which have made it one of the most famed archeological regions of the continent. **********Most of the region's 305 chapels and churches have been pillaged of their finest treasures and archeological sites have been cleared by clandestine digging. **********The local authorities are installing burglar alarms in 18 of the most important churches.  Mayor Willy Monzon said the budget of less than $25,000 was not enough to provide adequate security in the cathedral, which overlooks Cuzco's central square and was built in 1564. **********''The only protection our churches has is the good faith of the local people,'' he said. ''Unfortunately, that is no longer sufficient.'' **********Mr. Monzon charged that local people carried out the robberies on the orders of outside dealers. ''They are as well organized as the drug traffickers,'' he said. **********Government officials agree. ''The financing and organization comes from abroad and the locals are used for the dirty work,'' one official said. **********The Government is also taking action at home. Official sources said the public prosecutor would shortly bring charges against a number of prominent people involved in the illicit trade. **********The National Institute of Culture is also speeding up cataloguing of works held in museums, churches and private collections and tightening security in public buildings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/25/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Reagan's Script Draws Skeptics
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/25/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Reagan's Script Draws Skeptics
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/25/busin.body_text: **********THE main question people are asking about President Reagan's economic program is: ''Will it work?'' The question, of course, assumes that Congress will adopt the program pretty much as the President has proposed it. But even if the President gets nearly all he wants from Congress, he has warned the public not to expect a swift cure for the economy's ills. **********His economists are forecasting a slow recovery this year, with the real gross national product advancing only 1.1 percent, consumer prices climbing 11.1 percent and unemployment averaging 7.8 percent (compared with 7.4 percent in January). **********Those figures are roughly in line with the consensus forecast of private economists for 1981. The ''Blue Chip'' consensus of 42 private economic forecasting units, regularly assembled by Eggert Econometric Enterprises of Sedonia, Ariz., shows a gain of ninetenths of 1 percent in real G.N.P. for this year, an inflation rate of 11.4 percent in the Consumer Price Index and an unemployment rate of 7.8 percent in the year's final quarter. **********Among the forecasters included in the Eggert survey are such financial institutions as Citibank, Bank of America and Chase Manhattan, and such econometric services as Data Resources, Wharton and Chase Econometrics. **********Despite much public disparagement of economic forecasting, the consensus forecasts have been remarkably close to the mark in recent years. Last year, the consensus forecast a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in real G.N.P.; the actual result was a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent. For the years 1977 through 1980, the consensus underestimated actual growth by an average of only one-half of a percentage point a year and was consistently right in the direction of change. **********However, the consensus forecast regularly underestimated inflation. In the 1977-through-1980 period, the average error was a shortfall of eight-tenths of 1 percent. But on unemployment, the consensus erred on the high side, overshooting by an annual average of four-tenths of 1 percent. **********Though the Reagan Administration has stuck close to the consensus forecast for 1981, its model is more optimistic on 1982. Five major econometric concerns are forecasting real G.N.P. to rise by 3.6 percent in 1982, while the Reagan economists predict a rise of 4.2 percent. The econometric services foresee consumer prices rising by 9.7 percent in 1982, but the Reagan economists say they will go up by only 8.3 percent. **********Thereafter, the Reagan economists part further with private economists using standard econometric models. For instance, the Reagan forecast, set forth in ''America's New Beginning: A Program for Economic Recovery,'' projects a 5 percent increase in real G.N.P. for 1983, while Data Resources is projecting a 2.9 percent gain. **********The Reagan scenario gradually grows rosier and rosier. As a result of five years of steady growth in real G.N.P., averaging 4.4 percent a year, the Reagan economists say that the Consumer Price Index will be rising by 4.2 percent in 1986, with unemployment averaging 5.6 percent that year. **********Is this script credible? The Reagan forecasters were constrained by reality in 1981 and held close to the consensus forecast of private economists. But the big test of whether Reaganomics will follow the script laid out by the Reagan plan for economic recovery will come late in 1982, when the White House says it intends to reduce inflation to close to 6 percent. **********Meanwhile the financial markets remain highly skeptical, as do most private economists, both conservative and liberal, monetarist and Keynesian. For the Reagan economists have projected nominal economic growth - real increases in national output plus inflation - averaging 11.3 percent for the years 1981 through 1986. That would mean an 87 percent rise in current-dollar G.N.P., to the Reagan projection of $4,918 billion in 1986 from $2,629 billion in 1980. **********Yet, to slow down inflation, the Reagan plan calls for the annual rate of growth of the money supply to be cut in half, averaging about 4.5 percent, in line with the anticipated growth of real G.N.P. At the end of 1980, the most commonly used measure of the money supply, M-1B, which includes currency, demand deposits and other checkable deposits at banks and thrift institutions, totaled $412 billion. If that measure grew at a compound annual rate of 4.5 percent, the money supply would total $536 billion by the end of 1986, an increase of only 30 percent over its level at the end of 1980. **********Can so little growth in money support so huge a growth in currentdollar G.N.P.? From 1980 to 1986, the Reagan plan foresees a growth of $2,289 billion in nominal G.N.P. and an increase of $124 billion in the money supply (M-1B.) **********If the Federal Reserve holds to those money-supply guidelines, that would imply continuous pressure on interest rates, and slower real growth than the Administration is projecting. But if the Fed goes above the money-supply guidelines, that would imply higher inflation than the Administration is predicting. The way the Administration has laid out its plan, something has got to give.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/07/world.main_headline: U.S. ACADEMIC EXPERTS PREDICT POWER STRUGGLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/07/world.print_headline: U.S. ACADEMIC EXPERTS PREDICT POWER STRUGGLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/07/world.body_text: **********The death of President Anwar el-Sadat, at a time of internal unrest, is expected to ignite a power struggle, according to interviews with American analysts of Egyptian affairs. **********Nadav Safran, professor of government at Harvard University. said: ''With the death of Sadat, power and the direction of Egypt's foreign and domestic policies are up for grabs among the generals, cabinet ministers and aides who worked closely with him.'' **********In addition to the impact on Egyptian politics, Professor Safran said, the assassination will have ramifications for Arab-Israel relations. **********''Sadat looked as though he was going to get away with it,'' said Mr. Safran, ''He had made his separate peace with Israel, survived the Arab boycott and his regional isolation. Other Arab leaders were beginning to draw the lesson that maybe peace with Israel was politically possible. The peace plan proposed last summer by Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia was an indication of that trend. Now Sadat is dead, and that lesson is not going to be lost on other Arab leaders. You can look for Fahd to take more of a hard line the next time he makes a speech.'' **********Speaker to be Titular Leader **********There is no indication who President's Sadat's successor will be.  For the next 60 days, until an election can be organized, a temporary president, Sufi Abu Taleb, the Speaker of Parliament, will be the titular leader. **********Vice President Hosni Mubarak, Mr. Sadat's longtime protege, will exercise effective authority through his control of the armed forces and key government posts and he is the apparent frontrunner in any race for the presidency, according to the analysts.. **********But even if Mr. Mubarak is chosen, the analysts said, it will take him several months at least to consolidate his grip on the sprawling bureaucracy, the army and the public at large. **********In the meantime, rivals for power are likely to challenge his authority in the political back alleys, as they did when Mr. Sadat succeeded Gam el Abdel Nasser in 1970, and when Mr. Nasser toppled King Farouk i n 1952. **********Mr. Mubarak's tenuous position will not only limit his room for maneuver in domestic and foreign affairs, but could force him, or his rivals, to appeal for support to internal political groups or outside powers that have not previously been a factor in Egyptian politics. Sadat's Policies May Be Reviewed **********''By their very nature,'' Raymond Baker of Williams College said, ''power struggles in Arab politics reopen issues about foreign affairs and domestic politics that once appeared settled.'' **********To a great degree, Professor Baker said, many of those issues were reopened in recent months. The Egyptian unrest was sparked by sectarian clashes between Moslems and Coptic Christians, but it developed into a more broadly based opposition movement. Left-wing intellectuals and right-wing Moslem extremists found common cause in decrying Mr. Sadat's rule and staged the most violent demonstrations since he came to power 11 years ago. **********The severity of the demonstrations was reflected in Mr. Sadat's decision early last month to arrest 1,500 of his opponents, mostly Moslem extremists. But they also included some of the nation's best known political personalities, notably Mohammed Hassanein Heikal, a confidant of Mr. Nasser. Results of Camp David Talks **********''Sadat promised that Camp David would provide real peace and real prosperity,'' said Mr. Baker, referring to the accords signed with Israel in 1978. **********''But the average Egyptian was beginning to realize that it brought neither. This increasing awareness was at the root of the latest disturbances. All of these issues - relations with the West, with Israel, with the surrounding Arab states, the direction of the economy -are still lying in the street, ready to be picked up by any contender for power. **********''Sadat's death opens the possibility of realignment in these areas. It will be easy for Mr. Mubarak's rivals to seek popularity by pandering to these issues.'' Malcolm Kerr, a political scientist of the University of California at Los Angeles, said that, even if Vice President Mubarak were able to obtain power, it was not immedia tely certain that he would continue Mr. Sadat's policies. **********''A lot will depend on who is found to be responsible for Sadat's assassination and how Mubarak interprets the opposition that has built up in recent months,'' Professor Kerr said. ''He may seek to make a quick accommodation with the domestic opposition to consolidate his own hold on power.'' Accords May Become Unraveled **********This could lead to some degree of cooling in Egypt's relations with both Israel and the United States, which in turn could set off a chain of events that might unravel the Camp David accords. Relations with the other Arab countries, almost all of whom have severed diplomatic ties with Egypt, are also expected to undergo a major change, the analysts said. **********Rapprochement with Egypt was impossible for any Arab leader as long as Mr. Sadat was in power. Now Saudi Arabia and the other conservative Persian Gulf states are expected to make it easy for Mr. Sadat's successor to return to the Arab fold, both to entice him away from Israel and to bolster the ranks of the conservative states in their competition with the more radical Arab regimes. **********As for Egypt's relations with Syria, Libya or the Palestine Liberation Organization, a rapprochement will depend on how far Mr.  Sadat's successor is ready to move toward their end of the political spectrum. The radical Arab regimes can be expected to use whatever means possible to influence the selection of Egypt's new president.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/03/busin.main_headline: Business People; Top Clevepak Officer About to Retire Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/03/busin.print_headline: Business People; Top Clevepak Officer About to Retire Again
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/03/busin.body_text: **********When Hubert J. McPherson, one of the founders of the Clevepak Corporation, returned as president and chief executive officer last December, the company said that he would fill the post ''on an interim basis.'' **********Now Mr. McPherson, 67, who had previously retired to Saratoga, Calif., is again leaving the top post at the White Plains, N.Y., recycled paperboard and packaging and industrial products company, turning it over to Charles H. Moore Jr., 52, who will join Clevepak next Tuesday as president and chief executive. Edgar M. Bronfman, 51, chairman and chief executive officer of the Seagram Company, another co-founder, continues as its chairman. **********''I've got to get in and learn the business because I don't have a paper background,'' said Mr. Moore. ''I don't know any better way to get to know the business and its customers and to learn more about the competition than by getting into the field.'' **********Mr. Moore, who won a gold medal for the 440-yard hurdles and set a world record in the 1952 Olympic Games, began that year at Lenape Forge, a family-owned company that was later sold to Gulf and Western Industries. In 1973 he went to the Interpace Corporation as a divisional vice president and general manager, advancing to executive vice president and chief operating officer seven years later. **********Mr. McPherson, a certified public accountant, was president of Pacific Industries and executive vice president of the Thatcher Glass Company before Clevepak was established in 1962. He became president in 1963, added the chief executive's title 10 years later and has been chairman of the executive committee since 1975, a position he will retain. **********Speaking of his new association, Mr. Moore said: ''I'm satisfied from my external viewpoint that they've done a lot of the right things already. I clearly want to take advantage of what has been done and then build on top of that. The c ompa ny is capitalized to do some impressive growing both internally and e xternally.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/busin.main_headline: CONOCO ASKS DOME FOR TAX GUARANTEE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/busin.print_headline: CONOCO ASKS DOME FOR TAX GUARANTEE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/busin.body_text: **********Conoco Inc., vigorously opposing a bid by Dome Petroleum Ltd. of Canada to acquire Conoco's 53 percent stock interest in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company, challenged Dome late yesterday to indemnify it against any tax liability if Conoco accepted the Dome offer. **********Dome has been contending that Conoco would not be subject to a capital gains tax if it accepted the Dome proposal because of the way it was constructed; Conoco argues that the deal is taxable. **********In a message to John P. Gallagher, chairman of Dome, Ralph E.  Bailey, chairman of Conoco, said his company's tax lawyers had been unable to get Dome's tax lawyers to concede that there were ''not significant tax risks.'' But, he wrote Mr. Gallagher, ''You are free to avoid the tax question by offering to indemnify Conoco against any tax liability.'' **********There was no immediate response from Dome to the Conoco challenge.  Earlier in the day, Wall Street investment bankers who analyzed the tax aspects with their own lawyers had given Dome the edge in winning a bidding battle now under way between Dome and Husky Oil Ltd., also fighting to get control of Hudson's Bay. Liability Could Reach $300 Million **********If Conoco sold to the wrong bidder, analysts contended, it might have to pay a capital gains tax estimated at $300 million. Any offer but Dome's is regarded as a straight sale and, therefore, taxable.  Some tax lawyers feel the Dome offer for Hudson's Bay, which involves a stock swap, is not a sale and, therefore, less likely to be taxed. **********After jumping nearly $4 on Wednesday, Hudson's Bay stock rose only 50 cents yesterday, to $29.50, because of the uncertainty. Conoco slipped 25 cents on Wednesday but picked up more than $1 yesterday, to close at $54.75. Dome Petroleum rose $2.75 on Wednesday and $2.375 yesterday, to close at $89.875. **********Dome touched off the battle earlier this month when it offered to buy 13 percent of Conoco for $910 million. It said it might buy as much as 20 percent so that it could add that much of Conoco's profits to its own. Dome stressed that it did not want control of Conoco; rather it was seeking a way to swap the stock for the Conoco block in Hudson's Bay, without Conoco's having to pay a capital gains tax. Valuing Hudson's Bay Stock **********Although Dome did not say how much it would offer for the Hudson's Bay block, it suggested that 14 million Conoco shares should be sufficient. At $910 million, Dome's opening bid for Hudson's Bay thus totaled about $22.75 a share. **********Conoco then sued Dome, contending, among other things, that the offer was ''grossly inadequate.'' It added on Tuesday that it was negotiating with others to sell the Hudson's Bay shares. By late Wednesday, Husky identified itself as one of the others, but said that ''no understandings or agreements'' had been reached. **********Dome is known to have asked Conoco to supply it with inside information supplied to other bidders, but Conoco is understood to have refused unless Dome withdrew its tender offer. **********Mr. Gallagher had written earlier to Mr. Bailey, asking for a meeting ''to reach an agreement,'' and said that he was prepared to add cash to whatever amount of stock Dome would offer for the Hudson's Bay block. Adding a new element, he said that even if Conoco sold its Hudson's Bay block to someone else, it ''would not necessarily lead to the withdrawal of our tender offer.'' **********Mr. Bailey replied that he might now make the inside information available, if Dome signed a confidentiality pledge. He added that Conoco preferred a cash transaction, but assailed Mr. Gallagher's remark about not necessarily withdrawing its tender as one that ''raises serious questions as the true motivation of your actions.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/busin.main_headline: F.C.C. DELAY ON PHONE PLAN FORECAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/busin.print_headline: F.C.C. DELAY ON PHONE PLAN FORECAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission ''almost certainly'' will delay beyond March 1982 the planned implementation of its telephone deregulation program, according to one of the agency's members. **********The centerpiece of the program is a new subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that would sell on an unregulated basis a variety of communications equipment, ranging from telephones to complex switchboards, and offer sophisticated data and information services. **********Subject to pending appeals before the commission and in the United States Court of Appeals here, the plan, drawn up by the F.C.C., was to take effect March 1, 1982. But Joseph R. Fogarty, a commission member who specializes in telephone regulation, said that implementation of the program could slip to December of 1982 or even later. **********Oct. 7 Meeting Planned **********Some definite decisions on what to do about the lagging program, now being held up because staff officials at the commission say they are overburdened, are expected to be made at a meeting of the commissioners on Oct. 7, Mr. Fogarty added. **********Mr. Fogarty is only one of seven members of the commission, but he is deferred to by his fellow commissioners on telephone industry matters because of his expertise. He is expected to be especially influential on telecommunications issues in coming months because three members of the commission, including the chairman, joined the agency only this year. **********''When we delay the date for implementing the plans, I know it is going to be difficult for A.T.&T.,'' said Mr. Fogarty. ''They are busily working on restructuring plans to coincide with March.'' Shift of Equipment an Issue **********At the heart of the commission's problem is the lack of success in deciding how to transfer billions of dollars worth of existing Bell System equipment, such as telephones and switchboards, to the new subsidiary. **********In order to shift the equipment from the regulated side of the company to the unregulated side, it must be depreciated on a steppedup schedule, if not immediately. Quicker depreciation could drive up local phone rates and have other consequences, industry officials say. **********On Thursday, at a joint meeting of the House subcommittee on investigations and the subcommittee on telecommunications, there is scheduled to be a disclosure of the results of a long-awaited examination o f the F.C.C.'s Common Carrier Bureau. The subcommittees are expected to also delve into several recent controversial rulings by the commis sion. ''I think it will be the most important hearing wewill take par t in this year,'' Mr. Fogarty said, but he declined to be more speci fic. **********In particular the members of the commission are expected to be questioned about a closed-door meeting where they decided to grant A.T.&T. an increased rate of return, from 10.5 percent to 12.75 percent, which later resulted in increases in long distance phone rates in excess of 16 percent. Overseas rates declined over the same period. **********The increase was expected to result in an estimated revenue rise of more than $725 million this year. Overcharges and Cellular Radio **********In addition, according to members of the staff of the joint House panel, commission members will be questioned about the disposition of $100 million in overcharges A.T.&T. is said to owe customers, and a decision earlier this year to begin a new form of mobile telephone called cellular radio by guaranteeing A.T.&T. a part of the new service. **********The whole question of how to dispose of telephone equipment and how to provide for the maintenance of the phones and other devices after they are unregulated is a complex question involving phone company accounting departments, local utility boards and the Federal commission, Mr. Fogarty said. **********The manner of disposing of the old equipment could also affect A.T.&T.'s success in financing the new subsidiary, which may cost up to $20 billion to institute, he said. Bell must propose a capitalization plan in November. **********A.T.&T. officials, asked about the consequences of a delay in instituting the new plan, declined immediate comment, saying it would be premature to react before the commission moved.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/15/busin.main_headline: The Week in Business; BIG MERGERS AND LOWER RATES EXCITE THE MARKET
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/15/busin.print_headline: The Week in Business; BIG MERGERS AND LOWER RATES EXCITE THE MARKET
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/15/busin.body_text: **********The stock market rose last week on investors' hopes for lower interest rates and on a spurt of merger activity. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 4.05 points on Friday but still gained 21.15 points on the week to finish at 985.77. Stocks soared 22.15 points on Thursday. **********The prime rate dropped to 18 percent at most banks. Chemical Bank went further and cut the key lending rate to 17.5 percent. **********Auto sales jumped 8.5 percent in the March 1-10 period from the same 10 days a year ago, domestic manufacturers reported. Chrysler said sales soared more than 51 percent. But analysts were cautious, citing inflated gains from rebate programs. **********Money-market mutual funds continued to gain, with assets rising to a record $101.2 billion on a weekly increase of $3.2 billion. **********Retail sales climbed nine-tenths of 1 percent in February from a month earlier, the Commerce Department said. **********Business inventories rose 1.1 percent in January from the month earlier. Manufacturers accounted for most of the increase. **********I.T.T.'s profit rose 89 percent in the fourth quarter from the same period a year ago, with much of the gain attributed to the sale of timberland facilities. Sears said profit in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Jan. 31, increased by 9.5 percent and Woolworth reported a 3.8 percent gain in the same period. Gulf and Western reported fiscal-quarter earnings up 10.8 percent. **********O.P.M. Leasing filed for court protection from creditors. The computer leasing company is under investigation by the United States Attorney in Manhattan in connection with its leasing arrangements. **********British Columbia Resources offered $285.2 million in Canadian funds for an additional 29 percent of MacMillan Bloedel. **********Trust Houses Forte bid $130 million to buy the Savoy Hotel group, operator of four of London's most luxurious hotels. **********''Discover us,'' says St. Joe Minerals in a current campaign to lure investors. An offer by Seagram last week to buy St. Joe for $2.03 billion wasn't exactly what the company had in mind, though, and St. Joe is fighting. Seagram offered $45 a share when the stock was trading at $28. Not nearly enough, said St. Joe. **********A friendlier proposal came from Sohio for Kennecott. The oil company, which is 53 percent-owned by British Petroleum, said it signed a definitive agreement to buy Kennecott for $1.77 billion, or $62 a share (when Kennecott was selling for $27.) **********The two big merger proposals followed an offer a week ago Thursday by Standard Oil of California to buy Amax in a record $4 billion bid. Amax is fighting back. **********All three proposals were backed by oil profits (much of Seagram's wherewithal came from the sale of petroleum properties to the Sun Companies). And the offers for the mining companies have made other big companies in the industry newly attractive on Wall Street. **********Investigators, meanwhile, are watching. A Chicago options trading firm has charged in a suit that investors had learned of the Socal offer. Kennecott's stock was traded heavily in the days before the merger announcement and St. Joe's stock jumped over 2 points the day before the offer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/busin.main_headline: Better Auto Sales Seen DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP)
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/busin.print_headline: Better Auto Sales Seen DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP)
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/busin.body_text: **********New-car sales could increase 16 percent and truck sales could jump 30 percent in 1982 if the overall economy grows and interest rates continue their decline, the president of the Ford Motor Company, Donald E. Petersen, said today. **********''I am neither an optimist nor a pessimist,'' Mr. Petersen told a joint meeting of the Economic Club of Detroit and the Greater Detroit Chamber of Commerce. ''I think I am, however, a realist, and I believe the U.S. auto industry is basically much stronger than a lot of people say it is.'' **********If the nation's economy grows at a 4 percent to 5 percent rate and interest rates continue to fall, the American market could account for sales of more than 10 million cars and more than 3 million trucks next year, he said. **********Sales for this year are expected to reach about 8.6 million cars and about 2.3 million trucks.  The largest share of any sales improvement, however, will not come until the second half of 1982, Mr. Petersen said.  ''Clearly, the 1982 picture is not rosy,'' he said. ''The first half will be very rough sledding. The economy will be sluggish - perhaps until midyear - and the auto industry will remain depressed.'' **********Mr. Petersen called for concessions from the United Automobile Workers to help cut labor costs when negotiations begin on a new contract between Ford and the union next summer. **********''We have to reduce the Japanese cost advantage, which is now $10 an hour - an advantage that allows the Japanese to produce and land an Escort-size car in San Francisco for $1,400 less than we can make it here,'' he stated. **********Mr. Petersen also said that failure to cut labor costs will force the transfer of production - and jobs - to other countries.  ''The U.S. auto industry is committed to being cost competitive on a worldwide basis,'' Mr. Petersen said. ''It really has no choice. If we can't get our labor costs in line to do that here, the industry will increasingly and inevitably look elsewhere to get the job done.  That's not a threat. It's an economic reality.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/03/busin.body_text: **********''PEOPLE who buy these systems are conservative. They want to see it working somewhere else before they will invest in it.'' These were the words of a waste management expert i nterv iewed for the column that appeared here two weeks ago on treatment systems for organic wastes. **********They were practically identical to comments made by other experts during interviews for earlier columns on subjects as diverse as lubrication, robotics and baseball pitching machines. From the perspective of almost anyone in technology development, it seems, virtually all potential customers are conservatives. **********This suggests that while there is no denying the central role of research and development programs in the world of technology, marketing is also an important part of the story. The same message figured in recent announcements of advances in solar energy applications and coal mining. **********The solar news came from the Luz Engineering Corporation of Birmingham, Ala., which said that it had signed contracts to build and operate the nation's three largest privately financed industrial process heat systems based on solar energy. At about the same time, the Advanced Coal Management Corporation of Lexington, Ky., dedicated the first ''Thin Seam Miner'' to arrive in the United States, a machine said to be the most important advance in the coal industry since the continuous miner. **********Both Luz and Advanced Coal are distributing their products through unusual marketing arrangements that they say have been crucial to the successes they have achieved to date - and to their prospects. **********Luz's contracts call for it to install and operate solar collector systems at plants owned by three textile companies - the Bibb Company, Cone Mills and the J. P. Stevens Company. Luz will make its money on the systems, which cost between $2 million and $4 million each, by selling the companies steam at 350 degrees Fahrenheit for 20 years at a discount from what the local power company would charge. **********While Luz claims that its system is unusually efficient, Gaston White, the company's project manager downplays any suggestions that it contains any major changes in solar technology. ''We are marketing it as proven technology,'' he said. **********The efficiency imp rovement comes from a number of minor changes.  For example, computer controls help the parabolic collectors track the sun when it is behind the clouds. Parabolic collectors need to follow the su n in order to focus its rays on the oil-containing tube in which the sun's energy is converted to useful heat. Typical sensing devic es that reorient the collectors when the sun emerges from behind c louds have difficulty if the sun has been blocked for a lengthy perio d. The Luz system keeps the collectors moving so that the sensors n eed only perform a small and speedy adjustment. **********The improvements notwithstanding, Luz recognized that solar systems do not meet the payback requirements of most companies and that industrialists lacked the experience to be confident that they could successfully operate and maintain them. Moreover, according to Solomon Kimerling, the marketing consultant retained by Luz, the whole solar field is regarded by industrialists as ''unreal'' because most industrial solar projects have been Federally subsidized. **********To overcome these barriers, Luz decided to become the owneroperator of its systems. Mr. Kimerling noted that the strategy is akin to that pioneered by Air Products Inc., which built industrial gas plants beside or on the site of steel mills in order to supply them with their output by pipeline. ''What we are saying is that the customer does not have to invest in the technology, just the output,'' Mr. Kimerling said. ''The only way to get it accepted like other industrial equipment is to make it into a high-volume item.  Then we will be able to sell the equipment directly.'' **********Advance Coal's marketing strategy for its new coal mining machines is markedly different in detail, but notably similar in effect. Like the solar systems, the machines represent a huge investment - some $2.5 million each - and the potential users lack experience operating anything comparable. **********''It is too sophisticated a machine to put on this market,'' said James D. Stacy, the former coal mine owner who has cooperated with Rhine-Schelde-Verolme, a Dutch engineering and shipbuilding company, in developing it. He founded Advanced Coal to oversee his exclusive right to market the 200 units that Rhine-Schelde-Verolme will make and send here through 1985. **********The electronically controlled machine mines up to 85 percent of the coal left behind in the walls of strip mines. It recovers the coal in strips that are 89 inches wide, two to five feet thick and up to 220 feet deep, using sensors to detect the size and direction of the seam. No miners go underground and no blasting is required. **********Instead of trying to sell the machines, Mr. Stacy has set up a second company, the Thin Seam Miner Corporation, which, through a contract with Advance Coal, will lease them to mine owners and oversee both operation and maintenance. **********The arrangements will be structured so that Advance Coal is, in effect, either a contract miner for the mine owner at a fixed price, or a joint venture partner entitled to 65 per cent to 75 percent of the gross, Mr. Stacy said. In contrast to Luz , Advance Coal has adopted its strategy on a permanent basis, no t just as a vehicle to overcome initial reluctance to use its techno logy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/27/busin.body_text: **********At 4:57 P.M., Wes Campbell, a driller working for the Shell Oil Company, lowered a column of steel pipe deep into the Atlantic, 200 miles off the coast of Massachusetts. The drilling column stiffened slightly as it hit bottom and then punched a 17 1/2-inch hole in the sandy face of Georges Bank. **********Fifty miles to the west, the Exxon Corporation sent its drill bit spiraling into the layers of sedimentary rock in search of oil and gas. **********After six years of bitter legal wrangles between fishermen and oil companies, exploration began today on Georges Bank - one of America's richest fisheries.Zapata Saratoga rig were a knot of Shell Oil officials, nine journalists and a group of curious finback whales who poked their heads through the distant waves, sending up fountains of spray. **********''Thank goodness we finally got it started,'' said O.J. Shirley, manager of government and industry affairs for Shell. ''It's only a matter of time before the fishermen get used to having us out here.  We can have a very compatible relationship.'' **********Their relationship thus far has been anything but compatible.  Starting in the mid-1970's, New England fishermen, state governments and environmentalists brought various suits to block oil exploration on Georges Bank, or at least delay it until tighter safeguards were enacted. The Departments of Interior and Commerce and 22 oil companies argued that the need for domestic oil supplies outweighed the ''small'' risk to fishing. The existing environmental safeguards, they said, were sufficient to protect the fish and their habitat from oil pollution. Drilling Finally Approved **********Drilling was finally approved by the courts last year on the condition that the Government and the oil companies take additional environmental precautions. But these fell far short of what the fishermen had been seeking. **********Standing beneath the red, white and blue derrick of the Zapata rig, Mr. Shirley argued that oil exploration posed no serious threat to the marine life of Georges Bank. **********''We recognize Georges Bank is important, but its value as a fishery has been greatly overstated.'' he said. ''There are 20,000 square miles out here and I don't see any kind of event that could wipe out this fishing ground.'' **********The New England fishermen see it otherwise.  Since the 17th century they have made a living off the haddock, cod, halibut, lobster, flounder and scallops of Georges Bank. Its waters provide some 14 percent of America's food fish and serve as the basis of the $1 billion-a-year New England fishing industry. It was to preserve the treasures of Georges Bank from foreign fleets that the United States decided to enforce a 200-mile coastal limit. **********Harry Swain, president of a New Bedford, Mass., boat owners association, has not been out to view the Zapata Saratoga yet, but the 70-year-old fisherman has a sense of foreboding. **********''You know it's ironic,'' he mused from his office in the cobblestoned New Bedford pier district, where Herman Melville set off to write Moby Dick, ''when the oil companies first discovered oil, it put the whalers here out of business, because people didn't need the whale oil anymore. Their drilling in Georges Bank could well put the fishermen out of business again.'' **********''We're not talking about protecting the snail darter out there,'' said Douglas Foy, director of the Conservation Law Foundation of New England, which aided the fishermen in their legal fight. ''We're talking about a whole industry and fish that people eat every day.  Whatever oil they find will last only a few weeks, but the fish will be there for a lifetime - if you take care of them.'' 'The Iron Bottom' **********The fishermen's main fear is what they call ''the Iron Bottom.'' The drill bits, cable, pipe, and other equipment oil companies might lose, or dump overboard, can easily slice or snare fishermen's costly nets and lines. Mr. Swain said Norwegian fisherman claimed their catch dropped by one-third as a result of the debris left on the bottom of the North Sea from oil drilling. The companies are bound by anti-dumping regulations, but the fishermen are pessimistic about their enforcement under the Reagan Administration. **********''Oh, the companies came up here and promised lots of things,'' said Mr. Swain, who fished Georges Bank for nearly 50 years, ''and they showed us movies of colorful fish caught around the oil rigs in the Gulf of Mexico, but in the end they really didn't give us anything.'' **********Mr. Swain had some unflattering things to say about James G. Watt, the Secretary of the Interior, in whose reign ''the oilmen have gotten real cocky.'' **********The fisherman had also asked the companies to alter their shipping routes so they would not pass through key fishing grounds, and to tow away the tons of chemically treated ''mud'' used in the drilling process instead of dumping it into Georges Bank. The muds are deployed to cool the drill bit and equalize pressure in the hole. **********''They argued that it would cost too much money,'' said Jay Lanzillo, a fisherman-activist with the Chatham, Mass., Seafood Coop, ''and the Government backed them up. What can I say? We lost.  All we can do now is hope they don't find any oil.'' An Estimated 123 Million Barrels **********The Government estimates that the area being explored in Georges Bank contains at most 123 million barrels of oil - about two weeks of current United States consumption. Then again, it may contain no crude at all, as was the case in the Baltimore Canyon off the New Jersey coast. Mr. Shirley argues that it is still worth the risk. **********''The total domestic oil supply comes from a large number of small fields all over the country,'' he said. Even if Secretary Watt carries out his pledge to lease one billion offshore acres during the next five years, he added, ''there are only limited areas we would like to drill - sedimentary basins like Georges Bank.'' **********Guiding visitors through the beehive of pipes, tanks and catwalks that make up the six decks of the floating Zapata rig, Mr. Shirley showed off the myriad of safeguards being taken by the oil companies: blowout prevention measures, constant inspection, dillution of drilling muds and environmental impact studies. **********''Shell has drilled 4,000 offshore wells around the world and has never once had a blowout or a spill,'' he said.  Pat Doody, senior vice president for the Zapata Off-Shore Company, which leases the rig to Shell, predicted that after a few months the fishermen would be seeking out the oil platforms, which he said act as artificial reefs and attract fish. This is what fisherman in the oil-rich Gulf of Mexico do, he said. **********Poring over a wall-size contour map of Georges Bank, Dr. Robert Howarth, staff scientist at the Marine Biological Laboratory at Woods Hole, Mass., pointed to the spot where the Zapata Saratoa is anchored. An expert on the marine environment of Georges Bank, he knows the contours well. Rich in Nutrients **********It is precisely the uniqueness of Georges Bank as a fishing ground, he argues, that makes it so susceptible to oil pollution. The waters are among the world's richest in the nutrients fish need to survive.  The seas are extremely shallow and turbulent, which means the food is spread throughout as in a blender. **********In addition, the waters above this sandy bank follow a circular current pattern called a ''gyre,'' which keeps helpless fish eggs and larvae trapped inside. There they can live off the nutrients until they are large enough to survive in areas with fewer sea plants and less protection. **********''Georges is like a gigantic fish nursurey, and this is what must be protected from the oil drilling,'' said Dr. Howarth. ''You can't compare it to the Gulf of Mexico, which is not a nursury and produces mostly sport fish, not food fish.''  Shell Drill Is Stuck **********HYANNIS, Mass., July 26 (AP) -The drill bit on Shell Oil's drilling rig Zapata Saratoga became imbedded in rock at 120 feet into the ocean floor today, forcing a temporary halt to drilling in the Georges Bank, a company official said. A Shell spokesman, Norman Altstedter, said the problem was a common one in offshore oil exploration, but he said it could take hours or even several days to free the bit and resume drilling.
