https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/world.main_headline: U.S. ENDORSES PROPOSAL BY FRANCE FOR AN ARMS PARLEY AFTER MADRID
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/world.print_headline: U.S. ENDORSES PROPOSAL BY FRANCE FOR AN ARMS PARLEY AFTER MADRID
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/world.body_text: **********In an important step toward improving relations with its Western European allies, the Reagan Administration has endorsed a French proposal for monitoring military movements by the Warsaw Pact and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********The endorsement, disclosed yesterday at the 35-nation Madrid review conference on East-West cooperation, was hailed by the Western Europeans as a sign that the new Administration was willing to negotiate on security questions and to permit its allies to assume the lead on disarmament. **********''This puts aside the comments of all those who, whether through lack of knowledge or evil intention, attribute to the United States Administration an insufficient willingness to negotiate,'' said Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German Foreign Minister. **********Since President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France introduced his proposal for a European disarmament conference in 1978, the Western Europeans have gradually lent it support, in part to allow France an opportunity to re-enter East-West negotiations that had been boycotted by General de Gaulle. But the Carter Administration viewed the French idea with suspicion, fearing that it might start a disarmament process that would slip from American control. **********French Redraft Their Proposal **********In December, the French delegation to the Madrid conference redrafted the document, giving priority to strengthening so-called confidence-building measures among military blocs and relegating actual disarmament to a second stage. **********In its new form, the plan gained the support of all Atlantic alliance members except the United States. It would make prior notification of maneuvers mandatory from the Atlantic to the Urals, the mountain range deep inside the Soviet Union that is the traditional boundary of Europe. The Helsinki accords of 1975, under review here, called for voluntary notification in a zone reaching only 150 miles into the Soviet Union. **********By backing the French plan for a conference on confidence-building measures, the United States delegation helped preserve a spirit of Western unity that has been a striking feature of the gathering here since it opened in September. **********The American decision, which was announced by Max M. Kampelman, the chief delegate, after talks in Washington with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., also put the Soviet Union on the spot. Moscow has been pushing its own plan, for a disarmament conference in Warsaw, which the West has dismissed as a forum rendered meaningless by the intervention in Afghanistan. **********With the West presenting a solid front around the French proposal, the Soviet Union will not be able to appear as the sole champion of detente and disarmament at the Madrid talks. The chief Soviet delegate, Leonid F. Ilyichev, has rejected France's plan to expand the zone for confidence-building to the Urals. Impasse on Text Is Expected **********''As for the idea of extending the application of the measures of confidence to the Urals, as France wants, our answer is 'no,' '' Mr.  Ilyichev declared last month. ''This would create a disequilibrium, because the agreement would cover all of the territory of Europe, but it would exempt the United States and Canada.'' **********The two North American countries, because of their membership in the Atlantic alliance, have been included in the European talks on East-West cooperation. **********The Soviet refusal to consider extending the confidence-building zone has led diplomats to believe that the conference is heading for an impasse. **********Committees have begun the phase of the talks that should see the drafting of a final document, but the chances of finding common ground seem slim. **********The conference has a target date of March 5 for winding up, but most diplomats seem to expect haggling over the final language to carry the gathering beyond that date. It is believed that the Soviet Union will hold back agreement to convene another conference to review the Helsinki accords in an attempt to force neutral states to accept its idea for a disarmament conference in Warsaw.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/busin.body_text: **********I N its drive to reduce or eliminate Federal programs, the Reagan Administration continues to talk up volunteer efforts to fill at least part of the gap. In doing so, the Administration implicitly admits that some of the cuts it wants to make will cause genuine hardship. **********Of course, many of the Government activities that Mr. Reagan wants to cut cannot by their very nature be taken over by individuals, businesses or voluntary groups. **********There would be no credibility to a suggestion that the private sector could or would replace Federal efforts to insure clean air and clean water, to eliminate health and safety problems in the workplace, or to nudge employers toward getting rid of employment and promotion practices that exclude women and minorities. **********These Federal activities were undertaken because of the widespread belief that large and powerful parts of the private sector were acting so as to damage vital public interests. As the Federal Government abdicates in these areas, there will be no united fund to pick up the pieces. **********If the President's pitch for the private sector to take the place of Government has any credibility, it must be in the areas of health, education and social welfare. Here voluntary activities are already established, and are going on at a rate of about $18 billion annually. Unfortunately, there are strong reasons to believe that an attempt to get volunteers in the private sector to take over an appreciable part of public sector activities is doomed to failure. **********Social scientists who have studied voluntary efforts at action have noted that there is a persistent and systematic problem in mobilizing resources to support these actions. As Mancur Olson, the economist, pointed out in an influential treatise published 20 years ago, the rational self-interest of each individual points away from participating voluntarily even in a group whose purpose that individual enthusiastically approves of. **********When private organizations try to get donations for social purposes, many of the individuals asked to make a contribution will reason (quite accurately) that the dollars each gives can make little difference to the cause. After all, an individual who contributes even a substantial part of his salary may increase a charity's funds by only a thousandth of a percent or less. Reasoning in this way, many individuals will avoid making the contribution. Although each failure to contribute makes almost no difference, added together these failures make a huge difference. The result is slim pickings for charities. **********In a society of one million people, all of whom would support a law forcing each of them to pay $50 a year for social relief, voluntary collections would produce considerably less than $50 million. The more coldly rational that people are, the less that voluntary collections produce. It is precisely for this reason that human beings have organized governments with coercive taxing powers. **********Of course, we live in a society that is far from unanimous about anything, and in which majorities shift from one side to the other.  When the Liberals win, they use the power of government to coerce contributions from themselves and from those less liberal than themselves. When they lose, they lose the ability to use the coercion of the tax collector to collect even from fellow liberals what those liberals would be willing to give. **********Another problem with voluntary provision relates to the cost of making voluntary collections. While some charities have low collection costs, it is not unusual for voluntary organizations to spend more than 90 percent of the funds they take in on expenses relating to fund solicitation. This expenditure is not a sign of corruption. It is simply a necessity under modern conditions. **********B UT the result is that only a fraction of the contributed money goes to relieve the social distress that the donors were worried about. The knowledge of these high collection costs provides a further rationalization for not contributing. **********Another reason that we cannot go back to voluntary provision for a sizable proportion of social needs is the atrophy of habits and attitudes and institutions that used to support voluntary giving. A higher proportion of us used to attend religious services regularly, where we were regularly exhorted to give, where there was social pressure to give, where compassion for the less fortunate was instilled and where collection was done at low cost. **********The establishment of Federal programs to deal with social ills has had an adverse effect on the public's attitude toward the beneficiaries. The President now talking up voluntarism is the very man who as a candidate whipped up sentiment against clients of Federal programs, and characterized them as a pack of parasitic cheaters. **********A recent newspaper article told of a Florida city where transients were annoying the residents by hunting in their garbage pails for food. The city's mayor referred to the garbage eaters as ''vermin,'' and spoke of the possibility of dousing the garbage with kerosene. In a country where that kind of sentiment is publicly expressed, voluntary provision for the poor is going to be on the short side. **********We have our Scrooges, and lately the Scrooges have grown bolder in expressing themselves. But we are not a nation of Scrooges. On the contrary, we are a nation that, seeing voluntary efforts as commendable but chronically insufficient, has for almost 50 years been relieving social distress through the Federal Treasury, using the coercive powers of government to collect the funds. **********If a majority of the voters have become convinced that Federal social programs have become overly generous, it is certainly legitimate for the President to want to try to rein them in. But to ask volunteers to make up for more than a small portion of what the Federal Government is taking away is asking for the impossible. That helps neither the volunteers nor the poor.   ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Barbara R. Bergmann is a professor of economics at the University of Maryland and one of a panel of four economists appearing regularly in the Sunday Business Section.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/busin.body_text: **********The Marine Midland Bank, the nation's 13th-largest commercial bank, cut its prime lending rate yesterday to 19 1/2 percent from 20 percent. No other major banks immediately followed suit, but bank economists predicted that the 19 1/2 percent rate would soon spread throughout the industry. **********Further cuts in the key lending rate are expected in the next six months if the inflation rate continues to decline and the pace of economic activity slows, the analysts said. **********Several smaller banks also announced reductions in their prime lending rates yesterday. The UMB Bank and Trust Company, a subsidiary of United Mizrahi Bank of Tel Aviv, trimmed its prime to 19 1/2 percent from 20 percent, while the St. Louis County Bank dropped its prime rate to 20 percent from 20 1/2 percent. **********The fall in the prime was foreshadowed Monday when the Bank of New York and the Chemical Bank reduced their broker-loan rates, the fee charged to securities dealers on loans backed by stock as collateral, to 19 1/2 percent from 20 1/2 percent. Several others, including Irving Trust and Marine Midland, lowered their broker-loan charges to 20 percent from 21 percent. Marine Midland trimmed its broker-loan rate again yesterday to 19.5 percent. **********''It does look like there are pressures building for the rest of the industry to fall in line,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president of the Bank of New York. If the cost of Federal funds and certificates of deposit, two of the most important sources of bank funds, hold their present level, Mr. Sullivan said, ''a move to 19 percent is not unlikely in the near future.'' **********The Federal funds rate, the interest banks charge one another for overnight loans of uncommitted reserves, is considered an important indicator of the degree to which the Federal Reserve is making funds available to the financial system. The rate fell as low as 16.5 percent early yesterday, down from 20 percent as recently as last Friday, but closed the day at 18.58 percent. The Fed has apparently allowed the rate to drift lower because of a slackening in the growth of the nation's basic money supply over the last three weeks. Quarterly Tax Date Cited **********Mr. Sullivan said other major banks might delay their moves to the 19 1/2 percent level until after next Monday, when quarterly Federal income taxes come due. Businesses often borrow heavily to pay their quarterly tax liabilities. **********The prime is the basis for the rate that banks charge on most three-month loans to their best corporate customers, although many large corporations obtain short-term loans at rates well below the prime. The prime also serves as the basis for a variety of loans to consumers and smaller businesses. **********''The prime rate moves up and down much more frequently than it did traditionally, therefore a single move does not have the significance it did before,'' said John R. Petty, president of Marine Midland. ''The modest easing of New York, London and Federal fund interest rates led us to believe that 19 1/2 percent is the right rate for the near future. Whether this is the start of a long-term trend is too early too determine.'' **********However, Irwin L. Kellner, senior vice president and chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover, described yesterday's drop in the prime as ''the early stages of what will be a long-term downturn in interest rates.'' Although he foresees a steady decline in interest charges, Mr. Kellner said there would be a few ''ups and downs'' along the way. Drop Called Justified **********Mr. Kellner said the fall in the prime lending rate to 19 1/2 percent was justified because companies were demanding less credit from commercial banks at the present costs. With the economy slowing and the pace of inflation down to an annual rate of 10 percent or less, businesses are finding it increasingly difficult to pass on the high lending rates to consumers, he said. **********''With the Federal funds rate around 17 percent, it would seem that the Fed is under no great pressure to drain reserves from the system,'' Mr. Kellner said. ''As long as the Federal funds rate stays in that range, I think the others will follow the parade.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/23/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON BIG BUSINESS has taken its lumps with the sharp cutback projected for Export-Import Bank lending in the Reagan economic package. But corporate executives are still intent on helping the Administration sell the plan. **********As Cabinet officers fan out to build up public support for the proposed tax cuts and spending cuts, companies are promoting the package in advertisements and public forums. A typical advertisement run by Lone Star Industries, the cement producer, is addressed to members of the 97th Congress. ''Want to get re-elected?'' it asks.  ''Don't pull this nation apart. Pull us back together again.'' **********An executive of a leading multinational corporation said, ''Sure, we're disappointed about the Ex-Im Bank cuts, but we want the package to hold together.'' The bank lends to foreign purchasers of American-made products. **********Business favors the sharply improved depreciation schedules in the Reagan plan. The fast write-off of research and development equipment (three years) is especially valuable for high-technology producers and exporters. **********Corporate lobbyists brought heavy pressure on David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget and architect of the spending cuts, to leave the Export-Import Bank alone. Having lost the battle, the lobbyists now say they will bury that issue for the time being and fight to keep the package together in the House and Senate. **********''If it breaks apart on the Hill, and I'm not so sure it won't,'' said one lobbyist, ''then we'll fight tooth and nail to rescind the Ex-Im cuts.'' **********One Cabinet officer said chances were excellent for getting most of the cuts through the Senate - and relatively soon. In the Democraticcontrolled House, with heavy Democratic representation on the Ways and Means Committee and Rules Committee, the going will be much rougher, he conceded. Visitors From Abroad **********European economic officials are trooping to Washington to get briefed on the Reagan program and the outlook for interest rates in this country. **********Karl Otto Pohl, president of West Germany's central bank, will arrive Wednesday after talks in New York with Anthony M. Solomon, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. **********Rene Monory, Finance Minister of France, arrives next Sunday.  Money managers have been shifting funds into high-yielding dollar securities, intensifying pressure on most European currencies. In recent weeks the Federal Reserve has been intervening in the currency markets, along with West Germany's central bank, to slow the fall of the mark. The Bundesbank acted last Thursday to force short- and medium-term interest rates higher in West Germany. **********Reagan officials are expected to tell the visitors, who are eager to see interest rates in this country fall and relieve the currency pressures, that the Administration's program is designed to do just this. They are expected to reject any demands for an international compact on interest rates. Pegging rates, they tell all comers, could be dangerously inflationary. **********The Administration's hope is to knock inflationary expectations out of the present rate structure. Japanese Autos **********The task force report on autos, being prepared by Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis, will be ready in early March, Reagan aides say, and will probably pave the way for ''voluntary'' restraint by the Japanese on shipping cars to this country. **********The Administration strongly opposes quotas mandated by legislation. However, although no firm decisions have yet been taken, a consensus seems to be forming around the notion that the Japanese be urged to keep their exports below a fixed level. **********Restraints go against the grain of free-market advocates in the Cabinet, but Ford's huge loss for 1980, piled on top of Chrysler's problems, has strengthened the hand of pragmatists who think a deal with Japan should be made, provided the auto industry brings something to the table in the form of wage, price and investment concessions. Briefcases *********** Marc E. Leland, London partner in the New York law firm of Proskauer, Rose, Goetz & Mendelsohn, has been quietly tapped as the new Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, succeeding C. Fred Bergsten, now at the Carnegie Endowment. *********** Sam Y. Cross, former United States delegate to the International Monetary Fund and an old Treasury hand, is moving to Liberty Street as senior vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/19/world.main_headline: MEXICO CRUSHING A MAVERICK, RAZES A NEIGHBOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/19/world.print_headline: MEXICO CRUSHING A MAVERICK, RAZES A NEIGHBOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/19/world.body_text: **********Isabel Arroyo de Garcia sat on a rickety wooden chair and watched her husband and brother slowly demolish the tiny cement-block house that they built with their savings six years ago. She seemed close to tears. ''We've been given 24 hours to rescue what we can,'' she said, ''then the bulldozers are coming.'' **********A few yards away, young antiriot policemen slouched in the shade, one eye on their horses and another on the somber family groups gathering their belongings - an oven, a bed, perhaps a television -on the unpaved street before their ruined homes. ''We don't like doing this,'' a policeman said, ''but we have to obey orders.'' **********The order to dismantle the so-called Second of October Encampment caught the squatters by surprise. Suddenly, around 11 A.M. on March 2, 6,000 policemen fell upon the slum, some waving pistols and submachine guns as they burst into homes to search for weapons, others standing guard while heavy machinery reduced the first 500 shacks to rubble. **********Officials explained that the squatters had ''consented'' to be moved to plots in another part of Mexico City where water, drainage and electricity were already installed. The flattened area, they said, would be turned into parks and children's playgrounds. ''No money will be spared in improving the quality of life here,'' a government planner pledged. Settlement's Leader Arrested **********But the real reason for the eviction may have been different. For the past six years, the militantly independent squatter community has been a thorn in the side of the authorities and the Government's patience seems to have run out. On the day of the police raid, the settlement's leader, Francisco de la Cruz Velasco, was arrested and charged with crimes that could keep him in jail for 40 years. **********''The Government didn't move against them because they were squatters,'' said a leftist who helped organize the slum. ''There are squatters all over the city. It acted because it cannot tolerate an independent organization that doesn't follow the political rules of the system.'' **********The Second of October Encampment -its name commemorates the killing of some 300 anti-Government demonstrators here on Oct. 2, 1968 - began life like most Mexican slums with the illegal ''invasion'' of undeveloped urban land by homeless families, many of them recent migrants from the countryside. **********The organizer of the group, ''Pancho'' de la Cruz, now 55 years old, had come to Mexico City as an illiterate peasant from Oaxaca State in 1958, but he was determined to improve himself and, after years of evening classes, graduated as a lawyer from the National University in 1974. Community Organization Formed **********After the seizure of some 100 acres in the Ixtacalco district of Mexico City on March 10, 1975, Mr. de la Cruz emerged as the new slum's undisputed leader. And to help persuade the Government to grant legal titles and provide public services in the area, he set about building a strong community organization. **********The squatters built a three-floor building for offices and meeting halls as well as a health clinic, a kindergarten, a cheap restaurant and a mechanic's shed. But Mr. de la Cruz also inspired other squatter settlements to become more militant and eventually helped found the Urban Block of Popular Communities, made up of some 30 slum organizations. **********As Mr. de la Cruz emerged as a political figure, however, his relations with the Government deteriorated. One night early in 1976, the police raided the encampment to arrest him and, although he escaped, a fire broke out and five children died. Mr. de la Cruz went into hiding outside Mexico City. **********When he returned in January 1977, soon after President Jose Lopez Portillo took office, he found his leadership challenged. And in the subsequent conflict, the couple who had run the organization in his absence formed the breakaway Independent Democratic Committee. A Friend in High Places **********Over the next four years, the authorities sought hard to neutralize Mr. de la Cruz. For example, they encouraged his opponents to take their complaints about his alleged corruption and authoritarianism to local newspapers. There were also occasional clashes in the community. **********Early in 1979, though, the president of Mexico's ruling party, Gustavo Carvajal Moreno, began courting Mr. de la Cruz and, according to the squatter leader, even offered to make him a member of the Chamber of Deputies in the elections of July that year. Mr. de la Cruz in turn tried to use his friendship with the party boss to squeeze concessions out of the city authorities. But after a few months, the bizarre alliance collapsed. **********Around the same time, apparently eager to expand his influence, Mr. de la Cruz used the squatter organization to ''protect'' a fleet of over 2,000 ''pirate'' taxis whose drivers were given special injunctions to shield them from arrest for driving without proper permission. Each driver paid the organization around $500 for the injunction and a further $10 a week for ''protection,'' although friends maintained that Mr. de la Cruz needed the money to pay large bribes to police officials. **********Mr. de la Cruz's political manuevering won him new enemies. His ''pirate'' taxi operation led to clashes with established taxi fleet owners who had influence in the Government. The city authorities also complained that he had repeatedly blocked their efforts to bring order to the encampment. Finally, on March 2, the decision was taken to break the organization. Supporters Are Loyal **********Until the end, Mr. de la Cruz's supporters - some 5,000 squatter families - remained loyal. Wherever he went, he was ''guarded'' by dozens of women. Even on the day of his arrest, he was accompanied by a crowd of several hundred when he was called to a government office for a meeting, but only he and four aides entered the building. The doors were then locked and he was seized. **********Now, sitting in jail awaiting trial on charges including theft, assault and arson, Mr. de la Cruz feels betrayed. ''The mistake of any leader is to believe in the authorities,'' he told the political weekly Proceso from his cell. ''I believed in the agreements, in their promises and here I am.'' **********He asserted that his downfall came when he refused a bribe of $450,000 from Mr. Carvajal, the party chief. ''It meant selling out my people and I refused,'' he said. ''Carvajal told me that since I didn't want power, I didn't want money, I didn't want to become a deputy, our relations were over.'' **********Mr. de la Cruz insisted that he never took money from the squatter organization. ''Everyone used me, everyone wanted to use my name,'' he said. ''I never thought of myself as a god, but I was a good leader because, when I spoke, people followed me. I always understood the problems of my followers because I am also from humble extraction.'' 'Like a Father to Us' **********Climbing among the dusty ruins of their homes, picking out clothes, dolls and cooking pots from among the bricks, waiting for city trucks to take them to their new plots, Pancho de la Cruz's supporters seem lost without him. ''He was like a father to us,'' a grandmother said, tears rolling down her face. ''After all we have suffered here, we must now suffer more.'' **********In the sprawling slums surrouding the Second of October Encampment, life goes on normally. Only people in the zone controlled by Mr. de la Cruz are being evicted. In a temporary office, Government officials conferred with leaders of the rival Independent Democratic Committee. **********But some of the men waiting to be transferred to their new plots seven miles away vowed to keep up ''the fight.'' ''They said that the Second of October Encampment will soon be only a memory,'' a young man said defiantly. ''Well, the memory will live on in the new Second of March Encampment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.body_text: **********Construction contracts will rise by 12 percent in 1981, to $164.5 billion, or about $10 billion less than was predicted six months ago, the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company said yesterday. **********In an update of its ''1981 Dodge-Sweet's Construction Outlook,'' McGraw-Hill predicted a 1 percent gain in nonresidential construction, to $53.1 billion, as President Reagan's reindustrialization program goes into effect. **********It forecast a 12 percent rise in the value of public works construction and a 10 percent increase in the number of residential building units, a decrease from earlier forecasts. **********In the nonresidential category, office building construction for 1981 was estimated at $13.03 billion, down 3 percent from last year; stores and other commercial buildings at $11.6 billion, up 2 percent; and manufacturing buildings at $7.9 billion, down 4 percent. **********''While there is bound to be a reversal of the recently strong rate of contracting for commercial and industrial buildings, manufacturing building should be showing improvement in the second half of 1981, as the new Administration's program for reindustrialization gets under way,'' said George A. Christie, McGraw-Hill vice president and chief economist.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/14/busin.body_text: **********OF all the financial futures introduced in recent years, none has as much potential for use by the international money market as does the Eurodollar futures contract that started trading last week on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The reason is because Eurodollar interest rates are beyond the control of all central banks, they are the most sensitive in the international money market. **********Indeed, the new Eurodollar futures market could eventually be used by monetary authorities as an inexpensive, convenient and highly leveraged method of intervening in support of the dollar and other currencies, according to John M. Blin, senior vice president of the New York Futures Exchange. **********Mr. Blin, an economist, is regarded as one of the designers of Eurodollar futures, which he helped develop for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's International Monetary Market several years ago. In an interview last Friday, Mr. Blin observed: **********''Consider first the sheer magnitude of the Eurodollar market. It is staggering. While the exact amount of dollars floating outside the country is not known, most money market dealers place the total close to $1 trillion. **********''Actually,'' he continued, ''much of these 'overseas dollars' exist only on the books of foreign branches of American banks, mostly in London, rather than in the overseas vaults of domestic or other financial institutions.'' **********What is more important, he said, is the fact that the interest rates on Eurodollars have long been considered the most valid barometer of the international cost of money. The London interbank offered rate is the base borrowing cost of these dollars, which are lent to foreign governments as well as to large corporations. Mr.  Blin added: **********''One major reason is that these Eurodollars are not influenced by the monetary policy of the Federal Reserve because they are outside the country. Similarly, the Bank of England exercises no control on these funds because they are not sterling. Unlike ordinary bank deposits here or abroad, Eurodollars are not subject to central bank reserve requirments, which are a factor in determining the prime and all other lending rates.'' **********Much of today's international financing involves Eurodollars, which are mainly deposits from the Middle East oil exporting countries, Mr. Blin said. ''The banks that use these dollars for lending have always faced big risks because of the often volatile rate moves. Often, the petrodollars deposited in London are for shorter periods than the maturities on their loans to customers.'' **********As for the Eurodollar futures, the lenders can lock in rates just as grain and other commodity dealers can hedge their exposure.  ''Also,'' Mr. Blin stressed, ''Government monetary authorities could eventually use this market, in effect, to insure against adverse fluctuations in the value of their currencies through the purchase and sale of Eurodollar futures. Assuming, as many of us believe, the Eurodollar futures market will grow large enough to accommodate such operations.'' **********Traditionally, a central bank seeking to stabilize the value of its currency would either support it through purchases and sales or enter into various ''swap'' arrangements. **********The Chicago Mercantile's three-month Eurodollar time deposit futures contract carries a face value of $1 million. The minimum price move is $25 per contract. For the first time in any commodity futures market, the underlying goods are not deliverable, although the delivery months are January, March, June, September and December. Instead, all contracts are settled for cash. **********No Eurodollar futures contracts will change hands, just as New York banks operate in the London Eurodollar market without one dollar actually moving between the two cities. When the contract expires, the exchange will, in effect, average the interbank rates of the leading banks in London on that day and that will be the final settlement price for the delivery. **********At last Friday's close, for example, the active March Eurodollar delivery at ''85.80'' was off $150. The 85.80 means a rate of 14.20 percent on an annual basis on the March contract (100 percent face value minus 85.80 equals 14.20 percent).

Bue, ruling after three weeks of testimony, said there were no relevant questions for jurors to decide. **********''We were always convinced of the correctness of our position that this was baseless litigation,'' Herbert Hunt said after the decision. But an attorney for Houston-based Coastal States said his client would appeal the dismissal. **********Coastal States contended that following Libya's nationalization in 1973 of the Sarir oilfield, which previously had been owned by the Hunts and the British Petroleum Company Ltd., the Hunts had conspired to restrain trade by notifying potential customers that purchases of Libyan oil could result in litigation. British Petroleum was not named in the suit. **********The Hunts argued that the oil was rightfully theirs because the Libyan Government had illegally nationalized their interest and voided a long-term marketing contract.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/07/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; BOND PRICES ADVANCE SLIGHTLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/07/busin.body_text: **********Bond prices rose slightly yesterday, but some analysts said the large price gains of the last three weeks might be followed by a period of consolidation before prices increased again. **********They explained that a large volume of new corporate notes and bonds could help keep prices from rising as much as in the last three weeks, when some long-term bonds, such as the 12 3/4 percent Treasury issue due in 2010, rose from a low of 96 3/4 on Dec. 11 to yesterday's close of 109. **********Another reason for caution is the continued high level of shortterm interest rates. ''So long as the investor can earn 17 percent and more on commercial paper versus 13 percent on a long-term bond, they tend to buy the paper,'' one dealer said. **********High Federal Funds Rate Cited **********''Right now, I'd say the bond market's advance is inhibited by the high rate for Federal funds,'' said Jay Goldinger, an associate at Cantor, Fitzgerald & Company, a bond and money-market brokerage firm. If the funds rate, which is the cost of overnight loans arranged by banks and others, does not decline soon, Mr. Goldinger and others say, the market might even give up some of its recent gains. **********A decline in the funds rate is widely predicted, however, and Mr.  Goldinger concluded that ''the market rally is for real, with an excellent possibility of further gains.'' **********Similarly, Robert Wade, president of the Crocker Investment Management Corporation, an affiliate of the Crocker National Bank, observed that ''over the first half of the year we still expect the bond market to give a good performance, perhaps even a superior one'' compared with the equity markets. In the immediate future, however, ''we are cautious because the market has already come so far so quickly,'' he added. **********Over the longer term, Mr. Wade noted that many investors were still wary of fixed-rate investments, such as bonds, and were continuing to emphasize stocks, whose values they think will rise along with inflation. ''If the Reagan administration does anything good to combat inflation, it will be good for bonds,'' Mr. Wade said, ''but it will be even better for the equity markets.'' Many Companies Plan Sales **********While investment bankers cannot agree on how low interest rates will go, they do agree that a large number of companies are preparing to sell notes and bonds now that rates have declined from the midDecember peak, where Treasury issues yielded 13 percent and Aaa-rated telephone issues yielded 15 percent. **********''There is at least $10 billion of corporate issues'' poised for public sale, ''with one heck of a lot of intermediate maturities,'' said S. Daniel Evans, a vice president at E.F. Hutton & Company. If the optimists are correct, and the Reagan administration does show some ability to reduce inflation, then more companies might issue traditional 30-year bonds later in the year, he added. **********The first sign of that volume came yesterday afternoon when plans were announced for $300 million of 20-year Conoco debentures, $200 million of Tenneco 10-year notes and $150 million of Commonwealth Edison Company bonds. Investment bankers said more issues would follow. **********Investor demand was brisk for the few corporate issues that came to market while it was rallying. Yesterday, underwriters reported quick sellouts for a $100 million issue of Aa-rated American Express Credit Corporation 12 7/8 percent notes due in 1991 and a $100 million issue of Baa/BBB rated Alabama Power Company 14 3/4 percent notes due in 1991. Both issues were initially offered at par and then at slight premiums late in the day. Treasury Prices Up Slightly **********In the Treasury market, prices were only slightly higher yesterday. After the Treasury sold $1.5 billion of new 11 3/4 percent 20-year bonds at an average yield of 11.82 percent, the outstanding 12 3/4 percent bonds closed at 109 to yield 11.64 percent. The 15 1/8 percent notes due in two years were offered at 104 20/32 to yield 12.41 percent. **********In the tax-exempt market, yields are continuing to decline. In advance of today's $200 million issue of Aa-rated Oregon bonds due in 1991-2000, dealers estimated that yields of 9 percent and more would be readily available, with some of the longest-term bonds yielding as much as 9 1/2 percent. **********The sharp decline in rates in the last month was clearly shown at yesterday's auction of housing project notes by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. After bidding for $1.1 billion of the United States Government-guaranteed notes, underwriters were reoffering notes due in August 1981 to yield 7.05 percent, compared with a 9 percent yield for comparable notes sold a month ago. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auction of 20-year onemonth Treasury bonds:
